title: No Plan to Ask Meese to Resign, Baker Reports
description: The White House Chief of Staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that President Reagan had no intention of asking Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to resign because he is under investigation for his involvement in an Iraqi pipeline project.

title: A Concert in Honor Of Vittorio Rieti at 90
description: To honor the 90th birthday of the composer Vittorio Rieti, the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is to give a concert devoted to his work at 8 P.M. on Wednesday at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: A Debate Over the Impact Of Delaware Takeover Law
description: The rules governing many corporate takeovers are about to change dramatically, all with the stroke of a pen in Wilmington, Del. The state's Governor, Michael N. Castle, is expected to sign tomorrow a bill that makes unfriendly takeovers harder.

title: Dukakis Aide's Out for 'Stunt'
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts said today that it had apologized to Senator Paul Simon, a rival, over a Dukakis staff member's attempt to ''volunteer'' at a Simon campaign office.

title: Article 637188 -- No Title
description: The Treasury will auction a full slate of new issues this week, starting with $12.8 billion of short-term bills today and continuing the next three days with note and bond sales totaling $27 billion.

title: Iowa Paper Picks Candidates
description: Iowa's largest newspaper, The Des Moines Register, endorsed Bob Dole and Paul Simon today in the state's Feb. 8 Presidential caucuses. The Register normally does not endorse candidates before the caucuses.

title: Cardinal Is Seen as Kind, if Firm, Monitor of Faith
description: ''In essence, you are looking at the Grand Inquisitor.''

title: The Super Bowl Strut
description: WHAT was the score of the Super Bowl? That is, in the terms of corporate America, of which the National Football League is happily and devotedly part and parcel, what was the bottom line?

title: Kentucky Beats Notre Dame
description: Rex Chapman's 3-point play with 1 minute 18 seconds remaining sparked Kentucky to a 78-69 victory today over Notre Dame.

title: Broncos Get Caught Up in a Stampede
description: Their explanations came easily. Painfully easily.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The challenge is not simply to stop the war, because if our people continue to suffer, war will break out again.'' - Brooklyn Rivera, the Miskito leader, on Nicaragua's civil war. [ A3:3. ]

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: What Kind Of People Are We?
description: The outcome of the war in Nicaragua may not be determined by the pending Congressional votes on further aid to the ''contras'' organized and trained by the C.I.A. But that vote will say much about the United States' right to view itself as a peaceful nation dedicated to self-determination and the rule of law.

title: Data on Specialist Activity in Plunge
description: The New York Stock Exchange's specialists failed to respond to nearly two-thirds of the trading messages they received through the intermarket trading system during the October market collapse, according to an internal report prepared by the exchange.

title: Techniques to Add Speed Can Improve Form, Too
description: THE start ramp is steep. The first three gates look like a forest of slim trees that have been placed directly in your path. ''Ready . . . Go!'' the starter says, and you push off. Your heart is in your mouth and your legs are trembling as you breathe hard and aim straight at that first gate.

title: Dr. Leon Menaker, Psychologist, 72
description: Dr. Leon Menaker, a charter member of the Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy in Manhattan, died of liver cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: Gephardt Raises Eyebrows With His New Look
description: Has it been the tough television commercials about foreign car manufacturers stealing away American jobs?

title: Episcopal Panel Prompts Debate On Gay Couples
description: An Episcopal Church official said yesterday that the decision of the Newark Diocese to bless homosexual couples ''has set off a lot of sparks'' and has placed the issue of homosexuality high on the church's agenda.

title: Racial Issues Arise at Talks on New York's Future
description: In a mansion that was home to barons of a bygone era, more than 100 government officials, academics, foundation executives and civic leaders met here this weekend to debate New York City's social and economic future in the wake of last fall's Wall Street collapse.

title: TV Review; 'Weekend War,' ABC
description: THE television movie ''Weekend War'' is less impressive as a drama exercise than for what it reflects, probably accurately, about widespread public perceptions of United States Government policies in Central America. Especially since the Iran-contra hearings, the overall picture is riddled with covert maneuverings, evasions and, to put it gingerly, disinformation. ''Weekend War,'' being broadcast at 9 P.M. tonight on Channel 7, is perhaps the first prime-time television ''entertainment'' to cope with the subject and, from its own skeptical perspective, to do it bluntly.

title: 13 Are Reported Slain In South Africa Clashes
description: Hundreds of homes were burned to the ground and 13 people were reported killed in violence around South Africa over the weekend.

title: Forty Niner Draws Post 5 in Hutcheson
description: Forty Niner, the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby May 7, drew post five today for his seasonal debut Wednesday against a surprisingly strong field of 3-year-olds in the Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: In Atlanta, A Cultural Crossroads
description: With the retirement this spring of Robert Shaw from the post of music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, an era will end in this city's cultural life.

title: Singer Funds For Bilzerian
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor whose bid to take over the Singer Company has been accepted by company executives, said yesterday that he had obtained about $505 million in financing for his offer.

title: 76ers Lack Punch In Loss to Celtics
description: Larry Bird scored 29 points and grabbed 17 rebounds to lead the Boston Celtics to a 100-85 victory over Philadelphia today as the 76ers hit a National Basketball Association season low with 29 points in the first half.

title: School System Will Be Spared On Budget Cuts
description: The New York City Board of Education will be spared a 2.5 percent spending cut that the Koch administration plans to impose on all other city agencies, city and education officials said yesterday.

title: Accustomed to His Latest Face
description: Minutes after vanishing from his rococo subterranean hell in the final scene of ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' Michael Crawford begins his daily half-hour ritual of transformation, from the ghoulish star of Andrew Lloyd Webber's new musical to the soft-spoken, 46-year-old English actor who has returned to Broadway after 21 years to wide critical acclaim.

title: Stephen P. Schwartz
description: Stephen P. Schwartz, 53, will have a sensitive job as the person in charge of two midrange office systems -System/36 and System/38 - that have been lagging in rugged competition with minicomputers from other companies. Mr. Schwartz will head the I.B.M. Application Business Systems, which will be responsible for System/3X products.

title: Record Rushing From Rookie
description: The Washington Redskins' starters were about to be introduced today before Super Bowl XXII when Don Breaux, who coaches the running backs, walked over to Timmy Smith, his prize rookie.

title: Arrests Made
description: A police spokesman, who asked not to be identified, said an undetermined number of arrests were made tonight stemming from the Super Bowl XXII celebration. The spokesman cited incidents of looting, window breaking and fighting. No official arrest estimates were available because of the large number of people in the area, the spokesman said.

title: A New Twist in Offer For Giant in Belgium
description: When Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian financier, began his attack from the south, Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest holding company, was forced to seek help from a neighbor to the north.

title: Learning From Errors
description: Colleen Walker was sitting in a tent two summers ago, describing in detail her every golf shot to reporters at the Mastercard International Pro-Am. She was recounting her final round, explaining how for the first time she had placed second in a Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour event.

title: Contra Aid Bill: The 'Hidden Costs'
description: When the House considers new aid for the Nicaraguan contras this week, the package from the White House will carry a price tag of $36.25 million for four months, a figure the Administration argues is relatively modest.

title: Patrick A. Toole
description: Patrick A. Toole, 50, takes command of I.B.M. Technology Products, with responsibility for semiconductors and packaging for systems. Mr. Toole previously ran the Information Systems Technology Group.

title: Advertising; People
description: * James M. Kimmelman has joined Greenstone & Rabasca South, Boca Raton, Fla., as executive vice president and general manager.

title: Assailant Dies in Subway Attack
description: A 48-year-old man was fatally stabbed in a dispute with two younger men yesterday after he assaulted their mother on a Queens subway train, the police said.

title: Advertising; Promotional Campaign For CBS-TV
description: A NEW promotion campaign for CBS-TV breaks today on the network, and if the hopes of Gene F. Jankowski, president of the Broadcast Group, are realized it will help bring a younger audience to the network that attracts the oldest.

title: Capital Plan Is Based on Risks Involved in Bank Assets
description: The Federal Reserve Board's proposal to increase its bank capital requirements is based on the concept that certain loans and other assets held by banks carry a higher risk than others.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Was Russ Francis the receiver for the San Francisco 49ers who caught the touchdown pass from Joe Montana in the last minute of the 1981 championship game victory over the Dallas Cowboys?

title: Being a Mother Takes Art and Science, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Notebook; Soviet Help Sought for Seoul
description: Ever so quietly, senior officials of the International Olympic Committee are still working on resolving the issue of North Korea's participation in the Seoul Olympics later this year.

title: Advertising; Wall Street Journal Hails I.B.M.'s Insert
description: The Wall Street Journal was so pleased about the 16-page I.B.M. advertising insert it carried Friday that it heralded its coming with both print and radio ads.

title: 3 Visual Artists Win $5,000 Film Awards
description: Two film makers and a video artist are the recipients of this year's Maya Deren Awards, sponsored by the American Film Institute. The three - Bruce Conner, Yvonne Rainer and Bill Viola - will each receive a $5,000 cash award. J. Hoberman, a film critic for The Village Voice, is to receive a citation for contributions to independent film and video.

title: Redskins Rout Broncos, 42-10, in Super Bowl
description: The most exciting Super Bowl in history may have been played in the second quarter of today's game here.

title: LYLE'S BOGEY WINS PLAYOFF
description: Sandy Lyle of Scotland almost committed the cardinal sin of missing his tee time this morning. But he capped a big comeback when he won the Phoenix Open by beating Fred Couples on the third hole of a playoff. He won with a bogey 5 after Couples drove into a pond on the left of the 18th fairway for the second time in less than an hour.

title: Weighing of 2 Perils Led to Needles-for-Addicts Plan
description: For more than two years, top officials debated whether giving clean needles to New York City drug addicts would do more good or harm in a city that is home to half the nation's heroin addicts and that expects to bear the worst damage from the rising AIDS epidemic.

title: Nuclear Plant Drain Put At $100 Billion for U.S.
description: Nuclear plants that were abandoned before completion or finished at excessive cost will cost the nation's economy as much as $100 billion, according to utility experts. The penalty for this technological wrong turn will be shared by residential and business electric customers, Federal taxpayers and, increasingly, utility stockholders and bondholders.

title: Anxious Moments for Cable Viewers
description: It did not come to pass, but many cable television subscribers in Manhattan spent part of yesterday contemplating Super Bowl Sunday without the Super Bowl.

title: Concert: Slatkin Leads St. Louis at Carnegie
description: LEONARD SLATKIN is a conductor dedicated to new music with a particular slant.

title: Deerfield Journal; 'Deerfield Boy' Is Wary Of Life After Girls
description: In 10 minutes, the headmaster of Deerfield Academy would be breaking the news to many of his 560 boys. ''A few will hiss or boo,'' Robert E. Kaufmann predicted.

title: American Brands Set To Buy E-II
description: American Brands Inc. announced yesterday that it would buy E-II Holdings Inc. in a deal valued at $2.7 billion, ending a tangled month-long takeover fight that began when E-II made an offer for American Brands.

title: Medical Establishment Blocks Pain Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Director Defends Spying on Political Groups
description: William Sessions, the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Saturday defended the bureau's spying on groups opposed to the Reagan's Administration's policies in Central America.

title: George H. Conrades
description: George H. Conrades, 48, is described by Myron Kerstetter, an analyst at Gartner Securities, as soft-spoken, personable and a tough manager. He will run the group that I.B.M. calls Personal Systems, embracing the company's personal computer divisions and its typewriters, displays and other low-end products that have previously been run under different corporate units.

title: Ecuadoreans Vote For New President, With 10 in Running
description: Some four million Ecuadoreans voted today for a successor to President Leon Febres Cordero from a record field of 10 candidates backed by 17 different parties.

title: INSIDE
description: Israelis and U.S. TV Israelis wince and debate as they watch American TV news film of the recent Palestinian demonstrations in the occupied territories. Page A8. Paying for Nuclear Energy The nation will pay as much as $100 billion for abandoned nuclear plants or those finished at excessive cost, utility experts say. Page D1. Dallas Notices Its Divisions Long proud of its harmony, Dallas is seeing it is a city like many others, with social divisions that sometimes result in violence. Page A18.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Paper for Posterity
description: Hold that memo! That stack of while-your-were-out telephone messages! That snippet from a draft of the State of the Union Message. Those who would shred their White House paperwork have to face the preservationists of the Reagan tenancy.

title: Social Democrats in Britain Split Over Merger of Parties
description: The Social Democratic Party voted today to merge with the Liberal Party in the latest effort by Britain's centrists to break the dominance of the governing Conservatives and opposition Laborites.

title: To Help Families, Help Housing
description: In his State of the Union Message, President Reagan urged Congress to rally behind family values. Meanwhile, hard-pressed American families are finding out the truth of December's grim statistics: Total housing starts dropped 18 percent below November. Apartments are what home-starved city families need; families already combing the streets for vacancies know that apartment- house starts dropped a mammoth 33 percent. If Washington wants to help families, it should stimulate, not block, construction of housing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 1, Flyers 0: Kelly Miller scored 3 minutes 17 seconds into overtime to give Washington the victory over Philadelphia yesterday in Landover, Md. The victory moved Washington into second place in the Patrick Division, 4 points behind the Flyers and 1 ahead of the third-place Islanders.(AP) Jets 4, Sabres 4: Ray Sheppard's second goal of the game tied the score with 2 minutes 20 seconds remaining to lift Buffalo into the tie with Winnipeg and force an overtime in Buffalo. Sheppard's goal, his 20th of the season, erased a 4-3 Winnipeg lead that Mark Kumpel had given the Jets at 12:46 of the third period. (AP) TENNIS First Pro Title for Fendick: Patty Fendick of the United States defeated Sara Gomer of Britain, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the final of the $50,000 Virginia Slims tournament in Auckland, New Zealand. Fendick won the first Slims title of her career. She teamed with Jill Hetherington of Canada to win the doubles title against two American sisters, Cammy and Cynthia MacGregor, 6-2, 6-1. (AP) Mattar Upsets Teltscher: Luiz Mattar of Brazil defeated top-seeded Eliot Teltscher of the United States, 6-3, 6-3, to win a $130,000 tournament yesterday in Guaruja, Brazil. In doubles, Luke Jensen of the United States and Ricardo Acuna of Chile defeated Diego Perez of Uruguay and Javier Frana of Argentina, 6-1, 6-4.(AP) ROAD RACING Kempton Wins 7-Mile Run: Jamie Kempton of Nanuet, N.Y., regained the title yesterday in the New York Road Runners Club's 13th annual seven-mile run, covering the Central Park course in 35 minutes 43 seconds. Kempton won in 1986 and was runner-up last year. Janet Murenia of the Atlanta Track Club won the women's race in 43:26. The Central Park Track Club won the men's team title; Atlanta captured the women's. A field of 1,334 participated. AUTO RACING Jaguar Upsets Porsche: Jaguar ended the 11-year domination of Porsche as Raul Boesel of Brazil, John Nielsen of Denmark and Martin Brundle of Britain combined yesterday to win the Daytona 24-Hours race in Florida. The Jaguar XJR-9 prototype held off a late challenge from the Porsche 962 prototype driven by the pole-winner, Mauro Baldi of Italy, and two two-time Daytona winners, Brian Redman of England and Bob Wollek of France. Porsche had won seven straight Daytona 24-Hour races, and cars powered by Porsche engines had won 11 in a row in the United States' premier sports-car endurance event and the season-opener in the IMSA Camel GT series. Nielsen was at the wheel of the winning car when it took the checkered flag after 728 laps on the 3.56-mile Daytona International Speedway course. The winners averaged 107.943 miles an hour.(AP) HORSE RACING Cagey Exuberance Takes Berlo: Cagey Exuberance took the lead after entering the stretch yesterday and went on to carry 114 pounds under Chris Antley to a 1 3/4-length victory in the $68,800 Berlo Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. In covering six furlongs on the fast track in 1:09 4/5, Cagey Exuberance established a stakes record. Cagey Exuberance paid $9.80 for $2 to win as the second choice. Super Diamond Wins: Super Diamond, the favorite, won a stretch duel from Judge Angelucci by a neck yesterday to capture the $158,500 San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Russian Wins Pole Vault: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union beat Thierry Vigneron of France in the pole vault yesterday at an indoor meet in Stuttgart, West Germany. Bubka's best vault was 19 feet 1/4 inch, well short of his world indoor record of 19-7. Vigneron finished second at 18-8 1/4. Mark Witherspoon of the United States won the 60-meter dash in 6.75 seconds, beating Ernest Obeng of Britain, in 6.77. Larry Myricks of the United States won the long jump at 26-7 3/4, beating Robert Emmiyan of the Soviet Union, at 26-3. Nelli Cooman of the Netherlands beat Evelyn Ashford of the United States in the women's 60-meter dash, clocking 7.21 to the American's 7.22. (AP) GOLF Rodriguez Richer: Chi Chi Rodriguez dominated the Senior Skins Game that ended yesterday in Honolulu, winning $300,000 of the $360,000 total purse. Rodriguez, 52 years old, won three holes and $260,000 on the final day of the two-day event. He concluded by winning a sixth playoff hole, worth $90,000, in a sudden-death showdown that dwindled to him and Arnold Palmer.(AP)

title: A Smokestack in Poland Emits Odor of Indecision
description: The Delta knitwear factory would simply be closed down, the article said, because environmental officials were tired of waiting for the company's management to put in chimney filters that stop soot.

title: Ms. Friedlander Weds John Andrew Vacovec
description: Beth Friedlander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Friedlander of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to John Andrew Vacovec, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin S. Vacovec of Webster, Mass. Marvin Axelrod, an associate leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Corporate Bowl
description: Football may have provided the excuse, but as any hospitality suite hopper in San Diego could attest last week, the real reason for the Super Bowl is money. The kind that executives of a dozen or so corporations are hoping shows up on the bottom line to justify the millions of stockholder dollars they spent on Super Bowl and other National Football League promotions and sponsorships, not to mention their own Super Bowl travel and entertainment expenses.

title: Music: 'Jacques Brel,' Revue, at Town Hall
description: IT was almost exactly 20 years ago that the revue ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' opened in New York at the Village Gate and introduced a young generation of theatergoers to the dramatic songs of the Belgian singer and poet, who died 11 years later at age 49. Arriving when the antiwar movement was in full flower and Bob Dylan's folk-rock diatribes had brought a caustic realism to American pop, Brel's songs of love, death, war and the homeland also spoke to the moment, though in a different vocabulary. In their softer, more traditionally theatrical way, they too cut through the official sentimentality of pop convention to evoke a life-or-death urgency in a time of strife.

title: The Basic Speech; 'America Can Do Better' in Offering 'More Opportunity in the Next Decade'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: In Egyptian Schools, Israel Is Still on the Map
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami's New Orchestra Teaches While It Plays
description: The inaugural concert on Feb. 4 of a new symphony orchestra has stirred up greater interest and expectation here than any other cultural event in recent times.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Environmental Agenda
description: When President Reagan was first elected in 1980, the Heritage Foundation had waiting for him a long agenda of actions he could take in dealing with environmental problems. The recommendations reflected the foundation's conservative perspective. National environmental groups, whose views were generally in direct opposition to those of the foundation, wrung their hands.

title:
Should the Contras Be Newly Funded?;
No, Because Human Rights Won't Benefit
description: LEAD: Many positive developments on human rights have taken place in Nicaragua in the last few weeks. After initially playing down their significance, the Reagan Administration is not giving them another ''spin'': it claims that these improvements have been brought about by the continued pressure of the contras on the Sandinista regime.

title: U.S. Envoy Ends Jordan Trip
description: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, left Jordan today to return to Washington after a day of talks with King Hussein. American and Jordanian officials refused to comment on the talks beyond saying they focused on the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: 4 Palestinians and an Israeli Wounded in Clashes
description: At least four Palestinian youths were reported shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers today in continuing civil unrest, and a Jewish settler was severely burned by a gasoline bomb.

title: Mets' Fans Get in Line
description: Thousands of people lined up today outside the new St. Lucie County Sports Complex to buy tickets for the Mets' spring training games.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1988
description: International A3-14

title: Dance: Olesker and Pou at St. Mark's
description: LIZZIE OLESKER plunged into the supposed trivialities of life and Alyson Pou rose above them in a program of performance art presented by the Danspace Project on Friday at St. Mark's Church. In ''House Work,'' Ms. Olesker conjured up three generations of women and paid a glance to a fourth, in the guise of a young sociology student engaged in a Marxist-feminist interpretation of housework. Ms. Pou took on jealousy, violence and death in ''The Juniper Tree,'' a stylized theater-dance version of the old children's tale.

title: Thomas J. Conlin, Army Officer, 81
description: Thomas J. Conlin, a retired colonel in the Army, died Wednesday at the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue, L.I., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

title: Pregnant? Do Exercise But Exercise Care, Too
description: THE age in which a pregnant woman was regarded as a delicate flower to be secluded until her baby was born passed long ago, but questions remain about just how active she should be. Increasingly, doctors are advising patients to exercise and stay fit if they wish; some even urge sedentary patients to begin an exercise program after becoming pregnant.

title: Italian Snowslides Kill 3
description: Avalanches in the Italian Alps killed three people and stranded others this weekend, the authorities said today.

title: Jazz: Wayne Horvitz and James (Blood) Ulmer
description: THE keyboardist and composer Wayne Horvitz and the guitarist and composer James (Blood) Ulmer unveiled two entirely different approaches to music at the Bottom Line Saturday night. For his records, Mr. Horvitz, who sounds as happy swinging through be-bop as throwing notes around with the saxophonist John Zorn, constructs perfect musical miniatures. The tunes hint at references: funk bass lines, ethnic percussion patterns, pretty melodies and an upwardly mobile, slick veneer allow him to draw a listener in, all the while fiddling with the forms of the music.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 17 about newspaper editors' views on the character of Gary Hart misstated the year in which Richard M. Nixon ran for the Presidency against George McGovern. It was 1972; his rival in 1968 was Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE EXCELLENT EMPIRE. The Fall of Rome and the Triumph of the Church.

title: Party Line in Washington: Cheering for the Redskins
description: By late Sunday afternoon, the streets of this city were eerily deserted as all those Washingtonians who had not been able to make their way to Jack Murphy Stadium in San Diego headed for television sets and Super Bowl parties.

title: Outdoors: Hunting Waterfowl When the Weather Is Cold
description: HUNTING in the bitter cold of mid-winter does not necessarily require indifference to discomfort. In fact, such stoicism may be beyond most of us. But it can be both productive and instructive.

title: Williams Stars as Redskins Smash Broncos
description: Doug Williams turned Super Bowl XXII into a record-setting offensive show today, as well a historic event, by throwing four second-quarter touchdown passes in the Washington Redskins' 42-10 victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: Robertson May Be Cause for Uncertainty in Iowa
description: It is hard to know what to expect of Pat Robertson in Iowa, where his unorthodox Presidential candidacy, like the more conventional campaigns of his rivals, will get its first major test Feb. 8.

title:
Should the Contras Be Newly Funded?;
Yes, Because Democracy Would Gain
description: LEAD: If Congress flip-flops once again by voting against additional aid to the Nicaraguan resistance, the hopes for a national dialogue that could eventually lead to democracy and protect human rights in Nicaragua will be shattered.

title: Concert: 3 Overtures At the Schubertiade
description: SCHUBERT at age 15 reminds us of a legatee who, bursting with new-found wealth, puzzles over how to spend it. Thus Saturday's Schubertiade concert at the 92d Street Y - the third in this year's series of eight - overwhelmed us with Schubert's spirit even when the invention seemed squandered and misdirected.

title: Social Themes in Art
description: An exhibition that opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art explores social and political themes in American printed art from the 1960's to the present, using 144 prints and 36 books by 108 individual artists and 16 collectives. The printed works are organized into six categories: governments and leaders; race and culture; gender; nuclear power and ecology; war and revolution; economics, class struggle and the American Dream. Titled ''Committed to Print,'' the exhibition will run until April 19. Museum hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Fridays through Tuesdays and 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. Thursdays. The museum is closed Wednesdays. Admission: $5, or $3.50 for students.Information: 708-9400.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY The Fed may increase capital requirements for banks by 1992, a move that could stall the acquisitions of large savings institutions. [ Page A1. ] The proposal is based on the concept that certain loans and other assets of banks carry a higher risk than others. [ D8. ] A rule governing takeovers will change dramatically tomorrow when the Governor of Delaware signs a bill into law. [ D1. ] The rate of growth in the nation's economy slowed in January, lagging December in production and employment, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management. [ D1. ] Nuclear power plants that were abandoned or finished at excessive expense will cost the nation's economy as much as $100 billion, utility industry experts say. [ D1. ] COMPANIES The General Services Administration allowed bids by competitors of A.T.&T. for telephone contracts even though it knew the rivals had obtained secret bid information, two agency employees said. [ A1. ] American Brands will buy E-II Holdings in a deal valued at $2.7 billion, the companies announced. [ D1. ] MARKETS Specialists failed to respond to two-thirds of the messages they received through the intermarket trading system during the October market collapse, a report says. [ D5. ] Interest rates in the credit markets have fallen sharply on the assumption that the Fed would push short-term rates lower. [ D9. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The company that Societe Generale de Belgique sought out in its battle with Carlo de Benedetti may be a Trojan horse. [ D5. ] The I.M.F. wants to design less harsh lending conditions for debtor countries, officials of the international agency said. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A tiny manufacturer of medical equipment had the backing of some prominent scientists, but that wasn't enough for state regulators, who have halted its stock sale. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] A key segment of the insurance industry lacks important rules that could avert an insurance crisis, New York's Superintendent of Insurance contends. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Investors are unlikely to confront another utility bankruptcy, despite last week's move by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, analysts said. Market Place [ D8. ]

title: Release of Cubans Reported Up Since Riots
description: The Federal Government is releasing five times as many Cubans from prison each month as it did before uprisings at two prisons last year focused attention on the Cubans' efforts to remain in this country, according to a report today in The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.

title: With Managua's Assent, Indian Rebel Holds Rally
description: Brooklyn Rivera, the Miskito Indian leader whose forces are at war with the Sandinista Government, was allowed to travel openly to the Miskito region this weekend and hold a public meeting.

title: City Ballet: 2 Debuts In 'Square Dance
description: BECAUSE every cast of a ballet inevitably brings something personal to it, ballet lovers constantly return to certain works just to see how they will look with a particular set of dancers. Recent performances of the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater featured some interesting interpretations.

title: Iowans Bristle at the Cornfield Image
description: A photographer for a national magazine recently approached Kathleen Wood with a request: find a Presidential nominating caucus that will take place in a one-room schoolhouse.

title: 'Writers in Performance'
description: Two Irish poets, Derek Mahon and Paul Muldoon, will open this year's ''Writers in Performance'' series on Feb. 15 at 8 P.M. at the Manhattan Theater Club's Stage One, City Center, 131 West 55th Street. A columnist and screenwriter, Mr. Mahon is the author of ''Poems: 1968'' and ''Antarctica''; Mr. Muldoon, who has taught at Columbia University and Princeton, is the author of ''Meeting the British'' and ''Selected Poems: 1968.'' Admission is $8. Information: 645-5848.

title: Stage: 'Heart of a Dog'
description: FOR Mikhail Bulgakov, turning Russia's peasantry and proletariat into a ruling class was not unlike an operation turning a mongrel cur into a human being. You may dress him up to look the part, but initially his behavior will remain rude, crude and socially unacceptable.

title: Grand Central at 75: Beauty and Misery
description: Looking grander than it has in a generation, Grand Central Terminal will mark its 75th anniversary tomorrow with a clear Beaux-Arts victory over decades of neglect and abuse but without its fabled title, ''Gateway to a Continent.''

title: Donahue vs. Winfrey: A Clash of Talk Titans
description: The reports of Phil Donahue's death at the hands of Oprah Winfrey have been grossly exaggerated.

title: Cabarets Celebrate End Of Painful 'Prohibition'
description: The rafters stayed in place, but another kind of ceiling was lifted at clubs across New York City over the weekend.

title: Man Seized for Threats Dies in an Ambulance
description: A Brooklyn man taken into police custody after threatening neighbors in his apartment building died in an ambulance en route to the hospital on Saturday, the police said, and it is unclear what caused his death.

title: Medical Establishment Blocks Pain Treatment; A False Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Brooklyn Union Gas Co. named Robert V. Delaney senior vice president and chief administrative officer, Craig G. Matthews senior vice president and chief financial officer, and Helmut W. Peter senior vice president and chief engineer.

title: B.A.T. to Get Financing
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said that it had secured a $3.2 billion line of credit from a consortium of banks to finance its unsolicited bid for Farmers Group Inc. Last month Farmers, a Los Angeles-based insurance group, rejected a $4.2 billion bid from the British tobacco conglomerate. B.A.T., based in London, said Saturday that it would finance the deal - worth $60 a share - through debt and cash. The company said the group of lenders included 31 banks from North America, Europe and Japan.

title: Market Place; Utility Risks Seen As Few, for Now
description: FOR people who follow developments in the electric utility industry, the announcement on Thursday by the beleaguered Public Service Company of New Hampshire that it had filed for bankruptcy protection came as no surprise.

title: Fed Backs Bank Merger
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the proposed merger of the Shawmut Corporation of Boston and the Hartford National Corporation of Hartford. Shareholders of the two banks overwhelmingly approved the merger last November. The combined bank, to be called the Shawmut National Corporation, will have assets of about $25 billion. The merger, which the Federal Reserve approved on Friday, still requires the approval of Massachusetts and Connecticut regulatory authorities.

title: I.B.M. Restructuring Bolsters Its Managers
description: The management restructuring that the International Business Machines Corporation announced last week is intended to bring the responsibility for decision-making closer to the company's operations. The move will give the five general managers who will run the new major units much greater visibility in the world's largest computer maker.

title: Borges Is Prolific, in Wagner Tradition
description: At Wagner College, the undergraduate enrollment is about 1,500, the longest walk from a dormitory to a classroom takes five minutes, and students still pay a quarter for a round-trip ride on the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Neoax Raises Its Bid for IU
description: Neoax Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its offer for the IU International Corporation by $1 a share, to $20 a share, or about $548 million.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending Dec. Tuesday Leading Indicators Dec. New-Home Sales Dec. Prices of New Homes Dec. Wednesday Factory Orders Dec. Thursday Productivity Fourth Quarter Friday Consumer Borrowing Dec. Unemployment Jan.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Arms Debate: Faulting the Fixtures And Sorting Out What Goes Boom
description: Throughout the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's first week of hearings on the new arms control treaty, a steady stream of senators have made discreet pilgrimages from their offices to have a peek. Their interest was not in the proceedings, but in the room itself, a cavernous, modern hall of wood and marble in the Hart Senate Office Building.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 31, 1988: MONDAY Airborne Freight NCH Corp Data-Design Labs Xerox Corp Lockheed Corp Zurn Industries MBIA Inc TUESDAY CBI Industries IE Industries Diamond Shamrock Kansas City Pwr & Lt General Housewares WEDNESDAY Corning Glass Works Panhandle Eastern Corp Eagle-Picher Indus Peoples Energy MA Hanna Co Pilgrims Pride Corp Lee Enterprises Thomas & Betts Corp McKesson Corp UtilCorp United Inc THURSDAY Amer Genl Corp IU International Avon Products Mercantile Strs Bemis Co Inc Phillips-Van Heusen Chemed Corp Universal Corp VA Coastal Corp Universal Leaf Tobacco Contel Corp FRIDAY Dean Foods Sterling Drug Dennison Mfg Temple Inland Kroger Co Timkem Co OH Progressive Corp SATURDAY Allied-Signal Inc

title: Dance: Works by Women
description: ALTHOUGH the young choreographers who took part in the Choreographers Showcase on Friday night at the Robert Yohn Dance Loft had ideas, their kinetic images did not always embody those ideas.

title: 20 Are Seized in Gambling Raids
description: An illegal gambling ring that handled about $500 million in bets on sporting events - including $5 million on the Super Bowl - was the target of raids on seven apartments in Manhattan Saturday night that resulted in the arrests of 20 people, the police reported.

title: In U.S. TV, Israelis Find An Unflattering Mirror
description: Not too far from the ancient walls, a modern dish antenna is aimed as if in supplication to the heavens above the Holy Land, eavesdropping on America's nightly news images of Israel.

title: EUTHANASIA ESSAY PROMPTS PROTEST
description: An essay in The Journal of the American Medical Association describing a young physician's decision to inject a lethal dose of morphine into a terminally ill patient has drawn a flood of letters from doctors calling the action unethical and illegal.

title: Advertising; U.S. Marketer Accounts To Martin and Gleckler
description: The Martin Agency in Richmond and Gleckler & Company in New York have both picked up United States marketers of foreign high-tech products.

title: Dream Street
description: Something there is about a Bond Street or a Rodeo Drive or a Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore that makes the head spin and the fingers itch and the ribs feel the scorch of a red-hot wallet. ''Buy me,'' the glories in the shops proclaim, ''and you'll get a leg up on life.''

title: Show Has Lectures, Gear For Outdoors Enthusiasts
description: FOR the second consecutive year, a hunting, fishing and outdoor sports show will be held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. The Dodge National Sportsmen's Show will run Feb. 4-7.

title: Why Does New York Have to Be So Noisy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Santa Fe Turns to Olympia & York
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation joined forces yesterday with the Reichmann family of Canada to fight a bid for control of the large rail, oil and real estate company by the head of the Henley Group.

title: In Japan, Unsettling Ripple of Crime
description: ''Because that's where the money is,'' Willie Sutton supposedly said when asked why he robbed banks.

title: Ellen M. Hancock
description: In a company whose upper ranks have long been an exclusive male bastion, Ellen M. Hancock stands out. Not only is Mrs. Hancock the highest-ranking woman to be an I.B.M. operating officer, but she may also hold one of the company's toughest jobs.

title: Barge Spills Oil Near Puget Sound
description: A barge carrying 318,000 gallons of heavy fuel oil sank four miles offshore today and began leaking, the Coast Guard said.

title: Joyce L. Shub Marries Leonard Reed, Writer
description: Joyce Lasky Shub, a writer and a special adviser to the Under Secretary for Political Affairs in the State Department, and Leonard Reed, a writer and contributing editor of The Washington Monthly magazine, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Washington by Judge Harold H. Greene of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia.

title: COLOMBIANS GROW WEARY OF WAGING THE WAR ON DRUGS
description: Shaken by the murder of the country's Attorney General last Monday, many influential Colombians have begun arguing that this country is paying too high a price for combating powerful drug traffickers.

title: 4 Injured in Derailment Of a Train in Harlem
description: Four people were slightly injured when the eighth car of a 10-car D train was derailed just south of 145th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem last night, officials said.

title: Finns Choosing President in 2-Day Election
description: Finns began voting today in a two-day presidential election, with President Mauno Koivisto regarded as almost certain to win a second six-year term as custodian of Finland's sensitive relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Reloading for Patrick Battle
description: Reprise was the theme sought by all three metropolitan-area Patrick Division teams over the weekend, as each attempted to generate something resembling a winning streak.

title: Hart Tries to Disperse Cloud on Campaign
description: Like the comic strip character Linus and his blanket, Gary Hart trails anger wherever he goes.

title: Medical Establishment Blocks Pain Treatment; Controlled Substances
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Anger Toward Brazil
description: Volkswagen dealers are raising Cain in Washington because of reports that their imports from Brazil could be hit by trade sanctions President Reagan is now weighing against that country.

title: Washington Talk: Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms; A Bureau That Battled Bootleggers Is Tough Target for Budget-Cutters
description: Mounted in a prominent spot in the offices of one of Washington's major law-enforcement agencies is a blown-up formal photo of a man in his 30's, neatly dressed, hair parted in the middle.

title: THE BIG-PLAY QUARTERBACK
description: EVER since George Halas sat on an automobile running board at the Hupmobile agency in Canton, Ohio during the 1920 founding of the National Football League, coaches have talked about their teams having to ''make the big plays.'' But nobody ever made more big plays quicker in a big game than Doug Williams did yesterday in the Washington Redskins' 42-10 triumph over the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXII.

title: Panel Is Advised It Must Abolish New York City Board of Estimate
description: The commission working to restructure New York City's government has been told by its legal experts that it must devise a radically new form of government - one that abolishes the powerful Board of Estimate and distributes its authority elsewhere.

title: Leaky Mine Threatens A-Waste Storage Plan
description: Far below a fierce landscape of sand and sagebrush a red laser pierces the darkness, guiding miners cutting the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository from walls of salt that are hard as stone.

title: In Yonkers, the Rifts Continue After the Housing Vote
description: The end to the legal battle over desegregating Yonkers' neighborhoods left the city with a bitterly divided government and a large bloc of voters renouncing the very officials they elected just three months ago.

title: Protests Erupt in Poland Over Big Price Increases
description: Polish protesters hurled snowballs at the police outside a Warsaw church today as scattered protests erupted against large-scale price increases ordered by Poland's Communist Government.

title: Patriotic Air
description: As usual, patriotism was very important to the ceremonies. In a dramatic pre-game event, the Navy's Blue Angels fighter jets zoomed over the field just as Herb Alpert held the last note of the national anthem on his trumpet. Minutes before, dozens of young men and women carrying red, white and blue balloons formed the Stars and Stripes to Alpert's performance of ''America the Beautiful.'' . . . No sooner did confetti made of yellow telephone-book pages float down after Nattiel's touchdown than nine groundskeepers charged onto the field to start picking up the pieces. They didn't stop there, though. After each change of possession, they came out quickly, and not merely to police the area. They replaced all divots, tamping them down with their feet.

title: Bush's Altitude Is Also Rather's
description: While the Bush-Rather clash is passing into history, an interesting question remains unanswered: Why did everybody care so much?

title: McDonnell to Retire
description: Sanford N. McDonnell, the chairman and chief executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said he would retire in March. Mr. McDonnell, 65 years old, has headed the company since 1980. He said he would be replaced by his cousin, John F. McDonnell. John McDonnell, 49, is the president of the St. Louis-based aerospace company and the younger son of its founder, the late James S. McDonnell. Sanford McDonnell will remain a director.

title: Donald L. Rogers, Executive, 59
description: Donald L. Rogers, president of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, died Jan. 18 of colon cancer at his home in Washington. He was 59.

title: Circumcision Under Criticism As Unnecessary to Newborn
description: Pamela and David Maier are expecting their first child in six months. Besides choosing a name for their new baby, the Maiers face another difficult decision: If it's a boy, should he be circumcised?

title: 12th Infant Gets New Heart At a Hospital in Loma Linda
description: Surgeons transplanted a heart into an 18-day-old boy born with a fatal defect and said today the infant was in critical but stable condition.

title: Thoughts Far From Football As Foes Gather Before Game
description: Somewhere far away, the Super Bowl parties were reaching their climax and two weeks of analysis were near their end. But inside this hotel ballroom where about 1,000 people sat, Super Bowl XXII was nothing more than a point of reference.

title: Dr. Melanie R. Adams Weds Dr. Dennis M. Fisher
description: Dr. Melanie Ruth Adams, a resident in pathology at the University of California at San Francisco, and Dr. Dennis Marshall Fisher, an associate professor of anesthesia and pediatrics at the university, were married yesterday at the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue in New York. Rabbi George Cohen and Cantor Donald Ritter officiated.

title: Gifts of Varying Size Continue to Be Sent For Neediest Cases
description: Gifts of all sizes, large and small, from $1 to $110,000, continue to flow in to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The 76th annual appeal, which opened after Thanksgiving, runs through February.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption Saturday with an article about the Writers Room on Waverly Place misidentified the writers at work in the photograph. They were Leonard Marcus, Ruth

title: Bridge: Jersey Judge Demonstrates Management Style in Match
description: On rare occasions a player can usefully adopt at the bridge table a technique developed in a daily non-bridge occupation.

title: For Japanese in U.S., School, Japanese Style
description: A leading Japanese university plans to build the first high school for Japanese students in the United States on the campus of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Pet Tiger Hurt in Car Wreck
description: A 290-pound pet tiger, riding in the back seat of a car on its way to a public appearance, was slightly injured in a traffic accident last week but is now back home with its owner. The cat's owner, Edwin Corders, remained at its side last Thursday for the seven hours it spent at a veterinary clinic here.

title: Wallace Groves Is Dead at 86; Developer of Resort in Bahamas
description: Wallace Groves, whose Wall Street career ended in the 1930's when he was convicted for mail fraud and who then went on to develop the city of Freeport in the Bahamas into a major resort and gambling area, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital in Miami, six days after suffering a stroke. He was 86 years old.

title: Rock: Joe Ely and Band, at the Ritz
description: JOE ELY delivered twanging, stomping, full-tilt rock-and-roll at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, on Friday night. For a decade, Mr. Ely has been singing and writing songs that match basic rock to lyrics that delight in wordplay and imagery. In the 1970's, he put together a band that reflected his Lubbock, Tex., background, mixing Mexican accordion, soul saxophone and country steel guitar with guitar-driven rockabilly; on his 1984 album ''Hi-Res,'' he also flirted with computers and synthesizers. Now, with his recent album, ''Lord of the Highway,'' and in concert, he's decided to trade eclecticism for punch.

title: AIDS, Marriage and Folly in Illinois
description: The Illinois Legislature and Gov. James Thompson have set an inglorious example of what not to do about AIDS. Ignoring the advice of their own and other public health authorities, they enacted a law last year that compels everyone getting married in Illinois to be tested for the AIDS virus. The classic results of this stubborn folly would be ludicrous were it not for the nuisance and dismay inflicted on so many people.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Help for Caribbean
description: Little noticed in President Reagan's State of the Union Message was his endorsement of further trade help for the Caribbean Basin. Under 1983 legislation 22 Caribbean countries benefit from tariff-free access to the United States market.

title: Chiefs Reach a Greek-Turkish Accord
description: After meeting in this Alpine ski resort, the Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey announced what they said was an important agreement today to help bring peace and cooperation to their traditionally hostile countries.

title: Nets' Promise Is Thwarted
description: The Nets have often been a troubled franchise since they came into being in 1967 as the New Jersey Americans in the American Basketball Association. But at the midpoint of this National Basketball Association season, they have a 9-32 record after beating the Detroit Pistons Saturday night.

title: Karen Monson, 42, Music Critic and Author
description: Karen Monson, a music critic and author, died of complications arising from cirrhosis of the liver Saturday afternoon at the Monmouth County Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. She was 42 years old.

title: Metro Matters; Special Access: Helping to Shape Koch's Outlook
description: Press the first button on the private telephone at Gracie Mansion and you'll automatically be connected with a special woman in Mayor Koch's life. ''I have very special access,'' she said. Nearly every day at 6 A.M., the Mayor picks her up for a 40-minute workout on a treadmills in a downtown gym. He dines at her apartment almost weekly. She is an unsalaried member of mayoral commissions on the Status of Women and on the Year 2000. She is a sounding board and a source whose complaint about pickpocketing led to creation of a special police squad that arrested more than two dozen suspects on the Madison Avenue bus. Her tip about tony stores that help customers avoid sales taxes, a scam confided to her by a friend, has already raised more than $12 million in penalties and back taxes for the city.

title: U.S. AGENCY KNEW OF CONTRACT LEAK, TWO AIDES TESTIFY
description: The General Services Administration knew that competitors for Government telephone contracts had improperly obtained secret bid information about the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but the agency allowed them to bid on the contracts anyway, according to two agency employees.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Collecting His Dues
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, figures the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers owes him -$1,994.46 to be precise.

title: I.M.F. Trying to Be More Flexible
description: The International Monetary Fund, long criticized for insensitivity to the consequences of its demands for austerity in debtor countries, is trying a new approach.

title: Bush and the Iran-Contra Affair: Uneasy Stalemate
description: For more than a year, Vice President Bush has been groping for a way to prevent the Iran-contra matter, the Administration's worst foreign policy disaster, from becoming his own political albatross.

title: Investigations On Boesky Tie Clear Goldin
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, has been cleared of any charges of legal or ethical misconduct after a yearlong series of investigations into his financial relationship with Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator.

title: Killing Jars Dallas Into Taking Stock
description: This has always been a city that has defined itself by the ways it differs from other cities: a cool, managerial island of businesslike calm amid the ferment of urban America.

title: Festive Fans Vocal In Their Devotion
description: The Redskins' victory in Super Bowl XXII brought thousands of fans into the streets to celebrate tonight, some of them rabid followers and some of them foreigners with an attitude of pleased befuddlement.

title: Carl J. Conti
description: When Steve Chen, one of the nation's leading supercomputer engineers, left Cray Research Inc. in a dispute last year, it was only hours before Carl J. Conti called. As I.B.M.'s chief of mainframe computer development, Mr. Conti, 50, seized an opportunity to move I.B.M. into the only major computer field where it currently has no offerings. I.B.M. announced in December that it would market Mr. Chen's next 64-processor supercomputer, probably sometime in 1992.

title: Unsuccessful Transition
description: On the basketball court, Bob Gaeta has always been a gunner. He lived and died by the jump shot.

title: Business and the Law; Regulator's Fears On Bond Insurers
description: JAMES P. CORCORAN is on a mission. To Mr. Corcoran, the Superintendent of Insurance of New York State, a key segment of the insurance industry lacks important rules, and as a result, the possibility of an insurance crisis looms.

title: PLAN COULD STALL BANKING MERGERS
description: The drive by many of the nation's largest banks to expand through acquisitions may come to a near standstill for several years because of a proposal by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; A Potentially Hot New Issue Is Put on Ice
description: The Neuroscientific Corporation had the right names associated with it to be a hot new stock issue. By selling shares to the public, the tiny manufacturer of medical equipment hoped to transfer a device developed in the laboratories of Rockefeller University into practical and immediate use in the nation's hospitals. In the process, its stockholders could profit handsomely.

title: The Journal Gets a New Order
description: For years, The Wall Street Journal - with its huge circulation and staff and its soaring advertising revenues - has been the envy of newspaper publishers and editors throughout the land.

title: Inconsistency Is Knicks' Worst Enemy
description: The Knicks, one game past the midway point of the National Basketball Association season following their overtime loss in Chicago Saturday night, have baffled coaches, scouts and fans with their inconsistent play.

title: Osaka Journal; They Call Japan Home, but Are Hardly at Home
description: The narrow streets and small wooden homes look at first like any other Japanese neighborhood. But here and there, telltale signs appear - a sticker on a door with a tiny Korean flag, bolts of brightly colored Korean silk hanging in a shop window, posters of red-cheeked girls in Korean traditional dress, the kimchi pots of spicy pickled cabbage on display in the central market.

title: College Basketball; Syracuse Pounds Michigan by 89-71
description: The Orangemen had been waiting for what seemed like an eternity.

title: 'Highlights in Jazz' Concert
description: A number of noted jazz musicians, including Tito Puente, Phil Woods and Jon Faddis, are to perform at a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert on Thursday, at New York University, Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place. The concert marks the 15th anniversary of the jazz series. Also to appear are John Pizzarelli Jr., Bob Mover, Tony Monte, Kenny Washington and James Williams. Tickets are $9 ($6.50 for students.) Information: 998-4999.

title: Administrators of Neglect
description: Surrogate Renee Roth, are you and the city's other surrogates paying attention? It's hard to imagine a stronger claim on it than the just-disclosed ''sting'' operation in which court representatives were secretly videotaped stealing cash and valuables from the apartments of people they thought were dead. The culprits are investigators hired by the city's Public Administrators to inventory property in the apartments of people who have died.

title: Few Detect Signs of Fed Easing
description: While economists vainly looked for signs last week that the Federal Reserve had eased monetary policy, interest rates in the credit markets fell sharply on the assumption that the Fed would ratify those declines by pushing short-term interest rates lower.

title: Joseph J. Coffey Sr., Union Organizer, 80
description: Joseph J. Coffey Sr., a co-founder of Local 804, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died Saturday at City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, in Queens, after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Woodside, Queens.

title: Growth Lag Reported by Purchasers
description: The rate of growth of the nation's economy slowed in January, lagging behind December in production and employment, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.

title: Pressure on Elway A Key for Redskins
description: Washington's defensive schemes, which imprisoned John Elway's skills, and the use of the size advantage of its offensive line were the key elements in the Redskins' Super Bowl rout of the Denver Broncos.

title: D. S. Kane Dies at 81; Lawyer and Professor
description: David Schilling Kane, a former president of the American Patent Law Association and former adjunct professor at the New York University School of Law, died of cancer Saturday at Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital. Mr. Kane was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $10 million from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: RJR NABISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $208 million from discontinued operations and a charge of $80 million from the early retirement of debt. The earnings in the latest fourth quarter were reduced by a pre-tax contribution of $27 million to the RJR Nabisco Foundation, a corporate charitable fund. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $4 million for the quarter and $39 million for the year. The company said the 1986 fourth quarter was adversely affected by charges related to the early retirement of high-cost debt and a one-time corporate streamlining program; the company did not provide figures for the charges.

title: MDT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $554,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $121,000 and $304,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said that results reflect the acquisition of Castle Coal Co. on July 2, 1987 in a purchase transaction.

title: Takeover Planned For Taco Chains
description: A restaurant operator said he planned to acquire Naugles Inc. and Del Taco Inc. in separate transactions and combine them into what would be the nation's second-largest Mexican-American fast-food chain. Terms were not disclosed. Anwar Soliman, chief executive of the American Restaurant Group of Newport Beach, Calif., said the two chains would add about $250 million to his company's sales, which are already at $500 million a year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Never before have I been accused of taking 30 pieces of silver.'' - Senator Daniel K. Inouye, on the furor over a bill he sponsored. [ A1:1. ]

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Tobacco Co., a unit of American Brands Inc., said it had agreed to sell its non-cigarette smoking-tobacco brands, related assets and a Virginia factory to Dorsett STB Inc., of Stamford, Conn., for an undisclosed price.

title: Star Entertainer Loses Its Sparkle
description: For an entertainment company with an extraordinary mystique, MCA Inc. has been performing mundanely of late.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included gains of $417,000 for the quarter and $2,051,000 for the year related to certain real estate sales. c-Included losses of $381,000 for the quarter and $284,000 for the year related to certain real estate sales. The latest year also included 11 months of operations of Development Corp. of America, acquired in December 1986. The prior year also included a gain of $1,156,000 from the sale of a cable television subsidiary.

title: Early Cases of AIDS
description: USING a state cancer registry, researchers have identified what they believe were four of the earliest and longest-living AIDS patients in New York, providing a possible clue as to when the AIDS virus first appeared in the city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., appointed Richard M. Moose senior vice president of government affairs.

title: Senate Backs 2 U.N. Labor Pacts
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved two International Labor Organization conventions today, marking the first time in nearly 35 years that the United States has formally approved treaties with the United Nations agency.

title: New Evidence Citesv Overactive Nerves For Irritable Bowel
description: IRRITABLE bowel syndrome used to be considered a classic psychosomatic disorder. When patients complained of abdominal pain, gas, diarrhea or constipation that came and went with no apparent reason, their doctors often referred them to psychiatrists.

title: CUMBERLAND FEDERAL SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in May 1987.

title: New Leader In Seoul Finds Honeymoon
description: It was a small gesture, but South Koreans nonetheless took note the other day when President-elect Roh Tae Woo presided over a public meeting and said that people could smoke if they wished.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL SAVINGS OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in April 1987.

title: Gunman Kills One in Brooklyn
description: Four people were shot, one fatally, by a gunman who fired on his victims from atop a four-story building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Toxic Waste Settlement

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special provision of $5 million for loan and lease losses. c-Net income.

title: Extinctions and Isotopes
description: Two groups of scientists studying isotopes (forms of atoms) have reached sharply contrasting conclusions about the possible causes of mass extinctions. Their papers appear to add fuel to the debate over comets' role.

title: METROPOLITAN FINANCIAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $825,000 for employment contract termination. c-Net income

title: When Everybody Shouts, Who Listens?
description: When everybody shouts, nobody listens. The shouting in this country about Nicaragua gets louder and louder, the time for listening and thinking shorter and shorter.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $500,000 for the quarter and $2.8 million for the year. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dance: A World Tour in One Place
description: AMAN danced its way from country to country on Saturday night at Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: Carte Blanche Loses Plea
description: An arbitration panel has awarded $10 million to the Carte Blanche franchises in Malaysia and Singapore after finding that Carte Blanche International, the parent company, had breached an agreement to support the franchises.

title: ATALANTA-SOSNOFF CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from the repurchase of convertible debentures of $413,000 for the quarter and $766,000 for the year. In addition, the quarter income is after a pretax charge of $1.3 million for separation costs related to the resignation of the company's president and a $1.1 million in pretax trading losses. The income for the latest year is after a pretax charge of $1.9 million for separation costs related to employee resignations.

title: BANKS OF MID-AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included provisions for loan losses of $11,280,000 for the quarter and $64,179,000 for the year, compared with year-ago periods of $15,775,000 for the quarter and $72,997,000 for the year.

title: HWC DISTRIBUTION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
N.B.A. Notebood; Knicks Are Target Of Scoring Spurts
description: The Knicks appear to bring out the best in opposing players.

title: Koch Proposes Cut in Services With Tax Rise
description: Mayor Koch, saying New York City's fiscal condition was poised in the middle ground ''between the high slopes and the valley,'' proposed a $24.9 billion spending plan yesterday that calls for increased taxes and substantial cuts in services to close what he said would be a $758 million budget gap.

title: TERMIFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Report Urges Higher Margin on Futures
description: The staff of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission recommended today that futures exchanges consider increasing the margin, or down payment, investors must put up to buy futures contracts ''to insure greater protection against unexpected price spikes.''

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Another Performance Halted at the Met
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPITOL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter net was reduced by an increase of $4,025,000 in the bank's loan loss reserve and by the reclassification of about $22 million of loans and joint ventures as non-accruing.

title: Georgi Malenkov Dies at 86; Stalin Successor
description: Georgi M. Malenkov, who was a leading political figure in the Soviet Union after the death of Stalin but who was ousted in a Kremlin power struggle and sent into political oblivion, died last month, a Soviet official said yesterday. He was 86 years old. Malenkov was Prime Minister for two years and, for a short time, head of the Communist Party. He also gained notoriety in the Soviet Union for his personal role in helping conduct the Stalinist purges in which millions of Russians died.

title: Tax Watch; A Few Changes In 1987 Act, Too
description: THOUGH the focus of most taxpayers over the next two and a half months will be on April 15 and all the sweeping changes incorporated in their 1987 returns from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the Revenue Act of 1987 also holds immediate implications for many people.

title: For Local Elections in the West Bank and Gaza
description: LEAD: The news from Jerusalem that America is ready to push for the local election of Palestinian leaders in the West Bank and Gaza Strip is heartening and richly deserves support, not least from the American Jewish community.

title: Two Officers Are Cleared In a Killing
description: A Queens grand jury has found no basis for criminal charges against two police officers who fired 11 shots in killing a man who the police said was lunging at one of the officers with a knife.

title: Nova Seeks Tests On Cold Remedy
description: The Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation, as expected, asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve human testing of a cold remedy that the company hopes will revolutionize treatment of the common cold. Nova is developing a nasal spray compound known as bradykinin antagonist, aimed at blocking bradykinin, a powerful pain-producing substance in the human body. The company believes the substance, by blocking the bradykinin, can reduce such cold symptoms as sore throats and nasal congestion.

title: Our Towns; As a Mob Howls, One in Yonkers Pleads for Sanity
description: Laurie Recht says she is 4 feet, 10 1/2 inches tall, though she wears her hair teased up, so this may be a slight exaggeration. She is 34, has lived on her own since she was 18, working as a secretary. She's the kind of person who, before going shopping Sunday, peeked into her apartment building rec room and asked if anybody needed anything. Sure enough, a woman named Teresa - Ms. Recht didn't know her last name - needed a white bread.

title: Walton Gives Up a Post In Shuffle at Wal-Mart
description: Sam M. Walton, the chairman and chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., announced yesterday that he was relinquishing one of his titles as part of a management realigment.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MONEY AND CLASS IN AMERICA:

China Won't Become a Superpower Soon

description: b-After a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $6.2 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $4.6 million for the year, and gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $6.8 million for the quarter and $78.5 million for the year; the year also included an extraordinary charge of $4.7 million.

title: Big Assignment For Redskins Is to Win Again
description: Joe Gibbs was worried today, even with his second Super Bowl of the 1980's secure.

title: Directors' Guild Names Nominees for Top Prize
description: Two extremely dark horses are among the five nominees for the Directors Guild of America's award for the best movie director of 1987. Nominations were announced Sunday.

title: Damage to Puget Sound Area Feared After Oil Barge Sinks
description: Trying to avert an environmental catastrophe, Coast Guard officials here are struggling to contain heavy oil from a barge that sank in pristine water about 70 miles north of Seattle Sunday.

title: China Protests
description: The Chinese Government has protested a plan by the Pentagon to include China on a new list of nations that are considered hostile to the United States, according to officials of the Defense Department.

description: Down Corning is a joint venture of Down Chemical Co. and Corning Glass Works.

title: Why No Mouse Should Ever Escape AIDS Experiment
description: A LABORATORY at the National Institutes of Health has been turned into a maximum-security prison, with a full complement of locks and bars as well as deadly traps set to destroy any escapees. Pity the unlucky mouse who decides to make a break for it.

title: Careers; Selecting A Specialty In Medicine
description: ASTUDY by Glaxo Inc., the pharmaceutical company, confirms something that medical students have grappled with for years: Prospective doctors pick a specialty with difficulty, even a little agony. Glaxo discovered that ''an overwhelming majority of 80 percent of medical students'' believed they did not have enough valid information on which to base a decision.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Excludes unrealized gains of $123 million from investments. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $122.5 million from the sale of the 50- percent interest in the computerized airline reservation system (PARS). d-Net loss The company said 1986 was adversely impacted by the strike of TWA's flight attendants during the first half of the year and then favorably impacted in the fourth quarter by the sale of PARS and that results for the first nine months of 1986 do not include the results of Ozark Air Lines which was acquired and first merged with TWA's financial results beginning with the fourth quarter 1986. The company said that excluding the 1986 PARS gain, the results for the year ended Dec. 31, 1987 were ahead of the results for 1986 by $335 million. The company did not report revenue figures.

title: Derby Poses a Challenge for Forty Niner
description: Forty Niner's credentials as the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby May 7 might appear impeccable. The colt dominated his rivals last year when he was the 2-year-old champion. He is a son of Mr. Prospector, the nation's hottest sire. He is handled by Woody Stephens, who has won more Triple Crown races than any living trainer.

description: IT took less time to set up the computer than to clean up the packing materials afterward -the plastic wrapping and foam bracing and that imitation popcorn that sticks obstinately to everything.

description: Mark Johnson scored twice to lift the Devils to a 5-4 victory over the league-leading Calgary Flames tonight.

Suspect Held in Killing
description: A 26-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged in the slaying and robbery of a Manhattan executive last week, the police said. The suspect, Charles Youngblood of 295 Prospect Place, had been a frequent vistor to the apartment of the executive, Layne Alexander, Assistant Chief Aaron Rosenthal said. Mr. Alexander, a senior executive of Price Waterhouse, was found at the apartment at 36 West 15th Street in Manhattan.

title: G.S.A. Official Refuses To Testify on Bidding
description: Sureshar Lal Soni, the design engineer accused of giving secret bid information to competitors for Government phone contracts, exercised his Fifth Amendment right today, as expected, when he was questioned in a deposition proceeding by a lawyer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Orion Pictures
description: John W. Kluge, the chairman of Metromedia Inc., disclosed that he had increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kluge said he had raised his holdings in the motion picture and television production concern to 24 percent, from 23 percent. Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of National Amusements Inc., holds more than 26 percent of Orion's stock.

title: West Side Co-op Rejects Apartment for Museum
description: The American Museum of Natural History, seeking to provide its new president with an apartment, was turned down for a cooperative in the landmark Beresford Apartments, museum officials have said.

title: Astronomers Discover Geminga Does Exist
description: WORKING against such long odds that many colleagues had given up on the problem, two Columbia University astronomers have solved the mystery of Geminga, a seemingly empty point in the sky that emits intense gamma rays.

title: Finland's President Leads in Vote but Seems Likely to Face Runoff
description: In a surprisingly suspenseful conclusion to a dull campaign, President Mauno Koivisto failed today to win the clear majority he needed to nail down a second six-year term.

title: ELIOT BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item of $175,000. The bank converted to stock ownership in July 1987.

title: Advertising; New Mission For Bunny At Playboy
description: THE management of Playboy magazine feels it is beginning to recover from the body blow delivered two years ago when an intimidating letter was sent to retailers by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's Commission on Pornography. Advertising pages and circulation figures are turning up for the first time in a long time. This appears to be a good time for Playboy to advertise.
