title: Sanders in Awe Over Record
description: On Sunday, Ricky Sanders set a Super Bowl record with 193 yards in pass receptions. Then came seemingly endless visits from family and friends. He was weary and tired and happy. He felt he was on a roller coaster.

title: Foley Rated No. 1
description: Thomas S. Foley, the House majority leader, was rated the most effective leader in Congress in a recent poll of 317 senior Capitol Hill aides. Sixty-six percent of the aides said Mr. Foley, a Washington Democrat, was doing a very good to excellent job.

title: Candidates Spend a Lot Promising They Won't
description: Presidential candidates have poured nearly $1.8 million into television advertising for the New Hampshire primary, with Republicans outspending Democrats, 13-1, in increasingly testy arguments over who is the most qualified to cut the Federal budget deficit without raising taxes.

title: U.S. to Get Andes Condors
description: From 10 to 20 condors from the Andes in South America may be released later this year in California as part of an effort to revive the population of their California cousins.

title: Rigged Primary Rules
description: New York's nitpicking election law forces Presidential candidates to spend inordinate time and resources just to get on the ballot for the state's April 19 primary. But the highest price will be paid by rank-and-file Republican candidates, thanks to the way New York has rigged the political calendar.

title: Siege at Newspaper Ends With Hostages Safe
description: Two heavily armed American Indians took 17 people captive in a newspaper office this morning to protest the death of a black jail inmate. The Indians released about half the hostages after a few hours, then released the others after a 10-hour standoff.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Sports People; Coming to Terms
description: Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants' infielder, and Jeff Russell, the Texas Rangers' pitcher, agreed to new contracts with their clubs yesterday after having filed for arbitration. Uribe will earn a reported $535,000; Russell will receive a reported $190,000. . . . Arbitration hearings began yesterday. The first case heard involved the Braves' Gerald Perry.

title: College Basketball; Villanova Beats Georgetown
description: Villanova's 7-foot-2-inch Tom Greis scored 21 points tonight as the Wildcats built a 16-point lead early in the second half, then held on to defeat Georgetown, 64-58, in a Big East Conference game.

title: British Banks Lift Rates
description: Three big British banks raised their basic interest rates by half a point today, to 9 percent, after the Bank of England increased its money market rate. The central bank's move came as a surprise, but Barclays, Midland and National Westminister actrd quickly.

title: Sandstrom Returns to Form
description: A power outage having suddenly left his office in darkness, Coach Michel Bergeron carefully made his way down a short hall into the Rangers' locker room. There, in the meager light provided by an auxiliary floodlight, he stood, smiled, answered questions and waited patiently for somebody to flip the proper switch.

SEEDS OF NOBILITY SEEN IN BLUEBERRY
description: Bob Coffey insists that he is not sore at the President. But he thinks Mr. Reagan has had some bad advice, and he is willing to help correct that.

title: Big Program Trading Firms Unlikely to Cut Back Soon
description: Millions of Super Bowl television viewers learned on Sunday that Shearson Lehman Hutton would not engage in program trading for its own account. Similarly, several other brokerage firms, including Merrill Lynch, seem to be courting investors by sending the same message through newspaper ads these days.

title: Contributors From Overseas Give to Neediest Cases Fund
description: Sylvia D. Beyman of Rehovot, Israel, was so distressed over a recent editorial in The New York Times about the needy elderly that she wrote a note to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''Please use my donation to help some elderly man or woman,'' she said, sending $50.

title: Police in Warsaw Detain 50 In Protest Against Rumania
description: The Polish police halted a demonstration outside the Rumanian Embassy in Warsaw in less than a minute today, detaining at least 50 people as they unfurled protest banners.

title: Coral Kinsolving, 57, Advertising Executive
description: Coral Eaton Kinsolving, a former advertising and newspaper executive who was active in New York City community affairs and the management of Democratic political campaigns, died of cardiac arrest on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 57 years old.

title: Salant Seeking Apparel Maker
description: The Salant Corporation, an apparel manufacturer that emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings last June, has begun an unsolicited bid to acquire Manhattan Industries, one of the largest apparel makers, for more than $80 million.

title: 41% OF PREGNANT NAVY WOMEN FOUND UNWED
description: A study by a Navy nurse says a high percentage of the women in the Navy who become pregnant are unmarried.

title: Sports People; Honor for Syracuse
description: The undefeated Syracuse University football team was honored yesterday in Albany at a ceremony attended by Governor Cuomo and state legislators. The Governor, a former minor league baseball player, said that ''as an over-the-hill athlete from a long, long time ago, it was an absolute joy to watch Coach MacPherson and the Syracuse team this year.'' Joining the Governor at the ceremony were the Syracuse coach, Dick MacPherson, and 20 members of his team, including the outstanding quarterback Don McPherson. Syracusewent 11-0 in the regular season and then played a tie with Auburn in the Sugar Bowl.

title: After Slow Start, Kemp's Campaign Moves With Conservatives' Support
description: Are the Republicans re-discovering Jack Kemp?

title: ECUADOR RIGHTISTS SET BACK IN VOTE
description: In a major setback for conservative forces here, a Social Democrat finished first in Ecuador's presidential election Sunday and will face a left-leaning opponent in a runoff May 8.

title: Mildred Evans Williams, Psychiatrist, 81
description: Mildred Evans Williams, who practiced psychiatry for more than 30 years in Manhattan, died Saturday at the Candlewood Valley Nursing Home in New Milford, Conn. She was 81 years old.

Bolshoi Dancers to Star With City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet has announcedthat Nina Ananiashvili and Andris Liepa, two principal dancers of the Bolshoi Ballet, will perform five times with the company at the State Theater.

title: Sports People; Nehemiah Talks Track
description: Not many years ago, he was track and field's No. 1 hurdler, and world marks he set in 1981 and 1982 still stand. But from complacency that made him ''tire of track and field the way a child tires of a toy,'' Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah at the age of 24 sought new challenges in pro football and spent four years as a wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers. He showed occasional brilliance, but never achieved the dominance he had known as a hurdler. Nehemiah regained his amateur status in track in 1986, but his comeback was postponed last year by an Achilles' tendon injury that required surgery. Only now does he feel his speed and strength have returned intact, but he has yet to regain the hurdling technique that enabled him to establish a world record 12.93 seconds in the 110 meters outdoors in 1981 and a world best of 6.82 seconds indoors at 55 meters in 1982. ''I don't know if anyone, including me, can ever surpass those record times,'' said Nehemiah, now 28 years old and assistant track coach at Stanford. ''I'm old news to young guys in track now, but I want to reclaim my reputation for being the best. I have to forget about being a world-record holder and just be a competitor.'' Nehemiah is not talking or thinking about the Olympics now. His immediate goal is to regain form and win a race, the one on Friday in the Panasonic-Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden where his old rival, Greg Foster, will offer the main opposition in the 55-meter hurdles. ''The thought of beating Greg is a great incentive for me,'' Nehemiah said at a track writers' luncheon at Madison Square Garden. ''He's the number one hurdler in the world now.''

title: STAGE: 'MARTIN,' MUSICAL
description: IN ''Martin,'' Lamar Alford's musical pageant about the life and times of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., King himself remains a distant figure. Through the hour-and-45-minute work, fragments of King's speeches, spoken by Everett Van Darby, are scattered like marking stones among scenes depicting ordinary life in America between 1955 and 1968.

description: The city is paying $50,000 a year for a private tutor for the children of four women involved in a radical group that engaged in a deadly confrontation with the police three years ago, according to a published report.

description: Vice President Bush's televised quarrel with Dan Rather neither helped nor hurt his image, a New York Times Poll has found, but the persistent controversy over his role in the Iran-contra affair appears to pose a long-term threat to his credibility.

Antonio Araujo do Valle, president of the Rio de Janeiro rail workers' union and a member of the national strike command, said all 85,000 workers were on strike.

title: Concert: Kronos Plays Soviet Work
description: WHETHER or not female composers are getting enough chances to show their music, they are certainly getting more. As with all such cases - where a cultural movement has received its impetus in good part from outside sources - there will be a future reckoning, a shaking out process. At this date, some considerable reputations are going to have to stand on the basis of musical quality alone, not on questions of equal rights or past wrongs. And they are going to have trouble doing it - just as Vladimir Feltsman is going to have trouble being more than just another Russian pianist once the cachet of political martyrdom has worn off him.

The Stage: 'Ariano'
description: ARIANO seems to have everything going for him. His Laundromats and numbers operation bring in enough to provide his cute wife, Dolores, with a snazzy wardrobe and his cute 7-year-old son, Serafin, with an I.B.M. personal computer. But Ariano, who is of Puerto Rican descent, is obsessed with what he regards as white America's obsession with color. ''For them we are all black,'' cries the light-skinned Ariano, who wants everyone to know that his family comes from ''the whitest town in the whole island.''

description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had suspended the production of its disk camera six years after its introduction. The company said that declining demand and excess inventory had influenced its decision.

title: Sports People; Boxer Arrested
description: Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, the ninth-ranked heavyweight in the World Boxing Council rating, was arrested along with his brother and sister Sunday night after a dispute at an airline ticket counter in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The disagreement was said to have begun when Eastern Airline ticket agents told Juneau Ruddock, 20 years old, that her ticket to Toronto was invalid because of a travel agent's mistake. Ms. Ruddock began screaming, grabbed a ticket agent, and tried to pull her through the luggage opening at the counter, the police said. Edward Curran, a deputy, said she pushed him when he tried to calm her, and resisted his efforts to handcuff her. Then, the 6-foot-3-inch, 221-pound boxer became ''verbally abusive'' and punched a dent into a computer terminal, said a Broward Sheriff's spokesman, George Crolius. Four deputies subdued him. The other brother, Delroy Ruddock, 25, tried to grab Curran as he was trying to handcuff the sister, Crolius said. The Ruddocks were charged with battery and resisting arrest with vio-lence and were released on bond.

title: Schwab Cutbacks
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage, said it would reduce its nationwide work force by about 5 percent, or 160 employees. The company said the layoffs were necessary because of a drop in stock trading. They followed other cost-cutting moves in recent weeks.

title: Sports People; Fenner Enters Plea
description: Derrick Fenner, the former star running back at the University of North Carolina, has pleaded guilty to one count of cocaine possession, the Prince George's County state's attorney's office said yesterday. Sentencing was set for March 23 in Upper Marlboro, Md. Fenner could receive up to four years in prison. Under the arrangement, the prosecution agreed not to prosecute a weapons charge. A murder charge against Fenner was dropped last November by prosecutors who said new evidence had revealed that Fenner was not near the scene of the crime. Fenner has been trying to return to the University of North Carolina. He was the leading rusher in the Atlantic Coast Conference in 1986.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANK OF SAN FRANCISCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a provision for loan losses of $2 million.

title: Navy Payment To Grumman
description: The Navy said today that it would pay the Grumman Corporation up to $60 million to help cover unexpected expenses in the development of a new model of the F-14 Tomcat jet fighter. Under the agreement, the

title: INOUYE CONCEDES 'ERROR' IN SENATE
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, who may be in line to become the next Senate majority leader, acknowledged today that he had made ''an error in judgment'' in pushing a pet measure through Congress as it rushed to adjournment last year.

title: Yeltsin Speech Termed An Attack on Privilege
description: The former Moscow Communist Party chief denounced privilege and criticized Raisa Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in the speech that led to his dismissal, according to a document quoted by Le Monde reported today.

title: New York Board of Estimate Angry at Move to Abolish It
description: Members of the New York City Board of Estimate yesterday angrily rejected the idea that the powerful board was endangered because any effort to restructure it was likely to violate the Federal Voting Rights Act.

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $71,000 for the quarter and $1,576,149 for the year. c-After capital gains of $183,845 for the quarter and $3,012,436 for the year.

title: Home Video Industry Feeling Middle Age
description: The home video industry, born just a decade ago, is already feeling the effects of middle age.

title: Rail Controller Accepts Blame in Amtrak Crash
description: A control tower operator who fled his post after an Amtrak train and a maintenance vehicle collided last week has acknowledged causing the accident by forgetting to switch the train to an empty track, investigators said today.

title: Dance Figures Meet To Guess the Future
description: Alarms were raised, calls to action were made and there was a good deal of often-anguished self-analysis in the three-day ''1988 National Roundtable'' sponsored last weekend at the Vista Hotel in New York by Dance/ U.S.A., a service organization for nonprofit professional dance in America.

title: STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PEERLESS TUBE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of about $240,000 from a change in the method of determining the cost of its inventory from LIFO to FIFO.

title: Jury Sees Chambers Videotape Account of Killing
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s videotaped account to the police of the death of Jennifer Levin, perhaps the prosecution's central piece of evidence in his murder trial, was played to the jury yesterday.

title: Compaq's Net Soars to $49 Million
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, riding a crest of strong demand for personal computers, said today that its net income tripled in the fourth quarter to $49 million, or $1.25 a share, from $16.2 million, or 57 cents a share, in the comparable 1986 quarter.

title: Groups Challenging Abortion Rules
description: Lawsuits by two states and several advocacy groups are to be filed today to block new Federal regulations that severely restrict access to information about abortion.

title: MAURY FEDERAL SAVINGS- TENNESSE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writeoff of $88,000 of FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Shifting Style, Dukakis Turns to Emotional Heat
description: The audience fell absolutely silent as Michael S. Dukakis read from the memoirs of a journalist imprisoned during the rule of Argentina's military Government.

title: Indian Families Are Evacuated In Passaic Fire
description: One-fourth of this city's Indian community was made homeless Sunday by a fire that roared through a 96-apartment building, driving 500 people into the street.

title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution Urging Restraint by Israelis
description: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that appealed to Israel to exercise restraint in the occupied territories and called for the Middle East situation to be resolved under United Nations auspices.

title: Construction Spending Up Only 0.3% for 1987
description: Construction spending, depressed by weakness in apartment and office building, edged up a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in 1987 for the worst showing in five years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Late Selloff Pushes Dow Down 13.59
description: LEAD: Stock prices meandered yesterday, with smaller issues doing relatively better than blue-chip issues.

title: Profit Off 40% At T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines earned $51 million, or $1.20 a share, in the fourth quarter, down 40 percent from $85 million, or $2.36 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: AMPLICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $76,328,000 and $80,920,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Candidates to Old and Young: You've Got a Friend
description: Leon Wieseltier, an adviser to Senator Albert Gore Jr., likes to tell the joke about why grandparents and grandchildren like each other so much.

title: By Design; Tip Your Hand
description: Gloves keep hands warm in cold weather. But now, and especially for this coming spring, they have a more glamorous purpose. In fact, the right pair just may be the strongest gesture of a personal fashion statement. To contrast with, not match, the rest of an ensemble is the point. And the stronger the color, the better.

title: Congress Can Reduce Parental Kidnappings
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard Shaw of CNN Reflects on Long Climb
description: Bernard Shaw seems puzzled by all the fuss. The senior Washington anchor of Cable News Network, the all-news, 24-hour cable network, has received much attention in the media since early December when he joined Peter Jennings of ABC, Tom Brokaw of NBC and Dan Rather of CBS in a pre-summit interview of President Reagan.

title: BRANFORD SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year per share earnings were calculated as if the sale of 1,552,500 shares in November 1986 had taken place at the beginning of the year.

title: SUMMIT SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: MCI Posts Profit in Quarter
description: The MCI Communications Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter net income of $33 million, or 11 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $502 million in the 1986 period.

title: SALANT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes a credit of $1,000,000 for estimated Chapter 11 reorganization expenses for both periods, and also includes a tax credit of $1,714,000 and $3,545,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $9,400,000 for estimated Chapter 11 reorganization expenses for both periods, and also includes a tax benefit of $1,295,000 and $2,712,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company completed a reorganization plan and emerged from bankruptcy proceedings on June 2, 1987.

title: Brazil to Use Own Cash in Paying Debt
description: In a move toward ending its year-long moratorium on debt repayment, Brazil said yesterday that it would pay $350 million today to banks around the world.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-After gains of $563,000 from a change in inventory accounting and $1,149,000 from a change in tax accounting.

title: Rise in Seagram Bid Wins Martell
description: After an intense six-week battle, the Seagram Company yesterday won its bid for Martell et Compagnie, the 273-year-old cognac house.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review of ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' yesterday gave an incorrect closing date for the production, which plays weekends at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The last performance is Feb. 12, not this Saturday.

title: Japan Ends 8 Farm Quotas, Keeps 2
description: Caught between foreign pressure to end its quotas on agricultural goods and lobbying by its farmers to keep them in place, Japan's Government decided today to retain its quotas on starch and dairy products and drop eight others.

title: Another Collapse For the Broncos
description: Before all their bags were packed, before the dramatic morning-after drop in prices at the souvenir stand in their hotel lobby, the speculation surrounding the restructuring of the Denver Broncos had begun.

title: New Top Executive Due At Bateman Eichler
description: Richard J. Capalbo, a marketing executive known for developing innovative investment concepts and using videos to sell them, will become the chairman, president and chief executive of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., a Los Angeles brokerage.

title: 5-Year Notes From G.M.A.C.
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 1/2 percent notes, due in 1993, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: UNION TEXAS PETROLEUM HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss In the latest quarter, preferred dividend requirements nearly totaled net income. The company said that during 1987 its replacement of oil and gas reserves exceeded its domestic production.

title: MULTI-COLOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,740,000 from cumulative effect of a change in accounting methods for the latest quarter, and the year-ago period includes a loss of $41,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SYSTEMS & COMPUTER TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Manila-I.M.F. Accord
description: The International Monetary Fund, pleased with the Philippine economy's performance, has agreed to extend a standby credit facility, Finance Secretary Vicente Jayme said today. He told reporters after a meeting with President Corazon C. Aquino that the facility was extended until the middle of this year.

title: Advertising; Famous Swiss Knives Get a New Promotion
description: As well known as they are, Swiss Army knives have received little, if any, advertising support in the United States. That's about to change, and those sharp operators at Warwick Advertising are going to do it.

title: Soprano Wins $10,000
description: Marvis Martin, a soprano with the Metropolitan Opera Company, is this year's recipient of the $10,000 Florida Prize, which the regional newspaper group of The New York Times Company gives each year to a Florida native or resident for outstanding work in the visual and performing arts. Ms. Martin will receive the award at a ceremony Friday at the Lakeland Country Club, Lakeland, Fla.

title: Both Sides on Contra Aid See Vote Shifting Their Way
description: White House officials and Congressional Democrats asserted today that their latest counts showed the undecided votes in Congress on renewed aid to the contras were turning their way, but neither side was openly confident of victory.

title: The Mayor's Hard-Times Budget
description: Edward Koch remembers the ''Drop Dead'' days of the fiscal crisis. The budget he proposed yesterday proposes painful but necessary cuts and taxes. Will city and state legislators be as disciplined?

title: Chicago Printers Reject Pact
description: Union printers have overwhelmingly rejected a proposed contract with The Chicago Tribune and will continue their 31-month strike against the newspaper, union officials say. The vote Sunday by members of Chicago Typographical Union No. 16 was 284 to 51 against the proposed contract. The contract would have brought lifetime annuities of $500 a month to most of the striking printers, but it also would have meant that only a small minority would have kept their jobs.

title: A Theory Sees Life, Of Sorts, On Pulsars
description: COULD life exist on the surface of a neutron star, where the temperature hovers around 14,000 degrees Fahrenheit and the pull of gravity is powerful enough to squash atoms? Several scientists looking into the question believe it is remotely possible.

title: Inquiry on Court Aides Was Exposed Early
description: A ''sting'' operation in which New York City property agents were videotaped taking valuables from the homes of people they thought were dead was exposed prematurely last month when the authorities sought the cooperation of two people under investigation, officials said yesterday.

title: Prudential Bonds Backed By Life Insurance Loans
description: The Prudential Insurance Company and its subsidiary, Prudential-Bache Securities, yesterday disclosed an innovative $445.6 million sale of bonds backed by loans to life insurance policyholders.

title: RJR Nabisco
description: The Planters Lifesavers Company, a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., said it would consolidate some manufacturing operations by closing a plant in Canajoharie, N.Y., and transferring production to other sites. The plant, which has a work force of 450 and is situated 60 miles west of Albany, will be closed by Dec. 31, the company said. Planters said a majority of the jobs would be eliminated and the plant sold.

title: The Return of Printing With Ink
description: SURE, we'd all love to have a laser printer, but at $1,800 to $5,000 and up, lasers are out of the price range of most personal computer users.

title: Hyperactive Boys Often Turn Out Normal
description: CONTRARY to the expectations of many experts, a new study indicates that boys who are hyperactive do not always have emotional or intellectual difficulties when they grow up.

title: KEY RATES
S.&P. Cuts 5 Bank Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation reduced the debt ratings of five banking companies yesterday, but the rating service kept intact J. P. Morgan & Company's triple-A rating, the highest rating possible.

title: ARMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $35.1 million for the quarter and year; a loss for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit of $13.5 million, a gain of $8.3 million from the early retirement of debt and a $3.9 million tax credit, both for the year. c-After a tax credit of $3.9 million. d-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $10.1 million, $87.6 million, aand $21 million and a tax credit of $8.3 million.

title: Belzbergs Buy Countrywide Stake
description: An investment group led by members of the Belzberg family of Canada, has bought a 6.6 percent stake in Countrywide Credit Industries and said it might seek control of the mortgage banking holding company, which is based in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Stanadyne Accepts Bid By Forstmann Little
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a Manhattan investment firm specializing in management buyouts, has agreed to buy Stanadyne Inc., which makes diesel injection systems and Moen plumbing supplies, the two companies said yesterday.

title: ZZZZ Best Denial Issued
description: Ernst & Whinney, the auditor for ZZZZ Best, disputed today that it had impeded a Congressional investigation into the role that the accounting firm played in the collapse of the carpet-cleaning concern last July. The failure cost investors almost $70 million Barry J. Minkow, the flamboyant chairman of ZZZZ Best, has pleaded not guilty to charges of racketeering, securities fraud and tax fraud.

title: THE DANCE: RACHEL LAMPERT
description: RACHEL LAMPERT cracked choreographic jokes in the works that Rachel Lampert and Dancers presented Sunday afternoon at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, 33 East 18th Street. Although she did not maintain a consistent level of invention, she certainly had a sense of humor.

title: G.M. Increases Some Dividends
description: The General Motors Corporation increased the dividends on its class H and class E stock, reflecting improved earnings of the independently reporting subsidiaries that they represent. Class H shares, which represent G.M. Hughes Electronics, will pay 22 cents each, up from 18 cents. Class E stock, which represents Electronic Data Systems, will pay 17 cents a share, up from 13 cents. G.M.'s common stock will continue to pay a dividend of $1.25.

title: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $13,448,000. c-Includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $122,152,000, or $5.62 a share. The company said improvements were achieved in spite of a $17 million decline in sales and profits of its albuminar product line due to severe pressure on prices.

title: Why Murdoch Doesn't Deserve a Waiver
description: For years, I have been a proponent of reasoned deregulation of the broadcast industry.

title: U.S. IS PROPOSING A FRESH APPROACH TO MIDEAST PEACE
description: The United States has undertaken a new Middle East peace initiative to provide elections for Palestinian self-government in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a formula for an early peace conference on the Middle East, American and Israeli officials said today.

title: Settlement Is Set In Vast Cleanup Of Toxic Waste
description: The Army and the Shell Oil Company agreed today to jointly pay as much as $1 billion to clean up the Army's Rocky Mountain Arsenal, one of the most contaminated toxic waste sites in the country.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Ronald Fierman has been promoted to group senior vice president, finance and administration, at Warwick Advertising.

title: CAPE COD BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $137,000 for the quarter and $237,000 for the 6 months.

title: Najaf Journal; In Ancient Shrines, Prayers and the Seeds of War
description: Some of Islam's holiest and most ancient shrines are here, in this small town in Iraq. And the seeds of modern conflict were planted here, too, to spread across Iran and much of the Arab world.

title: Patterns
description: Accessories by Picasso

title: Terminal, 75 Years Old, Is Still Grand
description: It is tightly crowded by skyscrapers, its concourse is filled with the homeless as well as with travelers, and it no longer receives such spectacular trains as the Twentieth Century Limited, but Grand Central Terminal is still, at 75, as potent a symbol of New York as it has ever been.

title: SLANDERING BY ABC CHARGED AT TRIAL
description: Victor Lasky, an author who lectured on Communist subversion in America, testified in his libel case yesterday that an ABC television documentary was ''propaganda.''

title: ACETO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grace's Profit At $50.1 Million
description: Bolstered by strong performances by its specialty chemicals, energy and general business operations, W. R. Grace & Company reported yesterday that it had a net income of $50.1 million, or 59 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987, in contrast to a loss of $559.9 million in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose to $1.31 billion from $1.06 billion.

title: In Publishing, Job Mobility Starts at the Top
description: Book publishing has long been an itinerant profession, partly because for younger editors, the best way to win a raise or a promotion was to move to another house - preferably with an author or two in tow.

title: Toward Educating the Homeless
description: HOMELESS children are the nation's shame. Their number has grown to 500,000 to 700,000, according to the National Coalition for the Homeless, a Wasington-based advocacy group. They live in temporary shelters, in welfare hotels, in abandoned buildings or on the street.

title: Freshman Is Tugged by Rival Sides on Rebel Aid
description: Representative Bob Clement, who was sworn in as the newest member of Congress a week ago today, didn't realize he had so many friends.

title: Meese Reportedly Sent Peres to Security Aide
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the fall of 1985 to deal with the President's national security adviser in discussions about Israeli backing for an Iraqi oil pipeline project, according to American and Israeli officials.

title: Quarterback Breakthrough
description: Doug Williams's performance in Super Bowl XXII gave a resounding answer to anyone still harboring doubts about whether a black man could quarterback a National Football League team successfully.

title: U.S. Voting Act Exerts a Strong Influence Over New York Politics
description: Betty Dolen, executive director of the New York City Board of Elections, usually has more contact with the Justice Department in Washington than with City Hall a few blocks away.

title: Dart Group Raises Bid For Chain
description: The Dart Group Corporation has started a cash tender offer of $31 a share for all the shares of Stop and Shop Companies Inc., or a total of $860 million.

title: 2,000 Welcome Champions
description: Some 2,000 cheering fans hailed the return of the Redskins to the Washington area tonight, capping 24 hours of nearly continuous celebration of the team's Super Bowl victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: Savings Unit Note Offering
description: Federal regulators for the savings and loan industry in the Southwest said today they would try to lower the cost of funds for savings institutions in the region by issuing up to $4 billion in notes backed by certificates of deposit guaranteed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: Trump Set To Buy All Of Resorts
description: Ending his long-running struggle with the management and shareholders of Resorts International Inc., the developer Donald J. Trump reached an agreement yesterday to buy the remaining Resorts shares he does not already own for about $125 million.

title: Born-Again Couture Sets the Trends
description: Five years ago it would have been absurd to think of Paris haute-couture designers as pace-setters for the world's fashion trends. Charming anachronisms, the made-to-order collections were considered historical monuments, like the Eiffel Tower or the Arc de Triomphe. The action was in ready-to-wear.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Business People column yesterday about management changes at the International Business Machines Corporation identified one appointee incompletely. It is Stephen B. Schwartz who will head I.B.M. Application Business Systems.

title: Shultz to Discuss Arms In Shevardnadze Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union later this month in an effort to narrow differences on the issue of reducing long-range arms in preparation for another summit meeting in May or June, Administration officials said today.

title: Leo Steiner Eulogy Laughingly Recalls 'Prince of Pastrami'
description: Leo Steiner, co-owner of the Carnegie Delicatessen and Restaurant, was eulogized yesterday amid laughter and tears as a ''prince of pastrami,'' a ''deli lama'' and a quintessential New Yorker at a memorial service at the Sutton Place Synagogue.

title: Pause Interrupts Bond Price Rally
description: The bond market rally took a breather yesterday as prices fell slightly after rising sharply in overseas trading.

title: Ward Role For Kidder
description: After an internecine struggle, General Electric Capital has brought Kidder, Peabody & Company, the investment banking firm, back into the negotiations to buy Montgomery Ward & Company, according to Wall Street sources with knowledge of the talks.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest year included an idle- plant writedown of $3,521,000 and 1986 included a writedown of $1.4 million.

title: MERRIMACK BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock form, May 1986.

title: Sports of The Times; Bus Ride to History
description: TO the side, a burgundy Subaru sports car symbolized his stature as Super Bowl XXII's most valuable player. At the lectern, his football-shaped trophy glistened as Doug Williams hobbled up to the microphone yesterday on the damaged left knee that he had ignored while throwing four touchdown passes in the second quarter of the Washington Redskins' 42-10 rout of the Denver Broncos.

title: Wang to Acquire Convergent Unit
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. has agreed to acquire the Informatics Legal Systems subsidiary of Convergent Inc., the companies announced today. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: E-II Deal Maker Is Thinking of E-III
description: Is there life after E-II? Donald P. Kelly apparently thinks there is.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $815,000 for the quarter and $2,485,000 for the year. c-Includes extroardinary tax credits of $501,000 for the quarter and $1,040,000 for the year.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS BANK-MARYLAND reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $335,000. The company went public in December 1986.

title: Hot Plumes at Sea
description: One of the most intriguing recent discoveries at sea has been the sudden outpouring of vast quantities of hot, mineral-laden water from at least one mid-ocean ridge. They produce volumes of hot water that can be 12 miles wide and more than a quarter mile in thickness.

title: Contras' Top Fighter Vows No Letup
description: He is perhaps the most wanted man in Nicaragua.

title: A Gain by Working Women
description: For the first time on record, working women earned 70 percent as much as working men in 1987, the Government reported today.

title: COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from consolidated companies of $48,676,000 for the quarter and $135,356,000 for the year, and after equity in net income of $325,000 for the quarter and $911,000 for the year. c-Included income from consolidated companies of $17,275,000 for the quarter and $44,628,000 for the year, and after equity in losses of $1,041,000 for the quarter and $1,731,000 for the year.

title: Teamwork and Tradition Meet on Ice
description: LEAD: At the bar of the curling room at the Country Club of Darien, Conn., on Super Bowl Sunday, there was only furtive talk of football. Amid free-flowing drinks and general midwinter good cheer, most talk was about the nation's nine top women's curling teams, which had gathered from as far away as Alaska for the 12th annual United States Ladies Curling

title: TIMBERLINE SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said year-ago fourth quarter sales includes a one-time revenue contribution of $336,000 from a major product update sold to existing Timberline users.

title: Theory Explains Slow Emergence of Mental Ills
description: MEDICAL scientists have often seen illnesses that seem at first to be isolated reponses to external shocks but later take on lives of their own. A single episode of depression, for example, can be followed by repeated attacks that come and go with increasing frequency for no apparent reason.

title: Murder Trial of 2 in Klan Set
description: A jury of 13 whites and one black was seated today for the murder trial of two former Ku Klux Klan leaders accused in the death of a black teen-ager in a case that drove a Klan unit into bankruptcy.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $15 million. c-After income of $1 million for the quarter and a loss of $2 million for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: CARLUCCI FAVORS SHIFT IN MX BASING
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci told Congress today that he was uncomfortable with the current deployment of MX long-range missiles in silos that are potentially vulnerable to Soviet attack.

title: Breast Cancer Continues Gradual Rise
description: New cases of breast cancer among American women are being found at the highest rate ever recorded, the National Cancer Institute said today.

title: Mr. Meese's Pipelines
description: The Attorney General of the United States is supposed to be an administration's chief lawyer, the counsel who helps his President faithfully execute the laws and the nation's top cop. As Attorney General for the second Reagan Administration, Edwin Meese seems to be spending more time under the magnifying glass of justice than wielding it. His involvement with a Middle East pipeline project promoted by his personal attorney and friend brings the latest public shame.

title: Dollar Advances Overseas; Gold Little Changed in U.S.
description: After rising against all key foreign currencies in overseas trading yesterday, the dollar held its gains in New York, where it traded in a narrow range.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,557,000 from extinguishment of debt.

title: Waldheim Panel Seeks Telegram
description: A member of a commission investigating Kurt Waldheim's war record flew to Yugoslavia today to try to track down a document that is said to implicate the Austrian President in war crimes.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Calgary Tries a 'Snow Dance'
description: With the start of the Winter Games 12 days away, everybody around here has been talking about the weather. One person did something about it. As his personal contribution to insuring cold temperatures and a white landscape, Iain Baxter, a local artist, choreographed a ''contemporary snow dance'' the other day, by inviting 440 people listed in the Calgary telephone book to the Olympic Plaza downtown.

title: Stockman, at Nofziger Trial, Recalls Lobby Effort
description: David A. Stockman, President Reagan's first budget director, described in Federal District Court today how, in 1982, senior White House officials offered Presidential support for a New York military contractor in exchange for votes for an Administration tax bill.

title: KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PTL Sues Bakkers and an Aide
description: The PTL television ministry filed a suit today seeking $52.8 million from its former leader, Jim Bakker, his wife, Tammy, and a former employee, charging mismanagement and unjustified compensation.

title: The Experience of Touch: Research Points to a Critical Role
description: THE experience of being touched, new research shows, has direct and crucial effects on the growth of the body as well as the mind.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $402,000, a gain after taxes of $1,844,000 from the sale of the Woodland Hills facility, and a provision for a loss of $770,000 on the sale of the Simi Valley facility to Gibraltar Savings.

title: INDIANA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1987 and a 3-for-1 stock split paid in May 1987.

title: Market Place; Good Times Seen In Leisure Sector
description: SEVERAL sectors of the recreation and leisure industry stand to benefit from the sharply lower dollar, which makes foreign vacations more expensive, and the lingering fear of a recession, some analysts say.

title: NEWS SUMMRY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1988
description: International A2-8 Edwin Meese denied wrongdoing in connection with a billion-dollar Iraqi pipeline project and insisted that he knew nothing about any plan to bribe Israeli officials. It was his first public comment about the matter. Page A1 Mr. Meese advised Shimon Peres in a 1985 letter to deal with the national security adviser rather than with the State Department on secret discussions about the pipeline project, officials said. A8 A new Middle East peace approach has been proposed by the United States, officials said. It would provide elections for Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a formula for a peace conference on the Middle East. A1 The undecided votes on contra aid were reported by both White House officials and Congressional Democrats to be turning in their favor. But neither side was openly confident of victory. A3 The most wanted man in Nicaragua may be Israel Galeano Cornejo, who is, by all accounts, the most effective commander the contras have ever had. He is an eight-year veteran of war against the Sandinistas. A3 In Ecuador's presidential election, a Social Democratic lawyer finished first and will face a left-leaning opponent in a runoff May 8. The results were a major setback for conservative forces there. A3 A former Soviet official denounced privilege and criticized Raisa Gorbachev and the Soviet Foreign Minister in the speech that led to his dismissal, Le Monde reported. The official, Boris N. Yeltsin was Moscow Communist Party chief. A2 Najaf journal: Seeds of war in ancient shrines A4 New South Korean President finds cautious support A4 U.S. vetoes U.N. vote urging Israeli restraint A6 Carlucci favors shift in MX basing A6 Progress on Palestinians sought A6 Finland's President leads in vote A8 National A10-20 Senator Inouye sought to rescind an $8 million appropriation to help North African Jews in France, saying he made ''an error in judgment'' in putting the appropriation into a big spending bill that Congress passed in its rush to adjourn. A1 The Bush-Rather faceoff neither helped nor harmed the Vice President's image, but the persistent controversy over his role in the Iran-contra affair may be taking a heavy toll, a New York Times poll shows. A1 A $1 billion toxic waste cleanup of the most contaminated site in the country, the Army's Rocky Mountain Arsenal, will be paid for by the the Army and the Shell Oil Company, according to a court settlement. A10 Presidential candidates' advertising on television for the New Hampshire primary has cost $1.8 million, with Republicans outspending Democrats 13-to-1, according to a study of campaign spending. A14 Is Jack Kemp being re-discovered? Recent polls have found his standing among Republicans has improved, and conservative publications have rallied to his cause. A14 An oil spill in Puget Sound resulted when a barge sank in pristine water about 70 miles north of Seattle. Coast Guard officials, trying to avert an en-vironmental catastrophe, are struggling to contain the heavy oil. A13 AIDS research using a ''mouse jail'' is being conducted at the National Institutes of Health. The animals carry genes from the AIDS virus, and fears of their escape are the reason for the security precautions. C1 Hogeye journal: The noble blueberry A10 Arizona impeachment inquiry is stalled A10 Stockman recalls lobbying effort in Nofziger case A11 Groups challenge abortion rules A12 Candidates woo advocates of young and old A15 Gunmen release 9 hostages at North Carolina newspaper A19 Washington Talk A18 Key lawmakers are targets in drives for votes on rebel aid Regional A21, B1-3 A New York City spending plan of $24.9 billion was proposed by Mayor Koch. The plan calls for increased taxes and substantial cuts in services to close what he said would be a $758 million budget gap. A1 The status of the Board of Estimate in New York City is the subject of debate. Members of the board rejected the idea that it was endangered, because any effort to restructure it was likely to violate the Federal Voting Rights Act. A1 A fire in an apartment building in Passaic, N.J., destroyed much of the building and left about 500 people homeless, almost all of them former residents of India, officials said. There were no injuries among the residents. B2 A ''sting'' operation was exposed prematurely last month when court officials learned of the investigation, officials said. In the operation, property agents were videotaped taking valuables from the homes of people they thought were dead. B1 An appraisal: The architecture for Grand Central Terminal is monumental. It is deeply connected with the life of the city. Like New York's other great works of monumental architecture, it unites the noble and the ordinary. B1 Connecticut's fiscal horizon is cloudy as lawmakers gather for the new session. Analysts have warned them to prepare for a possible slowdown in the growth of sales tax revenue, which could lead to deficits. title: COLONIAL AMER BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The full-year nets included after-tax charges of $2.4 million in 1987 and $460,000 in 1986 for additions to loan loss reserves. The 1987 earnings also included a charge for settlement of a shareholder suit and a credit of $358,000, or 23 cents a share, for change in accounting for pension costs.

title: 7 Killed in Philippine Battle
description: Six Moslem separatist rebels and one soldier were killed in a one-hour gunbattle in the southern Philippines, the military said today. It said four soldiers and 15 villagers were wounded in the fighting, which erupted when about 200 rebels of the Moro National Liberation Front attacked an outpost in North Cotabato province on Sunday.

title: AARON RENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it acquired Ball Stalker Co. on Oct. 1, 1987 and the latest quarter and 9 months revenue figures include $4 million from the new company. During the year-ago quarter and 9 months the share earnings were reduced by 18 cents a share because of a retroactive reversal of investment tax credits.

title: In the Quiet World of Fruit-Eating Fish, a Biologist Feels Too Alone
description: MICHAEL Goulding works in what he calmly describes as ''the greatest evolutionary theater in the world.'' One of the few scholars to study the rivers of the Amazon basin, he spends months sifting through muddy streams in a region where a single river holds more species than all the waters of North America.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL DENIES WRONGDOING ON PIPELINE PLAN
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d denied wrongdoing today in connection with a billion-dollar Iraqi pipeline project and insisted he knew nothing about any plan to bribe Israeli officials.

title: ACTMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Postal Chief Is Selected
description: Anthony M. Frank, chairman and chief executive of the First Nationwide Financial Corporation, will be named to head the United States Postal Service, a spokesman for the nation's sixth largest savings and loan association said today.

title: Arizona Impeachment Hearing Is Stalled
description: Hearings to consider the impeachment of Gov. Evan Mecham broke down here today when he refused to answer questions from lawyers for a committee of the Arizona House of Representatives.

title: U.S. Plan Is Aimed To Give Palestinians 'A Stake in Future'
description: Explaining the new United States initiative in the Middle East, one official said today that the aim was to provide ''some kind of interim arrangement that would give the Palestinians a stake in their future.''

title: BellSouth Offer
description: The BellSouth Corporation said it hadwithdrawn its $564 million offer to acquire the Mobile Communications Corporation of America. The company said that negotiations had not resulted in a final agreement. But Mobile Communications said the talks were ended when it told BellSouth that other potential acquirers had expressed serious interest in buying the company, with offers in excess of BellSouth's proposal.

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $500,000 from the sale of a foreign subsidiary and a gain of $1.2 million from the resolution of certain tax matters for both periods. c-Included a gain of $1.9 million from the sale of surplus real estate for the quarter and year.

title: FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pipeline Plan: Origins in '83
description: The Iraqi pipeline project, now the focus of a special prosecutor's investigation, had its beginnings in 1983, when Bechtel, a San Francisco-based engineering services company, began discussions in the Middle East, according to present and former Administration officials.

title: Weinberger Is Made An Honorary Knight
description: Former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has been awarded an honorary knighthood in recognition of his ''outstanding and invaluable'' contribution to military cooperation between Britain and the United States, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Hong Kong Port Gain
description: Hong Kong has overtaken Rotterdam. the Netherlands, as the world's busiest container port, the Marine Department director, Gerry Higginson, said today. He told a news conference that the port recorded a 24.6 percent increase in container traffic in 1987, while officials in Rotterdam expected that their port registered no increase.

title: POSEIDON POOLS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $49,500. The company completed its initial public offering on Aug. 27, 1987.

title: GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $8,885,000 for the quarter and income of $18,586,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and tax credits of $5,671,000 for the quarter and $12,553,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $157,515,000 for the quarter and $96,875,000 for the year. Both year-ago periods' results include a charge of $368.8 million primarily associated with the writedown of certain assets and restructuring costs. Those periods' losses from discontinued operations include a provision of $220 million, after-tax, for the divestment of the agricultural chemicals business, partially offset by net gains of $44.4 million and $124.2 million in the fourth quarter and year, respectively, from divestment of retail and restaurant businesses. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on Dec. 10, 1987.

title: Fiscal Clouds: Connecticut Is Facing Time of Austerity
description: For the last four years, Connecticut and its General Assembly have basked in prosperity. Legislators in the nation's richest state have seen $1 billion in budget surpluses, cut taxes twice and put $313 million into a ''rainy day'' emergency fund. Last year they raised spending by 14 percent, one of the highest levels in the country.

title: Florida Weighs Crisis Over Malpractice Insurance
description: The Florida Legislature convenes Tuesday in a special three-day session aimed at easing a medical malpractice insurance crisis that is particularly acute in south Florida.

title: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paine Webber Profits Drop
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $7 million, or 16 cents a share, down more than 60 percent from $17.5 million, or 57 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1986.

title: Leading Indicator
description: For an event only XXII years old, the Super Bowl has generated amazing lore. Consider Koppett's Theory. It holds that if a team from the old, pre-merger National Football League wins the championship, the stock market will finish higher in the year ahead; if a team from the old American Football League team wins, it will finish lower.

title: SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess: Shot by Wilder Stuns Kogan In U.S. Championship Event
description: You can't just indiscriminately bull through openings in the hope of overturning received opinion - there are too many variations and where should you begin? All you can do is remain receptive to the inspiration for a new strategy when it does strike you.

title: TV Review; 'FRONTLINE,' ON GRENADA
description: ''FRONTLINE'' remounts the Grenada invasion tonight.

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $146,000 from discontinued operations. The company previously reported on a calendar year basis.

title: INDIAN HEAD BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Rout That Seemed Riveting
description: THE first reaction during and after the Super Bowl Sunday was:

title: Advertising; 2 New Bakery Accounts At Muller Jordan Weiss
description: Stroehmann Bakeries of Horsham, Pa., has acquired two additional bakeries - Taystee in New York and Dreikorn's in Holyoke, Mass. - and it has assigned them to its agency, Muller Jordan Weiss. Stroehmann, a powerhouse brand in Philadelphia, has been spending about $3 million through the agency. The new business adds more than $1 million to the pot. Taystee's former agency was Ketchum, Hicks & Greist.

title: BOOKS: ON CHILD ABUSE
description: BY SILENCE BETRAYED. Sexual Abuse of Children in America. By John Crewdson. 267 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: Two 'Hickey' Sequels, on 'Playhouse'
description: A LITTLE over a year ago, public television's ''American Playhouse'' presented the kind of period romp that sets clubbable types to sighing about the good old days. ''The Prodigious Hickey'' was based on Owen Johnson's ''Lawrenceville Stories,'' a collection of fond anecdotes about innocent pranks and character building at a prep school in the early years of this century. Public television, it would seem, had found its perfect entertainment, devilish without being threatening and positively saturated in nostalgia.

title: Sydney Journal; A Bad Lot, the Convict Fathers? Goodness, No!
description: Aunt Laura is not to be told, but old Ellen, the other relatives acknowledge with an indulgent smile, was rather a bad hat.

title: Where Ram's Horns Blew, New Fear
description: Jewish history in these ancient hills runs all the way from the ram's horn and the prophet Amos to the automatic pistol and Bob Brown.

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Okotoks, Alberta, Soviet Figure Skaters Are O.K.
description: The skaters were finishing a difficult lift, he raising her with one hand high above his head, and the crowd of 600 or so, roaring its approval. A woman standing behind rows of benches stuffed tightly with Okotokians clapped loudly.

title: Carlucci and Soviet Minister Plan Periodic Military Talks
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci and the Soviet Defense Minister have agreed to begin meeting periodically to discuss arms control and other military issues, Administration officials said today.

title: Young at Heart Politically, Elderly Lobby
description: At 4 feet 10 inches, Rose Kryzak could not be easily seen from her place behind the podium in Convention Hall here. But as she spoke in a reasoned and determined way about the needs of the elderly, she sure could be heard.

title: Theater: 'Dress Suits'
description: THE most striking quality in ''Dress Suits to Hire,'' Holly Hughes's bawdy farce of sexual identity, is the playwright's full-tilt fire-engine language. Like Sam Shepard, her most obvious influence, Ms. Hughes, who created ''Dress Suits'' in collaboration with its two performers, Peggy Shaw and Lois Weaver, invents rhapsodically raunchy stream-of-consciousness riffs to evoke characters whose multiple identities are straining to burst out of their skins.

title: EATING WELL
description: NUTRITIONISTS fall, roughly, into two categories: those who champion vitamin and mineral supplements - the more the merrier - and those who are dead set against them. The former are looked down on by the latter as quacks; the latter are looked down on by the former as old-fashioned fuddy-duddies, stuck in the mind set of the 1950's before certain nutritional information was known.

title: F.B.I.'s Chief Says Surveillance Was Justified
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the bureau began its surveillance of groups opposed to the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America because of information that activists were providing aid to a ''terrorist organization'' in El Salvador.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the after-tax earnings for 1986 were reduced by $42.7 million because of writeoffs that occurred primarily in the third and fourth quarters, which partially were offset by a one-time gain of $9.4 million from the company's leasing operations, because of revisions in federal tax laws. The earnings for the latest fourth quarter reflected the company's adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Opinion 96, which deals with deferred income taxes. The adoption of FASB 96 also caused a restatement of the results of the first three quarters of 1987.

title: HUDSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 19
description: b-Net income

title: Many Arab Schools Are Shut In Israeli Bid to Curb Unrest
description: Israel ordered widespread closings of Palestinian schools and universities in the occupied territories today in the face of continuing unrest.

title: U.S. Board Rejects Lilco Plan In Key Setback for Shoreham
description: A Federal licensing board today rejected the Long Island Lighting Company's evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The board said the plan was ''fundamentally flawed'' and might be inherently unworkable.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net for year 1986 is after a charge of $21.2 million from reduced operations in Maine.

title: Frenchman Slain in Car by Beirut Gunmen
description: Gunmen killed a Frenchman in East Beirut today in the latest attack on French citizens here.

title: When Trade Tigers Grow Up
description: President Reagan had good reason to drop Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore from a program that gives favored tariff treatment to most of the third world. Those nations, known in trade circles as the ''four tigers,'' no longer need special help. Indeed, the time has come for them to share more responsibility for world trade expansion by relaxing their own import restrictions, by adopting flexible currency exchange rates, or both.

title: Huxley Madeheim, Professor, 82
description: Huxley Madeheim, an engineer and former professor of industrial management at Baruch College, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Anthony M. Frank; Innovator for Postal Job
description: When Robert Setrakian, a governor of the United States Postal Service, needed advice on who might make a good Postmaster General, he asked one of the businessmen he trusted most:

title: U.S. HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $26,480,000 for the quarter and $29,957,000 for the year; the quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $399,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,328,000 for the quarter and $22,690,000 for the year.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1987 earnings benefited from an adjustment of 75 cents a share to the reserve for restructuring of operations, while 1986 earnings were reduced by $1.32 a share for a restructuring provision.

title: World of College Financial Aid Grows Fuzzier
description: Parents of college-bound students, welcome to the world of financial aid.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ABB Traction Inc., Purchase, N.Y., a new subsidiary of Asea Brown Boveri Inc. that will supply and service electro-mechanical equipment for the rail and transportation industries, named Carlo Gorla president.

title: HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the quarter loss included a charge of $8.5 million from non-cash writedowns related to the carrying value of certain mining properties and other one-time charges.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported a resignation at TW Services, the parent company of Denny's fast-food restaurants. Donald L. Pierce has resigned as president of Denny's and as a director of TW Services. Frank L. Salizzoni remains the chairman and chief executive of TW Services.

title: Rig Count Down Again
description: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States dropped again last week, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. The count fell by 62, to a total of 964. A year ago, the count stood at 826. Although the rig count usually declines during the first few months of the year, the drop last week was particularly large.

title: Koch Reverts To Poor Finance
description: New York City is again falling into the expedient and dangerous practice of using capital funds to finance current expenditures, one of the underlying causes of the 1975 fiscal crisis.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., engaged in the production, purchase and distribution of natural gas, and Entex Inc. of Houston, also engaged in natural gas distribution, said the period prescribed by law for the Federal Trade Commission review of a previously announced poposed acquisition of Entex by Arkla had expired Monday without action by the F.T.C.

title: Romaine Fielding, Businessman, 68
description: Romaine Fielding, who handled transactions with the Soviet Union for several companies, including his own, died of cancer Thursday. He was 68 years old.

title: Let It Pour
description: Over much of the Eastern Seaboard yesterday, people on rainswept streets battled blown-out umbrellas; those who stayed home watched the soaps. Pigeons sheltered on windowsills; stray cats crouched in doorways; housebound children drove their elders mad. The groundhog definitely failed to see his shadow.

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $2.5 million from discontinued operations for the quarter, and the year includes a loss of $10.3 million from discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss of $2.5 million and $6 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. The quarter also includes a $52 million charge for discontinued products and a one-time gain of $19 million in international operations. The company also said that in 1986 a $52 million charge was recorded by Frito-Lay for discontinuance of certain snack products and reduction of cookie production capacity. In 1987, a $13 million favorable adjustment to the 1986 charge was recorded, primarily reflecting a $10 million gain on the sale of a cooking manufacturing facility.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: IT seems as if almost everyone is, like me, on a postholiday diet but bored to death with simple pieces of fish, salads and grilled bits of this and that. Fortunately, the microwave oven can cook rich-tasting but low-calorie dishes quickly. You can make enough for just one or two or enough for a group of friends who won't even know they are eating diet food.

title: Prime Rate Is Lowered By Major Banks to 8 1/2%
description: The nation's leading banks lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 8 1/2 percent, its lowest level since September.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column yesterday misstated the number of branch offices acquired last week by Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., a brokerage firm with headquarters in Los Angeles. It added 3 offices, for a total of 37.

title: HOSTAGE INCIDENT AT SCHOOL ENDED
description: A gunman who said he wanted to help the homeless held dozens of children and teachers hostage today before the authorities fooled him into giving up his guns and then wrestled him to the ground, the officials said.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. (AP) N.B.A.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter restated to reflect an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests and the Sept. 10, 1987, 3-for-1 stock split.

title: Henley Lifts Stake In Santa Fe
description: The Henley Group said yesterday that it had increased its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation and vowed to continue its proxy fight to gain control of the company.

title: Benjamin Kuhn, 82, A Founder of College
description: The Rev. Benjamin Kuhn, one of seven friars who established Siena College here in 1937, died Sunday at St. Anthony's Hospital in Warwick, N.Y, after a heart attack earlier in January. He was 82 years old and lived in Warwick.

title: Account of Yeltsin Talk Denied
description: A Foreign Ministry spokesman today termed a ''fabrication'' a version of Boris N. Yeltsin's speech to Communist Party officials in which he reportedly criticized Raisa Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.

title: Manhattan Restrooms: An Elusive Amenity
description: IF you are Holly Golightly, and you possess a very grand pair of sunglasses and a confident stride, you can probably use any bathroom in New York City. But if you are less gorgeous (or less impudent), getting to a bathroom when far from home or office can be an ordeal, especially in New York, a city not known for the grace or abundance of its public amenities.

title: The Price Was Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized gains on sale of investments of $5,171,000 for the quarter and $56,591,000 for the year. c-After realized gains on sale of investments of $15,071,000 for the quarter and $52,985,000 for the year. The share earnings for 1987 reflect the effect of employee interests in Kemper Financial Companies.

title: How Five Studies Viewed The Market Collapse
description: Securities and Exchange Commission: New computer-assisted trading techniques that link the stock and futures markets fueled last October's wild swings in stock prices. The danger of extreme volatility persists, it said. Also found that many market-makers did not do enough to cushion the plunge in prices. The S.E.C. called for curbs on speculation in stock index futures. It recommended bolstering the financial strength of market-makers and encouraging greater disclosure of the identity of big buyers and sellers. Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms: Otherwise known as the Brady commission, attributed the market plunge mainly to a handful of major investors using computer-assisted trading techniques. Rather than ban those techniques, it urged greater coordination among stocks and futures exchanges, under one regulatory authority, possibly the Federal Reserve Board. Recommended unification of settlement and clearing mechanisms among stocks, options and futures and comparable margin (or down payment) standards on them. Also urged ''circuit-breakers'' on stocks to suspend and cool off runaway trading. New York Stock Exchange: Study by Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a former Attorney General, blamed speculation in stock index futures and recommended restraints on such trading. Also urged contingency plan for shutting exchanges in emergencies. General Accounting Office: Repeated breakdowns of computer systems on the New York Stock Exchange aggravated selling on Oct. 19. Faulted Federal regulators for inadequate contingency planning. Commodity Futures Trading Commission: Regulator of futures exchanges did not conclude that trading in stock index futures was the main problem. Urged better communication between exchanges.

title: 38 Argentine Officers Freed
description: The Argentine Army today freed another 38 noncommissioned officers accused of taking part in the military revolt at Monte Caseros on Jan. 16-18. A total of 130 officers have been released since Friday.

title: Far From India, the Appeal of Chutneys Grows and Grows
description: MAJOR GREY, the well-known mango chutney from India, has considerable competition these days. American chefs from coast to coast are preparing their own chutneys and serving them with grilled fish, poultry and meats.

title: Where Chip Wagons Rule the Snack Trade
description: LEAD: WHAT the ice-cream trucks are to Americans, chip wagons are to Pembroke. This logging community of 15,000, about 75 miles northwest of Ottawa, boasts 10 chip trucks and is touted as the chip capital of the Ottawa Valley. Crisp double-cooked chips, or french fries, sprinkled with salt and doused with white vinegar, are the trucks' mainstays, but chips with gravy and chips with cheese and gravy are gaining in popularity.

title: Warmth and Suspicion for Cantor and Rabbi From Soviet
description: The rabbi and the cantor of the Moscow Synagogue arrived yesterday at Yeshiva University for three months of study, amid questions of whether their presence represented a new page in Soviet ''perestroika'' or a new phase of Soviet propaganda.

title: TRW Lays Off 3,000 Workers
description: TRW Inc. said today that it would furlough 3,000 workers, or about 10 percent of its space and military sector work force, in the next few months because of proposed cutbacks in military spending.

title: Recital: Nico Castel
description: ADMIRERS of Nico Castel's sharply etched portrayals at the Metropolitan Opera (most recently a hilarious Majordomo in ''Ariadne auf Naxos'') had a chance to see another side of his work Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, where he gave a recital of musical Judaica ranging from Gounod's ''Le Juif Errant'' through settings of Heinrich Heine by Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco to Sephardic and Yiddish folk songs.

title: Troubling View of a Changed Market
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's report on the stock market collapse provides the most authoritative -and in some ways the most troubling -description yet of the way that trading in stock index futures has fundamentally altered the way the stock market works.

title: Wider Inquiry Into Stealing From the Dead
description: New York State and city investigators, expanding their inquiry into thefts of property from the dead, seized accounting records yesterday from Public Administrators' offices in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

title: Shad, Too, Signal the Season
description: THE groundhog did not see its shadow , and to confirm that spring is on its way shad is also here. The first are on sale at a few fish markets in the New York area. This succulent and richly flavored member of the herring family is excellent to broil, grill or bake. Shad roe is also available and is at its best lightly sauteed in plenty of butter or olive oil.

title: Carrington To Head Christie's
description: Lord Carrington will become chairman of Christie's International after his retirement in June as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the British-based auction house announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Soviet Halts Independent Publishing Cooperatives
description: The Soviet authorities have ordered a halt to the creation of independent publishing and printing cooperatives, a Government official said this week.

title: Political Memo; A Foggy Homestretch For Democrats in Iowa
description: And now, the finale.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 9
description: b-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $2,495,000.

title: Ex-Pan Am Executive Gets Continental Post
description: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., who was ousted two weeks ago as vice chairman of the Pan Am Corporation, yesterday was elected president of Continental Airlines Inc. For much of the last year, Continental has been seeking to solve service problems that brought a flood of customer complaints.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; In the Money
description: Leaders of the Democratic National Committee say they are encouraged by the successes of their fund-raising efforts in 1987.

title: Storytelling as an Art Form
description: The show tonight in Alice Tully Hall is called ''The Raconteurs,'' and thereby hangs a tale. Several tales, in fact, and they will be told by two of the most accomplished practitioners of what is sometimes called an endangered art.

title: Extend South Street Seaport Historic District
description: To the Editor:

title: Palmdale Journal; Where City Meets Desert Somewhat Awkwardly
description: This has long been Los Angeles County's last frontier, a sparsely settled oasis of clean air, light traffic and reasonable housing prices at the edge of the Mojave Desert.

title: Whirlpool Splits Into Seven Units
description: The Whirlpool Corporation of Benton Harbor, Mich., said it had reorganized into seven units, a structure it said would make each operation more accountable for its performance.

title: HUSSEIN WEIGHING U.S. MIDEAST PLAN
description: King Hussein of Jordan has agreed to consider a new American idea for getting Middle East negotiations under way by the end of the year, American officials and Middle Eastern diplomats said today.

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $9.6 million for the quarter and year. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $28,324,000 for the quarter and $53,157,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: 2 Officers In Robins Fund Plan
description: The two highest executives of the A. H. Robins Company may contribute a total of $10 million to trust funds set up to compensate women injured by Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device, according to a bankruptcy reorganization plan filed by the company late Monday night.

title: 14 Arrested at Alabama Capitol In Bid to Remove Confederate Flag
description: The president of the Alabama N.A.A.C.P. and 13 other blacks were arrested today as they tried to scale an 8-foot fence around the State Capitol in an effort to take down a Confederate flag atop the building.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged in Fatal Sniper Attack
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing one man and wounding three others in a sniper attack Monday evening, the police said.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Foster Wheeler
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation said its president, Louis E. Azzato, was prepared to meet with Asher B. Edelman, but not to discuss his proposal to pay $16.50 a share, or almost $575 million in cash, for the company's stock.
