Mr. Edelman, who holds about 11.5 percent of Foster Wheeler's common stock outstanding, proposed last week that the company create a recapitalization plan or, as an alternative, accept his buyout offer. Mr. Azzato responded that Foster Wheeler was already working on a restructuring plan it believed would strengthen the engineering and construction company and bring more value to shareholders.

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $9,698,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $176,000 for the quarter and income of $861,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The latest fourth quarter included foreign currency gains that equaled 2 cents a share, compared with a loss equaled to 2 cents a share for the year- ago period. The latest quarter earnings were reduced by 5 cents a share for environmental expenses. Foreign currency losses were 3 cents a share in 1987, compared with a loss of 6 cents a share for 1986. The company said earnings do not include any adjustment associated with FAS 96 for income tax accounting.

title: Excerpts From Reagan's Address on Aid to Contras and Democratic Reply
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech last night on aid to the contras, and from the Democratic response by Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network: PRESIDENT'S SPEECH

title: Calming the Allies' Jitters
description: Officially, our European allies are supporting without reservation the new treaty banning intermediate-range nuclear forces. This surface unanimity, however, masks a sea of uncertainty about the long-term reliability of the United States as a defense partner.

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included after-tax special non-cash charges of $315 million.

title: Fine Wine, Good Food, One Price
description: A DECADE or so ago, one of the best small restaurant cellars in New York was kept by Louis Daniel at Le Chambertin, on West 46th Street. Unlike the vast majority of people who owned French restaurants, Mr. Daniel knew his wines and treated them with great care.

title: USF&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses on investments of $9,576,000 and $107,414,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $7,425,000 and $13,816,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses on investments of $50,435,000 and an extraordinary charge of $42,173,000. d-Includes gains on investments of $32,455,000 and a tax credit of $21,340,000.

title: Grand Met Ends Bidding for Martell
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., a British hotel conglomerate, formally ended a six-week bidding war for the French cognac maker Martell & Compagnie by saying it would not contest a rival offer from the Seagram Company.

title: G. Mennen Williams, 76, Is Dead; Governor and Justice in Michigan
description: G. Mennen Williams, the former Governor of Michigan who later served as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court and as a Federal official in the Departments of State and Justice, died yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Detroit after suffering a massive cerebral stroke. He was 76 years old and lived in Grosse Pointe Farms, near Detroit.

title: Discount Stores for Fledgling Gourmets
description: IN the suburbs around New York City consumers weaned on Twinkies and cheese spread are broadening their gastronomic horizons at Passport Foods Outlet. The fledgling seven-store chain, retail experts say, is the nation's first to sell imported delicacies at discount prices.

title: Shuttle Crash Hurts 16 Near Grand Central
description: At least 16 people were injured, none seriously, when a 42d Street subway shuttle collided with a Transit Authority garbage collection train near Grand Central Terminal early this morning, officials said.

title: Advertising; A New Path For Diversion Magazine
description: DIVERSION is the name of the magazine. Its subtitle, ''For Physicians at Leisure,'' describes its mission perfectly.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Housing constitutes a basic social good and cannot simply be considered a market commodity.'' - The Pontifical Commission for Justice and Peace. [ A3:3. ]

title: Real Estate; New Tower At North End Of Times Sq.
description: FOR decades some sort of eye-catching advertisement, like today's neon Coca-Cola sign, has been the visual focal point of the northern end of Times Square.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $11.6 million from discontinued operations. The latest earnings from continuing operations included earnings of consolidated companies of $54.5 million for the quarter and $243.3 million for the year, compared with $48 million and $187.6 million for the year-ago periods, respectively. The equity in net earnings of associated companies also included in the continuing operations totaled $5.7 million for the latest quarter and $20.7 million for the year, compared with $4.1 million and $14.9 million for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Monday misstated the position held at New York University by Mayor Koch's sister, Pat Koch Thaler. She is an associate dean of the university's School of Continuing Education.

title: Networks Refuse to Broadcast Reagan's Plea
description: The three major broadcast networks carried their usual prime-time programs last night, refusing to provide live coverage of President Reagan's speech on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. The networks said the speech contained nothing new.

title: Tough Labor Organizer Leading Strike in Maine
description: At International Paper's sprawling mill here, amid dozens of posters and slogans that festoon its wood-receiving gate, a tiny sign captures the mood of the striking workers in a seven-month labor dispute. It says: ''Welcome Ray Rogers.''

title: 2 First Boston Leaders Resign Over Strategy
description: Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph R. Perella, the two men who made the First Boston Corporation a leader in mergers and acquisitions, announced yesterday that they had quit their posts at the investment bank after a policy dispute and would set up their own firm.

title: Phone Contract Testimony Indicates Early Sign of Leak
description: The General Services Administration met with a representative of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company weeks before the final bids were due for Government phone contracts to discuss a possible leak of the company's secret bid information to competitors, an agency official said today in a deposition proceeding.

title: Texaco to Mail Its Ballots
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it would begin mailing ballots to its shareholders today so they could determine whether the company should emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Knicks Capture 5th in Row at Home
description: The first half of the Knicks' season was filled with many glaring weaknesses, among them the problems of holding a fourth-quarter lead or winning a close game, especially on the road.

title: College Basketball; Syracuse Trounces Providence, 92-71
description: Derrick Coleman scored 20 points and grabbed 19 rebounds to lead Syracuse to a 92-71 rout of Providence in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: College Hockey Notebook; Beanpot Brings Out The Best in Goalie
description: The goalie's dream - the shutout - came at last for Bruce Racine in his 118th game in the nets for Northeastern. The occasion was perfect, the opening contest of the 36th Beanpot Tournament Monday night before 14,000 fans in Boston Garden.

title: THE BASIC SPEECH: Bob Dole; 'We're Going to Have a Spending Freeze in the Dole Administration'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: How Fragonard Came to Met
description: In the Jean-Honore Fragonard exhibition that opens this Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, both the artist and the museum have done their magic. The show radiates color, clarity and completeness of design, and the paintings hang like seemingly inevitable expressions in a seemingly permanent home.

title: Sports People; Not Guilty
description: Pete Johnson, the former Ohio State fullback who played for three teams in the N.F.L., was found not guilty of cocaine charges yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, after a United States District Court jury deliberated for only a short time. Johnson, 33, of Miami, had been charged with conspiracy to distribute cocaine, distribution of cocaine and traveling between states to promote a cocaine deal. He played for the Cincinnati Bengals, the Miami Dolphins and the San Diego Chargers. At the time his indictment in August, Johnson was selling cars in Miami.

title: This Is Probably a Golden Age of Historians
description: To the Editor:

title: Chase Manhattan's Variable Notes
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation is offering $300 million of variable-rate renewable notes with a final maturity in 1993 at a price of par, with the initial interest rate yet to be set, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Pentagon Adds to Jobs for Women And Demands End to Harassment
description: The Defense Department directed the military services today to enforce rules against sexual harassment more rigorously and to open more positions to women.

title: S.E.C. STAFF URGES CURBS ON TRADING OF STOCK FUTURES
description: A staff report by the Securities and Exchange Commission today called for a series of changes that would reduce the role of trading in stock index futures, which it asserted worsened the October stock market plunge.

title: Cossacks for Rodeos?
description: Things are going so well in United States-Soviet culture exchanges, said Senator Timothy Wirth of Colorado today, that the next slice of American life in Russia ought to be rodeo.

title: Document Cannot Be Found, Waldheim Investigator Says
description: A member of the Austrian commission investigating Kurt Waldheim's wartime past said today that he had not found a telegram purportedly linking the Austrian President to prisoner deportations.

title: Sports of The Times; More Than Half Good
description: CAN one swallow maketh a summer, or one woodcock a winter, or one half a football game?

title: Scrounging For Scandal
description: This Iraqi pipeline story is taking on the nature of a witch hunt.

title: 3 Soldiers and Panamanian Held on Drug Charges
description: A Panamanian citizen wearing a United States Army uniform was arrested along with three American soldiers after they stepped off a military transport plane carrying a large quantity of cocaine, the Federal authorities said Monday.

title: Campeau Amends Federated Offer
description: The Campeau Corporation has sent a letter to Federated Department Stores amending its $47-a-share cash offer for Federated to remove the condition that the offer be approved by Federated's board.This apparently signals that Campeau intends to proceed with its $4.2 billion offer even if Federated's board, scheduled to review the bid on Friday, rejects it. While this may have been expected to push up Federated's common stock, investors reacted more strongly to a report that two principals had resigned from Campeau's investment banker, the First Boston Corporation. Federated's stock fell $2.375, to $51.375.

title: 5 Arrested in Series of Muggings in Queens
description: Four men and a woman were arrested yesterday and charged with at least 20 separate street muggings in the last four weeks in eastern Queens, the police said.

title: OGILVY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue figures represent commission and fee income. Year-ago figures are restated. Latest quarter net includes the results of Decisions Center Inc. and Thomson-Leeds Co., which were acquired in August and October 1987, respectively, and are accounted for as poolings of interest.

title: Federal Judges Are Able To Appoint Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE RACE TO FASHODA: European Colonialism and African Resistance in the Scramble for Africa. By David Levering Lewis. Illustrated. 304 pages.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: A.T.&T. Lifts Phone Price
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has announced that monthly prices for its leased residential phones will rise by as much as 95 cents starting next month.

title: 'New Breeze' Is Noted as the Sandinistas, With Eye on the U.S., Cast Aside Old Rules
description: On Sunday morning, as about 2,000 anti-Government protesters made their way through Managua's dusty streets, a young man broke away from the march, ran toward the sidewalk and produced a can of spray paint.

title: Board Rebuffs Move by Futures Exchange
description: In a stunning last-minute rebuff, the board of the Commodity Exchange Center yesterday voted not to allow the New York Futures Exchange to move onto the trading floor at 4 World Trade Center next Monday, as previously agreed.

title: Balking Agent Loses Appeal
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation was justified in dismissing an agent who refused an order to investigate peace groups whose views he shared, an administrative judge ruled today.

title: New Clash on Estimate Board's Fate
description: The intensifying dispute over the future of the New York City Board of Estimate grew more pointed yesterday when the board's special counsel took public issue with Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Charter Revision Commission.

title: About New York; Why Lose Time? A Court Reporter Lives by His Pen
description: ''I want to show you that I can stand up on my head,'' Duncan Griffith said upon first meeting, in Room 1610 of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, at 100 Centre Street. ''It's something I learned back in 1950,'' he added, offering further that he was born in 1906.

title: Sports People; Agent Is Indicted
description: A grand jury in Tuscaloosa, Ala., has indicted Norby Walters, the sports agent, on three misdemeanor counts connected with payments he made to a former University of Alabama basketball star, Derrick McKey, said Attorney General Don Siegelman. Siegelman said that his office has been advised by Walters's attorney that Walters would waive extradition and voluntarily come to Alabama. No date was set immediately for the arraignment of the New York-based agent, who was indicted last Friday by a Tuscaloosa County grand jury, Siegelman said. Walters's firm, World Sports and Entertainment, also was indicted on the three misdemeanor counts. McKey lost his senior year of eligibility and Alabama was hit with a financial penalty because of his dealings with Walters.

title: Finnish Chief Wants to Cut Power of His Job
description: According to a Government official here, Mauno Koivisto once likened his mission as President of Finland to that of the character played by Gary Cooper in ''High Noon.''

title: Appeals Court Voids Ban on Surveys at the Polls
description: A Washington State law banning polls of voters leaving the polling place was ruled unconstitutional today by a Federal appeals court. The court unanimously held that the law violated freedom of speech.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: FOOTBALL season is over. I realized the end had come the other night when God was prominently mentioned several times on television. This doesn't happen much. I'm not counting those times on ''Dynasty'' when Alexis says, ''Thank God Blake will never own that oil pipeline.''

title: Levin Finding Was Withheld
description: The police detective who arrested Robert E. Chambers Jr. in August 1986 conceded yesterday that he had withheld information that could have backed up Mr. Chambers's account in a videotaped statement about Jennfier Levin's death.

title: 2 Guilty in Bomb Smuggling
description: A Federal jury today convicted two Canadian citizens of smuggling a bomb into the United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1988
description: International A2-12

title: Mr. Goldin, Off One Hook
description: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison Goldin, broke no law when he touted investments in companies controlled by Ivan Boesky. So says the city's Investigations Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, along with Federal and local prosecutors. It's a welcome finding, though it hardly settles the issue of propriety.

title: PANHANDLE EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,461,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $105,526,000 and $188,633,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said prior quarter and year include special charges related to settling three arbitration cases and writedowns of coal mining and contract drilling assets.

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net reflects a pre- tax gain of about $80 million from the sale of interests in Park Avenue Plaza, the company's headquarters building. The company said its fourth quarter was adversely impacted by losses in its risk arbitrage unit.

title: Bulgaria Reins In Its Enthusiasm for Change
description: At the end of the special conference of the Bulgarian Communist Party last week, Bulgaria was in the position it has occupied since the end of World War II -as close as possible to the Soviet Union.

title: Bridge: Best Possible Aceless Hand Turned Up in Quebec Game
description: Back in the 30's, Ely Culbertson offered a cash prize for an authenticated case of someone picking up the best possible hand - 37 high-card points, although he did not express it that way - or the worst possible hand, all the deuces, treys and four spots plus a five. Nobody collected.

title: Index of Economic Trends Drops A 3d Month but Few Are Worried
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge declined in December for the third straight month. Such a move has historically indicated a possible recession, but most analysts said the evidence of a downturn was not yet persuasive.

title: Ogilvy Wins Microsoft
description: Ogilvy & Mather of Los Angeles has become agency for the Microsoft Corporation, a leading computer software company based in Redmond, Wash. The budget is about $14 million.

title: MAYTAG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that results for 1986 include a charge from discontinued operations; that prior to the charge, net from continuing operations for the 1986 quarter was $31.4 million, or 36 cents a share; that 1986 also included an extraordinary loss for the early extinguishment of debt; and that merger expenses of about 13 cents a shre were charged to 1986 continuing operations.

title: BROCKWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Illini Hires Mackovicy
description: The University of Illinois selected John Mackovic, the former Kansas City Chiefs' coach, as its new football coach yesterday. Mackovic, 44, was selected during a closed-door meeting of the school's Athletic Association Board, the sources told The Associated Press. The Illini defensive coordinator, Howard Tippett, who also had sought the job, said Athletic Director Neale Stoner had called him to say Mackovic had been selected. ''Neale called me about half an hour after their meeting broke up,'' Tippett said. ''He said it was close call, a tough call, but they had offered the job to Mackovic and he had accepted.'' Mackovic is a 21-year coaching veteran with both collegiate and professional experience but has been out of football for about a year.

title: Greenspan Opposes Brady Plan
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today rejected a Presidential task force's proposal that the Fed take over supervision of trading in the securities markets.

title: Games Teach Black History
description: Teachers across the nation are turning their students' attention this week to lessons ranging from slavery to civil rights as Black History Month begins.

title: Diebold President Set To Add Job of Chairman
description: Diebold Inc., a maker of automatic teller machines and security equipment, said yesterday it would give its president and chief executive, Robert W. Mahoney, the additional post of chairman after its annual meeting in April.

title: Raymond Charles Barker, Church Founder, 77
description: Dr. Raymond Charles Barker, the founder of the First Church of Religious Science in Manhattan and its minister from 1946 to 1979, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday at the Eisenhower Hospital in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 77 years old and lived in Rancho Mirage.

title: For Tibetans, Quality of Life Slowly Improves
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeal Is Filed on Special Prosecutor Law
description: The Supreme Court was asked Monday to reinstate legal provisions that created special prosecutors to investigate charges of wrongdoing by high-ranking officials of the Federal executive branch.

title: Profits Plunge At First Boston
description: First Boston Inc., battered by losses in its risk arbitrage unit and by the general downturn in business activity after the stock market collapse in October, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings plummeted 91.7 percent on a 35.3 percent decline in revenues.

title: REAGAN, IN SPEECH, PRESSES CONGRESS ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: In an effort to salvage his aid request for the Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan offered tonight to give Congress a greater voice in deciding whether to release the military part of the package.

title: Heather O'Rourke, 12; Starred in 'Poltergeist'
description: Heather O'Rourke, familiar to moviegoers as the child swept into another world by ghosts in ''Poltergeist'' and its sequel, ''Poltergeist II,'' died at Children's Hospital and Health Center in San Diego Monday. She was 12 years old.

title: Film: 'Hoxsey' and Cancer
description: KEN AUSUBEL'S ''Hoxsey:

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: Printers, not scholars, decided the spelling of things, the utterly exasperating, often embarrassing, always confusing and inconsistent orthography of the mother tongue. The 15th-century British printers who translated to type what they heard on the street left a lexicon that has produced one generation of bad spellers after another.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a security loss of $12,338,000 for the quarter, and the year includes a security gain of $429,000 and an extraordinary charge of $7,903,000 premium paid on redemption of convertible debenture. c-Includes securitiy losses of $16,917,000 for the quarter, and the year includes a security gain of $721,000.

title: Girl in Dutchess Is Asked to Help Abrams Inquiry
description: A week after Governor Cuomo assigned him to investigate the case of a black Dutchess County teen-ager who said she was the victim of a racial and sexual attack, Attorney General Robert Abrams traveled here today and made a plea for the girl's cooperation.

title: BUSH TAKING AIM AT CONGRESS ROLE
description: Vice President Bush intensified his attacks on Congress today in an effort to tap anti-Congressional sentiment here in his battle against Senator Bob Dole of Kansas for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Chase Is Selling Paris Headquarters
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the large United States bank holding company, said it would sell its central Paris headquarters to raise capital. A Chase spokeman, Clement Redesdale, did not give the selling price or the identity of the buyer.

title: Citicorp Rates Fall
description: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.61 percent, down from 6.7916 percent last week. Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 6.635 percent, down from 6.879 percent.

title: Concert: James Joyce Set to Music
description: THE urge to set James Joyce to music is understandable:

title: Philadelphia Electric
description: The president of the Philadelphia Electric Company stepped down today as the company released a scathing report calling its Peach Bottom nuclear power plant ''an embarrassment to the industry and to the nation.'' At a news conference at the utility's company headquarters, L. Everett 3d, company chairman, announced that John H. Austin Jr. would retire early. Mr. Austin, 59, who has worked at P.E.C.O. for 38 years, denied he was being dismissed. ''I reached a conclusion after 10 years in this job that it was time for a change in command,'' he said.

title: Japan Hesitant On Quotas
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trades told Japan today to lift its import quotas on 10 types of farm products to comply with international rules. Japan said it accepted the ruling, which it had previously blocked but immediately made clear that it wanted to exempt two categories of items. Japan's Ambassador Yoshio

title: Thomas Johnson, 78; Lost Post in Congress
description: Former Representative Thomas F. Johnson of Maryland, who was convicted in a savings and loan scandal that cost him his Congressional seat, died after an automobile accident Monday. He was 78 years old.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $10 million from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: Economic Scene; 'Value-Added' Tax Has Advantages
description: BRUCE BABBITT'S rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination have leapt at the idea like cats seeking the jugular. Michael Dukakis says the Babbitt proposal for a broad-based consumption tax ''would soak the middle class.'' Paul Simon's spokesman says the tax, levied at each stage of production as a ''value-added'' tax, ''would leave the wealthy laughing all the way to the bank.'' Albert Gore dismisses it as ''a Republican idea.''

title: Vatican Urges Governments to Help the Homeless
description: A Vatican commission called on public authorities today to insure a just distribution of housing, condemning real estate speculation and other practices that treat property as a market commodity without social value.

title: MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $12,711,000 comprising of a gain of $3,833,000 on the disposition of the software division, securities gains and dividends totaling $1,258,000, interest expense of $16,867,000 and a foreign exchange loss of $935,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,900,000 and a pretax charge of $11,111,000 comprising of a gain of $1,898,000 on the disposition of G. Schirmer, a gain of $3,723,000 on the disposition of joint ventures, a provision of $6,000,000 for trade division reorganization, securities gains and dividends amounting to $1,695,000, a loss of $304,000 on the repurchase of debentures, interest expense of $11,003,000 and foreign exchange losses of $1,120,000. Share earnings are adjusted for the 5-percent stock dividend of Dec. 31, 1987. The company noted that a total of 10 acquisitions were made in 1987.

title: Bush Uses Plastic Pistol to Make a Point in Debate
description: Perhaps if the issue had been a different kind of arms control, say nuclear weapons, the debate here tonight between Republican candidates might have developed into, well, a debate.

title: British Unions in a Modest Resurgence
description: After years of curbing union power and industrial unrest under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Britain is dealing with an unsettling rash of strikes this week by coal workers, nurses and seamen.

title: Caledonian Chief Resigns
description: Sir Adam Thomson, the chairman and chief executive of British Caledonian Group P.L.C., resigned today in a move related to the airline's takeover by British Airways P.L.C., Caledonian said. Three other members of

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Insider's Intimate Portrait of a First Lady's Power
description: Is Nancy Reagan a closet liberal?

title: George Bush's Journal
description: I'd been out of the loop for months.

title: P.L.O. Plans a Twist To Exodus Ship Saga
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization is planning to charter a Greek car ferry for a symbolic voyage next week to return Palestinian deportees to Israel, Palestinian officials here said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Cooking at Pier 92

title: Policy on Black Judicial Nominees Is Debated
description: The Justice Department official in charge of screening potential Federal judges testified today that the small number of black nominees, six out of 367 chosen for judgeships in the last seven years, was largely a result of the paucity of qualified black lawyers who share the Reagan Administration's judicial and political outlook.

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 earnings included a provision of about $23 million to be refunded to residential electric customers during the summer of 1988.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $229 million, or 79 cents a share, after-tax charge taken in the fourth quarter related to plant Vogtle, a nuclear power plant. The company said it excluded $82 million, or 28 cents a share, from 1987 earnings to provide for the possibility that some amounts due from power sales to Gulf States Utilities Co. may not be collectible. The first quarter of 1987 included a $229 million, or 79 cents a share, after- tax charge related to plant Vogtle.

title: PROFILS SCOREBOARD
3 Publishers Announce Editorial Appointments
description: Patricia Soliman, formerly an associate publisher of Simon & Schuster, was named editor at large for Delacorte Press and Dell yesterday, effective immediately.

title: Foreman Is Fighting Waistline And Critics
description: Last March, after an absence of 10 years from the prize ring, George Foreman stepped between the ropes in Sacramento, Calif., to fight a journeyman named Steve Zouski.

title: Vietnamese Chief Building Political Base in South
description: The leader of the Vietnamese Communist Party, who came to power a year ago after what diplomats in Hanoi say was a bitter struggle with party hard-liners, appears to be building his political base here, rather than in the north.

title: Nets Lose on Road Again
description: Walter Berry scored 28 points tonight to lead the San Antonio Spurs to a 118-106 victory over the New Jersey Nets, who had ended a 26-game losing streak on the road Monday night. The Nets now have lost 19 of 20 road games this season.

title: Dole Makes Environment An Issue in New Hampshire
description: Senator Bob Dole unveiled broad elements of an environmental policy today while vigorously attacking the Reagan Administration's enforcement efforts.

title: Albert Abrams, Maker Of Esquire Polish, 76
description: Albert Abrams, a retired shoe polish manufacturer long active in charitable causes, died of leukemia Friday at Delray Beach, (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $9,575,000 and $25,133,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a gain from the refinancing of debt of $74 million for the both periods.

title: Sports People; Seeks N.F.L. Job
description: Michael Irvin, star receiver for the University of Miami's national football champions, said yesterday that he would forgo a final year of college eligibility. ''Michael Irvin's plan for 1988 is hopefully to be playing in the National Football League,'' said Irvin, who set school career records with 26 touchdown receptions, 143 catches and 2,423 yards in three seasons. The 21-year-old Fort Lauderdale native, said: ''Everybody thinks it's the money, but it's not the money. The biggest factor is that I set down goals before I started here and I have accomplished all my goals.'' Irvin is one of 16 children whose father died in 1983.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1988
description: Markets

title: Key Rates
A Mideast Vehicle. Who'll Steer It?
description: Suddenly there's a slim basis for hope, the first genuine opening for Arab-Israeli negotiations since the Camp David accords a decade ago. But as bullets fly and beatings continue in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and with U.S. and Israeli elections approaching, it will close just as quickly - unless the Reagan Administration moves fast.

title: California Bond Rate Higher In Response to Tax Rules
description: California's first issue of tax-exempt bonds with interest subject to the Federal alternative minimum income tax resulted in interest rates that were about half a percentage point higher than is traditional for the state's bonds, which are completely exempt from Federal income tax.

title: Lawmakers Criticize Kean Budget Plan
description: Governor Kean gave the New Jersey Legislature his proposed $11.8 billion budget for the coming fiscal year today, but the lawmakers focused more on what the Governor did not say than on what he did say.

title: Rangers Rally In Final Seconds
description: Whenever the two goaltenders of this dramatic 2-2 tie looked out across the ice before them, they saw tight checking and clogged plays, a reassuring, if unartistic, sight.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Two Denver Broncos - Dave Studdard, an offensive tackle, and Marc Munford, a linebacker, underwent surgery yesterday. Studdard suffered a torn ligament in his left knee in the second quarter of the Super Bowl loss Sunday to Washington. Munford, a rookie, had been sidelined several weeks with a herniated disk in his back. . . . Kurt Petersen, an offensive guard who missed the 1986 and 1987 seasons after suffering a knee injury Jan. 4, 1986, retired from the Dallas Cowboys. Petersen started five seasons at right guard for Dallas. . . . Tom Braatz, vice president of the Green Bay Packers, said he had offered the team's head coaching job to the Cleveland Browns' offensive coordinator, Lindy Infante, and said he wanted a reply today. Infante is in Honolulu.

title: Tribune Co. Profit Rises
description: The Tribune Company, a media company that owns The Daily News in New York and The Chicago Tribune, said today that its fourth-quarter profit had doubled.

title: EAST BERLIN FREES ITS RIGHTS LEADERS
description: Leading members of East Germany's fledgling human rights movement were released from prison today, and they left for West Germany, possibly against their will.

title: From Out of the Past, Angel Food Cake
description: SEVERAL weeks ago a friend served homemade angel food cake with raspberry sauce, and everyone asked for seconds. It wasn't until later that it dawned on me that I hadn't had angel food cake in 20 years. And that my angel cake slicer, the one with the long teeth, had been sitting idle in the silver drawer.

title: UNION TEXAS PETROLEUM HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss In the latest quarter, preferred dividend requirements nearly totaled net income. The company said that during 1987 its replacement of oil and gas reserves exceeded its domestic production.

title: Sports People; Arbitration Winner
description: Baseball's first salary arbitration case of the year was decided yesterday in favor of a player, Gerald Perry, the 27-year-old first baseman for the Atlanta Braves. Last season, at a salary of $225,000, Perry batted .270, hit 12 home runs, knocked in 74 runs and stole 42 bases. The Braves then offered him $375,000 for next season, but Perry asked for $425,000. The case was argued Monday in New York, and was decided yesterday in favor of Perry. . . . Among the latest of the 94 players who filed for salary arbitration last month to settle with their clubs yesterday were Don Carman, Tom Browning and Julio Franco. Carman, second in pitching victories on the Phillies last season with a 13-11 mark and a 4.22 earned-run average, agreed to a one-year contract with Philadelphia for $450,000, a raise of $205,000. Franco, who batted .319 as the Indian shortstop, agreed to a two-year contract with Cleveland for $2.2 million, $975,000 of it in 1988. Browning, who had an 8-13 record and 5.02 e.r.a. for the Reds last season, agreed to a one-year deal with Cincinnati for $442,500.

title: Nursing Candidates Take Compromised Test
description: Officials in 44 states and United States territories yesterday began administering a two-day national examination leading to the licensing of registered nurses despite evidence that a copy of the test had been stolen and photocopied in California.

title: New Mets Training Complex To Put St. Lucie West on Map
description: There is more to selling Florida real estate these days than promising an absence of backyard alligators and a plentiful harvest of oversized oranges. New communities tempt prospective settlers with famous resident tennis pros, championship golf courses, horse farms or, in the case of St. Lucie West, a hometown major league baseball team.

title: Study Says Rights Agency in New York Is Too Slow
description: A mayoral panel sharply criticized the New York City Human Rights Commission yesterday, saying that it took years to resolve many complaints that should be handled in weeks or months.

title: In Search of Accountability in Campus Courses
description: David Pillemar, a professor of psychology at Wellesley College in Massachusetts, recently became interested in how students pick their majors.

title: Cab Driver of Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: WEBB, DEL E CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $241,000 and $4,214,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectivley; the year also includes a $1,050,000 loss on the exchange of common stock for notes, and a $3,834,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes a loss of $750,000 and $946,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: Dollar Off in Quiet Trading After Prime Rate Reduction
description: The dollar declined against most major foreign currencies in quiet trading yesterday, largely because of a reduction in domestic interest rates and uncertainty about the outcome of this week's sales of $27 billion of Treasury debt.

title: ALCO HEALTH SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
60-Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN glancing through my recipes for meals that can be made in an hour, I am impressed by the number of hamburger dishes. Part of the appeal of hamburgers is that they can be teamed with a number of foods and flavors, altering their character with each addition.

title: Dow Up 8.29 After Listless Trading
description: LEAD: After a day of listless trading, stock prices turned higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 1,952.92, up 8.29 points.

title: Boxing Notebook; Film Role Proves Matchmaker for King
description: Lawrence Gordon, the producer of the Nick Nolte-Eddie Murphy film, ''48 Hours,'' is a fight fan.

title: The Pop Life
description: Still Shining at 40

title: Pentagon to Ask Funds For Midgetman Missile
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has decided to request enough money in the Pentagon's 1989 budget to keep alive development of the single-warhead Midgetman nuclear missile, Administration officials said today.

title: LOUISIANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WITCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $4.8 million from the sale in the fourth quarter of oil and gas properties.

title: The Diary Of an Eater: Confessing To Experts
description: EVERYONE knows that Americans eat too much fat, sodium and sugar, and that they ought to consume more whole grains, fruits and vegetables.

title: TV Reviews; The Smothers Brothers
description: TOM AND DICK SMOTHERS are in a helicopter that is taking them to their ''20th Reunion'' show at CBS. ''Don't forget,'' one says with evident satisfaction, ''this was the network that fired us.'' Suddenly, outside the studio below, a bunch of what look like suit-and-tie network executives man an antiaircraft gun and start firing at the chopper. We are back, happily, in the gently goofy but often pointed world of the Smothers Brothers, a world that was virtually banished from prime time in 1969, when CBS's censors seized and held the day.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter net, which is after a net writeoff of $8.7 million, did not cover preferred and preference dividend requirements. The company said it is restating 1986 earnings for accounting changes. After the restatement, net income for 1986 will be $10,369,000. The writeoff is a non-cash adjustment.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest quarter results include a charge of $1.1 million in reserve for costs associated with an offshore drilling rig, a charge of $4 million for additional interest expense, writedowns of about $5 million in pension expenses and writedowns of $3 million in additional contractural efficiencies and about $2 million in exchange losses.

title: Treasury Debt Issues Up Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose sharply yesterday as securities dealers became more optimistic that demand from domestic and Japanese investors would be strong the next few days.

title: Al Laney, Sportswriter, 92
description: Al Laney, a sportswriter for more than four decades, died last Sunday at his retirement home, the Fellowship Community, in Spring Valley. He was 92 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Armed With Credit Card
description: Americans wishing to contribute to the fight against gun control legislation can now obtain a special VISA credit card that will automatically make a contribution to the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms every time it is used.

title: Julius Joseph Jr., Advertising Executive, 79
description: Julius Joseph Jr., a partner in the Franklin & Joseph advertising agency in White Plains, died of heart failure Jan. 21 at the Veterans' Administration Nursing Home in the Bronx. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Excludes unrealized gains of $123 million from investments. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $122.5 million from the sale of the 50- percent interest in the computerized airline reservation system (PARS). d-Net loss The company said 1986 was adversely impacted by the strike of TWA's flight attendants during the first half of the year and then favorably impacted in the fourth quarter by the sale of PARS and that results for the first nine months of 1986 do not include the results of Ozark Air Lines which was acquired and first merged with TWA's financial results beginning with the fourth quarter 1986. The company said that excluding the 1986 PARS gain, the results for the year ended Dec. 31, 1987 were ahead of the results for 1986 by $335 million. The company did not report revenue figures.

title: Slow Comeback For New Issues
description: AFTER being derailed by the October collapse in stock prices, the new-issue market is getting back on track in 1988 - but only at a snail's pace.

title: A Faster Bobsled for U.S. Teams
description: WHEN the United States bobsled teams streak down the ice at the Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, later this month they may be able to challenge the East Germans, Swiss and Russians for the first time in years thanks to some recent innovations in sled design and construction made by engineers and high-tech companies working as volunteers.

title: SUPERMARKET CHAIN ACCUSED OF BREAKING VOW ON PESTICIDE
description: Consumer groups complained today that Safeway supermarkets had violated a promise to customers by selling apples containing trace amounts of a potentially hazardous farm chemical.

title: People
description: * Roger H. Clapp, advertising director of Richmond Newspapers, has been elected president of the International Newspaper Advertising and Marketing Executives.

title: Changes in Special Education Urged
description: Despite considerable progress in efforts to educate handicapped children since the passage of a landmark Federal law 12 years ago, so many flaws have developed in the various programs that they have become ''both segregated and second class,'' two experts in special education say.

title: MEESE ADDS LITTLE TO WEDTECH CASE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d testified in Federal District Court today that he could not remember details of the White House role in the Wedtech Corporation's efforts to obtain a $32 million Army contract in 1982. But he said at the time he wanted the company to receive a fair hearing.

title: Brazilian Debt Payment
description: Brazil paid about $350 million to its foreign bank creditors yesterday, as expected. This payment, which came from Brazil's currency reserves, was mainly for interest due Jan. 15 on previously restructured debt.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes after-tax charges of $11 million, or 15 cents a share, for employee severance at the New York Daily News subsidiary. c-Includes after-tax costs of $5 million, or 6 cents a shae, for New York Daily News severance and asset writedowns and $20 million, or 25 cents a share, in non-recurring charges for termination of interest rate swaps and disposition of a chemical business. The company said that excluding the charges of the 1986 fourth quarter, net income for the 1987 fourth quarter rose 18 percent to $55 million, or 71 cents a share, from $46 million, or 58 cents a share. New York Daily News subsidiary's after-tax charges in the 1987 full-year totaled $21 million, or 27 cents a share, and $9 million, or 11 cents a share, in 1986. The company also said that the 1986 full-year non-recurring items included gains of $181 million, or $2.24 a share, from the sale of assets and a charge of $20 million, or 25 cents a share, from the disposition of chemical operations and termination of interest rate swaps.

title: Addendum
description: * Middleberg Middleton has changed its name to Middleberg Middleton Picower, for its third partner, Mary Gendron Picower.

title: Strange Old Man on Sullivan St.: New Mob Power
description: Almost every afternoon, a graying, unimpressively dressed man emerges from an apartment building on Sullivan Street in Greenwich Village and gingerly crosses the street to a dingy store, where he spends several hours playing cards and whispering to confidants.

title: 4 Chosen for Hall of Fame
description: Alan Page, Mike Ditka, Fred Biletnikoff and Jack Ham were selected today to be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame next July.

title: Excerpts From S.E.C. Report on Factors in October Stock Market Plunge
description: Following are excerpts from the introduction and executive summary in today's Securities and Exchange Commission report on the stock market plunge: Introduction

title: Takeover Law Tested
description: The Black & Decker Corporation filed suit today against Delaware's corporate anti-takeover law, just hours after its enactment.

title: Playwrights Make Donations To the Neediest Cases Fund
description: A Manhattan playwright, John Tobias, recalls how he and his brother, as young children, used to stage variety shows and send the proceeds to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Outpatient Clinic for Those With AIDS Virus Opens in West
description: The opening of the nation's first outpatient clinic specializing in the treatment of people who tests have shown have the AIDS virus but have not developed symptoms of the disease itself was announced here today.

title: District of Columbia Will Provide Bleach For Addict Needles
description: District of Columbia health officials will begin giving drug addicts vials of bleach to clean hypodermic needles in an effort to halt the spread of AIDS, Health Commissioner Reed V. Tuckson has announced.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Georgi M. Malenkov, who succeeded Stalin as Soviet leader, misstated the current name of the town in which he was born. The town, Orenburg, was called Chkalov between 1938 and 1957; it is now once again called Orenburg.

title: An All-Rieti Concert For His 90th Birthday
description: ''I am going to be like an opera singer,'' Vittorio Rieti explained a few days after turning 90 last week. ''I will have a farewell, then another farewell, then further farewells.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Poor Taxpayer
description: Soreheads beware: while it may still be true that anyone is entitled to his day in court, a Federal appeals court here has served notice that henceforth that day may carry a price.

title: Who Says It's Only a Two-Party System?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Bronx: Cry for Help'
description: TELEVISION reporters often visit the South Bronx; political candidates do, too. Brent Owens didn't just visit, however, when he filmed ''The Bronx: a Cry for Help.'' He didn't have to; he already lived there. His distinctive one-hour documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight.

title: Race, Justice and the Brawley Case
description: Governor Cuomo finally had no choice but to appoint a special prosecutor in the case of Tawana Brawley: two local prosecutors disqualified themselves after Miss Brawley, a black Dutchess County teen-ager, alleged that she was the victim of a racially motivated kidnapping and sexual assault.

title: Signalmen Union Is Ordered To End a Walkout at L.I.R.R.
description: Signalmen on the Long Island Rail Road who walked off their jobs yesterday in a protest against what they said were hazardous working conditions were ordered back to work last night by Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Home Sales Off for Month And for Year
description: Sales of new homes slipped in December for the second consecutive month, while sales for 1987 fell 10.1 percent below their 1986 level, the Government reported today.

title: Recital: Boldorini
description: Raquel Boldorini, a pianist from Uruguay who has built a broad South American career and who toured in the United States twice in the 1970's, came to Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening for a concert of music from the first half of the 20th century.

title: N. M. Bodecker, 66; He Wrote and Drew Books for Children
description: N. M. Bodecker, an illustrator and author of children's books, died of cancer of the colon Feb. 1 at his home in Hancock, N.H. He was 66 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Effort in Mideast

title: City Ballet: 'Raymonda'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE gave the New York City Ballet a chance not just to shine but to glitter and explode when he choreographed ''Raymonda Variations.'' And the company rose to and beyond the occasion in a memorable performance of the ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater.

title: Don't Wait for the Stock Market to Cure Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawrence M. Rogin, Unionist, 79
description: Lawrence M. Rogin, a labor educator for more than 50 years and national director of education of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in the 1960's, died of cancer Jan. 26 at his home in Washington. He was 79 years old.

description: All per share and share data are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-1 split in August 1986 and a 2-for-1 split in May 1987.

title: The Editorial Notebook; At Home With Lyme Disease
description: A month ago, Lyme disease forced my wife, Elizabeth, back into the hospital. But this time she was allowed to leave quickly and self-administer the major part of her treatment in the comfort of home. There's a lesson in her experience that applies to far more than Lyme disease. Such home care saves money, buoys morale and upgrades the health care delivery system.

title: Chicago Board Offers System
description: As a result of the Brady commission's recommendation about the October market collapse, the Chicago Board of Trade has offered its computerized audit trail system to the New York Stock Exchange. In a letter dated Feb. 2, the

title: East Germany Faces Unrest Among Youth
description: East Germany, long insulated from critical calls for change, is facing an increasingly assertive human rights movement among the young.

title: Advertising; Emhart Begins Ads For Its New Operation
description: For some 75 years the Emhart Corporation had two operations, one producing such industrial products as machine tools, the other making such consumer goods as Tru-Temper lawn and garden tools and golf club shafts.

title: 2.5% Rise In Factory Orders
description: Factory orders, propelled by heavy demand for aircraft, surged 2.5 percent in December, closing out the best year for American manufacturers since 1984, the Government said today.

title: Study Backs Theory That AIDS Festered in Africa
description: A new study has found that a low incidence of AIDS infection in a remote African village is unchanged after a decade, suggesting that urbanization and war have played major roles in the continent's recent AIDS explosion.

title: Breakup of Savings Unit In California Considered
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is again leaning toward breaking the Financial Corporation of America into a number of pieces to solve the problems of the troubled savings and loan organization, a member of the bank board said today.

title: HERS
description: ''I HATE buffets; I'm bulimic,'' Maxine remarks casually, as if she's admitting that purple is her favorite color. We are standing in the buffet line at the Westwood Marquis Hotel, an unlikely choice for a confessional.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Battle Over Fish
description: Although the United States and Canada have signed a historic agreement to eliminate most trade barriers before the year 2000, they are still fighting over unprocessed fish.

title: Former Officials Propose Changes in Missile Pact
description: Richard N. Perle, a former defense official in the Reagan Administration, said today that the treaty banning land-based medium- and shorter-range missiles contained ''deficiencies'' that the Senate should correct.

title: Canadian Growth Seen
description: Canada's economy should shrug off any negative impact of the October stock market collapse and expand at a healthy rate, the Conference Board of Canada said today. The board's assessment is that the economy will grow by 2.9 percent this year and 2.6 percent in 1989.

title: Rev. Harold Mulqueen Dies at 93; A Longtime Professor at Fordham
description: The Rev. Harold Mulqueen, S.J., whose 80-year association with Fordham University gained him the name ''Father Fordham,'' died of burns Sunday at Bronx Municipal Hospital. University officials said the burns were sustained in a fire apparently started by his pipe. He was 93 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Francis J. Sorg, Printing Executive, 88
description: Francis J. Sorg, former chairman of the Sorg Printing Company, died Saturday at the Imperial Point Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: GREAT BAY BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings were not available; the company converted to public form of ownership on Dec. 30, 1987.

The company said the employee benefits business had an operating loss for 1987 of $54.5 million, compared with an operating profit of $139.4 million in 1986; for the fourth quarter, the employee benefits business had an operating loss of $57.1 million, compared with operating profit of $53.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1986.

Great American provided $29 million for loan and interest loss reserves in the latest quarter, including $11 million for real estate owned. The bank also realized a tax benefit in the latest quarter of $10.5 million. The year-ago quarter's net was restated to reflect impact of FASB 91.

title: The Great Garage Sale of Life
description: We are seeing the garage sales of the rich and famous - or at least of the once rich and famous. John Connally, Ivan Boesky and Eldridge Cleaver have been selling off cutlery. That some of these sales have taken place in penthouses and ranches shouldn't confuse us. They are still essentially garage sales.

title: ARCO Agrees to Buy Tricentrol
description: ARCO said today that it had reached an agreement to acquire Tricentrol P.L.C., an independent British oil and gas company, in a deal that values Tricentrol at more than $330 million.

title: A Correction
description: A letter Tuesday from Rhoda S. Jacobs, member of the New York State Assembly, gave an incorrect deadline for registration to vote in the New York State primary. The correct date is Feb. 19.

title: AIRGAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $187,000.

title: Holmes a Court Ends Agreement
description: The Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court has withdrawn from an agreement to buy several national newspapers in Australia and New Zealand from John Fairfax Ltd. The cancellation, made by mutual consent, comes as Mr. Holmes a Court continues to recover from the effect of the October stock market plunge on his international holdings.

title: Legislators Are Hesitant on Regulating Surrogacy
description: Despite a flurry of bills on surrogate parenting around the country last year, the practice and its legal, ethical and social implications remain in a legislative limbo.

title: 6 Areas to Get Water Meters
description: The Koch administration yesterday named the first six areas of New York City in which water meters will be installed in residences under a two-year-old water conservation plan.

title: ELCOTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRANK GEHRY'S CHAIRS: HE CAN'T GIVE THEM UP
description: PEOPLE who see Frank Gehry's cardboard furniture in 1988 may think they've seen it before. And they may have. Mr. Gehry, the iconoclastic architect based in Venice, Calif., introduced Easy Edges, a seating collection made from corrugated cardboard, in 1971. Because of their imaginative and experimental nature, the chairs continue to stand out in the crowd of architect-designed furniture.

title: BANKNORTH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Luge Racer at Center of Controversy
description: The Calgary Winter Olympics, with 57 countries participating, more than ever before, is on the verge of losing one over the interpretation of a rule governing accreditation requirements for athletes.

title: Stock Specialists Viewed as Jittery
description: October's stock market collapse may have given some stock exchange specialists a lasting case of the jitters, with many of them backing away from buying or selling stocks when they are most needed, the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission reported in its market study released Tuesday.

title: Son Helps Miller Fight 'Yips'
description: Putting has haunted Johnny Miller throughout most of his golf career.

title: Prison Aides Give Inmate Murder Alibi
description: A man charged by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office with murdering a stranger beneath a highway overpass one year ago tomorrow was in an upstate prison at the time of the killing, state correctional officials said yesterday.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Jane Talcott has been promoted to senior vice president, creative director at DDB Needham, New York, a subsidiary of Omnicom Group.

title: Senate, 97 to 0, Confirms Kennedy to High Court
description: The extraordinary seven-month battle over the vacant seat on the Supreme Court ended without a dissenting vote today as the Senate confirmed Judge Anthony M. Kennedy as an Associate Justice.

title: Profitable Chrysler Unit
description: The American Motors Corporation would have earned about $200 million last year if it had not been acquired by the Chrysler Corporation in August, according to Automotive News. The trade publication cited a study by Chrysler's financial staff.

title: Sports People; Packers Name Infante
description: Lindy Infante, the offensive coordinator who helped the Cleveland Browns to two consecutive appearances in the American Conference championship game, took over yesterday as coach of the Green Bay Packers. Infante, 47, signed a five-year contract. Tom Braatz, the Packers' executive vice president of football operations, said Infante's expertise made him attractive. Green Bay struggled on offense last season when it finished 5-9-1. Infante replaced Forrest Gregg, who resigned last month to coach at Southern Methodist University.

title: Gandhi's Wife Pulled Into India Political Fray
description: Returning from a recent holiday in the sun, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi faced new criticism for vacationing at a time of hardship in India. Even worse, it was described as a vacation with foreigners, including family and friends of his Italian-born wife, Sonia.

title: Musicians Vote to End Strike in San Francisco
description: The musicians of the San Francisco Symphony voted, 71 to 18, over the weekend to ratify a new contract and end a 12-day strike.

description: b-Includes capital gains of $72,000 and $1,220,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $305,000 for the quarter and $1,733,000 for the year.

description: Amid a tide of discrimination against homosexuals caused by the AIDS epidemic, gay men in New York City are beginning to discern a countervailing attitude - a new sense of openness and understanding on the part of some heterosexuals.

title: New Jackson Finding Dividends in Iowa
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson argues that he is already a winner in Iowa. And on a frigid Tuesday night, as he entered a union hall to warm applause, the distance he had traveled since his 1984 campaign was clear.

title: U.S. and Germany Called Pleased With Dollar's Level
description: The United States and West Germany, whose disputes over economic policies last fall contributed to the decline of the dollar's value, are content with one another's policies now and with current levels of the dollar and interest rates, an Administration official said today.

title: Market Place; Japanese Bought During Plunge
description: UNTIL the last stages of the bull market, Japanese investors were big buyers of United States equities. And even when Wall Street prices collapsed in October, the Japanese kept nibbling at stocks in this country, in contrast to the liquidation by American traders, mutual funds and other domestic institutions.

description: Marcus Schloss & Company, a New York brokerage firm, was tied to the ''Yuppie Five'' case today when the Government accused it of trading on the basis of nonpublic information.

title: Silver: Care and Repair
description: ''THE more you use it, the better it looks,'' said Robert Routh, the president of Thome Silversmiths. He explained that frequent use gives silver a patina ''with a soft, beautiful luster to it.''

title: Jams and All, Commuters Like Their Cars
description: Despite the jams and the jolts, a car culture flourishes in New York City, a survey of motorists commissioned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority shows.
