title: Exchanges' Battle Ends
description: A dispute that would have kept the New York Futures Exchange from moving to the Commodity Exchange Center at 4 World Trade Center on Monday was resolved yesterday, as quickly as it blew up.

title: The Office Fleet Is Fleeting, So Will Russians Go on Foot?
description: The office car, an omnipresent perquisite among the Soviet elite, is about to become a perk of the past for thousands of middle-level bureaucrats and factory executives.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Duplicate Studies
description: The inspector general of the Labor Department has begun an investigation to determine whether departmental procedures were violated by the award of a $1.3 million contract for a study that virtually duplicated a study done by the department's own Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Campaign '88: Lever a Winner
description: Lafayette Lever averaged 18.9 points a game last season, had 654 assists, 729 rebounds, 201 steals, made only 167 turnovers and led the league in triple doubles with 16.

title: Devils' Streak Ends at 3
description: Esa Tikkanen scored three goals and Dave Hannan had two as the Edmonton Oilers outscored the New Jersey Devils, 8-5, tonight.

title: Computer Love Letters: Just Fill in the Blank
description: LEAD: Valentine's Day is still 10 days away, but Elliot Essman of Manhattan has already mailed love letters to almost 400 women, and he told them all the same thing: ''My dearest, sweetest [fill in the name], you are my life, my light, all things, everything, the world, the skies, the heavens, the oceans and the stars to me.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Say ''root canal'' and most people shudder with imagined pain and apprehension. But ask the millions of Americans who have had root canal treatments in recent years and you will hear a far happier tale. In a 1985 survey of 1,019 adults, 80 percent said the procedure was painless and far less complicated and uncomfortable than they had expected. Of the 20 percent who said root canal therapy was painful, most have confused it with the pre-existing pain of the infected tooth.

title: The Basic Speech: George Bush; A Call for a New Emphasis on Education, Its Leaders and Its 'Four R's'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net of $25,332 and a loss of $450,603 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes net of $39,586 for the quarter and a loss of $74,380 for the year, both from discontinued operations. Year-ago earnings are restated. All periods reflect the sale of the company's Pattin division.

title: Jazz: John Carter Group
description: THE clarinetist John Carter ended his first set at Carlos 1 on Tuesday with a quiet climax. Given Mr. Carter's ease with the unexpected - his compositions hop around registers, while his improvisations set up contrasting section after section - it makes sense he finished the show with a ballad instead of the obligatory sweat-pourer.

title: Ronald Bladen, 69, Sculptor Famed for Stark, Poetic Images
description: Ronald Bladen, a sculptor born in Canada and known for his austere poetic imagery in steel, wood and aluminum, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEWPORT NEWS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Campeau Sharply Raises Bid for Federated
description: The Campeau Corporation strikingly increased, by $14 a share, its bid yesterday for Federated Department Stores Inc., seeking to blunt any opposition to its proposed takeover.

title: EXCELAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $259,000 and $854,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said figures for all periods were presented to include the results of Kinetics Inc., which was acquired in August 1987 in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Palestinian Demonstrations Continue
description: Twenty or more Palestinian boys and young men - rocks and chunks of concrete in their hands, checkered kaffiyehs wrapped around their faces - clustered excitedly by their barricade of burning tires at the turnoff to this isolated village among the stony hills, waiting for cars with yellow Israeli license plates.

title: Warren F. Savage, Professor, 65
description: Warren F. Savage, professor emeritus of materials engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, died of cardiac arrest on Jan. 24 in Reston, Va. He was 65 years old and lived in Averill Park, N.Y.

title: Contras Kill 8 in an Attack on Farm Cooperative
description: They are temporarily out of coffins in Boaco, the provincial capital, something that is happening more and more often these days. As a result, the bodies of Benito Calero, his wife and two children were being prepared today for burial at a nearby military base.

title: Grand Jury Questions Regan
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, and Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds were questioned today by the Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: Meese's Office Classified Memo
description: The Justice Department classified as secret a memorandum that has put Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d at the center of an inquiry into an Iraqi oil pipeline project, preventing him from releasing it, his lawyer said today.

title: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COHASSET SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a dividend of $193,000 from the Mutual Savings Central Fund of Massachusetts. The per share earnings for the latest year and both year-ago periods were not applicable; the company converted to stock form of ownership in May 1987.

title: Arkansas Savings Unit Finds Few Preferred Stock Buyers
description: The largest savings and loan organization in Arkansas stumbled on Wall Street yesterday when Prudential-Bache Securities could not arrange enough buyers at the Arkansas issuer's latest auction of preferred stock.

title: COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included a pre- tax gain of $1.8 million from the sale of servicing rights on loans serviced for other investors. The latest 9 months included an after-tax writedown of $5 million in the value of loans held for sale and a $1.2 million charge from the writeoff of the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Summer Camps In Winter
description: This summer, Dr. Robert A. Kramer, a dentist in Clifton, N.J., will take 12 children on a tour of the United States. His tour, Discovery U.S.A., is one of the most exotic of almost 50 summer camps that will participate in the National Children's Camp Show Sunday at the Walden School in Manhattan.

title: Justice for All in the Baby M Case
description: At a stroke, New Jersey's Supreme Court brought clarity and justice to the Baby M case, which so tormented the nation last spring:

title: REAGAN BACKS F.B.I. OVER SURVEILLANCE
description: President Reagan is satisfied that the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted a proper surveillance campaign against groups opposed to his policies in Central America, the White House said today.

title: A-PLANT'S CLOSING GAINS IN CAPITAL
description: The largest Government plant that makes plutonium for nuclear bombs, closed and under intense scrutiny in recent months because of its resemblance to the Chernobyl reactor in the Soviet Union, will not be reopened, the Department of Energy has told some legislators on Capitol Hill.

title: Talking Deals; Questions Raised On E-II's Strategy
description: WHEN Donald P. Kelly, the crafty, 65-year-old chairman of E-II Holdings Inc., acquired a large stake in American Brands Inc. late last year, it set the stage for a takeover that has left questions about whether he was preparing to set up American Brands to take a problem off his hands. The deal also raises questions about some managements' desire to stay independent - often at shareholders' expense.

title: Wall Street Executives Call Program-Trade Curb Weak
description: New York Stock Exchange restrictions on program trading do not go far enough, a number of chief executives of major Wall Street firms said yesterday at a special meeting at the exchange. The meeting of 25 chief executives was held to hear their views on the controversial trading strategy that has been cited as a factor behind increased volatility of stock prices.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house is heated by steam and one radiator makes a banging sound when it is on. What causes this, and can eliminate it? A. As the steam in a radiator dissipates, it condenses into water and runs through the radiator valve to the boiler for reheating. If the water cannot run out easily and meets the incoming steam, a knocking sound sometimes results.

title: Many Donors to the Neediest Share Fruits of Their Success
description: Peter Johnson, a carpenter in Rockland County, N.Y., had a prosperous 1987, so he sent $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for ''those who need it more than I.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the sale of a child, or, at the very least, the sale of a mother's right to her child, the only mitigating factor being that one of the purchasers is the father.'' - Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court, in the unanimousBaby M decision. [ B6:3. ]

title: Dance: Limon Troupe's 'Poems'
description: THE Limon Dance Company, which began the final week of its season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, has maintained a special relationship with Anna Sokolow since Jose Limon, the troupe's founder, died in 1972. Both choreographers belonged to the second generation in American modern dance, although they could be classed as pioneers in their own right.

title: Defeat of Contra Aid: The 219-211 Roll-Call Vote in the House
description: Following is the 219-211 roll-call vote by which the House today rejected President Reagan's request for $43 million in aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua. A ''yes'' vote is to approve the President's plan; a ''no'' vote is to reject it. Voting yes were 47 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting no were 207 Democrats and 12 Republicans. An xxx denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Anne-Marie Goelet, Legion of Honor Officer
description: Anne-Marie Goelet, who was named an officer of the French Legion of Honor for her services in World War II, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old and also lived in Newport, R.I.

title: Music: St. Thomas Choir
description: BAD weather can throw an instrument out of tune, and perhaps a choir as well.

title: Gene Defect Pinpointed in Bad Reactions to Drugs
description: An international team of scientists has discovered the genetic defect that makes as many as 10 percent of white Americans and Europeans suffer bad reactions to many drugs used to treat high blood pressure, disturbances of heart rhythm and other conditions.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Attack on Pipeline
description: Whether or not Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d played an improper role in seeking support for a proposed billion-dollar Iraqi pipeline, environmentalists here and in Israel say the project was a terrible idea.

title: Sports People; Yankees Bow Out
description: The Yankees told Donnie Moore yesterday that they were no longer interested in him. Moore, a relief pitcher who was declared a free agent Jan. 22, had been scheduled to be in New York today for a physical examination, but the Yankees canceled the appointment. Moore, who has one year left on his contract with the California Angels, was one of seven players included in the ruling by Thomas Roberts, an arbitrator. Roberts found that those players had been victims of the owners' collusive treatment of free agents after the 1985 season and should have another chance at free agency. He gave them a no-risk opportunity until March 1. Kirk Gibson is the only one of the seven who has changed teams, leaving Detroit for a three-year, $4.5 million deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers. Moore has indicated desire to leave the Angels, but the Yankees had been the only team to show interest.

title: Belgique's Stock Is Active
description: More than $700 million worth of shares in Societe Generale de Belgique apparently changed hands in fevered trading that began Tuesday night, deepening the uncertainty about the future of Belgium's largest company.

title: SEPARATING JOSEPH LEGENDS FROM HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: USG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $24,545,000 relating to restructuring. c-Includes a loss of $228,000 and $3,254,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations; the year also includes a loss on planned disposal of discontinued operations of $26,668,000. The company said the 1987 results included a first quarter after-tax gain of $29,988,000, or 58 cents a share, on the secondary public offering of about 25 percent of CGC Inc.'s common; results for 1987 also included third and fourth quarter after-tax charges of $30,134,000 related to restructuring.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (MIAMI, FLA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $2,617,000 from cumulative effect of change in accounting. c-Net income and after a charge of $2,538,000 from change in accounting. The company said the latest first quarter loss was primarily attributable to pre-tax losses incurred by American Savings & Loan's subsidiary, Kaufmann, Alsberg & Co., amounting to $11 million. The company also said Kaufmann, Alsberg's losses (including unrealized losses of $10.9 million) resulted from losses on securities transactions substained as a result of the stock market collapse in October 1987 and instability in the financial markets, which contained through the quarter.

title: Meager Arms Progress by Britain and France
description: President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac returned from a summit gathering in London last week disappointed by the meager progress achieved in intensifying military cooperation between Western Europe's two nuclear powers, according to officials and diplomats.

title: Bridge: Play From National Event Showed Exception to a Rule
description: When both sides have a fit in two suits, aggressive bidding is usually indicated and forthcoming. But exceptions arise when much of the high-card strength is located defensively, in the opponents' suits.

title: SURROGATE DEALS FOR MOTHERS HELD ILLEGAL IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that commercial surrogate-motherhood contracts were illegal but it allowed custody of Melissa Elizabeth Stern, the child at the center of the Baby M case, to remain with her father, William Stern, and his wife, Elizabeth.

title: British Airways
description: British Airways P.L.C. said it had signed a $2 billion order for eleven 767 jets from the Boeing Company with an option to buy 15 more. The first aircraft will be delivered in November 1989, the company said. The order was first announced last August. British Airways said that it had signed contracts totaling $400 million with the British engine maker Rolls-Royce P.L.C to supply RB211-524H engines for the aircraft.

title: REFRIGERATOR AS MESSAGE CENTER
description: A RECENT product called Play it Cool, right, may be just the thing to end the silent and sometimes cryptic messages that festoon the fronts of most refrigerators.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $48.9 million and $61.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from a writedown of assets; a charge of $733,000 and $1,794,000 for the same periods, respectively, from early extinguishment of debt; the quarter also includes a reversal of a tax credit of $2,535,000. c-Includes a charge of $2.9 million from a writedown of assets. d-Net income The company said the latest year loss includes a restatement of the first 9 months to reflect a change in depreciation method for plant and equipment.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Revenue
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $13,123,000 and a loss from the early retirement of debt of $1,045,000. c-Net loss d-After a loss on sale of Pioneer Western Corp. of $4,911,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of LDX Group Inc. of $4,910,000. e-After a loss from discontinued operations of Pioneer Western Corp. of $52,000, a loss from discontinued operations of LDX Group of $15,626,000, and a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $16,877,000. The year-ago quarter's loss from continuing operations included a $43.1 million after-tax charge for asset restructuring.

title: AMERICAN INDEMNITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $11,254 for the quarter and a gain of $1,688,746 for year.

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $700,000 for relocation costs.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Allegiance to Firearms

title: Stage: At the Hellinger, Rodney Dangerfield
description: AT age 66, Rodney Dangerfield is the youngest older comedian - or might he be the oldest younger comedian? - on the block. Whichever, Mr. Dangerfield, who opened a two-week engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theater on Tuesday, is the rare comic whose popularity transcends generations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said the Federal Aviation Administration had certified its aircraft collision avoidance system for use by United Airlines.

title: As Isabel Allende Sees Herself
description: Like most other serious novelists, Isabel Allende of Chile would prefer not to be fingerprinted and imprisoned in a confining category - not as a female writer or as a political writer or even as a Latin American writer. Just plain novelist, she said the other day, will do.

title: Tunisia Did Not Shoot Palestinian Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: HUNT, J B TRANSPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from an accounting change of $3,556,000.

title: Robert S. Sturtevant, Advertising Executive, 56
description: Robert S. Sturtevant, co-founder and chairman of a Manhattan advertising agency, Sturtevant and Hildt, died Saturday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges for restructuring of $6.8 million and $6.4 million for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Domingo Cancels
description: Placido Domingo has canceled his scheduled appearances in the Metropolitan Opera production of ''Luisa Miller'' on Feb. 10 and 13, saying he has a cold. The tenor Ermanno Mauro will sing the role of Rodolfo at those performances.

title: FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Products Set By Sun and Sony
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. has introduced a new work station, the Sun-4/110, which it said would offer users many times the power currently available from competing machines in such applications as artificial intelligence and computer-aided software engineering. The new machine is the latest to use Sun's high-speed chip, or Sparc, microprocessor and will sell for $18,900, the company said.

title: Michigan Law on South Africa Investments Upset
description: The Michigan Court of Appeals has declared unconstitutional a state law forcing public colleges to get rid of investments in companies operating in South Africa.

title: Separating Joseph Legends From History
description: To the Editor:

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bankers Held in Case Tied to Restaurant Slaying
description: The president of a bank, its former president and two New York State tax agents have been arrested as part of a Federal investigation into the tangled financial affairs of Irwin Schiff, an enigmatic millionaire businessman who was slain in a Manhattan restaurant.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December 1987.

title: The Crash and Its Best Students
description: In the latest formal study of the October stock crash, the Securities and Exchange Commission paints the picture of a rapidly changing market organized around obsolete rules and expectations. The proposed reforms could reduce the probability of another crash. But meanwhile, a much larger and more constructive change has probably already occurred among the pension and mutual funds that now dominate the market.

title: Futures Board Accuses Kidder on Index Trades
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has filed a five-count complaint against Kidder, Peabody & Company and a vice president at the firm, as well as a Chicago futures trading firm and two of its traders.

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Sports People; Bigger Than Life
description: The worst nightmare for National Basketball Association defenders - a 7-foot, 275-pound Larry Bird - came to Boston Garden last night, but only for a public unveiling at halftime of the Celtics-Indiana Pacer game. The detailed sculpture of the Boston superstar, hand carved in more than 2,000 hours from a single 1,800-pound block of laminated basswood, was the work of Armand LaMontagne, a Rhode Island sculptor.The study of Bird, crouched as if prepared to release a jump shot, was privately un-veiled on Tuesday night at a $1,500-a-couple benefit dinner for the New England Sports Museum.

title: Precious Metals Plummet Amid Many Uncertainties
description: Prices of gold, silver and platinum futures plunged yesterday as the ranks of sellers dwindled throughout the trading session.

title: CMS ENHANCEMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Congress Rescinds Measure To Build Schools in France
description: Acting at the request of its author, Congress has killed an $8 million appropriation to build schools in France for North African Jews.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,100,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: New York City, taking advantage of the recent decline in interest rates, offered $450 million of tax-exempt bonds yesterday through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Palestinians' Choice
description: Out of the turmoil in the West Bank and Gaza has come a moment of opportunity. There is a chance, just a chance, of turning from hatred and savagery to the path of negotiation. But that can happen only if the moment is seized by the crucial actors: Israel, the Palestinians, the United States.

title: Index Futures Causing Turf Battle
description: Government agencies are notorious for their turf battles, and the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today began what is bound to become an intense struggle between the S.E.C. and its sister agency, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, over the regulation of stock index futures.

title: DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Charges Dropped in Quarrel
description: Prosecutors today dropped charges of battery and disorderly conduct against Gary Dotson, whose rape sentence was commuted in 1985 after the woman who accused him of raping her recanted. Mr. Dotson was accused of stabbing a cook in a barroom quarrel Dec. 26. Officials said they were dropping the case because the cook did not want to pursue it.

title: Dow Falls 28.35 After Early Gains
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average, which was up in the early going, fell 28.35 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 1,924.57.

title: Robert S. Salzer, Retired Vice Admiral, 68
description: Robert S. Salzer, a retired Navy vice admiral, died last Saturday of heart failure at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 68 years old and lived in McLean, Va..

title: College Basketball; Michigan, With Big First Half, Tops Iowa by 120-103
description: Gary Grant, Glen Rice and Terry Mills led a first-half surge as Michigan scored a surprisingly easy 120-103 victory over Iowa in a Big Ten Conference game tonight.

title: Chinese Are Said to Restore Shaky Calm in Tibet
description: The Chinese authorities, using a mixture of jailings, political indoctrination and conciliation, have established a shaky peace over Tibet since the violent anti-Chinese protests four months ago, according to diplomats here.

title: Dr. Irving Goldaber, Sociologist, 62
description: Dr. Irving Goldaber, a Miami sociologist died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday in Monterey, Calif., where he was conducting a labor-management program. He was 62 years old.

title: Time to Save Open Land Is Running Out
description: At this rate, there may be no farmland left in New Jersey in two decades. Litchfield County, Conn., lost nearly half of its agricultural acreage over two decades. Scout camps in Hunterdon County, N.J., and Dutchess County, N.Y., beset by declining attendance, encroaching suburbs and even a lack of lifeguards, were coveted by developers. Community gardens on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, regarded a decade ago as a dirt cheap, though largely cosmetic, weapon against urban blight, are suddenly becoming too valuable to keep vacant.

title: A Film Maker Reflects On a 12-Year Project
description: Recent successes are encouraging young independent black film makers.

title: Tenacious Purslane Returns, Prettier and Good Enough to Eat
description: AONG the chief pleasures of gardening are the unpredictable discoveries and surprises that occur almost constantly. Even a very long lifetime is not sufficient to contain them all. We gardeners need to wear our knowledge lightly, for it is always subject to correction.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Chief Gives Up Presidency
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company elected Theodore H. Black president and chief operating officer yesterday, putting him in line as a potential successor to Thomas A. Holmes, chairman and chief executive.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Consumer's World page last Saturday about devices that clean air and mute noise identified an air-quality expert incompletely. It was Ron White, air conservation manager for the American Lung Association, who said, ''Small desktop-size air filters are probably worthless.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sports People; Baseball Contracts
description: Tim Laudner of the Minnesota Twins, Jim Winn of the Chicago White Sox and Jim Pankovits of the Houston Astros agreed to one-year contracts yesterday, reducing the number of players in salary arbitration to 55. Laudner, a free-agent catcher, agreed to a salary of $295,000, plus an additional $12,500 if he plays 95 games or more. Laudner had submitted a figure of $350,000 while the Twins had submitted $245,000. He batted .191 in 1987 with 16 homers and 43 runs batted in last season. Winn, who was 4-6 last season with six saves and a 4.79 earned-run average, will get $165,000 and has the opportunity to earn $207,500 more in incentive bonuses.

title: FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Names Alpine Ski Team
description: Tamara McKinney, a three-time Olympian, and Debbie Armstrong, who won a gold medal in 1984, headed the list of 18 skiers named today to the United States Alpine team for the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Advertising; Soviet Ad Conference
description: Barry Day, vice chairman and director of professional services at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will be telling 400 Soviet manufacturers today the basics about Western advertising at the first advertising conference in Moscow. Mr. Day is expected to show and discuss television spots for L'Oreal, Coca-Cola and Sony and warnings about drug abuse. The conference will last 10 days at the International Exhibi-tion Center in Moscow.

title: BANTA, GEORGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BELO, A H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on retirement of debt of $3,796,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $13.8 million from the sale of two radio properties for the quarter and a loss on retirement of debt of $12,766,000 for the year.

title: HOME & CITY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $6.2 million. The company said writedowns of real estate of $938,000 and a provision for loan losses of $850,000 in the latest fourth quarter, depressed earnings for the period.

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Federal Inquiry Sought on Attack
description: The chairman of a House judiciary subcommittee plans to ask the Justice Department to name a Federal prosecutor to investigate recent cases involving allegations of racism, including the Tawana Brawley incident in Dutchess County, according to his aides in Washington.

title: Profit Scoreboard
U.S. Asks Italy to Take F-16 Jets That Spain Has Ordered Removed
description: The United States has asked Italy if it would be willing to accept 72 F-16 jet fighters that must be withdrawn from Spain, Administration officials said today.

title: Robert Duncan, Poet and Author Of Works on the Creative Process
description: Robert Duncan, a poet and author of a work on the Imagist poet H. D. (Hilda Doolittle), died yesterday at his home in San Francisco. He was 69 years old.

title: Allegheny Needs $75 Million to Run
description: Allegheny International Inc., the consumer-products company hit by financial losses and a scandal over benefits paid to former executives, said it needed another $75 million to operate through April. The company said the $75 million reflected the amount it would fall short after calculating the revenues expected to be generated during this period.

title: Mae Gurevich, Active In Politics, Dead at 78
description: Mae Gurevich, vice chairman of the New York State Democratic Party for many years and more recently an aide to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, died of cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old.

title: AN INTERNATIONAL SET OF DESK ACCESSORIES
description: WHEN he started a product-design company in Tokyo 18 months ago, Ippei Inoh chose top talents from three countries as consultants.

title: A Woman For All Seasons
description: MARICICA PUICA'S sore left leg may be trying to tell her something: even the most versatile female runner of the decade may have her limits.

title: Film: Pavarotti in China, in 'Distant Harmony'
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI and China make a formidable match in ''Distant Harmony,'' a cheerful documentary about the tenor's tour of the country in June 1986. The director, DeWitt Sage, had the playful notion of playing off Western grand opera against traditional Chinese music and, in the course of these 85 highly entertaining minutes, reconciling them. So beginning today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, you can hear a version of ''O Sole Mio'' performed on Chinese instruments while residents of Beijing do their morning exercises on screen. Even more exotic, you can witness Mr. Pavarotti, hidden behind a marvel of a mask and a warrior's costume almost as colorful as the shirts he favors, take part in a Chinese operatic trio. This Western ear could detect no Italian accent.

title: Muzzleloading in Vogue Again
description: DAVE PEDIGO, a field representative for the National Muzzleloading Rifle Association, will explain the fundamentals of black-powder shooting at the meeting next Wednesday of the Nassau County Fish and Game Association.

title: PITNEY BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,869,000.

title: Advertising; N.W. Ayer Europe Wins Gillette Account
description: N.W. Ayer's European network of advertising agencies has won the Personal Care division of Gillette Europe. The budget is about $25 million.

title: Marcel Bozzuffi, Actor In Bad-Guy Roles, 59
description: Marcel Bozzuffi, a French actor known to the moviegoing public for his roles as a bad guy, died today after a long illness, family members said. He was 59 years old.

title: 2 Amateurs Succeed in the Toy Jungle
description: FOR many amateur inventors, the original idea came as a fluke. Consider two nonprofessionals who successfully brought their toy concepts to market.

title: Guerrillas in Colombia Step Up Their Attacks
description: Coinciding with a new wave of drug-related violence, a surge of leftist guerrilla activity is convulsing the Colombian provinces before important municipal elections March 13.

title: U.S. to Compensate Defector
description: Administration officials said tonight that the Nicaraguan military official who defected last fall, Roger Miranda Bengoechea, would get an unusually large payment from the United States Government.

title: Senseless And Sudden, Death Comes On West Side
description: There were 15 serious crimes in New York City on Jan. 24, according to the log at Police Headquarters. Five were homicides. But the case of Daniel Klagsbrun, a victim of one of those crimes two days past his 24th birthday, was not listed as a murder until two days later, when his grieving parents agreed to disconnect him from a respirator at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: Over a Philosophic Temple, Shadow of a Swastika

The Nazi past of the German philosopher Martin Heidegger has become the focus of a roiled debate among French intellectuals, one that is belatedly spilling over into West Germany as well.

The police reports alleged that Camacho pulled a gun on a person who made an obscene gesture at Camacho's companion. He was later released on bail. Camacho, 25, unbeaten in 31 bouts, has not fought since retaining his World Boxing Council lightweight title with a 12-round decision over Cornelius Boza-Edwards at Miami Beach, Fla., on Sept. 26, 1986. He later gave up the title because of increasing problems in making the 135-pound limit.

description: Two men and a 33-year-old Bronx woman were arrested last night and charged with the repeated rape of her 7-year-old daughter, the police said.

The team said that Nilan had suffered a ''significant sprain'' in his right knee. The Rangers acquired Nilan, a right winger, from Montreal on Jan. 27. He had a goal and an assist in three games with the Rangers.

With leaning walls and inclined floors, the building seems about to collapse.

A common feature of these bedsteads, chairs, commodes, washstands and chests of drawers was portability. Pieces that were not collapsible were fitted with handles or brackets through which poles for carrying them could be passed.

title: Searching For the Best In Day Care
description: A WELL-DESIGNED day-care program can foster your child's emotional and physical development in ways that you may not be able to at home. Studies have shown that children in group day care may be more self-confident and relate better to both children and adults than children who stay at home. A poor program, however, can be little more than a preschool parking lot. Unfortunately, child-care experts say, few parents know how to look for the subtle signs that can help distinguish a good program from an excellent one.

description: LEAD: A TOY inventor, a Polish emigre with a background in engineering, was given an assignment: play with ribbons, learn everything you can and try to come up with something new and great.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Flawed 'Tristan' That Improves With Distance
description: I LIKE the ''Tristan und Isolde'' of the Los Angeles Music Center Opera a lot better now than when I saw it in December. I have forgotten most of the things I thought were wrong, but the vestiges of what was right survive in my head, serving as reminders of the ''idea'' that Wagner's opera really is.

description: The New Jersey Supreme Court's decision in the Baby M case is not binding beyond the state's borders, but experts say it could deal a death blow to the commercial practice of surrogate motherhood in many other states.

description: Traffic was light today on Big Creek Lake. For the most part, the cars that usually cruise its frozen surface on brisk winter days stayed on land instead, their drivers cautious after a brief thaw.

title: BP America Bids For Lear Petroleum
description: BP America Inc., the United States subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company, has offered to acquire the Lear Petroleum Corporation in a deal that BP America has valued at $250 million. The Dallas-based Lear said it would study the offer with a recapitalization plan presented to the company by an investor group last month.

title: TV Review; 'THE GOLDEN YEARS'
description: AMONG the dividends in some basic cable hookups in the New York area is access to CUNY, the cable-television station of the City University of New York. CUNY is carried on cable channel A/ 14 in Manhattan and on 33 in Brooklyn and on Staten Island. The station has been especially adventurous in acquiring programs from abroad. It has presented series of productions from France, Germany and Britain's Channel 4. Two weeks ago, CUNY began running a German mini-series called ''The Golden Years - The Bitter Years.'' Each weekly installment can be seen on Thursdays at 10 A.M., 2 P.M., 6 P.M. or 10 P.M. Produced by Hans Hrischmann for the Bavaria Atelier, this particular epic runs for 19 episodes. There is still plenty of time to get on board.

description: b-Includes income of $3.7 million from technology license agreements and expense of $1.6 million relating to employee terminations.

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS CASE ON NOFZIGER

title: Spending Lag Stirring Few Worries
description: American consumers have been keeping a tighter grip on their wallets, but a close analysis of recent data and interviews with business people and consumers suggest there is little prospect that spending will fall far enough or long enough to end the nation's economic expansion, now in its sixth year.

title: Car Plant Shift Seen in Japan
description: Japanese auto makers will probably increase their annual production capacity at their United States and Canadian plants to 2.2 million vehicles by early 1990, from 300,000 in 1985, the Confederation of Japan Automobile Workers Unions said today.

title: Salk's Injectable Polio Vaccine May Be Revived
description: Health officials are considering a major change in the strategy of polio vaccination, using a new, more potent version of the injectable Salk vaccine that helped eradicate polio in the United States almost 30 years ago.

title: Desperately Seeking Iowa
description: Three cheers for the television networks for refusing to broadcast President Reagan's predictable speech urging Congress to vote further aid for the contras in Nicaragua. But don't expect the networks and the rest of the press to be as independent in giving next week's Iowa caucuses the coverage they deserve - which is not much.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1988
description: International A3-17

title: Music: By Schubert In His Teens
description: NO trip can be called an odyssey unless it inspires serious contemplation. With the 92d Street Y's odyssey-like Schubertiade, which intends to present the composer's complete work over the course of 10 years, listeners are invited to piece together the strands of a composer's evolution and, by extension, to reflect on the creative process itself.

title: The Decorated Pillow Suits Victoriana Perfectly
description: ANYONE with a taste for Victoriana or for the overstuffed English style cannot overlook the importance of the fancifully trimmed and beaded pillow as a decorative accessory. While pillows made from remnants of antique needlepoint or an Aubusson rug and trimmed in velvet and gold braid been available in antiques shops, they are getting harder to find. So Judyth van Amringe, a Manhattan accessories and clothing designer, decided to make her own.

title: Gulf War Premiums Cut
description: War risk insurance premiums have been cut, effective Thursday, for cargoes on ships sailing to and from many Persian Gulf ports, the War Risk Rating Committee said today. The decision stemmed from what the committee said was a slightly less volatile situation in the Persian Gulf and a decline in attacks on shipping. The new premium of 0.45 percent was down from 0.75 percent previously for shipments of crude mineral oils and products and gas cargoes.

title: Questions Persist in Dutchess Assault
description: Glenda Brawley says it was the night she found her 15-year-old daughter, Tawana, in a busy hospital ward in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., slipping in and out of consciousness, that she first became suspicious of how her daughter's case was being handled by authorities.

title: Hughes Aircraft To Buy Satellites
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said it had agreed to buy the satellite system of the Western Union Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Hughes, the Los Angeles-based subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said that it would operate the three orbiting satellites in Western Union's Westar VI-S system and that it intended to replace one with a newer model.

title: Note and Bond Prices in Retreat
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday as securities dealers absorbed $9 billion of new 10-year notes and prepared to bid today for $8.75 billion of new 30-year bonds.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $91,473,000, net of a $66,971,000 tax benefit, related to a personal injury settlement trust contribution, for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and includes a tax benefit of $3,878,000. Latest quarter includes a pretax charge of $18,283,000 and the year includes a pretax gain of $2,650,000, both from restructuring of operations. Year-ago quarter includes a pretax charge of $50,008,000 and the year includes a pre-tax loss of $46,975,000 from restructuring of operations. Preferred dividend requirement exceeded net income in the year-ago fourth quarter. The company said for calculating share earnings, cumulative preferred dividend requirements continue to be deducted, although no preferred dividends have been declared since the second quarter of 1982.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: John Mackovic, who formerly coached the Kansas City Chiefs, was named football coach at Illinois. The other finalist for the job, Howard Tippett, the defensive coordinator, resigned yesterday. Mackovic, 44, replaced Mike White, who resigned on Jan. 18. . . . Greg Kite, the center who was placed on waivers by the Boston Celtics earlier this week, has been acquired by the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Price Tag On Rescue In Texas
description: Federal regulators estimated today that between $6 billion and $7 billion would be needed initially to curb the capital shortages of battered savings associations in Texas. But industry advisers cautioned that the full cost of restoring health to the ahaelathe state's savings institutions to health would be much higher.
