title: Stage: Gurney's 'Scenes From American Life'
description: In ''Scenes From American Life,'' A. R. Gurney Jr. journeys through the midcentury to a prophetic future, which, in the revival of the 1971 play at the Long Wharf Theater, turns out to be today. The view is wry and satiric, sometimes wistful and, eventually, mordant. Despite the often cheerful surface, in Gurneyland complacency is its own nemesis.

title: BRITISH ARTS FESTIVAL IN LOS ANGELES
description: A three-month festival of British arts is to begin here Thursday with the city's first major retrospective of art by David Hockney; it will end April 30, after five performances by the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields. Squeezed in between will be more than 50 musical, theatrical and visual-arts events.

title: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $11,160,000, or 43 cents a share, on sales of properties.

title: THEARAPISTS SEE NEED FOR 'SECURITY BLANKET' THROUGHOUT LIFE
description: People who talk to themselves or who have imaginary companions are not necessarily mentally unhinged. To the contrary, experts say these tactics are two of innumerable helpful and healthy ways to find solace amid life's pains.

title: O'Neill Offers Budget That Taps 'Rainy Day' Fund
description: Stressing the need to maintain commitments to existing programs, Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed a $6.3 billion budget today that neither cuts nor raises taxes, but for the first time dips into Connecticut's five-year-old ''rainy day'' reserve fund.

title: Super Bowl's Ratings Spur Questions About Ad Costs
description: To the dismay of some advertisers who bought spots during this year's Super Bowl, the match between the Washington Redskins and the Denver Broncos received the lowest Nielsen ratings in 14 years.

title: Yonkers Is Given Simulcasts Stay
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board ordered Yonkers Raceway yesterday to end its simulcasts of Aqueduct racing beginning Saturday, but the Yonkers track won a stay of the ruling pending a hearing Feb. 11.

title: F.D.A. Issues Advice on Children's Ear Infections
description: Visit a pediatrician's waiting room these days, and chances are that one patient in three is suffering an ear infection, according to estimates by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss There were no share earnings for year 1986 after preferred share dividends. The results are in U.S. currency.

title: INTERCHANGE FINANCIAL SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings have been retroactively adjusted for a 3-for-2 split distributed Jan. 20, 1987, to holders of stock at Dec. 20, 1986. Corrected from Tuesday, Feb. 2, editions.

title: Advertising; Lord, Geller Shifts
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has reorganized its executive ranks. Edward D. Yaconetti, 49 years old, becomes vice chairman, from executive vice president; C. Ray Freeman, 45, is now executive vice president, general manager, from executive vice president, managing director, and Kevin B. O'Neill, 34, becomes executive vice president, creative director, from senior vice president, creative director. Lord, Geller, a subsidiary of WPP Group, also named Lewis E. Eichenholtz, 40, already a senior vice president, chief financial officer, to the additional job of director of agency operations. J. William Wardell, 49, senior vice president, managing director, was nameda director.

title: McDonnell Set For New Jets
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it intended to begin production by July on a new family of airplanes equipped with an advanced engine that is fuel efficient and quieter.

title: Argentina Reported Upset by Vaccine Test
description: The Argentina Government will send a formal protest note to the Pan American Health Organization over vaccine experiments on Argentine cows involving a genetically altered virus that it says accidentally infected humans, sources in the Foreign Ministry said Tuesday.

title: Exchanges Play Down S.E.C. Plan
description: Trying to ward off cumbersome new regulations, the heads of two Chicago futures exchanges and two major stock exchanges today criticized a proposal to give the Securities and Exchange Commission broad powers to regulate stock-index futures.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amax, Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a minerals and energy concern, elected Stephen C. Knup senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Martin V. Alonzo, who resigned last year.

title: IBP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The share earnings are pro forma. IBP went public in October.

title: First Fabulous Friday
description: The Muir String Quartet - Peter Zazofsky and Bayla Keyes, violinists; Steven Ansell, violist, and Michael Reynolds, cellist - will perform works by Haydn and Brahms, and the New York premiere of Sofia Gubaidulina's String Quartet No. 3, tonight at 8 in Weill Recital Hall. The concert is the first in a monthlong series called Fabulous Fridays. Tickets are $12. Information: 247-7800.

title: Film: 'She's Having a Baby,' From John Hughes
description: FOR John Hughes's Ferris Bueller, it was only a day off; for his Jefferson (Jake) Briggs, it may be an entire life. In the first scene of ''She's Having a Baby,'' which opens today at the Paramount and other theaters, Jake is seen marrying a woman he can barely stand, and this is only the beginning of his half-heartedness and disenchantment. He takes a dismal job in advertising. He moves to a sterile suburb. He winces at his wife's cooking. Jake seems bored with his entire existence, and as such he may be an even less sympathetic character than his teen-age antecedent.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax charge of $197,000. c-After a tax charge of $200,000. d-Net income and after a tax benefit of $440,000.

title: First Boston Official Quits
description: The First Boston Corporation suffered another high-level defection yesterday with the announcement that Yves-Andre Istel, co-head of its international operations, had resigned to join a new firm being formed by other former senior First Boston executives.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: In the Taylor Way

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $59 million for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes net from discontinued operations of $3 million, and a gain of $79 million on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $22 million and $66 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said net for 1987 includes net of $73 million, or 44 cents a share, on the sale of the company's remaining interest in Henley Group, Inc., and other related transactions, partly offset by a net charge of $30 million relating to the repurchase of high coupon bonds. The company also said net for 1986 includes a net gain of $46 million, or 26 cents a share, related to reversion of surplus pension funds.

title: Manes Had Stake in Collection Agency, U.S. Says
description: A new Federal indictment against a Queens lawyer and his son has charged that the late Donald R. Manes was a secret partner in a private agency ''corruptly'' set up to collect overdue parking fines for the city.

title: Photo of Jean-Honore Fragonard's ''Self-Portrait in Three-Quarter View, Facing Left'' THE GLORY OF FRAGONARD AT THE MET
description: THE adorable genius of Jean-Honore Fragonard looks perfectly at home in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Knick Defense Stops Pistons
description: Sidney Green was matched against Bill Laimbeer. Patrick Ewing was guarding Rick Mahorn. And Ewing and Bill Cartwright were in the lineup at the same crucial time, in the final minutes of the third period.

title: AVANT-GARDE ANTICS FOR FEARLESS AUDIENCES
description: IS it possible anymore for an audacious theater artist to go ''too far''? As experimental theater and performance activity reaches a peak of excitement around Manhattan this weekend, performers will be flinging down the gauntlet to fearless, inquiring audiences in work that tests as many different kinds of limits as there are artists willing to defy convention.

title: Metro Datelines; Koch Is Pessimistic On Estimate Board
description: Legal arguments have convinced him, Mayor Koch said yesterday, that the Board of Estimate runs a serious risk of being abolished.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Europe Research Plan
description: The European Community said it was willing to spend 550 million European Currency Units, or about $670 million, to co-finance research projects in advanced telecommunications to help companies enter a world market estimated to be worth more than $600 billion. The projects involve transmitting voice, data and images quickly and cheaply.

title: LYPHOMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
W. Marko Antich Investment Executive, 29
description: W. Marko Antich, managing director of the Redwood Capital Group, a venture capital concern in Manhattan that specialized in the health care industry, died in a skiing accident Monday in Vail, Colo. He was 29 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: STARRETT, L S CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
WARREN FIVE CENTS SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Warren converted to stock form of ownership in July 1986.

title: Camacho Bout Is Imperiled
description: Negotiations for Hector Camacho's fight with Ray Mancini, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, are continuing despite Camacho's arrest Tuesday in Clewiston, Fla., on charges of assault with a deadly weapon and possession of cocaine.

title: Drug-Free Games Expected
description: The chief medical officer of the Calgary Olympics said today that he did not expect any athletes competing in the Games, which start next Saturday, to test positively for a substance banned by the International Olympic Committee.

title: EX-HBO VIDEO CHIEF HEADING REEBOK UNIT
description: Frank J. O'Connell, who has been chief executive of HBO Video, has signed on with Reebok International Ltd. as president of the Reebok brands, which include the Reebok footwear and apparel divisions in North America.

title: New Bausch Shield
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., based in Rochester, said marketing of the first collagen corneal shield, which would deliver medication to the eye without blocking vision, would begin immediately, after approval last week by the Federal Food and Drug Administration. The lens has a potential yearly market value of $50 million for the company once improvements in the shield are cleared by the F.D.A., said Frank Jepson, a corporate vice president at Bausch & Lomb. The Bio-Cor 24 shield, which resembles a contact lens, is made from natural collagen, which dissolves over 24 hours as it delivers medication to the cornea.

title: Questions on Waldheim and Reprisal
description: Kurt Waldheim knew of and criticized Nazi reprisal killings of civilians in Greece in 1944, according to a newly discovered German army dispatch found by an American historian.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from a change in accounting of $4,547,000.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,602,000 for the quarter and $2,259,000 for the year. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $6,523,000.

title: HOME OFFICE REFERENCE LABORATORY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,486,000 from the repayment of the company's Mexico debt for both the quarter and year.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the adoption of FAS 90 in the latest year increased net income 8 cents a share for the year 1987.

title: Bush Reportedly Asked Cuba Deal on Grenada
description: A former senior Panamanian official said today that Vice President Bush, on the eve of the American invasion of Grenada, asked Panama's leader to intervene with Fidel Castro so Cuban troops would not fire on American soldiers.

title: 3 Share Lead at 67 At Pebble Beach
description: Jim Booros, who spent the last two years as the head pro at the municipal golf course in Allentown, Pa., decided that at 37 he would give the PGA Tour one more shot. He had not been too successful in five years on the circuit - 1977 and 1981, as well as 1983-85.

title:
About Real Estate;
3-Family Town Houses To Rise in Throgs Neck
description: LEAD: A development of 31 town houses on Miles Avenue in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx will offer purchasers a type of housing not easily found in large new projects - legal three-family dwellings sold to a single buyer.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $460,000 for the quarter and $1,198,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary gains of $520,000 for the quarter and $1,195,000 for the year.

title: Talks on Lear Bid
description: Executives of the Lear Petroleum Corporation and the United States arm of the British Petroleum Company met to discuss BP America's $250 million bid for the Texas natural gas concern. Oil industry analysts said such an acquisition would serve both companies well. Lear has not made money in two years, and needs a strong backer like BP America, which does not own any gas pipelines. ''It would be a very happy marriage,'' said John Olson, oil industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Houston. BP America owns or has an interest in 11,000 miles of pipeline in the United States that carry either crude oil or petroleum products.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $450,000 and $723,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Series of Conditions Makes 4-3 Trump Fit Appropriate
description: Standard bidding methods often have trouble finding the right game contract when a 4-3 trump fit is appropriate.

title: VOW TO PRESS ON
description: Nicaraguan rebel officials today bitterly criticized the House vote denying the contras further aid but vowed to continue fighting.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said it had repurchased 27.4 million shares last year for $1.1 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Earnings report in Business Day on Tuesday misidentified a company acquired by the MDT Corporation in July. It was the Castle Company.

title: ABI AMERICAN BUSINESPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Uruguayan Front-Runner
description: Uruguay's Foreign Minister, Enrique Yglesias, is emerging as a leading candidate for the presidency of the Inter-American Development Bank, a 44-nation Washington institution that makes development loans to Latin American countries.

title: J & J SNACK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
EXCHANGE LIMITING TRADING STRATEGY TIED TO COMPUTERS
description: In a move to restore investor confidence in the stock market, the board of the New York Stock Exchange voted unanimously yesterday to restrict a form of computerized stock trading that had been blamed for accelerating the market's chaotic plunge in October.

title: BANKWORCESTER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' nets included a one-time dividend of $447,000 paid to the company by Central Fund Dividend.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JUDAH P. BENJAMIN: The Jewish Confederate. By Eli N. Evans. 469 pages. Illustrated. The Free Press. $24.95.

title: UDC-UNIVERSAL DEVELOPMENT LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Luge Racer Must Obtain A Passport
description: Raymond Ocampo's attempt to retain his Olympic accreditation and represent the Philippines hinges on his ability to get a Philippine passport before the Games begin, a week from Saturday.

title: Music Benefit For Troupe Of Veterans
description: Several musical forms - jazz, choral singing, movie music and new music - by Dizzy Gillespie, Dave Brubeck, Anthony Davis, Philip Glass, Tania Leon and the Gregg Smith Singers will be presented in a benefit Sunday for the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company and the three-month-old Borden Avenue Shelter in Queens, the only shelter in New York specifically for homeless veterans.

title: Sports People; One at a Time
description: Butch van Breda Kolff ran up some impressive numbers in his career Wednesday night when his Lafayette College Leopards defeated Towson State, 73-60, at Easton, Pa. For van Breda Kolff, 64, the victory was the 700th in 1,200 games that he has coached in high school, college, the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association during the last 33 years. The coach was hospitalized briefly two weeks ago with an irregular heart beat.

title: U.S. Studying Dutchess Assault
description: The Justice Department is investigating the Tawana Brawley case in Dutchess County, N.Y., to determine whether civil rights laws were violated, a department spokeswoman said today.

title: Sports People; Oquendo Loses
description: Jose Oquendo, who hit a home run against San Francisco in Game 7 of the playoffs that helped St. Louis win the National League pennant last fall, lost his salary arbitration case yesterday.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 revenue figures are restated for an accounting change.

title: NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Letter on Pipeline Project Is Questioned
description: Avoiding normal channels, a close friend of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d arranged for a letter to be sent directly to Mr. Meese requesting a key legal opinion about a billion-dollar Iraqi oil pipeline project, according to past and present Government officials.

title: KEY RATES
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Chrysler Profit Up, but Less Than Expected
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 8 percent, but the results were below the forecasts of many analysts.

title: Times to Introduce A Television Weekly
description: The New York Times will introduce a new guide to broadcast and cable television programs on March 6. The magazine, called Television, will offer four-color advertising and will be printed by rotogravure on premium calendered paper, 8 1/4 by 11 inches, press-stitched and trimmed.

title: A City in Misery, Betrayed by a Taste for Clams
description: Lu Guiying, a portly woman in a white apron and cap, stood glumly outside her restaurant, her arms folded across her chest.

title: First Nationwide
description: The First Nationwide Bank, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said it had completed the acquisition of Uptown Federal Savings of Chicago for an undisclosed amount. Uptown Federal, which has deposits of about $1.5 billion and $2 billion in assets, operates 22 retail branches in Chicago and its northern suburbs, the company said. It said the acquisition increased First Nationwide's asset base to about $19 billion and raised its retail branch network to more than 370.

title: Film: 'Lightness of Being,' From Novel by Kundera
description: PHILIP KAUFMAN'S ''Unbearable Lightness of Being'' begins with much promise, as if it were a ribald fairy tale. ''In Prague in 1968,'' says a title card, ''there lived a young doctor named Tomas.'' Tomas (Daniel Day-Lewis) comes out of the operating room and goes straight to a pretty nurse waiting in the supply room.

title: CAPITAL CITIES/ABC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Includes a gain from sale of properties related to acquisition of ABC of $279,996,000 and a charge related to settlement of contract carrier litigation at the Kansas City Star of $14,250,000.

title: ARX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $298,000 from early redemption of debentures.

title: BARRY WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included a gains of about $167,000 from the adoption of new accounting rules for pension costs. The latest year included a gain of about $2,954,000 from a change in accounting for pension costs, a gain on the sale of a building, and prior-year royalty income from the settlement of a lawsuit. The year-ago quarter included a reduction of about $1 million as a result of personnel reductions and reversal of investment tax credits, and the year included a gain of $400,000 from an insurance settlement.

title: Financial Job Cutbacks
description: As many as 75,000 financial workers in London and New York may lose their jobs as a result of the Oct. 19 stock collapse, a banker told a conference today. Hans-Joerg Rudloff, deputy chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., said dismissals could total between 20,000 and 25,000 in London and up to 50,000 in New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Remembering Flo Hyman
description: THERE is only one thing wrong about the Flo Hyman Award: it came to be named for the Old Lady of volleyball much too soon.

title: ESCAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in April 1987.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a pretax investment reserve of $9.5 million, which is equivalent to about 70 cents a share.

title: Dollar Retreats With Bonds As Gold Rises in New York
description: The dollar retreated with bond prices yesterday, as disappointment with this week's Treasury refunding auctions appeared even before the sales ended late in the New York trading session.

title: Navy Sale to Japan Meets Opposition
description: A small group of lawmakers in the House of Representatives is trying to block the sale of the Navy's most sophisticated air defense system to Japan, an export that would be worth at least $500 million.

title: KENAN TRANSPORT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pall Picks Greenstone
description: The Pall Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial and medical filters based in Glen Cove, L.I., has named Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising, of Melville, L.I., to handle advertising for seven of its divisions. The budget exceeds $1 million. Jarman, Spitzer & Felix is the former agency.

title: A Jew Who Beat Jews in a Nazi Camp Is Stripped of His Citizenship
description: A Polish-born Jew accused of wartime atrocities surrendered his United States citizenship before a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday and admitted that he brutalized Jewish prisoners in a Nazi forced-labor camp and later entered this country illegally.

title: Sports People; Madlock to Japan
description: Bill Madlock, a four-time National League batting champion with a .305 career average, will play this season in Japan for the Lotte Orions, The Associated Press has reported.

title: DELTA WOODSIDE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
INDEPENDENT BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $80,000 for the quarter and $457,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $73,000 for the quarter and $411,000 for the year.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the effect of a $29 million payment the company received as part of a contract dispute settlement.

title: Metro Datelines; Detective Testifies On Chambers Story
description: Only a few hours before he admitted to the police that he had killed Jennifer Levin in Central Park, Robert E. Chambers Jr. denied being at the scene of her death and said his cat had left the red scratches that were visible across his face and chest, a police detective testified yesterday at Mr. Chambers's murder trial.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNIGHT-RIDDER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Art: 31 Late Drawings By Picasso in a Show
description: IT has always been accepted wisdom that late Picasso was lesser Picasso. During the decade or so before the artist's death in 1973 at the age of 92, Picasso's untiring energy was often spent on drawing images of splay-legged women. This was greeted by the artist's many followers with considerable, if reasonable, unease, especially coming as it did during the 1960's and early 70's when the women's liberation movement was beginning to gain steam.

title: Inside a 'Shooting Gallery': New Front in the AIDS War
description: Amid the flicker of stubby one-inch candles, the only light in an abandoned building near the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn, a 32-year-old man who calls himself Wollenski fidgeted as he watched another man glide a hypodermic syringe filled with cocaine and heroin effortlessly into his right biceps.

title: CRS SIRRINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a gain of $6.7 million from the termination of the company's defined benefit retirement plan.

title: Evolving Image for New Hampshire
description: New Hampshire has a secret: year by year, bit by bit, it is reinventing itself.

title: Brokers Play Down Surrogacy Case
description: Prominent surrogate-mother brokers around the country said today that commercial surrogate contracts were legally risky but that the New Jersey Supreme Court's ruling banning the agreements did not extend to their clinics.

title: GRENADA SUNBURST SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $570,000 for the quarter and $1,904,000 for the year.

title: 'SIDNEY SHELDON'S WINDMILLS OF THE GODS,' ON CBS
description: IF this is a CBS two-part dramatization starring Jaclyn Smith, it must be another Sidney Sheldon venture. Sure enough, ''Sidney Sheldon's Windmills of the Gods'' (that's the official title) gets under way with Ms. Smith this Sunday at 9 P.M. on CBS. The second half of the four-hour production will be broadcast on Tuesday. The hook this time around is an international scheme designed to encourage global paranoia. If nothing else, Mr. Sheldon thinks big.

title: CANCER CLUSTERS PROMPT U.S. STUDY
description: The National Institutes of Health have quietly initiated a study of cancer deaths among populations near nuclear power plants, according to a letter released today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: HEALTHWATCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fighting AIDS and Addiction: A Start
description: After two years of foot-dragging, Governor Cuomo has taken a small step toward exploring whether sterile needles and syringes might slow the wildfire spread of AIDS among drug addicts. The action, little and late, is nevertheless welcome.

title: People
description: * Katherine O. Jose has been appointed vice president, director of advertising, at The National Enquirer.

title: LINCOLN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Senate Panel Approves Bill To Regulate Lie Tests on Job
description: Legislation that would prevent employers from using polygraphs, or lie detectors, to screen job applicants was approved today by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee and sent to the Senate floor for a vote.

title: Washington Talk: The Justice Department; Despite Meese's Woes, Agency Muddles Through
description: ''Look at this,'' said a Justice Department official, pulling a yellowed newspaper clipping from his wallet. ''Words to live by.''

title: GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $2,350,000, or 44 cents a share, from a favorable settlement of claims against an Iranian client.

title: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for all periods reflect the merger with Vitramon Inc., acquired in July 1987 as a pooling of interests.

title: Nets Trounced, 115-87
description: The Houston Rockets made a team-record 25 consecutive free throws tonight in a 115-87 rout of the Nets.

title: Film: 'Julia and Julia,' With Kathleen Turner
description: ''JULIA AND JULIA,'' opening today at the Embassy 3 and other theaters, is minor movie making, but it does prove two things: that Kathleen Turner has become the kind of star who can carry even third-rate fiction without losing her beautiful, voluptuous cool, and that high-definition tape (on which this was initially shot) can be transferred to film and look as good as anything shot on film to start with.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANK CORP (MICH) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income in the latest fourth quarter was affected by an increase in the provision for loan and lease losses to $249,000 from $40,000 in the year-ago period, as a result of loan growth. The company said net securities losses of $300,000 were recognized in the fourth quarter as part of a program to reposition the investment portfolio in order to improve future yields, compared with net securities gains of $99,000 in the year-ago period.

title: DOMTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $2 million for the quarter and a special gain of $8 million for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Brent Owens, a film maker, misstated the release date for Spike Lee's film ''School Daze.'' It is to be released nationally on Feb. 12.

title: ENCOR ENERGY CORP LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included $406.5 million of writedowns. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Net Soars At Warner
description: With record results in its films, records and cable television divisions, Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 48.4 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Jan. 22, showing uncovered short sales for the New York Stock Exchange for the month ended Jan. 15, carried incorrect figures supplied by the Orion Pictures Corporation for its stock. As a result, the total Big Board short interest and the decline for the month were also incorrect. The figure for Orion Pictures was 104,704 shares.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Martha Love McCagg Snow Architect, 83
description: Martha Love McCagg Snow, an architect, died of colon and stomach cancer Wednesday at her daughter's home in Edison, N.J. She was 83 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: One Step Forward
description: The life or death, freedom or tyranny, peace or war talk that led up to the House of Representatives' vote against more aid to the Nicaraguan contras Wednesday sounds vastly overblown in Central America.

title: Heinz Acquisition
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had agreed to acquire Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. of San Diego. The price was not disclosed. Bumble Bee, which was acquired in a leveraged buyout from Castle & Cooke Inc. in 1985, produces tuna, salmon and oysters and Figaro cat foods. ''The acquisition of Bumble Bee will bring into Heinz operations another brand of well-respected, high-quality food products,'' said Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, Heinz's president, chairman and chief executive.

title: Plan for Savings Units
description: Savings industry regulators held talks today with four retail brokerage firms to determine their interest in selling certificates of deposit issued by savings and loans.

title: Federated, Fighting Bidder, Is Said to Consider Buyout
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. is weighing a management-led leveraged buyout to fend off a hostile takeover threat from the Campeau Corporation, banking experts familiar with the deal said yesterday.

title: Robert Fitzsimmons, Actor, 73
description: Robert Fitzsimmons, an actor and union leader, died of cardiac and pulmonary arrest on Jan. 31 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Senate, by 51-48 Vote, Backs Reagan Aid Request for the Contras
description: The Senate, giving President Reagan a surprising but only symbolic victory, voted tonight to support his request to provide at least $43 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: DOFASCO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: DELPHI INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a loss of $50,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $777,000 for the quarter and $1,924,000 for the year. c-After realized investment gains of $733,000 for the quarter and $480,000 for the year.

title: LaRouche, on TV, Cites AIDS
description: Lyndon LaRouche, the political extremist running for President as a Democrat, said on network television tonight that the AIDS virus was transmitted much like any other virus, including through casual contact, and that most medical warnings about how it is spread are ''an outright lie.'' Mr. LaRouche spoke on a 30-minute taped program televised nationally on CBS, from which his campaign bought air time. The candidate spent most of the program discussing what he said was a coming economic collapse and the regulatory and monetary steps he would take as President.

title: Restructuring For Polysar
description: The Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation, a Toronto-based holding company, told stock analysts yesterday that a restructuring plan it announced on Wednesday was in the works even before it received an unsolicited takeover bid from the Nova Corporation of Alberta.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Baby M Ruling Welcomed at Meeting of Surrogacy Experts
description: Lawyers and others participating in a workshop on surrogate motherhood today praised the New Jersey Supreme Court decision that restored parental rights to the mother of Baby M and said they expected it to influence lawmakers around the country.

title: Mets and Gooden Are Stalled
description: With less than two weeks to go to arbitration, the Mets and Dwight Gooden were hardening their positions yesterday over the issue of the two months that the star pitcher lost in drug therapy last season.

title: Expose Albany's Secret Spending
description: New York State's Legislature has budgeted a generous $167 million for its own operations in 1988, but how the money is being spent remains known only to the Assembly and Senate majority leaders, Mel Miller and Warren Anderson. Minority-party lawmakers, fed up with second-class treatment, justly complain.

title: TBC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock splits in February and September 1987.

title: Soviet Freedom, Soviet Fear
description: The West wonders how long Mikhail Gorbachev and his policy of perestroika, or restructuring, will last. Russians ask, too, even more fervently.

title: 'Cop,' a Thriller
description: JAMES WOODS is more frequently seen eating on-camera than just about any other actor, but he's so edgy and thin that there's nothing voluptuous about this behavior. If anything, it's borderline rude. So are Mr. Woods's smoking and his wisecracking; so is virtually everything else he does. Combine this taunting manner with the fierce, obsessive dedication Mr. Woods brings to almost any role and you have the makings of a perfect Elmore Leonard character, which Mr. Woods is bound to play some day. In the meantime, he has arrived as the detective hero of ''Cop,'' based on James Ellroy's crime novel ''Blood on the Moon.''

title: Dole Confronts Bush in Senate; Voices Anger at Criticism of Wife
description: Senator Bob Dole confronted Vice President Bush on the Senate floor twice today to denounce him for campaign statements that the Senator said were unfair to him and his wife.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; High-Level Gathering
description: In March, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will convene a rare summit meeting of Western heads of state. But on Thursday an unusally high-level delegation of Congressional leaders and Reagan Administration officials left for a more informal meeting with European counterparts in Munich.

title: Sports People; Irons Out
description: The United States Golf Association's executive committee reaffirmed its position that, starting in 1990, it will not permit use of the Ping Eye 2 irons in its competitions. The U.S.G.A. has declared that club illegal for general use starting in 1996, saying that the square grooves in the club are not set far enough apart.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: At the beginning of Tom Wolfe's ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' there is the disclaimer, so beloved of lawyers, that all of the characters are imaginary. But that is only partly true. The prosecutors and policemen and defense lawyers who populate the book may technically be fictional, but they are also the people Edward Hayes has known all his life.

title: IN SEARCH OF TOOTS SHOR: MANTLE'S BACK
description: The dreams of banishment he had every night, when he would wake up startled and sweating, are gone now.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on accounting adjustments of $200,000.

title: Breland Fights to Rebuild Reputation
description: From the start of his pro career, Mark Breland has been a special case.

title: Leon Schwartz
description: Leon Schwartz, an 84-year-old violinist, is to give two klezmer concerts today at the Richmondtown Restoration, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I. Mr. Schwartz, who was born in the Ukraine, has been playing klezmer music since the age of 12. Shows are at 8 and 9:30 P.M. Tickets are $6. Information: (718) 351-1617.

title: ARCO-Tricentrol
description: ARCO said it had acquired a controlling interest in Tricentrol P.L.C. today, a day after the small British oil company agreed to a deal valued at about $330 million. ARCO, which had held a 14.8 percent stake in Tricentrol, announced it had made additional stock purchases in the last two days that increased its interest to 54.5 percent.

title: RIVERBEND INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
The Law; For Complex Case, a Singular Mediation Effort
description: The separate legal worlds of the Federal and Connecticut courts are coming together in an unusual joint effort to handle a flood of lawsuits expected from the collapse of a new apartment building here last April 23 that killed 28 construction workers.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotations of the Day
description: ''People deserve better than this kind of low-down, nasty, mean politics. What kind of a candidate would put out a statement attacking another candidate and his wife without reading it.'' - Senator Bob Dole. [ A12:6. ]

title: ENERGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOSTER, L B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,778,000, a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $30,913,000, an extraordinary charge of $9,267,000, and a tax benefit of $8,334,000. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $869,000 for the quarter and $7,282,000 for the year; the quarter also included a restructuring provision of $21.3 million.

title: Gerald Knoff, 80, of Church Council, Dies
description: The Rev. Gerald E. Knoff, who served for 20 years as associate general secretary of the National Council of Churches, died of cardiac arrest Friday at the Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 80 years old and lived in East Sandwich, Mass.

title: Iraq Denies That It Requested Guarantees for Pipeline Plan
description: Iraq said today that it had not sought ''political guarantees'' from Israel or other parties in negotiations in 1984 over a projected oil pipeline to Jordan.

title: Ortega Says Contra Aid Rebuff Won't Stop U.S. 'War Against Nicaragua'
description: Despite the Congressional rejection of new aid for the contras, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that the six-year-old civil conflict here was far from over.

title: Gephardt Calls Simon Radio Ads In Iowa 'Negative Campaigning'
description: In a tight Democratic Presidential contest where the candidates are searching for any advantage, the campaigns of Representative Richard A. Gephardt and Senator Paul Simon traded volleys today over whether Mr. Simon was engaging in ''negative campaigning.''

title: A Candidate's Delight: To Say, 'Hi, Neighbor'
description: When Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts wants to reach the voters in New Hampshire, he can hold a news conference in his own office in Boston.

title: Jewish Group Calls Security Of Israel a 'Prime Concern'
description: A coalition of Jewish groups declared yesterday that concern among American Jews over the violent clashes in Israeli-occupied territories had not diminished the Jewish community's ''prime concern'' for Israel's security.

title: HEALTH MANAGEMENT ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inmates Assail Thai Prison Over AIDS Care
description: Forty-eight Thai and foreign prisoners in an AIDS unit of a Bangkok prison have asked the country's leading human rights lawyer and a Thai-American anti-AIDS campaigner to help them get medical care and draw attention to jail conditions that they say could help spread the disease.

title: Sarah Loening, 91; Began Biblical Garden
description: Sarah Larkin Loening, a writer who founded the Biblical Garden at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, died Monday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived for many years in Southampton.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $402,000, a gain after taxes of $1,844,000 from the sale of the Woodland Hills facility, and a provision for a loss of $770,000 on the sale of the Simi Valley facility to Gibraltar Savings.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Missing Ingredient
description: The Democratic candidates for the Presidential nomination have been accused of lacking ideas, vision, charisma and experience. But Governor Cuomo of New York thinks that is not their real problem.

title: West Coast Jazz Stars To Play
description: NEW YORKERS tend to get smug about the city's status as the world's jazz capital. This weekend, however, two of the best jazz groups in town can testify to the existence of jazz life in Los Angeles, the home of both John Carter, the clarinetist leading a quartet at Carlos 1, and Harold Land, the tenor saxophonist who's featured with the Timeless All-Stars at Sweet Basil. Mr. Land in the 1950's, and Mr. Carter in the 1960's, found that in Los Angeles they could bop around the clock.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Japan Posts A Trade Deficit
description: Japan posted a trade deficit for the first 20 days in January, but Government officials and economists said today that the unusual shortfall probably did not indicate a trend.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings results are restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in August 1987.

title: Millrose Features Milers
description: The men's and women's mile runs offer attractive matchups tonight in the 81st annual Panasonic Millrose Games, the first major metropolitan meet of the indoor track season.

title: Citicorp Singing
description: Cast members from the Off Broadway show ''Mama, I Want to Sing!'' are to perform songs from the show today at 1 P.M. in the first of a series of free performances at the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street. The series, called Mardi Gras at the Market, will run through Feb. 27 and feature jazz performances at various times throughout each day. In addition, a ''Kid's Karnival,'' with clowns, magicians and activities, is planned for Feb. 27 at 11 A.M. For a schedule of events, the number is 559-2330.

title: Defeat of Contra Aid: The 219-211 Roll-Call Vote in the House
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 219 to 211 Wednesday night by which the House rejected President Reagan's request for at least $43 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the President's plan; a ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 47 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 207 Democrats and 12 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: UNITED SAVER'S BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the losses in the latest periods resulted from writing down its equity portfolios by $15.5 million as of Dec. 1, 1987.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,000,000 for both periods; the 9 months also include a gain from the effect of an accounting change of $2,655,000. c-Net loss The company said net sales in the current quarter declined due to the sale in June 1987 of a 55.3 percent limited partner's interest in Permian Partners L.P.; the company said its remaining interest in Permian Partners is now recorded as an equity investment.

title: Police Investigate Assault Charges for Minister in Queens Incident
description: The Queens District Attorney's office and the police said yesterday that they were investigating an incident in which a black minister from Howard Beach, Queens, was charged with assaulting a white teen-ager who had purportedly thrown snowballs and rocks at the minister's car and called him racial names.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 417 money market mutual funds increased $326.1 million, to $275.24 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $426.5 million, to $80.68 billion. Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were down $177.3 million, to $81.06 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased $76.9 million, to $113.49 billion.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,753,000 and a charge of $2,622,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Mexican Asks U.S. Not to Use Force in Region
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico called today for a negotiated settlement of the Nicaragua-contra war and for a United States policy of nonintervention in Latin America.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE roadside diner, that stainless-steel citadel of all-American cuisine, is making a comeback in Manhattan. Recent examples include the spiffy Broadway Diner (two locations, 1726 Broadway, at 55th Street, 765-0909, and 590 Lexington Avenue, at 52d Street, 486-8838), Ellen's Stardust Diner (1377 Avenue of the Americas, at 56th Street, 307-7575), and now, the month-old Horn & Hardart Dine-o-Mat, at 942 Third Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets.

title: Film: A Collection Animated by Computer
description: HOW you gonna keep 'em down on the farm after they've seen Max Headroom? That question should have occurred to the producers of ''The Computer Animation Show,'' a collection of computer-generated shorts that has plenty of technology but none of Max's sophisticated wit. Creatively, this film, which opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, is the equivalent of pointing a camera at Mr. Potato Head and making him move from side to side.

title: A Burglary Suspect, 15, Is Shot in Brooklyn
description: A 15-year-old burglary suspect was shot in the neck yesterday during a confrontation with four police officers in the stairway of an apartment building in Brooklyn, officials said.

title: U.N. Aide to Go to Mideast
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is sending a special envoy to Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria to seek ways of achieving peace in the Middle East, a spokesman said today. The envoy, Under Secretary General Marrack Goulding, will also meet with Palestine Liberation Organization officials, probably in Tunis, said the spokesman, Francois Giuliani. He said it was uncertain when Mr. Goulding would begin his trip.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $64.3 million and $55.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $23.7 million on the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-After a loss of $7.9 million and income of $7.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year net both include $31 million of charges for restructuring the company's beauty businesses and a gain of $121 million on the sale of a minority interest in the company's Japanese subsidiary.

description: b-Includes pretax charges of $8.9 million and $13.2 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from closing or consolidating manufacturing operations, disposing of equipment, contract disputes and writedowns, and the quarter also includes a cumulative retroactive credit of $8 million resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The company said share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Nov. 19, 1987.

description: Supplyside

title: In New Hampshire, What Makes Stanley Run?
description: LEAD: Among those running in the New Hampshire Presidential primary is a man named Stanley Lock, who was described in the newspaper this way: Stanley Lock arrived by train and bus from Detroit, promising jobs to anyone who wants them.

title: The Films Of Cinecitta In Festival
description: Hercules displayed his strength there. Gladiators battled, several generations of lovers quarreled, Italian troops defeated foreign armies, and Elizabeth Taylor conquered Richard Burton. Great dramas have been enacted at Cinecitta, the cradle of Italian cinema, since its inception a half-century ago.

title: Italy to Consider Basing of F-16's
description: Italy is willing to consider accepting the F-16 fighter-bombers that the United States must withdraw from Spain, Defense Minister Valerio Zanone said today after consultations with Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci.

title: Mideast Tightrope: Clashes Stirring Call for Talks
description: In reviving some old ideas about Middle East peace and giving them new twists, the Reagan Administration is counting on a change in atmosphere, created by the recent clashes between Palestinians and Israelis, to remove the old obstacles to negotiations on the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: 450 LTV Layoffs
description: LTV Aircraft Products Group said it would lay off about 450 Dallas-area workers in the next two months and would slash its work force by 1,000 by the end of the year. The company said it was cutting back because of lower spending planned by the Defense Department. LTV Aircraft, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, said the layoffs would reduce the work force to about 10,000.

title: Pact Will Allow Agency to Hire Indicted Builder
description: In a confidential agreement, a New York State agency has cleared the way for awarding a $57 million highway construction contract in Queens to a company under Federal indictment for bid-rigging.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $742,000 and $133,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinay credits of $1,268,000 for the quarter and $7,186,000 for the year. The company said in the year ended Dec. 31, 1987, the extraordinary items include a $6.7 million charge related to the repurchase of $60 million principal amount of the company's outstanding 14 percent subordinated notes offset by a $6.8 million credit resulting from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards; in all other periods the extraordinary item is entirely a result of the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards. The company also said consolidated earnings includes the results of operations of acquired companies since their respective dates of acquisition: Rowenta - July 1986; Kittinger and Pennsylvania House - August 1986; McGuire - December 1986; and Gunlocke - September 1987.

title: A Poem for Seven Judges
description: Most of the important news stories journalists deal with are sad or dreary. People are killed, hijacked, swindled. Nations go to war, or spend their energies and fortunes preparing for it. Earthquakes, explosions, plagues. Everybody is always saying something nasty about somebody else. That's the way things are in the world - or that is how it comes out by the time we are finished slicing it up into words or pictures.

title: Struggle for Recovery Altering Rural America
description: On the day in 1982 when Jack Briggs opened Macon County's economic development office, the local Dairy Queen announced it was shutting down. That is just about the ultimate in despair for a dying small town in rural America.

title: L.I. Power Authority Upheld
description: A state law that created the Long Island Power Authority is constitutional, Justice Eli Wager of State Supreme Court ruled today. The decision clears the way for a takeover by the authority of the Long Island Lighting Company and the closing of the $5 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1988
description: Markets

title: State Dept. Aide Pressing Meese To Delay Closing P.L.O. Mission
description: The State Department's legal adviser is pressing Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to delay application of a law closing the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission at the United Nations, according to American diplomats and United Nations officials.

title: BNH BANCSHARES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: 'Land Of Promise,' By Wajda
description: AT first glance, the mid-1970's seems like the least inventive phase in the career of Andrzej Wajda, the brilliant, prolific Polish director. His trilogy from the 50's, ending with the masterly ''Ashes and Diamonds,'' assessed the emotional cost of World War II. In 1976, he would tear down Stalinist icons in ''Man of Marble.'' But earlier in the decade, films such as ''A Wedding'' and ''Land of Promise,'' both set in the 19th century, seemed to signal, if not a retreat from the political wars, at least an escape from the pressure of recent events.

description: To the Editor:

title: Shift at Sports inc.
description: Steven L. Isenberg, 46 years old, is giving up his post as interim publisher of Sports inc. The magazine styles itself ''The Sports Business Weekly'' and is directed at decision makers in the sports business. Scott Kabak, 33, will replace Mr. Isenberg and will continue as president of the magazine, which is one of the Times Mirror Magazines. Mr. Isenberg plans to return to his job as associate publisher at Newsday, which is owned by the Times Mirror Company.

title: Dumptruck at the Ritz
description: A rock triple bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), is to include Love Tractor, Dumptruck and Pianosaurus. The music begins about 11 P.M.; tickets are $10 in advance, $12 tomorrow.

title: Sony Disk Players
description: The Sony Corporation will begin marketing multidisk players able to play compact disks, compact disk videos and optical laser disks in the United States around May, a company spokesman said. The models cost between $970 and $1,315 in Japan at current exchange rates, but United States pricing is still undecided.

title: Accord Said to Be Near On the Sale of The Post
description: Rupert Murdoch is close to a deal to sell The New York Post to Peter S. Kalikow, a New York real-estate entrepreneur, sources familiar with the negotiations said last night.

title: ORIENTAL FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted from a mutual savings bank to a stock savings bank in April 1987.

title: New York Seen As Biggest Loser In Redistricting
description: New York State is likely to be the biggest loser and California and Texas the biggest winners when seats in the House of Representatives are reallocated after the 1990 census, a new study predicts.

title: John G. Brainerd, 83, Early Computer Expert
description: John Grist Brainerd, an electrical engineer who served as director of a project that built Eniac, one of the first electronic computers, died Monday at his home in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 83 years old.

description: PRODUCT liability lawsuits involving the effects of cigarette smoking have in recent years created a cloud over tobacco stocks. But a number of Wall Street analysts believe that investor fears on this score are overblown.

description: Clint Eastwood, the film star who was elected Mayor two years ago, says he will not seek a second two-term term as chief executive of this resort town of 4,700 people.

Productivity Up, but Rise Is Slower
description: The nation's businesses continued to improve their productivity in 1987 but were less successful in squeezing out more efficiency gains than in the previous four years, the Government said today.

title: College Basketball; No. 1 Arizona Is Upset by Stanford, 82-74
description: Todd Lichti scored 23 points and Howard Wright 22 as Stanford scored the final 10 points of the game tonight to upset No. 1-ranked Arizona, 82-74, ending the Wildcats' eight-game winning streak.

The prior year net included a $2,628,000, or 46 cents a share, gain from the termination of the company's salaried pension plan.

title: Mortgage Rates Down; Buyers Wary
description: The recent steep decline in interest rates has pushed mortgage lending rates in most areas of the nation to their lowest levels in more than six months. Yet consumers seem to be reacting cautiously to the decline.

title: Matra Offering Oversubscribed
description: The French Government's public offering of its 51 percent stake in Matra S.A., a military and electronics company, was oversubscribed almost fivefold, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said it had charges against earnings in the latest periods equal to about $10 million for the quarter and $17.6 million for the year, which resulted from revaluation of year-end inventory and provisions for costs associated with the introduction of stain-resistant residential carpet products. The year-ago periods included a $1.2 million LIFO charge for the fourth quarter and a $4.2 million LIFO credit for the full year. The latest fourth quarter results also included a LIFO credit of $4 million.

title: Concert: Muti Leads Philadelphians in Copland and Brahms
description: AARON COPLAND began his Symphony No. 3 in 1944 when the outcome of World War II was still in doubt, and finished it two years later in a time of national euphoria. Like other Copland works of the 1940's (''A Lincoln Portrait,'' for instance), it spoke in an optimistic, oratorical style that caught the upbeat mood of the times. Although it sounds now and then like a senator's exhortation at a war-bond rally, for most of its 40-minute length it exudes a healthy desire to make contact with the listener and a sense of conviction that is hard to find in much later Copland music.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included a $2.4 million gain from the purchase of annuities in the company's pension plan. The prior year included a gain of $3.9 million from the disposition of a distribution facility.

Malfunction of Rocket Stalls Anti-Missile Test
description: A major test of President Reagan's proposed anti-missle system was delayed today after a Delta rocket meant to launch a three-ton military satellite developed a problem with a fuel tank.

title: Rock: Sting At Garden
description: HANS EISLER, a composer who worked with Bertolt Brecht, might well have been amused to hear one of his melodies sung at Madison Square Garden with teen-age girls shrieking at the end of each chromatic phrase. But that was only one of the unlikely treats at Wednesday's concert by Sting, who somehow balances musicianly experiments and melancholy, high-minded songs with the charisma and showmanship of a pop star.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
European G.N.P. Jumps
description: Growth in the European Community accelerated in the third quarter of 1987, outpacing the United States but still lagging behind Japan, the European Community statistics office said today. The community's gross national product surged by 5.4 percent in the quarter because of strong domestic demand and higher exports, the office said. The agency said this compared with United States growth of 4.3 percent and Japanese growth of 8.1 percent in the quarter.

description: The chairman of Ashland Oil Inc. conceded today that ''mistakes were made'' by company employees responsible for the tank that ruptured on Jan. 2, spilling nearly a million gallons of diesel fuel into the Monongahela River.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Restaurants
description: AFTER four visits to Aquavit, the dramatic new Scandinavian restaurant in the former John D. Rockefeller town house on West 54th Street, I'm still hard-pressed to define this northern cuisine. Indeed, some of the ingredients are exotic - cloudberries, bleak roe, snow grouse - but the style of cooking, at least in this urbane establishment, is unmistakably French. Terminology aside, it's worth a visit, for some of the food can be as exhilarating as the morning's first ski run on pristine powder.

title: Grecian Music
description: Microcosmos is to play rebetika music from Greece Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street (206-1050). Tickets are $8; information, 691-9510.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: 3 Masters Have a Kick Left
description: In their prime, they were the best. Peter Snell of New Zealand won three Olympic gold medals and set world outdoor records for the mile of 3 minutes 54.4 seconds in 1962 and 3:54.1 in 1964. Jim Ryun, still a teen-ager, lowered the world record to 3:51.3 in 1966 and 3:51.1 in 1967. Frank Shorter's fastest mile was only 4:02.6, but he won Olympic medals in 1972 (gold) and 1976 (silver) in the marathon.

title: Talk With Rabin: Roots of the Conflict
description: Palestinian rioters have been winning the public relations battle against Israel in the world press, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin conceded today, stressing that the army is confronting something new and complex: a widespread uprising born of decades of Palestinian frustrations.

title: Congress Unit Sees Federal '89 Deficit Far Beyond Target
description: The Congressional Budget Office estimated today that next year's Federal budget deficit would be $176 billion, or $40 billion higher than the target stipulated in the budget-balancing law that Congress passed last year.

title: Pianist Has Bartok At His Fingertips
description: ''Bartok,'' said Zoltan Kocsis, who has specialized in his music and is currently performing his Third Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic, ''was very fond of French music, and he truly inherited something from Debussy.''

title: Reagan Is No Chamberlain
description: LEAD: Some opponents of the treaty on intermediate range nuclear forces are using the highly emotional words ''appeasement'' and ''Munich'' to rally support for their position.

The company said the 1987 results reflect lower income tax expense as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 principally due to a tax benefit of $28.8 million, or 68 cents a share, for the year, and $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share, for the fourth quarter, relating to the exclusion from taxable income of a portion of the ''fresh start'' discount on property and casualty loss reserves at Dec. 31, 1986.

title: How Great Were the Injustices of Arabs to Jews; 'Pacification' of Gaza

title: 2 New York Hospitals Plan To Start Liver Transplants
description: Two of New York City's largest teaching hospitals will perform the first liver transplants in the state under a new plan designed to eliminate competition among hospitals for scarce donor organs.

title: G.S.A., Citing Report, May Fight A.T.&T. Bids
description: The General Services Administration said today that, if the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received secret bid prices of its competitors for Federal Government telephone switch contracts, as said in a news report, it would seek to prevent the company from gaining the contracts.

title: Art: 'Committed to Print,' on Political Themes
description: WITH its new exhibition, ''Committed to Print,'' the Museum of Modern Art, defender of a relatively pure modernist faith, treads cautiously but deliberately where it doesn't often go: into the terrain where art and overt political sentiment mingle and sometimes fuse. The title invites two readings, and Deborah Wye, the organizer of the exhibition, makes good on both of them. She has sought out art that reflects a willingness to go on record, to communicate a strong position or searing fact, and that is also committed to some form of printmaking as the best medium for these messages.

title: Brooklyn Arts Council Holding Film Festival
description: The actor and director Danny DeVito once had a film shown there. So did Ira Wohl, who made ''Best Boy,'' winner of the 1980 Academy Award for best feature-length documentary.

title: Eleanor Marquand Delanoy, Rights Advocate, 91
description: Eleanor Marquand Delanoy, a co-founder of the Princeton Committee of the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc., died of heart disease Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Forget the Money And Bring On Art History
description: Harry Rand, a curator with the Smithsonian's National Museum of American Art in Washington, gets three or four calls a week from undiscovered geniuses. ''They have masterpieces in their attics,'' said Mr. Rand. ''Masterpieces in their closets.'' Maybe 1 in 200 times, it's actually something; maybe 1 in 1,000 will lead to an acquistion.

description: To many in the financial community, the Bankers Trust Company has become a commercial bank with a trading-room mentality - focusing on minute-to-minute profits instead of on long-term relationships.

description: LEAD: Wes Unseld, the onetime Baltimore Bullet strong man and the current Washington Bullet coach, has been elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

Sailboats For Rent: Dreams In the Sun
description: Like restless thoroughbreds shifting in their stalls, luxury sailboats rock in their slips at the yacht charter docks here, sleek bows straining at lines as the wind slaps halyards against tall masts with a metallic clang.

description: The New York Film Festival is in turmoil this week after the resignation of two critics on the festival's selection committee to protest actions taken by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the festival's parent organization.

title: Dining Out Guide: Bistros
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE UN DEUX TROIS, 123 West 44th Street (354-4148) - *(May 15, 1987) For its reliably animated atmosphere and straightforward bistro fare, this 10-year-old cafe continues to be one of the better bets for Broadway theater-district dining. The short regular menu is supplemented by many daily specials. Appetizer choices are well-seasoned duck-liver mousse; a special grilled boudin blanc with sauteed onions and apples, and beef sate. On the entree list, one old reliable is the simple breaded chicken breast with a mild mustard sauce and julienne of buttery carrots and zucchini. You might choose the grilled steak with french fries; steak tartare, or the mixed grill of calf's liver, boudin blanc and lamb chop (a special). Dinner entrees $13.50 to $18. Fridays through Sundays, noon to midnight. CHEZ LOUIS, 1016 Second Avenue, near 54th Street (752-1400) -

title: Donors Offer Memorial Gifts To Assist the Neediest Cases
description: An ecumenical memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan last month inspired Juliann Davidson to send a gift in memory of the civil rights leader to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: EMPIRE DISTRICT ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Court Rebuffs Joyce Brown, Citing Release
description: New York State's highest court declined yesterday to rule on Joyce Brown's appeal of her involuntary hospitalization, saying the issue was moot because she has been released.

title: Cineplex Film Deal
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had formed a joint venture with the New Century Entertainment Corporation to finance and distribute 25 to 30 New Century films in the next five years. The venture follows an agreement last week by which New Century acquired the independent film maker New Visions Inc. and named its principal, Taylor Hackford, co-chairman. Under the latest agreement, the Toronto-based Cineplex will put up half the film production financing and receive exclusive distribution rights outside the United States.

title: Britain Drops a Barrier To B.P. Bid for Britoil
description: The British Government indicated today that it was not worried that the British Petroleum Company's effort to acquire Britoil P.L.C. could be harmful by lessening competition, but it retained its veto power on Britoil's board.

description: Two agencies of the United States Government, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, maintained dossiers on Alfred A. Knopf, one of the country's most distinguished publishers, according to a book being published this spring.

title: Newark Man Fatally Stabs A Woman in a Bus Terminal
description: A 21-year-old woman died today after a man, apparently unprovoked, stabbed her in the back with a 12-inch butcher knife in a Penn Station waiting room, the N.J. Transit police said. Thomas J. Rouse, 33 years old, of Newark, was charged with homicide and criminal possession of a weapon, said Kevin Moran, a transit officer.

title: Police-Brutality Charges Are Found Unsupported
description: After what it called an extensive investigation, the Manhattan District Attorney's office has concluded that there is no ''credible evidence'' to support allegations by an English professor that he was illegally arrested and unjustifiably injured by transit police officers.

title: A Correction
description: An editing error altered a sentence in Tuesday's article ''For Local Elections in the West Bank and Gaza.'' The sentence should have said that Arabs in Gaza have insisted that the killing of four Arabs ''was an act of retaliation for the knifing murder of an Israeli merchant.''

title: First Executive
description: The First Executive Corporation said two of its shareholders had filed a lawsuit seeking to block the completion of a tender offer from the ICH Corporation and to overturn a standstill agreement. ICH, a Louisville, Ky., insurance holding company, began a $134.4 million tender offer last month for 11.2 million shares of First Executive at $12 a share. The offer would raise ICH's holdings in the Los Angeles-based insurer to 21 percent. The standstill agreement prohibited ICH from buying more than 25 percent of First Executive. The suit was brought by Michael E. Cottle and Morris M. Rottman, Chicago accountants, their lawyer, C. Timothy Smoot, said. They charge that ICH's tender offer is ''an entrenchment scheme'' endorsed by management that will preclude another tender offer from being made. First Executive responded that the contention was without merit.

title: Film: 'Serpent and the Rainbow'
description: IT'S a long way from a Harvard ethnobiologist's thoughtful account of his search for exotic Haitian medicinal potions to a film with the advertising slogan ''Don't bury me . . . I'm not dead!'' But in fact these two sides of ''The Serpent and the Rainbow'' aren't as different as they sound. Wade Davis's fascinating 1985 book is much more an adventure story than a scientific tract, and the film is the work of Wes Craven, whose horror credits (''A Nightmare on Elm Street,'' ''The Hills Have Eyes'') give an incomplete impression of his talents. This film amounts to Mr. Craven's crossover into the mainstream, even if it happens to be about zombies.

description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that its net income rose 46 percent in the fourth quarter because of higher revenues from its broadcast group and reduced costs. The company also said that the ABC Television Network had returned to profitability during 1987.

description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has campaigned for President on a populist theme, but when he flew a planeload of supporters to Iowa last week he took along the most inside of Washington insiders: about a dozen registered lobbyists.
