title: Horse Racing Notebook; Changes Promised For Forty Niner
description: The next time Forty Niner runs, he will be a horse of a different color, figuratively and literally.

title: Sports People; Molitor Honored
description: Paul Molitor, whose 39-game hitting streak during the 1987 season was the fourth longest in American League history, has been named the winner of baseball's Hutch Award by a panel of broadcasters and writers covering the major leagues.

title: Hearts - and Minds - on Nicaragua
description: By an eight-vote margin, the House has given a deserved rebuke to President Reagan's failed policy toward Central America. The majority told Mr. Reagan, in effect, that they and the people they represent believe he has been pursuing a war without end in Nicaragua, not peace. Accordingly, the legislators disapproved the Administration's plan for renewed aid to the contras.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Rizzo Ahead by a Shot: Patti Rizzo one-putted six holes yesterday on her way to a five-under-par 67 and the first-round lead in the Mazda Classic in Boca Raton, Fla., the opening tournament of the L.P.G.A. season. Trish Johnson of England, playing in her first L.P.G.A. event, and Missie McGeorge were next at 68. Jody Rosenthal, Amy Benz and Nancy Lopez, who birdied her last two holes, each shot 69 at the 6,368-yard Stonebridge Golf and Country Club course.(AP) Horse Racing Irish Chili Wins by a Nose: Irish Chili rallied through the stretch to outfinish Derby Hat and win by a nose yesterday in the $42,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Racing over a sloppy track, Irish Chili carried co-highweight of 122 pounds under Chris Antley six furlongs in 1:11 4/5 for his eighth victory in 29 career starts. He earned $25,200 for his owner, Barry K. Schwartz, and returned $10.20 for $2 to win as the fourth choice in the field of six. Tennis Canadian Upsets American: Jill Hetherington of Canada started her upset victory yesterday over Beverley Bowes of the United States outdoors, but finished it indoors a few hours later in the Virginia Slims of Wellington, New Zealand. Hetherington, seeded 13th, advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 7-6 victory over Bowes, of Lubbock, Tex. The match was halted by rain with the Canadian ahead, 2-0, in the first set. As the rain became more persistent, outdoor play was abandoned for the day and all scheduled matches resumed indoors two hours later. In other third-round matches, Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., seeded third, beat fourth-seeded Annabel Croft of Britain, 7-6, 6-3, and second-seeded Anne Minter of Australia easily defeated Kim Steinmetz of St. Louis, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) Boxing Olajide Wins Unanimous Decision: Michael Olajide Jr., the International Boxing Federation's top-ranked middleweight, won a unanimous 10-round decision from Cecil Pettigrew last night at the Felt Forum. All three judges, George Colan (8-2), Bernie Freidkin (8-2) and Carol Castellano (9-1) voted for Olajide. There were no knockdowns. With the victory, Olajide's record went to 25-1 with 17 knockouts. Pettigrew is 27-13-3. N.B.A. Warriors 96, Cavaliers 90: Chris Mullin scored 22 points last night, including two free throws that snapped an 88-88 tie in overtime, to send Golden State to its second road victory of the season, in Richfield, Ohio. Mark Price of Cleveland, an 89.6 percent foul shoter, missed a chance to put the game away in the closing seconds of regulation, missing two of four free throws in the final 35 seconds. Price made one of two free throws with 35 seconds left and again made one of two with 11 seconds to go in regulation, putting the Cavaliers up 86-84. But Golden State's Winston Garland banked in a 10-footer with five seconds left to force the extra period. Mullin then hit two free throws to put the Warriors ahead for good at 90-88 with 2:14 left. (AP) Nuggets 129, Spurs 123: In San Antonio, Lafayette Lever scored 6 straight points in the fourth period to lead Denver to a come-from-behind victory. The Nuggets trailed for most of the game before outscoring the Spurs, 42-28, in the final period. Alex English finished with 30 points and Lever had 26. San Antonio led by as many as 17 points, 59-42, in the second period.(AP) Bulls 113, Suns 101: Michael Jordan scored 37 points and John Paxson sank two 3-point goals during a fourth-quarter rally as Chicago won in Phoenix for the first time in 11 years and handed the Suns their 10th straight loss.Chicago had lost 14 straight at the Arizona Veterans Memorial Coliseum since last winning, 108-104, in overtime on March 2, 1977.(AP) Bucks 111, Celtics 101: Terry Cummings scored 22 of his 30 points in the first half and Milwaukee held on in the second half for the victory at home. Jack Sikma chipped in 20 points and Larry Krystkowiak added a season-high 18 points for the Bucks.(AP) Pacers 109, 76ers 95: Wayman Tisdale, honored earlier in the day by Nancy Reagan for his role in antidrug efforts, scored a season-high 26 points to lead the Pacers. The First Lady attended the game and participated in halftime ceremonies as part of the N.B.A.'s ''Just Say No'' program. Tisdale made his first five shots and was 11 of 13, including a basket in a 6-point spurt that put Indiana ahead to stay, 91-85.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 6, Maple Leafs 1: Derrick Smith scored twice in the third period and added an assist last night as Philadelphia beat visiting Toronto. The Maple Leafs are 1-13-6 in their last 20 games. Ron Sutter opened the scoring for the Flyers 1:10 into the game by tipping Smith's shot past Ken Wregget, the Toronto goaltender.(AP) Bruins 7, Canadiens 3: Cam Neely had the fourth three-goal game of his pro career to lead the Bruins at home. In taking a 3-2-1 lead in the season series, the Bruins moved 3 points behind first-place Montreal in the Adams Division. Boston has a game in hand.(AP) Penguins 1, North Stars 0: In Pittsburgh, Frank Pietrangelo, a rookie, stopped 31 shots for his first N.H.L. shutout and Doug Bodger scored on a first-period power play as Minnesota suffered its third consecutive shutout loss. The North Stars have been shut out for 233 minutes 55 seconds since scoring at 6:05 of the opening period in a 9-1 loss at St. Louis on Jan. 28. The Penguins moved into second place in the Patrick Division, 1 point ahead of the Islanders and Capitals.(AP)

title: Rose Bird a Commentator
description: Rose Bird, who was ousted by the voters as California's Chief Justice, will become a commentator for television stations KABC in Los Angeles and KGO in San Francisco, which are owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. Ms. Bird will begin work within the next few days, a spokesman for KABC said.

title: AIDS Virus, for First Time, Is Proved to Infect Colon Cells Directly
description: The AIDS virus can directly infect cells of the colon and rectum, a group of scientists reports, a finding that may answer questions about the transmission of AIDS and about why many of its victims have chronic unexplained diarrhea.

title: GARTNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Law; Kaisers Taking Lawyers to
description: Four members of the Kaiser family are waging a $2.8 million legal battle here against their longtime lawyers over what the four contend is the mismanagement of millions of dollars of stocks from their father's estate.

title: U.S. Ends an Effort To Deport Teacher On Basis of Ideology
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has abandoned its effort to deport Margaret Randall, an United States-born citizen of Mexico whose writings in praise of leftist revolutions led to a 1986 deportation order that became a cause celebre in the literary world.

title: 3d Party Has 10% Stake In Belgian Company
description: Compagnie Financiere de Suez said tonight that it had purchased a 10 percent stake in Societe Generale de Belgique, becoming the third major player in a struggle for control of Belgium's biggest company.

title: Days in the Lives of Nursing-Home Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese, Reacting to Allegations Of Illegal Fishing, Plan New Rules
description: Japanese officials, reacting to allegations that their fishing fleet is involved in widespread ''pillaging'' in American waters in the Bering Sea, said today that they would seek new regulations to control the problem.

title: No Irregularity in Pipeline Memo to Meese
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Raid Kills 2 Soldiers, Israelis Say
description: Palestinian guerrillas crossed into Israel from Lebanon early today and killed two soldiers, the army said. One Palestinian was reported killed in the raid, which the army said was a mission to seize civilian hostages.

description: b-Net income

title: Dow Eases by One Point, to 1,923.57
description: The stock market continued in its rut yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell one point, to 1,923.57, and other market gauges eked out small gains.

title: Rapid Rate Drop Seen Slowing
description: Interest rates are still far lower than a month ago, but as the Treasury concluded three consecutive days of note and bond auctions totaling $27 billion yesterday, there were signs that the rapid decline in rates had leveled off.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a pre-tax gain on asset dispositions of $49,245,000. The latest year included a pre-tax gain of $13,873,000 from a change in accounting for pension plans and termination benefits and a $9.9 million gain from the adoption of FASB 96. The year-ago quarter included a pre-tax gain on asset dispositions of $138,645,000.

description: b-Net income The latest first quarter included results of 11 stores, compared with two stores in year-ago period.

description: b-Includes an after-tax gain on the disposition of assets totaling about $17 million. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5.2 million and $71.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said there were no discontinued operations in the latest fourth quarter. Results for the 1987 fourth quarter include about $7.2 million, or 13 cents a share, of non-recurring net income, resulting from litigation settlements and the annuitization of certain pension plan obligations. Results for 1986 include a non-recurring charge of about $70.8 million, or $1.33 a share, due to restructuring of petroleum service units.

title: 'Die Winterreise'
description: Marian Thompson, a soprano, will sing Schubert's ''Winterreise'' on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Alexander Valery Ryvkin will be the pianist. Tickets are $10, or $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 362-8719.

title: CONTRA AID CUTOFF: A SETBACK, NOT A DEATH BLOW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -

title: Black & Decker Increases Bid for American Standard
description: The Black & Decker Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing its all-cash offer for American Standard Inc. by $9 a share, to $65 a share, or about $2 billion, for the New York-based producer of plumbing fixtures, air-conditioning units and transportation products.

title: American City Journals' Shift
description: American City Business Journals announced today that it was no longer for sale but would shed several unprofitable weeklies to shore up its ailing financial position.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Top Contra Official Resigns
description: Alfonso Robelo has resigned as one of the six leaders of the Nicaraguan Resistance, the contras' political organization, the group's headquarters announced here today.

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mistrial for Former Klansmen
description: The trial of two former Ku Klux Klansmen charged in the beating death of a black teen-ager ended today in a mistrial when a defendant collapsed as a former associate described making the noose used to hang the youth's body from a tree.

title: Simon Campaign Says Gephardt Exceeds Spending Limits in Iowa
description: Stepping up the level of confrontation in the final days of the Iowa caucuses, Senator Paul Simon's campaign manager today called on Representative Richard A. Gephardt to suspend television advertising here until his campaign had filed a report on his finances with the Federal Election Commission.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $303,000 on a sale of other investments.

title: The Resurgence of Takeovers
description: It is back to the barricades for corporate America.

title: HOUSE IMPEACHES ARIZONA GOVERNOR
description: The Arizona House of Represenatives late today impeached Gov. Evan Mecham for ''high crimes, misdemeanors and malfeasance in office.''

title: HORIZON FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in November 1986.

title:
Patents;
Equipment Assists In Editing of Documents
description: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation this week patented equipment that helps in the editing of complex documents, including text, graphics, images, tables and handwriting. It can be used with large or personal computers.

title: Riches in the Public Interest
description: The negotiations unfolded like a mini-series and should probably have been held in Geneva. ''Shirtless'' Butch Lewis, representing Michael Spinks, and the dynamic duo of Jim Jacobs and Bill Cayton, Mike Tyson's managers, mostly haggled about money, how to divide a gate expected to gross more than $30 million. It was a matter of principle, not principal, they said.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from an accounting change of $2,702,000.

title: Subway Panel Offers Safety Procedures
description: A task force on the safety of subway doors concluded yesterday that there is no ''quick fix'' to the problem of passengers being dragged by moving trains.

title: Baby M Surrogate Settles Fraud Suit
description: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould and her former husband, Richard, have agreed to a settlement of their Federal fraud and negligence suit against the Infertility Center of New York, which arranged the February 1985 surrogate-mother contract that the New Jersey Supreme Court invalidated Wednesday.

title: GROSSMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $552,000 and a loss of $1,204,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from retirement of long-term debt, and tax credits of $568,000 for the quarter and $6,922,000 for the year. c-After income of $2,437,000 and a loss of $75,567 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations, and a loss of $294,000 and a gain of $224,778,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the settlement of liabilities related to the reorganization of the company.

title: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the quarter and $17.9 million for the year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $14.1 million and $22.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively The latest fourth quarter includes a $32.4 million gain on the sale of electric power facilities, a state tax credit of $1.6 million, and a $3.2 million charge connected to two coal mines. The company said year-ago fourth quarter included a charge of $5.2 million to write down ore inventory and for other provisions. Fiscal 1986 results includes gains of $15.1 million from the sale of Australian iron ore and $800,000 from the sale of uranium reserves and a $5.6 million charge in connection with the buyout of the company's Tilden Mine debt obligations.

title: Goldman, Sachs Ends Program Trading for Itself
description: One day after the New York Stock Exchange announced new restrictions on program trading, Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it would no longer use the strategy to manage its own capital. However, the institutional firm will continue to execute such trades for its customers.

title: Fountain of Data: Cuomo's Librarian
description: Need to know how much money Governor Cuomo plans to spend this year in aid to private schools? How much the Thruway Authority needs to raise by 1996? How many grape growers there are in the state?

title: How Did the F.B.I. Go Astray?
description: Aggressive F.B.I. surveillance of the Government's foreign policy critics supposedly ended with the regime of J. Edgar Hoover. News that such activity apparently continued under F.B.I. Director William Webster does not yet warrant alarms about political police, but neither can the bureau be exonerated on the basis of what's been revealed so far. A Congressional inquiry is in order.

title: Foreman Wins Again
description: George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, tonight scored his seventh consecutive victory since returning to the ring last March, stopping a bloodied Guido Trane in the fifth round of their scheduled 10-round bout.

Texas Air said its consolidated fourth quarter results were hurt by charges to various reserve accounts, adjustments in the value of marketable securities and other year-end accruals by the parent company and its Systems One Reservations unit.

title: ADRIAN WILSON, 64, A PRINTING TEACHER AND BOOK DESIGNER
description: Adrian Wilson, a book designer and scholar who was considered one of America's leading fine printers, died Wednesday of congestive heart failure at the Pacific Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco. He was 64 years old.

title:
Patents;
Toy for a Cat
description: LEAD: A toy for entertaining a cat was patented this week by Robert B. Mohr for the Doskocil Manufacturing Company of Arlington, Tex. Patent 4,722,299 says the rounded housing has an opening through which a cat can insert a paw to swat a ball, and includes a bed in which the cat can curl up and sleep. The company is making the toy, called the Cat Circle.

title: AN ACCOUNT OF HOMELESSNESS INSPIRES GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Growing concern for the homeless, and especially homeless children like those found in the Martinique Hotel on Herald Square in Manhattan, has inspired many contributions to the 76th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: b-After a tax credit of $165,000. c-Net loss The year-ago figures are restated.

title: Shift of Titles Atop Ogilvy
description: William E. Phillips, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, said yesterday that he would relinquish his titles to Kenneth Roman, 57, the chairman of Ogilvy's largest operating company, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, at the firm's annual shareholder meeting on May 17.

title: Devils Lose by 5-1; 9 Power Plays Fail
description: Tony Tanti scored his 33d goal of the season at 13 minutes 24 seconds of the second period to snap a tie, and Rich Sutter scored twice as the Vancouver Canucks beat the New Jersey Devils, 5-1, tonight.

title: 2 Arrested in Hotel Stabbing
description: The police arrested two teen-agers yesterday in the stabbing of a 14-year-old boy during a drug-related robbery in a welfare hotel in midtown Manhattan. Another youth was being sought. The incident occurred Wednesday at the Bryant Hotel on Broadway at 54th Street. Sgt. John Venetucci of the police said the three youths stabbed the victim and stole $1,000. The victim, whose name was not released, was believed by the police to be a crack seller. He was in critical condition at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: German Backs Dollar Level
description: In the clearest sign of the intentions of the major industrial countries for the recently tumbling dollar, West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said today that the current exchange rate was acceptable.

title: COPING: WITH BUYING A CAR
description: When it comes to unappealing prospects, the average person probably ranks buying a new car right up there with public speaking and tax audits.

title: Meet The M-Bomb
description: Overkill is our style. ''Everything to excess,'' we reply to the Athenians' ''Everything in moderation.'' The spirit of the day, until Wall Street turned into Sucker's Alley, was expressed in the Yuppie's Creed: ''I want it all, and I want it now.''

title: Consumer Debt Rose $4.5 Billion in December
description: Consumer debt rose by $4.5 billion in December, the biggest monthly gain in three months, the Federal Reserve said yesterday. The December increase placed total consumer debt at $612.57 billion, up 6 percent from the end of 1986.

description: b-After tax credits of $1.3 million. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $58,000, tax credits of $1,158,000 and a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $1,502,000.

title: Casting Is Completed For the Musical 'Chess'
description: Casting was completed yesterday for ''Chess,'' the Tim Rice-Bjorn Ulvaeus-Benny Andersson musical that is scheduled to begin rehearsals Monday. The principals are David Carroll and Philip Casnoff as Soviet and American chess masters and Judy Kuhn as the woman in love first with the Russian and then with the American. The director is Trevor Nunn.

title: COMPONENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''In plain language, what he did was he utilized his position to sell the country of Panama to drug traffickers.'' - Leon B. Kellner, a Federal prosecutor, speaking of Gen.

title: Bond Prices Soar on Job Report
description: Bond prices soared and interest rates fell yesterday after the Government reported a smaller-than-expected rise in January non-farm employment.

title: A.T.&T. Lead Shared By Two
description: Mark Calcavecchia hit his second shot today over the back of the green at the first hole on Spyglass Hill, one of the longest holes on the PGA Tour. Then he chipped back strongly and the ball rolled into the middle of the cup for an eagle 3 on the 610-yard hole.

title: INSIDE
description: Sentence in Queens Attack

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., Melbourne, Australia, has agreed not to increase its stake in Bell Resources Ltd. beyond its existing 5 percent for at least two years, according to its capital restructuring plan.

title: 2 Europeans Seized in Lebanon
description: Two Scandinavians working for the United Nations were reported kidnapped in southern Lebanon today. No group claimed responsibility, but the police here said the kidnappers were Palestinian guerrillas loyal to Abu Nidal.

title: Village Concert
description: The Greenwich Village Orchestra will perform works by Haydn, Rossini and Schumann at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Washington Irving High School (Irving Place at 16th Street). A $5 donation, or $2 for students and the elderly, is requested. Information: 265-7000, extension 273.

title: Panel on Waldheim May Extend Work to Check Disputed Telegram
description: Historians on a panel assigned to examine President Kurt Waldheim's wartime record said today that they might have to extend their work because of a disputed document said to have been discovered in Yugoslavia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1988
description: Markets

title: French Concern Sides With Societe Generale
description: Compagnie Financiere de Suez, a diversified French concern, took the first steps today toward forming an alliance with the management of Societe Generale de Belgique, which is trying to fend off a bid for control by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti.

title: 13.09 Drop Sends Dow To 1,910.48
description: Stock prices remained listless most of yesterday before late selling pushed the the Dow Jones industrial average down 13.09 points to close at 1,910.48. Over all, the market ended mixed.

title: F.B.I. WILL GIVE PANEL MORE SURVEILLANCE FILES
description: More than 2,000 pages of classified files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, generated by an inquiry into an organization sympathetic to left-wing guerrillas in El Salvador, will be released to a Congressional subcommitee looking into the bureau's conduct of the investigation, Representative Don Edwards of California said yesterday.

title: INSITUFORM SOUTHEAST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer error, the film review of ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' in Weekend yesterday included a phrase erroneously in the second paragraph. The passage should have read: '' 'Take off your clothes,' says Tomas. After three seconds of playing hard-to-get, the nurse does. On the other side of a frosted-glass window several other hospital employees watch Tomas's technique with admiration.''

The results for 1987 reflect the consolidation of opering results of American Capacity Group Inc.

title: Arrest in Ghana Leads To Fight Over L.I. Home
description: Efua Cabiri last saw her husband in July 1986, when she waved goodbye to him at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Amending Lemon Laws
description: Lemon laws, enacted by 43 states since 1982 to protect owners of unrepairable vehicles, have themselves proved defective, according to attorneys general in several states that have amended these laws.

title: TRANSCAPITAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net writeoff of $1.8 million representing the company's required prepayment to the Federal Saving and Loan Insurance Corp. secondary reserve. c-After an extraordinary charge of $922,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Ballet: 'Ives, Songs,'' By Jerome Robbins
description: In ''Ives, Songs,'' his new ballet, Jerome Robbins has a nameless man look back upon his youth in early-20th-century America. For some, the knee-pants imagery of the childhood scenes might recall Norman Rockwell; the spirit of Mark Twain is more apt.

title: MUSIC: STUART DEMPSTER
description: For a moment on Wednesday, dreaded seriousness took the floor at the Alternative Museum. Stuart Dempster, the trombonist, wandered out from off stage, playing his plastic didjeridu -a long tube, derived from the Australian aboriginal wooden instrument of the same name, which, when blown into, makes buzzing sounds. He played it at the wall, at the ceiling, at a piece of art, and at the audience, as if pointing out the acoustical properties of each, sound for sound's sake.

title: 2,000 Protest Man's Parole
description: About 2,000 residents, law-enforcement officials and politicians gathered this evening to rally against the possible parole of a man convicted of killing two police officers in 1963. About 30 police cars from municipalities throughout Essex and Bergen Counties lined the street in front of the municipal complex. They were protesting a decision by a panel of the State Parole Board to release the convict, Thomas Trantino, who was convicted of shooting two Bergen County Police officers in a bar here. A special review of the case will be held by the entire board later this month.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the writedown of Molybdenum assets of $385.6 million and a gain of $38.3 million from the sale of oil and gas interests in the Dutch North Sea for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a gain of $279.1 million from sales of gold interests and a gain of $43.9 million from pension reversions. c-Includes expenses of $70.9 million and $80.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, for discontinued operations and other restructuring charges, and the year also includes a gain of $80.1 million from the recovery of excess pension assets.

title: No Room for Difference in East Germany
description: At a mid-January march commemorating Rosa Luxemburg, the German Communist murdered in 1919, East German police arrested 120 activists. Protesters carried banners quoting her appeal from the Kaiser's prison: ''Freedom is real only when there is freedom for those who think differently.'' Blasphemy, one official called it.

title: Ruling on Texaco
description: United States District Court Judge Charles L. Brieant is expected to rule early next week on whether Texaco Inc. may continue mailing its bankruptcy reorganization plan to shareholders. Judge Brieant heard arguments from shareholders opposed to the plan but has made no decision on their request to halt the mailing, which began on Wednesday. After Thursday's hearing Judge Brieant invited lawyers into his chambers for a meeting, which included Bankruptcy Court Judge Howard Schwartzberg. But lawyers in interviews yesterday said that the impasse was not broken. Last week, Judge Schwartzberg cleared the way for the mailing, but lawyers for the dissident shareholders filed an appeal to block it.

title: Northwestern Steel Accord Set
description: The Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said that it had tentatively agreed to be bought by a management group led by its president and chief executive officer, Robert Wilthew, and other employees and investors. The payment would consist of $18 a share in cash and 13 percent subordinated notes due in 1997 with a $4.50 principal amount. The cash portion of the offer for Northwestern's 7.5 million shares exceeds $135 million. The shares were unchanged today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $18.25 a share.

title: Renee Pollack, Health Aide,53
description: Renee Pollack, executive director of Westchester Jewish Community Services, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday in White Plains Hospital Medical Center. She was 53 years old and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title:
Patents;
Detecting Cancer Virus
description: LEAD: A method of detecting the virus that causes the form of cancer known as adult T-cell leukemia has been discovered at the Department of Health and Human Services. Patent 4,722,888 was granted this week to Dr. Samuel Broder, Shuzo Matsushita and Marjorie Robert-Guroff of the Washington staff.

title: FIRST UNION REAL ESTATE EQUITY & MORTGAGE INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
