title: Mario Cozzi, 72, Dies; Led Customs Inquiries
description: Mario Cozzi, former chief of the foreign investigative branch of the United States Customs Service, died of a brain tumor Jan. 29 in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in the Pelham Manor section of the Bronx.

title: FLEXTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Lawyer's Fast Track to Destruction on Wall Street
description: Six days before he was to be sentenced last month for his role in an insider trading scandal, David W. C. Clark collapsed at his mother's home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Within an hour, he was dead, a victim of chronic alcoholism.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $89,000. Year-ago sales include $628,000 from Land Mobile Radio Products which were discontinued in the 1987 second quarter.

title: Radiothon Continues
description: The New York Philharmonic-WQXR Radiothon, the 11th such fundraiser for the orchestra, continues this weekend with music and interviews that can be heard on WQXR (96.3 AM or 1560 FM) through midnight Sunday. Listeners who make donations may also receive gifts ranging from meals around town to helicopter rides. Visitors are also welcome in the west lobby of Avery Fisher Hall, from which the Radiothon is being broadcast. The number for those who wish to make pledges is 724-2131.

title: INTEGRATED GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 4th-Quarter Charge Widens Amax Loss
description: Amax Inc., the large natural resources company, announced yesterday that it had taken a fourth-quarter charge of $385.6 million to cover the costs of diminishing its molybdenum business. Largely because of that charge, the company reported a net loss of $280.8 million, compared with a net loss of $49.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: Spending Limit Up 14% for Primaries
description: Presidential campaigns will be allowed to spend 14 percent more in pursuit of the 1988 nominations than in 1984, but for some essential campaign goods and services they will get less for their money than their predecessors.

title: 'Star Wars' Contract
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Controlling Flow of Fuel In Spacecraft
description: LEAD: HAROLD A. ROSEN, a pioneer in satellite communication, has invented a method of controlling fuel flow in a spacecraft rocket engine. He was granted patent 4,722,183 this week, assigning it to the Hughes Aircraft Corporation in Los Angeles, where he is a vice president for engineering.

title: From Palestinian Rage, New Leadership Rises
description: As Palestinian protests head into a third month, what began as a spontaneous outburst of stone-throwing is developing a new underground leadership and organization in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Fletcher and Brown Triumph: Pam Fletcher won her second race in two days, and Mike Brown got a measure of revenge for being left off the Olympic team in super giant slalom races yesterday at the United States Alpine championships in Crested Butte, Colo. Fletcher flashed to victory in the women's race by more than a full second. Fletcher, who won the downhill on Thursday, successfully defended her two national titles of a year ago. Brown, a veteran on the team who thought that miscommunication by coaches cost him a spot on the Olympic team, was a decisive winner in the men's race. Brown finished second in the downhill Thursday. The 25-year-old Fletcher, of Acton, Mass., was timed in 1 minute 35.74 seconds. Kristin Krone, 19, of Truckee, Calif., was a surprising second in 1:36.92. Debbie Armstrong, 24, of Seattle was third in 1:37.09. Brown, 25, of Vail, Colo., was clocked in 1:30.63. Jeremy Nobis of Park City, Utah, was second in 1:31.50 followed by Andreas Rickenbach of Pleasanton, Calif., in 1:31.71.(AP) Tennis West Germany Leads Brazil: West Germany won both opening singles matches to take a 2-0 lead over Brazil yesterday in a world group Davis Cup first-round match in Essen, West Germany. Boris Becker put West Germany ahead with a 6-0, 6-2, 6-0 victory over Cassio Motta, and Carl-Uwe Steeb defeated Luiz Mattar 6-1, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Italy Takes Two From Israel: Italy swept two singles matches against Israel in Palermo, Sicily. Italy's No. 1 player, Paolo Cane, needed only 1 hour 35 minutes to beat Israel's top player, Amos Mansdorf, 7-5, 6-3, 6-2. Francesco Cancellotti outclassed Gilad Bloom in the marathon opener, winning by 6-1, 6-2, 6-8, 6-4 on the slow clay courts.(AP) Yugoslavia and India Tied: Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia outslugged Ramesh Krishnan of India, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4, and evened the Davis Cup world group match at 1-1 after the opening day of play in New Delhi. Earlier, Vijay Amritraj, India's captain, defeated Bruno Oresar, 6-3, 6-0, 6-3.(AP) Track and Field East German Sets Mark: Thomas Schoenlebe of East Germany set a world indoor best in the 400 meters last night with a time of 45.05 seconds at an international track and field meet in Sindelfingen, West Germany. He broke his own mark of 45.41. Walter McCoy of the United States was second at 46.53 followed by James Butler in 46.79. Ben Johnson of Canada, the world record-holder at 100 meters, pulled a thigh muscle while winning the 60-meter dash. Johnson won the event with a time of 6.50 seconds, after slowing in the final five meters. Johnson holds the world record of 6.41 seconds for 60 meters. (AP) Golf Lopez Ahead by 2 Shots: Nancy Lopez shot a 32 on her last nine holes yesterday for a four-under-par 68 and a two-stroke lead in the second round of the $200,000 Mazda Classic, which was suspended because of darkness with about 30 players still on the course. Lopez was at seven-under 137 after 36 holes on the 6,368-yard Stonebridge Golf and Country Club course. Betsy King and Patti Rizzo, the first-round leader, were next at five-under 139.(AP)

title: Kenyan Disbands Parliament And Frees 9 Before Elections
description: President Daniel arap Moi dissolved Parliament today to prepare for general elections March 21, and released nine political prisoners who had been held without trial.

title: About New York; The Lagelli Way To Cheaply Stage A Play by Pinter
description: Mickey Rooney used to say to Judy Garland (if he said it once, he said it a thousand times), ''Say, I've got an idea: Let's put on a show!'' So you take eight Northwestern University graduates, all drama majors, and you plop them down in New York, give them a few years knocking around looking for a break, pour a few beers down them one night in 1986, and inevitably one says, ''Say, why don't we put on our own show!''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Accord on Sale of Post Is Called Imminent
description: A tentative agreement to sell The New York Post for $37 million - contingent on large cuts in labor costs - was described as imminent yesterday as Rupert Murdoch and Peter S. Kalikow, a New York City real-estate entrepreneur, continued intensive negotiations.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on disposal of $900,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $630,000 and $915,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: State Dept. Denies Rift Over P.L.O. Mission
description: A State Department spokeswoman said today that there was no dispute in the department over a request to delay the closing of the Palestine Liberation Organization's mission at the United Nations.

title: Key Democrats Threaten to Stall Missile Treaty Over ABM Dispute
description: Senate Democratic leaders threatened tonight to delay approval of the new missile treaty with the Soviet Union after efforts to reach a compromise with the Administration on a key arms issue appeared to collapse.

title: T ROWE PRICE ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $2,468,000, or 18 cents a share, for curtailment of retirement plans.

title: IMPACT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $443,000. c-After tax credits of $376,000 for the quarter and $568,000 for the 9 months.

title: In Wrong Place With a Gun
description: A man with a gun was hustled away from a restaurant today as Gary Hart, a Democratic Presidential candidate, arrived to have breakfast, but the Secret Service said it was a case of ''being in the wrong place at the wrong time.'' A Secret Service spokesman said the man had a gun permit and apparently did not know Mr. Hart was planning to have breakfast at Pappy's Pizza in Manchester. The man was not arrested.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $4.4 million, or 11 cents a share, related to the repurchase of a portion of the company's outstanding convertible debentures. Corrected from Saturday, Jan. 30, editions.

title: Noriega Indictment Muddles Efforts By U.S. to Ease General From Power
description: While the indictment of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega holds little promise of leading to his arrest, it complicates efforts by the Reagan Administration to ease the Panamanian leader from power.

title: GENERAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the results for the latest quarter include a net loss from operations of $6.1 million, offset by a cumulative adjustment of $6 million to adopt the liability method of accounting for income taxes. The company also said the year-ago quarter included an after-tax gain of $471,000 related to land sales.

title: Site Set for Cup Defense
description: San Pedro Bay, off Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif., will be the site of the America's Cup defense in September, Sail America and the San Diego Yacht Club announced today.

title: FLORIDA ROCK & TANK LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Public's Indifference To On-Time Flight Data
description: Despite the Federal Government's efforts in recent months to inform the public of the major airlines' on-time performance, travel agents and others in the travel industry say the data are having little impact among ticket buyers.

title: Hart Asks for Ruling on Debt
description: Gary Hart's Presidential campaign has asked the Federal Election Commission for a ruling on whether it can use 1988 campaign contributions to repay debts from the 1984 race.

title: GEPHARDT IS WARY OF LEADER'S LABEL
description: After months of painful anonymity, Representative Richard A. Gephardt is beginning to show the telltale sign that proves he considers himself a front-runner. He is denying that he is ahead in next Monday's Iowa Democratic Presidential caucuses.

title: Mullin Impressive
description: In what his coach, George Karl, called ''the best game he's played since he's been back,'' Chris Mullin scored 18 of his 22 points after halftime Thursday night and sank two free throws in overtime to break a tie. Those 2 points put the Golden State Warriors ahead for good in a 96-90 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers in Richfield, Ohio. It was the fourth game for the former St. John's star since he returned after being treated for alcohol abuse.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Correction
description: An article yesterday about redistricting of seats in the House misidentified the Representative from the 11th District in New York. He is Edolphus Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, not Major R. Owens.

title: INSITUFORM EAST INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR SOVIET OFFICIAL, GOOD WILL AND FLU
description: When Vasily G. Zakharov, the Soviet Union's Minister of Culture, left New York for Moscow early yesterday morning, he took along the memory of a flood of good-will speeches, a few rocky moments with Congressmen who challenged the Soviet record on human rights and a severe case of the flu.

title: Israeli Army Also Worried By the Settlers
description: Growing unrest and threats of vigilantism among the Jewish settlements rooted like citadel-suburbs amid resentful Arabs are posing new problems for the Israeli Army as it faces a third month of Palestinian protest.

title: West to Resume Farm Aid to Ethiopia
description: The World Bank and several Western nations will resume agricultural development aid to Ethiopia, which has agreed to create new incentives for food production to combat a famine, United Nations officials and diplomats say.

title: Horn & Hardart In King's Table Bid
description: The Horn & Hardart Company, based in Las Vegas, Nev., said that it had agreed to acquire International King's Table Inc., which operates King's Table Buffet restaurants in California, Oregon, Washington and other Western states. Horn & Hardart, which already owns 19.9 percent of King's Table, will make a cash offer to purchase a minimum of 31.1 percent and up to all common shares oustanding for $20.25 in cash, or a total indicated price of $58.7 million. Shares of International King's Table, based in Eugene, Ore., rose 37.5 cents in over-the-counter trading today, to $19.625. A committee of independent King's Table directors has agreed to recommend the tender offer to the company's board. If the King's Table board does not approve the merger agreement, King's Table will pay certain of Horn & Hardart's expenses and may under certain circumstances pay a cancellation fee of $1.5 million.

title: Help on Children's Books
description: Adults who want to select the best in children's books may refer to ''Children's Books 1987: 100 Books for Reading and Sharing,'' a list available at branches of the New York Public Library. The guide, published annually since 1911 by the library's Office of Children's Services, costs $2 and cites books that are recommended by children's libraries. Areas include poetry, fiction, fairy tales and nonfiction.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1988
description: International 2-5 Panama's strongman was indicted. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega sold his position to drug traffickers for millions of dollars in bribes and turned Panama into a capital of international cocaine smuggling, the indictments say. Page 1 News analysis: The indictment holds little promise of leading to the arrest of General Noriega, and it complicates efforts by the Reagan Administration to ease the Panamanian leader from power. 5 A new Palestinian leadership and organization in the occupied territories is developing. This secret leadership committee is tied to the local factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Islamic fundamentalists. 1 Growing Palestinian unrest and threats of vigilantism among the Jewish settlements rooted like citadel-suburbs amid resentful Arabs are posing fresh problems for the Israeli Army as it faces a third month of Palestinian protest. 1 Approval of the pending arms treaty was threatened to be delayed by Democratic leaders over the issue of how treaties are interpreted. The issue has been a long-standing dispute between Senate Democrats and the Administration. 1 A prominent victim of Stalin's terror, Nikolai I. Bukharin, was wrongly convicted and executed, an official Soviet commission reviewing the purge trials of the 1930's said. The decision could have significant political ramifications. 1 Aid to Ethiopia will be resumed by the World Bank and several Western nations. Ethiopia has agreed to create new incentives for food production to combat a famine, United Nations officials say. 3 Poland's purging of many Jews in 1967 from the Communist Party will soon be acknowledged as a ''political error,'' according to a scholar who said he was conveying a message from the Polish leader. 5 Military analysis: The contras have been dealt a psychological blow by the Congressional rejection of President Reagan's aid package. But it will have little immediate effect on their ability to fight. 3 Vaaksy Journal: 100 million lures and still fishing 4 National 6-10, 28, 32, 50 Arizona's Governor was impeached by the State House of Representatives. Gov. Evan Mecham was accused of ''high crimes, misdemeanors and malfeasance'' and faces trial in the State Senate. 1 Royalties on patented animals may have to be paid by farmers to companies that hold the patents on the genetically engineered farm animals, the United States Patent and Trademark Office said. 1 Eastern Airline's shuttle will be put under the direct control of the Texas Air Corporation in an internal reorganization viewed as a move to press unions for concessions. 33 Fresh signs of economic slowdown were reflected in Government job figures for January, but the unemployment rate did not rise as many had expected and remained at 5.7 percent, the lowest level since 1979. 6 Spending by Presidential campaigns has been set at $23 million for 1988 primaries, a 14 percent increase over 1984, the Federal Election Commission announced. But for some goods and services campaigns will get less for their money. 9 George Bush stepped up his attacks on Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, saying that Mr. Dole started a fight with the Vice President's campaign but could not take it when they fought back. Mr. Dole tried to put the dispute behind him. 8 Signs of being a front-runner are emerging in Representative Richard A. Gephardt's campaign. After months of painful anonymity, he is denying that he is ahead in next Monday's Iowa Democratic Presidential caucuses. 8 Democrats step up attack in Iowa 8 Robertson forces are victors in Hawaii delegate selection 9 Payment to surrogate mothers for bearing a child should be prohibited if conditioned on the loss of parental rights, a panel of specialists concluded after a second day of heated discussion in Philadelphia. 28 Deaver Mayor faces an ouster move 6 F.B.I. to release more files in surveillance case 10 Florida legislators pass medical malpractice bill 32 Regional 10, 29-32 A drug court has cut a case backlog that almost overwhelmed judges and prosecutors in Manhattan last year when crack-related arrests soared, officials say. The new court aims to resolve felony drug cases in six days. 1 In the Howard Beach case, a white teen-ager convicted of manslaughter and assault for attacking three black men was sentenced to 6 to 18 years in prison. The judge said the youth had been a ''follower'' in the attack. 29 The sale of The New York Post could result from a tentative agreement described as imminent. Rupert Murdoch is negotiating the sale of the newspaper for $37 million to Peter S. Kalikow, a New York City real-estate entrepreneur. 29 In Robert Chambers's murder trial, police testimony was seized upon by the lawyer for Mr. Chambers to suggest that the body of Jennifer Levin had been mishandled by police investigators. 32 The death of a man tied to a scandal involving insider trading has resulted in a conflicting legacy. David W. C. Clark is viewed as either a criminal or a kind man who had allowed a dishonest stockbroker to lead him down the wrong path. 29 A Ghanaian woman fighting eviction from her Westbury, L.I., home, which is owned by Ghana, has no money and nowhere else to go. The woman, Efua Cabiri, lived there as the wife of a diplomat until her husband was arrested by his Government. 31 31 Doubts about a settlement with Lilco over the Shoreham nuclear power plant are being voiced by the utility's opponents. They say they doubt that a negotiated settlement will be politically acceptable. 30 Cuomo's Librarian: A fountain of data 29 Lawmaker questions need for public campaign financing 32 Neediest Cases 10

title: HDR POWER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Denver Mayor Faces an Ouster Move
description: When a Christmas Eve storm swept down from the Rockies five years ago, Denver's cigar-chomping Mayor, Bill McNichols, was slow to react, leaving many ice-covered side streets impassable for weeks. He quickly slipped in the opinion polls, paving the way for the election of this city's first Hispanic-American Mayor, Federico Pena.

title: Lilco's Foes Express Doubts on Talks
description: As the state and the Long Island Lighting Company intensify talks to end their battle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, Lilco's opponents on the Island are beginning to voice doubts that a negotiated settlement will be politically acceptable.

title: HICKAM, DOW B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a $336,000 non-cash charge resulting from the decline in value of certain deferred start-up costs related to Neotec.

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eastern To Lose Shuttle
description: In a reorganization intended to put pressure on its unions, the Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it would take the profitable Eastern shuttle away from its Eastern Airlines subsidiary.

title: Payton May Return
description: At tomorrow's Pro Bowl game in Honolulu, Walter Payton will be honored on the occasion of his retirement as the National Football League's career rushing leader. But while talking to reporters yesterday, his retirement after 13 seasons as a runner for the Chicago Bears didn't sound as definite as it had a few weeks ago.

title: CROSS, A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
School Staff Cleared In Steinberg Case
description: No disciplinary action will be taken against teachers, counselors and other school worker for failing to report signs that 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg was being abused, the superintendent of Community School District 2 said yesterday.

title: Caveat Investor on Monthly Trade Data
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,956,000 for the quarter and $7,550,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary credits of $2,424,000 for the quarter and $4,235,000 for the year.

title: 100 Million Lures Later, and They're Still Fishing
description: Do not be misled by the snow falling through the pines or the crust of ice across Lake Paijanne. On these frigid shores, 52 years ago, occurred one of the holy moments in the history of warm-water fishing.

title: Mortgages Dip Below 10%
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages have fallen below 10 percent for the first time since last April, according to a nationwide survey.

title: Emeric Pressburger Is Dead at 85; The Screenwriter for 'Red Shoes'
description: Emeric Pressburger, a British screenwriter whose widely acclaimed films made in collaboration with the director Michael Powell included ''The Red Shoes'' and ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia at a nursing home in Saxstead, England. He was 85 years old.

title: NORIEGA INDICTED BY U.S. FOR LINKS TO ILLEGAL DRUGS
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler of Panama, in effect sold his government to drug traffickers for millions of dollars in bribes and turned Panama into a capital of international cocaine smuggling, the Justice Department charged in two indictments made public today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Art Schlichter, the quarterback who is Ohio State's career leader in total offense, has been denied re-entry into the N.F.L. because of his gambling history. He plans to try out next summer with the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League. . . . Jack Evans of the Hartford Whalers, at 59 the oldest head coach in the National Hockey League, said he would retire when his contract expires at the end of the 1988-89 season, according to a report published yesterday in The Hartford Courant. With only 22 victories in 53 games this season, Evans has been loudly criticized by Whaler fans at recent games.

title: Lawmaker Backs Dole Over Contract
description: The chairman of a House committee says an investigation has found nothing to suggest wrongdoing by Senator Bob Dole in the award of a $26 million contract to a company owned by a former aide to the Senator from Kansas.

title: Milers, Led by O'Sullivan, Set the Pace at Millrose
description: The Millrose Games have always commanded attention largely for the blue-ribbon race of indoor track, the Wanamaker Mile. Last night, the 81st annual Panasonic Millrose Games produced one startling mile race after another.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of about $60,000 on the sale of fixed assets. c-After an extraordinary gain of $142,000.

title: Extradition of Sikh Is Approved in Jersey
description: A Federal magistrate yesterday ruled that the second of two Sikhs captured in New Jersey and accused of assassinations in India could be extradited to that nation.

title: Federated Rejects Bid By Campeau
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected the $47-a-share cash tender offer by the Campeau Corporation. Federated also challenged Campeau to prove that it had the financing for the $61-a-share merger offer it had announced Wednesday.

title: The Soviet View of What's Next
description: LEAD: The question of what should come next, after the signing of the intermediate nuclear forces treaty, is raised from time to time from practical considerations, and sometimes, from a broader political and philosophical perspective.

title: LINPRO SPECIFIED PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company commenced operations July 31, 1986.

title: Bridge:; With 1 No-Trump Opening, Some Hands Don't Fit Rules
description: The past two decades have seen the development of a plethora of conventions concerning competitive auctions following a one no-trump opening.

title: Panel Backs Curbs on Surrogate Motherhood
description: After a second day of heated discussion, a panel of specialists concluded today that payment to surrogate mothers for bearing a child should be prohibited when it involves a loss of parental rights.

title: Senate Group Says Canada Is Jeopardizing Trade Pact
description: The Senate Finance Committee's leaders on trade issues warned the Reagan Administration today that approval of a free trade agreement with Canada was imperiled by Ottawa's proposals to help its domestic apparel and dairy producers withstand American competition.

title: Beulah Bryant Is Dead; Singer of Blues Was 69
description: Beulah Bryant, a blues singer, died Sunday in Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital after a heart attack. She was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FIRST FAMILY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The loss for the year-ago 6 months resulted from a $2,550,000 charge when the company withdrew from the Southern California market.

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,445,000 for the quarter and $3,706,000 for the year, and a provision for loss on the disposal of the operations of $2,536,000 for the both periods. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,370,000 for the quarter and $501,000 for the year; both incomes included a net gain on the sale of real estate of $2,061,000. The latest year net from continuing operations included a pre-tax gain on the sale of real estate of $124,000. Both year-ago periods' nets from continuing operations included pre- tax gains on the sale of real estate of $283,000 for the quarter and $609,000 for the year.

title: Starling Is Winner In Lackluster Effort
description: Between the eighth and ninth rounds of Marlon Starling's title defense against Fujio Ozaki tonight, Starling's promoter, Cedric Kushner, stepped out of the Convention Center crowd and yelled at the champion.

title: BIO-MEDICUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: ALL-RIETI CONCERT
description: Vittorio Rieti turned 90 years old on Jan. 28, and Wednesday night he was honored by an elegantly accomplished concert of his elegantly accomplished music at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: On the Fields of Rhodesia
description: LEAD: One weekend recently, I found myself sorting through old high school photographs dating back to Rhodesia, circa 1950 -portraits of rugby, cricket, rifle and tennis stiff-backed teams. There we all were in our sports gear, upright and serious in the studio of a Bulawayo photographer, with the headmaster and coach in attendance.

title: G&K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
CONCERT: THE CLEVELAND AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: The clarinet explains Mozart as well as any other instrument. It was a relatively new and unused device in his time, but the quintet, trio and concerto he wrote for it form the base on which the clarinet literature has rested ever since. Mozart must have been attracted by its sour sweetness, soft yet with an aftertaste of tartness. The clarinet and Mozart's smiling melancholy make ideal accomplices.

title: PHILHARMONIC: DUTOIT CONDUCTS RACHMANINOFF
description: In 1940, when Rachmaninoff completed his last work, ''Symphonic Dances,'' the tides of history were running powerfully away from his heart-on-sleeve kind of music. For years, the score's only committed friend seemed to be Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, to whom it was dedicated. But tides, being tides, inevitably turn.

title: The Communist Gains In '47 Hungarian Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about Grecian music gave an incorrect date for a performance by Microcosmos. The group will play at 8 P.M. tonight, not tomorrow, at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street.

title: Public Money for Campaigns Is Questioned by Lawmaker
description: Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the New York Senate, yesterday questioned the need for government financing of political campaigns, but reiterated that he was ''not unalterably opposed '' to such financing for statewide campaigns.

title: Cuomo Reports A Spending Rise Of $258 Million
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that state spending in the current fiscal year would be $258.5 million higher than he had originally projected. That means total spending for will be 7.9 percent more than in the previous year, exceeding the 7 percent limit on growth the Governor had set.

title: Isaac L. Asofsky, HIAS Director, 98
description: Isaac L. Asofsky, retired director of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, died at his home in Manhattan Jan. 18 after a short illness. He was 98 years old.

title: A.T.&T., in a Rebound, Outshines 'Baby Bells'
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the original ''Ma Bell,'' is now outperforming the seven operating companies formed by its 1984 breakup.

title: Bank of New York
description: The Bank of New York filed suit in New York State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to enjoin the Irving Bank Corporation from issuing new convertible preferred stock to investors friendly to Irving's current management, the Bank of New York reported. Despite the objections of Irving's management, the Bank of New York has been trying to acquire Irving. The suit filed yesterday was in response to unconfirmed reports that Irving was planning to issue the new stock as a means of making it more difficult and more expensive for the Bank of New York to effect the takeover. An Irving spokesman declined to comment on the reports except to say that ''at a time like this a lot is going on.''

title: Edward S. Tauber, 79, Psychiatrist and Writer
description: Dr. Edward S. Tauber, a psychiatrist and author, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital Medical Center from complications of a stroke he suffered two weeks ago. He was 79 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: 53,000 Students Face Loss of Federal Grants
description: About 53,000 students will be denied college aid under the major Federal grant program next fall unless Congress provides more money or reduces the amount of each Pell Grant, according to the Department of Education.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AMAX GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Olympic Villages Are Opened
description: In near-zero temperatures, Juan Antonio Samaranch presided over his first official act of the Calgary Olympics today by declaring open the two villages that will house the 1,700 athletes.

title: GUIDEPOST
description: SHELF LIFE OF MEDICINE

title: KENNETH PORTER, WORLD WAR I ACE
description: Kenneth Lee Porter, one of the last surviving American air aces of World War I, died Wednesday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 91 years old.

title: Jackson Cooperative
description: The Bo Jackson saga, baseball division, continues. In view of Jackson's batting collapse in the second half of last season that cost him his starting assignment in left field, his career in the major leagues is now viewed as uncertain by the Kansas City Royals, who plan to open with Gary Thurman in left field. If Jackson is not to be a starter in Kansas City, how would he feel about playing every day in the minor leagues?

title: Poles Said Ready to Admit Error In Purging Jews From Party in 60's
description: Poland will soon acknowledge ''political error'' in 1967-68, when thousands of Jews were purged from the Communist Party, according to a scholar who said he was conveying a message from the Polish leader.

title: CARL MARKS SELLS UNIT TO BRITONS
description: Carl Marks & Company, the venerable New York investment bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its securities business, the largest sector of its operations in terms of personnel, to Smith New Court P.L.C., a British concern.

title: TELOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $89,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the quarter and $64,000 for the 9 months.

title: Carmen Lundy Sings
description: Carmen Lundy, a jazz singer, is to perform tonight at Twenty Twenty, 20 West 20th Street (627-1444). Sets begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; $15 cover and a $15 minumum at tables, a $10 cover and two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Ugandans to Ration Fuel
description: Uganda is beginning fuel rationing after years of periodic fuel crises. The Energy Ministry this week ordered all vehicle owners, including those with tractors and motorboats, to register at their nearest filling stations within 10 days.

title: Correction
description: Because of editing errors, articles from Washington on Jan. 30 and 31 about the Iraqi oil pipeline project, and an article on Feb. 2 that incorporated the error, misidentified a law against bribery of foreign officials by American companies. The law is the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, not the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

title: INSITUFORM GULF SOUTH reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Farmers to Face Patent Fees To Use Gene-Altered Animals
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office, in a new policy that could substantially change how lifestock and poultry are sold, has determined that companies holding patents on new animal forms have the authority to require farmers to pay royalties.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN INVESTORS CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan's Cruel Abortion Politics
description: Millions of Americans and third world women literally are hostages trapped in the Reagan Administration's cruel global war on abortion, taken prisoner primarily because they are poor and disadvantaged. Unless Congress or the courts intervene, these women will lose their right to effective family planning, the best protection they can get against unwanted pregnancy and, ironically, against abortion itself. The harm done to them will be a bitter legacy of the Reagan Presidency.

title: KEY RATES
SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $19.3 million for the discontinuance of the company's unprofitable ring laser gyro business, the planned disposal of a small aerospace unit, accruals for legal settlements, employee termination costs, and other matters. c-Included a charge of $31.7 million related to the company's government contracts disputes. The year-ago sales figures included $29.3 million for the quartr and $119.4 million for the year for the Sundstrand hydraulic power systems business, which was not consolidated in 1987.

title: EMPLOYMENT DATA SHOW SIGNS OF A SLOWING ECONOMY
description: Fresh signs of economic slowdown were reflected today in Government job figures for January, but the unemployment rate did not rise as many had expected, remaining at 5.7 percent, the lowest level since 1979.

title: Hitachi to Expand
description: Hitachi Ltd. said it would expand its semiconductor subsidiary here into a full-time production unit, which may employ 100 more workers. Hitachi Semiconductor America, which now employs 200 in an operation that handles computer chips imported from Japan, had suspended construction on its manufacturing plant here in October 1986 because of a slump in the semiconductor industry. The Tokyo-based Hitachi Ltd. said its decision to install a full-scale chip production plant had been prompted by the steadily improving international semiconductor market.

title:
Your Money;
Disability Policies For Long Term
description: LEAD: Most people do not have adequate long-term disability insurance to replace income lost when they are too sick or injured to work. If they want to maintain their standard of living, they should consider buying more coverage now, because rates on privately purchased disability policies are likely to climb soon.

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods included an after- tax charge of $53.2 million for the restructuring of the company's aviation group.

title: DRUG COURT CUTS NEW YORK BACKLOG
description: A drug court has been strikingly successful in cutting a backlog of cases that almost overwhelmed judges and prosecutors in Manhattan last year when crack-related arrests soared, officials say.

title: ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Islanders Earn Room to Brag
description: Bill Smith had just spent the last 20 minutes of hockey diving on his stomach and flopping on his back, all the time trying to keep his head from spinning. But despite the barrage of 17 shots, Smith maintained his equilibrium and preserved a 4-2 victory for the Islanders over the Capitals.

title: FRANKLIN COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: INNOVATIVE SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $81,000 for the quarter and $265,000 for the 6 months.

title: POLITICIANS IN EUROPE PRESS FOR ARMS TREATY
description: A panel of four European politicians told members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that failure to approve the new arms control treaty banning ground-launched medium- and shorter-range missiles would have disastrous consequences for the Western alliance.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Jan. 11 about the participation of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in a forum at Miami Shores, Fla., misidentified the sponsor. It was the Forum of North Dade, a nonpolitical organization, not the Democratic Party.

title: Florida Votes to Limit Medical Malpractice Costs
description: The Florida Legislature has approved a bill calling for major changes in medical malpractice laws, including a limit on the amount of money that may be awarded in malpractice lawsuits.

title: Bush Presses the Attack in Dole Dispute
description: Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign stepped up its attacks on Senator Bob Dole of Kansas today, saying Mr. Dole had started a fight but could not tolerate the Bush camp's fighting back.

title: 50 Years After His Execution, Soviet Panel Clears Bukharin
description: A Communist Party commission reviewing the purge trials of the 1930's announced today that Nikolai I. Bukharin, among the most prominent victims of Stalin's terror, was wrongly convicted and executed.

title: Congressional Pork, White House Pork
description: President Reagan mocked Congress recently for tucking dozens of frivolous expenditures into the catch-all 1988 budget bills. Shortly he will send back all the items that he says he would cross out if he had a line-item veto, and ask that they be canceled. That, he suggests, will test whether Congress really thinks the Government should subsidize such things as cranberry, crawfish and wildflower research. But if he were to submit a full and honest accounting, it would also show the White House in the forefront of political log-rolling.

title: ELDORADO MOTOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income

title: Redmen Take On Orange
description: In a matchup between a team that finally seems to be hitting its stride and one that may already have found its level, Syracuse plays St. John's at Madison Square Garden this afternoon.

title: LCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $132,000 settlement from early termination of a contract.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said it established a $3,900,000 provision for losses in 1987, $2,400,000 of that amount in the fourth quarter.

title: Rapid Rise of Fast Photo Processing
description: Fran Rosenthal-Myer burst into the 1 Hour Foto Lab in Times Square in Manhattan one day recently and plopped down a roll of film. ''When I need it fast, I come here,'' she said. A few hours later, she returned to pick up pictures she wanted to have before leaving town the next morning.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $8,571,000 and $12,571,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the extraordinary charge in 1986 represents premium paid to refund debentures and include additional loss related to the sale of a distribution unit.

title: A Misanthropic View
description: WOODCUTTERS. By Thomas Bernhard. Translated from the German by David

title: Perestoika in New York Schools, Please
description: The more I learn about the New York City Board of Education's amazing contract with its school custodians, the more I appreciate what Mikhail S. Gorbachev is up against. The hero of perestroika - restructuring - would surely find something familiar in an arrangement that rewards sloth and irresponsibility and discourages initiative.

title: Nancy Abraham Becomes a Bride
description: Nancy Abraham, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton, and Arnold Moss, a vice president of Integrated Resources, a real-estate and investment concern in New York, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Manhattan. Justice Alvin Schlesinger of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: ROBERTSON VICTOR IN HAWAII VOTING
description: Hawaii Republicans, voting in record numbers, have given Pat Robertson an overwhelming victory in a nonbinding straw vote. The voting accompanied the selection of delegates to the party's state convention.

title: BATTLE MOUNTAIN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in October.

title: Tops in Losses
description: Among National Basketball Association coaches, Gene Shue stands fourth in career victories with 767, only 171 behind the 938 of the leader, Red Auerbach. But in defeats, Shue heads the list. And on Thursday night in Los Angeles he became the first N.B.A. coach to lose 800 games when his Clippers fell to the Lakers, 117-86.

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $821,758 and $127,459 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $271,948 for the quarter and $5,877,618 for the year.

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $315,000 and $1,378,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the repurchase of debentures.

title: OMNICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included after-tax charges of $2,724,000 from the writedown of assets and the termination of an interest exchange agreement. c-After a gain of $1,220,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, and also included net unfavorable adjustments of $1,470,000. These adjustments included after-tax charges of $3,728,000 consisting of the previously mentioned fourth quarter charge and a loss on divestitures and tax adjustments net of a gain related to a pension accounting change, partially offset by net income of $2,258,000 from contracts that expired in July 1986. The latest quarter included an after-tax charge of $392,000, primarily for receivables reserves on equipment leases entered into in or prior to 1985 and on a note receivable relating to a previously sold business.

title: Out at Count of 36
description: Fighters older than 36 should be barred from participating in title fights, said Jose Sulaiman, World Boxing Council president, and he will ask his organization to do that at its convention in October.

title: Nashville Musicians Defy Order to Cancel Season
description: Musicians of the Nashville Symphony, defying a board decision to shut down the 85-member orchestra, vowed to appear as scheduled at the Tennessee Performing Arts Center tonight, even though orchestra officials designated last night's concert as the orchestra's final performance.

title: N.B.A. Union Asks To Be Decertified
description: Team representatives for the National Basketball Players Association voted unanimously tonight to decertify their union as the bargaining agent with the league. In a separate action, the union agreed not to call for a strike of the All-Star Game or the playoffs.

title: FERROFLUIDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses of $7,000 and $21,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from minority interest in a foreign subsidiary and tax credits of $123,000 for the quarter and $200,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago figures include results of the company's Japanese and Israeli subsidiaries sold during fiscal 1986.

title: More Heat Than Light on the Death of Dinosaurs; Stones, Bones, Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Given 6 to 18 Years In Attack Case
description: A white teen-ager convicted of manslaughter and assault for attacking three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, was sentenced yesterday to 6 to 18 years in prison by a judge who said the teen-ager had been a ''follower'' rather than a ''leader'' in the attack.

title: AIR WISCONSIN SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects pretax gains from the sale of aircraft and landing slots of $3,047,000 for the quarter and $5,190,000 for the year.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Rapist Convicted on DNA Match
description: A jury today convicted a man of rape on the basis of the DNA ''fingerprint'' of his blood.

title: LEINER P NUTRITIONAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Single Financial Regulator Backed
description: The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange today endorsed a key proposal of a Presidential task force by agreeing that just one Federal agency should dominate regulation of the financial markets.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said prior year results include special writedowns against operations made in the second quarter of 1986 of $502,915,000, or $488,733,000 after taxes, to recognize the reduction in the economic value of operating assets and related investments.

title: New Poll in Iowa Shows Dole Ahead of Bush and Robertson Special to The New York Times
description: A new poll in Iowa shows Senator Bob Dole with a small lead over Vice President Bush and Pat Robertson gaining ground.

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes one-time expenses of $1,639,000 associated with terminating personnel in connection with the restructure of the consumer operations, as well as the cost of refinancing the company's debt for the quarter, and the 6 months includes an accounting change gain of $568,000. c-Net income d-After losses of $3,090,000 and $4,102,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: BRENTWOOD INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Service to Keep Tabs on Credit Records
description: It's an interesting proposition: They keep the records; the records help lenders decide if you're a good credit risk; and for $35 a year you can keep tabs on the record keepers.

title: U.S. Agent and Suspects Slain
description: A Federal drug agent and two gunmen were shot to death today during an undercover drug operation, the authorities said. Two other Federal agents and a third gunman were wounded.

title: Officer Is Questioned on Photos of Levin
description: A police detective conceded yesterday that photographs of Jennifer Levin's body appeared to vary as to how much dirt was on her face, depending on when the photographs were taken on the morning of her death.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for 16wk to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,126,000 on repurchase of debentures.

title: 2 ARE SENTENCED IN WEDTECH CASE
description: State Senator Michael B. Mitchell and his brother, former state Senator Clarence Mitchell 3d, were sentenced today to two and a half years in prison each for taking payoffs to block an investigation of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: President Signs Housing Bill
description: President Reagan today signed the first major housing legislation passed in his Administration, saying it ''will efficiently and effectively meet the challenge of America's changing housing needs.'' The $30.6 billion measure is the first substantial housing legislation since 1980. It includes $15 billion for housing and community development in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 7, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 14 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts results in havoc. 3 3 33 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.)
