AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD, by Iris Murdoch. (Viking, $19.95.) The man at the center of Iris Murdoch's rich novel of ideas and passions is a serious academic writing a utopian revolutionary tract; he is surrounded by unserious academics who are in love with him and, once in a while, with learning. THE STRANGE NATION OF RAFAEL MENDES, by Moacyr Scliar. (Harmony/Crown, $19.95.) Rafael Mendes, descended from the prophet Jonah, discovers the records of his ancestors (all of them named Rafael Mendes too) in this picaresque, bemusing novel by a distinguished Brazilian fantasist. AMAZON FRONTIER: The Defeat of the Brazilian Indians, by John Hemming. (Harvard University, $29.95.) A dark and fascinating record of centuries of murder, disease and forced assimilation. A WOMAN RUN MAD, by John L'Heureux. (Viking, $17.95.) A novel dominated by a somber wit, in which a self-absorbed ex-professor embarks on an affair with a genteel shoplifter and murderer. LOVESONG: Becoming a Jew, by Julius Lester. (Holt, $17.95.) From son of a Methodist minister to black civil rights activist to member of a Conservative synagogue is some spiritual journey, told here with attention to the outer world as well as the inner. MAKEBA: My Story, by Miriam Makeba with James Hall. (NAL/ New American Library, $18.95.) The South African singer's wonderful vitality sustains this account of appalling humiliation followed by universal - but not uninterrupted - artistic triumph. KRAZY KAT: A Novel in Five Panels, by Jay Cantor. (Knopf, $16.95.) The innocent hedonism of the great and ditzy Kat is translated to print in this delightful novel-cum-homage, wherein the Coconino folk meet the Bomb, psychotherapy and S-E-X.

title: NEGOTIATING THE IN-LAW PACT
description: THERE'S a female rite of passage even more traumatic than the first date, and I recently came through it with flying colors. I dined alone, for the first time, with my future mother-in-law.

title: DATA BANK: February 7, 1988
SHERIFF WARNS OF GROWING TROUBLE AT BERGEN JAIL ANNEX
description: TENSIONS in Bergen County's 25-year-old Jail Annex are difficult to manage, says Sheriff Robert R. Herb, and unless changes are made, he contends, violence will continue and injuries increase.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Quechee, Vt.;
Small Town, Big Project
description: LEAD: TWENTY years ago developers looked at the woods and the pastures around this small central Vermont village and proposed construction of the largest vacation-home development in New England.

title: Rock: Frank Zappa Opens a Three-Show Series
description: LONG hours of rehearsal went into Frank Zappa's concert Thursday at the Beacon Theater. Opening a sold-out three-night stand, Mr. Zappa and 11 backup musicians played complex, irregular pieces - suite-length pastiches of everything from electro-pop to country to blues-rock to soundtrack marches to Stravinsky - that would test the memory capacity of a hard-disk drive.

title: 'Grand Old Men'
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the Consumer Binge Really Over?
description: FOR years, Americans have been the world's most determined, enthusiastic consumers. The simple living conveyed in Norman Rockwell's illustrations or Grant Wood's famous painting of a severe, Midwestern farmer and his wife, has been lost in the 1980's.

title: PASSING ONTHE JOY OF CARING FOR THE BIRDS
description: OUR family has a soft spot in our collective heart for all animals, and we have made an attempt each winter to provide food for the birds in our neighborhood.

title: BLAMING THE GREAT SOCIETY
description: LEAD: OUT OF THE POVERTY TRAP A Conservative Strategy for Welfare Reform. By Stuart Butler and Anna Kondratas. 264 pp. New York: The Free Press. $17.95.

title: F. Vernon Foster Dies; Stockbroker Was 94
description: F. Vernon Foster, a New York stockbroker for more than 70 years, died of complications following a blood infection last Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A LB CARTE
description: LOVERS are preparing for the romantic highlight of the year, Valentine's Day.

title: New Attention for Early Black Artist
description: The surreal setting of Joshua Johnson's ''Little Girl in Pink With a Goblet Filled With Strawberries'' adds drama to this folk portrait of a small child identified as Emma Van Name, which dates from about 1805. The painting, attributed to one of the nation's first black artists, was sold at Sotheby's last weekend for $660,000 - more than 14 times the previous record at auction for this artist - a price that represents a growing awareness of Johnson's importance. The buyer was Alexander Acevedo, a Madison Avenue dealer.

title: Dole and Gephardt Lead Poll
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri ranked first today in The Des Moines Register's final poll of Iowans before the state's precinct caucuses Monday night.

title: Chekhov's Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: LATE MOTHERHOOD
description: As the 46-year-old mother of a healthy 6-month-old daughter (and a 19-year-old son), I read Melvin Konner's article ''Childbearing and Age'' with considerable interest (Body and Mind, Dec. 27). While I do not dispute the reality of his statistics on the decreasing chances of conception with advancing age, it must be said that, despite atrophying organs and waning hormonal levels, the life force can be more generous to older women than mere statistics might lead us to believe. And improved methods of genetic testing - in my case a chorionic villi biopsy at 10 weeks, as well as ultrasound follow-ups - make the risks of late motherhood far more acceptable.

title: Who Will Speak for the Inner Cities?
description: America's urban centers are hemorrhaging jobs, while ''outer cities'' are flourishing in places like White Plains, Boston's Route 128 corridor or the area around Chicago's O'Hare Airport. In some such places, jobs now go begging, even while a few miles away, inner-city residents beg for jobs.

title: KENNEL CLUB PRESIDENT DECRIES SHOW-AND-GO COMPETITORS
description: LEAD: THE annual Westminster Kennel Club show gets under way tomorrow at Madison Square Garden, but Kenneth Marden, president of the American Kennel Club, believes that dog breeding is becoming ''just another sport, like skiing or skin diving,'' with an undue emphasis on winning at all costs.

title: Grow Your Own In-House Lobbyists
description: THERE'S plenty of help available to businesses that want to encourage employees or customers to register and vote, or to participate more actively in the political process.

title: Just Remember That Fathers Are Parents Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Pamela Grace Dorman, Editor, to Marry in July
description: Announcement of the engagement of Pamela Grace Dorman to Stuart Krichevsky has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Dorman of Dix Hills, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: HAIR OF DISTINCTION
description: Ruth La Ferla's article ''Under Cover'' (Men's style, Jan. 17), does not reflect the opinion of the many who feel that gray(ing) temples on a man are attractive and evoke an air of distinction and success (and there is no greater aphrodisiac than success).

title: 'SELF AS SUBJECT' EXAMINED IN SEVERAL MEDIUMS IN KATONAH
description: IT has been more than a decade since the age of narcissism was identified as such by Christopher Lasch. Tom Wolfe's proto-Yuppies, the ''me generation,'' appeared at about the same time. What was formerly deplored is now accepted, even applauded.

title: Package Deals in Three Capitals
description: TRAVELERS watching their pounds, francs or lire - and the dollar buys fewer of each these days -might consider buying a package deal to Europe. A weeklong package in Paris, London or Rome can represent a substantial saving over standard prices because airlines and tour companies get discounts by negotiating for large blocks of rooms. American Express, for example, says it books 250,000 a year. In addition, most tour companies guarantee prices in dollars.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SOUPSONGS and WEBSTER'S ARK. By Roy Blount Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) What do you do if you write cute verses, and they appear here and there, and people enjoy them? Why, you bunch them together and get them published as a collection. It's the only thing to do. If the author doesn't think of it himself, someone will suggest it to him.

title: Hints That Repression May Lead to Reform
description: FOR weeks, a battle has been raging in Angola that could have repercussions throughout southern Africa. The battle is for Cuito Cuanavale, the strategic town in southern Angola; the warring forces have been fighting for control of the region for more than a decade. On the defending side are the troops of the Angolan Government, backed by Cubans and Soviet advisors; on the offensive, the UNITA forces of Jonas Savimbi, the guerrilla leader, receiving 5-million-a-year in American military aid, stiffened by a South African army of at least 5,000, perhaps as many as 7,000 men.

title: SANTA BARBARA UPSETS NO. 2 LAS VEGAS
description: Carrick DeHart scored 16 points in a second-half run today as the University of California-Santa Barbara erased an 11-point deficit and upset No. 2 Nevada-Las Vegas, 71-66. It was the second time this year the unranked Gauchos had upset their Pacific Coast Athletic Association rivals.

title: And Now, a Magazine for the Over-40 Woman
description: FRANCES LEAR didn't know anything about headlines or deadlines. But she was convinced that she had an idea. Two years ago, armed with a huge settlement from her divorce from the television producer Norman Lear, she started work on a magazine for women over 40.

title: A Caustic Koch Assails Pension Plan Increase
description: In an unusually caustic attack on some members of the State Legislature, Mayor Koch yesterday released a barrage of statistics that he said showed how the city would be hurt by a state proposal to supplement the pensions of retired city and state workers.

title: 'THE STUDENT PRINCE,' OPERETTA IN DARIEN
description: TO fill the gap between two musical hits - ''42d Street,'' which recently closed an extended engagement, and ''La Cage aux Folles,'' next month's attraction - ''The Student Prince'' has been lugged into the Darien Dinner Theater for a spell.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington, D.C.;
Battling Over A Strip Center
description: LEAD: THE Zoning Commission is expected to set a hearing next month on a proposed design for a mixed office, residential and shopping center that would replace a Depression-era shopping strip in the northwest section of the city that has been vacant for two years.

title: MORE THAN ONE ROUTE TO BEETHOVEN
description: May I propose an inter-esting experiment: turn on your record machine and play - in either order you choose -Wilhelm Furtwangler's Bayreuth recording of the Beethoven Ninth Symphony (1951) and Roger Norrington conducting the same piece with the London Classical Players (1987).

title: Jones Shoots 70 for Third-Round Lead
description: Steve Jones has never broken par 72 on Pebble Beach Golf Links in the half-dozen rounds he has played here. But he said he will need to do just that on Sunday to have a chance to win the A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. The 6-foot-4-inch pro from Phoenix, who has yet to win in four years and three tournaments on the PGA Tour, took a three-shot lead today through three rounds of the event that used to be the Bing Crosby Pro-Am.

title: MISS LENESS IS AFFIANCED
description: The engagement of Christine Robertson Leness to David Lawton Boudreau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Boudreau of Plymouth, Minn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John G. Leness of New York and Quogue, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: Q and A
description: Squeeze on Water

title: THE SHAPE OF THINGS, PERHAPS
description: NEXT The Coming Era in Science. Holcomb B. Noble, General Editor. 190 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Rabi Memorial Service Set
description: A memorial service for Isidor Isaac Rabi, the Nobel laureate and University Professor of Physics at Columbia who died Jan. 11 at the age of 89, is to be held Thursday at 4 P.M. at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. Speakers will include Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia; Malvin Ruderman, Centennial Professor of Physics at Columbia, and William A. Nierenberg, director of the Scripps Institute of Oceanography in San Diego.

title: 'SCARED STRAIGHT' STUDY ASKED
description: LEAD: DESPITE nationwide experiments inspired by ''Scared Straight,'' the Juvenile Awareness Program at East Jersey (formerly Rahway) State Prison, there is still no consensus on its deterring juvenile crime. Two researchers whose evaluations helped fuel the dispute say that new studies are needed.

title: CHERISHING THE HERITAGE OF THE SHAKERS
description: FRANK TAYLOR pulled his car over to the side of the road, climbed out and scurried up the hill. He aimed his camera at the aging brown Shaker sawmill, took some pictures, and returned to the car.

title: Test May End 10-Year Rape Dispute
description: Illinois officials and the lawyers for Gary Dotson, a convicted rapist who was freed after Cathleen Crowell Webb recanted her accusation, are turning to a new genetic testing procedure in an effort to determine Mr. Dotson's guilt or innocence.

title: TOO FAR, TOO FAST
description: Carol Vogel states that Mrs. Gutfreund's ''style now is to hold Sunday night suppers offering a Texan menu of fried chicken and monkey bread.'' Since when has fried chicken and monkey bread, of all things, been considered ''Texan''? THE REV. DAVID H. MARION-DAVIS Houston

title: MARY CLIFFORD PLANS TO WED JOHN TITTMANN IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Rowland Clifford of Cornwall, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Rowland Clifford, to John Tittmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Tittmann of Concord, Mass. A July wedding is planned. Miss Clifford, a graduate of the Northfield Mount Hermon School and Connecticut College, is studying for a master's degree in international relations at the University of Chicago. Her father is a professor of history at Middlebury College, and her mother, Deborah Clifford, is a writer and historian.

title: The Vice President and the Anchor Man
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISED CASPI PLAN WINS APPROVAL
description: A MONTH after unanimously rejecting a $55 million complex of stores and condominiums, the White Plains Common Council last week approved a pared-down version that had been revised to answer neighbors' complaints.

title: THOSE OTHER L.I.R.R. RIDERS
description: Re: ''L.I.R.R. Main Line to Enter Electric Age,'' Jan. 17:

title: Maine Company Drops Suit
description: The Patten Corporation, a large development company based in Vermont, has agreed to drop its $1 million lawsuit against Hartford, Me., a small town in Maine's western mountains.

title: 2 Maine Agencies Curb Home Care of Elderly
description: A shortage of health care workers and inadequate state financing have prompted two of Maine's largest home health care agencies to stop accepting new patients under a state program designed to lessen the reliance of the elderly and the handicapped on nursing homes.

title: Lead Content in Mobil Glasses Is Questioned
description: With an eight-gallon purchase of unleaded gasoline, Mobil Oil service stations around the country have been giving motorists drinking glasses decorated with the logo of a football team in leaded enamel.

title: POSTINGS: Biltmore on the Block; Curtain Falling
description: ''Stardust'' is but a memory at the Biltmore Theater, though it still embellishes the marquee at 261 West 47th Street that once spoke of ''Barefoot in the Park'' and ''Hair.'' Since its last musical closed in May, the police say the theater has been used as a drug shooting gallery. On Feb. 16, it will be auctioned off at the Hotel Pierre.

title: Are U.S. Companies Learning to Share?
description: BATTERED by foreign gains in manufacturing and high technology, American companies are increasingly favoring cooperation over competition, as they band together in order to survive. Taking a hint from the Japanese, endangered industries are forming research consortiums to pool limited supplies of talent, money and managerial skill.

title: No Headline
description: It was nice to see our hero, Olympian skier Pirmin Zurbriggen, in The New York Times Magazine (''On the Edge of Greatness,'' by Trip Gabriel, Dec. 27). But what does Mr. Gabriel mean by calling him a ''Goody Two-shoes'' or a ''lollipop''? What is wrong with being shy, religious and modest? Pirmin Zurbriggen does not have to tell anyone he's good.

title:
GARDENING;
PROTECTING PLANTS DURING THE WINTER
description: LEAD: PLANTS that survive the average winter unharmed may succumb to that one winter in 10 or 20 years when the temperature drops well below the normal low.

title: 12 1/2% RISE IN BUDGET CAUSING CONCERN
description: Thanks to six years of a booming economy, Governor Kean has been able to initiate a number of programs in education, environmental cleanup and trasportation, and in his latest budget proposal last week he continued to target new spending in those areas.

title: Broadway on the Baltic Seeks Infusion of Zlotys
description: In a blotch of light on an otherwise dim stage, a man with white curled locks and beard, wearing baggy trousers, raises his hands and begins to sing ''If I were a rich man.''

title: U.S. Planning Show of Force for Seoul Games
description: The Reagan Administration plans a full-scale show of military force in and around South Korea next fall to deter possible North Korean terrorism or attack during the Olympic Games in Seoul, Administration officials say.

title: OLYMPICS TAKE A FIRST STEP ON THE ROAD TO REALITY
description: WHEN the Olympic athletes from 57 nations parade Saturday during the opening ceremony of the 15th Winter Games, one of the Canadian team members will be Andy Moog, the same Andy Moog who was an established goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League. And more than any other athlete in Calgary, he will be taking the first step to Olympic reality.

title: Primaries Don't Make Our Elections Wiser
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush as Hostage
description: Why can't George Bush simply come clean on his participation in the arms-for-hostages decision? Why does he respond by attacking the press for daring to ask the question, or by hiding behind his confidential relationship with the President, or by claiming that he's already answered everything?

title: THREE GOLDS A DAY
description: WHEN Torvill and Dean competed in the Olympics, they were DiMaggio rounding second, Evert placing a backhand, Erving dunking a basketball, grace and power, style and purpose, the champs.

title: Nick Pietrosante; Football Player, 50
description: Nick Pietrosante, a former running back at Notre Dame and with the Detroit Lions, died today of cancer. He was 50 years old.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/SCIENCE
description: THE MAGIC SCHOOL BUS INSIDE THE EARTH By Joanna Cole. Illustrated by Bruce Degen. 40 pp. New York: Scholastic. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: DEBORAH L. EICHHORN TO WED RUSSELL HINZ
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Jonathan Eichhorn of Kingston, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lynn Eichhorn, to Russell Alan Hinz, a son of Chief Warrant Officer Dale Hinz, U.S.A., of Mount Holly, N.J., and Lolita Eiden of Milwaukee. The wedding is to be May 29. Miss Eichhorn is a graduate of the State University at Albany, where she is studying for a master's degree in public administration. Her father is the rabbi of Temple Emanuel in Kingston. Her mother, Suzanne Eichhorn, is a computer instructional system coordinator for the Mid-Hudson Regional Computer Center in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Evans's Bamboozle, But in Reverse
description: ABOUT 40 years ago, as a young grandmaster, the syndicated chess columnist Larry Evans jocularly broached his idea that the easiest way to win a game was to pick the ripe moment for a transition to an ending where the opponent could be bamboozled. It was not quite all in fun either - he won loads of games ''transitioning'' his opponents.

title: Philadelphia Ex-Judge Convicted of Extortion
description: A former Common Pleas Court judge was convicted today of one of two Federal extortion counts. He is the third Philadelphia judge convicted of corruption in six months.

title: NANCY M. LYONS TO WED IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Lyons of Arlington, Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Marie Lyons, to Robert Patrick Callahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Callahan Jr. of Norfolk, Va. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: An Epic For Three Handkerchiefs
description: THE CARDINAL Starring Tom Tryon (in photo), Romy Schneider, Carol Lynley, Jill Haworth, Ossie Davis, John Huston, Burgess Meredith, Robert Morse, Raf Vallone, Josef Meinrad. Produced and directed by Otto Preminger. 1963. Video Treasures. 175 minutes. $9.98.

title: China
description: To the Editor: People who think their money will guarantee luxurious accommodations, familiar foods and paved highways in a poor, struggling country should stay home.

title: No Electioneering Inside the 7-Eleven
description: WAL-MART STORES, the nation's third-largest retail chain, held a major voter registration drive in late January in its 650 stores in 12 of the Southern states that will be participating in the March 8 ''Super Tuesday'' Presidential primary. The remainder of the chain's 1,114 outlets in the Southwest and Midwest will hold voter registration campaigns in September, in time to enable new registrants to vote in the November Presidential election.

title: Correction
description: A Sports of The Times column last Sunday about the old boy network in professional football gave an incorrect figure for the number of assistant coaches in the National Football League. There are 282, of whom 41 are black.

title: With New Editor, Paper In Maine Looks Ahead
description: When Matthew V. Storin decided to take a job as editor of a weekly newspaper in this little coastal town, some of his friends thought he was crazy.

title:
THE ENVIRONMENT;
REDUCING HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: LEAD: A STATE task force examining ways to reduce the production of hazardous waste has released its first report and has come under fire from some environmental groups for its limited recommendations.

title: Survey Finds a Clash on AIDS in Workplace
description: A clash between the rights of employees suffering from AIDS and those of noninfected co-workers could pose a growing problem for employers, according to a survey of attitudes toward people who have the disease.

title: Charting a Course for Vacations Afloat
description: LEAD: WITH the dollar's continuing weakness against foreign currencies, 1988 has become a good time to consider a cruise-based rather than a land-based European vacation. Most cruises offer air-sea packages with either free or optional shore excursions that compare favorably with land vacations, since accommodations, meals, transportation and entertainment are included in the cruise fare.

title: CATHERINE B. COX ENGAGED TO DANIEL J. BLUMENTHAL
description: Catherine Baum Cox and Daniel Jacob Blumenthal, a son of Mrs. Albert H. Blumenthal of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Blumenthal, plan to marry in the fall, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Cox of Newport News, Va., have announced.

title: 'SOCIETY WILL BUILD WHAT IT BELIEVES IN'
description: VINCENT J. SCULLY is the Sterling Professor of Art History at Yale. He has been teaching art and architecture history since 1947.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?

title: Let's Make a Deal
description: SOME IS WHERE the money is. NBC will not be moving to New Jersey. Thanks to Mayor Koch, it's going to stay at Rockefeller Center for at least another 35 years. ''The peacock can have both brains and beauty,'' the Mayor said last December as NBC accepted his offer.

title: FEDERAL DRUG OFFICIALS SKEPTICAL ON BASUCO
description: FEDERAL and local narcotics agencies are at odds over whether there has been an increase in the availability in New Jersey of a cocaine-based drug known to medical experts as basuco and to addicts as ''bazooka.''

title: SOVIET REMAINS THE FAVORITE IN HOCKEY
description: The Soviet Union, by virtue of its traditional pre-eminence in international hockey rather than its recent performances, remains the favorite to capture the gold medal. However, the development of competitive teams by the rest of the Olympic contingent has rendered the Russians vulnerable to more challengers than ever before.

title: Carmen Polo de Franco, Widow Of Spanish Dictator, Dead at 87
description: Carmen Polo de Franco, the Spanish dictator's widow, who was considered a significant influence on some of the repressive policies of his 36-year rule, died today in her Madrid apartment. She was 87 years old.

title: Architects Now Doubling as Developers
description: EVEN after construction crews completed work two years ago on Riveredge, an office complex in Florham Park, N.J., plenty of work remained for Edward Blake and Donald Rotwein, who served as the project's architects.

title: Cabaret: 'New Age Revue'
description: FEW subjects are more ripe for satire than the so-called ''new age'' movement with its assorted gurus, nuts and charlatans all spouting different brands of transcendental mumbo jumbo. Jeff and Julie Olmsted, the songwriter-performers who created ''Jeff and Jewel's New Age Blues Revue,'' which plays at Don't Tell Mama on Thursdays through the end of the month, have done their homework in researching a field that encompasses phenomena as different as Werner Erhard's EST training seminars and Shirley MacLaine's thoughts on reincarnation. But the show they have concocted is the lightest of spoofs and lacks real teeth.

title: Sports of The Times; Hoops, Chicago-Style
description: I INFORMED Mark Aguirre, the Dallas Maverick forward who has returned home to Chicago for the N.B.A. All-Star Game this afternoon, that he and I had graduated from the same grammar school, William Cullen Bryant on the West Side, though a number of years apart.

title: JULIE G. PRETZAT, PROFESSOR, TO MARRY B. R. MERCHANT
description: Julie Griffith Pretzat, an assistant professor of music at the State University College at Oswego, N.Y., and Benjamin Ralph Merchant, the owner of Kerner & Merchant Pipe Organ Builders in Syracuse, plan to be married May 21. The announcement was made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Pretzat of Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm so sick and tired of the great, galloping hordes of candidates criss-crossing the state and burrowing into every nook and cranny, every home. Every time you turn around you crash into one of them. Enough, enough!'' Betty Dumbaugh of Storm Lake, Iowa, who plans to stay home on caucus night. [ 1:1. ]

title: Correction
description: A roundup of educational tours on Jan. 10 misstated the languages used for liberal arts courses in the Paris program of the University of California at Berkeley. Only one class, ''France d'aujourd'hui,'' is conducted in French; the rest are in English.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: GENE M. BERNSTEIN;
VOLATILE TIMES AT NORTHVILLE OIL
description: LEAD: IN 1917, Samuel Bernstein, a teen-ager from the Lower East Side of Manhattan, began a business supplying coal and ice in Manhattan and Brooklyn. When the domestic ice age ended after World War II, he changed the company name from Premium Coal and Ice to Premium Coal and Oil.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/SCIENCE
description: LEAD: BUGS By Nancy Winslow Parker and Joan Richards Wright. Illustrated by Nancy Winslow Parker. 40 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Corruption Runs Deep in Panama
description: THE circle around Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega tightened last week, but Panama's military leader gave no indication that he is yet willing to relinquish control of his country. On Thursday, United States grand juries in Miami and Tampa, Fla., indicted General Noriega and 15 other people on charges of drug trafficking and racketeering. Earlier in the week, reports in Panama and the United States linked General Noriega and close associates to murder, the harboring of Colombian drug dealers and to intelligence work for all sides in the Central American conflicts.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE TRAGEDY OF DAVID FRIEDLAND
description: LEAD: AS YOGI BERRA once said, ''It's deja vu all over again.'' While Gen. Douglas MacArthur may no longer be available to re-enact his historic defiance after his World War II retreat from the Philippines, the lyrics of his theme song - ''I Shall Return!'' - linger on.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title:
INVESTING;
Have Bonds Advanced Too Quickly?
description: LEAD: AFTER a dismal 1987, fixed-income securities have rebounded in a powerful rally. Prices of the key 30-year Treasury bonds, for example, have jumped 5 percent in less than a month.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Trading Pinstripes For Chef's Toque

title: IMPORTANCE OF BEING ERNEST
description: THE TRUE GEN An Intimate Portrait of Ernest Hemingway by Those Who Knew Him. By Denis Brian. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ending Jan. 23 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park Area $154,500 102 East 22d Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 640-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar Art Deco building; fireplace, original moldings and details; maintenance $603, 53% tax-deductible (Broker: H.H. King) QUEENS Forest Hills $92,000 102-32 65th Avenue (The Richards) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft postwar co-op; dining area, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $360, 44% tax-deductible (Broker: Gala Realty) Neponsit $360,000 214 Beach 148th Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached ranch; dining area, large kitchen, 80- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Mitchnick-Kramberg Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Eltingville $182,000 61 Thorneycroft Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, frame house; dining area, large kitchen, rear deck, 28- by 85-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Victoria Realty) West Brighton $200,000 482 Bard Avenue 6-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, colonial; formal dining room, large kitchen, open front porch, 1-car detached garage, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,213 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: Feminism and Marxist Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; New Edition of Landmark Lures Tenants
description: A 55-YEAR-OLD Yonkers landmark, the Herald Statesman Building on Larkin Plaza, is being renovated into offices for two major tenants who are expected to bolster the local economy.

title: REAL-ESTATE GROUP POLL FINDS MANY SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT
description: A New York City real-estate trade group said last week that despite recent criticism of several ambitious development projects, a public opinion poll it commissioned has found a reservoir of support among residents for commercial and residential development.

title: Olympic Reflections: On Golden Pond
description: When it began, it was a pristine dream, the clear crystal palace of the Olympics. Now the palace does not shine so brightly. Memories of the Olympics still bring a warmth to my soul and a smile to my face. The Olympics, however, did not live up to my ideal.

title: NOT JUST A NOTCH IN THE RUST BELT
description: SECOND SIGHT By Mary Tannen. 259 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: SCHOOL STRESSES USES OF ETHICS
description: THE Dwight-Englewood School here is teaching students that ethical issues have a practical application in everyday life outside of textbooks.

title: DEBORAH GLASER IS BRIDE OF BRIAN JEROME HENRY
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Deborah Glaser, the daughter of Susan Heath of New York and David Glaser of Springfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Jerome Henry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Henry of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Adrian van Kaam performed the ceremony.

title: In Calgary, Samaranch Plans for Seoul
description: In his first meeting with a North Korean official since North Korea announced it would not participate in the 1988 Seoul Summer Olympics unless it is a co-host, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, warned that time was growing short for North Korea to participate in any form.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Four Designers Win the Olympic Coin Contest
description: LEAD: THE United States Treasury has unveiled the designs it will use on two special Olympic coins this year. They were chosen from among 84 entries in a limited, invited competition.

title: M.T.A. ACTS TO EASE PARKING PROBLEMS
description: LEAD: THE Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to request state authorization this month to spend $20 million on parking improvements at railroad stations owned by Metro-North, its subsidiary, over the next four years. County officials said that the move could significantly ease the growing problems faced by rail commuters.

title: TOO FAR, TOO FAST
description: My congratulations to James Sterngold for having written the article about John Gutfreund with a straight face. Here we have a sensitive report of the philosophical self-discoveries of an imposing man who denies himself millions of bonus dollars and only draws a million; who acknowledges disastrous misjudgments while promising to get it right next time; who enjoys the trust of the Salomons even though he pulled the rug from under them at great personal gain; whose acknowledgment and smile make the day for the senior officers of the ship he has run aground.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 7, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 2 OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) Tracking down a deadly disease that ophthalmologists pass on to their patients. 3 13 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Valedictorian, Denied West Point, Will Settle for Texas A&M
description: A Dallas high school student who was not allowed to apply to the United States Military Academy because she is not yet a citizen has received a scholarship to Texas A&M University.

title: TOO FAR, TOO FAST
description: I read with interest James Sterngold's article ''Too Far, Too Fast'' (Jan. 10), about John Gutfreund, chairman and chief executive of Salomon Brothers. Though I have had a minimal business relationship with Salomon Brothers in the last 10 years, my experience requires that I comment on the article.

title: ELIZABETH EDDY WEDS
description: At Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn., Elizabeth Blair Eddy and Andrew Cary Heublein were married yesterday by the Rev. John Donnelly. The bride is the daughter of Comdr. William P. Eddy, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Eddy of North Stonington, Conn. A graduate of the Loomis Chaffee School, she attended Randolph-Macon Woman's College. The bridegroom is a son of Patricia M. Heublein of Farmington, Conn., and Arthur C. Heublein of Ocean Ridge, Fla. He graduated from the Tabor Academy and Washington and Jefferson College.

title: DEMOCRATS, IN CONTROL, SHAPE BILLS IN SUFFOLK
description: LEAD: WITH the election of a Democrat, Sondra M. Bachety, last week as the Presiding Officer of the Suffolk County Legislature, Democrats solidified their control over a county in which they are outnumbered nearly 2 to 1 by Republicans and Conservatives.

title: Dance
description: The Ohio Ballet, which opens a week's season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue) Monday, has the look and feel of a well-tuned single instrument. Celebrating its 20th anniversary this year, the company is the creation of Heinz Poll, its director and chief choreographer, and Thomas Skelton, the lighting designer; and it bears the imprint of an informed and articulated artistic vision. New this season are Mr. Poll's ''Adagio for Two Dancers'' and ''Games,'' set to music by Albinioni and Mozart, respectively, and ''Solstice,'' a piece by company member David Shimotakahara. The Joyce repertory also includes two dances by Laura Dean and additional works by Mr. Poll.

title: Special Today
description: The Winter Olympics The 15th Winter Games begin Saturday in Calgary, Alberta. A special report that appears in Section 5 includes these articles:

title: ELDERLY VOLUNTEERS TRAIN TO COUNSEL THEIR PEERS
description: LEAD: A GROUP of elderly Westport and Weston residents will be visiting their peers to offer more than companionship.

title: ALLAN BLOOM'S GREAT IDEAS
description: Allan Bloom gave quite a revealing interview to James Atlas - particularly when he likened himself to a rock star in his excitement over his success as an author (''Chicago's Grumpy Guru,'' Jan. 3). ''It's like being declared . . . a rock star. All this energy passing through you. . . '' Could it be that this is how Mick Jagger feels when he is ''tarting it up on stage. . . .''?

title: CELEBRATING VALENTINE'S DAY
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Rodgers and Hart insist that ''each day is Valentine's Day,'' most of us have become accustomed to celebrating love and romance formally only once a year. This year, particularly for those revelers who mark the event with dancing and dining, the festivities will take place on next Saturday, St.

title: WHAT HE DID FOR HIS IN-LAWS
description: THE MEMOIR OF MARCO PARENTI A Life in Medici Florence. By Mark Phillips. 283 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $40.

title: China
description: To the Editor: In Betsy Wade's ''Going to China? What to Expect'' (Practical Traveler, Sept. 13), many valuable and valid hints for comfortable travel in China were given. I would like to give one additional hint. The old adage, ''When in Rome, do as the Romans do,'' might wisely be updated to ''When on a Pacific Delight tour in China, do as the Pacific Delighters do.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: RACINE, WIS.;
Marina Helps City Rebound
description: LEAD: A LUXURIOUS new marina here is a key element in plans to resurrect the downtown of this manufacturing city of 85,000 on the southwestern shore of Lake Michigan.

title: Wrong From the Start; Reagan's Contra War, Reagan's Failure
description: President Reagan lost a crucial funding vote last Wednesday on the contra war. Only a vote was lost, not a country. Yet the White House is sure to blame Congress if the Sandinistas fail to live up to the Central American peace plan. But it is Mr. Reagan, not Congress, who is responsible for the breakdown of U.S. policy. Congress might well have backed a genuine two-track policy of aid to insurgents and plausible diplomacy. Mr. Reagan, however, had only one track - war.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Which Way for Housing?

title: OPERA AS A CALL TO FREEDOM
description: LEAD: Europe in the mid-19th century was a maelstrom of political currents. Artists and composers were invariably drawn into the revolutionary movements urging freedom of expression and national independence. Verdi's early operas became the symbols of the fiery spirit of the Italian ''risorgimento.'' But Verdi had a long line of Italian national traditions to draw upon;

title: Attack on Nicaragua Bus Kills 17, Including Infant
description: Lying on a crude kitchen table, the body of perhaps the youngest victim of Nicaragua's civil conflict lay swaddled in white inside a dank mud shack today.

title: Skeptically, Koreans Await Demonstrations of Democracy
description: FOR optimists, here are some signs of a democratic breeze that has been blowing sweetly through South Korea since the mid-December election of Roh Tae Woo as President:

title: FICTION
description: WHITE LIES. By Julie Salamon. (Hill, $16.95.) Jamaica Just, a young journalist working for a large New York City daily, is the heroine of this first novel by the Wall Street Journal film critic Julie Salamon. Using the device of Jamaica's newspaper assignments on New York life and its characters, Ms. Salamon turns out some observant sketches of, among other subjects, welfare mothers and people who write letters to the editor. But it is a piece on the Holocaust that occasions a series of flashbacks to Jamaica's childhood as the daughter of two survivors who resettled in a quiet Midwestern farming community. Although the novel's psychological portrait of Jamaica is indistinct - she suffers, we are told, from a vague sense of unease, a nameless guilt about her parents' unspoken past - these retrospective views are the most successful sections of the book. The portrayals of Jamaica's Czechoslovak parents, her feisty mother and silent doctor father, and of the beauty and dangers of rural America are evocative and vivid, written with a light, bittersweet poignancy. This contrasts with Ms. Salamon's edgy presentation of Jamaica's up-to-the-minute life as a married working woman; here there is some sharp writing, but the unmodulated tone of New York street-smart flippancy is often misplaced and sounds a number of wrong notes. While one could argue that the story of one's life - and this book seems to be strongly autobiographical - does not require thematic coherence, ''White Lies'' has no center that would serve to pull together its unrelated, episodic set pieces.

title: YOUNG WERTHER IN THE 60'S
description: IN THE NEW WORLD Growing Up With America 1960-1984. By Lawrence Wright. 322 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Heavy Metal in a Quiet Room IT was hard to tell who was having more fun at the Nassau Coliseum recently, the 17,000 screaming teen-agers in the arena, who were boogying away to the heavy-metal sound of the rock band Whitesnake, or Rose Liss in the basement, who was ''up a couple of dollars'' in a deuces-wild seven-card-stud poker game.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Not So Gay Paree Not all the Americans in Paris haunted cafes and dance halls. Here is The New Yorker's Janet Flanner describing Edith Wharton's sober expatriation. She is quoted in ''Women of the Left Bank: Paris, 1900-1940,'' by Shari Benstock (University of Texas).

title: ABOUT SOFTWARE AND HARDWARE
description: The article ''Computers: A Necessary Insidiousness'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 17 ] renders a distinct disservice to your readers. Especially in the over-30 generation, there's enough nervousness about these marvelous machines without adding to it by maligning them, even if facetiously. Worse yet, to tell all sorts of untruths about them! An editorial consultant really shouldn't go for the giggle by sacrificing precision of thought.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday on fiscal issues before the General Assembly gave an incorrect figure for the amount of money to be taken from the 1986-87 budget surplus and state corporate tax and used for local property tax relief in the 1988-89 fiscal year. The amount is $42 million. The article also misstated an increase to that fund being sought by the Connecticut Conference of Municipalites.

title: COAST GUARD TO CUT NEW LONDON UNITS
description: BOATERS on Long Island Sound and its major estuaries are probably going to find the Coast Guard far less accessible next summer as a result of Congressional budget cuts.

title: Preventing a Recurrence of the 'Black Monday' Blues
description: TAMING volatility in the stock market appears to be the order of the day.

title: Cable TV
description: Cable this week has some sturdy vintage movies whose rare exposure makes them seem even more evocative of their times.

title: PROCEEDS OF GALA MAY SAVE L.I. STAGE
description: LEAD: AS fund-raising galas go, today's ''Save Long Island Stage'' should be celebratory as well as festive. Advance reservations indicate that the dinner-entertainment at the EAB Plaza in Uniondale will bring in enough to help the troubled theater company, Long Island's only full Actors Equity house, survive, at least through

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION

This eighth book in a series that spans nearly 20 years continues the anthropologist Carlos Castaneda's travels and teachings with Don Juan Matus, a Yaqui Indian sorcerer or nagual. The formula is familiar: Mr.

title: A Southern Novelist Serves as a Muse to Drama
description: In the mid-1950'S, Jim Lehrer was working his way through junior college behind a bus-station ticket counter in Victoria, Tex., when he heard that one of his sports heroes, the Brooklyn Dodger pitcher Don Newcombe, was in town. ''My mother called me up from the car dealership where she was working, and told me Newcombe's car had broken down,'' Mr. Lehrer, co-anchor of public television's MacNeil/ Lehrer NewsHour, recalled the other day. ''I rushed on over there, and he handed me a church key with his autograph on it.''

title: A JOYFUL NOISE
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Holcomb B. Noble's article ''A Joyful Noise'' (About Men, Dec. 27), about singing in a male chorus. It recalled an experience I had in early 1944 in Belfast, Northern Ireland, where I was on furlough for three days.

title: WENDY ENGEL TO WED A. S. COHEN IN AUGUST
description: An August wedding is planned by Wendy Joy Engel and Adam Seth Cohen, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Engel of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced. Mr. Cohen is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Cohen of Hewlett Harbor.

title: About Men; The Magic Classroom
description: I'VE BEEN MEETING FORMER students of mine lately: one on the A train, one in Zabar's, another at a street fair. They are shy about it at first - scrutinizing me, trying to find the someone they knew behind the years, the changes. ''You're Professor Lyons, aren't you?'' one asked, and I stuttered a bit, because the last time this happened, I said ''I was,'' meaning ''without the title now'' though I am still Lyons. ''You were a fantastic teacher,'' a man about 40 said to me - I'd have sworn I'd never seen him before - and I blushed and said something inane about its being nice to be remembered. ''No, no,'' he said, shaking his head, ''you don't understand. I hated school. It was a prison filled with affected, foolish people. You brought such life and energy into the classroom. You made me love what we read.'' And a woman who had studied with me 23 years ago told me in the subway, shouting to make sure I heard, that her passion for literature began in a class of mine in a grubby, dark, crowded room being used during renovations at the college. She mentioned Kafka, Yeats, Whitman and Melville; she still read and reread them all. I told her I did, too.

title: UCONN TOPPLES GEORGETOWN
description: Cliff Robinson scored 16 points and blocked 9 shots to lead Connecticut over Georgetown tonight, 66-59.

description: After meeting with President Nicolae Ceausescu for nearly three hours today, a visiting United States official said he had found the Rumanian leader unwilling to listen to American concerns about Rumania's human rights policies.

description: Renee Yvette Chenault, a television moderator and a producer for the New Jersey Network, a group of four PBS stations, and Michael Thaddeus Crawford, a copy editor at The Wall Street Journal, plan to be married March 19. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. E. M. Chenault of Littleton, Colo.

description: LEAD: A NEW way of measuring the social well-being of America - the Index of Social Health - has been developed at the Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy. The institute is based at the Fordham University Graduate Center School of Social Service in Tarrytown.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TRACING THE STICKLEY LEGACY
description: LEAD: COLLECTORS who prefer the glow of patina on old wood to a plain brown finish, complex forms and gentle curves generally bypass the furniture designs of Gustav Stickley (1857-1942), the multifaceted artisan-entrepreneur whose singular vision of a better world was based on harmony expressed through craft.

description: The Jan. 17 article ''Animal Rights Group Assails Egg Farm'' omits a crucial fact about factory farming: Since the hens that are crammed together in tiny cages could easily succumb to infectious illness, their feed is heavily dosed with antibiotics.

title: Piano: Barry Hannigan in Recital

The music consisted of two of the most admired, large-scale piano scores of the mid-1970's, both experimental and involving whistling and vocalizations from the performer, yet both looking forward to today's accessible post-modernism.

title: On Language; The Juddering Juice Shtick
description: BRITAIN'S STEADILY growing prosperity,'' boasted Nigel Lawson, the British Treasury Minister, ''is not some short-lived boom, which could come to a juddering halt at any moment.'' Only a year before, the leader of Britain's Labor Party, Neil Kinnock, expressed the hope that America's policy toward Nicaragua would be ''brought to a juddering halt.''

description: LEAD: THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES By I. F. Stone. 282 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $18.95.

title: Haitians Warily Enter an Uncertain New Era
description: AFTER teaching political science in the United States, France and Latin America for 23 years, Leslie F. Manigat, the new President of Haiti, believes he is going to have a chance to test his ideas of national development. But first, Mr. Manigat, who is to be inaugurated today, must ease the resentment over the blatantly rigged Jan. 17 election that brought him into office and patch things up with the United States, Haiti's main source of foreign aid and an influential force in the decisions of other donors.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
description: Wait until October. While George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin are toasting each other on a world-championship season, just ask Jack Clark. KARA YORIC Kinnelon, N.J.

title: NONFICTION
description: COUSIN JOE: Blues From New Orleans. By Pleasant (Cousin Joe) Joseph and Harriet J. Ottenheimer. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) On the last page of this curious memoir, the blues singer Pleasant Joseph writes: ''The good Lord gave me a chance to make a comeback. I had messed up my whole life from drinking: from slow horses, from fast women and bad whiskey.'' This passage comes as a complete surprise; although ''Cousin Joe: Blues From New Orleans'' contains frequent references to Mr. Joseph's drinking, gambling and womanizing, there has been no indication up to this point that these activities had ''messed up'' his life to the degree that there was ever anything other than a well-earned retirement for him to ''make a comeback'' from. Such is the nature of the book, which tends to be discursive in tone and casual in its approach to matters of substance. It is also strangely uninformative about Mr. Joseph's musical career, and anyone who isn't already aware of his importance is apt to find this account more confusing than enlightening on that score. ''Cousin Joe'' contains some incisive observations about race, poverty and music, and some entertaining anecdotes. But it seems awfully lightweight for a work that Mr. Joseph's collaborator, Harriet J. Ottenheimer, says took the two of them 20 years to complete. Ms. Ottenheimer, a professor of anthropology at Kansas State University, has attempted to distill Mr. Joseph's rambling reminiscences into a narrative ''intended for a general reading public.'' But since the book is so stingy with relevant information, it's hard to see what appeal it could have for that vast portion of the general public that has never heard of Cousin Joe.

title: Pros vs Amateurs
description: WHAT is it that separates the ''pros'' from the amateurs in photography? To many minds, it's a matter of equipment. Professional photographers, according to this theory, have access to a special breed of cameras, lenses, flash units and the like. Using pro-level equipment, they are able to take pro-level pictures. Amateurs, meanwhile, have to make do with amateur-level gear.

title: Car Stereos Cover the Ground
description: The uses of MOzart are manifold. For example, last week I discovered that the Haffner Serenade is good for frayed nerves while you're waiting to be pulled out of a ditch. No cause for alarm - it's all part of winter driving in the Berkshires, but it explains why, under certain conditions, a good sound system in a car gives as much comfort as a good heater. With this in mind, we'll focus on some stand-out designs in automotive sound.

title: U.S. Skaters Divided but Nearly Equal in Calgary
description: ONE by one by one they were almost dazzling last month in Denver. Showered with applause, flowers and teddy bears after their long programs, they had become America's ice-skating darlings, leaving the impression they were more a team than sometimes cutthroat competitors in a national championship. For these brief hours, one was no more appreciated than the next, separated in the final analysis only by the numbers of a scoreboard. Watching their freestyles, a rapt, sellout crowd in McNichols Sports Arena did not seem to care which of them won.

description: Unlike babies, not all stories come from the same place, and not all people who create stories go about it in the same way.

description: The Soviet Union is slowly disclosing the circumstances of the mysterious airplane crash 20 years ago that killed Yuri A. Gagarin, who was the first man to orbit the earth and was one of his nation's most popular heroes.

description: One thing a horseplayer can be sure of is that when his horse falls back from first to sixth turning for home, it is not going to win. Today at Gulfstream Park, though, that is exactly what Beauty Cream did en route to a half-length victory in the $200,000 Orchid Handicap.

title: LISA BURTON WED TO BRUCE ERICSON

Burton of Deep-haven, Minn., was married yesterday to Bruce Alan Ericson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Ericson of Snyder, N.Y. The Rev. Carla Bailey performed the ceremony.

description: Whoever said they were enslaved? Shed no tears over these freewheeling, free-spending, free-spirited guys. They never had it so good. Some of their salaries practically rivaled the Treasury balance. LARRY L. KUNTZ Brooklyn

description: The site of a 112,000-gallon chlorine dioxide leak at a paper mill was being monitored today by environmental officials while the mill awaited the Governor's permission to resume normal operations.

Gerrity 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrity Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard B. Andersen, the rector, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. Donald J. Pryor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Ups and Downs Aside, Iowa Has 'Middleness'
description: IN Waterloo, a town that has lost 12,000 manfacturing jobs in the last decade, the John Deere foundry and tractor plant has recalled 500 workers since November. In Albia, a rural crossroads where the farm crisis drove one bank and at least three shops out of business, a small pipe-making company plans to open a factory that will employ 100 people.

title: Barcelona
description: To the Editor: Two hundred and sixty dollars for dinner for four in Spain? Have travel writers no conception that many ordinary travelers choose Spain (and Portugal and Morocco and some others) because it is one of the less expensive places to visit? If the writer of a ''What's Doing in'' must indulge himself in expensive restaurants, let him do it in a special category placed between ''Hotels'' and ''Restaurants.'' Label it ''Affectations.'' WILLIAM D. SANTORO Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Who Makes Disney Run?
description: IT'S 7 A.M. ON A SUNDAY WHEN THE black Mustang convertible swings onto the Ventura Freeway. While Los Angeles is sleeping off the excesses of Saturday night, at least two million people dreaming of easy fame or easy money, Jeffrey Katzenberg is driving to work with a phone in his hand and a list of 500 phone numbers in his head.

title: FICTION
description: 1919: The Year Our World Began. By William K. Klingaman. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) The year 1919, by any yardstick, was an eventful one, and the historian William K. Klingaman persuasively demonstrates that it began with hope, ended in despair and shaped the 20th century. Consider these highlights: With hostilities ended in the Great War, Woodrow Wilson spends several months in Paris working on a treaty; by year's end, his dream of a League of Nations is shattered. Meanwhile, loyalist Russians wage a futile battle with Bolsheviks; Lincoln Steffens, an ardent supporter of Lenin, tells anyone who listens that he has ''been over into the future, and it works.'' As Germany accepts humiliating peace terms, a former corporal with mesmeric qualities joins a right-wing workers' party and articulates a philosophy of hate. In India, another charismatic leader - this one committed to nonviolence -begins to unite his countrymen against colonial rule. Throughout the world, hunger and unrest foment violence and strikes. Prohibition becomes law, Einstein's theory of relativity is validated, the White Sox throw the World Series and Charlie Chaplin joins Mary Pickford, D. W. Griffith and Douglas Fairbanks to form United Artists. Mr. Klingaman does an admirable job of getting us into the flow of the times with a narrative that relies heavily on contemporary news accounts. Readers will note the almost total absence of analysis, a shortcoming the author cheerfully acknowledges was intentional. But as a detailed record of 12 extraordinary months, his lively chronicle achieves immediacy and sustains attention.

title: Blooms for the Winter
description: INDOORS sow seed of geranium, petunia, salvia, begonia, impatiens, eustoma, portulaca and coleus. It is too early to sow vegetable seed indoors especially tomatoes, peppers, melons, eggplants; wait until March. Pot paperwhite narcissus bulbs in pebbles, but discard any of these tender bulbs that have already bloomed; they cannot be forced again. Cut down faded amaryllis flower stalks, but leaves must remain to renew bulbs. Pots of Flowers

title: Cambridge
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest your coverage on travel-study in England - Cambridge and Oxford (Travel, Jan. 10). In fact, the bit on Corpus Christi, Cambridge, brought smiles to me because some years ago I myself was a student at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, with Dr. E. J. Wolff's University of Detroit program there, and as part of our program we visited our sister school in Cambridge.

description: REMEMBER when your mother warned you to be careful what you wished for because you just might get it?

title: CHIEF KEAN ECONOMIST LEAVENS OPTIMISM
description: GOVERNOR Kean's leading economic adviser says that a glowing forecast for 1988, issued just two weeks ago, may have been overly optimistic.

title: AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS ON THE ISLAND
description: The article ''After School, They're at School'' on Jan. 3 has, I believe, some misinformation. To my knowledge, the oldest program, Clasp, is located in Great Neck. The second oldest program is the North Bellmore After-School Center Inc., which was incorporated in October 1979 and started in September 1980 at the Saw Mill Road School by Marilyn Deiner. GAIL R. BLUMENGARTEN Executive Director North Bellmore After-School Center

title: Piano: Thomas Lorango
description: THE first simple chords of Beethoven's ''Les Adieux'' Sonata at Alice Tully Hall Friday night let us know about Thomas Lorango's intelligence and sympathy for the piano literature. Each voice had its own life and each was joined together by Mr. Lorango's natural feel for the tensions of movement. This sensitive, almost private, feeling for music carried over into the finale of Schumann's Fantasy and the three Intermezzos from Brahms's Opus 119. In the latter's ''Handel'' Variations, Mr. Lorango also showed the foresight to bind many segments together with what was basically a common tempo.

title: Soviet Shifts Planning Chief After Criticism by Gorbachev
description: Nikolai V. Talyzin, the head of the powerful Soviet State Planning Commission who was criticized by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in June, has been transferred to another position, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: THE UGLY HISTORIANS
description: REFLECTIONS ON HISTORY AND HISTORIANS By Theodore S. Hamerow. 267 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $25. THE NEW HISTORY AND THE OLD By Gertrude Himmelfarb. 209 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $20.

title: Dole and Bush: Dramatic Contrast of Styles . . .
description: Since the Presidential campaign began, Gerald M. Boyd has been covering Vice President Bush while Bernard Weinraub covered Senator Bob Dole. Last week they switched assignments to report how the campaigns compared in style and in substance.

title: Stagehand Seized at Airport in Karate-Kick Slaying
description: A nationwide manhunt set off by the karate-style kick slaying of a young business executive on a Manhattan street ended Friday night with the capture of a 20-year-old part-time New York stagehand as he stepped off an airliner in San Francisco.

title: GROUPS MAKE WELCOME A RETURNING SPECIES
description: LEAD: THE boys in Cub Scout Den 10, Pack 58, in Lebanon, the men in the woodworking class at the Bristol Senior Center and the members of more than 100 other organizations around the state are building tiny houses for bluebirds.

title: LIFE ON THE LINE: VERMONT AND CANADA
description: It was a curious scene that Monday morning last week in the main hall of the Haskell Free Library. On one side of the thin, black line sat a Canadian judge; five Canadian witnesses for the prosecution; a Canadian attorney and George Terwilliger 3d, the United States Attorney for Vermont, who was there to question the witnesses.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WESTERN TRAILS. By Mary Austin. Edited by Melody Graulich. (University of Nevada, $22.50.) Mary Austin's reputation has been in undeserved eclipse since her death in 1934. The author of the nature classic ''The Land of Little Rain'' and the early feminist novel ''A Woman of Genius,'' Ms. Austin also wrote five collections of stories, from which Melody Graulich, an associate professor of English at the University of New Hampshire, has made the present selection, adding six previously uncollected or unpublished stories.

title: IN HASTINGS, A TREASURY OF HISTORY
description: EVERY weekday afternoon in Hastings-on-Hudson, the 4:30 whistle signals the end of the workday of yesteryear - calling phantom laborers from the abandoned factories that still line the waterfront and that may soon become condominiums.

title: Abrams Frustrated by Lawyer in Assault Case
description: New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams, who was appointed by Governor Cuomo last month as special prosecutor in the Tawana Brawley case, has expressed frustration over the continuing refusal of Miss Brawley's lawyer, Alton H. Maddox Jr., to cooperate in any way.

title: Cup Tactics Attacked
description: The choice of San Pedro Bay near Los Angeles as the site for the next America's Cup match is a move by the San Diego Yacht Club to gain a tactical advantage, Bruce Farr, designer of New Zealand's yacht challenger, said yesterday.

title: VOLUNTEER ROLES FOR RETIRED EXECUTIVES
description: LEAD: WHEN Roger Newburger of White Plains retired after a career in newspapers and publishing, he thought he was sufficiently prepared for the free time that stretched before him.

title: Town Is Heir to Land And Mystery: Where?
description: Woonsocket has fallen heir to a parcel of land in New England that may be worth up to $500,000. But the Boston-based company that advised the city of its inheritance has declined to say where the land is.

title: For a Very Sizable Majority More Than Enough Politics
description: There are many here who refer to this week as ''the end of the world.'' The candidates will stop talking to animals and will fly East. The reporters will stop caring that Iowa is the Jell-O-eating capital of the country, and will stop buying products of the new political tourist industry, like ''Ski Iowa'' T-shirts and ''Weak-End in Des Moines'' lingerie.

title: TOXIC ASH
description: THE $237 million garbage-to-energy plant in Peekskill has become one focus of a national debate over the proper handling of toxic ash.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Free Needles for Addicts; Experts Find Fault in New City AIDS Plan
description: WHEN the Cuomo Administration decided last week to let New York City give clean needles to drug addicts, it may have seemed like a bold new step to stem the spread of AIDS. But in the days that followed, the experimental program drew criticism and questions from a wide range of drug abuse experts who said the project will be plagued by problems.

title: High Praises for the Difficult Daphnes
description: LEAD: GARDENERS are expressing new interest in daphnes and searching out these plants at local garden centers and in mail-order catalogues. In a way this new interest is ironic, for Daphne Mezereum was one of the first plants imported to the New World by homesick English settlers.

title: ABC's $309 Million Package: 90 Hours, Three Weekends
description: TELEVISING the Olympics is only slightly less complicated than staging them.

title: Aide Seeks to Hasten Repairs For Hazardous Queens Road
description: A state transportation official has promised to speed up repair plans for a stretch of road that accounted for almost half the car accidents and injuries last year on the Whitestone Expressway in Queens.

title: Jazz: Cecil Taylor Quintet
description: FRANTIC, unpredictable, turbulent and - out of nowhere - harmonious, Cecil Taylor's music mirrors urban life in all its hyperactive sprawl. The pianist brought a new quintet to a packed Knitting Factory Thursday through last night; his Bosendorfer concert grand was squeezed onto the tiny stage along with Thurman Barker's drums and vibraphone and William Parker's bass. The quintet, with Leo Smith on trumpet and fluegelhorn and Carlos Ward on alto saxophone and flute, occasionally used a steady beat and a shared melody amid Mr. Taylor's usual torrent of music.

title: Boston Vista Clouded
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM BACH TO BACHELOR BALL
description: An Evening With Bach

title: Perception Vs. Reality In Iowa
description: Now it begins. Vice president Bush and Dan Rather were only prelude. Tomorrow night, television gets down to the real stuff. Who will win the Iowa caucuses? The candidates with the most votes, you say? Strictly speaking, that's true, but on television that's only part of the story. The other part has to do with perception. The real winners tomorrow night may be the candidates who run second or third. Recent history suggests the ineluctable appeal of the horse race. Anchors and correspondents grow restive with a sure thing; they want a little action. Iowa Republicans and Democrats will determine one set of winners. Anchors and correspondents, if they choose, will determine another. We may have trouble telling the two apart.

title: PACE IS PICKING UP FOR THE PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI
description: THE Philharmonia Virtuosi took January off, but February finds the ensemble back in concert action on this and the following two Sundays. Today at 3 P.M., Cyprien Katsaris is the featured soloist at the State University of New York at Purchase, with the brilliant French pianist tackling two great concertos, the Liszt A major and Beethoven's Third.

title: Pentagon AIDS Testing Finds 5,890 Infected
description: More than two years after starting an extensive screening program for infection with the AIDS virus, the Defense Department has tested nearly four million people and has identified 5,890 who carry the deadly virus.

title: Albany Notes; Cuomo Pushes Challenge To Salaries at Authorities
description: Governor Cuomo this week stepped up his campaign against the salaries at public authorities, calling them excessive and demanding that the authorities bring them under control.

title: Vindicated Bolsheviks
description: ' Of course, we can't return their lives, but this is a very noble deed. '

title: Aids in Justice System: Searching for Fairness
description: It was more than a question that Marvin Schecter posed. It was a scenario that he painted.

title: NORIEGA: A SKILLED DEALER WITH U.S.
description: For more than a decade, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military leader, played off United States Government agencies against each other and against other countries in a dizzying succession of alliances and betrayals.

title: Concert: Australian Orchestra
description: FOUNDED in 1975, the Australian Chamber Orchestra maintains an active schedule at home in Sydney, plays elsewhere in Australia and has toured Asia and Europe. But its current 16-city swing through the United States is its first in this hemisphere. A part of the Australian bicentennial celebrations, the tour brought the orchestra Friday night to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: IN HARTFORD, THE BEST AND WORST OF TIMES
description: LEAD: HARTFORD welcomed the new session of the General Assembly this month as a city in the midst of an immense building boom. Ground is soon to be broken for the tallest building in New England. The vacancy rate for office space is one of the lowest in the nation, Yet despite the new buildings, the general business health and the civic pride, Hartford has the lowest per capita income - $8,677 - in the state, according to recently released Federal Census Bureau estimates.

title: Photo of Don Harrelson with adopted sons, Doug and Jon, in 1980 Gay Couples' Wish to Adopt Grows, Along With Increasing Resistance
description: They live in a quiet residential neighborhood in San Francisco, a professional couple in their late 30's, with two adopted daughters, 5 and 2 years old. ''Our kids play with the neighbors' kids,'' said one of the parents. ''We swap recipes and borrow tools from the people next door. We're just another family.'' The couple, lesbian partners of 10 years, could not be called an average family, even in San Francisco, with its large openly gay population.

title: CHANCE ENCOUNTER WITH BITTER CHILDHOOD MEMORIES
description: HE CAME out of the elevator - dumpy, sixtyish, hair still dirty blond - and the shock of recognition went through me. It had been 15 years since I had seen him, nearly 20 since we shared the same household, and I no longer saw through the eyes of a boy.

title: Thomas Gibbons, 83, Of Philadelphia Police
description: Thomas J. Gibbons, who was Philadelphia's first Police Commissioner under the City Charter that was adopted in the early 1950's, died here Friday after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

title: View of the White House From the Nofziger Trial
description: The Federal ethics trial of Lyn Nofziger, now entering its fifth week, has provided a revealing glimpse at the ready access to high Reagan Administration officials that was granted to former aides who return as lobbyists.

title: Q AND A
description: Swiss Glasses Question:In a television program about the Swiss mountain railroads, I noticed the use of wineglasses with bent stems, designed so the contents would always remain level as the train ascends. Where can I obtain some of this glassware? - G. R., Alexandria, Va. Answer:The tilted wineglasses are used on the Glacier Express, which runs between St. Moritz and Zermatt, and the Swiss say they can be obtained only from the Swiss Dining Car Company. This is the company that supplies Swiss trains with glassware and china. The glasses cost 11 Swiss francs, or about $8, each. (Swiss Dining Car Company, CH-4601, Olten, Switzerland; telephone: 062-261026.) Olten, near Basel, is not on the Glacier Express route.

title: Legends Live Up To Their Billing
description: It started out as a nice game with everybody trying to be polite and allowing his teammate to get a shot. But the N.B.A. Legends Classic ended up resembling a regular-season game today, and it ended in sudden-death overtime.

title:
GARDENING;
PROTECTING PLANTS DURING THE WINTER
description: LEAD: PLANTS that survive the average winter unharmed may succumb to that one winter in 10 or 20 years when the temperature drops well below the normal low.

title: WHAT'S WHAT, WHO'S WHO, WHERE IT HAPPENS... AND KEEP AN EYE ON THOSE SKIERS CARRYING RIFLES
description: IN the early years of the Winter Olympics, the most successful athletes were mainly skiers and skaters from the northern European belt of Norway, Sweden and Finland. Then the Soviet Union joined the Olympic movement and started winning winter medals. Then East Germany did the same.

title: Guides to the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'WALLENBERG AT 75' Harvey Rosenfeld, the author of ''Raoul Wallenberg: Angel of Rescue,'' will give a talk in Hartford tomorrow about the Swedish businessman who ran an underground from Germany to England during World War II and saved many Jews from the Holocaust, The talk is titled ''Raoul Wallenberg at 75: The Unresolved Question.'' Wallenberg was arrested by Soviet officials in 1945 on charges of spying for the United States, and he reportedly died while still imprisoned 12 years later. There have been numerous reports, however, that he may still be alive.

title: Eye of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Mixing Uses; Greenwich Project
description: Choosing a clean sweep rather than a renovation of the 10-acre industrial complex, Arthur Collins and James R. Psaki began demolition last November of a former Electrolux factory in Old Greenwich, Conn. Next month construction will begin on a mixed-use development to take its place. The $75 million project on Forest Avenue will include a four-story office building, scheduled for completion in the fall of 1989, as well as 167 low-rise condominium units and a recreation center. Across the street, the developers have already begun construction of 24 single-family houses on the vacuum cleaner manufacturer's seven-acre parking lot.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: PROGRAMS ARE MANY AND AT THE SAME TIME
description: THIS will be another week of competing events. Today alone, there is a dance program at 2 P.M., a violin recital at 2:30, five solo or chamber concerts at 3 and seven recitals with 4 o'clock starts.

title: What's Doing in Cairo
description: From the 900-year-old walls that once marked the northern boundary of Cairo stretch the remains of a city many tourists never see. Graceful minarets still punctuate its horizon like exclamation points, while in the narrow streets below, men in turbans and striped robes sell onions, garlic and lemons from donkey-drawn carts.

title: New York's Cabaret Scene, Ertegun Style
description: A record set called ''New York Cabaret Music'' (Atlantic LP 81817-1, six disks; CD 81817-2) is both more and less than that title might suggest. There has been cabaret music of one sort or another in New York for decades, but this collection deals primarily with the 1950's. Even more specifically, it reflects the tastes and interests, personal and business, of the Ertegun Brothers, as indicated by its subtitle, ''The Erteguns' New York.''

title: A GRANDDAUGHTER LEAVES CHILDHOOD BEHIND
description: I DIDN'T cry when my grandfather died. This man had taken me in, loved me and did the job his son couldn't do, but when he died I didn't cry. His death wasn't a sad death or a shocking death. It was a long time coming: he was a long time going. We called it senility back then. But for those last five years, he had been in steady decline. In the beginning it was annoying. He would pile telephone books on the kitchen table and look up the names of people dead 20 years. He'd be angry that they weren't home when he called.

title: Two Years Make A Short Lifetime
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?

title: Body and Mind; Too Much of a Good Thing
description: WHEN A NEW acquaintance told me not long ago that he runs five miles every day, I felt jealous and ashamed (I jog only three miles, three times a week) and vowed to step up my program. Only later, and with some effort, did I remind myself that I jog as much as current medical opinion says is needed to keep my heart and lungs fit. Dr. Harvey Simon of the Harvard Cardiovascular Health Center, for one, recommends 20 to 30 minutes of aerobic exercise three times a week, at 75 percent of maximal pulse rate for one's age. So more jogging than I'm doing might not be better for me, but worse. For exceeding recommended amounts of almost all prescribed health practices, from the rigorous to the most innocuous exercise programs and beneficial diets, poses definite health risks.

title: Cabaret: Marlene VerPlanck
description: LOVE songs are normally an inevitable part of a cabaret singer's repertory, but Marlene Ver Planck has built her entire program at Dannys' Skylight Room (346 West 46th Street) on songs that trace the ups and downs of a love affair.

title: DNA 'Fingerprinting' Tests Becoming a Factor in Courts
description: Landmark discoveries of the 1970's in DNA and genetic engineering have begun creeping into the world of the courts and criminal evidence.

title: Laura Louise Foster; Artist, 70
description: Laura Louise Foster, a botanical artist, died last Sunday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. She was 70 years old and lived in Falls Village, Conn.

title: AMY ROBIN FIER ENGAGED
description: Amy Robin Fier, an associate in the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson in Washington, and Baruch Gitlin, a second-year student at the Georgetown University Law Center, plan to marry in April. Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Fier of New York have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Gitlin of North Massapequa, L.I.
