Ms. Fier is a graduate of the Columbia Preparatory School, New York University and the Brooklyn Law School. Her fiance graduated from the University of Virginia.

title: Subtle Interpretations Of the Beethoven Trios
description: Many first-rate recordings of Beethoven's complete trios have become available in recent years, and to these may now be added the cycle by the Borodin Trio, containing the basic six (the three of Op. 1, the two of Op. 70 and Op. 97), two sets of variations and several rarely heard early works. All are available on a set of four Chandos compact disks (CHAN 8352/3/4/5; also on LP and cassette).

title: What Is Being Lost
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: KEEPING SECRETS. By Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $17.95.) The television star Suzanne Somers, best known for her role as the blond bimbo in ''Three's Company,'' might seem to be a woman with a large wardrobe of shorty pajamas and nary a thought, let alone a care. Not so. Suzanne Somers is the adult child of an alcoholic.

title: CHINA'S MODERN MASTERS
description: IN THE LIBRARY OF A 23-ROOM apartment on Fifth Avenue, four blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a rug that was once in the emperor's quarters in Beijing's Forbidden Palace. Somehow, during the turbulent years following the Opium War of 1839-42, the rug was removed from the palace and, some decades later, found its way into the hands of an American pilot who had brought a single-engine plane to China, offering his air-freight services to opium traffickers. A grateful client had given the pilot the emperor's rug, which he eventually sold to Robert Hatfield Ellsworth - a noted Oriental art dealer and the owner of the Fifth Avenue apartment - because he knew of no one else who would dare put it on his floor.

title: Trident Missile Explodes in Launching Test
description: An unarmed Trident 1 nuclear missile exploded today 18 seconds after it was launched from a submarine in a test off the coast of central Florida, the Navy said.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: QUECHEE, VT.;
Small Town, Big Project
description: LEAD: TWENTY years ago developers looked at the woods and the pastures around this small central Vermont village and proposed construction of the largest vacation-home development in New England.

title: Israelis Storm Home of West Bank Clan
description: The intrusion was the sort of blurred moment, of off-the-street barrages of rocks and bullets, when the seeds of middle-class vendetta are being sewn amid the spirited villagers of the Palestinian protest.

title: A TALE OF TWO CITIES, SNOW AND ALL
description: HERE in Scarsdale we manage to keep in touch with the world, and when I learned that they had had nearly 12 inches of snow in Washington, it gave me an excuse to call William. Even though I am nearly 20 times his age, there is a bond between us - his mother, my daughter. He answered the phone himself. ''Hi, William. What's doing there?'' I asked.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-22

title: A CHALLENGE FOR HEALTH CARE
description: SEVEN months ago, New Jersey's health-care community received a challenge: to develop innovative and unique approaches to the state's most pressing health-care problems.

title: MISS EASTWICK TO WED DAVID L. ALLEN IN JUNE
description: Jennifer Louise Eastwick and David Lawrence Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Allen of Westbury, L.I., plan to marry in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Eastwick of Pittstown, N.Y., and Ludlow, Vt., have announced.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
CLOSING TIME
description: LEAD: THIS is not the saga of a longtime neighborhood pub forced out of business. Four generations of a family had not worked at the bar and there was no problem meeting the rent. Chase Landing had recessed lighting and terra cotta floors, pate and steak au poivre. The restaurant was open for only five years, and its recent sale to a real estate company netted the owners more $1.5 million in profit, one of the owners said.

title: Seeing London on a Tight Budget
description: LONDON may be dreary and drizzly in winter but it tingles with the excitement of concerts and theater and things to do. Question: Can an American enjoy an inexpensive holiday there with the dollar so sick? Answer: Yes, but you have to work at it.

title: OLD SAGG BRIDGE GETTING REPRIEVE
description: THE final chapter in a five-year dispute between Suffolk County officials and local residents over the fate of the aging Sagg Bridge, which has spanned Sagaponack Pond for 65 years, is being written.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Convent Station $312,000 13 Weathervane Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; porch, central air-conditioning, 2-car attached garage; taxes $3,087. South Orange $278,000 279 Beech Spring Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 44-year-old Tudor; fireplace, den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,318. Sparta $241,000 646 Glen Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, whirlpool in master bath, deck; taxes $3,486. Springfield $170,000 165 South Springfield Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, patio, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $2,369. Tenafly $250,000 416 Briarwood Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old split level; Florida room, full basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,645. West Orange $207,500 41 Clonover Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; central air-conditioning, fireplace, den, terrace; taxes $3,105. OTHER AREAS Syosset, L.I. $395,000 11 Wilshire Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; den, family room, .05 acre; taxes $5,400. Old Lyme, Conn. $220,000 22 Champlain Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, cul-de-sac, 1 acre; taxes unavailable. Bronxville, N.Y. $867,500 28 Homesdale Road 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 66-year-old stucco/frame Tudor-Norman; eat-in kitchen, den, walk to train, schools and stores; taxes $10,346.

title:
GARDENING;
PROTECTING PLANTS DURING THE WINTER
description: LEAD: PLANTS that survive the average winter unharmed may succumb to that one winter in 10 or 20 years when the temperature drops well below the normal low.

title: Steve Reich, Back When
description: LEAD: Although it may be hard to believe, Minimalism in music is a movement that is well over two decades old. And, whether one is a devotee or a detractor, it cannot be denied that Minimalism has invigorated the new-music scene in many positive ways. Steady pulse, tonal center, repetition, vernacular references - all have become acceptable once again, partly as a result of the defiant radicalism of Minimalism's first generation.

title: NEW CABARET DUO SINGS THE OLDIES
description: TAKING a giant step away from the traditional theatrical fare it produces so well, Long Island Stage is presenting John Wallowitch and Bertram Ross in a cabaret act called ''Back on the Town.'' This elegant and intimate show is a sophisticated musical routine during which these two urbane and talented men woo their audience with renditions of such rarely heard delights as Irving Berling's ''Cohen Owes Me $97.''

title: Policeman Gets Reprimand For Giving Shelter in Snow
description: The General Services Administration has reprimanded a Federal policeman who gave refuge in a snowstorm to a homeless man who has been living on the steps of the Federal courthouse here for much of the last eight years.

title: Taking Back
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye apparently is a sensitive kind of guy. The Hawaii Democrat said last week that he was ''hurt and angered'' when critics accused him of ''sneaking'' a measure through Congress that channeled $8 million to a campaign contributor's pet project. The $8 million, attached to a huge spending bill that was rushed through Congress in December, was to support the Jewish education of North African refugees in France. Mr. Inouye denied that he had pushed the measure through as a favor to a campaign contributor, Zev Wolfson, who is on the board of the organization that operates the refugee schools. While maintaining that he had done nothing improper, the Senator nevertheless asked that the appropriation be rescinded. Dragging the matter out ''would risk a further loss of public confidence in the Senate,'' he said.

title: AT A MINIMUM
description: AN EXPANSIVE GREEN-house that overlooks Manhattan in Alfred Hitchcock's 1948 movie ''Rope'' so inspired Jon Weiser, president of Charivari Men's, that he obtained a production still to show Shigeru Uchida, the Japan-based interior designer who had begun to renovate Weiser's new apartment. To Uchida, the views were intriguing and the space vast by Japanese standards. Yet the designer knew immediately how to create the kind of modern environment his client wanted. ''When people think of Japanese style, they still conjure up images of Shoji screens or Madam Butterfly,'' says Weiser. ''Today's Japanese esthetic is as sleek as their electronics.''

title: INCEST VICTIMS NEED MORE THAN SYMPATHY
description: Bravo to those quoted in the article ''Incest Victims Get Sympathy but Little Help'' [ Jan. 10 ] for having the courage to say what so many clinicians feel about our system of helping, be it legal or institutional. The system does not work.

title:
GARDENING;
They're Special Any Time
description: LEAD: WHAT makes heaths and heathers so special is their ability to transform a winter landscape into a springlike garden. Brush away snow from certain varieties of heath and you will find their evergreen stems covered with bell-shaped blossoms in red, pink, purple or white. Heathers, though they produce no winter flowers, offer vivid foliage.

title: PERSPECTIVES: City-Assisted Housing; Mixed-Income Condo Nears Completion
description: A SALES program is under way in the Towers on the Park condominium at the northwest corner of Central Park, at the edge of Harlem, and it is demonstrating a new concept in producing high-rise housing with government assistance for people of moderate to middle income.

title: Which Way Will Kennedy Tilt the Bench?
description: FOR all the bipartisan praise heaped upon Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the Senate's 97-to-0 confirmation of his nomination last week ushered in a period of uncertainty about the Supreme Court's direction.

title: IN BUSINESS, U.S. SAYS DONALD IS TRUMP
description: Donald J. Trump has built a business empire on his name. He calls his company the Trump Organization. Its home is Trump Tower. His fanciest condominium project bears the name Trump Parc. He owns casinos in Atlantic City called Trump Plaza and Trump's Castle.

title: Workers to Register
description: WHEN large employers sponsor voter registration drives for their workers, the number of new registrants can be as large as the voting population of an entire small town. The Nationwide Insurance Companies, with 14 regional offices, has registered or reregistered an average of 3,000 voters a year since 1984.

title: New Yorkers Lauded For Work to Improve City's Quality of Life
description: The Citizens Committee for New York City has chosen three prominent New Yorkers and five neighborhood organizations to receive its annual awards for ''enhancing the quality of life in New York City.''

title: DARCY MILLER, MAGAZINE PUBLISHER, WED TO JAMES R. DONALDSON 3D, A PRODUCER
description: Darthea Mary Miller, publisher of Chief Executive magazine, a bimonthly Macfadden publication, and James Robertson Donaldson 3d, a film director and producer, were married yesterday at the Explorers Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Richard E. Spalding, the pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church in Manhattan and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: LOTTERY PRIZE IS AFFORDABLE HOMES
description: LEAD: ROBERT and Deborah Donohue of Montauk were elated when they were among the winners of East Hampton's housing lottery in December. That meant they could acquire an affordable house on Long Island.

title: RAPE-CRISIS PROGRAM TO OPEN
description: LEAD: A NEW rape-crisis program aimed at providing emotional support to victims of sexual crimes will be instituted by the Putnam-Northern Westchester Women's Resource Center in Mahopac. The service will supplement a three-year-old ''intervention'' program run by the Victims Assistance Services in White Plains.

title: COZY, CHARMING AND IMAGINATIVE
description: AS I glided through Bellport last fall on my bike, I got a glimpse of a white frame 19th-century charmer. It was called the Old Inlet Inn. Was this a find? Would the food live up to the exterior charm?

title: TOO FAR, TOO FAST
description: In the middle of an analytical article on John Gutfreund, you inserted a full page on his wife, Susan, and her ''high living.'' What in the world has her living style to do with the way her husband runs Salomon? Wasn't the Gutfreund story designed to give us insights into the excesses of Wall Street, not Givenchy? EDWARD EHRENBERG Chicago

title: WESLEYAN EXHIBITS BIBLICAN PRINTS AND HARLEM PHOTOGRAPHS
description: THE story of the Holy Family's flight into Egypt is not one of the Bible's cliffhangers - St. Matthew devotes but three or four verses to it. Nevertheless, the tale becomes endearing and often quite dramatic, as it is told in the print show that is one of the two current attractions at the Davison Art Center at Wesleyan University.

title: Warming Up in the Wings: A Revival of 1970's Rock
description: A 1960'S REVIVAL IS gusting through rock. Musicians and critics are jostling one another to praise the human scale and anything-goes spirit of 1960's rock; college radio stations can play hours of recent music in which the hoarse vocals and garage-band production are virtually indistinguishable from the ''Nuggets'' collections (on Rhino Records) of half-forgotten 1960's singles. Yet even as the 1960's revival hits the big time, its sequel is brewing.

title: WENDY MUNOZ TO WED DR. ANDREW J. LERRICK
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Munoz of Freehold, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Munoz, to Dr. Andrew James Lerrick, a son of Mrs. Robert Lerrick of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Dr. Lerrick. A September wedding is planned.

title: In Central America, Trying To Deal With New Realities
description: THE House vote against aid to the contras reflects another sharp swing in Washington's attitude toward Central America, leaving the region wondering what will come next. No one pretends really to know.

title: Legislation to Help Alaska Natives Keep Land
description: A measure that has been signed into law by President Reagan gives Alaska's 85,000 Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts a fighting chance to keep native lands and other wealth in native hands, several of their leaders say.

title: JULIE BREENE TO MARRY WILLIAM T. ZIEBOLD JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. James K. Breene Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Warren, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie Brodie Breene to William Townsend Ziebold Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ziebold of Charleston, W.Va., and Hot Springs, Va. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: MANHUNTING, IN AN ARMCHAIR
description: The line between en-tertainment and news will be stretched a smidgen thinner beginning tonight, when Fox's fledgling network launches a weekly series called ''America's Most Wanted,'' described by its producers as ''a televised manhunt'' intended to enlist the public's help in the capture of fugitives.

title: Malle Confronts Haunting Memory
description: His name appears, at one moment, to be Jean Kippelstein - already a sign of a mixed identity - even though his classmates knew him as Jean Bonnet, teasing him for being a ''bonnet de nuit,'' a nightcap. The historical fact is that he was neither Kippelstein nor Bonnet. His real name was Hans Helmut Michel, and he was born in Frankfurt, Germany, on June 6, 1930. Little Hans played the piano and was the brightest boy in his class at the Petit College d'Avon, about 50 miles south of Paris, where he was given his false identity and hidden from Nazi persecution by the French priests there. One bright day in January 1944, the Gestapo barged into his classroom to take him away, and within a few weeks, after one of those nightmarish train rides that took place in Europe in those days, he arrived at Auschwitz, where he died.

title: Tibetan Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: DISCO GIRL AND THE VATICAN
description: HE GOT HUNGRY AND FORGOT HIS MANNERS A Fable. By Jimmy Breslin. 275 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: AN EMPHASIS ON ABUNDANCE
description: WHAT memories are supposed to be triggered, one muses, crossing the threshold of Memories Cafe in Stamford? Perhaps it is the live music heard nightly from 8:30 to about 11:30 that is intended to induce them.

title:
FILM;
Meryl Streep as an Accused Murderer
description: LEAD: Meryl Streep Stands be-side a sweltering glass phone booth in a street in the northern Australian town of Darwin.

title: Back to the 30's in the Deco District
description: LEAD: OLD Miami Beach at twilight, when the big Caribbean cruise ships are passing, is just the sort of place William Powell and Myrna Loy would visit on holiday. The Atlantic extends to the horizon, the moon is round and pale and beginning to show. A combo plays Gershwin at one of the small Art Deco hotels along the beachfront, and waiters lay down linens and silver at the Carlyle Grill.

title: Film
description: With the weather outside somewhat frosty, a welcome warning trend has settled into several theaters. ''Distant Harmony,'' at the Carnegie Hall Cinema (Seventh Avenue at 57th Street), gives us Luciano Pavarotti conquering and being conquered by China, during his 1986 tour with the cast of ''La Boheme.'' The merging of Italian grand opera and traditional Chinese music is done with tact and wit, and along with such agreeable potboilers as ''O Sole Mio'' and ''Torna a Surriento,'' we get a pleasant tour of Beijing. The Chinese audiences' excitement over Mr. Pavarotti's high notes and his expansive response to the music of his hosts sends the good-will thermometer way up. It's as satisfying as a big bowl of pasta - or a Mongolian hot pot.

title: DETROIT'S STRANGE BEDFELLOWS
description: OBSERVERS OF THE auto industry were not optimistic when the United Automobile Workers and General Motors sat down last July to negotiate a new three-year contract. G.M., its share of the domestic car market falling, was seeking to shrink its work force. The U.A.W., battered by layoffs, was equally intent on preserving jobs. To many analysts, a strike seemed a real possibility.

title: Paying Back
description: Anthony M. Frank, a successful California executive who came to the United States as a child when his parents fled Nazi Germany, figures he owes America something.

title: Art
description: One of the most distinguished exhibitions to have been mounted in recent years by a dealer's gallery is the loan show of 44 oil paintings, drawings and gouaches by Piet Mondrian that can be seen at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street, through Saturday.

title: Naming of Doctor in Mercy Death Is Resisted
description: The American Medical Association says only a court order could force it to disclose the identity of a physician who wrote an essay about injecting a terminally ill patient with a lethal dose of morphine.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
description: Free? Look what Jack Clark and Kirk Gibson just got for salaries! Seems expensive to me. RICHARD COWIT Farmingville, L.I.

title: Army Says Germ Warfare Lab Would Be Safe
description: The Army says it can build a laboratory in Utah to experiment with defenses against germ warfare without posing a threat to the public or environment.

title:
ART;
VISIONS OF RAW GRANDEUR
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND'S art museums enjoy a history of cooperative interchange, and two of them, the Heckscher Museum in Huntington and the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, have a particularly strong relationship. Founded by individual philanthropists for the benefit of those communities, both museums boast impressive collections of late 19th-century and early 20th-century American paintings, highlights of which are now on view at the

title: CAROLYN CONANT TO WED MICHAEL WYATT HILEY
description: Carolyn Marree Conant and Michael Wyatt Hiley, a son of Mrs. Robert Langford of Morristown, N.J., and David B. Hiley of Katonah, N.Y., plan to marry in July, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Conant of New Providence, N.J., have announced.

title: LABOR LAW: TWO LAWYERS, TWO VIEWS
description: ROY BARNES, a union labor lawyer, calls them ''union busters.'' But Patrick L. Vaccaro, the managing partner of the White Plains office of the law firm of Jackson Lewis Schnitzler & Krupman, said: ''That's a union cop-out. That's a term they use for any firm that counsels management.''

title: Looking Back
description: What did Martin Heidegger think about the Nazis, and when did he think it? Debate over the German philosopher's Nazi past was rekindled in France recently with the publication of a new book, ''Heidegger and Nazism,'' by a former student, Victor Farias. Mr. Farias produces evidence that Heidegger, whose thinking has had widespread influence on postwar intellectual life in France, was no mere dabbler in Hitlerian politics, as his apologists maintained after the war. Rather, says Mr. Farias, Heidegger remained an enthusiastic, dues-paying Nazi until 1945, praising Hitler and denouncing his colleagues for being too sympathetic to Jews. Heidegger admirers have leaped to the philosopher's defense. Francois Fedier, a philosopher and Heidegger fan, accused Mr. Farias of producing a ''shameful falsification.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Holyoke, Mass.;
One Victorian For 6 Condos
description: LEAD: WHEN Leslie Clement first saw the Cleary-Fitzgerald home in 1986, it had been vacant and on the market for almost a year. The 24-room, 97-year-old Victorian sits on the fringes of the city's faded downtown.

title: America Is Running Out of Time
description: AMERICA can't compete.

title: Being Fired
description: To the Editor:

title: Ghost Bands Very Much Alive
description: Back in the 60's, Woody Her-man was asked if the big bands would ever come back. His answer was blunt: ''No.''

title: 86-Game Slump Ends
description: The University of Dallas ended its 86-game losing streeak today, beating John Brown University by 76-68. The streak was the longest ever by a four-year college.

title: Guides to the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: GERMANY AND THE GERMANS: An Anatomy of Society Today. By John Ardagh. (Harper & Row, $24.95.) Like John Gunther's ''Inside . . .'' series, John Ardagh's book about Germany may be of some use to those readers who have absolutely no idea at all about the subject being dealt with. Like Gunther, Mr. Ardagh (the author of ''France in the 1980s'') leans heavily on information garnered from tourist boards. There is much quoting of statistics and polls about everything from employment to sexual attitudes. Unlike Gunther's books, ''Germany and the Germans'' offers no photographs, thereby forcing us to focus entirely on the text - and Mr. Ardagh's observations range from the merely naive to the dangerously foolish. The author breezily addresses many historical topics, with headings like ''Buoyant Berlin, the Survivor That Came in From the Cold.'' The tone is sometimes sappily optimistic, like a tourist brochure, even when discussing such grave subjects as the destruction of Germany's forests by air pollution and the problems of Turkish immigrants. As for the inevitable discussion of Nazis, past and present, the author's soft-pedaling of anything negative achieves shocking results. He speaks of a historical ''brighter side of this picture'' - for example, a few dozen Nazi war criminals received life sentences (most were later pardoned). Then he hastens to pooh-pooh the notion of neo-Nazism, describing it ''insofar as it does exist.'' Germans reading this inadequate effort might be astonished to learn that they are living in paradise.

title: Thomas B. Lamb, 91, an Inventor, Industrial Designer and Cartoonist
description: Thomas Babbitt Lamb, an inventor and industrial designer, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Carolton Manor convalescent home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 91 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: '88 RACE: ISLAND'S CONGRESS DELEGATION IS SPLIT
description: LEAD: AS the nation gets set for the first test of Presidential politics, tomorrow's Iowa precinct caucuses, members of Long Island's Congressional delegation are splintered on their support of candidates.

title: MOIRA VOSS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Voss of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Moira Damaris Voss, to Rene Garcia-Grayre, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raul Garcia-Grayre of Brooklyn. Ms. Voss, a graduate of Hampshire College and an intern at the Actors' Fund, is studying at Columbia University for a master's degree in social work. Her father is the news editor of The Daily News. Mr. Garcia-Grayre, who attended Hunter College, is a sculptor.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; A Superstore Rises in Tiny Edgewater
description: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

title: Jazz: The Art Farmer-Clifford Jordan Group
description: MAINSTREAM jazz - now essentially bebop - may be the most deceptive of all the kinds of music played under the name of jazz. It has staid connotations: middle-aged musicians play music demarcated by a rigid set of harmonic and rhythmic rules; not much goes on formally, and musicians prize a logical narrative flow, with a minimum of abstraction.

title: Director With a Trans-Atlantic Touch
description: Although he lives in London and directs an English company, in the last few years Max Stafford-Clark has become almost as frequent a presence in the New York theater as the most ubiquitous American director. Since 1982, when Mr. Stafford-Clark talked Joseph Papp into an exchange program between his own British group, the Royal Court Theater, and Mr. Papp's Public Theater, the enterprising Englishman has directed a production here every year.

title: 'ART INTO PRODUCTION'
description: Before the Revolution of 1917, Russian artists were already experimenting with radical visual vocabularies based on abstraction and geometric forms. The pioneers of Suprematism and later Constructivism further championed a new marriage of ''art and life.'' After the Revolution, artists such as Alexander Rodchenko, Vladimir Mayakovsky, Liubov Popova and El Lissitzky actively participated in advertising the virtues of their new society. But they were not simply servants of party politics; they applied their talents to improving Russian industry. The goal of the Productivist artists, as the avant-gardists became known, was to imbue material culture with a new beauty. As Elena Chernevich, a teacher at the Moscow Polygraphic Institute, writes in SOVIET COMMERCIAL DESIGN OF THE TWENTIES (Abbeville, $37.50), ''Art . . . was to be replaced by design, and design not for an elite but for the lives of the masses.'' A new slogan, ''Art into production,'' defined the idea that Russian applied artists had a role in restyling a variety of industrial products and, just as important, the advertising used to sell them. This required a new typography and layout style that completely rejected traditional symmetry and ornament in favor of more reductive and objective graphic forms. Until the publication of this book - edited and designed by the graphic artist Mikhail Anikst and translated by Catherine Cooke - few Westerners were aware of the wide range of Soviet advertising. This exciting material provides a fascinating look at accouterments of consumer culture before Stalin's socialist realism returned advertising design to an unimaginative state.

title: Capital Gains Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: At South Pole, Tourists and Cigarette Butts
description: Chalk up another point for inevitability: tourists have set foot on the South Pole.

title: AMBUSHED IN THE CACAO GROVES
description: LEAD: SHOWDOWN By Jorge Amado. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. 422 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: CECILY A. STEWART TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Norman W. Stewart and Dr. Ann Roberts Stewart of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cecily Ann Stewart to Dr. James Frederick Whiting, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Whiting of Binghamton, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
DINING OUT;
ANOTHER ATTEMPT IN BERNARDSVILLE
description: LEAD: THE BERNARDS INN, which is opposite the railroad station in the Somerset County town of Bernardsville, has gone through many changes since it was built in 1907.

title: In the Philippines, The Politics of Turmoil Casts A Murky Shadow Over the Arts
description: The major artistic creation of the Philippines today is a passion play in which a simple widow challenges a dictator she believes killed her husband, and leads her nation to freedom. In its second act, the widow, as president, faces down a series of violent challenges, clinging perilously to power as the forces of darkness struggle to reassert themselves.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
description: My response to the question - Are free agents free again in baseball? - is: Is anyone free? MICHAEL HASDAY Scarsdale, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
PROTECTING PLANTS DURING THE WINTER
description: LEAD: PLANTS that survive the average winter unharmed may succumb to that one winter in 10 or 20 years when the temperature drops well below the normal low.

title: CONNOTATIONS OF 'BLACK' HELD TO BE NONRACIAL
description: The McClean article represents another tiresome assault on English usage by people who should know better.

title: CARMEN MARIA FIAL IS WED
description: At St. Andrew's the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, Carmen Maria Fial, the daughter of Walter F. Fial of Baltimore and the late Carmen S. Fial, was married yesterday to Hans-Jurgen Sund, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Sund of Osterode, West Germany. The Rev. Edward J. Kiernan performed the ceremony. Mrs. Sund was, until recently, an assistant branch manager with Citicorp in New York and Los Angeles. Her husband, a pastry chef at Windows on the World in Manhattan, is a widower.

title: Tipping at Sea
description: To the Editor: ''Calming the Jitters About Tipping on Cruises'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 1) was timely. Some crew members on our recent Royal Caribbean Cruise Line cruise seemed to receive virtually no monetary remuneration, only uniforms, bed and board. With such an arrangement, company loyalty is minimal, and the caveat regarding personal effects (stressed by the cruise line) becomes more significant.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HEALTH GROUP EXPANDING
description: LEAD: The American Health Foundation, a nonprofit organization known for its research in preventive medicine, will be taking some measures this year to enhance its own well-being.

title: PLAN TO TAP FUND SPLITS LAWMAKERS
description: SOME of Connecticut's lawmakers sounded like weather forecasters last week after Governor O'Neill unveiled his $6.3 billion budget proposal for the next fiscal year and recommended spending $73.8 million of the state's five-year old budget reserve, more commonly known as the ''rainy day fund.''

title: Grand Concourse
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW KITCHEN AND WHAT IT COOKED UP
description: NOW that our last child will be leaving home for college and our net worth is down approximately 40 percent since October's Black Monday, I have finally realized my dream - a magnificent new kitchen. Just a few thousand dollars more than the original purchase price of our house in 1970, the room has brought me all the obvious anticipated pleasures.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN GETTING OUT THE VOTE
description: IT'S far too early to tell whether voter turnout for the 1988 Presidential election will be greater than the 53.1 percent of eligible voters who turned out for the 1984 Presidential election. But if it is, a number of businesses will be able take some of the credit.

title: Broader Medicare Is Urged To Cover Long-Term Cases
description: Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for more than 31 million elderly and disabled people, should be expanded to cover much more of the cost of long-term care, including nursing homes and home health services, according to a major new study by experts at the Brookings Institution.

title: BILLINGS DAY MARRIED ON L.I.
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., B. Billings Day, a daughter of Mrs. Vincent C. Banker of Locust Valley and Richard W. Day of New York, was married yesterday to Bradford Delano Smith, a son of Mrs. Frank Y. Larkin of Greenwich, Conn., and David S. Smith of Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery, assisted by the Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ABBEY IN THE WOOD. By Antony Lambton. (Quartet/Salem House, $15.95.) Antony Lambton's second novel, which expands upon a mysterious fragment left by the German poet Heinrich Heine, manages to celebrate and criticize 19th-century Gothic Romanticism and spin a vivid tale in the process. Josepha (or ''Sefchen''), the young heroine, is born inside ''the ruins of an Abbey built in the perpendicular Gothic style.

title: TEMPLE OVERWHELMS RUTGERS
description: Mike Vreeswyk scored 21 points for Temple today as the Owls defeated Rutgers, 84-53. The Scarlet Knights set a school record by losing their 13th consecutive game.

title: 'STUDENT PRINCE' IS GIVEN A BRIEF RUN
description: TO fill the gap between two musical megahits - ''42d Street,'' which recently closed an extended engagement, and ''La Cage aux Folles,'' next month's attraction - ''The Student Prince'' has been brought into the Darien Dinner Theater for a spell.

title: EXILED IRANIANS PRESS A POLITICAL CAUSE FROM IRAQ
description: With a softened ideology and assertions of battlefield prowess, Iran's principal exiled opposition movement, crushed during the Islamic revolution, is seeking to project itself as a new force in this region's conflicts.

title: Near-Record Shootout
description: Bimbo Coles scored a career-high 51 points today, including a 3-point goal that started a decisive Virginia Tech run in the second overtime as the Hokies defeated Southern Mississippi, 141-133.

title: Mozambique is Weighing a Political End To Its War
description: A JOKE around this capital city has President Joaquim A. Chissano, Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan out for a sightseeing drive in Washington. President Reagan instructs the driver to keep turning right. Seeing that the car is going in circles, Mr. Gorbachev takes over. He tells the driver to keep turning left. Finally, President Chissano takes command. Signal left, he tells the driver, but turn right.

title: Fighting to Stop 'Killer' Bees
description: THE Bee Battle of Mexico has started, and the bees have won the first encounter without wasting a sting.

title: TROUBLED ENTREPRENEUR: Stuart Karl; From Fonda and Hart To Flops and Hot Water
description: AS he walked into the Beverly Hills Hotel one day in January 1984, Stuart Karl surely felt on top of the world.

title: ABANDONED PETS REMAIN A PROBLEM
description: LEAD: SOME people, say animal-shelter officials, view a pet as an inamimate object rather than as a living creature that feels cold, hunger and pain, making it easy for them to dump, in a rural area or by the side of a busy road, a pet that has outlived its welcome.

title: Second Drug Agent Is Dead After Ambush by Suspects
description: A Federal drug agent was pronounced dead today, a day after he was shot in an ambush by drug traffickers. Another agent and two suspects died in the shooting.

title: STREETSCAPES: Pioneer Warehouses; In Brooklyn, a Romanesque Revival Repository Complex
description: THE Pioneer warehouse complex, on Flatbush Avenue at the foot of Livingston Street in Brooklyn, has been a familiar sight for more than 75 years.

title: JOHN P. MORAN TO WED MARYE BUCKLEY IN JULY
description: The engagement of Marye Esther Buckley to John Patrick Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Moran of Massapequa Park, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Frederick O. Buckley of Marblehead Neck, Mass., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Denial of Female Guard's Promotion Upheld
description: A female deputy sheriff was properly denied a promotion to sergeant that would have placed her in an all-male wing of the Oneida County Jail, the Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, ruled this week.

title: Trains Collide Near Omaha
description: An Amtrak train carrying 190 passengers ran a red signal and collided with a Burlington Northern freight Thursday, slightly injuring 13 people, the authorities said. The accident occurred about 15 minutes after the passenger train had left Omaha for Chicago.

title: Dupes or Partners?
description: General Noriega forestalled American retaliation for years by playing Federal agencies off against one another and against other countries, American officials said.

title: Reagan to Work for Contra Aid Compromise
description: President Reagan said today that he would reject any Congressional alternative for aid to the Nicaraguan rebels ''that is little more than a disguise for surrender and abandonment.''

title: Islanders Stave Off Sabres' Threat
description: A bad scare, and a little embarrassment about surrendering a four-goal lead, prompted the Islanders to come up with two more goals and defeat the visiting Sabres.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's. The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it. Is this the way to correct the problem?

title: HIGH WIND, LOW TEMPERATURE AND SAILS
description: LEAD: WHEN others cringe at the prospect of falling temperatures and strong winds, New Jersey's ice sailors start packing their trailers and vans for a day or two of sport.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BEFORE LIFT-OFF: The Making of a Space Shuttle Crew. By Henry S. F. Cooper Jr. (Johns Hopkins University, $18.50.) In October 1984, seven American men and women orbited the earth for eight days on the space shuttle. Preparing for that week in space, the crew members had spent a year in training, not only running through all the difficult technical aspects of such an operation but also bonding together as a team.

title: IN '88, GUNNING FOR THE EARLY BIRD
description: LEAD: The suggestion that 1988 is going to be a strange year in the annals of Presidential politics is unlikely to produce much dissent. Yet one of the more unusual aspects of this year's election seems to have received little attention.

title: Overtired
description: THE PROBLEM HAS ALWAYS been what to do with them. One Minnesota plant turns them into a re-usable rubber compound. And, of course, they make good rope swings. There are an estimated 2 billion discarded tires in this country; about 40 million - the world's largest pile (above) - are near Westley, Calif. There, with technology developed in West Germany, the New York-based Oxford Energy Corporation is burning them as hydrocarbon fuel, to provide electricity for Pacific Gas and Electric. ''One tire,'' says Robert Graulich, Oxford's vice president for administration, ''can serve the energy needs of the average northern California household for a day.''

title: Tacit Admission?
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS ENGEL PLANS TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Marcy Engel, a lawyer for Salomon Brothers, and Stuart M. Cobert, an associate in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to be married in October, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Engel of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced.

title: Waging Justice in Charleston
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE PLAN: NEW DRAFT GETS MIXED RECEPTION
description: LEAD: INITIAL reactions to the latest draft of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan seem to indicate that the plan has lost some of its radical-reformist image.

title: DR. HELEN TOWERS MARRIES DR. WALTER WEISS IN DUBLIN
description: The marriage of Dr. Helen Towers and Dr. Walter I. Weiss, graduates of the Royal College of Surgeons in Dublin, took place last evening at the Berkeley Court Hotel in Dublin. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg of Temple Rodelph Sholom in New York performed the ceremony.

title: Iowa Democrat Warns About Caucus Reports
description: Iowa's Democratic chairman today defended her party's complicated Presidential caucus process and criticized news organizations that she said would report inaccurate results Monday night in a search for simplicity.

title: CONNOTATIONS OF 'BLACK' HELD TO BE NONRACIAL
description: Professor McClean's effort to attribute to ''white racism'' 500 years of English usage, wherein the word ''black'' has come to have a derogatory or sinister meaning, is absurd.

title: Equity Library Theater Gives Itself a Party
description: ''AT Equity Library Theater, the actor is our focus,'' declared George Wojtasik, the theater's producing director.

title: Talks Reported
description: Denver Broncos Coach Dan Reeves has said his team will talk to the Dallas Cowboys about a trade involving running back Tony Dorsett.

title: Curbing Raiders Is Bad for Business
description: Congressional action to preserve a free market is now more necessary than ever, since Delaware, the nation's second-smallest state, adopted legislation to sharply restrict contested mergers. The measure, signed by Delaware's Governor last week, will affect companies around the country.

title: Malay Party Ruled Illegal, Spurring Conflicts
description: The political party that has headed every Malaysian Government since independence in 1957 was ruled illegal last week by a Malaysian judge because some of its branches were improperly registered. The unexpected ruling is likely to pose political, legal and possibly financial problems for Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the party, the United Malays National Organization.

title: PRODUCTS OF THE MIND OF THE INDUSTRIAL PAST
description: LEAD: FROM the treasure-trove of the state's industrial past comes an exhibit that reminds us of the pre-eminent role played by Connecticut's inventors and manufacturers.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/SCIENCE
description: LEAD: A MOOSE FOR JESSICA By Pat A. Wakefield with Larry Carrara. Photographs by Larry Carrara. Unpaged. New York: E. P. Dutton. $12.95. (All ages)

title: ALLAN BLOOM'S GREAT IDEAS
description: Allan Bloom's book is a pretentious account of his own nostalgia for the days when white-male authority went unquestioned. Such yearnings are the standard litany of extreme conservatism.

title: Singapore Ties Deaths to Chinese Transplants
description: At least seven Singaporeans have died in the last six weeks after kidney transplant operations at a hospital in southern China, according to their families and Singaporean Health Ministry officials.

title: WHAT YOU SEE IS HOW YOU VOTE
description: NEWS THAT MATTERS Television and American Opinion. By Shanto Iyengar and Donald R. Kinder. 187 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: Candidates Scramble as Iowa Campaign Nears End
description: Eleven of the 13 Presidential candidates crisscrossed Iowa today in pursuit of the uncommitted, the undecided and the persuadable as the campaign here drew to a close.

title: JEAN GRIFFITH ENGAGED TO ROBERT D. HOPKINS
description: The engagement of Jean Dashiell Griffith to Robert Dixon Hopkins has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Alexander Griffith of Ruxton, Md. The couple plan to wed March 19. Miss Griffith, a graduate of the Garrison Forest School and Towson State University, is an employment counselor for Nancy Adams Personnel in Baltimore. Her father is a real-estate broker in Towson, Md. Her mother, Joyce Griffith, is an interior designer and the vice president of the Baltimore Design Center.

title: Under Long Coats, Longer Legs
description: WHILE the gurus of fashion contemplate the next direction of the hemline (can a hem go sideways?), the current crop of wildly diverging lengths has created some interesting contrasts to hold our attention.

title: TALKING: House Rules; How Best To Win Compliance
description: A PICKUP truck belonging to a unit owner is continually parked in a New Jersey condominium parking lot in violation of house rules that permit only passenger cars.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: COLLEGE CONCERTS

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article and a caption on Jan. 31 misidentified a community group in East Harlem. It is the Union Settlement Association, not the East Harlem Settlement House.

title: Victim of Vietnam Identified
description: An Army laboratory in Hawaii has identified remains returned to the United States by Vietnam last September as those of Maj. Michael J. Bosiljevac of Omaha, an Air Force officer who disappeared on a flight over North Vietnam more than 15 years ago. He was the 146th American whose remains, having been returned by Hanoi since the Vietnam War, were subsequently identified by the Central Identification Laboratory in Honolulu. A total of 2,410 Americans are still listed as missing in Indochina as a result of the war.

title: Haugen Regains I.B.F. Lightweight Crown
description: Greg Haugen is the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion again.

title: GETTING TEEN MOTHERS OFF WELFARE
description: NEW JERSEY'S largest city has become a test site for a new Federal effort aimed at breaking the welfare cycle among teen-age mothers.

title: Pay Cited in Loss of Day-Care Staff in New York
description: Administrators and teachers in New York City's day-care centers are leaving their jobs for positions with higher salaries and better working conditions and the quality of care at the centers is suffering, according to participants in a symposium yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Many Haitians Ignore Strike on Inaugural Eve
description: On the eve of the inauguration of Leslie F. Manigat as President of Haiti, a general strike today closed most stores in the heart of the capital. But many people who earn their living in open-air markets and street stalls went about their business as usual.

title: BRIAN SMITH ENGAGED TO KATHLEEN PASTORE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Frank Haas of Center Harbor, N.H., formerly of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Haas's daughter, Kathleen Elizabeth Pastore, to Brian Francis Smith, a son of John F. Smith of Zurich and Marie R. O'Neill of Somerset, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: SUSAN HART IS ENGAGED
description: Susan Spangler Hart and Matthew Paul Smith, teachers at the Collegiate School, plan to be married March 19. The Rev. and Mrs. Sinclair Danforth Hart of Williamstown, Mass., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Smith of Brooklyn. Miss Hart graduated from Amherst College. Her father is an Episcopal priest. Mr. Smith is a graduate of St. Francis College in Brooklyn. His father is director of rehabilitation for the Home Insurance Company in New York.

title: MISS BUCHANAN TO WED IN JULY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Peter McE. Buchanan of New York and Quechee, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Willets Buchanan to Gary Raymond Pfister, a son of Sally D. Pfister of South Roanoke, Va., and Dr. Richard C. Pfister of Newton, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: CONNOTATIONS OF 'BLACK' HELD TO BE NONRACIAL
description: Prof. Vernon McClean's Opinion Page article on racism in language (Jan. 24) seems peculiarly misdirected. It also makes some arguments based on etymological errors.

title: FAMILY SAGA MOVES INTO VIDEO AGE
description: I'M an incurable romantic. I question couples on how they met. Their fairy-tale wedding albums are the end of the story. Similar to the wedding gown, the volume is boxed and wrapped for eternity. And as a history published three or four decades ago, it is a quaintly dated reference.

title:
INVESTING;
An Improved American Hoist
description: LEAD: THE American Hoist and Derrick Company has disappointed its fans for years. From 1982 to 1986, the Minnesota-based maker of industrial cranes posted an unbroken string of losses. The fiscal year that ended last November, however, brought a swing to profits of 56 cents a share. Robert C. Maples, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., looks for American Hoist to clear $1.05 a share this year from continuing operations.

title: QUICK FIXES
description: A HOW-TO BOOK PROMISES to create ''a more beautiful you'' in 21 days. Twenty-one days? It seems like an eternity. The book, by the way, was written in 1972.

title: SCHOOLS CITE SHORTAGE OF SPEECH THERAPISTS
description: FACED with a chronic shortage of speech-language therapists, Connecticut public schools are turning to parents, paraprofessionals, teachers and computers for help.

title: Calgary Has It Down Cold
description: It finally snowed last week, a blustery storm that lasted long enough to paint the entire landscape a pristine white and dump more than a foot in the nearby Rockies.

title:
ART;
THE INDUSTRIAL AND THE BESTIAL
description: LEAD: ART EX, the shedlike extension of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center just across the Connecticut border, is an appropriate rough-hewn site for the current exhibition of 12 paintings by Gerald McLaughlin, which have about them an odd sense of the machine shop.

title: A Basic Choice With Laser Printers
description: LASER printers are getting better, smaller, faster and slightly less expensive. That makes them more attractive than ever as replacements for the dot matrix or daisy wheel printers now in the office.

title: Regulators Battle To Define Turf
description: The regulatory waters are still being roiled by the October market collapse. The S.E.C. staff urged curbs on stock index futures trading, saying the technique aggravated the dive of Oct. 19. Among other things, the 900- page report recommended that margins on futures be raised from the current 10 percent. That was one of the few areas of agreement between that report and one issued by the staff of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission, which generally defended computerized trading of stocks and futures. Amid all the reports, there was some action. The Big Board voted to shut its computers to index-arbitrage programs on any day when the Dow Jones industrial average has moved 50 points or more. And in Chicago, the Board of Trade voted a 15 percent margin for trading its Major Market Index. In Washington, a turf fight was developing among the regulatory agencies over whatever control mechanisms may develop.

title: HOWARD RORY ELISOFON ENGAGED TO MS. KARTER
description: The engagement of Marguerite Karter to Howard Rory Elisofon has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Karter of New York. An April 30 wedding is planned.

title: PHYSICIAN TO WED DALE H. WOLFSON
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Wolfson of New York and White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Dale Honey Wolfson to Dr. William M. Reiff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Reiff of Chicago. An August wedding is planned.

title: Hutton's Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: Barclay Plager; Hockey Player, 46
description: Barclay Plager, a former National Hockey League defenseman for the St. Louis Blues who later coached the team, died of brain cancer today. He was 46 years old and was an assistant coach with the Blues at the time of his death.

title: Choice Dining Around Miami
description: JUST five years ago, the odds of wandering into a first-rate restaurant in greater Miami were roughly equal to your chances of finding a 16th-century Spanish doubloon in the Fontainbleau Hotel's swimming pool. Except for some gutsy Cuban haunts downtown, Miami cuisine was characterized largely by over-air-conditioned tourist places featuring humdrum chain-restaurant fare.

title: Secrets and Surprises
description: NO WAY OUT Starring Kevin Costner (in photo, right), Gene Hackman (in photo, left), Will Patton, Sean Young, Howard Duff. Directed by Roger Donaldson. 1987. HBO Video. 113 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: NEW YORKERS Etc.
description: THEY'RE out there somewhere; they must be. But who are they and where are they? Do they look like everyone else? Have they advanced degrees in science, math and languages? Do they occasionally have temper tantrums? Have they ever been heard to mutter, or even to come right out with, words like ''heck,'' ''darn,'' or ''oh, fudge?'' They're out there, we know, these people who actually read - and understand - appliance manuals. Otherwise we would have to believe that some of the world's largest appliance manufacturers are spewing out instruction manuals merely to infuriate some of the world's most eager appliance buyers. And that just isn't possible. Would these giants of business be ornery enough to delight in confusing and aggravating us?

title: The Power of 'Siegfried' To Enthrall and Edify
description: Friday night, the third shoe will fall, meaning that the Metropolitan Opera will unveil ''Siegfried,'' the third in its four new productions that make up Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle. It will join ''Das Rheingold,'' first seen earlier this season; ''Die Walkure,'' which bowed last season, and ''Gotterdammerung,'' due next season, to form a complete ''Ring des Nibelungen'' scheduled to be presented as a whole for the first time in April 1989.

title: FICTION
description: WINTERS' TALES: Stories and Observations for the Unusual. By Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Included in the publicity material sent to reviewers along with ''Winters' Tales'' is a quotation from Jonathan Winters's most famous fan. ''Jonathan showed me,'' Robin Williams writes, ''that anything is possible - one of the few people able to make me laugh from my soul.'' Notice that while praising his mentor, Mr. Williams does not specifically refer to the book itself, which may mean that he too found these dozens of whimsically macabre short pieces disappointing, sounding faint echoes of H. P. Lovecraft and Steve Martin's ''Cruel Shoes,'' even fainter echoes of such memorable Jonathan Winters characters as Maude Frickert. The comedian-turned-parabolist sometimes gives his stories an ending with a twist, sometimes gives them a twisted ending, sometimes gives them both. Recurring themes are nostalgia for small-town life, the importance of toys to both young and old, the bond between children and grandparents, the estrangement between children and parents, mental imbalance and death - lots of it. Unfortunately, the stories of cognitive animals who turn out to be stuffed, generals who are engaged in military combat with what are revealed to be lead soldiers and cranky partygoers who (surprise, surprise) are the President and First Lady are, if not predictable and menacing or predictable and sentimental, simply so arbitrary as to confound comprehension. What Mr. Winters, who at 60-plus is, in his daughter's phrase, ''proud to be strange,'' has come up with is the equivalent of Garbage Pail Kids cards for adults.

title: 2 Hospitals to Expand for Treatment of AIDS
description: Two of New York City's largest teaching hospitals - Beth Israel Medical Center and New York Hospital -plan to expand their treatment of AIDS patients as part of a major expansion of hospital-based AIDS care this year.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Summer Night Starring Mariangela Melato and Michele Placido. Directed by Lina Wertmuller. 1983. International Video Entertainment. 94 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: FROM NEW JERSEY, A POLITICAL TRAIN
description: The New Jersey Chamber of Commerce's annual visit here is a political as much as a business event, starting with the chartered train from Trenton on which politicians walk the aisles, renewing acquaintances and talking up their campaigns.

title:
Focus: Jackson;
Changes Add Life to Downtown
description: LEAD: AFTER a long period of business decline in the decades of the 60's and 70's, this Mississippi state capital of 216,000 is making progress toward establishing itself as a financial and trade center.

title: An Up-to-Date Look at A Very Old Habit
description: THE oldest ''rule'' in bridge, far older than the game itself, has been under attack for a quarter of a century. It's now in decline, but is likely, like Charles II, to be an unconscionable time dying.

title: Scholars in Poland Protesting Political Control
description: Poland's authorities are struggling to close a festering wound at the nation's prestigious Academy of Sciences, where members published an unusual open letter charging that inroads of political control crushed work in the academy's social science institutes.

title: Palestinian Turmoil Could Provide the Seeds of Peace
description: SINCE the birth of Israel nearly 40 years ago, the Arab-Israeli conflict has fallen into a circular pattern. Statesmen try to move ahead, push some distance but finally fail. Amid diplomatic stagnation, warfare erupts. Then the combat ends, having loosened some of the old positions, providing a period of diplomatic fluidity.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: The three long tales that make up THE BRIDGE OF LOST DESIRE by Samuel R. Delany (Arbor House, $17.95) display one of science fiction's finest writers at the top of his form. This book is an addition to Mr. Delany's unique Neveryon series, which slyly builds on archeological speculation to body forth a world at the very beginning of civilization in which such important events as the change-over from hieroglyphs to alphabet have occurred within the life spans of the characters.

title: Time to Speak Truth
description: When you see your best friend acting in a way that will ruin his life, do you pretend not to see? Do you insist to others that it is really not so bad as it looks? Do you tell yourself that it is his business, not yours?

title: 'Your Visas Have Expired!'
description: LEAD: IT was to be a trip like others we had taken.

title: CENSUS BUREAU LISTS THE RICHEST AND POOREST
description: LEAD: HARTFORD is the poorest community in the state, followed by Mansfield, Bridgeport, New Haven and Sterling, according to recently released estimates of per capita income made by the United States Census Bureau.

title: PETER M. RUGGIERO WEDS JOAN CRAIG
description: Joan Craig, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Craig of Moorestown, N.J., and Peter Michael Ruggiero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Ruggiero of Elmont, L.I., were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Raymond Finn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Too Close To Reality
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Witt Figures to Reign Supreme
description: HER name hung over Denver last month like the smog, and it almost did not seem to matter how badly any of America's best female figure skaters beat up on each other in the national championships. The significant other, thousands of miles to the east, lurked in spirit, nonetheless. Katarina Witt. Of course. The most beloved athlete of East Germany, the reigning queen of her sport at 22, she remains a menace to all other would-be Olympic champions and an unmistakable favorite of spectators.

title:
FOOD;
A TOUCH OF PORTUGAL
description: LEAD: AS EVERY creative chef knows, the search for new ideas is as important as the actual running of a restaurant. This means traveling whenever hectic schedules permit, sampling the creations of colleagues and, especially, reading.

title: Rude and Belligerent
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION: City Charter Changes; If the Board of Estimate Dies, Who Will Inherit Its Powers?
description: IF the New York City Board of Estimate is dismantled, as some legal experts were proposing last week, there could be an ironic result. A challenge to the board that originated in a desire for a more representative city government could so upset the city's system of checks and balances as to give more power to an already powerful mayor.

title: THE ACTOR AS ATHELTE: SUBTLE AND COMPLEX PORTRAIT
description: When Billy Dee Williams took over last week for James Earl Jones in ''Fences,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning play at the 46th Street Theater, it was a little like an athlete being asked, on short notice, to take over for Babe Ruth - or Josh Gibson. Mr. Jones won a Tony award for his towering portrayal of Troy Maxson, the Josh Gibson-like ex-Negro League slugger caught in a vise of frustration and limitation with members of his own family. But Mr. Williams, though he had not appeared on Broadway in 10 years and had only brief rehearsal time for ''Fences'' (four weeks as against several years and several different productions for Mr. Jones), brought his own well-worn pair of spikes to the part.

title: A SHOWPLACE FOR HORSES IS IN THE WORKS
description: AFTER 10 years of applying the spurs to reluctant bureaucrats, a horse-loving, horse-owning schoolteacher from Oakland in Bergen County has won the right to build a world-class horse-show arena for New Jersey.

title: Shorter Bout
description: The International Boxing Federation has decided to limit today's title fight in England between the middleweight champion, Frank Tate, and Tony Sibson to 12 rounds instead of the 15 the I.B.F. ususally insists on for a championship fight. In doing so, the I.B.F. appeared to be bowing to the safety concerns of British boxing authorities, who refused to sanction the fight at 15 rounds and called on the I.B.F. to follow the lead of the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association in trimming title bouts to 12 rounds.

title: Redmen Slow in Rout by Syracuse
description: Even the most loyal St. John's fan should have been able to predict this one.

title: The Fanciest Felines Are New on a Block
description: THE United States Postal Service is in the midst of issuing seven commemorative stamps in two weeks. Leading the way is a block of four that depicts domestic cats, two statehood issues and the 11th in the Black Heritage series.

title: MS. SHARE TO WED MICHAEL E. FLEISS
description: Mr.and Mrs. Harold S Share of Hudson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vicki Ellen Share, to Micahel Eric Fleiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel M. Fleiss of Plainview, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: In Jordan, Anxiety and Joy Over Palestinian Upheaval
description: The upheaval in the Israeli-occupied territories has brought both anxiety and exhilaration to Jordan, as Jordanians and Palestinians wonder where the events are leading them and how they will change the delicate alliance they have forged in this country in the last 40 years.

title: Correction
description: Last Sunday, in his essay ''Can TV Be Taken Seriously?'', John J. O'Connor neglected to mention that the British-made ''South Bank Show,'' currently being saluted in the Museum of Broadcasting's ''New York World Television Festival,'' is also available on the Bravo cable service; it is presenting the cultural series on Thursday evenings at 10.

title: HELIPAD PLAN STIRS EAST END
description: PROPOSALS to upgrade the helicopter landing pad on Dune Road in Southampton Village, halted by environmental objections for several months because the expansion would involve filling in wetlands, may now face a legal challenge by an adjoining property owner.

title: IF KING AND MALCOLM X HAD MET...
description: ''WE DO make quite a team,'' the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. remarks to Malcolm X at the end of a hypothetical meeting in a Harlem hotel room.

title: DECEPTION ON BUDGET LAID TO GULOTTA IN SUIT
description: IN a move that could have a significant impact on Nassau County government, a businessman is asking the State Supreme Court to rule on what he contends is County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta's ''manipulation'' of the county budget to ''mislead the people of Nassau County.''

title: MISS FRENCH TO MARRY ANTHONY PETER FUSCO
description: Martha Williams French and Anthony Peter Fusco, actors in New York, plan to marry in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. James M. French of San Francisco, have announced.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $290,000 93 South Snedecor Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old ranch; sunroom, fireplace, screened porch, basement, 300- by 280-foot lot; taxes $7,500. East Islip $178,000 127 Marilyn Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, new eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,500. Massapequa $285,000 18 Seabreeze Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; den with fireplace, new kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Nesconset $244,000 8 Hayes Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; 2 fireplaces, skylights, decks, 2-car garage; estimated taxes $4,600. Stony Brook $187,000 14 Maureen Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,200. Syosset $395,000 11 Wilshire Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; den, family room, .05 acre; taxes $5,400. OTHER AREAS South Orange, N.J. $278,000 279 Beech Spring Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 44-year-old Tudor; fireplace, den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,318. Old Lyme, Conn. $220,000 22 Champlain Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, cul-de-sac, 1 acre; taxes unavailable. Bronxville, N.Y. $867,500 28 Homesdale Road 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 66-year-old stucco/frame Tudor-Norman; eat-in kitchen, den, walk to train, schools and stores; taxes $10,346.

title: White House Criticizes Democrats For Threatening Arms Pact Delay
description: The White House today criticized Senate Democratic leaders for threatening to delay approval of the new Soviet-American treaty banning ground-launched medium- and shorter-range missiles after negotiations between the Senators and the Administration on a key issue appeared to collapse Friday.

title: KOHL WOULD KEEP TACTICAL MISSILES
description: In a major policy declaration, Chancellor Helmut Kohl today formally spurned the idea of eliminating short-range nuclear missiles from Europe but demanded negotiations that would reduce to equal ceilings the number of such weapons held by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: Federal Labs: Might a Link To Industry Aid Research?
description: THE Office of Management and Budget has provoked debate in the scientific community by suggesting that the laboratories of the National Institutes of Health be converted to a private research center, financed by government, industry and foundations.

title: Sunday Observer; Cartoon Crisis
description: SOMETIMES IT SEEMS I am being drawn by a cartoonist. How else can I explain my being in this supermarket with an impulse to ask the manager to recommend a soap for my dishpan hands?

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Baby M; Taking the Money Out of Motherhood
description: THE New Jersey Supreme Court last week undid most of the decision that a lower court judge reached in the case of Baby M, and it has declared that, contract or no contract, the woman who gave birth to her is her legal mother. But the new decision leaves Baby M, now Melissa Elizabeth Stern, where the earlier one did - with her biological father.

title: SHELBY F. NELSON TO WED BIOLOGIST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Courtney Andrew Nelson of Wells, Vt., and Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Shelby Forrester Nelson to Dr. Jon H. de la Harpe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. de la Harpe of Cape Town. An April wedding is planned.

title: Next Week; Who Was Better, Mantle Or Mays? (Or Snider?)
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Uncle Sam, American Sport Needs You!
description: In every Olympic year, many Americans seem to think that our privately supported athletes are at a disadvantage compared to the Eastern bloc's state-subsidized athletes. Unfortunately, a more serious United States disadvantage is being overlooked: our Government's attitude toward bidding for and staging international events.

title: The Dance: Ann Carlson's 'Animals'
description: ANN CARLSON had people dance like - and with - animals on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Her ''Animals'' was an eloquent five-part work that examined differences between people and animals, yet affirmed the kinship of all beings.

title: Dole and Bush: Dramatic Contrast of Styles . . . but There Is a Striking Similarity in Goals
description: Since the Presidential campaign began, Gerald M. Boyd has been covering Vice President Bush while Bernard Weinraub covered Senator Bob Dole. Last week they switched assignments to report how the campaigns compared in style and substance.

title: Contra Forces Reported on Verge of 3-Way Split
description: The commander of United States forces in Latin America has said that the Nicaraguan rebels are on the verge of a three-way split that will erode and possibly destroy their military strength.

title: DATA UPDATE: Fabruary 7, 1988
Capital Hitchhikers Beat the System
description: Commuters traveling to jobs in the nation's capital keep developing new twists, and the latest is organized hitchhiking.

title: SO MANY FEMALE RIVALS
description: LEAD: NO MAN'S LAND The Place of the Woman Writer in the Twentieth Century. Volume One: The War of the Words. By Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. Illustrated. 320 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.95.

title: Skipper Plans School for Young Sailors
description: John Kolius has needed the time to slow down. Little has been heard in the last year from the skipper who carried the New York Yacht Club's banner to Australia for the 1986-87 America's Cup series.

title: STERN HOPES FOR TALKS DESPITE NEW UNION MOVE
description: David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, today called the move by the players to decertify their union as their bargaining agent ''a strategem'' to step up pressure on the owners.

title: Latest Administration Tactic Makes Abortion Fight a Free Speech Issue
description: LAST week, the Reagan Administration published its new regulations ending Federal funds for any family-planning clinic that counsels women about abortions or refers them to abortion providers. But whether the rules will ever be enforced remains very much in question.

title: MAUREEN FERGUSON WEDS T. D. STEINER
description: The marriage of Maureen Elizabeth Ferguson, a daughter of Helen E. Ferguson of New York and the late Charles A. Ferguson, to Thomas Daniel Steiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Daniel Steiner of Glen Arbor, Mich., and Longboat Key, Fla., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans performed the ceremony.

title: How the Morgan Bank Struck Out
description: IN a highly visible advertising campaign, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has been holding itself out as the bank that stresses its ''relationship'' with its clients above all else. ''We don't promote M.&A. deals just to generate fees,'' heralds one ad that proudly shows an empty tombstone - symbolic of a takeover deal that wasn't done, presumably because it wasn't in the client's interest.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE SCHOOL TAKEOVER LAW: NO PANACEA
description: LEAD: LAST MONTH, Governor Kean signed a school takeover bill that had just been approved by the Legislature. This law gives the state's Department of Education the authority to take over school districts that have failed to provide their students with a ''thorough and efficient'' education, as mandated by New

title: POST OFFICE SEEKS AIRPORT SITE
description: LEAD: THE battlefield in the dispute over where the United States Postal Service will put a new regional mail-distribution center shifted a few miles south last week to the County Airport from Armonk.

title: CAN ART MAKE THE WORLD SAFE FOR ROMANTICISM?
description: Browsing through the romanticism exhibit at the New York Public Library on 42d Street, watching visitors pore over original manuscripts by Wordsworth, Coleridge, Shelley, Keats and Blake or gaze at paintings by Turner, Constable, Samuel Palmer and others, I wondered what has happened to romanticism, how it has weathered since Wordsworth. What would a 1988 version of romanticism be? Was it a just a historic movement, or is it something indestructible, something intrinsic to art, one of the fundamental ways in which we approach the making of poems, stories and paintings?

title: Trouble for Nettles
description: Things haven't been going too well for one former Yankee. Graig Nettles, the former Gold Glove third baseman and team captain, who was making $800,000 a year when he was traded to the Padres in 1984, has filed for bankruptcy in San Diego.

title: POSTINGS: On a Hilltop, w/Vus; Houses Share the Waters
description: Sparta Brook will share attention with the Hudson River in a colony of 20 houses being built in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Mitchell Hochberg, the co-developer, promises a backyard babbler for 12 of them and a Tappan Zee view for seven. The project, called The Orchard, will also retain some of the apple trees that once dominated the 30-acre hilltop off Scarborough Road. Construction began last month, and the first two homes will be finished in June. The three- to six-bedroom houses, priced from $685,000 to $875,000, will combine traditional, English and colonial exteriors with modern, unpartitioned interiors.

title: FICTION
description: GOD'S WATER CARRIERS. By Manes Sperber. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. Foreword by Elie Wiesel. (Holmes & Meier, $24.50.) In ''God's Water Carriers,'' Manes Sperber (1905-84) describes a time during his youth when, questioning God and beginning a lifelong debate over his faith, he climbed a barn roof in his shtetl in Poland to hurl stones into space, in the hope of challenging the God he was certain waited behind the ''trapdoor'' in the sky. This first volume of the autobiographical trilogy ''All Our Yesterdays,'' by a prominent intellectual, novelist and philosopher (and a self-described ''old revolutionary''), is an uneven but earnest account of the education of a religious rebel, the evolution of a man from devout Jew to faithful skeptic. Ably translated from the German, the book concentrates on Sperber's youth, spent in eastern Galicia. The grinding poverty of the time is here, as well as the specter of anti-Semitism and his life in the heder, the classroom where he learned to speak Hebrew by the age of 4. Sperber digresses often and with relish, moving from the literal anecdote to the expansive metaphor and back again. We are party not only to historical events but also to a wealth of personal recollections. As a diary of an education in skepticism, ''God's Water Carriers'' is disjointed, refusing to hew to a chronological narrative line. But as a chronicle of one of the century's more formidable intellects, the book is an enlightening work and a mirror of values - those of a man who, despite having arms too short to box with God, nevertheless rose to the challenge.

title: Reagan's Abiding Trust Is the Key to Meese's Survivability
description: ONCE again, Edwin Meese 3d is under fire. And once again, Washington is wondering how long the Attorney General, the nation's highest law enforcement officer, can keep on surmounting accusations of impropriety and misjudgment.

title: NORIEGA EXPECTED TO CLING TO POWER, PANAMANIANS SAY
description: The indictment of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in the United States on drug charges has stiffened his resistance and makes the likelihood of his peaceful departure from power more remote, Panamanian civilians, military officers and foreign diplomats say.

title: GROWING NUMBER OF HOMELESS PERPLEXES L.I.
description: CHARLES KILLIAN slept last month in a friend's abandoned car behind an auto parts store on Route 25A in Rocky Point. It had no heat and offered little protection from the bitter cold. But until he found work, he said, it would have to do.

title: Rangers Finish Road Trip at 4-2-1
description: The Rangers will have just 14 hours to savor what they accomplished here tonight, and most of that time will be spent worrying about longterm implications.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Supplies and Services For the Wedding

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Roosevelt Island
description: LEAD: ROOSEVELT ISLAND is a metropolitan paradox: a small town in the heart of America's biggest city. The close-knit and almost crime-free community has its own newspaper, its own grade school and town meetings - even an annual Little League parade.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Julia McKay van Roden to Andrew Howard Lerman misidentified Miss van Roden's mother. She is Amy McKay Biddle.

title: Maryland Legislator Sentenced to Prison For Wedtech Payoff
description: State Senator Michael B. Mitchell and his brother, former State Senator Clarence Mitchell 3d, were sentenced Friday to two and a half years in prison each for taking payoffs to block an investigation of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: TONI L. SCHACHTER MARRIES A BANKER
description: The marriage of Toni Lynn Schachter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin I. Schachter of Freeport,L.I., and Copake Lake, N.Y., to Seth Perry Bernstein a son of Laurel Culter of New York and Wilton, Conn., and Stanley D. Bernstein of Nutley, N.J., took place last evening at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Reuben M. Katz officiated.

title: SUBVERSIVE CHRISTIANITY
description: LEAD: REVOLUTION FROM THE HEART By Niall O'Brien. 310 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: Don't Forget Olympic Ideal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LOVING LITTLE EGYPT, by Thomas McMahon. (Penguin, $6.95.) In the early days of electrical power, Thomas Alva Edison fought with Nikola Tesla over whether direct current or alternating current would be the wave of the future. In this novel by Thomas McMahon, a Harvard science professor, Edison and Tesla are on opposite sides again, in a dispute over an electronics wizard who creates a secret underground telephone network for the blind. While the characters in the story are rather mechanical, Evelyn Toynton said here in 1987, ''in the descriptions of circuit switching [ and ] the exhilaration attendant on scientific discovery . . . Mr. McMahon's lyricism comes to the fore.'' THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Vintage, $10.95.) Britain's decision in the late 18th century to pun-ish criminals by exiling them to the far side of the planet led to the establishment of Australia, a country whose citizens, Robert Hughes says, developed a deeply ingrained suspicion of authority.
