Mr. Hughes, an art critic for Time magazine and the author of ''The Shock of the New,'' was born and educated in Sydney. He ''tells his vast story with his accustomed elegance and all his usual gift for making resounding historical and cultural connections,'' Thomas Keneally said here last year. THE FLAGELLANTS, by Carlene Hatcher Polite. (Beacon, $7.95.) In Carlene Hatcher Polite's classic novel of a black couple's disintegrating relationship, the flagellants (who assault each other both mentally and physically) are Jimson, an aspiring poet, and Ideal, who comes from a poor community in the South. In their continuing dialogue, the characters ''brilliantly and bitterly tear off layer after layer of rationalization and myth,'' one reviewer said in 1967. ''Novels so ambitious almost always fail. . . . 'The Flagellants' succeeds.'' BRIBES, by John T. Noonan Jr. (University of California, $14.95.) John T. Noonan Jr.'s erudite study of bribery traces such chicanery to early practitioners like Simon Magus and includes such contemporary examples as the Abscam scandal and Watergate. ''Mr. Noonan is a fine writer and a shrewd moralist,'' D. J. R. Bruckner said in The Times in 1984. ''There is scarcely a page in this huge book that does not raise an interesting question or make one redefine one's notions of the morality of public conduct.'' THE TRAVELER, by John Katzenbach. (Ballantine, $4.95.) By slaying an innocent family, an experienced murderer hopes to become immortalized in the serial killers' hall of fame. In 1987, our reviewer, Patrick Anderson, said that while the novel ''has some of the qualities of a best seller,'' it is also ''a serious statement . . . about a society that nurtures and in some ways - with biographies, television movies and journalistic frenzy -encourages its madmen.'' JOHNSON V. JOHNSON, by Barbara Goldsmith. (Dell, $4.95.) The fight by the children of J. Seward Johnson, heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, over his $500 million estate was as bitter and sordid as their oppressive family life. Though the author ''often allows her tape recorder to show,'' Herbert Mitgang said in The Times last year, she has put together ''a lively tale.'' HOME FIRES BURNING, by Robert Inman. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A tiresome newspaper editor's homespun wisdom annoys the residents of his small Southern community and might put off some readers as well, Tom Wicker said here in 1987. Nevertheless, the novel ''has stretches of real narrative skill, and its weighty way largely succeeds in causing the reader to care about a town and its people and a way of life.'' THINKING IN TIME: The Uses of History for Decision-Makers, by Richard E. Neustadt and Ernest R. May. (Free Press, $9.95.) The lessons of history, a seemingly obvious ingredient in government decision making, are often distorted or ignored, two Harvard University professors demonstrate. In 1986, James Chace said here that while the authors ''often lapse into dreadful jargon,'' the book is filled with ''rich [ and ] fascinating'' case studies. STRANGERS IN PARADISE, by Lee K. Abbott. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Though some of these stories are set in Vietnam, they are all about citizens of the desert metropolis of Deming, N.M. ''Plots tend to overlap, a peculiarity that often becomes a virtue,'' William Ferguson said here in 1987. ''It is as if several fields of force were being directed at a single invisible core of meaning, in a prose at once exuberant and inventive.'' CELEBRATING BIRD: The Triumph of Charlie Parker, by Gary Giddins. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $9.95.) When this biography of the jazz saxophonist Charlie (Yardbird) Parker was published last year, our reviewer, Jason Berry, called it ''an elegant, incisive essay. . . . It is as penetrating a character study of Bird as any yet written.'' MISSION TO CIVILIZE: The French Way, by Mort Rosenblum. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) Even after the loss of its empire, Mort Rosenblum believes, France continues to act like an imperial nation subtly bestowing its civilization on a needy world. In 1986, The Times's John Gross called the book ''an illuminating and extremely useful guide.'' CONTINENT, by Jim Crace. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) A wonderful new force called electricity causes strange cultural ripples when it is bestowed on the primitive inhabitants of Jim Crace's imaginary land. ''This brilliant, provocative and delightful book shows us why progress must prevail, but it also shows us the terrible price that must be paid,'' Robert Olen Butler said in The Book Review last year.

title: Cutting the Cost of Car Insurance
description: WHEN Mariarosa Cartolano, a New York lawyer, recently purchased her first car, a 1987 Chrysler Le Baron, she was prepared to find high prices in the dealer's showroom. What she wasn't prepared for was the size of the insurance bill: $4,000 a year, or about 25 percent of the cost of the car itself.

title: MISS WALKER IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Marylou Dillon Walker to George Washington Arnett 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Arnett 3d of Tiburon, Calif., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Walker of West Hartford and Westbrook, Conn. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Evoking Childhood Isn't Kid Stuff
description: Toward the end of Steven Spielberg's ''Empire of the Sun,'' there's a haunting sequence in which 13-year-old Jim Graham (Christian Bale), who has survived four years in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp outside Shanghai, witnesses the first American air raid on the adjacent Japanese airfield.

title: How Explorers Saw the Brave New World
description: Europeans took a long time assimilating their discovery of the New World. It was almost a century before artists, in representing the New World, broke away from Eurocentric preconceptions and classical or medieval styles. Initial attempts at realism may not have been great art, but they left a revealing historical record of one civilization's encounter with another.

title: CUTIES AND COCKROACH HUSBANDS
description: WOMANSWORD What Japanese Words Say About Women. By Kittredge Cherry. Illustrated. 151 pp. New York: Kodansha International. Paper, $13.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
description: As free as the polluted air that we inhale each day is! NICHOLAS D. DECURTIS New York

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: World Financial Center Mall; Taking Retail Risks in What Is Considered Terra Incognita
description: MANY developers of urban malls fail at the delicate art of attracting a successful mix of tenants. Herald Center, the vertical shopping center at 34th Street and Broadway, has been a disappointment since it opened three years ago. In lower Manhattan, dozens of retail spaces sit vacant at the South Street Seaport as the developer strives for new ideas and new vitality.

title: When Dance Leaps Onto the Silver Screen
description: Life is too short, you realize after dropping in on ''Dance on Film, Dancin' in the Movies,'' a wonderfully eclectic series that continues at Film Forum 2 through Feb. l8. Does anybody nowadays have time to sample everything from big-band musicals to ''The Red Shoes,'' Merce Cunningham and the Bolshoi?

title: Ex-Syracuse Mayor's Schemes Detailed in Memo
description: Federal prosecutors have detailed the kickbacks and coverups that were conceived and directed over 16 years by Lee Alexander, the former Mayor of Syracuse.

title: Far From Typical
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Notebook; Economist Says McReynolds Will Lose Arbitration 3d Time
description: If Kevin McReynolds loses his salary arbitration case with the Mets, he will join Julio Cruz as the only three-time losers in the 13-year history of the system. People on both sides of the arbitration table have speculated that McReynolds will indeed lose because they think he submitted too high a number, $1.15 million. Now an economist who has studied salary arbitration supports that belief.

title: RAGAZZO TO RICHES
description: VERDI A Life in the Theatre. By Charles Osborne. Illustrated. 360 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BOCA RATON, FLA.;
Reviving the Mizner Touch
description: LEAD: MORE than 50 years ago, the Great Depression ended the dream of the architect and developer Addison Mizner to create a European-style resort community here.

title: SARAH STRICKLER TO MARRY JONATHAN COLE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Strickler of Killingworth, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Allen Strickler to Jonathan Seth Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Cole of Wayne, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Miss Strickler, until recently a book sales coordinator at Publisher's International Marketing Services in New York, graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall and Skidmore College. Her father, of counsel to the New Haven law firm of Bachman & LaPointe, was the general patent counsel of the Cities Service Company in Tulsa, Okla. The future bride is a granddaughter of the late William S. O'Connor of Westport, Conn., the chief counsel for Aetna Life and Casualty in New York.

title: ALLAN BLOOM'S GREAT IDEAS
description: If it was distressing to be a professor during the 1960's, it was equally distressing to be a student. Instead of sharing Professor Bloom's youthful experience of walking through the gates into a world in which intellectual endeavor was taken seriously, the student was plunged into a society ruled by demagoguery of the most extreme kind, in which slogans were substituted for ideas, and even attending class was sometimes a risky business. If we have been left with a university system that essentially does nothing but provide vocational training for middle-management employees, this is, in good measure, because it became dangerous to discuss ideas.

title: BARBARA SUZANNE CHRISTMAN, BANKER, IS WED TO WILLIAM PRESTON HUTCHINGS
description: At St. James's Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday, Barbara Suzanne Christman, the daughter of Clyde Salle Christman and Suzanne Carter Christman of Yakima, Wash., was married to William Preston Hutchings. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Ford Hutchings of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, and New York.

title: Where to Obtain More Information
description: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook. Ill. 60521 (312-954-2944; 800-323-7308).

title: EXECUTIVE IS WED TO MISS PRITCHARD
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Ruthann Mary Pritchard, an associate at the First Boston Corporation, and Howard Alan Silverstein, a general partner in Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: CATALOGUE OF IDEAS FOR SAVING PHOTOS
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after Randall Bourne became a father, he found himself with a shoebox filled with photographs that needed to be organized. This eventually led to his beginning his two-year-old business, Exposures, in South Norwalk.

title: FARE TO TAKE THE CHILL OFF, FROM BRISKET TO TORTE
description: ON winter weekends, I like to make meals that will warm people after an active day in the cold outdoors. Old-fashioned food - thick soups, stews and pot roast - is what I enjoy most.

title: City in Rhode Island Proposes New Rules On Guests at Hotels
description: A proposed city ordinance to require people checking into hotels, motels and inns to show an identification card bearing a photograph is being supported by local officials, but criticized by hotel industry organizations.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCSAE
description: WEEKEND by Marlene Fanta Shyer. Warner Books. 316 pages. Paperback, $3.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW THAI SPOT FOR WHITE PLAINS
description: LEAD: REKA SOUWAPAWONG has not officially opened her second Thai restaurant in the county (the first continues to thrive in Mohegan Lake); she waits for new carpeting, crystal, ''silver,'' more Thai exotica and a refurbishing of the roomy bar and lounge area before lighting the rockets. But while she is waiting, there is no need for lovers of Thai cuisine to wait with her.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BLACK HISTORY MONTH Although officially it began last week, Black History Month really gets into gear this week as museums and libraries throughout the Island study the past, celebrate the present and look into the future. For example, ''Out of Africa,'' a traveling photographic exhibition from the Smithsonian Institution that traces the rich cultural heritage of West Africa, is at the African-American Museum in Hempstead, 110 North Franklin Street, through February. It is accompanied by a series of Sunday lectures at 2 P.M. (today's is by Dr. Josef Ben-Jochannan, an Egyptologist); concerts Feb. 21 and 28; Saturday crafts workshops for children at 11:30 A.M., and a puppet show next Saturday at 2 P.M. There is an opening reception at 6 P.M. Saturday. For hours and a complete schedule call 542-0470.

title: Science Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 3 TV SPOTS TO ENTICE OUT-OF-STATE TOURISTS
description: TELEVISION viewers in New York will soon be treated to glimpses of New Haven pizzerias as Connecticut takes to the airwaves to seek tourism dollars.

title: A FALL WEDDING FOR MISS MARSHALL AND D. B. STRONG
description: Mr. and Mrs. David L. Marshall of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lea Marshall to Douglas Bavier Strong, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Strong Jr. of Fairport, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in October.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday with an article on the Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation misidentified the market where the company's stock is traded. The shares are traded over-the-counter.

title: On Long Drives, Tolstoy Helps
description: WHEN we prepare for a long driving trip, one of our tasks is picking a taped book to play on our cassette deck during the hours spent on monotonous interstates. We call an 800 number and rent one because a six-hour tape is an expensive purchase. If it's a book we discover we like, it can then be bought for our shelves at home.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BIKING TO RUSSIA
description: LEAD: From London to Moscow on bicycle - it sounds like an adventure movie, but according to Frank Behrendt of Chappaqua, it is a journey 24 Americans will take this summer. Mr. Behrendt, a fan of international bicycle tours, said he will lead what he called ''the first bicycle tour ever taken by foreigners to Russia.

title: THE NATION: Congress, the President and N.I.H.; The Political Ingredients of Medical Grants
description: THE campus of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., is studded with buildings named for members of Congress who channeled billions of dollars into it. Among them is the Clinical Center, a 540-bed research hospital, named for Warren G. Magnuson, a Democratic Senator from Washington for more than three decades. And part of the National Library of Medicine memorializes Lister Hill, an Alabama Democrat whose influence over the N.I.H. budget and programs was unmatched in his 45 years in Congress.

title:
FOCUS: Jackson;
New Projects Bring Life to Downtown
description: LEAD: AFTER a long period of business decline in the decades of the 60's and 70's, this Mississippi state capital of 216,000 is making progress toward establishing itself as a financial and trade center.

title: Why Israel Needs Arafat
description: LEAD: There is now universal agreement that the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza was not initiated by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Many Americans are hoping that an alternative leadership is emerging. The implicit assumptions are that Yasir Arafat is not interested in a permanent peace settlement and that the cause of peace would be better served by some alternative leadership.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY BASEBALL

title: CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING STAIRS
description: INSTALLING a prefabricated disappearing stairway as an attic entrance is worth considering if a larger or more convenient opening is needed. The task is simple for two people (an assistant is necessary to help maneuver the staircase), provided that the opening for the stairway can be cut so that its long sides are parallel with the existing ceiling joists, and that the roof is supported by rafters, not trusses.

title: Contributors Donate Stock To Neediest
description: A retired executive from Manhattan contributed 647 shares of Bancorp Hawaii stock, worth $30,570.75 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Driver Is Suspended
description: NASCAR officials in Daytona Beach, Fla. suspended Tim Richmond indefinitely yesterday after he tested positive for a substance prohibited under the stock car sanctioning body's policy.

title: Soviet Youth League Falls on Difficult Times
description: Viktor I. Mironenko's son, Dima, turned 14 a month ago, and like most Soviet teen-agers he now faces an important decision. Will he join Komsomol, the huge youth arm of the Communist Party and the route to power and prestige for generations of Communists, including Mikhail S. Gorbachev?

title: Smalley on the Move
description: The deals that sent Roy Smalley from the Yankees to the Chicago White Sox during the 1984 season and from the White Sox to the Minnesota Twins before the 1985 season were not your usual baseball trades. They were more like rent-a-player deals in which the Twins and the White Sox each secured the right to return the player to his previous club in exchange for a minor leaguer.

title: 4 HOSPITALS PLANNING TO SHARE BED SPACE
description: FOUR eastern Connecticut hospitals, all facing a shortage of beds partly because of population increases, are working out an agreement to share space.

title: Barcelona
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Barcelona'' by Paul Delaney (Travel, Dec. 20) is an example of the tendency of many writers to describe exorbitantly expensive hotels and restaurants, thus giving a misleading picture to potential travelers.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: WHEN the 112th Westminster Kennel Club dog show opens tomorrow at Madison Square Garden, Richard L. Bauer of Mahopac will be exhibiting not one, not two, not three, but 15 dogs. Mr. Bauer, one of the best-known handlers in the show-dog world, has been running from show ring to show ring for 30 years in a profession he describes as ''part trainer, part jockey.

title: ARENA PLAY MIRRORS WAR CRIMINAL TRIAL
description: LEAD: WHILE fact is frequently stranger than fiction, Joseph S. King hopes that his fiction proves just as engrossing as the reality it resembles, especially since, the playwright says, he began writing a drama about a Long Islander accused of being a Nazi war criminal before the Karl Linnas deportation case began.

title: South Africa Police Disperse Funeral March
description: Hundreds of police officers and soldiers used tear gas to disperse mourners and marching students at the funeral of a black youth leader today.

title: Radioactivity At Air Force Site
description: FOR more than 27 years, a three- acre slab of concrete, surrounded by barbed wire, has been a silent witness at Fort Dix, N.J., to the deadly potential of nuclear arms.

title: YALE AMONG GROUPS IN U.S. STUDY OF AIDS
description: YALE UNIVERSITY is one of three schools chosen by the National Institutes of Health to undertake a study aimed at finding a cure for AIDS.

title: NEHEMIAH SEEKS OLD FORM
description: Renaldo Nehemiah is angry. Not at his longtime archrival, Greg Foster, who won the hurdles Friday night in the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden. Not at the others who beat him in that race as he finished next to last. Not at the public, which wants to know what has happened to the old Renaldo Nehemiah.

title: TABLE TALK PROSPEKS AS MARKET FALTERS
description: I WAS so taken in by the events of Oct. 17, Black Monday, that I actually read past the first page of the daily business section now and keep the car radio set to news so I can keep track of the ups and downs of the stock market.

title: On Seeking A Better Rattrap
description: RATS are not a big problem in Takoma Park, Md., but when the city moved to help homeowners who were occasionally troubled by them, it found no easy solution.

title: Dance: Limon Company
description: THE presentation of dances-in-progress is always a tricky business. Unfinished, they defy reasonable critical analysis, and most tend to exist in a kind of limbo between inspiration and execution. The three pieces presented by the Jose Limon Dance Company in a gala showcase on Thursday at the Joyce Theater were no exception. Choreographed by members of the company, the dances had a sophistication that suggested long familiarity with the workings of established modern-dance companies and styles. But the raw spark of imagination at the other end of the spectrum was lost or missing.

title: MAKING THE FRIENDLY WORLD BEHAVE
description: POLITICS A Work in Constructive Social Theory. By Roberto Mangabeira Unger. New York: Cambridge University Press. Social Theory: Its Situation and Its Task. A Critical Introduction to Politics. 256 pp. Cloth, $39.50. Paper, $12.95. False Necessity: Anti-Necessitarian Social Theory in the Service of Radical Democracy. Part I of Politics. 653 pp. Cloth, $59.50. Paper, $18.95. Plasticity Into Power: Comparative-Historical Studies of the Institutional Conditions of Economic and Military Success. Variations on Themes of Politics. 231 pp. Cloth, $37.50. Paper, $10.95.

title: FACING FACTS ON NASSAU'S PROBLEMS
description: CONCERN is rising that Nassau County is rapidly reaching its capacity to absorb more people. Lack of planning, inadequate land-use controls, poor design and unsatisfactory maintenance of our ecological systems are taking a toll on our communities.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Slalom to Pelletier: Monique Pelletier, a member of the United States Ski Team's National Training Group, outdueled Tamara McKinney and other more experienced skiers yesterday to win the women's giant slalom at the United States Alpine championships in Copper Mountain, Colo. McKinney, in her first competition of the season, finished a respectable third, behind Pelletier and runner-up Heidi Voelker. McKinney had been sidelined since breaking a bone in her lower left leg on Nov. 9 while training on this mountain. She raced with a brace on her ankle, giving her lateral support. Pelletier had a combined time of 2:24.76. Voelker, an 18-year-old from Pittsfield, Mass., finished in 2:24.78; McKinney finished at 2:24.98.(AP) Speed Skating East German Wins 500 Meters: Christa Rothenburger of East Germany skated through frigid temperatures and biting winds yesterday to win the women's 500 meters on the first day of the world sprint speed championships in Milwaukee. Rothenburger, who holds the world record of 39.39 seconds, won the race in 41.30 seconds at the Wisconsin Olympic Ice Rink. Bonnie Blair of the United States, who held the world record until Rothenburger took it away in December, finished second in 41.60 seconds. Karin Kania of East Germany, who won four medals in the 1984 Olympics, was third in 42.04. American Dan Jansen, who grew up two miles from the rink, won the men's 500 meters in 38.70 seconds. (AP) Horse Racing Beru Triumphs: Beru, undefeated since finishing eighth in an 11-horse field in her debut on a sloppy track at Calder last July, ran her winning streak to four yesterday when she romped to a 14-length victory in the $69,200 Level Best Stakes at Aqueduct for 3-year-old fillies. With Nick Santagata riding, the daughter of Dr. Blum-Zany Girl, - the only New York-bred in the field of seven - covered a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:46 4/5 to earn $41,520 for Barry K. Schwartz and return $4.20 for $2 to win. Best Number was second. Curling Title to Seattle: A rink from Seattle, skippered by Nancy Langley, defeated one from Fairbanks, Alaska, 7-6, yesterday after an extra end and captured the United States women's national championship at the Nutmeg Curling Club in Darien, Conn. The victory means the rink, which also includes Nancy Pearson, Leslie Frosch and Mary Hobson, will represent the United States in the Glayva World Ladies Championship in Glasgow April 3 through April 8. Bowling Holman Wins Florida Open: Marshall Holman won four straight games yesterday, including a 275-211 victory over top-seeded Ron Bell in the title match, to capture the $140,000 Professional Bowlers Association Bowlers Journal Florida Open in Venice. Holman, who now owns 21 P.B.A. championships, rolled 1,032 for his four games - only 18 pins short of the four-game record of 1,050 set by Nelson Burton Jr. in 1984. Holman opened the day by eliminating Todd Thompson, 242-228, then routed Amleto Monacelli of Venezuela, 280-223, before beating Joe Firpo, 235-212.(AP)

title: A Recording Studio As Artists See It
description: The battle has raged for decades - is recorded music a valid substitute for live performance before an audience? The extremes have ranged from listeners and musicians who felt recordings were at best misleading to those like Glenn Gould who retreated to the recording studio and forswore live performance entirely. The ''abnormalities'' of the recording process have often been cited - from acoustics to ambiance to the lack of audience to the ability, particularly in more recent years, to edit tape into something far removed from a live performance.

title: POSTINGS: Geologist Strikes Marble; SoHo Landmark
description: Owain Hughes, a Welsh geologist, made a significant discovery recently. While rehabilitating a New York City landmark at 597 Broadway in SoHo, Mr. Hughes, who left Oxford University to mine real estate, found a white-marble facade beneath decades of accumulated grime. His training had almost failed him. ''It was so dirty and grungy,'' he said, ''it looked like sandstone.'' Meanwhile, cleaning the five-story structure, built in 1867 as a dry-goods store, was not easy. Since landmark law prohibits the use of high-pressure hoses or chemicals on historic facades, the scrubbing was done by ''men up there with little brushes in their hands, like toothbrushes,'' he said.

title: Wright Seen Anew as an Architect of Thoughts
description: In the 28 years since Frank Lloyd Wright's death, his associates, who have tried to keep the flame of his reputation burning, have often done more to damage his name than to enhance it. Under the rubric of Taliesin Associated Architects (named for the architect's famous houses in Spring Green, Wis., and Scottsdale, Ariz.) they have produced new buildings that are generally mediocre imitations of the great architect's late work. Through their Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation, they have continued Wright's practice of inviting students to pay for the privilege of studying with the master, even though there is no longer a master. And they have sold off various original Wright drawings to keep their operation going.

title: DR. SUSAN KELLIE TO MARRY DR. JAMES HARDING IN JUNE
description: Dr. Susan Margaret Kellie, a resident in internal medicine at Beth Israel Medical Center, and Dr. James Sutherland Harding, a resident in internal medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, plan to marry June 4, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Kellie of Brooklyn, have announced.

title: CAROLYN SCERBO, PHYSICIAN, TO WED
description: The engagement of Dr. Carolyn Mary Scerbo to Dr. William George Kaelin Jr., a son of Nancy P. Kaelin and Mr. Kaelin, both of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Scerbo of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: George Britt; Writer, 92
description: George Britt, a former newspaperman, author and teacher, died Thursday at the Meadow Lakes retirement complex in Hightstown, N.J., where he lived. He was 92 years old.

title: AMY SILBERSTEIN TO WED LAWYER
description: The engagement of Amy Jane Silberstein to James Howard Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Cohen of Wellesley, Mass., and East Parsonfield, Me., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. N. Ronald Silberstein of Chestnut Hill and South Dennis, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: The Big City on the Beach
description: A FRIEND stopping off in Miami to break up a New York to Buenos Aires trip inquired if there was anything to do in Miami for two days besides the beach. He didn't mean Miami Beach, of course. Everyone knew that was dead, he said, a kind of Far Rockaway with palm trees, and not too many of those.

title: A Specter of Wandering Garbage Barges Is Haunting America
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORS FIGHT PIERPOINTE PROJECT IN YONKERS
description: WHILE residents of the east side of Yonkers protest a Federal Court order to build 200 low-income housing units on the mainly white side of town, residents of the west side are fighting a condominium development proposed for their neighborhood because they say it would displace low-income minority families.

title: A Statute Was Needed to Stop Abuses
description: LAST spring the United States Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Indiana Control Share Acquistion Statute, which limits company takeover activity in that state. This statute requires certain hostile bidders to obtain the approval of the disinterested stockholders - the bidder or management - in order for the takeover bidder's shares to have voting power. Other state legislatures quickly acted to adopt takeover legislation. Some followed the Indiana model; others took a different approach. New York and New Jersey adopted provisions that call for a five-year moratorium preventing certain hostile bidders from doing a ''second step'' transaction, such as merging a newly acquired company with another.

title: THE CHILDREN OF THE CHILDLESS
description: IN the closing months of 1987, the people of the United States had 58 hours of shared anguish.

title: Producer Defends ABC Program in Libel Trial
description: A producer has testified that Victor Lasky, a conservative author, was portrayed fairly in her ABC News television documentary on the McCarthy era.

title: Jury by Trial
description: William Shakespeare must have just returned from jury duty when he wrote, ''The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.'' He might especially have had in mind the selection of civil juries in the New York State Supreme Court, a process that makes suicide seem user friendly.

title: Birds of a Feather
description: GUESTS were invited to create fantasy headdresses for the Christian Dior dinner Thursday at the New York Public Library for the opening of the exhibition ''Splendid Plumage.'' Chignons sprouted pheasant feathers, curls supported ostrich plumes and one bold spirit wore a bird's nest filled with eggs. Shown here, from left, Beatrice Dautresme, Helene de Margerie and Cheri Kaufman.

title: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY UNDER FIRE IN BONN
description: The West Germans' faith in nuclear energy, never too strong and even shakier since the Chernobyl disaster, has been further battered in recent weeks by a barrage of revelations about embezzlement, bribery and illegal shipments of nuclear wastes in the industry.

title: In Cornwall, a Meal in a Crust
description: IN the 18th century in England's Cornwall, tin smelters would stand around a basin of the silvery liquid as a huge block of wood dropped into it and sent up a fountain of molten metal. The impact of the wood made the tin boil off impurities. Sparks flew and the heat was intense, but according to a contemporary historian, the workers scarcely noticed the bright specks of tin flying about them. Their minds were on the pasties placed on the rim of the basin to be warmed for their dinner.

title: Editor's Note
description: A Washington article by The Associated Press on Jan. 24 about oil production at Prudhoe Bay in Alaska reported charges by three environmental groups that the tundra there was being polluted. The article said the American Petroleum Institute had declined to comment until it could see the report from the environmental groups.

title: U.S. and Soviet Film Makers Plan Joint Ventures
description: A delegation from the Hollywood film industry returned from the Soviet Union this week with three signed agreements for joint ventures.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: ROBERT VAN BUREN, chairman of the New Jersey Bankers Association, in a year-end statement released last month, credited the state's ''pro-business environment'' for the health of its commercial banks and called for an end to regulations prohibiting banks from entering securities, insurance and real-estate markets.

title: Why Managers Resist Machines
description: WHEN Procter & Gamble decided five years ago to build a manufacturing plant, the plans included so much electronic monitoring equipment that executives at headquarters, 500 miles away, would have been able to check the plant's exact output at any time.

title: JOKES ASIDE, SHE IS ACTING GOVERNOR
description: When speculation that Gov. Evan Mecham might resign started rising last October, Secretary of State Rose Mofford telephoned a good friend in Flagstaff and said, ''Good morning, this is Governor Mofford.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
description: No. To quote Janis Joplin, ''Freedom's just another word for nothing left to lose.'' EDWARD RANDALL New York

title: Where Fabric Reigns in Italy
description: PRATO is Florence's industrial alter ego, the milling ants to Florence's blithe cricket, as in the fables of La Fontaine. But when it comes to play, it is Prato that does the chirping. Porsches from Prato are parked outside the expensive restaurants of Florence, and it is the matrons of Prato who patronize the fashionable boutiques and jewelers of Florence. Indeed, not without a pinch of envy, the more parsimonious Florentines consider the Pratesi ostentatious.

title: Soviet Deserter Is Said to Urge Comrades to Resist
description: A young Soviet soldier who defected to the guerrilla forces in Afghanistan has appealed in an open letter to other Soviet soldiers to resist the war there, according to a human rights organization in New York.

title: Opposites Don't Necessarily Attract
description: Nietzsche Thought he put his finger on it with his distinction between Apollonian and Dionysian personalities. Other thinkers have divided us into such antagonistic camps as Yogis and Commissars, Hedgehogs and Foxes, Yea-sayers and Nay-sayers, Saved and Unsaved. Wagner detected a sharp difference between Day People and Night People. Classicists are forever at the throats of Romantics. I myself have heard arguments between Post-Modernists and Post-post Modernists. Something in us wants arguments to have two sides, each hotly, if not blindly, defended. To the barricades!

title: Success Spells Trouble for Airline in Alaska
description: Alaska's largest commuter airline, whose recent troubles range from a crash that killed 18 people to an errant flight into Soviet air space, may be the victim of its own success, a Federal official says.

title: WARMING UP TO WINTER
description: WE are about at the half-way mark of winter and I have been accused of counting time, even days, too much, as though I were not a great fan of the season. A few weeks ago, I was, in best Pollyanna fashion, buoying up a neighbor who was doggedly scraping ice from his car's windshield. I said, cheerily, ''Hey, less than two months until spring.''

title: ELIZABETH SHINE PLANNING TO WED M. S. ROSENZWEIG
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ochs Shine to Matthew Samuel Rosenzweig, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Y. Rosenzweig of Milwaukee, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Gretchen O. Shine and Warren S. Shine, both of New York.

title: Room Enough for 50 Earths
description: Seymour Simon's series of children's books on the planets, the sun and the stars reminds you of the old joke about childhood being too good to be wasted on kids. What do these books lack that a good adult book should have? The latest, URANUS (Morrow Junior Books, $12.95. Ages 4 to 8), like its companions, is beautiful, evocative, neat, simple, informative. Is it not, for example, neat and simple to point out, as Mr. Simon does, by way of stating that Uranus is about 31,000 miles across and thus much larger than Earth (7,926 miles across), that if Uranus were hollow, about 50 Earths could fit inside? And doesn't it ignite the imagination to be asked to pilot a spaceship high over Uranus as thick blue-green clouds sweep across the planet at 200 miles per hour, and to be told that as you approach the surface boiling drops of steam surround you and the temperature climbs into the thousands of degrees?

title: RIGHTING A WRONG
description: Russell Baker's amusing essay ''High-Flying Confusion'' (Sunday Observer, Jan. 10), on how journalists confess error, recalls an anecdote told about John Foster Dulles, a prominent lawyer who was Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Administration. Mr. Dulles was once asked whether he had ever been wrong. He is said to have pondered the question for some time before replying. ''Yes,'' he finally admitted, ''once - many, many years ago. I thought I had made a wrong decision. Of course, it turned out that I had been right all along. But I was wrong to have thought that I was wrong.'' NORMAN DORSEN New York, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: STRAYED TEACHERS Two one-act single-character plays that focus on teachers who have strayed from the norm are opening at East Coast Arts in New Rochelle. They will run from Feb. 18 through March 13 and three previews will be performed, at 3 P.M. next Sunday and 8 P.M. Feb. 16 and 17.

title: Soviet Called Ready to Back Iran Embargo
description: A Soviet official said today that Moscow is ready to support a United Nations Security Council resolution that would impose an arms embargo on Iran for failing to accept a cease-fire in its war with Iraq.

title: A House of Art That Is Quirky, Aloof and Grand
description: Though best known in his lifetime for having invented an invaluable antiseptic, Dr. Albert C. Barnes (1872-1951) had an auxiliary reputation as a major art collector and the founder of a private educational facility in the suburbs of Philadelphia. In its turn, that facility had also a double reputation. Dedicated to the propagation of Dr. Barnes' view of art history, it had the use of what is undoubtedly the greatest teaching collection ever assembled in one place.

title: PREPARE FOR THE WORST?
description: CALCULATED RISKS A Century of Arms Control, Why It Has Failed, and How It Can Be Made to Work. By Bruce D. Berkowitz. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Metro Matters; Long After Lisa, Tragedy of Abuse Can Still Happen
description: Nearly 100 days ago, Lisa Steinberg was fatally beaten in her family's Greenwich Village apartment. Not only could it happen again to someone else, it has.

title: The Massacre at Orangeburg
description: LEAD: Charles Hildebrand was testifying about events on Feb. 8, 1968, at South Carolina State College.

title: Who'll Take Him To 'the Other Side'?
description: In the last month of his life, my friend Bob Walden finally learned to love Mozart.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Judging of Breeds Starts at 9 A.M.
description: The Westminster Kennel Club show will feature 2,651 dogs vying for the best-in-show title. The sporting, hound and toy breeds will be benched and judged today, starting at 9 A.M., with the groups at 8 P.M. On Tues-day, the working, terrier, non-sport-ing seven rings, from 8:30 A.M.

title: Talks Set on Savings Unit Breakup
description: Federal regulators will meet on Wednesday with representatives of several California savings and loan institutions to discuss a proposal for breaking up the troubled Financial Corporation of America, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Gang Violence Shocks Los Angeles
description: It began as a pleasant Saturday night out for Karen Toshima: dinner with a friend and a stroll through the bustling Westwood Village on the affluent West Side of Los Angeles. A short time later Miss Toshima, a 27-year-old graphic artist, lay mortally wounded on the sidewalk next to a parking meter, a bullet through her head. She was the latest innocent victim of the West Coast's vicious youth-gang wars.

title: Officer Added in Shifts At Amoskeag, Fieldcrest
description: The Amoskeag Company, which controls Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., has taken a new top executive, C. Edward Midgley, from Wall Street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1988
description: Companies

title: 127 Die in Floods and Mud Slides in Brazil
description: Floods and mud slides have killed at least 127 people in Rio de Janeiro state since Friday, a civil defense spokesman said today.

title: Olympic Notebook; Skipping Games To Carry A Price
description: From now on, it could cost any country that does not participate in the Summer Olympics. But not much.

title: G.M. Chief Promises To Hold '88 Car Prices
description: The General Motors Corporation will hold the prices of its cars and trucks for the rest of the 1988 model year, Roger B. Smith, the company's chairman, promised dealers here.

title: Nigeria Plants Finished
description: Two petrochemical plants that Nigeria set out to build 18 years ago are finally ready, an official for the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation said Friday. The plants will turn part of the country's oil and gas output into stocks that can be used to make products ranging from drugs and paints to car parts and printers ink.

title: Sports of The Times; Oh, What a Flight
description: IT was so delightful, so delicious, so absolutely delovely that even Michael Jordan himself got embarrassed.

title: Broadway Plans Benefit For Victims of AIDS
description: A number of Broadway performers and other theater professionals are to take part in a free event on Feb. 10 at the St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street. The show, which starts at 11:30 A.M. and is open to the public on a first-come basis, is sponsored by ''Broadway Cares,'' a support and resource organization for victims of AIDS. Among those scheduled to appear are Peter Allen, Liz Callaway, Brian Dennehy, Joel Grey, Marvin Hamlisch, Judith Ivey, Linda Lavin and Penn and Teller.

title: Jordan Scores 40 And Wins M.V.P.
description: From the day the National Basketball Association awarded Chicago the All-Star Game, the expectation was that it would be a weekend made for Michael Jordan. It was.

title: Dog Shows; Westminster Opens Today
description: The Westminster Kennel Club, which has been holding dog shows since 1877, making its show one of the oldest continuous sporting events in the country, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden this morning. There are 2,651 dogs representing 140 breeds or varieties, and they come from 48 states (North Dakota and Hawaii are the exceptions), the District of Columbia, Canada, Puerto Rico and Bermuda.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A list of credits in Weekend on Jan. 29 with a film review of ''Anguish'' misidentified the screenwriter. The film was written and directed by Bigas Luna.

title: U.S. Role in Korean Jet Downing Merits Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: School Plan For Australia
description: University of Rochester officials and Mary Lady Fairfax, the widow of the Australian financier Sir William Fairfax, have agreed to open an American-style graduate business school near Sydney, Australia, officials of the school said last week.

title: Preaching Politics and Courting Votes
description: In pulpits all over Iowa this Sunday morning, the word went forth that Christians had a duty to fulfill, at once sacred and civic, in Monday's caucuses.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Bold on Charity, Bashful on Publicity
description: When his name surfaced last month in connection with a Congressional appropriation of $8 million to build schools in France for refugees from North Africa, Zev W. Wolfson was appalled.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AVX Corp., Great Neck, L.I., which manufactures electronic components, named Charles A. Dill president and chief operating officer, replacing Donald K. Thostenson, who has been named chairman of the executive committee.

title: Don't Fear for NATO
description: Many Americans believe that the Soviet Union could overwhelm NATO defenses in a conventional war in Western Europe. They must have been surprised last week when a group of European political leaders opposed the idea that the West should build up its conventional forces before the United States ratifies the treaty banning short- and medium-range missiles.

title: No Way to Cut Strategic Nuclear Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has agreed to acquire a majority interest in Imparc, Dusseldorf, West Germany, from BBDO Worldwide, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Portugal Cuts Rates
description: Portugal announced on Friday a half-point reduction in interest rates to help ease credit costs and increase investment in one of Western Europe's fastest-growing economies. The Finance Minister, Miguel Cadilhe, said the cut, the fourth in just over a year, would take effect Monday. He said the maximum interest rate for all loans would drop to 18 percent while the minimum rate for time deposit savings of between six months and a year would fall to 13.5 percent.

title: Advertising; Zwiren in Chicago Wins A Product of Miles Labs
description: After a three-way competition, the household products division of Miles Laboratories has assigned a Chicago agency, Zwiren & Partners, its SOS Glassworks cleaner and new-products account. The annual budget is $4.4 million.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Babe Ruth was switched from pitching to the outfield because of his ability to hit the ball even better than he pitched it. Just how good a hitter was Ruth as a pitcher?

title: Bork Clerk Makes It
description: The newest Supreme Court Justice, Anthony M. Kennedy, has hired one of Judge Robert H. Bork's former law clerks to join him when he begins work at the Court on Feb. 18. Judge Kennedy's new law clerk, Peter D. Keisler, who now works in the White House as one of six associate counsels to the President, got to know the future Justice when he was assigned to assist him with his Senate confirmation hearings in December.

title: Dassault Plane Order
description: Dassault, the French aerospace company, said Friday that it had won its first export order in more than two years when Jordan agreed to buy 20 Mirage-2000 multi-role combat aircraft. No exact value was given, but the sale ended a lean period for Avions Marcel Dassault-Breguet Aviation. The state-controlled company's previous significant sale had been more than two years ago, when India purchased Mirage-2000 aircraft. The company cut 1,261 of its 15,000-employee work force in October.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For me, time doesn't exist.

title: Dance: XXY Troupe
description: THE theater of XXY Dance/ Music might have been described best as multimedia in other times, when the point of incorporating several art forms was usually to create a smoothly-transcendent blend. But ''Steady On,'' presented by XXY on Saturday at the Emanu-El Midtown Y Dance Center, would more properly be described as collagist. The dance, music, film, slides and video that made up ''Steady On'' stood out as discrete elements, each holding its own without diminishing the impact of the others.

title: College Basketball; Purdue Is Alone Atop the Big Ten
description: Troy Lewis of Purdue scored 14 of his 20 points in the second half today as the sixth-ranked Boilermakers beat No. 11 Michigan, 91-87, to take sole possession of first place in the Big Ten Conference.

title: Joint Mitsui Venture Draws Lease Experts
description: Peter K. Nevitt, former chairman of the BankAmerilease Group, the leasing arm of the BankAmerica Corporation, has struck out on his own in a leasing venture in conjunction with the Japanese.

title: 'Super' Science Squeezes 'Small' Science
description: LEAD: Anyone who followed science news during 1987 must have gotten the impression, quite correctly, that the most exciting science activity was on the new superconductivity. He or she would, I suppose, also assume that those of us who work in this field are being more liberally funded than we were two years ago.

title: Second Drug Agent Is Dead After Ambush by Suspects
description: A Federal drug agent was pronounced dead Saturday, a day after he was shot in an ambush by drug traffickers. Another agent and two suspects died in the shooting.

title: Article 824188 -- No Title
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire I.M.S. International for $1.77 billion in stock.

title: Haiti Says Philadelphia Garbage Was Dumped by Ship on Its Beach
description: A cargo ship chartered in the United States has dumped about 4,000 tons of garbage from Philadelphia on a Haitian beach, according to Haitian Government officials.

title: Ms. Furman Weds Nathan Willensky
description: The marriage of Barbara Furman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Furman of Manasota Key, Englewood, Fla., to Nathan David Willensky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Willensky of Atlantic Beach, L.I., took place yesterday at the Stanhope in New York. Rabbi Bernard M. Zlotowitz performed the ceremony.

title: Police Chief Of Jersey City Kills Himself
description: At 6:15 A.M. yesterday, the Jersey City Chief of Police, John Fritz, walked into Police Headquarters at 8 Erie Street, went to his third-floor office and locked the door. He took his .38-caliber off-duty revolver from a safe and sometime in the next three hours, police officials said, sat down in his high-backed executive's chair and killed himself with a single shot to the right temple.

title: The Dance: Shamanic Rituals From Korea
description: KOREAN shamanic dance was a focus of two events over the weekend in New York City, one a seminar at Asia Society and the other a performance by Hi-ah Park on Friday night at the Open Center. The word performance is used advisedly here, for Miss Park herself stressed that the evening was a version of a shamanic ritual that was modified for the time and place. Her audience, clustered around her in the center's small ''teahouse'' performance space, seemed to have come as much to participate as to learn about and observe shamanic dance.

title: Sports World Specials; Mark of Assistance
description: As a fourth-grader, Suzie McConnell's grammar school did not have a girls' basketball team, so she did the obvious thing.

title: 'Ice' Hockey Without the Ice and the Blades
description: It took two Minnesota hockey players to discover that it is possible to play a decent game of ice hockey without ice. Brennan Olson and his brother, Scott, were rummaging around a Midwest sport shop one day in 1979 when they found an old skate with wheels attached in a straight line instead of in pairs. As avid high school hockey players, they were intrigued. Here, finally, was a way to train for hockey in the off season.

title: Desperately Seeking Hollywood
description: The seminar began at 9 A.M. on a sunny Saturday morning, but there were crowds of eager, bright-eyed hopefuls lining up even earlier. Indeed, the offering seemed to many like the Holy Grail.

title: Richard Feinson Weds Lynn Riley
description: The marriage of Lynn Riley, the daughter of Mary F. Riley of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Timbes Riley, to Richard Feinson, a son of Janice Feinson of New York and Melbourne Beach, Fla., and the late Burton Feinson, took place yesterday in Bronxville at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. John M. Kiernan. Village Justice Virginia S. Knaplund of Scarsale, N.Y., officiated.

title: Advertising; Goodyear Picks HDM For Los Angeles Work
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, based in Akron, Ohio, has named HDM, Los Angeles, to handle its Los Angeles retail broadcast advertising. The budget is estimated between $3 million and $5 million.

title: Offers Weighed By Federated
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., which rejected two takeover offers by the Campeau Corporation on Friday, is exploring interest received from ''various third parties'' in acquiring some of its principal assets or the entire company, Federated said in a weekend statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article from Puerto Rico on Wednesday about the arrest of three American soldiers and a Panamanian on drug charges misstated the location of two military installations.

title: Jazz: Sandra Reaves-Phillips
description: SANDRA REAVES-PHILLIPS is a big-voiced Southern blues belter who belongs squarely in a tradition that extends from Ma Rainey through Dinah Washington. But the singer, who is appearing at the Top of the Village Gate in a show called ''Heart to Heart, My True Confessions,'' would like to be more than that. In her previous one-woman show, ''The Late Great Ladies of Blues and Jazz'' last year, she impersonated a number of legendary singers, including Billie Holiday, whose stylistic essence utterly eluded her.

title: Analysts Question Drop in Yields
description: Disregarding the yellow flags waved by some economists, the credit markets have raced to lower yields in the belief that the Federal Reserve will try to stave off impending weakness in the economy by easing its monetary policy and reducing short-term interest rates.

title: INDIAN HOSTAGE CASE BRINGS UP QUESTIONS ABOUT RURAL JUSTICE
description: When the Rural Justice Center looked for a place exemplifying some of the most vexing problems of rural justice in the United States, it came here to Robeson County, which has a volatile population mix of whites, blacks and Indians, and a District Attorney who has put more people on death row than any prosecutor in the United States.

title: Dawn Upshaw to Sing With Chamber Group
description: The soprano Dawn Upshaw will be guest soloist with the Apple Hill Chamber Players on Wednesday when the group gives the first of three monthly chamber-music concerts at Merkin Concert Hall. The ensemble, which is based in Nelson, N.H., comprises a string quartet, double bassist and two pianists.

title: Fort Chaffee Journal; From Training Ground to Film Set
description: A visit to this nearly deserted Army post is a journey back in time, mostly to the grim, early days of World War II. Since then, Fort Chaffee has been a training camp for American soldiers, jail for German prisoners of war, reception area for Vietnamese refugees and holding camp for Cuban expatriates.

title: Mecham's Home and Business Are Damaged
description: A shotgun blast was fired Saturday at the home of Evan Mecham, the impeached Governor of Arizona, and today Mr. Mecham's car dealership was vandalized in a glass-breaking spree, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1988
description: International A2-9

title: 27-Year-Old Author Bemused by Success
description: Ethan Canin is 27 years old, a graduate of Stanford and a fourth-year medical student at Harvard. He is also the author of the just published ''Emperor of the Air,'' a collection of nine short stories. His work has appeared in The Atlantic, Esquire and Ploughshares, and has been reprinted in ''The Best American Short Stories'' of 1985 and 1986. He has also won the Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship, a prize awarded in the past to such writers as Philip Roth, Robert Stone and Robert Penn Warren.

title: Sports World Specials
description: More Than a Fantasy The problem with fantasy sports camps is not that the average person doesn't harbor fantasies of hitting a home run to win the World Series, it's that the average person would like to sustain those fantasies.

title: Don't Take Away Tenure of School Principals
description: To the Editor:

title: Caracas Journal; The Reconstructed Rebel He Fights by the Rules
description: Young, middle-class, well-educated and unabashedly inspired by the Cuban revolution, Teodoro Petkoff Malec was one of the leaders of the guerrilla war begun by Venezuela's Communists in the early 1960's to overthrow the country's new democracy.

title: Carbide Plea on Bhopal Aid
description: The Union Carbide Corporation complained Friday that a court order requiring interim relief payments to victims of the Bhopal gas disaster did not specify who would get the aid, the United News of India reported.

title: Film: 'Crazy Moon'
description: THE Festival Theater probably did not intend to have a mini-Kiefer Sutherland series. But after ''Promised Land,'' the new coming-of-age-in-Utah film featuring the actor, last Friday it brought in ''Crazy Moon,'' a 1986 Canadian movie in which he stars. You can't blame Mr. Sutherland for the lameness of either one. In fact, he and his co-star, Vanessa Vaughan, save ''Crazy Moon'' from its own worst tendencies. It keeps threatening to become ''Children of a Lesser God Goes to High School.''

title: FIVE MORE DEAD IN ARAB PROTESTS
description: Israeli soldiers firing into a stone-throwing crowd killed three Palestinians in this tiny village today as demonstrations flared all along the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Italians Fear Taint in Stock Drop
description: Until recently Raul Gardini was viewed as the embodiment of the new Italian entrepreneur: glamorous, aggressive and ready to play a role in financial markets around the world.

title: Rostropovich to Present New Soviet Composition
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, will present the world premiere next month of the first piece of music written for him by a Soviet composer since he left the Soviet Union in 1974.

title: Groundwork and Guesswork Mark The End of Iowa Caucus Campaign
description: The people of Iowa, having listened for more than two years to the men who would be President, will make their choices Monday night in nominating caucuses where the margins of victory will hinge on which campaigns do the best job of getting their supporters to attend.

title: Canadian Jobless Rate
description: Canada's unemployment rate remained unchanged, at 8.1 percent, in January as the growth in jobs was matched by an increase in the labor force, Statistics Canada reported Friday. The Government agency said that on a seasonally adjusted basis there were 12,228,000 people employed in January, up 38,000 from December. The number of jobless remained unchanged, at 1,072,000.

title: How Students Fought Censorship in the 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Aaron C. Sterling, Fund-Raiser, 63
description: Aaron C. Sterling, a fund-raiser and promoter of charitable causes, died of congestive heart failure Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Sports World Specials; Getting a Chance
description: In Division I college basketball, everyone has a story. The paths to the big time are winding. The tales are often legendary. David Wagner of Iona has a story, one that is unique in a unique world.

title: Air of Zaniness Brushes Iowa Just in Time for Caucus Day
description: There was the unmistakable air of carnival today, as if some zany festival of democracy had erupted in this ordinarily earnest Midwestern city.

title: Bridge: Some Fine Defensive Moves Are Written but Not Played
description: It is often important to make a crucial play without any revealing hesitation, and declarers often plan ahead, making the decision mentally a few tricks before the fact.

title: Static for Broadcaster
description: Sam Donaldson, the ABC White House correspondent who is noted for holding the President accountable for gaffes, is getting a taste of his own medicine.

title: States Assuming a New Role in Consumer Issues
description: State attorneys general, working collectively on consumer issues they say are ignored by Federal agencies, are emerging as an alternative national enforcement agency in an era of deregulation.

title: Guard Killed by Off-Duty Officer
description: A New York State correction officer was fatally shot by a New York City police officer last night in the Bronx in what the police said might have been an accident.

title: Donation to Neediest Honors Accountant As Good Samaritan
description: A young C.P.A. in Mamaroneck, N.Y., who was working late one recent bitter cold night, learned that the oil had run out in the home of an elderly couple. The man was recovering from a severe throat infection, and his wife was in bed critically ill.

title: Bordering on Scandal in Ulster
description: The British Government won't prosecute Northern Ireland police who blocked an investigation of the police shooting in 1982 of seven unarmed men, six of whom died. Nor will the Attorney General, Sir Patrick Mayhew, publish the report of an inquiry into these shootings. Thus he seems to confirm a cover-up but won't do anything about it for reasons of ''national security.'' You don't have to be Irish to scent something rotten about criminal justice in the British-ruled North; justifiably, it's stirring an outcry in the Irish Republic.

title: Fuzzbusted
description: Despite its evident good sense, banning radar detectors, or ''fuzzbusters,'' has not proved popular either in Congress or in state legislatures. Only Virginia, Connecticut and the District of Columbia have adopted such a ban.

title: Power-Sharing Plan Falters In a South African Province
description: Since white settlers began arriving here 150 years ago, Natal has been known for its magnificent beaches and mountains, its sugar cane and a brand of racial politics as conservative as any in South Africa. Now some of its leading citizens are promoting a plan for a multiracial government in the province, hoping that it will head off demands for black majority rule.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Jan. 16 about a call for an economic boycott to protest racism in New York City misidentified the group that urged action against WABC-TV. The group is the Committee to Eliminate Media Offensive to African People.

title: Why Was It There?
description: To the Editor:

title: Architecture: Shows on Stanford White
description: MCKIM, Mead & White are not the latest names in town, and an exhibition of this great architectural firm's work, most of which was done between the 1880's and 1910, would normally be the occasion for not much more than an appreciative nod. But this month there are not one but two exhibitions dealing with the firm's architecture, proof that McKim, Mead & White continues to possess, more than three-quarters of a century after its leading partners' deaths, nearly mythic status in New York. A disproportionate amount of the city's finest turn-of-the-century architecture, both buildings lost and buildings preserved, was designed by this firm. Stanford White and Charles McKim were in every sense New York's landmark architects.

title: Diverse Musical Series Planned for Tully Hall
description: The Composers' Showcase series will offer three programs at Alice Tully Hall this season. The series opens Feb. 29 with a Leonard Bernstein Song Celebration, performed by a wide range of artists from the worlds of classical music and Broadway. They will include Betty Comden, Adolf Green, Ben Holt, Julia Migenes and William Sharp.

title: The Dance: Premiere Of 'Shaman's Journey'
description: ''ASIA and the American Indian'' was the title of a symposium at the Asia Society on Saturday that explored the role of shamanism in America and Asia, and it was a dancer of American Indian descent -Raoul Trujillo - who best summed up the daylong scholarly lectures. In ''The Shaman's Journey,'' an extrardinarily vivid dance solo created for the occasion, Mr. Trujillo brought the event to a rousing and symbolic close in the evening.

title: The Anger in Bob Dole Is One Key to His Power
description: A Senate supporter of Bob Dole said recently: ''Bob Dole never forgives and never forgets. You know if you cross him, you've got problems.''

title: Hong Kong Dollar at Issue
description: A senior Hong Kong official said Friday that the colony's currency, which is linked to the United States dollar, would not be revalued and he denied that Washington had directly asked the Government to do so.

title: Woman to Go on Trial As Smuggler's Helper
description: Nearly two and a half years after a daredevil cocaine smuggler fell to his death on a driveway here when his parachute failed, a woman accused of being his accomplice is going on trial on drug charges.

title: Rock: Peter Himmelman
description: PETER HIMMELMAN brought simple, unquestioning rock-and-roll to the Bottom Line last Wednesday. Fronting a four-member group of friends from his hometown of Minneapolis, Mr. Himmelman, a guitarist and songwriter, put on a sturdy, tight show that brimmed with faith in the whole rock process and in himself as a song writer.

title: Peaceful Heavy Metal
description: American and Soviet schoolchildren are becoming acquainted here under an exchange between the Soviet Embassy school and some Washington area schools.

title: MARCHING IN LIKE SOCIAL LIONS AND OUT TO YAWNS
description: Next January a new cast of characters will take over at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue and there are some Washingtonians itching for the drama to begin. The capital thrives on change: new faces, new issues, new personalities, new political battles.

title: PANAMA RECALLS ENVOYS FROM U.S. AS CRISIS DEEPENS
description: In an action reflecting the growing crisis in relations between Panama and the United States, the Panamanian Government has recalled three senior diplomats, including its Ambassador to Washington, for ''urgent consultations,'' state-controlled radio stations and newspapers here said today.

title: Let the Music Play
description: A welcome court ruling that strikes down a dissonant provision of New York City's cabaret law could encourage a jazz revival in the city.

title: Battling Athletes Hurt Sports' Image
description: For the second consecutive game, the Cornell University basketball team is involved in a fight, this one against Syracuse in the Carrier Dome. It starts when Greg Gilda of Cornell and Derrick Brower of Syracuse begin bumping and pushing under the basket. Punches are thrown and both are ejected, as is Derrick Coleman of Syracuse, who left the bench to join the festivities.

title: INSIDE
description: Haitian President Sworn In

title: New York City, the Landlord: A Decade of Housing Decay
description: A decade after it began accumulating a vast stock of rundown apartment houses, New York City finds itself unable to manage them, repair them, return them to private landlords or improve the abysmal conditions for the tens of thousands of people living in them.

title: Sikhs Kill Four at Wedding
description: Sikh militants opened fire today on a Hindu wedding party, killing the bridegroom and three other people, the police said. Four Sikh radicals arrived at the party near the town of Kapurthala, about 43 miles north of here, and began shooting AK-47 assault rifles, the police said.

title: Whalers Make Coaching Change
description: Larry Pleau, coach of the Binghamton Whalers of the American Hockey Leauge, was named today to replace Jack Evans as the Hartford Whalers' coach.

title: Widow of Bukharin Fulfills Her Mission 50 Years Later
description: Anna Mikhailovna Larina was barely 17 years old when the Bolshevik revolutionary Nikolai Ivanovich Bukharin proposed to her. By the age of 22, she was his wife, a budding economist and a mother. By 24, she was his widow, inheriting scorn and infamy.

title: Golf; Lopez Wins Her First Opener
description: Nancy Lopez has won 37 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournaments, but today's victory in the $200,000 Mazda Classic was her first in a season opener.

title: 3 Borough Presidents Urge Balance of Power
description: Three of New York City's five Borough Presidents said yesterday that any new form of governance must not create an unchecked, all-powerful Mayor's office.

title: A Leader in Seoul Opposition Steps Down as Head of Party
description: In an effort to reunify South Korea's divided opposition, Kim Young Sam resigned this morning as president of one of the nation's two main opposition parties.

title: Yonkers Church Is Desecrated
description: Burglars broke into an Episcopal church in Yonkers for the second time in a month early today and desecrated the interior.

title: Advertising; An Orderly Succession At Ogilvy
description: ALTHOUGH William E. Phillips, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, said Friday that he would relinquish his title to Kenneth Roman, 57, the chairman of the Ogilvy Group's largest operating company, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, the news did not take many people by surprise.

title: OPEC Output Cut Reported
description: OPEC's oil production fell sharply last month, mainly because of cutbacks by Persian Gulf exporters, including Saudi Arabia, according to the International Energy Agency.

title: On Your Own: Running; Motivating Kids to Exercise Can Be Child's Play
description: ONE day not long ago I took our younger daughter, Jamie, who is 8 years old, out to the backyard to run. I set up a course and asked her to circle it several times. An active child, she'd been jogging on and off for a couple of years and began this session with a spirited stride.

title: Heads for Concessions at Pan Am Is Appalling
description: To the Editor:

title: Games Symbolic To North Korea
description: North Korea's demand to be a co-host of the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, is tied to its desire for reunification with South Korea, a senior North Korean sports official said Saturday night.

title: 3 Men Found Dead As Temperatures Dip During the Weekend
description: Two men believed to have been homeless were found dead on Manhattan streets during the weekend, and a third was found dead in a field on Wards Island as temperatures plunged to the lowest point in three weeks, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Recital: Sylvia Kowalczuk
description: SYLVIA KOWALCZUK'S recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night addressed two problems faced by everyone who plays the harp for a living. One is to find a consistently strong repertory; the other is to create clear, unambiguous diatonic statements - melodic lines and harmonic progressions capable of penetrating the harp's rainbow of overtones.

title: Richard Flickinger, Politician, 71
description: Mayor Richard Flickinger, who guided the passage of what may have been the nation's first municipal ban on pistols, died at his home Monday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: OSCAR WILDE. By Richard Ellmann. Illustrated. 680 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: British Air's Airbus Order
description: British Airways said today that it would take delivery of all 10 A320 aircraft on order from the European Airbus consortium despite a dispute over fuel consumption.

title: College Basketball Finds 3 To Be a Very Lucky Number
description: LEAD: WHEN Stan Albeck left professional basketball to rejoin the college ranks last season, he vowed his Bradley Braves' first shot would be a 3-point field-goal attempt. True to his word, on the team's opening possession, a Bradley player fired a shot from behind the new line, drawn 19 feet 9 inches from the center of the basket.

title: U.S. Schedules Interviews On Fate of Cuban Inmates
description: ''he Federal Government has begun moving to determine the fate of 2,400 Cubans transferred last year from riot-torn prisons in Georgia and Louisiana, amid criticism of the review process and of conditions under which the Cubans are now held.

title: Outdoors: Hunting From an Unusual Blind
description: ALTHOUGH the excuses offered by waterfowlers who fail to shoot their limit of birds are as plentiful as pinfeathers on a young duck, I have one that is, I believe, without precedent.

title: TV Review; A Family Disappearance, In NBC's 'Moving Target'
description: A YOUNG man returns home.

title: Advertising; Search Is Narrowed to 3 By United Jersey Banks
description: United Jersey Banks, Princeton, N.J., has narrowed its search for an ad agency. Still in the running are three New York shops: Geer, DuBois plus Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and McCaffrey & McCall. The previous budget was estimated at more than $2 million.

title: New Income Tax Rules Mean Work and Confusion for Filers
description: This year's tax filing season will be a historic, if confusing, time for American taxpayers as they grapple with the intricacies of the vastly revised Federal income tax system for the first time.

title: Depleted Rangers Topple Penguins
description: Six days ago, the Rangers lost Chris Nilan and, with him, much of their limited muscle. On Saturday night, they lost Kelly Kisio and the scoring punch he brought. In the last week, however, they have somehow gained both momentum and ground in the Patrick Division.

title: A Cautious Cushion for Banks
description: It's almost a deal: the Federal Reserve Board and regulators in Western Europe and Japan have agreed to common capital requirements for commercial banks. The reforms may crimp the style and profitability of some giant ''money center'' banks. But that's a reasonable price to pay to cushion the world financial system against the stresses of rapid growth and integration.

title: Panama's Financial Ills Grow Worse
description: Panama's central bank reserves are nearly depleted, its trade deficit is growing and it is increasingly hard-pressed in making payments to its creditors, according to United States Government officials and private bankers.

title: Networks to Broadcast Results of Caucuses
description: Results of the Iowa caucuses will be broadcast tonight by all three commercial networks, with NBC and ABC airing 30-minute news specials at 10:30 P.M. Eastern standard time, and CBS following at 11:30 (11:35 in New York City). Cable News Network will provide live coverage from Des Moines beginning at 8 P.M. Eastern time.

title: Art: Picasso's 'Demoiselles'
description: ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon,'' the 1907 masterpiece that liberated the savage genius of Pablo Picasso and set the tone for a century of artistic discontinuity and shock, has, for a few months at least, come home. In an exhibition of around 85 works that is itself ground-breaking, the Picasso Museum has documented the evolution of this complex and convulsive painting and presented it within its artistic context for the first time.

title: Golf; Steve Jones Earns First PGA Victory
description: Steve Jones achieved the first victory of his PGA Tour career today when he sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a playoff with Bob Tway to win the A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: A.M.A. Resists Giving Name Of Doctor in a Mercy Killing
description: The American Medical Association says only a court order could force it to disclose the identity of a physician who wrote an essay about injecting a terminally ill patient with a lethal dose of morphine.

title: Devils Relish Break After Another Loss
description: The break for the National Hockey League All-Star Game couldn't have come at a better time for the Devils, who are dispirited and hurting.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Market Index chart in Business Day last Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday carried incorrect values for all dates before Jan. 30. The values should have been two points higher.

title: Waldheim Placed in Town of Reprisals
description: A Yugoslav newspaperman has unearthed documents and interviewed witnesses that place Kurt Waldheim as the sole German Army officer in a small town when mass reprisal shootings and deportations of Yugoslav civilians were conducted during World War II.

title: Burton W. Marsh, 90; City Traffic Engineer
description: Burton Wallace Marsh, the first full-time city traffic engineer in the United States, died of cardiac arrest as the result of pneumonia Thursday at the Bethesda Retirement and Nursing Center in Maryland. He was 90 years old.

title: Across Soviet, Brezhnev's Name Falls
description: Where a monument to Leonid I. Brezhnev once stood, there is now an uneven sidewalk, covered with a dusting of snow and frozen dirt. The large black Cyrillic letters that spelled out his name on a nearby metal and concrete billboard have been erased.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Kenneth A. Glaser joins Solin Associates as executive vice president.

title: DONAGED-EGG SUCCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Facts Paint Iowa as a Civics Teacher, Gently Voicing Heartfelt Lessons
description: Iowa is small, flat and remote from the great capitals of finance, government and communications. It has neither beaches nor mountains, neither battlefields nor splendid colonial houses.

title: Carlucci Calls for New Tactical Missiles
description: Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci and ranking American legislators called upon West Germany and other European allies today to fulfill a five-year-old alliance commitment to modernize short-range nuclear weapons.

title: The Wilder Side Of Winter Sports
description: LEAD: MOUNTAINS and woods may seem full of hardship and danger in winter, but every year more people are finding fun, excitement and challenge outdoors during the season.

title: Talking Business; with Glauber of Presidential Task Force; Debate on Letting 2 Markets Interact
description: A provocative finding of the Presidential commission that studied the October stock collapse was that cutting off the ability to perform trades between the stock market and the stock index futures market aggravated the crisis.

title: Advertising; Ketchum Will Phase In Executive Realignment
description: Ketchum Communications, Pittsburgh, has announced an executive realignment to be accomplished during a year-long transition period. Edward L. Graf, 49, now executive vice president, will become vice chairman and remain chief financial officer. Herbert D. Gordon, 49, president of Ketchum Yellow Pages, will become executive vice president. And Michael J. Kaczmarski, 34, vice president and controller, will become senior vice president.

title: Fed's Talks This Week To Yield Signs on Goals
description: This week's meeting of the Federal Reserve, which stands almost alone these days in managing the economy, will provide important indications of its goals for growth and interest rates and will test its resistance to political influence.

title: Strike Begins Against Ford In Britain
description: A strike by production workers at the Ford Motor Company's 21 plants in Britain, which started late tonight, is the first national walkout in a decade at the nation's leading car maker.

title: Man Kills 3 and Himself at Party
description: A man killed three people, including his father, at a family anniversary celebration before mortally wounding himself, the police said today.

title: PRESS CURBS INCREASING IN COURTS
