description: In almost every high-profile case tried recently in the New York courts, judges have been sealing documents, holding secret hearings, curbing lawyers' out-of-court remarks or taking other actions to limit the access of news organizations and the public to sensitive information.

title: Fitness; Circling the Malls to Get in Shape
description: SNOW pelted car windshields and a stiff easterly wind cut through parkas one morning here recently, several hours before stores at the Aurora Mall in suburban Denver opened.

title: Girl, 14, Slain During Errand To Buy a Paper
description: A 14-year-old girl who had gone out to buy a newspaper for her family yesterday morning was found slain a few hours later on a railroad embankment in Richmond Hill, Queens, the police said.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO: A CONTRAST IN BUDGET FORECASTS
description: As Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch presented their budget plans for next year recently, a listener could be forgiven for wondering if the two men lived in the same state. Despite the stock market plunge in October, Mr. Cuomo, who presented his budget to the State Legislature last month, gave an optimistic appraisal of the economy. Predicting ''relatively little adverse impact'' from the sharp fall in stock prices, he called for a substantial increase in spending and proposed no major new taxes.

title: Rafi Nelson, Resort Owner
description: Rafi Nelson, a former journalist and public relations man who became the owner of a beachfront resort, died Saturday of a heart attack, the Israeli radio reported today. He was 57 years old. Mr. Nelson operated Rafi Nelson's Holiday Village, a popular resort in the tiny enclave of Taba, claimed both by Egypt and Israel. In the 1950's, Mr. Nelson made headlines when he sailed through the Suez Canal and was arrested and jailed briefly by the Egyptian authorities. Mr. Nelson's funeral is scheduled for Tuesday in Elath.

title: New York Prisons Find New Work for Inmates
description: At a time when some states are turning their prison workshops over to private managers, New York State prison officials are taking a different course: They are hunting for new products, new customers and new ways to put inmates to work.

title: Pitcher's Salary Cut in Arbitration
description: Mike Moore, the Seattle pitcher who suffered 19 losses last season, has become only the seventh player in the 13-year history of salary arbi-tration to suffer a pay cut in the procedure. Moore and Jime Acker, an Atlanta pitcher, learned yesterday they had lost their cases.

title: Strong Quake in Aleutians
description: A strong earthquake occurred this morning near the far western end of the Aleutian Islands, the United States Geological Survey said. It was centered in the Pacific Ocean, about 130 miles south of Shemya Island, and was felt slightly on Shemya. The quake registered 6.1 on the Richter scale.

title: Theme of Economic Forum Is a Tighter Belt for U.S.
description: They came, they skied, they chatted.

title: Lockheed Layoffs Set
description: Officials at the Lockheed Corporation confirmed during the weekend that its Aeronautical Systems Company division, which builds military air transports for the Air Force, expects to lay off 9,000 employees, mostly production workers, by next January.

title: Brazil Fights Back
description: Brazil has mounted a major diplomatic effort to head off $105 million of trade sanctions planned by the United States in retaliation against Brazil's reluctance to buy American computer software.

title: Japan Given Chip Proposals
description: The United States has suggested 18 specific steps that the Japanese Government and industries could take to increase imports of American-made semiconductors, and the two sides will discuss the issue this week, a Japanese official said.

title: Air Force Panel Reverses Part Of an Officer's Adultery Case
description: The adultery conviction of a female Air Force officer accused of having an affair with another officer has been set aside by the Air Force Court of Military Review, her civilian lawyer says.

title: Safety of All-Terrain Vehicles
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission and a Federal district judge are expected to decide soon whether to give final approval to an agreement on the future sale and production of all-terrain vehicles, which have been linked to about 900 deaths over the last five years. Under the pact, manufacturers have agreed to end production of three-wheel ATV's, but they would be allowed to continue making four-wheel models, which are considered less dangerous. A critic of the plan, Stuart M. Statler, a former commissioner at the Consumer Product Safety Commission who is now vice president for risk avoidance and product liability at A. T. Kearney Inc., an international management consulting firm, recently appeared before a House consumer subcommittee to call for more stringent measures. Here are excerpts from his testimony:

title: Market Place; Foreign Investors Return to Tokyo
description: OVERSEAS investors have jumped back into the Tokyo stock market.

title: Marinated in America
description: At last, tonight's the night. After watching months of campaigning, some 200,000 Iowans will assemble in gyms, firehouses and living rooms and declare for one of the six Republicans or seven Democrats running for President. And at last, three kinds of easy criticism will have to stop.

title: Music: Canadian Quartet
description: TOWARD the end of their Friday evening concert at the Public School 41 auditorium, the French Canadian traditional quartet La Bottine Souriante struck up a jig. Yves Lambert, who plays accordion and harmonica, began to vocalize in an argot that suggested an American mountain auctioneer singing in French in a jazzily syncopated diction. It also called to mind accelerated 20's jazz. While the piece, a singalong, was the most iconoclastic moment in the concert, its geographically far-reaching echoes were characteristic of a hearty traditional style that the quartet performed with exuberance and precision.

title: Results Plus
description: Speed Skating

title: Post's Buyer: Pursuing A Decade-Long Passion
description: The official biography of Peter S. Kalikow is a bland portrait of a New York City real-estate developer: a 45-year-old, civic-minded family man who graces the city with his buildings, gives time and money to worthy causes and has received numerous awards for his generosity and humanitarian efforts.

title: Music: Boston Quartet In 4 Composers' Works
description: THREE of the four composers on Sunday afternoon's program by the Boston Composers String Quartet have roots in either jazz or rock-and-roll; yet there was probably no one moment during this Weill Recital Hall event when either element spoke out directly. The pull of popular culture in all these pieces was, I think, more fundamental than imitation blues, synthesized bop chords or syncopation. Instead, there was everywhere the pull of traditional harmony and with it a groping for some sort of lingua franca capable of translating boldness into approachable terms.

title: Arts Festival Program Spans Century of Dance
description: The First New York International Festival of the Arts, scheduled in June and July, is announcing its offerings by discipline. Dance, listed below, was officially announced today. Details of the film and television programs are to be announced on Wednesday, and theater is to follow on Friday.

title: Pretoria Signals Move On Economic Change
description: South Africa's President P. W. Botha has announced plans to privatize five major state-run corporations that employ a total of 400,000 people and have combined assets of $30 billion.

title: Winners Chosen In 18 Specialties
description: Eighteen specialty shows were held at 12 metropolitan area sites yesterday in preparation for the Westminster Kennel Club show.

title: Murdoch Agrees to Sell The Post to Developer
description: Rupert Murdoch announced yesterday that he had agreed to sell The New York Post to Peter S. Kalikow, a New York City real-estate entrepreneur. But the $37 million sale is contingent upon significant concessions from The Post's labor unions, and Mr. Kalikow has given no guarantee that the newspaper will be kept open in any case.

title: Italian Financier Increasing Offer for Belgian Company
description: Carlo de Benedetti's investment company announced tonight that it would pay 4,000 Belgian francs, or $114, a share for up to 15 percent of the outstanding stock of Societe Generale de Belgique.

title: 2 Die in Bangladesh Quake
description: At least two people were killed and more than 100 injured Saturday night when a moderate earthquake shook Bangladesh and eastern India. The Government newspaper Dainik Bangla reported today that the deaths and most of the injuries occurred in the northeastern city of Sylhet. Walls of houses caved in around Slyhet, cracks opened up in a hospital building containing 500 beds and people ran into the streets in panic, the newspaper said. The weather office in Dhaka described the tremor as ''moderate,'' but no exact reading of its intensity was available.

title: Stage: Belasco Revival, 'Girl of the Golden West'
description: IT'S plain as the whiskers on a miner's face why any fella in Cloudy Mountain would give his britches for a kiss from ''The Girl.'' Not only does she run the mining camp's only saloon, but she also runs its ''academy,'' where Joe Miller's joke book serves as a primer. (''Can February march? No. But April may.'') She can handle men who smoke stogies and take their rotgut straight, and as she demonstrates at a critical moment, she can come up with a full house when required. She is untutored - ''I only got $32 worth of education'' - but no dummy. ''Your character's all right,'' says one of her admirers. ''That ain't your fault,'' she snaps back. Yet in Monique Fowler's altogether winning portrayal, beneath the barroom banter throbs an innocent heart. ''I got my first kiss to give,'' she confesses wistfully.

title: Dance: Biles's Company In Three of His Works
description: RICHARD BILES put steps neatly together in his choreography for the Richard Biles Dance Company, which performed Saturday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace. But the resultant dances were so bland that one longed for real flights of fancy.

title: Durrenmatt Event Canceled
description: Two evening sessions devoted to Friedrich Durrenmatt, Feb. 20 and 22 at the 92d Street Y, have been canceled because the Swiss playwright is ill. Ticket refunds or exchanges may be obtained at the box office. Information: 427-4410.

title: Regionals Rise in Bank Ranking
description: As giant banks flounder and regional banks flourish, the turmoil churning the nation's banking system is beginning to show up in the rankings of the nation's largest banking companies.

title: This Painting Shakes Hands And Audiences
description: Sometimes you get a little grouchy, said Stephen Taylor Woodrow, when you hang on a museum wall for six hours a day, covered with black spray paint.

title: Financings This Week Are Limited
description: Treasury financings this week are limited to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly sale of three-month and six-month issues totaling $12.8 billion and ending Thursday with a one-year issue of $9.25 billion.

title: CIVILIAN SWORN IN AS HAITI PRESIDENT
description: A 57-year-old former political science professor was sworn in today as President of Haiti, exactly two years after the Duvalier dictatorship collapsed.

title: Horse Racing; Equalize Outruns 15 Rivals
description: Equalize snaked his way through an overstuffed field of 16 to score a decisive 2 1/4-length victory over Yankee Affair in the $154,500 Canadian Turf Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: CONVEX COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $925,000 and $3,332,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $499,000 for the quarter and $1,740,000 for the year.

title: Dow, in Listless Trading, Falls 14.76
description: LEAD: Stock prices continued to erode yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.76 points to close at 1,895.72. The Dow has now lost ground in six of its last seven sessions.

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a pretax loss of $52,184,000 on sales of securities and a $22,372,000 provision for losses on investment securities and loans receivable. c-Net income

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-earlier quarter included a $26,566,000 gain on the sale of discontinued operations and charges of $3,635,000 from the termination of interest exchange agreements, $2,518,000 from the writedown of its Mexican unit, $1,255,000 from a work force reduction program and other charges totaling $1,629,000. The company also said 1986 year included the previously mentioned gain on sales of discontinued operations, the charges for interest exchange agreements, the Mexican unit writedown and the work force reduction program, in addition to a $1,804,000 gain on the sale of National Sanitary Supply Co. common, and $811,000 gain from a pension plan termination and several other charges totaling $722,000.

title: JEPSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $3,843,000, or 22 cents a share.

title: PENTAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in fourth quarter net is attributable to a tax credit from the company's Lake Superior Paper Industries investment.

title: SUNGARD DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $16,706,000 from discontinued insurance operations and a provision of $45 million for possible loan losses on discontinuance of mortgage insurance subsidiary. c-After a loss of $3,945,000 on Greyhound Lines Inc. bus operations and a gain of $33,099,000 on sale of Greyhound Lines, a loss from discontinued insurance operations of $35,645,000, a provision of $45 million for possible losses on discontinuance of mortgage insurance subsidiary, and an extraordinary loss of $6,211,000 on early extinguishent of debt. d-Net income e-After net of $2,621,000 for the quarter and $4,016,000 for the year, both from Greyhound Lines bus operations, which were sold on March 18, 1987; nets of $543,000 and $8,550,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from Greyhound Capital Corp., which was also sold on March 18; a gain of $79,741,000 on the sale of Greyhound Capital for both periods; losses of $124,000 for the quarter and $2,767,000 for the year, from discontinued insurance operations, and the year also included a provision of $8.1 million for discontinued reinsurance subsdiary. The revenue figures included the unconsolidated Financial Group.

title: Samaranch Blasts Drugs and Boycotts
description: The 93d session of the International Olympic Committee opened today with Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, strongly criticizing athletes who cheat by using drugs and nations that cheat their athletes by boycotting the Olympics.

title: Business and Health; Why I.M.S. Lures Dun & Bradstreet
description: THERE was wonderment, not to mention a dash of skepticism, in some financial circles when the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation announced Sunday that it was buying I.M.S. International, a medium-sized company that collects and sells facts about the drug industry. Why, some people wanted to know, would Dun & Bradstreet, the big information services company, agree to exchange more than $1.5 billion in stock for I.M.S., which had estimated earnings in 1987 of less than $45 million?

title: Measles Cases Decline After 3 Years on Rise
description: Measles is on the decline again after rising for three years, Federal health researchers report, but eradication, once believed to be at hand, may not come soon.

title: Music: The Buffalo Philharmonic
description: IF one listened closely enough during the Buffalo Philharmonic's performance in Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening, it was almost possible to hear the machinery of a career in the making. Semyon Bychkov, the ensemble's music director, was the source of this curious and distracting sound. The 35-year-old conductor, a Soviet emigre, has lately enjoyed a flurry of attention, fueled by several well-publicized appearances with major orchestras both in this country and in Europe, not least among them with the Berlin Philharmonic, which Mr. Bychkov led on a tour of Germany during 1985 -the only conductor aside from Herbert von Karajan to be given such a responsibility.

title: Farmers Group
description: B.A.T. Industries said it would hold an extraordinary general meeting Feb. 24 to seek shareholder approval for its previously announced proposal to buy Farmers Group Inc. for $4.2 billion. The board of Farmers, a Los Angeles-based insurance company, has rejected the $60-a-share offer.

title: The Stage: Five One-Act Comedies
description: IN Mary Gallagher's one-act play, ''Perfect,'' two single women compare notes on prospective mates. Mary Testa (an actress not averse to mugging) has found a man who is her match in every department, with the possible exception of politics. As she confides to her friend, the appealing Janet Zarish, ''I will not sleep with anybody who voted for him.'' The ''him'' in question is our incumbent President, and the comic issue is whether or not the woman will be able to compromise her principles in quest of romance.

title: The Post: 187-Year Fight to Survive Wildly Political and Violent Heritage
description: ''It was a terrible headache,'' said Dorothy Schiff, the 84-year-old former owner of The New York Post, as she looked back yesterday on the 37 years she owned the paper before selling it to Rupert Murdoch in 1976.

title: Fire Damages Office Building
description: A smoky fire broke out shortly before midnight yesterday in a six-story Midtown office building and was still burning out of control at 2:25 A.M. today. About 135 firemen battled the three-alarm blaze, which began on the fourth floor of the building at 552 Seventh Avenue near 40th Street, fire officials said. The building, which was heavily damaged, houses 35 wholesale fashion designers.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes about $4.1 million in writedown of assets for both the quarter and year.

title: Adams-Millis
description: The Adams-Millis Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by the Sara Lee Corporation in a stock swap worth at least $13 a share, or about $61 million. Adams-Millis said that amount might be raised to $16 a share, depending on its cash flow for 1988. Adams-Millis is an apparel maker that produces Hanes brand socks under license from Sara Lee. Its shares slipped 62.5 cents a share today, to $11.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: White House Reneging On Tax-Reform Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTRAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: WESTERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Virus Bars Diabetes In Mice
description: VIRUSES have been described as pieces of bad news wrapped in protein, but a new study suggests that a virus infection can be life-saving good news, at least in mice prone to diabetes. Also, there may be lessons in the research for treatment of human disease, according to a report in the journal Science.

title: FIRST-MORTGAGE ISSUE BY UTILITY
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company offered $200 million of 10 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2018 at a price of 99 1/4 to yield 10.332 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Dr. Richard Page, 76; Invented a Dental Drill
description: Dr. Richard Wilson Page, a dental surgeon and inventor who developed the first high-speed dental drill, died of bone cancer last Tuesday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Churchtown, N.Y.

title: USPCI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of about $4.7 million from expenses in connection with the tender offer by Union Pacific Corp. for the shares of USPCI. c-Net income

title: Air Force Seeking to Bar Visitors From Usual Shuttle Viewing Sites
description: For safety reasons, the military wants to bar all photographers, news organizations and visitors from the usual sites for watching space shuttle launchings at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, officials of the Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday.

title: Gene Gotti Allowed To Remain Out of Jail
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to revoke Gene Gotti's bail, allowing him to remain out of jail until the outcome of his new trial on racketeering and drug charges.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the ''Fort Chaffee Journal'' article yesterday mislocated Fort Chaffee, Ark.

title: Top Meredith Executive Adds Post of Chairman
description: The Meredith Corporation, a diversified media company whose publications include Better Homes and Gardens magazine and The Ladies' Home Journal, said yesterday that its board had elected Robert A. Burnett, the president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman. Mr. Burnett assumed his new duties yesterday.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Text of Gorbachev Statement Setting Forth Soviet Position on Afghan War
description: Following is Mikhail S. Gorbachev's statement on Afghanistan yesterday, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Action Due on Times Sq. Plan
description: The huge, long-awaited plan for redevelopment of Times Square is moving closer to reality as the directors of the Urban Development Corporation are expected today to authorize long-term leases with one of the project's largest development concerns.

title: Klecko of Jets Put on Waivers
description: The verdict that Joe Klecko had been grimly expecting since he failed a team physical on Dec. 28 came yesterday.

title: How Jersey City Team Rose to Top
description: Although it probably won't get him back his No. 1 national ranking, Bob Hurley Sr., the basketball coach at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, got a measure of revenge last week.

title: Topics of The Times; The Winter Budget Games
description: The new Federal budget hasn't been printed yet, but the flim-flam has already begun.

title: LEE GOODMAN, AN ACTOR AND COMEDIAN, 64
description: Lee Goodman, an actor and nightclub comedian, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 64.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: REDMEN FALL SHORT IN FINAL MINUTES
description: Boston College punctured St. John's man-to-man defense, then went on a 12-0 spurt in the closing minutes to hand the Redmen a 80-76 defeat at Alumni Hall last night.

title: MOMENT OF TRUTH FOR S.A.S. HEAD
description: Jan Carlzon, the tall, blond 46-year-old president of Scandinavian Airlines System, is Sweden's answer to Lee A. Iacocca: a charismatic executive who revitalized a major corporation and then wrote a runaway best seller about his managerial exploits.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,328,000 for the quarter and a gain of $56,489,000 for the year, both on investments. c-After gains on investments of $2,631,000 for the quarter and $6,106,000 for the year.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Belt Tightening
description: A popular summer education program for Federal judges is being discontinued this year, the victim of budget tightening throughout the judicial branch.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Mail Order Business
description: Along with just about every other outfit in the free enterprise system, it seems, the Government Printing Office is getting into the mail order business. Later this month, mailing lists of subscribers to and buyers of Government periodicals and publications will be made available by the office's Superintendent of Documents.

title: CASH AMERICA INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Shearson Is Charged By Gencorp
description: Gencorp Inc. today accused Shearson Lehman Brothers of improperly giving privileged information to hostile bidders during a 1987 takeover battle.

title: Sandinista Denies Leaders Are Split
description: Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who has been at the center of recent reports of dissent among Sandinista leaders, says differences on the nine-man National Directorate do exist, but do not threaten Government unity.

title: Flemish Bolster Societe Generale
description: As the stock of Societe Generale de Belgique soared 16 percent today in fevered trading, an alliance of largely Belgian institutions said it held a 27.5 percent stake in the company.

title: Viacom Owner Acts on Orion
description: A group led by Sumner M. Redstone, the owner of Viacom International Inc., said yesterday that it had asked Federal antitrust regulators for clearance to increase its stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. If approved, the Redstone group said, it would increase its holdings to 36 percent of Orion's stock, from 26.8 percent.

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,000,000 for the quarter, and the year includes a gain of $34,500,000 from investment transactions and income of $76,000,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes an after-tax gain from investment transactions of $10,352,000 and $30,236,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes income of $43,175,000 from discontinued operations. The company said certain amounts for the 1986 fourth quarter and full year have been restated to include the operting results of Fairmont Financial Inc., acquired May 21, on a pooling-of-interests basis; the effect of the restatement was to increase operating income for the fourth quarter of 1986 by $2,217,000; net income for the 1986 quarter was increased by $2,243,000.

title: NEECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Review; Docudrama, 'Do Guilty Go Free?'
description: MURDERERS escape punishment because of court rulings; on the other hand, the courts must act as they do. ''Do the Guilty Go Free?'' weighs the exclusionary rule, and comes down squarely in the middle. The Home Box Office documentary will be seen on the pay-cable network at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: 3 Advance to Westminster Show Final
description: Ch. NMK's Brittania V. Sibelstein, a German short-haired pointer from California, became the first finalist in the 112th annual Westminster Kennel Club show, which opened a two-day run in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: Meese Will Travel This Week To Spain, Italy and Mexico
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, who faces a rising number of calls for his resignation, will make trips to Spain, Italy and Mexico in the next week.

title: Richmond Hill Grieves for Girl Beaten to Death
description: Jamie Antomattei stopped his bicycle yesterday afternoon in front of the wooden stairs on 89th Avenue near 122d Street in Richmond Hill, Queens, where the police had put up yellow tape to keep people out.

title: Buyout Bid Is Received By Stevens
description: J. P. Stevens & Company, the giant textile producer, has received a $696 million leveraged-buyout proposal from five of its top executives, the company's board said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PAPERCLIP CONSPIRACY. The Hunt for the Nazi Scientists. By Tom Bower. 309 pages. Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,911,000 from an accounting change. The latest year includes writedowns of oil and gas operations equaling 8 cents a share, compared with 4 cents a share in 1986.

title: Salomon Loses $74 Million in Quarter
description: Salomon Inc., the parent of one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, announced late yesterday that it lost $74 million in the fourth quarter because of trading losses stemming from the stock market collapse and a series of moves to restructure its troubled operations.

title: Calcutta Journal; A Communist Who's Gone Far, but Not Far Left
description: For as long as anyone can remember, this crowded and squalid old city has danced to the rhythm of labor strikes, political agitations and Marxist theorizing.

title: 76 NAME LYNAM COACH
description: Matt Guokas, who stepped out of the broadcast booth of the Philadelphia 76ers on June 1, 1985, to succeed Billy Cunningham as the coach of the team, was dismissed yesterday. He was replaced by Jimmy Lynam, his chief assistant, who will handle the team for the remainder of the season.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ADVANCED TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A New Normality In Seoul's Politics
description: LEAD: With the imminent inauguration of Roh Tae Woo as president and with National Assembly elections soon to follow, South Koreans are adjusting to a new political normality. The Government believes it can retain power indefinitely by using political skill instead of brute force, and the opposition is in such disarray that it cannot mount a serious challenge in the near future.

title: Maddox More Balky In the Brawley Case
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., the lawyer for Tawana Brawley, said last night that the 16-year-old would not cooperate with authorities until arrests were made in her case.

title: NRM ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brokerage's Parent Cited
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the parent of London & Norwich Investment Services Ltd., a firm closed last week by British authorities, with violating United States laws.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lightning Strikes Plane In Germany, Killing 21
description: A commuter airliner was struck by lightning and crashed today, killing all 21 people aboard, the authorities said.

title: NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $4,195,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Standard Shares Climb on New
description: Spurred by an increased bid from the Black & Decker Corporation of $65 a share, American Standard Inc.'s stock climbed $3 yesterday, to $66.875 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said Black & Decker's new offer, totaling $2.1 billion, was an attempt to put pressure on American Standard directors to negotiate. The sharp rise in the stock was seen as speculation that American Standard would be able to negotiate an even higher price. Textron Inc. continued to be mentioned as a possible bidder, but people close to Textron said that such speculation was unfounded.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said non-recurring acquisition and merger related expenses for the latest 9 months were about $5.1 million on a pre-tax basis.

title: Breathe Life Into Amnesty for Aliens
description: Time runs out for many undocumented aliens hoping to stay in the United States. The 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act provided amnesty for those in this country since 1982. But it's a painstaking process, and they must apply by May 4. There would be real justice in extending it, but that means Congress must act, and quickly.

title: Market Place; Mutual Fund Investors Wary
description: IN the aftermath of the October market slump, mutual fund investors continue to tread the path of caution. They are shying away from aggressive stock funds and, in the fixed-income area, they tend to favor bond funds with short maturities.

title: Responsible for Leafs
description: John Brophy, the Toronto Maple Leafs' coach, has been given added responsibilities following the dismissal of Gerry McNamara, the club's general manager.

title: THE KNICK FROM QUEENS
description: HIS father used to come up with seats in the red section, which wasn't easy in the middle 1970's, but Mark Jackson wanted a closer look. As soon as he was old enough to go to the Garden on his own, he would wait outside the players' entrance.

title: Inquiry for Austria Declares Waldheim Knew of War Crimes
description: A commission of historians charged by the Austrian Government to look into President Kurt Waldheim's wartime record reported today that he must have been aware of atrocities committed around him and did nothing about them, and that he tried to conceal his military past. But the panel said it had no evidence that Mr. Waldheim himself was guilty of war crimes.

title: Alas Cabbage Patch! On to a Spaghetti-Eating Robot
description: Dancing dogs and teddy bears in tutus filled the halls, electronic board games and ball games cluttered the rooms, dolls that use computers and robots that eat spaghetti lined the shelves - but not a child was in sight.

title: Marghanita Laski, 72, An Author and Critic
description: Marghanita Laski, a novelist, critic and prolific amateur lexicographer, died Saturday, according to her family. She was 72 years old.

title: 2 Bolshoi Dancers Defer 'Symphony in C' Debut
description: Andris Liepa and Nina Ananiashvili, the two Bolshoi Ballet principals who are to be guest artists with the New York City Ballet, will not dance on Thursday as previously announced. A City Ballet spokesman said there was insufficient rehearsal time for their debut in ''Symphony in C,'' which is to take place next week.

title: Patrick V. Doyle Hotelier, 65
description: Patrick Vincent Doyle, Ireland's leading hotelier, died Saturday after undergoing heart surgery. He was 65 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1988
description: Companies

title: DIASONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes pretax non- recurring provisions of $19,720,000 for litigation settlements and litigation fees and $3,500,000 for other litigation related costs for both the quarter and year.

title: 2 Admit to Arson to Fight Drugs
description: Two men upset over drug trafficking in their neighborhood admit they have set fires to drive out crack dealers. They say it has worked.

title: Addendum
description: * Livingston & Co., Seattle, will open a San Francisco office on March. 1.

title: Jersey Agriculture
description: The New Jersey Department of Agriculture has retained Gillespie Advertising, Princeton, N.J., as its agency of record after a five-way review of local agencies lasting three months. The budget is $1 million. Gillespie, which created the ''Jersey Fresh'' slogan for the department's first major campaign, was initially chosen to handle the account four years ago.

title: WEIRTON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a provision for profit sharing of $7,847,000 and $40,282,000 for the latest quarter and year, respectively, compared with $5,015,000 and $15,028,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Net income for all periods is before contribution to an employee stock ownership trust.

title: The Ruin of a Building Owned by New Yrk
description: During the month of December, the window casing in Theresa Santiago's bathroom, for months twisted and swollen by water damage, finally fell out of the wall and crashed into her bathtub.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSIDE
description: Settler Kills Palestinian A Jewish settler killed a Palestinian youth in the West Bank as protests called to mark two months of unrest continued for a second day. Page A6. U.S. Troops and Panama Panama's leader called for American military headquarters for Latin America to be withdrawn. Page A12. In Search of Deductions Taxpayers can profit from some strategies used by tax professionals in filling out returns. Page D1.

title: Marchi, Backing Koch, Opposes Pension Rise
description: Backing Mayor Koch, a key state lawmaker said today that he would oppose a bill to increase the pensions of former New York City and state workers.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
F.D.I.C. to Sell Bad Loans
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation plans to sell $1.8 billion in bad loans it absorbed from the 1984 bailout of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, an agency spokesman said today.

title: College Hockey Notebook; Center Sparks St. Lawrence
description: Pete Lappin, the senior center from St. Charles, Ill., was in the thick of the action as usual when St. Lawrence earned two key victories on home ice against Colgate and Cornell last weekend.

title: Almost 'Got to Give God Credit,' Robertson Says in Thanking Staff
description: Pat Robertson's ''invisible army'' came out in force tonight for the former television evangelist, helping him to reshape Republican Presidential politics.

title: Gretzky, Lemieux Are Guiding Stars
description: For lack of anything more significant, the theme of this year's National Hockey League All-Star Game is the Gretzkys against the Lemieuxs.

title: U.S. Drafting Gloomy Report on U.N.
description: An official report being prepared by the United States suggests that support at the United Nations for the United States viewpoint on international affairs has fallen to a record low, but some American and United Nations officials say the report is based on misleading data.

title: LAM RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-After tax credits of $84,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Sea-Land Ships
description: The Sea-Land Corporation, a subsidiary of the CSX Corporation, said it had agreed to buy 12 container ships from Econ Associates Limited Partnership for $13 million to $14 million each. Sea-Land said that it would operate the ships for Atlantic trade. The ships originally cost about $47.5 million each when they were built three years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm going to be the nominee.'' - Pat Robertson. [ B6:1. ]

title: MOORE MCCORMACK REOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $4,533,000 and an $89,020,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Pit Bull to Learn New Tricks or Face Death
description: After a courtroom argument over whether old dogs can learn new tricks, a Superior Court judge granted a reprieve today for a pit bull terrier named Bandit who faced death by lethal injection for biting three people.

title: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a realized capital loss of $4,923,000 for the quarter and a realized capital gain of $2,440,000 for the year. c-Includes realized capital gains of $175,000 and $9,994,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: THERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $231,000. c-Net loss

title: Japan Bank Backs Holiday Inn Notes
description: Holiday Inns Inc. offered $400 million of notes yesterday, using a letter of credit from a Japanese bank to raise the notes to a top-flight rating from a speculative one.

title: ALLIANT COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $356,000 and $2,053,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a gain from extinguishment of debt of $1,201,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes tax credits of $956,000 for the quarter and $2,100,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter net is after a one-time charge of $275,000 in connection with a restructuring plan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Bank of New York, a subsidiary of the National Bank of Greece S.A., appointed as senior vice presidents: Marcy S. Cohen, John Gomilas, William O'Louglin and Peter Xanthopoulos.

title: Music: Schubertiade Ends First Season
description: THE 92d Street Y left Schubert on Sunday afternoon where he has always seemed most comfortable - at home, among friends. For the final concert in the first season of its projected 10-year-long Schubertiade, the Y presented music of an exclusively intimate nature: not the works composed for the concert stage but pieces written to be heard and performed in an informal, social setting.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: The company said the latest third quarter includes a charge of $19,360,000 related to writedown of inventory, capital equipment and goodwill pertaining to the consolidation of product lines, and the 9 months includes a charge of $20,460,000 for the expenses of consolidating product lines, plus separation costs associated with employment reduction, expenses related to facility closings and an inventory reserve associated with settlement of litigation. Year-ago 9 months includes a $978,000 provision for disposal of excess capital equipment.

title: MILITARY SATELLITE LAUNCHED TO TEST ANTI-MISSILE PLAN
description: An unmanned Delta rocket launched a three-ton military satellite into space yesterday afternoon as part of the most complex and costly experiment yet in President Reagan's anti-missile program.

title: Rig Count Rises Slightly
description: After falling sharply in the previous week, the number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States rebounded somewhat last week, increasing by 22, to a total of 986, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The rig count had dropped by 62 in the previous week. This week's total reflects the number of rigs working as of last Friday. A year ago, the count was 802, Baker Hughes said.

title: MAGMA COPPER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $25 million reserve for loss to close out forward sales contracts covering about 47 million pounds of copper during the first quarter of 1988.

title: Senators Soothe Europe on Arms Pacts
description: A group of leading senators told the European allies today that the Senate would not cooperate in a headlong rush to approve a treaty limiting strategic nuclear weapons before the end of the Reagan Presidency.

title: What Non-Western Cultures Are Able to Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JWP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Airline Delays Up in December
description: Flight delays increased sharply in December, partly because of harsh weather that disrupted traffic at some of the busiest airports, the Transportation Department said today.

title: Cast of 'Sarafina!' Performs in Harlem
description: The cast of the South African musical ''Sarafina!'' journeyed from Broadway to Harlem yesterday to perform in the morning for more than 700 schoolchildren and in the evening to benefit an unusual Harlem theater.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results include pretax losses related to declines in the stock market of $2,070,000 for the latest quarter and $2,642,000 for the 9 months, compared with $558,000 and $368,000 for the year-earlier quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Bradley About-Face on Contras Proves Intriguing
description: Senator Bill Bradley has long been known as a maverick.

title: Six Climbers Die in Britain
description: Rescuers today found the bodies of two mountain climbers lost in a blizzard in Wales, bringing to six the number of climbers killed in weekend accidents. Air force and volunteer teams found the bodies in northern Wales, one in Snowdonia's Ogwen Valley and the other in the Garn area of the mountains. Two people were killed and three injured Sunday in an avalanche in the Cheviot Hills, on the border between England and Scotland. Two climbers died in separate accidents Saturday.

title: Air Decontrol Benefits Cited
description: Airline deregulation has lowered fares, saving consumers $100 billion, the Federal Trade Commission said in a report issued today. The number of airline passengers increased 50 percent between 1978 and 1986.

title: Children's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $40,901,000 for early extinguishment of debt. Year-ago quarter did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax loss of $79 million from participating in the British Petroleum underwriting, an after-tax charge of $51 million from an agreement terminating Salomon's interest in the New York City Coliseum site project, an after-tax charge of $38 million from restructuring of Salomon Brothers' business and an after-tax gain of $31 million from disposal of Salomon Brothers' interest in a mortgage gathering venture. c-Net income

title: All Together Now
description: FOR many users of I.B.M. PC's and compatibles, Better Working Eight-in-One may be the only computer program they will ever need. Even people who have more ambitious requirements in one or two areas may find that Eight-in-One is just fine in the others.

title: One Physician Takes A Novel Stand Against Patients Who Smoke
description: DR. JOHN J. Cannell remembers how, at the age of 6, he watched his father, a cigarette smoker, die a wretched death from lung cancer.

title: Stake Is Increased In Postal Instant
description: A New York insurance holding company, the Orion Capital Corporation, has raised its stake in Postal Instant Press Inc. to 12.7 percent and might increase its stake ''to 20 percent or more.'' The move could revive a takeover battle between Postal Instant Press and the Kane-Miller Corporation.

title: The Latin Peace Bet
description: President Oscar Arias shows a sense of urgency now in pushing for the next steps in his Central American peace plan. He rightly hailed the House vote against aid for Nicaragua's contras as an ''opportunity'' and a ''big responsibility for us'' in Central America, not in itself decisive.

title: Court Backs Fed on Bank Underwriting
description: A Federal appeals court ruled unanimously yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board was legally correct in allowing banks to underwrite certain types of securities through special subsidiaries.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS DRUGS AND PERMISSIVENESS OF PAST
description: President Reagan came to Duke University here today to accuse past American leaders of tolerating drug abuse and to highlight the South's importance for the political fortunes of the Republican Party this year.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $529,000 and $995,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also includes a loss of $253,000 from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $313,000 and $743,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $1,221,000 on the planned disposition of subsidiaries for both the quarter and year, and the quarter also includes a loss of $951,000 from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. The company said the latest year results include non-recurring charges of $1.7 million from the settlement of a lawsuit and related legal expenses as well as $1.4 million of product development costs.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Organizations Raise Money To Give to the Neediest Cases
description: Each year, from mid-June until after Christmas, a large glass bottle stands in the vestibule of the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in the Bronx to receive donations for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A contest is held among the church schoolchildren who are invited to guess the amount of coins and bills collected.

title: Bridge: Superb Collection in French Contains Fine Defensive Test
description: Players who fancy their defensive skill should cover the East and South hands in the diagramed deal and make a plan for West in defending four spades.

title: What Non-Westers Cultures Are Able to Teach; The Speed of Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Board of Regents Faces New Attack From Politicians
description: The State Board of Regents, which was set up as a semi-autonomous body to keep it isolated from political pressures, is now under attack from politicians who complain that it has failed its mission of improving the state's educational system.

title: FERNANDEZ AGREES TO METS' TERMS
description: The Mets reduced their salary arbitration load yesterday by reaching agreement with Sid Fernandez on a $580,000 salary for the coming season. The biggest salaries of the day, however, were gained by two other pitchers, Ted Higuera of Milwaukee and Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles, who had been two of a dozen players seeking $1 million or more in arbitration.

title: Dionne Proceeds With No Apologies
description: MARCEL DIONNE was ending his post-game news conference in the middle of a rapidly emptying locker room Sunday afternoon, eager to get to the showers and then to the trainer's table for treatment of his chronically arthritic left knee. But as he turned and began to limp off, a final question was called at him.

title: India Tests Alternatives In Bid to Control Malaria
description: India, which spends millions of dollars on pesticides to fight malaria-bearing mosquitoes, is starting to concentrate on cheaper, environmentally safer ways of controlling the insects.

title: William Narduzzi, Columbia Coach, 51
description: William (Bill) Narduzzi, the defensive coordinator and linebacker coach of the Columbia University football team for the last two seasons, died of cancer on Feb. 4 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 51 years old.

title: PATTERNS
description: 7th Ave. Meets Wall St.

title: Rises After Filing
description: Federated Department Stores Inc.'s shares rose $2.50, to $59.125, on the New York Stock Exchange amid speculation that the company might receive a higher takeover offer from the Campeau Corporation or a third party. The company has spurned a $61-a-share bid from Campeau.

title: SOVIET SETS MAY 15 AS GOAL TO START AFGHANISTAN EXIT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced today that the Soviet Union would begin withdrawing its troops from Afghanistan on May 15 if the Geneva talks on the war there result in a settlement two months before that date.

title: American Brands To Sell Baker
description: American Brands Inc. agreed to sell its Sunshine Biscuits Inc. unit to G. F. Industries. American Brands declined to disclose details of the deal other than to say it was for cash. Privately held G. F. Industries operates the Granny Goose snack food business, principally on the West Coast.

title: Topics of The Times; Vital Partnership
description: Next month, Towers on the Park, a 600-unit condominium at Central Park West and 110th Street, opens its doors. It's the latest monument to the work of the New York City Partnership, whose founder and chairman, David Rockefeller, stepped down yesterday.

title: Japan-Pretoria Trade
description: Japan's leading business organization urged member companies today to restrain their trade with South Africa, following a Government plea. The Federation of Economic Organizations ''asked member firms to voluntarily restrain themselves from trading with South Africa,'' the director, Masaya Miyoshi, said. He provided no details of what the organization considered restraint and did not specify a time frame for the action. Foreign Ministry officials have expressed embarrassment over Japan's position as South Africa's top trade partner.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRUDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sleaze Control for City Politics
description: A bill now before the City Council offers a promising antidote to sleaze. It would establish public financing of city election campaigns, similar to the system used in national Presidential races since 1976. Today's Council vote on the measure will reverberate in Albany and across the country.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank of the West, San Francisco, a subsidiary of Banque Nationale de Paris, said it had offered to combine with WestAmerica Bancorp for $18.375 a share, or a total of $100 million, in cash. WestAmerica said it would study the proposal.

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Highly Diverse Forest
description: A new survey by botanists has found that the tropical rain forest of upper Amazonia in Peru may well have the greatest diversity of tree species of any place on earth. At two study sites near Iquitos, as many as 300 species were identified per hectare, an area equivalent to about two and a half acres.

title: Within the Arms Debate, a 2d Debate
description: The Reagan Administration effort to win speedy approval of the new missile treaty has been set back by a constitutional debate that seems to have nothing to do with the terms of the new accord.

title: Finder of Errant Files
description: THE file vanished on Groundhog Day. Not a shadow of it could be found in any of the logical hiding places. I knew it was in there somewhere, burrowed snugly in the 40 megabytes of hard disk on my writing machine, but where? Forty megs is a big hiding place, and I was looking for a relatively small file: a recipe for Josh's Megabite Chili.

title: Kean to Block Rise For Parkway Tolls
description: Governor Kean said yesterday that he would not approve any rise in the 25-cent tolls at the Garden State Parkway's 11 toll barriers until next Jan. 1 and would consider a 10-cent increase then only if the State Highway Authority improved its ''sloppy'' financial practices and capital planning.

title: U.S. Officials Praised Drug Effort by Noriega
description: Letters of praise for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the miltary ruler of Panama, have come back to haunt the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the Justice Department.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a dispute over bids submitted to the General Services Administration described Bell Atlantic's position incorrectly. The company maintains that it has done nothing wrong, and it has not offered to give up its contracts.

title: Occidental Net Up 90%
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 90 percent, to $38 million, or 17 cents a share, on sales of $4.4 billion, from $20 million, or 5 cents a share, on sales of $4.2 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: GENERAL MOTORS ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 consolidated net income included the results of GMAC's financing, insurance and mortgage operations.

title: Korean Surplus Grows
description: Helped by rising exports and increased tourism, South Korea's current account surplus reached $9.8 billion in 1987, Bank of Korea officials said today. The current account, which includes trade in goods and services, was up sharply from $4.6 billion in 1986, officials of the central bank said. The December current account surplus widened to $942 million, from $857 million in November and $478 million in December 1986.

title: Richmond Reinstated
description: Tim Richmond's Nascar license was reinstated yesterday after the driver passed a second drug test administered by the stock-car sanctioning body.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $7.3 million to cover the anticiapated costs of resolving the antitrust charges against units for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary gain of $57.8 million from refinancing of a unit's debt. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest year. The company attributed the increase in revenue to improved results at each of its operating units and the acquisition of Anixter Brothers Inc. at year-end 1986. In the latest year, Anixter contributed $835 million to Itel's revenue.

title: U.S. Takes a Wait-and-See Stance on Afghan Pullout Offer
description: Administration officials, expressing wariness about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to begin a 10-month Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan by May 15, said today that other issues besides the timetable had to be resolved before the United States would agree to end aid to the Afghan rebels.

title: Bork Calls Kennedy Unfair in Opposing Nomination to Court
description: Robert H. Bork said today that he once urged the White House to work harder to battle the campaign against his nomination to the Supreme Court, and he accused Senator Edward M. Kennedy of ''brutality.''

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $10,455,000 related to product line restructuring and merger and consolidation expenses. Results for the first 9 months of 1987 and for the prior year have been restated for mergers completed during the 1987 fourth quarter, accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Primerica Will Sell 81% Musicland Stake
description: The Primerica Corporation agreed today to sell its 81 percent stake in Musicland Group Inc. for about $330 million in a move to reduce the debt from its takeover of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company last year.

title: Urgent Effort to Save Ducks Begins in U.S. and Canada
description: Alarmed by a steep decline in the number of ducks and other waterfowl in North America, the United States and Canada are embarking on a last-ditch effort to rebuild the flocks of the migratory birds.

title: MOSINEE PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $998,000 from the elimination of investment tax credits.

title: Beanpot to Northeastern
description: Northeastern won the 36th Beanpot Tournament tonight with a 6-3 victory over Boston University before a capacity crowd of 14,451 at the Boston Garden.

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Judge Expedites Players' Appeal
description: A Federal judge today speeded up an appeal by National Basketball Association players. The players are appealing his ruling on labor law exemptions claimed by the league but contested by the players.

title: Nebraska's Governor Bounces Back
description: When the members of Nebraska's one-house Legislature returned here for a new session recently, they were greeted by the Governor handing out bouquets of flowers. Later, Kay A. Orr, the first Republican woman to become the governor of a state, fondly remembered one comment: ''Maybe she's confident enough to still be feminine.''

title: People
description: * Patrick T. Furey, Linda Honan and Vicki J. Tencati have been promoted to senior vice presidents, management supervisors at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

title: As Hems Dither, Pants March On
description: Pants, including pants suits, are on the march. Out of the mainstream of fashion for the last few seasons, overshadowed by the rage for fluttery clothes and short skirts, they are back in strength. Last month in Paris, couture designers, who never paid much attention to trouser fashions even in their heyday in the 1970's, gave them a surprisingly strong place in their spring and summer collections.

title: SYNBIOTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $18,000 for the quarter; the year includes a tax credit of $144,000. c-Net loss

title: XL-DATACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a one-time charge resulting from elimination of the investment of credit; the company did not give the amount of the charge.

title: Accounts
description: * Telemundo Group, a Spanish-language television company, to Widmann & Co.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Giuliani Announces Decision Not to Run For Moynihan Seat
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would stay on as the United States Attorney in Manhattan and would not challenge Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan this year.

title: Stage: Repertorio Espanol's 'Revoltillo'
description: THE troubles of the Marquez family are as amusing in Spanish as in English, and the tongues of its members may be sharper. Eduardo Machado's ''Revoltillo,'' one part of a trilogy about this Cuban-American clan that was first seen in English under the title ''Broken Eggs'' at the Ensemble Studio Theater in 1984, has now been added to the roster of Repertorio Espanol in Spanish.

title: Why Smoking Bans Are Dangerous
description: LEAD: The tobacco companies are, at long last, getting theirs. Across the United States, municipal authorities are enacting antismoking laws. One-third of all American corporations have instituted nonsmoking regulations, and the number is growing rapidly.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iris Vinton, 82, Author Of Novels for Children
description: Iris Vinton, an author of many children's books, died of breast cancer Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title: Hypothermia Researchers Take a Frigid Dip
description: HOT water bottles, electric heaters and warm blankets may be no help at all to people suffering the effects of extreme cold, according to six Canadian researchers who found out the hard way.

title: Sound Is Shaped Into a Dazzling Tool With Many Uses
description: USING beams of intense sound pitched above the limit of human hearing, scientists are learning to create novel substances that are expected to spawn remarkable technologies in the next century.

title: McDonald's Test
description: The McDonald's Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company are teaming up in a test that offers hamburgers from the fast-food chain at Sears stores. McDonald's and Sears are trying the idea at a store in Pittsburgh and investigating ''a few other locations,'' Sears told The Chicago Sun-Times.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net earnings and share earnings in 1987 reflect the fourth quarter after-tax charge of $6.6 million relating to the disposition and relocation of certain Industrial Products Division businesses.

title: WHEELABRATOR TECHNOLOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in September 1987.

title: A Huge Chunk of Antarctica Is Heading Out to Sea, at a Glacial Pace
description: A 90-MILE-LONG Antarctic iceberg, the latest product of an extraordinary two years of glacial breakup, seems to be plowing toward the shipping lanes at the less-than-hazardous rate of about a tenth of a mile per hour.

title: Chess: Anna Akhsharumova Wins '87 Women's Championship
description: Anna Akhsharumova was expected to run away with the 1987 United States Women's Championship and she did. The 31-year-old Soviet emigrant who now lives in Cambridge, Mass., lived up to the forecast by scoring a perfect 9-0 in the tournament, held at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo.

title: Stunning Result Carries a Grim Message for Bush
description: Iowa produced a stunning Republican result tonight, one that promised to alter dramatically the course of the 1988 Presidential campaign. A surprisingly feeble showing by Vice President Bush raised insistent questions about his chances of winning the nomination, even though almost every major politician had been decribing him for months as the favorite. A comeback is always possible; Ronald Reagan lost to Mr. Bush here in 1980 but went on to win the New Hampshire primary and, of course, the Presidency. But the outcome in Iowa was far more clear-cut this time.

title: Careers; How to Help Out-of-Work Managers
description: NO man is an island, the poet John Donne wrote years ago, and out-of-work middle managers surely appreciate the importance of networking.

title: Sedona Journal; 'Psychic Energy' and the Pot of Gold
description: Entrepreneurs in this picturesque hamlet in northern Arizona recently discovered a new source of income: driving jeep-loads of tourists into the surrounding rose-colored mountains in search of ''psychic energy.''

title: WICOR INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Air Cleaners At Plants Recalled
description: Citing workplace contamination by a low-level radioactive substance, the Government today announced the recall of more than 1,000 dust-catching devices used in the bottling of beverages, cosmetics and drugs.

title: By Design; Covering Gray Hair
description: Some women actually enjoy watching their hair silver as they age. But gray has a way of draining color from the skin.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $164 million for the quarter, and gains of $190 million for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes special gains of $102 million for the quarter, and charges of $230 million for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said the charges in the latest fourth quarter reflect Canadian Pacific's share of a writedown by 50.6 percent-held AMCA International Ltd., or about $124 million, plus a $40 million provision for a loss on the future disposal of Canadian Pacific's three leased hotel properties in West Germany. The company also said for the full- year, these fourth quarter charges are offset by $354 million of gains on the sales of Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd., Maple Leaf Mills Ltd., and a CP ships office building.

title: For Paperback Industry, Fear of Paper Shortage
description: Fearing a shortage of the paper on which they print their books, publishers of mass-market paperbacks are talking about cutting back print runs on certain books and possibily not printing some books at all. Smaller paperback houses, by contrast, are scrambling to try to get enough paper to meet their production schedules.

title: Plan to Insure Home Value Brings Chicago Racial Rift
description: Hoping to calm the fears of homeowners in racially or economically changing neighborhoods, this city is debating a plan that essentially attempts to insure against white flight.

title: Baker Proposes a 'Club' of Free-Trading Nations
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d threatened today to form a club of free-trading countries that would keep out nations that do not reduce their barriers to imports.

title: Nicholas Roerich, Artist, Author, Peace Builder
description: To the Editor:

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK OFFSHORE PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,575,000 for the latest quarter and $1,352,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: ELDORADO MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing McKinney and McGrath Win: Tamara McKinney, whose season was interrupted by a broken leg, overtook five others on the second run yesterday to win the women's slalom at the United States Alpine championships at Copper Mountain, Colo. McKinney, who placed third Saturday in giant slalom in her first competition of the season, said her victory would give her confidence a needed lift heading into the Olympics. McKinney, 25 years old, of Olympic Valley, Calif., was sixth after the first run, during which she lost her goggles after hitting the second gate. Beth Madsen of Aspen, Colo., was second followed by Heidi Bowes of Steamboat Springs, Colo.

title: 8 Somalis Sentenced to Die; Charge Is Plotting Sabotage
description: A special court has sentenced a former Vice President and seven other people to death by firing squad for plotting against the Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre.

title: Life and Death of a Broadway Producer
description: Norman Kean seemed to lead an enviable life. He produced one of the longest-lived shows on Broadway, and it was running in his own theater. He had a vivacious, talented wife and a teen-age son they adored, an apartment on Riverside Drive and a summer home in Montauk, L.I. He was a tough and knowledgeable business negotiator, and his neighbors on Long Island knew him as a supporter of good causes.

title: Advertising; Marketers Prepare for Cup Races
description: Dennis Conner and his crew are not the only ones scrambling to get ready for the America's Cup races to be held off Long Beach, Calif., in September, three years earlier than the defenders had planned.

title: Kickoff Classic Picks the Aggies
description: Texas A&M was selected to play in the season-opening Kickoff Classic today. There was no announcement of Texas A&M's opponent for the game, set for late August, although speculation centered on Pittsburgh.

title: Nofziger Closes Defense at Trial Without Testifying About Charges
description: Lawyers for Lyn Nofziger rested their case today without calling the former White House political director as a witness against charges that he illegally lobbyied for the Wedtech Corporation and other private clients in 1982.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 Charged in Texas In Savings Inquiry
description: Officials heading a Federal investigation of fraudulent transactions in the Texas savings industry today disclosed the first set of what they said would be dozens of criminal charges against former industry executives and real estate brokers.

title: 2 G.M. Units Raise Profits
description: Fourth-quarter profits were up at two subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation and down at a third, the companies reported today.

title: Jury in Alaska Acquits Man in In-Law's Death
description: A Superior Court jury has acquitted a former Anchorage businessman of first-degree murder in the slaying of his brother-in-law, with whom he was involved in a child custody fight.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest 6 months are subject to review pending completion of discussion with the S.E.C. accounting staff concerning about $5 million of after-tax gain recognized in the first quarter from the roll-up of certain limited partnerships in which Southmark held various interests. If Southmark is unable to recognize this gain, earnings per common share for the 6 months would be reduced by 10 cents to 13 cents a share.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Troubling Cost of Drugs That Offer Hope
description: The Armour Pharmaceutical Company introduced a major drug in October - the first blood-clotting factor for hemophiliacs made using the tools of biotechnology. This purer version of Factor VIII virtually eliminated any chance that hemophiliacs would contract AIDS, hepatitis or other diseases from treatment.

title: PITT STAR ENTERS PLEA
description: Craig Heyward, Pitt's all-America running back, was ordered yesterday to perform 50 hours of community service after pleading guilty in Pittsburgh to disorderly conduct. Heyward, 22 years old, was also ordered by Magistrate Joan Melvin to pay $150 in restitution to a University of Pittsburgh police officer whose glasses were broken during a Jan. 10 dispute at the Pitt Student Union.

title: For Snow, the Real Action Begins After It Falls
description: THE Eskimos have about four dozen words to describe snow and ice, and Sam Colbeck knows why.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dole Wins in Iowa, With Robertson Next
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas won a clear victory in the Iowa Republican caucuses tonight, and Pat Robertson, the former television evangelist, pushed Vice President Bush into third place.

title: GM HUGHES ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included accounting adjustments of $37.2 million for the quarter and $148.8 million for the year, which reflect the amortization of good will costs associated with General Motors Corp.'s purchase of Hughes Electronics. c-Included accounting adjustments of $37.2 million and $148.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, which reflect the amortization of good will costs associated with General Motors's purchase of Hughes. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid March 10 to stockholders of record Feb. 12. GM Hughes is a unit of the General Motors Corp.

title: LILLY, ELI & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $225.1 million for the quarter and $233.2 million for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $10 million for the quarter and $16.7 million for the year.

title: Murdoch Sets Deadline to Close Post
description: Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that he would close The New York Post in 11 days unless its unions accept cuts totaling $24 million over the next three years to enable him to sell the beleaguered newspaper to a New York real-estate developer.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Justice's Autobiography
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall, the only black to sit on the Supreme Court, has agreed to do an autobiography with the help of the columnist Carl Rowan. Justice Marshall told a reporter he had signed a contract with Little, Brown & Company for the project and hoped for publication in the spring of 1989.

title: U.S. General Tells of 'Shady' Dealings by Noriega
description: The former commanding general of the United State Southern Command, based in Panama, said today that although Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama was a ''venal'' politician, American Embassy officials described him as extremely cooperative in helping the United States crack down on drug trafficking.

title: The Shame of New Jersey's Mental Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Noriega Calls for U.S. Military to Leave
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler of Panama, said today that he wanted United States military headquarters in Latin America to be withdrawn from Panama.

title: American Perfects 'Ultimate Sledding'
description: There are not many people who enjoy swooshing down a mountain at approximately 80 miles per hour, on their backs, no less. Most of those who do enjoy it live in Europe. But who can blame Americans for disdaining the luge? If 80 m.p.h. is considered speeding on a highway, what must it feel like to go that fast on a small sled, feet dangling, in a posture more conducive to sleeping?

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $1,783,883 from a rate case settlement related to the canceled Seabrook Unit 2.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Faults Thais for Turning Back Refugees
description: United States officials said today that they were gravely concerned about Thailand's new practice of turning away Vietnamese refugees.

title: Contra Leaders Set Up a Fund For Aid in U.S.
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders said today that they had set up a fund to collect private donations in the United States and that they would postpone peace talks with the Nicaraguan Government scheduled for this week.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and for the quarter included $600 million in Chapter 11-related charges, and for the year included total charges of $3,235,000,000 for additional pension costs, a writedown of fixed assets, inventory, goodwill, debt discount and receivables, the idling of four steel facilities and the recording of a liability for the rejection of a partnership agreement.

title: Our Towns; Trying to Tell Us We're Too Young For Blackjack
description: You are supposed to be 21 to gamble in an Atlantic City casino, but Kim Cohen started at 15, first with slots, then blackjack. ''My girlfriend said: 'Why waste time on the slots? Make it faster at blackjack,' '' Kim said. One day, this friend had 10 minutes to kill before her after-school job - and won $40. ''It really impressed me,'' said Kim.

title: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-After net of $1,864,000 for the quarter and a loss of $39,125,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,370,000 for the quarter and $10,538,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter results included a charge of $2 million for idle facilities and in the latest year the loss from discontinued operations included a charge of $34.5 million from the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: CNW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary loss of $2,466,000 from the reacquisition of higher interest rate mortgage bonds. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year include a charge of $15 million for settlement of litigation.

title: Tiny Balloons May Help Open Fallopian Tubes
description: GYNECOLOGISTS in Chicago have borrowed a technique used to unclog coronary arteries to clear blocked fallopian tubes, a major cause of infertility in women.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,068,000 and a gain on disposal of assets of $13 million. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $442,000.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Dr. Edward S. Tauber, a psychiatrist and writer, misstated the date of his death. Dr. Tauber died last Wednesday.

title: Antimissile Byproducts
description: The ''Star Wars'' antimissile program may not save the nation from nuclear Armageddon anytime soon, but it at least might help give the President a new and improved lightweight flak jacket.

title: ARITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Administrator For Surrogates Will Resign
description: The Manhattan Public Administrator, whom state officials recently accused of mismanaging the estates of people who die without proper wills, said yesterday that he would resign upon the appointment of a successor.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company emerged from Chapter 11 protection from creditors on Sept. 17.

title: Chip Industry Ratio Is Steady
description: The chip-making industry's leading indicator was unchanged for January, as manufacturers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported their second consecutive month with more than $1 billion in orders, the Semiconductor Industry Association reported today.

title: CENTRAL JERSEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss and includes a $101.7 million after-tax charge associated with restructuring decisions.

title: DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago 6 months includes a pre- tax gain of $9,414,000 on the sale of marketable securities.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
