description: b-Includes for the quarter after-tax gains from asset dispositions of $147 million, consisting principally of a gain from the initial public offering in October of 49 percent of the stock of IBP Inc., partially offset by provisions for dispositions of other assets. Latest year includes after-tax gains from asset dispositions of $372 million, compared with $222 million in 1986. c-Includes for the latest quarter a gain of $15 million, or 7 cents a share, resulting from a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains; results for the latest year also include gains of $56 million, or 28 cents a share, in 1987 and $9 million, or 6 cents a share, in 1986, primarily from a tax benefit of a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains. Results for 1986 include after-tax gains of $107 million from the sale of various foreign and domestic oil and gas properties.

title: Change at Pepsi-Cola Brings a New Officer
description: The Pepsi-Cola Company, the soft-drink subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., announced a restructuring yesterday that establishes four geographic divisions. The restructured organization will be headed by Craig E. Weatherup, who has 14 years' experience in the company's international and domestic sales and marketing operations. He assumes the new position of president and chief operating officer of the company immediately.

title: TENERA LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are pro forma.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1988
description: International A3-16

title: Official Promoting, Too, Went Off Into Space
description: Conflicting desires for secrecy and publicity have been apparent in the military's planning for yesterday's launching of a research satellite as a test of a missile defense in space proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: CREDIT MARKETS U.S. Note and Bond Prices Down
description: Treasury note and bond prices declined modestly yesterday as securities dealers digested the $27 billion of new issues auctioned last week.

title: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $185 million for both the quarter and year. c-Includes special charges of $21,500,000 for the quarter and $71.5 million for the year, and the year also includes income of $5,624,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the charges in the latest period are primarily from the writedown of its Giddings & Lewis Inc. machine-tool business.

title: Race Driver Set Back
description: Roberto Guerrero, the Indy-car driver who is coming back from serious head injuries, has suffered another setback, breaking a bone in his right foot.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (COLO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PROGRESSIVE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After securities losses of $16,887,000 for the quarter and $1,566,000 for the year, and a gain of $3,705,000 for the both periods from an accounting change. c-After securities gains of $826,000 for the quarter and $9,371,000 for the year.

title: 37 Pit Bulls and a Man Held In Colorado Dog Fight Raid
description: The authorities have raided a suspected illegal dog-fighting operation here, arresting a man and seizing 37 pit bull terriers leashed to their dog houses.

title: Hanson Unit Sells A Cement Plant
description: Hanson P.L.C., the British-based conglomerate, said that one of its American subsidiaries, Kaiser Cement, had agreed to sell one of its California plants for $195 million to the Mitsubishi Mining and Cement Company.

title: Justices Favor Appeals In Occupied Territories
description: Israel's High Court of Justice has urged the Government to create an appeals court in the Gaza Strip and West Bank, a step long advocated by human rights lawyers who cite the military court system as a major grievance in the current Palestinian unrest.

title: St. John the Divine Show For U.S.-Soviet Ties
description: An of evening of music and dance, featuring Paul Winter, Paul Halley, the Omega Dance Company, the New York Russian Chorus and Tamir, a Russian actress, is planned tonight at 7:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Stree.

title: Pleas Meet Obstinacy As Democracy Unfolds
description: Lucy Reed was standing quietly underneath a blackboard with Representative Richard A. Gephardt's picture on it when her friends began urging her to round up some more Gephardt supporters.

title: HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Q&A
description: Q. Why do trees grow straight up all over the world? Why don't they point toward the sun?

title: Some New and Old Tactics For Last-Minute Tax Trims
description: With the sweeping revisions in the tax law, taxpayers searching for last-minute ways to trim their income tax bills will need to turn to some new strategies, as well as some old ones.

title: COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the prior fourth quarter and year include a gain of 18 cents a share from the sale of a division.

title: Space Station Chief Announces Retirement
description: An-drew J. Stofan, the head of the Govern-ment's program to build a space sta-tion, announced his retirement today.

title: Medics Search, Woman Dies
description: A 65-year-old woman died of a heart attack last Friday after paramedics based just a mile from her house became lost and took half an hour to reach her, the authorities said.

title: Alien Amnesty Effort Is Found to Be Falling Short
description: Participation in the Government's immigration amnesty program is likely to fall well below original projections, according to a comprehensive study made public yesterday.

title: Protest Over AZT Price Led to the Arrest of 19
description: Late in January, 19 people were arrested in a demonstration at the distribution center owned by the Burroughs Wellcome Company in Burlingame, Calif.

title: Poppe Tyson Picked By Summit Banks
description: Poppe Tyson, which just moved its New Jersey office from Union to Morris Plains, has been selected to handle the Summit Bancorporation account after a two-month review of a half-dozen agencies. The budget, which is more than $1 million, will be primarily devoted to print campaigns, possibly followed by some local radio spots.

title: Jewish Settler Kills an Arab Amid Continuing Disorders
description: A Jewish settler shot and killed a Palestinian youth in this remote village today, as widespread protests marking two months of unrest continued for a second day.

title: A Job for Jesse
description: Carnival time in Iowa is over at last. It is only 273 days until Election Day; patience.

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Drug Issue May Mar Mexico Talks
description: President Reagan travels to Mexico on Saturday for talks with President Miguel de la Madrid, and by all accounts the two chiefs of state intend to spend a lot of time smiling and patting each other on the back.

title: Concert: New York City Symphony
description: TAN DUN, whose music was the sole concern of Sunday's concert by the New York City Symphony at Avery Fisher Hall, is a Chinese composer working with Western materials. He brought us, among other things, a piano concerto, a piece for violin and orchestra (''Out of the Peking Opera'') and a new symphony with vocal quartet called ''The Great Wall.''

title: Wildflower Bill Keeps Us Competitive
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound Way Out of the Treaty Trap
description: Dumb. Deceitful. Self-defeating. The Reagan Administration set senators to sputtering when it offered up a new doctrine on treaties: Administration testimony during hearings on treaty approval need not be binding on Presidents. That doctrine, intended to protect President Reagan's Star Wars dream, prompted senatorial fury over legal treachery. Now the anger returns to haunt - perhaps even hinder - approval of the Administration's Euromissile treaty.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Unexpected Proposal
description: An inside Washington brouhaha erupted a few days ago when officials at the Federal Reserve Board let it be known that the Treasury's rather shy and professorial chief economist, Michael R. Darby, had sent a letter to some of the board's governors advising them that they allow interest rates to go down. Lower interest rates could give the economy and the fortunes of Republicans a lift in this election year.

title: Graphic Industries Buys Sorg Stake
description: Graphic Industries said that it had bought a 6 percent stake in Sorg Inc. and that it might seek control of the New York financial printing concern.

title: LTV, Reorganizing, Earns $140.6 Million
description: The LTV Corporation said today that it had earned $140.6 million in the fourth quarter of last year, compared with a $470.1 million loss in the 1986 quarter.

title: Mecham Stepping Aside for Now
description: Rose Mofford said today that she was confident she could be ''a healing Governor'' as she takes over the duties and authority from Gov. Evan Mecham, who faces impeachment and has said he will move out of his office temporarily this week.

title: Jazz: Jack DeJohnette at Bottom Line
description: OVER the last decade, the drummer Jack DeJohnette has led bands framing New York's most gifted young jazz musicians: David Murray, Arthur Blythe, John Purcell and Chico Freeman have all moved through the ranks. His current version of his band, Special Edition, is no different, with three extraordinarily talented stars-to-be - Greg Osby on alto and soprano saxophones, Gary Thomas on tenor saxophone and flute, and Lonnie Plaxico on bass - on the ramparts.

title: Inquiry in Britain
description: The British Boxing Board of Control says it will investigate the turmoil that broke out in the arena before Frank Tate's successful defense of his International Boxing Federation middleweight title against Tony Sibson of Britain.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about telephone companies' earnings misstated Bell Atlantic's involvement in computer hardware.

title: The Stage: 'Serious Money'
description: IN its transfer to Broadway's Royale Theater, Caryl Churchill's ''Serious Money'' retains its vituperative sense of humor. This is a neo-Restoration comedy crossed with a Jacobean revenger's tale. As the author indicates, with all malice intended, there is no end to greed.

title: Jury Rules ABC Documentary Did Not Libel Conservative Author
description: Victor Lasky, a conservative author, lost his libel case yesterday when a jury rejected his charge that an ABC television documentary had portrayed him falsely.

title: QUBIX GRAPHIC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1988
description: International A3-15

title: Of Yarmulkes And a Rabbi At the Lords
description: The question for Shimon Cohen today was this: When had there been so many yarmulkes in the Peers' Lobby at the House of Lords?

title: William E. Woodman, Insurance Executive, 68
description: William E. Woodman, a retired insurance executive, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 68 years old and also lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Clement G. Hurd, 80, Illustrator Of Many Children's Books, Dies
description: Clement G. Hurd, illustrator of ''Goodnight Moon'' and almost 100 other books for children, died last Friday in a convalescent hospital in San Francisco. He was 80 years old and had been ill with Alzheimer's disease for about two years.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars surrendered to the police yesterday in Toronto and was charged with assault in connection with a high-sticking incident at Maple Leaf Gardens last month. Ciccarelli, who arrived from Minneapolis with his lawyer, was arrested and released without bail. He is scheduled to appear in provincial court in Toronto on May 30. . . . Jim Robinson remained in extremely critical condition yesterday after suffering severe head injuries in last weekend's Copper World Classic stock car race at Phoenix International Raceway. Robinson, 42 years old, of North Hollywood, Calif., was leading the 40-lap race when his car tangled momentarily with a vehicle driven by Gary Collins. Robinson's car smashed head-on into the wall. . . . The Miami Dolphins have released Tony Nathan, fourth on their career list in receiving yards and second in pass receptions. Nathan, 31, was released during training camp but re-signed at midseason. His career totals with Miami were 3,543 yards rushing and 383 receptions for 3,592 yards.

title: KELLY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $1,500,000 in both periods because of the elimination of investment tax credits; the year included a gain of about $1,100,000 from the sale of land.

title: About Real Estate; Office Complexes Displace Jersey Barns
description: Until the mid-1970's, Freehold, a Monmouth County town in central New Jersey, depended for its economic well-being mostly on fertile farmland and to a lesser extent on an influx of summer visitors drawn by the county's oceanfront resorts.

title: Williams Is Given Keys To Open Road
description: In a couple of hours, Doug Williams would at last be back in Zachary and he had every desire that the sparkling red sports car next to him on the New York City ballroom floor should arrive in that tiny Louisiana municipality shortly thereafter.

title: Slow Gasoline Leak Rattles Nerves on L.I.
description: On Robin Hood Lane today, residents anxiously traded news about an 800,000-gallon gasoline leak oozing underground toward their homes.

title: Accounting on New York Coliseum Sale Passed Two Reviews
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Colleges - Still Segregated
description: LEAD: When the Supreme Court said in 1954 that segregated schools were unconstitutional, its ruling applied to colleges and universities as well as to elementary and secondary schools. At that time, the laws of every Southern state barred blacks from white colleges and required them to attend separate schools for blacks.

title: Miners Approve Pact as Separate Talks Continue
description: Members of the United Mine Workers have approved a five-year contract with major coal operators, and talks are scheduled to resume here Wednesday on a separate contract with the Pittston Coal Group.

title: Ambrose Nugent, 78, Korean War Prisoner
description: Lieut. Col. Ambrose H. Nugent, a prisoner of war in Korea who was later tried and acquitted of charges of collaborating with the enemy, died after a long illness Monday in Spohn Hospital in Corpus Christi, Tex.. He was 78 years old and lived in Corpus Christi.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include a pretax loss of $41.5 million from the December sale of the Denver Post. Year-ago results reflect a pretax gain of $222.2 million, or the equivalent of $1.32 a share after taxes, from the sale of assets. The share earnings 1986 are restated to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend issued Dec. 28, 1987.

title: Soviet Withdrawal Offer Raises Stakes for an Afghan Compromise
description: The Soviet offer to start withdrawing from Afghanistan in May is putting new pressure on the other parties in the civil war to reach a compromise peace settlement next month, according to officials involved in the United Nations effort for a settlement and other experts on the conflict.

title: Deductions Are Now More Limited
description: Like guests arriving late for a dinner party, most taxpayers will find the pickings meager when they look over the list of personal deductions that remain in the wake of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There really are no more Everests to climb, no more blank spots on the map to fill in.

title: Accusation Of Phone Bid Collusion
description: Some regional Bell telephone companies had access to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's secret bid price for Government telephone switch contracts and may have shared the information and used it to calculate competing bids, an official of one regional phone company said yesterday.

title: Employee of Market Shoots Clerk and Then Kills Himself
description: A porter at an East Side supermarket shot a coworker during an argument last night, then fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: Article 445988 -- No Title
description: In what experts were calling the largest single art theft ever reported in New York City, 18 paintings and 10 drawings valued at $6 million, mostly small works by old Dutch and Italian masters, were stolen overnight from a commercial gallery on the Upper East Side, the police reported yesterday.

title: PHOENIX RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year results are only from the date of the company's organization in July 1986.

title: U.S. ENVOY MEETS SHAMIR ON PEACE
description: An American envoy arrived tonight with a new proposal for peace in the occupied territories, even as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was sharply criticizing a possible feature of the plan: the acceleration of the Camp David plan for extending autonomy to the Palestinians.

title: Sports People; Undisputed Marriage
description: Mike Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, was married again yesterday, and this time he was licensed. The 21-year-old fighter and the actress Robin Givens, 23, were married by the Rev. George Clements Sunday in Chicago, but the couple did not have an Illinois license. ''In Chicago he grabbed me and said lets get married,'' Givens said last night in New York. ''To say the least, Michael is very spontaneous.'' Clements said Tyson didn't want to wait for the Illinois license. ''So he asked me to just perform the Catholic ceremony here,'' said Father Clements, ''and he said he was going to get a license in New York.'' At about 10 A.M., Tyson and Givens were married in the City Clerk's office by Judge Charles E. Ramos. Before the ceremony, the couple received a waiver, in State Supreme Court of the 24-hour waiting period required of people wanting to get married. The waiting period in Illinois also is 24 hours, but in that state, couples also are required to be tested for AIDS, and they have to wait from three days to three weeks for the results of the tests.

title: Nova-Polysar
description: Nova, an Alberta Corporation, said that merger talks with the Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation had failed last weekend over ''wide and irreconcilable differences over price.'' Polysar last week announced a reorganization plan that would distribute $900 million (Canadian) as an alternative to Nova's $14-a-share offer. Nova had asked Polysar to reconsider the restructuring, saying that it ''would unnecessarily weaken Polysar's financial position.''

title: VERSAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene, witnessed by Caroline F. Cannon, occurred during the morning rush hour at Broadway and 79th Street, where a panhandler was jingling coins in a paper coffee cup.

title: Head of Seminary Will Lead New York City Rights Agency
description: The president of an Ohio seminary will head the New York City Human Rights Commission, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

The latest year operating net included a gain of $10.1 million from the sale of broadcasting properties. c-Included capital gains of $546,706 for the quarter and $2,067,712 for the year.

title: Superior Industries
description: The Vista Group Ltd. said it and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. had made a $16-a-share, $96 million offer to cquire Superior Industries of Van Nuys, Calif., in a leveraged buyout. Superior, a manufacturer of aluminum and custom-made auto wheels said it was uninterested in holding talks. Superior said in a statement that the offer to discuss such a transaction had come from both companies. Prudential-Bache, however, denied that it had made an offer for Superior with Officials at Vista, which is basedf in Los Angeles, were unavalable to comment.

title: FORT HOWARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An architecture review of ''Stanford White's New York'' on Monday misstated the address of the exhibition site, the New York School of Interior Design. It is 155 East 56th Street.

title: CILCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company said its utility subsidiary, Central Illinois Light Co., contributed $3.06 to 1987 share earnings. That amount was offset, however, by a loss of 54 cents a share realized by its non-utility subsidiaries as a result of the stock market crash.

title: TELLABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israel Nathan Herstein, Mathematician, 64
description: Israel Nathan Herstein, a leading mathematician and educator at the University of Chicago, died of cancer Monday night at his home in Chicago. He was 64 years old. Dr. Herstein was the author of the widely used textbook ''Topics in Algebra.'' His own work included pioneering advances in the theory of rings, an algebraic system.

title: Two Former Policemen in Miami Are Found Guilty of Drug Charges
description: Two former Miami policemen were found guilty on drug charges today, bringing to 13 the number of officers who have been convicted in a two-year Federal investigation of the Miami Police Department.

title: Massachusetts Ratings Raised
description: The bond ratings of Massachusetts were raised yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, just a few days before the commonwealth plans to sell $200 million of bonds.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Union Leader Rejects Concessions Sought by Post
description: New York City's top newspaper union leader said yesterday that the unions at the New York Post would ''absolutely not'' meet Rupert Murdoch's demand that they grant $24 million in concessions by Feb. 19. Without the cuts, Mr. Murdoch said, he will shut down the paper.

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,963,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $9,217,000 for the quarter and year, and an extraordinary gain from the company's debt restructuring of $76,061,000 for the both periods.

description: * Affiliated Publications Inc., Boston, said its McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. affiliate had agreed to acquire privately held McCaw Communications Cos. for about 11.5 million class B common shares.

title: Economic Panel Is Said To Question Fed Policy
description: The President's Council of Economic Advisers will argue in its annual report next week that the Federal Reserve bears some blame for the slowing of the economy after the October stock market collapse, an Administration official said today.

title: New Hampshire Ponders Robertson
description: The voters of New Hampshire, their voices thick with the flinty accents of northern New England, like to speak of their first-in-the-nation primary and their refusal to follow anyone's lead in voting for President, especially a lead from those ''unrepresentative'' caucus-goers in Iowa.

title: Advertising; Sherwood & Schneider
description: After a three-way review, Curtain Country, a bed and bath retail chain of 33 stores in six states, has awarded its $2 million business to Sherwood & Schneider Advertising. The agency will focus on newspaper advertising, as well as the yearly production of 7.5 million circulars. Previous advertising was handled in-house.

title: Martha Graham at Work After Hospitalization
description: Martha Graham has returned to work after being hospitalized for 10 days at New York Hospital for dizziness and exhaustion. Miss Graham began work Sunday with her company on new choreography for her ''Persephone,'' on the reconstruction of her 1937 ''Deep Song,'' and preparations for a tour of Holland, Poland and Czechoslovakia in April. The Martha Graham Dance Company is to perform in New York at City Center in October.

title: Revenge Of the Reverends
description: Pray for the Republic - the ministers are coming!

title: Daredevils Hoping to Ski Into the Hearts of Olympic Officials
description: No matter who wins what medals at the Winter Olympics in Calgary over the next two weeks, among the most watched skiing events are bound to be the freestyle competitions - both by spectators and Olympic officials.

title: Adventurers Busily Explore Final Frontier: Imagination
description: LEAD: Swimmers, sailors, divers, climbers, chutists, pilots, runners, navigators and other explorers have been pursuing believe-it-or-not exploits forever. But adventuring has become something different today as the world has contracted, its last frontiers relegated to the Guinness Book of World Records.

description: b-Net loss Fiscal 1986 results are restated to reflect adoption of SFAS 90.

title: H. E. Reeves, 51, Dies; A Business Executive
description: Hazard Earl Reeves 3d, an executive in the real estate and communications industries, died of heart failure Jan. 30 in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Monroe, Conn.

title: Death of Black Man After Arrest in Texas Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a black truck driver who witnesses say was beaten by the police after his arrest in Hemphill, Tex., was ruled a homicide at an inquest today.

title: WHEN PROTEST IS TOO CLOSE TO EAST BERLIN
description: When demonstrators in East Berlin disrupted a march last month in memory of German revolutionaries, the head of East Germany's PEN club, Heinz Kamnitzer, called the action ''as reprehensible as blasphemy.''

title: A Tool to Track That Odd Noise
description: AMONG the automotive maladies that frustrate drivers most, mysterious noises and vibrations surely rank near the top. And it seems there are few mechanics who can determine the cause. The General Motors Corporation, which has 11,000 dealerships, has only one expert, Frank Pavlovcic, in all facets of vibration problems.

title: Salomon Expands at Top; Key Executive Resigning
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. announced a series of high-level management changes yesterday, suggesting continued turmoil at the top of the securities giant.

George Bush: Trying to Rebound, He Embraces New England Roots
description: Every four years the early primaries and caucuses produce more losers than winners, but sometimes they produce more than one winner at a time. Monday night, Iowans sent forth two official winners, Bob Dole and Richard Gephardt; a loser who seemed to win by placing, Pat Robertson; and a loser nobody was calling a winner, Vice President Bush. But winner or loser, that was just Iowa: Yesterday, the candidates set out on the rest of the campaign.

title: For the Poor of Calcutta, a Threat to Mobility
description: To some, the hand-pulled rickshaw makes life a little more efficient in one of the world's most unlivable cities. To others, it is a degrading anachronism symbolizing the city's inhumanity.

description: It is wonderful to win. But it is even better to get even, according to Bruce Racine, the victorious goalie as Northeastern demolished Boston University, 6-3, to capture the 36th Beanpot Tournament, this city's annual college hockey gala.

title: High-Tech Executive Signs On With Priam
description: The Priam Corporation, a struggling producer of disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that John V. Titsworth had been appointed president and chief executive. For Mr. Titsworth, who worked at the Control Data Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, the move is a return to management of a high-tech manufacturing concern after several years in venture capital.

Roswell Journal; The Darker Side Of a Beloved Founder
description: When Roswell King Sr. founded this town just north of Atlanta in 1838, he built the flour and cotton mills that would drive its economy. He and his son Barrington laid out the village, donated land for public buildings and churches, and lured plantation owners from Georgia's mosquito-infested coastal lowland.

title: 2 Suitors May Unite in Belgian Battle
description: Andre Leysen of Belgium and Carlo de Benedetti of Italy announced tonight that they were considering joining forces for the ''effective management'' of Societe Generale de Belgique, providing a new twist in the three-week wrangle for control of Belgium's largest and most important company.

title: In Iowa, Networks Address the Robertson Factor
description: BRYANT GUMBEL asked Pat Robertson on NBC's ''Today'' show yesterday morning why he had been so mad at Tom Brokaw on Monday night. Mr. Robertson didn't answer, although he did say he was a ''religious broadcaster'' and not an ''evangelist.'' In the television coverage of the Iowa caucuses, an issue had arisen.

title: Education; Volunteers In Dual Role On Campus
description: Between tomorrow's term paper and yesterday's social gathering, somewhere within the harried run of events that make up ''the college experience,'' more and more students are likely to be found working in soup kitchens or in other public service jobs but pursuing apparently different goals.

title: Advertising; Times Mirror Magazine Units
description: Times Mirror Magazines has formed two publishing groups for its eight magazines, naming Robert Beauregard, 48 years old, and John Crawley, 42, as group publishers. Mr. Beauregard, previously a senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, will oversee Golf magazine and Ski magazine, as well as Skiing and Yachting magazines. Mr. Crawley, previously publisher of Outdoor Life, will have the publishers of Field & Stream, Home Mechanix, Outdoor Life and Popular Science reporting to him.

description: Ever since 1637, when a board of 12 overseers elected Nathaniel Eaton as the first head of Harvard, colleges and universities have been trying to refine the process by which they select their presidents.

description: West Germany and its principal NATO partners are heading for a confrontation over the alliance's commitment to replace an aging short-range missile system, Western diplomats and German politicians say.

description: Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, solicited the Reagan Administration's help today in fashioning a bipartisan aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras.

description: General Motors Corp.'s earnings in 1987 were favorably impacted by a net tax credit of $60 million. The tax credit reflects primarily the continuing amortization of investment tax credits earned in prior years, and tax benefits amounting to $298 million, or 94 cents a share, of G.M. stock, related to the utilization of loss carryforwards at certain overseas operations. Overall, the income tax credit in 1987 was $240 million less than in 1986. There was a $800 million after-tax favorable impact of the adoption in 1987 of revised service lives of G.M.'s plants, equipment and special tools. The revision increased 1987 earnings by $2.55 a share of $1-2/3 par value common stock.

description: Raja Rao of India, the author of five novels and several collections of short stories, has won the 10th Neustadt International Prize for Literature.

title: Porter's Absence Aired
description: After missing practice without permission last week, Michael Porter, St. John's 6-foot-1-inch junior guard, was held out of the starting lineup in the Redmen's 80-76 loss to Boston College at Alumni Hall Monday night. Steve Shurina replaced him.

title: TV Reviews; Lanford Wilson's 'Lemon Sky,' on Channel 13
description: LANFORD WILSON'S ''Lemon Sky,'' heavily autobiographical, was first produced for the stage in 1970. Christopher Walken and Charles Durning played the father-and-son leads. I saw that production, which had a very brief run on Broadway, and found it a good deal less than memorable. Now, after having had a successful revival in 1985, ''Lemon Sky'' is an ''American PLayhouse'' presentation on Channel 13 tonight at 9, and it's terrific. What a difference a production can make.

title: Wilkins 49, Barkley 47
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 49 points, including a tie-breaking layup with two seconds remaining, and the Atlanta Hawks beat Philadelphia, 112-110, tonight in Jim Lynam's debut as the 76ers' coach.

title: Memory Chip From Korea
description: A consortium of three major South Korean semiconductor companies has developed a four-megabit semiconductor memory chip, industry officials said today. The Samsung Semiconductor

title: Thais Accuse U.S. of Theft Of Temple Art
description: A low-key campaign has been under way to bring a thousand-year-old temple carving back to Thailand from an American museum, but the campaign took an unexpected turn this week.

title: Henley Petitions Santa Fe Accord
description: The Henley Group Inc. asked the Delaware Chancery Court yesterday to invalidate an agreement between the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation and Olympia & York Developments Ltd. of Canada as a ''sweetheart deal.''

description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, accused of failing to do enough about priests who molest young boys and girls, yesterday defended their actions in such cases.

title: Inmate Accused of Data Fraud
description: A prisoner serving a 30-year term for embezzlement has been accused of tampering with computer records at the State Penitentiary, allowing him to sell about 100,000 pounds of cotton and possibly to seek early release.

title: Levin's Injuries Are Described By a Physician
description: ''Pinpoint hemorrhages'' in the soft tissue around Jennifer Levin's eyes showed evidence of a compression of her neck, indicating she had apparently been strangled, a doctor testified yesterday.

title: Royalty Rides the Bobsled
description: What makes Albert Grimaldi, the Prince of Monaco, unique among the 87 members of the International Olympic Committee is not his royal bearing. There are several other members of ruling families in the group, including Princess Nora of Liechtenstein and Sheik Fahad al-Ahmad al-Sabah of Kuwait.

title: Santa Rosa, Calif.
description: CALIFORNIANS are fond of discovering good restaurants hidden away in unlikely towns, preferably near redwoods. If you must drive forever to get there, so much the better. In that case, however, there must be a nice bed and breakfast nearby.

title: John Jennings, Lyricist And a Producer, at 54
description: John Jennings, who sang out the songs from his show ''Riverwind'' on a flatbed truck in Shubert Alley when a newspaper strike kept people from reading the reviews, died on Feb. 4 at Deaconess Hospital in Evansville, Ind. He was 54 years old and lived in Evansville.

title: Hodel's Plea to Abby
description: His wife hasn't ditched him, his boss isn't picking on him and his children aren't hanging out with the wrong kind of crowd, but Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel has written a ''Dear Abby'' letter.

title: Bob Dole: Happy Kansan Talks to New Hampshire On Foreign Policy
description: Every four years the early primaries and caucuses produce more losers than winners, but sometimes they produce more than one winner at a time. Monday night, Iowans sent forth two official winners, Bob Dole and Richard Gephardt; a loser who seemed to win by placing, Pat Robertson; and a loser nobody was calling a winner, Vice President Bush. But winner or loser, that was just Iowa: Yesterday, the candidates set out on the rest of the campaign.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for 14wks to Jan 2
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $291,000 and a $20,000,000 gain on the sale of business. c-After a pretax charge of $300,000 from plant consolidation and a loss from discontinued snack food business of $706,000 for the 14 weeks, and the 53 weeks include net from discontinued operations of $614,000 and a $15,100,000 gain on the sale of businesses. The latest 14 weeks results include a pre-tax gain of $3,843,000 from investments, classified as unusual items, including $5,148,000 from its investment in Centaur Communications Ltd., as reported; all of Centaur's shareholders accepted an offer from an investment group to buy 20 percent of Centaur's outstanding stock. The company said earnings in 1987 include a $5.1 million pretax gain from the sale of 20 percent of the company's interest in Centaur Communications Ltd. The company also said earnings in 1986 include operating profit of $2.1 million from Metropolitan Distribution and $2.6 million of interest income on funds related to the December 1986 special distribution to shareholders, and also included is plant consolidation charges of $5.3 million. Revenue in 1986 includes $163 million from Metropolitan Distribution Services.

title: Westminster Show; Pomeranian Takes Top Dog Ribbon
description: The smallest dog in the ring, a four-and-a-half-pound Pomeranian, scored the biggest victory of his career last night when he was selected by Michele Billings as the best of 2,651 dogs at the 112th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden.

title: Little Change Reported in Prices
description: A steep late-afternoon drop in the overnight rate for bank loans yesterday kept alive suspicions that the Federal Reserve might be encouraging lower short-term interest rates. But those suspicions caused little change in prices or in rates, partly because interest rates have already fallen sharply in the last month.

description: A 63-year-old New Jersey man was arrested at his Bronx office yesterday afternoon and charged with rape, sodomy and unlawfully practicing dentistry, the police said.

title: College Basketball; Smith Opens Up as Georgetown Wins
description: It seems that at some point in nearly every Georgetown game this season, Coach John Thompson has had to remind Charles Smith that he always has the green light to shoot.

title: Oh What A Lovely Life
description: Movies often inspire the young with dreams of the future.

title: Waldheim Report Leaves Austria as Divided as Before
description: The findings of the historians' commission about President Kurt Waldheim's war record appeared to confirm what most Austrians had feared, that an end to the punishing and divisive controversy has come no nearer.

description: b-Included a gain of $26 million, or 8 cents a share, from pension settlements and a sale of real estate. c-Included charges of $30 million.

description: b-Net loss The company said year-ago fourth quarter sales includes a one-time revenue contribution of $336,000 from a major product update sold to existing Timberline users.

title: The Dance: Ohio Ballet At the Joyce
description: THE Ohio Ballet presented the local premiere of Heinz Poll's ''Games'' at its opening last night at the Joyce Theater, along with two other Poll ballets and Laura Dean's ''Patterns of Change.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Monday about Peter S. Kalikow, prospective buyer of The New York Post, misstated the ownership of the building in which he lives, at 1001 Fifth Avenue. While Mr. Kalikow built the building, it is now a cooperative.

title: 10 Accused of Commodity Schemes
description: In a renewed crackdown on commodity fraud, 10 people were charged today with taking part in illegal trading schemes at the Chicago Board of Trade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Panama's Beleaguered Leader Finds an Enthusiastic Haven
description: Abroad, he is now wanted as a criminal, and in the capital there are daily demands for his ouster. But in this small provincial town tonight, a smiling Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega heard himself acclaimed as the defender of Panamanian sovereignty against Yankee colonialism and ''domestic traitors.''

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SALMON seems to maintain its freshness better than any other fish. Whether from Atlantic or Pacific waters, it comes to the kitchen in prime condition, provided it has been properly refrigerated.

title: Rewarding Bad Service?
description: To The Living Section:

Koch Is Rebuffed on Pension Limits
description: Raising the political stakes on the most highly charged issue of the legislative session, Mayor Koch and union leaders came here today to force lawmakers to choose between them on a measure to increase pensions for former New York City and state workers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Cleveland-Cliffs
description: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., an iron-ore supplier based in Cleveland, said it would spin off to its shareholders its 4.1 million shares in the MLX Corporation of Troy, Mich., a 26 percent holding valued at $12.8 million, based on Monday's closing price. This would amount to a one-time special dividend of about 78 cents for every share of Cleveland-Cliffs, the company said. MLX is a manufacturer of brakes and transmissions and a distributor of refrigeration systems. Cleveland-Cliffs has eight iron-ore mines in North America and Australia.

title: EG&G INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: There were 53 weeks in the latest year, compared with 52 weeks for the prior year.

title: U.S. Is Now Upbeat on Value Of Afghan Withdrawal Plan
description: The White House said today that a Soviet proposal to begin a troop withdrawal from Afghanistan on May 15 was ''a positive step,'' but that more details were needed before a final judgment could be made.

title: U.S. Opposes Job Equality Bill
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it opposes a House bill that would require Federal agencies to document their efforts to comply with equal employment laws.

title: Japanese Are Expected to Bid for California's Union Bank
description: Japanese banks without a foothold in California are the most likely suitors of Union Bank, the state's fifth-largest bank, industry analysts said today.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL ELECTRONCS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $98,205 and $421,246 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: The 'Baby M' Ruling: Elegant, Flawed
description: LEAD: It was easier for Solomon.

title: Under New Rule, Auditors Must Search Out Fraud
description: The chief regulatory body for accountants made it indisputably clear yesterday that accountants have a responsibility to look actively for financial fraud inside companies and not simply to detect fraud if it comes their way.

title: Life in the 30's
description: THE law is of necessity shrouded in words.

title: Advertising; Martin/Williams Wins Mercruiser Account
description: The Mercury Marine division of the Brunswick Corporation, based in Fond du Lac, Wis., has assigned its Mercruiser brand of boat stern drives and inboard propulsion systems to Martin/Williams Advertising in Minneapolis. Its budget is $1.5 million. The previous agency was Carmichael-Lynch, also of Minneapolis.

title: And Still the Hostages Remain in Beirut
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Generation at Cray
description: Cray Research Inc. will introduce its newest and most powerful supercomputer on Wednesday, hoping it will be viewed as a symbol not of what the company was but of what it will be.

title: 2 Bolshoi Dancers Learn New Style at City Ballet
description: ''Everyone knows we're here studying Balanchine,'' Nina Ananiashvili said. ''Everyone is waiting impatiently for us to come back and show them something.'' Miss Ananiashvili and Andris Liepa looked like dancers the world over, in a recent conversation backstage at the New York State Theater. She wore an ''I Love New York'' sweatshirt and chic leather pants and boots. He was dressed in a New York City Ballet T-shirt and ragged rehearsal clothes. Each talked of hard work and ambitions. But the two young Bolshoi Ballet stars had just embarked on a unique adventure.

title: Economic Scene; The Implications Of Iowa Results
description: WITH Richard A. Gephardt, Paul Simon and Michael S. Dukakis finishing a tight 1-2-3 in the Iowa Democratic caucuses, it is hard to assess who gained an edge in the race for the Presidential nomination. But there is a clear conclusion to be drawn from the Iowa contest. While some Americans may be disillusioned with the Reagan Administration's economic policies, the political process rarely rewards those who preach sacrifice.

title: Education; Lessons
description: If education and discipline really begin at home, then certain failures of our age - the decline of learning, the disorder of the classroom and the scourge of drugs in schools - must first be fixed where they belong, at the warm spot by the hearth.

title: 'Frugal Gourmet': A Minister Makes Food His Mission
description: ON a misty morning, just up the steep hill from Puget Sound, Jeff Smith was charging through the bustle of the Pike Place Market here, working his way from steelhead to salmon to squid. He was brought to a halt in front of Jack's Fish Spot and Crab Pot by a stranger who stuck out his hand and introduced himself as Chris Peters of Seattle. ''You're Jeff Smith, the Frugal Gourmet,'' Mr. Peters said. ''I watch you religiously.''

title: CHILI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months both include a charge of $566,000 for unrealized losses on the investment portfolio, and the 6-month also includes a gain of $600,000 for the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: HBO & CO (ATLANTA, GA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year included a $3.7 million gain on the sale of real estate.

title: Richard A. Gephardt: Facing the Challenge Of Winning Again On Less Familiar Turf
description: Every four years the early primaries and caucuses produce more losers than winners, but sometimes they produce more than one winner at a time. Monday night, Iowans sent forth two official winners, Bob Dole and Richard Gephardt; a loser who seemed to win by placing, Pat Robertson; and a loser nobody was calling a winner, Vice President Bush. But winner or loser, that was just Iowa: Yesterday, the candidates set out on the rest of the campaign.

title: Advances; A Bicycle Easy to Ride, Hard to Sell
description: FOR more than a century, people have been propelling bicycles by pushing pedals round and round so that a gear turns a chain connected to a wheel. This system is, to say the least, an example of an entrenched technology, something that works well and that most people see no need to change.

title: Dow Chemical Japan's Paper Is a First for Tokyo Market
description: Japan's efforts to broaden the scope of its capital market and allow more financing in yen by foreign companies moved ahead another step yesterday when Dow Chemical Japan issued 600 million yen, or about $4.6 million, of commercial paper in Tokyo.

title: Concert: String Music From Ottoman Court
description: NEW YORK has a voracious appetite for music from beyond the mainstream, whether it be from Cajun Louisiana or Anatolia. This creates a performance problem. Shows featuring functional music - music for weddings, for dancing or for rituals -don't have a context, and they can become museum exhibits, disemboweled parts of a culture, tough to make sense of. This wasn't the case for a concert on Sunday at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center featuring two of Turkey's leading classical musicians, Necdet Yasar and Ihsan Ozgen. From the first lacy notes it was clear they were playing art music, meant for listening.

title: Sports of The Times; Ironhead's Dilemma
description: IRONHEAD HEYWARD'S mother says that her son - she refers to him, in fact, as Craig, the name she gave him, and not by the nickname, Ironhead, which he generally answers to - is 21 years old, an adult, and ought to determine for himself what he'll do with his life.

title: Party Time: Wall St. Goes Broadway
description: The opening of the Broadway production of ''Serious Money'' was an evening of coincidences and odd juxtapositions.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Edward Haymes will join J. Walter Thompson later this month as executive vice president for finance and administration.

title: Journal Punishes News Agency Over Report
description: The New England Journal of Medicine has suspended prepublication delivery of its weekly magazine to the British news service Reuters for six months, saying the agency broke an agreement on how soon it could release information from the journal.

title: California's High Court Broadens Use of Illegally Obtained Evidence
description: The California Supreme Court has ruled that statements by suspects that were illegally obtained by the police may be admitted as evidence if the suspects choose to testify at their trial. The decision upset longstanding rules barring the use of illegally seized evidence in criminal trials in the state.

title: Sports People; Virginia Bound
description: While his father was searching in Iowa for delegates to the Democratic National Convention, Yusef Jackson was sifting through athletic scholarship offers from such universities as Duke, Syracuse, Wake Forest, Richmond, Rutgers and William & Mary. On Monday, the son of Jesse Jackson cast his vote. The 6-foot-3-inch, 215-pound linebacker at St. Albans in Washington accepted the offer of the University of Virginia and will sign a letter of intent today, the first day prospects may make a binding commitment to a college. . . . Forrest Gregg, the new head football coach at Southern Methodist University, will sign 15 recruits today and expects another 35 to 45 to join the Mustangs as walk-ons in the fall. The school canceled its 1988 season in the aftermath of the National Collegiate Athletic Association penalty that banned S.M.U. from playing last season. ''We have had tremendous response from around the country,'' Gregg said.

title: OPEC Asks Price Support
description: The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has urged non-member countries to help support oil prices and says a price range of $18 to $20 a barrel can be maintained throughout the year.

title: Outsider in Inner Circle?
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the author and professor at the City University of New York, has received many honors in his lifetime. But none quite so unexpected, and perhaps so inappropriate, as that bestowed on him last month.

title: Texaco Data Plea Denied
description: Federal District Judge Charles L. Brieant yesterday denied a request that Texaco Inc. be required to add more information to the description of its bankruptcy reorganization plan that it is mailing to the 230,000 shareholders who will vote on it.

title: Jury Hears Final Arguments In Monthlong Nofziger Trial
description: Final arguments in the monthlong Federal ethics trial of Lyn Nofziger were presented to the jury today and deliberations were expected to begin Wednesday.

title: CHAMBERS DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $308,000 for both the quarter and year, from debt refinancing. c-After an extraordinary charge of $131,000.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Hazards of Arms Control
description: What did the rise of Japanese militarism 60 years ago and the German pocket battleships of World War II have in common? Both may have been fostered by the major arms control agreements of the interwar years. With Mikhail Gorbachev pressing new treaties on the White House, the pitfalls of past attempts to control weapons are worth trying to avoid.

title: Ashton-Tate's New Products
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, the third-largest personal computer software company, will initiate a thrust into the market for Macintosh software Wednesday. That market is dominated by its rival, the Microsoft Corporation.

THERMO PROCESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Asian Tradition at War With American Laws
description: The ancient traditions of Southeast Asia and the laws of 20th-century America are increasingly causing conflicts in the lives of the 30,000 Hmong and Mien tribespeople who settled in the Fresno area after fleeing Laos, Thailand and Vietnam.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Iraq's denial that it had sought Israeli guarantees in talks on an oil pipeline misstated the relationship between the Bechtel Group and E. Robert Wallach, a San Francisco lawyer. Mr. Wallach had a financial interest in the project, but there is no evidence that Bechtel entrusted him with obtaining Israeli guarantees.

title: BUSH AND SIMON SEEN AS HOBBLED BY IOWA'S VOTING
description: Iowa's winners and most of Iowa's losers flew east today for their final drives in New Hampshire, some drafting new messages and others renewing old attacks.

title: Cabaret: Steven Davis Sings
description: EARLY in his cabaret act, Steven Davis reminisces about his Nebraska boyhood and growing up across the street from a cornfield. Instead of going outside to play baseball, Mr. Davis remembers, he became entranced by Fred Astaire movies on television. ''Today, the old world seems to have rocked itself out of romance,'' he remarked wistfully at the second of four Monday night shows at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street.

title: Blanche Lasker, Principal, 79
description: Blanche Lasker, a retired principal in School District 10 in the Bronx, died of cancer Sunday in the Tally Ho Manor in Boonton, N.J., where she lived. She was 79 years old.

title: NEW YORK ADOPTS PUBLIC FINANCING OF POLITICAL RACES
description: The New York City Council easily passed a bill yesterday that provides public funds to candidates in municipal elections who voluntarily agree to limits on campaign contributions and spending.

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the revenue increase resulted from its purchase last year of a stake in Donohue Inc., as well as the acquisition of printing plants in the U.S., and a general increase at its other businesses.

title: Court Rejects Arson Liability
description: A service-station chain cannot be held liable for damages occurring when arsonists used gasoline bought at one of its stations to set a fire that killed 25 people at a social club in the South Bronx, the state's highest court said today.

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a cumulative effect of an accounting change resulted in a net credit of $2,970,000. c-Net income The latest fourth quarter included a pretax charge of $4.6 million related to restructuring.

title: WINE TALK
description: About 150 French wine makers and exporters gathered here last week to find out why they are losing ground in the American market. Harold Binstein was happy to give his analysis.

title: J. P. Stevens Bidder Called Likely to Win
description: J. P. Stevens & Company's stock has risen above the $43-a-share price offered by a management group led by the company's chairman and chief executive, Whitney Stevens. But associates of Mr. Stevens and textile industry analysts said yesterday that the management group was likely to succeed, no matter what the price.

description: Nanci Griffith

INTERSTATE SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Baseball Teams Win Arbitration Round
description: Club owners gained a significant double-barreled victory yesterday when two arbitrators selected the clubs' salaries over those submitted by two noted relief pitchers, Tom Henke of Toronto and John Franco of Cincinnati. The outcomes had instant ramifications for salary arbitration cases involving three other relievers.

title: ALLIANCE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: The Times Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, yesterday reported a 45 percent drop in fourth-quarter income. Meanwhile, the Washington Post Company reported a 77.4 percent improvement.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $260,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $173,000 and $667,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Sympathy for the Homeless Expressed in Gifts to Neediest
description: Vivian Rivkin Friedman and her husband, Sidney, a native of South Carolina, met and fell in love in New York City and say, ''The city has been good to us.'' Both professionals, they bought a home here, had a child and plan to stay.

description: b-Includes a charge for restructuring costs of $2,651,000 and gains on the sale of land of $3,671,000 for the latest year; the prior year includes a $1 million provision for discontinuance of certain products. c-Net loss Prior fourth quarter and year include the results of Unitron Inc., acquired April 1, 1986.

title: Beijing Tries to Skewer a Cultural Sacred Cow
description: What many people here consider the fertile core of the Central Kingdom, the sanctum of Chinese civilization, is suddenly endangered.

title: Hyde May Raise High Voltage Bid
description: The New York investment firm Hyde Park Partners L.P. said it was willing to ''substantially increase'' its latest $17 a share tender offer for the High Voltage Engineering Corporation, but only if the management of the electrical products concern negotiates the terms of the deal.

title: Earth Moves as Rivals Arrive for Next Test
description: A light earthquake rattled parts of southern New Hampshire today as Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates arrived for the final week of campaigning before next week's crucial primary.

title: A 10-Year Term Given by Judge To Crime Figure
description: A 76-year-old former leader of the Gambino organized-crime family was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in Federal prison and ordered to pay fines totaling $380,000.

title: Chinatowns Find New Venues and New Dishes
description: CHINATOWNS are on the move: from the city centers of San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York to the suburbs and outer boroughs. And Chinese food is following, from Cantonese and Sichuan menus featuring dishes like orange beef and moo shu pork, to a sophisticated cuisine from Hong Kong emphasizing artfully presented seafood.

title: Profit Scoreboard
Brewer Named Editor Of Times News Service
description: The New York Times Company yesterday named John C. Brewer as executive editor of The New York Times News Service, replacing H. W. (Paddy) Thornberry, who will leave the position March 1 in preparation for retirement.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Advance Publications, Staten Island, has acquired Details magazine.

title: Strength of Robertson and Gephardt Spoke to Moral Anxiety and Economic Discontent
description: The Iowa caucuses delivered twin messages of protest on Monday night, as participants used the candidacies of Pat Robertson and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri to say that something in the nation has gone awry.

title: Dow Advances 18.74 in Late Rally
description: LEAD: A late rally that traders said was tied to stock index arbitrage pushed prices higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, after trading in a narrow range all day, closed at 1,914.46, up 18.74 points.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $375,000 for the quarter and $1,201,000 for the year.

title: Test Program Monitors Parolees With Electronic Sensor on Ankle
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had begun strapping electronic sensors to the ankles of a small group of Federal parolees as part of an experiment to monitor their movements outside prison.

title: Shultz Answers Democrats in Treaty Dispute
description: In an effort to avoid a delay in Senate action on the new missile treaty, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has prepared a letter to Senate Democratic leaders responding to their concerns on the key issue of how treaties are made and interpreted, Administration officials said tonight.

title: COLONIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West German Wines of '86 Yield Surprises in the Top Tier
description: WEST GERMAN bottlings from the 1986 vintage, which are arriving across the United States, are workmanlike wines for all seasons.

title: Pat Robertson: After Surprise Finish, He Wants to Shed Image as TV Preacher
description: Every four years the early primaries and caucuses produce more losers than winners, but sometimes they produce more than one winner at a time. Monday night, Iowans sent forth two official winners, Bob Dole and Richard Gephardt; a loser who seemed to win by placing, Pat Robertson; and a loser nobody was calling a winner, Vice President Bush. But winner or loser, that was just Iowa: Yesterday, the candidates set out on the rest of the campaign.

title: Scoring the Coliseum Match-Up
description: When two New York City Mayors disagree, it's a good bet that each is half right. That's the case in the showdown of Mayor Koch and former Mayor Beame over accounting for sale of the old Coliseum site at Columbus Circle.

title: Wisconsin Plans to Sue Chrysler on Plant Loss
description: The State of Wisconsin will sue the Chrysler Corporation in an effort to overturn the auto maker's decision to close its Kenosha plant, Attorney General Donald Hanaway said today.

title: Film and TV Programs Included in Arts Festival
description: Experimental film making and the performing arts are the influences most strongly reflected in the film and television programming of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, officially announced today. The festival's attention to Hollywood film making and to television qua television, on the other hand, is considerably less intense. The festival is unveiling its offerings by artistic discipline, with the theater schedule to be announced on Friday.

title: Music: Dorian Wind Quintet
description: LEE HOIBY joined the Dorian Wind Quintet at Hunter College Monday evening for two piano-and-wind pieces: His own 12-year-old ''Sextet'' (newly revised), and an arrangement of the theme and variations from Tchaikovsky's Suite for Orchestra (Op. 55). One could infer from either piece Mr. Hoiby's easy affinity for Tchaikovsky's music; the ''Sextet'' has some of the celebratory brightness and rambling energy that we value in the heavy parts of the Russian's ballet scores.

title: REDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Minneapolis
description: LEAD: FEB. 29 marks the beginning of the end of a favorite winter pastime here. On that date, all fish houses must be removed from Minnesota's 10,000 lakes. Fish houses -wooden cabins as large as 12 by 20 feet - are an integral part of the state's most passionately pursued sport: fishing.

title: TERMIFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: VISITORS to Seattle who take their coffee for granted may wonder what compels Seattle natives to line up at sidewalk carts for a shot of espresso, particularly when it can cost $2.25 and there are no refills. One taste, however, and even closed-minded visitors will probably agree that they really never knew their coffee from swamp water.

title: Excerpts From Report on Waldheim
description: Following are excerpts from the conclusions to a report, made public today, by a commission of historians on President Kurt Waldheim's wartime record, as translated by The Associated Press from the German:

title: About New York; Kvetch, Kvetch: A Little Shop Of Hardware
description: Somewhere in the back of the hardware store, amid the jumble of what an impractical eye could only catalog as arcana, was a letter that George Washington wrote to Thomas Jefferson. Jack Gasnick, the owner of the letter and the co-owner of the shop, along with his brother Walter, had called to say he had the letter, this being the season of Washington's birthday and all, but then he had forgotten he had called. He left.

title: Marvin Schwartz, Lawyer, 65
description: Marvin Schwartz, a lawyer, died of a stroke Feb. 2 at his home in Kingston, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: WITH the exception of an occasional Moon Pie or Goo Goo bar, chocolate does not loom large in childhood memories in the South. ''Chocolate was just not something we kept in the house,'' said Nena Williams, 29 years old. The warm, humid climate made storage difficult and kept consumption low.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Lost Fitzgerald Story to Be Published
description: A half-century after it was written, an unpublished short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald - rejected by Redbook but now seen by scholars as a forerunner of black humor and a new insight into the author's time of despair - is finally going to appear in print next week.

title: John D. Tracy, Biaggi Aide, 88
description: John D. Tracy, the executive assistant to Representative Mario Biaggi, died of a heart attack Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx. He was 88 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: The Shallowness of the Campaign
description: Mr. Robertson's performance cannot readily be explained just by his own strength. It's unlikely that a relative unknown could bring in enough supporters to score so well against the Vice President unless Mr. Bush's own support were shallow. In the shadow of the Iran-contra crisis, the Reagan record is a hard one for someone else to ride. Even Iowans who most approve President Reagan were as likely to say ''Dole'' or ''Robertson'' Monday night as to stand up for Mr. Bush.

title: Citicorp Rates Fall
description: Interest rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.431 percent, down from 6.61 percent last week. Another $50 million of 182-day paper was sold at an average rate of 6.4306, down from 6.635 percent.

title: McKesson Sale Of Stationer
description: The McKesson Corporation plans to divest itself of its unprofitable office products operation. McKesson said on Monday that it had agreed to combine the unit with the Stationers Distributing Company Inc. of Fort Worth, a wholly owned subsidiary of the privately held SDC Corporation, exchanging inventory and certain other assets in return for a 20 percent equity interest in the combined operation.

title: Sports People; Blue Wants to Return
description: About one year after announcing his retirement from baseball, Vida Blue, 38 years old, now says that his drug problems are a thing of the past and that he hopes to make a comeback as a major league pitcher this season. After pitching one scoreless inning on Sunday in ''Dream Game 88'' between the 1972 Oakland A's and the Cincinnati Reds in Phoenix, the left-hander said: ''I've already gotten a couple of nibbles from a couple of major league teams.''

title: Memorial for Kleban
description: A memorial tribute to Edward Kleban, the lyricist for ''A Chorus Line,'' will be held at 12:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Susan Anspacher Theater at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Mr. Kleban died in December at the age of 48. Among the speakers are to be Betty Buckley, Bob Balaban, Avery Corman, Marvin Hamlisch, Sheldon Harnick, Priscilla Lopez, Peter Stone and Wendy Wasserstein.

title: Pete C. Sianis, Hanoi Raids' Planner, 68
description: Maj. Gen. Pete C. Sianis, retired, an Air Force officer who planned devastating B-52 bombing raids on North Vietnam, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Bellevue.

title: Court Backs New York's Right To Order Building's Top Razed
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that New York City can force the developer of a 31-story apartment building, erected on a site zoned for no more than 19 stories, to tear down the top 12 floors.

description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., the Brooklyn civil rights lawyer, spoke without notes for two hours Monday night to a friendly audience at the Star of Bethlehem Baptist Church here, detailing how a young black woman from Wappingers Falls had entered the troubled history of race relations in New York.

description: COULD it be that such fashionable ingredients as broccoli di rape, chilies, morels, carambola, passion fruit and cherimoyas add not only variety to the modern diet but also a generous dose of good health?

title: Bridge: Top Players Are More Likely To Use a Strong Club System
description: The higher one looks in the hierarchy of tournament players, the greater the frequency of strong club systems, with a corresponding diminution of standard methods.

description: Since the thaw in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union began, there have been cultural exchanges of art, music and dance. Now comes laughter.

description: When Senator John C. Danforth recently called for a vote on an anti-abortion amendment to a civil rights bill, the matter was deemed so important that Senator Bob Dole and Vice President Bush broke off their Presidential campaigns in Iowa to be on hand to support it. Senator Paul Simon, another Presidential hopeful, interrupted a trip to Texas to oppose it.

title: Sports People; Cutting Ties
description: According to a message sent by Zola Budd to a friend and adviser in Johannesburg, the South Africa-born running star, a target of protesters whenever she competes because of her strong identification with the apartheid nation, has broken her allegiances to her native country and will return there only to see her family at Christmas. Fanie van Ziji said yesterday in a statement to the South African Press Association that Budd, a naturalized British citizen since 1984, had written to him: ''I have completely cut my ties with South Africa. I am proud to be a Briton and will do my utmost for Britain.''

description: The Reagan Administration today asked Congress to ratify a free-trade pact with Canada, saying it would provide a huge improvement in overall access for American companies in the Canadian market. Not to ratify, it added, would be thinking small.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for increased openness and democracy have had the unintended effect of encouraging the Soviet Union's nationalist groups to step out of the shadows and agitate more openly for greater autonomy.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Confidant Turns Against Noriega, but Why?
description: For two days, Jose I. Blandon has transfixed Capitol Hill with vivid accounts of wrongdoing by his former boss, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader. But it is still unclear why a man many Panamanian exile leaders in Miami and Costa Rica denounce as General Noriega's confidant in unsavory operations over the years would suddenly switch sides.

title: Parole Scheduled for Convict In Tylenol Extortion Scheme
description: An imprisoned tax accountant who plotted to extort $1 million from the manufacturer of Tylenol after seven people were killed here by cyanide-filled Tylenol capsules will be paroled in August 1989 if he stays out of trouble, a Federal official says.

title: Reagan Didn't Know of Afghan Deal
description: An American commitment in 1985 to end military aid to the Afghan guerrillas at the beginning of a Soviet troop withdrawal was made without the knowledge or approval of President Reagan, according to White House and State Department officials.

title: Expansion Backed At Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's board yesterday authorized the quasi-governmental agency, known as Freddie Mac, to broaden the variety of securities it may issue to include up to $15 billion in real estate mortgage investment conduits and an unidentified amount of interest-only, principal-only securities.

Pagliarulo Loses Arbitration
description: Mike Pagliarulo, who in the previous two winters encountered bitter contract negotiations with the Yankees, lost his salary arbitration case yesterday after having rejected a compromise settlement.

title: Rating Game: Parents Try To Fill Gap In Guidelines
description: WHEN people who now have children were children, there was no Terminator and no Dead Kennedys, no mention of condoms on sitcoms and no video cassettes. On ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' the Rolling Stones had to change the words of ''Let's Spend the Night Together.'' Roman Catholics over 30 can remember when the Legion of Decency could rate a movie ''condemned'' for the cut of a neckline.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Translator Indicted
description: A former translator of Chinese for the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been arrested and indicted on a charge of providing classified information to the Government of Taiwan, the bureau announced today.

title: EVANS'S 20 ASSISTS LEAD TEMPLE, 98-86
description: Mark Macon, a freshman guard, scored a season-high 31 points and Howard Evans, the senior playmaker, had 15 points and a school-record 20 assists tonight to lead No. 1 Temple to a 98-86 rout of Villanova.

description: TRW Inc. said yesterday that Joseph T. Gorman, its president and chief operating officer, would succeed Ruben F. Mettler as chairman and chief executive later this year.

title: Citing Recent Violence by Gangs, Los Angeles to Add 150 Officers
description: With officials saying gang violence is on the rise here, the City Council has voted to hire 150 new police officers.

title: Recital: Marian Thompson
description: IN Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening, Marian Thompson gave an honest, devoted and unaffected performance of Schubert's master work in song, ''Die Winterreise.'' She did not sing any of the 24 songs in an unusual or surprising way, nor did any of them seem to slip through her without contact, as happens when temperamentally unsuited artists essay the work. She sang the cycle without interruption and without a single lapse of memory or concentration.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation and Olympia & York Developments Ltd., two major real estate developers, yesterday joined the Campeau Corporation's bid for Federated Department Stores Inc., agreeing to provide a total of $660 million for the deal.

title: Description By Chambers Is Disputed
description: Jennifer Levin's neck was compressed by a ''considerable force'' lasting at least 20 to 30 seconds and perhaps a minute or more, a pathologist testified yesterday.

title: U.S. Declares Japan in Violation On Whaling and May Curb Trade
description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. today declared Japan in violation of a moratorium on commercial whaling. A spokesman for Mr. Verity said the Secretary might recommend an embargo on imports of fish from Japan.

description: Dale Fowler said he thinks there is a strong market for antique chrome-faced one-armed bandits, made during the golden years of slot machines decades ago.

description: Bill Cosby, the actor, and Edward Lewis, the publisher of Essence magazine, offered a $25,000 reward yesterday for information about the reported sexual attack on Tawana Brawley, a black teen-ager from Wappingers Falls, N.Y.

title: Former University President Is Acquitted in Federal Court
description: The former president of the University of the District of Columbia has been cleared of Federal charges arising from an investigation into alleged misuse of special discretionary funds within the office of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. A jury in Federal District Court deliberated about two hours Tuesday before acquitting Robert L. Green of charges that he had stolen a stereo and television from the school and had lied to a grand jury about the alleged thefts.

title: YIELDS ARE DOWN
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down modestly for the week ended yesterday. A reduction in the prime lending rate on Feb. 2 and recent price rises in Government securities continued to affect the money markets.

title: Common Operation Aimed at Strokes Faces New Questions About Safety
description: Major clinical tests have begun in an attempt to resolve one of the more troubling controversies in medical practice: whether surgery to clear clogged arteries to the brain is worth the risk.

title: TYSON'S ATTENTION TURNS TO DIFFERENT KIND OF RING
description: Tony Tubbs slipped into his seat a few minutes before the satellite news conference linking New York and Tokyo was to begin.
