description: b-Net loss

title: Tolentine Runs Record to 20-1
description: St. Nicholas of Tolentine won its 20th game this season, defeating Springfield Gardens, 64-60, last night at the Gauchos' gym in the Bronx.

title: Peres Welcomes a U.S. Plan on Palestinian Rule
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel welcomed a new American peace plan calling for Palestinian autonomy, but there was no indication of an immediate breakthrough.

title: Weakened Pistons Turn Back Knicks
description: Joe Dumars, the subject of trade rumors, scored 12 of his 18 points in the third quarter tonight, leading the Detroit Pistons to a 98-87 victory over the Knicks. The loss was the Knicks' 16th straight on the road.

title: Collapsible Bicycle In Progress
description: THE Italian designer Richard Sapper, creator of the Tizio lamp, is now at work on a bicycle. Although the project is still in the planning stage, Mr. Sapper did say that his new bicycle would be a lightweight fold-up variety, ''long and narrow like a stick so you can take it into a bus.''

title: NETS SCORE VICTORY DESPITE JORDAN'S 34
description: Michael Jordan, the National Basketball Association's master showman, helped draw 16,567 fans tonight to Byrne Meadowlands Arena, where the Nets usually play to a lot of empty seats.

title: City Ballet: Balanchine's 'Jewels'
description: ''JEWELS'' is a crowd-pleaser that is also, in subtle ways, one of George Balanchine's most problematic ballets. Presented by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, ''Jewels'' was danced by a cast that included a number of dancers in new and recently acquired roles. It was a performance that pointed up the ballet's difficulties.

title: Florida County Administrator Quits as Allegations Continue
description: Dade County Manager Sergio Pereira, under fire for alleged indiscretions that included a secret land deal that was said to have netted him $120,000, announced tonight that he was resigning.

title: 2 Indicted in North Carolina In Newspaper Hostage Case
description: Two men who held 19 people hostage at a newspaper office last week to dramatize complaints of discrimination and public corruption have been indicted on weapons and hostage-taking charges.

title: Deducting Job Expenses Harder but Still Possible
description: Writing off the cost of a leisurely lunch at the Four Seasons in Manhattan or a night on the town as a business expense is still possible under the new tax law. So is the cost of hunting for a new job, going to night school or traveling to a midwinter convention in balmy Palm Beach, Fla. - provided a good business connection can be shown.

title: Complaint Filed
description: Mike Cingiser, the Brown University basketball coach, faces arraignment in California on Feb. 23 on charges of disorderly conduct and of assaulting a fan who heckled his team in December.

title: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it restated the year-ago 6-month results for a change in accounting to recognize an accrual for retiree health-care costs; the restatement reduced previously reported net by $425,000.

title: GIRLS, AT 7, THINK THIN, STUDY FINDS
description: Girls come to believe that thin is beautiful as early as age 7 or even younger, according to a new report linking that attitude to a rising incidence of eating disorders in young girls.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the theft of art from a Manhattan gallery gave an incorrect first name for the commander of a police squad investigating the theft. He is Capt. Joseph M. Greeley.

title: Terra Cotta On Exhibit And as Part Of the City
description: TERRA cotta, the fireproof and durable baked clay material that has ornamented many of New York's most famous facades, is making a comeback. No longer restricted to gargoyles and Art Deco swirls, it has captured the interest of contemporary urban artists and architects, who see it as a pliable, practical building material that can still respond to an artist's imagination.

title: John B. Madden, 69; Led Brown Bros. Firm
description: John Beckwith Madden, a general partner in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 69 years old and also lived in Christmas Cove, Me.

title: WOLVERINE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $698,000, or 19 cents a share, for a change to the LIFO method of accounting from FIFO. c-Includes a net gain of $680,000, or 20 cents a share, from the sale of the company's idle Lincoln Park, Mich. facility.

title: On to Royalty Filly Winner
description: On to Royalty stamped herself as Florida's leading 3-year-old filly with a 1 1/2-length victory over Social Pro in the $61,700 Forward Gal Stakes today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Meese Postpones Announcement On Closing P.L.O.'s U.N. Mission
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, who was expected to announce today that he would order the closing of the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission to the United Nations next month, postponed the announcement this afternoon.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $45 million special gain and earnings were impaired by about $50 million as a result of a strike. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Oh, to Be a Child Again
description: WHEN it comes to being fashionable, children are at a definite advantage.

title: Waldheim Telegram Called Fake
description: The Yugoslav press agency reported today that a document said to link President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to Nazi war crimes was a fake and that a forgery investigation was under way.

title: PROFIT SCOREBOARD

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Weyerhaeuser Picks Successor to President
description: LEAD: The Weyerhaeuser Company of Tacoma, Wash., said John W. Creighton Jr., an executive vice president, would succeed George H. Weyerhaeuser as president. Mr. Weyerhaeuser will continue as chief executive and succeed Robert B. Wilson as chairman, becoming the first person to hold both jobs at once.

title: Metro Matters; When a Student Is Counted As 94% of One
description: Two centuries ago, framers of the United States Constitution devised an ingenious formula to skirt the slavery issue. They cryptically declared that representation and direct taxation shall be apportioned among the states by adding to the total number of free persons ''three fifths of all other persons.''

title: Gephardt Grasped The No. 1 Issue
description: The last two Presidential elections have been fought over the issue of which party was better equipped to arrest the decline of America. In 1980, Ronald Reagan promised voters to restore America's ''place in the sun.'' In 1984, he claimed that ''America is back.'' In 1988, the worry about decline continues to plague voters; however, it is no longer focused on military comparisons with the Soviet Union or the memory of American humiliation in Iran but rather on a falling living standard and rising trade deficit.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Budget Cuts? 'Not in My District!'
description: It was bound to happen.

title: CHRISTIANA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the substantial decline in revenue resulted from the previously reported sellout of its condominium projects.

title: WPP in Deal For Anspach
description: WPP Group P.L.C., a London-based marketing firm that owns J. Walter Thompson, said it had acquired Anspach Grossman Portugal, a corporate-identity consultant with offices in New York and San Francisco. The British firm has agreed to pay up to $36 million in cash for the firm, whose major clients include American Express, Citicorp, Hewlett-Packard, Quaker Oats, Sara Lee, Texaco and Unisys.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Toughening the Marines
description: Gen. Alfred M. Gray, the new Commandant of the Marine Corps who is seeking to restore certain tough traditions among his troops, has ordered a change in the name of marine units that are poised aboard ships to intervene in foreign nations. They have dropped the word ''amphibious'' in favor of ''expeditionary.''

title: New Opera Seasons Announced
description: New York's two major opera companies announced their new seasons yesterday. The Metropolitan Opera will present five new productions in an extended 32-week 1988-89 season, one of them a double bill, as well as three complete cycles of its new production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.''

title: British Court Refuses 'Spycatcher' Press Ban
description: The British Government lost another round today in its 20-month effort to ban publication of ''Spycatcher,'' the memoirs of a former British counter-intelligence officer, which the Government calls a threat to national security.

title: CLAIRSON INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: Year-ago net income and share earnings are pro forma, presented as if the company had accrued an income tax liability prior to its initial public offering in November 1986 and the termination of its S-Corporation status.

title: GNI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $76,070 for the quarter and $138,562 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Malaysia Stops Traders
description: Malaysia closed 16 commodity firms today and said it was investigating them for suspected illegal trading on overseas exchanges, a senior official said. Malaysia's Commodities Trading Commission said the 16 had been trading on a number of overseas exchanges but had not been registered. The firms' premises were raided by the authorities early this morning.

title: News Agency Defiance May Change How Medical Findings Are Reported
description: In a move that could dramatically change the way medical news is reported, Reuters will no longer feel bound to observe restrictions on when it can report material from The New England Journal of Medicine, according to the head of the British news agency's operation in this country.

title: French in Societe Generale Accord
description: The group of Belgian stockholders headed by Andre Leysen of Geveart N.V. and a French group headed by Compagnie Financiere de Suez signed an agreement tonight to collaborate in shaping the future of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest concern.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (TENN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings are not available for the year-ago periods; the company went public in April 1987.

title: INSIDE
description: Ginsburg-TV Probe Dropped

title: Options Customers Will Get $1 Million In an Amex Refund
description: In an unusual effort to calm investors' fears about the options market, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday that as much as $1 million would be refunded to some customers who traded stock index options on Oct. 20.

title: Long Live the King
description: ''Judicial activism'' is a term of special abuse in modern conservative rhetoric. Judges who protect individual liberty in constitutional cases are accused of distorting history, disrespecting elected legislators and ignoring the practical needs of government.

title: 2 Senate Democrats End Threat to Delay Pact
description: Two Senate Democratic leaders announced today that they were dropping their threat to delay hearings on the new missile treaty with the Soviet Union after receiving a letter from Secretary of State George P. Shultz addressing their concerns about how treaties are made and interpreted.

title: Topics of The Times; Good Deal for a School
description: It's not often that the chance to help a New York City school combines with a commercial real estate development at no cost to taxpayers.

title: MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEMPEST TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEKELEC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1987 year include a $381,000 charge from the discontinuance of two product lines.

title: Hers
description: ''KILL her!'' the audience howls as Anne Archer pulls the trigger on Glenn Close in the movie ''Fatal Attraction.'' I would like to unclench my fist and join the ecstatic applause. If only life were so clear cut.

title: CUBAN DISCUSSES DECISION ON SEOUL
description: Cuba decided two years ago not to attend the Seoul Olympics if some events were not staged in North Korea, the president of the Cuban Olympic committee said today.

title: Piano Recitalist Replaced
description: Roy Kogan, who won an international piano competition sponsored by the American Music Scholarship Association, will not appear at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening because of an injury to his hand. Mr. Kogan won the gold medal at the 1986 piano competition and was to have made his Lincoln Center debut as part of his award. Appearing at 8 P.M. in place of Mr. Kogan will be Bruce Brubaker, who won the silver medal at the same competition. Mr. Brubaker is to play works by Roger Sessions, Haydn, Schoenberg and Schumann. Tickets are $6, $8 and $10. Information: 362-1911.

title: AMERICAN CAPACITY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $93,383.

title: Slave's Daughter, 104
description: Daisy Turner, the daughter of a slave who ran away from a plantation and moved to Vermont after the Civil War, died Monday. She was 104 years old.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Tomorrow is Lincoln's Birthday; Washington's Birthday is observed Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Monday, begins 9:15 A.M. at 35th St. and heads north on 5th Ave. to St. Patrick's Cathedral. Parking: Alternate-side rules are suspended tomorrow and Monday. Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping either day. Government offices: Federal and state offices are open and city offices are closed tomorrow; all are closed Monday. Post offices: Open tomorrow; closed Monday, except for special delivery and Express-Mail delivery. Banks: State-chartered banks have the option to close and federally chartered banks are open Friday; all banks have the option to close Monday. Financial markets: Open tomorrow; closed Monday. Transportation: Tomorrow, subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on weekday schedule; on Monday, subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule. Schools: Option to close tomorrow and Monday; New York City schools closed both days. Libraries: New York Public, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed tomorrow and Monday. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices are open and state and city offices are closed tomorrow; all are closed Monday. Post offices: Open tomorrow; closed Monday, except for special delivery and Express-Mail delivery. Banks: Option to close tomorrow and Monday. Transportation: Tomorrow, N.J. Transit on weekday schedule; Monday, N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no rail service on Montclair Branch, Boonton and Pascack Valley lines. Schools: Option to close tomorrow and Monday. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices are open and state and city offices are closed tomorrow; all are closed Monday. Post offices: Open tomorrow; closed Monday, except for special delivery and Express-Mail delivery. Banks: Closed tomorrow and Monday. Transportation: New Haven line on weekday schedule tomorrow and holiday schedule Monday. Schools: Closed tomorrow and Monday.

title: Jazz: Bill Frisell Quartet
description: BILL FRISELL'S music dances on quicksand. Nothing is solid or dependable; his guitar notes slide off the beat, his tone mutates from glassy clarity to echoes and noisy distortion. His better pieces are equally unstable; they start out as country tunes or boppish jazz lines, only to add extra beats or dissolve to new tempos partway through. For listeners, navigating such shifty material demands that the performers convey a secure sense of direction, but in Tuesday's first set, opening a five-night stand at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street, Mr. Frisell's quartet was not entirely sure-footed.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on investments of $1,769,000 and $8,354,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes gains on investments of $1,437,000 for the quarter and $5,775,000 for the year.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Up a Half-Point
description: Treasury bond prices rose about a half-point yesterday, while interest rates were little changed on short-term bills.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Wind Chill Wins: Wind Chill fought off an early challenge by Derby Wish and drew away through the stretch to score a 6 1/2-length victory in the $47,000 allowance feature yesterday at Aqueduct. Ridden by Chris Antley, Wind Chill carried 115 pounds over 1 mile 70 yards on the fast track in 1:44 3/5 to earn $28,200 for his owner, Topofthepines Farm. Badwagon Harry was the runner-up. The victory was the 10th in 36 career starts for the Michigan-bred 5-year-old horse. He paid $4.60 for $2 to win. Jose Santos rode five winners in the first six races. Tennis Connors and Edberg Advance: Jimmy Connors and top-seeded Stefan Edberg scored opening-round victories in a tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Fifth-seeded Henri Leconte was upset in a second-round match by Christian Saceanu of West Germany, 6-4, 6-2. Connors, seeded second, defeated Jaro Navratil of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-2, and Edberg beat a fellow Swede, Frode Waern, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) High School Basketball 79 Points for Guard: Finnel White of Lowcountry Academy scored 79 points, including a game-winning, 3-point shot in a 90-89 victory Tuesday over Andrews Academy in Leston, S.C. White, averaging more than 55 points a game, was the only starter in the lineup for much of the game. Two starters fouled out in the first half, a third -a girl - was sidelined by the flu. The other usual starter missed the team bus and did not arrive until two minutes remained in the game.(AP)

title: Itinerant Painter Only Does Ceilings
description: THE itinerant ceiling painter Larry Boyce has arrived in New York City after clocking 8,600 miles across the Canadian Rockies on his bicycle. Mr. Boyce may be identified by his zebra-striped tights and his tendency to color-coordinate his clothes with his ceilings.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIKONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $2,000 and $123,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $11,314,000.

title: At The Post, An Obituary Is Drafted
description: Jerry Tallmer was searching, just as he does when he writes, for the right words. He was silent a moment, tried to recall the precise quote, went to look it up and then wrote it out on a slip of paper, complete with punctuation and citation:

title: CASTLE ENERGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $1,672,319 from the settlement of debt. Prior year results aren't available due to the company's switch to a fiscal year ended Sept. 30 from a calendar year.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest periods' results include those of Screen Graphics Inc., which was acquired in October.

title: U.S. Will Investigate Black Man's Killing By 2 White Officers
description: The United States Justice Department said yesterday it would investigate a Queens case to see if two white police officers violated the civil rights of a black man they fatally shot when, according to the police, he lunged at one of the officers with a knife.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELECHARGE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ABUSES OF RIGHTS DECLINE IN SOVIET
description: The State Department said today that human rights abuses had eased somewhat in the Soviet Union in the last year despite continued violations that remained a central concern to the United States.

title: Foundations Contributing To Neediest
description: On behalf of the Ernst Foundation of Manhattan, a trustee, Howard Ernst, sent a gift of $250 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with the request that it be used to aid the homeless.

title: Robert L. Turner, Concert Hall Manager, 50
description: Robert L. Turner, general manager of Avery Fisher Hall and Alice Tully Hall, died on Monday. He was 50 years old.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $515,000 gain from a change in accounting for income taxes for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: A Dazzling Light Show Animates a Bridge
description: THE most visible decorations along the approach to the Benjamin Franklin Bridge used to be gaudy casino billboards. But since last fall, Philadelphians and New Jerseyans have been treated to an animated light show on the bridge, which runs nearly three-quarters of a mile over the Delaware River and is the link between Philadelphia and Camden, N.J.

title: Can the Good Petain Be Rescued From the Bad?
description: In the gloomy chamber where the town council convenes, Mayor Jacques Barat-Dupont pointed a stubby finger at the slab bearing the names of Verdun's citizens of honor. In freshly carved wooden letters stood a surname that stirs pride and shame in France: ''General Petain, victor of Verdun.''

title: DATAREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERSPEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $235,000 for the quarter and $1,111,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $147,000 for the quarter and $227,000 for the year.

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,885,000, a pre-tax charge of $3.1 million, or $2.2 million after taxes, from the adoption of the LIFO method of determining cost for a substantial portion of its domestic inventories for the quarter; extraordinary gains of $137,505,000, primarily representing $97.1 million in net gains from the tender of Borg-Warner shares and $39.5 million in after-tax gains relating to an investment in Union Carbide Corp., a pre-tax charge of $5. million, or $3.6 million after taxes, from the adoption of the LIFO method of determining costs for a substantial portion of its domestic inventories, for the year. c-After extraordinary gains of $30.5 million for the quarter and $212,475,000 for the year, from GAF's investment in Union Carbide's common stock; the year also included tax credits of $11.1 million.

title: Piano: Emanuel Krasovsky
description: EMANUEL KRASOVSKY drew a select and musical audience to his performance at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening, and it was immediately easy to hear why; the Lithuanian-born Israeli pianist has a command of the keyboard and a substance to his musical thinking that compel attention. He began with Beethoven (Op. 27, No. 1), distinguished by easy control of dynamics - especially in well-balanced soft playing, a difficult feat in this hall - and strong independence of fingers. He is able to take fast tempos with minimal reliance on the pedal to run things together.

title: Philharmonic Planning Its First 'Voix Humaine'
description: Francis Poulenc's ''Voix Humaine,'' an opera for solo soprano, will be presented by the New York Philharmonic for the first time at 8 P.M. next Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Buckling Up The Young
description: Kermit the Frog hopped up to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to join lawmakers and safety advocates in the observance of this week as National Child Passenger Safety Awareness Week. The week is intended to call attention to the need for adults to buckle children properly into safety seats in automobiles.

title: NORTHWEST ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company acquired Terex Corp. and Koehring Cranes & Excavators Inc. on Dec. 31, 1986, and Jan. 16, 1987, respectively. It acquired Terex Equipment Ltd. of Scotland on June 30, 1987.

title: Temple Vandal Sentenced
description: The son of a Russian Orthodox priest was sentenced today to five years probation for spray-painting swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans on a synagogue, Temple Beth Shalom, in Mahopac last November. The youth, Andrei Federoff, 17 years old, of Mahopac, was also ordered to pay damages, get counseling and do community service. The youth, who was arrested wearing a makeshift Nazi uniform, admitted to several earlier attacks on the synagogue.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Wurlitzer said its previously announced agreement to sell its keyboard operations is proceeding, and if completed, the company anticipates the transaction will close in late February.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27

title: Enter the Villain: Museum Marks Soviet Shift
description: Fifty years after the opening of the Central Lenin Museum, the sanctum sanctorum of this city's Communist memorials, the arch heretic of the Bolshevik Revolution has been admitted.

title: Gore Asks U.S. for Ruling On Foes' Spending for TV
description: Questioning the practices of two rivals, Senator Albert Gore Jr.'s Presidential campaign today asked the Federal Election Commission to rule on the legitimacy of skirting state spending limits by counting television advertisements as fund-raising expenses.

title: Metromedia Chief Raises Orion Stake
description: John W. Kluge, chairman and president of the Metromedia Company, has once again raised his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kluge said that he had increased his Orion stake to 25.6 percent, from 24 percent, through open market purchases of 283,000 Orion shares between Jan. 29 and Feb. 8, for prices ranging from $13.87 to $16 a share. The stock closed today at $17.75, up 62.5 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: A Furnished Apartment Is a Start for a Homeless Family
description: ''IT looks like we went out and bought the furniture,'' said Edwin DeLeon, still in shock six weeks after opening the door to his new apartment and finding it furnished like a Seaman's showroom. ''It was exactly what we had in mind.''

title: Kuwait B.P. Stake
description: The Kuwait Investment Office announced it had further increased its stake in the British Petroleum Company to 19.27 percent from 19.24 percent. The London-based investment arm of the Kuwaiti Government said it had bought another two million partly paid shares on Tuesday. It did not disclose the purchase price.

title: Critic's Notebook; Decrescendo in the Concert Business
description: THE troubles suffered recently by the Nashville Symphony, which was forced by financial problems to stop performing, come as the latest in an ominous series of setbacks for orchestras around the country. In the past several months, ensembles in New Orleans, San Diego, Vancouver, Denver, Detroit, Oakland, Calif., and elsewhere have been disbanded, gone on strike over wage cuts or accepted reduced salaries or shortened schedules. At the same time, recital series, once a flourishing part of the music scene, have been abandoned or scaled back drastically all across the country.

title: DECLINE PREDICTED FOR MAIL SERVICE IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Mail service in New York City is likely to deteriorate because of a ''crazy'' Government mandate to reduce spending on operations and mail-processing plants, John M. Nolan, postmaster of the New York division of the Postal Service, said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1988
description: International

title: Manhattan Board Rejects Salant Bid
description: Manhattan Industries said that its board had rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from the Salant Corporation. The apparel maker characterized the $16-a-share offer as inadequate and not in the best interests of its shareholders. Officials at Salant, also an apparel company, said they had no official comment on the rejection. But one of the company's financial advisers, Michael A. Lubin, said, ''We continue to be willing to negotiate any and all aspects of our offer.''

title: Israelis Furious Over an Arab Plan to Sail 'Home'
description: Furious Israeli officials vowed today that they would not allow a ship carrying Palestinian deportees to dock in Israel.

title: CORKEN INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split effective Oct. 15.

title: Cello: Christopher Costanza
description: CHRISTOPHER COSTANZA is an excellent young cellist with fleet fingers and an unflinching, deep-in-the-strings way of producing sound. The 23-year-old musician, a student at the New England Conservatory in Boston, made his New York debut at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening as part of the Young Concert Artists Series. His program included works by Francoise Francoeur, Chopin, Hindemith, Debussy, Glazunov and Gaspart Cassado - works that provided ample opportunity for Mr. Costanza to mold fluid, singing lines and toss off brisk, highly detailed passagework.

title: Nofziger Jury Starts Debate on Whether He Broke Ethics Law
description: A jury began deliberations today in the Federal ethics trial of Lyn Nofziger, the former White House political director who is accused of unlawfully lobbying on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation and other private clients in 1982.

title: CONVERGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,755,000 and $2,203,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $3,861,000 on disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. The company said the results for 1987 are after substantial costs associated with the start-up of the company's Convergent Business Systems subsidiary and a $12 million adjustment in the fourth quarter to certain intangible assets.

title: EL POLLO ASADO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Net income

title: New Look For Urban Newsstands
description: HELP may be on the way for the New York City newsstand, which has come to resemble ''a gigantic coat hanger for every conceivable object,'' in the words of Bartholomew Voorsanger, a vice president of the New York City chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

title: G.A.O. Urges Caution on a Glass-Steagall Repeal
description: The General Accounting Office has recommended that Congress take a go-slow approach should it decide to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, which separates banking from securities underwriting.

title: Mark D. Soroko, Corporate Executive, 87
description: Mark D. Soroko, a retired senior vice president and board member of Revlon Inc., died of heart failure Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami. He was 87 years old and lived in Bal Harbor, Fla.

title: Parent & child
description: ALL parents will, at some point, object to something that is happening to their children at school. If the problem is clear-cut, as when a teacher hits a child or writes scathing personal comments on his papers, we act without hesitation to insure his safety and correct the problem. The response is automatic.

title: South Africa Quells Coup Attempt in a Homeland
description: The South African Government sent troops into a nominally independent black homeland today and reinstated its leader 15 hours after he was ousted in a military coup.

title: DIXIE YARNS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Savings Unit Deposits
description: Deposits at the nation's savings institutions increased in December for the third consecutive month, continuing a trend that began after the October stock plunge, the Government said Tuesday. Net deposits rose by $2.4 billion in December, after gains of $3.2 billion in November and $6.2 billion in October, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. Withdrawals had exceeded deposits in seven of the first nine months of the year.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Commuter Plane Crashes
description: A commuter plane on a training flight crashed near Springfield Municipal Airport on Tuesday, killing three people, the State Highway Patrol said. Officials said the Piedmont Airlines plane was practicing takeoffs and landings at the airport when it crashed about 3 P.M.

title: Fight Canceled
description: The International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight title fight between Charles Williams of Grand Rapids, Mich., the champion, and Tom Collins of Britain, scheduled for Feb. 20 in Windsor, England, was canceled yesterday.

title: The Doughnut On Rose's Bat
description: ''A new fielder's glove has arrived from Sears and with it the early morning sound of a ball rolling off the barn roof and landing back up there again with a sharp plunk. . . . It has been an early spring. . . .''

title: Hospitals Expanding Procedures to Assist Patients for Discharge
description: Where do patients go after being discharged from hospitals and what services will they need while they recuperate?

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Working Profile: David E. Price; Professor in Congress Is Doing Homework On Theory and Reality
description: For 17 years, David E. Price taught political science. His specialty was Congress, his subspecialty the Congressional committee system.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the Iowa caucuses misstated the percentage of Republican voters for Pat Robertson who said in a New York Times/CBS News Poll that one reason for their support was that they did not like any of the other candidates. It was 5 percent, not almost half.

title: T.W.A. Nominates 5 to Texaco Board
description: Trans World Airlines Inc., which is controlled by Carl C. Icahn, said yesterday that it had nominated a slate of candidates to oppose the five Texaco directors up for re-election at the oil company's annual meeting in May.

title: Thompson Aims for Biathlon Medal
description: Josh Thompson says there are certain advantages to being a biathlete.

title: HOMOSEXUAL BAN IN ARMY REJECTED BY APPEALS COURT
description: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco struck down the Army's ban on homosexuals yesterday, ruling that homosexuals are entitled to as much protection against discrimination as members of racial minority groups.

title: John D. Tracy, Biaggi Aide, 88
description: John D. Tracy, the executive assistant to Representative Mario Biaggi, died of a heart attack Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx. He was 88 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,365,000. c-Net income

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $91.4 million for both periods from reorganization plan which became effective Dec. 31, 1987; a $20.5 million charge to provide for further consolidation of operations and other non-recurring items for both periods; $6.8 million and $38.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from a change in accounting for pensions and settlement of pension obligations; a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,644,000 and $32,859,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and for the year also includes a loss from continuing operations of $8,807,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from continuing operations of $6,070,000 for the quarter; the loss from continuing operations for 1986 is after a provision of $30.9 million to reduce the carrying value of certain assets and now after a loss from discontinued operations of $12,777,000 and a charge of $15,695,000 to reduce the carrying value of certain assets from discontinued operations.

title: Group Living
description: To The Home Section:

title: Small Manufacturers Lead Revival
description: A neatly lettered sign sits behind Dick Swennumson's desk at the LDI Manufacturing Company on the outskirts of this gritty old railroad town. ''In the final analysis,'' it proclaims with deceptive simplicity, ''success is measured in profit, not volume.''

title: Houston to Offer Bonds for Airport
description: Houston is offering $85 million in airport senior lien revenue bonds through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for an issue due in 2017.

title: U.S. FINDS 6 STATES FAIL TO MEET GOALS IN DESEGREGATION
description: The Education Department said today that six Southern and border states were still in partial violation of a 17-year-old court order to rid their public colleges of the effects of segregation.

title: Topics of The Times; Housing Bonus for Harlem
description: A proposal by the New York City Planning Commission would rezone Fifth Avenue north of 96th Street to encourage construction of badly needed new housing between 96th and 110th Streets. The plan deserves the Board of Estimate's support.

title: BAKER FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: New York State Sets Bond Sale
description: New York State is offering $180 million in general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 7.40 percent for bonds due in 30 years through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Capital Markets.

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a writedown of $23.7 million U.S. oil and gas properties.

title: Comments From Findings on Bias in Colleges
description: The Education Department's finding that six Southern and border states had failed to desegregate their higher education systems included a number of steps that the department said were required to bring the systems into compliance. Following are some of the steps ordered and comments about those state's systems.

title: NETWORK SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNITED SAVINGS & LOAN (SOUTH CAROLINA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company converted to stock ownership in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH resilient floors -asphalt, linoleum, vinyl, rubber, cork - require little maintenance, they are not impervious to damage. Flooring that is stained, scratched, blistered or torn can be repaired.

title: Palestinians Are Using the News Organizations; Jewish Self-Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $49.6 million for the quarter and $135.5 million for the year; gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $179.6 million and $181.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses on the extinguishment of debt of $100,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $57.6 million and $129.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively; gains on disposal of discontinued operations of $187.7 million for the quarter and $185.6 million for the year, and losses on extinguishment of debt of $2.3 million and $14.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Prior year net is restated for the disposal of the company's magazines and recorded music operations. The company said on Jan. 5, the business and assets of CBS Records were sold, and its operations are treated as discontinued in 1987, with the gain on the sale to be reported in the first quarter of 1988.

title: Italy's Government Falls After Budget Defeats
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned today after six months as head of Italy's 47th postwar Government, a coalition battered by political infighting and a hostile Parliament.

title: Music: Vox Nova Woodwind Quintet
description: EXCEPT for a concert opener by Franz Danzi, the Vox Nova woodwind quintet concerned itself exclusively with the 20th century - and primarily with the last decade - at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon. One work, Judith Lang Zaimont's ''When Angels Speak,'' was heard for the first time; another, ''Isonova'' by Louis Calabro, had its first New York performance.

title: Books of The Times
description: WIND STAR. The Building of a Sailship.

title: DUKAKIS MOUNTS 2-FRONT OFFENSIVE
description: The campaign of Michael S. Dukakis is achingly aware of the stakes in New Hampshire. Asked today whether his Presidential bid could survive a loss in next Tuesday's primary here, Mr. Dukakis's reply was a single word: ''No.''

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 310
description: The company said latest year includes a charge of 23 cents a share resulting from an order of the Missouri Public Service Commission. Prior year results are restated to reflect a new accounting standard.

title: Chaya Schneerson, Wife of the Leader Of the Lubavitchers
description: Chaya Moussia Schneerson, the wife of Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, the Lubavitcher Rebbe, died early yesterday at New York Hospital. She was taken to the hospital Tuesday night complaining about feeling ill. She was 86 years old and lived in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn.

title: Shultz Rebuts Asian Official
description: An Asian official's public attack on a recent United States trade decision sparked a face-to-face confrontation rarely seen in a diplomatic setting and a toughly worded lecture today from Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: NFS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Olympic Notebook; Good Start for Zurbriggen
description: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, the favorite, recorded the fastest time today in the first men's downhill training run for the XV Olympic Winter Games. Competition in Alpine skiing will start Sunday with the men's downhill.

title: INTREX FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $3,312,000 for the quarter and $7,574,000 for the year, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $7,099,000 for the both periods. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $9,000 for the both periods. There were no share earnings for 1986 because the company converted to stock form of ownership in May 1986.

title: Jazz: Shearing Trio
description: SINCE George Shearing gave up playing with a quintet 10 years ago, he has been performing in a duo with a bassist. However, as part of his annual three-month stand in the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, he has enlarged his group to a trio for the month of February.

title: A Purged Chinese Intellectual Derides Talk of Liberalization
description: China's most prominent dissident intellectual, breaking an imposed silence, today assailed harsh political controls on university students and teachers.

title: Who Won, if at All?
description: As returns flowed in from the Iowa caucuses, I was privileged to sit before a television set with Dr. I. F. Attall, the incumbent holder of the Literary Digest Chair of Current and Near-Term Anthropology at Nostradamus University. Dr. Attall had agreed to share his interpretation of the returns exclusively with readers of this column, after first measuring them at 1.201 percent of registered Republicans who say they will take part in the South Carolina caucuses on March 5, if it doesn't rain that day.

title: Israeli Doves Call for End Of Occupation
description: A growing minority of Israelis, including some well-known artists and writers, are reacting to the harsh measures being used to quell the Palestinian protests by calling for an end to the Israeli military occupation.

title: Repeal the P.L.O. Shutdown Law
description: The law ordering the closing of the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission at the United Nations affronts American traditions and violates U.S. obligations as host to the U.N. Unless Congress reverses itself, this law, already a profound embarrassment, could produce an adverse judgment in the World Court.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1988
description: International A3-15

title: VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $2,398,000, or 89 cents a share, in net non-recurring gains recorded in the third quarter.

title: Otto Nuttli, Seismologist, 61
description: Otto Nuttli, an earthquake expert and professor of geophysics at St. Louis University, died Tuesday of cancer at the age of 61.

title: Bid for Control Looms At American Standard
description: The Black & Decker Corporation, rebuffed on its $2.1 billion bid for American Standard Inc., said yesterday that it would turn to stockholders to gain control of the big plumbing supplier.

title: Merrill Lynch Official Joins Savings Institution
description: Gary Lieberman, executive vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc., has left the firm to become chairman and chief executive of a new merchant banking unit of Franklin Savings Association of Ottawa, Kan.

title: GINSBURG INQUIRY FINDS NO VIOLATION
description: The Justice Department has decided not to seek a special prosecutor to review conflict-of-interest allegations against Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, a department official said today.

title: Contras to Resume Cease-Fire Negotiations
description: A Nicaraguan rebel leader said today that the contras would resume cease-fire negotiations with the Sandinistas in Guatemala next week.

title: 80 Reported Slain as Bangladesh Votes
description: Supporters of rival candidates in local elections battled each other with rocks, guns and homemade bombs today, and 80 people were reported killed and hundreds wounded across the country.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Camp socks, Chain Store Age Executive magazine and the Victrex line of ICI Advanced Materials to Baron & Zaretsky.

title: A Shift in Third World Funds' Flow
description: The world's poorest and most indebted countries are beginning to get less in combined aid each year from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund than they are paying in interest and principal on outstanding debt to the two organizations, an analysis has disclosed.

title: Q&A
description: Q.We put down new carpet in our entrance hall with a thick pad beneath it. The bottom of the front door had to be trimmed slightly to clear the carpet, and now on windy days we get cold drafts under the door. I can't put regular weatherstripping along the bottom of the door because it won't clear the carpet. Can you suggest a solution?

title: Man Gets Prison Term in Bid To Send Metals to Pakistan
description: A man convicted of trying to export to Pakistan special metals used in making nuclear bombs was sentenced today to five years in prison.

title: Question Raised As to the Father Of an Asian Girl
description: The touching story of a veteran who saw the photograph of a young Vietnamese girl in a magazine and thereby found the long-lost daughter he fathered in the war has taken an unexpected turn: The girl he brought back to California may not be his child.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Laws that limit the acceptable focus of one's sexual desires to members of the opposite sex, like laws that limit one's choice of spouse (or sexual partner) to members of the same race, cannot withstand constitutional scrutiny absent a compelling governmental justification.'' - Federal Judge William Norris, in a decision overturning the Army's ban on homosexuals.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $250 million for the quarter; the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $86 million. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $46 million for both periods, and the quarter includes income from discontinued operations of $13 million. d-Net income

title: Michael Feinstein's Blue Heaven
description: THE very first night Michael Feinstein spent in the first home he has ever owned - the time was early January; the place, Hollywood -the 31-year-old singer-pianist went to bed thinking: ''I'm a grown-up now! Oh, my God, isn't this wonderful?''

title: On Exhibit: A Lamp Called Sardine
description: ''IT is meant to look like a cat ate it,'' said Tucker Viemeister, the designer, along with Lisa Krohn, of a lamp called Sardine that is being shown at the ''Furniture and Counter-Parts'' exhibit at Gallery 91 in Manhattan.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Labor Dept. Child-Care Study Misleads Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Deals; The Hostile Bid Reaches Europe
description: IT can now be said that the hostile bid has arrived in Europe - and in a big way. Hostile has certainly become the right word since Carlo de Benedetti stirred so much antagonism with his bid to take control of Societe Generale de Belgique. He has encountered a hostile management, hostile Government, hostile press and hostile citizenry.

title: Work-Spend Ethic
description: To The Home Section:

title: CBS Net Up 12.8% In Quarter
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 12.8 percent, buoyed by cost-cutting efforts and by strong results at its television and radio stations.

title: Palestinians Are Using the News Organizations; Not Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Criticizes Judge In Howard BeachCase
description: The mother of a white teen-ager sentenced to 10 to 30 years for manslaughter and assault in the Howard Beach case charged yesterday that the judge had ''basically acted as a prosecutor'' and had ''set out'' to have her son and two other teen-agers convicted in the racially volatile case.

title: The Modern Picks Scholar as Pivotal Curator
description: In a long-expected move but one attended by staff controversy, the Museum of Modern Art has named Kirk Varnedoe, a professor at New York University's Institute of Fine Art, to the powerful post of director of painting and sculpture.

The company said the extraordinary losses resulted from the demolition of a company-owned building caused by an earthquake on Oct.1, 1987.

Sharp Associates Ltd. have been accounted for on an acquisition basis.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CFM International, a company jointly owned by General Electric Co. and Snecma of France, said Lufthansa German Airlines had placed a firm $150 million order for 15 CFM aircraft engines.

title: U.S. Detects Radioactive Leaks at 3 More Plants
description: Federal officials said today that they had found three more plants where a widely used industrial device leaked tiny particles of radioactive polonium, but added, ''So far we've seen nothing that would pose a threat to public health.''

title: New Chairman At Rockwell
description: As expected, the Rockwell International Corporation today named Donald R. Beall, who is 49 years old, chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Robert Anderson, 67, who has served as chairman of the aerospace giant since 1979 and announced plans to resign in October.

title: Auto Pricing And Politics
description: One of the hottest political questions in Washington is how much a $10,000 Chrysler car exported from the United States sells for in South Korea. The answer, according to

title: Talks on Dana Unit
description: Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., a privately held manufacturer of electrical appliances and auto parts, said that it was negotiating the acquisition of the Racine Hydraulics division from the Dana Corporation, based in Toledo, Ohio. The German company said in a statement that its Robert Bosch Corporation unit in Broadview, Ill., was holding talks with Dana representatives. Racine produces pumps and ventilators for stationary and mobile hydraulics. The purchase of the unit would enable Bosch to expand its activities in the lucrative American hydraulics market, Bosch said.

title: AMISTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Stage: 'Loose Ends'
description: MORE than most of his theatrical peers, Michael Weller writes plays that could serve as time capsules of their period. His first full-length work, ''Moonchildren,'' summarizes the 1960's through the perspective of a crucial academic year. ''Loose Ends,'' a play with broader scope, focuses on the 1970's - post-hippie, pre-yuppie, a time of searching and changing identities. The failed idealism of the previous decade is replaced by a kind of extended ennui, experimentation by fragmentation.

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,060,000 for the quarter and year, and extraordinary losses of $3,178,000 and $6,636,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income

description: b-Includes an after-tax network reconfiguration charge of $4,081,000 for the quarter; the year includes a credit of $5,733,000 from an accounting change.

title: More Arena Football
description: After averaging 11,400 fans for 13 games during 1987, the Arena Football League will resume competition on April 29.

title: Brass in Myriad Forms
description: ''IT'S organized chaos here,'' said Carole Benson, who with her husband, Gerry, runs the Ben Karpen Brass Corporation in Manhattan.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $403,173.

title: Graphic Design Out of a Utopian Past
description: THESE are some of the things Tibor Kalman, a founder of the New York graphic design firm M & Co., finds ''endlessly inspiring'':

title: Runaways Of the 80's: Victims Of Abuse
description: Runaways in the 1980's bear little resemblance to 1960's youths who trekked cross-country with a sense of adventure, according to a survey by a youth-services organization.

title: Ferrer Emerges as Strong Voice for Bronx
description: Shortly after he became Borough President of the Bronx last spring, Fernando Ferrer made room in a corner of his office for a large, hand-lettered placard that somebody had displayed at a rally. ''Recall Koch -Ferrer for Mayor,'' it read.

title: Beyond Needles: the AIDS War
description: Imagine Sam, a heroin addict: His habit is up to $100 a day - he's dropped out of community college and started stealing cars full time. But that's the least of it. Now his girlfriend has begun to hassle him about AIDS. She's plainly terrified that he might get the disease from one of the junkies with whom he shoots up, passing needles around. Suddenly Sam realizes he ought to be terrified, too.

title: Museum Show Honors 25 Years of Channel 13
description: The Museum of Broadcasting at 1 East 53d Street will mark the 25th anniversary of WNET starting tomorrow, with a three-month survey of distinguished programs that have been seen on the public television station since its inception.

title: Inquiries Confirm That Goldin Is Off All Hooks
description: To the Editor:

title: REGULATORS SHIFT FINANCIAL CORP. STRATEGY
description: Federal regulators, indicating a significant shift in their strategy for solving the problems of the ailing Financial Corporation of America, have decided to begin selling the savings and loan company's $17 billion portfolio of mortgage-backed securities.

title: Workshop Opens Doors In Directing for Women
description: For 10 years Randa Haines worked as a script supervisor on other people's movies - all of them directed by men. Then she heard about Directing Workshop for Women, sponsored by the American Film Institute. She applied, was accepted, directed her own project for the workshop and began a new career, going on to win an Academy Award nomination as best director for ''Children of a Lesser God.''

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,359,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax benefit of $12,912,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,050,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net loss The latest quarter operating net included a pre-tax charge of $1.6 million from the writedown of securities. The latest year results also include a net gain of $44.6 million from the sale of an investment and a pre-tax charge of $1.6 million from the writedown of securities.

title: William E. Woodman, Insurance Executive, 68
description: William E. Woodman, a retired insurance executive, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 68 years old and also lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: First Issue of Sassy Due Out Next Week
description: The premier issue of Sassy, a magazine for teen-age girls, is scheduled to hit newsstands on Tuesday. An issue will cost $2, with a yearly subscription $13.98.

title: DIAGNOSTIC MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $31,000.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Lone Sailor Is Not Alone
description: The United States Navy memorial on Pennsylvania Avenue was inaugurated last October in a ceremony that evoked the nation's maritime heroics with its statue of the Lone Sailor on the edge of an outdoor amphitheater. But there was also a relatively unsung international aspect to the project.

title: Walsh Hires Counsel In Iran Case Challenges
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, in another sign that he would seek criminal charges in the case, said today that he had hired a former Federal judge to oversee legal challenges to the investigation.

title: Art Gallery Raid Involved Daring Acrobatics
description: The thieves who took $6 million in paintings and drawings from a New York City art gallery this week carried out ''a very daring raid,'' lowering themselves from a skylight in an acrobatic rope manuever in which one slip could have sent them plunging down a four-story stairwell, a top police investigator said yesterday.

title: First Executive
description: The First Executive Corporation said that a Delaware state court had refused to halt a tender offer for First Executive shares from the ICH Corporation, an action sought by two shareholders as part of a lawsuit. The suit seeks to overturn a standstill agreement between the Los Angeles-based insurer and ICH, of Louisville, Ky. The suit is not affected by the ruling.

title: Against the Clock
description: Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, the miler who has won all three of his indoor starts this season, is prepared to take a gamble in his specialty Saturday night at the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Bush Does an About-Face After Iowa
description: Vice President Bush is in so much trouble in New Hampshire that he came here to a forum with his opponents tonight that he had repeatedly said he would not attend.

title: Democrat Leaving Congress
description: Representative Ed Jones, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that he would retire from Congress at the end of his term, leaving the seat he has held since 1969. Mr. Jones, who is 75 years old and a ranking member of the Committee on Agriculture, was first elected to fill the unexpired term of Representative Robert A. Everett, who died while in office.

title: Michael Jackson and U2 Share British Awards
description: Michael Jackson, Britain's George Michael and the Irish group U2 have won the British record industry's top 1988 awards.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESORS SBI reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Net income and includes a $199,000 gain from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: BOBSLEDDER REGAINS BACKUP POSITION
description: He received encouraging news from his attorney in Boston this morning and immediately began packing for his trip to the Winter Olympics. Although the issue has not been officially resolved, Donald LaVigne will be rejoining his teammates on the United States bobsled team, fulfilling a goal he set a year ago when he decided to take a year off from Harvard to pursue his Olympic dream.

title: TELEPROBE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $21,000 and $1,221,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax benefit of $94,000 and $133,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said sales for the year-ago second quarter were mainly the result of a contract with its principal customer, which has since been terminated.

description: b-Net loss

title: Alien Footprints on Sydney's Sands
description: Joan McDonald, who has been renting out deck chairs at Bondi beach for more than 50 years, recently added a sun blocking agent to the popular tanning oil she sprays from a hose.

title: 20-Year Note Sale By Pitney Bowes
description: The Pitney Bowes Credit Corporation is offering 8 5/8 percent noncallable notes due in 2008 for 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: RECAP ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $5.8 million tax credit. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: U.A.W. Action Set On Chrysler Unit
description: The United Automobile Workers union said it would oppose the sale of the Chrysler Corporation's Accustar subsidiary and would take action to try to prevent any sale, including seeking a meeting with Chrysler executives and demonstrating in front of Chrysler headquarters.

title: Take a Yes for Afghanistan
description: The United States has been trying for eight years to drive Soviet troops from Afghanistan. On Monday, Mikhail Gorbachev announced that the troops would all be gone by March 1989 if the U.S. keeps its pledge to stop aiding the Afghan rebels. It was an extraordinary statement, hailed by the Reagan Administration as ''a positive step.'' Yet some Administration hard-liners raise new objections. And now, incredibly, they risk unwinding the deal by claiming that the State Department agreed to halt rebel aid without President Reagan's approval.

title: KRUG INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: NASA May Replace 72 Bolts in Nozzles Of Shuttle Boosters
description: The space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc., the rocket manufacturer, are debating whether they must replace 72 bolts inside the nozzle of each space shuttle booster rocket as a safety measure.

title: FLORIDA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $14,211,000 from the prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Syracuse Wins The Showdown
description: A crowd of 16,798 packed the Civic Arena tonight to watch the Big East's two best teams duel in a conference showdown. Pro basketball scouts came in droves to see four of the nation's best big men: Charles Smith and Jerome Lane for Pitt, Rony Seikaly and Derrick Coleman for Syracuse.

title: Market Place; Behind the Slide Of Kodak's Stock
description: THE price action in the Eastman Kodak Company's stock shows how quickly a Wall Street favorite can undergo reappraisal by the investment community.

The company said the 1986 results are presented on a pro forma basis, summarizing the pro forma effect on the company of the sale of shares in its initial public offering, the acquisition of Tire America and the redemption of preferred stock, which occurred in January 1987.

title: Trump Revises Project for West Side
description: In an effort to reduce opposition to his proposed Television City project, Donald J. Trump disclosed a new plan yesterday that would include 760 low-cost apartments for the elderly and increased park space.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $175,000 and $449,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $130,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 6 months.

title: Bridge: Lucky Guesses by Experts May Well Be Results of Skill
description: Many years ago an inexperienced player was heard to complain: ''Those experts are so lucky. They always guess right.''

title: London Board Backs Index Arbitrage as a Market Stabilizer
description: The London stock exchange urged its members today to increase the use of a form of computerized stock trading that has been blamed in the United States for accelerating October's stock market collapse.

title: Remains of 6 Vietnam War Fliers Identified
description: Six sets of remains, including one returned two and a half years ago, have been positively identified as Navy and Air Force fliers missing from the Vietnam War, the Pentagon said Tuesday.

title: Prosperity (for Better and Worse) Spreads in New Hampshire
description: The New Hampshire that the Presidential candidates are barnstorming in 1988 is visibly different from the state their predecessors campaigned in four years ago.

title: 20% of Claims For Medicare Termed Faulty
description: Hospitals inaccurately report one out of five Medicare claims, and most of the discrepancies result in overpayments to the hospitals by the Government, according to a study issued today by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Bill Controlling Campaign Gifts Could Affect 3
description: A substantial majority of the campaign money raised by Mayor Koch and two other officials in 1985 would have been barred under a bill passed by the City Council Tuesday, according to Board of Elections records and politicians familiar with the campaigns.

title: Today's Bathrooms With Yesterday's Elegance
description: OUT of America's fascination with all things antique has grown a market for bygone bathroom styles that is bringing back the pedestal sink, the ornate ceramic toilet and the claw-foot tub.

title: HEALTH IMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year loss included a non- recurring expense of $1,827,325 for exchange of Junior common stock.

title: Ford Shift on Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would not buy the auto assembly plant in Westmoreland County, Pa., that Volkswagen of America plans to close later this year. Ford, which had given notice in November that it might bid for the plant, said it had decided that it had enough production capacity to meet demand for the next few years.

title: Old Images Of Colonial Life in U.S. Revised
description: COLONIAL WILLIAMSBURG is changing. The paint is peeling off the picket fences.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boise Cascade Corp., Boise, Idaho, a forest products company, elected as a director Edson W. Spencer, chairman of Honeywell Inc., Minneapolis.

title: Cuba's Callous War on AIDS
description: LEAD: Cuba has declared war on AIDS, with a campaign to test seven million Cubans - every man, woman and child over the age of 15 - for the disease. In a nation that sent homosexuals to work camps as late as the 1970's, this raises the specter of possible persecution and human rights abuses on an alarming scale.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: MASCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Concert: Quartet From Duke
description: AT the end of the slow movement in Beethoven's ''Harp'' Quartet (Op. 74), there are a series of short, delicate phrases separated by rests - nothing out of the ordinary but the sort of telltale gestures that require from the players a difficult blend of precision and grace. To make this passage really glow, which is what the Ciompi Quartet accomplished on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, it takes more: a genuine warmth of expression and an effortless sense of coordination among the musicians.

title: U.S. Says Schiff Was Mastermind of $40 Million in Fraud Schemes
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that Irwin Schiff, a wealthy businessman who was slain in a Manhattan restaurant last summer, was the mastermind of a series of fraudulent financial transactions believed to total about $40 million.

title: Advertising; A Bonus System for Agencies
description: ADVERTISING agencies and their clients have been talking for years about coming up with a better way of paying agencies for their services. R. J. Reynolds Tobacco U.S.A., the domestic cigarette marketing arm of RJR Nabisco Inc., has developed a system that some of its agencies think is the best solution yet.

title: Assembly Chief Leads Attack on Koch
description: The Speaker of the Assembly, Mel Miller, declaring that Mayor Koch ''has lost all credibility'' in Albany, said today that Assembly Democrats were considering changing the way some state aid to New York City was allocated so the Mayor had less direct control over it.

title: Tilting Skyscrapers
description: To The Home Section:

title: Heritage of Lincoln, the Lawyer
description: Using 20th-century tools - computers, data bases and statistical analysis - the entire legal career of A. Lincoln Esq., scratched down with quill pens in the 19th century, is for the first time being tracked all over the country.

NAC RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Fund Raising is Halted By Conservative Group
description: A political action committee headed by Representative Newt Gingrich has stopped raising money for conservative candidates because it is mired in debt.

description: b-Includes net of $156,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $23,750 and $177,450 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $58,413 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the year also includes a gain on a debenture exchange of $1,394,959.

JOSLYN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Political Marketing; Simon Gears A TV Attack On Gephardt
description: The Presidential campaign of Paul Simon, the homespun Illinois Senator who had rejected negative television advertising in Iowa, said today that it had borrowed $110,000 to begin a television offensive on Thursday against a Democratic rival, Richard A. Gephardt.

description: b-Includes tax credtis of $717,000 for the quarter and $1,193,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and includes losses of $820,000 and $356,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Kurt Adler, Conductor Who Led San Francisco Opera, Dies at 82
description: Kurt Herbert Adler, a Viennese-born conductor who led the San Francisco Opera for 28 years until his retirement in 1981, died of a heart attack Tuesday evening at his home in Ross, Calif., a suburb north of San Francisco. He was 82 years old.

title: Farley Industries Offering $500 Million in Debentures
description: Farley Industries is offering $500 million in speculative-grade debentures, accompanied by warrants entitling holders to buy another $250 million in debentures, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Personal Health
description: ''I've tried liniment and aspirin and my arm still aches. Can you suggest anything else?''

title: Eaton Profits Fall 44.9%
description: The Eaton Corporation, a manufacturer of vehicle components and electronic equipment, said today that it earned $25.8 million, or 97 cents a share, in the final quarter, down 44.9 percent from $46.8 million, or $1.53 a share, in the final three months of 1986. In October, Eaton announced it would sell its military electronics business, and from that point it accounted for that segment's performance as a discontinued operation. Eaton reported revenue of $805.1 million for the latest quarter, up from $700 million. In all of 1987, Eaton earned $201.2 million, or $7.16 a share, up 46.2 percent from $137.6 million, or $4.29 a share, in 1986. Revenue totaled $3.14 billion, up from $2.76 billion.

title: U.S. Lifts a Ban on Florida Citrus Shipments
description: The United States Department of Agriculture on Tuesday lifted a three-year embargo on shipments of fresh citrus fruit from Florida to other critus-growing states. The embargo was imposed as a protection against canker.

title: HARMON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OCE-VAN DER GRINTEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The results are in U.S. currency and were converted from Dutch florins at Dfl 1.8455 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: LONE STAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special credit of $51.9 million from the termination of over- funded pension plans. c-Net loss The latest quarter and year reflect the acquisition of John Zink Co. on June 30.

title: Palestinians Are Using the News Organizations
description: To the Editor:

title: RUTGERS HAS PRIZE IN ITS RECRUITING
description: Shawn Williams signed the one-page document in the athletic director's office and then posed for pictures with his mother, Ann, and his high school football coach, Tim Hadden.

title: Stage: 'Mythos Oedipus' at La Mama
description: ELLEN STEWART goes behind and beyond Sophocles in ''Mythos Oedipus.'' Gods, monsters, seers and appalling freaks of nature only mentioned in choruses by Sophocles inhabit the world of what Miss Stewart calls her ''dance-opera,'' being given its American premiere by the Great Jones Repertory Company at the La Mama Annex (it was first presented in Delphi and two other Greek locations in 1985). Sophocles could count on his audience knowing, and trembling at the mention of, these beings who are mostly dim mysteries now.

title: Nat Cohen Dies at 82; British Film Executive
description: Nat Cohen, a Cockney butcher's son who produced such films as ''Darling'' and ''Murder on the Orient Express,'' died today after a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: RETAILING CORP OF AMEICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Verdict Due Today in Death of Artist
description: For three weeks, a judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan has been hearing testimony in the murder trial of the sculptor Carl Andre, who is accused of pushing his wife through a window of their 34th-floor apartment in Greenwich Village.

title: TV Changes Character of the Iowa Caucuses
description: The Iowa caucuses aren't what they once were, and they probably never will be again.

title: New Zealand to Cut Taxes
description: New Zealand said today that it would start cutting company and personal taxes in a few weeks but deferred action on imposing a planned single rate of income tax for further consideration.

title: CURTISS WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $234,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,548,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $501,000 and $1,445,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Events: Tours, Shows and a Symposium
description: Backstage Tour

title: EMERALD HOMES LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent units. Full year 1986 earnings are pro forma since the company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31 in 1986 as part of its restructuring to facilitate its 1987 initial public offering.

title: Murdoch Defends Selection Of Kalikow to Buy The Post
description: Defending his selection of Peter S. Kalikow to buy The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that the proposals offered by at least five other bidders would have demanded even greater concessions than the one from Mr. Kalikow.

title: Admirality Island Journal; In Drilling for Treasure, Miners Protect the Wild
description: The nation's largest silver mine is taking shape here alongside a sparkling salmon stream in the heart of a lush and wild rain forest.

title: Stocks Gain Broadly; Dow Rises 47.58
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved strongly higher across a broad front yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 47.58 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,962.04.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Tuesday, about Senator Bill Bradley and his vote against aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, misidentified the only non-Southern state with a Democratic Senator who voted for the aid. The state was Nebraska, not Kansas. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the year in which Senator Bradley began his support of the aid. It was March 1986, not 1987.

title: Charity From Gooden
description: Dwight Gooden announced yesterday that he would give $1,000 to a children's hospital every time he pitched a victory for the Mets this season. He will select a hospital in each city in the National League and make a donation wherever he wins. He opened the program by giving $1,000 to the All-Children's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he lives.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Accountant Says Noriega Helped Launder Billions
description: An accountant testified under oath to Congress today that he laundered billions of dollars in illegal drug profits through Panama's banking system with the help of Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega, commander of the country's army and police and de facto leader.

title: Violence Erupts Again in Bangladesh Vote
description: Election-related violence broke out in three cities near the capital today, a day after similar violence left at least 80 people dead, officials said.

title: Art: Jennifer Bartlett
description: JENNIFER BARTLETT'S latest works, now at the Paula Cooper Gallery, are smart and suave and highly polished, and they cast a seductive, unsettling spell. For her latest exhibition, the well-known former Minimalist has returned to familiar ground, depicting boats, houses and fences on four huge canvases (9 by 14 feet), in front of which have been placed sculptural re-creations of the painted images.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $51,000 for the quarter and net of $111,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations; the year also included a gain of $6,334,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $203,000 for the quarter and $376,000 for the year.

title: Film: 'Traveling North'
description: ''TRAVELING NORTH,'' opening today at the Plaza Theater, is a modest, essentially dreary Australian movie made bearable by the robust performance by Leo McKern in the star part.

title: Samaranch Calls for 'Vigilance'
description: With the opening ceremonies of the XV Olympic Winter Games two days away, less attractive Olympic issues continued to share the forefront with final preparations.

title: WHITE HOUSE SETS NEW SPACE POLICY
description: After a bitter internal struggle, the White House yesterday made public a new policy meant to rejuvenate the Government's ailing space program and speed the growth of the nation's emerging commercial space industry.

title: Whatever You Do, Don't Call Burns Bobby
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about reactions to a commission's findings on the war record of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria characterized Simon Wiesenthal's background incorrectly.
