Mr. Wiesenthal, head of the Jewish Documentation Center in Vienna, had been acquainted with Mr. Waldheim and had spoken in support of restraint on the Waldheim issue until the evidence was complete. But he was never Mr. Waldheim's ally.

title: TV Weekend; Ramey In 'Don Giovanni'
description: ''DON GIOVANNI'' may be the world's best opera; we remember the music even when we've forgotten which grieved woman was Donna Anna and which one was Donna Elvira. ''Great Performances,'' on Channel 13 at 9 tonight, presents the Salzburg Festival production of Mozart's great work. It is not a feast for the eyes; on the other hand, it is ''Don Giovanni.''

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Parents Not the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Pat Cotter's Skills Range Across Games and Sports
description: Versatility in active games and sports is not uncommon, nor in intellectual pursuits.

title: Julie Christie in 'Gold Diggers,' From Britain
description: THERE are critics in Britain who have praised Sally Potter's ''Gold Diggers'' as ''witty,'' ''visually entrancing'' and ''an absorbing pleasure,'' and there may also be like-minded individuals on the planet Jupiter. But by any reasonable earthly standard, this thing - a 1983 oddity, sort of a feminist, deconstructionist, riddle-filled anti-musical, much of it set on the Icelandic tundra - is pure torture. Its only noteworthy attribute is the presence of Julie Christie, who embodies some sardonic notion of the archetypical unenlightened movie heroine through the ages. Like it or not, Miss Christie is infinitely better off playing such creatures straight than she is satirizing them here.

title: Chambers's Lawyer Challenges Pathologist About Pressure on Neck
description: The defense attorney for Robert E. Chambers Jr. suggested yesterday that pressure applied to Jennifer Levin's neck could have resulted in her death much more quickly than the 20 seconds to 30 seconds estimated by a pathologist.

title: Art People
description: Invasion of Price Lists

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Advertising Arguments

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Love Songs
description: Al Carmines, a composer and pastor of the Rauschenbusch Memorial Church, and Speckled Bird, a folk-gospel trio, will present a sampler of love songs, with champagne and hors d'oeuvres, on Sunday at 5 P.M. on the second floor of the Trinity Presbyterian Church, 422 West 57th Street. Tickets, which benefit the Rauschenbusch church, are $25. Information: 245-8128.

title: Badolato Journal; He Tried to Sell the Town In More Ways Than One
description: Domenico Lanciano is the town philosopher in this very small town, which is dying because no one much likes to live here anymore.

title: John Reich Dies at 81; Led Goodman Theater
description: Dr. John Reich, who guided the Goodman Theater from an academic adjunct of the Art Institute of Chicago to one of the nation's best resident professional ensembles, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 81 years old.

title: Stage: John Gielgud Stars in London Play
description: As the curtain rose Wednesday night on John Gielgud's first stage performance in a decade, the audience's trepidation was palpable. Mr. Gielgud is 83 years old and the sole active member of the acting trinity whose other legendary figures, Laurence Olivier and Ralph Richardson, are retired or dead. In such circumstances, the gnawing question is not only whether Mr. Gielgud retains the stamina to sustain a theatrical role but also whether the mortal instruments of his art - the body and the voice - remain sound. While an elderly actor can fool the movie camera in short takes, Mr. Gielgud has bravely elected to test himself in a two-month run of a new full-length play, ''The Best of Friends'' by Hugh Whitemore, that requires his onstage presence virtually throughout.

title: Gay Ex-Soldier Wants to Return to the Army
description: Thoughout his 16-year stint in the Army, Perry J. Watkins said today, he made no secret of his homosexuality, even performing as a female impersonator. Early in his Army career he asked for a discharge, naming his lovers so that the Army could substantiate his claim.

title: Plea Ends Copter Export Case
description: Two brothers being tried on charges of illegally exporting 87 high-performance Hughes helicopters to North Korea have pleaded guilty to reduced charges, a prosecutor said.

title: U.S. File on Waldheim: Why Panel Didn't See It
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d ordered aides not to provide an Austrian investigative panel with the Justice Department's evidence on the wartime activities of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, according to department officials.

title: Early Music Players
description: The Early Music Players will present a program entitled ''Musick With Her Silver Sound'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. that includes pieces from the English courts of Henry VIII, Elizabeth I and James I, played on original instruments, at St. Bartholomew's Church (109 East 50th Street). A $5 contribution is requested. Information: 751-1616, extension 226 or 227.

title: Redesigned Rocket For Shuttle Is Tested For Margin of Safety
description: The space agency today tested a section of the space shuttle's redesigned booster rocket with intentionally flawed joints to determine whether the new design had a dependable safety margin.

title: Film: From Bunuel, 'Los Ambiciosos,' at the Public
description: LUIS BUNUEL said that ''Los Ambiciosos'' (''The Ambitious Ones''), also known as ''La Fievre Monte a el Pao,'' was not a good film, and he was right.

title: RENAISSANCE GRX reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRANDON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
One Winning Appeal From Death Row
description: Since last April, when the Supreme Court rejected Warren McCleskey's argument that the administration of the death penalty was unconstitutional because of its racially disparate effects, the nation's 2,000 death row inmates have had to draw their hopes and their appeals more narrowly. One who has won a measure of success, although not on any ground related to race, is Warren McCleskey himself.

title: Estimate Board Reacts To Threats With a Vote
description: The Board of Estimate, its existence threatened by the prospect of changes in the New York City Charter, rose up in oratorical ire yesterday to assert its powers and challenge Mayor Koch's right to order quietly the closing of a Brooklyn firehouse.

title: Advertising; Leo Burnett: Steady as It Grows
description: The worst snowstorm of the season struck today in a city not known for its gentle weather. But while many Chicagoans refused to go outside, the Leo Burnett Company's most famous advertising creations -Tony the Tiger, the Pillsbury Doughboy and Charlie the Tuna - as well as its top executives stood in the 11-below-zero cold to celebrate the near completion of the agency's 50-story headquarters building.

title: Winner of Nobel Prize Assails Candidates on Issue of AIDS
description: Opening the annual meeting of the nation's leading scientific organization, Dr. David Baltimore, a Nobel prize-winning molecular biologist, today criticized the Presidential candidates of both major political parties.

title: Negligent Landlord Is Ordered Confined To Ill-Kept Tenement
description: A Brooklyn landlord has been sentenced to spend 15 days under house arrest in an apartment building that he owns and where he failed to correct nearly 400 building code violations.

title: Mr. Waldheim and Mr. von Weizsacker
description: Nothing better illustrates Kurt Waldheim's unfitness for leadership than his response to the new report on his World War II record. The report confirms his knowledge of Nazi atrocities by his army units and his subsequent concealment of this record. Yet what Austria's President pulls from the report, sadly for Austria, is exoneration.

title: Revamping of Air Traffic System Urged, Including Private Control
description: The new Secretary of Transportation called today for a restructuring of Federal aviation regulations and said that turning the air traffic control system over to private industry should be among the options.

title: Economic Scene; Military Budget Under Pressure
description: THE effort to bring down the United States' budget deficit, which has swollen the gross national debt from $1 trillion to more than $2.5 trillion in the last seven years, is increasing the pressure on the military budget.

title: It's Not Luge Weather
description: Warm weather and sudden gusts of wind hampered practice runs today for the Olympic luge competition and were blamed for two crashes on the Calgary Olympic Park course.

title: Lukewarm Welcome for Professionals
description: In the past, the Olympics were closed to professional athletes, or at least those defined as professionals by the International Olympic Committee. In fact, a double standard existed, most clearly exemplified by athletes from the Eastern European countries, who are subsidized by their governments, but who usually listed their occupation as student or soldier.

title: Gephardt Eyes Dukakis's Backyard
description: On the face of it, the Democratic primary in New Hampshire next Tuesday is a straightforward affair: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts should win on the strength of his New England-ness, with Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois fighting for second place.

title: On Eve of Tet, Vietnam Tries to Ease Friction
description: As Vietnam prepares to celebrate Tet, the Lunar New Year - and the 20th anniversary of a series of wartime attacks known as the Tet Offensive - the Vietnamese people and army are being urged to get along better with each other.

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF HISTORIAL DOCUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $3,859 for the latest quarter and $12,711 for the year-earlier period.

title: Our Towns; Casinos' Allure: Weaning a Girl From the Tables
description: The 12 casinos in Atlantic City say they turned away minors at the door 200,000 times last year and kicked them off casino floors more than 30,000 other times. The casinos say they do their best to keep out those under 21. If so, what is striking about the case of Kim Cohen, an Atlantic City teen-ager who started playing blackjack at 15, is the encouragement the casinos gave her to keep gambling.

title: Film: 'Au Revoir les Enfants,' From Louis Malle
description: LOUIS MALLE'S ''Au Revoir les Enfants'' (''Goodbye, Children'') is based on an event that took place during January 1944, when the French writer and director, then 12 years old, was attending a Jesuit boarding school near Fontainebleau. At the end of the Christmas holidays, in the middle of the scholastic year, there appeared at the school three new boys, one of whom became the young Malle's chief competitor for scholastic honors and then, briefly, his best friend.

title: Advertising; Hartz Names Keyes
description: Hartz Mountain Industries, Secaucus, N.J., the real estate subsidiary of the Hartz Mountain Corporation, has tapped Keyes Martin Gaby Linett Advertising, Springfield, N.J., as the agency for its waterfront project in Edgewater, N.J. The $1 million budget will be used for print, outdoor and direct marketing campaigns. The agency has handled other projects for Hartz, including the Meadowlands.

title: The Philadelphia
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Riccardo Muti, will present vocal works by Bruckner, Mozart and Verdi on Monday at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $16 to $30. Information: 247-7800.

title: Rebels Hint New Actions In Argentina
description: Some of the soldiers involved in a rebellion last month have indicated in recent days that they intend to continue agitating against the military leadership and the civilian Government.

title: THE LAW: AT THE BAR
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani's flirtation with politics is over, at least for the moment. But the debate over Mr. Giuliani himself - what he was up to, what the future holds for him, and, ultimately, just what kind of man he is - rages more fiercely than ever.

title: Campeau Renews Bid for Retailer
description: The Campeau Corporation, strengthened by an alliance with two powerful real estate developers, yesterday renewed its $61-a-share cash offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. Separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission supported Campeau's right to challenge Delaware's new anti-takeover law.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Group Says It Controls Belgian Societe Generale<
description: A consortium of Belgian and French investors said today that it had obtained majority control of Societe Generale de Belgique, apparently thwarting a bid by the Italian entrepreneur Carlo de Benedetti.

title: Ailing Mexico Economy Will Be a Focus of Talks
description: As President Miguel de la Madrid and President Reagan prepare for their last scheduled official meeting, Mexico is struggling to emerge from its worst economic crisis in half a century and hoping the United States will play a key role in helping it recover.

title: INSIDE
description: Shultz May Visit Mideast

title: Gay Rights and the Court; Justices Likely to Confront Anew the Issue Of Government Bias Against Homosexuals
description: A Federal appellate ruling Wednesday that the Army's ban on homosexuals was unconstitutional casts doubt on all governmental discrimination against homosexuals, whether in the military or in civilian employment.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PULLMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $173,000. Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the sale of a temperature monitoring device business and the anticipated disposition of an electrical components business.

title: The Great Game Goes On
description: Mikhail Gorbachev faces a challenge entirely worthy of his abilities as a master politician.

title: Art: By Charles Sheeler, Paintings and Drawings
description: THE restrospective of Charles Sheeler's work at the Whitney Museum of American Art has a dry, cautious feeling to it, as if there's not quite enough art on the walls or enough personality in the art. As seen here, Sheeler's career spans five decades, from 1910 to the late 1950's, in the media of painting, drawing and photography. From beginning to end, it is a remarkably consistent career - a modest, yet highly formal picturing of the world that seems never to have faltered in its restraint or its technique, but that never seems to have aimed very high either.

title: After Delay, P.L.O. Ship Is Set to Sail to Israel
description: After days of delay, the Palestine Liberation Organization announced today that a ship carrying Palestinian deportees would leave for Israel in 36 hours.

title: ROYAL TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Advertising; Mingo Reorganizes
description: Frank L. Mingo, who runs Mingo-Jones Advertising, has reorganized the firm's executive ranks so he can devote more time to clients of the mi-nority -owned shop. Mr. Mingo turned over the posts of president and chief operating officer to Samuel J. Chis-holm, who will look after day-to-day operations. Mr. chisholm was execu-tive vice presiden tand general man-ager. Mr. Mingo, who will continue as chairman, also restructured the jobs of two co-creative directors, Allan R. Corwin and Samuel Reed, by giving them the additional duties, respec-tively, of executive creative director and secretary-treasurer.

title: 'Chronosymphonies'
description: The American Composers Orchestra and the Kronos Quartet will perform the premiere of Matthias Kriesberg's ''Chronosymphonies'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra, conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, will also present works by Gordon Getty, John Alden Carpenter and Roy Harris. Tickets are $11 to $17.50. Information: 247-7800.

title: Apathy Cancels a Parade
description: It was never on the scale of the Thanksgiving or Veterans Day parades. Still, over the last 90 years, the parade in honor of Washington's Birthday - led by the Knights of Columbus Color Corps with its capes draped over tuxedos, swords and plumed hats -had become a tradition.

title: CFS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said both fiscal 1987 periods include a loss provision on real estate of $815,000 and a $464,000 decrease in income from mortgage banking operations.

title: Stop and Shop Rejects Offer
description: As expected, the board of the Stop and Shop Companies rejected a buyout offer of $1.03 billion, or $37 a share, from the Dart Group Corporation.

title: A New Global Status for Cognac
description: For centuries, cognac makers have boasted that nothing has changed in the way they make their world-famous brandy -neither the copper-distilling equipment, nor the oak barrels in which the cognac ages.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Audible Rituals

title: Film: 'Shoot to Kill'
description: IN the cool green mountains of the Pacific Northwest, a red-hot thriller unfolds. It's ''Shoot to Kill,'' a film that marks the return of Sidney Poitier after a long absence from the screen, and a reappearance of good old-fashioned storytelling technique as well. This is essentially a formula film, and as such it's nothing fancy. But it has crisp, spare direction, enormous momentum and a story full of twists and turns. For anyone who thinks they don't make spine-tingling detective films the way they used to, good news: they've just made another.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Five-Stroke Lead in Seniors: Bob Charles of New Zealand flirted with a PGA Seniors Championship record yesterday, shooting an eight-under-par 64 that led him to a five-stroke lead after 18 holes of the $350,000 golf tournament. Charles, coming off a Seniors victory in South Africa, was nearly flawless in posting an opening round of eight birdies and no bogeys on the par 72, 6,530-yard Champion course at PGA National. Arnold Palmer holds the course and tournament record of nine-under-par 63, set in 1984. ''It was one of those days where everything went right,'' the 51-year-old left-hander said. Gary Player, Al Geiberger, Larry Mowry, Tommy Aaron, Harold Henning, Orville Moody and George Lanning were at 69.(AP) Neumann Ahead by Four Shots: Liselotte Neumann of Sweden fired an eight-under-par 64 to take a four-stroke lead after yesterday's first round of the $225,000 Sarasota Classic. Beth Daniel and Jan Stephenson shared second place with 68s. Nancy Lopez, the defending champion and winner of last week's Mazda Classic, shot one-over 73, making a birdie and two bogies. Neumann, 21, had six birdies and an eagle on the 349-yard 15th hole when she sank a 144-yard second shot with a 7-iron. Donna Caponi made a hole-in-one on the 178-yard 12th hole at Bent Tree Country Club, the second ace of her 23-year L.P.G.A. career.(AP) Mudd Shares Lead: Jodie Mudd twice holed from off the green in a six-under-par 66 that gave him a share of the first-round lead with Richard Zokol of Canada yesterday in the $600,000 Hawaiian Open in Honolulu. Mudd, who hasn't been a winner in seven seasons on the PGA Tour, said he was lucky and added, ''I chipped in once, holed a bunker shot and made a couple of 50 footers.'' He had seven birdies, an eagle and three bogeys. The United States Open champion, Scott Simpson, who played without a bogey on the Waialae Country Club course, and Brad Bryant were a shot back at 67. (AP) N.B.A. 76ers 119, Bucks 113: Charles Barkley scored 46 points as Philadelphia beat the visiting Milwaukee Bucks in overtime last night, giving Jim Lynam his first victory as the 76er coach. Barkley's driving basket gave Philadelphia a 112-110 lead with 2:01 left in overtime, but Ricky Pierce tied it on a short jumper with 1:09 remaining. Philadelphia regained the lead on a layup by Gerald Henderson with 47 seconds left and Barkley added three free throws and a dunk at the buzzer to finish the scoring.(AP) Tennis Navratilova Rallies Back: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova, trailing by 2-4 in the first set, rallied to a 6-4, 6-2, third-round victory over Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union yesterday in the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Dallas. Savchenko's serve-and-volley game and unpredictable tactics confounded Navratilova early in the match. ''She made some crazy shots, shots you wouldn't normally try in certain situations,'' Navratilova said. Savchenko, 21 years old, is one of six Soviet women competing this winter on the Virginia Slims tour in preparation for Olympic competition. Fourth-seeded Zina Garrison of Houston beat Maria Lindstrom of Sweden, 6-1, 6-1. Seventh-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria was a 6-0, 6-1, winner over Gigi Fernandez of San Juan, Puerto Rico. (AP)

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,100,000 and $4,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after a net restructuring charge of $78.5 million.

title: Washington Talk: The Commerce Department; In 'Lockup,' Itchy Reporters Count the Secnds
description: None have been handcuffed, none subjected to strip searches, none fingerprinted. But for reporters covering the United States Government's periodic releases of critical economic statistics, their compulsory incarceration for a half-hour or so before the magic moment of data release produces a sensation not all that different from being under arrest.

title: The Stage: 'Cave Life'
description: EARLY in ''Cave Life'' (at the Circle Repertory Company), Robin Bartlett leads a tour through the prehistoric wing of the Museum of Natural History. As she stops at an exhibit of Neanderthal man, one of the loin-clothed sculptural figures suddenly leaps to life and grabs the guide in a passionate embrace. The caveman, as we quickly learn, is a figment of the woman's hyperactive imagination, and she is, in all respects, mentally unhinged. The encounter is amusing. Then the play plunges ahead - and downhill.

title: Kluge Lifts Stake In Orion Pictures
description: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Company for the second consecutive day. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Kluge said he had raised his holdings to 26.7 percent from 25.6 percent, through purchases of an additional 221,400 Orion shares on Tuesday at an average price of $17.02 each. Orion's shares, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, were unchanged today at $17.75.

title: Allah and Gorbachev Mixing in Central Asia
description: Worshipers who come to the mosque of Imam Ibudulayev Nasrulo may sometimes find it difficult to tell where Mohammed leaves off and Mikhail S. Gorbachev begins.

title: N. Carolina Wins in Overtime
description: J. R. Reid and Scott Williams scored 4 points each in overtime to lead sixth-ranked North Carolina to a 75-73 victory over No. 16 North Carolina State in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Bourne Retrospective
description: A retrospective of films by the American independent film maker St. Clair Bourne begins tomorrow at noon at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street. Mr. Bourne is known for his documentaries and feature films about the lives of blacks living in the United States and abroad; among them are profiles of the writers Amiri Baraka and Langston Hughes. Screenings this weekend are today at noon and 3 P.M. and Sunday at 1 and 4 P.M. The series runs through Feb. 28. Screenings are included in museum admission, $4 ($2 for children). Information: 570-3676.

title: ALLSTAR INNS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company went public in April 1987.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article about a piano recital to be given tomorrow by Bruce Brubaker misstated the site. It will be at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Greenwich Village Sculptor Acquitted of Pushing Wife to Her Death
description: Carl Andre, the sculptor, was found not guilty yesterday of charges that he murdered his wife by pushing her from the window of their 34th-floor Greenwich Village apartment.

title: Asante Dancers
description: Drummers and dancers from the Asante tribe in Ghana will give a free demonstration on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Hillside School, 54 Orange Avenue, Montclair, N.J. The performance is sponsored by the Montclair Art Museum as part of a celebration of Black History month. A reception will follow at the museum, South Mountain and Bloomfield Avenues. Information and directions: (201) 746-5555.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Testing Of Rail Workers
description: The Government's policy of requiring railroad workers to submit to drug or alcohol tests after accidents or rule violations was struck down as unconstitutional today by a Federal appeals court.

title: Conferees Seek 'Founding Mothers'
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor told nearly 1,500 women here today that the Supreme Court would ''linger for a good many more years'' on women's rights cases in order to eliminate some of the effects of a Constitution that makes ''no specific mention of women.''

title: TREASURES AND TRIFLES: BROWSING IN ART BOOKSTORES
description: IN matters of art, New York has everything in depth -museums, dealers, magazines, practicing artists. So it should come as no surprise that this is also a city where art bookstores are in good supply, a city, in fact, where books about art are as easy to buy as - and certainly more nourishing than - a takeout dinner. There are no fewer than 20 dealers devoted exclusively or in large part to selling art books. They range from such doyens of the trade as E. Weyhe, Seymour Hacker and George Wittenborn to dens of boutiquity like Rizzoli to the newest venture in SoHo, the soon-to-open partnership of Kolwyck-Jones.

title: NRBQ to Perform
description: NRBQ, a rock band, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300), with True Image opening. Double bills begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: JACO ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Auctions
description: Britain is currently in the midst of an unofficial Noel Coward festival. Revivals of his early plays, including ''Easy Virtue'' and ''The Vortex,'' are running in London and Glasgow, and last week the New Sadler's Wells Opera launched its nationwide tour of ''Bitter Sweet,'' Coward's 1929 operetta, in Plymouth.

title: ENVIROPACT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $149,200. c-Includes a tax credit of $93,500 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Film: 'A Tiger's Tale,' Starring Ann-Margret
description: ORDINARILY you can tell a lot about a film from the names of its characters, and the principals in ''A Tiger's Tale'' include Rose Butts (Ann-Margret), Shirley Butts (Kelly Preston), Bubber Drumm (C. Thomas Howell), La Vonne (Angel Tompkins) and Claudine (Ann Wedgeworth). To be fair, this film, written, produced and directed by Peter Douglas (from a novel by Allen Hannay 3d), is a little better than that, but it does place excessive stock in rustic quirks and cracker-barrel humor. It's a romance, after all, in which the young hero declares to his older sweetheart that he's ''stuck on you like a tick.''

title: Threat Investigated
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday it has entered the investigation of a death threat that prompted Tony Yates, the University of Cincinnati basketball coach, to stay away from Wednesday night's game in St. Louis, the first game he has missed in five seasons.

title: EDAC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2.5 million from life insurance proceeds.

title: The Silos
description: The Silos, a rock band, will perform Sunday at 9:30 and 11 P.M. at Under Acme, 9 Great Jones Street (420-1934). Tickets are $5.

title: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $1,336,644 for the quarter and a capital gain of $764,579 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $938,147 and $6,730,523 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PARADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $276,000 and $445,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes an extraordinary charge of $12,000 for the quarter, and the year includes a tax credit of $381,000.

title: SOMERSET GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,607,000. The company was formed in April 1986.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on page B1 yesterday about holiday weekend closings referred incorrectly to a parade. The Washington's Birthday parade, originally scheduled for Monday, has been canceled. An article on the subject appears today on page B2.

title: Townsend Harris Coup
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagans to Help Raise Funds
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will appear at a $10,000 a couple fund-raising event Friday for the California Republican Party, state party officials said. The event will be held at the Bel-Air home of David Murdock, a real estate developer. The event is expected to draw 100 to 125 people. The Reagans are making a brief stopover before traveling to Mexico over the weekend to visit President Miguel de la Madrid.

title: G.M. Rebate Plan Special to The New York Times
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was offer-ing a $1,000 cash rebate to buyers of eligible 1988 Pontiac Firebirds, in a program that expires on April 30. First-time buyers will qualify for an additional $600 payment in a pro-gram that ends Sept. 30.

title: On Stage
description: The Smell of Success for Mamet

title: Vital Repair for Civil Rights Law
description: When Federal money flows to one department of a school or hospital, Federal law should prohibit discrimination in all parts of the institution. For years that was accepted as the clear intent of several Federal civil rights laws. Then in 1984, the Supreme Court narrowed their scope. The Senate now has restored the laws' broader reach and the House is about to follow. Sadly and ill-advisedly, Reagan Administration officials are signaling a veto.

title: Timeless All-Stars
description: The Timeless All-Stars - Harold Land on tenor saxophone, Bobby Hutcherson on vibraphone, Curtis Fuller on trombone, Cedar Walton on piano, Buster Williams on bass and Billy Higgins on drums - are performing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $5,230,000 and $859,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a net gain of $1,191,000 and $6,943,000 from restructuring of operations for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $4,498,000 and $31,683,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Advertising; WPP Refinancing
description: WPP Group, London, reported that it had signed its previously announced refinancing agreement for its acquisition of the JWT Group, which occurred last July. WPP said the new package includes a seven-year, $160 million loan set up by S. G. Warburg & Company, with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York acting as agent and lead manager. WPP Group also appointed as a director John A. Quelch, 36 years old. Mr. Quelch is an associate professor at the Harvard Business School.

title: Meadowlands Meet A Yardstick for Coe
description: At 31 years of age, with a decade of world-class competition behind him, Sebastian Coe is turning to something new. Coe will run in his first American indoor track meet, the Vitalis Olympic Invitational in Byrne Meadowlands Arena, tomorrow night.

title: KEY RATES
LONDON HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WHITE HOUSE BANS OFFICIALS HELPING CONTRA DONATIONS
description: The White House announced today that it had forbidden Reagan Administration officials to ''provide assistance or encouragement of any kind to private individuals or third parties raising funds'' for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Bush Leads in New York Filings, But Opponents Protest His Tactics
description: Vice President Bush had some good news in the Republican Presidential race yesterday when his New York supporters filed the most slates, the most candidates for delegate and the most signatures on petitions for the April 19 Presidential primary.

title: U.S. Is Considering Disciplinary Action In Alzheimer's Study
description: The Food and Drug Administration has notified a California psychiatrist that it is considering disqualifying him from testing new drugs because of doubts about a report he wrote asserting that a drug helped combat Alzheimer's disease.

title: Rap Group in a Salute To Paterson Principal
description: Run-DMC, the rap group, treated about 3,000 students at Eastside High School today to a high-decibel salute to the school's principal, Joe Clark.

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $5 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $56.2 million from debt refinancing. c-After income from discontinued operations of $8.1 million for the quarter and $11.7 million for the year. d-Net income The year-ago share earnings were unavailable.

title: Not All Tenants Praise Cuomo Proposals on Rent Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Counting Microchips
description: Late last year Congress banned Pentagon purchases of products of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan and Kongsberg Vaapensfabrikk of Norway as punishment for their sale of important military technology to the Soviet Union.

title: City Ballet: 2 Bolshoi Stars Visit
description: IF any idea once seemed highly unlikely it was that the New York City Ballet would be the first American company to play host to Soviet dancers for an extended time. Until his death in 1983, George Balanchine, the company's artistic director, did not hide his criticism of the Soviet Union, including its ballet. The Soviet Government, for its part, kept its dancers on a tight leash.

title: About Real Estate; Converting All-Suite Hotels in Stamford
description: As all-suite hotels continue to proliferate around the nation, some owners are taking advantage of their broader potential: transformation into residential condominiums should an oversupply develop or demand for transient accommodations slacken.

title: 2 Are Seized in Beirut, Then Freed
description: Gunmen kidnapped two Swedish journalists in Beirut's southern suburbs today but released them after realizing that they were not West Germans, the police said.

title: SEAGULL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Capitol Hill Maneuvers, and The New York Post's Future
description: LEAD: Amid all the attention devoted to the Federal Communications Commission's cross ownership rule, to the Kennedy-Hollings amendment barring a waiver of it and to the future of The New York Post, one key fact has been all but obscured.

title: YORK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm disappointed. It seems I have been found guilty of trying to get the White House to do what it promised to do.'' - Lyn Nofziger. [ A28:3. ]

title: Canadian Bank Examines Loss
description: The National Bank of Canada, the nation's sixth-largest bank, said today that it was investigating unauthorized trades by a bond dealer in its New York office. The trades cost the bank $25 million in Canadian funds, it said, and the amount will be taken as a loss against its first-quarter earnings. This equals about $20 million of United States funds.

title: IMMUNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RANGERS SINK; DEVILS 4, CANADIENS, 2
description: For Coach Jim Schoenfeld of the Devils, the words of praise did not appear to be enough to describe Bob Sauve's remarkable goaltending against Montreal tonight.

title: Exiled Afghan Dean Is Killed At Press Service in Pakistan
description: A prominent exiled professor from Afghanistan, Prof. Sayd Bahouddin Majrooh, was killed today by an unknown gunman in Peshawar, his son said.

title: Murdoch to Buy 2 More Magazines
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch will buy a consumer fashion magazine and an apparel trade publication, Murdoch Magazines said. Sportswear International, a trade publication, and In Fashion, a bimonthly consumer magazine, will be purchased for an undisclosed sum.

title: High Voltage Bid
description: The High Voltage Engineering Corporation of Burlington, Mass., has agreed to accept a sweetened offer of $18 a share, or about $91.8 million, from Hyde Park Partners L.P., a New York investment firm. Hyde Park had made unsolicited offers of $15.25 a share and then $17 a share for High Voltage, a which makes electrical and communications instruments. The Massachusetts company rejected the offers and said it was negotiating with another party.

title: U.S. Skater Tries Again
description: As the sun set below the Canadian Rockies far to the west, Team Swider-Peltz was finishing up another grueling workout inside the Olympic Oval. It's arguable which of the team members finds the workout most taxing.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aon Corp., Chicago, Ill., an insurance holding company, appointed John J. O'Connell executive vice president of its Aon Information Services division.

title: Girl's Lawyers Agree to Assist Attack Inquiry
description: The lawyers for a Dutchess County teen-ager who said she was the victim of a racial and sexual attack agreed today to cooperate with a state investigation, promising that she would be a witness ''at the appropriate time.''

title: Pop/Jazz; Resurgence Of Big Bands In New York
description: THE 1980's have seen an explosion of jazz activity, in just about every form imaginable. One of the most fertile movements of the decade, for instance, has been built around the re-emergence of the big band as a composer's forum. Artistically challenging orchestras have been like taxes: they seem to be everywhere. Large groups, led by musicians deep in jazz's vanguard, have graced the club and concert halls of New York City -the frenetic saxophonist David Murray; Hamiet Bluiett, who's currently running an orchestra at Carlos 1 for an indefinite stay of Monday nights; the experimentalist Muhal Richard Abrams; the pianist Cecil Taylor, and the saxophonist Jameel Moondoc have all reinvented the jazz orchestra in their own image.

title: ADVANTA CORP reports earnings for
description: b-Net income

title: District Judge Frees Suspect In Hostage-Taking at School
description: A man initially believed to have been an accomplice in a hostage-taking here last week was released from jail after a prosecutor said it appeared he had been forced to participate at gunpoint.

title: CERAMICS PROCESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AIDS Experiment Based on Salk's Theories
description: Some patients infected with the AIDS virus are being injected with an inactive form of the virus in a program in which Dr. Jonas Salk is using the same theories that led to his vaccine for polio.

title: Michel Camilo Trio
description: Michel Camilo, a pianist, will lead a trio and Dave Valentin, a flutist, will lead a quintet in a Latin-jazz double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1988
description: International A3-15

title: Bishop Frederick Donaghy, Missionary, 85
description: Bishop Frederick Donaghy, a Roman Catholic missionary in China and Taiwan, died of cancer Friday at Maryknoll, the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America's center in Ossining, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Kickoff Gets Nebraska
description: Nebraska, which defeated Penn State in the first game five years ago, and Texas A&M, winner of three straight Southwest Conference championships, will meet in the sixth Kickoff Classic this summer.

title: Islanders Beaten Late
description: Vincent Damphousse scored his second goal of the game tonight with 22 seconds left in regulation time as the Toronto Maple Leafs broke a six-game losing streak with a 4-3 victory over the Islanders.

title: Art: Chinese Paintings, 1800 to 1950, at the Met
description: TWO years ago, the Metropolitan Museum of Art was given 471 Chinese paintings dated from 1800 to 1950. The donor was Robert H. Ellsworth, a resident of New York City who is known worldwide as a dealer in Oriental art. The gift fills a big hole in the museum's holdings, and by implication it makes a pitch for the continuing interest and significance of Chinese painting throughout a period in which it is generally believed to have been in decline.

title: BUSINESSMEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment losses of $2,058,000 for the quarter and an investment gain of $58,346,000 for the year, and the year also includes a tax credit of $3,978,000. c-Net loss d-After investment losses of $661,000 and an investment gain of $10,333,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Few in Survey See Recession
description: United States manufacturers are largely unconcerned about their inventory levels and only one in four sees a recession this year, according to a survey of manufacturing executives made public this week. The National Association of

title: Anger in Miami Over a Resignation
description: Cuban-Americans responded with anger and sorrow today to the resignation of Sergio Pereira, the chief administrative officer of Dade County, who is under fire for personal indiscretions.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $351,200 gain from an accounting change. The company said that in 1987 it changed its method of inventory costing to include in inventory certain labor and overhead costs, which decreased its operating income for the year by 6 cents a share.

title: Dawson Shoots for Arbitration Record
description: While Andre Dawson was preparing to shoot for a record arbitration salary today, two other outfielders who had sought salaries of more than $1 million negotiated new contracts yesterday. Kirby Puckett of Minnesota accepted a $1,090,000 salary and Eric Davis of Cincinnati agreed to $899,000.

title: Young People's Concert
description: The New York Philharmonic will present a Young People's Concert featuring Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' tomorrow at 2 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. Zubin Mehta will conduct. Tickets are $4 to $15. Information: 874-6770.

title: Advertising; Pontiac's Gift to Soviet
description: David Deutsch Associates announced that Pontiac dealers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were planning to ship a red Pontiac Grand Prix to the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Timed to coincide with the gesture, a 30-second spot will appear on television in the New York metropolitan area over the next six weeks, with hopes of national syndication. ''It's a gift and is being done in complete good faith,'' said Donald Deutsch, executive vice president and creative director at the agency. ''We haven't called Mr. Gorbachev ahead of time and don't know whether he'll accept it.''

title: U.S. Must Keep Access To North Korea Open
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,809,000 on the sale of investments.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $3,126,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $155,000 for the year. c-After capital loss of $4,645,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $2,750,000 for the year.

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The New Protestant Ethic Is the Asian Ethic
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Grey Is Winner For U S West
description: Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, has come out the winner in the three-month competition for the U S West Inc. corporate advertising business, with a budget of $10 million. U S West, one of the regional Bell operating companies, serves 14 Western and Midwestern states. Its former agency, Fallon

title: Old Tollbooths on Merritt: Trying to Save 30's Artifacts
description: After a long campaign, the tolls on the Merritt Parkway will be abolished next July 1. Now, a new campaign is starting to save the tollbooths as a historical reminder of the 1930's, when people went motoring instead of commuting.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on bond redemption of $366,000 for the quarter and year, and tax credits of $2 million for the quarter and $7 million for the year. c-After tax credits of $3.4 million for the quarter and $4.9 million for the year; the year also included a loss on bond redemption of $1,712,000.

title: 2 More Quit In Turmoil At Salomon
description: Two more senior executives resigned from Salomon Brothers yesterday, joining the growing list of defectors from the large investment banking house, people close to the firm said.

title: Valley National Finds Chief at Smaller Rival
description: Banking ''is an all-out war now, while 15 years ago it was a fairly simple business,'' said James P. Simmons, who was elected chairman and chief executive of the Valley National Corporation earlier this week. Valley is the parent of Arizona's largest bank.

title: Stock Prices Mixed: Dow Off a Bit
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average edging lower and broader market gauges moving higher.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Fumes Sicken Hospital Staff
description: Surgery at the Westchester County Medical Center here was canceled today when 15 staff members were overcome by fumes as they prepared the operating floor in the morning. A spokeswoman for the hospital, Nancy McPartlin, said all elective surgery was postponed and emergencies were referred to other hospitals. Later the County Health Department found the fumes had disappeared.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jose Santos rode five winners for the second straight day yesterday at Aqueduct, giving him 10 winners in 13 races. The only other jockey in New York history to ride 10 winners in two days was Steve Cauthen, who did it twice in 1977. . . . Pat Riggin, the Pittsburgh Penguins' starting goaltender at the beginning of the season, was assigned to the Penguins' Muskegon farm club in the International Hockey League. Riggin had not played recently because of the emergence of Frank Pietrangelo as the Penguins' starting goaltender. . . . Andy Van Slyke, the Pittsburgh Pirates center fielder, who set career highs with a .293 batting average, 21 home runs, 82 runs batted in and 34 stolen bases after being acquired in a trade with St. Louis last April 1, has been named the 1987 winner of the Roberto Clemente Award. The award is presented annually by the Pittsburgh chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America to the player who best exemplifies the standards of excellence established by the late Pirate outfielder.

title: MORINO ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company reported a net loss for the year-ago quarter.

title: NOFZIGER IS CONVICTED ON 3 COUNTS OF VIOLATING FEDERAL ETHICS LAW
description: Lyn Nofziger, who served as one of Ronald Reagan's close advisers in the California Governor's office and in the White House, was found guilty today of illegal lobbying under the Federal ethics law.

title: VERTICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Largest L.I. Hospital Curbs Elective Care In Nursing Shortage
description: The Nassau County Medical Center, the largest hospital on Long Island, began turning away all non-emergency cases today because of a severe shortage of nurses.

title: OPTO MECHANIK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gymnast Will Pass
description: Kristie Phillips, the national women's champion and a good bet for a gold medal at the Summer Olympics, will not defend her championship in the American Cup championships next month, the United States Gymnastics Federation announced yesterday.

title: Staten Island Coach Likes a Challenge
description: Because he badly wanted to get back into coaching, Howie Ruppert left his job as an assistant to P. J. Carlesimo at Seton Hall in the big-time Big East Conference to take on the head coaching job at the College of Staten Island in the low-profile City University of New York Athletic Conference.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Carriers Inc., Overland Park, Kan., has rejected Baytree Investors Inc.'s $15-a-share tender offer for a 51 percent stake.

title: Albert Fink Milton, Executive, 90
description: Albert Fink Milton, a former financial executive in New York City, died last Friday at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: Israel Says It Seized 3 Guerrillas From Egypt
description: Israeli troops captured three armed guerrillas who infiltrated into the country across the southern border with Egypt last week, apparently to carry out an attack on civilians, the army said today.

title: Market Place; Behind Advance In G.M.'s H Stock
description: TAKEOVER situations dominate the handful of issues recently hitting new highs on the New York Stock Exchange. But the class H stock of General Motors - certainly no acquisition candidate - finds itself in this select group.

title: Infant Ejected in Car Crash
description: The police filed drunken driving and other charges today against the mother of a 13-month-old boy who hurtled out a car window in an accident early Wednesday and spent 15 minutes in an icy stream. The boy, Eric McCourt, was in critical condition at Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh suffering head injuries and exposure, a hospital official said.

title: The Trade Gap: Myths and Crocodile Tears
description: The trade figures scheduled for release today will no doubt show that Asian nations continue to sell us much more than we sell them, the declining dollar notwithstanding. In fact, America's trade deficit with the ''four tigers'' of Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan is now greater than our trade deficit with all of Western Europe. This is causing Americans to feel indignant, particularly during an election year, in which indignation is often a convenient substitute for thought.

title: IU Urges Caution On Neoax Offer
description: The board of the IU International Corporation urged stockholders to refrain from tendering their shares to Neoax Inc. because of uncertainties about its tender offer. IU said it was exploring alternatives to the hostile $20-a-share offer, including a recapitalization or a leveraged buyout.

title: Restaurants; French bistro on the East Side.
description: WHEN the wind chill hammers the thermometer into single digits, one of the most effective human antifreezes is a bracing stew along with a slab of rough country bread and a glass of husky red wine. To the French, that translates as pot-au-feu, and one of the best around is ladled out at Voulez-Vous.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MUCH DEPENDS ON DINNER. The Extraordinary History and Mythology, Allure and Obsessions, Perils and Taboos of an Ordinary Meal. By Margaret Visser. 351 pages. Illustrated.

title: Shultz Likely to Undertake Mideast Peace Mission
description: Administration officials said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would probably travel to the Middle East at the end of this month to explore the prospects for movement toward Arab-Israeli peace negotiations.

title: Interest Deductions Limited By Maze of New Regulations
description: Until this tax-filing season, deducting interest on home mortgages, car loans, margin accounts and business loans used to be a straightforward affair with hardly any limitations. To most taxpayers, interest was interest, and they were usually able to deduct any kind of interest expense in full with few complications.

title: Percy Jones
description: Percy Jones, an electric bassist, will perform tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $7.

title: Newmont's Gold Loan
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had recently obtained a loan of one million ounces of gold from a group of lenders led by the Bank of Nova Scotia. At current bullion prices, the loan is valued at roughly $445 million and is believed to be the largest of its kind by a mining company.

title: Study Urges Tougher Checks To Meet Clean Air Act Goals
description: More stringent controls to reduce smog and carbon monoxide pollution from motor vehicles are required if the nation is to reach the goals of the Clean Air Act, according to a study released today by the American Lung Association.

title: Michigan Sets Bonuses For Pension Managers
description: To compete with the high salaries of the securities industry, the Michigan Civil Service Commission yesterday approved a plan to pay bonuses to the state employees who manage Michigan's $15 billion pension fund, based on the fund's performance.

title: Regulators File Charges Of Juice-Price Scheme
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission yesterday accused a Florida investor of trying to manipulate prices of orange juice futures in September 1984.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge for a restructuring program of $150 million. The company said as part of the restructuring, it realized about $200 million in cash proceeds in 1987 from the sale of Kendall's fiber products division, the Lutravil joint venture, and other investments.

title: P.L.O. Dispute: U.S. and U.N. on Collision Course
description: After years of growing tension in their relations, the United Nations and the United States are on the brink of their most damaging confrontation as a result of Congressional moves to close the Palestine Liberation Organization mission here, diplomats and senior officials of the world organization say.

title: Merrill Research Chief To Head Equity Unit
description: In the latest example of how securities firms are responding to the tougher environment on Wall Street, Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced a reorganization of its huge capital-markets operation.

title: AIRLEASE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOLECULON INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Chinook: Gold-Medal Warmth
description: WE have seen the chinook wind and it works, melting the snow in its path like a giant microwave oven demolishing an ice-cream cone.

title: Tenants Strike Beneath Their Rooftop Pool
description: A cylinder of black-tinted glass that rises 46 stories above Second Avenue, the apartment building is the epitome of Upper East Side elegance. The view from a rooftop pool looks south over the midtown skyline. In the basement, two theaters show first-run films.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,539,000 and $9,098,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Many Donors Increase Gifts To Neediest
description: As the city's poor grow poorer and more numerous, many people have increased their usual contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Children's Benefit
description: Youngsters with professional theatrical ensembles around the city will take part in a special performance on Monday at 7:30 P.M. at the John Houseman Theater, 450 West 42d Street. Proceeds from the evening will benefit the Tibetan Children's Villages in Dharmsala and Bylakuppe, India, where more than 1,000 orphaned children are cared for. Tickets to the event, sponsored by the Special Relief League Inc., are $15 and $25 ($7.50 for children). Information: 741-1923.

title: THERMODYNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Rebuilding Techniques for Jaws Not Yet Proven
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Murdoch's Lawyers Argue for Cross-Ownership
description: Lawyers for Rupert Murdoch argued before a Federal appeals court here today that Congress acted unconstitutionally when it passed a law before Christmas whose sole object, they said, was to damage Mr. Murdoch.

title: Justice Dept. Finds No Violation Of Ethics Law in Ginsburg Case
description: The Justice Department has decided not to seek a special prosecutor to review conflict-of-interest allegations against Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, a department official said Wednesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Racer Is Restored To Bobsled Team
description: The International Olympic Committee and all other concerned governing bodies agreed today that Don LaVigne could be added to the United States Olympic bobsled team as the 13th member.

title: POST-REAGAN ERA PAINTED IN BUDGET
description: President Reagan's new budget lays down a comprehensive blueprint for Federal policies in the post-Reagan era, including increased spending on education and science and a dramatic expansion of his campaign for the private sector to take over Government functions.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ford-Mazda Car Is Shown
description: The Ford Motor Company today introduced a Japanese-American sports car, the Probe, which it hopes will recapture sales from Japanese companies like the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company.

title: In Philadelphia, a New Prelate, But Strict Views Are Familiar
description: In an atmosphere of majesty that radiated the accumulated moral authority of two millenniums of church history, John Cardinal Krol today turned over the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia to Archbishop Anthony J. Bevilacqua.

title: BUSH SHARPENING ATTACKS ON DOLE
description: Vice President Bush, searching for ways to stave off a challenge from Senator Bob Dole, campaigned without many of the trappings of office today and with a sharpened, more critical attack on his leading rival.

title: TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SPEX GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Simon and Gephardt Seek Funds
description: Two nights after his victory in the Iowa caucuses, Representative Richard A. Gephardt was a long way from New Hampshire, where other Presidential contenders were seeking support for Tuesday's primary.

title: Diner's Journal
description: RESTAURANT LAFAYETTE, the three-star French restaurant in the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue at 56th Street, has added some engrossing traditional winter dishes to its menu. Called ''menu d'autrefois,'' or menu of another time, the four-course meal, served at dinner, is prix fixe at $65 (intended for two or more diners, although any items can be ordered a la carte). It begins with sweetbread fritters with a verjus sauce (made with the juice of unripe grapes); followed by fillet of carp stuffed with mushrooms in red wine; backenoff of beef and pork (an Alsatian casserole), and blanc-manger, a chilled almond-and-pistachio cream.

title: Mozambique: Few Escape Fury of War
description: Hundreds of people sought refuge from war at a relief camp outside this decaying town. But Mozambique's cruel reality crept up on them there.

title: Jersey State Opera
description: The New Jersey State Opera will present Pietro Mascagni's ''Iris'' on Sunday at 6 P.M. in Newark's Symphony Hall. Adriana Maliponte, a soprano, will sing the title role. It is the first production of the opera in this area since its performance at the Metropolitan Opera in 1931. Tickets are $6 to $42. Information and directions: (201) 623-5775.

title: Buddy Tate
description: Buddy Tate, a saxophonist who played with Count Basie, will lead a quartet with the guest vocalist Carrie Smith tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, near Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Workers' Total For New York Soaring in 80's
description: Employment in New York City in the 1980's has risen to its highest level since the years just after World War II, with women experiencing the largest gains, according to a Federal report issued yesterday.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a realized loss on investments of $28,026,000 for the quarter and a realized gain on investments of $826,000 for the year. c-After realized gains on investments of $27,801,000 for the quarter and $70,388,000 for the year.

title: IMO DELAVAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1.4 million, or 19 cents a share, resulting from a change in accounting principles relating to income taxes. c-Net loss

title: Rabbi Israel Raphael Margolies Dies at 72
description: Rabbi Israel Raphael Margolies, who spoke out on a variety of social issues and was a longtime civil rights advocate, died of complications from hypoglycemia yesterday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: Film: 'Action Jackson'
description: ''ACTION JACKSON'' is named for a Detroit cop who is slow to take offense but when he does, get out of the way. Played by Carl Weathers, a member of the highly-developed-upper-torso school of movie hero, he is after a power-mad automobile executive skilled in karate whose henchmen are killing off the leadership of the auto union. So much for redeeming social content. Sergeant Jackson has a degree from Harvard Law School, but he doesn't flaunt it; his snappy repartee comes straight from a junior high school locker room. Crashing through are several raffish characters whose acting doesn't get in the way of the stunts.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,843,000 from life insurance proceeds.

title: Texaco Investors Win Plea
description: Shareholders challenging Texaco Inc.'s proposal to grant sweeping releases and indemnities to officers and advisers involved in its acquisition of Getty Oil will have the right to gather documents and testimony from them before the March 22 hearing on Texaco's bankruptcy reorganization plan, Bankruptcy Judge Howard Schwartzberg ruled yesterday.

title: Colgate Net Up in Quarter
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company yesterday reported sharply higher fourth-quarter earnings although its profit for all of 1987 tumbled because of restructuring expenses.

title: Mexico Delays Bond Auction
description: Mexico said yesterday that it had postponed for a week, to Feb. 26, an auction of up to $10 billion in bonds in exchange for loans held by banks around the world. The banks are being asked to exchange their loans to Mexico at a discount for the bonds, which would be backed by United States Government securities.

title: F.A.A. Is Urging Use of Crash Recorders by Commuter Lines
description: New rules that would greatly expand the use of crash recorders, particularly on smaller commuter airliners, are to be proposed today by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
James McGlincy, 70; Was a CBS Journalist
description: James McGlincy, a journalist who worked for several newspapers and for CBS News, died of cancer of the lymph glands on Tuesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 70 years old.

title: WINDMERE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $802,200.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $291,000 for the quarter and $946,000 for the year. c-Included equity in earnings of affiliated companies of $87,000 for the quarter and $152,000 for the year.

title: Harpsichord Concertos
description: John Gibbons, a harpsichordist, will perform harpsichord concertos by Bach tonight at 8 o'clock in Weill Recital Hall. He will be joined by a quintet of string players. Tickets are $12. Information: 247-7800.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Justice's Decision
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court has resigned from the Cosmos Club, the prestigious club whose all-male membership policy has come under increasing attack from the District of Columbia Government and from disaffected members as well as from feminists.

title: Leonard Martelli, 50, Writer and Executive
description: Leonard J. Martelli, a former publishing executive and co-author of ''When Someone You Know Has AIDS: A Practical Guide,'' died of complications resulting from AIDS on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 50 years old.

title: Second Stage Benefit
description: A $200 celebrity bowling benefit for the Second Stage Theater, sponsored by Seagram's, will be held on Monday at 6 P.M. at the Madison Square Garden Bowling Center, at 32d and Seventh Avenue. Couples may choose their bowling partners from a roster that includes Treat Williams, Marsha Mason, Betty Buckley, Kevin Bacon, Carrie Fisher and about 20 others, and prizes will be awarded. Registration: 787-8302.

title: Violeta and Corazon
description: The people here who would have the most to gain by fulfillment of the Central American plan for peace and democracy are not very optimistic. Of course, it is the long-suffering Nicaraguan population in general who would gain. But it is the opposition leaders and human rights advocates who are going to be the key players.

title: Film: 'School Daze'
description: FROM the intimate, funny sexual battleground on which Spike Lee's ''She's Gotta Have It'' unfolded, Mr. Lee has moved on to bigger, bolder and messier ambitions. The new occasion is ''School Daze,'' his scathing look at a fictitious white-financed, all-black college whose motto is ''Uplift the Race.''

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Today is Lincoln's Birthday; Washington's Birthday is observed Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parking: Alternate-side rules are suspended today and Monday. Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping either day. Government offices: Federal and state offices are open and city offices are closed today; all are closed Monday. Post offices: Open today; closed Monday, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: State-chartered banks have the option to close and federally chartered banks are open today; all banks have the option to close Monday. Financial markets: Open today; closed Monday. Transportation: Today, subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on weekday schedule; on Monday, subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule. Schools: Option to close today and Monday; New York City schools closed both days. Libraries: New York Public, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed today and Monday. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices are open and state and city offices are closed today; all are closed Monday. Post offices: Open today; closed Monday, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Option to close today and Monday. Transportation: today, N.J. Transit on weekday schedule; Monday, N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no rail service on Montclair Branch, Boonton and Pascack Valley lines. Schools: Option to close today and Monday. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices are open and state and city offices are closed today; all are closed Monday. Post offices: Open today; closed Monday, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Closed today and Monday. Transportation: New Haven line on weekday schedule today and holiday schedule Monday. Schools: Closed today and Monday.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring net gain of $148,688,000 which includes a gain from the public offering of Chemical Waste Management Inc. as well as restructuring charges.

title: The Police Brass Make a Night of It
description: From 6:30 on last night, the top officials of the New York City Police Department were out on the town, dancing, drinking and dining at the annual winter benefit dance of the New York City Police Foundation at Police Headquarters.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Fellow Travelers
description: Donna F. Tuttle, an Under Secretary of Commerce who heads the United States Travel and Tourism Administration, has a problem with one part of the private travel industry: the National Geographic Society's Traveler magazine.

title: Lewis Wolberg, 82, Clinic Psychoanalyst In New York, Is Dead
description: Dr. Lewis R. Wolberg, a psychoanalyst and founder and former chairman of the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health, died of a heart attack Feb. 3 at his winter home in La Penita, Jalisco, Mexico, near Puerto Vallarta. He was 82 years old and also lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Suggestion, on Intruder: Off With Its Head
description: There is no telling how many neighborly quarrels have flared, flamed and faded into the mists of the past on Elfreth's Alley, the oldest continuously inhabited residential street in the United States.

title: Illinois on Probation
description: The University of Illinois, which admitted to football recruiting violations during the tenure of Mike White, a former coach, was placed on probation yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association but received no major penalty. The N.C.A.A. Committee on Infractions said Illinois would be on probation until July 1, 1989, and must submit two internal audits of the football program. Chancellor Morton Weir called the N.C.A.A. requirements ''nothing that would cause us any difficulties during that period.''

title: SMELTER IS FINED FOR LEAD HAZARD
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration today levied its third largest fine ever, $2.78 million, against a Missouri smelting plant accused of exposing workers to high levels of lead and then dismissing them to sidestep Government medical leave requirements.

title: QUALITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on marketable securities of $505,500. c-Net income

title: AON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $17,381,000 and $28,870,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After realized investment losses of $3,603,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $63,039,000 for the year.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $3,481,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $4,012,000 for the year. c-After realized investment gains of $1,961,000 for the quarter and $16,381,000 for the year.

title: UNHAPPY DUNKER
description: Still miffed over the judging in last weekend's National Basketball Association slam-dunk competition in Chicago, Dominique Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks says he will not participate in the future - unless he gets the homecourt advantage.

title: Military Officers in Honduras Are Linked to the Drug Trade
description: Senior Honduran Army officers and a powerful drug dealer with past ties to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military leader, are setting up major drug operations in Honduras, according to American officials and worried Honduran political leaders.

title: Conference Focuses on Racial Strife
description: For almost two hours, the cacophony of lilting Caribbean accents, Brooklynese and the audible influences of Spanish and Asian languages filled the auditorium at the Pratt Institute as 70 Brooklyn community leaders sought ways to reduce racial and ethnic tensions.

title: Lutes of Many Lands
description: Lutes of Arabia, China and Iran will be presented tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street (362-8719). Simon Shaheen will play the Arab oud, Tang Liang-Xing will play the Chinese pipa and Dariush Dolat-Shahi will play the Persian setar and tar, all lutes of various shapes and tunings, in a concert presented by the World Music Institute (206-1050). Tickets are $12.

title: Retail Sales Rose 0.5% In January
description: In a report that many economists found reassuring, the Government said today that retail sales throughout the country climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in January and that December's sales, upon revision, were considerably higher than first estimated.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone Gets Client And Reports Profit Rise
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., Chicago, has won the account for the Chicago-based United States League of Savings Institutions over four local agencies and the incumbent, Metacom, New York. A national campaign is scheduled to begin this spring. The budget is $5 million. Foote, Cone yesterday reported a 37 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings. It said it had earned $5.6 million, or $1.30 a share, compared with $4.1 million, or 98 cents a share, in the 1986 quarter. Revenues rose 20 percent, to a record $104.1 million, from $86.9 million.

title: A&W BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results include the operations of Squirtco from its acquisition Dec. 17, 1986. Results for 1986 exclude Country Time and Vernors sales because A&W's licensing agreement fom Country Time took effect Jan. 1, 1987, and Vernors Inc. was acquired Oct. 20, 1987.

title: Scientists Urge Huge Project To Chart All Human Genes
description: An expert committee of the National Research Council said yesterday that the United States should immediately begin a 15-year effort to diagram and describe in detail the chemical language of all the possibly 100,000 human genes.

title: Polysar Spurns Bid
description: The Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation said it had rejected as inadequate an increased offer of $16 a share (Canadian), or about $12.60 (American), for its 13 million shares by the Nova Corporation of Calgary, Alberta. The new bid, raised from a previous offer of $14 a share, raises to about $163 million the total offer for the common shares, which would increase Nova's stake in Polysar to 31 percent from 10 percent.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE DRAFTING CONVENTION AGAINST MERCENARIES - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Battle Begins For Control Of Gillette
description: A complex battle for control of the Gillette Company broke out yesterday with the disclosure by Coniston Partners of New York that it owned about 6 percent of the big Boston-based producer of razor blades, cosmetics and other consumer goods.

title: Olympia Increases Stake in Santa Fe
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, has increased its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to 10.54 percent, from 10.3 percent. Olympia said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it expected to buy more Santa Fe shares.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Shot in School Cafeteria
description: A teen-age boy drew a gun in a fight in a high school cafeteria today and shot two teachers and a student before fleeing, officials said. One of the teachers, Richard Allen, was shot in the head. He was reported in serious condition in the hospital. The other teacher, who was shot in the abdomen and thigh, and the student, who suffered leg wounds, were reported in stable condition at another hospital.

title: Advertising; Jordache to Broadcast Its New Commercials
description: Jordache, a maker of jeans and casual clothes, will begin airing its latest 10- and 30-second television spots on Monday. The half-dozen spots, created in-house, will continue to aim at the teen-age audience with the tagline ''Jordache Basics - Because Life . . . Is Not.''

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Another Quake in California
description: A strong earthquake rocked a wide area of Southern California today, injuring at least 25 people and bringing on a fatal heart attack but apparently causing little damage.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; 71 Stakes Races Granted Higher Status
description: Is American racing getting better all the time? Apparently so, in the opinion of the committee that classifies the nation's most important stakes races. The North American Graded Stakes Committee recently published its listing of this year's top races, and changed the status of 76 of them: 71 were upgraded and 5 were downgraded.

title: JAN BELL MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Youth Gets 5 to 15 Years For Howard Beach Attack
description: After publicly expressing sorrow, a white teen-ager was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison for his part in the attack that led to the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: 10 Elected to Academy
description: John McPhee, Cynthia Ozick and Reynolds Price are among 10 leading cultural figures who have been elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. The other new members, whose names were announced yesterday, are Alex Katz, the painter and printmaker; Elmer Bischoff and Giorgio Cavallon, painters; Francis Thorne, the composer, and Raymond Carver, Leslie Fiedler and Evan S. Connell, writers. They will be inducted May 18 in a ceremony at the organization's Manhattan headquarters.

title: Times Co. Net Up 22.1%
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that net income rose 22.1 percent, to nearly $42.5 million, or 52 cents a share, in the last three months of 1987, from $34.8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the comparable 1986 quarter. Revenues rose 7.2 percent, to $447.8 million, from $417.9 million in the 1986 period.

title: HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CREDIT MARKETS
description: Government bond prices moved slightly lower yesterday, following the release of retail sales figures for January that were stronger than had been anticipated.

title: HAIG SAID TO BE SET TO DROP FROM RACE
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. plans to quit the Republican Presidential race on Friday and endorse the candidacy of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, Republican campaign officials said tonight.

title: 'Trickster of Seville'
