description: Ever since Tirso de Molina first recorded the story of the legendary libertine Don Juan in 1630, this drama of passion, seduction and revenge has been retold many times. A new version of the 17th-century Spanish writer's ''Trickster of Seville'' will be presented in a free staged reading Monday at 7 P.M. at the C.S.C. Repertory Theater, 136 East 13th Street. The play, translated by Lynne Alvarez, directed by Carey Perloff and starring John Turturro, will be followed by a discussion. Information: 677-4210.

title: State Dept. Is Faulted on Embassy Guard Incidents
description: A preliminary investigation by the General Accounting Office, the Congressional monitoring agency, has found that the State Department failed to inform military investigators of more than 500 instances of possible wrongdoing by Marine guards at American embassies worldwide, a Congressman said today.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $12 million to adjust the realizable value of certain real estate power for both periods; year also includes a gain of $35,044,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss d-Included a charge of $72 million from the establishment of a reserve based on the estimated value of an agreement to settle litigation.

title: Susan Osborn
description: Susan Osborn, the former lead singer of the Paul Winter Consort, will be singing a mixture of gospel, folk and other popular romantic ballads, tonight at 8 o'clock at the Church of the Holy Apostle, 296 Ninth Avenue (at 28th Street). Tickets are $12. Information: 219-2527.

title: Eastern Pilots Win Ruling
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Eastern Air Lines to produce internal documents about plans to transfer any of its major assets, including its shuttle operation on the East Coast.

title: GREGG GOES TO WORK REBUILDING S.M.U.
description: Forrest Gregg said he knew it would be a daunting job to rebuild Southern Methodist University's penalized and disgraced football program when he left professional coaching last month.

title: The Larger Peril in Panama
description: It's not necessary to believe all the charges against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to know he's an abomination and that his continued rule is disastrous for Panama and dangerous to the United States. Even the Reagan Administration says so. The problem is that no one seems to have a good plan for ousting Panama's strongman. The best track for now may be to keep up the pressure and wait for Panamanians to act.

title: DEROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
THE NEW YORK TIMES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included equity in earnings of associated companies of $7,054,000 for the quarter and $17,990,000 for the year. c-Included equity in earnings of associated companies of $5,497,000 and $19,560,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The 12-month results of 1986 included a second quarter non-recurring interest charge of $8.5 million relating to a court decision arising from the company's 1981 acquisition of two cable television systems.

title: Showing by Robertson in Iowa Race Buoys Conservatives
description: Conservative political operatives, many of them privately expressing doubts that the Presidential candidacy of their standard bearer, Representative Jack F. Kemp, will survive, saw hope for their cause today in Pat Robertson's surprising second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; G.A.O.'s Best Sellers
description: The General Accounting Office, a perennial scourge of waste and fraud in Government programs, investigates almost every Federal activity, from ''Star Wars'' to Congressional cafeterias.

title: Dining Out Guide: Pasta
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants reviewed in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHELSEA TRATTORIA ITALIANA, 108 Eighth Avenue, near 16th Street (924-7786) - **(Aug. 7, 1987) The brick and whitewashed dining room is tidy and calm at this friendly and easygoing restaurant that serves some stellar pastas. The menu is notable for the chef's pure and understated approach. The pasta options include agnolotti stuffed with ricotta cheese and spinach with pesto sauce; fettuccine with wild mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes; tagliolini with a tomato-based arrabbiata sauce spiked with garlic and hot green peppers; whole-wheat pasta with raw tomato sauce and basil, and fettuccine with fresh vegetables. Pastas: $11 to $14. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. POSITANO, 250 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street (777-6211) - **(Jan. 25, 1985) A three-tiered dining area with green marble tables and high-toned Italian design provides the backdrop for some superior pastas at this bustling and informal restaurant. The menu features cappellini putanesca, which is thin pasta with a sauce of tomatoes, olives and capers; cheese ravioli with tomatoes and cream sauce; radiator-shaped pastas with homemade sausage and cream sauce, and farfalle, a bow-tie pasta, with broccoli, sun-dried tomatoes, black olives, garlic and olive oil. Pastas: $13.50 to $14. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; closed Sundays. REMI, 323 East 79th Street (744-4272) - **(Nov. 13, 1987) This new East Side restaurant combines a striking setting, attentive service and distinctive food. The dining room is peach-toned with indirect lighting from ceiling beams, and gondola oars crisscrossed overhead. Some of the best pastas in town can be found on the changing menu. Among the specials are macaroni with duck breast, tomato and rosemary; farfalle tossed with mixed vegetables and shiitake mushrooms; small shells in a sauce with fresh fennel and sweet sausage, and fusilli tossed with cubes of smoked bacon and grilled radicchio in a light cream sauce. Pastas: $15. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 11 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M. TOSCANA RISTORANTE, 200 East 54th Street (371-8144) - **(Sept. 4, 1987) A dynamic spot worth visiting both for its evocative design and for the food is this Tuscan-style Italian veteran that moved into new quarters last year. The ultra-stylish modern decor is reminiscent of a luxury liner. Several of the pastas excel. If it's available, try the special of taglierini smothered in a voluptuous lamb ragout. Other good options are thin cheese-filled ravioli with zucchini flowers, baby zucchini and diced vegetables in a clear broth. Fettuccine with shrimp and radicchio in a smoky tomato sauce; angel-hair pasta, a special, tossed with eggplant, tomato, fresh basil and little cubes of mozzarella, and green fettuccine with scallops and spinach. Pastas: $18. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C24.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds increased $2.76 billion, to $278.03 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $1.65 billion, to $82.33 billion. Assets of the 208 general purpose funds were up $305.7 million, to $81.4 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds' assets rose $801.7 million, to $114.29 billion.

title: Painless Tax for New York Commuters
description: In search of ways to close New York City's projected budget gap, Mayor Koch asks the State Legislature to double the tax surcharge on commuters who work in the city.

title: CHAUS, BERNARD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income

title: Troops Kill Palestinian Youth
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian youth at the Tulkarm refugee center in the West Bank today, an army spokesman said. The shooting brought the unofficial death toll to at least 54 in more than two months of violence in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARARA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $900,000. The latest quarter net reflects a $1.6 million loss on the sale of loans and securities and a $750,000 benefit from an adjustment to a provision for income taxes. The year-ago quarter net reflects $10.3 million of gains on the sale of loans and securities.

title: Del Norte Funding Begins Offering
description: The Del Norte Funding Corporation is offering $200 million of secured lease obligation bonds in three tranches through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & company. All the bonds are priced at par and are guaranteed by leases from the El Paso Funding Corporation, a unit of the El Paso Electric Company.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A WEEKEND FOR LOVERS, PRESIDENTS AND DRAGONS
description: THE first great multi-holiday weekend has arrived. Thanks to a highly improbable convergence of several usually scattered midwinter holidays, Valentine's Day, the birthdays of America's first and 16th Presidents (now telescoped into a single, generic President's Day), and the warm-up to both Chinese New Year's and Mardi Gras (or Carnival) have all found themselves squeezed onto this weekend's calendar.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Roger Feuerman, Robert Tabor, Doreen Fox, Stephanie Pierson and Tino Pelino have been named senior vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates, part of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc.

title: RANGERS SINK; CAPITALS 5, RANGERS 3
description: It was as if the prospect of climbing closer to a playoff spot induced vertigo. The Rangers stumbled miserably at the start and collapsed typically at the finish in a 5-3 loss to the Capitals last night.

title: EHRLICH BOBER FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Women in the Law Aren't Yet Equal Partners
description: Like most major law firms in the early 1970's, Rogers & Wells resembled an elegant men's club, and the Manhattan firm had only one female associate among its 95 lawyers in 1971. A recruiting manual listed attractions like a villa on a Florida golf course and a private barbershop providing free haircuts.

description: b-Includes a charge of $12 million after-tax resulting from creation of new subsidiary. c-Net income

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1.4 million and $3.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively; a loss of $6.7 million and $32.6 million for the same periods, respectively, from the early redemption of debt; the year also includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $24.3 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $600,000 and $8.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also includes an $8 million gain on the sale of discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $6.7 million. Latest year net from continuing operations includes after-tax profit of $34.4 million from the sale of Avco Financial Sevices credit card receivables. Prior-year net from continuing operations includes an $18.9 million gain from the sale of certain receivables and corporate investments.

title: Recital: Dawn Upshaw
description: A TALENTED singer, like a great impostor, learns how to switch personalities, not merely clothes or facial expressions, to suit the occasion. The remarkable soprano Dawn Upshaw demonstrated such ability at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening in two successive, drastically different vocal dramas. Miss Upshaw, one of the Metropolitan Opera's most promising young artists, moved with astonishing ease and success from the hothouse passions of ''La Bonne Chanson'' by Faure to the extroverted wit of ''The Ugly Duckling, Part One'' by Jon Deak. If she had changed costumes at intermission, one might have thought she was two different singers.

title: Sparse Turnout at Koch Meeting on Pensions
description: Notably less confrontational, Mayor Koch met with a small group of New York City legislators yesterday to try to persuade them not to support a measure to increase pensions for former city and state workers.

title: UNUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $300,000 and $9.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The quarter also includes a $10.6 million after- tax restructuring provision, pretax charges of $11.5 million from a cost-reduction program, and $18 million from discontinuance of new sales of traditional medical policies as of March 1, 1988. c-Includes realized gains of $1 million for the quarter, and for the year includes capital gains of $13.9 million. The company went public in November 1986.

title: Brandenburg Ensemble
description: The Brandenburg Ensemble, conducted by Alexander Schneider, will perform works by Bach, Vivaldi and Handel on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. The pianist Peter Serkin will be the soloist. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: 'Deep Scars' for a Jerusalem Where Riots Define Borders
description: Even after Arab youths smashed the picture window in her living room for the second time, Laureen Rabbe was surprised by the violence that encroached on her suburban home.

description: FRIDAY TWO POETS AT THE GAS STATION

title: Wallace R. Cotton, 64, Supreme Court Justice
description: Justice Wallace R. Cotton of State Supreme Court died of melanoma, or skin cancer, Wednesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ethiopian Troops Said to Kill 20 at Aid Center
description: Ethiopian troops killed 20 people on Monday when thousands of drought victims at a food relief center in a northern region refused to leave for resettlement, Western relief officials and an Ethiopian rebel said today.

title: Future of South Africa Should Be Determined by All Its Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Simon Puts His Hope On Party's Traditions
description: It was late in the day near the end of a grueling week, but Senator Paul Simon stood ramrod straight before a group of New Hampshire residents and pleaded guilty to the charge of being ''an old-fashioned Democrat.''

HON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2

title: Lorimar Reports $19 Million Loss
description: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation said today that it had lost $19.2 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, largely because of a $22 million reserve for possible losses in its scandal-ridden home video subsidiary.

title: Alfred S. Eichner Is Dead at 50; Major Post-Keynesian Economist
description: Alfred S. Eichner, a leading member of the post-Keynesian school of economics and a professor at Rutgers University, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Closter, N.J., where he lived. He was 50 years old.

title: 8 in French Terror Group Get 10-Year Terms
description: Eight members of the terrorist group Direct Action were sentenced today to 10 years each in prison, the maximum term, on charges of criminal conspiracy.

title: Toyota Considers Exporting Planes
description: Toyota Motor Sales USA is working on a plan that could result in the export of small airplanes to East Asia. Brian Barents, a Toyota vice president hired recently from the Cessna Aircraft Company of Wichita, Kan., said the potential deal would help reduce the United States' trade imbalance with East Asia.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $7.8 million. c-Net loss and includes special charges of $159.3 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Kaisertech Units
description: Kaisertech Ltd., the holding company for the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, said that it had agreed to sell the rest of its chemicals assets to various purchasers as part of its strategy to concentrate on its aluminum business. In December, Kaiser announced its intention to sell the Harshaw/Filtrol Partnership, a specialty chemicals business, to the Engelhard Corporation. Under the agreements announced today, Kaisertech will sell industrial operations based mainly in Louisiana to newly formed LaRoche Chemicals Inc.; sell the FarBest Corporation to the Diversey Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of The Molson Companies, and sell its brine chemicals operations in Utah to the Reilly Tar and Chemical Corporation. Along with the Harshaw/Filtrol deal, the transactions are expected to net about $350 million, which will be applied to paying debt.

title: Olympics Notebook; BIATHELETE, 39, TO CARRY AMERICAN FLAG
description: Lyle Nelson of Essex, Vt., a biathlete who turned 39 years old Tuesday, was chosen today to carry the American flag in Saturday's opening ceremony of the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income The company said the net loss for the latest year was partly the result of a $113 million increase in allowances for doubtful accounts and writedown of investments in properties during the third quarter. The company also said the loss in the year-ago fourth quarter was the result of a $77 million charge to increase professional liability insurance reserves and to reflect the retroactive reversal of investment tax credits recognized in the first three quarters of 1986.

title: Black & Decker Is Backed on Bid
description: The Black & Decker Corporation announced that a group of commercial banks had arranged $2.2 billion in financing for the company's $2.1 billion hostile takeover attempt of American Standard Inc. The syndicate comprises 19 domestic and foreign banks, including Chase Manhattan Bank, which earlier pledged $750 million of its own funds toward the deal, the company said.

title: About New York; Where Are You? A Nameless Man In a Grim World
description: Where are you? You weren't at the subway stop this morning. Our mutual friend hasn't seen you either. She's the one you touched by saying, ''You certainly look beautiful today -but then you always do.'' She would try to pass you by, and you would say something like that, and turn her on her heel.

title: 2 SOVIET WARSHIPS REPORTEDLY BUMP U.S. NAVY VESSELS
description: Two Soviet Navy vessels deliberately bumped two United States warships in the Black Sea today as the American vessels sailed through waters claimed by the Soviet Union, the Pentagon said.

title: ZEUS COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a tax credit of $586,000.

title: RAYMOND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Margaret M. Heyman; Professor, 77
description: Margaret M. Heyman, a social worker and retired professor at Hunter College who researched industrial programs on alcoholism, died of a cerebral hemorrhage last Sunday at New York Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Anthony Streuli, 43, A CBS News Producer
description: Anthony Streuli, a longtime newsman for CBS who was in New Hampshire directing the network's coverage of the presidential primary, died in his hotel room today, the network announced. He was 43 years old. Mr. Streuli had been the Boston producer for CBS News since April 1986. He joined the radio network as a newswriter in 1969, and worked on the CBS Morning News and CBS Evening News programs and as assistant bureau chief in London.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1 Slain in Manhattan Restaurant; Suspect Is Seized in the Shooting
description: One man was killed and another was injured when a gunman opened fire in a lower Manhattan restaurant early yesterday, the police said. A suspect was later arrested and charged in the shooting.

title: Waldheim Backer Cites Jews
description: A former Foreign Minister and close associate of President Kurt Waldheim charged today that the panel that investigated Mr. Waldheim's wartime past was filled with Socialists or Jews.

title: Guidepost
description: Yields on I.R.A.'s Bank promotions for Individual Retirement Accounts are expected to be modest this year, compared with the marketing blitz when the I.R.A. was the most popular tax deduction for middle- and upper-income taxpayers. But despite new restrictions on the deductibility of contributions, the I.R.A remains a viable savings instrument. Millions of taxpayers will still qualify for the deduction; others may want to continue saving in an I.R.A. so that dividends or interest will accumulate tax-free. Typically, institutions offer I.R.A. certificates of deposit at rates that are one-quarter to one-half a percentage point higher than their regular C.D. rates. title: The Dance: Ohio Ballet in 'Solstice'
description: Heinz Poll, the Ohio Ballet's artistic director, not only choreographs for his company, he also commissions ballets from guest choreographers and encourages his dancers to do choreography of their own. David Shimotakahara, one of those dancers, was the creator of ''Solstice,'' which received its New York premiere Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. In both its strengths and weaknesses, it was just the sort of work one expects of this company from Akron.

title: Business Inventories Rose A Sharp 0.8% in December
description: Business inventories jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, reflecting a backlog of unsold products, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Maize-Products Co., Stamford, Conn., said it had canceled its proposed purchase of U.S. Tobacco's dry snuff business.

title: Concert: Tokyo Quartet Presents More Beethoven
description: Not least among the 92d Street Y's recent complete traversals of this and that is its current Beethoven quartet cycle with the Tokyo String Quartet, the second concert of which took place Wednesday night.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest third quarter and 9-months results include a gain on investments of $5.6 million resulting primarily from the initial public offering of stock in the company's subsidiary, Tempest Technologies Inc.

title: HILB, ROGAL & HAMILTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Your Money Financial Safety For Job Holders
description: LEAD: Since the stock market collapsed in October, many workers on and off Wall Street have become worried that they could lose their jobs soon. Financial planners generally urge people to bolster their savings so that they can weather a period of unemployment, and they especially recommend that workers whose jobs are in imminent danger take extra precautions.

title: U.S. Bonds Post a Sharp Decline
description: Treasury bond prices closed sharply lower yesterday after a session marked by an extreme swing in market sentiment.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results for an accounting change.

title: Campeau Threatens Suit in Takeover Bid
description: Putting additional pressure on Federated Department Stores to surrender to its takeover offer, the Campeau Corporation yesterday warned Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the No. 1 firm in leveraged buyouts, that it would sue if the firm entered into arrangements with Federated calling for ''breakup'' fees or ''lock-ups'' as part of a leveraged buyout.

title: ROOSEVELT FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $4,899,000. c-Included tax credits of $1,488,000 for the quarter and $6,798,000 for the year. There were no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company went public in January 1987.

title: Iran Gulf Raid Kills a Dane
description: An Iranian helicopter firing rockets and machine guns attacked a Danish supertanker in the Persian Gulf today, shipping executives said. They said a Danish seaman was killed and three others wounded. A spokesman for the owner, A. P. Moller of Copenhagen, said the attack crippled the 390,000-ton Kate Maersk. The crew quarters, bridge and radio room were severely damaged.

title: A Wise Court Salutes Tolerance
description: Homosexuals may not be kept out of the Army; their claims for equal protection under the Constitution are as strong as those of blacks and stronger than those the Supreme Court has ever recognized for women. So concludes the U.S. Court of Appeals on the West Coast.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Jersey Housing Lottery Makes Hundreds Happy
description: At 7 A.M. yesterday, an ecstatic John Galea was the first to arrive. He was two hours early.

title: Salinas: 'Let's Be More Open'
description: The paradox of Mexico is that it tries so hard and makes so much progress but always seems stuck on the treadmill of debt, unemployment and overpopulation.

title: Mexico, After Reagan and de la Madrid
description: The mini-summit meeting today between Presidents Miguel de la Madrid and Ronald Reagan at Mazatlan is the last encounter of two men who have learned to get along but not to understand each other. It also marks the end of the Reagan era in Mexican-American relations, a time of tensions and misunderstandings, resentment and deterioration on almost every item of the two nations' agenda.

title: Stage: 'Faithful Servant,' A Mild Joe Orton Work
description: The bite and twist of Joe Orton are present in ''The Good and Faithful Servant,'' which he wrote for British television shortly before his murder in 1967, but the plot is not twisty enough to surprise and the bite is not all that biting. The title character is one-armed Buchanan, whom we meet as he is about to be retired after 50 years ''in charge of the main entrance.'' His grandest memory is of once holding the door for the company's head, his proudest moment having his picture in the company's magazine.

title: Dallas Medical School: Fortunes Shift
description: In 1952, the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center was a struggling medical school - on probation, bereft of financing, abandoned by most its faculty and housed in shabby buildings that had once been military barracks.

title: Concert: Philharmonic In 'Sacre du Printemps'
description: A concert entirely made up of Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 and Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps'' may not be everyone's idea of judiciously balanced programming, but it is certain to give the eardrums a workout. Zubin Mehta, who conducted the New York Philharmonic in just such a program of Russian blockbusters on Thursday evening, could not salvage much out of the Tchaikovsky, which Alexander Toradze alternately brutalized and sentimentalized as the soloist. But the Philharmonic and its music director delivered the night from total disappointment with a ''Sacre'' of irresistible momentum and visceral excitement.

title: Adirondack Post Office Is Just Like Home
description: LEAD: If she were a contestant on ''What's My Line,'' Joan Reynolds might stump the stars.

title: Financier Avoids Jail in Deal to Aid Homeless
description: The financier Victor Posner avoided a jail sentence today on Federal tax evasion charges when he agreed to spend $3 million to help homeless men, women and children in south Florida and to devote 20 hours a week for five years to working with them.

title: Jazz: Buddy Tate at 72
description: Long ago, the tenor saxophonist Buddy Tate reached the point where every set of his deserved to be recorded. He's made an art out of unpredictability: at age 72, his solos have a feeling of wildness to them; they career into raunchy lower-register honks, then climb woozily into silvery squeaks, pushing the upper limits of his horn. His tone shifts constantly, from a puffy, hangover-in-the-morning growl to a loud rasp, and his phrases, taking off and landing at will around the beat, defy the lazyness of symmetry. There's nothing complacent about his music: it is still dangerous.

title: CAVALIERS BEAT NETS ON 35 OF 47 FOUL SHOTS
description: Ron Harper scored 28 points, and the Cleveland Cavaliers outscored the New Jersey Nets, 35-6, from the free-throw line to win, 98-96, tonight.

title: Prelate in Seattle Dispute Named Pittsburgh Bishop
description: Bishop Donald W. Wuerl, a conservative cleric whose appointment to share power with Seattle's liberal archbishop in 1985 angered some Roman Catholics, was installed today as leader of the Diocese of Pittsburgh.

title: LOCAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a charge of $374,000 from the prepayment of debt for the quarter, and the 6 months is after a $467,000 extraordinary charge. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months includes provisions for loan losses of $3,048,000 and $4,577,000, respectively, compared with similar provisions in the year-earlier quarter and 6 months of $333,000 and $626,000, respectively.

description: b-After a loss of $305,000 for the quarter and net of $443,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and a gain on the disposal of operations of $3,609,000 for the both periods.

title:
Patents;
Stretchable Sheets
description: LEAD: Sidney M. Weiss of New York reports that hospitals and nursing homes are adding pads to mattresses to provide skin care. As a result conventional sheets do not fit. He was granted patent 4,723,331 this week for a stretchable knitted sheet that serves as a bedcover, accommodating the pads. The patent is assigned to Sleep-Knit International, of Greenwich, Conn., which manufactures the knitted sheets.

title: INSIDE
description: Massachusetts U. Protest

title: Arizona Senators Sworn In
description: Despite a request by Gov. Evan Mecham of Arizona that his impeachment trial be delayed, the State Senate is moving ahead with the proceedings. Chief Justice Frank X. Gordon Jr. of the Arizona Supreme Court swore in the 30 Senate members Thursday as impeachment judges and took the oath as presiding officer of the trial, which is scheduled to begin Feb. 22. Mr. Mecham said on a radio talk show that he wanted the impeachment trial delayed until after his criminal trial on charges of concealing a campaign loan.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $639,000 for the quarter and $2,086,000 for the year, extraordinary charges of $2,766,000 for the quarter and extraordinary credits of $5,403,000 for the year, and a credit of $6 million from cumulative effect of an accounting change for both periods. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $397,000 for the quarter and $725,000 for the year, and extraordinary charges of $10,766,000 and $9,483,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: UNREST STIFFENS RESOLVE OF JEW AND ARAB ALIKE
description: Far from Flatbush, where her marriage proposal was conditional on the great adventure of migration to biblical Judea, Pauline Moskowitz said her husband is recovering now, his skull but not his spirit fractured by Palestinian stone throwers.

title: Haig Drops Campaign for Presidency And Gives His Endorsement to Dole
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. abandoned his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination today and endorsed Senator Bob Dole, saying that Mr. Dole ''is head and shoulders above George Bush.''

title: Panama Envoy Quits, Assailing Military Rule
description: A senior Panamanian diplomat resigned today, saying he could no longer work in good conscience for a government ''characterized by corruption, illegitimacy and dishonesty.''

title: PULASKI FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
Belgian Ends Societe Generale Role
description: In a dramatic turnaround, the Belgian entrepreneur Andre Leysen today abruptly dropped out of the battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company, after 3 of his 18 partners refused to ratify his plan for expanded control.

title: HOCKEY SPOTLIGHT SHUNNED
description: Suddenly everybody wants to be a hockey underdog in the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Thursday about police theories concerning a $6 million theft at a Manhattan art gallery incorrectly described the Art Theft Archives, a list of 28,000 stolen art works compiled under the auspices of the International Foundation for Art Research. The list is not computerized.

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest fourth quarter figures include Purolator Courier Corp.'s U.S. Courier operations. The company also said the latest year results include Purolator's operations from April 29, the date Emery acquired 83 percent of the company. The latest fourth quarter and year results reflect the competitive nature of the industry, as well as the costs associated with the Purolator acquisition.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $5,517,000 and $6,023,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the quarter and $67,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary gains of $210,000 and $1,510,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Taiwan Bars Rice Pact
description: Taiwan will not renew a five-year rice agreement with the United States when it expires at the end of 1988 because the accord is ''unfair and unnecessary,'' Koh Chin-chao, deputy chairman of the Council of Agriculture, said this week. The accord limited Taiwan's total rice exports to 1.375 million tons from 1984 to 1988. The agreement was signed in February 1984 after Washington threatened to restrict its imports of Taiwan products, including textiles.

title: Rumania, Faulted by West, Returns Aide to U.N.
description: The Rumanian Government, which has been strongly criticized by Western governments for its human rights record, unexpectedly allowed one of its citizens to return to his United Nations post in Geneva today after confining him to Rumania for over two years.

title: Dravo Chairman's Illness
description: The Dravo Corporation's chairman and president, William G. Roth, 49 years old, suffered a heart attack and will be absent for eight to ten weeks, the company said Thursday. Thomas J. Ward, whom the board elevated from senior vice president to lead the natural resources company temporarily, said that Mr. Roth was making good progress and was expected to return to his normal activities. Dravo this week reported a 1987 net loss of $126.5 million, after taking a fourth-quarter charge of $76.6 million for the cost of discontinuing its engineering, construction and waste-to-energy businesses.

title: KEY RATES
DANIEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''People get turned on by an emotional campaign. Robertson's campaign is emotional.

title: A Vilified Vanguard
description: To the Editor:

title: Islander Defense Takes the Night Off
description: After the 6-2 loss tonight to the Capitals, the doors to the Islander locker room remained closed for 20 minutes. When an ashen Terry Simpson finally emerged, he insisted the meeting's unusual length was not an indication of particular displeasure or panic.

title: I.B.M. to Raise Computer Rents
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would raise the monthly rental and lease charges on all of its computers and the maintenance fees on some of its mainframe computers by 7 percent, effective June 1. I.B.M. said it had also raised the hourly service rates charged by its national service division by 15 percent, effective today. Equipment rentals and other services account for a small portion of I.B.M.'s sales, about $3.3 billion out of a total of more than $54 billion in 1987. Its maintanence revenues totaled $7.7 billion last year.

title: 'Hope and Glory' Succeeding Despite Slow Start
description: Over the last two years John Boorman, the writer and director of ''Hope and Glory,'' has faced a multitude of problems, first in financing that film, then in keeping it afloat after a change in management at Columbia Pictures. Yet the movie has managed to survive in a competitive marketplace, and Mr. Boorman has spent the last month accepting awards or, as he put it, ''trekking around the world collecting strangely shaped objects.'' The awards, Mr. Boorman said, are ''curiously contorted pieces of glass'' that ''share a certain tackiness.''

title: Skaters' Appeal Rejected
description: The United States Olympic Committee today denied the appeal of a speed skater, David Cruikshank, and two teammates who challenged their team's selection process.

title: HOME BENEFICIAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital losses of $26,331 for the latest year and $35,886 for the year-earlier period.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE INDIANA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on fuel settlement of $52 million and a gain from an accounting change of $42.4 million. c-Net loss and after a charge from nuclear project loss of $140.9 million.

title: KERKHOFF INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $265,000. The company went public in October 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PROGRAM STRESSES PRENATAL CARE IN EFFORT TO REDUCE PREMATURITY
description: Nancy Sherman's first child, a boy, was born on Dec. 2, 1986, and lived for two hours. Her second, another boy, was born on June 2, 1987, and died in a Bronx emergency room after one hour of life.

title: Museums Need Space to Grow
description: LEAD: Not until I finally testified before the Board of Estimate in behalf of the Guggenheim Museum's proposed annex did I understand the esthetic fervor lurking behind opposition to it - as well as protests against growth at the Whitney and other museums across the United States. Like everyone else, I had been led to think that the opposition was both loyal and sane, grounded in concern over zoning violations and the sanctity of neighborhoods.

title: Steel Group Seeks Renewed Quotas
description: President Reagan's program of voluntarily restraining steel imports has been a success and a decision to renew it should be made promptly, the steel industry said in a statement today.

title: Sakaide Journal; In the Other Japan, a Bridge Is a Two-Way Street
description: Japan's Inland Sea is sometimes called the Aegean of the East. On calm days, it is an emerald mirror, embossed with many hundreds of dark, thickly wooded islands across its 300-mile length.

title: PRESTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time tax benefit of $5,753,000, or $1.00 a share, as a result of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standard 96.

title: OUSTED CALIFORNIA JUDGE IN CENTER OF NEW STORM
description: Since the California voters ousted Rose Elizabeth Bird as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court in 1986, she has not shied away from controversy.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included a $200,000, or 2 cents a share, gain from the sale of land in Portland, Ore. The latest year included a $923,000, or 9 cents a share, gain from the sale of land and office property at three locations. The year-ago quarter earnings were reduced by $315,000, or 3 cents a share, from tax changes, and included a $336,000, or 3 cents a share, gain from a reduction of LIFO inventories. The 1986 results were reduced by $1,350,000, or 13 cents a share, resulting from the settlement of a patent infringement suit. All share earnings were adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 1, 1988.

title: More Children Must File And the Bill Will Be Higher
description: For the nation's youth, this tax filing season is a turning point: Legions of children who never had to file a return before will be drafted into the ranks of the country's 105 million filers. And children of all ages, from toddlers to college students, will be subjected to very different and harsher tax treatment.

title: Mr. Gephardt's Reckless Driving
description: Richard Gephardt is campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination in a misused car. A Hyundai costs $10,000 in America, he says, but a comparable Chrysler K car would cost $48,000 in South Korea because Seoul slaps on ''nine separate tariffs.'' Mr. Gephardt's wrong-way stance on trade policy has led him to abuse the facts.

title: Palestinian Gets 30 Years for Rome Airport Attack
description: A confessed Palestinian gunman was convicted and sentenced to a 30-year prison term today for his part in the Rome airport attack in 1985 in which 16 people died. Two other defendants, including the Palestinian guerrilla leader known as Abu Nidal, were sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment for organizing the attack.

title:
Patents;
Encouraging Rainfall
description: LEAD: A French engineer has patented a method intended to encourage the fall of rain or snow. According to patent 4,723,707, granted this week to Lebrun Xavier of Paris, one means of encouraging precipitation is to release water at the site. The equipment includes a probe for detecting clouds and other atmospheric conditions, a lightning conductor to protect the apparatus, and a computer to analyze the information gathered and help decide when to start operation.

title: Gillette Stock Off; Profit Taking Seen
description: Despite an announcement on Thursday that the investment group Coniston Partners holds a 6 percent stake in the Gillette Company, the stock yesterday fell $1.875 a share, to $39.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Many analysts attributed the drop to profit takers, who have watched their shares gain handsomely as it was rumored that someone was accumulating shares.

title: Trump Holds Stake in MCA
description: MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company, said yesterday that Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, had notified the company that he owns 375,000 MCA shares, or about $16.9 million worth, and that he may acquire up to 24.9 percent of MCA shares.

title: Europeans Agree on a Budget Overhaul
description: An emergency meeting of the leaders of the 12-nation European Community reached a laboriously negotiated agreement early today that will permit an overhaul of its finances and ease the transition to a barrier-free market by 1992.

title: Spruced-Up Calgary Is Ready to Light the Torch
description: Who could forget that first date: the tingling sensations of excitement, the nervous exhilaration, the anxiety of remembering the proper way to look, act, speak and oh-my-gosh, did I forget aOything?

title: OGLEBAY NORTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the year is after a $373,000 loss from the early retirement of debt.

title: In a Weapons Race, Much Can Go Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniels Suspended
description: The Topeka Sizzlers of the Continental Basketball Association have suspended Lloyd Daniels, the former New York City high school star, for the rest of the season because he failed to get into playing condition and had not participated in a drug rehabilitation program. Daniels, 20 years old, pleaded guilty last summer to a misdemeanor charge of attempting to possess cocaine. He voluntarily submitted to a drug test Jan. 28 and was placed on the injured list. The Sizzlers' owner, Bernie Glannon, said he had not received the test results, but he was concerned that Daniels had not attended appointments as part of a drug rehabilitation program at a Topeka hospital. Daniels, who averaged 16 points in 29 games, said he planned to return to New York and file for the National Basketball Association draft this spring.

title: Gannett-Cowles
description: The Gannett Company, the diversified media company that publishes USA Today, said it had sold its 640,492 shares of the Cowles Media Company back to Cowles for $200 a share, or $128 million. Gannett had acquired the shares of the Minneapolis-based concern in 1985 for about $83 million. Most of the stake had been acquired in connection with Gannett's acquisition of The Des Moines Register, The Jackson (Tenn.) Sun and two Iowa weeklies from The Register and Tribune Company. Gannett said that Federal Communications Commission regulations had required it to hold the stock in trust because of its ownership of a television station in Minneapolis.

title: Bank Wary On Dollar
description: The Bank of England said this week that the recent fall of the United States dollar was likely to prove more important to the world economy than the October stock market collapse.

title: Getting Smaller
description: The first game is three months away, but already the ranks of the International Basketball Association, the league for players 6 feet 4 inches and shorter, have been diminished. The league has suffered the loss of one team and the movement of another one that is having trouble keeping its head above water. On Thursday, the Toronto franchise announced it was moving to Buffalo because of what the team's owner, Ruby Richman, called the difference in currency values. The American dollar is worth about $1.26 in Canadian currency, and Richman said the change ''could mean the difference between the team breaking even and making money or losing money.'' Yesterday, the Fresno Flames folded after General Manager Al Geller said the team was $75,000 in debt,and that Coach Ted Owens had not received a single paycheck. Geller said that the club's owner, John O'Donnell, had not paid the team's bills since the organization was formed last May. O'Donnell, a Newport Beach, Calif., businessman, said his losses in the stock market and other investments prompted his decision to fold the team, which reduced the league to eight teams.

title: Film: Justine Bateman in 'Satisfaction'
description: ''Hey, guys!'' That's Justine Bateman talking down and dirty as the lead singer of a female rock group called ''Mystery'' that tries to be the Bangles of the working class. There is one drug-addicted guitarist, one man-crazy guitarist, a thieving drummer and a token male keyboard player -a last-minute replacement who switches from Chopin to rock in a day. Only in Hollywood.

title: Nevada County Is Held Illegal
description: The formation of Bullfrog County, an unpopulated expanse of scrubland created to help the state win Federal dollars, violates the State Constitution, a judge has ruled.

title: Better Ties Brighten U.S.-Mexican Summit Today
description: President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid are to meet here Saturday with relations between the United States and Mexico smoother than at any time since they took office at the start of the decade.

title: MMI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Found in Contempt, Landlord Begins a Term in His Building
description: A Brooklyn landlord began serving a court-ordered stay in one of his neglected apartment buildings yesterday, a sentence imposed to give him a dose of his tenants' drab reality: leaky pipes, cold rooms, bold mice, falling plaster.

title: The Afghan Future: With Soviet Pullout Offer, the Talks Build Momentum
description: The Soviet Union's proposal for a 10-month withdrawal of its 115,000 troops from Afghanistan has plunged the United States, Pakistan and the Afghan guerrillas into intensive negotiations with one another over the wisdom of demanding that a coalition government be established in Kabul before an agreement is signed.

title: Don't Give Mice AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDOVER CONTROLS reports earnings for 16wks to Jan 10
Post and Unions To Hold Session On Cost-Cutting
description: Officials of The New York Post and the leaders of its 10 unions will meet Monday to discuss $24 million in cost cuts that Rupert Murdoch, the owner, calls mandatory if the paper is to be sold to a real-estate developer and not closed next Friday.

title: Gephardt Received 2 Unsecured Loans
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt's Presidential campaign and political action committee received unusual, unsecured loans totaling $200,000 in 1986 and 1987 from two banks whose top officers now hold key positions on Mr. Gephardt's campaign.

title: INTERNATIONAL AMERICAN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $239,000 and $1,007,000 for the latest 9 months and year-earlier period, respectively, from the sale of land acquired for investment and resale, and charges of $328,000 for the latest 9 months and $81,000 for the year-earlier period from a proposed debenture offering and acquisitions not consummated. The company said year-ago quarter and 9-month share earnings are retroactively adjusted for the additional shares issued under the Porten Sullivan acquisition agreement as of March 31, 1987.

title: Many Sources Finance Gifts To Neediest
description: Back in April 1986, the Rev. Fleming P. Rutledge was hit by a taxicab while crossing the street near his office at Grace Church at 802 Broadway, near 11th Street, in Manhattan.

title: College Dismisses 2 Physicists Who Disputed Reactor Safety
description: Two health physicists who complained about the safety of a nuclear reactor at the Georgia Institute of Technology have been dismissed by school officials, who said the moves were part of a program to improve safety and productivity.

title: LACANA MINING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $570,000 and $1,979,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
More Olympic Coverage For TV Dish Owners
description: Television viewers with dish antennas able to receive signals directly from satellites can see far more of the Winter Olympic Games than is broadcast by ABC. While 94 hours of network programming is scheduled from Calgary, Alberta, starting today and running through Feb. 28, satellites will carry a total of 550 hours of Olympic events.

title: Cordero Returns To Aqueduct Stage
description: Since Wednesday, Jose Santos had held the spotlight at Aqueduct as he became only the second jockey in New York thoroughbred history withU10 winners over two days. Yesterday, he dropped off center stage by failing to win in his seven races.

title: Refunds Bigger On '87 Returns
description: Fewer Americans are rushing to file their Federal income tax returns this year as they grapple with the new rules of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Returns are due by April 15. For taxpayers who have filed early, however, the average refund is up almost 20 percent from last year, the Internal Revenue Service said this week.

title: INFORMATION RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pentagon Revises Result of 'Star Wars' Experiment
description: The previously reported failure of part of a ''Star Wars'' experiment this week was a partial success, but a previously reported success was flawed.

title: Gerber to Shut Unit
description: The Gerber Products Company of Fremont, Mich., said it would close its trucking subsidiary, CW Transport Inc. of Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., because its management had been unable to secure financing for a leveraged buyout and no other acceptable offer for the company had been received. Closing of the company and its operating subsidiaries will put 1,500 people out of work. Gerber said funds have already been set aside to cover the company's liquidation costs.

title: SOO LINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $73 million charge from reductions in employment and freight equipment.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave (Tiger) Williams, the National Hockey League's career penalty leader, has been placed on waivers by the Hartford Whalers. Williams, 34 years old, has a career total to 3,966 minutes in penalties. . . . Doctors in Erie, Pa., have advised John Bowen, the Gannon University forward who is one of the leading rebounders in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division II, not to play basketball again this season because of a mild stroke. The 6-foot-8-inch Bowen was averaging 15.9 points and 12.7 rebounds per game when he was stricken Feb. 1. Doctors believe a blood clot that formed in his left leg caused him to become dizzy and suffer a temporary vision loss. . . . Orel Hershiser underwent surgery for appendicitis yesterday and will be about a week late reporting to spring training, the Los Angeles Dodgers announced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-6, 28 Two Soviet Navy vessels bumped two United States warships in the Black Sea as the American vessels sailed through waters claimed by the Soviet Union, prompting a diplomatic protest from the Reagan Administration. Page 1 Evidence of drug trafficking by the Panamanian leader appears to have been overlooked by the Drug Enforcement Administration in exchange for Panama's help in investigating other drug cases, officials said. 1 A Panamanian diplomat resigned, saying he could no longer work for a regime ''characterized by corruption.'' The diplomat was Lawrence Chewning Fabrega, Panama's minister-counselor to the Organization of American States. 5 A rift in Israel's governing coalition intensified as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir angrily accused Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of trying to ''sabotage'' his attempts at peace in the occupied territories. 1 In Rome, a Palestinian gunman was sentenced to a 30-year prison term for his part in the Rome airport attack in 1985 in which 16 people were killed. Two others were sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment as organizers of the attack. 3 Members of a French terrorist group were sentenced to 10 years each in prison for criminal conspiracy. They were members of the group Direct Action, which has claimed responsibility for a series of bombings and shootings in France. 3 News analysis: Moscow's proposal for a withdrawal from Afghanistan has led to negotiations about the wisdom of demanding that a coalition government be established before an agreement is signed. 6 The 12-nation European Community reached a laboriously negotiated agreement at an emergency summit meeting that will permit a major overhaul of its finances and ease the transition to a barrier-free market by 1992. 3 A U.S.-Mexican Presidential meeting will be held today in Mazatlan, Mexico, at a time when relations between the United States and Mexico are smoother than at any time since the two leaders took office. 5 Sakaide journal: A bridge is a two-way street. 4 NATIONAL 7-9, 33-34 The U.S trade deficit narrowed by $1 billion in December, to $12.2 billion, the lowest level in 11 months, the Commerce Department reported. The improvement consolidated the much larger November gain. 1 Prices at the producer level rose a surprising four-tenths of 1 percent in January, as higher food costs offset declines in energy prices, the Labor Department said. It was the steepest monthly rise since September. 37 Victor Posner struck a deal with a Federal District Court judge after pleading no contest to tax evasion charges. To keep out of jail, the financier agreed to spend $3 million for the homeless and to put in 5,000 hours of community work. 1 Pat Robertson's Southern supporters are out in force, well drilled and intensely committed. Partly because of their organization, Vice President Bush's lead in the South no longer seems comfortable. 1 Alexander Haig ended his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination four days before the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Haig endorsed Senator Bob Dole, saying Mr. Dole ''is head and shoulders above George Bush.'' 9 Unsecured political loans were made to Representative Richard A. Gephardt's Presidential campaign and political action committee. The loans came from two banks whose top officers hold key positions on Mr. Gephardt's campaign. 8 Senator Paul Simon stresses party orthodoxy 8 The blue-collar vote may be crucial in New Hampshire 8 Jack Kemp charges he has been the victim of a smear campaign 9 The F.B.I.'s sweeping investigation of a group opposed to United States policy in Central America was largely fueled by a Salvadoran evangelist turned undercover informer who has admitted that he invented much of his information. 33 A doctor who built a medical school into one of the top academic medical schools is retiring. Dr. Donald W. Seldin helped make the story of the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center an institutional rags-to-riches tale. 7 Soldier's body found a month after death 33 A major snowstorm stretches from the South to New England 34 REGIONAL 29-32 Infants' lives are being lost because of cocaine abuse and AIDS in the most devastated neighborhoods of New York City, nudging up the city's infant mortality rate after a long period of decline. 1 A landlord began his sentence at one of his apartment buildings. Morris Gross was ordered by a court to spend 15 days living in the building after he was convicted of failing to correct almost 400 building code violations. 1 An escaped prisoner was arrested by the F.B.I. David James Roberts, an escapee from Indiana State Penitentiary, had worked under an assumed name in homeless shelters and soup kitchens on Staten Island. 29 Mayor Koch canceled a trip to Rio, where he was to have been the guest of honor at Carnival. With his last-minute cancellation, Mr. Koch has stepped on a lot of important toes. ''He left us in a very difficult spot,'' one official said. 29 Winners of a lottery for housing qualified to buy one of 300 condominium units ranging from the mid-$90,000 to $160,000. in Mahwah, N.J., a wooded and mountainous community in northern Bergen County. 31 Officials of The New York Post and the leaders of its 10 unions will meet Monday to discuss $24 million in cost cuts that Rupert Murdoch calls mandatory if the paper is to be sold and not closed next Friday. 31 An Adirondack town's postmaster works out of an office adjacent to her living room. And while Joan Reynolds works for the Government, she is able to sit in her kitchen and still mind the store when activity is slow. 29 In an attack in a restaurant, one man was killed and another was injured when a gunman opened fire in the lower Manhattan establishment, the police said. A suspect was later arrested in the shooting. 31 Couples give secrets for long marriages 29 A Bronx program tries to reduce premature births 30 Neediest Cases 30

title: Fed Minutes Show Revival of Old Policy
description: With the economy calming down following the rout of the stock market, the Federal Reserve began reverting in December and January to its economic policies of the months before the collapse and worrying less about interest rates, the Fed said today.

title: KEMP ASSAILS USE OF 'SMEAR' TACTICS
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp said today that he had been the victim of a ''deliberate smear campaign'' organized by members of Pat Robertson's staff.

title: A Wrinkle Treatment Has Its Risks
description: Retin-A, prescribed to treat acne since 1971, is suddenly in the spotlight as an alluring lotion that makes wrinkles disappear, fades brown spots and gives skin a rosy glow. Dermatologists say it does, to some degree. But it is strong medicine, involves a long-term commitment and is not for everyone.

title: Triple Crown Nominees
description: Forty Niner, last year's champion 2-year-old colt and the favorite for the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park on Monday, heads a list of 380 nominees for this year's Triple Crown that was released today by the sponsors of the three races.

title: Books of the Times; Epiphanic Moments
description: DUSK AND OTHER STORIES. By James Salter. 157 pages. North Point Press. $14.95.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $1,068,000 for the quarter and $20,668,000 for the year from debt restructuring. Mattel said that its net loss for the latest year is after providing for restructuring expenses of $96 million and taxes on foreign earnings of $28 million.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said it is changing its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from June 30 and therefore this is its last reporting period of the current fiscal year.

title: Amoco Canada Firm on Dome Bid
description: The Canadian unit of the Amoco Corporation said it does not plan to raise its takeover offer of $5.5 billion (about $4.3 billion United States) for Dome Petroleum Ltd., although preferred stockholders are threatening to go to court for more money. ''Adding more money is absolutely out of the question,'' Amoco Canada's president, T. Don Stacy, said.

title: Drug Unit Said to Have Neglected Evidence of Noriega Trafficking
description: Members of Congress and Justice Department officials say the Drug Enforcement Administration appears to have overlooked strong evidence of drug trafficking by the Panamanian military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, while seeking Panama's help in investigating other narcotics cases.

title: Why Radio's Thrill Is Gone at NBC
description: Several months ago, the ups and downs of the National Broadcasting Company's six radio stations finally prompted the General Electric Company, NBC's parent, to put the stations on the block. But it has only recently become clear just why G.E. decided to seek buyers.

title: Unlikely Ski Jumper Lands, Hard, in Calgary
description: The red and white warm-ups identify Fast Eddie Edwards as a member of Her Majesty's Olympic team. He's an unlikely-looking athlete, though, at 5 feet 8 inches, peering through glasses with milk bottle lenses. Still, there are several countries that have an avid interest in the British ski jumper, a waif who has become Nordic skiing's adopted son.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BIDEN IS OPERATED ON FOR ANEURYSM IN BRAIN
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. underwent surgery yesterday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center to correct an aneurysm of an artery supplying blood to the brain, his spokesman said.

title: FINE HOMES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said comparable figures for the year-earlier periods are not available because Fine Homes went public on June 25, 1987. Prior to its initial offering, Fine Homes was a wholly owned subidiary of Merrill Lynch & Co. Fourth quarter 1987 results reflect a previously announced $12 million one- time charge taken after a restructuring of the company's mortgage banking division. The company also said financial data from the prior year's second half when the company was wholly owned by Merrill Lynch & Co. is not directly comparable. The company completed its initial public offering on June 25, 1987.

title: EMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1987.

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31PEGASUS GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $130,150 from the early retirement of debt for the quarter and year, and a gain from an accounting change of $1,063,163 for the both periods; the year also included an extraordinary gain of $454,887 from the settlement of litigation.

title: Mets Say Gooden Accepts Idea of Cut
description: Dwight Gooden's contract negotiations with the Mets took their most significant turn yesterday since Gooden filed for salary arbitration four weeks ago. Al Harazin, the Mets' negotiator, said that for the first time, Gooden's agent had said he would be willing to accept the idea of a pay cut.

title: MANAGEMENT COMPANY ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that since the results for the year-ago periods do not include three of its five subsidiaries, direct comparison to the same periods for fiscal 1987 is not meaningful.

title: VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest earnings reflect a fourth- quarter $6.3 million after-tax writeoff of finance income receivables by All Valley Acceptance Co., a subsidiary. The company said its earnings were impacted favorably by a reduction of its tax provision by $2.9 million.

title: An F.B.I. Inquiry Fed by Informer Emerges in Analysis of Documents
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's sweeping inquiry into a group opposed to United States policy in Central America was largely fueled by an undercover informer who has said he invented much of his information.

title: INDEPENDENT BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect the 50 percent stock dividend paid Sept.30, 1987,

title: Rancher Awarded $8 Million In Police Drug Raid Mistake
description: A sheep rancher and his family have been awarded $8 million because 60 law-enforcement officers took over their home and held them at gunpoint for eight hours, only to find the wrong place had been raided.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday from Athens on Palestinian plans to organize a sea voyage to Israel misstated the circumstances of the 1947 voyage of the Exodus. The passengers were put on a British vessel and taken to France, where they refused to disembark, and then to the British zone of Germany.

title: A Long Marriage: 'There Is No Secret'
description: The approach of St. Valentine's Day finds Florence and Ed Corcoran holding hands on a love seat in Edgewater, N.J., after 10 children, 42 years of marriage and one near-breakup.

title: The White House Stops Winking
description: What a contrast: The White House has sent a letter forbidding Administration officials to encourage or assist the raising of private funds for the contras of Nicaragua. The Reagan Administration that made winking at the law the hallmark of its contra aid policy is now taking pains to avoid more impropriety.

title: Child, 4, Dies From Injuries After Fire in Bronx Apartment
description: A 4-year-old boy died after a fire at his family's apartment in the South Bronx last night, the police said.

title: TV: Opera by Tippett, 'King Priam,' on Bravo
description: An operatic offering perhaps a little obscure for the average opera lover but of interest nonetheless will be presented this afternoon at 5 o'clock on the Bravo arts cable service. It is the American television premiere of Michael Tippett's second opera, ''King Priam,'' first performed in 1962.

title: Phelps Dodge Adds Accuride
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, said it had agreed to buy the Accuride Corporation, a maker of aluminum truck wheels, in a deal valued at about $270 million in cash and debt.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' nets refected income of 15 cents a share for the quarter and 61 cents a share for the year from the amortization of accumulated deferred investment tax credits.

title: ICEE-USA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
MASSACHUSETTS U. SCENE OF PROTEST
description: An estimated 200 black students took over a building at the University of Massachusetts today to protest a racially motivated attack on two students.

title: Insider Curb in British Bill
description: Britain said this week that it intends to make insider trading on financial markets an extraditable offense.

title: Arbitragers Return to the Game
description: Although individual and institutional investors are still nursing their wounds from the October stock market collapse, Wall Street's risk arbitragers are back at the tables. The resurgence of giant takeover deals is making it possible once again for them to rake in big profits in a matter of days or weeks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Misguided Guidelines on AIDS in Court
description: AIDS inflicts suffering on its victims and their families - and unreasonable fear on many people who should know better. The latest to succumb to such fear are New York State court officers and judges, many of whom apparently believe that defendants afflicted with AIDS imperil others in the courtroom.

title: Wings Rally to Top Devils
description: Gerard Gallant scored two of his three goals in the third period tonight, and the Detroit Red Wings beat the New Jersey Devils, 4-3, to win their fourth game in a row.

title: ADVANCED GENETIC SCIENCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TEMPEST TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
An Improved Method For TV Physical Exams
description: LEAD: Scientists at the Medical Center of Georgetown University in Washington were awarded a patent this week for an improved method of physical examination by means of television. The method involves scanning microscope images of tissues.

title: Test for Consumers: Finding the Real Bargain in Electronics
description: It's high season for electronics bargains. Presidents' Birthdays sales, running at full tilt, allow dealers to clear inventories before new products are introduced in April and May.

title: FILENET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $922,000 and $2,292,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $307,000 for the quarter and $590,000 for the year.

title: Cowboys, Not Boycotts
description: If this is the Olympics, the headlines are supposed to be of politics and problems. But not here in this Canadian prairie city of 640,000. Not yet, anyway.

title: MACROCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAFF BUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $110,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $440,000, or 22 cents a share, for the year. Staff Builders was formerly Tender Loving Care Health Care Services Inc.

title: It's Safe With Me, Pat
description: I'm not going to mention the line of work at which Marion (Pat) Robertson toiled before he started running for President of the United States.

title: Ethiopia Rebuts Atrocity Report
description: The Government said today that a report that troops killed at least 20 civilians at a drought relief camp was an ''outright lie,'' and it accused foreign news organizations of a disinformation campaign.

title: John Flynn; Yachtsman, 79
description: John Flynn, a yachtsman and retired boat-yard manager associated with several America's Cup campaigns, died of cancer today at Newport Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Double Life Of a Murderer Shocks S.I.
description: In the homeless shelters and the soup kitchens on Staten Island where he worked, Bob Lord was known as a gentle and compassionate man.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Bush Frolics in the Snow

title: Recital: Kiri Te Kanawa at Carnegie
description: If Kiri Te Kanawa felt a sense of urgency or passion toward the music she sang in Carnegie hall on Wednesday evening, it did not make itself apparent. There was a put-on, disengaged quality about her singing that gave to virtually all of this eminent soprano's performances a false ring. Much as one admired certain aspects of her work - the regal tone, the control across a range of dynamics -Ms. Te Kanawa never seemed other than removed emotionally from the music and this cast a chilling pall over the entire evening.

title: Dickens Indeed Dwelt On Little Nell's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Against Dart
description: The Stop and Shop Companies filed suit against the Dart Group Corporation in connection with a tender offer made by Dart for the retail company's stock. Stop and Shop earlier rejected Dart's offer of $37 a share. The suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Boston, charges that Dart violated Federal laws by not disclosing its purported intention to raise Stop and Shop's stock price so that Dart could sell its holdings at a higher price.

title: Hoyt to Start Term
description: At a time when other players will be reporting for spring training, LaMarr Hoyt will be going to prison. The 1983 Cy Young Award winner, whose career has been plagued by drug-related problems, will begin serving a year in Federal prison Feb. 22 for a probation violation in California. On Thursday, Hoyt was sentenced in Columbia, S.C., to two and a half years in prison by Special Judge Frank Eppes. The judge suspended the term to seven months and ordered the sentence be concurrent with the Federal sentence Hoyt must serve for a probation violation. Hoyt violated the conditions of his parole from a 1986 conviction when he tested positive for cocaine use. He was arrested Dec. 5 at his Columbia apartment and charged with possession of cocaine with intent to distribute and possession of marijuana.

title: Bridge:; Transfer Concept Explains A Strange-Looking Auction
description: The transfer concept, which was developed in Sweden and Texas more than 30 years ago, can have many ramifications.

title: Can Carnival Without Koch Still Dazzle?
description: On the eve of carnival, as preparations reached their peak to have Mayor Koch of New York as the guest of honor, the man who would have formally inaugurated the festivities, Mr. Koch, suddenly backed out.

title: COCAINE AND AIDS IN NEW YORK ADD TO INFANT DEATHS
description: Cocaine abuse and AIDS are taking the lives of children born in the most devastated neighborhoods of New York City, nudging up the city's infant mortality rate after more than a decade of decline and sowing fears of steeper increases to come.

title: Coping: With Bargaining for a New Car
description: This might have been the best place in the world to learn how to buy a car this week, when most of the country's automobile merchants flooded into the city for their annual convention. That meant more than 25,000 people -members of the National Automobile Dealers' Association and their guests - all talking cars in general and auto sales in particular. For a consumer, it made interesting listening.

title: WNYC-FM Plans Day Of Music of Americans
description: ''Americathon '88,'' a daylong program of live performances by American composers and artists, will be broadcast on Monday beginning at 1 P.M. on WNYC-FM (93.9). Those appearing in the annual broadcast, which will last until 11 P.M., include Wayne Horvitz, the World Saxophone Quartet, Jule Styne, the Roches, Eddy Clearwater and Women of the Calabash.

title: In a Dating Contract, Follow Your Head
description: Beware of commercial cupids. That's the Valentine's Day advisory from the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.

title: Blue-Collar New Hampshire: a Key Battleground
description: The talk these days in Presidential campaigns is of a New Hampshire that is really an extension of the Massachusetts economy and the Boston media market.

title: PERFECTDATA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cape Town Lifts Curb on Politics at Schools
description: A South African court today struck down Government curbs on universities that linked the granting of state subsidies to strictures against political activities.

title: Festival's Theater Program Offers O'Neill and Beckett
description: While 20 of the 29 shows in the First New York International Festival of the Arts theater section are new or contemporary works, some of this century's most influential playwrights do get a doff of the hat. In a few cases, they get a bit more.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,459,000 from debt forgiveness. c-After a gain of $16,374,000 from restructuring debt for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Older Skiers Gaining Interest in Slopes
description: Gray power is becoming an important force on the ski slopes.

title:
Patents;
Retrovir: A Treatment For People With AIDS
description: LEAD: A preparation for treating people who have AIDS was patented this week for the Burroughs Wellcome Company of Research Triangle Park, N.C. The treatment was approved last year by the Food and Drug Administration and is in use in 35 countries.

title: Art: Opening of Degas Retrospective in Paris
description: The Degas retrospective that opens Saturday at the Grand Palais is one of the great exhibitions this season. With nearly 400 works, it is the largest Degas show in more than 50 years, spilling onto three levels of the museum. It was so carefully selected and installed -and Degas's art, for all its nerve and audacity, is so reserved and discreet - that it is never unwieldy or overblown.

title: Stocks Rise After Report On Trade
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved higher yesterday in what traders said was a subdued response to the better-than-expected drop in the United States trade deficit.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping. Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Option to close. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule. Schools: Option to close; New York City schools are closed.
