Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no rail service on Montclair Branch, Boonton and Pascack Valley lines. Schools: Option to close. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule. Schools: Closed.

title: LIFECORE BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Henry J. Kelley; Professor, 62
description: Henry J. Kelley, the Christopher C. Kraft Professor of Aerospace and Ocean Engineering at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Blacksburg, Va. He was 62 years old.

title: Robertson Backers Eager for Southern Test
description: In the days since Pat Robertson finished second in the Iowa caucuses Monday night, ahead of Vice President Bush, his once invisible army is now out in the field, well drilled and intensely committed.

title: Music: American Songs
description: A perhaps unintended message from Wednesday's evening with the Alliance for American Song was that social rectitude and the musical muse do not necessarily walk hand in hand. Patrons of Weill Recital Hall, at any rate, were treated to a fascinating history - set to music - of this country's continuing indignation over the rich, the rapacious and the repressive among our own.

title: Soldier's Body Is Discovered After a Month
description: The body of an Army private killed after an automobile accident was not discovered until a month after he was reported missing, and the Kentucky state police say confusion at the accident scene was the reason.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Banks' Plans On Mexico
description: Leading United States banks are not expected to participate in Mexico's innovative debt-reduction plan, an American banker said today. But a senior official at the Swiss Bank Corporation said his bank will tender some loans.

title: New Squabbling In Israel Widens 2 Leaders' Split
description: As violence flared again in the occupied territories, a rift in Israel's governing coalition widened today as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir angrily accused Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of trying to ''sabotage'' his attempts at peace.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago results are restated.

title: American Cellular Deal Is Protested
description: Frederick A. Moran, president of Moran Asset Management, said that he plans to solicit other bidders to top a $25-a-share, or $230 million, merger agreement between the American Cellular Network Corporation and the Comcast Corporation.

title: Retail Sales Up In New York
description: Several of New York's leading department stores had average sales gains in January of 11.4 percent in the city and 7.4 percent in the area over January 1987, a spot-check found yesterday. In the full fiscal year, ended

title: Producer Prices Up In January
description: Prices at the producer level rose a surprising four-tenths of 1 percent in January, as higher food costs more than offset declines in energy prices, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: LORIMAR TELEPICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes about $22 million for the quarter and 9 months of reserves for the company's home video division; specifically the reserves relating to home video are due to a reserve for potentially uncollectible accounts receivable, and a writedown for inventory relating to both overstock of catalog titles that will no longer be distributed and revaluation of non-catalog inventory, primarily certain film titles. c-Net income

title: Mattel Closes Two Plants
description: Mattel Inc. said today that it had closed two plants in the Philippines where its Barbie doll production was slowed by labor strife and that it had dismissed 4,000 workers. Doll making was transferred to the company's other plants in Asia and Mexico.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Wednesday about the investigation into an attack on a Dutchess County teen-ager incorrectly described the role of an assistant attorney general in a previous case. The official, John M. Ryan, aided in the investigation of a 1975 bombing at LaGuardia Airport, but no one has been prosecuted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Elliott Sets Mark: Bill Elliott never trailed in a record-setting victory yesterday in the opener of the Budweiser International Race of Champions series at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. In the 40-lap, 100-mile race, Elliott averaged 186.239 miles per hour, the fastest winning speed in the series' history. Each driver used an identically prepared Camaro. Nascar drivers swept the top three places in the 11-car race, with Dale Earnhardt finishing two car lengths back in second, followed by Terry Labonte. The victory was the first in nine starts for Elliott, a two-time Daytona 500 winner, and gave stock-car drivers a total of 23 victories in 46 races. (AP) Golf Mudd and Zokol Tied: It was luck, Jodie Mudd said. And this time, it was the good kind. ''I've had my share of tough luck over the years, so it feels good to have a round like this,'' Mudd said after he shot a six-under-par 66 that gave him a share of the lead going into yesterday's second round in the $600,000 Hawaiian Open. Mudd twice holed from odf the green and dropped two birdie putts from 40 and 60 feet as he matched the score of Richard Zokol of Canada. Mudd made putts of 40 and 60 feet for birdies on the second and third holes. He chipped in for an eagle-3 from about 30 yards on the ninth, and he birdied the 15th with a 30-foot bunker shot. Scott Simpson, the United States Open champion, and Brad Bryant were a stroke off the lead at 67. (AP) Three-Way Tie: Swirling, gusting winds plagued Liselotte Neumann of Sweden yesterday in the second round of the $225,000 L.P.G.A. Sarasota Classic, while Beth Daniel an$ Jo Rosenthal rallied to pull into a three-way tie for the lead. Neumann, who opened with a 64 Thursday, soared to a five-over-par 77, including six bogeys, on the 6,170-yard Bent Tree Country Club course. Her three-under 141 total for 36 holes left her tied with Daniel, 68-73, and Rosenthal, 71-70. Cathy Johnston was a stroke behind the leaders at 142. (AP)

title: Robertson Comments on South Africa Unrest
description: Pat Robertson says black Americans ''don't understand what they're dealing with'' in South Africa, and that he will not criticize that nation to gain votes for his Presidential bid.

title: Smithsonian Guidebook
description: A free guide, published by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, offers information that is of special interest to museum visitors with physical disabilities. In addition to general information, ''A Guide for Disabled Visitors'' indicates the availability of wheelchairs, sign-language interpreters and sound amplification at the Smithsonian's 13 facilities. There are also maps and transportation information. For a copy, call (202) 357-2700 or write to the Visitor Information and Associates' Reception Center, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C. 20560.

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects charges to operations of $1.4 million from settlement of two lawsuits for both the quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $2,823,000 from the early retirement of convertible debentures.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

description: b-After losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $54,000 and $94,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $2,000 for the quarter and $49,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $236,000 for the quarter and $21,000 for the 6 months, a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $158,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and extraordinary gains of $4,705,000 and $2,200,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. In the latest quarter and 6-month, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

description: b-Net income The latest periods included a charge of $20.4 million from consolidation costs of the December 1987 merger with Advanced Systems Inc.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT NARROWS FURTHER AS EXPORTS GROW
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed by $1 billion in December, to $12.2 billion, the lowest level in 11 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: It's Time We Stopped Blaming the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Gossage Sent to Cubs
description: The San Diego Padres traded Rich (Goose) Gossage to the Chicago Cubs last night as part of a four-player deal that brought Keith Moreland, a third baseman and outfielder, to San Diego. Gossage, 36 years old, came to the Padres from the Yankees as a free agent in 1984. He is second on the career save list with 289. Last season, Gossage was 5-4 with 11 saves and a 3.12 earned-run average in 40 games. Moreland, 33, hit a career high 27 home runs in 1987 and had 88 runs batted in. He played 153 games, almost all of them at third base, but he will probably start in left field for the Padres. Gossage is expected to replace Lee Smith, who was traded to Boston. San Diego also sent Ray Hayward, a minor-league pitcher, to Chicago, while the Cubs gave up Mike Brumley, a minor-league shorstop.

title:
Patents;
A Catheter With Better Steerability
description: LEAD: Medical specialists in San Diego have devised a catheter with improved steerability for opening blockages in arteries. The device is faster than the equipment now in use and causes less stress to patients, according to its inventors. Blockages are caused primarily by a buildup of cholesterol.

title: 'Khovanshchina' at Met
description: Three singers will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts on Feb. 22 when Mussorgsky's opera ''Khovanshchina'' is performed for the first time since the 1985-86 season. The singers are Elizabeth Knighton, soprano; Stefania Toczyska, mezzo-soprano, and Timothy Noble, baritone. Others in the cast include Wieslaw Ochman, Denes Gulyas, Aage Haugland and Martti Talvela. James Conlon will conduct. Tickets are available at the box office or by telephone: 362-6000.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE MARKET VIEW;
Texaco and Pennzoil Both Lost Big
description: LEAD: ECONOMISTS have long debated the costs of the litigation proceedings and protracted negotiations that surround bankruptcy situations. But as yet, there has been relatively little hard evidence regarding the magnitude of these costs. The Texaco-Pennzoil case provides an ideal experiment for studying these issues.

title: She Loved Him
description: Once there was a little girl who had a crush on a little boy. He had blue eyes, brown hair and trouble pronouncing ''th.'' Never mind: she loved him.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Getting a Break On Car Rentals In Europe

title: Helping the Disabled Find Careers in the Arts
description: CAN ONE be realistic about the arts and still make money? Yes. The New Jersey Department of Labor's Division of Vocational Rehabilitation Services is a career-networking providing system that is designed to help the disabled find employment in the arts and promote the products of the division's clients.

title: A Palestinian Revolution Without the P.L.O.
description: TWO weekends ago, Hani Al Hassan, a senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, held a dinner party at his home in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Most of the guests were successful Palestinians working in the gulf region, and it became almost immediately obvious, in the heated, emotional exchange that ensued with the P.L.O. leader, that they led and he followed.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD JOINS SUITS
description: MANY of the teen-age girls who burst, giggling, past the bright blue doors of the storefront in Mount Vernon are dropping by after school to chat with staff members they know on a first-name basis.

title: Vermont Seeks to Help Dairy Farms
description: These have been frustrating years for Laval and Rita Bilodeau. Two artifical hips and a bad heart limit the amount of physical labor Mr. Bilodeau can perform on the 265-acre dairy farm he bought here in 1955. That means the milking and most of the heavy work fall to his two sons.

title: DEATH AND GOOD INTENTIONS
description: UNDER THE SUN By Erik Jay. 152 pp. Chester Springs, Pa.: Dufour Editions. $16.95.

title: Ringing the Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: Spread of AIDS Abating, But Deaths Will Still Soar
description: ''The way mankind responds to crisis is first disbelief, then denial, then the third stage is mobilization, and we're at the horizon of that now. '' Dr. Stephen C. Joseph New York City Health Commissioner

title: Committee Leaders In Congress to Give Priority to Trade Bill
description: Congress resumes work on a complex trade bill next week, giving it high priority but confronting events pulling members in opposite directions.

title: Notebook; Sutter Among 75 Seeking Post-Injury Comebacks
description: IN the Georgia countryside north of Atlanta, in the town of Kennesaw, there's a piece of rustic property 50 acres or so in size. Tucked away among the trees on that property are a pond, a swimming pool, a tennis court - and a pitcher's mound. On that mound the past week has stood the man who owns the property, and Bruce Sutter wasn't standing on it just to survey his domain.

title: Pointers on Points For Frequent Fliers
description: THIS summer when J. Russell King of New York and his mother, Mary Ann King of Ardmore, Okla., fly to London on vacation, they will take different airlines and land at separate airports. Mrs. King will take Delta at no cost; her coupon was a Christmas gift from a son-in-law who travels in his work and had points to share. Mr. King is taking Trans World Airlines to get the mileage points for his T.W.A. frequent travel account so he can win a coupon for a free trip to Europe in first class. Mrs. King will land at Gatwick and her son at Heathrow, and that will take a little working out.

title: Ex-Basketball Star Waits for New Start
description: DAY after day, Bill Willoughby waits for the telephone to ring and the voice on the other end to offer him a new chance to play professional basketball.

title: Afrikaner Farmer Is Ready to Negotiate, or Fight
description: Andeon Visagie, only a few months past his 40th birthday, has most things in life that a successful white man in South Africa could seek.

title: Life With Campeau: Allied's Year of Constant Change
description: AS CHAIRMAN and chief executive of the Allied Stores Corporation, Thomas M. Macioce spent much of his time in the company's Manhattan headquarters, meeting only occasionally with the chiefs of his 22 store divisions around the country. Austere and autocratic, Mr. Macioce kept a tight rein on operations from afar, handing down orders to the field through a layer of seven group executives.

title: Cadets' Bus in Collision
description: Nine people were injured Friday when a bus carrying 26 West Point cadets crashed into a jackknifed tractor-trailer on icy Interstate 81 near Avoca, the authorities reported. The truck was blocking the southbound lanes of the highway when the bus struck it, the authorities said.

title: Comparable Success
description: ONE gym divided by two basketball teams at one small school equals two top big-school basketball teams six years later. That, at least, seems to be the formula that explains why Temple is the top-ranked men's basketball team in the country and Iowa is the No. 1 women's squad.

title: Notebook; EAST GERMAN WOMEN LOOK STRONG IN LUGE
description: It was business as usual for East Germany's female lugers today in two training runs for the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: Speed-Skating Event Offers U.S. Best Chance for Gold Medal
description: If you enjoy watching Americans win gold medals, pay close attention when full-scale competition starts Sunday in the XV Olympic Winter Games. The Americans' best chance for a gold medal in these Olympics will come in the men's 500-meter speed skating.

title: IN KENT, ALL EYES AND BETS ARE ON A FROZEN RIVER
description: WOODEN ballot boxes sit on virtually every store counter and orange-colored posters are taped on the windows. All around town, the people of Kent are studying the calendar, consulting their private muses and digging into their pockets for dollar bills.

title: Tension Ushers in a Ritual Election in Paraguay
description: After a campaign marked by a surprising level of anti-government protests, the cyclical ritual of Paraguay's ''democracy without Communism'' climaxes Sunday with the election of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner to an eighth presidential term.

title: An 1840 Pact Again Haunts New Zealand
description: To avoid embarrassing questions, New Zealand marked Waitangi Day, its national day, this week with as little fanfare as possible.

title: Design; BY THE BOOK
description: HOW MANY SALAD BOWLS or toaster ovens or salt and pepper shakers does a just-married couple need? Usually, one is enough. To avoid receiving duplicates of such useful (and obvious) gifts, a growing number of couples are registering for china, crystal, silver and household objects at local department and gift stores. ''Bridal registries are booming,'' says an executive at Tiffany & Company. And not just for first-time marriages. Indeed, couples getting marrried for even the third or fourth times aren't shy about their desires.

title: Bail Is Set for Robbery Defendant Who Has Awaited Trial Since '85
description: A Federal judge has set bail at $1 million for a defendant who has been imprisoned for 30 months without an opportunity to be released while awaiting trial in a Wells Fargo robbery.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: As a Brooklyn Dodger fan living in the Bronx I did my best for the Duke against the Say Hey Kid and the Mick. But now, looking back, I'd have to rate my man third behind Willie (number one) and Mickey (a close second). NORMAN KRASNE Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: HISTORIC EVENTS SHOWN ON NEW ISSUES
description: RECENT issues highlight major events of the past 50 years. Last November, the Arab nation released three stamps with a theme ''International Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian People.'' A previous set of three spread the message, ''Al-Quds (Jerusalem) is an Arab City.''

title: One Killed and 20 Injured by Bombs in Strikes in Bangladesh
description: Hundreds of small bombs exploded across the capital of Bangladesh today, killing one man and injuring 20 at the start of the latest in a series of general strikes, the police and witnesses said.

title: Fordham Tops St. Peter's in 3 Overtimes
description: Greg Pedro hit a 3-point field goal to break a 63-63 tie and Fordham went on to register a 75-66 triumph over St. Peter's in triple overtime yesterday at Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: High-Flown Sex Much has been said about the unpersuasiveness of Hemingway's sex scenes, and George Plimpton found Papa rather defensive when he asked about them. He is quoted in ''The True Gen: An Intimate Portrait of Ernest Hemingway by Those Who Knew Him'' (Grove) by Denis Brian.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Philadelphia: For a Mansion, 'Mansionettes'?
description: LEAD: A 35-room mansion on Rittenhouse Square that belonged to Henry P. McIlhenny, the late Philadelphia art collector, is being considered for development as 14 or more European-style ''mansionettes.'' The mansion, a keystone property in the exclusive Rittenhouse Square area, sold for just under $3 million two months ago.

title: Toll Agencies Face Increased Scrutiny
description: THE Garden State Parkway's quest for a general toll increase has been slapped down, at least for the remainder of the year, but the public indignation that greeted the proposal will continue to reverberate in the Legislature for months to come.

Government offices: Federal, state and city offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Option to close. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule. Schools: Option to close; New York City schools are closed. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no rail service on Montclair Branch, Boonton and Pascack Valley lines. Schools: Option to close. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and city offices closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule. Schools: Closed.

title: Red Cross in Maine Is Cited by the U.S. Over Worker Safety
description: The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited the Portland office of the American Red Cross for not adequately protecting its employees from blood-borne diseases.

title: Braintree, Mass.: Classrooms To Condos
description: The classrooms where generations of Braintree students struggled with algebra and passed notes are well on their way to becoming the kitchens and bedrooms of condominiums, the result of a conversion project by Francis X. Messina, Braintree's largest developer.

title: CLASH OVER DRUGS AS REAGAN MEETS WITH MEXICO CHIEF
description: Tensions between the United States and Mexico over the control of international drug traffic flared today at a summit meeting between President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid.

title: THE WORLD: The Panama Canal; The Strategic Importance of A Waterway
description: IN a blistering manifesto, Panama's military last week demanded that the United States Southern Command be expelled from its headquarters here.

title: Political Notes; The '92 Race Begins Early For D'Amato
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's 1992 re-election campaign is already under way - or, at least, fund raising for it is. The New York Republican has set up two finance committees, D'Amato in '92 and Friends of Senator D'Amato '92, that have so far raised $771,000, according to Arthur W. Jaspan, the Garden City, L.I., lawyer who is the D'Amato campaign treasurer.

title: MS. IX IS MARRIED TO A. S. PEDERSEN
description: The marriage of Constance Ann Ix, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander F. Ix Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J., and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., to Andrew Soren Pedersen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Pedersen of Cedar Grove, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Moore performed the ceremony.

title: EXTRAORDINARY PEOPLE
description: THE INCREDIBLE ESKIMO Life Among the Barren Land Eskimo. By Raymond de Coccola and Paul King. Photographs. Illustrations by James Houston. 435 pp. Surrey, B.C.: Hancock House Publishers. Paper, $14.95.

title: NONFICTION
description: A COMMON ROOM: Essays 1954-1987. By Reynolds Price. (Atheneum, $23.95.) Most writers know something about their motives, though few are as impassioned - or as expansive - as Reynolds Price is in sharing them. Indeed, in many of these 57 essays by the acclaimed author of ''Kate Vaiden'' and other novels, the treacherous business of examining artistic intent - in his own writing as well as in others' - is managed with considerable grace. By turns thoughtful, ornery, eloquent, long-winded and wise, Mr. Price reflects on the work of artists as celebrated as Henry James and Eudora Welty and as little known as the American Indian author James Welch. Some of the selections are less successful than others. Only the persistent will want to wade through Mr. Price's long, pedantic essay on Milton's ''Samson Agonistes'' or a piece about his memories of the first book of Bible stories he received, at the age of 2. Likewise, Mr. Price's tone when discussing certain recurring themes - the Eastern literary establishment's preference for urban novels, the critical deflation of Hemingway, the indiscriminate praise heaped on Faulkner -tends, at times, to sound more chastising than critical. But these are quibbles. In the most discerning and incisive essays, Mr. Price ruminates on our shared need for heroes, the impulse to create, the significance of the word ''home'' and the mysterious ways in which personal history and collective myth combine in the making of art. The picture that emerges from this large collection is of a writer whose deepest concern is not only the telling of stories, but the hearing of them too.

title: VOTERS TURN DOWN A NEW TOWN HALL

Kennedy, publisher of Consultants News. By 1986, revenues had grown to $225 million, with the number of firms rising to 154 from 43.

For example, in Oyster Bay, at the library at 89 East Main Street, there's a concert at 3 P.M. of love songs and sentimental ditties, courtesy of Dayle, while down the road a bit, at the Manhasset Library, 30 Onderdonk Avenue, also at 3 P.M., the mezzo-soprano Susan Wagner, the soprano Teresa Arrigo and the tenor-baritone Ben Arrigo use tunes by Mozart, Brahms, Puccini, Gershwin and Rodgers and Hart to get their message across. At the Baldwin Library, at 2:30 P.M. at 2385 Grand Avenue, the Purple Cow Playhouse performs a ''Valentine Revue.''

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL

I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there. Is there anything else you can suggest?

title: NONFICTION
description: A FEW GOOD MEN FROM UNIVAC. By David E. Lundstrom. (MIT, $19.95.) This personal memoir, the latest volume in the MIT Press's History of Computing series, recalls the early days of the electronic computer industry, when machines with the capacity of today's miniature computers were ''a little larger than a single car garage.'' David E. Lundstrom, a retired electrical engineer who has worked for the Univac division of the Sperry Rand Corporation as well as the Control Data Corporation, offers an account of what he calls a ''narrow but typical slice'' of 30 years of computer history, introducing us to some of the personalities and back-room machinations that shaped this most volatile of industries. As a cautionary tale for executives, this book is valuable. The author astutely demonstrates how computer design is affected (that is, hindered) by such nonengineering problems as management egotism and administrative ineptitude, and he makes a convincing case for granting greater freedom to the innovative designers (those ''few good men from Univac'') who have tried to keep the industry on the fast track. But as a portrait of a lively and exciting business, the book does not succeed. Mr. Lundstrom's narrative skills are lackluster, and are enough to try the patience of even the most avid computerphile.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Televising an Olympic Games is only slighlty less complicated than staging one. ABC, which televised both the Winter and Summer Games in 1984, has moved 17 tractor trailers of equipment to Calgary and plans 90 or so hours of programming, beginning last Saturday through Feb. 28. Because of Calgary's Mountain Time zone location, most of ABC's coverage will be live. The bulk of that coverage will come in the form of 10 or 11 hours of programming on each of the five weekend days following the opening ceremonies. The general weekday schedule calls for three hours of coverage, beginning at 8 P.M. Eastern time and an additional 30 minutes at 11:30 P.M.

title: NAUGHTY, BAWDY AND WISE - A VALENTINE FOR CHAUCER
description: In college I took methedrine and read Chaucer. This was in 1968. During the day we sat in at Army induction centers, and at night we went to our boyfriends' apartments and took drugs and read Chaucer because there was a required Chaucer section on the senior English honors exam and we couldn't graduate with honors without it. Our seminar was taught by an elderly medieval scholar; we took turns translating aloud from Middle English, and when anything bawdy came up, he would assign a female student to read that part. We steeled ourselves and groped for the much more embarrassing euphemisms for Chaucer's everyday dirty words while no one acknowledged that any of this was funny or in any way exceptional - a group performance I have rarely seen equaled for the delicacy of its perversion.

I am a registered nurse, and the day I pricked my finger with a patient's bloody needle, my life changed. Because it would be a violation of his rights to have him tested against his will, it is I who must endure months, maybe years, of testing, waiting, wondering. I have young children, a loving, trusting husband. What right do I have, because of my job, to leave them without a mother, without a wife?

title: ART, AFTER A FASHION
description: When Diana Vreeland began staging her dynamic costume exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art 15 years ago, she not only narrowed the gap between fashion and art but also enhanced the perception of clothing as a field for serious study. Art museums all over this country and in Europe followed with their own fashion exhibitions, and books examining the sociological and cultural implications of clothing proliferated. This beautifully designed and printed volume is one of the best. With a text by the stage designer Zhou Xun and her assistant Gao Chunming, 5000 YEARS OF CHINESE COSTUMES (China Books and Periodicals, $49.95) intersperses delicate sketches of clothing with the paintings and sculpture from which they were derived. Edited by the Chinese Costumes Research Group of the Shanghai School of Traditional Operas, it is both art book and fashion history, starting with the animal skins and shell ornaments worn before the invention of fabrics and ending with contemporary cotton clothes. Even in the early eras, the colors were subtle and the patterns intricate. After all, the Chinese invented silk and learned how to handle it. The basic shape was the wraparound robe, but over the millenniums there were plenty of variations. Dramatic fashion changes were not invented in the modern era - they are part of the human condition. So are aberrations like the binding of women's feet, which became fashionable in the Sung dynasty (A.D. 960 to 1279). In looking at headdresses, purses, fans and changes in hairstyle for both men and women, the book offers other interesting insights into the development of fashion, Oriental style.

title: Income Up, Debts Down: After a Year of Subsidized Gains, Signs of New Hope

title: THE PASTOR'S PROBLEM
description: As a former Connecticut pastor, I have struggled with the same concerns as Mr. Brinton, and he has my sympathy. However, in his concluding remarks, he obscures what is at issue by turning the problem in upon himself. A pastor's poverty or relative poverty is useful in biblical terms only if it has symbolic import: effectively positing the need for an otherwordly ethic in a too worldly society. But we have crossed over a threshold that has rendered such symbolic poverty nonsensical. We no longer blush at even the most outrageously conspicuous consumption. Is it any wonder that the televised gospel of wealth is having a field day, while, when it comes to remuneration, the local pastor is considered at best an unfocused underachiever, and at worst a chump? REV. JAMES R. ANDERSON St. Paul
