description: LEAD: RECENT statements by Energy Secretary John S. Herrington are raising speculation that the Reagan Administration will soon begin a final initiative to promote Federal licensing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Federation Celebrates Black History Month
description: Associated Black Charities of New York, a federation of 59 health and welfare agencies, is using the observance of Black History Month in February to honor contemporary black leaders and underscore the early beginnings of black philanthropy.

title: NANCY FREEMAN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Freeman of Brielle, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jean Freeman, to Joel B. Moshin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Moshin of Brooklyn. Miss Freeman, who graduated from New York University, is a legal secretary at the New York law firm of Spengler Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling. Her fiance, a computer consultant with Howard Systems International in New York, graduated from City College.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: SLEIGH RIDE FESTIVAL

title: SUSANNAH DWIGHT TO MARRY LAWYER
description: The engagement of Susannah Fanshawe Dwight to James P. Prout has been announced by the future bride's parents, Margaret O. Bradley of Riverside, Conn., and George H. P. Dwight of New York. Mr. Prout is a son of Anne C. Prout of Cranford, N.J., and John Prout of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: HUMAN FIGURES ENSHRINED BY THE EARLY GREEKS
description: Like other Greek sculptures of standing women, or korai, this figure is frontal, her left leg slightly in front of the right. Her face is fleshy, ripe, her expression both attentive and aloof. Unlike Greek sculptures of standing males, she is clothed, but she seems both more naked and more secret than male figures nearby. Space hugs her. She and space fit. She was dedicated to Pallas Athena. She was found on the Acropolis in the 19th century. She embodies the classical balance between idealism and naturalism, immobility and movement.

title: THE NEVER-ENDING HUM OF THE UNIVERSE
description: LONGING FOR THE HARMONIES Themes and Variations From Modern Physics. By Frank Wilczek and Betsy Devine. Illustrated. 361 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: LOCAL PROTECTION OF GROUND WATER
description: For almost two years, the Housatonic Valley Association has been engaged in a Groundwater Action Project in four towns in northwestern Connecticut, so we were pleased to see attention drawn to this issue in the excellent article by Paul Guernsey (''Contaminants Seeping Into Ground Water Supplies,'' Jan. 17).

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
HEARTBURN'S CAUSE? CUPID'S ARROW
description: LEAD: IT'S Valentine's Day and we all know what that means. Right: Aggravation. You thought I meant to say ''love''?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ADAM'S DIARY. By Knut Faldbakken. Translated by Sverre Lyngstad. (University of Nebraska Press, Cloth, $23.95; Paper, $12.95.) This occasionally horrific, at times weirdly inventive book by the Norwegian writer Knut Faldbakken combines an old-fashioned amplitude of social detail with less conventionally realist techniques.

title: NONFICTION
description: NEW IMMIGRANTS IN NEW YORK. Edited by Nancy Foner. (Columbia University, $27.50.) Wrap a subway map around this academic book and you have one of the most useful and up-to-date guides to New York City in years. ''New Immigrants in New York'' takes eight recently arrived groups - Dominicans, Haitians, St. Vincentians, Grenadians, Jamaicans, Koreans, Chinese and Soviet Jews - and shows the impact the city has had on them and the impact they have had on the city. For example, we learn that Jamaican women are much more likely to work in New York than they were back home, a fact that has altered the city's garment industry as well as relations between the sexes in the immigrants' new homes. Almost any observer of New York has noticed that Koreans have become the new merchant class, fixing up shops throughout the city. Here we learn that most of these new shopkeepers were professionals in South Korea and that they have filled a vacuum created by Jewish and Italian merchants whose children did not want to follow them into business. The book was written by nine scholars who know how to present their research in a readable and informative fashion, replete with engaging anecdotes and helpful statistics. As editor of this volume, Nancy Foner (a professor of anthropology at the State University of New York, Purchase, and author of the chapter on the Jamaicans) deserves considerable credit for keeping her writers true to their assignments. Now if only she provided us with a subway token.

title: Private Enterprise Is Profitable Enterprise
description: PRIVATIZATION is spreading and succeeding throughout the world -in developed and developing countries, in democracies and dictatorships and in capitalist, socialist and communist nations.

title: A Range Of Events At Emelin
description: THE Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, as it so often does, provides a wonderful diversity of musical treats this week. Because many county youngsters are enjoying school holidays, children's programs fill the midday, midweek roster, starting tomorrow and Tuesday, when Puppetworks goes ''Around the World in 80 Days'' in what the troupe describes as ''a vivid and specially designed production'' of the Jules Verne classic. There are shows at 11 A.M. and 1 and 3 P.M. daily.

title: KATHY L. BORGOGNONI WED TO JOHN M. AYRES
description: The wedding of Kathy Louise Borgognoni to John Morgan Ayres took place yesterday in Syracuse. Msgr. Charles Borgognoni, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Center at Syracuse University.

title: Tension, Pain, Satisfaction: Inside the Recruiting Game
description: When I began coaching football in 1953, there was a phrase I picked up that was attributed to the late Red Sanders, then the head football coach at U.C.L.A. He said that the best way to be a successful college football coach and produce winning teams was to ''come by some good football players.''

title: CYNTHIA CANNELL BECOMES FIANCEE OF RAINER GROSS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Cannell of New York and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Cannell, to Rainer Gross, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich E. Gross of Cologne, West Germany.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: A STUDY of the impact of noise generated by aircraft using Newark International Airport has been begun by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: MUSSEL FARMING ON RISE IN MAINE
description: For as long as apparently anyone along the Maine coast can remember, mussels have not been popular among many shellfish eaters.

title: Men's Style; THE PROPRIETIES
description: TRADITIONAL WEDDINGS are glamorous spectacles, occasions to trot out the sort of finery one spies only at high official functions or in Andrew Lloyd Weber stage extravaganzas. Starched collars, stick pins and ascots - the accoutrements alone suggest a period piece, to say nothing of the clothing, a panoply ranging from morning suits to tailcoats. Indeed, for men, the requisite attire for a formal wedding has scarely changed since 1900.

title: A WITTY CELEBRANT OF AN AGE OF PLEASURE
description: The youth and early manhood of Jean-Honore Fragonard (1732-1806) are a joy to contemplate. He was quick, gifted, eager and adaptable. In a stocky, well-fleshed way he was very good looking. Everything went well for him, though he missed out on the classic art education that he could have got from the Academie in Paris. To have studied reputedly with Chardin and beyond question with Boucher was as good an introduction to the practice of art as could have been hoped for.

title:
INVESTING;
Choosing Cyclicals Over Growth Stocks
description: LEAD: INVESTORS find themselves in some strange places these days. G. Kenneth Heebner, who invests $2 billion in mutual fund and pension assets at Loomis, Sayles & Co. in Boston, for example, usually buys growth stocks. And he rarely holds cash or short-term securities, in any of the five mutual funds he manages.

title: WENDY RANCE TO WED PETER FRANCIS DUNNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cyril E. Rance of Hamilton, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Lee Rance to Peter Francis Dunne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Dunne of Garden City, L.I. The couple plan to wed Sept. 24.

title: The Army and the Law
description: 'Laws that limit the acceptable focus of one's sexual desires to members of the opposite sex, like laws that limit one's choice of spouse (or sexual partner) to members of the same race, cannot withstand constitutional scrutiny absent a compelling governmental justification. '

title: Why the Melody Doesn't Linger On
description: What ever hap-pened to melody in popular music? I'm not talking about tunes - hummable little ditties with short catch phrases - but a fluid, cohesive theme of at least 16 bars in which no musical phrase is repeated. Richard Rodgers's ''Some Enchanted Evening'' has such a melody. As it flows along, moving through rich, unforced chromatic harmonies, its indelibility can't be explained by the hammering home of a formula. Like the greatest popular melodies, it seems to unfold organically, with rightness that transcends analysis.

title: AMY MILLMAN TO WED ROGER CONANT FAXON
description: Dr. and Mrs. Louis Millman of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Millman, to Roger Conant Faxon, a son of Frances Parker Faxon of Concord, Mass., and the late William Faxon. The couple plan to marry May 1.

title: THE WORLD: Contrasting Birth Rates; Old World Fearful Of Third World's 'Silent Invasion'
description: ''WE are obsessed by the East,'' said an adviser to President Francois Mitterrand, referring to the menace of the Soviet bloc. ''But the threat of destabilization comes from the South.''

title: A Greater Role for Egypt's First Lady
description: Suzanne Mubarak, the wife of the Egyptian President, rejects the job description of ''first lady.'' That, she says, is ''an imported, a Western title'' in Egypt.

title: IF WE'RE SO RICH, WHY AREN'T WE SMART?
description: MONEY AND CLASS IN AMERICA Notes and Observations on Our Civil Religion. By Lewis H. Lapham. 244 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: A TOWN LOST IN THE GALAXY
description: SANDMOUTH By Ronald Frame. 476 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: At the Met, New Gloss for an Emperor's Retreat
description: Roman fantasies, en-riched by architecture and mythology, dominate the 17 painted panels from the bedroom walls of an ancient country villa that have been restored and reinstalled at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Off view for almost 40 years, these shimmering frescoes show aristocratic swans -wings spread, necks crooked and holding swagged ropes in their beaks - the sea nymph Galatea relaxing on a dolphin and several exquisite candelabra sprouting leaves and dangling jewels.

title: Back Home But Out of Place
description: IT was when I was walking into the lobby of one of New York's finest old hotels that I realized the world isn't small after all. I had just returned from summer vacation. The distance between the remote Irish coastal village where we have a holiday cottage and this gilded and brocaded interior was so vast that they seemed separated not only by an ocean but also by centuries. I had been in Ireland only a week earlier, but I felt as if I had been flung from one life into another by catapult.

title: Perspectives: Midtown Theaters; Offering an Incentive for Preservation
description: A novel zoning incentive from New York City planners, intended to preserve Broadway's legitimate theaters, is heading toward final Board of Estimate action as part of a package of midtown zoning amendments.

title: NASHVILLE OFFICIAL ASKS CURB ON SEX
description: A bill to ban sexual activity in about 200 city buildings as a means of fighting sexual harassment of female employees has drawn some ridicule, but the sponsor says the issue needs to be addressed.

title: DATA UPDATE: February 14, 1988
PSYCHOLOGY, TOPOLOGY AND THE WISE OLD MAN
description: JUNG A Biography. By Gerhard Wehr. Translated by David M. Weeks. Illustrated. 549 pp. Boston: Shambhala. $25.

title: Soiled Sails In the South Seas
description: THEY'RE KNOWN, TECHNICAL-ly, as ''tension membrane structures.'' But officials of World Expo 88, which opens in Brisbane, Australia, on April 30, call them ''sun sails,'' which seems appropriate; the theme of Expo 88 is, after all, ''Leisure in the Age of Technology.'' Made of a polyester fabric, the eight translucent canopies, each about 390 feet in diameter and together sheltering a ground area of close to 360,000 square feet, form the most striking architectural feature of the exposition site. Rising to 160 feet and fixed in place by a complex system of cables and masts, the sun sails are strung together so that visitors may traverse the site without leaving shelter. They were designed by a West German engineer, and chosen, says David Jay, deputy director of site development, ''to give the site some verticality, plus some visible unification.''

title: Froese Is Ready With No Complaints
description: Two months ago, they took away Bob Froese's goal, thereby erasing his barely dry name from the record books. Shortly afterward, he had his regular spot in the Rangers' goaltending rotation revoked and since then his name has rarely been penciled into the lineup.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: KILLING THE BLUES. By Paul Johnson. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The voice in Paul Johnson's first novel is tough, amusing, cantankerous and sometimes astonishingly gentle. And the story - well, it will do formidable things to your heart rate and keep you looking over your shoulder until the very last page.

title: GAMES BEGIN ON HIGH NOTE
description: The long countdown for Calgary that began more than six years ago reached its climax today as Jeanne Sauve, the Governor General of Canada and Queen Elizabeth's representative, declared open the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we look back at history, always when there is a tendency toward improvement in our relations we see some military provocation.'' Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman. [ 1:5. ]

title: Wendell S. Merick; Journalist, 60
description: Wendell S. Merick, a retired correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, died of chronic liver disease Thursday at his home in Bethesda, Md.. He was 60 years old. Mr. Merick was a correspondent with the United Press, now United Press International. He also worked for The Boston Traveler. He joined U.S. News & World Report in 1966 and retired in 1983.

title: AS CHILDREN AND OTHERS SEE IT
description: EMPEROR OF THE AIR By Ethan Canin. 179 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: HOSPITAL AIDES SEEK U.S. HELP
description: EXECUTIVES representing 45 New Jersey hospitals have told members of Congress that the Federal Government should help the state's financially strained hospitals by appropriating additional funds.

title: Tools of Childhood
description: Some things are inexplicably magical. One is ''Goodnight Moon,'' the children's book by Margaret Wise Brown, wonderfully illustrated by Clement G. Hurd and brought back to mind by news of his recent death.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: In the end the answer comes down to this: If you're a Yankee fan, Mantle was the best. If you're a Giant fan, Mays was the greatest. If you're (still) a Brooklyn Dodger fan, the Duke was better than the two of them put together. MICHAEL J. ESPOSITO Brooklyn

title: PROSPECTS
description: What's Next for G.M.?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE OTHER HAND CLAPPING. By Marco Vassi. (Permanent Press, $17.95.) Tentatively at first, and then with more determination, a man wanders away from his marriage. He falls in love, not with another woman but with the wide, inner sea of Zen meditation. Cross-legged on a small pillow, he begins to explore the world within his own head.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Branchburg Township $144,000 59 Station Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; 2-car detached garage, patio, dining room; taxes $1,243. Livingston $435,000 12 Homestead Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; den, C/A, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $5,266. Madison $425,000 76 Pomeroy Road 5-bedroom, l 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; den, patio, wooded lot, fireplace; taxes $2,380. Maplewood $190,000 122-124 Parker Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 34-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun room, fireplace; taxes $4,440. Short Hills $$416,000 54 Cambridge Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; C/A, full basement, porch, 2-car attached garage; taxes $5,935. South Brunswick $131,500 8 Foxtail Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old town-house condominium; deck, dining room, fireplace; monthly charges $116, taxes $1,694. OTHER AREAS Guilford, Conn. $327,000 79 Surrey Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old contemporary; alarm system, C/A, 1 acre; taxes, $2,738. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $290,000 Crow Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, playroom, stone walls, 1 acre; taxes $4,343. Massapequa Park, L.I. $382,000 121 Harbor Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 26-year-old split level; new kitchen, decks, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $6,400.

title: Q AND A
description: Security Deposit Question: For several years we received interest on the security deposit for the apartment we rent. This year we received notification that the interest had been withheld due to the Interest and Dividend Tax Compliance Act of 1983. Can you tell me what this act is and why we did not get interest this year? . . . C. H., Manhattan Answer: The law you refer to is a New York statute that requires landlords to pay interest on security deposits. It appears that your problem is the result of a clerical error through which your preference for how the interest on your security was to be paid was changed. Ask your landlord about the mistake.

title: How to Lose Influence
description: An important figure in the community of American support for Israel commented privately the other day about the need for Palestinians to play an effective part if negotiations are to get anywhere in the Middle East. It is essential, he said, that ''an empowered Palestinian leadership step forward.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
RADON TESTING
description: LEAD: ELEANOR Z. HIBBEN spends a great deal of free time in the basement of her Yorktown home, where she keeps such things as her sewing machine and her television set. Because something else may be lurking down there, Mrs. Hibben has been a little leery lately when descending the stairs.

title: Gay Spokesmen
description: To the Editor:

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: Mantle's injuries are legend, but Snider's were just as debilitating. Mays has to emerge as the best because his prime lasted longest. LEE DEJASU Rehoboth, Mass.

title: Trade Gap Narrows For the 2d Month
description: The trade deficit for December was the lowest in 11 months, coming in at $12.2 billion. With imports unchanged, the improvement came from a 4.2 percent gain in exports, to a record $24.8 billion. Most predictions had been for a December deficit of at least $13 billion, and the financial markets strengthened when the report came out. The December number was about 7.7 percent below November's deficit, and the November figure had been 25 percent below the October level. Still, the total deficit for 1987 was a record $171.22 billion.

title: BUSH ASSAILS DOLE'S LEADERSHIP SKILLS
description: Vice President Bush delivered a detailed attack on Bob Dole's Senate leadership skills today, suggesting that he was to blame for some of President Reagan's legislative setbacks.

title: Sunday Observer; My Tinny Valentine
description: ONE OF MY FAVOR-ite love songs is ''Tea for Two,'' probably because it is one of the few love songs I can sing. There is a better love song in ''Don Giovanni,'' a serenade the Don sings under a balcony to woo one of his ladies, but it requires a mandolin accompaniment and the voice of Cesare Siepi, neither of which I can manage.

title: Cincinnati Bus Strike Ends
description: Bus drivers and mechanics overwhelmingly approved a contract proposal Friday night to end an 11-day strike that had left 90,000 daily riders without public transportation. The Queen City Metro transit system hoped to restore bus service by Sunday morning.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CARLSBAD, CALIF.;
Green Light For the Hunts
description: LEAD: THE approval process for the Pacific Rim Country Club and Resort, a planned community with a resort complex in the coastal city of Carlsbad, 30 minutes north of downtown San Diego, took Hunt Properties Inc. six years and cost some $2 million in planning and consulting fees.

title: RECOMBINANT JAZZ: EVERY STRUCTURE TELLS A STORY
description: For six decades, ever since Louis Armstrong thrust soloists into the foreground of jazz, the vast majority of jazz performances have had the same form: theme-solos-theme. But since the 1930's, at least, some jazz musicians have been trying alternatives - narrative pieces, symphonic-scale suites and rhapsodies, free-form improvisations. During the 1970's and 1980's, in the wake of the free-jazz revolution, jazz composers have been wrestling with structure again, this time with all sorts of new options.

title: Magazine Now Calls Waldheim Paper a Fake
description: The West German news magazine Der Spiegel said today that it ''regretted'' publishing a document that purportedly linked President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to war crimes. The document was declared a forgery by the Yugoslav authorities last week.

title: Letting Off Steam: Con Ed Rebates
description: To those unfamiliar with central air-conditioning systems, steam seems the last thing to make them go. But two types of systems are powered by steam heated to more than 400 degrees. To remind building owners and co-op boards that steam can do more than provide heat, Consolidated Edison, which sells the steam it makes to generate electricity, is offering rebates until the end of the year of up to 50 percent to those that either upgrade a steam system or install a new one. In addition to increasing familiarity with steam air conditioning, the program will cut its original cost, said Patricia A. Valente, manager of space conditioning marketing. Though less expensive to operate, steam coolers can cost almost twice as much to install than electric systems.

title: 2 Physicists Dismissed In Reactor Complaint
description: Two health physicists who complained about the safety of a nuclear reactor at the Georgia Institute of Technology have been dismissed by school officials, who said the moves were part of a program to improve safety and productivity.

title: Presbytery Leader Assesses Her Role
description: LEAD: AS A child on Edisto Island, off South Carolina, Carrie Washington and her family attended the Edisto Presbyterian Church.

title: Resort Competition Rises as Skiing Popularity Levels Off
description: IN 1936, when the Union Pacific Railroad began developing the mountain valleys around Ketchum, Idaho, into America's first alpine ski resort, engineers were given a daunting challenge: how to transport skiers to the top of the mountain, so they could then savor the thrill of rushing back down.

title: New on Riverside: As Good as Old
description: The first new apartment building on Riverside Drive in 35 years was designed to look 35 years old. Though the 21-story condominium now rising at 94th Street will not attempt to match the weathered appearance of the venerable structures to either side, it will use the same materials. An Indiana limestone base will give way to Norman brick. Vertical recesses, terraced setbacks and punched windows will set it apart from most new buildings, but allow it to fit in with its prewar neighbors. The design by Bruce Fowle was approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The design was voluntarily submitted because the structure will be within a proposed historic district.

title: TRACES OF HISTORY': ART OF AFRO-AMERICA AT ROBESON GALLERY
description: BLACK History Month has rolled around again and, with it, exhibitions by black artists.

title: Georgetown Pledges Equality for Gay Groups
description: Georgetown University has announced that it will accord ''equal treatment'' to groups of homosexual students and agreed to provide a $3,740 subsidy to such a group at its law school.

title: LICENSE CASE SENDS COLLEGE TO VERMONT
description: LEAD: FRANCES J. CANELLI of East Haven, is in Vermont this weekend taking courses to complete a college degree in human services.

title: ON THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD'S TRAIL
description: LEAD: KAY AMORY-MOSHIER remembers going to the Park Street African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in Peekskill as a child during the Depression and being impressed by the large white ''crazy-looking'' cabinets in the basement of the 1852 structure.

title: FROM THE FOLKS WHO GAVE YOU LIQUID PAPER
description: MOTHERS OF INVENTION From the Bra to the Bomb: Forgotten Women & Their Unforgettable Ideas. By Ethlie Ann Vare and Greg Ptacek. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: City Auctions
description: To the Editor:

title: When Women's Work Is Done
description: A DECADE ago, outplacement firms saw relatively few women. But as more women reach senior management posts, where outplacement counseling is a company-paid benefit, that is changing.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: SOME books aspire to do more than inform; they enlist our advocacy to attack a current ideology.

title: Focus: Chicago; The Loop's Expanding
description: A $170 million office development planned for 1.25 acres over some railroad tracks near the Chicago River is expected to continue the outward push of office growth from Chicago's commercial core, the Loop.

title: Yugo GVX Is in Its Element in U.S. and Remains Unfussy
description: The man who named this town, they say, was a transplanted New Yorker who combined ''California'' and ''Saratoga'' to make himself feel at home. But that was then and now is now, and what is at home here today is the Napa Valley's newest winery, Clos Pegase.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN CUISINE IN SCARSDALE
description: LEAD: IT is with good reason that Il Cigno celebrates its third prosperous year in a vest-pocket shopping center of Scarsdale. This popular restaurant brings to the area interesting and for the most part well-executed Italian cuisine in attractive surroundings. Only the brick half-wall detracts from the nifty dining room with its deep salmon walls and smoked-glass partition setting apart a long bar.

title: SUFFOLK TEEN-AGERS FIND RESPONSIBILITY BEGINS WITH AN EGG
description: LEAD: AT the beginning of the week, it sounded like fun, carrying an egg around and caring for it like a baby. But by the end of 10 days, most of the students in Alice King's child psychology class at East Hampton High School were glad to give the baby back.

title: Two Literary Lions' Dens
description: LEAD: LITERARY types can sometimes be heard referring to the ''landscape'' of literature, as if the world's accumulated poems and novels were so many Himalayan ranges on the globe of human creativity. Yet, in American literature particularly, the idea of a landscape has a profoundly nonmetaphorical meaning.

title: Film: Whoopi Goldberg in 'Telephone'
description: THE idea for ''The Telephone'' might have seemed great at around 3 in the morning, after a long night out.

title:
GARDENING;
IT'S TIME TO SOW GOOD SEED
description: LEAD: AFTER several months of feeling deprived of homegrown vegetable tastes, I start to salivate while looking at the pages of seed catalogues. One of the most commonly grown vegetables is the love apple, also known as the tomato, a member of the Nightshade Family or Solanaceae. As a glance in any garden catalogue shows, there are plenty of tomato seed offerings.

title: State Aide Offers Advice on Joining a Health Club
description: LEAD: ONE OUNCE of prevention is worth a pound of cure, and James J. Barry Jr., director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs, has some tips for consumers who are considering joining a health club.

title: Consultants Pull Strings Of Electoral Marionettes
description: THE name of Louis Del Santo, a candidate for the Poughkeepsie Town Board, was signed to letters sent to residents of his ward during the 1985 election campaign, but the first he knew about what the letters said was when he looked in his mailbox like any other voter. And though his campaign literature advocated a master plan for the town, he testified before the New York State Commission on Integrity in Albany last month, ''I didn't know what a master plan was.''

title: 'What The Butler Saw'
description: ''JUST when one least expects it, the unexpected always happens.'' So observes Dr. Rance, an investigator ''from the mental branch of the government,'' who has come to check up on Dr. Prentice's private psychiatric clinic, a place where madness, according to Mrs. Prentice, is not cured but liberated and exploited.

title: THE ART OF MAILBOX STUFFING
description: FLOODED. The word brings to mind torrential downpours building to such awesome proportions that entire roads, submerged underwater, are temporarily lost from sight. That's a word picture that for many people comes to mind with the mention of the word.

title: U.S.A. MAKES FAST START
description: The game was a shooting spree, a scenario that fit the offense-obsessed United States hockey team and enabled it to race to a 10-6 victory over Austria in its opening game at the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: SHOWER DOORS FOR AN ELEGANT TOUCH
description: IF your bathtub is installed in a recess, that is, if the tub is surrounded by walls on three sides, creating a built-in appearance, one of the easiest ways to add a touch of elegance is to install bathtub shower doors in place of a shower curtain.

title:
THEATER;
A Dreamscape From the Dark Side Of America
description: LEAD: Get Len Jenkin going on the subject of carnivals and watch him light up and buzz like a penny arcade. It has been 40-odd years since his boyhood idylls around the freak shows of Coney Island's Surf Avenue, and he still hasn't recovered.

title: THE BLOODIEST OF WARS
description: BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM The Civil War Era. By James M. McPherson. Illustrated. 904 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30; after July 1, $35.

title: War on Smog Is Rude Awakening for Athens
description: With a sudden sweep of measures, the Greek authorities have begun a crusade against air pollution that seems to tilt at the country's intertwined obsessions: smog and the siesta.

title: Gephardt and Simon Fight for 2d Place
description: Richard A. Gephardt and Paul Simon clawed at each other today in a fight for second place in the New Hampshire Democratic primary next Tuesday. They were battling despite the fact that since 1952 no one has been elected President without coming in first in the New Hampshire primary.

title: Austria Provides Model for a Palestinian Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: CONQUERING THE PEAK
description: ''People hate to stand in line, and they especially hate standing in a banking line at lunchtime,'' said LeRoy M. Richey, explaining one of the reasons for The Bank of New York's new part-time teller program.

title: Notes on the Soviet Union; Hints of Internal Friction on Afghan Withdrawal
description: Some unusual breaks in Kremlin routine in recent weeks have suggested the possibility of internal friction over Soviet policy in Afghanistan.

title: When Will the O-T-C Wake Up?
description: DULLNESS attracts Binkley Shorts. He figures that by buying good-quality dull stocks - those small, obscure ones that nobody pays much attention to - you can make thrilling amounts of money. ''The duller a company appears on the surface,'' he said, ''the more invisible it becomes and thus the greater the opportunity. I like to be the only guy in town looking at something.''

title: OH MY CRACKING PISTONS!
description: I GAVE THE WOMAN A CHECK FOR $500, drove off in her '74 Datsun and left behind a whole life style. That was two years ago. Up to then, the only cars I had ever owned were Porsches. But as I wound the steep slopes of western Connecticut on my way home, my mind wasn't heavy with comparisons of hill power, or rack and pinions or swaybars. By jumping the yuppie car market, I had decomplicated my life automotively. I was ecstatic.

title: MY FRIENDS THE HIT MEN
description: DONNIE BRASCO My Undercover Life in the Mafia. By Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: New American Library. $18.95.

title: Some Vanity, Some Plates
description: October's market crash may have humbled some Masters of the Universe, as Tom Wolfe calls the movers and shakers in his recent New York novel, but not the owners of a brown Rolls-Royce Corniche convertible seen the other day on East 61st Street. Such a car sells for about $184,000, so a certain audacity emanates from the vanity license plate. It reads: 2ND CAR.

title: NEW BRITAIN TO ALLOW ANONYMOUS AIDS TESTS
description: LEAD: THE New Britain Board of Health voted last week to allow anonymous AIDS testing because of concerns of possible discrimination resulting from a positive test for the AIDS antibody.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: Duke Snider.In some hard-to-define way, he represented all that was the unique baseball team - the Dodgers of the late 40's and 50's. MATTHEW BAUM Baltimore

title: ITALIAN FARE FOR HEALTHY APPETITES
description: PEPPERCORN GRILL in Hartford is just what the ravenous diner ordered. Slipping easily into the high-ceilinged storefront space formerly occupied by Panache, this sparkling new eatery has high-voltage visual impact. Its white walls hold etchings, paintings and bright neon sculptures counterpointed by red chairs and park benches and track lighting in a black ceiling.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: STORES FILLING NEW YONKERS MALL

title: INSIDE
description: A Ritual Vote in Paraguay

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: Mantle was clearly superior to Mays, which is obvious at the first look at statistics. The two had identical lifetime slugging percentages, at .557, but Mantle's on-base percentage was higher, .420 to .383. Since these are the two most important offensive categories, Mantle already has him beat, but Mantle also had a higher stolen-base percentage, .80 to .77, and grounded into six fewer double plays per year than Mays. DAVID SIMONS Westfield, N.J.

title: RECYCLING PROGRAM IS OUTLINED
description: LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke released his long-awaited recycling plan for Westchester last Tuesday, and the initial reaction from members of the County Board of Legislators, who will have to approve it, has been enthusiastic.

title: Dr. Krim's Crusade
description: AS SHE SAT ON THE podium at Christie's, the auction house on Manhattan's Upper East Side, Mathilde Krim was in familiar company. She was sharing the stage with Leo Castelli, the SoHo gallery owner, and her friend Elizabeth Taylor, who set the tone for the evening by quoting Marcel Proust: ''Only through art can we get outside of ourselves and know another's view of the universe . . . and see landscapes which would otherwise have remained unknown.''

title: Hamilton Grange Needs Furniture (and $2 Million)
description: There is a certain sweet sadness to the Grange.

title: An Alternative To the D.H. Rule
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Israeli Payments Plan Cited in Memo to Meese
description: Planned payments to the Government of Israel and the Israeli Labor Party were mentioned in a 1985 memo to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d describing a proposed $1 billion Iraqi pipeline project that never was brought to fruition, according to a Swiss businessman who was a partner in the plan.

title: Queens Museum Inquiry Ends
description: An investigation into the use of city money by a museum in Queens has ended without criminal charges, according to a spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, which conducted the inquiry.

title: MUSIC FAIR AIMS FOR YOUNG
description: WAY before the advent of MTV and VCR's, the Westbury Music Fair, the eclectic entertainment center, was making a pitch for younger audiences. Its co-producer, Shelly Gross, even remembers the time Stevie Wonder was an opening act - he doesn't remember the act that followed - and the Doors and the Beegees played the theater in the round in the early 1960's.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NORFOLK;
IN THE 'ICEBOX OF CONNECTICUT,' WINTER CAN BE PARADISE
description: LEAD: Stillwhite your houses And slate blue your chimney plumes Snowlocked in silence As frostfeathers fall. - Bill Perry Norfolk poet AT the town skating rink, John Funchion, wearing a jaunty green-and-white ski hat, lined up a shot with his hockey stock as his 10-year-old daughter, Amanda, guarded the goal.

title: MISS MCKENZIE ENGAGED
description: Catherine Bates Mckenzie and Donald Campbell Bowman Jr., 1987 graduates of the University of Georgia School of Law, plan to marry in May. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Mckenzie of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bowman of Columbus, Ga. The future bride's father is president of the Japan/Canada, Australasia/Pacific Group of Sterling Drug in New York. Mr. Bowman's father, an accountant in Columbus, retired from the Army as a lieutenant colonel.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FOOL'S SANCTUARY. By Jennifer Johnston. (Viking, $15.95.) Sometimes writers seem to set their stories in flashback because they don't trust the story itself to move us, relying instead on the sentiment that memory creates. Such is the case with ''Fool's Sanctuary,'' Jennifer Johnston's seventh novel, in which Miranda Martin, a dying old woman, recalls the weekend that was to change the course of her life: It is in Ireland just after World War I, a land bristling with civil tensions, where the young girl falls in love.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor. I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there. Is there anything else you can suggest?

title: SECURITY PROBLEMS AT SCHOOL GAMES
description: LEAD: THE last-second shot that recently gave the Roosevelt High School boys' basketball team a dramatic overtime victory should have brought the house down. Only there was nobody home.

title: TAKEN BY SURPRISE BY GRIEF'S POTENCY
description: ON a Sunday in June 1986, my two teen-age daughters and I celebrated my parents' 47th wedding anniversary with them. The next day, I drove from my home in Connecticut to theirs in New York to pick up my mother and drive her to a hospital for elective surgery, a hip replacement.

title: Outdoors; Seminars Are Reeling In Anglers for a Day
description: THE average fisherman's hunger to learn more about his sport is insatiable.

title: James FitzPatrick, 71, Ex-Head Of Power Agency and Lawmaker
description: James A. FitzPatrick, a former state assemblyman who served as chairman of the New York State Power Authority from 1963 to 1977, died yesterday at Champlain Valley Hospital in Plattsburgh, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Plattsburgh.

title: On Safari in Kenya
description: CAMELS are wondrous creatures.

title: ANNE MARIE ZISSU TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benedict Zissu of Paris of the engagement of their daughter Anne Marie Zissu to Charles Austin Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Stone of Port Washington, L.I. A May wedding is planned by Miss Zissu, a professor of finance at Temple University, and Mr. Stone, a doctoral candidate in economics at the Graduate Center of City University.

title: Amid Murky Struggle, Italian Premier Is Told to Try Again
description: President Francesco Cossiga tonight ordered Giovanni Goria, who resigned as Prime Minister on Wednesday, to again seek the confidence of a Parliament that has repeatedly defeated him. The President cited the need for Parliament to pass ''indispensable'' budget legislation.

title: Only the Long-Term Capital Gains Need Help; Indexing for Equity
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Guide
description: NEW BRITISH FARCE

title: Sea Urchins
description: To the Editor: I was surprised by the first-aid piece by Betsy Wade (Practical Traveler, Dec. 20) in which she recommended using tweezers or a needle to remove sea urchin spines from your skin.

title: Loved Ones Inspire Gifts To Neediest
description: ''In loving memory of those dearest to me who left with me their love and hope for the future,'' Steffi Stern of Elmhurst, Queens, wrote. The note accompanied a $25 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, earmarked for the Children's Aid Society.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: It is the durability factor that would persuade me to pick Mays over Mantle. HENRY L. NAIZTAT Merrick. L.I.

title: New Hampshire Will Give Iowa Vote Its Meaning
description: AND so, at long last, after two years of preliminary skirmishing, strategizing, campaigning, fund raising, organizing, pontificating and poll-taking, the electorate, or at least a tiny sliver of it, has finally joined the labor of picking the two major parties' 1988 Presidential nominees.

title: WANTED: HITLER'S SCIENTISTS
description: THE PAPERCLIP CONSPIRACY The Hunt for the Nazi Scientists By Tom Bower. 309 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: U.S. Is Asked to Sharply Limit Use of Sedative
description: A private organization asked the Government Friday to sharply restrict the use of a widely used intravenous sedative that the group says has been associated with 40 deaths in its two years of use.

title: Next Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Q AND A
description: Older Drivers Question: I understand that Ireland has a limit of 70 years old on drivers renting cars. Are there such limitations in other European countries? - B. K., Ambler, Pa. - Answer: Drivers over age 70 can rent a car in Ireland. It is true that some auto rental companies there (not Ireland itself) set an age limit of 69 or 70, but the two largest agencies, which are both represented in the United States, do not. The one with the most cars is Dan Dooley Rent-a-Car (800-331-9301 or, in New Jersey, 201-381-8948). It has outlets in downtown Dublin, the Dublin, Shannon and Cork airports and at the ferry ports. Dooley sets no top age limit. The other agency is Flynn Brothers Rent-a-Car, or Auto Ireland, as it is described in the United States (800-343-0395 or, in Massachusetts, 617-899-7733), with outlets in Dublin, Shannon, Cork and Galway. Flynn officially limits rentals to people up to age 75 but sometimes waives the requirement. Both agencies rent minibuses (standard shift) as well as cars. Both have an age minimum of 21 years.

title: Art
description: The print, more than the painting, has been the chosen medium for political and social comment by artists. Traditionally, it's had a wider audience, and it's closer to the printed word. In recent years, though, we've been trained to view prints as more related to painting, alternate means for the artful expression of forms and colors. But the truth is that artists today - and good ones - are still using the print for its powerful function of message-bearing. In a new show called ''Committed to Print'' - which it says is the first museum exhibition ''to explore social and political subjects in American art from the 1960's to the present'' -the Museum of Modern Art gives us a look (through April 19) at this lively other usage.

title: FEELING THE LOSS OF 2 LIGHTS OF MONTAUK
description: WHEN I became editor of a weekly newspaper in Bridgehampton last May, there was a letter on my desk from Norman Kean's office in New York congratulating me. I didn't know why this busy producer of ''Oh! Calcutta!'' and other plays was taking an interest in me or the paper.

title: Classrooms To Condos
description: THE classrooms where generations of Braintree students struggled with algebra and passed notes are well on their way to becoming the kitchens and bedrooms of condominiums, the result of a conversion project by Francis X. Messina, Braintree's largest developer.

title: What's Doing In Puerto Vallarta
description: It is still possible to hear a rooster crow at dawn or midnight in Puerto Vallarta, but one must listen carefully. The city is on the go almost nonstop, especially from now until Easter. Streets are jammed with cars, trucks and shoppers in the daytime. Restaurants and bars are open late; 10 P.M. is a respectable time for supper. A little later, the discotheques crank up and boogie till almost dawn. The little fishing village at the mouth of the Rio Cuale about 400 miles northwest of Mexico City vanished long ago.

title: TEEN-AGERS HELP PUPILS AND ADULTS TO READ
description: LEAD: VIOLET BRACHE, a member of Literacy Volunteers Valley Shore, will never forget one man in particular whom she taught to read.

title: 'Moonstruck' Hits Us in the Heart; 'Broadcast News' Aims for the Head - And Misses
description: Somebody once de-fined literature as anything that was worth reading twice. On the same principle, you might say that any movie worth seeing twice qualifies as a classic - in which case, I am duty-bound to claim classic status for ''Moonstruck.'' Seeing it just after it had opened, and knowing nothing about it, I was enchanted. Seeing it a second time, I found it every bit as good - and very much better than that equally acclaimed romantic comedy of the hour, ''Broadcast News,''

title: MEG MCKEE ENGAGED TO ROBERT T. MULLANEY
description: The engagement of Margaret Greenway McKee to Robert Trainer Mullaney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mullaney of Westfield, N.J., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mary Greenway Carr McKee of Memphis and John Baskervill McKee of Friars Point, Miss.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: Who was better, Mantle or Mays? The answer is ungrammatically obvious. Both of them. KEN MACKENZIE Guilford, Conn.

title: Helping to Savor Mom's Apple Pie
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Big East Conference; Hoyas Overcome Orangemen, 71-69
description: Mark Tillmon scored 19 points and Charles Smith added 17 today as Georgetown rallied twice for a 71-69 Big East Conference victory over Syracuse.

title: Headliners; Conciliatorily, Kirk
description: A rather large bone of contention has been formally settled in the dog-eat-dog world of high culture. Over the objections of some people who will now be his subordinates, Kirk Varnedoe, a professor at New York University's Institute of Fine Art, was named last week to succeed William S. Rubin as director of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art. Mr. Varnedoe's appointment to what is perhaps the most influential curatorial position in the field of modern art had been expected. But some on the staff lobbied for other candidates, noting that while the Modern is a museum of 20th century art, Mr. Varnedoe's main interest has been in 19th century works. The new director said there was ''a possibility of antagonism built into the situation,'' but added that ''the problems I have with the staff'' did not seem insurmountable.

title: Soldier of Fortune Magazine Is Sued Over Slaying
description: A suit against the magazine Soldier of Fortune, brought by the family of the victim of a hired killer, will be heard in Federal District Court here next week.

title: Singapore Plan for Vote Change Stirs Dispute
description: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, asserting that British-style parliamentary democracy is not adequate for the country's long-term needs, is proposing a new electoral system in which voters in some constituencies will choose teams of legislators rather than single candidates.

title: EMERGENCY WORKERS AND AIDS
description: In his article ''An AIDS Nightmare'' (Jan. 17), John B. Judis reported on the moving case of Jewel Foster Lyles, a pregnant woman with the AIDS virus who was murdered. Emergency workers cited their ''right to know'' whether they had been exposed to the virus and called for full use of the criminal law to punish those who intentionally try to transmit AIDS. I would like to recount the facts of a similar case, in which I was an expert witness, and suggest sensible public-health alternatives to a ''right to know'' or draconian use of the criminal law.

title: Commercial Property: Small Office Buildings; Developers Seek Alternative Uses in a Soft Market
description: Shifting market conditions can move buildings in mysterious ways. Take the case of 110 East 55th Street, where the developer of a 19-story office project that has been sitting vacant since it opened half a year ago is pondering plans to convert it into a hotel.

title: Embattled Yonkers Mayor: A Tumultuous First Few Weeks in Office
description: LEAD: SIX weeks after taking office, Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko of Yonkers, the 28-year-old Democrat who swept to victory in a stunning upset last November, is waging a battle for political survival.

title: Joyner-Kersee Sets Mark
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee jumped farther than ever tonight at the annual Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track and field meet, far enough to claim an American record in the long jump, 23 feet 1/2 inch.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: Where Mays prevails is in mythology. He has been raised to a level where poets sing his heroics, where fathers brag to sons about having seen him. Mantle is frozen as a good ol' boy, fronting a saloon, buddy to Martin and Ford, running to fat in public.

title: Thomas M. Peters, 99, Ex-Arizona Lawmaker
description: Thomas M. Peters, a former Arizona state legislator who succeeded in several businesses and then turned his attention to charities for children, died Tuesday at the Venice (Fla.) Hospital. He was 99 years old.

title: In Britain, Renewed Labor Unrest
description: THE sprawling car plant stands abandoned, and outside the factory gate picketing workers cluster around an oil-drum fire, smoking and talking, as the police keep watch from a nearby van.

title:
GARDENING;
TAKING ADVANTAGE OF WINTER FOR SPRING
description: LEAD: ANY sign of spring can reinforce the feelings of restlessness people feel at this time of year.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: An everyday player can compete in five areas: hit for average, hit for power, run, field and throw. Mays could do all five excellently. A lifetime .300 hitter, 660 home runs, a base-stealing threat at all times, he made great catches (see Vic Wertz, 1954 World Series) and great throws (see Billy Cox thrown out at home trying to score from third on a single to right-center field). RONALD E. BERTI New York

title: Gurkhas Attack in India
description: Militant Gurkhas blew up road bridges, set fire to government offices and ambushed a police patrol on Friday night as a 40-day strike called to press their demand for autonomy took hold, security officials said.

title: Gossage the Cub
description: At the age of 36, he has been around, and now after four seasons with the San Diego Padres, Goose Gossage will take another turn, this time with the Chicago Cubs, a team he helped San Diego defeat for the 1984 National League championship. The reliever, who came to the Padres from the Yankees as a free agent in 1984, agreed to be traded to the Cubs in a four-player deal that sent Keith Moreland, a hard-hitting third baseman and outfielder to the Padres.

title: The Case Against Irradiation of Food
description: IRRADIATION: A preservation technique that drenches food in a shower of radioactive gamma rays to destroy microorganisms, control insects or delay the ripening of fruits or vegetables.

title: Bedford-Stuyvesant: The First Condos
description: A three-story brick building at 876 Jefferson Avenue, completed last month, offers the first six condominiums in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, beating out two other nearby projects for that distinction by a few months. But when Del Dellal, a partner in MFD Holding Ltd., purchased the vacant building at a city auction in 1986, he was rejected by several banks for financing and had to finance the $280,000 project himself. ''This was just to show the banking community that it could be done,'' said Mr. Dellal. Now, he said, he is considering two larger neighborhood buildings for renovation.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Nashua, N.H.: Growth Brings A New Hotel
description: LEAD: This bustling high-tech region got its third and most ambitious full-service hotel of the decade late last month when the $23.7 million Clarion Somerset opened in Nashua, a growing city on the New Hampshire-Massachusetts border.

title: Elisa Monte: Choreographer Seeking Ancient Beginnings
description: 'I ALWAYS SUSPECTED I would choreograph, but I never knew at what point it would start,'' said Elisa Monte, the modern-dance choreographer whose company opens on Tuesday for a one-week season at the Joyce Theater. That calm assurance also characterizes Ms. Monte's work, which pulsates with a forceful energy and a clear intelligence.

title: Now, About That Chandelier That Goes Crashing
description: Shall we begin by acknowl-edging that ''The Phantom of the Opera'' never did make sense?

title: Evening Wear, In Brief
description: POSSIBLY the shortest spring and summer evening dresses in the recent Paris couture showings were the sequin-studded, printed silk styles by Per Spook. Flowers or butterflies are among the prints. These sophisticated patterns were used for dresses so brief that the designer felt compelled to add matching shorts.

title: The U.S. Need to Lead in Israel
description: While the situation in the occupied territories continues to deteriorate, neither the Palestinians nor the Israelis can or will make the first genuine move toward reconciliation. Only strong action from Washington can end the violence.

title: Dance: City Ballet in Balanchine's 'Bugaku'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Bugaku'' is very peculiar. It often looks cliche-ridden, even corny. But the cliches turn into surprises, and even the corniest scene has a serious point. ''Bugaku'' was as fascinating as ever when the New York City Ballet danced it Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: THE DEATH SHE WANTED
description: LEAD: CLOUDS FROM BOTH SIDES An Autobiography. By Julie Tullis. Illustrated. 322 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $17.95.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: In the Mood Starring Patrick Dempsey, Beverly D'Angelo, Talia Balsam, Michael Constantine. Directed by Phil Alden Robinson. 1987. Lorimar Home Video. 98 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG-13.

title: THE DILEMMA OF HIGHER PRICES
description: THE dollar's drop in the international currency market is boosting the cost of photography. Since the year began, companies as geographically far apart as E. Leitz in West Germany and Nikon in Japan have raised the list prices of their cameras, lenses and accessories. Given that the dollar's fall has been especially steep against the German mark and Japanese yen, and that Germany and Japan are the major players in photography equipment these days, none of this is too surprising.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GARISH DAYS. By Lynn Caraganis. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) A cleanly written novel about an incredibly shallow 19-year-old, ''Garish Days'' is the story of an American's first Parisian jaunt and her subsequent coming of age shortly before World War II. Lynn Caraganis, who writes for The New Yorker and The Atlantic, has a vivid, economical style that is sadly limited here to physical description.

title: Origin of Virus Is Murky, But Signs Point to Africa
description: The evidence is getting stronger that the AIDS virus first simmered in Africa before it exploded into a worldwide epidemic. But whether the AIDS virus is a relatively recent mutation or an ancient germ that has resided in some humans for tens of thousands of years is a mystery.

title: In the Region: Long Island
description: Recent Sales

title: Focus on Current Directions in Jewelry
description: ''JEWELRY plays a greater role in today's world than it ever did in the past,'' Oppi Untracht observed a few years ago in the introduction to his comprehensive volume ''Jewelry: Concepts and Technology.''

title: A Task Force Plays Beat the Clock
description: THE first time Robert R. Glauber saw room 1116 at the Federal Reserve building in New York, it depressed him. That day in early November the big room where he would spend the next two months had one chair in it, one desk and one telephone.

title: Brazil
description: To the Editor: I appreciated the Dec. 27 ''Following the Sun'' feature with emphasis on the Brazil discoveries of Paraty and Sao Jose da Coroa Grande. I lived in Brazil for two and a half years and am familiar with both areas. They are ideal for the American who wishes to see parts of Brazil that the ordinary tourist would not see.

title: Winter Shopping Season Ends as 'Spring' Arrives
description: ARMED with a bag full of money - sorry, no discount coupons accepted - Peter O'Malley and friends took off on a shopping spree this winter.

title: 'AT-RISK STUDENTS' IN PROGRAM TO HELP KEEP THEM IN SCHOOL
description: THEY are talking about going to college now, and some are even planning their careers.

title: DESPITE THE ELECTIONS, 'FULL PLATE' IN CONGRESS
description: LEAD: WHILE the politics of 1988 focus on who next will occupy the White House, there will be an array of activities in Washington that hit closer to home for many Long Island residents.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor. I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there. Is there anything else you can suggest?

title: JOANNE BLODGETT ENGAGED TO MATTHEW LUXENBERG ROOT
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Blodgett of New York and Dublin, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanne Washington Blodgett to Matthew Luxenberg Root, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Root of New York and Roxbury, Conn.

title: When a Public Hearing Is a Travesty
description: TOO often, Trenton ''talks'' and the public does not hear.

title: Reagan's Disappearing Bureaucrats
description: SURROUNDED BY COMPUT-er gear, Federal personnel directories, and the requisite framed, signed photograph of himself with Ronald Reagan, Louis J. Cordia describes his predicament. ''I've probably got a hundred people in the Administration calling me,'' he complains. ''They're telling me, 'I'm looking to move into the private sector, and I understand you have that kind of operation.' I say to them again and again, 'We'll keep you in mind when a vacancy opens.' ''

title:
MUSIC;
2 Weeks of Concerts at Trenton State
description: LEAD: TRENTON STATE COLLEGE will be the site of a variety of musical offerings, including both concerts and master classes, in the next two weeks.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ON HOME GROUND By Alan Lelchuk. Illustrated by Merle Nacht. 72 pp. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95. (Ages 10 and up) <

title: France's Stylish Earthenware
description: THE antiques shop window, just off the Grande Place in the French city of Nancy, was filled with ceramics from many regions of France, but one particular platter captured the eye. The proprietor explained that the harmonious colors and graceful flowers were the signed work of Joseph Hannong, a member of the family responsible for some of the most beautiful ceramics ever produced in France.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: WHO HOLDS THE REINS;
'Privatizing' Doesn't Always Work
description: LEAD: PRIVATIZATION in developing countries is a highly desirable goal and is often long overdue. But the belief that privatizing is the only acceptable alternative to state ownership can lead to strategies that are economically impractical and politically naive.

title: ANTISMOKING CRUSADER: Richard A. Daynard; Using Liability Law To Put Tobacco On Trial
description: WHEN rumors hit Wall Street in late November that Richard A. Daynard, professor of law at Northeastern University, was about to disclose something embarrassing to the cigarette industry, it was enough to send the stocks of tobacco companies down 4 percent.

title: Sites With Views And Extra Taxes
description: A TAX on the view from your home? Some newer residents of Burlington, Conn., complained last year that part of the town's property tax seemed to add up to that.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: The Fight for Federal Funds; California Is Losing Its High-Tech Edge
description: WHEN it comes to science and technology, California has long been blessed - from the founding of Berkeley, Caltech and Stanford in the late 1800's, to the aerospace boom during and after World War II, to the rise of Silicon Valley.

title: Dance: Ruby Shang's 'Languages'
description: RUBY SHANG, a modern-dance choreographer with many unusual ideas, has now come up with a theatrical work that features an unusually erotic central duet, a leading Butoh artist from Japan and a marriage of concepts that might normally appear incompatible.

title: Kennedy Seeks Care Program for All 4-Year-Olds
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy has announced plans to introduce legislation that would encourage states to create a program of education and day care available to all 4-year-olds.

title: New Hampshire's Battle on the Right
description: The battle for the heart of Republican conservatives here has turned into a blood feud between Representative Jack F. Kemp of New York and Pat Robertson, the former television evangelist.

title: Dollar Backing
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE INSIDE STORIES: 13 Valiant Women Challenging the Church. Edited by Annie Lally Milhaven. (Twenty-Third Publications, Paper, $12.95.) Slightly less sensational than the title suggests, this book contains a series of interviews with three nuns, two former nuns and eight other laywomen whose challenges to the Roman Catholic Church range widely.

title:
FILM;
An Irish Director Examines English Passions
description: LEAD: ''I was interested in the way that the English, I mean the southern, middle-class English, hide what they really feel,'' says Pat O'Connor, describing what drew him to direct his latest film, ''A Month in the Country.'' The story (adapted by Simon Gray from a J. L. Carr novel, and bearing no relation to the Turgenev play of the same title), takes place in the Yorkshire of 1919, where two war-battered veterans spend a mending summer.

title: A Market Where Abundance Can Thrive
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea Urchins
description: To the Editor: In many parts of the world where sea urchins and humans are apt to collide, ammonia is the antidote of choice. Betsy Wade might not have been aware of this since each community assumes ammonia is a local remedy and most do not have access to the bottled household variety, making the subject somewhat delicate for an American lady's ear.

AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BY SILENCE BETRAYED: Sexual Abuse of Children in America, by John Crewdson. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) A broad, compelling survey of this widespread and, so far at least, apparently insoluble problem, by a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter. SHOWDOWN, by Jorge Amado. (Bantam, $18.95.) It's always behind time in Tocaia Grande, the Brazilian shantytown of the 75-year-old Mr. Amado's big, ribald, festively elegiac epic novel. THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A long (530 pages), comfy, perfectly paced novel that totally engages the reader in the story of a fairly ordinary Englishwoman, her children, her past and her house. NEWS THAT MATTERS: Television and American Opinion, by Shanto Iyengar and Donald R. Kinder. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) Volume One: The War of the Words, by Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. (Yale University, $22.95.) IN THE NEW WORLD: Growing Up With America 1960-1984, by Lawrence Wright. (Knopf, $18.95.) This young (well, 40) Texas journalist's personal account of the period succeeds in capturing the times much better than a lot of other people's prose has done. CALCULATED RISKS: A Century of Arms Control, Why It Has Failed, and How It Can Be Made to Work, by Bruce D. Berkowitz. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A trenchant critique by an experienced arms bureaucrat who believes some arms control measures can reduce the likelihood and costs of war.

title: ABIGAIL JOHNSON TO WED C. J. MCKOWN
description: The engagement of Abigail P. Johnson to Christopher J. McKown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. McKown of Sandy Creek, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Johnson 3d of Boston, parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: Anchovies From Spain
description: ALL along the Costa Brava, the stretch of coast that runs from Barcelona to the French border, Catalan bread topped with anchovies is a typical way to begin a meal at home and in restaurants. Pa amb tomaquet, slices of bread lightly toasted, rubbed with fresh tomato, then doused with one of the region's virgin olive oils, is the base. But the real star is the Costa Brava anchovy - so plump, sweet and subtle in taste it bears almost no resemblance to the skinny fillets tasting of salt that garnish pizza in the United States.

title: DATA BANK: February 14, 1988
Cable TV
description: What do ''King Kong'' (1933), ''The Letter'' (1940) and ''Lost Horizon'' (1937) have in common besides quality? Three of the best Hollywood scores ever written, so snugly integrated they're easy to take for granted. Lend an ear this week.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: TO HIM, FOSSILS SAID THE DARNEDEST THINGS
description: LEAD: SIMPLE CURIOSITY Letters from George Gaylord Simpson to His Family, 1921-1970. Edited by Leo F. Laporte. Illustrated. 340 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $29.95.

title: MISS SMITH IS ENGAGED TO ADAM BLACKWOOD
description: Announcement of the engagement of M. Michele Smith to Adam R. Blackwood has been made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Leon G. Smith of Essex Falls, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Talking Heads and The Public-TV Pickle
description: Public television should ''restate and clarify the social dilemma and the political pickle.''

title: Trump Appears Before Casino Panel
description: Donald J. Trump was back on the witness stand here this week to explain to the State Casino Control Commission his maneuvering to buy total control of Resorts International Inc.

title: HUSBAND'S AWAY? IT MUST BE SNOWING
description: IT never fails: when it snows in unpredictably large proportions, my husband is always out of town and I'm left to do the dirty work. There is no consolation when I pick up the phone at 6 A.M. on a Tuesday and hear my teaching colleague say, ''School's closed today. Pass the word.'' She can well afford to be happy about it, because her husband will be there to shovel the driveway and revive the frozen automobile. I say thanks, call the gal after me on the calling chain, turn over in bed and try to shut out the scene appearing in my mind's eye. A picture of me, the martyr, snow shovel in hand, trying to clear my 50-foot-road to civilization.

title: Report Says NASA Is Studying Problem With Shuttle Nozzle
description: Problems with the heat-resistant material that protects the nozzles of the space shuttle's booster rocket should be corrected before the next shuttle flight scheduled for August, according to an internal report being reviewed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
