title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HISTORIC REGIMENT

title: An Iraqi-Fired Cruise Missile Passes Close to U.S. Warship
description: A cruise missile launched by an Iraqi aircraft passed close to an American warship in the Persian Gulf on Saturday night before veering away to explode on the horizon, according to the Defense Department and press reports from the scene.

title: Move Over, Ozzie and Harriet
description: The only family that can disappoint you more than your own is a network executive's vision of a family. Television betrayed us when it gave us the perfect 1950's families in which every daughter was a princess and every son an honest and brave all-American boy. Our parents could never measure up to the kindness and patience we saw dispensed on television, and yet it seemed they should.

title: Choices for Benefactors
description: Children's Show

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY MISS PANCOAST
description: The engagement of Stacy Pancoast to Frank W. Clark Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of Boston, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Pancoast Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: STOP THE DECLINE IN STUDENTS' FITNESS
description: IT was ''Meet the Teacher'' night in our district - an annual open house throughout the country, but in our very upscale junior high school, an event attended by a large percentage of parents.

title: THE DRINK-A-DAY LORE
description: It seems to me that just because we do not understand how alcohol lowers the cardiac death rate is no reason not to recommend it. After all, it took over 200 years for us to understand how digoxin helps the heart. Furthermore, Dr. Bennett might have mentioned that there are several other epidemiologic studies that show that the overall death rate, cardiac as well as noncardiac, is reduced by moderate alcohol intake. Faced with these data, it would appear to me that a prudent physician would recommend that his patients take one drink a day, as well as exercising daily. ROBIN O. MOTZ, M.D. Assistant Professor Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons New York, N.Y.

title: Boy Scouts to Allow Women to Be Leaders
description: Officials of the Boy Scouts of America have voted to allow women in leadership positions, including scoutmaster, ending a male-only policy that has often been challenged in court, organization officials say.

title: This Butcher, Imagination: Beware of Your Life When a Writer's at Work
description: One crisp fall day, while admiring the flora and fauna in Riverside Park, I was stopped by a woman who announced that we had attended the same kindergarten. She said a few kind words about a book of mine, all the while looking at me with such great concern that I assumed someone had told her I had 10 days to live. ''I hope,'' she said, worry and pity accentuating all her vowels, ''that writing it down at least made you feel better.'' Perhaps she had confused me with someone else in our kindergarten class? Perhaps she knew about some catastophe I had overlooked?

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MAJOR COLLECTION OF LARGE CENTS TO BE AUCTIONED
description: LEAD: THE American Numismatic Association will sponsor three-day seminars on coin grading at three locations. The classes will be conducted by staff members. The first program will take place March 25-27 at the Sheraton Park Central Hotel in Dallas. The others are scheduled April 15-17 at the Marriott Hotel in Portland, Ore., and May 14-16 at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Chicago.

title: MS. FILMER TO BE BRIDE OF ROGER L. ANDERSON
description: The engagement of Vivianne Susan Filmer to Roger Leigh Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Anderson of Rochester, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Filmer of Cary, N.C., and Bay Head, N.J. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: KEY SENATORS BACK IMMIGRATION SHIFT
description: The Senate's two leading experts on immigration policy have agreed on a new bill that would make major changes in the system for deciding who can legally immigrate to the United States.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Wild, Clear Mountain Streams: Look, but Don't Drink
description: LEAD: FOR nearly a century, Rattlesnake Creek has been a main source of water for this mountain town, where many people have moved for a clean and healthy environment. In recent years, however, a hard-shelled creature called Giardia lamblia has made the clear, frigid water unsafe to drink.

title: FOR SOME, A POT OF GOLDFISH WAITS AT RAINBOW'S END
description: ''PLEASE, Robert, if you will just try the jacket on I will buy you any candy bar of your choice from Woolworth's, anything at all. Within reason.''

title: 'Ives, Songs': A Rollicking, Exquisite Odyssey
description: Both free association and a play with memory remain hallmarks of the 20th-century modernist sensibility. Literature showed the way with Marcel Proust and James Joyce, among others. But dance was not far behind in bringing nonlinear narrative to public awareness. The works of Antony Tudor and Martha Graham as well as George Balanchine's unexpected stream-of-conciousness approach to his ''Don Quixote'' come instantly to mind.

title: FRESHMAN DIES AFTER A FRATERNITY PARTY AT RUTGERS
description: A Rutgers University freshman died early Friday morning after a fraternity party, and the chief investigator in the case said the party ''involved a serious amount of drinking.''

title: Only the Long-Term Capital Gains Need Help; The Not So Well-to-Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking the Gold Triumphs
description: Seeking the Gold, the quickest 3-year-old in the country, survived a mostly successful experiment in a seven-furlong allowance race today at Gulfstream Park. The Mr. Prospector colt was held back off the early pace for the first time and still proved an easy winner, but his final time and final furlong were not up to his standards.

title: FRANK A. SIEVERTS WED TO SUE HUBBELL
description: Sue Hubbell, a beekeeper and writer, and Frank Arne Sieverts, the spokesman for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. William A. Wendt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Community of Hagar.

title: New TV Series Stars Newark Police Officers
description: THE first television series to be shot entirely in New Jersey will make its debut next month on WWOR-TV, Channel 9, and its formula - like its locale - will be unusual.

title: Talking: Mortgages; New Rules On Tax Deductions
description: Those who intend to buy a vacation home that would raise the total mortgage debt on a first and second home to more than $1 million, or are buying a primary residence needing more than $1 million in financing, will be limited by the Federal Government on the total loan amount eligible for tax deductions.

title: The Classic Victorians Of San Francisco
description: FOR an intimate introduction to the San Francisco Bay Area's Painted Ladies, its Victorian houses, visitors can tour three of them widely varying in style and just a few blocks apart. A short trip across the bay to two of Oakland's architectural grand dames will complete a good survey of local Victoriana from 1860 to 1900. All of these houses provide opportunities to sample views from bay windows and peek into hidden corners while learning about history and architecture.

title: Focus: Chicago; The Loop's Expanding Westward
description: A $170 MILLION office development planned for 1.25 acres over some railroad tracks near the Chicago River is expected to continue the outward push of office growth from Chicago's commercial core, the Loop.

title: MISS TIMMONS WED TO T. F. GIBSON 3D
description: At St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington, Kimberly Anne Timmons, a daughter of William E. Timmons of Washington and Jeane Lovegrove Stone of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., was married yesterday to Thomas Fenner Gibson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gibson Jr. of Indianapolis. The Rev. Francis Wade performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Said to Harden Stance on Missiles
description: The Soviet Union, in an apparent hardening of its position at the Geneva arms talks, has asked the United States to agree to limit the number of sea-launched cruise missiles that are armed with conventional warheads, according to Administration officials.

title: Opera: A New 'Siegfried' at the Met
description: BY now we know with some certainty what to expect of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Ring,'' the third installment of which was delivered Friday night with the premiere of ''Siegfried.'' As in the previous productions of this evolving cycle, the emphasis remained firmly on traditional Wagnerian staging. What was missing for most of the evening, as before, was traditional Wagnerian singing, but until the current vocal drought abates there seems to be small remedy for that.

title: MISS PARKMAN WEDS REV. ALAN FRENCH
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Mary Robinson Parkman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Parkman of New York and Seal Cove, Me., was married yesterday to the Rev. Alan Cochrane French, the rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Murray Hill, N.J. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seth Barton French Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, assisted by Bishop Mellick G. P. Belshaw of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.

title: ORTON'S 'LOOT' STAGED BY BOSTON POST ROAD
description: FAY, a murderous nurse, urges a widower, McLeavy, whose wife has been dead three days, to remarry at once, granting that a fortnight, perhaps, is ''a decent interval of mourning.'' Having done in his wife - and, it seems, seven of her own husbands as well - Fay offers herself as the next Mrs. McLeavy, only she has her eye on Dennis, who also happens to be the undertaker, a bank robber and the bisexual lover of McLeavy's son Hal.

title: 59 SPECIES FOUND TO BE THREATENED
description: The Fish and Wildlife Service added 59 species to the list of endangered and threatened species last year, the second-highest number ever, the service has reported. The most ever added was 68, in 1979.

title: Saudis Behead Four
description: Four Saudi citizens and a Sudanese expatriate, all convicted murderers, were beheaded Friday in Riyadh, the Interior Ministry said.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN PEACE
description: Because James LeMoyne wrote at considerable length on Nicaragua in his article on Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, I am compelled to respond to two inaccuracies.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection has proposed rules changes to permit higher buildings on piers in return for larger public plazas.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Forget Briefcases And Power Ties

title: WHERE TO RING IN YEAR OF DRAGON
description: PACK up winter worries. The season's woes melt away for one brief week in February. Lovers are celebrating today with flowers and candy; shoppers are reving up for Presidents' Day sales; travelers are heading to New Orleans for Mardi Gras, and serious eaters are in training for Chinese New Year feasts.

title: Biden Is Alert After Surgery For Fault in Artery to Brain
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware was alert and talking with members of his family today after surgeons corrected a fault in an artery supplying blood to his brain.

title: Recital: Renata Scotto In Italian and French Bill
description: RENATA SCOTTO'S adoring followers don't find her on New York's opera stage that often these days, but when she appeared at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night they were there to throw out the traditional mating cries of the opera-singer aficionado. What Miss Scotto gave in response to these whoops and yells of approval was approximately what she always has. Judging by last night's recital of mostly Italian arias and songs, the virtues and defects of this distinctive soprano voice have survived the past 10 years more or less intact.

title: Campaign Finance; Problems in the PAC's: Study Finds Frustration
description: Political action committees say they are increasingly resentful of greedy lawmakers, yet go along with their demands for contributions for fear of losing vital access in Congress.

title: Report Says Landfill Imperils Estuary
description: A TEAM of Rutgers University biochemical engineers has charged that New York City has failed to clean up a toxic landfill that is leaching hazardous waste into Jamaica Bay, which empties into the Hudson-Raritan estuary, possibly imperiling North Jersey marine fisheries.

title: Jobless Rate Is Top Woe for Spain's Socialists
description: On the fashionable north side of town, Spain's Socialists held their 31st Congress last month, planning how to maintain their overwhelming majority in Parliament, discussing sophisticated economic policies and paying homage to their charismatic leader, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez.

title: Fire Destroys Former Performing Arts High School
description: The landmark Manhattan building that once housed the High School of the Performing Arts was destroyed in a five-alarm fire early yesterday.

title: The Run in New Hampshire Is Now a Run for the Money
description: More than ever before, the voters of New Hampshire have it in their power when they cast their ballots Tuesday to drive many of the Presidential contenders from the race forthwith. The reason is money. All but a few of the candidates are broke or in debt, before even a single primary vote has been cast. The money has been spent on organization, on making themselves known in Iowa and other early caucus and primary states, on staff salaries, on polling and, of course, on raising money.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS HAIL 5-YEAR PLAN FOR OPEN SPACES
description: CAUTIOUS and keeping commitments may be the most used descriptions for Governor O'Neill's 1988-89 budget proposal. But conservation groups are calling the spending plan historic in its generosity.

title: ANTIQUES: The Sandors: Changing With the Times
description: LEAD: THAT facet of the antiques business that established Herbert and Richard Sandor as eminent dealers in Americana has been broadened at their new location here to include choice furnishings from England, France, the Netherlands and Scandinavia, along with Oriental objets of interest and decorative smalls.

title: Borrowing Capitalism, but Not Freedom, From the West
description: ON the face of it, there is little common political ground between Singapore, with its resoundingly successful free-market economy, and Communist Vietnam, which seems only to grow more desperately poor. But new currents are flowing in Southeast Asia, and they cross in unexpected places.

title: FOR SOME, HOME IS WHERE BUSINESS IS
description: The weather outside is frightful. The roads are covered with ice; the trains are late.

title: Swami Falls From Grace In New Delhi
description: At the height of his influence, the tall, bearded swami was regarded as one of the most powerful men in India and was an adviser to Indira Gandhi, then Prime Minister, and her son Sanjay.

title: H. GLENN MEIBURG AND MISS GIUSTI WED IN STAMFORD
description: Patricia Ann Giusti and H. Glenn Meiburg were married yesterday at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Benedict Tighe performed the ceremony.

title: ASH SITE AT HOSPITAL DEBATED
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Kings Park Psychiatric Hospital has agreed with the state to stop dumping ash from its furnaces in a ravine on the hospital grounds by 1989, some Smithtown officials are still worried that the existing ash might be endangering local water supplies.

title: PAMELA MARCUS TO WED IN MAY
description: The engagement of Pamela Stacey Marcus to Jeffrey Allan Erksine, a son of Phyllis E. Small of New York and the late Victor Erskine, has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Dianne Wallace of New York and Alan J. Marcus of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: 9 Seized on a Ship Off Beirut Reported Released by Militia
description: Eight seamen and a teen-age boy who were seized by Lebanon's main Christian militia seven weeks ago were freed today, militia figures and Lebanese officials said.

title: INCREASE IN MOTH EGGS SEEN IN FAIRFIELD COUNTY
description: JUST as a gypsy moth infestation that has plagued Connecticut since the late 1970's is moving out of the eastern part of the state, a new swarm seems to be moving into Fairfield County.

title: A Balmy Beach Town In New South Wales
description: I SAW Byron Bay for the first time three years ago. I was driving north on the coastal highway from Sydney to Brisbane with my wife. The rain had stopped just beyond the town of Ballina, where the highway snakes inland toward the foothills of the northern coastal ranges. By the time we were west of Byron Bay, the iron-gray wedge of cloud had lifted to let the sun cast its warm, early evening light across the undulating grasslands to the flat brown marshes and pale dunes on the ocean's edge. Cape Byron was a distant grass-covered dome surmounted by a white lighthouse. Shafts of sunlight caught the rainfall evaporating from its rocky ledges and the salt-laden spray blowing in from the sea to form a bright rainbow that bridged the shores of the Cape and the patchwork of colored rooftops to the west of it.

title: Disorientation Express
description: ROCKING AROUND THE CLOCK Music Television, Postmodernism, and Consumer Culture. By E. Ann Kaplan. Illustrated. 196 pp. New York: Methuen. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $11.95.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $4.95.) An ex-con, an ex-cop and an ex-nun become involved with contras, Sandinistas and even a Miskito Indian in a plot to free a Nicaraguan woman from a leper colony in Louisiana. Despite this ''preposterous business,'' Walker Percy said here last year, Elmore Leonard ''knows what he's doing.'' ''His New Orleans is done up with meticulous accuracy. [ He's ] got his usual diverting cast of grifters and creeps up his sleeve and action as Byzantine as ever Chandler himself thought up.'' POPULUXE, by Thomas Hine. (Knopf, $16.95.) Finally someone has come up with a good name for the style and world view of the 50's, which embraces such unforgetta-ble artifacts as TV dinners, Tupperware, automotive tail fins, two-tone refrigerators and the Howdy Doody Show.

title: Jazz: Judy Carmichael
description: THE stride pianist Judy Carmichael, who was one of the regular attractions at Hanratty's until that Upper East Side restaurant closed more than a year ago, has found a new home - a spacious room with hanging plants under a huge skylight on the second floor of the Fortune Garden Pavilion, a restaurant at 209 East 49th Street, near Third Avenue. Miss Carmichael's trio, with Michael Hashim on alto and soprano saxophones and Chris Flory on guitar, has inaugurated a jazz policy there, playing Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays through this month.

title: Officials Have Applied Brakes at the Daytona 500
description: The 150,000 spectators who will jam into the Daytona International Speedway today for the Daytona 500 stock car race, and the millions more that will watch it on television (Channel 2, 12 P.M.), will almost certainly see a slower race than last year.

title: Soviet Says It Hopes 'Provocation' By U.S. at Sea Won't Hurt Talks
description: The Soviet Union today blamed the United States for the ''military provocation'' in which two American Navy vessels and Soviet warships bumped in the Black Sea on Friday.

title: WHITE PLAINS WEIGHS A PROPOSAL TO REORGANIZE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: NEIGHBORHOOD elementary schools in White Plains would be replaced by a system in which parents choose the public school their children attend under a reorganization plan being considered by the White Plains Board of Education.

title: VALENTINES OF YESTERYEAR ARE BROUGHT OUT FOR TODAY
description: ACCORDING to 15th- and 16th-century diaries, Valentines were not cards but people upon whom such elaborate gifts as jewelry were bestowed. Gradually the gifts became less expensive, and by the late 17th century, cards began to replace gifts, according to Christine Ermenc, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Historical Society.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: COUSIN BRUCIE! My Life in Rock 'n' Roll Radio. By Bruce Morrow and Laura Baudo. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) Hyper, happy, hokey and wholesome, Bruce (Cousin Brucie) Morrow was one of the greatest disk jockeys of the 1960's, a man whose high-speed delivery helped make New York's WABC the highest-rated Top 40 station on the AM dial.

title: STARS BEHIND BARS
description: LEAD: THE PEACEABLE KINGDOM A Year in the Life of America's Oldest Zoo. By John Sedgwick. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: Willliam Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: On Language; Falling in Love With Luv
description: ON VALENTINE'S day, philologists wonder: What's happening to love?

title: Annual AIDS Test
description: Boxers are not one of the groups known to be at heightened risk of contracting AIDS. Nevertheless, over the last year, British boxing authorities have screened foreign boxers for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, New Jersey authorities have mandated plastic gloves for all cornermen, and the medical advisory board to the New York State Athletic Commission has recommended that all boxers and ring personnel undergo tests for the virus.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 7 misstated the number of condominiums in Scrimshaw House now under construction in Yonkers. It will have 138 units.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
North Brunswick's Housing Compromise
description: LEAD: AS much of the vacant land in North Brunswick was blanketed by housing over the last decade, local officials tried to hold the line on a 404-acre industrially zoned tract in the southern half of the township. It is close to warehouses and a rail line and along Route 130, a state highway lined with strip shopping malls.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 in some copies of the Travel section today misstates airline policy on frequent flier programs. Points cannot be shared among family members belonging to an airline's program, although the coupons awarded at fixed point levels can be.

title: Piano: Perahia and Lupu Play Duets
description: THE smallest and the largest piece on Friday's program of piano duos at Avery Fisher Hall was the Schubert F-minor Fantasy. It is the work a serious Schubertian longs to hear at such a concert, but almost dreads seeing there.

title: Tracking AIDS Through World Since '81
description: Since AIDS was recognized as a disease in the United States in 1981, it has appeared in three-quarters of the world's countries, about 160 nations in all, according to the World Health Organization.

title: CASTLE GALLERY FEATURES COMPOSITIONS OF FOUR 'ASSEMBLERS'
description: IN the beginning was collage, pioneered as a kind of trompe l'oeil by the Cubists. Then came assemblage - or three-dimensional collage - in which found objects were transformed into Surrealist mysteries.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. PAUL, MINN.;
A Pastel House Upsets the Hill
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION of a boxy pastel town house on Ramsey Hill in St. Paul has ignited a debate over whether zoning restrictions should be tightened for the historic neighborhood, which has one of the nation's largest collections of Victorian-era homes.

title: The Deficit: What, Me Worry?
description: If President Reagan is worried about the Federal deficit, he conceals it well. He is the man, after all, who has more than doubled the national debt in a mere seven years. Yet his imminent Budget Message, leaked last week, takes credit for the trivial deficit-reduction package worked out with Congress after the October crash. It is not a serious response. He doesn't call for new taxes, or for restraint in the swelling pension programs that account for much of the growth in Federal spending.

title: Lawmakers Fill War Chests
description: NEW JERSEY lawmakers have stockpiled more than $3.3 million in political contributions from corporations, unions, special-interest groups and individuals in anticipation of the 1988 elections, with more than half of it for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg's campaign.

title: REAL THINGS AT LAST
description: SISTER SHIPS And Other Stories. By Joan London. 118 pp. New York: Penguin. Paper, $5.95.

title: CEDARHURST PARKING GARAGE AT ISSUE
description: LEAD: ONE point that the business community, residents and officials of Cedarhurst agree on is the need to ease traffic and parking problems in the central shopping district, with its 450 businesses and retail shops. But that is the only point where they find themselves on common ground in this village of 6,200 people near the

title: ST JOHN'S HALTS A 3-GAME SLIDE
description: After three consecutive losses to Big East Conference opponents, St. John's found a team it could beat yesterday. And, oh, how the Redmen beat Providence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: Headliners; Desperately, Scott
description: In 1937, F. Scott Fitzgerald was 40 years old and in need of quick cash. His best-known work, ''The Great Gatsby,'' was 12 years behind him; perhaps he sensed that death, then three years away, was closing in. In any case, Fitzgerald produced a short story that year, titled ''A Full Life,'' that was shot through with uncharacteristic black humor. In a letter, he urged his agent to ''sell it right away,'' to sacrifice it ''for immediate gold.'' But there were no takers; one editor said the story was ''too crazy.''

title: RESULT PLUS
description: N.H.L. Canucks 6, Bruins 5: Doug Wickenheiser scored with 3 minutes 25 seconds remaining for the victory at Vancouver. The goal, Wickenheiser's fifth of the season and first since last Jan. 17, was set up by a centering pass by Dave Saunders. The victory, the Canucks' third in their last 11 games, snapped a six-game Boston winning streak. The Bruins had a 5-3 lead before Garth Butcher scored at 17:49 of the second period. Petri Skriko then set up the defenseman Jim Benning to tie the score at 10:13 of the third period with a short-handed goal.(AP) Whalers 4, Canadiens 1: Lindsay Carson broke a second-period tie to help extend the Canadiens' longest losing streak to the season to four games at Montreal. The Whalers insured the victory with two goals in the final 90 seconds by Kevin Dineen and Paul MacDermid. Mike Liut made 12 of his 32 stops in the final period.(AP) Maple Leafs 7, Flyers 4: Miroslav Frycer and Ed Olczyk scored two goals each and Ken Wregget turned away 49 Philadelphia shots a Toronto. Tom Fergus, Todd Gill and Al Iafrate also scored for the Leafs. Murray Craven scored three goals and Dave Poulin one for the Flyers, who suffered their second loss in two nights. Toronto took a 4-1 lead in the second period when Wregget turned away 24 shots. Toronto has three victories in its last 24 games.(AP) Nordiques 7, North Stars 3: At Bloomington, Minn., Peter Stastny scored a goal and had four assists for the Nordiques. Stastny, the Nordiques' leading scorer, continued his recent hot streak in which he has 21 points in the last 12 games. Minnesota is 0-4-1 in its last five. The North Stars were outshot, 20-6, in the second period. After Neal Broten narrowed the North Stars' deficit to 4-3, Brown, Stastny and Lane Lambert scored for Quebec.(AP) Blues 5, Red Wings 3: Tony McKegney scored two goals and added an assist to help end a six-game unbeaten streak by visiting Detroit. It was the first victory in seven games this season with Detroit, which squandered a three-goal lead, then went ahead for good on Rick Meagher's third-period goal. The Blues have won 8 of their last 10 games, but had lost their last two.(AP) N.B.A. Pistons 82, Bulls 73: Dennis Rodman scored 8 of his 15 points in the fourth quarter and the Pistons held Chicago to a team-tying record low at Pontiac, Mich. The Pistons, who have won four straight, held the Bulls to their previous season-low of 74 points in an 89-74 victory at Chicago last Tuesday night. Michael Jordan, who leads the league in scoring with 33.2 points a game, scored 27 points for Chicago.(AP) Hawks 105, Bullets 103: Dominique Wilkins scored 45 points and Glenn Rivers hit a jumper with two seconds for the Hawks at Atlanta. Rivers's game-winner capped a comeback from an 89-79 deficit in the final seven-and-a-half minutes when Wilkins scored 15 points and Rivers 9. Jeff Malone, who led the Bullets with 29 points, missed a shot at the buzzer.(AP) Road Racing Texan Wins Central Park Run: Tony Colon of Dallas, a former all-American at Manhattan College, was a 200-yard winner over Mike Feurtado in 15 minutes 39 seconds in the New York Road Runners Club Horoscope 5-kilometer run at Central Park. A field of 850 competed in the 3.1-mile race in 24 degrees over the icy course. Feurtado, of South Ozone Park, Queens, posted a time of 15:58. Gillian Beschloss of New York was the women's winner in 17:49. Auto Racing Allison Holds On: Bobby Allison took the lead with two laps remaining and held off Geoff Bodine and Darrell Waltrip on the final lap to win the Goody's 300 Busch Grand National stock car race yesterday at Daytona International Speedway. Allison, one of the main contenders in today's $1.5-million Daytona 500, averaged 132.825 miles per hour for the 300-mile event, which was slowed six times by caution flags. An accident on the 103d lap of the 120-lap event involved seven cars and resulted in a spectator injury when the hood of one of the cars fluttered over the fence on the main straightaway just past the finish line. The unidentified male spectator was taken to nearby Halifax Medical Center.(AP) Bowling Milton Takes Title: Tom Milton of St. Petersburg, Fla., capitalized on his opponent's only bad shot yesterday to capture the title match in the $150,000 Professional Bowlers Association Miller Lite Classic. Milton defeated Rick Steelsmith of Wichita, Kan., 233-221, to lock up his fifth P.B.A. crown and the $27,000 winner's share. Both bowlers started with four strikes. Milton spared in the fifth, but Steelsmith left the difficult 4-6-7-10 split and failed to convert.(AP) Soccer Liverpool Wins: Liverpool, the runaway English League First Division leader, defeated Watford, 4-1, yesterday and stretched its unbeaten streak to 26 games. John Barnes celebrated his return to his former club by scoring the final goal. Peter Beardsley scored twice for Liverpool. The victory enabled Kenny Dalglish's team to open a 12-point lead over Manchester United, which beat Chelsea 2-1 and has 54 points in 28 games.(AP) Tennis American Advances: Todd Nelson of the United States, ranked 119th, defeated Yannick Noah of France, and Yaya Doumbia of Senegal beat Eduardo Masso of Argentina yesterday in the semifinals of the $280,000 Lyon Nabisco Grand Prix tournament. Nelson beat Noah, last year's winner, 7-6, 6-3, and Doumbia eliminated Masso, 6-4, 7-6.(AP) Curren Takes All in Exhibition: Kevin Curren beat Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, 6-1, 6-3, last night in a $85,000 winner-take-all exhibition match in Aberdeen, Scotland. Before the match, about 30 people staged an anti-apartheid demonstration outside the hall, organized by Aberdeen Trades Council in conjunction with Britain's Anti-Apartheid Movement. They did not get near the players. The demonstrators were protesting at the participation of both players at the South African Open tournament in Johannesburg last November, which Cash won.(AP) Surfing Australia Gains Lead: Australia took an early lead with 75 points in the 1988 World Amateur Surfing competition yesterday in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico. Organizers said Brazil, Hawaii and the United States were tied for second with 70 points each. All results were for Friday, the first day of the 10-day competition. Other teams starting well included France B (Tahiti) with 68 points, Israel with 66 and New Zealand 64. (AP)

title:
DINING OUT;
A Ski Resort's Appealing Concept
description: LEAD: A RECENT press release from the Great Gorge Resort touts the ''spectacular new $12 million spa and country club'' that have been added to the popular Sussex County ski area.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: Your readers should be aware of one inaccuracy in the otherwise very informative article on economic factors affecting tourists to Mexico (''Mexican Prices Down Just a Bit,'' Travel, Dec. 13). While it may be true that in Mexico some credit cards ''use the controlled rate'' (about 1,750 pesos to the dollar) American Express does not. Travelers to Mexico who use the American Express card will be charged at a free market rate comparable to that offered by Mexican banks, plus 1 percent of the converted amount (about 2,245 pesos on the day before the article appeared). Therefore, the rates offered by American Express are competitive with rates available to travelers who use cash in Mexico. GILBERT E. AHYE New York, N.Y.

title: One More Time, Lowell on Jarrell
description: To the Editor:

title: Unisex Insurance Inching Ahead
description: SOME states prohibit sex discrimination in automobile and health insurance - for which women have usually paid more than men. Last year, the Massachusetts Insurance Commissioner issued a regulation barring sex bias in all forms of insurance - including life, for which women have usually paid less.

title: Dallas Punches A Hole in the Heart Of Its Skyline
description: Five years ago, the archi-tectural energy of Texas seemed concentrated in one city, and it was not Dallas. This old and, by Texas standards, staid city could barely compete with the brashness of Houston, where towers popped into the sky at a mind-boggling rate, each one, it seemed, more flamboyant than the last. Beside Houston's glittering skyline, downtown Dallas seemed like little more than a collection of dull boxes.

title: About Men; Life Intrudes
description: I NEVER SPOKE BACK. I was quiet and obedient.

title: All in the Eye Of the Beholder
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Residential Resales

Wonica)

title: TURBULENT TIMES AHEAD FOR GRUMMAN
description: THE Grumman Corporation, the producer of more than 33,000 fighter planes, bombers and cargo jets, may soon be out of the airframe business. At least that's the word from Washington to Wall Street. Many Government and financial analysts predict, as one Washington company wrote in its 1988 forecasts, that ''Grumman will drop out of the airframe building business.''

title: 'DON'T TAKE ANYTHING AT FACE VALUE'
description: TIMOTHY WEST receives about 12,000 complaints a year as head of the Complaint Center at the Department of Consumer Protection.

title: DRESSING FOR TODAY, WITHIN THE LIMITS
description: A BIG WHOOP-DE-DO WED-ding is like most gala occasions today. Everyone involved can dress in any number of ways and look just fine. But a wedding does impose a few fashion parameters, some traditional and others contemporary. One universal: The bride sets the tone; this is her day. She can be swathed in clouds of tulle and trailing a train. Or her gown can be quite bare, strapless on top, above her knees all around or cut up in front and swooping down in back. Her headdress can be simple or elaborate. She might opt for an elegant suit with a midi-length hemline, balanced by a wide-brimmed hat. She will not, however, wear pants. Brides still overwhelmingly select white, ivory or cream. But pale pink is not a bad idea, though for some reason pale blue or green would seem askew. Blazing red would certainly cause a scandal.

title: Police Officers Tell of Strains Of Living as a 'Black in Blue'
description: James Hargrove remembers the time he saw a robbery in progress in Manhattan. As a police officer, he wanted to jump out of his patrol car. As a black man in civilian clothes, carrying a weapon, he knew better.

title: Health-Club Contracts Curbed
description: LEAD: A LAW that went into effect as 1987 drew to a close is expected to help protect consumers from some health-club contracts.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 9 Flew Over the Osprey's Nest LOOKING like the American soldiers raising the flag at Iwo Jima, the nine East Hampton nature lovers struggled to raise a 20-foot-long telephone pole with an odd-shaped frame attached to the top.

title: Turnpike Stranding Subject Of Inquiry
description: LEAD: A MOTORIST'S nightmare - a breakdown on the New Jersey Turnpike and no one stopping to help - became a reality for Peter Donovan and his family one cold night this winter.

title: Industry to Give Vast New Data On Toxic Perils
description: Beginning next month, industrial plants all over the country will be required to disclose to state and local committees a flood of information on whether they are using and storing any of more than 300 ''extremely hazardous substances.''

title: Duel Looms in Downhill
description: As he smiled and posed with Michael Mair of Italy, who was celebrating his 26th birthday today, Pirmin Zurbriggen stole a glance of the result board at the bottom of the men's downhill run, his smile slowly fading as he appeared a bit preoccupied.

title: WHEN SATIRE DIDN'T CLOSE ON SATURDAY NIGHT
description: GOING TOO FAR By Tony Hendra. Illustrated. 480 pp. New York: A Dolphin Book/Doubleday. $19.95.

title: BIG MAN IN THE KITCHEN
description: I was reading Linda Wells's article about Charles Palmer, ''Big Man in the Kitchen'' (Dec. 13). Mr. Palmer was making me feel right good about cooking in general and New York cooking in particular, until I ran up on his disparaging remark about one of the genuine delicacies of this world: catfish. ''With all the damn fish around, who the hell wants to eat catfish?'' he asks.

title: What to Look for in Laser Printers
description: SOME companies justify the higher expense of a laser printer on a strict bottom-line analysis. A laser costing $2,000 or more can be shared by several personal computers and cough out material quickly enough to keep everybody happy - none of the waiting in line that slower shared printers create. On a per-user basis, that can eliminate the price advantage of daisy wheels and dot matrix printers.

title: Transkei Confronts Corruption After a Coup
description: Among military leaders who have seized power in Africa, Maj. Gen. Harrington Bantubonke Holomisa is something of an exception to established patterns.

title: A COUNTERBLOW OBLITERATES A BLOW
description: WHEN kings are castled on opposite wings and each faces violent attack, it is hardly time to honor the precept of noblesse oblige, yet Michael Wilder did something very like that in his game against Grandmaster Sergei Kudrin in the United States Championship in Estes Park, Colo. Not surprisingly, the 25-year-old Princeon, N.J., international master was awarded the $100 Craig Crenshaw prize for the most interesting combination.

title: LOOKING AT PICTURES THE OLD-FASHIONED WAY
description: PAINTING AS AN ART Bollingen Series XXXV No. 33 By Richard Wollheim. Illustrated. 384 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $45.

title: A LA CARTE
description: A DECADE ago, I spent every summer Sunday on the beach and every winter Sunday searching for the perfect eggs Benedict at restaurant brunches. Those were the days of Long Island's brunch craze, when even the most unlikely restaurants offered these midday melanges.

title: South Africa Reports Attack By Zimbabwe-Based Rebels
description: Guerrillas attacked a white farmer's house with rockets and firearms early today, then fled across the border into Zimbabwe, the Government said.

title:
ART;
PRIZE WINNERS AND ISRAELI PRINTS
description: LEAD: TWO exhibitions are sharing the spotlight at Gallery North in Setauket this month. In addition to works by the prize-winning artists from last year's annual outdoor art show, the gallery is featuring a selection of prints from the Weizmann Art Gallery in Israel, which operates its own graphics workshop.

title: P.L.O. 'Exodus' Sailing Is Postponed Yet Again
description: Efforts by the Palestine Liberation Organization to secure a vessel for a symbolic voyage to Israel remained inconclusive today as one more target date for the ship's departure from the Greek port of Piraeus came and went.

title: One Farmer's Story: It Looks as if the Children May Go to College After All
description: WHAT a difference three years, a little luck and a lot of hard work have made, Shorty Gladbach mused as he sat at the kitchen table in his 100-year-old yellow farmhouse, while his wife, Gerry, smiled down from her chores at the sink.

title: Need to Edit Another Man's Pose?
description: The two million own-ers of camcorders probably expected that making their own video tapes with these camera-recorder combinations was just a matter of point and shoot. That, at any rate, is the impression fostered by advertisements that would have you believe that shooting video is as simple as taking snapshots.

title: BETH DANIEL LEADS IN SARASOTA CLASSIC
description: Beth Daniel, who is trying to end a slump of two-and-a-half years, matched par 72 today in the third round of the Sarasota Classic to take a two-stroke lead into the final 18 holes of the $225,000 L.P.G.A. tournament.

title: THE LAWYERS OF DEATH ROW
description: DAVID BRUCK leaves his law office in Columbia, S.C., one cool, bright December morning and drives by the Civil War-era courthouse just around the corner. A few minutes later, he parks in front of the sprawling brick and granite state penitentiary, parts of which are as old as the courthouse.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 7 misidentified the bus line serving Roosevelt Island. It is Queens/Steinway Transit Corporation.

title: ELDERLY'S PLIGHT SURPRISES LEGISLATORS
description: THE State Senate will form a special panel to look into the problems of the elderly. Officials said they were acting in the wake of a report last week that documented employment, transportation, housing and other issues affecting the aged.

title: BLACK STRUGGLE IS ARTIST'S 'ROAD'
description: LEAD: DISTRESSED because a ''view of black life has not been shown to a proper degree,'' the artist Alice B. Johnson set out five years ago on ''The Stony Road,'' a multimedia work that through paintings, drawings, montage, poetry, prose and background music offers her interpretation of the history of blacks in

title: Humane Lay-Offs
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WINDOW JOGGING
description: LEAD: No more trudging through slush and sleet and falling snow to do your morning exercises. No more bitter cold or icy dawns.

title: Panamanians Use Technology to Balk Censor
description: With the help of modern-day technology, a small band of exiles is piercing the censorship in Panama.

title: A Woman Of Two Minds, Both in Turmoil
description: He's successful, he's rich.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
RYE
description: LEAD: Last year, when one of Rye City's four volunteer fire companies wanted a new emblem for a recently acquired truck, it selected a clam. For this Long Island Sound community with eight miles of waterfront, it was logical.

title: VILLAGE OFFICIALS STRUGGLE TO KEEP TAX RATES DOWN AND SERVICES UP
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH they are among the most highly taxed areas in the nation, many villages in Nassau County are having difficulty maintaining essential services in the face of rising costs.

title: Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
description: In a career spanning almost exactly the same seasons, Hank Aaron won twice as many r.b.i. titles and as many batting titles as Mantle, Mays and Snider combined. He accomplished this while winning as many home run titles as any of the celebrated triumvirate.

title: SABINE JACOB TO MARRY LANCE KIMMEL IN MAY
description: A May wedding is planned by Sabine Jacob, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Willy Jacob of Wilhelmshaven, West Germany, and Lance Jon Kimmel, a son of Irwin Kimmel of New York and Adele Kimmel of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Headliners; Innocently, Lyn
description: When Lyn Nofziger signed documents pertaining to meetings with White House officials in 1982, he might as well have been signing a confession, in the view of jurors who last week convicted Mr. Nofziger of illegal lobbying.

title: CHALLENGES FACED BY THE CATHOLIC CHURCH
description: The article on the declining number of Catholic priests [ ''As Catholic Rolls Rise, Priests Diversify,'' Jan. 17 ] presents graphically a challenge that the church on Long Island and throughout the world should be addressing realistically.

title: Princeton Eating Club Weighs Alcohol Policy
description: An eating club for Princeton University upperclassmen suspended the serving of alcoholic beverages this week after a 19-year-old student nearly drank himself to death at the club's annual initiation party.

title: A Costly Surprise From Mutual Funds
description: THOUSANDS of investors who thought they had outsmarted the tax collector by year-end selling of mutual funds in which they had big losses received an unpleasant surprise during the last few weeks. Large capital gains distributions from the funds, paid in 1988 but taxable in 1987, have upset their careful tax-planning maneuvers.

title: LAT IN THE NIGHT, A BATTLE OF WITS
description: MANY of us can recall, probably before the enthusiasm of youth gave way to the settled habits of middle age, playing rubber bridge or Chicago for most of the night and perhaps for longer periods. Some 40 years ago this writer played non-stop for 34 hours, in a tournament, a hotel bedroom, a train and a club, before succumbing to sleep. Others can no doubt beat that dubious record.

title: REACTOR REPORT STIRS UP SEABROOK
description: Few residents were impressed in January when the largest owner of this town's dormant power plant filed for bankruptcy protection. What caused a stir instead was the release of a 300-page report saying that the plant might be unsafe because of drug and alcohol abuse among workers and that the plant's management tried to hide the problem.

title: Blacks Postpone a Meeting On Resolving Campus Sit-In
description: Black students occupying a University of Massachusetts building for the second day canceled a meeting this morning with the chancellor to discuss their demands that the school act against campus racism.

title: DOLE, ACTING ON VICTORY IN IOWA, RECASTS NEW HAMPSHIRE STRATEGY
description: After a speech in a packed auditorium at Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter the other night, Senator Bob Dole turned to questions from the audience.

title: SUCCESS FOR DARIEN HIGH SCHOOL INVENTOR
description: LIKE most high school girls, Kimberly Allen's schoolday atire tends to the casual -jeans, a sweatshirt and sneakers. As a freshman, though, she puzzled her friends by occasionally turning up at Darien High School in a blazer and skirt or a dress.

title: DRAMATIC RISE IN USE OF POWER BRINGS PUSH FOR CONSERVATION
description: WHEN the state's utilities called on customers last month to cut back on the use of electricity, Judi C. Friedman and Elaine T. Moreland were at a loss.

title: KEEPING THE TRADITION ALIVE
description: LEAD: IT is May 25, 1953. Frank Foster, saxophone player, is walking down a Detroit street, fresh from Army duty in the Korean War.

title: CHALLENGES FACED BY THE CATHOLIC CHURCH
description: Please accept the compliments of a Catholic with 20 years of Jesuit education and three degrees from Catholic universities, including one in theology. The excellent article confirms the inflexible attitude of the Vatican hierarchy. To lament the shortage of priests and to pray for more ''vocations'' (God's call, supposedly) to the priesthood is to stubbornly reject four solutions not opposed to Catholic theology.

title: LAURA BEATRICE KAVESH, A COLUMNIST, TO WED DR. STEVEN STERN, A PROFESSOR
description: Laura Beatrice Kavesh, a columnist for The Chicago Tribune, and Dr. Steven Stern, a professor of psychiatry and psychology at the Northwestern University Medical School, plan to marry in May, the parents of the future bride, Ruth Kavesh of Montclair, N.J., and Dr. Robert A. Kavesh of New York, have announced.

title: 'A GIFT OF MURDER,' COMEDY WITH CLUES
description: WHEN the action of a play takes place in a remote area of the north of England, it is a good clue that the play is in the mystery thriller genre. Unfortunately, as is the case with the Arena Players current show, ''A Gift of Murder,'' the genre is not always mysterious or thrilling.

title: Words Can Be Their Own Music
description: Some years ago, i was fascinated to learn that an ambitious British composer had chosen as a theme thoughts from Ludwig Wittgenstein's ''Tractatus Logico-philosophicus,'' one of the most brilliantly arcane works in the history of linguistics. For all I know, many musicians who were also professional philosophers took it into their repertories, but I never heard of it again. That should be no surprise. Certain kinds of prose, even if famously wise or beautiful, fiercely resist being grafted onto music.

title: SHINSPLINTS IN THE OLD WEST
description: THE FAST MEN By Tom McNab. 345 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: F.B.I. Stand Is Contradicted On Surveillance of Policy Foes
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says its widespread inquiry into opponents of the Reagan Administration's Central American policy ended two years ago, but Dr. Paul F. Knitter says he has reason to believe that, in his case at least, that is not so.

title: GEPHARDT PAPERS SUPPLIED BY BANK
description: In an effort to show that its transactions with Richard A. Gephardt's Presidential campaign were legitimate, a Washington bank furnished documents today detailing $1.4 million in loans it made to the campaign last year.

title: Music
description: New Yorkers are never long deprived of the chance to hear top-notch pianists perform, with at least two or three usually scheduled somewhere in town each week. The next several days, however, provide an especially fine opportunity to hear a range of established and up-and-coming young players, both as soloists with orchestra and in recital.

title: Back Before Bach, There Was Bach
description: The musical and procrea-tive fecundity of the Bach family is legendary, but it is often assumed to have begun with the most celebrated Bach of all: Johann Sebastian. The fact is, however, that there were Bachs in the music business well before J. S. was so much as a tune in his parents' sketchbook. Their history was later chronicled by Johann Sebastian in family annals and an ''Altbachisches Archiv'' (''Archive of the Earlier Bachs''), in which he collected such of their compositions as he was able to assemble. The extant cantatas of these grand-uncles, uncles and other kin have now been recorded by Musica Antiqua Koln under Reinhard Goebel on a superior two-CD set from Archiv (419 253-1/2, also on LP).

title: Leon Goossens, Well-Known Oboist, Is Dead at 90
description: Leon Goossens, an oboist who helped refine the instrument's potential and inspired composers to write music to showcase it, died Friday night at the age 90, his family said today.

title: A NEW ASSOCIATION AND OLD FILMS SAVE A THEATER
description: For years, the 1,250-seat Stanford Theater, like so many movie palaces of the Art Deco era, has been unable to justify itself economically. Its future, some thought, was as a shopping mall.

title: Going for the Gold in California
description: ON a small, grassy hill overlooking the ruins of Chinese Camp, an old mining settlement, stands St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic church. The tombstones in its graveyard bear the names of Irish and English immigrants who crossed the Atlantic in search of gold. But the most arresting monument to those who sought riches here is the lush canopy of trees that covers much of the town.

title: Columbia Campaign Raises $600 Million, Exceeding Its Goal
description: A five-year fund-raising campaign by Columbia University has raised $600 million, $200 million more than the original goal.

title: Billy Wilder to Receive The Thalberg Award
description: Billy Wilder is to receive the Irving G. Thalberg Award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Oscar night, April 11. The award honors a body of work that ''reflects a consistently high quality of motion picture production.''

title: Our Interstate Highways Are Becoming a Falling-Rock Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEAKING MUTI'S LANGUAGE
description: Minutes before a Philadelphia Orchestra rehearsal not long ago, Riccardo Muti, the music director, was lying down, his feet dangling over the arm of a dressing room couch at Carnegie Hall. He looked happy and relaxed. He cajoled an assistant about packing luggage for a trip, and chatted, one after the other, with the orchestra's general manager, Joseph Kluger, and its concertmaster, Norman Carol, about the ensemble's recent labor disputes. When it was time to go to work, Mr. Carol said ''avanti.''

title: Brighter Mood for Zimbabwe Region
description: A newfound optimism is flowering amid the rugged tangle of shrub and desert in southwestern Zimbabwe.

title: MISS HUSTING WEDS ON L.I.
description: The marriage of Alison Mead Husting, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. Husting of Locust Valley, L.I., and Cedric Christopher Janien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cedric J. Janien of Chatham, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., took place yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Those people looking for a consumer-led recession may have to re-evaluate. The consumer is not spent out.''

title: Body and Mind; Quirks and Oddities
description: For by his face strait

title: Food; A PIECE OF CAKE
description: THE WEDDING CAKE WAS ORIGI-nally conceived as a table decoration.

title: U.S. Adds to Lead Over Soviet in 'Star Wars'
description: THE Pentagon's successful ''Star Wars'' experiment last week vividly illustrates the growing gap in how East and West measure up on exotic anti-missile arms. As the United States pushes ahead with space spectaculars seen as vital to the perfection of orbiting battle stations, the Soviet Union is keeping a lower profile, seeming to concentrate on basic research confined to the laboratory.

title: Ballet: Winners Name In Boston Competition
description: ''This is the place to be,'' one member of the audience murmured to another on Thursday at the Wang Center, where the Boston Ballet presented its Boston International Choreography Competition. Indeed, it seemed that much of Boston had turned out for the culminating event of the project, initiated 10 years ago by E. Virginia Williams, founder of the Boston Ballet. And the packed theater was treated to an ambitious and fully realized program that built steadily, ending with a ceremony in which Ralph Lemon, one of five finalists, was presented with the first prize.

title: Sexism on Film: The Sequel
description: When the characters in John Hughes's ''She's Having a Baby'' catch a brief glimpse of the old ''Dick Van Dyke Show'' on television, the film sounds an amazingly nostalgic note. There, amid the sourness, petulance and misanthropy of Mr. Hughes's new comedy, are Rob and Laura Petrie, who led simple lives and fought over the silliest things. Despite it all, Rob and Laura were happy. And they liked each other infinitely more than Jefferson (Jake) Briggs (Kevin Bacon) and his wife, Kristy (Elizabeth McGovern), ever will.

title: Correction
description: A correction in this section on Jan. 10 misidentified the translator of Octavio Paz's Dec. 20 review of ''Mexican Churches.'' He is Roberto Tejada.

title: Straight Talk Brings Down Japan House
description: All this week, Japan's Parliament was brought to a standstill because an influential member rejected one of this country's most cherished social graces, an apology.

title: Poetry and Word Processing
description: To the Editor:

title: LINDSEY GRUSON PLANNING TO WED JANE E. WHITNEY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo C. Balzereit of Jupiter Island, Fla., and Jenkintown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ellen Whitney, to Lindsey Gruson, the son of Flora Lewis Gruson of Paris and Sydney Gruson of New York. The couple plan to marry May 8.

title: Philadelphians Choosing Sides Over City Hall
description: If there is anything in this city that is the target of more jokes than the city itself, it is City Hall. ''The world's most beautiful ugly building,'' a ''monument to corruption,'' an ''architectural abomination'' are among the many unflattering descriptions the building has earned.

title: Equalizers Let the Fingers Serve the Demanding Ear
description: Audiophiles wishing to exercise their egos and perform other salutary tasks can do so by adding an equalizer to their sound systems. These increasingly popular devices enable you to countermand von Karajan - or any other recorded conductor - in matters of tonal balance. How's that for self-assertiveness? The main object, however, is to smooth out acoustic quirks in either the listening room or the recording.

title: THE PASTOR'S PROBLEM
description: I envy Henry G. Brinton for writing the About Men essay I was hoping to write someday (''The Pastor's Problem,'' Jan. 17). I, too, work in a part of the world in which affluence is the way of life. I, too, find there is too much month left at the end of the money.

title: Opera: 'Macbeth' Recast
description: WITH the exception of Samuel Ramey, as Banquo, new singers took over the principal roles Thursday evening in the Metropolitan Opera's troubled production of Verdi's ''Macbeth.'' After a last-minute cancellation by Shirley Verrett, Olivia Stapp took her place as Lady Macbeth, and suffice it to say that her performance was crude and melodramatic in a way that even the maniacal role cannot bear.

title: EILEEN CARROLL IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Denis Edward Carroll of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Eileen Alanna Carroll to Donald Scardino, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lawrence Scardino, also of Bayside. Ms. Carroll, a mechanical engineer with General Motors Corporation in Tarrytown, N.Y., graduated from the Columbia University School of Engineering. Her fiance, who graduated from the Pace University School of Law, is a criminal defense lawyer with the Legal Aid Society in New York.

title: SARAH PIERCE MARRIED TO DRU BEGUELIN
description: At the Congregational Church of Christ at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., Sarah Steinkamp Pierce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Franklin Pierce Jr. of Etna, N.H., was married yesterday to Winslow Drury Beguelin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dayton Beguelin of Locust, N.J. The Rev. Donald Mckenzie officiated. Cynthia Pierce, the bride's sister, and Kay Crawford Pierce, the bride's sister-in-law, were the maid and matron of honor. Robert Dayton Beguelin was the best man for his brother.

title: IMPERSONAL PROSE OF PERSONAL ADS
description: A SMILING young couple pose above the caption ''They Found Each Other Through the Personal Ads,'' and each time I notice them, I wonder if they are merely some editor's fiction, extended from the fantasies reflected in the ads themselves.

title: LAURIE ANN BARTLETT, A LAWYER, WEDS DR. MARK KEATING
description: At Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco, Laurie Ann Bartlett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund G. Bartlett of Piedmont, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Taylor Keating, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Keating of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The Rev. Canon Marc DuPlan Lee performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Maurice M. McCormick, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Music: Kyoko Takezawa Gives Violin Recital at Y
description: KYOKO TAKEZAWA, who made her New York recital debut Thursday night at the 92d Street Y, has a familiar biography, if a rather more distinguished one than most. Born in Japan, she won prizes for violinists there before coming to the Aspen Music Festival in 1985 to work with Dorothy Delay. She has continued her studies at the Juilliard School with Miss Delay and Masao Kawasaki.

title: Koch's Ire Focuses Attention on Pension Increases
description: Mayor Koch's vociferous campaign against a state bill to increase pensions for retired city workers has drawn attention for the first time to a system that has been in operation for more than a decade.

title:
GARDENING;
TAKING ADVANTAGE OF WINTER FOR SPRING
description: LEAD: ANY sign of spring can reinforce the feelings of restlessness people feel at this time of year.

title: Cuomo Proposes a Rights Unit in Abrams's Office
description: Governor Cuomo made a surprise appearance today at a meeting of black and Hispanic elected officials and civil-rights leaders, and, in an apparent effort at compromise, proposed the creation of a special civil-rights unit in the State Attorney General's office.

title: PROBLEM WITH OLD HOUSES IS THEY'RE OLD
description: WHEN my new husband and I moved to Putnam County into our first house, a 200-year-old Colonial, it wasn't two weeks before the predictions started coming true. ''You'll see,'' family and friends had told us, smiling kindly but, I thought, a little grimly. They were all homeowners, these Cassandras. ''Things will fall apart after you move in.''

title: NEW JERSEY OPINION: The Natural State
description: LEAD: THE SUN was warm, but the wind had February in its teeth. Up on the hillside, it may well have been shirt-sleeve weather, but down near the water, on this icy shelf, the climate was strictly goose down.

title: CLARE MIDDLETON LUCE TO WED
description: Clare Middleton Luce and Clifford Louis Abbey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Abbey of Sweet Home, Ore., plan to marry in April, the parents of the bride-to-be, Margarget H. Howe of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Peter P. Luce of Boulder, Colo., have announced.

title: EMERGENCY WORKERS AND AIDS
description: Our desire to avoid ostracizing AIDS patients should not deter us from practicing appropriate public-health measures. Although the risk of transmitting AIDS by touching a contaminated arrowhead must be exceedingly low, not to seal it in plastic would have been foolhardy.

title: The Prince and His Czar - Letters From Exile
description: The countries of the world should be divided into two classes, countries of immigrants and countries of emigres. Everybody knows that America - her might, her prosperity, her culture - has been created mainly, if not exclusively, by huddled masses yearning to breathe free. The culture of Russia, on the other hand, has been created, almost to the same extent, by her emigres, the wretched refuse of that ancient, pompous empire. Virtually the same observation applies to Poland or Hungary or, for that matter, to my native Lithuania, to all parts of that ill-defined realm called Eastern (or sometimes Central) Europe, which remains within the empire's reach.

title: Russia's Divisive War
description: ALEKSANDR SIMONOV returned from the war in Afghanistan last summer, tanned and sinewy from carrying his weight in weaponry on mountain patrols.

title: Streetscapes: The Leonori; A Building That Recounts The Multiple-Dwelling Story
description: Workmen are putting finishing touches on the new marble in the lobby of the turn-of-the-century Leonori, at the southeast corner of 63d and Madison Avenue, a building whose successive alterations document both the history of the multiple dwelling and of the Upper East Side.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor. I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed. I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there. Is there anything else you can suggest?

title: In New Hampshire Presidential Primary The Watchword Is, 'Don't Bet on It'
description: WHEN Vice President Bush was asked the evening of the Iowa caucuses last week how his surprisingly poor third-place finish would affect his political fortunes in the New Hampshire primary day after tomorrow, he had a ready answer.

title: AMTRAK PLANS A STOP IN YONKERS
description: SIXTY parking spaces and a few signposts are all that stand in the way of new Amtrak rail service at Yonkers, according to Amtrak officials and Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko of Yonkers.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIBERAL: Adolf A. Berle and the Vision of an American Era. By Jordan A. Schwarz. (Free Press, $24.95.) Jordan A. Schwarz presents the best summation of his subject in the first paragraph of his preface. Adolf A. Berle (1895-1971), Mr. Schwarz writes, was ''entranced with power and how ideas shaped it.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; From a Sturdy Mill, Stately Apartments
description: WHEN the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Mill moved to the South in 1971, it left more than a dozen enormous brick buildings standing vacant in Enfield, a Connecticut city of 45,000 residents on the Massachusetts border whose economy Bigelow had dominated since 1914.

title: MGM Confection
description: BROADWAY MELODY OF 1938 With Eleanor Powell, Judy Garland (in photo) and Robert Taylor. Directed by Roy Del Ruth. MGM/UA Home Video. 113 minutes. $29.95.

title: STEPHANIE PERELL TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Perell of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie G. Perell, to Clifford Krause, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Krause of Woodbury, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Alfonso Valdes Cobian; Dies in San Juan at 98
description: Alfonso Valdes Cobian, an industrialist, banker, sportsman, politician and member of one of the most prominent families in Puerto Rico, died Monday in San Juan after suffering a heart attack two days earlier. He was 98 years old.

title: Getting Down to Brass Talks
description: A curiosity of world politics is that many problems arise from military perceptions yet military adversaries seldom talk to each other. Diplomats talk, often to discuss matters well understood only by the warriors. Warriors, somehow, seem to talk directly only when the shooting stops. All of which explains why there's something encouraging afoot between American and Soviet military men.

title: AID AND COMFORT
description: IT MAY SEEM CONTRADIC-tory that the extravagant formal wedding is regaining popularity in an age when both brides and their mothers have so little time to actually execute their plans. It all makes sense, though, given the increasing popularity of bridal consultants.

title: New York Suburbs Spilling Westward
description: Lured by out-of-date house prices and a twin set of superhighways, growing numbers of New York and New Jersey residents are settling into dozens of small northeastern Pennsylvania communities stretching from the old mill town of Easton to the heart of honeymoon land in the Pocono mountains.

title: North Carolina Needs a Rally
description: Jeff Lebo scored 18 points and North Carolina overcame a 17-point deficit to outscore Virginia, 12-2, in the final 4 minutes 5 seconds today, beating the Cavaliers, 64-58.

title: Nora Astorga, a Sandinista Hero And Delegate to U.N., Dies at 39
description: Nora Astorga, Nicaragua's chief delegate to the United Nations and one of her Government's leading voices on the international scene, died of cancer yesterday in a Managua hospital. Thirty-nine years old, she had been one of the Sandinistas' leading guerrilla heroes in the revolution that overthrew the Somoza regime in July 1979.

title: Soviet Musicologist Set for Exchanges
description: Boris Ivanovich Kulikov, rector of the Moscow State Conservatory, paused last Friday in his headlong flight across musical America to talk about Soviet-American relationships. He is for them. Mr. Kulikov commented briefly on the sleet and wind (''Moscow weather,'' he said) then launched enthusiastically into pending projects for exchanges between the two countries. Under the auspices of the United States Information Agency, the Russian pianist, conductor and educator has spent most of the last month touching down at such musical bases as the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia, the Peabody Institute in Baltimore and Indiana University in Bloomington. He is surprised only at how few surprises these institutes of musical education have presented him. He is, in other words, convinced that the two cultures are close in both aim and practice.

title: Apartheid Foe At University Bridges a Gap
description: A red and yellow poster advertising a campus symposium on the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution last November is the only decoration on the dark-wood panels of Jakes Gerwel's office.

title: TRION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
East Bloc Aircraft Deals Seen
description: Western aircraft manufacturers are positioning themselves for possible sales to Eastern Europe, as chinks appear in what was once a closely walled Soviet market.

title: Lisa Rosenzweig Married
description: Lisa Rosenzweig, a lawyer who is a law assistant in New York City Criminal Court, was married yesterday to Mitchell Benus, a managing director of Summit Myco Capital Management in New York and Chicago. Rabbi Amnon Haramati officiated at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aron Rosenzweig of Brooklyn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Benus of Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: MOLECULAR BIOSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company indicated that all revenue figures include interest income.

title: PROVENA FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nixon Says Kennedy Should Be Candidate
description: Former President Nixon said today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts should run for President this year.

title: Tyson-Spinks: It's On
description: Mike Tyson and Michael Spinks will fight for the heavyweight title.

title: The Sick Are Under Siege and Need Rescuers; New Strategies Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors: Help Far From Home
description: ANYONE who has ever gone hunting or fishing far from his usual haunts knows that such expeditions are sometimes fruitless or even impossible without the services of a guide or outfitter.

title: PERCEPTION TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Washington's Birthday Observed
description: NEW YORK Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping. Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail. Banks: Option to close. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule. Schools: Option to close; New York City schools are closed. Libraries: New York Public, Brooklyn and Queens libraries are closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Saturday schedule, no rail service on Montclair Branch, Boonton and Pascack Valley lines. Schools: Option to close. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed. Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule. Schools: Closed.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $824,000 for the quarter and $1,590,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $301,000 and $702,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Far-Reaching Changes Seen in Soviet Science
description: -delegation of Soviet scientists to a meeting here today outlined sweeping institutional reforms and a new climate of candor that the delegates said were stimulating far-reaching changes in Soviet science.

title: Jansen Falls in Bid for Gold Medal
description: One of the United States' few chances to win a gold medal in the Calgary Olympics ended in stunning fashion tonight when Dan Jansen fell entering the first turn and Nick Thometz finished eighth in the men's 500-meter speed-skating race.

title: MID MAINE SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank became publicly held in December 1986.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; No Business Like the Real Estate Business
description: Broadway may be enjoying its best year of the decade, with blockbuster hits lighting up every available playhouse, but to hear the story told by Gerald Schoenfeld, the biggest name in the theater business, you would think this season represents nothing more than a temporary respite in the 60-year decline of the industry.

title: Steer Away From Tragedy
description: ''Come ride with me,'' beckons an advertisement for all-terrain vehicles, ''and I'll take you where you've never been before.'' Buyers of the balloon-tire buggies often don't realize where that might be. In the last five years more than 900 riders of all-terrain vehicles wound up dead, and another 330,000 wound up in the hospital. Almost half those killed were under the age of 16. The figures show why such vehicles ought to be tightly regulated.

title: Auto Racing
description: Bobby Allison raced to his third Daytona 500 victory today, outdueling his son Davey to win stock car racing's top event.

title: Business and the Law; Suits Mounting On Toxic Waste
description: IN what has become a virtual race for the courthouse, manufacturers and insurance companies are filing a flurry of lawsuits against one another over who must pay for the cleanup of toxic waste sites throughout the nation.

title: Arthur Mizener, 80, Critic Who Wrote Work on Fitzgerald
description: Arthur Mizener, a professor, critic and author of the acclaimed first biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the Metacom Manor Health Center, a nursing home, in Bristol, R.I., where he lived. He was 80 years old.

title: FIRST HOME FEDL ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There are no common share earnings for the 1986 year because the S&L converted from a mutual to stock form in August 1986.

title: CAMPAIGN TO FIND DRUGS FOR FIGHTING AIDS IS INTENSIFIED
description: After a sluggish start that provoked criticism and bitter disputes, Federal and private efforts to develop new drug treatments for AIDS are accelerating.

title: Winter Is the Time to Set Stage for Smooth Going
description: MOST world-class athletes work at their sport all the time, tweaking and tuning their skills, even on days off. Sailors are among them, taking advantage of winter's downtime to keep the heat on. You don't have to be as compulsive as the best, but you can pick up a few hints from them - enough to give you a head start on the summer racing season.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Essay; The Shultz Shuttle
description: Fact No. 1: Our Secretary of State is headed to Moscow next week, and after returning home to brief the President, will make his way to the Middle East.

title: CALFED INCOME PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The partnership said that since it began operations in December 1986, there are no comparable results for the year-ago periods.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1988
description: International Report

title: A Car Bomb Kills 3 P.L.O. Officers in Cyprus
description: A car bomb killed three senior officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization in the Cypriot resort of Limassol today.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAN WITH A GUN. By Robert Daley. 475 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: EMONS HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $93,269 and $244,866 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a $2,050,176 loss from reorganization and a charge of $71,033 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards. d-Net income and includes a $2,050,176 loss from reorganization and a tax credit of $90,086. The company said year-ago share earnings were not presented since all of the Emons Industries common stock was canceled upon completion of a plan of reorganization; new shares of Emons Holdings Inc. were issued under the plan on Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Piano: An Austrian in Debut
description: ONLY 23 years old, Stefan Vladar has already won the International Beethoven Piano Competition in his native Vienna. The Austrian Institute brought him to Weill Recital Hall Sunday afternoon in a program that reflected both Mr. Vladar's seriousness of purpose and his central-European roots.

title: Falling Debris Shuts the Belt
description: The Belt Parkway was closed to all traffic for about six hours yesterday in Brooklyn when pieces of concrete fell on the six-lane highway from an overpass at Flatbush Avenue, the police said. Traffic was backed up as far as the Van Wyck Expressway and Cropsey Avenue as the police detoured traffic around the overpass starting at 3:30 P.M. A car was struck by the falling debris before the closing, but no one was injured. At 9:30 P.M. city engineers announced that the debris had been removed and that the overpass was sound. The eastbound lanes were then reopened, but the westbound lanes were closed until 11:30 P.M.

title: Man is Held in Death Of His Bride on Cruise
description: The body of a woman who was on a honeymoon cruise has been found in the Pacific Ocean, and her husband has been booked for investigation of murder, the authorities said today.

title: Markets Form Joint Venture
description: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade have ratified a joint venture agreement with the Chicago Board Options Exchange that will allow members of both exchanges to trade new options and futures, officials said.

title: U.S. Cites Asian Piracy
description: The United States is not satisfied with Asian efforts to end piracy of patents and other intellectual property rights, a senior State Department official said Friday.

title: Metro Matters; Battle to Block The Re-naming Of Fifth Avenue
description: ''How can a Negro be conservative?'' Marcus Garvey once asked. ''What has he to conserve?''

title: Mets Have a Confident Lame Duck
description: DAVE JOHNSON approaches his fifth and presumably final year as manager of the Mets this week with several constants in his mathematical mind.

title: DIAGNOSTIC VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The 1986 results are restated for an accounting change.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Getting the Business

title: Rise of Refugees Leaving Soviet Taxes Agencies
description: While still only a trickle compared with the heyday of detente in 1979, the increasing number of Jews being allowed to leave the Soviet Union since the recent improvement in superpower relations has strained the resources of the charitable agencies that resettle them in America.

title: FASTENAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
