New Jersey Worried Over Crowded Ballot
description: New Jersey election officials hope more Presidential candidates drop out before the state's primary, or they may have to rent voting machines to accommodate crowded ballots.

title: Yankees' Fortune Hinges on Pitching
description: EVER since their season ended on a cold, blustery day in early October, the Yankees have been doing the things they do best. They dismissed a general manager, resurrected Billy Martin once more, added a potent bat to the lineup and tried desperately to shore up their typically vulnerable pitching. Now, three days from the reporting date for pitchers and catchers, they appear to be a team that improved its strength but did almost nothing to fortify its weakness over the winter.

title: Dalai Lama Also Wants Tibet Modernized
description: To the Editor:

title: GEONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TRC COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIO-VASCULAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a $74,306 gain on the forgiveness of debt.

title: INDUSTRIAL TRAINING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Springfield Journal; Standing In for a Myth In the Land of Lincoln
description: Even in the Civil War, being the 16th President of the United States may have been a very easy job in a way; Abraham Lincoln just had to be himself. But it's quite something else to live up to the myth of Abraham Lincoln in 1988 when you're really Harry Hahn.

title: Stage: A Black Athlete's Struggle, in 'Anchorman'
description: PAUL CARTER HARRISON'S musical drama ''Anchorman'' is subtitled ''a blues operetta,'' but that doesn't mean it contains any of the buoyancy one associates with operetta. This hysterically enraged expression of racial antagonism is about as lighthearted as a wake.

title: DELTA DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Phyllis Eleuthera Harrison Is Married To Mark To Ballantine in the Bahamas
description: Phyllis Eleuthera Harrison and Mark Thompson Ballantine were married yesterday at the Harbor Island Anglican Church on Eleuthera Island, the Bahamas, by the Rev. Donald George. The bride, a daughter of Sarah S. Harrison and Preston Harrison, both of Richmond, graduated from the Trinity School in Richmond, the Oldfields School and Mount Vernon College. She was presented at the Holly Ball in Wilmington, Del., and at the Bal du Bois in Richmond. Mrs. Ballantine is a sales representative for Evermay Enterprises, florists and landscapers in Alexandria, Va., Her father is a real-estate broker and a vice president of Morton G. Thalhimer Inc., a commercial real-estate concern in Richmond. The bride is a great-granddaughter of the late Eugene E. du Pont of Greenville, Del., a director of the Du Pont Company.

title: CHASE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk; Aide Says Fears Led to Contra Affair
description: A senior Justice Department official says the Reagan Administration might have avoided its mistakes in the Iran-contra affair if it had the political nerve to stand by its plan to curb leaks with widespread polygraph tests and expanded censorship.

title: GROUP 1 SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABC Technology Brings Fire to the Ice
description: THE Winter Olympics have always generated a sense of grace, and not just the raw power of the Summer Games - from the stylized body movements of the speed skaters, to the hunched-down aerodynamic forms of the ski jumpers, to the fluid dance of the figure skaters. But ABC-TV has taken the Games to a new dimension: sensuality.

title: CXR TELCOM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 1-for-25 reverse stock split which is effective Feb. 4.

title: Richard A. Buch Weds Cynthia Marks, Writer
description: Cynthia Marks, the daughter of Dorothy Marks of New York and Stanley Marks of Hollywood, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Richard Allan Buch, the son of Joseph Buch of Buffalo and the late Shirley Buch. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: The Sick Are Under Siege and Need Rescuers
description: To the Editor:

title: Cartwright's Hopes For Trade Linger
description: With the National Basketball Association's trading deadline only 10 days away, Bill Cartwright, unhappy with his role of backing up Patrick Ewing at center, would prefer that the Knicks trade him.

title: Caren A. Zwickler Is Wed To Michael David Levine
description: The marriage of Caren Amy Zwickler, the daughter of Seymour Zwickler of Hollywood, Fla., and Sandra Lewin of Floral Park, Queens, to Michael David Levine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Levine of Plainview, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Joseph I. Singer performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,426,000 which includes a pretax charge of $2.2 million that was reserved for disposition of West Coast mortgage banking operation. c-After a tax credit of $5,655,000 and a charge of $628,000. d-Includes tax credits of $1,015,000 and $3,862,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Judge Gives Naturalized Citizens Right to U.S. Security Clearances
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that naturalized American citizens have the same rights as other Americans to security clearances that give them access to government secrets.

title: Olympian's Fall Ends His Dream
description: Dan Jansen of the United States, whose sister died of leukemia early yesterday, fell and lost his bid for a gold medal in the 500-meter speed-skating event at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta. Jansen was the favorite in the event, which was won by Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany in world-record time.

title: Office Growth Slows in Boroughs Outside Manhattan
description: A campaign by New York City to attract large-scale office developments to the boroughs outside Manhattan is being stalled by a wave of economic uncertainty created by the stock market collapse, according to city officials and business executives.

title: The Treaty, Europeans and the Jitters
description: What does Europe think of the treaty to eliminate Euromissiles? The answer, as the Senate weighs ratification, is clear: Virtually all West European leaders support the treaty. Some Americans say that behind the official blessings lie deep divisions and doubts. But they confuse genuine support for this treaty and equally genuine concern about the state of the alliance. Failure to ratify the treaty would only deepen those concerns.

title: Biden's Condition Improves
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware was listed in satisfactory condition today after undergoing surgery to correct an aneurysm that burst in an artery supplying blood to his brain, a hospital spokesman said. The 45-year-old Senator, who remained in intensive care at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, was ''alert and talking to his family and resting comfortably,'' said Michael McGinnis, a spokesman for the hospital.

title: Ghandi Is Shuffling Cabinet to Reinforce His Party in North
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi shuffled his Cabinet today in a move to strengthen his standing in the populous northern Hindi-speaking areas, where his political foes have gained strength in recent months.

title: 'SLIPPED OUT FROM UNDER ME'
description: THE ICE is smooth now, glazed by a Zamboni machine. But for more than an hour during the Olympic 500-meter sprint last night, the white smear leading to the red base of the padded gray wall resembled the skid marks of an automobile accident. And in the years to come, spectators at the indoor Speed-Skating Oval will point to the ice on that first turn.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Tuning Out
description: When viewers of the Christian Broadcasting Network tune in on Tuesday to find out how the New Hampshire primary is going, what will they learn? Absolutely nothing. The television network, which was founded by Pat Robertson, the Republican Presidential contender, has decided not to cover the race.

title: Dionne Earns Rangers A 4-4 Tie
description: Phil Esposito, who may or may not prove to be a learned general manager, clearly knows something about the business of scoring goals. Having scored 717 himself, he was asked yesterday afternoon how Marcel Dionne had managed to accumulate 719. Esposito, smiling at his own immodesty, simply pointed to his head. ''It's all there,'' Esposito said. And it was all on display yesterday, as Dionne scored two goals, the second with 6 minutes 12 seconds left in the third period to give the Rangers a 4-4 draw with the Islanders at Madison Square Garden.

title: GENERAL METALS & ABRASIVES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Debate, Bush Issues a Plea for Help
description: Vice President Bush, who has seen his once overwhelming lead in New Hampshire evaporate in a matter of days, tonight issued a cry for help in his struggle to salvage his Presidential candidacy.

title: In U.S., 30 Juvenile Offenders Await Execution
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTIST'S PAINTINGS DEPICT THE ANTARCTIC EXPERIENCE
description: ''We came to probe the mystery, to reduce this land to the terms of science,'' the Australian explorer Douglas Mawson wrote of Antarctica, ''but there is always the indefinable which holds aloof, which rivets our souls.''

title: Believers Hold Out for God's Tornado
description: Annie Sims, the preacher's wife, delivered the prophecy at a prayer meeting late in December:

title: The Stage: 'Elephant Man'
description: ''THE ELEPHANT MAN'' is back. A young actor named Jonathan Courie brings to the Equity Library Theater a sensitive and witty portrayal of John Merrick, the deformed figure at the center of Bernard Pomerance's admirable 1979 play. There really was a Merrick, and from his last years in a London hospital between 1884 and 1890, when he achieved considerable celebrity, Mr. Pomerance created a morality tale that permits no easy moral.

title: Rise of Shearson as a Deal Maker
description: When Frederick M. Frank received the telephone call on Jan. 4, he had to think fast. Mr. Frank, a managing director of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., had been discussing the Eastman Kodak Company's strategic options with a group of Kodak executives. The caller told him that Hoffmann-La Roche & Company had just made a surprise bid for Sterling Drug Inc., a drug company that Kodak had considered for a joint venture or friendly acquisition.

title: Vote Set to End U.S. Control Of a Jersey Teamsters Local
description: A court agreement setting a date for elections that would end Government control over a crime-ridden New Jersey teamsters local has been approved by a Federal District judge.

title: British Inflation Eases
description: Britain's annual inflation rate registered its sharpest decline in 15 months in January, the Department of Employment said Friday. It said that the Retail Price Index remained unchanged for the month and that the price increase for the year came to 3.3 percent. The annual inflation figure in December was 3.7 percent. The drop of four-tenths of a percentage point was the biggest since a drop of 1.2 percentage points in April 1986.

title: REICH & TANG L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are pro-forma. Reich & Tang L.P. began operations on June 1, 1987 upon the transfer of substantially all of the business of Reich & Tang Inc. to the partnership.

title: Clarinet: Richard Stoltzman
description: IN the murky musical territory known as ''classical crossover,'' where jazz and pop meet and mingle with traditional concert fare, there are almost as many roads to take as there are artists willing to travel them. Some performers - especially singers - use the opportunity to pander to pop audiences. Others, like the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman, seem genuinely interested in fusing genres, although doing so successfully isn't easy.

title: Rail System Fined Over Safety
description: The Government is levying fines of $734,900 against the Northeast's Guilford rail system for an array of safety violations over a four-year period, the Federal Railroad Administration has reported.

title: Running: Good for the Soul, Too?
description: ANY research psychologist worth his Ph. D. must, from time to time, cast a yearning glance at the runners he sees passing in the streets. Surely, runners must be different psychologically from everyone else, prime subjects for a research project that would probe their personalities and inner resources.

title: Cyprus Chief Loses Election; Runoff Set to Pick Successor
description: President Spyros Kyprianou lost his bid for re-election, returns showed early today, leaving a conservative and a Communist-backed millionaire in a runoff next Sunday.

title: POLK AUDIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
The Dance: Atlanta Ballet In 'Kinesthesis' Premiere
description: THE Atlanta Ballet presented three new works Saturday night under the auspices of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, where the company from Georgia has been involved in a visiting residency program for five years.

title: Profit Reported by Aeroflot
description: Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline, carried 119 million passengers and earned $3.3 billion in 1987, officials said Friday.

title: Women's Style Suits Globetrotters
description: It started out as a gimmick, a way to add flair to a team that thrives on trickery. The Harlem Globetrotters, the clown princes of basketball, added a princess to the lineup as an extra attraction to their unique show.

title: Brazil Seeks To Mend Rift With Lenders
description: One year after suspending most payments on its $113 billion foreign debt, Brazil has quietly abandoned its confrontational debt strategy and is now seeking to restore normal relations with its creditors as soon as possible.

title: Makers of Semiconductors Meeting to View the Future
description: For many in the computer industry, the International Solid State Circuits Conference, which will begin here Wednesday, serves as an unofficial leading indicator of technological prowess. It is a place where engineers are let out of the back room to discuss the latest in the tiny silicon circuits that can do everything from perform millions of multiplications a second to draw pictures on a computer screen.

title: Donnica Moore, Physician, Weds
description: The marriage of Dr. Donnica L. Moore, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia, to Dr. Stanley Bernard Jr., a medical marketing consultant, took place yesterday in Philadelphia. Rabbi Max Hausen performed the ceremony at the Fairmount Park Horticultural Center.

title: What to Call Pat Robertson
description: Pat Robertson has taken to portraying himself as a victim of religious oppression because of what people call him. If he keeps it up, what they are apt to call him is a dissembler.

title: TMK-UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes securities losses of $894,000 and $106,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes securities gains of $133,000 and $11,639,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: R. M. (Max) Leggette, Hydrogeologist, 88
description: R. M. (Max) Leggette, a hydrogeologist, died in San Diego Feb. 2. He was 88 years old and lived in the San Diego retirement community of Wesley Palms.

title: U.S. TEXTILE INDUSTRY'S TURNAROUND
description: Five years ago the textile industry looked pretty bad. It was battered by imports and hampered by outmoded plants. Since then, however, it has poured money into modernization and today has become one of the most efficient industries in the United States - operating at near capacity and turning out steady profits.

title: BALCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West Is Easing Policy on Sales To Soviet Bloc
description: The United States and allied governments are trying to make it easier for companies to sell nonmilitary goods to the Soviet bloc, reflecting the inexorable demand of industries for new markets and the swift global diffusion of technology.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $39,000 on settlement of EPA superfund claim. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $7,000 for the quarter and $15,000 for the 9 months.

title: SEABOARD S&L ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Library as Day Care: New Curbs and Concerns
description: Public libraries across the nation are increasingly being used, and librarians say abused, by parents who drop off their children for hours because day care is too expensive or unavailable.

title: A West Bank Village's Sons Return
description: Joe Hammad's long white Mercedes, paid for by his chain of liquor stores back in California, climbed the steep ancient paths with the plodding power of the goatherds being nudged aside by the returning son.

title: P.S.A.L. Tourney Spread Across City
description: The Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament this year will be played in high school gyms across the city and a good subway and bus map will come in handy.

title: James FitzPatrick, Power Agency Head And Lawmaker, 71
description: James A. FitzPatrick, a former state assemblyman who served as chairman of the New York State Power Authority from 1963 to 1977, died of leukemia Saturday at Champlain Valley Hospital in Plattsburgh, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Plattsburgh.

title: Ferdinand Loses To His Stablemate
description: Judge Angelucci scored a 3 1/2-length victory today over Ferdinand, his stablemate and 1987 Horse of the Year, in winning the $269,000 San Antonio Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: Stephens vs. Lukas: New Round Begins
description: Racing's best rivalry since Affirmed and Alydar a decade ago will be renewed at Gulfstream Park on Monday. The rivals are not specific horses, but their handlers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The state refuses to recognize most Monday holidays. We celebrate presidential birthdays the old-fashioned way -inconveniently.'' - Howard Mansfield of Hancock, N.H., on his state's contrariness. [ A13:5. ]

title: Orser, Boitano On Two Paths To Same Goal
description: FOR the last four years, they have stalked each other, only occasionally in close proximity. For all their intensity and electricity, those times only served as a tease for the ultimate showdown.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Private Talks on a Broken Knuckle at the Chambers Trial
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s right hand was so badly injured that he couldn't even make a fist. There were bite marks and he apparently had a broken knuckle. About three hours after he was arrested and charged with the murder of Jennifer Levin, and about 19 hours after her body was discovered, he was taken by the police to a hospital emergency room for treatment.

title: Nkomo Sees Beginning of Zimbabwean Unity
description: Joshua Nkomo, the patriarch of Zimbabwean black nationalism, stood before an attentive crowd at a political rally and said he had a story to tell.

title: Manned Space Station Commits Us to Future
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Generation
description: Skiers representing the United States at the Olympics will have a long way to go to top the performance of a group of youngsters who represented this country at the world junior championships. They won one gold medal, two silvers and a bronze, and an informal point count put the team way ahead of any of the other nations competing.

title: TV Reporter Expelled For Panama Coverage
description: A reporter for the Cable News Network has been expelled from Panama after the Government said his coverage of the political situation here lacked objectivity.

title: PERSONAL DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 76ers Falter, And Nets Win by 4
description: The Philadelphia 76ers' troubles began in the second quarter today with the ejection of Charles Barkley; they ended with a 14-point final quarter. The combination paved the way for a 109-105 Net victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: For Bucharest, a Great Leap Backward
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu's bristly stand toward his allies in the East and friends in the West has led Rumania to what Western and Communist analysts here say is virtual isolation.

title: Lucky Dukakis Sits Above the Fray
description: ''Steady as she goes,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis says with a smile and an equanimity he easily can afford.

title: Paris Journal; Merci, Senator, but We Are Not a Charity Case
description: ''It is scandalous to say that Jews in France, whoever they are, are discriminated against,'' said Jacques Lazarus, a journalist who came here from Algeria. ''What is even more scandalous is the magnitude of the money. When we heard this we said this must be a peculiar American crazy story.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Tale of Two Georges
description: George III and Henry VI were the two maddest kings of England. They had another connection, through the school for needy scholars that Henry VI founded in the shadow of Windsor Castle. George III (pictured here) often sought refuge there from the intrigues of London and his attacks of porphyria, a disorder that affected his mental balance. Alone of his subjects on either side of the Atlantic, the boys did nothing to cause him grief or set off his fits.

title: Big Losses For Health Insurers
description: Surging inflation in medical costs and heavy expenses associated with starting health maintenance organizations have resulted in record losses for the nation's health insurance industry.

title: VM SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POSEIDON POOLS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $49,500. The company completed its initial public offering on Aug. 27, 1987.

title: A Pole Apart for Nordic Skiing
description: AN unusual new pole for cross-country skiing has been banned for use by Nordic skiers at the XV Olympic Winter Games. But biathletes competing in Calgary can use it, and so can you on cross-country trails near home.

title: Frederick Loewe Dies at 86; Wrote 'My Fair Lady' Score
description: Frederick (Fritz) Loewe, the composer who with his longtime lyricist partner Alan Jay Lerner created the scores for ''My Fair Lady,'' ''Camelot,'' ''Paint Your Wagon,'' ''Brigadoon,'' and ''Gigi,'' died yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif.. He was 86 years old.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES: PASSING UP THE PARADE
description: SCOTT FUSCO told his hockey teammates not to worry about not marching in the opening parade for the Olympics on Saturday. He'd marched in one and didn't enjoy it all that much.

title: TRANS LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago comparisons are not meaningful as the company was in a developement stage at that time.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the reduction of a provision for loss on discontinuance of a business division of $578,000, a gain on the sale of stock of $1,416,000 and tax loss carryforwards of $309,000.

title: Watson's Problems Help Wadkins Win
description: Given breathing room by Tom Watson's four-putt collapse, Lanny Wadkins came on with a six-under-par 66 to score a one-stroke victory today in the Hawaiian Open.

title: WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest period reflect a 40 percent tax rate for the second quarter, compared with 57 percent for the year-earlier period, which included a one-time reversal of investment tax credits in accordance with federal law legislation.

title: Lakers Hold Off Celtics' Late Drive
description: Byron Scott scored 17 of his 38 points in the final quarter today as the Los Angeles Lakers, after wasting a 20-point halftime lead, rallied to beat the Boston Celtics, 115-106.

title: Grocer Seen as Leader Of Possible Buyout Deal
description: Byron Allumbaugh got his start in the grocery business as a meatcutter. But for the last 12 years he has been chairman of the Ralphs Grocery Company, a 129-store Southern California supermarket chain owned by Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: EX-CBS NEWSMAN STARTS OWN COMPANY
description: When Ike Pappas was laid off from his job as a newsman at CBS it gave him an opportunity to forge a career in an area he has long wanted to pursue: running a television production company.

title: BODDIE-NOELL RESTAURANT PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in May 1987.

title: I.B.M. EXHIBIT HONORS COLUMBUS ANNIVERSARY
description: The IBM Gallery of Science and Art is making an early start on the quincentenary of Christopher Columbus's voyage to the New World. Instead of waiting until 1992, the gallery will begin celebrating with an exhibition of rare documents, prints, maps and illustrated books from the John Carter Brown Library at Brown University in Providence, R.I., starting tomorrow and running through April 9.

title: IRVINE SENSORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Review; 'TANNER 88,' A SATIRE ON PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGNS
description: Call it imaginative; call it satire; call it a mixed result. ''Tanner '88: the Dark Horse'' is too real to be funny, but it's also not real enough. How can a film make fun of politics when politics makes fun of itself? The Home Box Office presentation does not find the answer, although it may make the year's most interesting try. It will be seen on the pay-cable network at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Ohio's Law On Takeovers
description: Gov. Richard Celeste signed into law Friday emergency legislation that enables the state to assess the economic impact of takeover bids by foreign corporations.

title: Thatcher Is Choice for President, British Poll Says
description: Forget about Dole and Dukakis, Bush and Babbitt, or any of the other Presidential aspirants. If the American people had their druthers, and the chance, they would elect Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher President of the United States.

title: Bangkok Emerges as a Major Jewelry Center
description: Bangkok is rapidly climbing to the top of the international jewelry trade, and Thai jewelers say it is partly because cutting and setting gemstones is still a traditional family craft here.

title: Our Stakes in Afghanistan
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's televised broadcast to the Soviet people last week suggests that the Russians almost certainly desire and plan to withdraw from Afghanistan. The United States should be delighted and welcome this step. But foreign policy is never that simple.

title: Iran Warns the Saudis Not to Block Pilgrims
description: Iran warned Saudi Arabia today not to bar Iranians from the annual pilgrimage to the Moslem holy city of Mecca.

title: ABIOMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Net income

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinian-American Link In Deir Dibwan, a village in the occupied West Bank, Palestinians return from the United States with wealth, pride and hope. Page A6. Estrangement for Rumania Rumania is reported to be virtually isolated as a result of its leader's bristly stand toward allies in the East and friends in the West. Page A8.

title: Put an End to Failed One-Way-Toll Trial on Verrazano Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Refuses Polish Credits
description: Poland failed to get trade credits to finance imports at a meeting of American and Polish trade officials last week, but came away with a broad program to expand commerce between the countries.

title: Federal Judges Deny Bail More Frequently
description: Judges have used broad discretion granted under the Bail Reform Act of 1984 to jail a much higher percentage of people awaiting trial for Federal crimes, the Government said today.

title: No More Thursday Parties
description: The University of Rhode Island's Thursday night fraternity parties have succumbed to the complaints of professors who teach Friday morning classes. The Interfraternity Council voted last week to halt the parties after professors complained that too many students were sleeping in class or cutting class the next day.

title: Meese Deserves Justice, Not Abuse
description: LEAD: There was a time, not too long ago, when you could be considered a criminal only after you had been charged in an indictment, a jury returned a verdict and a court of appeals upheld the fairness of the proceeding. Appeals seemed, however, to drag matters out too long, and defendants seldom won on their technical legal arguments.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 Surrender, 1 Seized In Slaying of Cabby
description: Two men surrendered to the police over the weekend in the slaying of a gypsy-cab driver in the Williamsbridge section of Bronx on Friday, the police said yesterday.

title: FIRST STATE FINCL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company converted to public ownership in December 1987. The company attributed the earnings decline to gains on the sale of investments during 1986.

title: Koch and Unions End Their Feud And Agree to a City Pension Rise
description: Ending a bitter political battle over pension increases for New York State and city workers, Mayor Koch and union leaders announced yesterday that they had reached a compromise. The agreement would save the city $70 million but would fall far short of the savings the Mayor had sought.

title: Karen B. Cohen Is the Bride of Steven O. Moldin
description: Karen B. Cohen, the administrator of the department of radiation oncology at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, was married yesterday to Steven O. Moldin, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology of Yeshiva University. Rabbi Louis Frishman performed the ceremony at the Dellwood Country Club in New City, N.Y.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abraham & Straus, Brooklyn, N.Y., appointed Joseph Yewdell senior vice president.

title: American Home Enters Limelight
description: In an era when companies with new wonder drugs are the darlings of the investment world, the American Home Products Corporation has been something like a church deacon: solid and respectable but hardly flashy.

title: WINTER OLYMPIC MEDAL WINNERS
description: Speed Skating Men's 500 Meters

title: Smokers on Trains Lament New Ban
description: In the crowded bar car on the New Haven Line's 5:23 express train from Manhattan Friday night, commuters savored one last legal smoke and lamented the passing of an era.

title: Coe Upset by Poor Showing
description: The contrast between the performances of Sebastian Coe and Doina Melinte was a sharp one.

title: Canada Gets Stern Test in Hockey
description: The Canadian Olympic hockey team started its quest for a medal here with a shutout of Poland, a team that was expected to collapse before the Canadians but instead played a grim defensive game that allowed the Canadians just a single goal, but left itself with none.

title: James King, 74, Dead; Expert on Arms Control
description: James E. King, a specialist in arms control and disarmament who served for many years in Government and academic posts, died of lung cancer on Feb. 1 at his home in Garrett Park, Md. He was 74 years old. Mr. King, a native of Sumter, S.C., was a graduate of Harvard and a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford. He taught government at Harvard before serving in the Army in World War II. He was awarded the Bronze Star and was wounded in the invasion of Normandy.

title: DIVERSIFIED INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that in 1987 it realized profits on the sale of loans and investments of $1,854,562; in 1986, the company experienced a loss on such sales of $62,839.

title: Dollar Soars Against Yen
description: The dollar soared against the Japanese yen in early trading in Tokyo today after last Friday's report of a lower United States trade deficit.

title: Dr. Deborah Sherman Weds Dr. Mark Rubin
description: Dr. Deborah S. Sherman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Sherman of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Mark I. Rubin, the son of Geraldine Rubin of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Murray Rubin. Rabbi Steven Lerner performed the ceremony at the James House in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Art: Orsay's 'Van Gogh in Paris'
description: For the first major exhibition at the Musee d'Orsay, ''Van Gogh in Paris'' is a natural. With van Gogh, popular success is assured. The subject is the crucial period between March 1886 and February 1888, when van Gogh lived in Paris and introduced his palette and brush to space and light. Defining the importance of 19th-century Paris for a great Dutch artist underlines the importance of this year-old museum of 19th-century French art. In June 1888, in Arles, van Gogh wrote to his sister Wilhelmina that compared with Paris, ''all cities become small; Paris seems big like the sea.''

title: FORMER MINISTER RESPONDS TO SUIT
description: A former Methodist minister accused in a civil suit of trying to strangle his wife says he is innocent and has been staying away from his California apartment to dodge reporters, not court officials.

title: STATESWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: This is the company's first fiscal year of operations.

title: New Gas Leak at Plant in Maine
description: A hazardous gas leaked today for the third time since late January from an International Paper Company mill that has continued operating during a strike, and seven people were taken to hospitals, officials said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 5, Flames 4: Mike Gartner's second goal of the game 20 seconds into overtime gave Washington its victory over Calgary yesterday in Landover, Md. Mike Ridley sent a centering pass into the slot and Gartner beat Doug Dadswell, giving Washington its third straight victory. Washington's Dale Hunter had forced the extra period by scoring with 1 minute 27 seconds remaining in regulation.(AP) Blackhawks 4, Sabres 3: Steve Thomas's goal with 1:12 left in overtime gave Chicago a victory at home over Buffalo. Thomas beat Tom Barrasso, the Sabres' goalie, with a 25-foot slap shot and kept the Sabres from a victory in 10 overtime games this season, 0-1-9. After being held without a single shot on goal for nearly four minutes of a double-minor penalty, the Sabres' John Tucker tied the score, 3-3, at 14:07 with a 35-foot slap shot. With 12 minutes left in the third period, Denis Savard scored his 34th goal to give the Blackhawks a 3-2 lead.(AP) Jets 3, Nordiques 2: Dave Ellett had a goal and an assist, giving the Jets a victory at home. Winnipeg took a 1-0 lead on Fredrik Olausson's power-play goal at 10:18 of the first period and made it 2-0 at 15:10 when Ellett sprung Dale Hawerchuk for a short-handed goal. Alan Haworth scored for Quebec at 7:01, but Ellett restored the Jets' two-goal margin just 25 seconds later.(AP) Oilers 7, Canucks 6: Craig Simpson scored twice in 47 seconds midway through the third to give Edmonton a victory at home. Simpson snapped a 5-5 tie by tipping in Charlie Huddy's slap shot at 13:06, then made it 7-5 by slamming in Glenn Anderson's pass at 13:53. Mark Messier scored three goals for the Oilers. Tony Tanti had two for Vancouver.(AP) Tennis Navratilova Beats Shriver: Martina Navratilova easily beat Pam Shriver, 6-0, 6-3, in the Virginia Slims of Dallas. Navratilova, the tournament's top-seeded player, won the Dallas championship for the eighth time in the last 10 years. Navratilova called the match her best since 1986 when she was the undisputed No. 1 player in the world.(AP) Horse Racing Beru Triumphs: After battling head and head through the last six furlongs, favored Beru edged away from Joe's Tammie in the final yards to score a three-quarter-length victory in the $83,600 Sag Harbor Stakes at Aqueduct for New York-bred 3-year-old fillies. Joe's Tammie was easily second best in the field of six. For Beru, who carried co-highweight of 121 pounds under Nick Santagata, it was the fifth consecutive victory in six career starts and the third straight stakes victory. The daughter of Dr. Blum-Zany Girl went a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:45 4/5 to earn $50,160 for Barry K. Schwartz and paid $3.40 for $2 to win. Track and Field Joyner-Kersee Sets Mark: Jackie Joyner-Kersee set an American indoor record of 7.88 seconds in the women's 60-meter high hurdles yesterday at the Mobil One Invitational track and field meet at Fairfax, Va. She also set an American indoor long jump record of 23 feet 1/2 inch Saturday at the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational in East Rutherford, N.J. Yesterday, she broke the hurdles mark of 8.02, set in 1983 by Stephanie Hightower. Kim McKenzie-Turner was second in 8.21, and Candy Young finished third in 8.25. Diane Dixon won the 400 meters, catching Valerie Brisco at the tape in 52:30. Greg Foster easily won the men's 60-meter hurdles, pulling away to a one-yard victory over Tonie Campbell. Foster was timed in 7.48, with Campbell finishing in 7.56. Renaldo Nehemiah was third in 7.60. Antonio McKay won the men's 400 meters in 46:36, defeating Roddie Haley and Danny Harris. Doina Melinte of Rumania, who set a world indoor record of 4:18.86 in the women's mile on Saturday at East Rutherford, won the mile yesterday in a leisurely 4:39.49.(AP) Catholic Schools Final: Joe Tuttle won two events and Paul Whittaker posted a meet record yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field championships at Draddy Gym on the Manhattan College campus in the Bronx. Sam Rice of Cardinal Hayes also set a meet mark in winning the 55-meter dash in 6.3 seconds. Tuttle, a 16-year-old junior from Moore Catholic on Staten Island, was an easy winner of the 3,200-meter run in 9 minutes 29.4 seconds, a personal best, then came back later to win the 1,600 meters in 4:22.5. Whittaker, a senior at Xaverian in Brooklyn, took over the lead early in the 1,000 meters and won in 2 minutes 30.9 seconds, four-tenths of a second under the meet mark. Rice, a senior from the Bronx, got off to his usual fast start in the dash and continued undefeated in the sprints this season, winning his eighth straight race yesterday. He also anchored Hayes's 800-meter relay team to a meet record victory in 1:33.9 with a 22.6-second 200 anchor sprint. Eric Dixon of Nazareth edged Fred Owen of Hayes in the 300-meter dash in 35.4 seconds, tying the meet standard. Unbeaten Ian Jones, also from Nazareth, registered his sixth triumph of the season when the Brooklyn senior won the 600 meters in 1:22.9. In field events, Monsignor Farrell and St. Anthony's, who were expected to push Archbishop Molloy of Queens for the team title, each won two events. Brian Gallen took the long jump at 21 feet 5 1/4 inches, and Vincenzo Insingo the shot-put at 48 feet 9 3/4 inches for Farrell; Tom Schmitt won the high jump at 6 feet, and Russell Crandinetti was first in the pole vault at 13 feet for St. Anthony's. Race Walking Null Wins at Central Park: Gary Null of New York won the New York Walkers Club Polar Bear 5-kilometer race in 23 minutes 59 seconds at Central Park. Tom Gustafson, also of Converse, was the gold medalist in the 10-kilometer walk in 52:43.

title: Catching On
description: There are very few basketball courts in Venezuela, where Alex Roberts was born, or in Trinidad, where he spent his adolescence.

title: Governor Backs Residency Rule For Policemen
description: Governor Cuomo said this weekend that he plans to propose legislation requiring newly hired New York City police officers and firefighters to live in the city.

title: HOLIDAY-RV SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1988
description: International A2-9, A22

title: Music:Smith Singers and Chanticleer
description: SERIOUS choral singing took on a bi-coastal air Saturday night when the Gregg Smith Singers and San Francisco's Chanticleer came together at St. Peter's Church. It was a program of the old and the new.

title: Joyce Brown's Ascent From Anonymity
description: Not too long ago, Joyce Brown lived on an Upper East Side sidewalk in front of a restaurant's hot air vent. She hurled insults at some passers-by, made friends with others and used the street for her bathroom.

title: Metro Datelines; Off-Duty Patrolman Held in Firing of Gun
description: An off-duty police officer was arrested Saturday and suspended from the force after he was accused of firing his service revolver at a traffic-enforcement agent who had ticketed his parked car, the police said.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said the losses for the quarter and year relate to expenses incurred in its acquisition of Plessy Peripheral Systems.

title: Question Box; By Ray Corio
description: QUESTION: Has a major league pitcher ever hit a home run in a game in which he pitched a no-hitter?

title: Cubs Beat Dawson In Arbitration Case
description: Andre Dawson, who virtually had to beg the Chicago Cubs for a job a year ago, encountered another setback with them yesterday. Despite becoming the National League's most valuable player while earning only $700,000 last season, Dawson lost his salary arbitration case and a chance to establish an arbitration record.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Industrial Production... Jan. Housing Starts... Jan. Thursday Capacity Utilization... Jan. Friday None

title: SYSTEMS & COMPUTER TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Golden Words
description: Former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger likes to quote Churchill to the effect that history will treat him well ''because I intend to write the history myself.'' Even before writing the first sentence of his planned book, Mr. Weinberger is busy telling his version of current affairs in speeches for which audiences like the New York Bankers Association, where he spoke in January, are being asked to pay from $25,000 to $35,000.

title: Lisa Jayne Oppenheim Marries Robert Schultz
description: Lisa Jayne Oppenheim, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Oppenheim of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert David Schultz, a son of Mrs. David Schultz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Schultz. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Chieftans estate.

title: GAMMA BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Colonel Belew Wed in Texas
description: Lieut. Col. Beverly Ann Belew, an Army nurse who is attending the Army Command and General Staff College in Fort Leavenworth, Kan., and Col. Michael Richard Antopol, a cardiothoracic surgeon and the commander of the Brooke Army Medical Center at Fort Sam Houston, Tex., were married yesterday. Col. Irving C. Njus, a Protestant chaplain, performed the ceremony at the Gift Chapel at Fort Sam Houston.

title: Ballet: 2 Bolshoi Stars
description: HAVING passed through a baptism by fire last week, the New York City Ballet's two young guests from the Bolshoi Ballet came back for a second round Saturday afternoon. Mixed metaphors notwithstanding, the result was a triumph.

title: 3 Die in Explosion at Ski Area
description: Three employees of the Canaan Valley Ski Resort were killed today in an explosion at a maintenance building.

title: RESULTS AND STANDINGS
description: PAIRS SHORT PROGRAM

title: India Confronts Horrors Of the Past in TV Series
description: Forty years after the upheaval of India's birth and partition with Pakistan, an extraordinary television series is confronting millions of Indians anew with questions of blame for past and present violence.

title: MICRO BIO-MEDICS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Senators Say Black Sea Affair Casts Doubts on Soviet Aims
description: The Senate majority leader said today that the bumping of United States Navy warships by Soviet naval vessels in the Black Sea on Friday was bound to make Americans and Europeans more skeptical of the aims of the Soviet leadership.

title: Day-Care Effort Pressed For Municipal Workers
description: A few weeks after the first baby sitter arrived, Beverly J. Hoff began to notice money and food missing from her home. The second sitter kept Ms. Hoff's son David in his playpen all day. The third let him run into the street one day as his mother drove up.

title: VAC-TEC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: M.S. CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Men's Downhill Postponed a Day
description: At the base lodge, Swiss fans carried their country's red flag with its white cross and rang cowbells in anticipation of the downhill race their skiers were expected to dominate. Spectators mingled in a party tent, others rode chairlifts to the intermediate slopes and, at ABC's request, Bill Hudson of the United States team wished a happy Valentine's Day to his nieces back home.

title: Stacy Richmond Married In West to James Wallman
description: At Temple Isaiah in Los Angeles, Stacy Shaw Richmond and James David Wallman were married yesterday by Rabbi Robert Gahn.

title: Two U.S. Wars
description: Two wars that Americans think of quite separately have begun to converge in middle America. It is a matter of priorities that overlap and distort policy decisions.

title: STATEN I. HAS FRESH OUTLOOK FOR TOURNEY
description: Two all-star players, one most valuable player award, a coach of the year award, and a first-place league record of 13-1 are the makings of a potential championship team.

title: Wisconsin Pursues Chrysler Suit
description: Gov. Tommy Thompson asked Wisconsin's Attorney General on Friday to prepare a lawsuit against the Chrysler Corporation because of its plans to close its auto plant in Kenosha, Wis., but left open the possibility of a settlement.

title: Political Marketing; Candidates Sharpen Attacks In New Hampshire TV Ads
description: Presidential candidates are airing more negative television advertising than ever before, and they are doing it earlier in the campaign.

title: Franklin H. Kissner, Rare-Book Collector Who Was Financier
description: Franklin H. Kissner, a financier and collector of rare books, died Feb. 4 at New York Hospital after a fall and cerebral hemorrhage. He was 77 years old, with residences in Manhattan and in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Portuguese Voice Dismay Over U.S. Aid Cut
description: A Reagan Administration decision to cut aid to Portugal is creating political problems for Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva, who has threatened in the past to scrap a treaty that allows American use of a base in the Azores Islands.

title: SYNTECH INT'L INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $146,000 from discontinued operations. The company previously reported on a calendar year basis.

title: MARGAUX reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Russian Wins Cross-Country
description: Vida Ventsene, a 23-year-old Soviet student in only her third season of international racing, held off Raisa Smetanina, her 36-year-old teammate, by 8.7 seconds to win the women's 10-kilometer cross-country ski race at the Canmore Nordic Center yesterday and earn the first gold medal of the Winter Games.

title: Leon Goossens, Gifted English Oboist, Dies at 90
description: Leon Goossens, the English oboist who took an ancient instrument and gave it modern refinement and flexibility, died in Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England, on Friday. He was 90 years old.

title: Reagan Plan to Privatize Government Is Gaining Support From Democrats
description: In the budget he submits to Congress this week, President Reagan revives the debate over one of his oldest and most contentious causes - his desire to turn over more of the Government to private industry.

title: Sports World Specials; Flying Tackle
description: Chad Hennings has always seemed just a bit out of place at the Air Force Academy, a school where the big men on campus tend to be wiry types with cool-eyed gazes dreaming of the day they will squeeze into the cockpits of jet fighters and leave contrails streaked across the sky.

title: Ukrainians, in Pravda, Urge Election Reforms
description: Advocates of liberalization in the Communist Party proposed today in an article on the front page of Pravda that more than one candidate be put forward for top party posts and that all party members be allowed to vote.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 14, 1988: MONDAY Chicago Rivet & Machine Goodrich (BF) Co Cooper Tire & Rubber Realty Refund Tr Dana Corp Wendy's Intl TUESDAY Briggs & Stratton First Interstate Bancorp Cincinnati MilacronInterpublic Group of Cos Coleman CoOhio Edison Duquesne Light Whirlpool Corp WEDNESDAY Armtek Corp Intl Minerals & Chemicals Capital Holding CorpLawter Intl Florida East Coast IndusSherwin-Williams THURSDAY AmSouth Bncrptn Kollmorgen Corp Dresser Indus Loctite Corp Florida Progress Corp Nalco Chemcial Greyhound Corp Perkin-Elmer Illinois PwrRuss Berrie & Co Insilco Corp Sterling Bancorp Kimberly-Clark Sundstrand Corp FRIDAY Brown & Sharpe Mfg Illinois Tool Works Chelsea Industries Raymond James Fin'l Commonwealth Edison Reynolds Metals Edwards (AG) Inc South Jersey Indus IC Industries Texas Utilities

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; C.I.A. Secrets
description: There is no shortage of memoirs and books by former intelligence officials. But when Graham Fuller retired from the Central Intelligence Agency, leaving his post as national intelligence officer for the Near East and South Asia, his first publication had nothing to do with cloaks, daggers or nasty deeds in back alleys.

title: Virgil D. Hawkins; Broke Color Barrier To Become Lawyer
description: Virgil D. Hawkins, who waged a 28-year battle to practice law in Florida and helped break the color barrier at the University of Florida Law School, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: PARAGUAYAN WINS HIS EIGHTH TERM
description: The Government announced today that Gen. Alfredo Stroessner had been overwhelmingly elected to an eighth presidential term, and the opposition charged the voting was marked by widespread fraud.

title: Washington Talk: The Executive Branch; Push for New U.S. Fees Has Touched Off Furor
description: Ever since stagecoaches clattered over the first American toll roads and cattle began grazing on public lands, the United States Government has tried to get those who benefit directly from Federal services to pay for them.

title: Bridge: Small, Specialized Concerns Filling a Void in Publishing
description: In the past two decades general publishers have shown diminished interest in publishing bridge books and thus opened a door for small, specialist houses that do not have general distribution.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 6 about a threatened cutoff of Federal aid to some college students misstated the circumstances of those at risk of losing such aid. The Department of Education said 53,000 students were at risk; all are eligible for grants of more than $100.

title: Mary S. Hays Marries Robert Stern in Florida
description: The marriage of Mary Susan Hays, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Karl Hays of Winter Haven, Fla., and the late Mr. Hays, to Robert Stern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Stern of Stamford, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., took place yesterday at the Ringling Museum of Art in Sarastoa, Fla. Rabbi Lewis Bogage and the Rev. Jim Marsh, a Southern Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Scandals Slow Tory Rebound in Canada
description: The improving political fortunes of Canada's ruling Progressive Conservative Party, which last year recorded some of the lowest public-opinion ratings ever for a Canadian Government, appear to have been set back by allegations of financial impropriety by members of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Cabinet, including Mr. Mulroney himself.

title: The Sick Are Under Siege and Need Rescuers; We're Growing Older
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: New Capital Gains Rule Raises Rates for Some
description: Taxpayers who cashed in their winnings from stocks or other investments last year face a bigger tax bite on their long-term profits.

title: Villagers in the Golan Heights Battle Israeli Police
description: Druse villagers in the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in 1967, battled the police today to protest Israeli rule over the area, as sporadic unrest continued in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: JANE CAROL ABRAMS WEDS JOHN CHALIF
description: The marriage of Janet Carol Abrams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Abrams of Huntington, W.Va., to John Lewis Chalif, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Chalif of New York and Garrison, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Vizcaya Museum in Miami. Justice Rosemary Barkett of the Supreme Court of Florida performed the ceremony.

title: Companies Match Gifts To Neediest
description: The members of the Finance Department of the Beauty Group of Avon Products, Inc. of Manhattan, sent $927 in contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Shuttle Defect Reported
description: An internal report being reviewed by the space agency recommends correcting problems with the heat-resistant material that protects the nozzles of the space shuttle's booster rocket before the next shuttle flight, scheduled for August.

title: Choices For Writers
description: SHOPPING for word-processing software? The choices are more numerous and more complicated than ever. It used to be simple to choose a package back when Wordstar was the only program available. Today there are dozens of programs on the market.

title: A Sneak Preview of Fall Designs
description: For two weeks, most major European designers have been presenting their new collections quietly in their showrooms in New York. There are no dazzling theatrical presentations with elaborate choreography and special effects, as there will be next month in the high-tech spaces in Milan's Fiera or the tents in the courtyard of the Louvre in Paris.

title: Music: Composers Orchestra and Kronos Quartet
description: THE American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon reminded us how much we in this country have to choose from and, in terms of quality, how precarious the choices can be. Sunday's program came in every size, shape and level of competence - from Matthias Kriesberg's complex and crowded ''Chronosymphonies'' to the unintentional Minimalism of Gordon Getty's ''Plump Jack.''

title: Treasury's Bill Auctions Set Today
description: The only Treasury auctions scheduled this week are today's sale of three-month and six-month bills.

title: Milky Way Is 'Warped', New Study Reveals
description: The disk-shaped Milky Way galaxy is not flat, but instead resembles a warped phonograph record and is adorned with a delicate scalloped edge, new observations show.

title: Missile Cuts Are Just a First Step
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1988
description: International A3-8, A22

title: Market Place; Investing Now For a Recession
description: BEFORE last week, Donald H. Straszheim, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, was predicting a period of uneven economic growth. But he now believes that a ''garden-variety recession'' will begin within the next 6 to 18 months, and he picks early 1989 as the likeliest starting point.

title: Bush Wins Poll in Puerto Rico
description: Puerto Rico Republicans today gave Vice President Bush overwhelming support in a straw poll boycotted and denounced as illegal by supporters of Senator Bob Dole.

title: Merrill Pollack, Editor, 63
description: Merrill Pollack, a sculptor, writer and former editor of The Saturday Evening Post, died Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Parkersburg, W.Va., after a short illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Grantsville. His family did not disclose the cause of death.

title: Man Sought in Fatal Stabbings
description: A man who raped his 12-year-old stepdaughter yesterday and then fatally stabbed his wife and his 19-year-old stepson in their Brooklyn apartment, was being sought early today, the police said.

title: Bartlett H. Hayes Jr., an Educator And Art Historian, Is Dead at 83
description: Bartlett H. Hayes Jr., an educator and art historian who was director for many years of the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., died of congestive heart failure on Sunday in Peterboro, N.H. He was 83 years old and had lived in Peterboro since 1985.

title: Simple Tests Developed To Diagnose Dyslexia
description: Neurologists and psychiatrists reported here today that about one-third of all children suffering from acute reading problems have brain abnormalities that can be diagnosed by simple drawing or tapping tests.

title: U.S. and Florida Fight Texas and California Over Citrus Shipments
description: State and Federal officials are fighting efforts by Texas and California to keep out Florida citrus fruit after the lifting of a Federal ban imposed to keep a plant disease from spreading.

title: Paradox of Reagan Budgets: Austere Talk vs. Record Debt
description: The paradoxes of President Reagan's budget policies have left a seven-year record that has puzzled some fiscal experts and upset liberal critics and conservative supporters alike.

title: Older People Aided by Gifts To Neediest
description: The plight of lonely older people is among the main concerns of donors responding to the 76th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Stage: 'Taming of Shrew'
description: WHAT makes Katherina, in ''The Taming of the Shrew'' tick? And what mutual chemistry ultimately unites her with Petruchio, her unflappable suitor who turns her into an obedient and loving spouse? Although these questions are not precisely addressed in a workmanlike new production of the Shakespeare play, directed by Julie Taymor, for Theater for a New Audience, at the Triplex Theater, Ms. Taymor's production at least presents both characters as more-or-less likable. They are intelligent combatants in a game of love in which both end up winners while the rest of the world watches mystified.

title: Walt Whitman Sings Anew, But Now With a Chinese Lilt
description: Her desk is small, a table really, its grainy rosewood polished by her palms, the frayed bindings of dictionaries, the tissue-thin paper she fills with tiny ideograms.

title: Careers; Employees, Benefits and Computers
description: TRADITIONALLY employees have relied on year-end reports from the company for timely information about their benefits and how some, like 401(k) savings plans, have grown through the year. Or a worker may visit or phone the company's benefits office for answers.

title: Bush Wins in Dixville Notch
description: Thirty-four registered voters in this mountain hamlet cast their ballots in the New Hampshire primary at midnight, six hours before voting booths open in the rest of the state, and gave Vice President Bush and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri winning votes. In the Republican field, Mr. Bush received 11 votes; Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, 6; Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, 5; former Gov. Pete du Pont of Delaware, 2; Alexander M. Haig Jr., 2, and Pat Robertson 1. Among Democrats, Mr. Gephardt received 4 votes and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, 3. No other Democrats received votes.

title: PATTERNS
description: Focus on Newcomers

title: China's Account of Riot in Tibet Is Disputed
description: The most senior Tibetan religious figure in China has disputed official assertions that Chinese policemen did not shoot at demonstrating monks during a riot in Lhasa last October.

title: C.I.A. Cover-Up?
description: Stamp collectors visiting the Smithsonian's National Philatelic Collection might suspect a Government cover-up after reading the description of the $1 Rush Lamp Stamp with Inverted Candleholder.

title: Cyprus to Hold Runoff Presidential Election
description: A runoff election is to be held next week between a conservative and a Communist-backed businessman to determine who will succeed President Spyros Kyprianou, who lost his bid for a third five-year term.

title: Bridge: 2 Careful Leopards Showed How to Disguise Their Spots
description: It was the prophet Jeremiah who asked, rhetorically, this question: ''Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?''

title: BORN TO SKI 'TO THE LIMIT'
description: FIFTY-ONE HUNDREDTHS of a second. The blink of an eye. The slip of a ski in the snow. Too much time in the air after soaring off a bump. Not crouched low enough in a glide.

title: Gotti's Brother Called Rising Star in Gambino Mob
description: Aided by nepotism and courtroom victories, Gene Gotti, a younger brother of John Gotti, is carving a niche for himself as an imposing figure in the Gambino organized-crime family, law-enforcement officials say.

title: Fryar Is Arrested
description: Irving Fryar, the New England Patriots' wide receiver, was arrested Sunday on weapons charges in Pemberton, N.J., after a state trooper found a loaded shotgun and handgun and a hunting knife in Fryar's car, the police said. Fryar, 25 years old, had been stopped for speeding. He was charged with four counts of illegal weapons possession and released on $100 bail. He also was issued a summons for driving with a suspended license. The police said the weapons were registered in Massachusetts. New Jersey law permits only police officers to carry loaded guns in their cars. Fryar was staying with his mother yesterday in Mount Holly, where he went to school, said a spokesman for the Patriots.

title: Nation's Biggest Banks Had Worst Year in 1987 Since the Depression
description: Not since the Depression of the 1930's did the nation's biggest banks perform as poorly as they did in 1987, a survey of their financial results indicates.

title: Robertson Comes Under Fire for Asserting That Cuba Holds Soviet Missiles
description: Pat Robertson's assertion that Soviet missiles are pointed at the United States from Cuba was emphatically denied by the White House today and denounced by his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Paper Mill to Be Watched Closely After a 3d Leak
description: State officials plan to remain at a strikebound International Paper Company mill indefinitely following a chlorine gas leak that sent seven workers to a hospital.

title: We Are Losing The War on Drugs
description: After a brief absence, illegal drugs are back in the news. Honduran Army officers are setting up drug operations in their country. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military leader of Panama, has been indicted in Florida for trafficking in drugs. The Attorney General of Colombia was murdered for his opposition to the Medellin drug cartel. Front page headlines announced that according to a Justice Department study, upward of three-quarters of the men arrested for serious crimes in 12 major cities had tested positive for drug use. In New York, a 17-year-old was arrested after an 8-day, 11-robbery spree in which he murdered 5 innocent people and wounded 6 others -all to support his crack habit.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I was told as a child that you can tell how far away a thunderstorm is by counting the seconds between a lightning flash and the sound of thunder. Is this correct? If it is, why? A. Counting can be used as a roughly accurate guide, said Tom Ross, a meteorologist at the National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C.

title: Depression: Studies Bring New Drugs And Insights
description: A NEW generation of drugs to treat depression is giving medical scientists a fresh view of the best strategies for coping with this severe and widespread mental disorder and important clues to its nature.

title: FROESE RETURNS TO WIN
description: All afternoon, there was something going on in front of Bob Froese. Rangers and Canadiens were swinging sticks, trading punches, exchanging insults.

title: U.S. Aide Calls Soviet 'Brutal'
description: Edward L. Rowny, special adviser to President Reagan on arms control, told a meeting of American scientists today that the Soviet Union was ''squandering time'' in its current disarmament negotiations with the United States and ''remains a brutal adversary.''

title: Syracuse Player Quits
description: Keith Hughes, a 6-foot-7-inch sophomore forward from Carteret, N.J., has quit the Syracuse basketball team and left school, according to Syracuse officials. Hughes sat out five of Syracuse's last six games after averaging 16 minutes a game during the Orangemen's first 17 contests. He was averaging 5.4 points and 2.7 rebounds per game.

title: Foreign Stocks Rise Slightly
description: Stocks edged higher in most overseas markets today. The financial markets in the United States were closed to observe Washington's Birthday.

title: Britons Buy U.S. Book Publisher
description: Pearson P.L.C., the British conglomerate that owns The Financial Times, announced today that it had agreed to buy the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company for $283 million.

title: Hippocratic Oath
description: To the Editor:

title: At School, Cabbies Learn Courtesy and How to Find S.I.
description: Paul Schlichtman gazed at the 25 prospective taxicab drivers in a classroom in midtown Manhattan and opened the floor to questions. The drivers appeared suspicious. ''O.K., suppose you pick up a passenger,'' one said, finally, ''and he dies in the car?'' (''Call the morgue,'' said Mr. Schlichtman.) ''While you're looking at your map before the trip,'' asked another, ''can you turn the meter on?'' (''Not usually,'' answered Mr. Schlichtman.) It was the first day of a session at the New York City school for taxicab drivers, the New York City Taxi Driver Institute. The course has been required since 1984, after the Taxi and Limousine Commission had found that in an industry with a very high turnover many new drivers did not know what they were doing. #30,000 Graduates Mr. Schlichtman, a former taxicab driver, was the instructor.

title: Packers Draw Fire
description: By not naming a black as their new head coach to replace Forrest Gregg, and by including only one black among their new assistant coaches, the Green Bay Packers have drawn criticism from the Milwaukee branch of the N.A.A.C.P. ''We are dismayed and disappointed that the organization has not displayed any active approach to implementing affirmative action proposals, hiring qualified management personnel, reinvesting in the minority community or utilizing minority businesses, professionals or service-oriented,'' said Felmers D. Chaney, the president of the Milwaukee chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People at a news conference in Milwaukee yesterday. The team has retained Willie Peete, a black assistant coach under Gregg, who is now head coach at Southern Methodist. The new head coach, Lindy Infante, has hired Greg Blache, who is black, as one of the new assistant head coaches. ''The Green Bay Packers have made some significant strides in the last year as far as minority hiring is concerned,'' Robert Parins, the team's president, said in response to Chaney's remarks.

title: The Political Clean Air Act of 1988
description: The smell of pervasive privilege and manipulation rises over Washington as one influence-peddling conviction follows another. In the next day or two, there'll be a chance to do something about it -if Senate Republicans will finally abandon their adamant opposition.

title: 2 Officers Shot By Robber With Hostage
description: Two police officers responding to a report of a robbery were wounded on the Upper West Side yesterday afternoon when a gunman holding a hostage forced the officers into an elevator and opened fire, the authorities said.

title: A Mockery of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Traders Show Uncertainty
description: The bond market rally ran out of steam last week as more signs emerged that the economy was not as weak as some expected and that the Federal Reserve was not trying to push short-term rates lower.

title: Unions and The Post Hold Tense Talks
description: The New York Post and its unions yesterday held tense talks on ways for the newspaper to save $24 million over the next three years, but agreed only to meet around the clock starting tomorrow in a last effort to avert a shutdown of the paper on Friday.

title: Our Towns; From Meat Truck To Pulsing Stages Of Rock-and-Roll
description: When Ed Feldt's daughter Veronica announced she wanted to be a rock-and-roll star, Mr. Feldt had strong feelings. Veronica already had a good job driving a wholesale meat truck. Mr. Feldt, a meat man himself, had broken her in and helped her build her own route. She loved driving so much that she had taken a double course load at Smithtown High School West to graduate early and start on the truck. ''I had it planned at 13,'' Veronica said. ''I told my guidance counselor - she was a real libber. She said, 'Great!' ''

title: Stage: U.S. Dramas In London
description: Even as the English stand accused of hijacking the modern Broadway musical, they have mounted a sneak attack on the vintage American drama. Last year's shattering National Theater production of Arthur Miller's ''View From the Bridge,'' as acted by Michael Gambon and directed by Alan Ayckbourn, was no fluke. Just as ''Bridge'' prepared to end its sold-out West End run Feb. 20, it was joined by major and revelatory new productions of Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' at the National and Eugene O'Neill's ''Touch of the Poet'' at the Young Vic. All three plays occupy second-best positions in their authors' canons, but to see them in tandem -with actors like Mr. Gambon, Ian Charleson, Vanessa Redgrave and Timothy Dalton - is to remember that our classic theater boasts a depth and continuity that our scattered diet of New York revivals rarely allows us to savor.

title: Texas Town Awaits Navy With Hope and a Case of Nerves
description: Extraordinary changes are facing this town, with its empty houses and idle plants, when the Navy breaks ground this week for a $140 million home port for the battleship Wisconsin.

title: YESTERDAY'S MEDAL WINNERS
description: Alpine Skiing Men's Downhill Gold: Pirmin Zurbriggen, Switzerland Silver: Peter Meuller, Switzerland Bronze: Franck Piccard, France Cross- Country Men's 30 km Gold: Aleksei Prokourorov, Soviet Union Silver: Vladimir Smirnov, Soviet Union Bronze: Vegard Ulvang, Norway Luge Men's Singles Gold: Jens Meuller, East Germany Silver: Georg Hackl, West Germany Bronze: Iouri Khartchenko, Soviet Union Totals: Soviet Union - 2 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze; Finland - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Switzerland - 1 gold, 1 silver; East Germany - 2 gold; West Germany 1 silver; the Netherlands - 1 silver; France - 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Norway - 1 bronze.

title: Translation of Ancient Tao Text Brings $130,000
description: After a spirited auction involving eight publishers, Harper & Row has agreed to pay $130,000 for a new translation of a Chinese book of philosophy and religion written more than 2,000 years ago. The amount is one of the highest ever paid to a translator, and it is certainly the most for a work in the public domain that has already been translated into English dozens of times.

title: Sex and the O.E.C.D.
description: The Washington office of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the 24-member forum of industrialized countries that is based in Paris, has received a bit of a surprise in the mail from the District of Columbia's Zoning Division.

title: A Book That Grew Up
description: BACK in 1974, what has been called the first cult computer book was published.

title: KNICKS ROAR BACK ON JACKSON SCORING
description: Trent Tucker played only 12 minutes and scored 2 points last night. But he explained better than most could how the Knicks defeated the Nets, 97-96, to run their Madison Square Garden winning streak to eight games, the longest since the 1983-84 season.

title: Actress's Complaint Negotiated
description: Lincoln Center Theater and the Actors' Equity Association are negotiating a settlement in a dispute between the director of ''Sarafina!'' and an American actress who joined the Broadway cast.

title: Stage: Buscemi and Boone
description: STEVE BUSCEMI and Mark Boone Jr., two performance artists and writers who have been working together for the last five years, make ideal comic foils. Skinny and quiveringly sensitive with eyes so expressive that they seem to bulge out of their sockets, Mr. Buscemi is a thin-skinned ectomorph continually menaced by Mr. Boone's roly-poly endomorph. In their best performance pieces, the two ritualistically parody male power struggles as an ongoing clash between these opposite, mutually suspicious types.

title: Holmes a Court Reports $750 Million Loss in Stock Plunge
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian investor, said today that his Bell Group conglomerate had lost more than $750 million in the October stock market collapse, more than experts had estimated.

title: Tackling the Taj Mahal
description: The National Park Service is going international. It has agreed to help India develop the Taj Mahal as a national cultural park.

title: Recent Setbacks Stirring Doubts About Search for AIDS Vaccine
description: Bleak results from recent experiments indicate that the quest for a vaccine against AIDS will be even more difficult than many experts had imagined. The results also raise the possibility that current lines of vaccine research may be fruitless.

title: BUSH IN STRUGGLE WITH SURGING DOLE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: The New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign, characterized by dazzling shifts in voter loyalties, ended today with personal invective, muddled forecasts and advice to Republicans from a venerable conservative hero.

title: With Halley's Help, Sun's Size Is Found to Be Constant
description: IT was the era of a peculiar and now-vanishing species, the English gentleman scientist.

title: A Treaty's Words Stand on Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis Over Dropouts: A Look at Two Youths
description: James Diggs and Anthony Colon come from troubled and impoverished families, from neighborhoods where drugs offer the constant temptation of escape and quick money, and both have poor academic skills. It is easier to find the similarities in their lives than the differences that led James to return to school and Anthony to remain a dropout.

title: Coach's Controversial Tactics Divide U.S. Speed Skaters
description: The United States speed-skating team, which was expected to produce the most American medals in the XV Olympic Winter Games, is in disarray.

title: Blast Disables P.L.O.'s 'Exodus' Ferry in Port
description: An explosion today crippled a ferry that was expected to carry Palestinian deportees on a symbolic voyage to Israel, port officials and the Palestine Liberation Organization said.

title: Europe Talks: Pragmatism and Fury
description: Facing the press in Brussels at 2 A.M. on Saturday, an exhausted-looking Margaret Thatcher permitted herself the kind of nationalistic outburst that is supposed to have gone out of fashion since the members of the European Community vowed to tighten their political and economic links.

title: TV Review; 'Frontline' Looks at Flight Problems
description: WHY is your flight delayed or canceled, and why is an airport so often a mess? ''Frontline'' provides some reasonable answers tonight: too many planes in too little airspace, a surfeit of passengers and not enough technology to control things. The PBS documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M. and Channel 49 at 9 P.M., is imaginatively and intelligently done.

title: Science Can't Keep Up With Flood of New Journals
description: THE number of scientific articles and journals being published around the world has grown so large that it is starting to confuse researchers, overwhelm the quality-control systems of science, encourage fraud and distort the dissemination of important findings.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council

title: INSIDE
description: For-Profit Radio in Africa

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Intermark Head Hunts For Midsize Companies
description: LEAD: Charles R. Scott, the president and chief executive of Intermark Inc., buys midsize companies through friendly acquisitions, gives their managements a stake and capital with the freedom to spend it, then sells some or all the stock for a big profit.

title: A Serious Scrape, but Still a Scrape
description: When Soviet frigates bump U.S. warships, they set off public alarm. Yet if Friday's incident in the Black Sea is unsettling, it is also predictable, one episode in a longtime policy disagreement. More, it's manageable, a small piece of a complex relationship.

title: Three Candidates in 2 Parties Bracing for the Battle of Their Political Lives; George Bush: The Vice President Tries to Cope With a Troubled Campaign
description: Vice President Bush smiled and smiled as Barry Goldwater, once Mr. Republican, endorsed him and said Mr. Bush was a better leader than his chief rival, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.

title: Reagan Budget Proposes Increase In U.S.-Subsidized Housing Units
description: As part of an effort to accommodate the homeless, President Reagan proposes adding 135,500 units to the nation's pool of Government-subsidized housing, a White House official said today.

title: Georgetown Edges Villanova
description: Charles Smith scored 17 of his 22 points in the second half tonight to lead Georgetown to its third straight Big East Conference victory, a 56-54 triumph over Villanova.

title: Family's Autopsy Finds Evidence of Beating
description: The family of a Brooklyn man, who died of an apparent heart attack in an ambulance while in police custody Jan. 30, says a private autopsy shows he suffered injuries consistent with a beating.

title: Austin Briggs-Hall, 73, Actor and a Historian
description: Austin Briggs-Hall, an actor who was a founder of the American Negro Theater and an authority on African history, died of heart failure Jan. 13 in Kings County Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Tyson Sets Up Fund
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, announced yesterday that he was contributing $50,000 to help form a foundation to aid young victims of violent incidents. On Saturday, Tyson said he, his wife, the actress Robin Givens, and the promoter Don King visited Tawana Brawley, the student from Wappinger Falls, N.Y., who was the victim of a purported racial attack. Brawley, Tyson said, would be the first recipient of an award from the as-yet-unnamed foundation. ''It will be for her education,'' said Tyson. ''Whatever school she wants to go to.''
