Tyson said that events involving athletes and entertainment-world figures would be staged to raise funds for the foundation. ''And perhaps,'' he said, ''I'll fight exhibitions.'' Tyson said aid would be given to victims from all races. ''If you're hurt,'' said Tyson, ''black, white, green or blue, the feeling is the same.'' Tyson said King would be working with him to organize the foundation. King said he was contributing $50,000 of his own to the charity. Tyson is scheduled to leave today for Tokyo, where he will fight Tony Tubbs on March 21.

title: Music: Feltsman Plays At Philharmonic Benefit
description: IT has been a long time since musicians competed against other musicians in the Olympics. And a good thing, too. The Greeks, who were wise in many ways, probably went wrong in putting musical performance in the same category as discus throwing. It is a waste of time to try to rank artists, grading them as if they were prime, choice or utility cuts of athletic meat. So, to say that Vladimir Feltsman should not be burdened with the title of the world's greatest pianist, is simply to protest against such naive and misleading labeling. He deserves to be heard and appreciated for who he is and what he does, no more, no less.

title: Close Sweatshops but Don't Restore Homework
description: To the Editor:

title: Hockey Notebook; League Leader Has Not Emerged
description: The league champion has been decided in three of the four Division I leagues. In the fourth, the E.C.A.C., the race will continue until the final game between Harvard and St. Lawrence on Feb. 27.

title: Israel Detains 2 In Burial Alive Of Palestinians
description: The Israeli Army said today that it had opened an investigation into reports that its troops had buried four young Palestinians alive. It said that it had detained two soldiers and that it expected to detain others.

title: Murky Danger: L.I. Brown Tide Thrives
description: The frigid winter waters off Simons Point, a flicker of land in Flanders Bay, are not particularly friendly to marine life. Scientists, though, have found one tiny organism thriving unexpectedly: the algae that make up the ''brown tide.''

title: Ethics and Abortion of Multiple Fetuses
description: To the Editor:

title: With So Much Known, Exploration Evolves
description: WHEN dreams drifted off to the Indies and Antipodes, when the source of the Nile beckoned from beyond every cataract, no one entertained any doubt about the meaning of exploration. To explore was to follow human curiosity to the ends of the earth. To explore - the word, in one version of its etymology, comes from the Latin to cry out - was to search out and exclaim discovery.

title: Advertising; Meredith's Conservative Approach
description: WHEN Jack Rehm was named president of the Meredith Corporation recently, many in the publishing industry thought that the 55-year-old executive was ideal for the job. He has been at Meredith for 26 years, nearly all his professional life, and if there is such a thing as the quintessential Meredith man, Mr. Rehm is it.

title: Federated Seeks Offers From Suitors
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating with several parties, including the Campeau Corporation, that are interested in buying all or part of it.

title: Lehman Routs York, 87-62
description: Lehman, the defending champion, trounced York, 87-62, last night as the 23d annual City University of New York tournament began.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CRI Inc., Rockville, Md., a worldwide financial services and investment company, appointed Yvonne S. Distenfeld senior vice president, general counsel.

title: By Design; Fashion Fallacies
description: Some undeniably chic fashions are also expected to be functional. But let's face it: they often aren't. Take jump suits. Forever being touted as the most contemporary, streamlined attire, they are, in fact, often a hindrance. Just try dealing with one in a jumbo jet's minuscule bathroom. Also, since a jump suit is cut in one piece, unless it is fitted perfectly, it tends to ride up. For airline travel, jersey pants and a tunic or sweater might be better choices.

title: OF GEEPS AND BAA-BAAS
description: LEAD: My 18-month-old son Nathaniel loves sheep, but he cannot say ''sheep.'' He also loves goats, but he cannot say ''goat.''

title: Fair Share for City Schools
description: More than a third of New York State's public-school children live in New York City. Yet the city receives less than a third of state aid to local schools. Fairness and necessity cry out for the gap to be closed.

title: Sell the Post Office? Lease the Capitol Next
description: To the Editor:

title: Latest Japanese Import Goes on Patrol
description: Some people mistake Officer Wayne Sato's koban for an instant photo-processing booth. At Officer Herman Jones's koban, tourists try to buy tickets for a cable car ride.

title: Unknown Spanish Bird
description: The fossil of a small bird has brought to light a previously unknown branch of the family tree of birds, paleontologists report.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dresser-Rand Selects A Chief Executive
description: LEAD: William E. Bradford was named on Friday as the president and chief executive of the Dresser-Rand Company of Corning, N.Y., which manufactures industrial compressors.

title: The Long Fortnight of George Bush
description: Harold Wilson, the former British Prime Minister, used to say that two weeks is a lifetime in politics. He might have been talking about George Bush.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer programming error in the tabulation of a New York Times/CBS News Poll on the Iowa caucuses, a news analysis on Feb. 10 incorrectly stated the percentages of Republican voters who listed ''moral values'' as a central concern. Sixty-eight percent of Pat Robertson's backers did so, not 70, and so did 19 percent of other Republicans, not 18. The analysis also misstated the support of President Reagan among Mr. Robertson's voters; they approved of him by a margin of about 3 to 1, not 2 to 1. In addition, the programming mistake induced numerous errors of one to eight percentage points in a table showing the characteristics of supporters of various candidates. A corrected table appears today on page B7.

title: Doctor vs. Doctor
description: The doctor at the dinner party, a surgeon of renown, was in a state of controlled irritation about all the attention being paid to AIDS.

title: Advertising; Scali, McCabe Awarded Greek Tourist Account
description: After a 10-way review, the Greek National Tourist Organization has tapped Scali, McCabe Sloves, a unit of the Ogilvy Group, as its new agency. The budget is $2 million. The review, which began at the end of last year, came down to five finalists, including the former agency, Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, which was behind the ''I'm Going Back to Greece'' campaign, featuring 35 celebrities.

title: Italian Begins Bid in Belgium
description: Carlo De Benedetti, the Italian financier, formally began his bid today to take control of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company. But the company's shares climbed well above the offering price.

title: Taxi Test: Where's Columbia?
description: Following are some questions from the New York City Taxi Driver Institute test. They were taken from the student workbook used in the course. 1. It's a slow summer night in New York and you haven't had many fares. Two men hail your taxi in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal and tell you they need to be at Kennedy Airport in 30 minutes. You realize that it is almost impossible to make the trip that fast. What do you do? (a) You tell the men, ''No problem, I'll get you there on time.'' (b) You tell the men that the trip usually takes 45 minutes, and to make it in 30 minutes is almost impossible. (c) You tell the men that you can get to Newark Airport in less than 30 minutes, and offer to take them there instead. (d) You offer to drive down the highway at 80 miles an hour, but only if they give you a $25 tip. 2. You stop for a passenger on 72d Street and Park Avenue. A middle-age man enters your taxi. He says very loudly: ''55th and Sutton Place. Turn off that stupid radio. I hate listening to that garbage!'' (a) You explain that it is your radio and you refuse to turn it off. (b) You turn off the radio and complain, ''You don't have to shout.

title: A Trimmer Bethlehem Is Breathing Easier
description: In a dimly lit control room overlooking the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's rolling mill here, Joseph L. Voye pointed proudly to the bright computer screens, whose colorful charts and graphs detailed the thickness, smoothness and temperature of the steel sheets being molded below.

title: Banker Seen as a Contender For Vacancy on Fed Board
description: Wendell Wilkie Gunn, a banking consultant and a former special assistant to President Reagan, is a leading candidate to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Three Candidates in 2 Parties Bracing for the Battle of Their Political Lives; Paul Simon: The Illinois Senator Pins His Hopes on Finishing Second
description: After a week that would have tested any candidate, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois took a serene leap of faith today over polls and pundits, and landed on the side of optimism.

title: For-Profit Radio in Gabon Offers Snapshot of Africa
description: The young man in wraparound sunglasses leaned toward a sponge ball microphone and intoned: ''Bonjour Afrique - bonjour africains.''

title: G.M. Eases Dealer Policy
description: The General Motors Corporation is easing its long-held opposition to publicly traded automobile dealers, a key executive said today. The development could spur stock offerings by some of the large multifranchise dealers that are beginning to dominate the retail car market.

title: Audience Has Found 'Sarafina!'
description: The line Saturday began forming outside the Cort Theater just before the box office opened for the matinee. It was sunny but cold, below freezing, with the wind gusting across 48th street making it feel like the mercury was stuck at zero.

title: Opera: Mascagni's Rare 'Iris' by Jersey Troupe
description: Usually, it is nothing more than a nostalgic pastime, but occasionally a peek through the attic yields some forgotten heirloom. Mascagni's ''Iris'' may not quite be the priceless gem one dreams of finding tucked away among the dusty boxes of old and forgotten musical scores, but it is a far more satisfying discovery than most of the curios unearthed during recent years by operatic scavengers.

title: McReynolds, Mets Settle at $975,000
description: Kevin McReynolds, who had a good chance to become only the second three-time loser in baseball salary arbitration, capitulated yesterday in his bid for a $1,150,000 salary by accepting the Mets' new offer of $975,000.

title: If Willis Gets $5 Million, How Much for Redford?
description: 20th Century-Fox has paid Bruce Willis $5 million to star in a movie. For Hollywood, the result is equivalent to an earthquake. The map of movie-star salaries must now be redrawn.

title: Bid for Belgian Insurer
description: Belgium's largest insurer, Groupe AG S.A., said today that it had raised its offer for a rival insurer, Assubel-Vie S.A. by 20 percent, to about $205.71 a share. Groupe AG announced the new bid, its second for Assubel-Vie, to offset a counter-offer for Assubel-Vie's stock by a group of investors backed by Assubel-Vie. The new bid, which values Assubel-Vie at about $257 million, will be started Tuesday and run through the end of the month, Groupe AG said in a statement.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transcription error, a dance review yesterday of the appearance of two Bolshoi Ballet dancers with the New York City Ballet misstated a characterization of their performance on Saturday afternoon.

title: Cordiality and Racial Anger Mix in Massachusetts U. Protest
description: When the minority students occupying a University of Massachusetts building here discovered that the brother of the chancellor was ill, they sent the chancellor a card this morning expressing their best wishes.

title: Music: Elodie Lauten
description: ELODIE LAUTEN, a composer and keyboardist, brought her homemade amplified lyre, the cellist Arthur Russell, some prerecorded tapes and gallons of pretension to her show at La Galleria at La Mama on Saturday. Standing with her ''trine,'' as she calls the instrument, head back as if in artistic ecstasy, with Mr. Russell dutifully sawing away at his cello next to her, she seemed like a National Lampoon parody of avant-garde art.

title: New Studies Link Exercise to Delays In Menstruation - and Less Cancer
description: EXERCISING hard may delay the onset of menstruation, but it does not affect the ability to have children later and it reduces susceptibility to cancers of the breast and reproductive system, new studies show.

title: Report Lists Threats at National Parks
description: From gypsy moths in the Shenandoah to wild pigs in the Great Smokies to creeping kudzu in the West, an invasion of exotic animal and plant species is threating the nation's national parks.

title: Upbeat 'Head Hunter' for a Lame Duck President
description: As Administration veterans return to private life in the twilight of the Reagan years, the task of recruiting fresh replacements for a lame duck Presidency has fallen upon Robert H. Tuttle, the White House personnel director.

title: 76ers Will Retire No. 6
description: The Philadelphia 76ers said yesterday they would retire Julius Erving's number before an April 19 game against the Milwaukee Bucks. Wearing the number 6, Erving scored 18,364 points with the 76ers over 11 seasons before he retired at the end of last season. ''If there was ever an athlete, or a man, deserving of this honor, it's certainly Julius Erving,'' said the 76ers' owner, Harold Katz.

title: Chevron Buys PPG Unit
description: PPG Industries said Friday it had agreed to sell its commercial biochemical business to the Chevron Chemical Company, a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Three Candidates in 2 Parties Bracing for the Battle of Their Political Lives; Jack F. Kemp: The Congressman Has to Finish Third to Remain Credible
description: In shopping malls and burger joints, a bowling alley and a general store, Jack F. Kemp passed the dwindling hours of the New Hampshire campaign fighting for his political life.

title: Nuclear Carrier Launched
description: The $2.7 billion nuclear aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln was christened and launched here Saturday. The 1,092-foot ship is the Navy's fifth Nimitz class nuclear-powered carrier. All have been built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, where a sixth Nimitz carrier, the George Washington, is scheduled for completion in 1991.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You can judge for yourselves whether your President is the young lieutenant - or even the distorted picture of this officer of the Wehrmacht - or whether your President is a man who, for decades of his life, worked for justice, tolerance and peace. I ask you to form your own judgment.'' - Kurt Waldheim. [ A6:3. ]

title: City Ballet: La Fosse As Frantz in 'Coppelia'
description: IN the earliest versions of ''Coppelia,'' the role of Frantz, the young male lead, was danced by a woman in men's clothes. Swanilda, the pertly willful young heroine, was the center of the ballet despite the dramatic potential inherent in the character of Coppelius, the mad old toymaker who mistakes Swanilda for a suddenly living doll. The focus is very much on Swanilda in the New York City Ballet's happy, breezy production of the 1870 French ballet, choreographed by George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova to the traditional score by Leo Delibes. But the balance shifted on Sunday night, when City Ballet performed ''Coppelia'' at the New York State Theater. For Robert La Fosse, new in the role of Frantz this season, created such a sunny and ebulliently charming character and danced with such daring and exactitude that he filled the stage whenever he was on it.

title: Infected Boy Shows Signs of AIDS
description: One of three brothers who were banned from school because they were infected with the AIDS virus has developed AIDS-related complex, but his doctor says he can remain active.

title: TV SPORTS: SHARING A CLOSE-UB ON GRIEF
description: VIEWERS in 18 million homes shared a family tragedy Sunday. What set it apart from the gratuitous violence often seen on television was that it involved an American Olympian and became the major theme of Sunday night's ABC telecast of the Winter Games.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1988
description: COMPANIES Pearson agreed to buy Addison-Wesley for $105 a share, or $283 million. Pearson, which owns The Financial Times, Madame Tussaud's wax museum and other properties, will become an international force in book publishing with this deal. [ Page D1. ] Federated Department Stores said it was negotiating with several parties that are interested in buying all or part of it. In addition, Campeau plans to raise its bid to $65 a share. [ D1. ] I.B.M. introduced an improved operating system for its mainframe computers. [ D2. ] 1987 proved the worst year for the nation's biggest banks since the Depression, a survey of their financial results indicates. [ D5. ] Sales of American-made cars and light trucks rose 2.8 percent in early February. [ D8. ] G.M. is easing its long-held opposition to publicly traded automobile dealers, a key executive said. [ D2. ] Robert Holmes a Court said his Bell Group conglomerate lost more than $750 million in October's stock plunge. [ D2. ] Olympia & York said it would buy up to 14 million additional Santa Fe shares, or 9.1 percent, for $17.50 each. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan's trade surplus with the U.S. fell to its lowest level in two years, $2.97 billion, in January. Japan's overall trade surplus fell for the ninth consecutive month on a year-to-year basis. [ D1. ] The loss of confidence in the peso has brought a ''dollarization'' of Mexico's economy. [ D7. ] The dollar fell and gold prices rose in Europe, where trading was quiet because of holidays in West Germany and the U.S. [ D7. ] THE ECONOMY The paradoxes of President Reagan's budget policies have upset both critics and supporters. Fiscal experts fear that the huge debts incurred during the Reagan years will afflict the nation into the next century. [ A1. ] A top candidate for the Federal Reserve Board's vacant seat is Wendell Wilkie Gunn, a former special assistant to President Reagan, Administration and Congressional officials said. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Real estate vacancies are likely to rise in New York City, while declining elsewhere, an expert predicts. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Bond traders remain uncertain over the economy and the Fed's stance on short-term interest rates. Credit Markets. [ D13. ] The possibility of a recession means that investors should prepare to alter the balance of their portfolios. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: Koch Says Agreement on Pensions Will Cause Severe Cuts in Services
description: Mayor Koch says the compromise agreement on pensions for municipal workers will force the city to make cuts in essential services. But whether those cuts will occur, or occur with the severity the Mayor has forecast, is, to a certain extent, unpredictable.

title: No Headline
description: President Mauno Koivisto was re-elected to a second six-year term today, winning a second-round victory in the electoral college.

title: Just a TV Evangelist
description: John Glenn, the astronaut, earned his political credentials as a Senator from Ohio before his try for the Presidency in 1984. Jack Kemp, the quarterback, paid his political dues as a member of the House from New York before offering himself for the Republican Presidential nomination this year.

title: MUELLER GLIDES TO GOLD IN LUGE
description: Jens Mueller of East Germany rode his luge down the 4,104-foot course at Canada Olympic Park in 46.367 seconds yesterday in the fourth and final heat for a two-day total of 3 minutes 5.548 seconds, nearly four-tenths of a second faster than Georg Hackl of West Germany at 3:05.916.

title: Russians Claim Computer Knowledge
description: Senior Soviet scientists asserted today that they have no need to steal computer secrets for military applications because the level of computer science in their country is already high.

title: On Trade: Wrong, Long Arm of the Law
description: The Senate voted stiff penalties last spring against Toshiba Corporation of Japan and Kongsberg Vaapenfabrik of Norway for selling advanced submarine technology to Moscow. The Senate's anger was just. Its remedy is wrong. Senate and House conferees, who today start negotiating the final trade bill, would do well to let this part die.

title: Tendency to Get Ear Infections Is Inherited, New Study Shows
description: MIDDLE-EAR infections, which plague millions of young children, are an inherited trait and have nothing to do with environment or access to medical care, a new study indicates.

title: NO END TO ORDEAL FOR A PARAGUAYAN
description: Two months after completing a 25-year jail sentence, Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner remains under house arrest, with armed policemen stationed at his front gate to prevent him from receiving visitors.

title: Georgia Tech Closes Its Reactor, Citing Continued Safety Concerns
description: The Georgia Institute of Technology shut down its nuclear reactor today and the school's president said it would remain idle at least until safety concerns were resolved and, indeed, might never be restarted.

title: A SPECIAL SCHOOL OPENS IN CHICAGO
description: South Loop Elementary School opened its doors today to 335 youngsters from a range of racial and economic backgrounds after two years of disputes over the makeup of its student body.

title: Sales of U.S. Vehicles Rose 2.8% for Feb. 1-10
description: Early-February sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 2.8 percent from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ANTHILLS OF THE SAVANNAH. By Chinua Achebe. 216 pages. Anchor Press/Doubleday. $16.95.

title: Washington's Words Echo Through Senate
description: Senator Terry Sanford of North Carolina gave the traditional reading of George Washington's farewell address to a nearly empty Senate chamber today.

title: Sensory Stimulation Helps Rats Stay Smart
description: Rats given additional sensory stimulation in infancy were able to think and learn better in their old age, according to a group of researchers studying the effects of aging on the brain.

title: MINNESOTA STORM CLOSES HIGHWAYS
description: Hundreds of snowbound motorists spent the night in their cars, on farms and in National Guard armories as a blizzard clogged major roads for nearly 24 hours in southwestern Minnesota, the authorities said today.

title: Martin K. Speckter, 73, Creator of Interrobang
description: Martin K. Speckter, a retired advertising executive known to lexicographers as the creator of the interrobang, a punctuation mark used to convey disbelief, died of bone cancer Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Winter Repairs Bolstering L.I. Parks
description: On a typical winter day, gulls outnumber the hardy visitors who brave icy Atlantic winds to walk here at Jones Beach.

title: Pirelli Is Silent On Firestone
description: Several Italian newspapers said over the weekend that Pirelli S.p.A. was negotiating to acquire the tire division of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for $1 billion. But Pirelli, the world's fifth-largest tire maker with sales of $3.65 billion last year, declined today to confirm or deny the reports. Pirelli's managing director, Jacopo Vittorelli, said through a spokesman that the Milan-based company ''always has contacts with big and small competitors, but in this specific case we can't confirm the substance of the reports.''

title: Talking Business with Mirante of Cushman & Wakefield; Commercial Side Of Real Estate
description: Commercial real estate, a business ordinarily fraught with uncertainties, now seems even more risky. In New York, the collapse of the stock market on Oct. 19 has increased vacancies, lowered rents and raised fears of a local real estate recession. Elsewhere, a rapid pace of building from 1980 to 1985 has created cases of oversupply, particularly in the Southwest, where entire buildings remain empty.

title: FATAL CAR FIRE NEAR 10 DOWNING
description: A car burst into flames early this morning at the entrance to Downing Street where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher lives, killing an unidentified man who was in the car, the police said.

title: Olympia & York Adding To Its Stake in Santa Fe
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the big Canadian real estate company, announced yesterday that it would pay $17.50 a share for up to 14 million additional shares, or 9.1 percent, of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

title: Concert: Ukrainian Choral Music
description: IT is not every day that one celebrates an important millennium. It was in A.D. 988 that the Ukrainians formally accepted the church into their lives, and this 1,000 years of Christianity was marked by a festive, grandly scaled evening of music at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday. A big mixed chorus from Georgia - the Choral Guild of Atlanta - sang; members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra played, and there were five singers from the international opera scene. William Noll conducted. It was an evening of Ukrainian music given (mostly) by Ukrainian performers. Five composers were represented, but this program wisely centered its time on two of them. Although Mykola Lysenko and Dmytro Bortniansky wrote in vastly different styles, both created powerful music. In the two Sacred Choral Concertos and the operatic excerpts from ''Le Faucon,'' Bortniansky spoke a Mozartean language that was rich, poised and highly sophisticated. Concert programmers looking for fresh repertory would do well to re-explore his music.

title: Forty Niner Shows His Determination
description: Forty Niner and Notebook slugged it out for the length of the stretch at Gulfstream Park today before Forty Niner thrust out his nose at the wire to score the most courageous and important victory of his career.

title: Savings Unit Breakup Off
description: Federal regulators are unlikely to pursue a plan to break up the savings and loan branch network of the Financial Corporation of America because of tax complications, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: I.B.M.'s New System For Huge Computers
description: Seeking to outmaneuver several Japanese competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation introduced an improved operating system for its largest computers yesterday. It said the system would be provided without charge to current owners of its most advanced mainframes.

title: Swiss 8Skiers Are 1st and 2d In Downhill
description: Only 13 minutes passed, but it felt like forever for a pair of Swiss skiing teammates and bitter rivals at opposite ends of the downhill course. Peter Mueller stood impassively at the bottom of Mount Allan, having charged down the hill, the reluctant rabbit, establishing the standard the others would have to beat. At the top, Pirmin Zurbriggen anxiously waited for his turn at the Olympic gold medal.

title: Margaret Parker Isaac, Art Gallery Manager
description: Margaret Parker Isaac, the manager of the Fourcade Gallery in Manhattan for 14 years until last October, died in an automobile accident on Dec. 19, just outside of Winchester, Va. She was 35 years old. Her 14 month-old daughter, Marina, survived the crash unharmed.

title: commercial Tenants Offered Equity Stakes
description: Major real estate developers, facing wary lenders and intensifying competition for prime tenants, are giving away the store.

title: Tax Shelters Hit Hard By New Filing Rules
description: Real estate and tax shelter investors will soon see close up the heavy toll that the new tax law inflicted on their investments, be it an oceanfront vacation home rental on Long Island or an oil-drilling partnership in Texas.

title: A Helpful Oncogene
description: A GREAT deal of research has focused on oncogenes and the changes in their DNA that makes them either dangerous or useful, but now a scientist has discovered a potentially important property of the much studied oncogene called ras. When activated in cells growing in laboratory cultures, ras makes those cells resistant to radiation.

title: Theater: 'Crystal Night'
description: THERE are laughs sprinkled through John Herman Shaner's ''After Crystal Night,'' but the play is not funny. Essentially it is a long harangue spoken in nine voices about the necessity of Jews' becoming aggressive, even violent, in the battle against anti-Semitism. In the production at the New Federal Theater the cast members make the most of the humor in the play, but the message overwhelms them. Often it seems the characters are just fooling around until the time comes for the next big, angry set speech.

title: Turbine on Jetliner Shatters, But No Injuries Are Reported
description: A turbine blade from an Eastern Air Lines A-300 Airbus shattered on takeoff today and started a brush fire just outside the airport, but the twin-engine plane returned safely and no one was injured, officials said.

title: Tugboat Workers Begin Strike
description: The union representing 2,500 tugboatmen and barge workers in New York Harbor struck nine towing companies at 12:01 A.M. this morning following a breakdown of negotiations yesterday.

title: Algeciras Journal; Many Fish in Morocco's Sea, but None for Spain
description: Normally, the dock bars and eateries here are packed with the men who sail the fishing boats.

title: Drug Combination Gains Support As Alternative to Surgical Abortion
description: DRUGS that induce miscarriages may eventually replace traditional surgical abortions in the first three months of pregnancy, according to a World Health Organization official. In particular, a panel that recently evaluated international drug tests determined that a specific two-drug combination was safe and effective when used early in pregnancy.

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing King's Swan Wins Stymie Handicap: King's Swan stalked pacesetting Wind Chill to the stretch yesterday, took the lead and went on to carry highweight of 126 pounds to a 4 1/2-length victory in the $169,200 Stymie Handicap for 3-year-olds and up. Wind Chill finished second in the five-horse field ahead of Feeling Gallant, Mr. Classic and Proud Debonair. The victory was the second in three starts this year for King's Swan, whose record would be unblemished except for a disqualification from his first-place finish in the Aqueduct Handicap on Jan. 2. The 8-year-old gelding by King's Bishop-Royal Cygnet earned $101,520 for Alvin Akman and returned $3 for $2 to win as the favorite after covering a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:51 2/5 under Jose Santos. N.B.A. Bulls 126, Hawks 107: Michael Jordan scored 32 points, grabbed 13 rebounds and had 8 assists in leading Chicago at home yesterday. The Bulls dealt Central Division-leading Atlanta its sixth loss in nine games, and it was the 34th time this season Jordan has scored 30 or more points in a game. Brad Sellers held Dominique Wilkins of the Hawks to 15 points in the first three quarters. Wilkins finished with 25 points.(AP) Pistons 102, 76ers 95: Dennis Rodman scored 15 of his 19 points in the second half to lead the Pistons and give the Sixers their 13th consecutive road defeat, their longest road-loss streak since 1973, when they dropped 15 straight. Detroit is 5-0 since the All-Star Game break, not allowing more than 100 points in a game. Charles Barkley scored 32 for Philadelphia.(AP) Bucks 114, Bullets 110: Jack Sikma had 27 points and 12 rebounds and the visiting Bucks held off a fourth-quarter Washington rally. Milwaukee went more than 8 minutes of the fourth quarter without a field goal before Ricky Pierce hit a jumper with 7:04 left. A 3-point play by John Lucas with 4:04 left put the Bucks ahead, 102-97, and the Bullets got no closer than 3 thereafter. The Bullets were led by John Williams, who scored 22 of his career-high 28 in the second half.(AP) Warriors 126, Spurs 122: Chris Mullin scored 27 points and Rod Higgins 26 as the Warriors rallied from a 25-point deficit and won for the third time in 24 road games. It was the fifth consecutive loss for San Antonio. The Warriors, after being outrebounded, 32-18, in the first half, won for the fourth time in five games. Their overall record is just 13-33.(AP) Cavaliers 104, Kings 95: Brad Daugherty scored a season-high 30 points for the Cavaliers at home last night. Cleveland trailed, 80-77, entering the final quarter. Behind 6 points each by Mark Price and Mark West, the Cavaliers rallied to take a 93-85 lead with 4:08 left. Cleveland got its eighth victory in its last 11 games. Reggie Theus led the Kings with 29 points, but was held to 2 in the final quarter.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 5, Whalers 4: Dave Brown's tip-in goal from the crease at 1 minute 25 seconds into overtime gave the Flyers a home victory yesterday. It was the Whalers' first loss after two victories under their new coach, Larry Pleau. Brown's goal came off a shot by Derrick Smith and ended a rough game that included 36 penalties for 100 minutes and five power-play goals. The Flyers took a 4-3 lead at 8:47 of the final period when Ron Sutter picked up a loose puck at center ice, skated in and beat the Whalers' goalie, Mike Liut, over the glove hand. Just 17 seconds later, the Whalers tied it, on Dean Eavson's second goal of the game.(AP) Red Wings 6, Kings 1: Steve Yzerman scored his 45th goal and assisted on another as Detroit won on the road yesterday. The Wings got goals from six different players while dominating each period of the game. Yzerman netted a 20-footer at 8:17 of the first period to give Detroit a 2-0 lead. Detroit has won five of its last six games, and is 14-4-4 over the last 22 games, good for first place in the Norris Division.(AP) Tennis Sanchez Loses in Upset: Emilio Sanchez of Spain, the sixth-seeded player, was an upset victim at Milan yesterday in the opening day's action of the Stella Artios tournament, falling to Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 7-5, 6-3. In an evening match, Eric Jelen of West Germany edged Francesco Cancellotti of Italy, 4-6, 6-4, 7-5, to advance to the second round of the $500,000 event. Earlier in the day, another Italian hopeful, Claudio Mezzadri, was eliminated by West Germany's Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 6-2. In the final match of the day, Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden beat Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-2.(AP)

title: 10 Injured as Wall Collapses
description: Wind blew over a wall 30 feet high at a condominium complex under construction today, trapping 18 workers for about five minutes, the authorities said. Ten workers were injured, three of them seriously. Lieut. James Hagerty of the Franklin Fire Department said the workers were using long poles to raise the sheetrock-and-plywood wall when the wind caught it and if fell on top of them. Three workers were hospitalized with back injuries.

title: Arizona Senate Urged To Hold an Open Trial
description: The majority leader of the State Senate called urged his colleagues today to scrap a plan to meet privately in the impeachment trial of Gov. Evan Mecham.

title: Judge Medina's 100th Birthday: Time for Tributes
description: When Amanda Medina Murray meets history professors at Cornell University, where she is a freshman, they ask if she is related to Harold Raymond Medina, the Federal judge who presided over a landmark trial of Communists in the United States.

title: Chess: A Dazzling Dzindzichashvili Wins the Continental Open
description: The 19th annual Continental Open Tournament, held at the Hilton Hotel in Rye, N.Y., was won by Roman Dzindzichashvili. The New York grandmaster, who originally hailed from the Soviet Union, scored 5-1 to capture the $2,000 first prize in the six-round Swiss-system event.

title: WALDHEIM ASSAILS 'SLANDERS,' VOWS NOT TO STEP DOWN
description: Despite the deepening divisions in Austria and growing calls for his resignation, President Kurt Waldheim told his nation today that he would ''not retreat in the face of slanders, hateful demonstrations and wholesale condemnations.''

title: U.S. SUFFERS HOCKEY SETBACK
description: Coach Dave Peterson wore a long face after the United States hockey team wasted a 3-0 lead and suffered a 7-5 loss tonight to Czechoslovakia. But his first encounter with unhappiness at Calgary did not sway him from his strategy for the young Americans, whose enthusiasm for scoring goals often leaves them wanting on defense.

title: Smoking Ban Leads To Arrest on L.I.R.R.
description: On the first day of a smoking ban on commuter railroads in the New York metropolitan region, a Long Island Rail Road passenger was arrested on charges of kicking and slapping two conductors after they told him to put out his cigarette.

title: Sunset Limited Journal; There's Something About a Train. . .
description: Thrice weekly the Amtrak sleeper train clacks across the desert Southwest with its human cargo, a rolling collection of the neurotic, the phobic, the curious and the adventurous.

title: More Mexican Prices 'Dollarized'
description: People here have long been fond of saying that ''no one in Mexico has ever lost money betting on the dollar.'' But the latest downturn in this nation's six-year economic crisis has given a new and added cogency to that adage.

title: National Arts Club Honors Carlos Fuentes
description: Carlos Fuentes, the Mexican novelist and critic, is to receive the Medal of Honor for Literature from the National Arts Club, at 15 Gramercy Park South, at its 20th annual literary award dinner on Feb. 24.

title: Japan's U.S. Surplus at 2-Year Low
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States fell in January to $2.97 billion, the lowest level in two years, the Ministry of Finance reported today.

title: Yonkers Group Plans Protest in Washington
description: Opponents of a desegregation plan here will go to Washington to ''lay this open before the nation,'' an organizer said today.

title: Chinese Official Lists 6 Grievances Against U.S.
description: In the strongest language to date, China has described its relations with the United States as potentially unstable and attacked what it said was interference in its internal affairs.

title: Burning It Up As a Flame
description: If April is the cruelest month, March in Ithaca, N.Y., more than prepares you for what's coming. The snow levels are high, and the wind off Lake Cayuga is brutal. Perhaps most discomforting for much of the college town's population, however, is that funds for pizza and beer have by then evaporated.

title: Report by New York Agency Finds Rent Office Inefficient
description: Almost a year after the Governor's housing commissioner defended his agency's record in administering New York City's rent laws against a blistering attack by legislators, the Cuomo administration now says that the basic activities of the Office of Rent Administration are ''not functioning.''

title: 3 Children Die in Fire In Jersey City Building
description: Three brothers, aged 1, 2 and 3 years old, were killed today in an apartment fire.

title: Pathologist Says Levin Wasn't Drunk
description: Jennifer Levin was not drunk when she died, a pathologist testified yesterday, but the alcohol level in her bloodstream was equivalent to at least three drinks consumed an hour earlier.

title: Chrysler Plans Fund In Layoffs
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which has been accused of misleading workers at its plant in Kenosha, Wis., annnounced today that it would establish a trust fund of about $20 million to assist workers after the plant is largely closed later this year.

title: Zurbriggen Takes Lead in Combined
description: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland took a major step today toward his second gold medal of the Winter Olympics by winning the downhill portion of the men's combined by nearly half a second.

title: I.B.M. Names Unit Head
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has named C. Michael Armstrong, a senior vice president, to be chairman of the IBM World Trade Europe/Middle East/ Africa Corporation. He will continue as president of the corporation, which is responsible for operations in 85 countries. Mr. Armstrong succeeds Kaspar V. Cassani, who was recently promoted to a vice chairman at I.B.M. Mr. Armstrong will also continue as president director general of IBM Europe, and as a member of the I.B.M. corporate management board. Mr. Armstrong joined I.B.M. in 1961 as a systems engineer in Indianapolis, Ind. He became a senior vice president in 1983.

title: A Trailer-Town Play That Was Born in the News
description: The germ of an idea for a play or a book can originate anywhere: in personal experience in a mundane job (the real-estate office in David Mamet's ''Glengarry Glen Ross''), in something that's in the public consciousness (the Vietnam dramas of David Rabe) or even in a short newspaper report.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior quarter and full-year adjusted for changes in corporate income tax rate accounting. The adoption of certain accounting standards resulted in a restatement of the 1986 results of 1 cent for the fourth quarter and 4 cents for the full year.

title: WNEW-AM May Be Sold
description: The Metropolitan Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it was talking to several parties who have expressed interest in buying WNEW-AM, its New York station that for more than 50 years has been known as the home of ''Make Believe Ballroom.''

title: Metromedia-Orion
description: John W. Kluge, chairman of the Metromedia Company, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation to 28.3 percent from 26.7 percent. Orion, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed today at $17.75 a share, up 50 cents. Mr. Kluge, who has been steadily purchasing shares of the motion picture and television production company since October, has not altered his original statement that the shares have been purchased for investment purposes.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Kriek Downs Purcell: Johan Kriek overcame a slow start to beat Mel Purcell, 6-7, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday in the second round of the $415,000 United States Indoor championships in Memphis. Kriek, seeded 15th, from Naples, Fla., had trouble with Purcell's variety of soft shots in the first set, but found his serve midway through the second set and dominated the rest of the match.(AP) Becker Wins Despite Erratic Play: Despite some sloppy and erratic play and a late lapse, Boris Becker defeated Guy Forget of France, 6-4, 1-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the Milan indoor tournament. Becker, the defending champion, trailed by 0-30 at 4-4 in the third set against Forget after losing 6 points in a row. But he then won 8 straight points, capped with an ace, to move into the second round of the $500,000 tournament.(AP) N.H.L. Jets 7, Nordiques 3: Laurie Boschman scored two third-period goals last night to help Winnipeg win at Quebec and extend the Jets' unbeaten streak to seven games. Ron Wilson, Thomas Steen, Dave Ellett, Doug Smail and Dale Hawerchuk, also scored for Winnipeg. Gaetan Duchesne, Michel Goulet and Gord Donnelly had goals for the Nordiques. Winnipeg, which has one of the league's top power-play units, scored on two of the three-man advantages it had. The Jets also added a short-handed goal.(AP) Sabres 3, Blues 0: Ray Sheppard scored his 22d goal, and Christian Ruuttu set up two others as the Sabres broke a three-game losing streak with a road victory. The goalie, Tom Barrasso, stopped 25 shots for his 12th career shutout and first of the season. The Sabres lost a defenseman, Joe Reekie, who was hospitalized after a fight in the opening minute. Reekie suffered a laceration over his right eye and a broken nose during his fight with Herb Raglin and was taken to Jewish Hospital for observation of a possible concussion.(AP)

title: Greenspan Implies Fed Won't Cut Rates Soon
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that important features of the economy seemed stable, if not particularly strong. Economists said his remarks implied that the Fed wanted interest rates and the dollar to stay where they are.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $38,148,000 on debt restructurings. c-After a gain of $84,570,000 on debt restructurings for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: American Cooks Win Prizes In England
description: A team of student chefs from Johnson and Wales College, a cooking school in Providence, R.I., won 23 prizes in the British Open Cookery Championship in London. They were the first American team to enter the contest.

title: U.S. to Consult Iraqis on Preventing Attacks
description: The United States is sending a team of military officials to Iraq to review steps to prevent accidental attacks by Iraqi jets on American forces in the Persian Gulf, a Pentagon official said today.

title: Downing St. Car-Fire Death Called Suicide
description: British news organizations reported today that a man killed when his car exploded in flames about 120 feet from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's official residence had left a suicide note protesting unemployment.

title: Soviet Pairs 1-2; Bronze to U.S.
description: In the pairs figure skating competition at the XV Olympic Winter Games, the Soviet Union, led by Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov, won the gold and silver medals.

title: Engine Failure Halts Flight
description: An engine on a USAir jetliner bound for Newark failed Monday morning, forcing the plane to return to Pittsburgh. The Boeing 737, carrying 80 people on Flight 264, was about 45 miles east of Pittsburgh when its right engine compressor stalled and oil pressure dropped. No one was injured in the incident, which the authorities were investigating today.

title: STV ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $66,000 from amortization of contract rights.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $30,000 and $183,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Slider Doesn't Let Her Spirits Slip
description: The words came tumbling out almost as fast as Bonny Warner had slid down the icy chute on her high-tech sled. Even an eighth-place standing after today's first two runs of the luge singles competition - which included a brush with a wall on her second run -did not dampen her enthusiasm or hopes of eventually placing among the top five or six women when the event is completed on Wednesday.

title: Tug and Barge Workers Go on Strike in New York
description: A union of 2,500 tugboat and barge crew members went on strike yesterday morning after negotiations collapsed on a three-year labor contract with nine towing companies.

title: Aid Is Asked on Recreation in Forests
description: The Agriculture Department today announced a major new program for encouraging private business to develop recreational facilities in national forests.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in the 1,500 meters, has a heavy cold and fever and will not be able to run in a 3,000-meter race Friday night in the Los Angeles Times/GTE Indoor Games. ''It's disappointing, but I wouldn't be giving myself a fair chance to redeem myself,'' Coe said. ''I'm just not in shape to run respectably, and it would be silly to push on.'' . . . Herman Lewis, a former minor league outfielder for the Mets, has been named adminstrative assistant for the club's scouting and minor league operations. The 28-year-old Lewis, who spent the last three years as a beauty supply company executive in his native Buffalo, replaces John Barr, who left the Mets to head the Minnesota Twins' scouting operations on the East Coast.

title: The Discreet Charms of Paris Bistros and Brasseries
description: These are trying times for American gourmands in Paris, what with the dollar as deflated as a punctured souffle and local prices steadily climbing. A three-course meal with wine in an average Parisian restaurant easily tops $40 a person; it's considerably more if you are picky about wine. A bottle of decent Beaujolais, for example, can run $20 or more, and the price of a better Bordeaux is downright scary, often 25 percent or more over New York restaurant prices.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-earlier periods include a charge of $800,000 related to retroactive repeals of investment tax credits.

title: Andrew Young Makes Apology for Remark
description: Mayor Andrew Young apologized today to local ministers for remarks last week about Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jesse Jackson that were interpreted as being critical of preachers.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Florida Power and Light Company offered $125 million of 9 5/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2018 at a price of 99.75 to yield 9.649 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Albert J. Sica, Fordham Dean, 71
description: Albert J. Sica, former dean of the Fordham University School of Pharmacy, died of melanoma Monday at his home in Delmar, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Sports People; Arbitration for Gooden
description: Barring a last-minute settlement, the Mets and Dwight Gooden will meet in salary arbitration today. Al Harazin, the Mets' senior vice president, said he had not heard from Gooden's agent, Jim Neader, yesterday and had no reason to think they would not debate their differences in a hearing. Gooden, who earned $1.5 million last year, submitted a $1.65 million figure, the Mets $1.4 million. Neader has said that Gooden would accept a pay cut, as the Mets want him to, but only $10,000 and not $50,000, as the Mets would like. . . . Mitch Webster and the Montreal Expos settled their case yesterday, agreeing on a $550,000 salary one day before arbitration was scheduled. Mark Gubicza of the Kansas City Royals and Chris Brown of the San Diego Padres presented their cases to arbitrators yesterday. Also scheduled for hearings today are George Bell of the Toronto Blue Jays and Frank Tanana of the Detroit Tigers.

description: Hawaiian Touch

There were charges of $150,000 and $350,000 in the year-ago third quarter and 9 months, respectively, relating to Washington Public Power.

title: Engineer in Amtrak Crash Guilty Of Manslaughter in Plea Bargain
description: An engineer accused of running a stop signal and driving three freight locomotives into the path of a speeding passenger train pleaded guilty today to one count of manslaughter in the deadliest crash in Amtrak's history.

title: SCHOOL CONTROL FOR THE MAYOR IS ABANDONED
description: Cuomo administration officials said today that they had abandoned for now their efforts to give the New York City Mayor more direct control over the city's Board of Education.

title: Soviet Says Pakistan Is Blocking A Settlement to the Afghan War
description: The Soviet Union said today that Pakistan was obstructing an end to the war in Afghanistan by insisting that a change of government in Kabul precede the signing of a peace agreement.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES

description: Chuck Person scored 23 points and Vern Fleming's 6 points in the third quarter helped Indiana take the lead for good tonight as the Pacers defeated the Knicks, 117-104, for their fifth straight victory.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New York Agency Offering Long Island Hospital Bonds
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority is tentatively offering $102 million of tax-exempt bonds for the Long Island Jewish Medical Center with a maximum yield of about 7.79 percent for an issue maturing in 2027 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

description: Tucked away in President Reagan's budget message to Congress is the germ of an idea that could lead to a destructive assault on the environmental integrity of America's public lands.

title: A Woman Wins Her 14-Year Fight To Be Scoutmaster
description: Catherine N. Pollard got out her old Boy Scout uniform with the Troop 13 patch on the shoulder last weekend and announced proudly, ''I can still get in it.''

title: Soviet Skaters Prevail in Pairs
description: The Soviet Union maintained its dominance of the pairs event in figure skating tonight, winning the gold and silver medals at the XV Olympic Winter Games. The third Russian pair finished in fourth place.

title: The Bald Truth
description: There is a man here who knows a terrible secret about a lot of important people, and he is making a great deal of money off it. He is a physician who has restored forelocks and cowlicks to the heads of a Senator, two members of the House of Representatives, a general and a former member of the Reagan Cabinet and many others.

title: Grown-Ups Dine Out, Too
description: AFTER enduring Excedrin headache music, waiters' amateur hour, backbreaking chairs and food so current that it lasted only a week on the menu, I can't tell you how nice it is to see that grown-up restaurants are coming back into fashion.

title: Prosecutor Accuses Westies of a 'Reign of Terror'
description: Summations in a Federal racketeering trial ended yesterday as a prosecutor told the jury that a Manhattan gang called the Westies had carried out a ''reign of terror.''

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The year-ago periods' earnings were restated. Results for 1987 include operations of the Blue Bell companies acquired in November 1986.

title: Chefs From China Bring Authenticity to New Year's Banquets
description: LEAD: THE start of the lunar Year of the Dragon today has special meaning for Li Yuehua, an award-winning chef from the Sichuan province of China. It is his first in the United States under an unusual project that imports not food, but the people who prepare it.

title: Paramount Pictures Hires D'Arcy Masius
description: Gulf and Western's Paramount Pictures has assigned its media and marketing business, worth more than $70 million, to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Los Angeles. The creative side is being handled by smaller agencies, as is typical in the movie business. Other Los Angeles shops in the race, which began at the end of the year, were the incumbent, AC&R/ DHB & Bess, a Saatchi & Saatchi unit; BBDO West, a division of BBDO Worldwide, and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide's unit. Also participating was Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Southern California, based in Torrance.

title: Real Estate; New York Is Not at Top Of Cost List
description: NEW YORK companies often complain about the high cost of doing business in the city, but a recent international survey shows not only that Manhattan office rents are a comparative bargain but also that costs are rising much faster in many other cities worldwide.

title: WMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $560,000 from restructuring of work force at the company's amusement game facilities for the latest quarter; the year- ago quarter includes a loss from discontinued telephone business of $320,000.

title: A. Daniel Fusaro, Court Clerk
description: A. Daniel Fusaro, a retired chief clerk for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, died of cardiac arrest Feb. 8 at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

description: Companies

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Smith Helps Guide Islander Fortunes
description: The Islanders were effective in every phase of their play tonight and posted a resounding triumph against the best team in the National Hockey League.

title: Instead of Jail: 'Welcome, Reptile!'
description: At first glance it sounds outrageous, like too much crime and too little punishment. Two startling sentencing decisions, in Florida and New York, have resulted in white-collar criminals getting off without any jail time. No jail at all is too little. Still, by fashioning creative sentences, the judges in these cases have tailored the punishment to the crime and the criminal.

description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission is to consider two rules today intended to enhance driver safety.

description: LEAD: IT was only a matter of time before the personal computer, whose cool silicon nose pokes into so many other aspects of life, was harnessed in the fight against fat.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $301,000 for the quarter and $463,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter revenue includes $2 million related to the sale of its Cars- 36 Systems Product to EDS.

title: 2 Sea Films at Museum
description: Two films by the independent film maker Peter Gimbel - ''Andrea Doria: The Final Chapter'' and ''Blue Water, White Death'' - will be shown tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. The screening is part of a series devoted to films about social and political issues. ''Andrea Doria'' will be shown at 3 P.M. and ''Blue Water'' at 7. Mr. Gimbel, who specialized in filming underwater adventures, died last year at the age of 59. Information: 708-9490.

title: Navy Promotes Its Ex-Chief
description: John F. Lehman Jr., who was Secretary of the Navy in the first six years of the Reagan Administration, has been chosen for promotion to captain in the Naval Reserve, the service said today. Mr. Lehman, a naval flight officer who left the Government last April to pursue a career in investment banking, was selected for a captaincy along with more than 450 other commanders. The promotions take effect in the 1989 fiscal year, which begins next Oct. 1.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: Oil Discovery in England
description: Oil has been found beneath a wheat field in eastern England. Enterprise Oil Investments said its test well at West Firsby in Lincolnshire flowed at 864 barrels of oil a day. Analysts said it might be Britain's third-largest onshore deposit. Most British oil comes from the North Sea.

title: ARABS REJECT BID TO USE CAMP DAVID AS BASIS FOR PEACE
description: Many Arab countries, led by Egypt and Jordan, have told the United States that they firmly reject any further interim Middle East negotiations based on the Camp David accords.

title: THRIFTY RENT-A-CAR SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter includes a net gain of $2.6 million pre- tax on the sale of substantially all the assets of the company's Astrotech Space Operations Inc. unit.

title: Al Cohn, 62, a Jazz Saxophonist, Arranger and Partner of Zoot Sims
description: Al Cohn, a tenor saxophonist and arranger who worked with the Artie Shaw, Buddy Rich and Woody Herman orchestras, died of liver cancer Monday in Poconos Hospital in East Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 62 years old and lived in Canadensis, Pa.

title: Military 4 1/2, Civilians 2
description: James C. Miller 3d, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, told a group of Republican members of the House of Representatives yesterday that the budget President Reagan is to submit on Thursday will call for wage increases of 4.5 percent for those in the military but less than half of that, 2 percent, in wage increases for civilians employed by the Government.

title: G.M. Cancels Insert After Article on Perot
description: The General Motors Corporation has pulled from Fortune magazine an eight-page advertising insert after Fortune ran a cover article about H. Ross Perot, entitled ''How I Would Turn Around G.M.''

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Greece Won't Extradite Italian
description: The Greek Gov ernment today overruled a Supreme Court decision to extradite to Italy a member of the Red Brigades who was sought by the Italian authorities for terrorist attacks.

title: P.L.O. 'Exodus' Ferry Faces a Sea of Trouble
description: The Sol Phryne lay at rest today, a ship of a certain age and an opaque past. A sign on the gaping mouth of the ferry's car deck announced, belatedly, ''No visitors.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Feb. 9 about the Scandinavian Airlines System misstated the basis for the airline's ranking among European carriers. It ranked eighth in revenue passenger miles - the number of paying passengers multiplied by the distance they are flown.

title: The Big Prize: Credibility; The Republicans
description: Vice President Bush saved his political skin by winning the New Hampshire primary today and set up what seems likely to be a prolonged struggle with Senator Bob Dole of Kansas for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Trade Move In Deadlock
description: House conferees on the trade bill insist that their Senate counterparts accept a House-passed measure that would require foreign investors to disclose their holdings in the United States. In exchange, the House conferees would accept a Senate-passed revision of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, according to Senate and House aides.

title: U.S. Disputes Waldheim Assertions
description: Reagan Administration officials today disputed assertions by President Kurt Waldheim of Austria about the Justice Department's investigation of his war record.

title: U.S. WON'T REOPEN PLUTONIUM PLANT
description: The United States Department of Energy said yesterday that it would not reopen the nation's largest plant for making plutonium for nuclear weapons, which has been shut for safety improvements for 13 months.

title: Cloning Brings Factory Precision to the Farm
description: A new and powerful biological technology that enables livestock breeders to clone large numbers of identical animals from a single embryo is nearing commercial application in the United States and Canada.

title: Census Undercounts Too Imprecise to Adjust
description: To the Editor:

title: Ash Wednesday: Faithful Decide on Going Public
description: Millions of Americans who normally give little public sign of religious allegiance will walk around today with one smudged on the forehead.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Report Clearing Judge Ginsburg Is Released
description: The Justice Department looked into 16 instances in which Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, then the department's antitrust chief, dealt with cable television industry matters while holding cable stock, but found either his participation or chance of gain was too small to violate Government conflict-of-interest laws, it was reported today.

title: Richard Feynman Dead at 69; Leading Theoretical Physicist
description: Richard P. Feynman, arguably the most brilliant, iconoclastic and influential of the postwar generation of theoretical physicists, died Monday night in Los Angeles of abdominal cancer. He was 69 years old.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represent commissions and fees.

title: New Sears Store
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company will open its first home fashions store in midtown Manhattan late this spring. The new store, a 20,000-square-foot unit aimed primarily at apartment dwellers, will be in the Windsor Court apartment development between 31st and 32d Streets from Lexington to Third Avenue. The store will ''feature a highly focused, market-driven assortment of bed and bath fashions, bedding, window coverings, floor coverings, lifestyle furniture and other selected products,'' said W. Stan Knipe, general manager of Sears's New York region.

title: Japan's Output Rises
description: Japan's industrial production in December rose a revised 2 percent from the previous month and a revised 9.2 percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: The Expanding Microwave Galaxy
description: Move over, microwave popcorn. The 30-second hot fudge sundae and many other new microwave food offerings are landing in supermarkets.

title: Tandem Computers To Buy Ungermann
description: Tandem Computers Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Ungermann-Bass Inc., a leading maker of local area networks, for approximately $260 million.

title: Max L. Heine, 77, Founder and Head Of Securities Firms
description: Max L. Heine, a founder and chairman of leading mutual funds and president of the Heine Securities Corporation, died Friday after being struck by an automobile in Tucson, Ariz., where he was vacationing. He was 77 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: About New York; Trying to Give Cupid an Assist On His Shots
description: People in the love game are feeling pretty good here in the middle of the week after Valentine's Day, just as caterers in other trades are happy to have got the biggest day of their year behind them. In Abby Hirsch's case the market was particularly strong in gift certificates. Ms. Hirsch runs a dating service.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary income of $338,000 and $490,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income d-After extraordinary income of $188,000 for the quarter and $451,000 for the 6 months.

title: Wider Use of Experimental Drug For AIDS Ailment Is Approved
description: Federal health officials today announced approval for wider use of an experimental drug to treat AIDS patients who suffer from a life-threatening form of pneumonia.

title: For Arabs, a Quiet 'Day of Anger' on West Bank
description: A Palestinian call for a ''day of anger'' today produced almost total observance of a commercial strike in the occupied territories but only scattered clashes between protesters and the Israeli Army.

title: John G. de Roos, 61, Former Chief Of New York City Transit Agency
description: John G. de Roos, a lawyer who spent a sometimes bumpy four years running the Transit Authority at the height of New York City's fiscal crisis, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Census Undercounts Too Imprecise to Adjust; Use Political Process
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH OVERCOMES DOLE'S BID AND DUKAKIS IS EASY WINNER IN NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARIES
description: Vice President Bush soundly defeated Senator Bob Dole in the New Hampshire Republican primary today, keeping his Presidential candidacy alive after one of the most difficult weeks in his political life.

title: CANDELA LASER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
College Basketball; Temple Tops Penn State, 50-49
description: Mark Macon's 3-point play with 42 seconds left helped Temple survive a scare from Penn State for a 50-49 victory in an Atlantic 10 Conference game tonight.

title: Seven Reportedly Killed as Ex-Employee Seizes Plant
description: A disgruntled former employee took over a top-secret military plant for several hours here today and shot at least 12 people, according to the authorities, with seven of those reported to be fatally wounded.

title: I.R.A.'s, Not as Useful Now, Still a Good Idea for Many
description: With new restrictions on Individual Retirement Account deductions, millions of Americans have to decide whether to continue what has been the annual tradition of contributing to an I.R.A. - but now without the lure of a $2,000 deduction.

title: Ammunition for Critics of Gandhi's Wife
description: To the Editor:

title: Biden Out of Intensive Care; Condition Called Satisfactory
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been moved out of intensive care, and his condition continues to improve after surgery to correct an aneurysm in an artery supplying blood to his brain, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said today.

title: Cruel, and Needless, Choice of Refugees
description: Thailand's patience has snapped. After years of receiving refugees from Communist neighbors, it is now experiencing an unexpectedly large new flow from Vietnam. Officials and deputized fishermen are pushing the boats full of newcomers back to sea. More than 100 refugees have died - and now the U.S. State Department is considering an idea that would make the tragedy even worse.

title: With a Civilian in Charge, Guatemala Still Can't Fully Rein In the Brutality
description: Set providentially beside one of the world's most beautiful volcanic lakes, yet shaken by unending cycles of terror and death, the village of Santiago Atitlan is an apt metaphor for Guatemala.

title: Have Bicycle, Will Travel (Stylishly)
description: NEITHER rain, nor slush, nor fumes from cars, nor numbing cold can keep hardy New Yorkers off their bicycles. With gritty determination, they stylishly pedal out to meet the elements, often with an amusing originality. A messenger battles midtown traffic like a Phantom of the Street, his face covered with a hockey mask to protect him from churned-up mud and sleet. A woman tops her suede coat with a sable scarf, a tote bag flung over the bicycle handlebars, her head crowned with a safety helmet. Another woman weathers the vagaries of traffic and winter in a fake fur coat and a curly wool bonnet by Sonia Rykiel. In SoHo, a young woman glides along the streets in a canvas aviator's helmet topped with ski goggles, a rakish scarf tied around the collar of her jacket. Should the weather turn bad, more drastic measures are needed. To have his coffee and drink it, too, a messenger recently devised a kind of automatic coffee feed. Grasping the container firmly in his teeth, he tossed back his head to send a sip through a hole in the lid. Nothing, it seems, would stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed round.

title: Eating Well
description: LEAD: HOW often have you seen a shopper pause before an unusual item in the grocery store and ask what it is and what to do with it?

title: An Impasse For Austrian
description: It was by common consent the bitterest week to date of the two-year-old Waldheim affair. But after all the recriminations, accusations, speeches and threats, the sense here was that an impasse had been reached.

title: American Given Life in I.R.A. Case in London
description: An American, the first member of the Irish Republican Army to be extradited from the United States, was convicted today of killing a London policeman in 1975 and sentenced to life in prison.

title: Angola Terms on Cuban Troops Seen as Major Sticking Point
description: Angola is willing to send home all the Cuban troops stationed there, according to a senior Angolan official, but only under conditions that few diplomats and other experts expect South Africa to accept.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: BREAD crumbs or bread crumbs blended with cheese are probably the most widely used and appetizing coatings for food. If you want to surprise your guests with a spectacular variation on the breading theme, you might try coating fish fillets with sesame seeds, which give the outside a crunchy texture. And if you want more zest, you might blend those seeds with freshly grated Parmesan cheese.

title: ERIE LACKAWANNA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the 1986 fourth quarter and year are restated due to the reduction of capital stock to be issued as a result of the expiration on Nov. 30, 1987 of the rights of all security holders of the debtor and other claimants to participate in the company's plan of reorganization.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Decline
description: Bond prices declined for the second consecutive trading session yesterday as the sharp rally of the previous five weeks seemed to have been defused by a spate of stronger-than-expected economic statistics.

title: INSIDE
description: Shooting at Defense Plant An ex-employee of a top-secret plant in Sunnyvale, Calif., shot 12 people before surrendering. As many as seven died, authorities said. Page A11. Cultural Rapprochement Arts exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union are surging, delighting some in the field but worrying others. Page C17. Abortion Rule Blocked A judge has blocked a rule that prevents many clinics from helping women obtain abortions. Page A10. Guilty in Amtrak Crash An engineer pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the train collision that killed 16 people last year. Page A10.

title: A NEW ART FORM: DESIGNING STORE SHELVES BY COMPUTER
description: It's no secret in the supermarket business that how items are placed on shelves and how often the inventory turns over can be crucial factors when it comes time to tote up the profit-loss statement. As supermarkets have gathered more and more data about which items sell best and which make the most money, the computer has moved center stage, dictating not only what appears on the shelves, but also how merchandise is positioned.

title: LAWSON MARDON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $3,073,000 from a writeoff related to a restructuring for the quarter and year. The results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $300,000 and a credit of $1,703,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-Net income and includes $360,000 of gains from the sale of certain facilities.

title: For California Chardonnays, A Graceful 12-YeaR Evolution
description: CALIFORNIA chardonnay is the Cinderella of American wines. Largely klutzy, over-oaked and superalcoholic 12 years ago, it is today often seductively complex and smoother.

title: William U. Gardner, Professor, 80
description: William U. Gardner, professor emeritus of anatomy at the Yale University School of Medicine, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday at the Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Orange, Conn.

title: Sports People; Tibbs Traded to Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles have acquired Jay Tibbs, a right-handed pitcher, and Alfredo Cardwood, a minor league pitcher, from the Montreal Expos for three minor league pitchers - John Hoover, Doug Cinnella and Rick Carriger. Tibbs, 26 years old, was 4-5, with a 4.99 earned run average in 19 games and 12 starts with Montreal last year. ''Tibbs will be in the running for a starting spot in our rotation,'' said Roland Hemond, the Orioles' vice president for baseball operations. . . . The Houston Astros have agreed to terms on a one-year contract with Glenn Davis, a first baseman. Terms were undisclosed. Davis, 26, hit .251 last season for the Astros with 27 homers and 93 runs batted in. By agreeing to terms before the start of spring training, Davis avoided a repeat of last season's holdout.

title: 'Attack' Remains Strategy For U.S.
description: Just as soon as they had absorbed the disappointment of their 7-5 loss to Czechoslovakia Monday night, a glum group of United States Olympic hockey players began plotting their strategy against the Soviet Union for what has become a must-win game on Wednesday.

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: Not long ago, the President offered a lesson. ''Money,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''can never take the place of basics like . . . homework.'' Pedagogical poverty aside, a number of teachers here thought he did not go far enough. Homework is much more than old-fashioned drill, one of the basics; it is education's essence. To wit:

title: Trump Interested In Buying Patriots
description: Donald Trump, the New York real estate magnate and one of the principal voices in the defunct United States Football League, was added today to the roster of potential buyers for the New England Patriots.

title: F.A.A. Says Eastern Has Improved Maintenance
description: Eastern Airlines has significantly improved maintenance deficiencies that led to a record $9.5 million fine two years ago, but more changes are still needed, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend in January 1988.

title: Banks File $83 Million Suit Charging Finley, Kumble
description: Four major United States banks filed suit in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday seeking more than $83 million from the law firm of Finley, Kumble, which dissolved Jan. 4.

title: The Big Prize: Credibility; The Democrats
description: Michael S. Dukakis won where he had to win today, in his own backyard, but the result proved little about the ability of the Governor of Massachusetts to win outside New England.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $19.7 million and $64.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations; realized investment loss of $32.5 million for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $33.5 million for the year, both from continuing operations; realized investment loss of $2.7 million and a realized investment gain of $4.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations, and a $20.9 million tax expense from utilization of loss carryforward for the quarter and the year includes an extraordinary credit of $13 million and a loss from the early extinguishment of debt amounting to $3.8 million. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $12.7 million and $38.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively; realized investment gains from continuing operations of $32.9 million for the quarter and $147.8 million for the year; a realized investment loss of $4.3 million for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $9 million for the year; and extraordinary tax benefits from utilization of loss carryforward of $83 million and $125.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

description: b-Includes a provision for a loss of $865,000 related to the termination of its contract to acquire two nursing homes in Bristol and Kingsport, Tenn. c-Net income

description: b-Includes a restructuring charge for both the 12 weeks and 52 weeks of $83,000,000, and net expenses of $3,667,000 and $2,148,000 for the 12 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively, for changes in certain accounting estimates related to the company's first quarter early retirement program. c-Net income

title: Dance: Monte Company Opens at the Joyce
description: OOZE and anvil are alternately suggested as the motor pulse behind Elisa Monte's choreography and her splendid dancers flow like molasses or strike with pistonlike force.

title: Withholding Snag for Some
description: Many Americans may have had too little tax withheld from their paychecks last year, so they will owe money when they file their tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 earnings were adjusted to account for that year's 2-for-1 split of the company's common stock. Sales represent worldwide sales.
