title: CONSOLIDATED NATUARL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 net is restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting statement concerning utility plant abandonments.

title: BROKERS SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $380,350 on redemption of debentures. c-Includes a loss of $730,211 from redemption of debentures.

title: Capital Rise Expected To Gain in World Bank
description: The 151 member governments of the World Bank are expected to agree this week to a $75 billion increase in capital, but Congressional leaders warned that it would be unusually difficult to persuade Congress to approve United States participation in this election year.

title: UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,415,000, or 99 cents a share, from the sale of transmission facilities to Wisconsin Electric Power Co.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 10 about a court ruling in a New York City zoning case incompletely described the error in a map at the center of the dispute. The developer, Parkview Associates, relied upon a map published by the city in putting up a 31-story building.

title: NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; A Growing Legitimacy For Cable
description: ADVERTISER spending on the 16 advertiser-supported cable television services is expected to rise 30 percent, to about $246 million in the first quarter of 1988, according to the Cable Advertising Bureau.

title: Collection by 10-Year-Olds Benefits the Neediest Cases
description: A group of 10-year-olds from the Gimel Class of Temple Israel in Ridgewood, N.J., shoveled snow, took out garbage bags and did other chores to raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. In two weeks' time, they collected $100 in tzedaka (charitable funds), which they designated for helping homeless people.

title: Key Rates
Use Those Missiles for Peace
description: LEAD: Should the Senate ratify the intermediate range nuclear forces treaty in its present form, the two superpowers will finally face the task of actually eliminating more than 800 short and intermediate range ballistic missiles.

title: Is This Icy Strip Worth $32 Billion?
description: The frozen Arctic coastal plain of northeast Alaska may hide the largest untapped oilfield in America. Should Congress let the oil companies search for it?

title: Compaq's OS/2
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation on Wednesday will begin shipping its version of OS/2, the new operating system used on the PS/2 line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation. Compaq, the leading vendor of I.B.M.-compatible machines, also said it would offer a 3.25-inch disk drive as an option for its portable computers, which until now have come with 5.25-inch drives. The moves indicate growing support within the industry both for the new smaller disk drives, which I.B.M. uses on its PS/2 machines, as well as for OS/2, which is expected to be the successor to the MS-DOS operating system now used in most personal computers.

title: Sports of The Times; Here Come the Old Champs
description: HERE come the Soviet players, firing the puck furiously in practice, skating backwards in unison, heads snapping vigilantly from side to side, under the intense watch of their coach.

title: Rent Control Has Made Apartments Into Endangered Species
description: To the Editor:

title: James Molinski, Host At Sardi's, Dies at 74
description: James Molinski, the host and dining-room manager at Sardi's restaurant for more than 30 years, died of a stroke Feb. 6 after gall stone surgery at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Bayville, L.I.

title: Citicorp Rates Up
description: Interest rates rose about one-fifth of a percentage point at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.625 percent, up from 6.431 percent last week. Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 6.667 percent, up from 6.4306 percent.

title: Colleges Seek Ways to Keep Blacks in School
description: As colleges and universities struggle to stem the decline in blacks entering college, a major new concern has emerged: how to keep those who are already there.

title: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago periods included a restructuring provision of $8.1 million pretax, or $4 million after tax.

title: Home Sales Steady in '87
description: Sales of existing homes held steady in 1987 at close to four million units despite volatile mortgage rates and the October stock market collapse, a national real estate trade group reported today.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: State-mandated school reforms are on a collision course with demands to give teachers and school administrators greater powers to decide how and what to teach. A classic war is shaping up between political and professional power. The battle is between those who believe schools can be improved through legislation and those who insist that the search for better schools must be led by teachers who know what students need.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,052,000 and $21,478,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and both the quarter and year includes a tax credit of $21,614,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,326,000 for the quarter and $6,329,000 for the year.

title: Bear Stearns Profit Drops
description: Reflecting the difficult operating environment that has enveloped the securities industry since the stock market plunge on Oct. 19, the Bear Stearns Companies yesterday reported third-quarter net income of $36.8 million, or 40 cents a share, for the three months ended Jan. 29, a drop of 38.3 percent from the $59.6 million, or 70 cents a share, earned in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: WENDT-BRISTOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago periods were restated to reflect an increase in the average shares outstanding.

title: NASA to Test 2 Escape Systems for Shuttle
description: Two systems designed to help astronauts escape a disabled space shuttle will undergo extensive tests in coming weeks to determine if one will be used when flights resume this summer, space officials said today.

title: A U.S.-Soviet Cultural Rapprochement
description: A little more than two years after Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union signed the General Exchanges Agreement at Geneva, a remarkable number of cultural exchanges are bursting out between the two nations and prompting a mixture of awe, delight and occasional doubt and scorn.

title: A Commuter Station Will Provide Access To Yankee Stadium
description: LEAD: The operating committee of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad voted yesterday to approve construction of an $8 million commuter station that would provide direct rail access to Yankee Stadium and surrounding areas of the Bronx.

title: Ashton-Tate Products Due
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, the dominant force in software programs to help microcomputers manage large data bases, will introduce its dBASE IV system today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New President Named For Helikon Furniture
description: LEAD: Herman Miller Inc., an office furniture supplier based in Zeeland, Mich., yesterday named Frank Novakowski as president of the Helikon Furniture Company of Taftville, Conn.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAVANNAH ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: FRANKLIN HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net realized losses on investments of $327,419 for the quarter and $247,129 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes net realized gains on investments of $103,076 and $41,822 for the quarter 9 months, respectively.

title: Life After Shanker: Leader Mends Fences
description: In the two years since she became president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman has carved a broad role for herself, aiming not only to better the lot of teachers but also to be a major force in turning the New York City school system around.

title: Dow Tops 2,000, but Trading Is Slow
description: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday in subdued post-holiday trading.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Charlotte Rosen Musician, 95
description: Charlotte Rosen, a musician and teacher, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95 years old. Born in Berlin, she was trained as a violinist. After immigrating to New York in 1939, she switched to the viola, and performed at New York Public Library branches and the New-York Historical Society.

title: One Marketplace, Indivisible
description: The financial markets in New York and Chicago today stand at a crossroads. They can fight turf battles or they can take the bold steps needed to stabilize the markets. One thing is certain, though: Without proper safeguards, there remains the long-term potential for a stock market break of the severity and speed of last October's, with even more far-reaching consequences.

title: U.S. Ability to Monitor Strategic Pact Is Doubted
description: Members of the Senate Intelligence Committee have warned the Reagan Administration that current surveillance systems, unless modernized, will not be adequate to monitor Soviet compliance with a proposed treaty to reduce long-range nuclear missiles.

title: SOUTHWESTERN ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $2,071,000 credit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Pursuit of Civil Rights Isn't a 'Special Interest'
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan for Reagan Library Faces Local Resistance
description: Planners of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, forced to abandon a site at Stanford University after widespread protests, have proposed to build the library near this Southern California city, but they are running into resistance from local municipal officials.

title: Dr. John Meng, 81, Ex-President At Hunter and Marymount, Dies
description: Dr. John J. Meng, the president of Hunter College from 1960 to 1966 and later executive vice president of Fordham University and president of Marymount College,, died of heart failure on Monday at his home in Jackson, Miss. He was 81 years old. Dr. Meng, a historian and an authority on French-American relations in the period of the American and French Revolutions, retired in 1973 as president of Marymount but remained active in educational affairs. He served as executive director of the Consortium of Small Private Colleges and since 1983 had headed the Foundation for Educational Futures.

title: Walesa Plans Australia Trip; First Time Abroad Since '81
description: The Polish Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, has accepted an invitation to an international trade union congress in Australia next month - his first trip abroad since his union was banned under martial law in December 1981.

title: ESSELTE BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $776,000 for the year. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $433,000 and $811,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Wine Talk
description: ONE of Philippe de Rothschild's more significant contributions to French wine was his success in 1973, after almost half a century of demanding, wheedling and politicking, in making his beloved Chateau Mouton-Rothschild a first growth.

title: Bridge: Famed Convention's Author Is Still an Active Journalist
description: Few of those enthusiasts around the world who regularly employ the world's most famous bridge convention know that its originator is alive and well and living in Indianapolis.

title: Ramadi Journal; For Prisoners of War, Boys' Summer Camp?
description: Mohammed Rova Rahimi hesitated and offered a sly smile when asked whether, when he was 14 years old, he really wanted to be a hero, let alone a martyr.

title: Castro Foe, Freed by Venezuela, Accused in U.S.
description: Orlando Bosch, a symbol of anti-Castro militancy among Cuban exiles in the 1960's and 70's, returned from Venezuela today after his third acquittal on charges of planning an explosion aboard a Cuban jetliner in 1976 that killed 73 people.

title: ENRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net of $2,000,000 and a loss of $65,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $120,900,000 for the quarter and $185,500,000 for the year. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in both the latest periods and the year-ago quarter. The company said results for the year-ago fourth quarter and for full- year 1986 and 1987 have been restated to reflect as discontinued operations the company's chemical business segment for 1986 and its speculative oil and petroleum products trading operation for 1986 and 1987. Results for 1987 also include a third- quarter charge of $85 million in connection with the discontinuance of a unit.

title: GAF Shuns Takeover Law
description: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had decided to exempt itself from the recently enacted Delaware law that limits hostile takeovers.

title: ADVANCES: REPLACING AN ANCIENT PHONE NET
description: EACH time employees place a call on the Federal Government's telephone system, they use technology put together a quarter-century ago and that has now become so outmoded and expensive to operate that it would be cheaper to place the calls on the public telephone system. Federal officials say that getting a sophisticated new telephone network into place as soon as possible is essential to cut costs and deal with the growing volume of information associated with the typical bureaucrat's job.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax provision of $2,580,000 for anticipated costs of consolidating certain manufacturing facilities for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,093,000 and $7,298,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said year-ago quarter and year losses from discontinued operations include an after-tax charge of $14,900,000 for the anticipated loss on the disposal of the American Seating subsidiary, and an after- tax gain of $11,171,000 from the sale of Fuqua's investment in Triton Group Ltd.

title: Tempe Journal; A Place in the Sun Finds an N.F.L. Team
description: For as long as anyone can remember in this overgrown river crossing, where a native is somebody who bought a house last year, Tempe has coveted a National Football League team.

title: MORRISON KNUDSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $41.8 million. c-Net income and the year is after net from discontinued operations of $1.2 million. The latest fourth quarter results reflect after-tax loss provisions of $11 million for contracts in progress at the company's shipbuilding subsidiary and $2.3 million for resolution of a dispute on a long-term mining contract. It also includes a non-recurring gain from the sale of certain rock- crushing operations of $2.6 million after taxes.

title: Canada Sputters to Victory
description: The tighter the game, and the less predictable their grip on its outcome, the more familiar it seems to feel to Canada's Olympic hockey team.

title: Executive Role for Clavell in TV Series
description: On ''Noble House,'' the eight-hour mini-series that begins Sunday on NBC, James Clavell is not credited merely as the author of the original novel. He also acted as executive producer of the mini-series, and he was closely involved at every stage of production. ''Noble House,'' a tale of intrigue in the business community of contemporary Hong Kong, stars Pierce Brosnan, Deborah Raffin, John Rhys-Davies, Khigh Dhiegh and Denholm Elliott.

title: Leader Faults Bid by Cuomo On Residency
description: The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, said today that he was against requiring newly hired New York City police officers and firefighters to live in the city.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the actual figures for the full-year 1986, include operating results of acquired bottling companies, from their dates of acquisition, except the Louisiana Coca- Cola Bottling Co., which was acquired in February 1986 and consolidated as of Jan. 1, 1986 and Barron Cos., acquired during July 1986 and consolidated as of July 1, 1986; Beatrice Bottlers and JTL Bottlers were acquired and consolidated on Sept. 23 and Sept. 29, 1986, respectively.

title: Notebook; Vanishing Act Is Explained
description: The mystery over why a Rumanian speed skating coach and three female skaters disappeared Saturday, more than a week before they were scheduled to compete, was solved today.

title: Cradle-to-College Plans For Tuition Payment
description: Education officials in Massachusetts have devised a plan to encourage parents to start saving money early for their children's college education. They say it will serve as a model for other states.

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $763,000 and $255,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: 5 Unions Back Newspapers' Joint Pact
description: Five newspaper unions today dropped their their opposition to the proposed partial merger of two Detroit newspapers, saying joint operation was the ''only way to assure the survival'' of The Detroit Free Press.

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Independence Day Passes Like Shadow In Lithuania Capital
description: The 70th anniversary of Lithuania's independence passed over the Lithuanian capital like a shadow today, marked only by the police and security forces who kept a daylong vigil at the city's national and religious shrines.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Life in the 30's
description: IF hospitals truly wanted to perform a valuable service for new parents, they would put an Enforcer on staff. The Enforcer would enter your room just after the baby arrived for the 2 o'clock feeding, and would stand at your bedside surrounded by smoke. He would look a little like the Grim Reaper, only shorter, and he would say in a hollow voice:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on Monday about Senator Joseph R. Biden's surgery misstated his medical problem. An aneurysm in an artery supplying blood to his brain leaked but did not burst. The Associated Press, which distributed the report, later sent a corrected version, which The Times omitted through an oversight. A later report on Senator Biden's condition appears today on page A12.

title: I.R.S. Is Urged to Investigate Jackson's Church Collections
description: A Washington-based lobbying group has asked the Internal Revenue Service to investigate the Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the possibility of Federal tax law violations.

title: Lust and Unnatural Acts
description: Bruce Babbitt was by far the most attractive candidate in the whole herd, probably because he never had a chance. Being an attractive candidate ought to be easy when you're under no temptation to do something dreadful or asinine, which is the fate of people who do have a chance.

title: Market Place; Book Publishers In the Spotlight
description: TAKEOVER fever struck the dwindling band of independent book publishers after Monday's announcement that Pearson P.L.C., a British conglomerate, would acquire the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company for $283 million.

title: Economic Scene; Putting the Brakes On Easy Trading
description: IS Wall Street drowning in a tide of trading? Complaints about the Street's casino mentality are treated as public relations headaches by the exchanges and the big brokerage houses. Nor are they taken seriously by most free market economists, who see rapid turnover as the welcome consequence of increased competition and computerization. And they are dismissed as sour grapes by business school types whose arcane trading strategies have generated a bonanza in profit. Even Congressional Democrats, inclined to lay down the law to speculators after the October crash, are having second thoughts about rules that might slow the market machinery.

title: JAPANESE-HELD U.S. BANK PLANS ACQUISITION
description: In a bid to bolster its position as a business lender, the California First Bank said today that it had agreed to acquire the much larger Union Bank, a subsidiary of Standard Chartered P.L.C., for $750 million.

title: Biltmore Theater Is Sold
description: The Biltmore Theater, at 261 West 47th Street, was sold at auction yesterday for $5.35 million. The purchaser, Morris Gluck, said through a spokesman that he intended ''to preserve the theater function'' of the 948-seat house. Lawyers for Mr. Gluck and for the seller, Sam Pfeiffer, were still negotiating the details of a contract last night, according to Gary Waskow, a spokesman for Properties at Auction, which managed the sale.

title: Soviet Students Now Asking 'Why?'
description: The 15- and 16-year-olds filed into Lev Sobolev's sparely furnished classroom in Moscow's school No. 67, some with the sprightly step of the well-prepared, some with bored looks, some full of gossipy whispers. From under their arms peeked ''War and Peace.''

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a captial loss of $34,514,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1,409,000 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $38,796,000 and $121,965,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included an extraordinary loss of $110,023,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said its 1986 fourth quarter results were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Sports People; McPherson Honored
description: Saying that his only preference for playing professional football was ''to play in this country,'' Don McPherson, the all-America from Syracuse, became the first black player to receive the Davey O'Brien National Quarterback Award when he was honored Monday night in Fort Worth. But, he pointed out, although he appreciated the honor, the award would not erase the stereotype that black quarterbacks operate best out of an option offense similar to that at Oklahoma and out of the country, notably Canada. Referring to the Washington Redskin quarterback who became a Super Bowl hero 17 days ago, McPherson said: ''There's really nothing unique about Doug Williams or Don McPherson as quarterbacks other than the fact we happen to be black. And that has nothing to do with our performance.''

title: BEAR STEARNS COS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After an extraordinary item.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from foreign exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $2,632,000 for the quarter and $4,326,000 for the year. c-Included losses from foreign exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $1,781,000 for the quarter and $2,685,000 for the year. Revenue represents gross income.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SYRACUSE HONORS COLUMNIST
description: Syracuse University has established an endowed faculty chair in honor of William Safire, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The New York Times, the university's Chancellor, Melvin A. Eggers, announced last week. The William Safire Chair in Modern Letters was proposed by Robert B. Menschel, a trustee of the university and a roommate of Mr. Safire's at Syracuse in the 1940's. A search for the first occupant of the chair, which has an endowment of $1 million, is to begin in the next few months.

title: New Zealand Ponders a 'Nuclear Survival Kit'
description: Isolated in the distant South Pacific and stubbornly free of nuclear weapons and nuclear power, New Zealand has begun examining ways to survive a nuclear war.

title: Ortega Mutes His Tone
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra still wants talks with the U.S., although his Sandinista regime is committed now to direct cease-fire negotiations with the contras.

title: Nortek-Mohasco
description: Nortek Inc. has purchased a 7 percent stake in the Mohasco Corporation and said it might seek control of the carpet and furniture manufacturer, which is based in Fairfax, Va. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Nortek said that its efforts last week to discuss a friendly transaction with Mohasco had been rebuffed by the company's management. In a prepared statement, Mohasco said only that it would study the Nortek filing. Nortek, a building materials concern in Providence, R.I., said it might sell Mohasco's carpet division if it gained control of the company.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A MERCHANT BANKER STARTS OWN FIRM
description: It has been a long and winding road from the 1960's to the late 1980's for Ken Miller, a route that has taken him from social activism to the hottest money-making realm of Wall Street, merchant banking.

title: STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES: VOODOO STATISTICS?
description: Garrison Keillor, the folk humorist, has provoked many a smile by his description of the mythical town of Lake Wobegon as a place where the women are strong, the men good looking and ''all the children are above average.''

title: Kodak Film in Test
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said its professional photography division was trade-testing what will prove to be the world's fastest black-and-white film, intended for professional use. Kodak said the film was designed to produce optimum results at an index of EI 3,200, but acceptable prints had been obtained at speeds up to EI 50,000. A spokesman said EI, or exposure index, was a measurement of film sensitivity. Kodak's statement said it expects to introduce the film later this year, when details on trademark, price, speed rating and availability will be disclosed.

title: Firestone to Sell 75% of Tire Unit In $1 Billion Deal With Japanese
description: In what analysts describe as the largest investment by a Japanese company in an American manufacturing concern, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had preliminarily agreed to sell 75 percent of its tire operations to the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan for $1 billion.

title: Election by Ailey Group
description: Harold Levine has been elected president of the board of the Dance Theater Foundation, the parent organization of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and its subsidiary companies and school. Mr. Levine, co-founder of the advertising agency of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, succeeded Betty Cott Ruder as board president.

title: Financial Woes Threaten Survival Of the Historical Society in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Historical Society has told state officials that the society is in a financial crisis and that it must decide within a few weeks whether to begin laying off its staff and curtailing its operations.

title: SECURITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (CLEVEAND)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $564,000. Share earnings are not available; the thrift went public Jan. 15.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Friday about an appeals court ruling on homosexuality in the Army misstated the number of Supreme Court mem bers who have retired since the Court's June 1986 decision upholding laws against homosexual sodomy. In addition to Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., who retired last June, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger made his retirement effective in September 1986.

title: Accord Seen in Protest At U. of Massachusetts
description: A tentative understanding that could end the five-day takeover of a University of Massachusetts black studies center by nearly 200 students was reached today, school officials said.

title: COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $195 million, or 35 cents a share, related to the sale of 51 percent of the stock in Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. Year-ago figures are restated to report results of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. and T.C.C. Beverages Ltd., under the equity method of accounting.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Tonight, I somehow feel that I have a lot in common with Mark Twain. Reports of my death were greatly exaggerated.'' - Vice President Bush. [ A1:6. ]

title: U.S. Confronting AIDS With Sense of Realism
description: America is confronting AIDS in 1988 with a new sense of realism and a surge of activity by a broad range of public and private groups, according to health policy experts who only a year ago were lamenting the nation's complacency.

title: Stage: One-Act Comedies In Punch Line Festival
description: IN David Ives's ''Sure Thing,'' a young man sees an attractive young woman sitting by herself in a cafe. Planning his maneuvers, he wonders if he should be cool, forward or flattering. She is reading ''The Sound and the Fury,'' and, furrowing his brow, he tries to remember what he knows about Faulkner. Later, Woody Allen is mentioned; his spirit already pervades the play.

title: Feltsman in Talk
description: The Soviet pianist Vladimir Feltsman will discuss his life and career, at 4:30 P.M. tomorrow at Minor Latham Playhouse, Barnard College, Broadway and 119th Street.

title: Huge Warhol Catalogue
description: The auction catalogue of the Andy Warhol collection, which goes on sale today at Sotheby's, is the costliest at $95, weightiest at 8 1/4 pounds and one of the largest ever published.

title: NEXT AMBASSADOR
description: The United States is planning to change ambassadors to Israel next summer. According to State Department officials, William A. Brown, currently ambassador to Thailand, will replace Thomas R. Pickering, who has served in Tel Aviv since 1985.

title: 'Frank's Place': The Restaurant As Life's Stage
description: LEAD: VERISIMILITUDE is not usually what television situation comedies are known for; mostly, they are the medium's Wonder Bread. Not so with ''Frank's Place,'' the CBS series about a New Orleans restaurant and its owner.

title: Film: 'Frida,' Tribute To Mexican Artist
description: FRIDA KAHLO'S death in 1954 at the age of 47 caused no great stir in the United States. In her native Mexico, however, she had been a celebrity, at least within radical political and artistic circles. About a year before, the first major exhibit of her paintings had been shown at Mexico City's Gallery of Contemporary Art. And for decades before that, she had been widely known as the somewhat flamboyant wife of Diego Rivera and as his comrade in Communist causes. ''Frida,'' the Mexican movie that opens at Film Forum today, is an affectionate and affecting tribute to a colorful woman.

title: Boxing Notebook; Mike Tyson's Soft Spot
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, and his new wife, the actress Robin Givens, were discussing their courtship earlier this week at their apartment on the East Side.

title: US HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $40,030,000, or 78 cents a share, and $40,030,000, or 78 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, on the sale of a 50-percent stake in Healthwin Inc.

title: Rule on Abortion Counseling Is Blocked
description: A Federal district judge in Colorado has temporarily blocked enforcement of a new rule that prevents many of the nation's family planning clinics from helping women to obtain abortions.

title: Article 655788 -- No Title
description: The failure of a leading mortgage insurer to meet its obligations has led banks and savings and loan associations to declare nearly $500 million in home mortgages in the Southwest in default.

title: A King's Fall: Tax Changes Reverse Rise Of Developer
description: The fortunes of one of New York City's most flamboyant real-estate executives, Gerald Guterman, have taken a precipitous fall.

title: BARRY BLAU & PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represent fees and production revenue.

title: Article 655888 -- No Title
description: Johnson & Johnson and Playtex Holdings Inc. announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle for the big health care company to buy Playtex Family Products Inc. for $726 million.

title: VICTORIA CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1988
description: International A3-9

title: TV Review; Tales of Discontent, on 13
description: AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE offers a 90-minute double feature, two tales of rural life and its discontents, tonight on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock. First comes ''Revolt of Mother,'' based on a short story by Mary E. Wilkins Freeman, who wrote around the turn of the century. The mother is played by Amy Madigan and her revolt consists of turning the new barn, which her husband had meant to use for some cows, into a new home for the family, which has been squeezed into the old house for years.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year includes a gain on redemption of Series A preferred of $193,000.

title: CALGENE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Devils Closer To Soviet Deal
description: The Devils are on the verge of signing Vyacheslav Fetislov of the Soviet Olympic team, according to a source involved in the negotiations.

title: ABC's Unenviable Choices
description: IF you're an average American fan, about every four years you generate enough interest to watch a hockey game in prime time. Then the network puts on a commercial and -wouldn't you know it? - someone goes and scores while you're looking at Spuds MacKenzie.

title: SOONER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter includes a $7.8 million addition to loan loss provision and real-estate related reserves.

title: Douglas Provides Spark for Syracuse
description: There comes a time in every basketball game when an alarm goes off inside a coach's head. It warns the coach who is ahead to brace for a final assault and implores the coach who is behind to launch a last-gasp attack.

title: DATASOUTH COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Runoff Set in Milwaukee
description: Martin J. Schreiber, a former Acting Governor of Wisconsin, and State Senator John O. Norquist led a field of seven candidates today in an election to succeed Mayor Henry W. Maier. They will meet in a runoff April 5. Mayor Maier, who is 70 years old, announced last year he was retiring after 28 years in office. Mr. Schreiber, 48 years old, served as Lieutenant Governor from 1970 until 1977, when he took over as Acting Governor after Gov. Patrick J. Lucey resigned to become the United States Ambassador to Mexico.

title: Korea Trade Investigation
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, and a private industry group took actions today against what they consider unfair trade practices by the Government of Korea in barring imports of American cigarettes and beef.

title: U S Sprint Is Said to Plan Its Own Bid for Phone Contract
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company, after what was apparently a dispute with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, has decided to form a bidding team to compete on its own for contracts to build a new Government telecommunications system, people close to both companies said today.

title: Campeau Lifts Federated Bid by $5 a Share, to $66
description: The Campeau Corporation again sweetened its bid for Federated Department Stores Inc. yesterday. The offer was raised by $5 a share, to $66 in cash, or a total of $5.7 billion.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $2.5 million from the sale of land and the sale of a 208-room motel in Houston.

title: Judge Denies Approving Huge Fee To Lawyer With White House Tie
description: A Federal district judge denied today that he had improperly approved payment of $1 million in attorneys' fees to the firm of a lawyer with White House connections. The judge, Eugene Lynch, who at the time was on the bench of the San Francisco Superior Court, had been seeking the lawyer's help to gain White House backing in his bid for the Federal judgeship.

title: Music: A Barker Tribute
description: WHILE many other composers have abandoned in recent years the paths carved out by Schoenberg, Webern and their heirs, Thomas E. Barker held the line. Last month Mr. Barker died of bone cancer at the age of 33. As a memorial, several of the works he composed since 1980 were performed Monday evening at Symphony Space.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $252.8 million, or $1.68 a share, on the sale of 24 percent of a British subsidiary for the quarter and year. ITT Corp. said net income for 1987 was aided by ''fresh start'' tax benefits at its Hartford Insurance unit of $100.5 million, or 67 cents a share, for the full year and $30.9 million, or 21 cents a share, for the fourth quarter. The 1986 full year results included a gain of $50 million, or 33 cents a share, on the sale of ITT's interest in Abbey Life Insurance Co.; net of $12 million, or 8 cents a share, from discontinued operations; a fourth quarter loss of $98 million from the transfer of the telecommunications manufacturing operations to the Alcatel NV joint venture and fourth quarter after-tax provisions of $80 million for strategic reserve actions. ITT said that during 1986 it recorded an extraordinary charge of $46 million for the premium incurred in connection with the early retirement of several high interest debt issues and of this, $39 million was reflected in the fourth quarter. The company also said net for the full 1987 year was negatively impacted in the first quarter by $66.7 million, representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change at ITT Defense Technology.

title: Sports People; Team on the Rise
description: The irony is inescapable. Using a wide-open offense that averages 109 points a game, Loyola Marymount of California, with a 20-3 record, ranked 20th this week in making its first appearance ever in The Associated Press college basketball poll. The head coach is Paul Westhead, the same coach who was dismissed by the Los Angeles Lakers 11 games into the 1981-82 season after Earvin (Magic) Johnson complained publicly that Westhead's offense was slow and stodgy. Westhead, now in his third season at Loyola, said he feels no bitterness about his abrupt departure from the Lakers, nor toward Johnson. He seems amused, however, that he was let go because his approach to offense wasn't considered wide-open enough. ''My coaching methods have always been the same, the running game, shoot within seven seconds,'' said Westhead, whose team has won 17 straight games and is the National Collegiate Athletic Association's highest-scoring club. ''Sometimes, for a variety of reasons, people can maybe see things differently. First and foremost, I'm a running coach. I don't mind being hung out for my weaknesses, but not running is not one of them.''

title: Music: Muti Conducts Philadelphia Orchestra
description: EVEN more than most glamorous conductors of big-time symphony orchestras that regularly visit New York, Riccardo Muti has made the highlights of his Philadelphia Orchestra concerts at Carnegie Hall his periodic presentations of complete operas in concert form.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Appear to Ease Position on a Future Government
description: Guerrilla leaders in Afghanistan were reported today to be ready to modify a longstanding position and accept minor participation by members of the current Communist regime in Kabul in a future interim government.

title: North Conway Journal; The 'Malling' of a White Mountain Resort Town
description: It is a clear, crisp morning in this White Mountain town, a perfect day to hit the slopes.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Susan Irwin has joined McCann-Erickson Worldwide as senior vice president, director of communications.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Jackson, Hart and I were sort of the skunks at the garden party, always saying 'This debate is supposed to be about something' and raking our fingers down the chalkboard.'' - Bruce Babbitt. [ A18:6. ]

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
Publishing: Editor Going to New Yorker
description: Pat Strachan, who started as an editorial assistant at Farrar, Straus & Giroux and rose to associate publisher, will leave the independent house on March 10 to become a fiction editor at The New Yorker.

title: Whimsical Crafts on View in Baltimore
description: A few years ago Judith Strong, a Florida ceramist, had a small but bothersome problem. Her husband, Sal Guastella, liked to drink strong Cuban coffee but could not find the right size cup for it. The solution seemed simple enough. Since she is a clay artist, she created a four-inch-tall narrowed vessel that has become one of her best sellers.

title: Shultz Said to Back Pakistan On Afghan Coalition Regime
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz assured Pakistan today that he would convey its demand for a coalition government in Afghanistan to the Soviet Foreign Minister, according to State Department and Pakistani officials.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (SAN DIEGO,CALIF)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $19,141,000 for the quarter and the year includes a $2,757,000 gain from the cumulative effect of accounting changes. The latest fourth quarter reflects a charge of $44 million for loan loss reserves. The company said it established a loss allowance of $77.8 million, which included a $3.3 million allowance for the writeoff of its FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy's New Post
description: To keep up with rising demands for worldwide media placement, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide has named Kenneth E. Caffrey to the new post of director of worldwide media. Mr. Caffrey, 49, is also an executive vice president and executive director of operations at Ogilvy & Mather, New York. Jules Fine, vice chairman of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, held the responsibilities that Mr. Caffrey will assume. Two other agencies, McCann-Erickson Worldwide and Young & Rubicam, have introduced similar positions recently. Ogilvy & Mather, a unit of the Ogilvy Group, reported that it had placed nearly $5 billion worth of advertising around the world in 1987 and indicated that media placement had climbed 5 percent in the last year.

title: YESTERDAY'S MEDAL WINNERS
description: CROSS- COUNTRY Women's 5 km Gold: Marjo Matikainen, Finland Silver: Tamara Tikhonova, Soviet Union Bronze: Vida Ventsene, Soviet Union SPEED SKATING Men's 5,000 M Gold: Tomas Gustafson, Sweden Silver: Leo Visser, the Netherlands Bronze: Gerard Kemkers, the Netherlands ALPINE SKIING Men's combined Gold: Hubert Strolz, Austria Silver: Bernhard Gstrein, Austria Bronze: Paul Accola, Switzerland TOTALS: Soviet Union - 3 gold, 4 silver, 2 bronze; Finland - 2 gold, 1 bronze; East Germany - 2 gold; Austria - 1 gold, 1 silver; Switzerland - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; Sweden - 1 gold; the Netherlands - 2 silver, 1 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; West Germany - 1 silver; France - 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Norway - 1 bronze; United States - 1 bronze.

title: Bridge: Trying for Terrible Contract, Player Was Teased by Fates
description: When providence smiles kindly on a declarer and permits a virtually hopeless contract to be made, the declarer may feel inclined to offer thanks for a miracle.

title: Hunter Gains Final; Staten Island Wins
description: Hunter College rallied from a 7-point halftime deficit in the semifinals of the CUNY tournament at Nat Holman Gymnasium last night to score a 78-64 victory over Lehman.

title: Health; Study Finds Shock Waves Useful in Treating Gallstones
description: A study from Europe has provided new evidence that shock wave machines, which have already proved effective in treating kidney stones, can also safely smash gallstones and replace surgery for many patients.

title: Yields Are Down Again
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down for the second consecutive week, but in the week ended yesterday the steepness in the decline eased.

title: Students End Takeover At U. of Massachusetts
description: Minority students at the Amherst campus of the University of Massachusetts today ended their occupation of a school building after administrators met many of their demands on addressing campus racial problems.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $66,000 for the quarter and $85,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the year.

title: Landlord in His Own Jail: Tenants Debate His Fate
description: Last Friday the lobby of the apartment building at 320 Sterling Street, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, was crowded with milling reporters and angry, shouting tenants.

title: Advertising; Ad Clutter: Even in Restrooms Now
description: Studies show that the typical consumer is bombarded by 5,000 advertising messages a day, and the number of ads is expected to increase steadily. That trend has many executives in the industry worried about the growing advertising clutter.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Regulatory Czar
description: S. Jay Plager, a senior official at the Office of Management and Budget, is in line for a new, more important position as the Reagan Administration's regulatory czar, the man who reviews virtually all the regulations issued by the Government.

title: Super (for Republicans) Tuesday
description: The realization settled in yesterday that New Hampshire wasn't going to anoint the Presidential nominees any more than Iowa did. The public may thirst for clarity but there's still none of that famous momentum to sweep this Republican or that Democrat on to victory. How inconvenient; how undramatic. Why, if this keeps up, the nominees will end up being drably chosen according to how many delegates they have won.

title: Melvin Van Peebles: Original Notes In a Spare Space
description: MELVIN VAN PEEBLES - writer, film maker, producer, actor, songwriter, director, financial analyst - never does anything quite the way anyone else does. His style combines the straightforward and the theatrical.

title: GORMAN-RUPP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers Propelled By Dahlen's 2 Goals
description: Ulf Dahlen does not have Joe Nieuwendyk's gaudy statistics. He does not have Brett Hull's heritage. Last night, though, he had two more goals and a hand in a 5-3 victory by the Rangers.

title: Concert: Verdehr Trio
description: LAST season at Alice Tully Hall, the Verdehr Trio presented an excellent if underattended concert of five recently composed works, its fourth such concert in New York. If the trio's return to Tully Tuesday night, with a program of new works and new transcriptions of old works, didn't reach quite the level of last season's, that didn't mean the performances were any less winning or the concert's high points any less meritorious.

title: Rumanian Incident: 4 Conflicting Tales
description: Four conflicting reports have arisen over the reason that all three Rumanian female speed skaters and their coach returned home last weekend, before their Winter Olympics competition began. The reports revolved around defection, drugs, an automobile accident and a family matter.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES: THE BEAR ON THE BOBSLED
description: IN his red-white-and-blue Olympic warm-up suit, Willie Gault was holding forth on his sudden presence on the United States bobsled team. But he's always a presence. Although best known as a wide receiver for the Chicago Bears, he organized and was the lead singer of their ''Super Bowl Shuffle'' rap video. He has danced in a benefit ballet. He's studying to be an actor. And yesterday, between auditions for a bobsled part at the XV Olympic Winter Games on Saturday and Sunday, he was surrounded by several photographers.

title: Ideology of the Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Share earnings results are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 1.

title: Calton Investor Plans Takeover
description: Michael S. Weinstein, the chairman of Coated Sales Inc., has purchased a 5 percent stake in Calton Inc. class A common stock and said he plans to acquire control of the company through a tender offer.

title: Goodrich to Sell Complex in Akron
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company announced plans to sell its vacant 27-building downtown complex to the Covington Capital Corporation, a group of New York developers. Terms were not disclosed, but Goodrich's treasurer, Robert A. McMillan, described the price as nominal.

title: 'Prison Program' Lets Families Do the Talking
description: THE young boy talks too loudly into the telephone, his mouth too close. ''Hello Daddy,'' he says. ''It is nice outside here. My birthday is soon. I will be 6. When will you come home? I love you.'' He is not sure his father is listening, but he can be fairly certain that thousands of other people are. This is ''The Prison Program,'' a weekly radio show that allows the relatives of inmates to telephone station KPFT-FM and have their words broadcast to their fathers, brothers, husbands or sons. (There are no women's prisons within the 80-mile reach of the station's signal.) The inmates cannot answer.

title: Fragmented Health Care Hurts the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz Expected to See Sakharov in Moscow
description: To dramatize the Reagan Administration's campaign for improvement in the Soviet human-rights record, Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to meet with Andrei D. Sakharov and other rights campaigners when he visits Moscow early next week, a senior Administration official said today.

title: BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $1,700,000 and $9,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from early retirement of debt, and the year also includes net from discontinued operations of $2,000,000 and a tax benefit of $41,400,000. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $130,100,000 for the quarter and $268,200,000 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $19,400,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year.

title: FURNITURE YOU WON'T FIND IN CONRAN'S
description: IT is not your ordinary clock: a larger-than-life bust of a man with pointed ears and a leering grin, holding an orb with a simple clock on its face. Sculptured in papier-mache by Adam Kurtzman of New York, the piece is gilded and lacquered and looks like a surreal cartoon in three dimensions.

title: Circle K Studies Charter Store Deal
description: The Circle K Corporation, in a bid to increase its market share in the South and Northeast, said it was considering buying 538 gasoline and convenience stores from the Charter Company for $120 million. Circle K, based in Phoenix, already operates 3,562 stores, mostly in Western states, and is the nation's second-largest convenience store operator after the Southland Corporation's 7-Eleven subsidiary.

title: P.L.O. SCUTTLES SHIP PLANS
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it had shelved plans for a ''ship of return'' to take 130 deported Palestinians to Israel, two days after the vessel was bombed in a harbor in Cyprus.

title: CAMPAIGNS FOCUS ON RAISING FUNDS
description: With the first two electoral contests out of the way, most Presidential campaigns today began a frantic race for money.

title: Missing in Lebanon: Who the Captives Are
description: AMERICAN TERRY A. ANDERSON, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, missing since March 16, 1985. THOMAS M. SUTHERLAND, dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, June 9, 1985. FRANK HERBERT REED, director of the Lebanon International School in Beirut, Sept. 9, 1986. JOSEPH JAMES CICIPPIO, acting controller of the American University of Beirut, Sept. 12, 1986. EDWARD AUSTIN TRACY, author, Oct. 21, 1986. JESSE TURNER, visiting professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College, Jan. 24, 1987. ROBERT POLHILL, assistant professor of business at Beirut University College, Jan. 24, 1987. ALANN STEEN, journalism professor at Beirut University College, Jan. 24, 1987. LIEUT. COL. WILLIAM R. HIGGINS, a United States Marine officer who is head of an observer group attached to the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, Feb. 17, 1988. BRITISH ALEC COLLETT, New York-based journalist on assignment with the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, March 25, 1985. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems asserted on April 23, 1986, that he had been hanged in retaliation for the American air raid on Libya that month. His body has not been found. JOHN McCARTHY, cameraman for London-based Worldwide Television News agency, April 17, 1986. TERRY WAITE, Anglican Church envoy who had been seeking the release of foreign hostages, Jan. 20, 1987. FRENCH MARCEL FONTAINE, vice consul at the French Embassy in Beirut, March 22, 1985. MARCEL CARTON, the embassy's protocol officer, March 22, 1985. MICHEL SEURAT, researcher at the French Center for Studies and Research of the Contemporary Middle East of the French National Council for Scientific Research, May 22, 1985. On March 5, 1986, the Islamic Holy War group asserted that he had been killed. JEAN-PAUL KAUFFMANN, journalist working for the French weekly L'Evenement du Jeudi, May 22, 1985. INDIAN MITHILESWAR SINGH, visiting professor of finance at Beirut University College, Jan. 24, 1987. IRISH BRIAN KEENAN, teacher at the American University of Beirut, April 11, 1986. ITALIAN ALBERTO MOLINARI, businessman, Sept. 11, 1985. NORWEGIAN WILLIAM JORGENSEN, worker for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, Feb. 5, 1988. SWEDISH JAN STENING, employee of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, Feb. 5, 1988. WEST GERMAN RUDOLF CORDES, businessman with Hoechst AG, Jan. 17, 1987. RALPH RUDOLF SCHRAY, employee of a Beirut chemical company, Jan. 27, 1988. UNKNOWN NATIONALITY Two people of unknown nationality were kidnapped on Jan. 26, 1987. (Source: Associated Press)

title: BABBIT WON'T 'OVERSTAY WELCOME'
description: On the 618th day of his campaign, Bruce Babbitt stopped campaigning. Instead, he drank a chocolate milkshake, read telegrams urging him to stay in the Presidential race and took his sons to the Lincoln Memorial so they could read the Gettysburg Address etched in bronze there.

title: Music: Pogorelich Plays
description: IVO POGORELICH is a remarkably talented pianist who can be a remarkably infuriating one.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHO AM I THIS TIME? Uncovering the Fictive Personality. By Jay Martin. 255 pages. Norton. $18.95.

title: Mardi Gras Accidents Kill 2
description: Two people were killed in separate Mardi Gras accidents Tuesday. One of the victims was an 11-year-old boy, Michael W. Dupree, who, watching a parade in suburban Gretna, reached for a trinket under the wheels of a truck that was pulling a float, and was crushed. About two hours later an unidentified man in his early 20's was killed when he ran up to a truck float in city traffic, leaped between the cab and the float, lost his grip and slipped beneath the tires.

title: ST JUDE MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VISIONARY'S DREAM CITY ON PAPER
description: SMALL and scruffy and held together, it seems, only by the strong will of a dedicated few, the Storefront for Art and Architecture, in SoHo, occupies a critical place in New York's artistic ecology. The gallery specializes in idealistic work done by artists who choose not to show in commercial galleries.

title: Jazz: Luis Resto Show At Dance Workshop
description: BITS of cabaret parody, Tom Waits's Americana, jazz-rock fusion, Charles Bukowski's poetry, theater and humor collided Monday for Luis Resto's show at the Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street.

title: Soviet Skater First After Compulsories
description: In the arcana of competitive figure skating, the operative words today were ''outside rocker,'' ''paragraph double three'' and ''back change loop.''

title: Wright Preparing Aid Package for Contras
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, said today that he was preparing a new package of aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that would continue supplying them at current rates of about $1.8 million a month.

title: TENNANT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEDCO CONTAINMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results of operations for the year-ago periods have been restated to reflect the merger of Porex Technologies Corp., then a 54.1 percent holder of Medco's common, into Medco effective Sept. 10, 1987, and a 5-for-4 stock split effective Nov. 4, 1987.

title: French Jet Venture For Westinghouse
description: Electronique Serge Dassault said it had agreed with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, based in Pittsburgh, to develop on-board data transmission systems for new-generation military aircraft. A spokeswoman for the French concern gave no financial details but said the two companies had been holding talks since mid-1987. The venture would include work on a transmission system for the Rafale jet being developed by Avions Marcel Dassault-Breguet Aviation.

title: FGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes writedown of $1.2 million for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a $2.2 million writedown in the third quarter. c-Includes realized investment gains of $553,000 for the quarter and $1,360,000 for the year. d-Includes realized investment losses of $12,000 and realized investment gains of $530,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings are fully diluted. The company said the writedowns were due to the company's conversion to a new computer system and to staff reductions.

title: Everybody in the Act
description: ''Whatta catastrastroke,''

title: Switzerland Extradites Fugitive Italian Financier
description: A financier accused of masterminding a web of criminal and political conspiracies involving many of the most powerful men in Italy was extradited from Switzerland today in a predawn police operation, officials said.

title: Top New York Court Backs Tas Break for Developers
description: New York State's highest court yesterday unanimously upheld a state law that granted tax abatements to both commercial and residential space in new, mixed-use apartment buildings.

title: Manila Says At Least 33 Die In Ambush and Voter Clash
description: The Government said today that at least 33 people were killed Tuesday as political groups clashed during regional elections in Sulu Province and rebels ambushed a police patrol in Luzon.

title: Joseph Brodsky Begins Queens Reading Series
description: Joseph Brodsky, winner of last year's Nobel Prize in Literature, is to read from his works on March 7 at 7 P.M. at the Queens College Student Union, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing. Mr. Brodsky, who left the Soviet Union more than 15 years ago, gave his first poetry reading in the United States at the college. He will read in English and Russian.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; How They Like to Spell Frustration: B U D G E T
description: The arrival of President Reagan's 1989 spending blueprint on Capitol Hill Thursday marks the beginning of what has come to be an annual exercise in frustration and futility otherwise known as the Congressional budget process.

title: UNION VALLEY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflect a $1,285,000 pretax loss related to the company's withdrawal from its electronic security business, or about $700,000 after tax. c-Includes extraordinry gain of $281,000, or 8 cents a share, from termination of a defined benefit pension plan net of taxes.

title: New Baby M Decision Will Breed Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reduced by $7 million because of a change in accounting for sales incentives programs.

title: With New Hampshire Now History, Campaign Enters a Different Phase
description: After New Hampshire primaries that anointed no new leaders, the two parties' squads of Presidential candidates headed south and west today as the campaign emphasis shifted from small-state glamour events to the pursuit of larger blocks of national convention delegates.

title: Portugal Woos Two Aggrieved Ex-Colonies
description: Portugal and two troubled former colonies, Angola and Mozambique, are forming closer ties after more than a decade of tense relations.

title: Israeli Actions Raise Questions on U.S. Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Law and Ideology
description: Compare two Federal investigations.

title: Zurbriggen Falls Near Finish
description: This was to be his second gold medal in a collection that some thought would equal the five rings on the Olympic flag. Sometimes, though, even the mighty fall hard on the mountain, and today Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland had his first taste of snow when he least expected it -approximately halfway through the second slalom run in the Alpine combined, a race he needed only to survive to win.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Bridgestone's agreement to buy 75 percent of Firestone's tire-making operations described the status of a Tennessee truck-tire plant incorrectly. Bridgestone bought the plant from Firestone in 1983; it is not part of the current deal.

title: Presser Trial Delayed Again
description: Federal District Judge George W. White said Tuesday that he was rescheduling the start of the trial of Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union, to July 12 because of the 60-year-old labor leader's health problems. It was the second time the case has been delayed.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $111,857,000 for the quarter and net of $321,000 for the 9 months, from discontinued operations; the 9 months also included a $110,069,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $2,379,000 for the quarter and $10,442,000 for the 9 months.

title: Fire Kills AIDS Patient at a Manhattan Hospital
description: A smoky, fast-moving fire erupted near an oxygen respirator at Beekman-Downtown Hospital in lower Manhattan yesterday, killing a 26-year-old AIDS patient as he lay in his bed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abbott Laboratories, North Chicago, a maker of hospital, laboratory and diagnostic products, elected as a director H. Laurance Fuller, president of Amoco Corp., Chicago,

title: Creating Cataclysm In Six Easy Steps
description: A soap opera, by one definition, is a dramatic device to prevent a story from ending properly. The Senate debate over ratifying the treaty on intermediate range nuclear forces is beginning to look like a soap opera. This is because in diplomacy the United States has carefully devised an obstacle course that too often stands in the way of even simple agreements.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $8.4 million gain from the transfer of the Eagle Food Stores and a $1.3 million gain from the 1987 effect of capitalizing inventory carrying costs for the quarter; the year included net from discontinued operations of $26,420,000 and a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $5,907,000. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $182,050,000 for the quarter and $183,561,000 for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $7,315,000 from the early retirement of debt for the both periods. The latest year's net from continuing operations included a LIFO credit of $1.6 million. The year-ago quarter and year nets from continuing operations included restructuring costs of $15.9 million.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year includes an after-tax gain of $5,597,000, or 47 cents a share, from the sale of the company's cable television properties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Thursday about refunds to options investors misidentified a group that said it had received 356 complaints from investors about options trading. It is the North American Securities Administrators Association.

title: Film Board Names 2 Critics
description: David Sterritt, the film critic of the Christian Science Monitor, and Phillip Lopate, a freelance film critic, novelist and programmer for the Houston Museum of Fine Arts, were named to the five-member program committee of the New York Film Festival yesterday. Their appointments apparently end the troubles of the Festival, troubles that began last October when Richard Roud, long the Festival's director, was asked to resign.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1988
description: International A2-12, A17

title: Gooden Awaits Contract Decision
description: Unable to agree on the size of a pay cut, the Mets and Dwight Gooden argued their salary differences before an arbitrator yesterday. Roger McDowell, though, decided to forgo his hearing, scheduled for tomorrow, and agreed to the Mets' offer of $615,000 for this year.

title: SONY CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of yen 123 equal to U.S. $1.00, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of Dec. 31, 1987. Each depositary share represents one share of common stock.

title: Amoco Wins Big Judgment
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it had won a $383 million arbitration judgment against the Emirates General Petroleum Corporation, an agency of the United Arab Emirates, in a dispute over the nonpayment for natural gas.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Whalers 4, Jets 3: Carey Wilson scored twice last night to help end a seven-game unbeaten streak by visiting Winnipeg. Wilson, who has 17 goals for the season, including 8 in 14 games since being acquired last Jan. 3, scored both his goals on deflections. His game-winner came at 7 minutes 46 seconds of the third period as Wilson, in the slot, tipped in a low shot from the left circle by Ron Francis. (AP) Kings 5, North Stars 4: Luc Robitaille and Bob Carpenter scored 53 seconds apart late in the third period, rallying the Kings at Bloomington, Minn. Robitaille tied at 4-4 at 16:24 on a rebound for his 37th goal. He then set up Carpenter for his 17th goal at 17:17 in front of the net. (AP) Canadiens 3, Bruins 2: Mike McPhee scored winning goal from a goal-mouth scramble with 1:35 to play as Montreal snapped a five-game losing streak. With the puck in a swarm of players near the net, McPhee whirled to his backhand at the side of the crease and tucked the puck past Rejean Lemelin for his 18th goal. (AP) Red Wings 4, Blackhawks 3: Shawn Burr's short wrist shot midway through the third period snapped a final tie at Chicago. Burr fought off a check from the defenseman Dave Manson and scored his 11th goal of the season with 8:42 to play, giving the Red Wings their sixth victory in seven games and moving them 11 points ahead of second-place St. Louis in the Norris Division. Chicago, which had a four-game unbeaten streak snapped, tied the score at 6:53 of the third period. (AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 115, 76ers 107: Mark Price scored 28 points and Tyrone Corbin made a key defensive play late in the game to help send Philadelphia to its third consecutive loss and 11th in the last 14 games. The Sixers are 1-4 under their new coach, Jim Lynam. Cleveland, which has only eight road victories, two more than all of last season, led by 107-103 on a layup by Brad Daugherty with 2:19 remaining, but Albert King's 3-point shot put the 76ers a point behind with 2:11 to play. After Mark West and Ben Coleman of Philadelphia exchanged field goals, the 76ers had a chance to take the lead with just over a minute to play, but Corbin stripped Charles Barkley of the ball.(AP) Mavericks 123, Bullets 108: Mark Aguirre scored 15 of his game-high 35 points in the first quarter, boosting Dallas to an early 20-point lead. The Mavericks made their first eight shots of the game and shot 69 percent from the field in the opening period. John Williams scored 22 points and Jeff Malone 18 for the Bullets, who lost for the seventh time in their last eight games. (AP) Bucks 115, SuperSonics 93: Terry Cummings scored 20 points and the Bucks started the fourth period with a 21-5 spurt. Seattle, which lost for the eighth time in the last nine games, has not beaten the Bucks in Milwaukee since the 1982-83 season. The Sonics were led by Dale Ellis, who scored 26 points. Nate McMillan, averaging 8.3 assists a game, had 10 of Seattle's 14 in the first half and finished with 13.(AP) Nuggets 138, Celtics 125: Alex English matched his season high with 37 points and Blair Rasmussen scored a career-high 34 as the Nuggets swept the two-game season series from the Celtics for the first time. The Nuggets took control with an 18-4 spurt in the second quarter during which Rasmussen scored 10 points. He also collided with Larry Bird and broke Bird's nose. Bird, averaging 39.2 points since the All-Star Game break, scored only 13 and played only 6 minutes in the second half. The Celtics were led by Kevin McHale's 33 points. (AP) Tennis Becker Advances: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany overcame his erratic serve to defeat Sweden's Magnus Gustafsson, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the $500,000 Stella Artois tournament. Becker, the defending champion, managed only one ace to the Swede's four.

title: Crack Use Pervades Life in a Shelter
description: At the Fort Washington Armory in upper Manhattan, where 850 men sleep in one huge room, drug use, particularly crack, pervades every aspect of life and gives the shelter a mood of perpetual danger.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,307,000 and net of $63,497,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss of $3,697,000 for the quarter and income of $6,322,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Stabbing on a Jetliner
description: A passenger was slashed in the throat by another traveler on a flight from Panama to Miami on Tuesday, leaving the victim in critical condition and the man accused as his assailant under arrest. Eduardo A. Noel, a 35-year-old aviation inspector from Panama, was slashed with a pocketknife. Robert Dean Clark of Austin, Tex., and Corona Del Mar, Calif., was charged with attempted murder.

title: New York Through The Eyes Of Children
description: CROWDS and zoos, parks, drugs and dirty swimming pools: that's what New York City is made of, a panel of some of its youngest residents said Tuesday.

title: Drugs and Honduras: U.S. Concerned
description: The State Department expressed concern today that some officials in Honduras might be involved in drug trafficking, adding that the situation should improve when the Drug Enforcement Administration opens an office in that country in a few weeks.

title: Unions at The Post Offer Deal
description: With a deadline of 2 P.M. tomorrow looming, representatives of eight unions at The New York Post made a new proposal yesterday to representatives of Rupert Murdoch in an effort to avert the threatened closing of the newspaper.

title: Conspiracy Trial of 14 White Supremacists Begins
description: Opening arguments began in Federal District Court here today in the trial of 14 members of the white supremacist movement, including 10 leaders who are charged with seditious conspiracy by plotting to overthrow the Government by force.

title: Matikainen Takes Cross-Country Gold
description: Marjo Matikainen of Finland took the lead at the 4-kilometer mark today and held on to win the women's 5-kilometer cross-country ski race.

title: Health; New Approach Draws From Diverse Schools Of Psychotherapy
description: The rigid lines between psychotherapies - between behavior therapy and psychoanalysis, for example - are blurring as part of a movement to unite under a single integrated approach what often have been warring factions.

title: 'Welcome, Reptile,' Cont'd.
description: For failing to correct 400 code violations, Morris Gross, a 77-year-old Brooklyn slumlord, was ordered by a judge to pay $137,900 and to serve 15 days of house arrest in his sorely neglected building. Civil Court Judge Ira Harkavy meant to deter other slumlords as well as to give Mr. Morris a taste of the dreary conditions his tenants have to endure. The judge would better have given Mr. Gross a taste of jail before imposing house arrest. Worse, it now appears that the defendant will be given time off -for ''good behavior.''

title: Drinking Themselves to Death
description: Rutgers University has now banned fraternity and sorority parties indefinitely, too late to save James Callahan but maybe soon enough to keep other young people from drinking themselves to death. That's what Mr. Callahan, an 18-year-old freshman, apparently did at an initiation party.

title: Divided Labor Leaders Forgo Picking Presidential Favorite
description: When it comes to Presidential politics, the mood of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council these days is one of indecision. But that is not necessarily regarded by many as a bad thing.

title: VISIONTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a charge of about $2,279,000 to write down the carrying value of certain production equipment, a charge of about $437,000 to write off certain license agreements, a charge of about $1,088,000 relating to the writeoff of goodwill acquired as part of the Softsite acquisition in June 1986, and a credit of $1,071,000 relating to the recognition of R&D income for which no additional expenditures are to be incurred. c-Net income

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Breaking Stalemate in Demjanjuk's Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $107,000 and $411,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the repurchase and early retirement of debt. c-After extraordinary charges of $499,000 for early retirement of debt. The company said the latest quarter and year nets reflect pretax charges of $1.3 million and $1.8 million, respectively, related to a plant consolidation and both the quarter and year include $475,000 in acquisition costs written off after a proposed acquisition was opposed by the Federal Trade Commission, and the year also includes a net gain of $858,000 resulting from the conversion of debt into a subsidiary's common stock.

title: Two Texas Issues Total $313 Million
description: Two issues of double A-rated tax-exempt bonds totaling $313 million were offered by issuers from Texas yesterday.

title: Federated Holders Get Sweetened Tender Offer
description: The Campeau Corporation turned yesterday to the shareholders of Federated Department Stores Inc., raising its cash tender offer by $14, to $61 a share.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday and a brief sports report about the New Jersey Devils' attempts to sign Soviet hockey players misidentified one player. He is Vyacheslav Fetisov, not Fetislov.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1988
description: The Economy

title: KOMAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $750,000 for the quarter and $2,845,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: The Stage: 'Woman in Mind'
description: THE true test of an artist, whatever the art form, is often to be found in the half-tones, not the primary colors. Stockard Channing, an actress whose indelible recent performances in ''The House of Blue Leaves'' and ''Joe Egg'' leave her with little need to prove anything, subjects herself to this rough test and triumphs in ''Woman in Mind,'' the modest but watchable Alan Ayckbourn play at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: ECONOMY GROWING AT SLUGGISH PACE, LATEST DATA SHOW
description: The Government released two reports today that indicated the economy would continue to expand, though at a sluggish pace.

title: Paper for All Purposes
description: ''PAPER is a common denominator of all my interests,'' said Wendy Stewart, owner of 80 Papers. ''I like photography, calligraphy and bookbinding. Paper is so important for all those things. Also, I really love Oriental things, and the Japanese make wonderful paper.''

title: Joffrey Plans New Ballet For Its 1988 Season
description: The Joffrey Ballet will present a new ballet, ''Concerto Grosso'' by James Kudelka, as the highlight of its 1988 season. Set to music by Jean Papineau-Couture, a Canadian composer, ''Concerto Grosso'' was commissioned for the 1988 Winter Olympic Festival in Calgary, Alberta.

title: ITT's Profit Up Sharply
description: The ITT Corporation's net income soared in the fourth quarter of last year to $447 million, from $102 million a year earlier. Revenue in the period rose by 10.6 percent, to $5.2 billion from $4.7 billion.

title: China Studies Subsidies
description: Acting Prime Minister Li Peng said today that the Chinese Government might expand its subsidies of important commodities to cut the inflation rate, which hit 7.5 percent last year. In a speech marking the Lunar New Year, Mr. Li said the rapid rise in prices, especially for food, was China's most pressing economic problem, the official New China News Agency reported. He did not specify which subsidies would be increased or by how much. Any such move would be a dramatic step away from the Government's goal of gradually letting market forces take over.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
