description: b-After a $45 million increase to one- time charges related to the divestiture of the company's diagnostic imaging business for the quarter and one-time charges of $380 million for the year.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a $35 million oil and gas writedown.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Texas Southwestern Medical Center misstated the patient-admissions policy of its major teaching unit, Parkland Memorial Hospital. Private patients account for about 10 percent of Parkland's admissions.

title: Injustice in an 'Obscenity' Case
description: LEAD: Memo: To Justice William J. Brennan Jr. A new book is out, ''Black Mondays: Worst Decisions of the Supreme Court,'' by a Washington lawyer, Joel D. Joseph, with a foreword by your brother Justice, Thurgood Marshall. I regret to say that it includes a decision that you wrote, in Ginzburg v. United States.

title: Ski Jumping, Luge Put Off
description: High winds forced the postponement of two events today and officials feared that the disruptive weather pattern would continue.

title: Housing Aides Are Charged In Bribe Case
description: Four of the 10 supervisors responsible for awarding more than $55 million a year in contracts to repair housing owned by New York City were charged yesterday with accepting bribes from private contractors.

title: Resnik Family in Settlement Over the Challenger Disaster
description: The parents of the astronaut Judith Resnik said they had reached a multimillion-dollar settlement with Morton-Thiokol Inc. over the death of their daughter in the Challenger disaster.

title: Rikers Inmates Set Up Barricades
description: Rebelious prisoners erected barricades early this morning in a dormitory area of the Rikers Island prison, authorities said.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sudan Makes Debt Plea
description: The Sudan, crippled by drought and war, appealed to its creditors today to give it 40 years to repay its foreign debt of about $12 billion.

title: Suspect in Murders and Rape In Brooklyn Arrested on L.I.
description: A Brooklyn man wanted in connection with the fatal stabbing of his wife and stepson and with the rape of his stepdaughter was arrested today. the police said.

title: C.F.T.C. Nominee Gains
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved the nomination of Wendy Gramm to be chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The full Senate may vote on her nomination this week, Senate staff members said.

title: INSIDE
description: Housing Supervisors Seized

title: Japan's Resilient Exporters
description: By reducing costs, Japanese manufacturers remain competitive, even as the strong yen has made their goods more costly overseas. Page D1.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Jewelmark Originals to Kovics & Kovics to introduce the Faberge collection of fashion jewelry.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dow Declines 4.98 Points, to Just Over 2,000
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average barely remained above the 2,000-point level it had penetrated on Tuesday.

title: Gretzky Ties Howe Mark
description: Wayne Gretzky tied the National Hockey League career record for assists tonight, setting up Mark Messier's goal as the Edmonton Oilers tied the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-4.

title: Calendar: For Gardeners and Explorers
description: Senior Gardeners

title: Salvador Rebels Kill 12 in Raid on City
description: Salvadoran guerrillas killed a family of seven and five soldiers early today in a poorly executed attack aimed at the main army headquarters in this eastern city.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ARGUING with our children is as much a part of being a parent as nurturing them.

title: Pop: Jack Jones Returns To Sing in Manhattan
description: JACK JONES is a crafty saloon singer with a deeper feel for jazz and a more sophisticated sense of humor than such signature songs as ''The Impossible Dream'' and ''The Love Boat'' might lead one to believe. In the history of pop crooning, he stands as the stylistic link between Frank Sinatra and Barry Manilow, with stronger leanings toward the former. Punching out pop standards, Mr. Jones can be almost as brawlingly visceral as Mr. Sinatra in his swinging mode. The more contemporary aspect of his musical personality surfaces in pop-rock ballads like ''I Am a Singer,'' his newest album's title song, which is a stylistic clone of Mr. Manilow's 1975 hit ''I Write the Songs.''

title: 11-Year-Old in College Dreams of M.D. Degree
description: The desks are far too big, but other than that, Kristen Banerjee, an 11-year-old premedical student, said she felt perfectly at ease on the Lee College campus.

title: Rescued Boy Quits Hospital
description: A 9-year-old boy who was trapped 40 minutes under the ice of a frozen pond walked out of the Medical University of South Carolina Hospital today, smiling shyly at reporters. The boy, Kendall Smith, and two other children were playing on the pond Jan. 12 when the ice gave way. His companions were rescued quickly but it was almost 40 minutes before Kendall was rescued. Doctors have said he is one of about five children known to have recovered after having been under water for more than 30 minutes.

title: Dole Must Now Face Hard Battles in South
description: The history of Presidential politics is replete with the stories of candidates who are given an opportunity to clinch a nomination early - and just miss. The candidates who just miss are usually forced into exhausting and dispiriting marathons that, as often as not, end in failure.

title: Board of Trade Reduces Limits
description: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade voted on Tuesday to reduce daily price limits for Major Market Index futures to 20 points and Institutional Index futures to 12 points. The changes will become effective only if approved by the Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission. A 20-point move in the Major

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegis Corp., Chicago, parent of United Airlines, said it had started its tender offer to buy up to 35.5 million common shares at $80 a share.

title: NEW YORK COURT STRIKES DOWN LAW TO CURB LOITERING
description: In a case affecting hundreds of homeless people in New York City, the state's highest court ruled today that a law banning loitering in major transportation centers like the Port Authority Bus Terminal and Pennsylvania Station was unconstitutional.

title: A Settlement In Silver Case
description: A company accused of cornering the silver market with the Hunt brothers of Texas in 1980 has agreed to pay a Peruvian company $3.65 million in an out-of-court settlement, a lawyer for Minpeco S.A. said today.

title: NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $14.8 million from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss of $112.9 million from extinguishment of debt.

title: Man Held in Wife's Beating
description: A Bethpage man was arrested and charged wifh severely beating his newlywed wife on Valentine's Day, the Nassau County Police said late today. A police spokesman, Officer Charles Koller, said no details on the arrest of the man, Thomas Porcella, 30 years old, were immediately available. The woman, Anne Marie Porcella, 24, is listed in critical condition with a fractured skull at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.

title: Hundreds of Bronx Nurses Call In Sick at 2 Hospitals
description: Hundreds of nurses at two Bronx hospitals called in sick yesterday to protest what they said were deplorable working conditions that prevented them from providing patients with adequate care.

title: Lawsuit Challenges Census on Illegal Aliens
description: Forty members of Congress, arguing that including illegal aliens in the 1990 census would deprive some states of seats in the House, plan to file a lawsuit to force the Census Bureau to exclude the aliens from calculations for the next Congressional reapportionment.

title: Jay Leyda, Film Historian, Writer And a Student of Sergei Eisenstein
description: Jay Leyda, a film historian and professor of cinema studies at New York University, died of heart failure Monday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 78 years old.

title: Opposition to Steagall Act
description: More than three-quarters of the chief financial officers of the nation's largest non-financial corporations favor the repeal of a Federal banking law that separates commercial banking from securities underwriting, according to a survey conducted by the Senate Banking Committee and made available this week.

title: Jogger in Park Testifies He Saw Man and a Body
description: A doctor who was jogging in Central Park in the predawn darkness of Aug. 26, 1986, testified yesterday that he saw a man shaking an apparently lifeless body in woods behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art but did not stop to help.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE SERVICES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,522,000.

title: Surprises in the Academy Award Nominations
description: It was a year when Hollywood insiders despaired of accurately predicting the Academy Award nominations. And when the nominations were announced, they were even more surprising than expected.

title: Merrill Man Will Head Paine Webber Division
description: After struggling for a year to find within its ranks an executive to head its retail division, Paine Webber Inc. went outside for Joseph Grano Jr., it was announced yesterday.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,097,000 related to the repurchase and retirement of $762,000 of the company's 10 percent convertible subordinated notes.

title: REPUBLIC AMERICAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized losses of $47,000 for the quarter; the year includes realized gains of $17,000. Both periods include a tax benefit of 5 cents a share and 19 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, related to the fresh start allowance, which was partially offset by an incremental alternative minimum tax accrual of 3 cents a share and 11 cents a share for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes realized losses of $35,000 for the quarter; the year includes realized gains of $22,628,000.

title: Black & Decker Discloses Proposal
description: The Black & Decker Corporation disclosed that it had offered American Standard Inc. ''major concessions,'' including a possible higher price than its current bid of $65 a share, if the big plumbing supplier would agree to a friendly business combination. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Black & Decker said that Nolan D. Archibald, its chairman, had offered ''a pre-emptive price, board seats and financial arrangements for employees of American Standard,'' if a friendly transaction were consummated.

title: KEY RATES
Safety Board Executive Moves to US Air Group
description: Patricia A. Goldman, who spent much of the last eight years investigating airplane, boat and car crashes for the Federal Government, has crossed the Potomac River to become a senior vice president at USAir Group Inc.

title: Soviet Defeats U.S. in Hockey
description: The Soviet Union defeated the U.S., 7-5, last night, further dimming the American hockey team's chances of winning a medal in the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: Red Barber Honored
description: Red Barber, the baseball Hall of Fame announcer, was saluted on his 80th birthday at a ceremony yesterday in Tallahassee, Fla. Barber's career included 33 years with the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Yankees and the Cincinnati Reds. The Florida Cabinet declared yesterday ''Red Barber Day'' in Florida, and a birthday party was held in the state capitol building. Eddie Stanky, the former Brooklyn Dodger, wrote in a message to Barber: ''You are still in the catbird seat, and you are still the best as far as I'm concerned.'' In another message, Howard Cosell wrote: ''You are the man who has always told it like it is. A beacon light who never resorted to becoming a public relations arm for any team, any league, any organization.''

title: WANTED: DUMP WITH CHARM
description: NO matter what dump Marley the artist lived in, he managed to be evicted. Another artist, Daria, had a loft without a bathroom door.

title: Advertising; Elle Is Opening In China in July
description: Elle magazine will make its debut in China on July 14, as a result of an agreement between Hachette Publications, its parent company, and the Shanghai Translation Publishing House in Shanghai.

title: Whole-House Automation To Raise the I.Q. of the Home
description: FORGET about waiting in your bathrobe for the tub to fill or padding around at night to lock the doors and turn off the lights.

title: Tennessee Upsets Kentucky
description: Greg Bell made a 5-foot shot with one second remaining to give Tennessee a 72-70 upset over Kentucky tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: IN NEW WEST, A MUSEUM TO CAPTURE THE OLD WEST
description: A HUNDRED years ago the West was still ''the West of the Indian and the buffalo-hunter, the soldier and the cowpuncher,'' as Theodore Roosevelt described it.

title: What Do You Do After a Drubbing at the Polls? Claim Victory!
description: In the face of defeat, candidates in a Presidential primary can generally be counted on to do the obvious: claim victory.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $4,672,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $4,443,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Hand-Sanding Keeps Furniture's Quirks
description: LEAD: SANDING during the building of furniture has a dual purpose: smoothing surfaces and insuring that they are perfectly flat. Sanding a stripped piece to prepare the surfaces to take on another finish is not so demanding. On old furniture, the larger surfaces are rarely true, as there may be cupping or warping, or ridges where two boards have been edge-joined.

title: Charges and Cuts Seen At Lomas & Nettleton
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest mortgage bankers, said today that it expected to take write-offs totaling $93 million after taxes in the current quarter because of rising foreclosures and bankruptcies.

title: Health: Medical Costs; A Few Expensive Procedures Are Focus of Effort to Trim Bill
description: The coronary bypass operation, developed in the 1960's, was still uncommon 15 years ago. But as techniques improved, more Americans began to demand it and insurance plans began to pay for it. Thousands of lives have been saved by the procedure, in which blood is shunted around clogged portions of an artery to the heart.

title: Soviet Schools Sharply Faulted By Top Official
description: A senior Soviet leader said today that the education system is afflicted with underfinancing, rigid central control and physical conditions so primitive that 40 percent of schools have no indoor toilets.

title: ROBERT HALF INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $372,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss of $262,000 and $368,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. d-Includes a loss of $30,000 and $5,228,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, relating to assets spun off in connection with the June 1987 restructuring. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effected June 30. Latest quarter results reflect the company's acquisitions of Robert Half and Accountemps Personnel Services operations, which the company began acquiring in July 1986.

title: Icahn Proposes to Build Apartments in Morrisania for the Homeless
description: About 100 apartments for homeless families will be built in a poor area of the South Bronx under a philanthropic venture conceived by Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street takeover specialist.

title: Truce in Border Fight By Thais and Laotians
description: Thailand and Laos agreed today to a truce and disengagement in a disputed, sparsely populated border area where hundreds of their soldiers have been killed since November.

title: Market Place; Trump and MCA: Doubts Arise
description: SOME investors have begun to have doubts about the plans of the developer Donald J. Trump to take a large stake in MCA Inc. After rising nearly $8 in the previous two days of trading, MCA's shares fell $2.25, to $45.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Dukakis, Talking Tough, Marches Into Dixie
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts crossed the Mason-Dixon line today with a display of flag-waving and muscular oratory, attempting a pre-emptive strike against the idea that he is too liberal for the South.

title: Redmen Walloped At Carrier Dome
description: St. John's, overmatched at nearly every position, took a wicked thrashing tonight.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: As the serious and possibly life-threatening effects of body-building steroids become better known, specialists are increasingly alarmed about the growing use of these drugs by college and high school athletes and by teen-age boys who want an athlete's body without the work.

title: GARDEN DESIGNS FOR ALL AGES
description: ''IF you're not careful, a sandbox can be disgusting - a huge kitty-litter bin,'' said Dudley Mason. Ms. Mason and her partner, Signe Nielsen, are landscape designers who specialize in city gardens. But coping with a sandbox is only one of the myriad concerns in planning a garden for a family with children.

title: OPPENHEIMER CAPITAL LP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago results are pro forma. The company went public July 9, 1987. The share earnings are in partnership units.

title: Football Awards
description: Walt Hameline of Wagner, whose football team won a national title, has been named Division III coach of the year. Receiving Lambert/Meadowlands Cups as the best Eastern teams in their divisions were Syracuse (Division I-A), Holy Cross (Division I-AA), Indiana, Pa. (Division II) and Wagner (Division III). Don McPherson, the Syracuse quarterback who was second to Tim Brown of Notre Dame in the Heisman Trophy voting, received the E.C.A.C. Player of the Year Award for Division I-A. The I-AA award went to Jeff Wiley, the Holy Cross quarterback who led the nation in passing efficiency. The other Player-of-the-Year awards went to Al Niemela, West Chester State, quarterback (Division II); Chris Hickey, Bates, running back (Division III New England); Ray DeCarr, Ithaca, quarterback (Division III Upstate New York); Chuck Downey, Stony Brook, defensive back and kick returner (Division III Metro New York-New Jersey), and Anthony DiGrazia, Wilkes, wide receiver (Division III South).

title: Talks Collapse in a Racial Attack Case
description: After two days of talks, lawyers for a black Dutchess County teen-ager who says she was abducted and raped by six white men indicated yesterday that they would not for now permit their client to cooperate with a state investigation. Although both sides said that they were at an impasse, they indicated that they were open to further discussion.

title: A REMODELED ROOM COMFORTS AIDS PATIENTS
description: THE 44 residents of Bailey House, an AIDS hospice in the former River Hotel on Christopher Street, already had rooms of their own. What they wanted was rooms together: lounges in which to socialize, read and prepare food. A room on each of the four floors was designated as a lounge, but the spaces needed work.

title: Swede Wins in 5,000 Meters
description: Tomas Gustafson of Sweden, the 1984 gold medalist who nearly gave up his sport two years ago, won another gold medal in 5,000-meter speed skating today.

title: HERS
description: ''POVERTY stinks,'' Bette exlaims when we meet at a faux-Nantucket seafood house in Santa Monica. Is she comparing herself with illegal aliens or the Rockefellers, I wonder. She is wearing a $300 orange and purple quilted satin jacket over a $400 crushed velvet skirt.

title: Gardiner C. Means, 91, Is Dead; Pricing Theory Aided U.S. Policy
description: Gardiner C. Means, an economist whose theory regarding pricing practices in some industries was influential in setting national policy in the New Deal and later when inflation struck after World War II, died of complications from a stroke Monday. Dr. Means, who was 91 years old, suffered the stroke six months ago at his home in Vienna, Va., where he died.

title: Gladys G. Calkins, 90; Y.W.C.A.'s President
description: Gladys Gilkey Calkins, a former president of the Y.W.C.A.'s of the United States, died of a respiratory ailment Tuesday at Goodwin House, a retirement home in Alexandria, Va., where she lived. She was 90 years old.

title: TYCO TOYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $526,000 and $671,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: 2 Former Executives Of Beech-Nut Guilty In Phony Juice Case
description: A former chief executive of the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation and another former executive were found guilty yesterday of violating Federal laws by intentionally distributing phony apple juice intended for babies.

title: Emotional Defense in Israel Nazi Trial
description: The time of trial is dwindling as the son sits in the front row of the theater audience watching his father on stage, the older man all pink pate and owlish stare as he absorbs the accusation that he is the Nazi killer nicknamed Ivan the Terrible, the gas chamber operator of the Treblinka death camp.

title: Budget Fantasies, Deficit Realities
description: The budget that President Reagan submits to Congress today is effectively his last. But he need not fret about his waning power. He has already left his mark: a monumental legacy of deficits and debt. Mr. Reagan can claim to have rebuilt the nation's defenses, slowed the spread of government and cut taxes. Right: with borrowed money. The national debt has doubled in his Presidency, to $2.5 trillion. Interest alone now costs $140 billion a year, and counting.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Business People column on Friday misstated new responsibilities of the broker/dealer division of Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Societe Generale's Record Stock Price
description: The stock of Societe Generale de Belgique closed at a record high of 5,000 Belgian francs, or $143, a share, up 140 francs on the Brussels stock exchange today. The closing price was 1,000 francs above the price offered by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti in his public bid for 15 percent of the company.

title: A HOME ON THE MAKE-BELIEVE RANGE
description: FOR the first nine months Robert and Toby Smith lived in their 1909 redwood house in Ojai, Calif., they refused to furnish it in the one style that the house demanded: Western.

title: Sums Revised in Case Against Meese Adviser
description: Federal prosecutors have reduced their estimate of the amount of money that is unaccounted for that the investment adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d transferred to Hong Kong from 1985 to 1987.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Grey Earnings Rise
description: Grey Advertising has reported an 18 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings. It said on Tuesday that net income had climbed to $2.74 million, or $2.06 a share, from $2.32 million, or $1.66 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 26 percent, to $98.1 million, from $77.8 million. For the year the agency reported that profit was up 13 percent, to $10.3 million, or $7.43 a share, from $9.1 million, or $6.60 a share. Revenues climbed 21 percent, to $320.6 million, from $265.5 million in 1986.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; East Meets West
description: There is a circle in Washington for whom every week is German Week -an unending stream of visiting politicians and military officers, most from West Germany, including Chancellor Helmut Kohl this week.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption with the Sports of The Times column on Tuesday misidentified a skier. He was Christophe Ple of France.

title: Employers Endorse AIDS Guidelines
description: Some of the nation's leading companies and organizations yesterday endorsed a new 10-point ''bill of rights'' on AIDS issues in the workplace, formulated by a citizens' commission.

title: Talking Deals; More Japanese Investing in U.S.
description: THE pace of Japanese investment in the United States continues unabated. The type of companies making acquisitions is changing, and so is the type of targets. This week Japanese companies have announced plans to make their largest investments in the United States so far - in a manufacturer and in a financial institution.

title: Leaner Japanese Manufacturers
description: After capturing big shares of markets around the world, Japanese manufacturers are now showing that they can hold on to them and still make money in spite of the strong yen.

title: TRANSCO EXPLORATION PARTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash charge of $284.7 million to reduce the book value of the company's oil and gas properties.

title: As Man Dies, a Friend Says E.M.S. Crew Refused to Help
description: A 68-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack in a Bronx church last night and a friend of the man said that he had urged a city ambulance crew buying sandwiches at a delicatessen to come to the man's aid, but that the paramedics refused.

title: U.S. Aides Sought North Inquiry in '86
description: More than half a year before the secret White House resupply network to the contras was exposed, a young prosecutor and a Federal agent in Miami were repeatedly frustrated in their attempts to pursue a criminal investigation of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others, according to private testimony released today.

title: Love That Turned to Hate Is Linked to the Killing of 7
description: A man's obsession for a woman who spurned his love ignited a violent spasm of gunfire that left seven people dead and four others wounded at a high-security military plant here Tuesday, police investigators said today.

title: Music: Jazz Passengers, A Modernist Septet
description: SEVEN seems to be a lucky number for avant-gutbucket jazz. Henry Threadgill's seven-member Sextett, the Microscopic Septet and now the seven-piece Jazz Passengers make jazz that's smart and witty and raucous. For all its unpredictable forms and modernist dissonances, the music comes across as boisterous fun.

title: Rochester Asks Teachers for 'Extra Mile'
description: This city, determined to end the failure of its schools to educate poor inner-city children, is preparing to push the teacher-student relationship beyond the classroom, into the community.

title: U.S. Rally Comes Up Short Against Soviet Union
description: Chris Terreri, the losing goaltender, spoke of the pucks he didn't see flying his way, and of the Soviet skaters he and his teammates saw but couldn't stop. He also spoke longingly of a slap shot launched by Brian Leetch that the Soviet goaltender, Sergei Mylnikov didn't see, a shot that would have fulfilled a late comeback by the United States and tied the score at 6-6 had it not slammed harmlessly into the right post.

title: Critic's Notebook; Transcending Distractions in the Opera Audience
description: ONE of the signs of King Ludwig of Bavaria's supposed madness was his penchant for having Wagner's operas staged for himself alone, as he sat serenely and presumably undistracted in his Royal Box at what is now the Bavarian State Opera in Munich. Such waste! cried his critics, several of whom were politically motivated bureaucrats overseeing the Bavarian budget. Such nutty extravagance!

title: Health; Treatment For Cancer Is Criticized
description: Many cancer patients are not receiving state-of-the-art treatments that could prolong their lives, according to a new Federal report.

title: Suspended Policeman Denies Role In Beating of a Marijuana Dealer
description: A suspended New York City police lieutenant denied in court yesterday that he had abetted the beating of a marijuana dealer by other officers, and asserted that the beating never took place.

title: Rock: Bodeans at Ritz
description: THE Bodeans' sold-out show at the Ritz on Saturday was one more example that the best American popular music involves the audience - making music becomes the act of reinforcing, or inventing temporarily, a community.

title: The Child Will Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Bucharest Journal; It's Mother Nature, Not Ceausescu, Who Relents
description: An exceptionally mild winter, days on end of spring sunshine instead of the usual leaden skies of February, have brought an air of well-being to Bucharest. It is an illusion.

title: Alternative Minimum Tax Likely to Affect More People
description: The alternative minimum tax, long the bane of the upper-income set, will pose an even bigger threat this year to the pocketbooks of the rich and the not-so-rich who try to take too much advantage of tax breaks that were not swept away by the new tax law.

title: Ulster Police Order New Inquiry
description: The Northern Ireland police announced a disciplinary inquiry today against officers involved in the killing of six unarmed men in the province in three incidents in late 1982.

title: Court Refuses to Give Opinion on Shoreham
description: New York State's highest court declined to take a stand today regarding the Cuomo administration's efforts to block the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADR); each ADR represents 10 UK ordinary shares. Results are in U.S. dollars; U.S. dollar equivalent amounts are translated at the exchange rate of Dec. 31, 1987, one pound equals $1.83, and at Dec. 31, 1986, one pound equals $1.47. Results exclude British Caledonian Group Plc (BCal), which was acquired during the quarter.

title: Uruguayan Expected To Lead Latin Aid Unit
description: Uruguay's Foreign Minister, Enrique V. Iglesias, is expected to be elected president of the Inter-American Development Bank at a special meeting of its executive board Thursday, bank officials said today.

title: TV Review; Fireworks, Not Issues, In the News
description: IT peaked early, a minute or so before 7 P.M. on Tuesday. Vice President Bush, Peter Jennings reported, had ''pulled it out just by that.'' He gestured to indicate the size of the victory. How big was that? The ABC anchor wouldn't say; technically, the New Hampshire polls were still open. When CBS and NBC came on at 7, however, the polls were closed. Dan Rather and Tom Brokaw leaped in.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wood Fires Restricted By Resorts in Colorado
description: Worried that dirty mountain air might tarnish their image and turn away skiers, Colorado resort towns are clamping down on pollution from wood-burning stoves and fireplaces.

title: Assembly Minority Opposes Giving Addicts Free Needles
description: The State Assembly's Republican minority went on record unanimously today as opposing the Cuomo administration's decision to give hypodermic needles to some drug addicts as a possible way to halt the spread of AIDS.

title: Global Classrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a realized capital loss of $20 million and a realized capital gain of $3.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $10.6 million for the quarter and a tax credit of $49.5 million for the year. c-Includes realized capital gains of $19.6 million and $150.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively; gains on debenture repurchase of $100,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the year, and tax credits of $49.2 million and $177.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said in the latest quarter and year the net tax benefits from the fresh start provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 were $28 million and $177 million, respectively.

title: Access Talks In Japan Falter
description: The United States and Japan are almost back where they started months ago in trying to solve a dispute over access to the Japanese construction market, an American official said today. Although Japan's negotiators surprised the Americans with new proposals today, he said, they would effectively shut American concerns out of sectors where they are most competitive.

title: Road Team Announced
description: The five-man team that will represent the United States in a 50-kilometer (31-mile) relay road race against eight other national teams on April 9 in Manhattan was announced yesterday at the weekly luncheon of track and field writers at Madison Square Garden. The race, called the Asics Cup America's Ekiden, will be held in New York City, the first time an Ekiden race will be held outside of Japan. The American team will consist of Steve Scott, Mark Curp, Pat Porter, Mark Nenow and John Gregorek. Teams from the United States, Japan, England, France, the Soviet Union, Ireland, South Korea, Canada and Italy will compete in the race.

title: FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,847,000 for the quarter and $4,372,000 for the year; gains from an accounting change of $152,000 and $2,753,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $512,000 for the quarter and $13,199,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $63,563,000 and $50,783,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, gains from an accounting change of $22,933,000 for the quarter and $44,949,000 for the year, and the quarter also includes an extraordinary loss of $25,830,000.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BANISTERS, or balustrades as they are also called, consist of a handrail supported by posts and spindles (called balusters). Like staircases, banisters usually reflect the most sophisticated carpentry in a home. As a result, their construction may be mysterious to some homeowners because care is taken to hide all signs of fasteners.

title: MARINE WITH U.N. SEIZED IN LEBANON
description: An American Marine officer serving with a United Nations truce monitoring group was reported kidnapped today in southern Lebanon.

title: Liquidation Is Studied For Ticor
description: California's Commissioner of Insurance said late yesterday that she would seek to liquidate the TMIC Mortgage Company, the deeply troubled insurer of home mortgages, if a plan to save the company was not found soon.

title: E.P.A. Reports Dip in Lead Emissions
description: Emissions of lead into the atmosphere declined 59 percent in 1986, the second straight record drop, the Environmental Protection Agency said today in its annual report on air pollution.

title: Study Finds Most Health Insurers Screen Applicants for AIDS Virus
description: Most health insurance companies screen applicants for signs of the AIDS virus, and some consider sexual orientation a factor in deciding on eligibility, according to a Congressional study issued today.

title: Bond Prices Off in Slack Trading
description: Bond prices fell slightly yesterday amid slack investor demand.

title: Ford Pact Is Reached In Britain
description: The Ford Motor Company and unions representing its 32,500 workers reached a compromise Tuesday night intended to end a damaging 10-day strike. The tentative agreement, which workers will vote on Thursday, limits Ford's ability to introduce sweeping changes in work practices.

title: U.S. Studying Injuries Linked to Child Car Seat
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating injuries linked to a children's automobile seat made by Fisher-Price to decide whether they merit a Federal recall action.

title: High on the Hog in the Cattle Country
description: Wearing a stetson, a western-cut jacket, pointed boots and a silver belt buckle, Rob Brown was in garb that seemed the uniform of the week at Orange County's big convention center here.

title: Alain Savary, 69, French Official Who Set Off Protests Over Schools
description: Alain Savary, whose policies as Education Minister in 1984 provoked street protests, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: Arizona Senate Grants Mecham Week Delay in Impeachment Trial
description: The Arizona Senate today granted Gov. Evan Mecham a one-week delay of his impeachment trial, which had been set to begin Monday.

title: 'Uptight' Devils Fall Closer to Cellar
description: The Devils are in danger of falling into last place for the first time this season.

title: Home Loan Banks In Big Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday offered $2.32 billion of new bonds divided into one-, three- and five-year maturities.

title: COURT AUTHORIZES FORCING STERILITY
description: The Iowa Supreme Court said today that lower courts could authorize the sterilization of mentally retarded people but refused to say when the procedure was appropriate.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The cedar shingles on our 60-year-old home were originally stained, then painted several times. The paint is peeling, and I would like to go back to stain. Can the shingles be sandblasted professionally and then stained? A. The paint can be removed by sandblasting, but this could damage the shingles if not done carefully. As a rule, having the paint removed by using chemicals and pressure-washing is usually safer and more effective, but this, too, must be done carefully by an experienced contractor. After the paint is removed, the shingles can be stained. Q. We recently had our oak floors sanded and refinished with polyurethane. The company that did the job advised me not to wax or polish the floors, just damp mop occasionally. However, a friend who had her floors finished the same way 15 years ago has used polish on her floors and they still look like new. Who is right? A. I agree with your friend, and the condition of her floors proves it. Polyurethane is a tough finish that does not scratch easily, and many companies say that waxing is not necessary or even advisable. But in my experience occasional waxing or polishing does help to preserve the finish and maintain the gloss, and it certainly does not hurt. Q. A brown toilet shows white stains, although there is no such problem with my white toilets. I have tried many cleaners on these stains, but nothing helps. Can you help? A. It sounds as if water with a high mineral content is leaving the streaks. You cannot see them in the white bowls, because the stains are white. Usually, scrubbing with a toilet-bowl cleaner (let it soak on the stain first) or with a product like Limeaway will get rid of these streaks. If this does not work, scrub with Zud, a strong cleaner sold in supermarkets and hardware stores. The stains will probably come back in time; for a permanent cure you may have to install a water conditioner. Q. I painted the trim around my front door a year ago. It is now peeling and the wood under the paint is wet, almost soft. Is there any way to dry the wood sufficiently so that I can paint it again? A. You probably have some rot in that wood, as well as dampness, or it would not be soft. The bottom of the wood should not touch the ground, and there should be caulking around the trim that keeps water from seeping in behind it.

title: J. P. Morgan Loses a Top Credit Rating
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, the last bank holding company in the United States to hold the top rating of the two major credit-rating agencies, lost one of those ratings yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; Applying Logic And Equity To Welfare
description: New York State is spending $7.4 billion on aid to local schools this year and the State Education Commissioner says that if only he had three or four million dollars more he might be able to figure out where the money is going.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Bush Camp Plans to Attack Dole Sharply in South
description: A buoyant Vice President Bush won the 1988 New Hampshire primary, his aides feel, by avoiding the mistake that cost him the same event in 1980.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Moses Malone of the Washington Bullets has been fined $3,500 by the National Basketball Association for his part in a fight during a game against the Milwaukee Bucks on Monday. Jack Sikma of the Bucks drew a $1,000 fine. Five players were fined for an altercation during a game between the Indiana Pacers and the Phoenix Suns last Saturday. The Pacers fined were John Long ($2,500), Ron Anderson, Greg Dreiling and Scott Skiles ($500). Jay Humphries of the Suns was fined $1,000. . . . The San Diego Padres have raised Tony Gwynn's salary to $1,090,000 this season and to $1,190,000 for 1989. Under his old contract, Gwynn, the All-Star right fielder, was to be paid $840,000 this year and $940,000 in 1989.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Recession Forecast
description: Rudolph G. Penner, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, is predicting a recession next year. But until then he foresees nothing worse than a ''slowdown, and not a very severe one.''

title: 800 in Tel Aviv Hear Appeals for Talks
description: A dozen Israeli playwrights, poets and other intellectuals made an urgent appeal to the Government tonight to ''talk peace with the Palestinians.''

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $252.8 million, or $1.68 a share, on the sale of 24 percent of a British subsidiary for the quarter and year. ITT Corp. said net income for 1987 was aided by ''fresh start'' tax benefits at its Hartford Insurance unit of $100.5 million, or 67 cents a share, for the full year and $30.9 million, or 21 cents a share, for the fourth quarter. The 1986 full year results included a gain of $50 million, or 33 cents a share, on the sale of ITT's interest in Abbey Life Insurance Co.; income of $12 million, or 8 cents a share, from discontinued operations; a fourth quarter loss of $98 million from the transfer of the telecommunications manufacturing operations to the Alcatel NV joint venture, and fourth quarter after-tax provisions of $80 million for strategic reserve actions. ITT said that during 1986 it recorded an extraordinary charge of $46 million for the premium incurred in connection with the early retirement of several high interest debt issues and of this, $39 million was reflected in the fourth quarter. The company also said net for the full 1987 year was negatively impacted by the cumulative effect of an accounting change at ITT Defense Technology which amounted to $66.7 million and is charged against ITT's 1987 restated first quarter results. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Cause of Bissell's Death Ruled a Drug Overdose
description: The American Ballet Theater star Patrick Bissell died of an overdose of cocaine, codeine, methadone and other drugs, according to an autopsy report released today.

title: Cocaine-Related Death
description: A star football player at Forestville High School in Maryland died of cocaine intoxication, according to Dr. John Smialek, the state's Chief Medical Examiner. In a report in The Prince George's Journal yesterday, Smialek was quoted as saying that initial toxicological tests showed there was a considerable amount of cocaine in the blood and stomach of Rico Marshall, who died last Saturday. The report said that Marshall had idolized Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star who also died of cocaine intoxication. Marshall's parents have denied any knowledge about their son's involvement with drugs, including his arrest last year as a juvenile on a charge of possession with intent to distribute cocaine. The police said an acquaintance, identified as Belinda Hill, had told them that Marshall had told her that he had swallowed six ''rocks'' of crack, a cocaine derivative, to avoid being caught with the drug by the police early Saturday. The police said a search of Marshall's pockets produced six empty envelopes and about $150 in cash. Since he had no drugs, Marshall was released. He died about two and one-half hours later.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Pact to Protect Ozone Layer Goes to Senate for Approval
description: An international agreement intended to help protect the ability of the upper atmosphere to filter out harmful radiation was sent to the Senate today with a recommendation by the Foreign Relations Committee for approval.

title: Waldheim Linked to Nazi Roundup
description: The Justice Department based one of its principal charges against President Kurt Waldheim of Austria on captured German documents that point to his involvement in the deportation of 488 Yugoslav civilians to slave labor camps in 1942, possibly making him an accessory to war crimes.

title: Employers Adopt AIDS Code
description: Thirty leading companies and organizations endorsed a 10-point ''bill of rights'' on AIDS issues in the workplace. Page B11.

title: Peerless Pair
description: Every once in a while an athlete comes along who so outclasses the competition that he, or she, seems to be performing in a different event. That person has no real peer but himself; his only real contest is with his last performance. Torvill and Dean, who won an Olympic gold medal for ice dancing in 1984, are that kind of athlete. So are Ekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov of the Soviet Union, who this week won the gold medal for pair skating at Calgary.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $9,248,000 and $27,762,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After realized investment losses of $1,609,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $142,946,000 for the year.

title: U.S. EMBASSY IS HIT BY FIRE IN MOSCOW
description: A brief but intense fire swept through several rooms of the main building of the United States Embassy here today, disrupting operations five days before a visit by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: PRONET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $48,000 and $198,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $44,000 and $47,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Boitano Takes Lead
description: Brian Boitano and Brian Orser let the question of their Olympic supremacy linger on a bit tonight.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AST Research Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of computer hardware and software products, appointed Bruce Edwards chief financial officer and a senior vice president and Bruce Cassel senior vice president of United States sales.

title: Efforts Pressed To Avert Closing The Post Today
description: Differences between The New York Post and its unions were said to have narrowed yesterday, but two points threatened to overwhelm the negotiators and force the talks to come down to the deadline - 2 P.M today.

title: TOLLAND BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank did not report comparable figures for 1986 because it changed to a calendar year from a March 31 year. Also there were no per share earnings for the year-ago quarter because the bank converted from a mutual to a stock company on Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Brazil Agrees to Renew Meetings With I.M.F.
description: Ending a three-year boycott of talks with the International Monetary Fund, Brazil expects to start negotiations on a new borrowing arrangement next month and to conclude an agreement by the end of June, Finance Minister Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega said here today.

title: INMAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The latest periods include one additional week.

title: Bristol Journal; The Border War That's Fought With Billboards
description: A border war is brewing along Interstate 94, the major thoroughfare between Chicago and Milwaukee. It involves Wisconsin and Illinois and is being waged in three-foot-high letters on a pair of billboards at the state line just south of here.

title: Writer, Twice Restrained, Has New Salinger Book
description: Barred by the courts from publishing an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger by Ian Hamilton, Random House will soon publish what it describes as ''a substantially new book'' by Mr. Hamilton about the reclusive Mr. Salinger.

title: RAYCOMM TRANSWORLD INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net of $13,000 and $158,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss of $39,000 and $69,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Doubt, Not Materialism, Besets Freshmen
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRAL MAINE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior quarter and year included an after-tax writeoff of $11 million related to investment in nuclear plant.

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized losses of $25,531,296 for the quarter and realized gains of $27,731,277 for the year. c-Includes realized gains of $33,988,666 and $98,477,843 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Utility in Offering Of Option Bonds
description: The Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., offered $250 million worth of 8 3/4 percent noncallable first mortgage bonds yesterday at 99.72, to yield 8.82 percent to 1993, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds have a final maturity in 1998.

title: Martha Granger Krock, 87, Ex-Society Columnist
description: Martha Granger Krock, a former society columnist in Chicago and Washington, died of pneumonia yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She was 87 years old and lived in Washington.

title: 'MYSTERY!' AT OXFORD
description: ''MYSTERY!'' turns plummy tomorrow night. Chief Inspector Morse looks for a killer among Oxford's dons. The dons inhabit spacious, sunny offices amid turrets, spires and greens. Morse drinks ale, listens to Wagner, and solves difficult crossword puzzles in his bachelor apartment. There is not a handgun to be seen. The two-part series begins on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: Stage: Len Jenkin's 'American Notes,' at the Public
description: IN his plays, Len Jenkin has often taken us on dark midnight rides to mythic environments. With ''American Notes,'' his new play at the Public Theater, he leads us through a stretch of the American landscape. Though the route is almost as strange as ever, there are signposts, identifiable at least to those who have seen ''Buried Child,'' ''Blue Velvet'' and other baleful studies of small-town provincial life. As we are told, this place ''looks ordinary,'' but just outside, a potential rapist is abusing a car in a motel parking lot, an aged alligator named Bonecrusher is warming up for its day's activities and extraterrestrials are arriving from outer space.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Edward E. Rhatigan Dies at 78; Former New York Welfare Chief
description: Edward E. Rhatigan, a former New York City Welfare Commissioner, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 78 years old and had lived in Greenwich for more than 20 years.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $17 million and $52 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said that as a result of the 1986 Tax Reform Act, income taxes were reduced by $17 million in the latest fourth quarter due to the payment of a portion of the taxes on installment sales previously deferred at higher tax rates.

description: The per share earnings for the year- ago 9 months is not available; the company converted to stock form of ownership in October 1986.

title: TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iowa Team Fulfills A Coach's Dream
description: This is all her fault. Nearly five years ago, having just accepted the job of building the women's basketball program at the University of Iowa, C. Vivian Stringer stood before the lights and cameras and spoke of dreams.

title: Art: Skewed World Of Steve Gianakos
description: STEVE GIANAKOS in his new paintings at the Barbara Toll Gallery comes on at first like a cartoonist. A master of everyday embarrassments and nighttime fears, he touches terrain often worked over by others. Of old, we know his baffled businessmen. The house that goes out of control is also a familiar ploy, though one with unlimited potential. Such is Mr. Gianakos's succinct and telling way with line that we never fail to smile, and sometimes to laugh aloud, at what he sets before us.

title: NATIONAL GUARDIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $948,000 on repurchase of debentures. The year-ago quarter net was reduced by 7 cents a share as a result of the retroactive repeal of the investment tax credit.

title: CENTRAL BANK GETS ADVISE
description: Using the 1989 Budget Message as a platform, the Reagan Administration continued to warn the Federal Reserve Board today against clamping down on economic growth and pushing up interest rates.

title: Latin Aid Bank Selects Leader
description: Uruguay's Foreign Minister, Enrique V. Iglesias, who once headed one of the largest private banking groups in his country, was elected president of the Inter-American Development Bank today.

title: How Major Government Programs Would Be Affected by Reagan's Budget
description: Education

title: PAN AM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Pan Am said it posted $60.4 million of foreign exchange adjustments in 1987, compared with $46.8 million in 1986. It said the adjustments in both years were primarily related to yen- denominated debt. The latest fourth quarter included foreign exchange adjustments of $34.6 million, compared with a gain last year of $1.7 million. The 1987 results also include an $18 million provision for settlement of an age discrimination suit that is to be paid over the next three years, as well as $42 million for increased allowances for inventory obsolesence, uncollectible receivables, and costs associated with the worldpass frequent flyer program. The corporation also said its expenses in the latest fourth quarter and full year were further adversely affected by final adjustments to commission expense, outside maintenance services, and vacation accruals.

title: Sports of The Times; Relax, U.S. Will Survive Winter Games
description: All right, you Americans mourning the lack of medals at the Winter Games, open the blinds, let in some daylight and repeat after me:

title: The Law; Special Counsel Hires Expert
description: The independent prosecutor investigating the Iran-contra affair said today that he had retained Laurence H. Tribe, a leading constitutional scholar, to defend the 1978 law authorizing courts to appoint such special prosecutors.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds decreased $1.19 billion, to $276.85 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds decreased $1.32 billion, to $81.01 billion. The 208 general purpose funds had an increase in assets of $370.9 million, to $81.78 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased $235 million, to $114.07 billion.

Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Crew Gives Statement in Ambulance Inquiry
description: The New York City Emergency Medical Service said yesterday that it had received statements from an ambulance crew that was said to have refused to leave a Bronx delicatessen to help a man dying of a heart attack in a church a block away.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Fight for Green Space
description: About 70 citizens of a tiny Japanese coastal town paid $3,000 each to come to Washington this week to protest the proposed construction of United States military housing units in the last open green space in the Tokyo metropolitan area.

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Law; In Celebration of 'Dignified Frivolity'
description: Whereas the law profession is often perceived as ruled by arcane stuffiness and sartorial solemnity, and whereas it is considered stylishly unsafe for any one party to appear too different, be it known that one day each year the Manhattan firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts will henceforth spoof itself by celebrating the lowly bow tie.

title: Albany Fund Plan Seeks Road Bonds
description: Adding another wrinkle to the debate over how to spend hundreds of millions of dollars in surplus revenues that the state put aside last year, Assembly Democrats proposed today that half the money be used for a bond issue to pay for road and bridge repairs.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $8,300,000 and $2,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, charges from debt repurchase of $4,100,000 for the quarter and $28,100,000 for the year, and the quarter also includes a charge of $107,800,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $45,200,000 and $50,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a gain of $80,100,000 from an accounting change. The latest year includes a pre-tax provision of $401,100,000 from losses on properties and investments, compared with $25,900,000 in the previous year. The latest year share net is after $4,400,000 in accrued preferred stock dividends, compared with $10,300,000 in 1986.

title: U.S. Needs Help to Advance
description: It will take close to a miracle, and some unsolicited cooperation from the Soviet Union, for the United States hockey team to advance to the medal round.

title: Pickens Seeks Part Of Texaco
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman and corporate raider, has notified Texaco Inc. that he is seeking clearance from antitrust regulators to buy up to 15 percent of the company.

description: b-Included a tax credit of $446,000. The loan loss provision in 1987 was $1,276,000, compared with $4,431,000 for 1986.

description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $232,000 and $482,584 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $39,115 for the quarter and $81,115 for the year.

title: Jean-Paul Bourelly's Avant-Garde Jazz
description: Jean-Paul Bourelly, a young guitarist from Chicago, moved to New York eight years ago. He immersed himself in the avant-garde of the city, working with the composers Muhal Richard Abrams and Henry Threadgill, and playing with the saxophonist and band leader Steve Coleman.

title: Factory Use Unchanged In January at 82.2% Rate
description: The nation's factories, mines and utility companies operated at 82.2 percent of capacity last month, unchanged from December's levels, the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: The dean of Stanford Law School has called it ''the most innovative and exciting experiment in legal education in the country.'' A Harvard professor said it ''stands as a role model for all of us.'' And the president of the American Association of University Professors said it had pierced ''the barriers of methodology, subject matter and admissions standards which have shackled much of legal education for nearly three decades.''

title: Is Central America Ready for Self-Government?
description: To the Editor:

title: PICTURETEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Carter Hawley, Penney Gain
description: The J. C. Penney Company yesterday reported an increase in its fourth-quarter profit despite a slight drop in sales, while another important retailer, Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., also said it had stronger fiscal second-quarter earnings.

title: C.F.T.C. Head Is Confirmed
description: The Senate today approved the nomination of Wendy Lee Gramm as the next chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: More Time Allowed on Canada Pact
description: The Reagan Administration and Democratic Congressional leaders agreed today to allow the White House more time to present the Canadian free-trade accord to Congress for final approval. The agreement assures that a vote will be taken this year.

title: Lisbon Seeks Revision Of U.S. Defense Accord
description: Portugal plans to ask for a ''thorough overhaul'' of a 37-year-old mutual defense treaty with the United States that allows the use of military sites in the Azores Islands, the Portuguese Foreign Minister says.

title: Hewlett Net Rises 54.3%
description: Buoyed by strong sales growth in all its product lines, the Hewlett-Packard Company today reported improved revenues and earnings for its first quarter, which ended Jan. 31. Hewlett-Packard also said order levels were the highest for any quarter in the company's history.

title: Kennedy Sworn As 104th Justice On High Court
description: Anthony McLeod Kennedy took his two oaths as the 104th Justice of the Supreme Court today, in separate ceremonies at the Court and the White House.

title: Film: 'Lust for Freedom'
description: THE worst kind of exploitation film masquerades as a spoof, luring innocent but otherwise intelligent people to the theater. In ''Lust for Freedom,'' when an undercover detective sees her fiance-and-partner gunned down during a botched drug bust, she loses her professional demeanor and runs away in tears. ''Cops were dying all over the place and all I could do was act like a woman,'' she says, tearing off her brunette wig to reveal long blond tresses, rainbow-colored makeup streaming from her eyes. Soon she is kidnapped and thrown into a women's prison, where she bides her time until she can shoot her way out. Gillian (Melanie Coll) looks and talks like a romance-cartoon heroine, and we expect her to become a female mock-Rambo. There is something comically offensive in the idea that girls just want to be macho.

title: 'Indigo Blue,' Drama, At the Billie Holiday
description: ''Indigo Blue,'' the Billie Holiday Theater's final production of its current three-play repertory season, will open today. The new play, by Judi Ann Mason, is a drama of two middle-aged sisters awaiting the return of a man each once loved, The Billie Holiday Theater is in the Restoration Plaza complex at 1368 Fulton Street.

description: The year-ago periods' results included a net gain of $2.5 million from the sale of three plants.

description: b-After a tax benefit of $1,904,000. c-Net loss and after a tax benefit of $869,000.

title: In the Hall of Mirrors
description: Right now, I do not know whom I will vote for when New York State, where I live, holds its primaries. I do not know whom I will wind up voting for on Election Day nor whether the lucky fellow will be a Republican or a Democrat.

description: b-Net loss Results for year-ago periods are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB 96.

title: Du Pont Quits Republican Race; Babbitt Makes Pullout Official
description: Former Gov. Pete du Pont of Delaware, who had vowed last Tuesday night to take his battered Republican Presidential campaign south for the crucial primaries on March 8, capitulated to fiscal and political reality today and withdrew from the race.

title: '89 REAGAN BUDGET, A 'CONSENSUS' PLAN, GOES TO CONGRESS
description: In keeping with a bipartisan agreement reached last year, President Reagan today sent Congress a $1.09 trillion budget devoid of the ideological fervor that enabled a small band of committed conservatives to reorder Federal spending priorities in the last seven years.

title: Is Central America Ready for Self-Government?; Trained in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Nations Seek U.N. Debate on U.S. Plan to Close P.L.O. Office
description: Arab countries said today that they were formally requesting an emergency session of the General Assembly to debate an American move to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's United Nations observer mission in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Official and Africans Confer On Testing AIDS Vaccines There
description: Large-scale tests of potential AIDS vaccines may have to take place in Africa, a senior Federal health official said yesterday, and he has begun discussing the possibility with African officials.

title: Washington Talk: Nicaragua Peace Talks; American Sitting Opposite U.S.-Backed Rebels
description: When Nicaragua resumed peace talks today with with rebel leaders, it may have seemed strange to some that one of the four Sandinista Government delegates sitting opposite the American-backed contras was himself an American, Paul S. Reichler.

title: IMREG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Imreg is a start-up biotechnology firm and does not yet have revenue to report.

title: Sports People; Bird Expected to Play
description: Larry Bird, who suffered a broken nose Wednesday night in the Celtics' 138-125 loss to the Denver Nuggets, is expected to play tonight when Boston continues its trip in Portland, Ore., against the Trail Blazers.

title: V.A. UNDER ATTACK AT HOUSE HEARING
description: The Veterans Administration came under attack today as a chaotic monolith badly in need of reform.

title: White Supremacists, at Trial, Charge Persecution for Beliefs
description: Opening statements on behalf of white supremacists on trial here on charges of seditious conspiracy and conspiracy to murder Federal officials were completed today.

title: Ungermann-Bass Chairman Finds a Merger He Likes
description: When Ungermann-Bass Inc. successfully rebuffed a takeover proposal by Digital Communications Associates Inc. last November, analysts predicted that Ralph K. Ungermann would never agree to any kind of merger. But this week Ungermann-Bass, which produces local area networks that link computers, agreed to merge with Tandem Computers Inc., in a deal worth about $260 million.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dow Loses 14.58 Points, to 1,986.41
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell below the 2,000-point level yesterday as many cautious investors remained on the sidelines.

title: Sports People; Reed and Nets Meet
description: Willis Reed, the former Knick captain and coach who is Bill Russell's top assistant with the Sacramento Kings, has had his third interview for the Nets' coaching post. Bob Casciola, the Nets' executive vice president and chief executive officer, flew to Cleveland last Monday, where the Kings played the Cavaliers, to meet with Reed. They spent three hours together.

title: Ski Jumping Is Postponed
description: Gusting winds today prompted officials to postpone the 90-meter team ski jumping to next Wednesday.

title: Conde Nast Campaign Breaks Into Four-Color
description: It has been four years since Conde Nast Publications created a new trade campaign, and with its new one, beginning this month, it is moving away from its traditional black-and-white style.

title: Doner Effort For Arby's

title: Kane-Miller Voids Pact With P.I.P.
description: The Kane-Miller Corporation has terminated a standstill agreement with Postal Instant Press Inc. and is considering seeking control of the Los Angeles-based franchiser of printing centers, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Deficits Fill a Vacuum; Election-Year Surrender of Responsibility By Congress and Reagan Is Seen in Budget
description: For once, no one is calling President Reagan's budget ''dead on arrival,'' as Democrats in Congress described most of his earlier proposals and as indeed they turned out. The President and Congress have already agreed on the broad outlines of how much to tax and how much to spend, so the disputes this time are in the details.

title: UNION THREATENS STRIKE AT PAN AM
description: The head of the teamsters' union's airline division warned yesterday that the union would strike Pan American World Airways Sunday unless the airline withdrew what the teamsters called ''unreasonable'' contract demands or agreed to binding arbitration.

title: BOND PRICES END THREE-DAY SLIDE
description: Bond prices rose modestly yesterday after three consecutive days of declines.

description: FOR a United States-Soviet Union hockey game to succeed for the 80 million fans watching on television, the game has to be set up with dramatic tension.

description: Three New Yorkers and five community groups representing hundreds more were honored last night for their efforts to make the city a better place.

title: American Skier Injured in Practice
description: Instead of ski poles, Pam Fletcher's arms were wrapped round crutches, and her right leg was in a fiberglass cast. Only an hour before she was scheduled to be the first starter in the women's downhill at Mount Allan today, her Olympic hopes were ended when she broke her leg after colliding at the bottom of a warm-up slope with a volunteer course worker. Thus, she became the latest casualty in a star-crossed season for American skiers.

description: Local residents were told months ago that many Olympic events, including hockey, speed skating, figure skating and curling, were sold out. They have become angry because there have been large blocks of empty seats at these events.

title: Dr. Melville A. Platt, Hospital Official, 60
description: Dr. Melville A. Platt, a retired deputy director of New York Hospital, died of kidney cancer Monday at the hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Elmsford, N.Y.

title: Knicks Win 9th in Row at Home, 108-104
description: The Knicks beat the Sacramento Kings by 108-104 last night to run their winning streak at Madison Square Garden to nine games, their longest at home since the 1975-76 season.

title: Sports People; Wagner Star Sidelined
description: Dean Borges of Wagner, the nation's fifth-leading scorer with a 25.4 average, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee Wednesday and will be out for the rest of the season, said Coach Neil Kennett.

title: Jazz: Roy Haynes and Band
description: THE great drummer Roy Haynes drove his young band through a set of jazz standards at Visiones on Wednesday. Mr. Haynes, who's made significant contributions to jazz history by playing and recording with everyone from the saxophonist Lester Young and the pianist Thelonious Monk to John Coltrane, was on his band like a blanket, all set long.

description: To the Editor:

title: John Mackenzie Jr., Investment Banker, 70
description: John Mackenzie Jr., an investment banker, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Couples Takes Lead: Fred Couples capped a nine-under-par 63 with a birdie-birdie-birdie finish yesterday to take the opening-round lead at the $650,000 Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif. Couples, who lost the Phoenix Open in a playoff, birdied 10 of the 18 holes at the North course at the Torrey Pines Golf Club. Phil Blackmar, who at 6 feet 7 inches is the tallest player on the PGA Tour, birdied six holes in a row at one stretch and dropped a 60-foot eagle putt on his final hole for a 64 that left him one shot back.(AP) Two-Way Tie in Philippines: Steve Bowman of the United States and Hsieh Chien Seng of Taiwan each shot a four-under-par 68 to share the first-round lead in the Philippines Open. One stroke back were Mark Aebli of the United States, Yuan Ching Chi of Taiwan and Carlos Espinosa of Mexico. (AP) Tennis Cash Holds On: Five seeded players, including Pat Cash of Australia, swept into the quarterfinals with victories in the $500,000 Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. Cash overcame Sergio Casal of Spain, 6-3, 7-6. The victory moved Cash into the final eight against Yannick Noah of France, who rallied to beat Alex Antonitsch of Austria, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2. Henri Leconte of France, seeded seventh, defeated Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 7-6, 6-4. The Frenchman faces top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany. The third quarterfinal will match Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, a 6-4, 6-0 winner over Jonas Svensson of Sweden, against countryman Milan Srejber, who beat Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2.(AP) Edberg Upset: Unseeded Jim Grabb upset the defending champion, Stefan Edberg, 6-4, 6-4, in the $415,000 United States Indoor championships in Memphis. Except for a three-game lapse in the second set in which Edberg rallied from a 5-1 deficit to 5-4, Grabb dominated the Swede, the third-ranked player in the nation and the tournament's top seed. (AP) Lindqvist Upset: Unseeded Hu Na, who defected from China five years ago to play in America, upset eighth-seeded Catarina Lindqvist 6-2, 6-2 to move into the quarterfinals of the $250,000 Virginia Slims in Oakland, Calif. In another second-round match, third-seeded Hana Mandlikova blew a set point and a first-set tiebreaker before recovering to beat Elna Reinach of South Africa, 6-7, 6-1, 6-1. (AP) N.B.A. Pacers 88, Cavaliers 83: Steve Stipanovich drove round Brad Daugherty for the go-ahead basket with 1:11 left and the Pacers held the Cavaliers scoreless the rest of the way for their sixth consecutive victory. Chuck Person came off the bench to score a game-high 22 points for Indiana. (AP) Lakers 111, Rockets 96: Byron Scott scored 27 points and Magic Johnson 26, and they combined for 21 as the Lakers took a 20-point lead in the first quarter on way to their seventh consecutive victory. Michael Cooper of the Lakers suffered an ankle injury in and was carried from the court by teammates. The early diagnosis, according to Coach Pat Riley, was a sprain. (AP) Spurs 122, Suns 114: Alvin Robertson scored 31 points, Johnny Dawkins added 27 and the two led a decisive 13-0 fourth-quarter run as the Spurs snapped a five-game losing streak.Jay Humphries led the Suns with 26 points. (AP)

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Gulfstream Times Mystify Handicappers
description: How good a race was the Fountain of Youth Stakes last Monday, in which Forty Niner outdueled Notebook by a nose? Because the race was at Gulfstream Park, speed handicappers are still trying to figure it out, without much success.

title: More Wheat to Soviet
description: An additional 500,000 metric tons of subsidized United States wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. At recent prices averaging $2.82 a bushel, the wheat would have a value of $52 million. Nearly 5.7 million tons of subsidized wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union under the department's Export Enhancement Program for delivery in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.

title: UNITED BUILDING SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
6,000 Firefighters Protest Budget Cutbacks
description: Six thousand uniformed firefighters -almost half of New York City's force -paraded across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall yesterday to protest $11.2 million in cuts from the Fire Department's proposed 1989 budget.

title: Federated Shares Dip as Deal Stalls
description: The price of Federated Department Stores' common stock fell $1.75, to $60, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, suggesting that some investors may be growing uncomfortable with the lingering impasse in the Campeau Corporation's takeover attempt. Federated's directors rejected Campeau's $66-a-share offer on Tuesday, and the next day Campeau went directly to shareholders with a tender offer of $61 a share.

title: Violence of Workplace: Unseen Signs, Unexpected Explosions
description: When a shooting spree erupts in the workplace, workers everywhere are suddenly uneasy. The latent rage in an office or factory, a confined environment where self-esteem and financial worth are on the line, takes on new meaning.

title: Concessions by Sandinistas Asked In Peace Talks With the Contras
description: In an effort to break the deadlocked peace talks here, the mediator today offered his own peace proposal and asked the Nicaraguan Government to make major political concessions to the rebels.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1988
description: Companies

title: CUNY Final Is Tonight
description: There will be two objectives for College of Staten Island in the CUNY Conference basketball final tonight in Nat Holman Gymnasium. One is in the hands of the players, but for the other, the players can only keep their fingers crossed.

title: Late Flyer Goal Ties Islanders
description: When it was over, most of the Islanders talked somberly of the goal they gave up with 23 seconds left, another in an expanding series of infuriating late lapses and one that left them with an unsatisfying 3-3 draw against the Flyers.

U.N. AND AMAL SEEK ABDUCTED MARINE
description: United Nations forces aided by local Moslem militiamen virtually sealed off the southern port of Tyre and surrounding areas today in their search for a kidnapped United States Marine officer.

title: Irish Music
description: Martin (Buddy) Connolly on button accordion and Ken Vesey on fiddle will play Irish traditional music tomorrow at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: TWO NIGHTS OF SINGING THE BLUES
description: IN an ironic fit of democracy, the local music of some of the most dispossessed citizens of the United States - black, rural Southerners - has changed the nature of international life. The relatively small, 200-mile-long area known as the Mississippi Delta produces music full of pride, rebellion and emotion, a deeply felt version of the blues. It has become rock-and-roll, and in its international dissemination, the music has influenced how people think, move and act. And in America, where vernacular culture has provided both our musical high art and our tone as a nation, a study of Mississippi blues is a study of our common traits.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year includes a pretax loss of $1,909,000; prior year includes a pretax loss of $3,578,000 from costs related to the discontinuance and restructuring of certain operations.

The year-ago quarter results were adversely affected by a reversal of investment tax credits of $396,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: * British Petroleum Co., London, said it had received 79.8 percent of Britoil P.L.C.'s shares and that it was extending the closing date of its $:2.5 billion offer to next Wednesday.

title: Fake Food, Real Problems
description: LEAD: Dieters' hearts were set aflutter by recent announcements of two new fat substitutes, now under review by the Food and Drug Administration. The news accounts depicted the fake fats as veritable miracle workers. The nagging question is, Are they too good to be true?
