title: Richard Deneen, 49; Audit Bureau Official
description: Richard W. Deneen, senior vice president of auditing services for the Audit Bureau of Circulations, died of an apparent heart attack last Friday at Memorial Hospital in Woodstock, Ill. He was 49 years old and lived in Woodstock.

title: Sports People; Gretzky Ties Mark
description: Down by 2-0 after the first two periods, the Toronto Maple Leafs battled back to take a 4-3 lead in the third period Wednesday night before Mark Messier of Edmonton scored with 26 seconds left in regulation, giving the Oilers a 4-4 tie. But the goal gave more than that to Wayne Gretzky. It was his second assist of the game, and it enabled him to tie Gordie Howe at l,049 on the career assists list. ''Anytime I reach a record held by Gordie it's pretty exciting,'' Gretzky said.

title: Bridge: New York Pro-Am to Pair Novices and Life Masters
description: There is no normal way that a tennis tyro can hope to play with, say, Steffi Graf, or a golfing novice with Jack Nicklaus. But something of the kind can happen in bridge.

title: The Road To a Ticket
description: The Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary have mercifully passed away, mini-events - let us manfully refrain from calling them pseudo-events - that may have made it somewhat more likely that the Democrats will enliven things with a ''brokered convention'' at Atlanta next summer.

title: GIANT GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $6,315,000 for the quarter and the year includes tax loss carryforwards of $6,762,000.

title: An Opera Innovator Readies Britten Work
description: While New York's major opera companies continue their decades-long dithering over the establishment of a smaller alternative house, adventure and flexibility in opera productions is left to the small independents struggling for life in this city.

title: Elmar Oliviera
description: Elmar Oliviera, a violinist, will be the soloist with the conductor-less Opheus Chamber Orchestra in works by Mozart and Saint-Saens tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $11 to $20. Information: 247-7800

title: Classical Quartet
description: The Classical Quartet will present works by Boccherini and Beethoven on period instruments tonight at 8 o'clock in St. Michael's Church (225 West 99th Street). Tickets are $9, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 874-4037.

title: Sweep in the Luge For East Germans
description: Steffi Walter, who took last year off from competition to have a baby, led an East German sweep in the women's Olympic luge race.

title: NORTHWEST ILLINOIS BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
First Baby Is Placed in Organ-Donor Ward
description: A baby born with most of his brain missing has become the first patient in a special ward set up to use such infants to supply organs for transplantation, hospital officials said today.

title: Arbitrator Cuts Gooden's Pay $100,000
description: The Mets registered their first victory of the year yesterday, emerging as a philosophical and financial winner over Dwight Gooden in their salary-arbitration encounter. The outcome made Gooden only the eighth player of the 265 whose salaries have been determined by arbitrators to have his salary cut.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said that the changes in the U.S. federal income tax rates increased share earnings by 9 cents in the second quarter and 15 cents in the 6 months.

title: Standard Acts to Foil Decker Bid
description: In a move to thwart an unwanted takeover offer from the Black & Decker Corporation, American Standard Inc. said yesterday that its directors had approved a recapitalization plan that was ''financially superior'' to Black & Decker's cash offer of $65 a share, or $2.1 billion.

title: GEPHARDT'S ALLIES DELAY VOTE
description: It pays to have friends in high places.

title: SOVIET JEWISH ART, 1912-1928
description: The Russian Revolution fostered a brief though remarkable burst of artistic creativity that was particularly pronounced amoung many of the country's Jewish artists. Yet unlike others in the new Soviet avant-garde, many of the Jewish artists incorporated traditional and folk-art styles into their work.

title: A New Yorker Back From Paris Sees Home in a Dimmer Light
description: To the Editor:

description: A leading conservation group called today for reform and a major expansion of the national park system. The proposal drew quick support on Capitol Hill.

title: Anthony Newman
description: Anthony Newman will perform works by Bach on the new Rieger tracker organ in Holy Trinity Church (316 East 88th Street) on Sunday at 5 P.M. It is the first of three consecutive Sunday concerts by Mr. Newman featuring the complete preludes, fugues, toccatas and fantasies. Tickets are $7, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 289-4100.

title: FIRST SERVICE BANK FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings for 1986 was not available; the bank converted to stock form of ownership in August 1986.

title: ETHICS COMMITTEE URGES THE HOUSE TO REMOVE BIAGGI
description: The ethics committee of the House of Representatives recommended today that Mario Biaggi be expelled from Congress.

title: Yen-Denominated Paper From Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it had received approval from Japanese officials to issue yen-denominated commercial paper in Japan.

title: Sports People; Foreman to Fight Qawi
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, announced yesterday that the next opponent for George Foreman in the former heavyweight champion's comeback would be Dwight Muhammad Qawi on March 19 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: YOUNG DANCERS WHO STAND OUT IN A CORPS
description: THE New York City Ballet's winter season at the New York State Theater comes to an end this weekend with a number of public and private closing rituals. One of those rituals is the benefit performance on Sunday night, coordinated and introduced by Sean Lavery, for the Dancers' Emergency Fund, which provides help for City Ballet dancers facing crises without the necessary resources. A more private ritual is that last surveying look at the dancers who have shone this season. And this weekend offers a glimpse of some of the younger or newer dancers, still members of the company's corps de ballet, who have recently distinguished themselves. Some have danced lead roles. Some have begun to. And some simply dance their corps parts, night after night, with such verve, resonance and intelligence that they stand out in the crowd.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1988
description: International A2-8

title: FARM CREDIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the major factor in the drop in the loss for the Farm Credit Systems to $17 million for 1987 from $1,913,000,000 in 1986 was a $1,994,000,000 reduction in the provision for loan losses.

title: Art: African Artworks and Artifacts Shown in 2 Exhibitions
description: AT the moment, two exhibitions of African art that have just opened in uptown museums are igniting an unexpected dialogue and exchange of ideas. ''Art/ Artifact: African Art in Anthropology Collections,'' now at the Center for African Art, takes as its subject not so much African art per se, but the various ways Westerners have displayed it since the late 19th century. It sets out to examine how the different physical and institutional contexts of the art gallery, the ''curiosity room,'' the anthropology museum and the art museum can condition perceptions and different notions of value, moving objects back and forth on a sliding scale between art and artifact.

title: FILM: A NON-TURGENEV 'MONTH IN THE COUNTRY'
description: ''A Month in the Country'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27. The film opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, at Third Avenue.

title: Congress Need Not Like The Budget to Adopt It
description: Members of Congress today received President Reagan's 1989 budget with the acknowledgment that there was little inclination on Captiol Hill to seek major changes even if the President's deficit estimate proved too optimistic.

title: Fed in Shift On Reporting M-2 and M-3
description: The Federal Reserve surprised economists yesterday by announcing that it would report weekly, rather than monthly, changes in the broadly defined M-2 and M-3 money supply measures.

title: A Budget Without Bluster
description: There is a welcome breath of reality in President Reagan's new budget. His past budgets have been studded with blustering assaults on the fundamental social functions of government. Not the new midnight-blue tome for fiscal 1989. There will be battles with Congressional Democrats over individual priorities. But this budget, already constrained by a deficit reduction treaty with Congress, picks no foolish fights.

title: UNITED INSURANCE COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $216,000 for the quarter; the year includes capital gains of $208,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $53,000 and $289,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The Computer as Scapegoat
description: LEAD: Computer bashing - scapegoating, really - has become popular. In a recent minor version, a waiter at a fancy new hotel explained, after a long delay, why my breakfast was delayed: ''The computer is down.'' I commented to colleagues at the table that we'd be hearing that excuse far more often in the future.

title: Dollar Up Modestly in U.S.; Gold Prices Mostly Lower
description: The dollar closed moderately higher in New York and mixed in London yesterday after falling in Tokyo earlier in the day.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Aiding the Rebels
description: While the White House has taken great pains to dissociate itself from private efforts to raise money for the Nicaraguan rebels, a political organization called Citizens for Reagan, is trying to take up the slack.

title: Strike Ends At British Ford Plants
description: Workers at the Ford Motor Company's factories in Britain voted overwhelmingly today to end an 11-day strike that had threatened production across Europe and cost the company millions of dollars, Ford said.

title: State Dept. Aide Hints at a Deal If Noriega Quits
description: A top State Department official has told Panama's President that indictments against the Panamanian military leader might be dropped if the general and his top associates withdraw from politics and go into exile, Administration officials and Congressional staff members said today.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Silverstein's Designs
description: An exhibition devoted to Louis Silverstein's contributions to the redesign of The New York Times is on view at the Houghton Gallery and Lubalin Study Center of Cooper Union at 7 East Seventh Street. During the 1970's and early 80's, when Mr. Silverstein was an assistant managing editor and corporate art director at The Times, the paper gave itself a major facelift, introducing nine new sections, redesigning several old ones and shifting to a six-column format. The exhibition, ''Louis Silverstein: Design and The New York Times, 1952-1986,'' is open Mondays through Fridays from noon to 7 P.M., and Saturdays from noon to 5 P.M., through March 17. Admission is free. Information: 353-4214.

Francisco Manrique, Argentine Official, 69
description: Francisco Manrique, a former Argentine naval officer, journalist and presidential candidate who served as Secretary of Tourism under President Raul Alfonsin, died of lymph cancer Monday at the Diagnostic Institute in Buenos Aires. He was 69 years old and lived in Buenos Aires.

title: Harshness, and Hope, in Israel
description: Listen to the progressive echoes of history resound in the news: President Waldheim of Austria rejects conclusions, from a commission he requested, that he must have known about Nazi atrocities in World War II . . . Palestinians contemplate sending a ship from Cyprus to Israel, mimicking the heroism of the Nazi survivors who sailed on the Exodus in 1947 . . . And from Israel comes ever more ugly evidence that the use of brutal force is brutalizing.

title: Jansen Tumbles; Gold to Guliaev
description: Four nights after having fallen on the first turn of the Olympic 500-meter only hours after his sister's death, Dan Jansen of West Allis, Wis., fell again tonight on the backstretch straightaway during the 1,000-meter speedskating event.

title: Advertising; Joint Venture For Fortune In France
description: IT is entirely appropriate that the first issue of Fortune France has the chairmen of Louis Vuitton and Moet-Hennessy on the cover toasting one another with - what else? -champagne. The pair are the subject of the lead article on the giant luxury goods conglomerate.

title: A NEW SITE OPENS FOR OLD MOVIES
description: OLD-MOVIE buffs in New York have had little to cheer about in the last few years, with revival theaters closing or being transformed into first-run theaters at the faster-than-life pace of a Mack Sennett comedy. But good news finally has arrived, in the form of a new revival house called the Biograph Theater that opens today at 225 West 57th Street.

title: The Public's Stake in the Brawley Case
description: Tawana Brawley can thank her lawyer, Alton Maddox Jr., for helping win the appointment of a special state prosecutor to pursue the ugly charges of her rape case. But he is not entitled to anyone's thanks for continuing to withhold the black teen-ager's cooperation. The public is entitled to have the disturbing charges of this episode investigated properly and have justice done promptly.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK (SEYOUR, IND)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings were not available; the company went public Jan. 22.

title: ELDORADO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''People don't like to pay taxes, people like the programs the Government spends money on, and people like to be told fairy tales.'' - Alan Blinder, an economist, on the Federal budget. [ A1:5. ]

title: Our Towns; Herb and Herb: Spreading Cheer To the Disabled
description: When some people decide they want to walk again, they make pilgrimages to Lourdes. They start watching more television evangelists. But this isn't for everyone. Sometimes even if you want to walk again, you don't have the patience to listen to someone talking loud on TV on Sunday morning.

title: Interpublic Profit Up
description: The Interpublic Group - which comprises McCann-Erickson Worldwide; Lintas: Worldwide; Dailey & Associates, and interests in Lowe Marschalk and other companies -announced that fourth-quarter earnings rose 28 percent, to $18.7 million, or 86 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 67 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues increased 25 percent, to $301 million from $240.4 million.

title: Murdoch's Riches: His Edge in Post Talks
description: Like a rich, savvy gambler holding most of the aces, Rupert Murdoch is in a position of great strength in today's showdown with union leaders at The New York Post, according to union officials and industry analysts.

title: PATRICK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: FRIDAY IN THE DRAGON'S YEAR

title: Violin: Grubert
description: LONG before the end of the Ysaye sonata that opened his debut program in Town Hall on Wednesday evening, Ilya Grubert established himself as a musician of exceptional talent, a violinist in the tradition of the great Russian virtuosos, possessed of a clear, unwavering tone and an extraordinary technique. The 34-year-old player, a prize winner at the Paganini, Sibelius and Tchaikovsky competitions, appeared as part of the Russian Nights series that, during the past few months, has brought several Soviet musicians to New York in their recital debuts. Mr. Gruber performed with his older brother, Naum, a pianist of considerable skill who accompanied the program of works by Prokofiev, Grieg, Shostakovich and Wieniawski.

title: Soviet Ousts Yeltsin From Ruling Body
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, a onetime ally of Mikhail S. Gorbachev whose sharp criticism of the pace of reform last October led to his ouster as Communist Party chief in Moscow, lost his Politburo post today while two new Gorbachev allies joined the ruling body.

description: For the last few years Justice William A. Bablitch of the Wisconsin Supreme Court has traveled around the state lecturing law students and lawyers on the need to write clearly and crisply. To illustrate his point that too often ''legal writing'' is a contradiction in terms, he opens each lecture with this passage from a brief submitted to the Wisconsin court:

title: I.R.S. Harder to Convince On Doing Business at Home
description: A personal computer, a luxury car, a home-office and even hobby expenses can still be written off under the new tax law by many employees and self-employed business people. But many taxpayers will also find that they can no longer count on the Government to provide as much of a helping hand in subsidizing the cost of an I.B.M. PS/2, a Mercedes or an orchid-growing sideline.

title: Exorcising Brezhnev's Foreign Policy
description: Having removed the name of the erstwhile leader Leonid I. Brezhnev from all public places, General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev is now attempting the more daunting task of exorcising Mr. Brezhnev's foreign policy legacy. If he makes good on his pledge to remove Soviet troops from Afghanistan, he will begin to render credible Moscow's much publicized ''new thinking'' about the Soviet role in the world.

title: Folk Guitarist
description: Dan Ar Bras, a folk guitarist from Brittany, will perform tomorrow at 8 and 10 P.M. at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street (219-2527). Tickets are $9.

title: Ford Had Record Net Of $4.6 Billion for 1987
description: The Ford Motor Company today reported a profit of $4.6 billion for 1987, an increase of 39.4 percent from $3.3 billion in 1986 and the best earnings ever for an automobile company.

title: ZZZZ Case Guilty Plea
description: An associate of Barry Minkow, the young entrepreneur whose ZZZZ Best Company collapsed amid scandal last year, pleaded guilty to three fraud charges today. Thomas Gordon Padgett, who posed as the source of ZZZZ Best's phony carpet restoration contracts, was the second of 11 co-defendants to plead guilty to what prosecutors described as a scheme that defrauded investors and banks of $24 million. At a bail hearing Wednesday, defense lawyers said they expected Mr. Minkow's co-defendants to plead guilty and testify against him.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $23,722,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and $39,794,000 for the year, and pre-tax investment gains of $90,253,000 and $69,548,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a $29,666,000 tax benefit. c-After net from discontinued operations of $7,228,000 for the quarter and $17,476,000 for the year; the quarter also included pre-tax investment losses of $58,651,000 and a tax benefit of $40,378,000, and the year also included pre-tax investment gains of $220,751,000 and pre-tax income of $23,589,000 from the settlement of a pension plan's obligations.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE flourishing neighborhood between Union Square and the Flatiron district has spawned yet another stylish restaurant, Ristorante da Umberto. Owned by Umberto Assante and his wife, Kathleen, the three-month-old establishment specializes in the hearty cuisine of Florence. The high-ceilinged dining rooms are bright and tidy, with sponge-dappled amber walls and well-spaced tables.

title: Restaurants
description: THERE are only a handful of restaurants in the Lincoln Center area where I could be persuaded to pass an evening unless I was at the business end of a revolver. At first I had reservations about the newcomer Cameos, a splashy, pastel-hued, piano bar with an overly energetic public-relations staff. But word began to trickle in that, in fact, some harmonious cooking was taking place there, and it seemed worth a try.

title: Dole, Stung by Loss, Lashes Out at Bush in South
description: Angry and somber, Senator Bob Dole traveled across the South today, lashing out at Vice President Bush and pressing the theme of ''strong leadership'' that has dominated his Presidential campaign.

title: Yesterday's Medal Winners
description: Luge: Women's Singles Gold: Steffi Walter, East Germany Silver: Ute Oberhoffner, East Germany Bronze: Cerstin Schmidt, East Germany Speed Skating: Men's 1,000 Gold: Nikolai Guliaev, Soviet Union Silver: Uwe-Jens Mey, East Germany Bronze: Igor Gelezovsky, Soviet Union Totals: Soviet Union - 4 gold, 4 silver, 3 bronze; East Germany -3 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze; Finland - 2 gold, 1 bronze; Austria - 1 gold, 1 silver; Switzerland - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; Sweden - 1 gold; the Netherlands - 2 silver, 1 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; West Germany - 1 silver; France - 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Norway - 1 bronze; United States - 1 bronze.

title: Art: A Tamer Vito Acconci in Show at the Modern
description: ONCE confrontational, he now cajoles. Still, Vito Acconci continues to implicate an audience in his discomfiting scenarios. Having created a reputation during the 1970's as a Conceptual artist who staged bizarre, often sexually charged events, Mr. Acconci turns his attention these days to superficially peaceable pastimes -constructing environmental sculptures that function something like playgrounds or parks. Several of them make up ''Vito Acconci: Public Places,'' currently on display at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Art People

title: Art Directors Museum

title: Whale Expedition Defended
description: Japan will not stop a hunt in the Antarctic in which 300 whales are to be killed for what it calls research purposes, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The spokesman, Yoshifumi Matsuda, said the International Whaling Commission, which has imposed a moratorium on commercial whaling, does not regulate whaling for research. Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said on Feb. 10 that the expedition violated the moratorium.

title: Rothschild's New Trouble
description: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., the brokerage house that went into a precipitous decline in the wake of the stock market crash, announced yesterday that it faces further problems because its net worth has declined sharply.

title: A Dance-Music Project
description: Meet the Composer has initiated a $1.3 million national project to pay for collaborations between American composers and choreographers. The three-year project was begun by a $300,000 first-year grant from the Ford Foundation, with an additional $600,000 committed over the next two years, and a contribution of $450,000 from the Pew Charitable Trusts. Grants ranging from $5,000 to $60,000 will be awarded to professional dance companies for commissioning fees and related music costs for composers and choreographers. The application deadline for the project is April 15 . Application materials are available from Meet the Composer, 2112 Broadway, Room 505, New York, N.Y. 10023. Grant awards will be announced in July.

title: Martin Lays Out Agenda As His Fifth Term Begins
description: For most of the morning, the sun struggled in vain to break through the haze that stretched across the Florida sky. The day never fully warmed, but the pictures made it feel like spring anyway: children hanging over the dugout roof, players slowly filing into the clubhouse, uniforms being carefully unfolded.

title: Dining Out Guide: 3-Star French, Part 1
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. The date of original publication is listed after the phone number. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AURORA, 60 East 49th Street (692-9292) - (Jan. 31, 1986) Well-spaced tables and comfortable chairs and banquettes contribute to the luxurious atmosphere of this midtown restaurant. Burnished-wood wainscoting and muted colors play against a lighthearted bubble theme on plates, windows, overhead lights and even the waiters' jackets. And the food can soar as high as bubbles on a windy day. You might start with terrine of foie gras with truffle ice cream; cassolette of squid and black pasta, or warm oysters and spinach with saffron and caviar sauce. Entree options include poached lobster with ginger, lime and Sauternes; veal chop with prosciutto julienne and pepper-mustard sauce, and napoleon of salmon with a smoked salmon and caviar sauce and crisp potato. Desserts rarely disappoint. Pre-theater $37.50; dinner entrees $31 to $37.50. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. LA COTE BASQUE, 5 East 55th Street (688-6525) - (Aug. 22, 1986) Habitues of this classic French restaurant look for comfort, cosseting and food they can really get their teeth into - and that is what they get. The wraparound dining room exudes a timeless glamour with its murals of coastal France, red leather banquettes and splendid flower clusters. The cooking style is characterized by reduced sauces, lavish presentations and prodigious portions. Recommended appetizers are puff pastry with scallops in a fish-stock-and-cream sauce with Sauternes; fresh foie gras with shiitake mushrooms and veal-stock sauce, and lobster terrine. Entrees follow classic French cooking from a lusty steak au poivre and roast duck with puffed crisp skin and a pepper sauce to stuffed quails in pastry crust with truffle sauce and sweetbreads in a veal-stock sauce touched with Madeira. Dinner prix fixe $48. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. LA RESERVE, 4 West 49th Street (247-2993) - (June 28, 1985) The two elegant dining rooms at this Rockefeller Center restaurant are enchanting, with beige- and peach-colored banquettes, high ceiling, giant paintings of birds in marshlands and soft lighting. The cooking orientation is strongly classical with a light touch. You might start with warm lobster and asparagus flan garnished with lobster morsels and tangy watercress sauce; fresh foie gras sauteed with Madeira or port wine, and a special seafood charlotte of silky sole mousse filled with pieces of scallops, shrimp, tomato and mushroom with a beurre blanc sauce. Fish dishes, focused and straightforward, include the grilled fillet of red mullet with clove sauce, and poached salmon with beurre blanc sauce touched with coriander. Other entree options are roast duck with ginger sauce, and sauteed noisettes of venison with five spices. Desserts are copious and ever changing. Dinner prix fixe, pre-theater $36, after 7 P.M. $48. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M.: Saturdays, 5:30 to 11 P.M. LA TULIPE, 104 West 13th Street (691-8860) - (March 1, 1985) This is a charming and intimate little restaurant with a Parisian-style bar up front, chocolate-colored walls and graceful tulip sconces. The kitchen offers a small seasonal menu. To start, you might choose layered eggplant terrine, blini with three caviars, or oxtail consomme. The entrees are nearly always well conceived, stressing flavor over flashiness. Selections include grilled boned squab with braised cabbage and vegetable batons; sauteed fillet of venison with prunes and celery puree; grilled tournedos of beef with home-cured prosciutto with scallions and potato galette, and red snapper cooked in parchment with herbs and vegetables. La Tulipe is dessert heaven, and one option is a terrine of ice cream and glazed fruit from Nice with toasted almonds. Prix fixe dinner $59. Fridays to Sundays, 6:30 to 10 P.M. LE CYGNE, 55 East 54th Street (759-5941) - (April 18, 1986) This excellent French restaurant, in a two-story town house with two small dining rooms on both levels, is one of those discreet institutions that hum along from year to year at a steady pace. Appetizers are uniformly wonderful: succulent little scallops from Maine in lime-accented fish stock with julienne of endive; a sparkling salmon terrine in aspic, and smooth pheasant or duck terrine. Among the entrees are sauteed fillet of snapper with tomato and basil sauce; fresh broiled salmon with mousseline of fresh herbs, and roast squab in a melange of cloves, cepes and artichokes. The frogs' legs, simply prepared in garlic and butter, are some of the best in New York. Dinner prix fixe $56. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the star rating means, page C26.

title: Film: Judy Davis Stars in 'High Tide'
description: ''HIGH TIDE'' begins with shots of a cut-rate Australian Elvis impersonator, and rarely has an Elvis impersonator given off this much heat and light. This man's flash has nothing to do with his act, of course, and everything to do with the pop exuberance with which the director Gillian Armstrong (who made ''Starstruck'' in much the same spirit) captures him on screen. His feet tap; his lips curl; his hips wiggle like mad. Meanwhile, behind him, three singers in blond Cleopatra wigs and glittering green mermaid dresses smile and shimmy for all they're worth.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S PRIORITIES
description: Some programs he wants to increase: Education: Spending for discretionary programs up $656 million to $16.9 billion. Additional increases in the Pell Grant program for needy college students. AIDS: Nearly $2 billion in spending on research, education and treatment, a 38 percent increase. Space: About $11.5 billion, including $1 billion to start building a manned space station, $1 billion for the space shuttle and money for a new program to study exploration of other planets. Science: A 5 percent increase for non-AIDS health research, $363 million to start building a superconducting super collider, and an increase in National Science Foundation support for basic research. Air Traffic: $1.6 billion, a 44 percent increase, to upgrade the nation's air traffic control system. Prisons: Spending on prison construction would more than double, a move aimed at overcrowding. Crime: $3.9 billion to enforce drug laws and treat addicts, a 13 percent increase; $4.5 billion, a 6 percent increase, to fight white collar crime, organized crime, terrorism and corruption. Military: Up 2.8 percent, to $299.5 billion, the smallest military spending increase President Reagan has sent to Congress (inflation, by comparison, is projected at 4.3 percent). Some programs he wants to trim or eliminate: Farming: Reduce crop price supports, particularly on sugar. Medicare: Trim the extra payments made to teaching hospitals and payments for certain procedures and medical supplies. Eliminate: The Interstate Commerce Commission, the Economic Development Administration, Small Business Administration direct loans, urban development action grants, and public subsidies for Amtrak rail passenger service and mass transit systems. Privatize: Sell to private operators $12 billion in loans, the Naval Petroleum Reserves, an Alaskan utility, Federal prison industries, and the helium program; study the sale of a southern utility, uranium enrichment facilities and certain postal operations.

description: The first major American film festival in Moscow opened today with a screening of ''Roxanne,'' Steve Martin's comic updating of ''Cyrano de Bergerac,'' and lines of Muscovites patiently waiting for tickets.

title: CRIMINAL PENALTY GUIDELINES ARE VOIDED BY FEDERAL COURT
description: Guidelines intended to bring consistency to sentencing for those who commit Federal crimes have been declared invalid by two judges in the Southern Federal District of California.

title: BellSouth Signs Pact To Purchase Mobile
description: The BellSouth Corporation, one of the seven regional Bell telephone companies, announced in Atlanta yesterday that it had signed an agreement to buy the Mobile Communications Corporation of America for $28.75 a share, or $710 million. Mobile, based in Jackson, Miss., provides cellular telephone and paging services.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,463,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Turkey Deserves Priority Attention
description: LEAD: Turkey is exposed to pressures from its historic rival the Soviet Union, to the north, and the new wave of Islamic fundamentalists, to the east and south. It is too little exposed to Americans. We need to tune in more closely to its progress at home and abroad.

title: Jean Baube, 81, Former Aide to de Gaulle
description: Jean Baube, a French journalist and confidant of de Gaulle who served as counselor for press relations at the French Embassy in Washington for nearly three decades, died of heart failure yesterday at Venice Hospital in Venice, Fla. He was 81 years old and had lived in Boca Grande, Fla., since his retirement in 1974.

title: LANGLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Speculator Held on Gun Charges; Said to Have Threatened Boesky
description: A top Wall Street speculator was arrested late Thursday on charges of illegal possession of a gun that he purportedly intended to use on witnesses against him in a Government securities investigation.

title: Eskimo Guards on Alert Off Siberia
description: Tensions between East and West may have been reduced in the wake of successful negotiations to reduce nuclear arms in Europe. But for the Eskimo scouts of Alaska's National Guard the cold war persists with a frigidity to match an Alaskan winter.

title: Gardens Of Sweet Ignorance
description: The good news is that giant snowdrops and brilliant yellow winter aconite are blooming in our garden. I found them Thursday morning, which was mild and cloudy, in that patch between the out-of-control climbing rose bush and the coffee bean tree.

title: Canada Ruling On Hyundai
description: Canada's Department of Revenue and Customs said today that it had found that the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea is dumping cars at unfair prices in the Canadian market.

title: Stage: 'Shirley Basin,' on a Lonely Mining Town
description: Shirley Basin, as described by Molly Ivins in a 1978 article in The New York Times, was an incredibly isolated uranium-mining town in a desolate area of Wyoming. The town was like ''a moonscape capped with snow, a huge clot of trailers, one after another, and nothing else.'' There were no trees, houses or parks and the barren social life revolved around the bar at the Bad Medicine Inn. The subject might have been an appropriate one for Bret Harte to study.

title: Grumman to Pay M.T.A. $40 Million in Bus Case
description: LEAD: Four years after its troublesome Flxible buses were banished from New York City streets, the Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $40 million to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: E'TOWN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Air Crashes Kill 18 in Carolina and New Jersey
description: Eighteen people were killed last night in the crashes of two airplanes, 12 aboard an American Eagle commuter plane taking off from Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina and six in the crash a small plane in a wooded area near Atlantic City.

title: GUIDEPOST
description: Mail by Courier With the United States Postal Service curtailing some services, consumers may want to consider alternatives for urgent mail. There are four major private courier companies to choose from, in addition to the Postal Service's Express Mail, for reliable overnight delivery of letters. Express Mail will deliver on Saturday and offers limited Sunday delivery in some major metropolitan areas. All private couriers have no Saturday pickup or limited pickup. Some have weekend surcharges. Know the recipient's complete address and phone number. Ask about a signature waiver to insure delivery if the person is away. All the companies accept cash and personal checks; most accept credit cards. The prices here are for overnight weekday letters mailed from almost any major city to nearly all municipalities with a population of 100,000 or more in the continental United States. $ Letter rate Time it takes Weekday for pickup hours Airborne $14.00 1 hour 8 A.M.- 9 P.M. Emory/ Purolator $13.75 1 hour 7 A.M.- 5 P.M. Express Mail $10.75 No pickup 8 A.M.- 5 P.M. Federal Express $14.00 1-2 hours 9 A.M.- 8:30 P.M. United Parcel Service $12.50 1 day 8 A.M.- 5:30 P.M.

title: After a Death, Quiet Nights At Rutgers
description: At Rutgers University, as at many colleges, Saturday nights on fraternity row usually mean no studying, loud parties and a steady flow of beer.

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,120,000 for the quarter and $5,348,000 for the year. c-After losses of $1,294,000 and $1,868,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Prosecution Witness Clears 3 In a French Terrorist Group
description: A special antiterrorist court today acquitted three members of the Direct Action leftist guerrilla group of charges of tempted manslaughter after the prosecution witness said the police had forged his signature on a statement.

title: Concert: Northern Sinfonia
description: The Northern Sinfonia, a chamber orchestra based in Newcastle, England, presented in its program at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening music by Elgar, Robin Holloway, Mozart, Gounod and Haydn - ingratiating works, for the most part, rendered in gentle, carefully crafted performances. Barry Tuckwell conducted the ensemble and doubled, with reasonable success, as soloist in the Mozart E-flat Major Horn Concerto.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Campaign: Prose and Cons
description: LEAD: All of the candidates in pursuit of the Democratic and Republican Party nominations have this in common: Each has so far concealed from the voters the one thing many of us need in order to choose wisely. Not one of these men has shown us a solid example of his writing, untouched by editors or image makers.

title: Bomb Kills 14 Near a Base in Namibia
description: At least 14 people were killed and more than 30 wounded today when a bomb exploded in a bank branch office near a military base in South-West Africa, the territory also known as Namibia.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, articles last Saturday and Sunday about an F.B.I. inquiry into organizations opposing United States policy in Central America omitted the name of the group that disclosed it. The Center for Constitutional Rights, a lawyers' group based in New York, obtained the data through the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Charles Delaunay, 77, Jazz Scholar in France
description: Charles Delaunay, a French jazz scholar, died of Parkinson's disease on Tuesday near Paris. He was 77 years old.

title: A Hemisphere at Risk From Drugs
description: The specter of drugs is haunting the Americas.

title: Brazil Talks to Continue
description: Negotiators from Brazil and a committee of its major commercial bank creditors will continue discussions this weekend on a new multibillion-dollar financial package, the Brazilian Finance Minister, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, said yesterday.

title: Private-Label Clothes Find New Buyers
description: My name or yours?

title: Teaching the Classics In Student Productions
description: Annabelle Howard wanted to teach Greek history to her fifth-grade class, but she didn't like the textbooks on the subject. So she cast her students in a Greek tragedy instead.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Coast Federal Savings and Loan Association, Sarasota, Fla., said it had accepted a $20-a-share tender offer from Hugh H. Culverhouse.

title: APACHE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $7,725,000 and $9,342,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $1,096,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $909,000 for the quarter and $4,430,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter and year results include the previously reported after-tax charge of $75 million, relating largely to recent contract settlements with gas pipeline purchasers and the low average gas prices.

title:
Patents;
Fiber Connector Sends TV Over Phone Lines
description: LEAD: Apparatus for interconnecting large groups of hair-thin optical fibers was patented this week for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Bell Laboratories of Murray Hill, N.J. Patent 4,725,120 was awarded to William J. Parzygnat, a staff member.

title: U.S. and Bonn Agree on Need For Review of Arms Control
description: President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed today on the need for a comprehensive review of NATO arms control strategy as a follow-up to the American-Soviet treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles in Europe.

title: Ballet: For Soviet Pair, A Challenge
description: Nina Ananiashvili and Andris Liepa, the dancers from Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet who have been guest artists with the New York City Ballet this season, faced their biggest challenge Thursday night when they performed George Balanchine's ''Symphony in C'' at the New York State Theater. It was a challenge they triumphantly met.

title: MMR HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Money Managers Still in Shock
description: Even though four months have passed since the stock market collapsed, professional money managers are still acting as if it happened yesterday. Stunned by the experience, they prefer to hold billions of dollars in cash instead of buying now-cheaper stocks.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: City Tow Trucks Will Help Drivers on 4 S.I. Highways
description: A city fleet of tow trucks will offer free gasoline, jump starts and tows to motorists on Staten Island highways in a test beginning Monday.

title: Fed's Report Shift Stuns Traders
description: Trading in fixed-income securities ground to a near-halt yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced late Thursday that it would report weekly, rather than monthly, changes in the nation's broader money supply, or M-2 and M-3.

title: JOHN PAUL'S SOLEMN TEACHINGS
description: The encyclical letter issued by Pope John Paul II today is his seventh. It is his second encyclical focusing on the church's social teachings but the first to emphasize international issues.

title: Emmis to Buy 5 NBC Radio Stations
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to sell five of its seven radio stations, including two in New York, to the Emmis Broadcasting Corporation for $121.5 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Gretzky, Lemieux Hurt: The top two scorers in the league, Mario Lemieux and Wayne Gretzky, were hurt during the Oilers' 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins last night at Edmonton. The Oilers lost Gretzky at 4 minutes 45 seconds of the first period when he was hit in the eye with a stick. Gretzky suffered a bruised cornea and is expected to be out of action for six days. Late in the first period, a slapshot by Doug Bodger hit Pittsburgh's Lemieux on the bridge of the nose. The league's leading scorer suffered a cut and did not return to the game. A former Penguin, Craig Simpson, scored two goals late in the second period to give the Oilers the lead for good. Skating with a two-man advantage, Simpson tied the score at 3-3 at 15 minutes 39 seconds with assists from Mark Messier and Jari Kurri. Simpson then put the Oilers ahead, 4-3, with another power-play goal at 19:26.(AP) Flyers 5, Sabres 4: Rick Tocchet scored two first-period goals, helping Philadelphia overcome a 2-0 deficit to beat Buffalo at home. Tocchet gave the Flyers a 3-2 lead with his 19th goal of the season. (AP) Capitals 6, Jets 0: Clint Malarchuk recorded his second shutout of the season as the Capitals took their fifth straight victory. Washington's Mike Gartner scored his 37th and 38th goals of the season and Kevin Hatcher had three assists for the Capitals.(AP) Golf Pooley Leads by a Shot: Don Pooley fired eight birdies yesterday on the way to a seven-under-par 65 and a one-shot lead at the midway point of the $650,000 Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif. Pooley completed one round on each of two courses at 132, 12 shots under par. Tom Kite and Bob Tway were tied for second at 133 after each shot 65. Kite birdied four of his last five holes on the North course and Tway birdied six of his first seven at the South. Tom Watson rolled in a 30-foot putt for eagle-3 on his final hole at the North course and was next at 134. (AP) Douglass Ahead by 2: Dale Douglass had six birdies on his way to a five-under-par 67 for a two-stroke lead after the first round of the $300,000 Suncoast Seniors classic in Tampa, Fla. Orville Moody and Don Massengale were tied for second at 69. (AP) Tennis Becker and Connors Gain in Italy: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany routed Henri Leconte of France, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $500,000 Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. Becker used his big serve and sharp ground strokes, including 18 passing shots, to overpower Leconte in under an hour of play. Earlier, Jimmy Connors lost the first four games before rallying to beat Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 7-5, 6-3, and reach the semifinals without dropping a set. In the opening match, unseeded Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia upset countryman Miloslav Mecir, seeded third, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6. (AP) Navratilova-Garrison Matchup: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova and Zina Garrison, the defending champion, overwhelmed opponents in the $250,000 Virginia Slims of California tournament in Oakland, setting up their second semifinal meeting in two weeks. Navratilova beat 16-year-old Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-0. Garrison, seeded fourth, defeated Hu Na, 6-2, 6-0. Both matches were finished in under an hour. (AP) Horse Racing Tempt Sec Rallies to Win: Tempt Sec, ridden by Jose Santos, came from last in the field of seven to score a four-length victory yesterday in the $42,000 allowance feature at Aqueduct. Tempt Sec, a 4-year-old colt by Czaravich from the Secretariat mare Temptation, earned $25,200 for his owner, Alvin Akman, and paid $5.60 for $2 to win as the second choice.

title: Murdoch and Unions Reach Deal, Averting Threat to Close The Post
description: The New York Post and its unions agreed early today to cut labor costs by $24 million over the next three years, clearing the way for Rupert Murdoch to sell the beleaguered newspaper to the real-estate developer Peter S. Kalikow.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Murdoch's Man Lauded as Charming
description: In seeking cuts from the unions at The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch has relied on Victor Strimbu Jr., a lawyer whose negotiating skills have won him high marks among newspaper publishers and employees in several cities.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10 million and a tax benefit of $3.5 million. c-After an extraordinary charge of $3.7 million for the quarter, and the year is after a loss from discontinued operations of $24 million and a tax benefit of $600,000.

title: Trump Studies Fight
description: The decision on the site for the Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks fight will apparently be made next week. Donald Trump said yesterday that he would be reacting soon to the asking price he has received in writing. ''I haven't accepted,'' said Trump, ''but you could say that more than likely I will accept.'' According to Mark Etess, an executive of Trump Plaza, if Trump accepts the proposal, the bidding for the fight will be terminated and the live rights to the bout will belong to Trump Plaza. The bout would be staged in the Atlantic City Convention Center in June.

title: New Pact for Parcells
description: A lot has changed since Coach Bill Parcells led the Giants to victory in the 1987 Super Bowl and then made a handshake deal with the general manager, George Young, on a contract extension. There was a sharp drop in the team's fortunes to a 6-9 record last season. Despite that, one thing that has apparently not changed is the club's confidence in Parcells, whose former contract ran through the 1988 season. Yesterday, he signed the four-year extension. It will pay him an estimated $3.2 million and keep him with the Giants through the 1991 season. Parcells, who has a 47-38-1 record with three playoff berths in five seasons with the Giants, delayed the signing because of tax considerations.

title: HAWTHORNE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
Diagnosing AIDS Virus
description: LEAD: Harvard College received a patent this week for a protein regarded as important in the diagnosis of an AIDS virus and in the development of a vaccine. Patent 4,725,669 was granted to two faculty members, Myron E. Essex and Tun-Hou Lee.

title: Chrysler to Weigh Kenosha Extension
description: The Chrysler Corporation, under fire for planning to close a plant that it acquired in its buyout of the American Motors Corporation, will consider a ''modest, short'' extension of production there, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said. He had met in Washington with Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, who has threatened to have the state sue Chrysler.

title: BABIES ARE SOUGHT FOR ORGANS OF INFANT WHO IS BRAIN DEAD
description: Doctors and nurses continued their efforts today to find recipients for the organs of an infant born with only a brain stem who was kept on a respirator to preserve his organs for transplant.

title: The System Frustrates 'Temporary' Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: 14 Die in Namibia Attack

title: Film: 'Stranded,' Sci-Fi
description: Sheriff Hollis McMann - we know he is Sheriff Hollis McMann because he shouts ''This is Sheriff Hollis McMann!'' into his megaphone before beginning every speech - arrives at the house where the kindly grandmother and her sweet teen-age granddaughter are being held hostage. ''How many people are in the house with you?'' he asks. ''They're not, uh, people, Sheriff,'' the teen-age girl answers, thus providing ''Stranded'' with its only touch of anything resembling humor.

title: OFFICIALS CRITICIZE FEDERAL RESERVE
description: The Reagan Administration today blamed the Federal Reserve, along with October's stock market rout, for the slowdown in the election-year economy. The President's economic advisers also said that the Federal Reserve had helped cause the rout but that its current policies were satisfactory.

title: GENZYME CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PRO-IRANIAN GROUP CLAIMS ABDUCTION
description: A clandestine group believed to be made up of pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalists said today that it was holding a United States Marine officer who was kidnapped Wednesday.

description: The Economy

description: b-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $2,626,000.

description: Senator Bob Dole's campaign organization, seeking to turn the tables on Vice President Bush, today issued a ''challenge'' to Mr. Bush to ''make up his mind on taxes.''

description: b-After an extraordinary charge from long-term debt refinancing of $708,000 for the quarter and year.

Polaroid Suit Seeks $5.72 Billion
description: The Polaroid Corporation is seeking as much as $5.72 billion in damages from the Eastman Kodak Company for infringement on its instant photography patents, according to court documents released yesterday by the Federal District Court in Boston.

title: Haiti's Unrequited Gifts to U.S. History and Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Investment Group Seeks Dravo Role
description: Drillbit Partners L.P., an investment group led by Arthur M. Goldberg, said it had discussed the possible acquisition of the Dravo Corporation, a mining and engineering company based in Pittsburgh, with several banks.

title: P.I.P. May Accept $66 Million Offer
description: Postal Instant Press said it was considering a $17-a-share, or $66 million, buyout offer from an investor group that includes some of its managers and a Chicago leveraged-buyout firm. P.I.P., which franchises quick-printing outlets, also said it had adopted a plan to curb hostile takeovers, to be triggered if a shareholder obtained at least 20 percent of the company's stock.

title: Kluge Files to Buy More Orion Shares
description: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, is seeking Federal antitrust clearance to raise his stake in the Orion Pictures Company to as much as 50 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Kluge said that the purchases of shares in the New York-based motion picture and television company would be for investment purposes.

New York Has Mishandled Water Conservation

title: Webster Retires
description: Mike Webster, the Pittsburgh Steelers' center for 14 years, said yesterday he was retiring. Webster, 35 years old, was the last active Steeler to have played in all four of the team's Super Bowl victories.

title: Bob Stivers, 66, Dies; Produced TV Specials
description: Bob Stivers, a producer of television entertainment programs, died of cancer Wednesday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. Mr. Stivers, who lived in Los Angeles, would have been 67 years old on Thursday.

description: b-Includes $6.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from special gains on the sale of an affiliate's stock and land, less the effect of certain acquisition costs and writeoffs.

title: Candidates Less Than Eager For Advice From Economists
description: For all the Presidential candidates' promises on matters of trade, taxes, jobs, welfare and Social Security, something quite novel is happening this election year. They are making much less use of economists and their advice than candidates did in the past.

title: An Unsparing View of Economic Ills
description: Theologians scrutinize papal encyclicals the way constitutional lawyers pore over Supreme Court decisions, looking for subtle shifts in phrasing, new lines of argument, discreet silences about past statements that are now better forgotten. Pope John Paul II's

Salvadoran Recants Confession in Slaying
description: A man who had confessed to a role in the slaying of the country's most prominent human rights advocate recanted Thursday and said he had been drugged and abused in jail.

title:
Patents;
Detecting Cancer Cells
description: LEAD: For the Beth Israel Hospital Association in Boston, a method of determining the presence of cancer cells in a patient was patented this week. Patent 4,725,538 was granted to Donald R. Senger of Medfield, Mass. A patient's cells are tested with an antibody, and the subsequent reaction indicates the presence of any cancer cells.

title: Bowles Wins in Hurdles
description: Dawn Bowles was smiling when the race was over last night. Monifa Taylor was laughing. The nation's two best high school performers in the 55-meter hurdles had just completed another duel, this time at the Colgate Women's Games at Madison Square Garden. But the two athletes would not overplay the importance of one meet or the significance of who won.

title: OLYMPICS MIND GAMES
description: One winter we invented a new sport while working the night shift. We would take a Frisbee into the hall and try to sling it past each other from 20 yards away.

title: Staten I. Takes Title
description: The College of Staten Island won the men's CUNY Conference basketball tournament last night by beating Hunter College, 72-69, in the championship game at the Nat Holman Gym at City College.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Senators Wary of Bank Mergers
description: Members of Congress cautioned the Federal Reserve Board today about the possible ill effects of permitting hostile takeovers among the nation's largest banks.

description: b-After a net charge of $2,696,000 from a provision for litigation damages and a gain of $1,048,000 from an accounting change for the both periods.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Korea Tariff Cut Praised
description: United States Government officials today applauded an announcement by South Korea that it would lower import tariffs on cars and more than 400 other products next month. The Ministry of Finance said the move was intended to curb inflation and reduce the country's trade surplus.

title: 2d Bidder May Emerge In Fight for Federated
description: A potential challenge to the Campeau Corporation's bid for Federated Department Stores Inc. may emerge from a group including Dillard Department Stores Inc. and the Jay Pritzker family, people close to the takeover rivals said yesterday.

title: 2 Die in Texas Plane Crash
description: A small plane barely missed traffic on an Interstate highway this morning before it smashed into a shopping mall's parking lot and burst into flames. The crash killed at least two people on the plane, both of them unidentifed, but there were no casualties on the ground.

title: Starrett City's Sound Racial Policy
description: LEAD: The 23,000 residents of the Starrett City housing complex, built 15 years ago on the site of a former landfill on the outskirts of the East New York section of Brooklyn, have proved that a highly visible, viable, safe, well-kept and integrated large-scale development can encourage maximum minority participation in the community.

title: Slaught Hopes to Win a Job
description: On the first day of spring training, the Yankees gathered in their clubhouse early this morning and introduced themselves to one another.

title: When Is a Sale a Sale?
description: With spring just a month away, winter clearance sales are in full swing. But just what is a sale?

title: Uncovered Short Sales Inch Up on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Feb. 12 rose by 3.3 million shares, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 383.4 million, from a revised 380.1 million in the previous month.

title: PAPAL ENCYCLICAL SAYS SUPERPOWERS HURT THIRD WORLD
description: Pope John Paul II today issued an encyclical letter charging that the ideological rivalry between East and West was subjecting poor nations to imperialistic ''structures of sin'' that deny them freedom and development.

title: BURLINGTON HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago figures were those reported by Burlington Industries, before its acquisition by Burlington Holdings.

title: Returns Have More Traps And Cost of Mistakes Rises
description: With the tax law's numerous changes, 1987 tax returns contain many more pitfalls that can surprise unwary taxpayers and draw the attention of Internal Revenue Service auditors.

title: Andrysiak Loses
description: Terry Andrysiak, the Notre Dame senior who started four games at quarterback last season until he suffered a broken collarbone, will not be permitted to play a fifth season although he played only four minutes in his freshman season, the university announced. ''In Terry's case, there is not sufficient medical evidence of physical injury in his freshman season to merit the extra season being approved,'' said Richard Rosenthal, the athletic director.

title: About New York; Artists' Model Bares Physique But Hides Secret
description: It is not the custom of this corner to sketch and obscure, but then it is not every day one deals with a man's darkest secret. That said, no doubt it is best to start at the beginning.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Indy Suit Filed
description: The widow of a man from Rothschild, Wis., who was killed by a tire that flew off a car driven in the 1987 Indianapolis 500 by Tony Bettenhausen has filed a $9 million wrongful death suit against the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, the United States Auto Club, Bettenhausen and other defendants. Lyle G. Kurtenbach, 41 years old, was hit in the head by the tire while in the stands. His widow charged that the car and tire were defective and that spectators were not accurately informed of the potential dangers of watching the race.

title: LUXTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The company said the share earnings for the latest quarter was less than one cent.

All of the extraordinary charges are related to the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Swaggart Is Subject of Investigation by His Church
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, the television evangelist, is under investigation by his church, the Assemblies of God, a church spokeswoman said today. Newspaper and broadcast reports said the inquiry involved allegations of sexual misconduct.

title: Music: 'La Voix Humaine'
description: Some artists stick to what they know they can do well, content to carve out careers in narrowly defined grooves, or, in extreme cases, ruts. Others, an honorable few, are driven to branch out into unlikely roles and whole idioms that stretch their talents interestingly, if sometimes to the breaking point. Among sopranos, Jessye Norman has proved herself one of these others, moving successfully beyond the recital and concert stages where she made her first international impact into a widening circle of operatic roles. So one should not have been surprised to find Miss Norman taking on one of opera's most daunting challenges, Poulenc's ''Voix Humaine,'' as she did in a concert version of the work with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening.

title: Lois C. Campbell, Advertising Executive, 53
description: Lois C. Campbell, vice president of Willliam Altman Advertising Inc., died of complications after surgery Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.
