title:
Patents;
Prosthetic Heart Valve
description: LEAD: A prosthetic heart valve has been patented for Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. of Deerfield, Ill. Ernest Lane and Hung L. Lam were granted patent 4,725,274 this week.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Benjamin H. Brinton, Stock Exchange Official, 95
description: Benjamin H. Brinton, a lawyer and a former treasurer of the New York Stock Exchange, died Wednesday at his home in Tucson, Ariz., after a long illness. He was 95 years old.

title: Trash Disposal Problem Besieging Philadelphia
description: Much like last year's unhappy garbage barge from Islip, L.I., two cargo ships are plying the high seas somewhere today, presumably in the Caribbean, laden with ash from this city's trash incinerators and looking for somewhere to dump it.

title: Pretoria Denies Role In Zimbabwe Killing
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOLGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $190,000 and $298,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $215,000 for the quarter and $1,015,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $5,008,000 for the quarter and $12,843,000 for the year.

title: TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the year-ago third quarter benefited by $133,500, or 6 cents a share, as a result of the sale of land.

title: N.H.L. Close to Soviet Deal
description: The prospect of as many as 10 players from the Soviet Union playing in the National Hockey League next season is now merely a matter of money, Alan Eagleson, director of the N.H.L. Players Association, said today. Eagleson and John Ziegler, the N.H.L. president, have been negotiating with officials from the Soviet hockey federation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When the West gives the impression of abandoning itself to forms of growing and selfish isolation, and the East in its turn seems to ignore for questionable reasons its duty to cooperate in the task of alleviating human misery, then we are up against not only a betrayal of humanity's legitimate expectations - a betrayal that is a harbinger of unforeseeable consequences - but also a real desertion of a moral obligation.'' - Pope John Paul II. [ 5:1. ]

title: Notebook; Selective Nostalgia For Close of Games
description: Oleg and Lyudmila Protopopov, who won the Olympic pairs figure skating gold medals in 1964 and 1968, were invited to take part in the closing ceremony of the XV Olympic Winter Games here. Then the invitation was withdrawn because, the organizers said, the ceremony would have run longer than the allotted 90 minutes.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the merger of two Manhattan law firms gave incorrect addresses. Lord, Day & Lord is at 25 Broadway, and Barrett Smith Simon & Armstrong is across the street, at 26 Broadway.

title: 2 IN G.O.P. DEBATE AND 2 STAY AWAY
description: Half the Republican Presidential field debated here tonight, opening with criticism of the other half for refusing to take part.

title: Regulator Seeks TMIC Liquidation
description: In a widely expected move that will sharply increase the likelihood of losses from the collapse of the TMIC Insurance Company, the California Commissioner of Insurance moved yesterday to liquidate the company.

title: F.D.A. Budget for AIDS Called Too Low
description: The chairman of President Reagan's AIDS commission said yesterday that the Federal Food and Drug Administration urgently needed more money and staff to help speed the approval of new drugs to fight AIDS.

title: Owens-Illinois Merger Blocked
description: A Federal appeals court has stayed a lower court decision that would have allowed a merger creating the nation's largest glass-container company. The United States Court of Appeals said today that the stay, which keeps the proposed merger between Owens-Illinois Inc. and Brockway Inc. on hold, remained in effect until further notice.

title: Family of a Deceased Smoker Charges Improprieties at Trial
description: The plaintiffs in a tobacco liability case that ended in a hung jury last month have charged representatives of the defendant, American Brands Inc., with improper contact with some jurors while the trial was under way.

title: A Fitting Finale For Boitano, Orser
description: In a fitting crescendo to their rivalry of the last three years, Brian Boitano of the United States and Brian Orser of Canada will lead a field of 24 Saturday night into the freestyle program, the final event of the Olympic men's figure skating competition.

title: States Spurring Outlays In Biotechnology Field
description: State governments are playing a more important role than ever before in financing biotechnology research and helping young companies develop new products, according to industry analysts and state officials.

title: Andre F. Cournand, 92, Is Dead; Nobel Prize Winner in Medicine
description: Dr. Andre F. Cournand, a professor of medicine at Columbia University for many years who won the Nobel Prize in 1956 for perfecting a simple method of exploring the heart through catheterization, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home in Great Barrington, Mass., after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: An Impasse Halts Nicaraguan Talks
description: Negotiations between Nicaraguan Government and guerrilla representatives were suspended today by the official mediator, who said the two sides remained too far apart to have meaningful talks.

title: NETS FALL AS BARKLEY SCORES 43
description: Charles Barkley scored 43 points, hitting 16 of 22 shots from the field, to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 115-100 victory over the Nets tonight.

title:
YOUR MONEY;
Financial Plans For New Parents
description: LEAD: Couples should overhaul their finances when they start their families so that they can meet the costs of rearing children, financial planners say.

title: No Aid for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: On Heroin; Right for Many of the Terminally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: APACHE PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year includes additional amortization of $70,000,000 to reflect a reduction in the carrying value of oil and gas properties. Year-ago quarter and year includes additional amortization of $153,497,000 to reflect a reduction in the carrying value of oil and gas properties.

title: Excerpts From Papal Encyclical on Social Concerns of Church
description: Following are excerpts from the encyclical letter ''Sollicitudo Rei Socialis'' (''The Social Concerns of the Church''), issued yesterday by Pope John Paul II: SURVEY OF CONTEMPORARY WORLD

title: A Friend From England
description: In such previous novels as ''Look at Me,'' ''The Debut'' and ''Family and Friends,'' the British writer Anita Brookner has mapped out a recognizable social world, a world where politely accented exchanges and genteel activities - chamber music concerts, tea dances, family dinners - belie an adherence to harsh Darwinian rules. Here, innocence nearly always succumbs to sophistication; sincerity to shrewdness, cunning and duplicity.

title: The Dance: Mitchell Rose
description: Mitchell Rose has a comic turn of mind that allows him to see not just the undersides but the quirks of things. He doesn't always fully communicate those quirks and his responses to them. His humor has grown gentler in the last few years. But there were moments when everything came together in a program of 13 new and recent pieces by Mr. Rose that was presented on Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, and they were memorable moments.

title: Sematech Facing Cut
description: The semiconductor industry's new research consortium, Sematech, is facing a sharp cutback in Federal financing in the 1989 fiscal year under the President's proposed budget, which was released this week.

title: Insuring a Long Life For Compact Disks
description: A number of new mechanical cleaners for compact disks are being advertised in record catalogues and are appearing in specialized audio shops.

title: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and for the quarter reflects a pre-tax provision of $2.8 million for disposition of product lines, and the year included a charge of $7.4 million representing provision for losses associated with divestitures and from the disolution of a Mexican joint venture.

title: SUNSHINE-JR. STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter reflects a 14-week reporting period, compared with a 13-week period a year ago.

title: ZYCAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,025,000 for the quarter and $2,693,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: In South Korea, a New Cabinet Full of Old Faces
description: President-elect Roh Tae Woo of South Korea, who will take office next week, named a Cabinet today filled with holdovers from the present Government in many key positions.

title: YESTERDAY'S MEDAL WINNERS
description: Alpine Skiing: Women's Downhill Gold: Marina Kiehl, West Germany Silver: Brigitte Oertii, Switzerland bronze: Karen Percy, Canada Cross-Country: Men's 15 km Gold: Mikhail Deviatiarov, Soviet Union Silver: Pal Gunner Mikkelsplass, Norway Bronze: Vladimir Smirnov, Soviet Union Luge: Men's Doubles Gold: Joerg Hoffmann, Jochen Pietzsch, East Germany Silver: Stefan Krausse, Jan Behrendt, East Germany Bronze: Thomas Schwab, Wolfgang Staudinger, West Germany Totals: Soviet Union - 5 gold, 4 silver, 4 bronze; East Germany -4 gold, 3 silver, 1 bronze; Switzerland - 1 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze; Finland - 2 gold, 1 bronze; West Germany - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; the Netherlands - 2 silver, 1 bronze; Austria - 1 gold, 1 silver; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Norway - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Sweden - 1 gold; Canada - 1 bronze; France - 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; United States - 1 bronze.

title: TV: 'Noble House,' Four-Part Mini-Series
description: ''Noble House'' clunks through eight hours on nearly leaden feet. The fire in the floating restaurant is spectacular; the horse race isn't bad; the landslide is at least dramatic. Otherwise, there's not much to see. People get in and out of cars or on and off of junks and yachts or wander through board rooms, houses and lobbies. ''Noble House,'' a four-part mini-series beginning on NBC at 9 P.M. tomorrow, follows aimlessly.

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and both periods reflect a restructuring charge which reduced total 1986 net by $30.2 million.

title: Brown Lifts Devils To Fourth-Place Tie
description: In the battle to avoid last place in the Patrick Division and close in on a playoff berth, the Devils defeated the Rangers, 6-3, tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Caraguatay Journal; People Leave and the Dollars Arrive
description: Many inhabitants of this small farming town have never visited Asuncion, the Paraguayan capital, and a few speak only the traditional Guarani language, but everyone, it seems, has a daughter or a cousin or some other close relative living in New York.

title: Weapon Against Gays
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Landlord Freed 8 Days Early
description: The landlord who had been under house arrest in one of his neglected apartment buildings in Brooklyn for 15 days was ordered released yesterday, eight days early because of time off for good behavior.

title: Informer Shuns Pact At Hearing
description: A major Mafia informer testified for the first time yesterday at a court hearing, but refused to answer many questions and said he could not remember if his family had received ''threats of violence.''

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $625,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $2,033,000 for the year. c-Includes realized investment losses of $1,879,000 and realized investment gains of $1,291,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago results were restated to reflect the inclusion of Loyal American Life Insurance Co. as combination of previously separate entities under common control.

title: For Bronx Nurses in Protest, Staying Home Is Painful
description: For Carmen Fascio, the decision to call in sick on Tuesday was easy, compared with the life-or-death judgments she makes every day as a head nurse in the emergency room at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx.

title: AIDS Risk Articles Criticized
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop today criticized articles minimizing the risk of heterosexual transmission of AIDS.

title: Rikers Island Warning Signals
description: The riot at Rikers Island was not the first at New York City's main correctional facility. It is not likely to be the last unless serious steps are taken. In contrast with the heavy-handedness used to quell the last riot, in October 1986, the Department of Correction handled this disturbance well. But overcrowding, inadequate services and management problems remain, tinder for trouble.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

Patents;
A System to Prevent Phone Eavesdropping
description: LEAD: Herbert H. Waldman, who patented his first remote telephone-answering service in 1956, was granted a patent this week for a telephone privacy circuit. According to the patent, the circuit provides total protection against eavesdropping and bugging. It is made by Fonetronics, a division of Measurement Specialties Inc.

title: Coping: With Catered Parties
description: Planning a large catered party, especially a wedding that calls for flowers and limousines and champagne, is a once-in-a-lifetime experience for many people. But even when a catered affair is more limited in scope it is bound to cost thousands of dollars. At any price, the party ought to be memorable, and that requires attention to every detail.

title: New York's Chinese: Living in 2 Worlds
description: In Flushing, Queens, some Chinese businessmen urge others to put up English signs, even though the bulk of their relatively affluent customers are Chinese. They suggest it might seem more neighborly.

title: Bush Edges Dole in a Straw Poll in Nevada
description: Vice President Bush has won a Presidential straw poll among Nevada Republicans, but his total was nearly equaled by the undecided votes, many of which were said to have been cast by supporters of Pat Robertson in an attempt to control later balloting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6, 28 Rivalry between the superpowers was condemned by Pope John Paul II in an encyclical letter, charging that it subjected poor nations to imperialistic ''structures of sin'' that deny them freedom and development. Page 1 News Analysis: Papal encyclicals are scrutinized by theologians the way constitutional lawyers pore over Supreme Court decisions. John Paul II's ''Sollicitudo Rei Socialis'' will keep the theologians very busy during the next week. 5 Failure to control drug trafficking in Panama and Mexico should not be penalized by the United States, a Government report concluded. The countries are still eligible for aid, the report said. 1 A kidnapped U.S. Marine officer is being held by a clandestine group believed to be made up of pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalists. The group accused the officer, Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins, of being a C.I.A. agent. 1 A bomb exploded in Africa killing at least 14 people and wounding more than 30 in South Africa, known as Namibia. It is believed to be the biggest blast and the highest death toll in a single incident in a 22-year-old bush war. 3 Nicaragua talks were suspended between the Government and guerrilla representatives by the mediator whosaid the two sides remained too far apart to have meaningful discussion, creating an impasse. 3 NATO arms control strategy must be thoroughly reviewed as a follow-up to the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles in Europe, President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed. 6 The South Korean President-elect, Roh Tae Woo, who will take office next week, has named a Cabinet filled with holdovers from the present Government in many key positions. His emphasis is on political and economic continuity. 28 Caraguatay journal: People leave and the dollars arrive 5 NATIONAL 7-10, 50 Economic growth is less robust than it could be, because of past Federal Reserve policy and the October stock market rout, the Administration said in its annual economic report. The criticism of the central bank was the harshest that the Administration has made recently. 1 A top Wall Street speculator was arraigned on charges of illegal possession of a gun that prosecutors said he planned to use to kill Ivan F. Boesky. The accused man, John A. Mulheren, has been under investigation for the past year. 1 Economists in this year's campaign are playing a smaller advisory role than they did in the past. One reason seems to be that a view of economists as seers and problem solvers has diminished. Another reason is the economy itself. 1 Biotechnology research programs are being supported by state governments more than ever before, according to industry analysts and state officials. States are likely to spend $150 million this year on the industry. 7 Jesse Jackson campaigned at home this week, seeking votes from Southerners who find the promises of the New South unfulfilled. Mr. Jackson is confident he will do well in Super Tuesday Democratic contests next month. 8 Dole challenges Bush on taxes 8 Two in G.O.P. debate and two stay away 8 The problem of waste disposal is crystallizing in Philadelphia, where angry residents are attacking Mayor W. Wilson Goode's decision to build a trash-to-steam plant. 7 For National Guard Eskimo scouts, the cold war persists with the frigidity of an Alaskan winter. The Eskimos are suspicious of their Soviet neighbors in Siberia and say they are the first line of defense against the Russian bear. 7 To speed new AIDS drug treatments, the Food and Drug Administration needs more funds and staff, the chairman of the President's AIDS commission said at a hearing on the adequacy of the nation's drug development program. 9 The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, the television evangelist, is under investigation by his church over matters that could cost him his credentials, the governing body of his denomination, the Assemblies of God, said. 9 Federal sentencing guidelines held unconstitutional 10 Marine acquitted of attempted murder at 2d trial 50 Teen-ager arrested in ax slaying of four in family 50 REGIONAL 10, 29-32 Grumman will pay the M.T.A. $40 million for its troubled Flxibile buses, four years after they were banished from the streets of New York City. Both sides said they were satisfied with the settlement. 1 The fate of The New York Post remained in doubt as negotiations continued beyond Rupert Murdoch's deadline for closing the beleaguered newspaper. The bargaining might continue well into the weekend. 1 Rupert Murdoch's lawyer for The New York Post, Victor Strimbu Jr., -sometimes known as ''Slick Vic'' -has injected calm into what might otherwise have been acrimonious bargaining sessions, negotiators said. 32 Post talks keep Kheel in the limelight 32 Nurses who called in sick as part of ''sickouts'' at two Bronx hospitals said it was hard to stay away from their patients. The ''sickouts'' were organized to protest inhumane working conditions. 29 The landlord under house arrest in one of his neglected apartment buildings in Brooklyn for 15 days was ordered released yesterday, eight days early, because of time off for good behavior. The early release angered tenants of the building. 30 A fleet of city tow trucks will offer free gasoline, jump starts and tows for disabled motorists on Staten Island highways in a test to begin Monday. 31 A major Mafia informer testified for the first time yesterday at a court hearing, but refused to answer many questions and said he could not remember if his family had received ''threats of violence.'' 31 Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis will not be tried a third time in a triple-murder case that provoked national attention over charges that the authorities had framed both men, New Jersey prosecutors said. 29 A death at Rutgers forces a policy change 29 D'Amato says Kemp should challenge Moynihan 30

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the early retirement of debt of $1,709,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter includes a pretax gain of $6.8 million from the company's sale of part of its Lease Portfolio to General Electric Capital Corp.

title: Publisher Sells Control of U.P.I. to WNW Group
description: Mario Vazquez-Rana, the Mexican newspaper publisher, announced last night that he had sold control of United Press International Inc. and that the former president of the Financial News Network Inc. will take over direct operational control of the company.

title: Texaco Stock Rises After Meeting
description: The stock of Texaco Inc. jumped in heavy trading yesterday after James W. Kinnear, its president and chief executive, told securities analysts that the company was negotiating with an oil-exporting country for the sale of an interest in its refineries in Texas, Louisiana and Delaware.

title: Negotiations With Post Keep Kheel in Limelight
description: For Theodore W. Kheel, perhaps the most influential industrial peacemaker in New York City in the last half-century, advising the newspaper unions in their negotiations with The New York Post is a matter of providing guidance and ''clarification'' - in what are acknowledged by both sides to have been very important dollops.

title: Soviet Skier Wins Nordic Gold Medal
description: Mikhail Deviatiarov, setting a blazing pace from the start before bursting free in the last leg, won the men's 15-kilometer cross-country ski race today, giving the Soviet Union its third gold medal in four cross-country races.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for the 4-for- 3 stock split effected in June 1987.

title: Boy, 16, Charged in Ax Murders Of 4 in His Family in Minnesota
description: The authorities today arrested David Brom, 16 years old, in the ax murders of his parents, a brother and a sister. Prosecutors said they would seek to try him as an adult on murder charges.

title: Figini and Walliser Shut Out
description: She stood near the photo corral, her eyes fixed on the finish line, unwilling to wave to the crowd or pose for pictures until the last racer had completed her run. Marina Kiehl of West Germany had been burned before in the downhill, twice losing World Cup races to late starters who had been overlooked. So she was certainly not about to celebrate prematurely now, in the most important downhill of all.

title: Brawley's Lawyers Deny Setting Conditions
description: Lawyers for Tawana Brawley, the black teen-ager who says she was abducted and raped by six white men last November, denied yesterday that they had given Attorney General Robert Abrams five major sets of conditions under which she would cooperate with the authorities.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the potential impact of President Reagan's budget on major Government programs misstated the change proposed for the Environmental Protection Agency. The $1.63 billion budget would be an increase of $48 million over this year, not a decrease.

title: PAPAL AIDES CITE ORIGINS OF LETTER
description: Pope John Paul II's encyclical letter condemning the superpower rivalry is a highly personal document that reflects his Polish heritage and is characteristically both blunt and meditative, according to senior Vatican officials.

title: In Guatemala, Growing Pessimism on Human Rights Issues
description: In Guatemala, where thousands of people have died in political violence during the 1980's, human rights advocates have never been popular. So the creation last year of an independent agency empowered to denounce any and all abuses aroused considerable curiosity and even some hope.

title: Anti-Poverty Program Seeks to Build Self-Esteem
description: On a raw winter morning near Skid Row, a dozen mothers on welfare listened to a story about a poor woman like them who once thought she had not a chance in the world.

title: GOOD JOURNALISM FOR STUDENTS EXTOLLED
description: In response to Kim Jenkins's Jan. 31 Opinion Page article ''First Amendment: Is It Just for Adults?'':

title: Dining Modestly on St. Barts
description: ''HAVE you found that little hole in the wall where we can get some simple grilled fish and a glass of wine without spending a fortune?'' That was the challenge presented by a friend and colleague we happened to meet while vacationing on St. Barthelemy.

title: On the Alert for A Bad Ice Cube
description: WHEN we visited our son when he was in college in Bogota 10 years ago, I asked with some embarrassment about drinking the water. He snorted and said the water at the Hilton was as safe as at home. Since his arrival there, he had not reported being ill, so I followed his lead. But when we traveled to San Andres Island, Colombia, he took one look at the tap in the hotel room there and said: ''Not this water.''

title: A WEEK THAT STARS THE AVANT-GARDE
description: THE big musical event of the week is the six-day series of lectures, discussions and concerts that Wesleyan University is devoting to the avant-garde composer John Cage, who has turned 75 years old.

title: IF OLD SONGS DON'T FIT, DON'T SING THEM
description: ''What would you like to hear?''

title: ANNA T. PETITE IS WED TO THOMAS GREEFF LEE
description: At the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Anna Tobey Petite, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Clinton Petite of Bronxville, was married yesterday to Thomas Greeff Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Lee of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. C. Carter Via performed the ceremony.

title: THE NATION: The Funds; How Much Does Money TAlk?
description: SENATOR KERRY. We had 11 new senators come in last time.

title: Poll Finds Less Optimism in U.S. On Future, a First Under Reagan
description: For the first time since Ronald Reagan became President more than seven years ago, the American public generally does not believe the nation's future will be better than its present or its past, according to a New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Riboud's Lens Is Connected to the Heart
description: ''I owe Cartier-Bresson every-thing. I learned from him the supreme importance of geometry -the relationship of abstract shapes within a frame,'' says Marc Riboud. And it was Cartier-Bresson who inspired him with ''the idea of the 'decisive movement,' that instant seized on film which reveals a visual order in the chaos of reality.'' Mr. Riboud brought his own genius to these lessons. A show of 119 of his works spanning the last 35 years is at the midtown branch of the International Center of Photography, 77 West 45th Street (through March 12) and his new book, ''Marc Riboud: Photographs at Home and Abroad,'' is being published by Harry N. Abrams.

title: MARTHA MOSS IS ENGAGED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert M. Moss of Huntington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Moss to Dr. David DiBenedetto, a son of Mrs. Joseph DiBenedetto of Belmont, Mass., and the late Mr. DiBenedetto. Miss Moss expects to graduate in May from the Boston University School of Medicine. Her fiance, a dentist in Pembroke, Mass., is an alumnus of the Boston University School of Graduate Dentistry.

title: SCHOOL PRINCIPAL PLAN DRAWING FIRE
description: OPPOSITION to a key aspect of a plan to revise certification standards for school principals is intensifying.

title: SECRETS OF THE RAIN FOREST
description: It was exciting to read about how Donald Perry has learned to traverse the jungle canopy to explore the secrets of the rain forest (''Secrets of the Rain Forest,'' by Erik Eckholm, Jan. 17).

title: 6 Indicted in Attack With Racial Overtone
description: The reputed leader of a Chicago-area white supremacist group called the Skinheads and five others were indicted today for attacking a woman and drawing a swastika on her wall with her blood.

title:
INVESTING;
Behind the Rally in Bank Stocks
description: LEAD: THEIR stocks were market laggards for almost two years, and many of the country's largest banks reported huge losses last year, but money-center and regional banking companies have enjoyed a rally since December.

title: An Iran-Iraq Peace Is Up to the U.N.
description: ''If the Iran-Iraq war does not come to an end officially in 1988, it will at least be practically over.'' This judgment, so contrary to the prevailing image of the war as a conflict without end, was expressed several weeks ago not by an armchair observer from afar but by Crown Prince Abdallah of Saudi Arabia, who had just completed a round of consultations about the war in the major Arab capitals followed by a summit meeting of Arab Gulf states. His is still a minority view, but there is growing evidence that this seemingly interminable war may be winding down at last.

title: Paying Damages For a Lynching
description: IT WAS a year ago this month that a Federal jury in Mobile, Ala., decided that when Ku Klux Klansmen commit violence, not only they - but the group to which they belong - can be held liable for damages.

title: FICTION
description: THE DARK PATH TO THE RIVER. By Joanne Leedom-Ackerman. (Saybrook/Norton, $19.95.) Joanne Leedom-Ackerman's first novel is a densely plotted, dialogue-filled story that reads like commercial fiction yet examines unconventional territory. Frequently shifting points of view, the book focuses on the fates of two American friends and former newspaper colleagues who are united in their interest in a small, unnamed African country on the brink of revolution. Olivia, a black freelance journalist, has spent years living in Africa and is familiar with the leaders and aims of the National Liberation Association (N.L.A.), a group wishing to free the country from the corrupt excesses of its self-proclaimed president-for-life. Jenny, a white writer at work on a book about African women, is less attuned to the nation's internal problems but has a personal reason for her concern: her husband's investment company has financed a mining operation that may be manipulating both sides of the political struggle. Neither woman has yet reached her potential as a writer, and Ms. Leedom-Ackerman shows how their preoccupation with the country's crisis also liberates them professionally. She is particularly successful in building suspense throughout Olivia's search in New York City for two vanished N.L.A. leaders. Unfortunately, the author has also weighed down ''The Dark Path to the River'' with a lengthy subplot involving Jenny's attempt to extricate her maddeningly naive husband not only from the clutches of unscrupulous businessmen but also from another woman. Ms. Leedom-Ackerman concludes with too many simple solutions and loose ends. However, her writing is often sensitive and ambitious enough to keep the reader interested in both the political and personal spheres she explores.

A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. 2 226 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 52 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life as a series of losses. 4 68 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 5 3 INTRUDERS, by Budd Hopkins. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weigthed to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Baseball; Johnson Greets 9 Position Players
description: Dave Johnson began his fifth and final year as manager of the Mets today with a new spring training address but with the old thunder, and predicted: ''We should win. We could dominate.''

title: A CHILD IN AUSCHWITZ
description: GUNS AND BARBED WIRE A Child Survives the Holocaust. By Thomas Geve. Illustrated. 220 pp. Illinois: Academy Chicago. $18.95.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; 'Affordables' at the White Plains Station
description: Downtown White Plains is getting something city officials have wanted for a long time - medium-priced condominiums in the midst of a half-dozen new, large office buildings near the railroad station.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Rhinos Elect The 'Spaceman'

title: Pact to Save The Post Is Reached; Buyer Looks to Regain Advertisers
description: Rupert Murdoch and 10 unions agreed early yesterday on $22 million in concessions to save The New York Post, and hours later plans were under way to rejuvenate the paper and win back readers and advertisers who have defected in recent months.

title: KATHRYN O'NEILL TO MARRY WRITER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. O'Neill of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagment of their daughter Kathryn Mary O'Neill to Nicholas C. Katz, the son of Carol Cambas of New York and Sanford M. Katz of New York and East Hampton, L.I.

title:
ART;
SCULPTURAL FORMS OF AFRICAN ART
description: LEAD: A SENSE of discovering a wealth of powerful, inventive sculptural forms is the first impression generated by the current exhibition of African art at the Hofstra Museum.

title: Surprising DePaul Shocks St. John's
description: St. John's lost for the second time in three days last night, this time to a surprising DePaul team.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A MEDAL FOR THE 7 CHALLENGER ASTRONAUTS
description: LEAD: A new medal honors the seven astronauts who lost their lives on the ill-fated Challenger mission. It is being sold to raise funds for an even more impressive tribute to the astronauts: a Challenger Space Monument.

title: RUMANIA AND HUNGARY LET WAR OF WORDS SLIP OUT
description: Relations between Hungary and Rumania, neighbors and allies in the Warsaw Pact, have worsened to such a degree that they now speak to and about each other only in accusation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article on the Stay in School Partnership Program misidentified the school where William Ford teaches. It is John Burroughs Junior High School in Yonkers.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
SMITHTOWNZ
description: LEAD: Smithtown, the eighth largest town in the state and the fifth most populous on Long Island, lies along Suffolk County's North Shore. Its 117,308 residents live in three incorporated villages - Head of the Harbor, Nissequogue and The Branch - and the unincorporated areas of Nesconset, St. James and Kings Park as well as parts of Commack, Hauppauge, Fort Salonga and Lake

title: Senior Boxing Remembered
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Alternative to Prison in New York: Six Months of Counseling and Tutoring
description: If he were a head shorter, Maximo Blake said, he would have probably ended up in trouble with the law instead of working with the law-enforcement authorities to give young offenders fresh starts.

title: Mildred Seydell; Journalist, 98
description: Mildred Seydell, a journalist who interviewed Mussolini and covered the Scopes trial, died today. She was 98 years old.

title: NEW GROUP OF THE UNEMPLOYED EMERGES
description: FOR 33 years the Senior Personnel Employment Council of Westchester has offered a no-fee employment service for workers older than 55. The first organization of its type in the nation, it has been replicated many times. The key ''plus'' that the council offers to workers is the absence of any discrimination because of age: employers list jobs with the full knowledge that we on the council deal only with workers 55 and older.

title: Duke Rallies to Top Kansas in Overtime
description: Quin Snyder scored 21 points, including 7 in overtime, as Duke came back twice to beat Kansas, 74-70, today.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower. However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout. I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub. Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

title: Olympics Viewer Feels Frustrated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Protecting Health in Realty Transactions
description: LEAD: Over the last decade, the state's real estate industry has not only grown bigger and busier, but also more complex - in part because of environmental, health and social concerns.

title: DR. G. J. RUTH IS WED TO ALYSE D. GORDON
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York, Alyse D. Gordon, the daughter of Philip Gordon of New York and the late Elizabeth P. Gordon, was married last night to Dr. Gary J. Ruth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Ruth of Auburn, Wash. Rabbi Saul Berman, assisted by Cantor Sherwood Goffin, performed the ceremony.

title: The Changing World of Alcoholics Anonymous
description: Adapted from ''Getting Better: Inside Alcoholics Anonymous,'' by Nan Robertson, to be published by William Morrow in April.

title: NEWARK RESIDENTS LOSE FIGHT TO BAN INCINERATOR
description: AS MORE than 100 demonstrators protested, ground was broken last week on Blanchard Street, in the city's Ironbound section, for Essex County's resource-recovery plant.

title: Opera: At Juilliard, 'Beatrice and Benedict'
description: BERLIOZ'S opera ''Beatrice and Benedict'' contains some of his most magical music, but with its rigorous demands for accomplished acting and singing and its musical complexity, it is rarely performed. Thus one welcomed Friday evening's production by the Juilliard American Opera Center, especially in the confines of the city's best opera facility, the Juilliard Theater. But gratitude couldn't compensate for an unsure production and performance.

title: U.S. 'COLONY' IS FEELING A BREEZE OF CHANGE
description: OF all America's possessions, none has appeared more content with the relationship, at least in recent years, than the Virgin Islands. But there are signs of change.

title: FROM THE ARTS TO THE STARS
description: LEAD: LECTURE offerings in the county this spring are once again plentiful and varied.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN GARRISON, A TOUCH OF THE PAST
description: LEAD: RECOVERING from several years of culinary decline, the venerable Bird and Bottle Inn appears to be making a comeback, a welcome and worthy direction for this splendid 18th-century up-county tavern. Burnished wood paneling, wide-plank floors, low beamed ceiling and the luster of pewter preserve the aura of its stagecoach-stop past.

title: PARIS CREATES
description: Some seasons, the Paris couture is everything it is supposed to be - and more. This spring is certainly one of those. The collections shown last month not only had plenty of clothes for the couture clientele to choose from, but, even more importantly, they were loaded with multiple messages for the fashion community at large. The use of several strong colors in one costume, the sometimes mad mix of flower patterns and stripes, the plethora of polka dots, the penchant for lace and the return to fluttery tulle for fairy-tale ball gowns - all were among the suggestive fabrications. Though general silhouettes remained unchanged - short skirts and fairly close-fitted shapes being the norm - there were some interesting variations, the most notable being skirts that belled or swelled from slightly heightened waistlines. There were a few shapes that forecast new directions. Three pencil-slim, midi-length costumes balanced on top by wide-brimmed hats designed by Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel were radically different from anything in the rest of his collection, or, for that matter, elsewhere in Paris. Though obviously not easy to wear - a woman would have to be trimmer than trim and as chic as all get-out to carry them - they are bound to stimulate other designers into new slinky thinking. The high-waisted soft pants of Christian Lacroix should do likewise. And Yves Saint Laurent's intriguing mixes of color - his crossing of several seemingly discordant shades of blue with just an accent of acid green in one daytime costume, for instance - is sure to tempt others to try to follow suit. Accessories and embroideries were full of invention, from Saint Lau-rent's reincarnation of famous paintings in sequins (executed by Lesage) to Eman-uel Ungaro's plastic roses glazed like cheap candy but nonetheless curi-ously desirable. Saint Laurent is bring-ing back the evening cape. But it is the su-perb jackets that Christian Lacroix concocted that will stir the imagina-tions of many a fashion fan.

title: In Britain, Many In the Arts Say Profit and Loss Has Replaced Beauty and Truth
description: After more than eight years, Britain's artists, actors and writers show few signs of being won over by Margaret Thatcher. Some of their deep-seated animosity toward her recently surfaced publicly as a cultural debate. A few weeks ago The Sunday Telegraph ran a prominent article that asked the question: Why do the intelligentsia hate her so much? In reply, Jonathan Miller, the stage and film director, cited the Prime Minister's ''odious suburban gentility and sentimental, saccharine patriotism,'' which, in his view, cater to the ''worst elements of commuter idiocy.'' Writing in The Guardian, Hanif Kureishi, the author of the screenplays for ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' and ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid,'' described Mrs. Thatcher's Britain as 'a narrow-minded, authoritarian rat hole.'' Artists of every persuasion have accused the Government of philistinism because of its desire to reduce its role in subsidizing the arts and expand that of the private sector. It has insinuated the values of the marketplace onto the high ground of the arts, these critics say, properly the realm of beauty and truth, not the profit-and-loss statement.

title: NICARAGUA ORDERS A 10% BUDGET CUT
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced new austerity measures today to accompany the jarring currency devaluation he decreed a week ago.

title: Sell Solutions, Not Just Products
description: SOME say multinational corporations threaten the economic and political independence of developing countries and represent one of the greatest obstacles to development. Others find progress in the third world inconceivable without companies operating on an international scale. Multinationals, they say, transfer technologies, as well as exemplary standards for production safety, the environment and social responsibility.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sports section on Feb. 7 previewing Winter Olympic competition misidentified the current world hockey champion, and another article misidentified the 1984 winner of the Olympic bronze medal in hockey. Sweden is the world champion and won the bronze in the 1984 Games at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: Two Soviets Take an Eye-Opening Historic Step
description: George Balanchine was a complex man of firm convictions and deep contradictions. Like many Russian emigres, he had a love-hate relationship with his native land and he could not abide the Communist regime. Yet, he enthusiastically accepted its invitation to visit the Soviet Union twice and show off the fruit of his 60-year artistic endeavor abroad - the masterworks he had choreographed and the fabulous company, the New York City Ballet, that he had created and molded. Contemporary Soviet ballet held no attraction for him, but after World War II, he engaged several Soviet-trained emigre teachers for the School of American Ballet.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION
description: NEARBY RAFTING North American Whitewater Expeditions Inc., based in Hamden, Conn., offers what it believes is ''some of the best whitewater rafting in the East'' beginning in March and continuing through early May. An eight-mile stretch of the upper Housatonic River, starting at Bull's Bridge Gorge in western Connecticut, provides a course through rapids that drop 90 feet in the first mile, then rushes through steep chasms, over large waves and difficult ledge drops.

title: Lawyers for Brawley Halt Aid in Inquiry
description: Contending that the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, ''is aligning himself with the culprits,'' lawyers for a black teen-ager who says she was kidnapped and sexually attacked by six white men broke off cooperation with Mr. Abrams yesterday.

title: Missing Ingredient
description: Deregulation aside, the folks in Washington still insist that a product labeled ''apple juice'' have something in it that came from apples. Federal prosecutors charged that for several years, executives at the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation deliberately ignored such standards and sold as pure apple juice intended for babies a concoction derived mainly from beet sugar and sugar cane syrup. Last week, a jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn found Niels L. Hoyvald, who was president of Beech-Nut at the time of the indictment in 1986, guilty on 350 counts of mislabeling the phony juice. The prosecutor, Thomas H. Roche, called it a case of ''corporate greed and irresponsibility.'' John F. Lavery, a former Beech-Nut vice president, was also convicted of hundreds of violations of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. No sentencing date was set.

title: Swaggart Is Silent on Inquiry
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, who accused Jim Bakker, the ousted PTL leader, of sexual misconduct, had no comment today on reports that the Assemblies of God church was investigating similar allegations against him.

title: RYE RESIDENTS ORGANIZE EFFORT TO BLOCK PLANS FOR AVON SITE
description: AVON Products, makers of women's cosmetics, has been the largest taxpayer in the city of Rye for many years. Now more than 350 residents have organized in opposition to its expansion and are asking the city to block its plans for two office buildings.

title: Binoculars
description: To the Editor: ''Gifts of Gear and Gadgets'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 22) by Betsy Wade contains information about the type of binoculars to buy, but there are no specifics on manufacturers, magnification, field, etc. The price is given as being in the ''several hundred dollar'' range.

title: NANCY CAREY PLANS TO WED
description: The engagement of Nancy Elizabeth Carey to Alan P. Goldberg has been announced by Miss Carey's father, Hugh L. Carey, the former New York Governor. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Goldberg of Swampscott, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Hrudey Gets 2d Shutout
description: It is not every night that a goaltender comes away with a shutout, so Kelly Hrudey of the Islanders had something to celebrate tonight.

title: One Woman's Quest For a Hong Kong Suit
description: IF you think having a suit made in Hong Kong, where the tourist association's booklet on shopping and restaurants lists 142 tailoring establishments, is easy, think again. At least, if you have visions of a beautifully made, perfectly fitting suit with the construction, fit and hand-sewn touches that come only with custom work. Maybe it's easier if you happen to be a man. A lot of things seem to be, especially in Asia. There are certain accepted standards for men's suits made in Hong Kong. There should be no question about the hand-stitched lapels or pad-stitching on the underside of the collar to give it that soft roll. Narrow cotton tape should be applied along the lapel seam and down the front of the jacket to keep it from stretching out of shape, and wool canvas (called hair canvas) used to give body to lapels, collar and shoulders. For women's suits there seem to be no general standards of workmanship.

title: MODERNISTS, GO HOME
description: LEAD: A SINKING ISLAND The Modern English Writers. By Hugh Kenner. 290 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: MODULAR HOMES SHED MOBILE LOOK AND COME OF AGE
description: LEAD: ONCE upon a time, there were trailers, which begot mobile homes, which, by way of prefabs, eventually begot modular homes. And any resemblance between modular homes, also known as factory-built housing, and their forebears is probably only in the archives of social historians.

title: VERONICA FIELDING TO MARRY
description: Veronica Lee Fielding and William Charles Petzinger Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Petzinger of Toms River, N.J., plan to marry in April, the future bride's mother, Florence Fielding of South Toms River, N.J., has announced. Miss Fielding, also the daughter of the late Robert Fielding, is the manager of marketing in the news retrieval division of the Dow Jones Company in Princeton, N.J. Her fiance is a public relations account executive with Poppe Tyson Advertising and Public Relations in Morristown, N.J.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bradford, Conn. $235,000 26 Riverside Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; landscaping, near river, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,274. Clinton, Conn. $142,000 10 Hurdbridge Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; in-law apartment, pool, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,199. Madison, Conn. $296,000 5 Frank's Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; exceptional insulation, near town center, huge master bedroom, 1.4 acres; taxes not yet available. Ardsley, N.Y. $465,000 108 Euclid Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; deck, patio, cathedral ceiling; taxes $8,081. Purdy Station, N.Y. $215,000 First Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 138-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, barn, brick patio, new well; taxes $2,023. Yonkers, N.Y. $240,000 23 Covington Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, den, porch, playroom; taxes $2,946. OTHER AREAS Howell, N.J. $207,000 25 Rimwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; deck, w/w carpeting, pool; taxes $2,751. Millburn, N.J. $221,000 15 Rahway Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; c/a, fireplace, porch, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,312. Laurel, L.I. $142,000 571 Peconic Bay Boulevard 4-bedroom, 2-bath, colonial; dining room, study, basement; taxes $1,600.

title: A Serene Place To Work, Not a Corporate Spaceship
description: It is a common conceit to de-scribe architecture in terms created for sound - there are buildings that are shrill, and others that are cacophonous.

title: It's Not Easy to Speak Audio
description: In a recurrent fantasy, I envision George Orwell reading a hi-fi catalogue. His gaunt gray face looks puzzled. The great champion of clarity and integrity in language - the man who skewered newspeak, cant and blather -frowns at the jargon of audio.

title: MIRROR IMAGES
description: BOTH OF THE SMALL glass jars have colored filaments swirling through them; both are sold with little plastic paddles, one pink and the other green. One is Estee Lauder's Eyzone Repair Gel, the other is Revlon's Anti-Aging Firming Eye Gel.

title: FRENCH ACCENT, L.A. LIGHT
description: CITRUS IS THE SAME IN French and English, conjuring up images of freshness, lightness and zesty flavor. The year-old restaurant named Citrus in Los Angeles blends French and American cuisines to produce lively and remarkably healthful dishes.

title: HERE, SMALL STEPS OF HOPE
description: FROM Bayberry Avenue in the courthouse-complex country of Garden City, the long, low building across the iced front lawn could have been any Long Island school. The visitor watched buses arriving to discharge small passengers for a day of what might be, elsewhere, such minor miracles as spelling a word correctly or grasping one more of the arcane mysteries of arithmetic, or the like.

title: A REWARDING PASSAGE TO INDIA
description: A QUICK and delicious passage to India can be made enjoyably at a modest storefront restaurant named Bonani in Stamford.

title: MERYL JUSTIN PLANS TO WED
description: The engagement of Meryl Sali Justin to Michael Chertoff, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gershon B. Chertoff of Elizabeth, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joshua I. Justin of New York, the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned. Miss Justin, an associate in the New York law firm of Schoeman, Marsh, Updike & Welt, graduated from Harvard University and the Harvard Law School. She was a law clerk to Judge Myron H. Thompson of the Federal District Court in Montgomery, Ala. Her father is a chemical development fellow at Merck & Company in Rahway, N.J. Her mother, Norma Justin, is an ophthalmic research analyst at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: The Guerrilla Fight in Mozambique Also Takes a Toll on Zimbabwe
description: As the crippling war in Mozambique spills over into Zimbabwe, the Government of Executive President Robert G. Mugabe is increasingly faced with competing pressures over this country's military involvement in the conflict.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MRS. CALIBAN, by Rachel Ingalls. (Laurel/Dell, $6.95.) An unhappy California housewife has an affair with a 6-foot-7-inch amphibian humanoid named Larry, who is fleeing from the law. In 1986, our reviewer, Michael Dorris, compared the novel to ''a strange conversation overheard on a bus: sketchy, incomplete, maddening, but totally unforgettable. . . . Rachel Ingalls has created a tight, intriguing portrait of a woman's escape from unacceptable reality.'' THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB, by Richard Rhodes. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Albert Einstein's letter to Franklin D. Roosevelt in October 1939, urging the United States to make an atomic bomb, has become enshrined in the mythology of World War II. According to Richard Rhodes's history, which won a National Book Award, it was actually Alexander Sachs, a Wall Street financier, who persuaded F.D.R. of the need for what came to be called the Manhattan Project. Last year in these pages, William J. Broad praised the book for its ''remarkable breadth and depth, revealing new connections, insights and surprises. . . . Short on heroes and villains, [ it ] is populated instead with complex figures in a compelling plot.'' THE FISHER KING, by Anthony Powell. (Norton, $7.95.) In this novel by Anthony Powell, the author of ''A Dance to the Music of Time,'' the fisher king - the impotent ruler of Arthurian legend - is Saul Henchman, a famous photographer who is involved in a difficult romance with his beautiful assistant. In 1986, John Gross said in The Times that the enigmatic story is not ''for newcomers to Mr. Powell's work. . . . But for anyone who has already succumbed to [ his ] spell it can hardly fail to have considerable fascination.'' A MODERN DAY YANKEE IN A CONNECTICUT COURT: And Other Essays on Science, by Alan Lightman. (Penguin, $6.95.) The physicist Alan Lightman's decision to become a theorist rather than an experimenter was made in college after a disastrous experience in an electronics lab; he also learned along the way that he has a talent for telling stories about science. ''Throughout his yarns and reflections, [ he ] marvels at our intellectual bravado and the potency of the human mind,'' Yvonne Baskin said here last year. THE LOVER OF HORSES: And Other Stories, by Tess Gallagher. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) When Tess Gallagher's first collection of short stories was published in 1986, our reviewer, Bette Pesetsky, said she tried to forget that the author was already an accomplished poet. ''The reward was to find an excellent writer of prose who savors the elegance of simplicity and whose stories resonate and linger.'' DEPARTURES: Memoirs, by Paul Zweig. (Penguin, $6.95.) During a short life of painful introspection, the poet and critic Paul Zweig was obsessed by the notion that he was trapped inside what our reviewer, Michael Davidson, called a ''bubble of self-awareness.'' ''Although he wrote in many forms,'' Mr. Davidson said in 1986, ''the memoir may have been Zweig's most appropriate medium. It allowed him to reach back to specific moments and see them in all of their lucidity.'' A SPLENDID EXECUTIONER, by Timothy Downey. (Ivy/Ballantine, $2.95.) The newspaperman Pete Killharney's ''hit list'' of the 10 most reprehensible New Yorkers is an annual journalistic event; when someone starts killing the members of this rogues' gallery, he takes it upon himself to find the murderer. Last year Newgate Callendar said here that the novel is ''brisk, bright, often grimly amusing and a pleasure to read.'' REAGAN'S AMERICA, by Garry Wills. (Penguin, $8.95.) According to Garry Wills, Ronald Reagan's success in selling the public on his version of the American dream shows that he is ''the opposite of a chameleon: environments adapt themselves to him.'' Last year in The Book Review, C. Vann Woodward called this biography a ''remarkable and evenhanded study. . . . For efforts to find Mr. Reagan's 'place in history,' [ it ] will be indispensable.'' DELIRIUM ECLIPSE & OTHER STORIES, by James Lasdun. (Norton, $7.95.) In 1986, our reviewer, Jonathan Penner, said he was not impressed with all of these stories, which won the Dylan Thomas Award for Short Story Writing. But as a whole, the collection ''reveals a combination of talents - narrative, rhetorical, inventive, meditative - so rare that one forgives all else. James Lasdun is a writer to watch.'' HOLY FEAST AND HOLY FAST: The Religious Significance of Food to Medieval Women, by Caroline Walker Bynum. (University of California, $12.95.) To medieval theologians man represented reason and the divine, while women - who were used to feeling subservient -were symbols of humanity, exercising their religious role in rituals involving food and fasting. ''The evidence [ the author ] amasses makes this daring thesis seem inevitable,'' John Freccero said here last year. ''Her work is a prodigious labor of social history, employing every resource imaginable.'' THE FAR CRY, by Fredric Brown. (Black Lizard, $3.95.) After George Weaver has a nervous breakdown, he flees Kansas City for the mountains of Taos, N.M., where he rents a house whose last tenant was a killer. In 1951, Anthony Boucher said here that the novel contains ''a fine bitter study of a bad marriage, and an admirable sense of the reality of murder.'' Mr. Boucher was also taken with Fredric Brown's HIS NAME WAS DEATH ($3.95), which has been reissued by the same publisher. The story of a woman who unwittingly sets off a chain of murders has ''one of the very few endings that have genuinely surprised me in a long time,'' he said in 1954.

title: LOBBYING GROUPS RATE WASHINGTON DELEGATION
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Bay Islands of Honduras
description: AS predictably as sunset burnishes the half-moon coves and secluded cays of the Bay Islands, off Honduras's Caribbean coast, visitors begin to wonder how long the islands can escape the kind of large-scale tourist development that has both benefited and blighted so many other tropical beauty spots.

title: Missing Out
description: When Dan Jansen fell, it was not from grace. Last week, hours before he was to compete in the first of two Olympic speed-skating events in which he had high hopes of winning medals, Jansen got word that his sister, Jane Jansen Beres, had died of leukemia. He was noticeably distraught as he started the 500-meter finals, and tumbled to the ice in the first turn. The folks back home in West Allis, Wis., sent a banner to Calgary, Alberta, to cheer him on.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: Are Corporations Less Charitable?; Giving Gets Unfashionable
description: TRADITIONS that we inherit sometimes lose their vitality and fall into disuse. Ideas have no claim on us if we haven't made them our own. Principles that become institutionalized in organizations often wind up as empty rules and regulations enforced by people who have given the word ''bureaucrat'' a bad name. Ideas that are inspiring to one generation may, over several generations, become meaningless ritual.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LIQUIDATION SALE IN SCARSDALE Boutique Elle in Scarsdale was the first of three stores of that name selling stylish Italian sportswear, cocktail and evening wear. The others are in Cedarhurst Center in Cedarhurst, L.I., and the Woodbury Common in Woodbury, L.I. The two Long Island stores are remaining open and the mailing list will continue to alert shoppers to their sales, but the Scarsdale branch is having its final week of a liquidation sale beginning today and Monday - days it is usually closed -and continuing through Saturday.

title: BOOT CAMP FOR DELINQUENTS
description: CASTAWAYS The Penikese Island Experiment. By George Cadwalader. 193 pp. Chelsea, Vt.: Chelsea Green Publishing Company. $17.95.

title: A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
description: From the moment I arrived in the emergency room of New York Hospital complaining of chest pains, I was treated by doctors, nurses and technicians with promptness, consideration and good humor. I don't know how you measure a good outcome like mine against the terrible misfortune of Libby Zion. But I do know that a fair analysis would not have focused on specific cases of negligence at one hospital without mentioning specific cases at any other hospitals. Might it not be possible that what is distinctive about New York Hospital is the highly publicized nature of its problems? ALAN JOHN SEGAL Westport, Conn.

title: About Men; Rights and Choices
description: WHAT CAN A MAN do when the woman carrying the child they both deliberately created has a change of heart? What can a man do when the woman he loves wants an abortion and he passionately does not?

title: Cable TV
description: An impressive array of performances by women brightens the cable movie week. Joan Crawford, Ginger Rogers, Jennifer Jones, Sophia Loren and Glenda Jackson are all Oscar-winners. For dessert? A surprisingly vivacious stint by ice skater Sonja Henie.

title: Social Events
description: Having Fun, Aiding Others SoHo Dinner-Dance Feb. 24 - The Yorkville Common Pantry, which expects to supply 54,000 meals to the needy this year, is holding a benefit at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street, at Houston Street. Cocktails and jazz at 7 P.M. will be followed by dinner, dancing and an auction. Gabe Pressman, a reporter for Channel 4, will be honored. Tickets, $150, from 212-628-6070. 'Phantom' Party Feb. 24 - The American Council for the Arts, a national advocacy group that seeks to increase public and private support for all the arts, is holding a black-tie benefit that will begin with the 8 P.M. performance of ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' A dinner-dance at the Marriott Marquis will follow. Tickets, $500, from 212-245-4510. New Year's Celebration Feb. 25 - The Year of the Dragon, the Chinese New Year of 4686, will be celebrated at a benefit for the Pan Asian Repertory Theater at the Dish of Salt restaurant, 133 West 47th Street. Now in its seventh season, the company produces new plays, adaptations and American premieres of Asian works. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by entertainment and dinner. Tickets, $200, which includes a special March 4 performance of the play ''Yellow Fever''; $100 for the benefit alone; $65 for students, from 212-505-5655. B'nai B'rith Awards Feb. 25 - For 75 years, the goals of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith have been ''to stop the defamation of the Jewish people and to secure justice and fair treatment to all citizens alike.'' Its annual awards dinner will be held at the Plaza Hotel starting with cocktails at 6 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $400, from 212-490-2525, extension 382. Up, Up and Away Feb. 26 - Superman has turned 50; Jerry Siegel, a writer, and Joe Shuster, an artist, created the Man of Steel in 1938. DC Comics is sponsoring a multimedia celebration of the comic-book hero at the Puck Building to benefit the National Foster Parent Association. Show times, with refreshments, will be at 6, 7:30 and 9 P.M. Tickets, $12 for adults, $6 for those 12 and under, from Ticketmaster, 212-713-6300. Beaux-Arts Ball Feb. 26 - Traditionally one of the city's liveliest benefits, the annual Beaux-Arts Ball of the National Urban League Guild will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria starting at 9 P.M. and concluding with a Champagne breakfast. The evening will benefit the New York Public Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. Tickets, $135, which includes the breakfast; for the ball alone, $85 in advance from 212-310-9223, or $90 at the door. Network for the Blind Feb. 26 - Founded in 1977 by a stockbroker who was going blind, the In Touch Network is a closed-circuit radio network that reaches thousands each day with readings by volunteers from newspapers and magazines. The annual benefit for the network will be a cocktail party from 6 to 7:30 P.M., followed by a performance of the New York City Opera's revival of ''The Music Man'' at the New York State Theater. Tickets, $150, from 212-873-6770. Roulette, Etc. Feb. 26 - Gambling, dancing, libations and hors d'oeuvres will be the order of the evening at Bridgewaters restaurant at the South Street Seaport from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. The evening, which includes an auction of trips, is sponsored by the Manhattan Society, an auxiliary fund-raising group of the New York chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, and Travel Today magazine. Tickets, $75 in advance from 212-463-7787, or $90 at the door, both of which include $200 in gambling scrip. Downtown Beach Ball Feb. 27 - Fountain House, a social and vocational rehabilitation center for those with mental and emotional problems, is holding its second annual Beach Ball at the Puck Building, with dancing and entertainment from 8 P.M. to 2 A.M. Tickets, $30 from 212-582-0340, extension 37, or $40 at the door. Brooklyn Museum Gala Feb. 27 - The Cleopatra Gala, a benefit party at the Brooklyn Museum, will have the queen of the Nile as both its theme (including an orchestra of 16 women dressed in Cleopatra garb) and its purpose. The black-tie benefit from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M., featuring North African delicacies and other surprises, will benefit ''Cleopatra's Egypt,'' a major exhibition opening at the museum in October. Call 718-638-5000, extension 326 for tickets, at $75 each, and for information on bus transportation from Manhattan. Musical Treat Feb. 28 - The 100-member New York Youth Symphony, whose members are from 12 to 22 years old, will hold a 25th-anniversary benefit concert at Carnegie Hall. In addition to training promising young musicians at no cost, the symphony presents six free concerts each season. Donor tickets at $100 and patron tickets at $250 entitle the holders to reserved box seats for the 3 P.M. concert and to attend a cocktail party afterward at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, Tickets from 212-581-5933.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Stowe, Vt.: Controlling Development
description: LEAD: A development plan that is expected to help maintain the balance between tourism growth and land conservation is being formulated in this ski resort town.

title: The Cost of Caring for Elderly Parents
description: AS the baby-boom generation grows older, more children are contributing to the support of their aging parents and looking to basic tax devices to reduce their costs.

title: THERE ARE FOUR SIDES TO EVERYTHING
description: MAMA DAY By Gloria Naylor. 312 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: Ambulance Workers To Face Discipline In a Death in Bronx
description: Two Emergency Medical Service ambulance workers face disciplinary action because they waited for sandwiches in a Bronx delicatessen before responding to a report that a man was suffering a heart attack in a church one block away, officials said yesterday.

Laurel, L.I. $142,000 571 Peconic Bay Boulevard 4-bedroom, 2-bath, colonial; dining room, study, basement;

title: The Random House Dictionary Down With Astrology
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera: 'Curlew River,' Britten's Mystery Play
description: DURING a trip to Tokyo in 1956, Britten twice attended a Noh play, and saw in its static, austere forms a solemn, graceful poetry. ''Sumidagawa,'' the story of a madwoman who had lost her child, struck the composer for the slowness of its action, the combination of speaking, singing and chanting, and the quiet, mystical intensity that sustained the piece, presented both times with no conductor guiding the ensemble of players and musicians.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FROM CAMELOT TO KENT STATE: The Sixties Experience in the Words of Those Who Lived It. By Joan Morrison and Robert K. Morrison. (Times Books, Paper, $12.95.) Civil rights activists, Peace Corps volunteers, antiwar protesters, Vietnam veterans, feminists and former acid freaks reminisce about the 1960's in this engaging oral history.

title: Controversy - and Platitudes - Writ Large
description: ''Committed to Print'' at the Museum of Modern Art is an exhibition of ''social and political'' material - prints, posters, books and magazines that relate to concerns of today and yesterday in the United States. In almost all of them, the word ranks equal with the image. The general tone is defined by the museum as ''leftist or liberal,'' and for much of the way the word pulls the image along, the way horses pulled a covered wagon. Without the word, many of these images would be dull and inert.

title: A NEED TO STIR INTEREST IN ENGINEERING
description: MANY people say that young Japanese students went into engineering while ours thronged into law, that the products developed by one of these groups found eager buyers around the world while the product of the other found none.

title: Last-Place Rangers Struggle
description: James Patrick, who had the misfortune of playing many of the 60 humiliating minutes against the Devils the night before, sat with his head in his hands and his back, appropriately, against the wall.

title: HOW HE SAVED HIS SKIN
description: THE ADVENTURES AND SUFFERINGS OF JOHN R. JEWITT, CAPTIVE OF MAQUINNA Illustrated by Hilary Stewart. 192 pp. Seattle: University of Washington Press. $29.95.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FLOWERS THROUGH THE SEASON
description: LEAD: AS the name implies, annuals live but a single season and must be started from seed each year. Since started plants can be planted out almost as early as seeds can be safely sown outdoors, most annuals are started in greenhouses or cold frames 8 to 10 weeks ahead of the planting season. By doing this, it is possible to enjoy them longer.

title: Next Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Suburb of Washington At Odds Over Evictions
description: In the early days of World War II, the owners of many of the stately homes in this Washington suburb were asked to rent their spare rooms to help accomodate the influx of military and civilian workers into the capital.

title: THOSE HANDY CLAMPS
description: A MAXIM among woodworkers is that one can't have too many clamps.

title: TENANTS CARRY THE PROPERTY TAX LOAD
description: ALTHOUGH most New Yorkers live in apartment buildings, the city's property tax system displays a curious political tilt against them and in favor the minority of city dwellers who own one-, two- or three-family homes.

title: KELLY A. FREEHILL BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Kelly Ann Freehill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Bernardin Freehill of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Carey Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Hoffman of Barker, N.Y. Msgr. Francis Boyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: COIFFEUR TO STARS HELPS TROUPE
description: THE Trenton Civic Opera's production of ''The Sound of Music'' next Sunday will mark the culmination of months of work by dedicated amateurs, with one exception - the hairdresser and wig and hat designer.

title: THE NATION: The Opportunities; Can Republicans Wrest Control?
description: QUESTION. Who's hard to beat - on both sides.

title: Budget Called Bad for New York Area
description: Legislators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say that President Reagan's $1.09 trillion budget calls for too many sacrifices from the region's cities, but that the most improvement they expect is revisions for several key programs.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: BLACK HISTORY MONTH

title: Jazz: Saxophone, Doug White
description: IN the 1950's and early 60's, after the focus of jazz had shifted from swing to be-bop and before it was buried by the arrival of the Beatles, the guitarist Joe Puma and the bassist Knobby Totah were in the forefront of jazz activity. Mr. Puma played with Artie Shaw, Louis Bellson and Lee Konitz and was accompanist to Peggy Lee in the 50's and to Morgana King in the 60's. At the same time, Mr. Totah was with Charlie Parker, Woody Herman, Gene Krupa, the Al Cohn-Zoot Sims group and Bobby Hackett.

title: BREEZES OF CHANGE WAFTING THROUGH LAWRENCEVILLE
description: LEAD: FROM every appearance, Lawrenceville School is a traditional preparatory school where things have not changed much since its founding in 1810.

title: U.S. Industry's Unfinished Struggle
description: THROUGHOUT the country, corporate chiefs are sounding paeans to American industry's rebound from the competitive doldrums. In speeches, published papers and annual reports, they note how they have cut the fat out of management layers and divested businesses that did not fit in with overall corporate strategy.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After a year as a relief pitcher with the Boston Red Sox, Joe Sambito wants to make a new start with his original major league team, the Houston Astros. The Astros said that Sambito, who broke in with the club in 1976, would attend training camp as a nonroster player. . . . Leslie Frazier, a cornerback for the Chicago Bears during the 1985 season, when they won the Super Bowl, has been named the head football coach at Trinity College in Deerfield, Ill., when it fields its first football team since its 1887 founding. Frazier, 28 years old, was forced to retire as a player last summer because doctors feared he might suffer lifelong paralysis if he reinjured the left knee that required surgery before the 1986 season.

title: SoHo Marble
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Alaska Ferries Question: I am told there are ferries from Seattle to Alaska that stop at ports in the way cruise ships do. Are there sleeping accommodations? Where do you write for information? - H. C., Hauppauge, L.I. Answer: A ferry service called Alaska Marine Highway operates year-round between Seattle and Skagway, Alaska. Passengers can stop off at ports on the route and board the next ferry passing through, sailing south or north. The vessels also carry cars. Departures from Seattle are only once a week, but the line runs daily service on the northern part of the route, between Prince Rupert, British Columbia, and Skagway, enabling passengers to make brief stopovers and take land excursions. The line's ships have cabins with berths for two, three or four people, but generally the cabins accommodate only about half of the passengers. Those without cabins sleep in chairs or bed down in sleeping bags on the carpeted decks of public rooms. An official of Alaska Marine Highway (Post Office Box R, Juneau, Alaska 99811; 800-642-0066) said that all berths on the Seattle-Skagway service had already been booked for the summer of 1988. Berths were available on the other ferries between Prince Rupert and Skagway, he said.

title: Electronic Watchdogs for Computers
description: IN December, a computer enthusiast wreaked havoc at Lehigh University by programming a self-destruct code in personal computers on campus. The prank, which affected an estimated 200 people, was a sobering reminder that computer-dependent executives are vulnerable both to careless leaks and intentional sabotage.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: WHEN the use of landfills cost only a few dollars a cubic yard - lo, those many months ago - no one thought twice about the fairness of charging everyone the same small fee for picking up garbage.

title: Family of Mexicans Wins 3-Year Fight To Stay in the U.S.
description: A Mexican family living in Leicester has won a three-year fight to stay in the United States.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent
