description: To the Editor:

title: China
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the informative article by Ross Terrill on his visit to the Liangshan Yi Autonomous Region in China (Travel, Dec. 20). However, I take exception to a couple of comments the author seems to have accepted at face value from Han Chinese informants.

title: Broken Marriage and Brawl Test a Cohesive Caste
description: After five years of marriage, Ganga walked out on her husband the other day, announcing that she would no longer submit to his beatings. She then returned to her parents in another part of this northern Indian village.

title: Favorite Elective at Bowdoin: Food
description: Bowdoin College has a message for all those who remember dormitory food as the worst they ever ate: It doesn't have to be bad.

title: Skiing Weekend Ahead, Diaster Down the Track
description: Most people in the first coach car were trying to sleep in the wee hours this morning when the California Zephyr pulled into the small station here to pick up passengers.

title: 2 Arabs Killed in Clashes on West Bank
description: Israeli security forces shot and killed two Palestinians, one of them a 12-year-old boy, in another day of protests today. The shootings raised the death toll to at least 61 Palestinians in the 10 weeks of what Arabs are calling ''the uprising.''

title: COMMUNITIES PRESS CABLE-ROUTE FIGHT
description: LEAD: AFTER nearly two years of battling, the stage is set for the showdown between several southern Westchester communities and the New York Power Authority, which wants to run a cable taking inexpensive electricity to Long Island beneath their streets.

title: Ex-Teacher Sues School at Harvard Over Tenure
description: A former teacher has filed a lawsuit charging Harvard Business School with denying her tenure because she is a woman and with discrimination in hiring and admissions.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FLOWERS THROUGH THE SEASON
description: LEAD: AS the name implies, annuals live but a single season and must be started from seed each year. Since started plants can be planted out almost as early as seeds can be safely sown outdoors, most annuals are started in greenhouses or cold frames 8 to 10 weeks ahead of the planting season. By doing this, it is possible to enjoy them longer.

title: COUNTY SEEKS TO REGAIN WOODFIELD COTTAGE AID
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER'S 13 state legislators are making a concerted effort to regain $1.7 million in matching funds the county needs to enlarge Woodfield Cottage, its 16-bed secure facility for high-risk male juvenile offenders.

title: Fischer-Dieskau Series Of Lieder at Carnegie
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau will give three recitals of lieder - his first performances in the United States in eight years - at Carnegie Hall on March 22, 24 and 27. He will sing works by Schumann on the 22d, excerpts from Mahler's ''Knaben Wunderhorn'' on the 24th, and Hugo Wolf's ''Morike Lieder'' on the 27th, all with Hartmut Holl at the piano.

title: Music
description: The Lower East Side is still home to some of the most creative rock-and-roll groups in the country. The area that fostered Blondie, Velvet Underground and Television supports groups that push rock forms to their limits. The music often winds its way in and around political lyrics; just as often, pop-styled songs with user-friendly melodies grab listeners' attention, only to hit them with odd-angled rhythms, subversive lyrics and crooked harmonies.

title: GABRIEL MARQUEZ ON LOVE, PLAGUES AND POLITICS
description: Gabriel Garcia Marquez is about to publish ''Love in the Time of Cholera,'' a work he calls a novel of manners: the story of two people whose love, thwarted in their youth, finally flourishes when they are close to 80.

title: MET ON A GREAT BATTLEFIELD
description: THE GENERALS Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee. By Nancy Scott Anderson and Dwight Anderson. 523 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Shultz Plans Arms Focus in Moscow
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he and Soviet leaders would try to ''energize'' their sluggish negotiations on a strategic arms treaty when he holds talks in Moscow Sunday and Monday. But he cautioned against expecting any breakthroughs.

title: Too Close To Reality
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: UNION MAVERICK: Charles E. Bryan; A Struggle Over the Fate of Eastern Airlines
description: SEVERAL days after Frank Lorenzo took control of Eastern Airlines in 1986, Charles E. Bryan, the head of the company's 13,000-member machinists union, sent him a welcoming telegram expressing interest in working together to strengthen the company.

title: DIPLOMATS DO NOT HURRY TO ENLIST IN THE WAR ON DRUGS
description: WHEN President Reagan signed the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, he vowed to wage ''a national crusade against drugs, a sustained relentless effort to rid America of this scourge.'' Two years later, the supply of drugs on American streets is larger than ever, the enforcement effort suffers from lack of money, and officials in at least a dozen Government agencies are divided on how best to stop the flow of narcotics into the country.

title: HOW PARAGUAY'S GENERAL STILL KEEPS THE WORLD AT BAY
description: THE official version was that, in a moving display of loyalty and enthusiasm, Paraguayans turned out en masse last Sunday to approve Gen. Alfredo Stroessner's eighth successive presidential term. No less predictably, opposition leaders, the Roman Catholic Church and foreign diplomats said the elections were too fraudulent to be taken seriously.

title: South Carolina House Passes A Measure on Sex Education
description: The State House of Representatives here has given preliminary approval to a mandatory sex education program that would separate birth-control classes by sex and prohibit discussion of homosexuality except in negative terms.

title: '88 WINTER OLYMPICS: Sports of The Times; Falls From Olympus
description: Judging by what's happening to too many athletes here, the XV Olympic Winter Games are in the wrong city. They should be in Great Falls, Mont. Sadly, almost incredibly, Dan Jansen, the American speed skater from West Allis, Wis., fell not only in the 500-meter sprint but also in the 1,000-meter sprint. He had been hoping to win a gold medal in the memory of his sister, who died last Sunday of leukemia at age 27.

title: For a Change, The Superpowers Will Venture Beyond Topic A
description: WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrives in Moscow today for talks, he will be carrying an agenda with an unusually heavy emphasis on regional disputes, most notably Afghanistan, the Iran-Iraq war and the Arab-Israeli conflict. And he is likely to find Soviet leaders sharing his eagerness to accomplish something in these areas. ''It coincides with our intention,'' a Soviet official said last week of the American sense of priorities. ''We approach this with the aim of moving forward, not just to compare notes.''

title: Merle Takes Lead In Combined Event
description: Anita Wachter of Austria and the Swiss duo of Vreni Schneider and Brigitte Oertli positioned themselves as the skiers to beat for the gold medal in the women's combined competition in Mount Allan, Alberta.

title: Boitano Wins First Gold Medal for U.S.
description: With the performance of his life tonight, Brian Boitano won the Olympic gold medal in figure skating, the first gold won by the United States in the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: United States Braces For Showdown on Ice
description: The players politely considered the question, which promoted the notion that the game between the United States and West Germany on Sunday night would be hockey's version of World War II.

title: AN EARLY PEEK AT SPRING IN MID-WINTER
description: LEAD: THE Champion International Greenhouse in Stamford is the only one offering regular educational exhibits.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE NEW ADVENTURES OF SHERLOCK HOLMES: Original Stories by Eminent Mystery Writers. Edited by Martin Harry Greenberg and Carol-Lynn Rossel Waugh. (Carroll & Graf. $18.95.) Perhaps the best testament to the durability of the cult surrounding Victorian literature's great detective lies in the number and variety of apocrypha that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's creation continues to generate.

title: Dance
description: Dancing is an exhausting profession, and one that leaves little time or resources for providing for an unforeseen problem. Sunday night the New York City Ballet closes its winter season at the New York State Theater with the Dancers' Emergency Fund Benefit. Instituted three years ago, the benefit raises money that is used to help resolve sudden crises in the lives of the dancers who bring the City Ballet repertory to life season after season. The program will be a gala stew of excerpts, with Bolshoi Ballet dancers Nina Ananiashvili and Maris Liepa appearing in the pas de deux from ''Le Corsaire'' and ''Apollo.'' It's a lively and loveable tradition, and those who can't attend the performance may still participate with contributions made payable to ''NYCB Dancers' Emergency Fund.''

title: A JUNE WEDDING FOR LAURI LOWELL
description: Lauri Jan Lowell, a daughter of Vivian Lowell of New York and Stanley H. Lowell of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New York, and Isaiah David Cooper plan to marry in June. The future bridegroom is a son of Florence Cooper of Middletown, N.Y., and the late Paul H. Cooper.

title: DATA UPDATE: February 21, 1988
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units)

title: A Golf Birthday
description: Just in case anyone needs a reminder of why Feb. 22 is a very special date, a group of golfers will gather at the St. Andrews Golf Club in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., this afternoon for a ceremony, one day early, marking what the organizers are calling ''the centennial of golf in America.'' To put a finer point on it, they are marking the 100th anniversary of the first game of golf reliably known to have been played on an American course operated by a club that is still in existence.

title: PEGGY SULERZYSKI MARRIES
description: Margaret D. Sulerzyski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Sulerzyski of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Evan C. Jensen, the son of Margit Jensen of Monroe, N.Y., and the late Einer Jensen. The Rev. Johnnie Nystrom, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan. The bride, known as Peggy, is a vice president and the director of financial analysis and budgeting for Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. Mr. Jensen is a systems programming consultant.

title: FICTION
description: PURSUED BY THE CROOKED MAN. By Susan Trott. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) You've heard of novels based on the Bible, Greek myths or even Arthurian legend; this may be one of the first inspired by Mother Goose. But why not? The heroine, Miliana Bartha, who is possessed of ''three children, one husband, two lovers, and a woman friend,'' has an inspiration while scrubbing the floor one day. She decides to write a series of essays on the true meaning of Mother Goose. In doing so, she comes to see these familiar nursery rhymes as revealing the particulars of her own life. Nothing demonstrates this better than the ditty that begins, ''There was a crooked man . . .'' Six years before, Miliana left her second husband, Dominic Racatelli - whom she sees as the crooked man - and took with her a substantial sum of his money. Understandably, he has been searching for her ever since. Hence the title and hence the plot, which involves everything from a dog atop a Ferrari to a journey to the pyramids in the Yucatan. Susan Trott, the author of five previous novels, has an arch style that is very appealing and is a good match for this Mack Sennett-like story. It stands her in particularly good stead when she is writing about her main character, a delicate combination of free spirit and paranoiac. When the banter prevails, this short novel has an eccentric charm. It is only when the author tries to get serious that the charm, and the reader's interest, threaten to flag. Fortunately, though, this tendency mostly reveals itself near the end of the novel. And by then, Ms. Trott has put us in a forgiving mood.

title: OPPORTUNITY IN ORPHAN TRACTS
description: LEAD: SUFFOLK COUNTY planning officials are encouraging towns to foreclose on and make use of land parcels of unknown ownership, with mixed results.

title: Kalikow to Solicit New Advertisrs
description: Yesterday's agreement between Rupert Murdoch and the unions at The New York Post sets the stage for another attempt to do what newspaper professionals have long said cannot be done: turn a long-term profit at The Post.

title: BRIAN J. MAYER IS ENGAGED TO WED SUZANNE HERZBERG
description: The engagement of Suzanne Ruth Herzberg to Brian J. Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Mayer of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Walter J. Herzberg of Fair Lawn, N.J., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: 54 Economists Back Rise in Minimum Wage
description: Fifty-four economists told Congress today that raising the minimum wage would have little adverse effect on the economy.

description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Atlanta;
In the Spirit Of Carnival
description: LEAD: OTHERS may call it Charley's Folly. But Charles Ackerman shrugs off the criticism of his specialty retail and restaurant center that he calls Rio. He is building the $17 million complex on six downtown acres in partnership with two nonprofit community development organizations.

title: Jazz: Irma Thomas
description: IRMA THOMAS'S 47th birthday was celebrated during her early set Thursday at the Lone Star Cafe -much to the audience's, and apparently the singer's, surprise - when her fan club president brought a cake onstage. Although Ms. Thomas has been making records since 1958 and had a string of New Orleans rhythm-and-blues hits in the early 1960's, time has been on her side. In her first New York appearance since 1966, she sang with all the spunk, sultriness and flexibility she had 25 years ago. In fact, she sounds better now; her voice is fuller, her approach more knowing yet more playful.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: BENJAMIN ANDREWS;
'WE STILL SUFFER FROM DISCRIMINATION'
description: LEAD: BENJAMIN ANDREWS has been the president of the 20,000-member state branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for 18 years.

title: BIG OIL SPILL STIRS WATER SAFETY FEARS
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND'S largest recorded underground petroleum spill, 800,000 gallons of leaded gasoline from a Northville Industries Corporation storage tank in East Setauket, has raised questions about how well Suffolk County's ground water is being protected.

title: PRAGUE, WITH BALLOONS AND ANGELS
description: MY FIRST LOVES By Ivan Klima. Translated by Ewald Osers. 164 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: New Rochelle Condos: Boat Slips On the Creek
description: Guy Blundon is not one to waste a waterfront. Of the 16 apartments that compose the Davenport Slip condominium he is developing with his partner, Lenard Thylan, 12 will have stepped terraces and sliding glass walls facing New Rochelle Creek. The four other apartments will have dockside views. The creek, a stubby estuary off Long Island Sound in the New Rochelle, N.Y., is lined with marinas, making for lively viewing. ''It's like a street scene,'' Mr. Blundon said. ''People boat watch.''

title: Contributions To Neediest Used All Year
description: Apologizing for being late, Stuart Price of Manhattan sent $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, with the request that his contribution be used to help someone with AIDS.

title: The Random House Dictionary
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: 2 More Killed in West Bank

title: Q AND A
description: Fee-Simple Condo

title: BETSY DAVIDSON IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Alice Elizabeth Davidson and John Morrison Pickering, the founders and partners of Pickering Associates, a literary agency in New York, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Joan K. Davidson of New York. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE SECURITY
description: ''YEARS ago, security was at the bottom of the totem pole,'' said Michael Goodrich, general manager of Spectra Audio Research Inc., which makes electronic security devices. Now, he went on, executives are quietly investing in bodyguards, bulletproof vests, automatic vehicle locators to trace a missing car and other high-tech gear.

title: QUILTS: MORE THAN JUST WARM COVERS
description: ''MORE Than Just Something to Keep You Warm,'' the title of an exhibition of Afro-American folk art at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science, adds an affirmative twist to a black woman's modest appraisal of a quilt she had made.

title: PAMELA PHILLIPS, A TEACHER, IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Pamela Jillson Phillips, the daughter of Patricia B. Phillips of Fairfield, Conn., and William A. Phillips of Greenwich, Conn., to Richard Bernard Noonan, a son of Robert W. Noonan of Osterville, Mass., and the late Frances E. Noonan, took place yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony.

title: NAVY ASKS TO RESTRICT ACCESS TO SHIP BASE
description: THE United States Navy wants to impose a restricted zone across the entire width of the Thames River from Groton to Waterford, encompassing about 200 acres.

title: INCEST VICTIMS: NO MORE MARTYRS
description: The excellent article ''Incest Victims Get Sympathy but Little Help'' alerted the public to a serious social problem in Suffolk County but did not explain that in Nassau County we have developed an extensive range of services for victims.

title: Only One Maker
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE TRIVIAL SERIOUSLY
description: OSCAR WILDE By Richard Ellmann. Illustrated. 680 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
description: Individual physicians, or even New York Hospital, should not be blamed for the deaths of Andy Warhol and Libby Zion. The system failed these patients, and the system must be changed. When interns, fresh out of medical school, are forced to work for 36 hours without sleep and are left alone at night in charge of 30 or 40 seriously ill patients, deaths that should be avoidable will occur.

title: South Africa Jets Hit Namibia Guerrillas in Angola
description: The South African Air Force struck two guerrilla bases in Angola today, after a bomb blast in South-West Africa on Friday that killed 18 people.

title: For the Schools: Next Things Next
description: Governor Cuomo has, surprisingly soon, stopped pushing to restructure New York City's Board of Education. He thinks that current tensions between the Legislature and Mayor Koch make this an inopportune time to press for giving the Mayor control of the central school board.

title: A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
description: Nine years ago, I graduated with the last class of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing, one of the very few nursing schools for college graduates seeking a Bachelor of Science degree in nursing (''A Great Hospital in Crisis,'' by M. A. Farber and Lawrence K. Altman, Jan. 24). Your article was the first to recognize any link between the closing of that exceptional school and the lack of ''superior nursing'' now evident at New York Hospital.

title: STATE MAY HOLD A KEY TO PRESIDENTIAL CHOICES
description: ALTHOUGH it still has a number of stops to make before it arrives June 7, the Presidential political bandwagon is heading toward New Jersey. And the way things are going in both major parties, New Jersey voters could play an important role in picking the nominees.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC'S FUTURE
description: To The Editor:

title: Soviet Takes Lead in 2-Man Bobsled
description: Ianis Kipours of the Soviet Union, aided by deteriorating track conditions that slowed Wolfgang Hoppe of East Germany, the defending gold medalist, jumped from fourth to first on the second run in the Olympic two-man bobsled today to set up what could be one of the biggest upsets with two heats remaining Sunday.

title: A Lengthy Test for Jade Hunter's Speed
description: If Mr. Prospector were a better sire of grass horses, this season's handicap racing in Florida would be much poorer, because Jade Hunter would be wintering in Europe.

title: Correction
description: An item in the Record Notes column in Arts and Leisure on Feb. 7 incorrectly characterized New World Records. It is a nonprofit organization, not a commercial company.

title: THE SILENT MAJORITY'S LEGACY OF LIFE
description: MOST people avoid cemeteries. For years I have as well. With time in such short supply, who needs to pass it among those for whom time has run out?

title: Opera: 'Tristan and Iseult' Opera: Medieval Version Of 'Tristan and Iseult'
description: IT seemed like a good idea, maybe, and there were some occasionally pleasing musical performances. But by and large the Boston Camerata's newly cobbled medieval-operatic version of ''Tristan and Iseult,'' which received its world premiere Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall before performances in Boston and at French music festivals, seemed more hokey than illuminating.

title: A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
description: You refer, in the article on New York Hospital, to an ''almost palpable anxiety . . . about how the institution looks from the outside, especially to . . . philanthropists.''

title: Concert: Jonathan Haas Puts Timpani Out Front
description: WITHIN the fatness of the symphony orchestra there are always a few thinner soloists longing to get out. Some instruments do it better than others, the timpani not so well at all. Yet Jonathan Haas - who plays with the New York Chamber Symphony, at the Aspen Festival, and with a number of smaller groups around New York - has persisted, and surrounded by colleagues, he gave a recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night.

title: RETRIALS IN MURDER OF SUFFOLK BOY RAISING CRIMINAL-JUSTICE QUESTIONS
description: JOHN PIUS JR. was 13 years old on the night of April 20, 1979, when he was killed in one of the most shocking crimes in Long Island history. When his body was found the following afternoon, it was buried under a pile of logs and leaves in the woods near a Smithtown schoolyard with six rocks stuffed down his throat.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Times Magazine on Jan. 10 about Nicaragua's leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, misstated the date of a secret meeting at which the Sandinistas sought to take control of the provisional legislature by adding members. It was May 2, 1980.

title: New Sheen for the 'Welfare Banks'
description: NATHAN SHANE licked his counting finger, scooped up a check and identification card from a rumpled, bent-over woman and began nimbly counting dollars.

title: THEM AS HAS
description: THE FOUNDING FORTUNES A New Anatomy of the Super-Rich Families in America. By Michael Patrick Allen. 438 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/ E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: RULING THE JET SET
description: In his article, William Safire describes members of the upper class as ''those to the manor born.'' The original phrase, from ''Hamlet'' (Act I, Scene 4), contains, instead, the homophonous manner, and the connotation is quite different. When Hamlet says ''. . . though I am native here/ And to the manner born . . .'' he is alluding to his acquaintanceship with a certain custom of the area in which he was born and raised. He is not necessarily implying aristocratic endowment. SUSAN S. NIMS Kenny Lake, Alaska

title: A GURU ON THE RAMPARTS
description: TO DWELL IN PEACE An Autobiography. By Daniel Berrigan. Illustrated. 356 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Missing Colonel
description: In Lebanon, where kidnapping is a cottage industry, the abduction last week of an American Marine, Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins, created more than the usual stir: Two apparently different groups of Islamic militants took credit for the kidnapping and a third Moslem militia undertook to rescue him. After Colonel Higgins, who was attached to the United Nations truce supervision organization, was snatched from his car, a man claiming to represent the Islamic Revolutionary Brigades said the group had kidnapped him because it suspected he was an American intelligence agent. Later, a group called Oppressed of the Earth made similar claims. Meanwhile, leaders of the Amal militia, who had met with Colonel Higgins just before his abduction, mounted a massive search for him.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: YELLOWSTONE KELLY: Gentleman & Scout. By Peter Bowen. (Jameson Books/Kampmann, $17.95.) Why did the Americans slaughter the Indians? Why did the British slaughter the Zulus? Expect ''Yellowstone Kelly'' to offer a philosophical discussion of manifest destiny and imperialism. Just don't expect it polished.

title: What's This? A Lot of Hot Air
description: The Super Maine, a huge hot air balloon, rose 50 feet over frozen Sebago Lake several times today, carrying as many as 60 people at a time, though it was firmly tied to the ground. The designers, builders and supporters of the 210-foot-high, 168-foot-wide balloon simply wanted to make a balloon larger than the Virgin Atlantic Flier, which crossed the Atlantic last summer. The balloon holds 300,000 to 500,000 more cubic feet of hot air than the 195-foot-high Flier, said Tom Handcock, its chief pilot.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Volubility of Tongue There have always been minimalists, people who distrust language, as if it had a will of its own and could trick us out of ourselves. This is Thomas Sprat, a 17th-century historian, quoted in ''One Culture: Essays in Science and Literature,'' edited by George Levine (University of Wisconsin).

title: IF TAX RISES ARE COMIN, WHICH ONE WILL THEY BE?
description: ALTHOUGH the budget President Reagan submitted last week formally projects that the Federal deficit will fall in each of the next five years, reaching a relatively negligible $23 billion in 1993, politicians and economists generally agree that the chances of this happening are practically zero.

title: Postings; Survey Shows Gains: Affordability
description: Housing affordability is at its highest level in over 10 years nationwide, but fewer purchases are being made by first-time buyers, a survey by the National Association of Realtors shows. It also indicates that those with incomes well over the median dominate the market.

title: STEAKHOUSE GOES BEYOND CLICHES
description: BRYANT & COOPER in Roslyn is a steakhouse with a difference. Its dual personality will delight those who normally shun beef palaces. But fear not, the red meat gang will definitely not be shut out.

title: Silence of American Jews Supports the Wrong Side; Waking Up
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NUCLEAR AGE AND ITS PROBLEMS COME TO THE STAGE
description: When two arms negotia-tors, the American Paul Nitze and the Russian Yuli Kvitsinsky, took a walk in the woods just outside of Geneva during the summer of 1982, they forged an original and provocative nuclear-weapons agreement. While it would later be rejected by their respective Governments, their proposal eventually ignited a groundswell of hope for what might still be achieved. Now that encounter serves as the basis for a new American play, ''A Walk in the Woods,'' starring Robert Prosky and Sam Waterston and directed by Des McAnuff. It opens next Sunday at the Booth Theater.

title: Sunday Observer; Just for the Record. . .
description: THERE'S TOO MUCH record-breaking going on. You can't pick up a newspaper or turn on the television any more without discovering a half dozen incredibly uninteresting new records have been set overnight.

title: 'JOURNALISM STINKS,' HE TELLS HER
description: FAMILY BUSINESS By Anna Murdoch. 592 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: YESTERDAY'S MEDAL WINNERS
description: Biathlon: Men's 20 km Gold: Frank-Peter Roetsch, East Germany Silver: Valeri Medvedtsev, Soviet Union Bronze: Johann Passler, Italy Figure Skating: Men Gold: Brian Boitano, United States Silver: Brian Orser, Canada Bronze: Viktor Petrenko, Soviet Union Speed Skating: Men's 1500 meters Gold: Andre Hoffmann, East Germany Silver: Eric Flaim, United States Bronze: Michael Hadschieff, Austria Totals: Soviet Union - 5 gold, 5 silver, 5 bronze; East Germany -6 gold, 3 silver, 1 bronze; Switzerland - 1 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze; Finland -2 gold, 1 bronze; Austria - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; United States - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; the Netherlands - 2 silver, 1 bronze; West Germany - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Norway - 1 silver, 1 bronze; France - 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Sweden - 1 gold; Italy - 1 bronze.

title: Tomba Moves Into Spotlight
description: The Swiss bickered among themselves. The skiers, in general, complained about the wind and lack of snow. The ticket-holders arrived at this winter resort about 65 miles west of Calgary, not knowing whether they would see a race, much less which one. Still, nothing that happened during the first week of the Alpine events here at Mount Allan has caused as big a stir as Alberto Tomba of Italy is likely to when he begins competing Sunday.

title: AUSTRIANS DEBATING THE HIGH COST OF WALDHEIM
description: THERE is an Austrian saying that seemed to sum up the mood here as the bitter dispute over Kurt Waldheim increasingly battered and divided his small nation: ''Better a horrible end than horror without end.''

title: Recalling Blitzstein
description: To the Editor:

title: Micro-loans to the World's Poorest
description: WITH the help of 5 of her 12 children and a son-in-law, Maria Alfonsa Lopez braids rope in La Colonia Independencia, one of the western hill barrios of Tegucigalpa, Honduras. It is an occupation her family has pursued for generations.

title: 'BLOOD BROTHERS,' NEW FROM BRITAIN
description: ''BLOOD BROTHERS'' at the Downtown Cabaret Theater has the earmarks of a double event. Here is the American premiere of a 1983 award-winning, long-running -and downbeat - British musical that can alienate and attract audiences, and what a bold step this is for a theater noted for unthreatening, familiar fare! By rights, anyone interested in musicals ought to get right on to Bridgeport on that intelligence alone.

title: RONALD HODGE 2D BECOMES FIANCE OF MISS KREITLER
description: Katherine Thayer Kreitler's engagement to Ronald Gray Hodge 2d, the son of Patricia Kues of Morehead City, N.C., and Ronald G. Hodge of Charlotte, N.C., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. Kreitler of Southport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Mexican Owner Sells Control of U.P.I.
description: Mario Vazquez Rana, the Mexican publisher who has owned United Press International since 1986, announced Friday that he had sold the right to operate the news service to an investment group associated with Financial News Network, a cable television service.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: GROTON LONG POINT;
BRING BACK THE DREADED SUMMER PEOPLE
description: LEAD: WHEN blustery cold air makes the warm days of Indian summer a distant memory and the first hints of springtime seem too far away to fathom, Groton Long Point is in the doldrums of winter.

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: When it comes down to Olympic tradition, the biathlon is the best Winter Olympic sport. Cross-country skiers swiftly stride through the woods, pushing the limits of physical endurance, then immediately gain absolute control of mind, body and emotion to prove their marksmanship, with the clock ticking in the background. JOHN MA Cheshire, Conn.

title: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING
description: THE FASCINATION WITH FASHIONS PAT-terned after animal coats comes and goes. This winter, however, it arrived full force. Faux pelts have been spotted everywhere. From skirts to handbags to slipcovers, everything appeared to be more desirable if it had leopards' spots or tigers' stripes. These beasts' natural markings are carried out in complicated sequin embroideries; printed on silk, satin, denim or cotton, or stenciled on calfskin. Of course, the real hides are never used or worn. These are animals on the endangered list. But why the rush to the jungles for inspiration? As Bill Blass, whose designs have been among the most popular, says: ''Animal patterns always work when clothes are short and snappy. They don't when skirts are midi-length and draggy.'' The markings of the wild beast, it seems, are for the racy days.

title: Pro Basketball; Absent Woolridge Calls Before Loss
description: After missing the team bus for Friday night's game in Philadelphia against the 76ers, then failing to report for tonight's 113-101 loss to the Seattle SuperSonics at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Orlando Woolridge, the Nets' high-scoring forward, finally contacted the team.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Home Buyers Board Ronkonkoma Train
description: LEAD: For Margaret and Harris Yale, who have contracted to buy a house in the Long Island community of Bohemia, a train commute to New York City of less than an hour was essential. Before the Long Island Rail Road electrified the 23.5-mile stretch of tracks between Ronkonkoma and Hicksville they might have looked elsewhere.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Demand Still Outpaces Room In Soviet Hotels

title: Article 849088 -- No Title
description: A Geneva-based businessman seeking United States Government help in building an Iraqi pipeline paid $150,000 to a close friend of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, people familiar with the transaction said today.

title: A Palestinian View
description: OBVIOUSLY, A LONGSTANDING conflict like that between the Israelis and the Palestinians can be resolved any number of ways - particularly when one side has the power to impose a settlement on the other. The question here, however, is not about a so-called ''agreement'' that one side forces the other to accept, but a true, lasting settlement that elicits a reasonable degree of consent from both. Briefly, is there a political prescription that can be given to Palestinians and Israelis that will encourage them to take part - willingly - in a process that will truly bring their conflict to an end?

title: Pagnol, From the Source
description: More than a decade after the death of Marcel Pagnol, the international triumph of ''Jean de Florette'' and ''Manon des Sources'' introduced millions of people to Pagnol's Provence - as distinctive and enduring a terrain of the imagination as William Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha County. Contemporary audiences could be pardoned for believing that these picturesquely colored views of Yves Montand making mischief in the arid hills of the Midi - so scrupulously orchestrated by the director Claude Berri - were indeed the real thing. Yet true aficionados knew that something intangible was missing, just as it had been from all of the American reincarnations of ''Fanny.'' For pure essence de Pagnol, the photography has to have the harsh tones of black and white, and at the center of the frame there must be the irreplaceable Raimu of the wily gaze and slackened jaw, muttering the blunt cadences of Provence as spontaneously as the water that flows from Manon's spring.

LEAD: A $10 million physicians' office building now under construction in this community along the New York State border will increase the pressure for high-quality housing in the area, local authorities say.

title: 'Looking Backward'
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: I'm not tremendously educated in the art of figure skating, but I enjoy what I see. The beauty and physical efficiency of the competitors, the graceful and sophisticated movements, the poise, the confidence, the acrobatic ability that is exhibited is what provides for the most glamorous, yet most difficult of the winter sports events. HARRY WARREN New York

title: The Wolfe Isn't at Our Door
description: LEAD: At 11 o'clock on a Friday morning, my wife and I were on our way to Connecticut. Avoiding the Triboro Bridge, we took the underpass that would take us to Bruckner Boulevard. In tune with Mayor Koch's other economies, it was completely unlit, and, at about 35 miles an hour, we hit a pothole large enough to bury a barrel.

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: Only ice hockey requires the molding of 18 to 20 individuals into a competitive team. Moreover, there is a uniqueness in the contrasting styles of play among the Europeans, Canadians and Americans. And the unpredictable nature of the Olympic ice-hockey tournament adds to the sport's premier status in the Winter Games. ANDREW B. BORINSTEIN New York

title: U.S. to Use Tortilla Packages To Send Amnesty Reminder
description: The government is sending message in tortilla packages to remind illegal aliens about the deadline to apply for immigration amnesty.

title: YUPPIES FLEE THE MADDING CROWDS
description: LEAD: OVER the hills and through the woods, young and formerly urban and suburban Connecticut professionals continue to go.

title: Candidates Flail Away, but 'Undecided' Is Still Ahead
description: WHAT did the voters of New Hampshire and Iowa tell the American people?

title: PROSPECTS
description: High Tech's Next Twist

title: Seat Belts For Trains?
description: AFTER Amtrak's worst passenger train collision, in which 16 people were killed and 178 injured, John Riley, administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration, said he would seek comments from railroads on whether trains in the busy Northeast Corridor should have seat belts.

title: Iris Murdoch's England
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR WINTER READING
description: WEATHER permitting, this is a good season to prune dormant trees especially young apples and pears to strengthen them, but wait until after flowering to prune stone fruits such as peaches, nectarines and cherries. Grapevines are pruned any time this month and next. Arrange for tree pruning by arborists if shade or specimen trees have grown too thick and tall or have been weakened by ice or snow storms. Good Books

title: Bingham's Copyrights
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SAN FRANCISCO, TV BATTLES ON THE FRONT LINES AGAINST AIDS
description: Early in 1983, Jim Bunn, a new reporter for KPIX-TV here, finished writing his first AIDS report and knew the story was like none before. It had sex, death, medical intrigue, a host of complex social issues - not the least of which were civil rights and gay life styles - and, by definition, it was going to challenge every taboo known to television.

title: Rene Char, French Poet, 80, Dies
description: Rene Char, called ''the greatest French poet of the 20th century'' by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, died here Friday, according to the publishing company Gallimard. He was 80 years old and lived in Paris. Gallimard said Mr. Char died at the Val-de-Grace military hospital. No cause of death was given.

title: PRISON PRAYER EDICT UNDER APPEAL
description: FIVE members of the Nation of Islam (also known as the Black Muslims) are appealing a Federal District Court ruling that upheld the New Jersey prison system's right to prohibit them from praying together during recreation in the prison yard.

title: Outdoors; New York Plans Action on Neversink Land
description: The controversy over New York State's effort to establish a park, the Neversink River Unique Area, in the river's magnificently wild gorge in Sullivan County has entered a new phase. On Feb. 4, Thomas C. Jorling, commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation announced that his office would seek to accomplish that end by eminent-domain proceedings.

title: DANCING ON TOP OF THE WORLD
description: DOLPO Hidden Land of the Himalayas. Photographs by Eric Valli and Diane Summers. Text by Diane Summers. Unpaged. New York: Aperture. $39.50.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MORNING. By Nancy Thayer. (Scribners, $19.95.) The subject of ''Morning,'' Nancy Thayer's fifth novel, could not be trendier - the suffering and uncertainty a woman undergoes when she tries to become pregnant at the age of 34. Once an up-and-coming editor at a publishing firm in Boston, Sara Kendall has gladly settled down to have children with her husband, Steve, on cozy Nantucket Island.

title: A SUPPORT GROUP FOR MINORITY MEN
description: LEAD: THE overheated meeting room of the Thomas H. Slater Community Center in White Plains was filled with an angry cacophony as the assembled men discussed being black and Hispanic in Westchester.

title: THOSE GOING UP AND THOSE GOING DOWN
description: DUSK And Other Stories. By James Salter. 157 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $14.95.

title: INTO EACH LIFE A LOT OF SNOW SHOULD FALL
description: SNOWED IN!

title: A LATIN REVIVAL TAKES THE STAGE AT JOHN JAY HIGH SCHOOL
description: DOROTHY (DOBBIE) R. NICHOLLS loves the insults her classes hurl at her on exam days. ''Nos morituri te salutamus,'' they shout. (We who are about to die, salute you) and ''Dux femina facti.'' (The woman is the leader of the deed.) Mrs. Nicholls is a teacher of Latin - the so-called dead language that this 43-year-old classics enthusiast has made the ''in'' language at Katonah's John Jay High School.

title: Native American Literary History
description: To the Editor:

title: Once a Candidate, Always a Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW PESTICIDE RULES CAUSE OUTCRY
description: LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Conservation has put together stringent regulations for the application of pesticides by farmers, commercial lawn care companies and exterminators. The regulations have upset business owners who feel that the rules will adversely affect their livelihood.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: There are certain inevitables in life and there is absolutely no point fighting them because it won't help. The only good thing that can be said about them is that they're nondiscriminatory: they happen to everyone -maybe not every single one to every single person, but most of them to most people. One woman calls them laws of physics, as good a term as any because it sounds impressive; it even sounds right.

title: The Judges' Subjective Yardsticks
description: In a world of triple axels, double toe loops, death spirals and sit spins, clocks and yardsticks have no place.

title: Jersey Doctor Accused Of Fraud in Drug Tests
description: A New Jersey doctor who is the former chairman of a hospital board has been indicted on charges of defrauding pharmaceutical companies of nearly $2 million by falsifying test results on experimental drugs.

title: MS. KUEHN AND BANKER WED AT MANHATTANVILLE
description: Stephanie Louise Kuehn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Percy Kuehn of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Westerly, R.I., was married in Purchase, N.Y., yesterday to Hans Christoph Vitzthum von Eckstadt 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vitzthum von Eckstadt 3d of New York; Jacksonville, Vt., and Bailleul, France. The Rev. Henry C. Schriever, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Manhattanville College.

title: BETSY WHITEHEAD MARRIED IN JERSEY TO D. F. SEATON 3D
description: St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Margaret Whitehead, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Whitehead of Essex Fells, to Donald Francis Seaton 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seaton Jr. of Mercer Island, Wash. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony.

description: Bay Shore $210,000 51 Bayview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, sunporch, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. title: They Are Not Non-Persons
description: Some legislators and citizens, and the states of Kansas and Pennsylvania, have brought a suit demanding that illegal aliens not be counted when Congress redistricts after the 1990 Census. They claim that undocumented aliens in states like New York and California will skew the results and perhaps cost their states a House seat. To win, they must persuade the courts that the aliens are not ''persons,'' since persons, not citizens, are what the Constitution requires to be counted.

title: Preparing for Nepal's Rugged Reality
description: I STOOD before the courtyard of the great Buddhist monastery at Tengboche in Nepal; the festival of Mani-Rimdu was about to begin. First there were long blasts on the conch shells - an unearthly sound. Then a procession of monks dressed in robes of deep red, over tunics of yellow, apricot and orange, began to wind around the courtyard. In the center, under a canopy of brilliant streamers, stood the Rimpoche, whom the Buddhists consider a reincarnated saint, his face utterly serene. Cymbals clashed, horns blared. Beside me, a tiny shriveled man in a tattered robe stood, hands clasped, transfixed in awe, staring at the Rimpoche six feet from us. I could scarcely believe I was seeing such sights, hearing such sounds; tears of astonishment filled my eyes.

title: Baseball; Yanks Impressed Early by Dotson
description: Richard Dotson sat quietly in front of his locker stall this morning, his attention drawn to a copy of the Yankee media guide that someone had handed to each of the players. Beside him sat Lee Guetterman, a pitcher of imposing physical proportions - he is 6 feet 8 inches - and not far away was Tim Stoddard, who is 6-7 and a former basketball player on North Carolina State's national championship team in 1974.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Burlington, Mass.: Hamlet Seeks Slower Growth
description: LEAD: Thirty-five years ago Burlington, a 12-square-mile hamlet with a population then of under 5,000, set aside its northwest quadrant for commercial development.

title: A TYRANNY OF CLOWNS
description: ANTHILLS OF THE SAVANNAH By Chinua Achebe. 216 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $16.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DIAMANTE. By Enzo Siciliano. Translated by Patrick Diehl. (Mercury House/Kampmann, $14.95.) If you like stories with a plot, then the point of this slender new novel, ably translated by Patrick Diehl, may elude you. In it, journal entries, letters and notes for a novel give a patchwork account of a young Roman's stay with a wealthy and powerful Calabrian family, that has hired him to catalogue their books.

title: JULIE FREUDENHEIM TO MARRY SPENCER G. FELDMAN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Freudenheim of Buffalo of the engagement of their daughter Julie R. Freudenheim to Spencer Greg Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Feldman of Patchogue, L.I. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: WAR-CRIME PLAY PARALLELS HISTORY
description: WHAT makes a regional theater a viable artistic entity is its ability to reach out and challenge audiences with new, developing work.

title: FOCUS: Akron, Ohio; A Pivotal Mixed-Use Project
description: There are positive signs for the economy of Summit County. Akron's population of 227,000 has been stable over the past few years and unemployment among the county's 508,000 residents has dropped from its peak of 12.3 percent in 1983 to 7.5 percent last year.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TUCSON
description: With Tucson expanding to mountain ranges on all but its south side, it seems only natural that its cultural growth would take shape in its heart rather than on its sleeve. In the last few years parts of the downtown area, largely abandoned by retail and business enterprises, have undergone a slow and somewhat hesitant rebirth.

title: In Nicaragua, They Learn the Prosthetics Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: A FAMILY'S LOVE OF FLAGS HELPS TO AVERT TRAGEDY
description: >I USED to live on the third floor of an apartment building facing a row of town houses. When one of those houses changed hands, the new owners erected an oversized flagpole in the small yard beside their front steps. Every morning around seven, either the husband or the wife would emerge with a flag, attach it to the halyard and hoist it up, and every evening, not precisely at sunset but around that time, it was lowered and carefully folded away for the night.

title: William Dempsey, 81, Former F.C.C. Counsel
description: William J. Dempsey, former counsel of the Federal Communications Commission and a communications lawyer, died of heart failure Tuesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

title: C-SPAN: Electronic Sunshine
description: Whatever else this presidential campaign is, it is the first in which candidates, prominent supporters and even bit players are now fully wired for sound.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: HOUSE TOURS

title: HARRIS'S 'STEPPING OUT' AT THE MCCARTER THEATRE
description: IN THE lobby of the McCarter Theatre here is a display of Fred Astaire accoutrements -a top hat, a straw hat, a white tie and all manner of cigarette holders - and photographs of his screen partners, mostly Judy Garland.

title: CONCERTS AT COLLEGES, CONSERVATORIES
description: YOU needn't be a parent to enjoy back-to-school events next weekend, because several of our county colleges and conservatories have scheduled concerts of high promise. The first is on Thursday, when the resident Sarah Lawrence Woodwind Quintet offers music by Telemann, Danzi, Barber and Francaix at its 8 P.M. campus recital in Reisinger Auditorium (call 337-0700 for reservations).

title: SCHEDULE OF EVENTS AT MORRISTOWN FLOWER AND GARDEN SHOW
description: Following is a schedule of events: Saturday

title: DEFYING TRADITION: PRINCE CHARLES RECASTS HIS ROLE
description: BEHIND PALACE DOORS, THE PRINCE OF Wales sometimes refers to journalists as ''creeps and bloody hacks.'' In the past, such outbursts have greeted aides' suggestions that he hold private, off-the-record meetings with British editors in an attempt to get them to pay more attention to his speeches and less to his troubled marriage.

title: Photography
description: ''The Return of the Hero'' is a group show that asks, then answers, the question: Does Lt. Col. Oliver North represent merely the tip of the iceberg when it comes to our current yearnings? Apparently. The 13 artists included - not all of them photographers, it should be said - seem to be in agreement that warrior-like appearance and behavior are definitely ''in'' in the late 80's. But while they find the signs and symbols of military macho a subject of fascination, they don't necessarily approve. Minnette Lehmann parodies the superheroes of comic-book fame, while David Levinthal puts distance between us and the cardboard representations of combat derived from World War II photojournalism.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This makes it all the more likely that Texaco will be a drastically changed company in a few months.''

title: Silence of American Jews Supports Wrong Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry's Bar
description: To the Editor: It was gratifying to find, in C. L. Sulzberger's piece (Travel, Jan. 3), that newsmen still find Harry's New York Bar in Paris newsworthy.

title: FRANCES TESTA IS A BRIDE
description: Frances Ann Testa and Richard William Egan were married yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in Maywood, N.J., by the Rev. Stanley Kostrzomb. The bride, a daughter of Madeline Testa of Saddle River, N.J., and the late Florindo Testa, is the director of medical records at the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Egan of Lake Huntington, N.Y., is a senior systems analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York.

title:
ART;
STRETCHING PHOTOGRAPHIC TRUTHS, AT THE BRUCE MUSEUM
description: LEAD: IN one respect, ''Photographic Truth,'' the current display at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, is a commentary on and an expansion of ''Photographic Fictions,'' the exhibition of contemporary staged or manipulated photographs that was presented at the Whitney Museum branch in Stamford The first show had a hip sensibility; photographers coolly demonstrated dozens of photographic tricks and techniques.

title: Going to Jerusalem
description: Secretary of State Shultz had the idea years ago of improving the ''quality of life'' of Palestinians under Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza. By that he meant easing Israel's restrictions on their lives and commerce, building a degree of mutual confidence.

title: RIDERS HUFF AND PUFF AT RAIL SMOKING BAN
description: ON the New Haven line trains last week, grumbling was in the air where smoke had once been.

title: Crewman Dies, 16 Hurt in Fire Aboard a Train
description: A smoky fire in a crew car aboard the Amtrak system's California Zephyr killed a crew member and injured 16 people early today, officials said. Passengers said they had received no warning of any danger and had been given no help in getting off the train.

title: FLASHING THE FASHIONABLE METALLIC SMILE
description: SOMETIMES it seems as if everyone is wearing them. Braces are in, especially if you are 11 years old and attending junior high school. There it is de rigueur to flash a metallic smile. You can make your peace with not eating bagels and with spending time in the orthodontist's office, where, periodically, the doctor tightens your wires and decorates your mouth with rubber bands.

title: Film, 'Koyaanisqatsi,' With Live Music
description: Tickets go on sale tomorrow at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, for two screenings - on March 18 and 19 at 8 P.M. - of the film ''Koyaanisqatsi'' with live accompaniment by the Philip Glass Ensemble.

title: THE RIGHT AGAINST REAGAN
description: The conservative attempt to equate the INF treaty with the Chamberlain-Hitler Munich agreement distorts the historical record (''The Right Against Reagan,'' by Hedrick Smith, Jan. 17).

title: 34 Die in Punjab in 2 Days Of Bombings and Ambushes
description: At least 34 people have been killed in 24 hours in bombings and ambushes by Sikh separatists in Punjab, news reports said today.

title: Composing Prize Awarded
description: Jay Anthony Gach, born in New York in 1953, has won first prize in the first Frederick P. Rose Competition of the Brooklyn Philharmonic for new orchestral works by American composers. Mr. Gach won a cash award of $10,000 and a performance of his score, ''Chant,'' during the orchestra's 1988-89 season. Second prize was shared by Kamran Ince for ''Infrared'' and Nils Vigeland for ''My Father's Song.'' Each won $3,000 and a future performance of his work.

title: Did Ives Fiddle With the Truth?
description: In the pantheon of American heroes there is no more appealing figure than Charles Ives, the iconoclastic Yankee insurance man and spare-time composer who, though supposedly unaware of avant-garde developments in European music, anticipated many innovations credited to Debussy, Mahler, Scriabin, Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Hindemith. Unfortunately, that story may now have to be reclassified as myth, along with George Washington's cherry tree, or at least drastically revised to bring it in line with a rising flood of apparently damning disclosures.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FLOWERS THROUGH THE SEASON
description: LEAD: AS the name implies, annuals live but a single season and must be started from seed each year. Since started plants can be planted out almost as early as seeds can be safely sown outdoors, most annuals are started in greenhouses or cold frames 8 to 10 weeks ahead of the planting season. By doing this, it is possible to enjoy them longer.

title: Black Whose Death Penalty Was Overturned Is Convicted
description: A black teen-ager sentenced to death at the age of 15 was convicted today of murder in a retrial brought after the state Supreme Court overturned his original conviction by an all-white jury. The prosecutor said he would not seek the death penalty again.

title: D'Amato Criticizes G.O.P. Rules Governing Primary in New York
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has attacked the Republican Presidential primary voting system in New York as ''onerous'' and ''a stain on the party.''

title: AMERICAN COMPANY AND SOVIET AGREE ON SPACE VENTURE
description: For the first time an American company has contracted to have the Soviet Union carry Western commercial payloads into orbit. The agreement is likely to spur similar moves by other companies, Federal officials said.

title: DANIELLE I. SCHANZ WEDS B. O. GARBASSI
description: Danielle Iris Schanz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Schanz of New York and East Quoque, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to Bertrand Otton Garbassi, a son of Eva Wellisz of New York and Umberto Garbassi of Leivi, Italy. Surrogate James D. Benson of Dutchess County, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Westbury hotel.

title: 'Blunt Force' Is Cited in a Death in Police Custody
description: ''Blunt force injuries'' inflicted in a struggle with the police contributed to a Brooklyn man's death in police custody last month, the New York Medical Examiner's office has said.

title: Putting On the Pressure
description: AT the top of the game, those who are thought of as great bidders are rarely perceived to be great dummy players and vice versa. There is a psychological reason for this, which is unconnected with any absolute standard of performance.

title: Esther Oshiver Fisher; Marriage Counselor, 77
description: Dr. Esther Oshiver Fisher, a retired marriage counselor, died of complications from Alzheimer's disease Feb. 13 at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 77 years old.

title: Arbitration: In Settlements, Size Counts
description: What victory?

title: LISTEN CAREFULLY TO THE MILK
description: MUCH DEPENDS ON DINNER The Extraordinary History and Mythology, Allure and Obsessions, Perils and Taboos, of an Ordinary Meal. By Margaret Visser. 351 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

title: Biathlon to East German; U.S. Is Far Back
description: What was supposed to be a day in which the United States scored a breakthrough in the biathlon was instead another bitter disappointment. Josh Thompson left the starting line in this test of endurance and marksmanship, envisioning an Olympic medal, only to cross the finish with tears in his eyes, a victim of his own expectations.

title: AIDS PANEL WANTS WIDER DRUG TESTS
description: Members of the President's AIDS commission said yesterday that they would strongly recommend greater use of neighborhood doctors and patients to test potential drug treatments for AIDS as a supplement to the government-sponsored tests at academic medical centers.

title: 100% INCREASE IN SYPHILIS PUZZLES HEALTH OFFICIALS
description: LEAD: THE spread of syphilis in Connecticut reached epidemic proportions last year, which health officials said was unexpected because of concerns about AIDS.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: RICHARD KENNEDY: Collected Stories. Illustrated by Marcia Sewell. 270 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95. (Ages 6 to 11)

title: RUSSIA AND THE JEWS: PHOTOS OF A TURBULENT PAST
description: The photographs, all in black and white and many very rare, have been mounted on illustration boards and arranged in neat piles on long tables, hundreds of photographs, waiting to be put up on the gallery walls of the Jewish Museum for the exhibition on Russian and Soviet Jewry opening Thursday. Looking up at me from one of the photographs is the dreamy-eyed face of the young Marc Chagall. The curly forelocks tumbling across his forehead give him the features of an Apollo, the gaze of a golden boy.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: YALE GLEE CLUB IN BERGEN The 100-voice Yale Glee Club will appear at the John Harms Center for the Performing Arts in Englewood Friday evening in a benefit for the Scholarship Fund of the Bergen County Yale Alumni Association.

title: LORRAINE ADAMS, REPORTER, WEDS
description: The marriage of Lorraine Adams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore V. Adams of Summit, N.J., to Michael Stanford, the son of Dr. Geoffrey Stanford of Dallas and Rosemary Stanford of Oxford, England, took place yesterday at the Americas Society in New York.

title: To Stay Undercover on Road, F.B.I. Has Bought 5 Toyotas
description: In a departure from longstanding Government policy, a Federal agency has bought five foreign automobiles for use in this country, prompting an outcry from political, industry and labor leaders.

title: MISS UNTERBERGER WEDS R. D. FINE
description: The marriage of Susan Marcia Unterberger, a daughter of Mrs. Leon Orsher of Philadelphia, and the late Dr. Herbert Unterberger, to Robert David Fine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Fine of Providence, R.I., took place last evening. Rabbi Theodore Gordon performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Correction
description: An article Feb. 7 from Baghdad, Iraq, about an exiled Iranian opposition movement, the People's Mujahedeen, incorrectly gave the reason that Massoud Rajavi, the movement's leader, was jailed in 1971. Mr. Rajavi was in jail for revolutionary activity against the Shah, not for purportedly trying to abduct the American Ambassador in Teheran.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Soft Breezes, Hard Water THEY prefer ''hard water'' to ''soft water,'' but not from the tap. Hard water means ice to a certain segment of Long Island's sailing population, and sailing on ice tops sailing on water any day, iceboaters contend.

title: Michigan Jury Rules Libel Over False Arrest
description: A jury has ruled that The Battle Creek Enquirer libeled a man in reporting that he was arrested in a rape investigation but not that he was never charged with the crime. The jury awarded him $1 million.

title: A LOW-KEY SKI RESORT IN COLORADO
description: AS a ski resort, Copper Mountain is a natural. A ''nearly perfect ski mountain,'' wrote the United States Forest Service in 1969, adding, ''If there ever was a mountain that had terrain created for skiing, it would be Copper Mountain.''

title: U.S. Ice Dancers at Full Strength
description: When Scott Gregory and Suzanne Semanick won their second straight United States ice dancing title last month, they were operating at less than full strength. Because Gregory suffered a herniated disk last November, he could not lift his partner.

title: After the Primary Primaries
description: Nouvelle Hampshire, The Washington Post called it, and the change can be seen in the old brick factory buildings in Manchester. Forlorn eight years ago, they now gleam with electronics businesses. Boutiques abound. Parking spots do not.

title: GROUP OFFERS ADVICE ON OLDER BUILDINGS
description: NEW LONDON LANDMARKS, a nonprofit preservation group, has begun a program to provide owners of the city's many older homes and other buildings with advice on rehabilitation and restoration.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's sort of like living with your husband. After a while it's not the same as it was in the beginning. Things happen, as most of us know. After any President serves eight years, you're ready for something fresh, for some new ideas.''

title: WEST BANK ENMITY TAKES ON THE MARKS OF PERMANENCE
description: THE Department of Public Works announced plans the other day for some new roads on the occupied West Bank.

title:
MUSIC;
CANADIAN BRASS IN ENGLEWOOD
description: LEAD: THE Canadian Brass, a quintet known for its unusual mix of musical styles and offbeat musical humor, will perform at 3 P.M. next Sunday at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Engelwood.

title: A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
description: On Feb. 20, 1983, my 25-year-old daughter died at New York Hospital. I was convinced that her death was the result of gross negligence on the hospital's part, and sought a reasonable explanation. Instead of receiving sympathy and cooperation, I was stonewalled by administrators and doctors alike. Eventually, I felt I had no choice but to begin legal action against the hospital.

title: Socialist Individual
description: 'Everyone deserves the opportunity to make an independent assessment of reality - and make a critical evaluation as well. In this situation the ideals and values of socialism can be established not by implantation but by the free will of an individual mind. '

title: An Israeli View
description: TO BE AN ISRAELI THESE DAYS IS, for many of us, to live with the sense that our world has begun to crumble, that our deepest beliefs and most cherished dreams are being shattered.

title: New Loans Easing the Process
description: Because married couples increasingly need the incomes of both spouses to qualify for a mortgage, a problem can arise when an employer relocates one of the partners. The spouse of the transferred employee may take several months to find a suitable job in the new location and thus have the second income needed for the loan.

title: In Japan, Visitors Will Be a Little Less Alien
description: Japan, often accused of xenophobia and sometimes with justification, took a small step this week to make visitors from abroad feel a bit less alien.

title: KATRIN NAELAPAA WEDS DOUGLAS B. MACLAURY
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Katrin Kai Naelapaa, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Heino Naelapaa of Mexico City and Dallas, was married yesterday to Douglas Bartlett MacLaury, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. MacLaury of Titusville, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: French Arms Merchants
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging In for Tough Times at Crazy Eddie
description: WHEN Elias Zinn, an electronics executive, and Victor H. Palmieri, the turnaround specialist, took over Crazy Eddie last November after a heated proxy fight, they ran into more trouble than they expected.

title: Jansen Plans To Continue
description: Dan Jansen said today that he planned to compete in two more international events this season. Jansen, 22 years old, spoke after the funeral for his sister, Jane Beres, 27, who died of leukemia last Sunday, hours before he competed in the men's 500-meter speed-skating race at the Olympics.

title: At Braintree's Only University, Higher Education in Doughnuts
description: The day before their final exam, the students at this town's only university were cramming for the grueling, eight-hour test. Julie Eringis had been at it for hours, but she still worried that her cake doughnuts might turn out too greasy on the big day. Allan Gunn had studied 18 hours a day for the past week, but he was nervous too.

title: OLD MACDUFFERS
description: FOR the last century, a ''royal and ancient game'' has been capturing a new land -winning the hearts of a new nation of ''duffers'' and ''pro's,'' threatening church attendance and nonplaying spouses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title:
DINING OUT;
WEST CALDWELL: ACCENT ON SEAFOOD
description: LEAD: OCEANUS, a restaurant on Bloomfield Avenue in West Caldwell, is almost, but not quite, recognizable as the old Pier 74. To begin with, the inside has been given a most attractive facelift. Purportedly, so has the menu, which bears little resemblance to the old Pier 74 menu, apart from the fact that seafood was and still is featured.

title:
Body and Mind;
Lesions of the Soul
description: LEAD: ANY CANCER IS horrible, but cancer of the brain adds insult to injury. When a growth occurs in the colon or breast or liver, that is bad enough; but at least we can imagine ourselves outside it, above it, looking down. Brain cancers bore from within; from the start, they are inside our very perceiving centers.

title: BEST SELLERS: FEBRUARY 21, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 16 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 2 13 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 3 3 35 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 4 5 8 WINTERS' TALES, by Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. 5 4 18 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 6 6 5 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $18.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 7 11 5 THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Abrahams/Dutton, $21.95.) Turmoil and rebellion in 19th-century Ireland, observed through the eyes and voices of many witnesses. 8 7 12 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga begun in ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 9 8 30 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles international terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 10 * 13 4 MORTAL FEAR, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) The death of a distinguished biologist leads to discoveries about medical science's mysteries and Boston's nether world. 11 9 5 MONGOOSE R.I.P., by William F. Buckley Jr. (Random House, $17.95.) Blackford Oakes in charge of a secret operation involving Fidel Castro, Soviet missiles and President Kennedy's death. 12 * 12 23 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 13 10 8 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $19.95.) The experiences of a Berlin family, from Kaiser Wilhelm to Adolf Hitler. 14 1 THAI HORSE, by William Diehl. (Villard, $18.95.) The pursuit of a man who disappeared in Vietnam 15 years ago. 15 1 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 10 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 2 10 2 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society recalled by a woman who married into it. 3 2 15 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 4 5 41 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 5 * 3 13 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 6 6 30 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 7 4 30 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former senior member of the British secret service. 8 * 14 4 DETOUR, by Cheryl Crane with Cliff Jahr. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) Lana Turner's daughter recalls the circumstances under which she killed her mother's gangster boyfriend 30 years ago. 9 11 3 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 10 1 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $17.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 11 8 37 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 12 * 7 5 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 13 9 21 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 14 13 24 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 15 1 OSCAR WILDE, by Richard Ellmann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the dramatist, essayist, poet and wit. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 3 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor. (Putnam, $17.95.) The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 2 2 33 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 3 128 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 1 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK AND EASY MENU COOKBOOK. (New American Library, $17.95.) Dishes that can be prepared in less than an hour. 5 4 13 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM: The Civil War Era, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30; after July 1, $35.) This volume in the Oxford History of the United States delivers up-to-date scholarship, unfailing lucidity and a skilled, literate narration of the bloodiest and most tragic of our nation's wars. EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) A first collection by a prodigiously talented 27-year-old; its nine short stories are all promising, some highly accomplished. THE FAST MEN, by Tom McNab. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Mr. McNab's charming novel exploits a little-known fact of frontier history, the popularity of pedestrianism; his heroes are men who settle the pecking order out West with footraces, not with six-guns. MOTHERS OF INVENTION. From the Bra to the Bomb: Forgotten Women & Their Unforgettable Ideas, by Ethlie Ann Vare and Greg Ptacek. (Morrow, $17.95.) Amusing capsule biographies of creative women (some of them far from forgotten) who made important scientific discoveries or ingenious contrivances. MONEY AND CLASS IN AMERICA: Notes and Observations on Our Civil Religion, by Lewis H. Lapham. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $18.95.) The aristocratic editor of Harper's magazine derides the aimless rich and the equally aimless pursuit of richness. THE PAPERCLIP CONSPIRACY: The Hunt for the Nazi Scientists, by Tom Bower. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) The not-very-nice story of America's rush to recruit German military scientists after World War II, sometimes without regard for their dubious backgrounds. CAPTIVITY CAPTIVE, by Rodney Hall. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.95.) A grim, beautiful Australian novel that concerns a really nasty family but offers redemption by a kind of tragic grace.

title: New York Judge Bars Restriction on Abortion
description: A Federal district judge in New York has temporarily barred the enforcement of new regulations that would prevent most family planning centers in the state from helping women to obtain abortions, a spokeswoman for the American Civil Liberties Union reported yesterday.

title: AMIE M. PILLAR TO WED R. A. FELDMAN IN JUNE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pillar of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amie Michele Pillar, to Robert Alan Feldman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome O. Feldman of Merrick, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Perspectives: Times Square; A Major Mall in a Broadway Building
description: As large new construction projects move forward on Broadway in the Times Square area, the main unanswered question, amid all the concern over design and scale, is who will occupy the buildings.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SOCIAL SECURITY SHIFT
description: LEAD: Jack Scarangella, district manager of the Social Security Administration, says it is a move to ''promote efficiency.'' Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood of Mount Vernon calls it a cutback.

title: From Fathers to Sons on the Waterfront
description: ON RAW DAYS LIKE THIS, with the wind whipping off a hide-brown Hudson and his containers slick with snow, Joseph Benedetto Jr. is numb to everything but the four levers at his finger tips and the greasy square of asphalt 50 feet beneath him. One distraction and whatever is in that 40-foot aluminum shipping crate he's lifting - shoes or whisky or computers - could slip out of his grasp and go crashing down on the men below.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Soviet Agrees to Wider U.N. Talks on Iran Embargo
description: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have taken a significant step toward imposing an arms embargo on Iran as part of their attempt to end the Persian Gulf war, according to diplomats involved in the negotiations.

title: KAREN LESSALL WEINER TO WED CHARLES GOSS
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Weiner of Sands Point, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lessall Weiner, to Charles A. Goss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Goss of Piscataway, N.J.

title: THE U.S.A. - NOW ON SALE
description: LEAD: BUYING INTO AMERICA How Foreign Money Is Changing the Face of Our Nation. By Martin and Susan Tolchin. 400 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article last Sunday about pressures faced by black police officers misidentified the department where Sgt. Donald Jackson works.

title: Increasingly, Women Are Becoming Veterinarians
description: For Dr. Becky McCarthy, it was an ordinary day in the life of a country veterinarian, quite different from the dramatic emergencies depicted by James Herriot in his books and television shows.

title: Pinstripe Suits With Kevlar Vests
description: THE shooting of a Merrill Lynch stockbroker by a distraught investor during the October market collapse sent shivers throughout corporate America. Fearful that violence could increase if the economy sours, a growing number of companies are hiring ''executive protection security personnel,'' or bodyguards, for top executives.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE DOUGLAS LETTERS:

title: Campus Racial Tensions - and Violence - Appear on Rise
description: IN the last 16 months, the University of Massachusetts at Amherst has endured just about the worst kind of publicity a college could get.

title: Governors Take Aim at U.S. Strings That Come Without Money Attached
description: On a side street in one of Philadelphia's poorest and meanest neighborhoods, there sits a vacant stone building that is about to be transformed into a residence for 25 homeless people. It might serve as a minor monument to the way in which a meddling Federal Government, in the view of governors and mayors, often frustrates local efforts to address many of the nation's urgent domestic ills.
