title: Home, Smart Home
description: Does the world offer a more beautiful sight than the crimson stare of a burglar alarm? Not to people who live by themselves, or with small children, or who are not named Rambo. There it is, the watchdog that doesn't have to be walked, ready to roar if anyone so much as tries to jimmy a window. If millions of Americans are happier in their beds, it is because of all those angry red eyes watching over their sleep.

title: Narrowing the Extremes
description: ''The difference is that the limits are narrowing,'' a young, American-educated Salvadoran businessman said. ''The extremes, right and left, are being ruled out, as more and more people see they can't solve anything.''

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: My choice is luge, perhaps because it is so unusual. To those who say that being a luger seems much too sedentary, isn't that a snap judgment? Actually participating seriously in this sport should rapidly dispel erroneous conclusions. THOMAS G. MORGANSEN Jackson Heights, Queens

title: A Dark and Difficult Genius
description: FYODOR DOSTOYEVSKY A Writer's Life. By Geir Kjetsaa. Translated by Siri Hustvedt and David McDuff. Illustrated. 437 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $24.95.

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: The best Winter Olympic sport? The 12-yard dash between my TV and refrigerator! RICH STEINHAUS Bayside, Queens

title: Sheet Music Is More Than Just Song Titles
description: ''Sheet music is a whole world,'' said Marianne Wurlitzer, a partner of Wurlitzer-Bruck, a New York firm specializing in antique musical instruments and musical material. ''You could do a history of the United States through sheet-music covers.''

title: Czechoslovak Catholics Appealing for Rights
description: More than 300,000 Czechoslovak Catholics have signed an appeal to their Government to guarantee the Roman Catholic Church fundamental rights, after the church leader threw the weight of his authority behind the petition.

title: Seton Hall Overcomes B.C.
description: Seton Hall did not try to disguise its intentions against Boston College today. The Pirates wanted to work the ball inside to Mark Bryant, stop Dana Barros and earn a Big East Conference victory.

title: Pre-CPC Days
description: To the Editor:

title: ABORTION DEBATE REVIVED IN CANADA
description: After an uneasy political truce that lasted nearly 20 years, Canada has been thrust anew into a bitter dispute over its abortion laws.

title: Virus' Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower. However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout. I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub. Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

title: MISS VAN BEUREN TO WED AN ARCHITECT
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Archbold van Beuren of New York and Middletown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara van Beuren to Stephen L. Glascock, the son of William Van Dyke Glascock of Greenbrae, Calif., and Dr. Jean Davison of San Anselmo, Calif.

title: Opera or Musical? It Can Be a Close Call
description: A traveling swindler comes to town. What he sells to the rural folk isn't worth much, but the power of suggestion runs rampant. From apparent fraud emerges surprising results - love, happiness and success. As an operagoer's ''who am I?'' quiz, this one isn't very difficult: Donizetti's ''Elixir of Love.''

title: During Talks on Concessions, Players Use Their Best Bluffs
description: It was around the midpoint in three days of talks to save The New York Post, late Thursday evening, and all seemed well on the surface.

title: THE DRAWBACKS OF PLAYING FAVORITES
description: BEING known for a favorite defense is a two-way street. If you are really good with it, you will intimidate many an opponent and score victories against listless play. Yet no matter how good you are with it, it does point the opponent toward what he has to prepare when he comes up against you. And there are opponents who cannot be intimidated.

title: MISS PERA TO WED PETER D. SANDERS
description: The Rev. and Mrs. George A. Pera of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracey Pera, to Peter David Sanders, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David S. Sanders of Claremont, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: Not for Kids Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor: I'd like to add to a Q. &A. answer on Medjugorje, the Yugoslav village that has become a popular place of religious pilgrimage.

title: What Price U.S. Patrols In the Gulf?
description: AMID conflicting calculations by officials over the cost of United States military operations in the Persian Gulf, it is clear that costs have risen and that little relief is in sight, despite the decision last week to reduce the naval force there slightly.

title: Focus: Akron, Ohio; Mixed-Use Project Pivotal For Economy
description: When officials at GenCorp withdrew plans to build a corporate headquarters in Bath Township, nine miles northwest of downtown Akron, Ohio, in 1981, development prospects were uncertain for the 358-acre parcel near Interstate 77.

title: Tropical Storm in Brazil Leaves at Least 65 Dead
description: At least 65 people were killed and some 10,000 were left homeless when a tropical storm struck Rio de Janeiro Friday night, the authorities said today.

title: N.Y.U. Names Vryonis Head of Onassis Center
description: Dr. Speros Vryonis Jr., an expert on the effect of Hellenism and Byzantine culture on Asia Minor and the Balkans, has been named the first director of the Onassis Center for Hellenic Studies at New York University.

title: Street Fashion; Snapping Out of the Winter Blahs
description: THERE are many ways to fight the winter blahs, like flying to the Caribbean or to Tahiti, or livening up an outfit with a snappy hat or a flashy accessory. The latter solution may not be as relaxing as the others, but it's cheaper and will also cheer up other poor souls who can't get away from the land of icy gusts.

title: The Hull Story
description: THE MYSTERY AT THE HEART of the yachting world's raging controversy is scheduled for unveiling March 27, when Michael Fay, a New Zealand investment banker, is to launch the boat with which he'll compete for the America's Cup in September. The $3 million yacht is being built (above) near Auckland by Marten Marine Ltd. The hull is made from fiberglass laminates; otherwise, the design principles are secret. ''This is the most advanced composite construction technique ever used in boats,'' Fay says.

title: Commercial Property: Downtown Offices; Nonfinancial Firms Fail to Fill Growing Vacancies
description: Shrinking banks and brokerage houses are creating a void in the downtown office market that stronger sectors of the Manhattan economy will offset only marginally in coming years.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A WINTER CHILL THAT WARMS OUR HEARTS
description: LEAD: DESPITE all of their discomforts and difficulties, these cold winter mornings are very special.

title: NONFICTION
description: RAISING YOUR JEWISH/CHRISTIAN CHILD: Wise Choices for Interfaith Parents. By Lee F. Gruzen. (Weber/Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) Lee Ferguson Gruzen is a Protestant married to Jordan Gruzen, a Jew. Like all parents in mixed marriages, they had some important choices to make regarding the religious training of their children. The result of Ms. Gruzen's sincere and well-intentioned quest for answers is this shallow book, an unfocused narrative derived from her reading and interviews with rabbis, priests, counselors, children and other puzzled parents in mixed marriages. More concerned with life styles than with religion, ''Raising Your Jewish/Christian Child'' suffers from a lack of breadth. For the most part the author's reporting is extremely narrow, as she searches for enlightenment in the Trinity School on New York's West Side or in the movies of Woody Allen. There are, however, two observations worth noting. One is ''the clergy's common recommendation'' that whether you are going to raise your children as Jews, Christians, both or nonbelievers, decide early what you want to do - certainly before the baby is born - so as to avoid a sudden and rending disagreement later. The other observation comes from an unnamed priest possessed of transcendent wisdom. How should parents decide? ''Go with the strength,'' he answers Ms. Gruzen. ''If one parent is more involved and committed to his or her faith, then offer that to the child. If the other religion is the more vital one within the home, then honor that one.''

title: On Language; The Player's The Thing
description: THIS IS TO REPORT the promotion to field-grade officer of a locution that had previously been a mere vogue word in the ranks.

title: Arbitration Season Ends
description: After starting slowly, players in salary arbitration finished with a flourish, winning two of the last three cases and five of the last eight. In the final decisions yesterday, Bob Boone of California and Mark Thurmond of Detroit won, and Tim Burke of Montreal lost.

title: JOHN WATERS CAVORTS IN THE MAINSTREAM
description: THE VIZIER OF VULGARITY, the titan of terrible taste, the man whose 1972 movie ''Pink Flamingos'' is still disgusting 16 years later, stood - of all places - in front of a film festival audience and licked the rain of applause from his face.

title: The Coarse and the Sacred Are Fused in Shadow Plays
description: ''When I was a kid,'' the Balinese shadow puppeteer I Nyoman Sumandhi says, ''I loved to play with puppets - but not real ones, just a special kind of leaf. My father and my grandfather didn't let me play with their puppets, because we call the puppet a kind of sacred thing.''

title: Reporter Cited for Contempt
description: A reporter for The Boston Globe was ordered jailed for contempt of court after refusing to disclose the identities of confidential sources cited in a 1982 article about a former city official. Judge John P. Sullivan of Suffolk Superior Court said Thursday he would allow the reporter, Charles A. Radin, to remain free at least a week to appeal. In the article, Mr. Radin said Richard J. Sinnott, a former city licensing chief, had applied for a disability pension, citing emotional stress he suffered while attending a licensing board meeting and two rock concerts.

title: MARINE'S CAPTORS ELUDE SEARCHERS
description: The kidnappers of a United States Marine officer have apparently slipped him through a security net set up in southern Lebanon by United Nations forces and local Moslem Shiite militiamen.

title: NASSAU MEDICAL CENTER UNDER SIEGE
description: THE Nassau County Medical Center's recent decision to turn away all but the most acutely ill patients until it improves its nurse-to-patient ratio marks a drastic step for a hospital in crisis.

title: A MAY WEDDING FOR HILARY CURTIS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Connick of New York have announced the engagement of their niece, Hilary Whittaker Curtis, to William George Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hartman Jr. of Northbrook, Ill. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Clinton B.F. Brill, 94, Former Thruway Chief
description: Clinton B. F. Brill, a civil engineer, architect and former chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, died of a heart attack Feb. 9 at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 94 years old.

title: Sweetening the Deals in a Soft Market
description: Taking a cue from anxious developers, Leonard D'Andrea stirred some flash into the strategy for selling his home in Stamford, Conn. Besides posting a competitive price on the two-bedroom condominium, he is offering to pay the buyer's $160-a-month maintenance fee for six months.

title: U.S. Skater Narrowly Misses Gold
description: More than any of the other United States speed skaters, Eric Flaim has been hailed as a potential ''Eric Heiden of the future.'' And tonight, his future almost arrived.

title: Stars Injured
description: IT was billed as a battle of titans, but the 17,500 fans who jammed the Northlands Coliseum in Edmonton on Friday night didn't get to see much of the two high-scoring stars, Wayne Gretzky, the hometown favorite, and Mario Lemieux of the visiting Pittsburgh Penguins.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FLOWERS THROUGH THE SEASON
description: LEAD: AS the name implies, annuals live but a single season and must be started from seed each year. Since started plants can be planted out almost as early as seeds can be safely sown outdoors, most annuals are started in greenhouses or cold frames 8 to 10 weeks ahead of the planting season. By doing this, it is possible to enjoy them longer.

title: The Safest Technique Is to Be Discreet
description: IN October, a chief executive was horrified when his company's confidential boardroom deliberations hit the newspapers. He called in Corporate Loss Prevention Associates Ltd., whose technicians turned up a bug in the telephone switching equipment.

title: THE ADVENT OF DO-IT-YOURSELF PRINTS
description: THE longest lines at my friendly neighborhood film-processing lab aren't at the counter. They're over in the corner where the self-service printing machine sits. No matter that it may take 30 minutes to get to the front of the line, the appeal of while-you-wait prints is apparently too great to resist.

title: PHOTOGRAPHERS TAKE AIM AT THE IMAGES FROM EARLIER WORKS
description: MARCEL DUCHAMP bestowed a moustache on a reproduction of the Mona Lisa in 1919. However, art about art didn't take root as an official policy until the 1950's when Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns began their careers parodying Abstract Expressionism and it was another two decades before photography followed suit.

title: AS AMERICA GOES, SO DOES A BUSINESS
description: A MILLION DOLLAR yearly phone bill would send most companies into shock, but to Michael H. Wellner, president of the Kemwel Group in Harrison, it is an indication that business is good. The Kemwel Group includes a number of related companies, specializing in the vacation travels of Americans, primarily to Europe.

title: STAKING OUT THE GLOBE
description: THE AGE OF EMPIRE 1875-1914. By E. J. Hobsbawm. Illustrated. 404 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title: TERRI LYNN LIEBOWITZ PLANS MAY WEDDING TO S. K. FELD
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Liebowitz of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terri Lynn Liebowitz, to Sanford K. Feld, the son of the late Edith Feld and the late Albert Feld of Sands Point, L.I. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Does Meyerbeer Deserve His Years of Obscurity?
description: Whatever hap-pened to Meyerbeer?

title: SANDY SIMMONS PLANS TO WED G. P. LEONARD
description: The engagement of Sandy Sevier Simmons to Geoffrey Porter Leonard, the son of James Leonard of New York and the late Georgine Leonard, has been made known by the future bride's mother, Mrs. John M. Simmons of Olympia, Wash. A July wedding is planned.

title: True Champion Is Recalled
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Canada and Sweden Reach Medal Round
description: Canada, which had scored six goals in its first three games, got seven in the first period today and clinched a medal-round berth with a 9-5 hockey victory over France.

title: HOSPITALS GET NEW LEADERS TO HELP MEET NEW NEEDS
description: HOSPITALS are facing many new challenges, and, in many cases, they are meeting them with new administrators.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BLACK AND SCANDINAVIAN HERITAGES
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Historical Society will observe Black History Month with a symposium Saturday entitled ''18th-Century Black History: A New Jersey Perspective.''

title: Toxic Chemical Spill
description: About 100,000 gallons of flammable toluene has spilled from a ruptured Sun Company pipeline into the Sandusky River near here, forcing the evacuation of about 5,000 people. Mayor Fred Singer said today that those evacuated Wednesday and Thursday would be allowed to return home.

title: A Compromise For Hall of Fame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NIGHTMARE: Uncovering the 56 Strange Personalities of Nancy Lynn Gooch. By Emily Peterson and Nancy Lynn Gooch with Lucy Freeman. (Richardson & Steirman/Kampmann, $18.95.) Nancy Lynn Gooch, a troubled teen-ager, startled her foster parents one Sunday in November 1975 when she appeared in a new outfit and coolly announced with an altered voice and demeanor: ''I am not Nancy.

title: 2 GUIDES ISSUED ON CHILD CARE IN COUNTY
description: LEAD: TWO new publications are now available for working parents in Westchester who have been seeking before- and after-school care for their children. One provides information on what programs exist in the county, and its companion publication outlines how parents, community organizations or recreational groups can start a program of their own.

title: Mark of Champion
description: It apparently takes more than a broken nose to stop Larry Bird. Two days after breaking his nose and leaving the game with only 13 points in a Celtic loss to the Denver Nuggets, Bird returned to the Boston lineup for a game against the Trail Blazers in Portland on Friday night, and as near as anyone could tell, the injury did not hamper his play. He scored 40 points as the Celtics swept to a 124-104 victory.

title: THE GUIDE
description: MOLIERE AT YALE REP Lewis J. Stadlen, a Tony Award nominee for his performance as Pangloss in the Broadway production of ''Candide'' in 1974, plays the title role in Moliere's ''Miser,'' which will run to March 12 at the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: Save a Spot for Amateurs in the Olympics
description: Two weeks before my scheduled participation in the Olympics, perhaps the ultimate dream of every athlete, I was abruptly awoken. I discovered I was being replaced on the United States bobsled team by a well-known professional football player, Willie Gault of the Chicago Bears.

title: NONFICTION
description: IN SEARCH OF THE DARK AGES. By Michael Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Michael Wood, author of ''In Search of the Trojan War,'' has now turned to slightly more modern times: the genesis of the English nation. He begins in A.D. 60, when Boadicea led her Celtic tribesmen in a doomed revolt against Roman rule, and ends a millennium later with William the Conqueror. The book's main subject is Anglo-Saxon England, ''a remarkably unified country . . . with a vernacular literature unmatched in Europe . . . and sophisticated machinery of government, chancery, coinage and law.'' Each chapter profiles a historical figure. The list includes Arthur, Alfred and others less famous, such as Offa (who unified central England) and Athelstan (''an English Charlemagne''). Mr. Wood is skilled not only at retelling events but also at showing how the era has been pieced together from archeological finds, Old English poems and surviving documents. Particularly interesting are the connections he suggests between Dark Age Britain and the present day. Tenth-century Northumbria resented rule from Wessex, which may help explain why the modern North of England votes Labor during Tory landslides. Alfred the Great appears as ''an oversensitive, highly-strung young man, strongminded and inventive,'' an early version of T. E. Lawrence. And Ethelred really did deserve to be called ''the Unready'' - the name is a barbed bit of Anglo-Saxon political satire. The companion volume to a BBC television series, this copiously illustrated book is first-rate popular history.

title: Under the Clock: Church to Offices
description: A former 24-pew Methodist church in Warwick, N.Y., is being converted into a 14,000-square-foot office building. While New York City has its cathedral of commerce - the gothic Woolworth Building - and its Limelight discotheque - once the Church of Holy Communion - the Orange County project is one of the rare altars-to-office conversions. Space will start at $15 a square foot.

title: Atlantic Record Sought for Speedboats
description: The 150-year-old Blue Riband, a trans-Atlantic speed title claimed two years ago by a powerboat team from Britain, is expected to generate two more multimillion-dollar record attempts this June.

title: Going 'Home' to Africa
description: ON a trip to the Cape Verde Islands off West Africa, I met my great-grandaunt, Maria Nharita. She was a vivid reminder of my African ancestry. She lived in a hut.

title: Japan's Alps: A Refuge for Everyone
description: JAPAN and megalopolis are synonymous in the minds of many travelers, but more Americans are discovering a Japan of mountain wilderness that is accessible to the adventurous visitor. Most itineraries emphasize visits to shrines, temples and sushi bars, so it can be startling to learn that you can go hiking in the Japanese Alps. For centuries the Japanese themselves considered these mountains the sacred domain of the spirits, to be trod upon only by Buddhist priests and white-robed pilgrims. A British missionary, the Rev. Walter Weston, changed all that in the 1890's. When he was not evangelizing, Weston liked to climb mountains, first in the Swiss Alps, later in Japan.

title: THE PARKWAY FOLLIES, STARRING TOM KEAN
description: WHEN the New Jersey Highway Authority, operator of the Garden State Parkway, features Frank Sinatra, Liza Minelli or Bruce Springsteen at its Arts Center in Holmdel, the S.R.O. sign goes up weeks before the performances.

title: At Home The Story's Different
description: Because most theatrical movies made in any year are instantly disposable, without any aspirations beyond being amusing for a limited span of time, it's not easy to argue that movies are debased when they show up on television, reduced in size and clarity, in what is, in effect, their second run.

title: Little Washington
description: To the Editor: William L. Tazewell's article, ''A Washington Outside the Beltway'' (Travel, Dec. 27), was read with delight at the recognition the Inn at Little Washington received. I, too, have been a guest there and thought of it as my little secret.

title: DRAWING THE LINE ON STUDENT RIGHTS: CENSORSHIP HAS NO PLACE IN HIGH SCHOOL
description: FREEDOM of speech. As an American I've come to take that for granted.

title: WHY THE COURSE OF AIDS IS DEFYING AFRICA'S PRECEDENT
description: HAVING finally persuaded much of the public that the United States is on the verge of a heterosexual AIDS pandemic, health officials are suddenly reversing their prognosis. For months, a growing volume of statistics has been showing that HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, is not moving rapidly through the population after all. The human immune deficiency virus is indeed being transmitted heterosexually - to the partners of drug users and bisexual men. But unlike in Central Africa, it does not seem to have leaked in any significant way beyond these so-called risk groups.

title: COMMUTER TAX: THE JOKE'S ON KOCH
description: Rural life may be a ''joke'' to Ed Koch and the suburbs a ''sterile'' place to dwell, but if the Mayor believes he's about to double the city income tax for commuters, he has another guess coming.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC'S FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Frozen Pizzas And Labels
description: YOU buy a frozen pizza in the supermarket. Should the food processor tell you in a prominent label whether you're getting real cheese?

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Big Easy Starring Dennis Quaid, Ellen Barkin, Ned Beatty, Ebbe Roe Smith, Marc Lawrence, John Goodman, Lisa Jane Persky, Charles Ludlam. Directed by Jim McBride. 1987. HBO Video. 100 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: Nation's Armed Forces Running Short of Uniforms
description: The nation's armed forces are running short of a critical spare part: uniforms.

title: Ski-Jump Article Is Refreshing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ROBIN MARIE PUGH, LAWYER, IS MARRIED TO W. G. FILMYER JR., MEDICAL STUDENT
description: At Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in New York, Robin Marie Pugh was married yesterday to William George Filmyer Jr. by Msgr. Myles M. Bourke. Susannah Pomeroy Scannell and Elizabeth Cancian Rust were the maid and the matron of honor. Milton Webster Anderson was the best man.

title: Down With Astrology
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: Few Americans have suffered in such a curious manner from distorted public image as have those of Italian background. The prejudices have been less harsh than those affecting other groups, but no less demeaning. THE ITALIAN AMERICANS (Macmillan, $49.50), an account by Allon Schoener, a cultural historian, of Italian life in the United States in word and picture, is a more positive testimony to the nature and achievements of these remarkably vibrant people. It is a beautifully produced book. The lavish illustrations include maps of early Italian exploration (under other national sponsorship) of the New World. There are photographs depicting the development of a community, from the debarkation of immigrants to the integration of later generations into the mainstream of American life - but with a distinctive cultural heritage that still manifests itself. The book avoids the familiar pattern of stressing the well-known figures (though they are in evidence), concentrating instead on the broader picture: workers, shopkeepers, church and veterans' groups. Here are the restaurants, the socials, the family and its members, from Italian grandparent to Yankee grandchildren. These ingredients project the warm feeling of a family album. A well-written introductory essay by A. Bartlett Giamatti, formerly the president of Yale University and now the president of baseball's National League, offers a cohesive overview of Italian-Americans, addressing questions of identity, language, stereotypes, religion, education and, yes, crime. Lee Iacocca has the last word in a brief epilogue to this heroic story from American history.

title: Oregon's Law on Open Coastline Faces Test
description: Twenty years ago, when Gov. Tom McCall signed a bill declaring the uncluttered sands, high dunes and rocky shores of the 362-mile Oregon coast off limits to the claims of private property, some developers called it ''the communist manifesto.''

title: U.N. Cuts Lebanon Relief
description: Relief services for about 260,000 Palestinian refugees in Lebanon will be cut to the minimum because the kidnapping of two employees of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency have raised fears over staff safety, the agency said today. The two employees - Jan Stening, 44 years old, of Sweden, and William Jorgensen, 58, of Norway - were kidnapped Feb. 5. A spokesman said the agency had already canceled a repair program for the war-ravaged Shatila and Burj al Brajneh Palestinian refugee districts in Beirut.

title: Knits That Sway
description: LEAD: ''I'M tired of seeing the backs of women's legs,'' said Valerie Louthan, the cashmere specialist who has recently added silk knitwear to her repertory. ''But I think knees look quite interesting.''

title: INCEST VICTIMS: NO MORE MARTYRS
description: In regard to the Jan. 10 article ''Incest Victims Get Sympathy but Little Help,'' I would like to say I agree with the statements that our current laws concerning the rights of abused children are considerably lacking in defending those rights.

title: RULING THE JET SET
description: William Safire refers to the phrase ''jet set'' as having ''first appeared in print in 1951 to describe the fashion-conscious group that used jet aircraft to take them to the world's watering spots in passionate pursuit of pleasure'' (On Language: ''Ruling the Jet Set,'' Jan. 24).

title: Local Authorities Aided By U.S. in Prosecutions
description: Two years ago Leon B. Kellner, the United States Attorney here, took over the prosecution of several Miami police officers accused of drug trafficking and racketeering, This arrangement, requested by Janet Reno, the State Attorney for Dade County, evolved into a pattern under which virtually all local corruption cases here are going to the Federal courts for trial. It exemplifies a trend in many metropolitan areas.

title: College Basketball: Big East; Panthers Hang On To Beat Hoyas
description: Charles Smith scored 25 points, the final 10 on free throws, as Pitt outlasted Georgetown, 70-65, today in a physical Big East Conference game that ended with a brawl.

title: Discrimination and the New York Job Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes: 503 Fifth Avenue; A 6-Story, 1860 Remnant Of a Genteel Midtown
description: Surrounded by office towers, the six-story building at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Fifth Avenue gets barely a glance from passers-by. But empty buildings do not remain on prime corners indefinitely. Thus the future of 503 Fifth Avenue, built in 1860 and one of the oldest buildings on the avenue, does not seem bright.

title: HOLOCAUST CENTER: ISSUE OF PRINCIPLE
description: THE fight to remain open in a residential Woodmere community has become more than a zoning issue for the Life Center for Holocaust Studies. It is a matter of principle and recognition that the study of the Holocaust cannot be separated from the Jewish religion, according to Rabbi Benjamin Kamenetzky.

title: Social Climbing on Mount Halla
description: In this Island there is a Mountain of a vast Height all cover'd with woods and several small Hills which are naked, and enclose many Vales abounding in Rice . . . - Hendrick Hamel, 1668, ''The Description of the Kingdom of Corea''

title: Lights! Camera! Easel!
description: What do Edward G. Robinson, Alec Guinness, Daryl Hannah and Dick Van Dyke have in common? Apart from being artists in the entertainment sense, they have also played artists in the artistic sense. And as Hollywood and the New York art world move closer together in the 1980's - with their star systems, the big prices and instant fame that awaits hot new discoveries - Hollywood has started to take the art world seriously (or humorously, as the case may be). Kirk Douglas's portrayal of Vincent van Gogh in ''Lust for Life'' has always been a classic for art theory students - for whom it embodies all the cliches of the angst-ridden artist. In fact, some bidders at auctions where astronomical sums were paid for ''Sunflowers'' and ''Irises'' have admitted that their interest was fueled by Hollywood's singular portrayal of van Gogh.

title: Invitation to a Dance
description: DRIVING along the paved road to Kah-Nee-Ta Lodge at noon on Sundays from May to September, visitors are likely to be caught in a parade of cars, vans and pickups holding American Indian families that have come to dance. Watching them arrive and settle themselves may be the best introduction to the pleasures of this Indian-owned resort on the Warm Springs Reservation about 60 miles northeast of Bend, Ore.

title: India Bus Crash Kills 35
description: At least 35 people were killed and many injured when a bus plunged into a ravine in northern India today, the Press Trust of India said. About 60 people were aboard the bus when the accident occurred 40 miles from Simla, the capital of Himachal Pradesh state.

title: DATA BANK: February 21, 1988
As Greek Cypriots Vote, Reunion Is the Hope
description: As Cyprus prepares for a presidential runoff election on Sunday, the result is far from clear, but the problem that will confront the winner is evident: how to revive efforts to reconcile and reunite the island's Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities.

title: SIKORSKY AIRPORT HOPES TO LOSE ITS ANONYMITY
description: TO Morgan Kaolian, it is ''the best-kept secret in Fairfield County.'' Mr. Kaolian is referring to Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, of which he is the manager. Although it is within a half-hour's drive of anywhere in the county, the airport remains a little-known resource.

title: DRAWING THE LINE ON STUDENT RIGHTS: COMMUNITY VALUES ARE ESSENTIAL
description: AS a former member of a Board of Education on Long Island, I believe that the recent Supreme Court decision upholding control of student publications should be supported. I do not believe the decision to permit school boards and administrators to ban material deemed unsuited for publication is either a devastating blow to freedom of speech or ''the wrong civic lesson'' for teen-age students.

title: Not for Kids Only
description: To the Editor:

title:
RECORDINGS;
A COMPOSER'S 'PICKLES AND JAM' PRESERVED ON DISK
description: LEAD: That testy victorian professor and composer, Sir Charles Villiers Stanford, once compared Louis Spohr's highly chromatic musical vocabulary to ''pickles and jam,'' and warned his Cambridge students that a good diet required more substantial stuff. Nearly a century has passed since that assessment was made, and pickles and jam or not, Spohr's luscious brand of preserves is astonishingly fresh-flavored after so many years on the shelf.

title: Seven Are Reported Detained in Poland as Solidarity Tries to Meet
description: The police have detained at least seven opposition leaders, apparently in an effort to prevent the outlawed trade union Solidarity from convening a meeting this weekend, opposition spokesmen said today.

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: Downhill skiing. Even those who haven't struggled to get on a chair lift, or stood at the top of the smallest slope and wondered, ''How am I going to get to the bottom?'' can appreciate the guts, skill, power and lunacy it takes to defy death and ski down an icy slope at speeds exceeding 80 miles per hour. FRANCINE M. SCUDERI Ozone Park, Queens

title: Allisons Thrive on Respect
description: Joyful anticipation, tinged with perhaps a touch of anxiety, showed on the face of Judy Allison last Sunday as the final laps of the Daytona 500 unwound. Her husband, 50-year-old Bobby, and son, 26-year-old Davey, were leading the pack on the mad dash for the checkered flag.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC'S FUTURE
description: To The Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
'HOTTEST'
description: LEAD: WHEN he was 3 years old, Ira D. Hall was forced from his house at gunpoint. He and his family were black and lived in a mostly white neighborhood in Oklahoma City. A white neighbor discovered that the house the Halls had recently bought had in its deed a clause prohibiting sale to blacks. The neighbor notified the sheriff, who evicted the family.

title: LILCO TURBINE PLAN UPSETS BABYLON
description: LEAD: A PLAN by the Long Island Lighting Company to add a 200-megawatt gas turbine generating system to its substation and transmission facility in West Babylon has drawn protests from residents who believe that the plant would threaten their safety and hurt their neighborhoods.

title: Westernization and Empires
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO IMPROVE STATE'S SCHOOLING
description: In his State of the State address, Governor Kean tried to increase or shift the level of mediocrity from one school area to another.

title: Board of Estimate in Conflict: The Final Phases
description: The ranking members of New York City's government are in an uproar, and have been for weeks. With the exception of Mayor Koch, they are angry, even shaken, by a formidable threat to their power.

title: Jazz: Jelly Roll Kings In Mississippi Blues Bill
description: RAW-BONED, loose-limbed Mississippi blues - music so traditional it can sound avant-garde -twanged and strutted at the Triplex on Friday night, in a triple bill presented by the World Music Institute. Two of the oldest Mississippi styles and one of their wayward, electrified offspring filled the theater with sounds usually heard at barbecues, back porches and juke joints, defying the formality of a concert hall with down-home directness.

title: Western Fund Set Up to Aid Polish Farmers
description: With help from David Rockefeller and encouragement from the Polish authorities, a foundation has been set up in Poland to stimulate the lagging agriculture and food industries.

title: Murder Most Lunatic
description: NADINE Starring Kim Basinger (in photo), Jeff Bridges (in photo), Rip Torn, Gwen Verdon, Glenne Headly and Jerry Stiller. Directed by Robert Benton. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 82 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG.

title: INTERSTATE 95: THE DEVIL'S HIGHWAY
description: IN the 1950's, it was heralded as a paragon of construction technology. A shining and proud example of what highways could be, it was a masterful and much-anticipated artery for the enhanced exchange of interstate commerce and a promise of great things to come.

title: LIZA MELTZER PLANS TO WED JOHN FIXX
description: The engagement of Liza Meltzer to John Durling Fixx, a son of Mary Durling Fixx of Oberlin, Ohio, and the late James F. Fixx, has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Meltzer of Rochester, the parents of the bride-to-be. A July wedding is planned.

title: H. P. HAVELES JR. WEDS MISS KENT IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Hingham, Mass., Elisabeth Anne Kent, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Kent of Hingham, was married yesterday to H. Peter Haveles Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Haveles of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Nicholas Morcone performed the ceremony.

title: AMANDA ZINSSER PLANS TO WED JAMES MOFFAT
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Zinsser Jr. of New York and West Cornwall, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Zinsser's daughter Amanda Locke Zinsser to James Matthews Moffat, the son of Mrs. Daniel G. Quigley of Bedford, N.Y., and John Moffat of Cooperstown, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: SHE'S THE TOP
description: As a neighbor and friend of Patti LuPone, I remember that Patti was always bursting out with a song, even when she was a little girl (''She's the Top,'' by David Sacks, Jan. 24). I would be outside, doing my weekend building. She would be coming down the hill to play with my children. She would see me and would sing, in her own style: ''Good morning, Mr. Scarola; how are you?'' Then I would answer. We had a duet going that would have made Jeanette and Nelson jealous. David Sacks has told it well. Patti LuPone is a star. J. M. SCAROLA Northport, L.I.

title: South Africa's Liberals: Divided and Dropping Out
description: South African liberals are more divided than ever about their future.

title: NEW YORK'S BRIDGES ARE CRUMBLING TOWERS OF NEGLECT
description: THE next time someone tries to sell you a bridge in New York City, be sure to ask for a warranty. Officials say about half the city's bridges are rated in poor or fair condition, 31 have had to be at least partly closed off and 100 need to be replaced.

title: DEATH CAMPS IN EVERY VILLAGE
description: HAING NGOR A Cambodian Odyssey. By Haing Ngor with Roger Warner. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: Physician, Heal Thyself
description: THE CITADEL With Robert Donat (in photo), Rosalind Russell (in photo), Ralph Richardson and Rex Harrison. Directed by King Vidor. 1938. MGM/UA Home Video. 113 minutes. $24.95.

title: I.B.M. Puts Its Cards on the Table
description: NEWLY restructured, hungry and aggressive, I.B.M. is preparing a barrage of new products for its Personal System/2 line of microcomputers.

title: A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
description: The authors purport to examine problems at New York Hospital by focusing on a few celebrated cases, but their own statistics do not support their allegations. If the hospital admits roughly 40,000 patients a year, and 109 complaints have been registered in the last three years (with only 29 percent of those apparently justified), greater than 99 percent of the cases are handled without significant incident. Even if Andy Warhol and Libby Zion died as the direct result of negligence or malpractice, the overall record of the hospital seems sound.

title: DRIED FRUITS CAN BRIGHTEN DESSERTS
description: IF you are looking for new ideas for winter desserts, consider dried fruits. They are at their best during the winter and are a fine alternative to expensive tropical or out-of-season fresh fruit. You can now get prunes, dried apple rings, apricots, pears, peaches and figs, mostly from California, good enough to eat straight from the package. Apart from being a pleasant snack, they also make elegant desserts -souffles, mousses, and compotes -that are easy to prepare and high in nutrition.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING A JUMP ON SPRING CROPS
description: LEAD: AFTER a winter of inactivity gardeners cannot wait to start planting, but sometimes their impatience rules over logic. On the first warm day they are out in the garden sowing seeds and setting out seedlings. Then along comes snow, a deep freeze or both.

title: EMILY DUHAMEL PLANS TO BE WED TO M. C. BROWER
description: Emily Ritchie DuHamel and Montgomery C. Brower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brock H. Brower of Princeton, N.J., plan to marry in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Notley Y. DuHamel Jr. of Montclair, N.J., and Sakonnet, R.I., have announced.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Red Wings Win Third Straight: Shawn Burr scored twice and Glen Hanlon stopped 23 shots yesterday as the Red Wings won their third straight game by beating the Chicago Blackhawks, 6-1, in Detroit. Burr's first goal, 10 minutes 50 seconds into the second period, increased Detroit's lead to 2-0. Burr took a pass from Dave Barr in the Chicago zone and lifted a 15-foot backhander past Bob Mason. After Jim Nill converted John Chabot's centering pass at 14:44 to stretch the Red Wings' lead to 3-0, Burr scored his 13th goal of the season, skating the length of the ice and beating Mason with another backhander while Detroit was killing a penalty.(AP) Track and Field Indoor High-Jump Mark: Stefka Kostadinova of Bulgaria improved her world indoor record in the women's high jump yesterday, leaping 6 feet 9 inches at a meet in Piraeus, Greece. Kostadinova cleared the record height on her second attempt. The previous world indoor mark was 6-8 3/4, set by Kostadinova in the World Indoor Championships at Indianapolis in March 1987. Kostadinova also holds the world outdoor record of 6-10 1/4. (AP) 1,000-Meter Record: Rob Druppers of the Netherlands set a world indoor record for 1,000 meters of 2 minutes 16.62 seconds. Druppers's time was more than one second under the previous record of 2:18.00, held by Igor Lotarev of the Soviet Union. The race was part of the Dutch indoor track and field championships.(AP) Soccer Arsenal Advances: Alan Smith scored two goals as Arsenal defeated Manchester United, 2-1, yesterday in a fifth-round match of the English F.A. Cup. Joining Arsenal in the quarterfinals of the elimination competition were Nottingham Forest, Portsmouth and Wimbledon from the English League's First Division, and Manchester City of the Second Division. (AP) Tennis Connors to Face Noah: Jimmy Connors defeated Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1, yesterday to reach the final of the Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. Yannick Noah of France also advanced to today's final on the strength of a final set tiebreaker that gave him a 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 victory over top-seeded Boris Becker, the defending champion. Noah won the tiebreaker by 8-6. Connors, who at 35 is 11 years older than Srejber, kept his opponent off balance with well-placed lobs.(AP) Agassi Gains Indoor Final: Sixth-seeded Andre Agassi moved into the final of the United States Indoor Championship, using a powerful assortment of ground strokes to eliminate 10th-seeded Kevin Curren, 6-1, 6-4. Agassi displayed an assortment of strokes as he preferred to play most of the match from the baseline and wait for an opportunity to power the ball past his opponent when Curren ventured near the net. The victory put the 17-year-old Agassi, whose only tour victory came last year at Itaparica, Brazil, into today's title match against ninth-seeded Mikael Pernfors of Sweden. Pernfors eliminated unseeded Robert Seguso, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) Wrestling Cubans Excel: Cuba won nine gold medals and the United States picked up one in the finals Friday night of a Pan American wrestling tournament in Cuba, according to the Cuban Government press agency. Prensa Latina reported in a dispatch monitored in Mexico City that Bruce Baumgartner of the United States defeated Domingo Mesa of Cuba in the 130-kilogram (286-pound) class to win a gold medal. High School Basketball P.S.A.L. Tournament: Darryl Williams scored 19 points, 15 in the first period, to lead undefeated Abraham Lincoln to its 21st victory season yesterday, an 81-46 romp over Eastern District in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League championships at Canarsie High School in Brooklyn. Eastern District finished the season at 12-9. Boys & Girls, the Brooklyn III regular-season champion, earned its 20th victory in 23 outings with a 67-55 triumph over Lafayette (10-13). Shawn Troutman had 18 points for Boys & Girls, which will meet Lincoln next Saturday. Golf Faxon Leads: Brad Faxon sank a 35-foot eagle putt on the 18th hole yesterday to take a one-shot lead after the third round of the Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif. Faxon, seeking the first victory of his five-year PGA Tour career, moved in front with a six-under-par 66 on the South course at the Torrey Pines Golf Club. That gave him a 54-hole total of 200, 16 under par. Steve Pate was next at 201. (AP) Windy Day for Seniors: Dale Douglass overcame high winds and cold temperatures to shoot a three-under-par 69 and keep his lead after two rounds of the GTE Suncoast Seniors Golf Classic in Tampa, Fla. Playing with 40-mile-per-hour winds ripping across the Tampa Palms Golf and Country Club course, only two other golfers besides Douglass posted sub-70 rounds. Douglass, who shot a 67 on Friday, was at 136, four shots ahead of Bob Brue, who had the day's best round, a 68. Arnold Palmer and Gary Player were tied for third at 141 with Bob Charles.(AP)

title: THE WORLD'S MAJOR SPORTS EVENTS ARE THE TOPIC
description: THE final set in Canada's Winter Olympic Games series features alpine skiing, figure skating, luge and curling. The four sports epitomize the speed, grace and precision of winter sports. Curling is not a medal event, but a demonstration sport.

title: MISS TYLER BRIDE OF DAVID A. NUFER
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Julia Vitale Tyler, a daughter of Celia Vitale of Southbury, Conn., and Naples, Fla., and the late Alexander Vitale, was married yesterday to David Arnold Nufer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. George Nufer of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. John Halborg performed the ceremony.

title: 'BORN YESTERDAY' IS REBORN IN CHICAGO
description: Chicago! What a perilous, politically-blooded arena in which to revive ''Born Yesterday,'' Garson Kanin's 1945 play about governmental corruption in wartime Washington. Fixes and graft have long been a form of street theater in Chicago; most citizens' knowledge of municipal deals darker than the century-old bricks of the Steppenwolf Theater building lies as deep in memory as their childhood prayers. Besides, the national mores have indeed changed enormously since those idealistic postwar days when Mr. Kanin - sensing that a tale about a junk tycoon's efforts to buy a United States Senator was too strong for the movies -crafted it instead for the stage.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Feb. 6 MANHATTAN Murray Hill $400,000 127 East 36th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar, duplex co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, 2 exposures; maintenance $1,700, 59% tax-deductible (Broker: B.J. Gottesman) Gracie Mansion Area $959,000 528 East 87th Street 2-family, 4-story town house; 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, formal dining room, 3 fireplaces, terrace, south garden in primary triplex; 1 bedroom, 1 bath, fireplace, roof garden in 4th fl. rental unit; 19- by 63-ft. lot; taxes $9,100 (Broker: Lyons & Associates) Gracie Mansion Area $170,000 525 East 89th Street (Gracie Gardens) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $880. 58% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) Upper West Side $720,000 490 West End Avenue (83d St.) 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; manned elevator, formal dining room, entry gallery, maid's room; maintenance $992, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Clara Madlin Real Estate) West Side $117,000 180 West End Avenue (69th St.) 525-sq.-ft. postwar, studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, separate dressing area and kitchen; maintenance $462, includes gas and electricity, 54% tax-deductible (Broker: Olshan Realty) BRONX Parkchester $210,000 1133 St. Lawrence Avenue 2-family, detached, frame house; dining area in 1st fl. unit; large kitchen in other; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath in each; full basement, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Riverdale $160,000 3935 Blackstone Avenue (Woodlands) 2-bedroom, 2-bath. 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, terrace; maintenance $560, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) BROOKLYN Cobble Hill $450,000 203 Amity Street 3-family, 4-story, Victoran brownstone; 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, dining area, large kitchen, deck in owner duplex; 1 bedroom, 1 bath, den in floor-through rental units, 18- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,100 (Broker: Barbara D'Erasmo) Midwood $66,000 745 East 31st Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft, postwar co-op; dinette, birch cabinets, wall-oven; maintenance $358, includes gas, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Dwork & Korn) QUEENS Flushing $270,000 27-21 165th Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, finished basement, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Forest Hills $110,000 69-60 108th St. (Cromwell) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, raised dining alcove, hardwood floors; maintenance $338, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kraham Realty) STATEN ISLAND Great Kills $187,000 152 Tanglewood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, frame house; dining area, large kitchen, finished basement, 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty) St. George $135,000 80 Scribner Avenue 2-family, detached house; 4 bedrooms in primary unit, 3 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, formal dining room, in each; 30- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $816 (Broker: Rand Properties) West Brighton $168,000 166 Marion Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, Tudor; formal dining room, finished attic, 2-car garage, 75- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate)

title: As Important As Anyone In His Generation
description: Categories are conven-ient; they allow us to relate one thing to another, to set up connections between events that might otherwise (we fear) fly apart into a myriad of fragments in a mad, dissociated universe. So there's probably no harm in calling John Zorn's latest album, ''Spillane'' (Nonesuch 9-79172, all three formats), a pop record. The title ''track'' of the three portions of this disk is a homage to the B-movie music heard in Mickey Spillane detective films, and the middle portion was written for the blues guitarist and singer Albert Collins.

title: Democratic Group Said to Agree on $25 Million Package of Aid for Contras
description: A task force of 15 House Democrats representing liberal, moderate and conservative wings of the party has tentatively agreed on a $25 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Congressional aides. Jim Wright, the House Speaker, hopes to bring the proposal to the House floor for a vote on Thursday.

title: Japan Seeks Stake In American Tires
description: Bridgestone Tire agreed to pay $1 billion for 75 percent of Firestone in what is believed to be the largest Japanese investment yet in an American manufacturer. Firestone is the nation's third-largest tire maker, with $2.6 billion of tire sales annually. But after the deal, its largest business will be 1,500 retail stores that sell tires and other automotive goods and services. Bridgestone is the world's third-largest tire maker, after Goodyear and Michelin of France. Overcapcity has brought drastic changes in the American tire industry. Goodyear spent heavily to fight a takeover threat from Sir James Goldsmith; Gencorp was bought by a West German company, and Goodrich and Uniroyal effectively abandoned the business by merging their tire operations into a separate company.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: Are Corporations Less Charitable?; Not Selfish, Sophisticated
description: LAST fall, as the drop in the stock market rattled the financial community, another kind of business downturn spread panic among nonprofit organizations. The news was that after 15 boom years, corporate philanthropy was about to enter a period of decline.

title: Cheap Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: Chariots of Poetry: Bards Pursue Olympics Gold, Too
description: The three winners stood on the podium, their official Olympic medals hanging from their necks as the crowd cheered.

title: BEYOND THE CHANCELLOR'S HONEYMOON
description: DR. Richard R. Green, who will become New York City's Schools Chancellor on March 1, is preparing for what is likely to be a brief honeymoon in an environment that has been notoriously unfriendly to outsiders. But he made it clear in an interview last week that without underestimating the difficulty of attempting to reform a system widely considered enormously resistant to change, he feels ready to take on any forces that might think of him as an easily manipulated newcomer.

title: PORTENT OF SPRING: FLOWER AND GARDEN SHOW
description: LEAD: AN EARLY and welcome sign of spring - the New Jersey Flower and Garden Show -opens Saturday at the Morristown Armory, where it will continue in full bloom through March 6.

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: What's the best Winter Olympic sport? Contemplating spring training. FRED LANDES New York

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower. However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout. I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub. Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HARD RAIN. By Peter Abrahams. (Dutton, $18.95.) A good thriller needs style, atmosphere and a surprising plot. ''Hard Rain,'' a new novel from the author of ''The Fury of Rachel Monette,'' has all of these and something extra: depth of feeling. Jessie Shapiro, Peter Abrahams's heroine, lives in Los Angeles with her young daughter, Kate.

title: Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
description: Take the sublime natural ingredients -the mountain, the sky, the wind and the snow - add the requisite dash of danger, and you have uncovered the classic dish of the Winter Olympic feast: downhill skiing. JACK PARL Bayside, Queens

title: City Hall Notes; New York Panel Draws a Whimsical Picture of Government
description: One thing New York City's government has never been accused of is being artistic. Colorful, maybe. But not artistic. Until now. In an effort to explain the current city government to an electorate that will be voting on changing it next November, the Charter Revision Commission has issued a whimsical poster that illustrates the city's vast bureauracy.

title: MELANIE CZARRA TO MARRY EDWARD PANEK JR. IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar F. Czarra Jr. of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melanie Anne Czarra to Edward Stephen Panek Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Panek of Westfield, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: GIVE PRIVATE ENTERPRISE A CHANCE
description: HIGHER gasoline taxes, rusting bridges, tainted water supplies, unending crusades to ''increase efficiency'' in government offices ''to better serve the public.'' All these result from our constant attempts to stretch government farther than its resources can reach.

title: Killer Tells of Requests for His Help in Crimes
description: John Wayne Hearn, a convicted murderer whose classified advertisement in Soldier of Fortune magazine led to a suit against the publication, says most of the people who answered the ad were seeking help in crimes like bombings, assaults, jailbreaks and murders.

title: AT THE BEN SHAHN, SURREALISM'S LEGACY
description: IF THE beginnings of Dada were ''disgust,'' as one of its leaders, Tristan Tzara, said, the beginnings of Surrealism might be called organized disgust.

title: Jets Can Learn From Redskins
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JULIA A. KOSASKY TO WED IN MAY
description: The engagement of Julia Anne Kosasky to William Lane Hallisey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hallisey of Riverside, Calif., has been made known by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Harold J. Kosasky of Chestnut Hill and Falmouth, Mass. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Joys of Banking
description: An elderly lady stepped up to a teller's window in the Chemical Bank branch at 86th and Columbus the other day. She unfolded scraps of paper, unearthed cards and finally asked for $200 in cash.

title: Brain-Dead Infant Is Taken off Life Support
description: A baby born with only a brain stem whose body was kept alive to preserve his organs for transplant was removed from life support machines today after no suitable recipient could be found, officials said.

title: A NATION WITHOUT HERETICS
description: A WORTHY TRADITION Freedom of Speech in America. By Harry Kalven Jr. Edited by Jamie Kalven. 698 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $35.

title: More Than the White House Is Up for Grabs
description: THOUGH voting in the Presidential primary contest is just beginning, the candidates' scramble has long been under way. But members of Congress also have long been engaged in the enterprise that will preoccupy most of them until Election Day - campaigning for re-election and the election of others in their own party. The fight for the Senate is of particular importance. In 1980, the Democrats lost control of that chamber for the first time in a quarter century; arguably, their recapture of it in 1986 marked the beginning of the end of the Reagan era. The fate of the new President's legislative program might well rest on which party wins the majority in 1988.

title: A Rationing of Resources To Handle Super Tuesday
description: With 20 states and American Samoa holding Democratic primaries or caucuses on March 8, and 17 states having Republican contests, it sounds as if there will be 38 separate elections.

title: KNOWING WHEN IT'S TIME TO GIVE UP AN UNSOCIABLE HABIT
description: I HAVE been a smoker, on and off, for almost 40 years and a nonsmoker, on and off, for one. So I feel qualified to make some general unscientific observations and some purely subjective remarks on the subject.

title: Fixing Up: The Home Show
description: Under the high glass ceiling of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a complete house is being assembled, landscaped and decorated in preparation for the Greater New York Apartment & Home Show. It opens next Saturday for a run until March 6 and it promises many informative seminars and displays on ownership, management, renovation and decoration of a home, be it a rental apartment, a pied-a-terre condominium, a family-size co-op or a suburban ranch.

title: Report Sees Hope for Battered Environment
description: The decline in the earth's environmental health can be reversed, but only with a substantial investment by the rich nations, according to the 1988 State of the World report published by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: WESLEYAN SYMPOSIUM CELEBRATES CAGE AT 75
description: UNLIKE the man they are honoring, the music faculty at Wesleyan University has tried to leave nothing to chance.

title: Court Rules Against Succession Rights in Apartments
description: In a decision that could affect hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, a state appeals court has ruled that rent-stabilized apartments cannot be passed on to a live-in relative after the tenant named on the lease dies or moves out.

title: Doorman Shot in Back As Woman Is Robbed
description: A 61-year-old doorman was shot in the back, and a woman was then robbed of jewelry valued at $15,000 in the elevator of an apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: Straying TV Preachers Jar Followers' Faith
description: The acknowledgment of moral lapses yesterday by the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart was only the latest in a series of scandals among television evangelists in recent years that have rocked their supporters, depressing donations and creating public distrust.

title: Peter J. Robotti, 87; Owner of Restaurant
description: Peter J. Robotti, longtime owner of Le Chateau Richelieu, a French and Continental restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan, died after a brief illness at his home on Thursday. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Advertising; Pacific Bell's Mini-Series Campaigns
description: THE story of Garland, Lawrence and Mary Ellen unfolded over 12 episodes. As boys during the 1920's, Garland and Lawrence became fast friends. During the 1930's, they helped each other through the Depression and vied for the affections of Mary Ellen. They went off to war, and when they returned, Lawrence's heart was broken when Mary Ellen chose to marry Garland - but the two men remained best friends.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Corporate Loan Demand Is Strong at Many Banks
description: Judging by corporate loan demand at banks across the nation, the nation's economy remains strong, if spotty, with many smaller businesses particularly robust.

title: Medical Care Sought by Arbitrager Held on Gun Charges
description: John A. Mulheren, the arbitrager arrested last Thursday on charges of illegal weapons possession, spent the weekend in a county jail in New Jersey and will seek to be hospitalized this week, according to people familiar with his case.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Charcuterie Tour Eiffel, which sells pates and delicatessen meats to supermarkets and specialty stores, to Image Concepts, Paramus, N.J.

title: SPAIN PLANS TALKS WITH SEPARATISTS
description: The Spanish Government has agreed to open formal peace talks with the radical Basque group that has waged a violent campaign for autonomy in northern Spain.

title: James Baldwin Tribute To Take Place at N.Y.U.
description: A two-day tribute to the author James Baldwin - comprising screenings, interviews and a jazz performance - is to be held on Feb. 29 and March 1 by New York University. The writer died in December. On Feb. 29, a daylong screening of films featuring appearances by Mr. Baldwin or adaptations of his works will begin at 9 A.M. at the Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place. A panel discussion with film makers who worked with the author is to begin at 3 P.M.

title: Lifting of Secrecy Reveals Earthy Side of Justices
description: The Supreme Court has long been shrouded in secrecy and inaccessibility, hindering public understanding of its role while perhaps enhancing its mystique.

title: Cabbie Found Fatally Shot
description: A cab driver who had been fatally shot in the neck was found slumped over the steering wheel of his car last night in Harlem, the police said. The driver, identified as Attillo Pena, 41 years old, was found at 8:55 P.M. at the corner of West 147th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, where his car had been pulled over to the curb, according to Sgt. Maurice Howard, a police spokesman. Sergeant Howard said the driver was found with his foot on the brake pedal and the engine of his car still running.

title: Brazil Investigating 'Loss' of $8 Million Sent From New York
description: Varig Airlines of Brazil, the Brink's security company, a local cargo concern and the federal police are still referring to the ''loss'' of two bags containing $8 million. They were being shipped from the Federal Reserve Bank in New York to Buenos Aires this month.

title: Several Leaders of Solidarity Held Over Weekend Are Free
description: The authorities today released several opposition leaders who had been detained over the weekend in an apparent effort to prevent them from attending a meeting of the outlawed trade union Solidarity.

title: Phoenix Journal; At Shelter, Homeless Monitored By Police
description: Every night, each homeless person who arrives at a shelter a few blocks south of downtown is asked to give his name and Social Security number. And every night, the list is turned over to the police, who try to match names on it with those on arrest warrants.

title: F.D.I.C. Finds Ways to Sell Ailing Assets
description: Federal regulators are employing novel ways to sell billions of dollars in troubled banking assets, including the sale of so-called dirty banks.

title: Teeing Off With Plastic Club Head
description: The golf purist who remains loyal to persimmon wood may cringe at what technology has wrought: a solid-plastic club head. There is no wood, metal or graphite in the mix. The head has the color and sheen of the inside of an oyster shell.

title: Swaggart Says He Has Sinned; Will Step Down
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, who last year condemned a fellow television evangelist, Jim Bakker, as ''a cancer on the body of Christ,'' today confessed to sins of his own and begged to be forgiven.

title: Motorists Protest Rates for Insurance
description: About 100 motorists drove to the state capital yesterday to protest high auto insurance rates and demand that lawmakers address the problem.

title: Pause and Protests in Bobsled
description: The final two heats of the two-man bobsled were postponed midway through today's racing because of deteriorating track conditions aggravated by wind-blown sand.

title: The Dance: Risa Jaroslow in 'Nahual'
description: RISA JAROSLOW is a performer of great though quiet eloquence. And that gift was evident in two pieces presented by Risa Jaroslow and Dancers on Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: Koch Ends Boycott Over Movie Tickets
description: Mayor Koch says he is ending his campaign to boycott Manhattan movie houses that charge a $7 admission. He said he was giving it up because of a lack of support from moviegoers.

title: A Much-Tangled Story: Getting Maigret on TV
description: Of all the detectives in crime fiction, Chief Inspector Jules Maigret of the Surete is perhaps the most doggedly persistent. Arthur Weingarten is a lot like that.

title: Teamsters Let Deadline Pass For a Strike Against Pan Am
description: Teamsters union members reported to work at Pan American World Airways yesterday despite the expiration of a strike deadline and a breakdown in contract talks. But a union representative threatened to strike the airline ''at whatever time will hurt them most.''

title: Experts Say Plants Used Spill as Cover To Dump Pollutants
description: One or more industries seem to have taken advantage of a fuel spill last month and dumped their own chemicals into the Ohio River, chemicals that are more dangerous pollutants than the fuel that spilled, water quality experts say.

title: Prosecutors Are Critical Of Plan for Rights Unit
description: Several district attorneys in New York State are expressing concern about Governor Cuomo's proposal to set up a civil-rights unit in the State Attorney General's office, fearing that the new unit might take over bias investigations they originate.

title: SHULTZ IS FOCUSING ON RIGHTS ISSUES IN MOSCOW TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz made human rights a major theme of his first day of talks in Moscow today, meeting with leading rights campaigners and devoting most of his morning discussions with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to the topic.

title: Sale of The Post Winding Down To Last Details
description: With the hard bargaining past and a rescue package for The New York Post in place, only a few details remained yesterday for the completion of Rupert Murdoch's $37.6 million sale of the newspaper to the real-estate developer Peter S. Kalikow.

title: Ruing Fixed Opinions
description: Justice Antonin Scalia says one thing has disappointed him since he joined the Supreme Court in 1986: the absence of give and take among the Court's members when they meet in conference to discuss and vote in cases they have heard.

title: William W. Eagles, Military Officer, 93
description: Maj. Gen. William W. Eagles, a decorated infantry commander who led the 45th Infantry Division in the battle for the Anzio beachhead in Italy, died Friday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. The retired officer, who lived in Washington, was 93 years old.

title: Volcker Urges Cut in Deficit
description: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve Board chairman, warned today of financial chaos and recession unless the United States reduced its dependence on foreign savings by reducing the Federal budget deficit.

title: Gore Lashes Out at Rivals and Image
description: Everywhere he traveled this weekend, from San Francisco to Los Angeles to Las Vegas to the nation's capital, Albert Gore Jr. was asked about Garry Trudeau.

title: Praise and Pity Heard in Bronx For Rep. Biaggi
description: The essence of Mario Biaggi, said Peter Fata, a Bronx resident, is not in the legal trouble that has brought him to the brink of expulsion by his colleagues in the House of Representatives.

title: Heavy Schedule of Financings This Week
description: A fairly heavy calendar of Treasury financings are scheduled for this week, including today's sale of three- month and six-month bills. On Wednesday, $8.75 billion in two-year notes will be auctioned, followed on Thursday with a regular monthly sale of five-year notes totaling $7.25 billion.

title: P.L.O. PULLS BACK ON ATTACK THREAT
description: Under pressure from its Arab backers, the Palestine Liberation Organization has withdrawn its threat to revive attacks on Israelis outside Israel and the occupied territories, according to Cairo-based diplomats and Palestinian officials.

title: Greek Cypriots Elect as President A Leftist Who Offers Unity Talks
description: A millionaire businessman who had the backing of the powerful Communist Party defeated a conservative opponent to become President of Cyprus in a runoff election held today.

title: Outdoors: Hunting in Winter
description: NOW that waterfowling has ended throughout the nation, including the bonus seasons for scaup and Canada geese in some portions of the Northeast, only a handful of hunters are abroad.

title: Sports World Specials; 4 Legs to 2
description: When Dave Johnson speaks, his voice has an instant effect on a stranger. It is clear and crisp, almost perfect. If it is a voice that sounds familiar to the ear, it's because most sports fans have heard Johnson's utterances before.

title: On Your Own: Tennis; How Important Is First-Serve Success Rate?
description: IF you watch tennis on television, the most common statistic you'll hear commentators mention during the course of a match is first-serve percentage: how many first serves a player connects on. In the recent Australian Open men's singles final, for example, the winner, Mats Wilander, successfully put into play 77 percent of his first serves, compared with just 61 percent for his opponent, Pat Cash.

title: Mine Sinks a French Trawler
description: A French fishing boat hit a mine in the English Channel today and sank when the mine exploded, but all four crew members were rescued, the coastal authorities said. An official at the search and rescue headquarters in Cherbourg said the trawler hit the mine early this morning about 30 miles north of the Normandy coast. The four crew members were rescued by another trawler. The official said that authorities were trying to determine what type of mine the ship hit, and how it got into the channel, but that they had very little information.

title: Bush's Home Is Where the Primary Is
description: George Bush, the cowboy, came out tonight in this flat, dusty town north of San Antonio.

title: One Way to Shore Up Filipino Democracy
description: Two years after the triumph of ''people power'' in the Philippines, the future of democracy in the ''Pearl of the Orient Sea'' still hangs in the balance.

title: Nicaragua Impasse: Who Will Bend?
description: Peace talks between anti-Sandinista guerrillas and the Nicaraguan Government have become deadlocked in what is essentially a debate over the legitimacy of the Sandinista revolution and those who oppose it.

title: Sports News Briefs; Player Suspended
description: John Johnson was suspended indefinitely from the University of Viginia basketball team Saturday after failing a drug test, the university announced.

title: College Basktball; Temple Smothers N. Carolina
description: Despite coming to the University of North Carolina campus as the topranked team in the nation, the Temple Owls knew they had something to prove. Critics had pointed to their schedule, which had included only two ranked opponents, as an unreliable indication of the Owls' strength.

title: Advertising; Sherwood & Schneider
description: Consumers Digest, a Chicago-based magazine that sizes up products ranging from automobiles to zoom lenses, has tapped Sherwood & Schneider to handle its consumer and trade advertising, after a three-way competition. The budget is somewhere in the $1 million to $1.2 million range. The former agency is Jameson Advertising. This will be the first new account to be handled at Sherwood & Schneider's new downtown Manhattan office, opening today at 350 Hudson Street. The agency is a subsidiary of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, a WCRS Group company.

title: Fitness; Exercising Safety With Home Videos
description: JANE FONDA is dressed in tights and she smiles. ''Set those shoulders on fire,'' she cries, waving her arms energetically. ''Make it burn.''

title: Power Level Reduced At Weapons Reactor
description: The Department of Energy has ordered a further reduction in the power level of its last remaining plutonium-producing reactor in an effort to assure that the reactor operated within the capacity of its emergency cooling system, a departmental official said tonight.

title: Haitian Puzzle: Where Will President Take Nation?
description: According to an axiom making the rounds in Haiti, for at least the next hundred years, each time a president takes office Haitians will be thrown into an anxious fit trying to divine if the new regime will be as tyrannical as the reign of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier, whose family controlled the country for three decades.

title: Bakker's Parents Lose Jobs
description: The parents of Jim Bakker, the former president of the PTL television ministry, have applied for unemployment benefits after being dismissed from their jobs as greeters at PTL's Heritage USA religious theme park. Raleigh Bakker and his wife, Furnia, both 81 years old, still live at the resort. PTL, which is involved in Federal bankruptcy proceedings, has cut 1,800 jobs since 1985, a spokeswoman said.

title: Unfinished Work on a Genocide Treaty
description: After 40 years, Congress is moving toward the final step on an international convention against genocide. The Senate gave its approval to the treaty in 1986, and it only remains for Congress to pass implementing legislation to amend the criminal code.

title: Brain-Dead Baby Allowed to Die; No Recipients Found for Organs
description: A brain-dead baby boy was taken off life-support machines Saturday after no recipients could be found for his organs, but another baby, also born without a brain stem, was on a respirator today in hopes of saving her organs for transplant.

title: William C. Hayes Jr., NASA Official, 63
description: William Claiborne (Red) Hayes Jr., the official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who greeted John Glenn after his history-making flight in 1962, died Saturday. He was 63.

title: 'Structures Of Sin'
description: By issuance of his 20,000-word, personally written encyclical, ''The Social Concerns of the Church,'' Pope John Paul II risks becoming known as the foremost political-moral relativist of our time.

title: Cuomo Rejects Call to Discuss Brawley Case
description: Governor Cuomo has turned down a request to meet today with two clergymen to discuss the case of a black Dutchess County teen-ager who says she was abducted and attacked by six white men, a spokesman for the Governor said yesterday.

title: DR. LEAH GRUSS IS WED TO DR. JOEL SPIELMAN
description: Dr. Leah P. Gruss, a radiology resident at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and Dr. Joel H. Spielman, an orthopedic surgery resident at the Montefiore Medical Center, were married yesterday. Rabbi Samuel Orenstein performed the ceremony at the New York Hilton.

title: Music: Bach Highlights Duo's Recital
description: BEAUTIFUL, fluid Bach playing, full of vitality and color, was the highlight of the violin and harpsichord recital given by Joseph Swensen and John Gibbons Friday night at Weill Recital Hall. The pairing had looked odd in prospect, as Mr. Swensen is a rising young violinist on the standard-repertory concerto circuit and Mr. Gibbons is an early-instrument specialist. Indeed it continued to seem odd as late as intermission Friday; the solo works on the first half did not immediately suggest how the violinist's muscular style, which seemed a little unrelenting in Bartok's unaccompanied sonata, would merge with the harpsichordist's rhythmically free, fanciful Baroque playing.

title: Sports World Specials; Shipboard Shots
description: For gym rats, extended periods of time away from basketball can be excruciating. John Hillin is a gym rat, and last year he was faced with 170 consecutive days without any contact with the game. Hillin refused to accept this fate.

title: Boycott Threat Blocking Sale Of Abortion-Inducing Drug
description: While a new abortion-inducing drug is expected to be sold in France, China, England and other countries, opponents of abortion are blocking sale of the drug in this country.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Earl Morse, Official In the Food Industry And Jewish Affairs
description: Earl Morse, a food industry executive, art collector and former chairman of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, died after a long illness Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: University Seeks King Tapes
description: Lawyers for Boston University have asked a judge to order Coretta Scott King to release tapes of conversations between her husband, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and others recorded secretly by Federal investigators.

title: Chief of Rail Agency Faults Congress on Safety Matters
