description: The Federal Railroad Administrator has criticized Congress for failing to improve rail safety in the year since 16 people died in an Amtrak crash in Maryland.

title: Post for Strauss
description: Robert S. Strauss has told his partners at Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld that he expects to be named chairman of the National Economic Commission. There is talk that Mr. Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman who was United States Trade Representative in the Carter Administration, will have a Republican co-chairman, but this has apparently not yet been decided.

title: Profit-Sharing Record at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that it would distribute $635 million to its United States employees in what it said was the largest profit-sharing payout ever made by an American company.

title: Boitano Kept to Goal in Final
description: With seconds to go in his freestyle program Saturday night, Brian Boitano let the world know exactly how he felt about his performance. His smile seemed to stretch from one side of the Saddledome to the other; his fists were clenched at his heart in triumphant joy.

title: Music: Juilliard Orchestra In Stravinsky Symphony
description: REPEATEDLY ambushed over the past 75 years, neither Romanticism nor the Romantic symphony orchestra have been that easy to kill off. Lowell Liebermann, for example, is only 27 years old, but he has already composed a big symphonic work interesting enough to be featured at the Juilliard Symphony's concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night. Mr. Liebermann's First Symphony speaks with a distinctive voice and uses the orchestra's traditional formats with confidence - facts even more striking when one notes that the piece was written six years ago.

title: 'Other Guy' in Hurricane Carter Case: Troubles Are Not Over
description: For 21 years, John Artis says, he has been the neglected ''other guy'' in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case.

title: Foe Who Also Lost Church Urges Prayers for Swaggart
description: A subdued congregation in a New Orleans suburb wept along with its pastor, Marvin Gorman, who cried aloud this morning after offering prayers and sympathy for his former colleague, and current adversary, the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart. ''My heart has been deeply saddened by the news of the past few days,'' said Mr. Gorman, a defrocked Assemblies of God minister who has been named in news reports as the person responsible for telling the church's officials that Mr. Swaggart, also of the Assemblies of God, had engaged in sexual misconduct.

title: U.S. and Soviet Plan Theater-Dance Studies
description: The American Council of Learned Societies and the Soviet Theater Union have established the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Commission on Theater and Dance Studies, a group that is to study theater and dance history, theory, criticism and practice.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 The topic of human rights prevailed during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's first day of talks in Moscow. He made human rights a theme of his discussions with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and met with leading rights campaigners. Page A1 China sought Soviet cooperation in 1958 for a plan to lure United States troops into central China and then attack them with Soviet nuclear weapons, the Soviet President, Andrei A. Gromyko, has written in his forthcoming memoirs. A1 A rent boycott persists in Soweto, despite the South African Government's nationwide state of emergency. Officials say unpaid rent and service charges in the black township exceed $100 million. A1 Two more Palestinians were killed during demonstrations held in the Israeli occupied territories to protest the forthcoming visit of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. A group of less radical Palestinians asked the Palestine Liberation Organization for permission to meet with Mr. Shultz. A3 The P.L.O. has withdrawn a threat to revive attacks on Israelis outside Israel and the occupied territories. The move was in acquiescence to pressure from the organization's Arab backers, diplomats and officials said. A3 News analysis: Deadlocked talks seeking peace between anti-Sandinista rebels and the Nicaraguan Government are stalemated over issues of legitimacy and are likely to drag on until one side is willing to make concessions. A9 Haitians are anxiously scrutinizing their new President, Leslie F. Manigat, for signs that will tell whether Haiti under his leadership will be a tyranny or a democracy. Many consider the election he won illegitimate. A5 News analysis: Brazil's moratorium on payment of its foreign debt was a mistake because it created economic uncertainty, the country's new Finance Minister says. Other Latin Americans appear sobered by Brazil's experience. D1 NATIONAL

title: Safety at Sea
description: Congress has spent hours debating airline safety, train safety, highway safey, but it has yet to tackle what have been called the most dangerous and unregulated crafts of them all: commercial fishing vessels.

title: Tocchet's 3 Goals Spark Flyers, 5-3
description: Rick Tocchet scored three goals for the first time in his National Hockey League career today to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Catching the Moment's Ups and Downs
description: THERE is a moment in victory, or defeat, when your face tells the story. Writers spend their cash advances wearing out typewriter ribbons to try to capture that instant.

title: Lakers Top Pistons After Trailing by 16
description: Mychal Thompson scored a 3-point play with 41 seconds left today and Wes Matthews added 5 points in the last 30 seconds as the Los Angeles Lakers came back from a 16-point deficit to defeat Detroit, 117-110.

title: Sports World Specials; Drag-Race Rent-a-Car
description: Last July, Richard Shaw watched the National Hot Rod Association Summernational drag races in Old Bridge, N.J., from the grandstands. Earlier this month, the 30-year-old fashion industry executive had a different perspective on the action at the Winternational event at Pomona, Calif. Shaw watched it from behind the canopy of an 800-horsepower gas dragster, as he became the first winner in a new race series that permits drivers to rent rides rather than entering their own cars.

title: Corrections
description: An article Sunday about a New York State appeals court decision that the right to a rent-stabilized apartment is not automatically passed on to a relative incorrectly identified the court and the territory covered by the ruling. The ruling was made by the First Department of the Appellate Term of the State Supreme Court,and while it is expected to establish a precedent for the entire city, it is binding only in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Bridgestone's New U.S. Challenge
description: If the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan can perform the kind of magic at the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's tire plants that it has performed at its own plant here, one thing appears certain: The American tire business will become even more competitive.

title: SYSTEM TO TREAT MENTAL PATIENTS IS OVERBURDENED
description: Overcrowding at municipal psychiatric wards in New York City has reached record levels, according to city doctors, who say they fear that the mental-health system is heading for a collapse.

title: After Kidnappings, U.N. Curtails Its Operations in Lebanon
description: Some United Nations operations in southern Lebanon have been curtailed sharply since the kidnapping of a United States Marine officer and other United Nations personnel this month.

title: Gena Cohen and R. J. Moses Are Married in Washington
description: The marriage of Gena Cohen, an associate at the Washington law firm of Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin & Kahn, and Robert Jeffrey Moses, an associate at the law firm of Epstein, Becker & Green in Washington, took place yesterday. Rabbi Avis Miller officiated at the Arts Club in Washington.

title: Brian Dennehy Masters a Classic Role
description: An enormous hulk of a man, Brian Dennehy is probably better known for such stereotypically macho movie roles as the sheriff who made the grave error of jailing Rambo in ''First Blood'' and television parts like Buffalo Bill Cody than for classics of the stage.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a major league pitcher ever been voted the Rookie of the Year Award, the Cy Young Award and the Most Valuable Player Award in his career?

title: Article 048888 -- No Title
description: Federal officials seized 165 pounds of heroin with a street value of $165 million dollars yesterday and arrested six men on charges of distribution of the drug, the authorities announced yesterday.

title: An Off-Duty Officer Is Shot While Intervening in Dispute
description: An off-duty police officer was shot in Brooklyn early yesterday when he intervened in a dispute, the police said. The officer suffered minor wounds when a passer-by, trying to help, shot him accidentally.

title: TV Review; 'Television With Edwin Newman
description: ''TELEVISION,'' the eight-part series that examines the medium and all its wondrous effects, looks tonight at television news. In 40 years, it has moved from simple illustrated lectures to global instant replay. Where will it go next? ''Point of View,'' the fifth part in the series, doesn't say, but it does express a cautionary note. The PBS documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: Woolridge, Gone a Day, Will Meet With Nets
description: Orlando Woolridge, the high-scoring Nets' forward whose whereabouts were unknown to the team for more than 24 hours, will meet with team officials today and might participate in the morning workout, the Nets said yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; One Year Later And Cuomo's No Still Means No
description: Fully a year has gone by since Mario Cuomo formally said no, and the Governor insists he has no regrets.

title: On Return, Post Employees Join in Ritual of Relief
description: It was quiet yesterday outside The New York Post building in lower Manhattan. Inside, about two dozen reporters and editors gathered in a ritual of relief.

title: Fewer Young Adults Using Cocaine: Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy On Brink In Panama
description: The festivities at the traditional pre-Lenten carnival here recently seemed more subdued than usual, and no one needed to ask why. ''There's not a cent for dancing in the streets or any other fun,'' one newspaper complained on its front page.

title: Courtenay Journal; Survival on France's Bleak but Abundant Earth
description: At first glance, it seemed that the long arm of the European Community had reached Remi Guinebault and Philippe Follet on their 300 acres amid the verdant flatlands between the Yonne and Loire rivers.

title: Baseball; A Familiar Position for Clark
description: For most of the morning, as it poured rain outside, Jack Clark lay quietly on his back in the trainers' room at Fort Lauderdale Stadium and read the Sunday newspaper. He wore a Yankee cap pushed back off his forehead, and he seemed genuinely oblivious to both the attention that was being paid to his right ankle and the small horde of reporters that waited patiently near his dressing stall in the crowded clubhouse.

title: Rock: Throwing Muses
description: THROWING MUSES have unlearned just about everything rock songwriters take for granted. The four-member band from Boston, which performed Thursday at Drums, rejects concise melodies, conventional chord sequences, naturalistic singing, narrative lyrics and just about anything else that might suggest symmetry or surface clarity.

title: Shortage of Nurses and Catch-22 on Foreigners
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins' Lemelin Stops Devils
description: The Devils created plenty of chances this afternoon and played with enough intensity, but they were denied by a hot goaltender and one of the better teams in the league.

title: West Germans End U.S. Medal Hopes in Hockey
description: In the end, all of its youth, enthusiasm and infatuation with goal scoring wasn't enough as the United States Olympic hockey team was convincingly knocked from medal contention by a sturdy contingent from West Germany.

title: Joyner-Kersee Is on Course For Even Greater Conquests
description: WHEN Jackie Joyner-Kersee was growing up in East St. Louis, Ill., she made the mistake one night of losing track of the time.

title: Churches, Politics and Money
description: Without the black church, the civil rights movement would have been impossible. So would the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign, which has its base there.

title: Coalition Seen In Belgium
description: A new coalition of French and Belgian shareholders in Societe Generale de Belgique is forming to thwart the raid of Carlo de Benedetti, according to analysts who follow the company.

title: Yesterday's Medal Winners
description: Alpine Skiing: Men's Super G Gold: Franck Piccard, France Silver: Helmut Mayer, Austria Bronze: Lars-Boerje Eriksson, Sweden Alpine Skiing: Women's Combined Gold: Anita Wachter, Austria Sivler: Brigitte Oertli, Switzerland Bronze: Maria Walliser, Switzerland Cross-Country: Women's 20-km Relay Gold: Gavriliuk, Reztsova, Nagueikina, Tikhonova (Soviet Union) Silver: Jahren, Wold, Dybendahl, Dahlmo (Norway) Bronze: Maatta, Matikainen, Savolainen, Kirvesniemi (Finland) Speed Skating: Men's 10,000 Meters Gold: Tomas Gustafson, Sweden Silver: Michael Hadschieff, Austria Bronze: Leo Visser, the Netherlands Totals: Soviet Union - 6 gold, 5 silver, 5 bronze; East Germany -6 gold, 3 silver, 1 bronze; Switzerland - 1 gold, 3 silver, 2 bronze; Finland - 2 gold, 2 bronze; Austria - 2 gold, 3 silver, 1 bronze; United States - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; the Netherlands - 2 silver, 2 bronze; West Germany - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Norway - 2 silver, 1 bronze; France - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Sweden - 2 gold, 1 bronze; Italy - 1 bronze.

title: The Big Picture
description: In the era of movie cassette rentals and closet-sized theaters, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has lavished Oscar nominations on the biggest, widest, tallest movies of the year. Epics like ''The Last Emperor,'' ''The Untouchables'' and ''Empire of the Sun'' are marvelous. But where does Hollywood expect these movies to be seen?

title: Market Place; Big Gold Loan's Effect on Prices
description: ONE of the oldest anti-gold arguments used by monetarists, those who would sever any link between bullion and paper money, is that gold is a ''sterile investment.'' Why? Because gold does not yield interest or dividends; its value is largely dependent on investor concerns about other assets.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOT MONEY. By Dick Francis. 324 pages.

title: Business and the Law; Unclaimed Assets In State Disputes
description: STATE treasurers are closely watching a recent lawsuit against the State of New York that could decide who can lay claim to abandoned property that rests in the hands of scores of businesses and banks.

title: Brief Period of Stability Seen for Interest Rates
description: Continuing a consolidation phase after the sharp declines registered in January, interest rates are likely to move in a relatively narrow range for the next week or so, credit market analysts said. But they added that a further drop in yields seemed quite probable before the quarter ends.

title: New Law Will Warn Californians Of Chemical Risks of Modern Life
description: Starting Saturday, life will change for the 24 million residents of California. Almost daily, they will receive pointed reminders about the chemical risks of the good life of the 20th century in the nation's largest state.

title: Japan Construction Talks
description: A senior United States official said Saturday that little progress had been made in negotiations to open the Japanese construction market to foreign companies. Japan allows only companies with construction experience here to bid on new projects, and the restriction has become a major trade issue between the nations. Officials had hoped to resolve the matter last week when a Washington delegation visited Tokyo to work out an agreement. ''We're dealing with a narrow foot bridge here,'' said the American official, who declined to say whether the talks had broken down. A Japanese delegation may visit Washington next week to continue discussions, the official said.

title: Maple Leaf Coin No. 1
description: Canada's Maple Leaf has regained its position as the world's most-purchased gold coin, overcoming the upstart United States Eagle in 1987. Official figures will be released next month, but a spokesman for the Royal Canadian Mint said Friday that 1987 sales ranged between 1.3 million and 1.5 million ounces. In 1986, 1.5 million ounces had been sold. Sales of the Eagle last year fell to 1.3 million ounces from 1.8 million in 1986, when it was introduced by the United States Mint as an alternative to South Africa's banned Krugerrand.

title: Princeton and the Met Joining on American Art
description: In a major art-world job switch, John Wilmerding, the deputy director of the National Gallery of Art and a leading figure in the study and exhibition of American art, has been appointed to a new, fully endowed professorship at Princeton University and will become a visiting curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the university announced yesterday.

title: A Touch of Havana Brings Life to Union City
description: It is early on a Saturday morning on Bergenline Avenue, the main commercial strip here, but moving about is already difficult. Amid throngs of shoppers, merchants are setting out goods, cars are double-parked and children are skipping down the sidewalk.

title: Sports of The Times; '88 Winter Olympics; The Russian Classic
description: IN the University of Calgary bookstore, the end of the line was over among the shelves with the Greek and Latin classics. Eventually the autograph seekers wound through the aisles to a Russian classic. No, not Tolstoy or Solzhenitsyn, not even a book in hard cover or paperback.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Cuts Back in Lebanon Some United Nations operations in Lebanon have been curtailed sharply since the kidnapping of a United States Marine officer and other United Nations personnel. Page A3. Palestinians Seek Talks As two more protesters were slain, a group of Palestinians sought permission from the Palestine Liberation Organization to meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Page A3. Demystifying the Court Nearly all the Supreme Court Justices have broken with the tradition of avoiding public statements about anything interesting. Washington Talk, page A16. Striving to Be Good Ol' Boys George Bush, a New Englander when in New Hampshire, goes cowboy in Texas, as Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee protests his portrayal as a prince from Harvard. Page A12. Cuomo Rejects a Plea Governor Cuomo declined to meet with two clergymen involved in the Tawana Brawley case. Page B1.

title: 2 More Palestinians Killed In Protest Over Shultz Visit
description: Two more Palestinian protesters were slain today in demonstrations called to protest the visit of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, while other Palestinians were seeking permission from the Palestine Liberation Organization to meet with Mr. Shultz during his stay here this week.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Portfolio Manager Finds Smaller Firm Appealing
description: LEAD: Alan J. Strassman, a portfolio manager, appears to like getting in on the ground floor of money managementfirms because he has done it so often. Now after 14 years as chief operating officer at one of the largest and most successful such firms in the country, Mr. Strassman has left to join a fledgling operation in Boston.

title: Blueprint for Trouble: A Child's Life in Welfare Hotels
description: Calvin Watkins cannot afford a lamp or even a flashlight, so as he rummaged through a plastic bag of family photographs the other day, the only light in his room in a Brooklyn welfare hotel came from the fast-fading sun. From the tattered bag he drew a picture of his son James. Mr. Watkins has 19 children, but it is James of whom he is proudest.

title: The Real U.S. Commitment on Afghan Pullout
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Reputed Mafia Figures Retried In Slaying of Detective in Queens
description: For the second time in a year, the execution-style slaying of a New York City police detective is being relived in a Queens court.

title: Blacks Pressing A Rent Boycott In South Africa
description: The one area of black resistance that the South African Government has been unable to break under its nationwide state of emergency is a 20-month-old rent boycott by blacks in Soweto, South Africa's largest black township.

title: F.B.I. Sought 'Terrorism' in the Wrong Place; When Death Is O.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance: 'Pawn Shop Blues'
description: THE Washington Square Repertory Dance Company accurately called its Friday night program ''Dances From the Home Front: Choreography With American Themes, Music and Images.'' Unfortunately, despite its strong subject matter, each item on this concert at the University Theater of New York University was deficient in some way.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
description: Companies

title: Big East Will Confer On Fighting Sanctions
description: In the wake of Saturday's game-ending, bench-clearing brawl between Georgetown and Pittsburgh, Dave Gavitt, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, has called a special meeting of the league's executive committee. The purpose of the meeting, which will be held today or tomorrow, is to formulate tough, uniform policies for controlling fights and punishing those players who participate in them.

title: Cycling; 2-Continent Race Coming to Florida
description: A multi-stage professional bicycle race spanning two continents rolls into its North American segment this week with six days of road-racing events crisscrossing Florida.

title: Baseball; Wilson Still Wants A Trade
description: Mookie Wilson, the ''other'' center fielder on the Mets and the man most likely to be traded by the Mets, conceded today that ''there are a lot of things worse in the world than sitting on the bench in New York.''

title: Piccard Steals Super-G Show From Zurbriggen and Tomba
description: This was supposed to be the Mount Rushmore of Alpine skiing, where Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and Alberto Tomba of Italy would etch their profiles in the Olympic snow. But since Zurbriggen won the downhill last Monday with a spectacular run down Mount Allan, he and others among the world's more renowned male and female skiers have found the slick, icy slopes to be unforgiving.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; A Real Estate Collector Seeks a Soapbox
description: Philip Pilevsky thinks big thoughts, about international peace and brotherhood, about disarmament and terrorism, but as a collector of shopping centers he doesn't have much opportunity to exercise them. ''You don't need a Ph.D. to make money in real estate,'' he said.

title: Video Cassettes Pushing Books Off Shelves
description: Barely a decade after the video cassette recorder began its relentless march into America's living rooms, a new type of home library - filled with dozens, or even hundreds, of videotapes - is rapidly emerging.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Babbitt's Little Problem

title: Music: A Retrospective Of Works of John Cage
description: FOR nearly a half century, John Cage has been picking away with his perceptive, gentle wit at the conventions of the serious music scene. It is a sign of how entrenched those conventions remain that Mr. Cage's music continues to surprise and humor listeners three and four decades after it was written, as was the case on Saturday evening in Alice Tully Hall, where Continuum presented a retrospective honoring the composer's 75th birthday.

title: Ruling Due on Bhopal Plea
description: A judge said Friday that he would rule March 7 on the Union Carbide Corporation's appeal of a court order that it pay $270 million in interim relief to victims of the Bhopal gas leak.

title: State Rates and Benefits Have Also Been Altered
description: Many taxpayers, including residents of New York State, will discover in this filing season that their state returns have undergone revisions almost as major as those on their Federal returns.

title: Notebook; Polish Hockey Star Is Banned
description: The International Olympic Committee announced today that Jaroslaw Morawiecki, Poland's best hockey player, has been banned from these Olympics after testing positive for steroids. It was the first penalty for drug use at the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: Islanders Complete Winning Weekend
description: Winning twice at the expense of the Hartford Whalers, a team with a season-long scoring problem, the Islanders picked up 4 points in the standing this weekend.

title: Publisher Takes Glossy Resume to Post
description: Peter O. Price, who has spent much of his life in such successful and lustrous enterprises as Princeton University, Time Inc. and Avenue magazine, will bear much of the burden of attempting to turn around The New York Post, widely acknowledged to be the grittiest and most vulnerable newspaper in New York City.

title: Southland to Sell Unit
description: The Southland Corporation has agreed to sell its Dairies Group to Morningstar Foods Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Morningstar, an affiliate of the Houston-based investment firm of Duncan, Cook & Company, will buy 10 regional dairies throughout the United States, along with 25 plants and distribution points. Morningstar expects to retain the Dairies Group employees, and the dairies will be operated under their recognized brand names. The sale stems from the December 1987 leveraged buyout of Southland, which owns the 7-Eleven chain of convenience stores, by the JT Acquisition Corporation, a unit of the Thompson Company, which is the investment firm of Southland's founding family.

title: Chairman Is Chosen At National Education
description: H. David Bright, who was instrumental in reviving the National Education Corporation, was named chairman of the nation's largest network of vocational schools last week.

title: Horse Racing; Jade Hunter Rallies To Win by a Nose
description: When Jade Hunter held off Cryptoclearance by a length in the Donn Handicap Jan. 30, the runner-up's backers began looking forward to the prospect of a rematch in the Gulfstream Park Handicap. The latter race would be a furlong farther, and Cryptoclearance would surely get up in time.

title: Bridge: The Negative Double Can Be Too Much of a Good Thing
description: The negative double, developed as part of the Roth-Stone system 40 years ago, was a major step forward in bidding theory and has been adopted by almost all serious players around the world.

title: Gromyko Says Mao Wanted Soviet A-Bomb Used on G.I.'s
description: The Soviet President, Andrei A. Gromyko, reports in his forthcoming memoirs that Mao Zedong sought Soviet cooperation in 1958 for a plan to lure United States troops into the interior of China, then attack them with Soviet nuclear weapons.

title: Sports News Briefs; Steelers' Webster Changes His Mind
description: Mike Webster, the center who surprised the Pittsburgh Steelers on Friday by announcing his retirement, surprised them again today by saying he would return next season.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 21, 1988: MONDAY Century Tel Ent FPL Group Inc Conn Natural Gas United Illuminating Crane Co TUESDAY Angelica Corp Kellwood Co Bausch & Lomb Longs Drug Stores Gap Inc Merck & Co Ipalco Enterprises Philip Morris Cos WEDNESDAY Amer Bank Conn NL Industries Belding Hemingway Pacific Scientific Cigna Corp Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt Deere & Co THURSDAY Arvin Industries Springs Industries Bank of Boston Unisys Corp Bowater Inc FRIDAY Aetna Life & Casualty Dexter Corp Bairnco Corp Harris Corp CTS Corp Nashua Corp Centex Corp Univar Corp

title: Allegheny Files Under Chapter 11
description: Allegheny International Inc., the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances and Northern electric blankets, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code during the weekend.

title: Better Cooperation Urged in Europe
description: With America's appetite for imports slowing and West Germany's reluctance to stimulate its economy growing, European policy makers are desperately seeking ways to break the continent's long cycle of torpid growth.

title: Ethiopian Rebels Seize Europeans
description: Six medical relief workers from Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands were abducted by a rebel group in the Ethiopian province of Tigre, officials here said today.

title: Save Vanderbilt Statue
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Sun-Diamond Goes to Y.&R.
description: Young & Rubicam, San Francisco, will no doubt be toasting its 10th anniversary this month with glasses of prune juice.

title: Dance: Balanchine Work From Los Angeles Ballet
description: First there was the Los Angeles Ballet, and now there is the Ballet of Los Angeles. John Clifford has begun anew. In 1973, Mr. Clifford - at that time, a dancer and choreographer with the New York City Ballet - returned to his native Los Angeles to found the Los Angeles Ballet, which he directed until 1985, when economic troubles closed it down. Undaunted, this season he organized the Ballet of Los Angeles, which performed Saturday night at the Count Basie Theater.

title: The Really Latest Returns
description: The CBS television affiliate in the Washington area mistakenly began its ''Face The Nation'' broadcast today with last week's preview of the New Hampshire primary.

title: The Texaco-Pennzoil Aftershocks
description: LEAD: The legal battle between Texaco and Pennzoil may be over but we are still living with the aftershocks and will for some time. Much has been made about the effect of the case on the ability of Texas to draw business - a valid concern. But of far greater concern is the damage the case may do to the United States' ability to compete in international markets.

title: Hospital, Criticized, Wins Accreditation
description: The Nassau County Medical Center, criticized by the State Health Department for the quality of its patient care, has received full, three-year accreditation.

title: Brazil's Reversal of Debt Strategy
description: When a slump in hard currency reserves forced Brazil to suspend most payments on its $113 billion foreign debt last February, the Government felt confident that the moratorium would serve as a weapon for extracting a dramatically better deal from its creditors.

title: USG Stock Speculation
description: Stock in the USG Corporation rose further Friday on speculation that Desert Partners L.P., which holds a 9.9 percent stake in the construction-materials company, had obtained financing for a buyout offer. USG shares gained $1.50 Friday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $32.875, adding to Thursday's gain of $2.375 a share. Analysts said rumors had circulated that Desert's partners, the Texas oilmen Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, have a financial backer. Desert and USG have declined to comment. In November, Desert Partners offered more than $50 a share for USG stock, but later said that it had failed to obtain financing for a buyout.

title: PAUL S. LURRIE IS WED TO WENDY ANN MILLER
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., Wendy Ann Miller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Miller of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul Scott Lurrie, a son of Eileen Lurrie of Glen Oaks, Queens, and the late Lawrence Lurrie. Rabbis Morris Friedman and Gilbert Klaperman and Cantor Marcus Ehrlich officiated.

title: Ballet: 'Snow Maiden' at Olympics
description: If there is one gold medalist in Calgary during the Winter Olympics who differs from all others, it is Vadim Pisarev of the Soviet Union. The 23-year-old Mr. Pisarev has won his unusually large collection of gold medals at international ballet competitions - in 1986 in Jackson, Miss.; in 1985 in Moscow; in 1984 in Helsinki and Paris. Americans saw his dazzling pyrotechnics last fall when he toured nationally with the Moscow Ballet.

title: Something About a Veto
description: There must be something about Californian governors to make them such fans of the line-item veto.

title: Official of Amtrak Disputes State on Cause of Train Fire
description: An Amtrak official disagreed today with state officials on the cause of a fire in a crew car on Amtrak's California Zephyr that killed one man, and he defended the crew's handling of the emergency.

title: Rangers Fall to Canucks
description: Pity Brian Leetch. His dream snuffed out in Calgary, he now gets to join a nightmare in full progress.

title: Results Plus
description: Track and Field Remigino Takes 800-Meter: Mike Remigino, a freshman at Manhattan College and son of a former Jasper, Lindy Remigino, the 1952 Olympic 100-meter gold medalist, captured the 800-meter run in 1 minute 54.04 seconds yesterday at the Reebok/Metropolitan Athletics Congress indoor championships at West Point, N.Y. Mike Flynn of the New York Athletic Club won the mile in 4:14.12. Michelle Williams of the Bronx International Express was the only double winner, crossing the finish line in 7.24 in the 55-meter dash and in 25.48 in the 200-meter sprint. Clive Wright of Bronx Community College took the men's 55-meter dash in a meet-record 6.23. Golf Pate Edges Haas With Birdie Putt: Steve Pate dropped a six-foot birdie putt on the final hole to break a tie with Jay Haas and win the Andy Williams Open at La Jolla, Calif. It was his second PGA Tour victory of the season. He won the Tournament of Champions last month. The 26-year-old Pate won this tournament with a final round of four-under-par 68 on the South course at Torrey Pines, for a total of 269. (AP) Tennis Navratilova Tops Savchenko: Martina Navratilova beat Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday to win the $250,000 Virginia Slims of California event in Oakland. The top-seeded Navratilova won all five of her matches during the tournament in straight sets and lost only 16 games.(AP) Agassi Defeats Pernfors: Andre Agassi hit powerful ground strokes to beat Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, 6-4, 6-4, 7-5, in the final of the $415,000 United States Indoor championship yesterday in Memphis. (AP) Horse Show Canadian Wins in Florida: Mario DesLauriers of Bromont, Quebec, won the year's first show-jumping grand prix, the $30,000 Chrysler United States Equestrian Team Grand Prix, yesterday at the Palm Beach Polo Club in West Palm Beach, Fla. Eleven horses of the 55-horse field completed the 16-jump, 624-yard course without penalty to qualify for a timed jumpoff. Greg Best of Flemington, N.J., rode third over the seven-jump jumpoff course, and took the lead by riding fault-free in 30.907 seconds on Santos. Best's lead held until DesLauriers turned in a clean ride on Box Car Willie in 29.689. Auto Racing Pontiac 400 to Bonnett: Neil Bonnett charged from two laps back, took the lead with 48 laps left and drove to a disputed victory over Ricky Rudd yesterday in the Pontiac 400 at the Richmond Fairgrounds Raceway. It was the last Nascar Winston Cup event of the season. Rudd complained that Bonnett was one lap behind at the end of the 400-lap race on the half-mile oval. Officials of Nascar met with Kenny Bernstein, Rudd's team owner, and explained the scoring that gave Bonnett the victory. (AP) P.S.A.L. Basketball Grady and Westinghouse Gain: Both games yesterday in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn championships were decided on game-ending shots at South Shore High School. Grady eliminated Midwood, 44-42, and Westinghouse defeated Canarsie, 54-53. With the score tied, 42-42, in the first game, Shaan Francis of Grady picked up a loose ball and dished it to Pat Alphonse, who slammed a dunk for a game-high 22 points. In the second game, Russell Nick converted on a 3-point play with one second left.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do not plan in any way to whitewash my sin. I do not call it a mistake, a mendacity. I call it a sin.'' The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, television evangelist [ A1:1. ]

title: Strange Money
description: The S.D.R. may rise again. The Special Drawing Right is a form of money, but not the kind that people use to buy a loaf of bread. Consumers have never seen one. It is money managed not by the United States Treasury but by the 151-government International Monetary Fund. Only governments use it, to pay their bills.

title: Dollar's Depreciation Isn't Devaluation
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreigners' Investing: A Warning
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, has privately warned an international conference of government ministers and business executives that the surge of foreign investment in the United States was creating a backlash here.

title: For San Antonio and Its Mayor, an Emergence Is Envisioned
description: From the air as he tours San Antonio in a helicopter, Henry G. Cisneros envisions a new city unfolding below him.

title: Why Girls' Schools Remain Necessary
description: LEAD: As Deerfield Academy, following Lawrenceville, departs from its traditional mission of single-sex education for boys, I, like others involved in girls' schools, am saddened that few voices were apparently raised to defend a mission I cannot help comparing to our own.

title: Underground Newspapers
description: New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority seems intent on making life harder for countless New Yorkers who wouldn't think of boarding a subway car without a newspaper or magazine in hand.

title: Corrections
description: The De Gustibus column in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified the owners of Le Bernardin in New York. The restaurateurs are Gilbert and Maguy Le Coze.

title: Brass Quintet in Premiere
description: The American Brass Quintet is to give the world premiere performance of ''Colchester Fantasy'' by Eric Ewazen and the New York premiere of Milton Babbitt's ''Fanfare,'' Thursday evening at 8 in the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street. The program includes Two Sonatas by Bertali, a 17-century Suite of Dances by Simpson and Brade, Contrapuncti III and VII from Bach's ''Art of the Fugue,'' ''Serenade for Brass'' by Starer and Venetian Songs by Bartolini, Guami and Gabrieli. Tickets, at $8 and $5, (free for students and the elderly) are available weekdays in the Juilliard Concert Office. Information: 874-7515.

title: Isabel Bishop, Painter, Dies at 85; Work Celebrated Women's Lives
description: Isabel Bishop, a painter and printmaker, died of Parkinson's disease Friday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 85 years old.

title: F.B.I. Sought 'Terrorism' in the Wrong Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Life, Industrialized
description: Item: The National Academy of Sciences last week advocated a $3 billion project to work out the full chemical data base of human genes.

title: Nasser Son Reportedly Plans To Return for Trial in Egypt
description: The self-exiled son of Gamal Abdel Nasser has reportedly said he will return to Cairo to face trial on terrorism charges.

title: Skin Is Found to Be Surprisingly Active
description: SCIENTISTS are finding that human skin, far from being just an elegant waterproof wrapper, is a surprisingly complex organ that produces or remodels hormones, enzymes and other substances that may have vital effects throughout the body.

title: Sports People; Montana Has Surgery
description: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback, underwent surgery in Redwood City, Calif., for an inflamation of the right elbow. Dr. Michael Dillingham, the team physician who performed the operation, described it as minor and said, ''The elbow looks real healthy.'' Montana is expected to be able to begin throwing again soon after a splint comes off, which will be in 8 to 10 days. The elbow bothered Montana last season, but he threw for a club-record 31 touchdown passes and led the National Football League in passing.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SAY PROGRESS IS MADE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: The Soviet Union and the United States announced today that progress had been made in two days of negotiations on a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons.

title: The Stage: 'Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding'
description: AS well-wishers stood on the sidewalk outside the Washington Square Church, throwing rice at Tony and Tina Nunzio, an elderly passer-by inquired what was going on. Told that it was a show about a wedding, she stared in disbelief and said flatly, ''No, it couldn't be.'' Noticing that the bride and groom were smoking while posing for pictures, another observer said, ''It must be a cigarette commercial.'' Neighbors across the street must have been wondering why this same couple was marrying every Saturday and Sunday afternoon for the last three weeks. Beginning this week, they will also marry on Thursday and Friday evenings.

title: College Basketball; Hawkins Scores 63 In Bradley Victory
description: Hersey Hawkins scored a career-high 63 points tonight to lead Bradley to a 122-107 victory over the University of Detroit.

title: Pearson Chairman Returns To U.S. to Oversee Purchase
description: Lord Blakenham, the chairman of Pearson P.L.C., has returned to the region of his college days to oversee the purchase of the American textbook publisher Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, based in Reading, Mass.

title: John B. Buckley, 64, Lawyer and Executive
description: John B. Buckley, a lawyer and an executive in the pharmaceutical industry who served as a special assistant to the United States Attorney General in the 1950's, died of cancer Thursday at St. Joseph Medical Center in South Bend, Ind. He was 64 years old.

title: U.S. Plans Big Cut in Funds to U.N. Food Agency
description: The Reagan Administration plans a 50 percent cut in its contribution to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization as part of an economy drive aimed at international organizations that are deemed not to serve American interests, according to United States diplomats and United Nations officials.

title: PHM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter was primarily due to a foreclosure loss provision of $33,387,000. In December 1987, PHM Corp. became the public held parent company of Pulte Home Corp.

title: Lieberman Begins Bid To Win Weicker's Seat
description: Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, stressing family and consumer issues and such statewide concerns as high housing costs, today formally announced his campaign to unseat Republican Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. ''Connecticut needs a Senator who will put Connecticut first,'' Mr. Lieberman said, standing in freezing temperatures on the steps of the Connecticut Supreme Court Building, surrounded by about 120 supporters.

title: Outlook: Dueling PC's
description: The stage is set this year for a tumultuous showdown between I.B.M.'s year-old PS/ 2 series of microcomputers and the ''industry standard'' PC's that I.B.M. spawned and then abandoned. No matter who wins, the average PC user can expect a shower of rewards, although they will probably precipitate from a cloud of confusion.

title: UNIVATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter net equals less than 1 cent a share.

title: BMC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $1,502,000 from the sale of equipment. c-Net loss and after a loss of $5 million from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. The company said it restated its 1986 provision for income taxes, resulted in a retroactive reduction of $1,304,000 for the fourth-quarter and full-year 1986 provision for income taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY The I.R.S. is giving incorrect information to people who call for help with their returns at least 25 percent of the time, the agency concedes. The G.A.O. says the bad information is offered in response to 39 percent of the questions. The telephone assistance program is more important than ever because most provisions of the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 take effect this year. The I.R.S. expects to field 26 million telephone queries, an increase of 16 percent from last year. [ Page A1. ] The top international trade official resigned at the Commerce Department. S. Bruce Smart Jr. decided to leave his post when Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said he would not promote Mr. Smart to Deputy Secretary, the No. 2 position. [ D1. ] The Supreme Court will judge the validity of a 5 percent tax that Illinois imposes on all telephone calls charged to in-state numbers. The Court said it would study arguments that the tax interfered impermissibly with interstate commerce. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stock prices moved up smartly, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 25.70 points, to close at 2,040.29. The Dow is now at its second-highest point since October's stock market plunge. On Jan. 7, the Dow closed at 2,051.89. Technology stocks led yesterday's rally, which picked up steam late in the session. [ D1. ] The N.Y.S.E. applied sanctions to two specialist firms, La Branche and Lawrence, O'Donnell. The exchange was critical of the firms' performance on Oct. 20, the day after the market's collapse. Lawrence, O'Donnell has voluntarily agreed to withdraw as specialist in Neiman-Marcus; La Branche agreed to stop making markets in the stocks of E. F. Hutton and A. G. Edwards. [ D1. ] Bond prices rose slightly in very slow trading. Market participants were unwilling to take new positions in advance of a spate of economic reports scheduled to be released this week. [ D19. ] The dollar drifted lower against most other currencies in listless trading that analysts said reflected uncertainty about the outlook for the U.S. economy and for interest rates. Gold was down 75 cents in New York, to $444.25 an ounce. [ D22. ] Prices of cotton futures collapsed in a selloff linked to the impending expiration of the March contract. The plunge in March contracts touched off computerized selling programs that drove other contract prices down. [ D22. ] COMPANIES Franklin Savings will buy L. F. Rothschild, the financially troubled 89-year-old Wall Street investment house. The deal would involve close to $100 million. Although the terms could change, Franklin expects to exchange a package of cash and securities that it values at $4.40 for each Rothschild share. Franklin will also lend $30 million to Rothschild. [ D1. ] Shares of Manufacturers Hanover rose strongly, partly as a result of rumors that West Germany's Deutsche Bank was planning to acquire the giant New York bank holding company. Deutsche Bank denied the rumors. The stock was also buoyed by signs that negotiations between Brazil and Argentina and their creditor banks were going well. Manufacturers Hanover is a big lender to both Brazil and Argentina. [ D2. ] I.B.M. will overhaul its PS/2 line, getting a step up on the ad- vancing clone makers. Some industry experts think a price war may be in the offing. Others say I.B.M. will hold the line on prices but provide more technology. [ D2. ] The Comptroller of the Currency tried to ease concerns about the financial stability of First Republicbank, the largest banking institution in Texas. [ D9. ] Foodmaker will pay $230 million for Chi-Chi's, topping two competing bids for the chain of family-style Mexican restaurants. The offer amounts to $10.50 a share. [ D5. ] Seven-Up will introduce two soft drinks - 7-Up Gold and Diet 7-Up Gold, with an amber color and a spice flavor. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Honeywell is pushing for data on doctors' performance, in order to evaluate the physicians better. Insurers are not happy. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Pollution control stocks are expected to benefit from further earnings gains. Investing in them involves risk because of environmental uncertainties, but they have done well. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Computer's Sale Studied
description: The Reagan Administration confirmed today that it was investigating accusations that a United States computer system that could help determine optimal targets for nuclear missiles had been illegally shipped to the Soviet Union.

title: Savings Group to Get L.F. Rothschild
description: In its third venture into investment banking in the last 15 months, the Franklin Savings Corporation, of Ottawa, Kan., agreed yesterday to buy L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., the financially troubled 89-year-old investment house.

title: Henley Request To Santa Fe
description: In another move to increase its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, the Henley Group asked Santa Fe to revise its plan to issue about $780 million in pay-in-kind debentures in favor of issuing buy $780 million of new Santa Fe common stock, which Henley would acquire at $17.50 a share. Henley's chairman, Micheal

title: Surge of Violence in Capital Linked by Police to Narcotics
description: The illicit drug scene in the nation's capital has become one of the most violent in the country, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can only conclude that the decision to reduce the elvel of our fleet to a point that it may never reach the 600-ship goal was motivated by other than military and strategic reasoning.'' - James H. Webb Jr., Navy Secretary [ A1:3. ]

title: TIE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax writedown and restructuring charges totaling $37,097,000 and $37,997,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also includes a tax credit of $472,000. c-Includes tax credits of $312,000 and $1,179,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes income from discontinued operations of $1,543,000. The company said the losses for the latest quarter were attributable to reduced sales volume and increased operating expenses associated with the acquisition of Honeywell Communications Services business and the retirement of Canadian patents and technology originally purchased from Plessey four years ago. The company also said reserves were taken in the fourth quarter to cover anticipated losses that will be incurred during the first quarter of 1988 in connection with the sale of the Chatlos-Technicom Systems subsidiary, slated for late February.

title: Hanover Stock Rises; Takeover Rumors Denied
description: Shares of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation rose strongly yesterday, partly as a result of rumors that West Germany's Deutsche Bank was planning to acquire the giant New York bank holding company.

title: INSIDE
description: Hostage Videotape Issued The kidnappers of a marine in Lebanon released a videotape in which he appealed to Washington to meet his abductors' demands. Page A3. Setback for Evangelicals The High Court won't hear an appeal from parents who say their children should not have to read schoolbooks offensive to their beliefs. Page D29.

title: Democrats Stress Campaign Financing
description: Setting the stage for a partisan battle over campaign financing, Governor Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller held a news conference today to back legislation for public financing of political campaigns and to press the Republican-controlled State Senate to agree.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations $2,101,173 and $3,008,135 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a gain of $1,835,310 from the termination of a pension plan for both the quarter and year.

title: Chambers Trial Is Told of Loss Of Blood Clues
description: A blood-spotted skirt and blouse found on Jennifer Levin's body were so badly mishandled by pathologists that the bloodstains could not be analyzed for evidence, a forensic expert testified yesterday.

title: 1985 Pipeline Memo to Meese Said Peres Party Would Profit
description: A memo written to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in 1985 said ''a portion'' of the proceeds from a projected Arab oil pipeline would ''go directly'' to the Israeli Labor Party. A copy of the document was made public today by Mr. Meese's lawyers.

title: Angie Debo, Oklahoma Historian, 98
description: Angie Debo, who came to Oklahoma in a covered wagon and wrote 13 books and hundreds of articles about Indian and Oklahoma history, died Sunday at a hospital in Enid. She was 98 years old and lived in Marshall, a small town in central Oklahoma.

title: PRIVATE BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share net in the latest first quarter is after $82,850 in preferred dividend requirements; there were no preferred dividend requirements a year ago.

title: The Minimum-Wage Illusion
description: It's small wonder that politicians like the idea of raising the minimum wage: improving the lot of the lowest-paid workers seems virtuous, at no apparent cost to the public. But the rationale is half-true at best, and the free price tag is false.

title: Galanos: Perfection, and Lots of It
description: Since 1951, James Galanos has been designing beautiful, expensive clothes in California. It's a one-man job: he picks the fabrics and sells the clothes as well as designing them. This is as close to couture as ready-to-wear can get, and the clothes seem to be getting better and better.

title: Dole Endorsed by Thurmond
description: Senator Strom Thurmond, the grand old man of the Republican Party in South Carolina, endorsed Senator Bob Dole for President today but acknowledged that Mr. Dole was running third as his state's March 5 primary approaches.

title: KYSOR INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Sept. 14. The year-ago periods' earnings included a net gain of $3,560,000, or 53 cents a share, from the favorable settlement of patent litigation.

title: Missing Speaker
description: A long-planned series at the Smithsonian Institution on life in South Africa has had to be modified after at least one of the speakers was denied a travel permit by the South African Government.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Vancouver Canucks, apparently unable to arrange a trade for their disgruntled goaltender, Richard Brodeur, assigned him yesterday to their Fredericton, New Brunswick, farm team of the American Hockey League. . . , Andre Dawson, the National League's Most Valuable Player of 1987, was honored yesterday by Florida A&M University in Tallahassee, where he starred for three seasons in the early 1970's. The Cub outfielder turned pro before graduation, but encouraged athletes to stay in col-lege in his remarks at the ceremony.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: KNOWLEDGE DATA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the cumulative effect of a change in accounting of $633,000. c-Net loss The company said that in the latest fourth quarter it changed its income tax accounting method with effect from Jan. 1, 1987, to reflect adoption of SFAS 96. The effect of the change was insignificant to the fourth quarter and increased earnings before cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes by about $141,000, or 2 cents a share, for the latest year.

title: Quest for Fastest Computer Chip: International Contest Intensifies
description: THE race for dominance in making semiconductors, the tiny chips that carry electronic circuits, is entering a new phase as scientists convinced they have almost exhausted the present technology strive to use X-rays to make chips that are faster and more powerful.

title: Simon and Kemp Pin Hopes On Caucuses in Minnesota
description: Stragglers in both parties are trying to use the Minnesota Presidential caucuses Tuesday night to bolster their floundering campaigns and attract a new infusion of energy and money heading into the major southern primaries two weeks from now.

title: Isolated Aged Parents Need More Than Pity; Respect as a Person
description: To the Editor:

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'I Could Not Give Her Health, but I Could Give Her Rest'
description: Following is the essay in the Jan. 8 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association that has become the subject of a dispute with prosecutors in Chicago: It's Over, Debbie

title: Author Cites $100,000 Fee for Kennedy Article
description: Judith Campbell Exner, who told People magazine she arranged more than 10 meetings between John F. Kennedy and Sam Giancana, the Chicago mob boss, in the early 1960's, was paid about $50,000 for the interviews, the author of the magazine article said today.

title: R. W. Miller, 93, Dies; Was U.N. Consultant
description: Raymond W. Miller, a consultant to the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations and a lecturer and writer on public relations, died of Parkinson's disease Friday at the Althea Woodland Nursing Home in Silver Spring, Md., where he lived. He was 93 years old.

title: Campeau Extends Bid for Federated
description: After failing to obtain acceptance by Federated Department Stores Inc. of its takeover offer of $66 a share, the Campeau Corporation extended the bid, which was to have expired at midnight Sunday, until Friday. As before, the proposal was conditioned on obtaining a definitive merger agreement from Federated for all shares. Campeau said that without Federated's approval, the price would be $61 a share. Federated's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $60.75, in heavy trading, and the company's board was said to be planning this week to review all proposals to acquire either individual assets or the entire company.

title: Inquiries Rise on Drug Use by Correction Officers
description: About 200 uniformed correction officers were seated for roll call yesterday afternoon at the Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island. Martin Levy, the warden, was making routine announcements.

title: Shamir Threatens to Break Up Coalition in Israel
description: Vowing not to give up occupied territory, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today threatened to force early elections unless the Government agrees on a stand before Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrives this week with new American peace proposals.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Refuse to Hear Tennessee Case on Bible and Textbooks
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear the last appeal of seven evangelical Christian families who say Tennessee public schools violated their children's religious freedom by requiring them to read textbooks that contradict their beliefs.

title: CARLISLE COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
City Ballet: Benefit for Dancers' Fund
description: The Fourth Annual Dancers'

title: LEECO DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 20
description: b-Net loss

title: The Reading Scores For New York City Schools
description: Following are the scores released by the New York City Board of Education on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in May 1987.

title: LIFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $107,000 and $375,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from litigation costs. c-Includes a charge from litigation costs of $275,000 for both the quarter and year. All share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in September 1986; in March 1987, the company issued 600,000 shares to Echlin Inc.

title: Texts of Documents Involving Meese, Peres and a Proposed Iraqi Pipeline
description: Following are the texts of documents made public today by lawyers for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d on a proposed Iraqi pipeline project. The first letter is from Shimon Peres, then the Israeli Prime Minister, to Mr. Meese on Sept. 19, 1985; the second letter is from Mr. Meese to Mr. Peres on Oct. 7, 1985. The memorandums are from E. Robert Wallach, a lawyer involved in the project, to Mr. Meese on Sept. 25, 1985. Misspellings appear as they do in the original documents. Letter From Peres To Meese

title: CATALYST THERMAL ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $97,000 for both the quarter and year. The company attributed the increased earnings primarily to the addition of the Philadelphia and Boston District Heating and Cooling Systems, acquired Jan. 30, 1987 and Feb. 6, 1987, respectively.

title: Justices to Decide Constitutionality of Special Prosecutor Law
description: The Supreme Court said today it would decide whether the Constitution bars the appointment of special prosecutors not under the control of the President to investigate possible crimes by high Government officials.

title: CARMIKE CINEMAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and year are after a charge of $325,000 from the settlement of litigation.

title: Doubleday Plans an Imprint in Britain
description: Doubleday announced yesterday that it will establish an imprint in Britain next year. It also announced that Nan A. Talese, editor in chief of Houghton Mifflin's adult-trade division, will become publisher and editorial director of her own line of books for Doubleday's flagship publishing company in New York.

title: Bryant's Best Game Carries Seton Hall
description: It's been a long time since a local basketball crowd at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena was filled with this sort of jubilation.

title: TV Review; 'Battles in War on Cancer,' on 'Nova'
description: ''NOVA'' is worthwhile tonight. Indeed, it's superb.

title: CLC OF AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $716,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss Year-ago fourth-quarter share net is restated to reflect the recapitalization resulting from the company's bankruptcy reorganization.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $812,000 and $1,324,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Share earnings are restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split, distributed during fiscal 1987.

title: 2 Specialists Lose Role on Some Stocks
description: As part of a continuing series of sanctions following the stock market collapse in October, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that two specialist firms - La Branche & Company and Lawrence, O'Donnell & Company - had been asked to stop making markets in several stocks.

title: Business and Health; Honeywell's Push To Track Doctors
description: FOR some doctors, the name Honeywell may soon seem about as appealing as malpractice suits and hypochondriacs. The Minneapolis company is one of a small number of American employers that have decided to become pushy in dealing with the medical community that cares for their employees. If these companies are successful, a lot of employers might decide they have been passive too long and use them as models.

title: Scientists Admit AIDS Identification Error
description: HARVARD AIDS researchers have acknowledged a laboratory error, clearing up confusion about AIDS-related viruses that infect humans and monkeys in Africa. As some other scientists previously suggested, cells studied in the Harvard laboratory became contaminated with a monkey virus that was mistakenly identified as a human virus.

title: NAVY CHIEF QUITS, ASSAILING CARLUCCI OVER BUDGET CUTS
description: Navy Secretary James H. Webb Jr. resigned today, sharply criticizing Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci's plan to cut the Navy's fleet and his approach to managing the Pentagon.

title: Castro Rebuts Robertson
description: Fidel Castro, in an interview published today in USA Today, denied Pat Robertson's charge that the Soviet Union had nuclear missiles in Cuba. President Castro said there ''is not even a semblance of a Soviet missile in Cuba - not one. I repeat, not one.'' Mr. Robertson, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said recently that 25 intermediate-range Soviet SS-4 and SS-5 missiles, armed with nuclear warheads, were in Cuba. The White House later said it had ''no indication'' of any nuclear weapons there.

title: No Changes for Time Being, U.P.I.'s New Managers Say
description: The new managers of United Press International plan no hirings, firings or changes in service for at least two months while they study the company's future, the news agency's new president said today.

title: HANCOCK FABRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago figures are pro forma because of a recapitalization of the company immediately prior to the spinoff May 4, 1987, of the company shares to shareholders of Lucky Stores Inc.

title: DAKOTA STRATEGY PROVES A SUCCESS
description: When the South Dakota Legislature shifted the state's Presidential primary to February from June, political leaders hoped to make the state an important - and more widely noticed - arena for Republican and Democratic contenders.

title: Report Faults Biaggi for 'Criminal Conduct'
description: In a report released today, the House Ethics Committee said Mario Biaggi was guilty of ''criminal conduct of a most serious nature going to the heart of his representation responsibilities.''

title: 3 in the Loud Family To Be in TV Seminar
description: Members of the Loud family, subjects of an acclaimed 1973 public television series, ''The American Family,'' are to appear today at a Museum of Broadcasting seminar to celebrate Channel 13's 25th anniversary. Craig Gilbert, who produced the series, is also to participate.

title: ANALOG DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Kidnapped Colonel Seen on Videotape
description: The kidnappers of a United States Marine officer released a videotape today in which he appealed to Washington to meet his abductors' demands.

title: Trial of Larry Davis Goes to the Jury
description: A Bronx jury is to begin deliberations today in the trial of Larry Davis, who is charged with murdering four suspected drug dealers in the South Bronx 16 months ago.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of oil and gas rigs engaged in exploration in the United States rose by 10 last week, to a total of 978, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. A year ago the count was 839. The rig count is the most widely watched industry index of drilling activity.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $3,412,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principles. c-Net loss

title: College Hockey Notebook; Concentration Falters; Harvard Loses 2
description: Because the college hockey season lasts from October to March, some coaches say it is just about impossible to keep a team sharp for every game.

title: Church Orders 2-Year Rehabilitation for Swaggart; NATURE OF INCIDENT UNCLEAR
description: The 52-year-old Mr. Swaggart has often faced criticism for the opulence of his life style and the flamboyance of his ministry, but until now has not been subjected to serious scrutiny about his sexual behavior.

title: CANDIDATES URGED TO STIFLE CRITICISM
description: Concerned about the safety of a kidnapped United States marine in Lebanon, the White House admonished political candidates today not to make hostage-taking an issue in the Presidential campaign.

title: Ethics Panel Won't Ask Felon to Be a Witness
description: When the New York State Commission on Government Integrity holds hearings next week on the influence of politics on the judiciary, it will not call an expert on the subject.

title: Winners in First Presidential Tests Gain National Support, Poll Finds
description: After major campaign tests in Iowa and New Hampshire, a majority of the public is now paying attention to the Presidential race and throwing more support to three of the early winners, Michael S. Dukakis, Richard A. Gephardt and Bob Dole, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: CASTLE, A M & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Spain's Communist Party Elects New Leader
description: The Spanish Communist Party elected Julio Anguita as its Secretary General today amid hopes the southern politician can restore the party's influence and reverse a decline in membership.

title: Hyundai to Fight Canadian Ruling
description: The Hyundai Corporation said it would continue to sell its cars in Canada despite a Canadian ruling that the auto maker was dumping its product by selling it at a lower price than it charged in South Korea. Hyundai officials also said the auto maker will finish an assembly plant, now under construction in Bremont, Quebec, by early next year as scheduled.

title: V BAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OLD DOMINION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Essay on Mercy Killing Reflects Conflict On Ethics for Physicians and Journalists
description: An anonymous essay in The Journal of the American Medical Association, describing the killing of a cancer patient by a resident physician, has astonished doctors and touched off a struggle between local prosecutors and the American Medical Association, which has vowed to protect the author's identity.

title: Larry Shay, Composer And Music Coach, 90
description: Larry Shay, a composer and music coach for such greats as Al Jolson, Jimmy Durante and Sophie Tucker, died of lung cancer and emphysema on Monday. He was 90 years old.

title: O'Rourke Lists Rebuilding Plan In Yearly Speech
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke stressed the ''rebuilding and renewing'' of Westchester in his sixth State of the County address today. But he also touched, for the first time, on allegations of mismanagement in his administration.

title: Witness Says Supremacists Sought to Avenge Death
description: The chief prosecution witness against 14 white supremacists testified here today that the death of a tax protester, killed in a gunfight with law-enforcement officers, led to a plot to kill a Federal judge and a Federal agent.

title: Dance: Felicia Norton
description: SOMETIMES at a dance concert, the program as a whole seems greater than the sum of its parts. But at the concert of music and dance on Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, each separate part somehow seemed stronger than the program as a whole. This was because a strained and unnecessary attempt was made to have the parts add up.

title: Woolridge Offers His Account Of Absence
description: Orlando Woolridge was at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today to explain why his whereabouts were unknown to the Nets for more than 24 hours Friday and Saturday. He told the club that he was injured in an accident on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANAGERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $356,661 and $24,063 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $19,745 and $586,330 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the 1987 provision for federal income taxes included the fresh-start adjustment of the new tax law. The fresh-start loss reserve discount favorably affected the 1987 full-year operating income by $547,000, or 14 cents a share. For the latest fourth quarter, the fresh-start effect was $205,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ACA Joe Inc., San Francisco, said it had received default notices on $9 million of bank loans and $9.5 million of term notes, including accrued interest.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Munir Bashir of Iraq Plays Oud Recital
description: Perhaps not since Paderewski has a musician parlayed his art into political power in the way Munir Bashir has managed to do. The Polish pianist became Prime Minister of his country after World War I. Several generations later, Mr. Bashir - who is a virtuoso on the oud - enjoys enormous authority over the cultural affairs of Iraq. Among his exalted other posts, he is director of the department of musical affairs of the Iraqi Ministry of Culture.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings results reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effected in July 1987.

title: Prague Journalists Try for Independent Voice
description: Citing precedents in the Soviet Union, a group of Czechoslovak journalists is negotiating with the Government in an effort to register an independent newspaper.

ZENITH ELECTRONICS CORPORATION OF INDIANA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Actions of Brawley Lawyers Raise Troubling Questions
description: The legal stalemate over the case of Tawana Brawley, a black Dutchess County teen-ager who says she was abducted and sexually assaulted by six white men, has raised troubling questions about the conduct - and ultimate objectives - of the girl's lawyers, Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason.

title: Ban on 'Nonlethal' Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Struggling Rangers Still in It
description: Michel Bergeron spent yesterday morning watching films of his team's 6-4 loss Sunday night to the Vancouver Canucks. Remarkably, the coach of the Rangers emerged from the screening feeling only mild chagrin.

title: Church Orders 2-Year Rehabilitation for Swaggart
description: The television evangelist Jimmy Swaggart, who has been the subject of reports of sexual misconduct, was ordered tonight by the hierarchy of the Assemblies of God Church in Louisiana to immediately begin a two-year rehabilitation period that will limit his preaching and place him in counseling, an official said.

title: G-R-I CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-ago fourth quarter net included credits of $227,000 for discontinued operations and $250,000 for a tax loss carryforward. The fiscal 1986 net included a tax credit of $250,000 and a loss of $273,000 from discontinued operations.

description: IS a Meyerbeer revival possible? The composer who dominated

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1988
description: International A3-15

title: Market Place; Earnings Strong In Waste Control
description: RISING profits for pollution control stocks have made them consistent winners on Wall Street. Standard & Poor's index for this group showed price gains of 67 percent in 1985, 52 percent in 1986 and 28 percent in 1987, compared with gains of 26 percent, 14 percent and 2 percent in the S.&P. 500-stock index.

title: Heidegger Had Ritual Of Giving Nazi Salute
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Examines First Republicbank
description: The Comptroller of the Currency tried today to ease concerns about the financial stability of the First Republicbank Corporation, the largest banking institution in Texas.

title: Gwyda DonHowe Service
description: A memorial service will be held for Gwyda DonHowe, an actress, on Friday at 4 P.M. at the Edison Theater, 240 West 47th Street. Miss DonHowe died on Jan. 15.

title: Music: A Foss Concerto
description: THERE'S a dreamlike quality to the Renaissance Concerto for Flute and Orchestra by Lukas Foss. A wispy, intangible spirit floats through the work's four movements, each of which presents music of the Renaissance filtered through the composer's modernist sensibility.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Takes Holiday Off Ice
description: On Sunday night, they were knocked from medal contention in an unflattering loss to West Germany. Today they took a break from hockey and toured the Olympic pagaent. And on Tuesday they will begin preparing for a match against Switzerland to decide seventh place in the tournament.

title: KEY RATES
Aftermath of a Bronx Fire: Desperate Quest for Housing
description: For most of the 45 families who were burned out of their apartments on Beech Terrace in the South Bronx last month, the grief of losing their homes is compounded by the realities of searching for new ones.

title: Human Rights Promise, and Promises
description: The new winds keep blowing in the Soviet Union, now in the direction of human rights. Secretary of State Shultz this week got the Kremlin's word that a big barrier to emigration will soon come down. And Mikhail Gorbachev promises a remarkable step, a Communist Party meeting devoted to the unsettling question of the rights of nationality groups in the Soviet Union.

title: Criminal Trial Is Postponed For Gov. Mecham of Arizona
description: A judge today ordered that the start of Gov. Evan Mecham's trial on criminal charges of concealing a $350,000 campaign loan be delayed until March 22.

title: PATTERNS
description: Classic From Kawakubo

title: Johnson Welcome to Stay, Mets Say
description: The Mets, who announced five months ago that Dave Johnson would not return as manager in 1989, opened spring training today with a bit of a blockbuster: Johnson may return next year, after all.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,702,000 from an accounting change.

title: Roger J. Williams Is Dead at 94; Biochemist and Nutrition Expert
description: Roger J. Williams, an internationally known biochemist and nutritional scientist who discovered the growth-promoting vitamin pantothenic acid, died of pneumonia Saturday at the Four Seasons Nursing Home in Austin, Tex. He was 94 years old and a longtime resident of Austin.

title: School Will Not Waive Rules For Talks on Racial Tension
description: The chancellor of the University of Massachusetts today rejected calls to excuse students from classes for two days so they could discuss racial tensions at the school.

title: ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $332,000 from an accounting change for the quarter and year. c-Includes a loss of $292,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter; the year includes income of $2,149,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Rockets 119, 76ers 106: Eric (Sleepy) Floyd scored 20 points, leading seven Houston players in double figures last night as the Rockets sent the 76ers to their 15th straight road loss. Buck Johnson tied his season-high with 19 points for Houston, which has won 10 of its last 12.(AP) Nuggets 100, Bullets 87: Danny Schayes led Denver in scoring for the first time this season with 21 points, and Alex English scored 7 straight points in the fourth quarter for the Nuggets. It was the Nuggets' eighth victory in their last nine home games. The Bullets, playing the fourth game of an eight-game road trip, lost for the 20th time in 25 road games.(AP) N.H.L. North Stars 4, Maple Leafs 2: Pat Micheletti and Shawn Chambers, two rookies, scored their first goals to lift Minnesota at home.
