The North Stars' victory, their first in their last nine games, left them at 17-35-9 for 43 points, worst in the league.(AP) Tennis Masur Is Upset: Jorge Lozano of Mexico upset Wally Masur of Australia, 6-4, 6-2, last night in Philadelphia to advance to the second round of the United States Pro Indoor Tennis Championship. On Lozano's second match point, Masur returned the serve into the net to end the match. Lozano won the first set with a shot that forced Masur to hit the return under the net with a running forehand. Lozano took the second set with a run of three games. The 16 seeded players drew byes in the first round and will play today or Wednesday. Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, winner of the title in 1986, will begin play Wednesday.(AP) Soviet Women Advance: In Fairfax, Va., Natalia Zvereva and Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union registered straight-set victories yesterday to advance to the second round of the Virginia Slims of Washington Tennis Tournament, but fifth-seeded Barbara Potter ended the Soviet winning streak with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Natalya Bykova. Zvereva, seeded eighth, beat Lisa Bonder, 6-4, 7-6, and Meskhi won a pair of tiebreakers from Akiko Kijimuta of Japan in a baseline duel that lasted 2 hours 11 minutes. Top-seeded Martina Navratilova, who will be vying for her third straight tournament victory, is scheduled to open play today against Judith Wiesner.(AP) Horse Racing Slewsbasque by a Neck: Slewsbasque, ridden by Frank Lovato Jr., came from off the pace yesterday to score a victory in the $31,000 Grecian Queen Purse for 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. The favorite in the field of six, Avie's Gal, with Jack Kaenel up, ran second, two lengths ahead of Bob's Big Girl. The victory was the first in two starts this year for the daughter of Seattle Slew. She ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:49 4/5 to earn $18,600 for Tayhill Stable and paid $16 for $2 to win. (AP)

title: DOLE CAMP HIRES A NEW AD AGENCY
description: The Presidential campaign of Senator Bob Dole hired a new advertising agency today, the latest phase of a debate over television strategy that some aides said had persuaded Mr. Dole not to respond to Vice President Bush's last-minute offensive last week in New Hampshire.

title: Shultz Is Upbeat on Prospects for Afghan Accord
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were generally in accord on terms for ending the war in Afghanistan but that ''delicate and tense'' negotiations would be required to complete a peace agreement.

title: Sports People; Expletives Deleted
description: During a radio network broadcast Sunday from the locker room of the Missouri Tigers, after a 90-72 victory over Oklahoma State, Coach Norm Stewart of the Tigers erupted into an expletive-filled tirade - primarily against the news media - that caused the program to be pulled off the air by KMOX in St. Louis. Clay Matthews of KGBX in Springfield, Mo., said his station broadast the entire show, but that the coach's comments evoked 15 telephone complaints from listeners.

title: Style Distinguishes Top Figure Skaters
description: She is the undisputed queen of these Olympic Games, famous enough to join Ali, Pele, Reggie and Martina among those athletes recognized by one name only.

title: Sun Equities' Stake
description: The Sun Equities Corporation said it had increased its holdings in Computer Memories Inc. to 25 percent by buying 1.7 million shares previously owned by the Intel Corporation for $3 million. The Far Hills, N.J., investment concern headed by Paul and Natalie Koether plans to solicit proxies to elect its own nominees to the board of Computer Memories, based in Chatsworth, Calif. The company stopped manufacturing in 1986, but is publicly traded and has assets of $25 million in cash. Earlier this month, Computer Memories called off a merger with DIC Animation City Inc. of Burbank, Calif., the second buyout it has terminated in the last year. The Koethers had opposed both deals.

title: Bulgaria Resort Fire Kills 6
description: Six people, including two Dutch tourists, were killed today when fire swept through a hotel in the ski resort of Borovets, the official Bulgarian press agency said. The resort is about 30 miles south of Sofia.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $7,000 for the quarter and $46,000 for the year.

title: Yesterday's Medal Winners
description: Alpine Skiing: Women's Super G Gold: Sigrid Wolf, France Silver: Michela Figini, Switzerland Bronze: Karen Percy, Canada Bobsled: Two-man Gold: Kipours, Kozlov (Soviet Union) Silver: Hoppe, Musiol (East Germany) Bronze: Lehmann, Hoyer (East Germany) Cross-Country: Men's 40K relay Gold: Ottosson, Wassberg, Svan, Mogren (Sweden) Silver: Smirnov, Sakhnov, Deviatiarov, Prokurorov (Soviet Union) Bronze: Nyc, Korunka, Benc, Svanda (Czech.) Speed Skating: Women's 500 meters Gold: Bonnie Blair, United States Silver: Christa Rothenburger, East Germany Bronze: Karin Kania,, East Germany Totals: Soviet Union - 7 gold, 6 silver, 5 bronze; East Germany -6 gold, 5 silver, 3 bronze; Austria - 3 gold, 3 silver, 1 bronze; Sweden - 3 gold, 1 bronze; United States - 2 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; Finland - 2 gold, 2 bronze; Switzerland - 1 gold, 4 silver, 2 bronze; West Germany - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; France - 1 gold, 1 bronze; the Netherlands - 2 silver, 2 bronze; Norway - 2 silver, 1 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 2 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 2 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Italy -1 bronze.

title: Phoning I.R.S. With Tax Queries? 39% of the Replies May Be Wrong
description: The Internal Revenue Service is giving incorrect answers to 39 percent of the questions posed by people who call for help with their tax returns, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: Dance: Desrosiers in Calgary
description: In the world of Robert Desrosiers's dances, a fish that floats on stage and into the air is apt to convince us that we are in a fishbowl along with it. With his brilliant ability to blur the lines between the fantastic and the real, the Toronto-based choreographer was the perfect choice for a major commission from the Olympic Arts Festival here.

title: Safeway Selling Postage Stamps at Discount
description: A supermarket chain has found a way to slash the price of a little item that almost everyone buys and always at full price: United States postage stamps.

title: Our Towns; Art on Demand: A Quick Pastel At the Busy Bee
description: Peter Paul Rubens could make a nice living painting Queen Marie de' Medici being delivered to Marseilles by Neptune, but there's not much demand for that kind of thing at the Busy Bee Mall. Doris Pryor finds that to survive as a mall portrait artist she must be sensitive to Busy Bee shoppers' artistic demands.

title: U.S. Faults Bahamas on Drug Effort
description: Despite excellent official cooperation between the United States and the Bahamas on drug enforcement efforts, narcotics-related corruption remains a ''serious problem'' in the Bahamas, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Douglaston Windmill Burns
description: A century-old windmill that was being restored by residents of Douglaston, Queens, burned to the ground last night in the Alley Pond Environmental Center. The tower of the windmill was moved to the center in November 1986, from its original site on Arleigh Road, in Douglaston. Pat Juviler, the chairman of the Committee to Save the Windmill, said that despite the fire, the community would ''continue with its plans to restore the windmill.''

title: LINCOLN FOODSERVICE PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Piano: Mitsuko Uchida
description: MITSUKO UCHIDA'S elegant Mozart recordings scarcely prepare us for the headlong passion she brought to Chopin at the Frick Collection on Sunday Afternoon. The ubiquitous B flat minor Piano Sonata is not exactly a welcome item on the program of so interesting a musician, but one was struck by. Miss Uchida's broad rubato in the first movement and a fury in the second that stretched both the music and her excellent technique to their limits. In contrast, was the rock-solid tempo of the Funeral March and her approach to the finale - which became an angry buzzing rather than a cloud of mystery.

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $26.4 million for the quarter and year; the year also included a credit of $35 million for the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income d-Included a net gain of $3.4 million from the sale of ISI Systems Inc. The latest periods results were also after a net charge of $36 million related to a settlement with the Navy. The loss from discontinued operations in the latest periods is related to an out-of-court settlement with the New York Metropolitan Transit Authority.

title: U.S. Fires a Warning in Gulf
description: A United States warship, arriving in the Persian Gulf today as the newest addition to the Navy's escort squadron, fired machine-gun warning shots to chase away two fishing boats that ventured too close.

title: Concert: Orpheus Group
description: ORPHEUS brought a strongly played, well-conceived concert to Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The American chamber orchestra, which operates with rotating concertmasters and without conductors, used Haydn's F minor Symphony, ''La Passione,'' to start and ended with the ''Short Symphony'' by Aaron Copland. In between Elmar Oliveira was the solo violinist in music by Mozart and Saint-Saens.

title: For Lacroix's Owner, a Fashion Empire Is in the Making
description: The fashion world is waiting to see how Christian Lacroix will fare with his first ready-to-wear collection, part of which made its debut yesterday in New York as part of the pre-fall showings.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5.1 million for the latest year and $2.5 million for 1986. The latest year included gains on security transactions equal to $1.20 a share, compared to similar gains of $6.93 a share for 1986. The latest year also included a positive ''fresh start'' adjustment of 81 cents a share, and included the operations of Selby Insurance Co., acquired in December 1986, and Safeco Title Insurance Co., acquired in January 1987. Alleghany said the businesses of its MSL Industries unit that were spun off in a distribution to shareholders in June 1987 have been retroactively reclassified as discontinued operations.

title: QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Cyprus President Urges End to Enmities
description: President-elect George Vassiliou called today for fresh efforts to heal the scars between the island's Greek and Turkish communities, separated for nearly 14 years by barbed wire and minefields.

title: Nissan Considers Expansion in U.S.
description: The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation said it might expand production at its assembly plant in Smyrna, Tenn. Jerry L. Benefield, president of the American manufacturing subsidiary of the second-largest Japanese auto maker, said he would recommend that engines, axles and bumper assemblies be added to the components now made in Smyrna. He said he might also recommend a second assembly line for the Sentra cars and light trucks.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Your Taxes
description: How should taxpayers adjust their finances to take advantage of the new tax system, with its fewer deductions and lower rates? Wading through the maze of tax changes to file a return by April 15 can provide some guidelines.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why does skin wrinkle after a bath or swim?

title: 25.70 Gain Puts Dow At 2,040.29
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved up smartly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 25.70 points to close at 2,040.29.

title: Axel A. Johnson, Swedish Industrialist, 77
description: Axel Axelsson Johnson, a Swedish industrialist and head of the Johnson Line, died of heart failure on Friday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: Subtle Clues Are Often The Only Warnings Of Perilous Aneurysms
description: FOR months, maybe even years, Senator Joseph Biden Jr. of Delaware carried a silent time bomb in his head. Two weeks ago it almost killed him. For some time, he had suffered from neck pain attributed to a pinched nerve and a viral infection. Mr. Biden, a Democrat and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, wore a neck brace in January during hearings on the nomination of Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court, and he was too ill to vote when the Senate confirmed the Judge.

title: Tie With Sweden May Haunt Canada
description: Both needed a victory, but both were uncomfortable with taking risks that could cause a loss. And because they were unwilling to gamble, Canada and Sweden skated to a 2-2 tie this afternoon.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Oil Price Drop Victimizes Banks
description: LEAD: Pushed by worldwide overproduction, oil prices are sinking again. The latest sag of $2 a barrel, from about $16 a barrel, can be expected to inspire economists of all ideological persuasions to hail another smashing victory over inflation. Such hurrahs for the defeat of inflation, however, call to mind the rueful dispatch of Pyrrhus: ''Another such victory, and we are undone.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * British Petroleum Co. said that Lord Barber would retirefrom its board on March 31 and that James H. Ross would be appointed president and chief executive of its BP America subsidiary in Cleveland.

title: Making the Best Use of Judges' Time in New York Civil Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Patient Wins Decision In Rights Case
description: An administrative law judge for the New York City Commission on Human Rights ruled yesterday that the agency had the power to investigate complaints against health-care workers who refused to treat people with AIDS.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Olaker and Hester Offer Four Centuries of Music
description: For a program entitled ''Cords and Strings'' at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon, Charlae Olaker and Daryl Hester presented music for soprano, lute and guitar that spanned four centuries. Ms. Olaker sang works by Campion, Handel, Britten, Villa-Lobos and others. She was terrific. Mr. Hester accompanied and performed selections for solo lute and guitar.

title: PAXAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses of $47,000 for the quarter and $85,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Includes losses of $768,000 and $700,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: Advertising; Magazine Supplement Devoted to Ireland
description: AS part of the celebration of the 1,000th birthday of Dublin, the advertising partnership of the Irish Tourist Board and Aer Lingus will be running a high-toned Sunday newspaper insert on May 1 to reach the most affluent consumers in their four best tourist markets.

title: CBS Records' Dispute Seen
description: A dispute is emerging over the price that the Sony Corporation will pay for CBS Records, someone close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Sports People; Tarkanian Review
description: The United States Supreme Court agreed yesterday to review a Nevada court ruling that barred the National Collegiate Athletic Association from suspending Jerry Tarkanian, the basketball coach at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas. A two-year suspension of Tarkanian was ordered in 1977 by the N.C.A.A. for alleged recruiting violations, but Tarkanian went to court to challenge the order and it has never been implemented. Last August, the Nevada Supreme Court held that the coach's rights of due process had been violated during a two-and-a-half-year N.C.A.A investigation in the mid-1970's. Tarkanian refused to comment on yesterday's development, but his attorney, Sam Lionel, said in Las Vegas: ''I'm surprised the court acted to review, but I'm confident our position is right and I feel comfortable.''

title: INTERNATIONAL BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $4,957,000 and an extraordinary gain of $506,000. The latest first quarter figures do not include $1,931,000 in revenue from the week ended Jan. 3 because of a change in its fiscal year.

title: A New 'Fast Lane' in Computers
description: When Andreas V. Bechtolsheim, a Stanford University graduate student, could not find a computer that would satisfy his needs, he built his own, a machine that used standard microprocessors and software and easily connected to other computers.

title: From Filing Maze, Financial Insight
description: Wading through the maze of tax law changes is likely to be a confusing and anguishing ordeal for most Americans, but in the process taxpayers will gain a much better insight as to what they need do to adjust their financial lives to this radically new tax system of fewer deductions and lower rates.

title: Astronomers at Work: Stressful Nights at Kitt Peak
description: THE moon was rising, so the bright-time people were on the mountain.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Health 'Oasis' for Homeless Kids
description: Paul Simon, the singer and composer, reasoned that if he couldn't change the world for New York's homeless, he might at least make sure their children got the kind of medical care that most American families take for granted. (About all welfare hotel families can take for granted is a rotten room, a balky elevator, junk food and shouts in the corridor.) That's why today he's the founder and major funder of The New York Childen's Health Project.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year includes results for T-Bar Inc., acquired in December 1986. The company said its 1986 results are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB-96 in 1987; the company also said the effect arising from the change is that tax benefits from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards are no longer shown as an extraordinary credit.

title: Careers; Wider Skills Needed in Accounting
description: LAST July Price Waterhouse, the big accounting firm, startled the profession when it announced an increase in salaries of beginning accountants to at least $29,000 from $23,000.

title: Supernova Remnants
description: Pulsars, stars that emit rapid and highly regular pulses of energy, have puzzled astronomers ever since the first was discovered in 1967. Initially dubbed ''Little Green Men,'' pulsars were suspected for a time of harboring intelligent beings that might be trying to communicate across interstellar space using precisely timed, pulsed signals. Astronomers later concluded, however, that pulsars must be tiny stars made of immensely dense material that spin very rapidly and emit lighthouse-like beacons of radio and X-ray energy.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: I.B.M.'s New Strategy Worries the Industry
description: Less than a year after introducing their newest personal computer line, the PS/2, officials at the International Business Machines Corporation are now planning an overhaul of the line that will distance the company from advancing clone makers. The move is creating concern among industry executives who fear a sharp round of price-cutting and a flurry of new products could cause enough confusion to stall the industry's healthy recovery.

title: Advertising; Mullen Will Handle Account for Timberland
description: Mullen Inc., previously known as Mullen Advertising, has brought the Timberland Company account back to New England.

title: Full Court Sets New Arguments in 2 Cases
description: In an action apparently prompted by the arrival of Anthony M. Kennedy as its newest Justice, the Supreme Court said today it would hear a second round of arguments in two cases: one of great importance to military contractors and the other a death penalty case.

title: Emotion Is Key to Swaggart Church
description: The Assemblies of God church, once again enmeshed in a scandal involving a prominent television evangelist, offers a highly personal, emotional approach to religion that has made it the fastest-growing major Christian denomination in the United States.

title: Quandaries Of Timing On Infant Organs
description: Last week, the Loma Linda University Medical Center for the first time carried out its policy of keeping certain brain-dead infants on respirators so their organs could be transplanted. But the effort ended in a sad anticlimax.

title: Bridge: Sometimes, a 'Superstition' Has a Valid Technical Basis
description: A player who has a two-way guess for a queen will usually have a technical or psychological reason for a particular course of action. The bidding or the early play will often offer a clue, perhaps based on distribution or the location of known high cards.

title: Sports of The Times; Candlestick Park North
description: THE first clue was the vivid orange headquarters alongside the Trans-Canada Highway, reminding a visiting Yank of something equally windy, something equally ill-conceived.

title: Big East to Discuss Fighting
description: For many coaches, the bench-clearing brawls in the South Carolina-Louisville and Georgetown-Pittsburgh games on Saturday underlined the fact that college basketball, with its emphasis on speed and aggressiveness, has become more physical than ever.

title: Soviet Psychiatric Prisoners
description: LEAD: In Magadan, on the shore of the Okhotsk Sea, Valentina Bondarenko's husband, a police sergeant, took to drinking and went on drinking bouts with his police chief. In time, he stopped spending nights at home. Finally, Valentina Bondarenko decided to divorce her husband, but he wanted to have a house, along with a beautiful wife, in reserve.

title: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Seven-Up Soft Drinks
description: The Seven-Up Company announced today that it would introduce two new soft drinks - 7-Up Gold and Diet 7-Up Gold. They will be amber in color and have a spice flavor and will be marketed to appeal particularly to men between the ages of 18 and 34.

title: High Court To Rule on Phone Tax
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to judge the validity of a 5 percent tax Illinois imposes on all telephone calls charged to in-state numbers. The Court said it would study arguments that the tax interfered impermissibly with interstate commerce.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PRETORIA AIRCRAFT DOWNED IN ANGOLA
description: The military announced today that a South African plane had been shot down in southeastern Angola and that three more of its soldiers had been killed in combat.

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Net income

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rio Grande Filing
description: Rio Grande Industries Inc. filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to acquire the Southern Pacific Transportation Company for $1 billion from the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation. Rio Grande, which would combine the Southern Pacific with the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad, said that if the acquisition succeeds, it planned to sell a 25 percent stake in the merged railroads to Morgan Stanley Limited Equity Fund, a limited partnership affiliated with the Morgan Stanley Group. The I.C.C. has approved an expedited schedule for the application, which follows a formal purchase agreement that Rio Grande, a unit of the Anschutz Corporation, entered into with Santa Fe Southern Pacific.

title: Reagan Plans News Session
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference, his first in four months, at 8 P.M. Wednesday, the White House announced today. Marlin Fitzwater, the chief White House spokesman, said the news conference was not ''issue oriented,'' but it would be held less than a week before Mr. Reagan travels to Brussels for a NATO meeting March 2 and 3. The President's last news conference was Oct. 22, shortly after the stock market collapse.

title: 2 Lonely Governors
description: Is anyone out there listening?

title: The Latest Word From Lacroix
description: Christian Lacroix is determined to win acceptance for his ready-to-wear just as he has for his couture clothes. And it looks as if he has made it. He plays by the rules. The rules say that in February, before the March showings in Paris, a good proportion of the fall ready-to-wear collection should be ready to be shown to store buyers in New York.

title: Government Posts Surplus
description: The Federal Government posted a rare $16.09 billion surplus last month, primarily because Social Security checks for January were mailed early, the Treasury Department said today.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Not So Bright A Future
description: No one should be surprised - it may even be salutary - that some Americans have confessed to poll takers that they no longer believe the nation's future will be better than its present or its past. These Americans were only acknowledging what has long been happening - but too many of us have refused to perceive or believe.

title: Aid Group Says Rebels Released 6 in Ethiopia
description: Six European relief workers who were abducted by rebels in Ethiopia have been released, a medical aid official said today.

title: Bill Is Voted to Revamp U.S. Nuclear Agency
description: Legislation to replace the five-member Nuclear Regulatory Commission with a Nuclear Safety Agency headed by a single administrator was approved today by a Senate subcommittee.

title: What the Kidnappers Want in Lebanon
description: By kidnapping an American colonel in Lebanon, a Lebanese faction backed by Iran does more than attack America, the Great Satan that Iran so loves to hate. It attacks the stabilizing United Nations presence in southern Lebanon and attacks Amal, the mainstream Shiite militia that welcomes the U.N. If such acts of terror succeed in diminishing the U.N. presence, Lebanon's tragic chaos might yet reach even deeper depths.

title: Sports People; Spring Training
description: Some baseball players with medical question marks took their first tentative steps yesterday as the first full week of spring training began. Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd and Bruce Hurst threw for 10 minutes each at the Boston Red Sox camp in Winter Haven, Fla. Dr. Arthur Pappas, the Boston team physician, said that Boyd, who underwent right shoulder surgery last August after appearing in seven games, ''threw well, feels comfortable and has no discomfort.'' Hurst, who won 15 games last season, is being monitored closely after what was originally diagnosed as arm fa-tigue turned out to be mononucleosis. ... In Miami, Don Aase of the Bal-timore Orioles, who was a top re-liever two years ago, tested his in-jured jright shoulder. Aase underwent arthroscopic shoulder surgery that limited him to seven games last sea-son. ''He looked good,'' the pitching coach, Herm Starrette, said.

title: Lack of Vote Doesn't Deter Delegate From Guam
description: Ben Garrido Blaz enjoys virtually all the perquisites of a member of Congress except one: as Guam's delegate to the House of Representatives, Mr. Blaz cannot take part in a floor vote.

title: Head of National Security Agency Plans to Retire
description: Lieut. Gen. William E. Odom, the director of the National Security Agency, said today that he planned to retire Aug. 1. Earlier, the Joint Chiefs of Staff had unanimously recommended against extending his tenure beyond the typical three years accorded his predecessors.

title: Music Noted in Brief; A Guitar Recital By David Russell
description: David Russell, a Scottish guitarist of Spanish upbringing, gave a short and expert recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about overcrowding in New York City psychiatric wards described New York State's plans incorrectly. While the state intends to eliminate 7,000 psychiatric beds in upstate communities over the next 10 years, it has no plans to close hospitals.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income The latest third quarter includes a non-recurring charge of $1.1 million for a pension liability arising from discontinued operations, and a loss at Farm House's 80 percent owned affiliated, Entree Corp., relating to its seafood operations.

title: WAINOCO OIL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Soviet Couple Leading
description: Natalya Bestemianova and Andrei Bukin, the world champions, got one perfect 6.0 score and easily won the original set pattern portion of ice dancing tonight.

title: Former Paper Official Joins Fashion Business
description: Richard Leeuwenburg, a paper and forest products executive, is now getting a firsthand look at California's influence as a fashion trendsetter.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Hiram Walker to Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Chicago, for Irish Mist Liqueur assignment.

title: Gustavia Journal; On Hushed St. Barts, a Loud Echo From Wall St.
description: A lot of Americans with deep pockets think of this tiny French island as paradise. It is uncommonly neat and tidy. The hotels are small and quietly elegant. The food is exquisite and everywhere the eye turns there is natural beauty.

title: REALIST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $74,000 and $390,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Austria Can Keep Waldheim
description: Millions of Austrians wanted Kurt Waldheim for President. They knew what he was and they elected him. Austrians who voted for him, knowing, should stick with him.

title: Chess: Despite Early Loss, Karpov Wins Event at Wijk-aan-Zee
description: Despite a crushing second-round loss to the Yugoslav grandmaster Predrag Nikolic, Anatoly Karpov fought back to capture first prize in the 50th Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands. The former world champion displaced the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson from the lead in Round 12 and the two drew in the final round.

title: Austrian Wins In Skiing
description: The critics back home should be placated now. In a sport in which rivalries are fueled by nationalism, the Austrian skiers had fallen in disfavor as the neighboring Swiss had become all the rage of the Alpine set in the past two World Cup seasons. While the Swiss collected medals, the Austrians lived on memories of Franz Klammer's almost death-defying downhill run for the gold in the 1976 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria.

title: Writing Music Electronically
description: Until six years ago, Andy Goldmark, a successful 36-year-old New York songwriter and producer, composed on an acoustic grand piano. But now, with abstract electronic sound becoming an ever-more-important ingredient of pop records, he and other enterprising songwriters for hire have for the most part abandoned the piano and become musical engineers.

title: Rhoden Is Hoping To Hurl 200 Innings
description: It has been five months since Rick Rhoden last threw a pitch and saw his season end on a mound at Exhibition Stadium in Toronto. When he looked back today, he saw a season of injury and unfulfilled expectations, a season that might have pleased others but left him mostly empty.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $2 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $20 million and a tax credit of $1 million.

title: First Restore Order in Gaza and West Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $50,000 and $3,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes income from discontinued operations of $572,000. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $38,731,000 for the quarter and $46,437,000 for the year. The company said the latest fourth quarter also includes gains of $1,257,000 on sale of a plant.

title: SYNERGEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $31,300 from the reversal of tax credits. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $134,400.

title: Sandpoint Journal; Children's Love Follows Caribou Into the Wilds
description: For many years, the vast herds of caribou that once roamed the mountain wilderness of northern Idaho have been gone, the forgotten victims of encroaching civilization and overhunting.

title: Acid Spill Threatens Missouri Town's Water
description: Eleven cars of a 133-car Union Pacific Railroad freight train derailed Sunday and spilled an acid solution into a creek, threatening the water supply for thousands of people, the authorities said.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $76,000 in the latest quarter and $96,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Big Arbitrager Still in Custody
description: Despite efforts by lawyers for John A. Mulheren to transfer him to a hospital, he remained yesterday in the Monmouth County Correctional Institution in New Jersey, according to his lawyers.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $6,917,000 gain from debt restructuring. The company said the latest quarter and year include a pretax gain of $31,890,000 from pension plan restructuring; the latest quarter and year share earnings were reduced by higher preferred stock dividends. Prior year periods were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Advertising; Chiat/Day Unit Lures Wunderman Executive
description: Chiat/Day, now that it is in the $550 million-in-billings class, is acting just like a mega-agency. Not only does it have offices in Los Angeles, New York and San Francisco, but now it also has a direct marketing subsidiary. Created after many months of work by Robert Perkins, with the agency for four years and now the subsidiary's president and chief executive, the division has finally come into being thanks to the acquisition of a veteran creative man. He is William Butler, former executive vice president and creative director of Wunderman Worldwide, the direct marketing subsidiary of Young & Rubicam. Mr. Butler will have the same title at Perkins/Butler. Both executives are 40 years old.

title: British Stand on Ulster Police Reopens the Rift With Dublin
description: Ever-fragile relations between Britain and Ireland have slipped into a new cycle of erosion in the face of Britain's refusal, on the ground of national security, to prosecute police officers found to have perverted justice in Northern Ireland.

title: Hawaii Chooses Spaceport Site
description: THE state of Hawaii, encouraged by President Reagan's policy to encourage the commercial space industry, is moving ahead with plans to create a private spaceport for launching commercial rockets into space.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Richard Voehl has been named executive vice president, creative director at Widmann & Company.

title: Only a Stop Sign
description: Lyn Nofziger, the former White House political director, has shown few signs of repentance since he was found guilty of illegal lobbying, a conviction he compared to ''running a stop sign'' under a Federal ethics law that he dismissed as ''lousy.''

title: Knicks Fall Short As Bird Prevails
description: In the first half tonight, the Knicks had visions of ending their club-record 17-game road losing streak. But in the end, Larry Bird brought the Knicks back into the world of reality as the Celtics scored a 95-93 victory at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: PHOTO-MARKER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it agreed in principle to acquire H.F. Ross & Associates Inc., Anderson, S.C., an industrial chemical manufacturer. It said the purchase will be made for stock and cash payable over five years, but aggregate totals were not determined at this time.

title: Cuomo Won't Remove Abrams in Brawley Case
description: Two clergymen traveled here today to demand that Governor Cuomo remove State Attorney General Robert Abrams as the special prosecutor in the Tawana Brawley case. But Mr. Cuomo refused, saying ''we've done everything we can reasonably do'' until Ms. Brawley cooperates with state investigators.

title: Land-Rover Strike Begins
description: About 6,000 employees began a strike today at Land-Rover. It was the first walkout against the state-owned auto maker in six years and the second strike in the British auto-making industry this month. Production resumed at the Ford Motor Company today after a two-week stoppage.

title: BERRY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in revenue and net income for the fourth quarter and the year is due principally to the sale of the company's Cypress property and 50 percent of its interest in the Rincon leases in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: FIRST ESSEX BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company converted to stock form on Aug. 11, 1987.

title: PHOTON TECHNOLOGY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Medium-Size Raider Turns Sights on Dravo
description: LEAD: Arthur M. Goldberg has a reputation as medium-size corporate raider. Not a Carl C. Icahn or a T. Boone Pickens, but he is nonetheless a raider with an eye for the hidden value in smaller companies in trouble.

title: FISCHER & PORTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net charge of $600,000 for an unfavorable court decision in a lawsuit.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Walsh Team Hears Blandon
description: Jose Blandon, a former top aide to Panama's strongman, met with Iran-contra prosecutors today. Mr. Blandon has testified that the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, agreed to provide training for Nicaraguan rebels after receiving a request in 1985 from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, a former National Security Council official who is a target of the Iran-contra investigation headed by Lawrence E. Walsh.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL PARAMETRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $250,000 from an accounting change.

title: John Allegro, 65; Aided Deciphering of Dead Sea Scrolls
description: Dr. John Allegro, who was renowned for his work in deciphering the Dead Sea Scrolls but ridiculed for his theories that Western religions were based on the worship of mushrooms, died Wednesday. He was 65 years old.

title: Moore McCormack
description: Southdown Inc., an energy and cement concern, said it would offer $31 a share, or a total of about $177 million, for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. Southdown, based in Houston, also filed suit in United States District Court against Moore McCormack's chairman, Paul R. Tregurtha, contending that he and the board had violated their fiduciary duties by illegally trying to prevent shareholder consideration of the tender offer. Moore McCormack is based in Stamford, Conn.

title: SOCIALISTS ASSERT WALDHEIM MUST GO
description: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky's Socialist Party said today that the continuing furor over Kurt Waldheim's wartime record made it impossible for Mr. Waldheim to continue as Austria's President and called for talks aimed at replacing him.

title: A New Hope for Koreas
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that Roh Tae Woo, the in-coming president of South Korea, intends to offer to meet with the president of North Korea, Kim Il Sung. Samaranch said that he was ''guessing'' that an attempt of ''rapproachment'' to Mr. Kim will come in Mr. Roh's inauguration speech Thursday.

title: Plan Urged For Markets
description: Several key members of Congress have requested that Federal regulators formulate a contingency plan to handle future crises in the stock and futures markets.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comic-Book Fantasies
description: MANY computer games already look like translations of comic books, as indeed some of them are. Now one publisher is making the connection explicit.

title: Mob Figure Gets 15 Years; He is Also Fined $820,000
description: The convicted underboss of the Gambino crime family - who last December chose to go to jail rather than renounce any criminal affiliation - was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in Federal prison and fined $820,000.

title: Notebook; '88 WINTER OLYMPICS; Barred Polish Athlete Protests
description: Jaroslaw Mirowiecki, the Polish hockey star who failed a drug test at the XV Olympic Winter Games last week, proclaimed his innocence today. He was supported by Polish officials who said they were turned down when they requested another test.

title: By Design; Color Coordination
description: A tricolor scheme is a great way to coordinate a wardrobe. Every element is in one, or a combination, of the three colors, in both solids and patterns. A fast-moving woman can mix the elements to create any number of looks, and her accessories always key in. She can also pack in a jiffy.

title: ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $114,000 from a reduction in the provision for the estimated loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $252,000 and $91,700 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a reduction in the provision for the estimated loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,300,000 for the both periods.

title: Blair Captures 500-Meter Gold In Record Time
description: In just 39.10 seconds tonight, Bonnie Blair of Champaign, Ill., gave the United States speed-skating team an Olympic gold medal at last.

title: ABC Still Going for the Gold
description: NOW what for ABC - and us? The American kids are gone from the Olympics hockey scene except for a consolation game. Does that mean a return to the television mainstream: ''The Equalizer,'' Vanna White, Morton Downey Jr., Andre the Giant?

title: International Trade Official Resigns at Commerce Dept.
description: S. Bruce Smart Jr. resigned today as the Commerce Department's top international trade official.

title: Theater Prize to Churchill
description: Caryl Churchill, the British playwright who wrote ''Serious Money,'' has won the 10th Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, which is awarded annually ''to a woman who deserves recognition for having written a work of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater.'' Elizabeth Diggs, an American playwright, was runner-up for her play ''St. Florence.''

title: Books of The Times
description: SHORES OF REFUGE. A Hundred Years of Jewish Emigration. By Ronald Sanders. 673 pages. Illustrated. Henry Holt & Company. $27.95.

title: UNITED HEALTHCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes for the year a $920,000 tax credit. Prior year figures include results for Peak Healthcare Inc. from Nov. 7 through Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Lack of Nurses Impedes New York AIDS Care
description: Efforts to increase the capacity of hospitals in New York City to deal with the worsening AIDS crisis are being thwarted by acute staff shortages, primarily among nurses, according to state officials and city hospital administrators.

title: Isolated Aged Parents Need More Than Pity; A Lack of Caring
description: To the Editor:

title: Special School in Harlem Tops New York in Reading
description: A school for gifted children in Harlem scored highest among New York City's public elementary and junior high schools in a reading test administered last spring, according to figures released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Marines Are Said to Suspend Alleged Lesbians
description: The Marine Corps investigating homosexuality among women at the Parris Island boot camp and plans to court-martial or discharge up to 10 women, according to three women who said they are being investigated.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Brian Dennehy's performance in ''The Cherry Orchard'' carried an incorrect identification, provided by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, of the actress shown with him.

title: Stage: 'Twelfth Night'
description: THE young Shakespeare Stage Company has dedicated itself to fidelity to Shakespeare's text and language as well as to ensemble acting - consummations devoutly to be wished in an age when such fidelity is often honored in the breach. Although the company's new production of ''Twelfth Night'' rarely takes poetic wing, its spirits are almost as high as its intentions, at least when it is clowning around.

title: FAMOUS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $53,000 and $1,008,000 for the 13 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $572,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the 13 weeks, and the 53 weeks includes a pretax charge of $12,500,000 for establishment of a reserve.

title: Soviet Spacecraft Will Use Laser to Examine Moon of Mars
description: A PAIR of Soviet spacecraft scheduled to set out for Mars in July will carry a laser gun with which scientists expect to discover information about the solar system in its infancy, more than 4 billion years ago.

title: Pupils No Match for Kasparov, Even Simultaneously
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, opened every game with the same move: king's pawn to E4. Then he slowly circled the children who had packed the gymnasium. He stared intently at each board for about 10 seconds, made a move and went on to the next.

title: ENDEVCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago quarter and year includes a writedown of assets of $3,623,000.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses of $12,090,000 and $6,000,000 from discontinued operations for the quarte and year, respectively.

title: Nofziger Files Motion To Void Convictions
description: Lyn Nofziger's defense attorneys filed motions today to set aside the former Presidential aide's illegal lobbying convictions on the grounds that prosecutors failed to prove he violated the law.

title: Gabon Keeps Strong Links With France
description: In the late 1950's, as the winds of independence swept across Africa, Gabon was the only one of 14 French colonies in Africa to vote to join France as a department.

title: New Site for Mamet Play
description: David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow'' will move to the Royale Theater on Broadway after its initial run in March and April at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. The new play, which is being staged by the Lincoln Center Theater director, Gregory Mosher, stars Madonna, Joe Mantegna and Ron Silver. The play is to be at the Newhouse from March 29 to April 24 and begin performances at the Royale, 242 West 45th Street, on April 26.

title: Scientists Gain Full Picture of Cancer Protein
description: SCIENTISTS have determined the complete three-dimensional structure of the product of an important human oncogene, an aberrant gene believed to play a role in causing cancer. The new picture of the oncogene product, a protein, should add to the understanding of how oncogenes work and might someday lead to the design of drugs that could change malignant cells back to normal.

title: PSYCHIATRIC BIOSCIENCE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said its board approved the change of the corporate name to Princeton Diagnostic Laboratories of America Inc. It said the matter will be considered at the annual shareholders' meeting on May 17.

title: How Good Is West Point Leadership Training?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Inch Up Cautiously
description: Bond prices rose slightly in very slow trading yesterday.

title: MERCURY GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $88,000 for the quarter and $634,000 for the year. c-After realized investment gains of $339,000 for the quarter and $2,352,000 for the year.

title: Foodmaker to Acquire Chi-Chi's Restaurants
description: Foodmaker Inc., an operator of fast-food restaurants, said today that it would pay $10.50 a share in cash, or $230 million, to acquire Chi-Chi's Inc., topping two competing bids for the chain of family-style Mexican restaurants.

title: European Farm Pact Completed
description: European Community foreign ministers agreed today on a final set of farm spending limitations, clearing the way for a huge cash injection for the community over the next five years, a spokesman said.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results include accrued interest expense and amortization of discount totalling $4,939,000 and $4,541,000 for the fiscal 1988 and 1987 quarters, respectively, relating to the company's 15 percent Secured Income Notes.

title: Campaign Test on Long Island
description: Last year, New York's Legislature got caught in an embarrassing payroll scandal involving the use of legislative workers in political campaigns. Has it mended its ways? The special elections on March 15 to fill five vacant Assembly seats offer an instructive test.

title: Bonds Advance After Fed's Report
description: Bond prices rose yesterday in fairly active trading after commodity prices dropped and the Federal Reserve predicted that economic growth would be more modest than it had previously anticipated.

title: Woolridge Admits to Cocaine Problem
description: One day after Orlando Woolridge told the National Basketball Association that he had a cocaine dependency problem, the league announced yesterday that the Nets' high-scoring forward had been placed in the hands of drug counselors, in accordance with the 1984 agreement between the league and the players union.

title: PAROLE BY BRITISH STIRS IRISH FUROR
description: Britain announced today that the only British soldier to be sentenced to life imprisonment for fatally shooting an Irish civilian had been paroled and restored to service after only 26 months of prison confinement.

title: Job Opening
description: A job of uncommon power is opening up in Washington: that of executive director of the 12-member National Economic Commission, the eminent bipartisan panel that in March of next year will offer Congress and the White House a way out of the budget deficits.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Governors Seek Housing and Child Care Changes
description: Seeking to reshape a Federal system they consider out of kilter, the nation's governors today announced a major effort to increase state responsibilities substantially in housing and child care.

title: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Net loss and includes a charge of $3,400,000 before taxes, or $1,950,000 after tax, from an increase in the loss reserves of its reinsurance subsidiary. The latest year included 53 weeks, compared with 52 weeks in the prior year.

title: New Zealand Is Jolted By a Speedy Decontrol
description: In its rapid shift over the last few years from one of the most tightly regulated economies outside the Eastern European bloc to one of the most free and open, New Zealand has been experiencing what people here call ''speed wobbles.''

title: City Ballet: Both 'Faun' And 'Antique Epigraphs'
description: JEROME ROBBINS re-creates the world of the ballet studio in ''Afternoon of a Faun.'' In ''Antique Epigraphs,'' he creates a world outside of time and place. Both ballets are set to dappled scores by Claude Debussy. Together, as they were performed by the New York City Ballet on Saturday night at the New York State Theater, they seem an even more exquisitely allusive pair of dances.

title: About New York; Moishe's Rise: From Sneakers To Moving Vans
description: Six years ago this month, a 25-year-old Tel Aviv University law school dropout named Moishe Mana was living in an abandoned building in Brooklyn and selling gloves, scarves, socks and sneakers on the sidewalks of Manhattan. Next month he is moving from a Chelsea studio to a $650,000, two-bedroom condominium on the Upper East Side, surroundings that better befit a man who founded a company that grosses $12 million a year. Mr. Mana likes America.

title: '88 Winter Olmypics: Notebook; Hockey Schedule Draws Fire
description: The first prime-time game in the medal round of Winter Olympic hockey will send the Soviet Union against Canada. The medal round will begin Wednesday with three games in the Saddledome: Sweden against Czechoslovakia at 12:30 P.M., New York time; Finland against West Germany at 4:30 P.M., and the Soviet Union against Canada at 8:30 P.M.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Garrison Advances: Zina Garrison combined an aggressive net game with a steady serve to score a straight-set victory over ailing Isabelle Demongeot of France yesterday in the opening round of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Washington tournament in Fairfax, Va. Garrison, seeded sixth, was about to receive serve at match point when Demongeot clutched her stomach and walked off the court. Garrison held a 6-2, 5-0 lead when Demongeot retired 56 minutes into the match. Demongeot, who had been fighting the flu over the past four days, said she was out of breath at the end and simply could not continue. It was the second match of the day halted by retirement, and a third was altered due to illness. Earlier, Terry Phelps beat Peanut Harper, a last-minute replacement for Eva Pfaff, 6-3, 6-2; and Ann Henricksson retired with lower back and groin muscle injuries while trailing Robin White, 6-2, 2-0.(AP) Reggi Defeats Hy: Raffaella Reggi of Italy, seeded third, fought through a first-set tiebreaker and went on to defeat Patricia Hy of Hong Kong by 7-6, 6-4 in a first-round match at the $100,000 Virginia Slims of Oklahoma tournament in Oklahoma City. Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, seeded seventh, also advanced by defeating Michelle Torres of Northfield, Ill., 6-2, 6-3.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 131, Pacers 111: Dominique Wilkins scored 43 points and combined with Antoine Carr to lead a second-quarter surge last night to end the visiting Pacers' seven-game winning streak. Wilkins scored 15 points and Carr 13 in the second quarter, when the two Hawk forwards increased the Atlanta lead to 13 points. Carr finished with a career-high 22 points.(AP) Bulls 104, SuperSonics 97: Michael Jordan scored 39 points, including 6 in overtime as Chicago won at home. Seattle's Xavier McDaniel sent the game into overtime with a 35-foot, 3-point shot with one second left that tied it at 95.(AP) N.H.L. Jets 4, Penguins 3: Mario Marois scored at 2:40 of overtime last night as the visiting Jets ended a three-game losing streak. Dale Hawerchuk of the Jets won a faceoff and Marois's slapshot from the right point eluded Frank Pietrangelo, the Penguin goalie, to extend Pittsburgh's losing streak to four games.(AP) Canadiens 3, Nordiques 1: Mats Naslund and Claude Lemieux scored goals 80 seconds apart midway through the second period to lead the visiting Canadiens. Brian Hayward, the Montreal goaltender, made 25 saves and had a shutout bid ended with 5:27 to play, when Gaetan Duchesne beat him with a low slapshot from the top of the left faceoff circle.(AP) Flyers 11, Red Wings 6: Mark Howe and Murray Craven had two goals each as the visiting Flyers scored six times in a 9:17 span of the third period after trailing by 5-1. Steve Yzerman scored his 48th goal for Detroit with 4:53 remaining in the second period to set a club record for a center, breaking the mark of 47 by Marcel Dionne in 1974-75.(AP) Whalers 3, Bruins 2: Kevin Dineen scored with 55 seconds left to play and John Anderson had three assists to lead the Whalers at home. Ray Bourque had an assist to extend his consecutive point streak to 15 games.(AP)

title: Auction of Stadium Blocked by Patriots
description: The debt-ridden Sullivan family took a step toward keeping the Patriots in New England by blocking yesterday's planned auction of their stadium in Foxboro, Mass.

title: Robertson Hints a Bush Link To Disclosures on Swaggart
description: Pat Robertson asserted today that it was no accident that news of the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart's difficulties broke two weeks before the South Carolina Republican Presidential primary, in which Mr. Robertson, a former television evangelist, hopes to score a major success.

title: INSIDE
description: Penalty on Panama Urged

title: Drugs Detected in Switchman
description: Marijuana was detected in the system of an Amtrak switchman who fled his post after a train derailment near Philadelphia last month, officials said today.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: British Economy Grows
description: The British gross domestic product rose by 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1987 over the third quarter, according to data released today by the Central Statistical Office. This compares with a 2.1 percent gain in the third quarter of 1987 over the second. The annual growth rate was 5.23 percent.

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hostile Bidder for IU Tops a Friendly Offer
description: The protracted battle for control of the IU International Corporation intensified today as the company announced a friendly leveraged buyout proposal and later became the subject of a higher hostile takeover offer.

title: It's a Trap!
description: In case anyone is wondering how well the Central Intelligence Agency is policing itself these days, there was a hint in the parking lot facing agency headquarters on Tuesday: there stood a uniformed security guard deploying a radar gun, happily registering violators of the 25-mile-an-hour speed limit - nearly all of them agency employees.

title: GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,009,000 for the quarter and $3,861,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $962,000 for the quarter and $4,054,000 for the year. The latest quarter net included a 4 cents a share ''fresh start'' benefit related to the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The latest year operating net included $2,976,000 in ''fresh start'' benefits relating to the 1986 tax reform act. The year-ago results are restated to reflect retroactive implementation of an accounting change. Revenue represents earned revenue.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-After special charges of $23.2 million for the quarter and $24.7 million for the year. c-Net income and includes special gains of $5.4 million and $3.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the special charges were primarily related to the phase-out of the fashion conspiracy and Gussini divisions. It also said that during the latest fourth quarter it adopted a change in accounting for taxes, which reduced the 1987 net loss by $8.9 million. Of this amount, $8.7 million represents the cumulative effect on prior years' income.

title: Pearson-Les Echos
description: Finance Minister Edouard Balladur has opposed the planned sale of the French financial newspaper Les Echos to Pearson P.L.C. of Britain, saying he will not allow the transfer of ownership to proceed automatically. Mr. Balladur said the deal, worth about $158 million, that was signed Jan. 11 between Pearson and Les Echo's owner, Jacqueline Beytout, ''is subject to the explicit authorization of the French authorities.'' Mrs. Beytout called the Government's position ''exclusively political.'' Officials said the main stumbling block was the 20.5 percent stake in Pearson held by the publisher Rupert Murdoch.

title: FIRST WORLD CHEESE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes results for newly acquired Mountain Farms Inc. The company said that of its $440,000 in operating net, about $225,000 is attributable to Mountain Farms. Mountain Farms contributed $7.5 million to the latest quarter's revenue. c-Net loss

title: NEC Challenges Intel Copyrights
description: The NEC Corporation and its California subsidiary asked a Federal judge to rule that the Intel Corporation had forfeited the copyrights it claims for the powerful and widely used 8086 and 8088 microprocessors. The action by NEC of Tokyo and NEC Electronics Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., is the latest salvo in a two-and-a-half-year battle with Intel over the microprocessors.

title: ENTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income

title: Education; Protesters Seize Dormitory
description: A small group of Hampshire College students occupied part of a dormitory today to protest what they said was a failure by the school administration to deal with campus racism.

title: Group Burns Records On Euthanasia Survey
description: Amid a controversy over an anonymous essay in The Journal of the American Medical Association describing the killing of a cancer patient by a resident physician, the Hemlock Society said today that it had destroyed responses to a recent survey of doctors about euthanasia.

title: Portable Macintosh Details Published
description: A trade journal published this week contains thorough details of Apple Computer Inc.'s portable Macintosh personal computer - a serious breach of internal security. Macintosh Today said its article was based on a 160-page confidential document. Apple has declined comment. The article said the machine, code-named Laguna, will weigh 12 pounds and will feature an active matrix screen, which will work better with graphics than the displays in current laptops. The machine will be based on a Motorola Inc. microprocessor. It will sell for about $6,000.

title: INTEGON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $924,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $9,795,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $2,167,000 for the quarter and $7,333,000 for the year.

title: '88 Winter Olympics; Yesterday's Medal Winners
description: Biathlon; Men's 10K Gold: Frank-Peter Roetsch, East Germany Silver: Valery Medvedtsev, Soviet Union Bronze: Sergei Tchepikov, Soviet Union Ski Jumping; 90-meter Gold: Matti Nykaenen, Finland Silver: Erik Johnsen, Norway Bronze: Matjaz Debelak, Yugoslavia Speed Skating; Women's 3,000 Gold: Yvonne van Gennip, the Netherlands Silver: Andrea Ehrig, East Germany Bronze: Gabi Zange, East Germany Figure Skating; Ice Dancing Gold: Natalya Bestemianova, Andrei Bukin, Soviet Union Silver: Marina Klimova, Sergei Ponomarenko, Soviet Union Bronze: Tracy Wilson, Robert McCall, Canada Totals: Soviet Union - 8 gold, 8 silver, 6 bronze; East Germany -7 gold, 6 silver, 4 bronze; Austria - 3 gold, 3 silver, 1 bronze; Sweden - 3 gold, 1 bronze; United States - 2 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; Finland - 3 gold, 2 bronze; Switzerland - 1 gold, 4 silver, 2 bronze; the Netherlands - 1 gold; 2 silver, 2 bronze; West Germany - 1 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; France - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Norway - 3 silver, 1 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 3 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 2 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Italy - 1 bronze; Yugoslavia - 1 bronze.

title: Sports People; Rowing to Antarctica
description: Ned Gillette, a 43-year-old explorer-adventurer, launched a 28-foot boat early Monday for the start of a 600-mile rowing expedition from the tip of South America to Antarctica. Gillette and three teammates set off from Cape Brecknock, a land mass in the Chilean archipelago above Cape Horn. The trip across the treacherous Drake Passage is expected to take 15 to 20 days. Their boat, a heavy-gauge aluminum craft named Sea Tomato, has sliding rowing seats in the bow and stern. Gillette, a 1968 Olympic cross-country skier from Stowe, Vt., is accompanied on the expedition by Mark Eichenberger, 35, of Costa Mesa, Calif.; Jay Morrison, 34, of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Fred Trombly, 32, of Wareham, Mass.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Dolls in Paris Fashions Of '46 Will Tour Again
description: In 1945, to show the world that French fashion had survived World War II, Paris designers planned a world tour of their creations. But with material, models and money in short supply just after the war, the designers turned to miniature mannequins to show their clothes.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,606,000 from an accounting change. The latest first quarter results included the operations of Kingston- Warren Corp. and Hayes-Albion Corp., acquired at the end of December 1986.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said it had introduced liability insurance policies for independent corporate directors.

title: 'Manchurian Candidate,' Old Failure, Is Now a Hit
description: To the surprise of nearly everyone, ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' a 26-year-old suspense movie, is a box-office winner.

title: Reagan Chooses a Skilled Infighter to Lead Navy
description: President Reagan today chose a veteran Capitol Hill infighter, William L. Ball 3d, to step into a simmering dispute over Pentagon budget cuts as his new Secretary of the Navy.

title: College Basketball; Temple Holds Off W Virginia, 62-61
description: Mike Vreeswyk made two free throws with six seconds left and top-ranked Temple went on to beat West Virginia, 62-61, and clinch its second-straight Atlantic 10 Conference season title.

title: ODYSSEY ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company had no revenue in the year-ago quarter and 9 months.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Creating an Envelope: A System to Prevent Air Collisions
description: AS a United Airlines DC-8 descends for a landing here, a series of white diamonds move across a video screen on the cockpit control panel. They are part of the long-awaited, much-debated collision avoidance system that tracks nearby planes and advises pilots on evasive action when collisions are imminent.

title: 2.8% Decline In Orders For Durables
description: Orders to United States factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods fell 2.8 percent in January, the biggest decline in a year, reflecting sharp drops in demand for aircraft and primary metals, the Government reported today.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,491,000 and $2,643,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $1,620,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes losses of $1,488,000 for the quarter and $5,089,000 for the 9 mohths, both from discontinued operations.

title: Oil Rig Collapses in Gulf
description: An oil-drilling rig collapsed in 30-knot winds and waves up to 10 feet high in the Gulf of Mexico on Monday. The 34 workers on the rig, which is owned by Keyes Offshore Inc., were evacuated in lifeboats and then transferred to a workboat for the 82-mile trip north to Galveston, where they arrived this morning. No one was injured, and company officials said they believed they would be able to salvage the rig.

title: More Than Arms Control
description: Something modest, but potentially momentous, occurred during Secretary of State Shultz's visit to Moscow this week. The United States and the Soviet Union seemed in position, perhaps for the first time, to make as much progress on regional disputes and human rights issues as on arms control.

title: As Protests Go On, 2 More Palestinians Are Killed
description: Two 13-year old Palestinians, a boy and a girl, were shot and killed as protests continued today in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BROWN-FORMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
2 NETWORKS TO CUT ELECTION COVERAGE
description: At least two major broadcast networks, NBC and CBS, have decided to reduce prime time coverage of the March 8 primaries on the ground that the elections do not seem likely to yield a decisive result.

title: Berlin, N.H.
description: SINCE washing clothes is a drag, while eating is fun, a diner-laundry doesn't seem outrageous. Well, not too outrageous. Welcome to Berlin, home of the Eastern Depot Restaurant and Laundromat. Here you will find that elusive hybrid, a place where you can cram your clothes into a washing machine, then escape next door for first-rate diner fare. Two eggs, home fries, toast, coffee and a refill cost $2.41. The washers are $1.25 a load; the dryers, 25 cents for 8 minutes.

title: Advertising; DDB Needham Names Head in San Francisco
description: Dennis P. Wilkinson, 39, has been appointed president of DDB Needham San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group. His appointment marks the completion of the reorganization begun a year and a half ago at the $35 million agency.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLOOD AND WATER AND OTHER TALES. By Patrick McGrath. 192 pages. Poseidon Press. $15.95.

title: DECISION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects $2,630,000 of costs incurred for legal and financial services relating to the recent takeover activities; $6,738,000 of costs associated with the acquisition and merger agreement entered into on Nov. 23, 1987, with Onset Corp., and $3.8 million of charges associated with the repositioning of the company's system product. c-Includes a cumulative adjustment of $2,932,000 in reference to the adoption of the new accounting principle relating to income taxes. d-Net income and the quarter includes 62 cents a share of restructuring income and unusual items, primarily reflecting the sale of 51 percent interest in Decision Industries European subsidiaries to Olivetti in connection with the formation of a joint venture.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: New-issue activity was relatively light in the tax-exempt market yesterday, except for the Maryland Health and Higher Educational Facilities Authority, which tentatively offered $210.9 million of refunding revenue bonds for Johns Hopkins University. The bonds have a maximum yield of 7.54 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Alex. Brown & Sons.

title: Reagan News Session Will Be on Air Today
description: President Reagan's news conference at 8 o'clock tonight will be broadcast on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,025,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,284,000 and $1,661,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and also includes a gain of $621,000 from the termination of a pension plan for both periods.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no calming down in the territories. The riots there come in waves. We are in a stage of things growing more serious.'' - Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. [ A3:4. ]

title: 3 Airlines Raise Discount Fares
description: Three leading carriers -American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Air Lines -plan to increase their lowest discount fares by $10 per round trip, effective March 2. The seasonal adjustment comes at a time when traffic usually strengthens after a period of weakness at the beginning of the year.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PACIFIC SILVER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 'My Daughter Is a Lesbian'
description: Typically, the parent of a gay child passes through successive stages of shock, disbelief, sorrow and, sooner or later, acceptance. For many of us, however, there is yet another phase: outrage against society's stereotypical thinking that would relegate our gay loved ones to second-class citizenship.

title: Seoul Urged to Make Amends for 1980 Massacre
description: A special Government committee said today that in the name of national harmony, South Korea's new leadership should apologize and pay compensation to survivors of a 1980 massacre in the city of Kwangju.

title: Mr. Webb's Petulant Resignation
description: It's a fine thing to resign on principle. But James Webb seems to have resigned as Secretary of the Navy on something closer to pique. He failed to get on with his boss, Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci, and left with a gratuitous personal blast. Mr. Webb's departure raises no great debate about the future of the Navy, merely an eyebrow as to whether he was really suited to his office.

title: Advertising; Ketchum in Pittsburgh Wins Equitable Gas Job
description: Ketchum Advertising/Pittsburgh has gained the business of the Equitable Gas Company, a utility, that formerly was handled by George Hill & Company of Pittsburgh. It is expected to bill about $1.5 million.

title: Bechtel's Link To the Pipeline
description: Bechtel has not been charged with any illegality in connection with the scuttled Iraqi pipeline project but is being scrutinized by the special prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: News Corporation Profit Up
description: The News Corporation Ltd., an international media and entertainment company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, yesterday reported a 45 percent increase in profits and a 31.4 rise in revenues for its second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
POLYMER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $2,723,000 in gains from the public offering of about 26 percent of an interest in a Canadian subsidiary.

title: Education; Deflecting Protests With Open Heart and Mind
description: For just about any other college chancellor, it would have been a nightmare: 100 minority students occupying a campus building to protest racial violence and harassment, vowing not to leave until the school met their demands.

title: Regent in New York, Under Fire, Drops Bid for Re-election
description: Dr. Salvatore J. Sclafani, whose performance as a member of the Board of Regents has been criticized by a state school board association and by elected officials, abandoned his candidacy for a second full term on the education panel today.

title: TURNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the writedown of property values and expenses in connection with real estate development activity and losses in the discontinued Trans-Con operation as reported in the third quarter were the principal reasons for the loss for the latest year. The company also said results of operations from the Rickenbacker air cargo facility have been reclassified in the prior fourth quarter and year from general and administrative expenses and other income to earnings (losses) from real estate operations.

title: PRIME MEDICAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Revenue represents fee revenue.

title: Worker Held In Theft of File On Brawley
description: A printing machine operator at the New York State Attorney General's office was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing a copy of a 200-page transcript of grand jury testimony in the Tawana Brawley case.

title: Peru Rebels Black Out Cities
description: Suspected Marxist guerrillas blew up two power stations Monday night, blacking out nine coastal cities in Peru, the police said today.

title: U.S. Seen as Confident of Afghan Pullout by Soviet
description: Intelligence reports from Afghanistan showing Soviet troops retreating to defensive bases and dependents leaving the country have increased American confidence that the Soviet Union is preparing to withdraw its forces, a senior official traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: Gloria Hollister Anable, 87, Dies; An Explorer and Conservationist
description: Gloria Hollister Anable, an explorer, scientist and conservationist who set a women's world record for ocean descent in a bathysphere in 1931, died of cardiac arrest Friday at the Carolton convalescent home in Fairfield, Conn., where she had lived for three years. She was 87 years old and had previously lived in Stamford.

title: Kissinger Balks at Treaty on Strategic Arms
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, told Congress today that the United States should not conclude a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons until progress is made toward a separate agreement on conventional arms in Europe.

title: A Judge Orders Company to Pay Love Canal Cost
description: A Federal judge today found the Occidental Chemical Corporation responsible for the multimillion-dollar cost of cleaning up the Love Canal landfill.

title: Duguay Glad To Go to Kings
description: Early Monday morning, Phil Esposito hung up his phone and smiled. He had just reached an agreement in principle on a contract for Brian Leetch, the promising young Olympic defenseman. Late Monday night, he picked up the phone again, but this time it was hard not to feel a little bit sad. He was about to trade Ron Duguay.

title: A Good Restroom
description: To The Living Section:

title: Agent Affidavits Needed
description: For the first time since 1971, players in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament next month will have to submit notarized affidavits stating that they have not signed with an agent and will not do so during the tournament.

title: GEN-PROBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amfac Hawaii Inc., Honolulu, a subsidiary of Amfac Inc., a diversified food, retail, real estate and lodging concern, named Robert H. Ozaki executive vice president and chairman.

title: Real Estate; Outlet Mall Planned for Manhattan
description: ALTHOUGH Manhattan has long had discount shopping districts, like Orchard Street on the Lower East Side or the stretch of 14th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, bargain hunters in New York City have had to leave town to find deep discounts offered in the region's growing number of factory outlet shopping centers.

title: RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $193,000 and $264,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain on the disposal of a discontinued operation of $3,883,000 and a tax credit of $18,000.
