The company said the increase in its revenue reflects the contribution of HPM Industries, which was acquired Oct. 1, 1987.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $2,926,000 for the quarter and $3,212,000 for the year from early retirement of debt.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 33 cents a share from a change in accounting for revenue. c-Includes a charge equal to 2 cents a share from a loss on repurchase of first mortgage bonds.

title: On Battered Rio Hillsides, Homeless Dig Out
description: Jose Messias, a 54-year-old odd-job man, thought he was going home high up on a hillside slum of Rio de Janeiro, but he found his home was no longer there.

title: NEWS CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $20,632,000 for the quarter and $70,757,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $7,331,000 for the quarter and $4,529,000 for the 6 months. The share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (ADR). The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: 'Thirtysomething,' a Chronicle of Everyday Life
description: There are no car chases, no romantic triangles, no stars to bolster the ratings. Yet much of America's television audience finds ABC's ''Thirtysomething'' series as gripping as gangsters, as addictive as soap opera, and as memorable as a full-length feature film.

title: 2 Israelis Are Killed in Ambush in South Lebanon
description: Two Israelis were killed and several were wounded today in a guerrilla ambush in southern Lebanon, according to police officials here.

title: MIDSOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began operations March 31, 1986.

title: Education; Lessons
description: It has always seemed an addled adage: ''Those who can, do. Those who cannot, teach.'' Some of the doers, it now seems, have long yearned to educate. Lawyers, nurses, millwrights, accountants and executives - people of experience - in growing numbers are leaving their professions, earning teaching certificates and heading for the classroom.

title: The Iran Panel Never Received Pipeline Memo
description: The Justice Department failed to provide a memo to the Congressional Iran-contra committees that said Israel felt it was owed American help on a Middle East pipeline project because it had helped free an American hostage in Lebanon.

title: Books: Paradise Lost
description: BUYING INTO AMERICA. By Martin and Susan Tolchin. 400 pages. Times Books. $19.95.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PARK OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arab Satellite Delay
description: The Arab Space Communication and Satellite Organization is postponing the launching of a new satellite until 1995 but plans to extend the life of two already in orbit. The group, which has had two satellites in orbit since 1985 with an original seven-year life span, said after a Monday board meeting that it would extend their lives by three years. The two are controlled by two main ground stations in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Tunis, while 15 Arab states have so far built receiver stations.

title: Rise in Firefighters' Medical Leaves Seen as Protest
description: A marked increase in the number of New York City firefighters requesting medical leave for on-duty injuries, apparently to protest the closing of a Brooklyn firehouse, has cost several hundred thousand dollars and has prompted the city to consider invoking a state law that bars job actions by public employees.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,584,094. c-Net income and after a loss of $309,783 from discontinued operations.

title: Hopes for Peace Fade Despite Contra Cutoff
description: Six months after the signing of a regional peace accord, prospects for an end to the Nicaraguan conflict appear to be dimming.

title: Bechtel Faces Lack of Big Projects
description: The low-profile Bechtel Group has found itself in the limelight in recent weeks because of its role in an ill-fated proposal to build an oil pipeline through Iraq and Jordan.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included a gain of $362,000 from an accounting change.

title: Peres Says Hint of Bribe Offer Is 'Nonsense'
description: Shimon Peres, the Israeli Foreign Minister, today dismissed as ''nonsense'' reports suggesting that his Labor Party was offered a bribe in 1985 in exchange for a promise not to interfere with the building of a proposed Iraqi pipeline.

title: West Virginia Budget Held Unconstitutional
description: The state Supreme Court declared West Virginia's $1.49 billion budget unconstitutional today because it contains a deficit, and the state auditor's office said all state spending would cease immediately.

title: Gooden Says He's Ready for 'New Start'
description: Dwight Gooden sat in a Washington Redskins T-shirt in the locker room and said it was all behind him - the drugs, the nights cruising around with the guys from the old neighborhood, the hassling over money with the Mets.

title: Hijacking Confession 'Illegal'
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation illegally obtained a Lebanese Shiite Moslem's confession to leading a 1985 plane hijacking during ''relentless interrogation'' that violated his rights.

title: Larry Shay, 90, Dies; Composer and Coach
description: Larry Shay, a composer and musical coach who worked with such stars as Al Jolson and Jimmy Durante and whose best-known song was ''When You're Smiling,'' died of lung cancer on Monday at Hoag Memorial Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: Education; Colleges Grapple With Dark Side of Fraternities
description: The death here of a Rutgers University freshman who drank too much at a fraternity initiation party has increased the edginess of campuses across the nation already grappling with the darker dilemmas of fraternity life.

title: Afghan Rebels Reported Furious Over Rumors of U.S.-Soviet Deal
description: The political leaders of the Afghan guerrilla forces were reported today to be furious with the United States and concerned that Washington and Moscow had already struck a deal in principle on ending the war.

title: MBIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: MBIA in late 1986 became the successor to the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, a consortium of major insurance companies, and thus the 1986 periods are presented on a pro-forma basis as if the reorganization had occurred at the beginning of 1986.

title: Meese and the Pipeline: The Story So Far
description: 1980: War breaks out between Iran and Iraq, and Iran shuts off Iraq's access to the Persian Gulf, through which Iraq had previously shipped most of its oil exports. 1982: Syria, sympathetic to Iran, shuts down an oil pipeline carrying Iraqi oil to the Mediterranean. Iraq, desperate for funds to finance its conflict with Iran, begins shipping its oil across Turkey and Jordan and negotiating with Turkey, Jordan and Saudi Arabia for rights to build permanent pipelines. 1983: Jordanian diplomats ask American officials to obtain Israeli guarantees against attacks on pipelines. The Bechtel Group Inc., the San Francisco-based engineering services company, begins discussions about a pipeline in the Middle East. 1984: Bechtel holds further talks with Jordan and Iraq about the pipeline project, and discusses the plan with the United States Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Jordan and Iraq require additional guarantees that Israel will not sabotage the pipeline, and U.S. officials obtain the requested assurances in the spring of 1984, when Shimon Peres of the Labor Party is Prime Minster. February 1985: Bechtel brings in Bruce Rappaport, a Swiss businessman with connections to Israeli officials, as a partner. A few months later Mr. Rappaport retains E. Robert Wallach, a San Francisco lawyer, to help represent him in the deal. In late February Mr. Rappaport produces a letter from Prime Minister Peres saying Israel won't interfere with the pipeline. May 1985: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, at the request of Mr. Wallach, arranges a meeting for Mr. Rappaport and Mr. Wallach with Robert C. McFarlane, then President Reagan's national security adviser. June 1985: Mr. Wallach and Mr. Rappaport meet with Mr. McFarlane, who endorses the $1 billion pipeline project. Aug. 15, 1985: Mr. Rappaport pays Mr. Wallach $150,000 for his services. >Aug. 31, 1985: Bechtel submits a new proposal to Iraq and Jordan. Sept. 19, 1985: Prime Minister Peres writes a letter to Mr. Meese expressing great interest in the project and saying he intends to it and Israeli guarantees with Secretary of State George Shultz during an October visit to the U.S. Sept. 25, 1985: Mr. Wallach addresses an ''eyes only'' memo to Mr. Meese on the status of the pipeline negotiations, in which he asserts that payments of $65 million to $70 million would be made to Israel, ''a portion'' of which would go directly to the Israeli Labor Party. Oct. 7, 1985: Mr. Meese responds by letter to Mr. Peres's letter of Sept. 19, suggesting that the Prime Minister should confer with Mr. McFarlane, rather than Mr. Shultz, about the pipeline during his U.S. visit because of Mr. Shultz's previous involvement with Bechtel. Oct. 16-24, 1985: Mr. Peres visits Washington and New York and talks with Mr. Meese and National Security Council officials and staff members about the pipeline project. Oct. 17, 1985: The Overseas Private Investment Corporation seeks a ruling from the Justice Department on the legality of assigning Israeli foreign aid from the United States as part of the pipeline's financial security package. Justice Department lawyers subsequently find the assignment of aid to be legally questionable. Late 1985: Israeli and American officials continue to explore ways to arrange financing and a security package for the pipeline. By the end of the year the Jordanians and Iraqis have rejected Bechtel's proposal and President Reagan's new National Security adviser, Adm. John M. Poindexter, has abandoned alternative ways of pledging Israeli funds to the project. May 1987: A special prosecutor, James McKay begins an investigation into the association of Mr. Meese and Mr. Wallach. Late summer 1987: Mr. McKay expands the investigation of Mr. Meese to include the pipeline project. October 1987: First news reports appear concerning Mr. Meese and the pipeline project.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OTF EQUITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: AMERICAN CENTURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; '88 Winter Olympics; Bonnie Blair's Golden Opportunity
description: SHE'S already the Mary Lou Retton and more of these XV Olympic Winter Games. And now Bonnie Blair, the lady leprechaun who seems to have stepped off the drawing board of a Disney artist, has the golden opportunity to win what no American female speed skater ever has: two Olympic gold medals. But she's too smart to talk about another gold, only about the possibility of a silver or a bronze, or both.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15 News analysis: In Nicaragua, political recriminations have become more bitter than at any time since the regional peace accord was signed. The tensions make prospects for an end to the conflict there appear to be dimming. Page A1

title: Rock: Budka Suflera
description: BUDKA SUFLERA, a six-member Polish rock group, made its New York debut on Saturday at the Beacon Theater. Not surprisingly, since much of the world has embraced Anglo-American music as cultural overlord, the group sounded denationalized; even though its members sang in Polish, the group trafficked in a sort of gray rock internationalism. The audience, mostly Polish, acted like rock audiences internationally: there were a few fights, the requisite grumbling that the group wasn't playing its old hits, and a half-hearted rush to the stage, blocked by one very large bouncer.

title: Financial Support For Sail America
description: Dennis Conner's Sail America syndicate picked up some critical financial support yesterday for its planned defense of the America's Cup next summer. Marlboro, joining Pepsi-Cola, became the second of what Conner hopes will be four major sponsors of the $12 million effort.

title: CHICAGO MILWAUKEE ST PAUL & PACIFIC RP., DEBTOR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,704,000 for the quarter and $18,410,000 for the year. c-Includes a loss of $593,000 and a gain of $17,598,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and gains from tax benefits of $6,574,000 and $28,210,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Blazers Keep Nets Mired in Bad Luck
description: The Portland Trail Blazers, one of the better teams in the National Basketball Association this season, played their part in the Nets' disastrous season tonight. They breezed to a 114-102 victory, then left the Byrne Meadowlands Arena before any of the Nets' bad luck could rub off on them.

title: Western States Get a Taste of Prosperity as a Weak Dollar Spurs Exports
description: After three years of troubled times, much of the West is experiencing an economic rebound, spurred by a weaker dollar, which has stimulated exports, as well as increased demand for the wood, minerals, livestock and other commodities produced in the mountains and plains of the region.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and 6 months includes a one-time charge of $5,276,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: LOBLAW COMPANIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; High Court Expands States' Rights To Tidelands Miles From the Ocean
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 3 today that coastal states own or may have some rights to all the lands affected by the ebb and flow of the tides, including land miles from the ocean.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $1,694,000.

title: Sports People; Paxson Traded
description: The Portland Trail Blazers traded their team's career-scoring leader, Jim Paxson, a guard, to the Boston Celtics yesterday for reserve guard Jerry Sichting and unspecified future considerations. Paxson, who became the 30th active player in the National Basketball Association to pass the 10,000-point mark Sunday night, averaged 16 points a game in his eight-plus seasons with Portland. The Trail Blazers would rather have acquired a power forward, but team officials said that Paxson's age, 31, and salary reduced his value on the market. He reportedly earns $850,000 a year with the amount to grow to nearly $1 million next season.

title: Which Hats Are in the Ring?
description: Until this month the image most likely to be evoked by ''he threw his hat into the ring'' was a felt fedora or a straw skimmer. No more. Judging by the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, the hat most apt to be found on a Presidential aspirant's head is the one that proclaims he's just folks. That, surely, is the reason candidates Gephardt and Bush have been sporting duck-billed caps. (The Vice President, who appears to have a large wardrobe, has also worn a Stetson in Texas and a ski cap wherever there's been snow.) The man who wears a duck-billed cap is, by implication, a man who knows how to drive a tractor, gut a fish and fell a tree - useful talents in Iowa and New Hampshire. Campaign attention now turns to Maine, which holds caucuses this week, which means the candidates have to hang on to their duck-bills for a few more days.

title: Greenspan Sees Lag in Economy
description: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, who dominates economic policy-making at present, today predicted a slower but fairly sound economy for this year and indicated that he saw little reason now to help it through such means as cutting interest rates more.

title: Party Guests Stand By As Girl, 17, Is Murdered
description: A 17-year-old Massachusetts girl visiting relatives in Brooklyn was shot to death early yesterday at a party by a man who assaulted her for 30-minutes while other frightened party-goers waited outside an apartment without calling for help, the police said.

title: PHONEMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $204,000 and $601,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $199,000 and $481,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Inmate Escapes From Manhattan Court
description: A man charged with trying to kill police officers escaped from a holding pen at the State Supreme Court building in Manhattan on Monday and was still at large yesterday, officials of the New York City Department of Correction said last night.

title: U.S. Agencies and Foundation Join to Aid Artists
description: Two Federal agencies and a major private foundation have joined forces to get more exposure for American arts and artists at exhibitions and festivals abroad. The joint effort was announced yesterday in New York by officials of the National Endowment for the Arts, the United States Information Agency and the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: SOUTHERNNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $539,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and a $1,650,000 tax credit for the year. c-Net loss and the quarter includes about $2.6 million of expenses associated with the company's merger with Tel-Man Inc. The 1986 results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Telecommunications Systems Inc. in April 1987.

title: Women: Out of the House But Not Out of the Kitchen
description: It has been at least 25 years since women began campaigning to have their husbands share the household chores, but according to a recent New York Times nationwide survey, they have not made much headway. A quarter of a century after Betty Friedan wrote ''The Feminine Mystique,'' the book credited with igniting the feminist movement, women are still doing almost all the cooking and grocery shopping.

title: A.T.&T.'s Unix Is a Hit at Last, And Other Companies Are Wary
description: AFTER nearly 20 years of unfulfilled promise under the wing of its creator, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Unix computer operating system is becoming a hit, emerging with the potential to establish an industry standard.

title: Winfield Is Wasting No Time Getting Into Camp Routine
description: In past springs, he has been among the later arrivals in camp, never here on the day the regulars were asked to report, never apparently bothered by the criticism that usually followed. This year, however, Dave Winfield - newly married and perhaps beginning his final season as a Yankee - was on time.

title: Senate Begins Filibuster on Campaign Funds
description: The Senate, stalled for the past week over whether to take up a bill changing the system of financing Senate campaigns, today began its first round-the-clock filibuster in 10 years.

title: HEALTH CONCEPTS IV reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Big East Notebook; Directors Approve A Ban for Brawling
description: In response to a string of bench-clearing brawls in the Big East Conference this season, Commissioner Dave Gavitt and the league's athletic directors approved legislation yesterday that calls for an automatic one-game suspension of any player leaving the bench to participate in a fight or any player ejected for fighting.

title: Attorney General Clouseau
description: Edwin Meese has not been shown to violate criminal laws, but newly released correspondence shows the Attorney General again behaving like Peter Sellers's Inspector Clouseau in the ''Pink Panther'' movies - a bumbler unable to detect mischief before his very eyes.

title: Pop: Michael Jackson Opens Tour
description: The electronic image of two unmistakable, scoreboard-high legs, strutting across the stage, opened Michael Jackson's first United States tour here tonight at a sold-out Kemper Arena. Those legs, as much as the hits that made Mr. Jackson's ''Thriller'' the best-selling album in pop history and his new ''Bad,'' a top-10 album since its release in 1987, were the centerpiece of a show that reaffirms Mr. Jackson's place as one of pop's most brilliant live performers. Those legs shimmied, kicked, twitched, rose on their toes, moon-walked; they even pedaled air as Mr. Jackson lay on his back.

title: Bridge: Son of Nobel Prize Winner Is Famed in His Own Right
description: Fame is a funny thing. Two decades ago a middle-aged man checked into a hotel and the clerk seemed excited when he read the name.

title: ARMY TO DESTROY OLD CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The Army will dispose of its aging stockpile of chemical weapons by burning them in closed incinerators to be built at the eight sites where the chemicals are now stored, a top official said today.

title: Advertising; In Richmond, A Shop Tests Path to Fame
description: LAST night was a big one for the Richmond advertising community. The Advertising Club announced the winners of its Addy Awards at a black-tie-optional banquet at the Marriott. Everybody who is anybody was there.

title: U.S. and Rome Back Relocating of F-16's From Spain to Italy
description: The United States and Italy have reached preliminary agreement on relocating the 72 American F-16 jet fighters now in Spain to a base in Italy, senior diplomats from the two countries said today.

title: MOORE CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,798,000 for the quarter and $29,883,000 for the year. The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Southdown Chief Goes From Seller to Bidder
description: About a year ago, Southdown Inc., a Houston-based cement maker, was looking for a buyer. The company's president, Clarence C. Comer, was approached by the head of Moore McCormack Resources Inc., a Stamford, Conn., cement maker who thought the two businesses would make a good combination.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $28,700,000 reflecting adoption of new accounting rules for income taxes. c-Net loss The company said the year-ago quarter was affected by a strike.

title: Pop: Tackhead At the Ritz
description: TACKHEAD'S first three songs at the Ritz on Saturday re-emphasized its status as one of the finest rhythm sections of the 1980's. Skip McDonald on guitar, Doug Wimbish on bass, and Keith LeBlanc on drums - the core of the famed early rap label Sugarhill Records - put on an astonishingly hard show; the beat sounded like a thousand iron doors shutting at once.

title: New Stock Is Issued By Irving
description: In another move that could thwart the Bank of New York's $1.08 billion hostile takeover bid, the Irving Bank Corporation announced yesterday that it had issued $100.1 million of preferred stock to 15 investors.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year included a $95 million gain from the sale of 20 percent of Homestake Gold of Australia Ltd. The latest year also included a $5.7 million gain on the sale of exploration properties in New Zealand and South Dakota. The prior full-year earnings included about $8 million from the settlement of natural gas contract disputes. All share earnings reflect the company's 2-for-1 stock split in November 1987.

title: Choosing Health Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Engineer Joins Thiokol
description: Judson A. Lovingood, a space shuttle rocket engineer who on the day before the Challenger explosion voiced concern about the launching, has retired from the space agency to join the company that built the shuttle's booster rockets.

title: Sharpton: Champion or Opportunist?
description: When Governor Cuomo met two weeks ago with representatives of a 16-year-old black Dutchess County girl who says she was abducted and sexually assaulted by six white men, the Rev. Al Sharpton was there.

title: Connecticut Bonds Attract Investors
description: The thin supply of tax-exempt issues in the marketplace was evident in the yields of a $125 million issue of Connecticut special tax obligation bonds priced yesterday to offer a maximum yield of 7.347 percent for an issue due in 2008.

title: Sports People; Cub Games at Night?
description: A City Council committee in Chicago has approved an ordinance drawn up by Mayor Eugene Sawyer's staff that would allow the Cubs to play eight night games at Wrigley Field this season and 18 next season. But opponents of night games at the field, the only major-league stadium without lights, criticized the proposed ordinance as a betrayal of community interests. ''It contains no specific measures for limiting impact on the neighborhood,'' said Mike Quigley, a member of Citizens United for Baseball in the Sunshine. ''It men-tions no dollars for creating new parking spaces or clean-up services. Since the ordinance contains no ap-propriations language. Its provisions are basically unenforceable.'' The or-dinance is scheduled to go before the full Council today.

title: Denver Journal; Center Attends to Cancer's Other Toll
description: Silence ruled the Langford house for nearly two years. When Lezlie Langford mentioned her sick sister's name, her father, Ken, would walk away. ''I just crept into a corner and wouldn't react to anything,'' he recalled.

title: Black & Decker Raises Standard Bid
description: The pressure on American Standard Inc. tightened yesterday as the Black & Decker Corporation raised its takeover bid to $68 a share, or $2.1 billion.

title: While the Dollar Falls, Paris Bistros and Brasseries Surge
description: AMERICAN travelers, victimized by two ruthless pickpockets in the past year -the falling dollar and the plunging stock market - seem to have lost their appetite for stellar French restaurants. Instead, they are seeking out more affordable fare in brasseries and bistros.

title: The Dinner Party Quietly Bows To More Casual Alternatives
description: ANDREA GROVER, who lives in West Orange, N.J., is adding a dining room to her home and redoing her kitchen so that she can have dinner parties more comfortably. That makes her something of an anomaly among her friends, who rarely entertain guests at dinner.

title: COMPUCOM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the revenue in the latest periods include the operations of Tristar Data Systems Inc. and Office Automation Inc., since their acquisition as of July 1.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE is something to be said for spending $32 in a Paris hotel for a breakfast of grapefruit juice, two eggs and coffee: it steels one for what is to come.

title: Egyptian Art Treasures Need Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Botanical Garden Plans an Expansion
description: The New York Botanical Garden is planning an ambitious expansion that will include a new plant science center and the renovation of its landmark museum building in the Bronx to house exhibitions.

title: Florence Journal; The City's of Two Minds on Digging Up the Past
description: ''This city is like a very beautiful woman who gets nausea everytime someone takes a long look at her.'' That alarming diagnosis came from a man who is single-handedly giving Florence a prolonged case of upset stomach, Francesco Nicosia, Tuscany's Superintendent of Archeology.

title: Byzantine Stratagems Made Simple
description: When military officers arrive from the field for duty in the Defense Department, they are often bewildered, frustrated and sometimes dismayed by the bureaucratic ethic that pervades the corridors of the Pentagon.

title: High Court Hears Challenge to New York Curb on Men's Clubs
description: A skeptical Supreme Court today heard a constitutional challenge to a New York City law intended to force some of the country's most prestigious men's clubs to admit women as members.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
David Otis Fuller, 84, Fundamentalist Pastor
description: The Rev. David Otis Fuller, a fundamentalist preacher who helped establish a children's radio ministry and the Grand Rapids Baptist College and Seminary, has died at the age of 84.

title: Indians Are Said to Kill 20 Tamils In Sri Lanka After Troops Slain
description: Indian troops shot and killed 20 ethnic Tamil civilians today after 4 soldiers died in an ambush by Tamil rebels, Sri Lankan military officials said.

title: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included a $2,246,000 charge resulting from the sale of a controlling interest in MSA Africa Ltd. Mine Safety said the charge primarily represents a transfer of prior years' cumulative currency translation losses to the income statement.

title: Limits Imposed on Smoker
description: A woman who said she smokes just to annoy her estranged husband has been ordered not to light up in front of him or their three children and to confine her smoking to one room of their house. The order, from Justice Ralph Diamond of State Supreme Court, involves Elizabeth Roofeh, 41 years old, of Kings Point, L.I. Her husband, Jahanshah, a non-smoking orthopedic surgeon, went to court to get her to stop smoking around the family. Mrs. Roofeh filed for divorce last May. ''I smoke just to annoy him,'' she said last year. ''I'll quit when I get him out of the house.''

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
Oliver Swan, 83, Literary Agent With Eye for Worthy Unknowns
description: Oliver G. Swan, a literary agent whose career spanned almost 40 years, died of pneumonia yesterday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 83 years old. Among the authors he represented were Conrad Richter, Richard Wright, Morris West, Alex Hailey and the estate of Henry James.

title: Central America Budges
description: The underlying issue in countries of Central America is not the ideological and security question of the Washington debate, although their high officials have learned to echo it to please Americans. It is whether the region is finally beginning to change, to emerge from what the Nicaraguan anti-Sandinista Arturo Cruz Jr. has called his country's ''100 Years of Turpitude,'' a play on the novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez's title ''100 Years of Solitude.''

title: '88 Winter Olympics; Nykaenen Jumps For a Second Gold
description: Matti Nykaenen of Finland scored an overpowering victory in the 90-meter jump today, completing a first-ever sweep of the ski-jumping events at the Winter Olympics.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Europe Meat Ban Voided
description: The European Court of Justice today voided a 1985 European Community law banning the marketing of hormone-treated meat in the 12-nation trade bloc.

title: BRE PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of investments of $1,353,000, or 17 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: ISOMEDIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects restructuring charges of $266,000 for the quarter and $436,000 for the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Foodmaker Inc.'s purchase of Chi-Chi's Inc. misstated the price to be paid for each share. Foodmaker will pay $10.15 a share, or a total of $230 million, for the chain of Mexican restaurants.

title: SMUCKER J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
11 Off Broadway Shows To Help AIDS Fund
description: Box-office receipts from special Monday night performances added to the schedules of 11 Off Broadway shows are to be donated to the Equity Fights AIDS Fund, a nonprofit fund established by the actors' union to provide direct financial help to members who have the disease.

title: '88 Winter Olympics; In Hockey, 5 Teams Take Aim at the 6th
description: There is nothing surprising about the identity of the six hockey teams that will open the Olympic medal round Wednesday. And as has been the rarely broken rule since the Soviet Union began sending a hockey team to the Olympics some 30 years ago, the Russians will be defending their gold medal.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Ozzie Newsome, the career leader in receptions among tight ends in the National Football League, sayid he will attempt to play another season with the Cleveland Browns. ''I don't have anything to accomplish individually,'' Newsome said. ''I'm playing to provide the role - whatever it is -to help this team win the Super Bowl.'' . . . It's four down and one to go for the Duquesne basketball team after the team lost its starting forward, Brian Shanahan, who suffered a severe ankle sprain in practice. Shanahan is not expected back until the Atlantic 10 tournament begins on March 5. The injury cuts the roster to nine players, including Clayton Adams, the only starter left from the opening game. . . . The Cleveland Cavaliers made an expected roster move yesterday, placing veteran Kent Benson on the injured list and activating Johnny Rogers. Benson, a 6-foot-10-inch center, has an inflamed right elbow and will be out for at least one week. The hyperextended elbow caused him to miss the first 41 games of the season. Rogers, a 6-9 forward, had been on the injured list with a sprained left ankle and missed the last 12 games.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: Prior 12 months reflect a decrease in earnings of $43,741,076, or 78 cents a share, from the December 1986 provision for the coal mining operations fund.

title: 800 Attend Mass for Nicaraguan
description: More than 800 people gathered last night in St. Patrick's Cathedral for a memorial Mass for Nora Astorga, Nicaragua's chief delegate to the United Nations, who died of cancer last week at the age of 39.

title: Salute to a Chief
description: She is 278 feet long, has a cruising range of 10,800 nautical miles, carries the nation's most advanced navigation, communication and laboratory facilities and will soon be renamed The N.O.A.A. Ship Malcolm Baldrige.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: DEVELOPING a taste for one food or another may depend on the context in which that food is eaten. I know several baseball buffs who consider a hot dog with sauerkraut absolutely vital at a game. And yet these same people look on a platter of sauerkraut, using the pickled vegetable as the focal point of a main course, with something that borders on contempt.

title: IOWA SOUTHERN UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,928,179 from an accounting change.

title: Ex-Judge Who Was at Center Of Scandal Is Guilty of Perjury
description: A former assistant county judge who was at the center of misconduct charges against three State Supreme Court judges has been convicted of lying under oath.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,702,000 from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles and also includes $350,000 from resolution during the fourth quarter of gas contract demand issues affecting the company's Peoples Natural Gas division. Utilicorp said the resolution should have a positive impact on future net income of about $4.2 million annually.

title: Houston
description: FEW of Houston's best-known restaurants are in quaint brownstones or at sidewalk level with a view of passing pedestrians. Instead, they are in the hundreds of small shopping malls that are synonymous with this city. Tony's is in a strip shopping center, as is its brother restaurant, Anthony's; both are owned by Tony Vallone. Rivoli is in a shopping center. So are Uncle Tai's and Casablanca.

title: Want to Dine at a Hot Restaurant? Call Early and Often
description: BOOKING a table at one of the most popular restaurants in New York has become as complicated and onerous as making a reservation for one of those maxsaver air fares. Telephone lines are busy; restrictions are many; weekend seats are few; reconfirmation is essential; reservations are accepted only at certain hours on certain days. And at a few places you must forfeit a deposit if you fail to cancel.

title: All-Terrain Vehicle 'Critic' With a Curious Client
description: To the Editor:

title: Injury Riddled Islanders Win
description: Denis Potvin, who has played defense for almost every minute of his 15 years in the National Hockey League, treated his extended service on offense tonight as second nature. Greg Gilbert, who has rarely, if ever, played defense well in his life, treated his brief stint behind the blue line more as an amusing experiment.

title: '88 Winter Olympics; Soviet Gets Gold In Ice Dancing
description: The Soviet Union made its Olympic superiority in the couples events in figure skating complete tonight when Natalya Bestemianova and Sergei Bukin, the world champions of the last three years, won the gold medal in dance.

title: QVC NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1,341,000. c-Net loss

title: Biden Needs 2d Operation
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who underwent surgery on Feb. 12 to repair an aneurysm in an artery supplying blood to his brain, left Walter Reed Army Medical Center today, but officials said he will require another operation to correct a second aneurysm. Larry Rasky, a spokesman for the Biden family, said the 45-year-old Delaware Democrat would not return to his Washington office until he had recovered from the second operation, which has not yet been scheduled.

title: Advertising; Baltimore Agency Adds 2 Health Care Accounts
description: Eisner & Associates, a 49-year-old Baltimore agency with $46 million in billings, is adding not only to its client list but also to its life expectancy with the acquisition of $2 million worth of health-related accounts.

title: Education; Campus Notebook; Applications for College Running at Record Pace
description: Whatever happened to those gloom-and-doom warnings that these would be the years when colleges would have to tighten their belts - if not close down entirely - because of a decline in the college-age population?

title: FOOD NOTES
description: E.A.T. Adds an Oven

title: Disparities of Rich and Poor Prompt Gifts to the Neediest
description: Natalia Somers came from Russia and she loves the freedom of New York, according to her husband, Thomas Milo Somers of Manhattan.

title: In Budget War, Some Fall Amid Din and Others Go in Silence
description: James H. Webb Jr. and James R. Ambrose could not be more different, but the nation's troubled military budget has woven a fateful common thread into their final weeks at the Pentagon.

title: F.B.I. Admits Informer Misled Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that it had been repeatedly misled by an undercover informer whose information led to a two-year surveillance campaign against Americans opposed to the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: A Computer Traffic Cop
description: Anyone who has ever given a computer a command and received a response, intelligible or not, has used a computer operating system. People who seek to explain computers to the unintiated often search for operating system metaphors. A traffic cop is a common one. Another is a super-efficient office manager. A stage manager is another. So is the orchestra conductor.

title: THE PIPELINE DRAMA: 5 ACTORS
description: Edwin Meese 3d: A longtime associate of Ronald Reagan who became counselor to President Reagan in 1981, and Attorney General in February 1985. Backers of the pipeline project sought his aid in obtaining United States Government support for their plans. Bruce Rappaport: A Swiss businessman based in Geneva, who has close ties to officials in Israel, including Shimon Peres. Mr. Rappaport, a partner in the pipeline project with the Bechtel Group, Inc., was responsible for security and financial arrangements. E. Robert Wallach: A San Francisco lawyer and college classmate of Mr. Meese, who represented the Attorney General during his confirmation hearings. He was hired in 1985 by Mr. Rappaport, a partner in the project. Mr. Wallach was indicted in December for conspiring to win contracts for the Wedtech Corp., a Bronx military contractor, including efforts to influence Mr. Meese. He has pleaded not guilty to the charges. Shimon Peres: Prime Minister of Israel from September 1984 to October 1986. He became involved in the pipeline project in February 1985 when he wrote a letter to Mr. Rappaport expressing Israel's intention not to attack the pipeline. Now Foreign Minister, he is the head of Israel's Labor Party. Bechtel Group Inc.: The giant privately-held San Francisco-based engineering and construction services company. A Bechtel susbsidiary was going to manage the construction and engineering of the pipeline. Bechtel entered into a joint venture with Mr. Rappaport in 1985.

title: San Francisco
description: CALIFORNIA'S passion for food includes an insatiable curiosity about its historic and cultural aspects, as seen in the following events around the state.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $43,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter, and the year includes a $1,000,000 tax credit. c-Net loss and after losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $368,000 and $7,181,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $6,299,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Opera: 'Khovanshchina'
description: IT'S an unbelievable story, really.

title: SWAGGART ACTION RELATIVELY LIGHT
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart was apparently given relatively mild discipline for his ''moral failure'' because he did not confess adultery, according to a source familiar with church disciplinary matters.

title: In a Clean Glass
description: A mind in search of an idea:

title: Boxing Notebook; King Hoping to Do Business in Soviet
description: When Don King says that the Soviet Union is moving forward ''under the dynamic leadership of Gorbachev,'' the antennae of a boxing observer raise up.

title: First Commodity Settlement
description: The Midamerica Commodity Exchange and the First Commodity Corporation of Boston have agreed to a $3.5 million settlement ending all fraud litigation against First Commodity, the exchange said Monday.

title: '88 Winter Olympics; East German Wins 2d Gold in Biathlon
description: Frank-Peter Roetsch of East Germany won the 10-kilometer biathlon today and became the first man ever to sweep the individual Olympic biathlon events.

title: A Dispute With Religious Overtones
description: The southern rim of Soviet Transcaucasia, the focal point of recent nationalist demonstrations, is an arid mountainous region crisscrossed by ancient scars of geology and the more recent scars of Islamic-Christian friction.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Owens Illinois
description: The Federal Trade Commission asked a Federal appeals court today to prevent Owens-Illinois Inc., the nation's second-largest glass container manufacturer, from acquiring Brockway Inc. for $750 million while it appeals a lower court's refusal to halt the deal. The F.T.C. contends that the merger, which would create the nation's largest glass container manufacturer, would reduce competition and raise the price of bottles, jars and other containers the companies make for foods and drinks. Owens-Illinois controls 22.7 percent of the market, while Brockway holds 15 percent.

title: Bahrain Offers Rare Welcome to U.S. in Gulf
description: The rains that drenched Bahrain last weekend were a good omen for the people of this dry desert land, but they nearly ruined the American Fourth of July celebration.

title: Economic Scene; A Little Daylight On the Deficits
description: VIRTUE is nice, but sometimes luck will suffice: Four months and much hand-wringing after the October crash, the United States economy seems no worse for wear. In fact, there is growing reason to think that the stock plunge may actually protect the nation from a dollar crisis that would cut deeply into income and employment.

title: Channel 13 Executive To Head Public Radio
description: Stephen L. Salyer, a senior vice president at Channel 13, has been named president of American Public Radio, effective April 1. He succeeds Al Hulsen, who resigned last August.

title: 56 G.O.P. Legislators Urge Jersey Milk Suit
description: The 56 Republicans in the Assembly urged Attorney General Robert Abrams today to sue New Jersey to break what the legislators said are that state's barriers to the sale of New York milk.

title: SBARRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
20 Senators Ask Reagan for Guarantees on Canada Pact
description: A group of 20 Senators, most from Western states, called on President Reagan today to provide guarantees that Canada will end subsidies to its natural resource producers as American tariffs are lowered under a free-trade pact recently concluded by the two Governments.

title: HMSS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GEPHARDT, DUKAKIS SPLIT TWO RACES AMONG DEMOCRATS
description: Richard A. Gephardt won the South Dakota Democratic primary yesterday, defeating Michael S. Dukakis in a race that both men had counted on for a lift in the two weeks before the crucial day when 20 states, mostly in the South, hold nominating contests.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Drops by 1.17 Points
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.17 points to close at 2,039.12, but many issues moved higher.

title: Women at Home
description: To The Living Section:

title: GV MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Caspar Weinberger, G.B.E.
description: Former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger became an honorary knight today. Queen Elizabeth II bestowed the medals on Mr. Weinberger in a simple ceremony at Buckingham Palace, but that does not mean he can call himself Sir Caspar. The title Caspar Weinberger, G.B.E. will have to do. He received the gold cross of the Order of the British Empire and the silver star of a Knight Grand Cross.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I APPLIED to college barely a year after the '68 student uprisings. It was a difficult time for my parents. I was opposed to the war in Vietnam in a uninformed way, and my parents were not opposed to it, with a kind of reflexive patriotism that most adults still had then.

title: Robertson Emerges as Superstar of Super Tuesday Spending
description: Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign has spent some $3.1 million in the 17 states with Republican primaries or caucuses March 8, about $1.1 million more than any other Republican.

title: Gore Now Favors Carriers and Draws Attack by Gephardt
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. said today in Norfolk, Va., where two new aircraft carriers are being constructed, that he was the only Democratic Presidential candidate who was in favor of building the carriers.

title: President Is Named At Continental Can
description: Robert A. Fox contends that microwave foods will provide the greatest growth for the packaging industry and that research and development in this field will become his priority.

title: '88 Winter Olympics; Corporate Rivalry Far From Calgary Over Games Logo
description: What is the difference between an official Olympic sponsor that advertises on an Olympic telecast and a sponsor of an official Olympic telecast? Between $5 million and $15 million, by one reckoning. Some special sauce and a sesame seed bun by another.

title: Market Place; More Retail Takeovers Seen
description: IF the takeover battle between Federated Department Stores and Campeau is any example of an unlikely set of opponents, as many as 15 other retail companies are being viewed as acquisition targets regardless of their size, internal strengths or weaknesses.

title: Don't Overrate Our Nuclear Arsenal's Safety; Defenses Are Feasible
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Finalists Are Named For Hemingway Award
description: Writers from three nations - Toni Morrison of the United States, Nadine Gordimer of South Africa and Michael Ondaatje of Canada - were named as the finalists for the $50,000 Ritz Paris Hemingway Award yesterday. The prize, for the best novel published in English during 1987, will be presented April 11 at the Ritz Hotel in Paris.

title: A Bug to Help Out On Gravy Stains
description: The latest news from the detergent industry's never-ending war on stains is that biotechnology has produced an enzyme that will split fatty acids. This means that those troublesome gravy spots that won't come out in the laundry (not to mention the lipstick stains on a collar that a teen-age heartthrob sang about a generation ago) may finally yield.

title: Takeover Talks For Public Service
description: A Massachusetts electric holding company has begun talks aimed at taking over the ailing Public Service Company of New Hampshire, except for its 36 percent share of the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant, a Public Service spokesman said.

title: Education; A Career-Improvement Tax Break Ends
description: After becoming a telephone service representative four years ago, Tanya Davis took several courses in journalism and magazine publishing to pursue her dream of a career in the field.

title: Chambers's Fingers Were Bitten, Doctor Testifies
description: Almost 24 hours after Jennifer Levin died, the hands of Robert E. Chambers Jr. were ''inflamed, swollen, red and tender'' from human bites that had broken the skin on three fingers, a doctor who treated him testified yesterday.

title: Israel's Main Goals, And Mr. Shultz's
description: The peace journey of Secretary of State George P. Shultz has had a salutary influence even before the takeoff. It has stimulated currents of thought that were previously held in the grip of prolonged inertia.

title: Rates Move Lower On Citicorp Paper
description: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company said it had sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.567 percent, down from 6.625 percent last week.

title: Drop in U.S. Steel Jobs
description: Employment in the nation's steel industry fell in 1987 to its lowest level in at least 54 years, but wages increased slightly, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. An average of 163,300 people, including 120,900 production workers, were employed in the steel industry in 1987, the lowest number since records were first kept in 1933, the institute said. As recently as the late 1970's an average of 450,000 workers were employed in the industry, but significant improvements in operating efficiency and the reduction in United States steelmaking capacity because of a flood of imports prompted the decline. In 1987 steel employees were paid hourly average salaries of $23.71 an hour, covering all employment costs.

title: Healthful Eating as a Way of Life
description: TO the public, Sidney Wolfe is someone who has taken on the Food and Drug Administration, the food industry, pharmaceutical companies and anyone else he thinks is not giving the public a fair shake when it comes to health and safety. He directs the Public Citizen Health Research Group, a consumer organization in Washington that he founded with Ralph Nader in 1971.

title: SHOREWOOD PACKAGING reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes charges of $46,000 and $175,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the writeoff of deferred debt acquisition costs as a result of pre-payment of certain long term debt. Average shares are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in the form of a dividend in October 1987.

title: Walden Theater Group To Offer 'Corner Boys'
description: ''Corner Boys,'' a play by James Himelsbach about four young men coming of age in the 1960's, is to be presented by the Walden Theater Company weekends through March 5 at the 1010 Theater, Park Avenue Christian Church, Park Avenue and 85th Street.

title: WEYENBERG SHOE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Government to Yield Its 'Golden Share' of Britoil
description: The British Government said today that it would relinquish its ''golden share'' of Britoil P.L.C., removing a major roadblock to the British Petroleum Company's takeover of the independent North Sea oil company.

title: Guitar: Larry Almeida
description: ''TEMPERAMENTS,'' a short guitar composition in five sections by Leslie Bassett, had its New York premiere Monday at a Merkin Concert Hall recital by Larry Almeida. It is a reasonably attractive piece that seems to wander at times; it also provided a concise summary of the strengths and weaknesses of Mr. Almeida's playing through the rest of the evening. The guitarist is an assistant dean at the North Carolina School of the Arts, and he has studied with several eminent practitioners on his instrument. His program evinced an earnest care for new music, a sound command of technique and a style that tends to the reticent.

title: State Department Asks Reagan to Penalize Panama Over Drug Trafficking
description: Rejecting the conclusions of its bureau in charge of drugs, the State Department has recommended that President Reagan penalize Panama for failing to take adequate steps to control drug trafficking, State Department aides said today.

title: Goldwater Tells Mecham: Go Back to Car Business
description: Former Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the impeached Governor, Evan Mecham, should go back to selling cars, and he said his endorsement of the auto dealer in the 1986 election had been a mistake.

title: Questions and Answers In the Brawley Inquiry
description: Three months ago today, 15-year-old Tawana Brawley vanished after stepping off a bus near her home in Wappingers Falls, N.Y. Four days later, the black high school junior was found nearby, brutalized, incoherent and covered with excrement and scrawled racial epithets. Repeated efforts to gain her testimony have been stymied by disputes over who should investigate the case. The grotesque mystery has ignited charges of racism in the Hudson Valley - a second big civil-rights rally is set for Saturday - and thrown shadows of suspicion on law-enforcement officials in Dutchess County. Few clear facts have emerged. Here are some major questions and answers based on available information.

title: Kodak-Fuqua Deal Blocked
description: A Federal judge has issued a temporary injunction blocking the Eastman Kodak Company's deal to merge its photofinishing operations with those of Fuqua Industries of Atlanta. United States District Judge

title: POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $800,000. c-Net income

title: Advertising; Private 18-to-34 Survey Widens NBC Audience
description: Like undocumented aliens who go uncounted in the census, viewers who watch television in public places like pubs and college dorms are not recorded by A. C. Nielsen, the great enumerator of audiences.

title: TEXACO WILL PAY $1.2 BILLION TO U.S. FOR OVERCHARGES
description: Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to pay the Energy Department $1.25 billion to settle a complaint that it had overcharged customers for crude oil and refined oil products between 1973 and 1981, when Federal price controls were in effect.

title: Corrections
description: A chart of Olympic medal winners in Sports Pages yesterday gave an incorrect nationality for Sigrid Wolf, the winner of the women's Super G race. She is from Austria, not France.

title: Williamsburg, Va.
description: ''WILLIAMSBURG was a sophisticated little urban area in the 18th century,'' said Rosemary Brandau, manager of historic food programs at Colonial Williamsburg here. ''All the local and imported food sources meant that the finest tables could be set here.''

title: It's Citrus That Puts Zest in the Cuisines of Many Cultures
description: ORANGE juice may be the American breakfast beverage of choice, and grapefruit is certainly the dieter's delight, but when it comes to cooking with citrus fruits, as a nation we lack imagination.

title: Stage: 'Esther: A Vaudeville Megillah'
description: PURIM is one of the most joyful of Jewish holidays, and it is also a time of tomfoolery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
description: Companies

title: WESTMARK INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $3.9 million charge for employee severance and office closure costs from the consolidation of the company's international and domestic ultrasound operations; also includes a $5.6 million charge for the revaluation of international (non- U.S.) ultrasound inventories. The charge primarily reflects the adoption of uniform accounting practices by Westmark's foreign subsidiaries, which are consistent with those followed by its domestic operations in current and prior years, for the provision of obsolescence and other valuation reserves. c-Includes pretax reorganization costs of $3,949,000. d-Includes an international tax credit of $1,607,000. The company said it incurred a charge in the latest quarter and restated its results for 1986 following a review of the procedures that have been used to determine the consolidated cost of its international ultrasound cost of its international ultrasound inventories. It said that as a result of this review, it determined that an overstatement of the cost of such inventories and previously reported pretax income had occurred totaling $4.8 million in 1986 and $2.5 million in 1987. These amounts were charged to the fourth quarter results of each year.

title: Soviet Reports Major Unrest In Armenian Areas in South
description: The Soviet Union today reported major Armenian nationalist disturbances in an ethnically volatile area in the southern part of the country.

title: Japanese Weigh Backing a Harlem Project
description: A contingent of Japanese real-estate executives, visiting New York City yesterday, said it was considering an investment in Harlem on the Hudson, a huge development that would transform 40 acres of Harlem riverfront into a center of new housing, business and cultural events.

title: Home Sweet Home As Knicks Prevail
description: The Knicks committed 26 turnovers last night. Earlier in the season that would have spelled almost certain defeat. But these are different Knicks. They still do not have any player they can count on to give them a big game, but they have learned to cover up for their errors with outstanding defense and they have learned to win consistently on their home court.

title: Sports People; Johnson Honored
description: When he broke the world record for the 100-meter dash at the world track and field championships in Rome last summer, Ben Johnson of Canada did so in 9.83 seconds, shaving a full 10th of a second off the previous mark. It was the kind of stunning performance worthy of another sprinter, Jesse Owens, more than 50 years ago. So it was not unnatural that last night, Johnson was awarded the Jesse Owens International Trophy for athletic excellence in 1987. Johnson shrugged off his achievement yesterday, saying, ''I wasn't surprised about my time. I had run that fast in practices. The best thing about the race was that I won it.'' The 26-year-old Jamaican-born sprinter from Toronto has finished first in his last 26 races and in 37 of his last 38, not counting qualifying heats.

title: FORMICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $8,506,000. The company said the extraordinary charge in 1987 resulted from the premium paid in June 1987 to retire an issue of 16.5 percent subordinated notes.

title: Sale by Federated Of Unit Held Near
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. stock inched up 12.5 cents yesterday to close at $60.875, a tick away from the $61-a-share tender offer by the Campeau Corporation. Reports persisted that Federated was close to a sale of its Ralphs Grocery Company supermarket chain in California.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Feb. 8 with an article about the 25 largest bank holding companies in the United States omitted one company. Marine Midland Banks Inc. had assets of $25.5 billion on Dec. 31, and should have been ranked 22d.

title: '88 Winter Olympics; Multinational Bazaar on Alpine Slopes
description: Olympic skiers clump through the machine-made snow, traversing past spectators who are trading pins, munching on hot dogs and hamburgers or simply taking in the sights. Olympic flags and those of the participating nations flutter in brisk winds at the base of Mount Allan, but appear tranquil considering the Ice Station Zebra conditions that often exist at the top.

title: Music: Thomas Hampson
description: THOMAS HAMPSON, the American baritone who has been making such a good impression in lyric roles at the Metropolitan Opera recently, came to Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon with an interestingly chosen program of Haydn (English canzonets), Meyerbeer, Debussy and a series of songs based on ''Des Knaben Wunderhorn,'' one of the folk anthologies that redirected German poetry in the 18th century. Geoffrey Parsons accompanied with fluent, easy authority; Mr. Hampson sang with elegance and intelligence. It was a satisfying recital.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Stage: Bergman Version Of Ibsen's 'Doll's House'
description: ''NORA,'' Ingmar Bergman's stripped-down adaptation of ''A Doll's House,'' is akin to an opera composed entirely of arias. Having eliminated the Helmer children and servants, he offers two hours of confrontations.

title: Justices Bar Some Suits By Union Benefit Plans
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 8 to 0, that multi-employer union benefit plans may not sue companies in a Federal court for refusing to make contributions after expiration of a collective bargaining agreement.

title: Stage: 'Struttin',' a Musical of Struggle
description: INNOCENT Ida Mae from Asbury Park, N. J., learns so much so quickly in wicked New York cabarets in the 1920's that it's no trick at all for her to cross the pond and become the queen of the naughty nightclubs of the Paris of the 30's. Ah, but the feisty black entertainer has perils to face and troubles to overcome along the way in Lee Chamberlin's musical, ''Struttin','' being presented at the Amas Repertory Theatre. Even at the end a new threat looms, but by then we know she has the strength to triumph, no matter what the challenge.

title: KEY RATES
Gene Rambo, Cowboy, 67
description: Gene Rambo, a former world champion cowboy, died Sunday of an apparently accidental self-inflicted shooting. He was 67. Mr. Rambo apparently was trying to climb a fence when the trigger of his rifle caught and the weapon fired, said Tom Crompton, a Monterey County deputy coroner.

Kalikow, the developer, has revived his efforts to build a new apartment tower on the site of a historic East River apartment block, this time with plans to erect the tallest building on the Upper East Side. But the plan is drawing the same angry opposition from residents and neighborhood leaders that defeated his previous efforts to build at the site.

title: Anti-Defamation League Honors Vuitton for What It Didn't Do
description: No one knows how the rumors began, but they have plagued and pained the Louis Vuitton company since the early 1970's. In New York and Paris, word spread that the purveyor of luxury goods had run employment ads in French newspapers that said, ''Israelites S'Abstenir.'' (''Jews Need Not Apply.'') In 1974, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith investigated and found the rumors groundless. Still the slanders persisted and were even elaborated to include charges that Jewish customers were treated shabbily at Vuitton boutiques. Subsequent investigations by the league also found those allegations to be untrue.

title: Hampshire College Students Present List of 12 Demands
description: About 100 students of Hampshire College who took over a dormitory office to protest racism, marched across campus today to present a list of 12 demands to the college president.

title: Kramer Acquitted
description: It took only a little more than an hour yesterday for a jury in Minneapolis to acquit Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota Vikings' quarterback, of a drunken-driving charge. Kramer was arrested last July 24 after leaving a restaurant in Bloomington, a Minneapolis suburb. Three police officers testified that Kramer's car was weaving on the road and that, after he was stopped, he had trouble with a balance test and reciting the alphabet. The police also said Kramer refused to take a blood-alcohol test. Kramer said he declined the test because he thought the traffic stop was without merit. After the verdict was announced, one of the jurors, John McDonald, said, ''There was a credibility problem with the police department. They didn't come off very well on the stand.'' Kramer, 32 years old, was arrested for a similar offense in Houston in 1980 and underwent chemical-dependency treatment in California two years later. After his arrest in July, he underwent treatment for alcohol abuse at the Hazelden Foundation in Minnesota.

title: Konroyd is Sidelined
description: Steve Konroyd, the valuable defenseman for the Islanders, has a fractured orbital rim above one eye as well as a fractured frontal sinus. He was hit in the face with a puck Sunday in Hartford and is expected to miss three weeks. The loss of Konroyd is just one more setback for the Islanders, who have been troubled by injuries in recent weeks. Tomas Jonsson, another defenseman, left the game Tuesday against Vancouver after one period because of a thigh bruise and will not play in tonight against the Blackhawks. Gord Dineen, a defenseman who had missed the team's most recent seven games with a sprained ankle, is listed as possible for tonight.

Federated's stock rose $1.125 a share yesterday, to $62, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Soviet Union Rolls On In Hockey Tournament
description: Canada had perfected its formula, perhaps to the detriment of fun or flair, so that it could be applied like a sort of glue to the styles of other Olympic hockey teams, and expressly to the sinuous machinations of the Soviet Union's team.

title: Steve Martin Honored By Hasty Pudding Club

Don't Sell a Refuge For a Mess of Oil
description: Veiled in a fog of doubletalk, the Senate Energy Committee voted last week on behalf of the oil industry to open up one of the world's great biological reserves to certain environmental degradation for the sake of uncertain profits. The 10 to 9 vote to permit development of the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge was based essentially on two major assumptions, one highly dubious, the other demonstrably false.

title: Tennessee Tops Florida, 65-63
description: Greg Bell of Tennessee hit a jumper from 16 feet with three seconds left tonight as the Volunteers rallied from a 15-point deficit to beat Florida, 65-63, and give Coach Don DeVoe his 300th victory. DeVoe's career record is 300-193.
