title: U.S. Concerned On Coffee Price
description: The United States suspects that coffee is being sold to some nations at a 25 percent discount, the American delegate to the International Coffee Organization, Bruce McMullen, said today. He said the United States wanted the subject discussed when the organization's board meets this week in London.

title: Ice Dancing: Taking a Step Backward
description: Not to worry. The all too frequent debate over whether ice dance is sport or art came to a rest at the Olympics when the free dance program wound up the ice dancing competition. Whatever was on view, it wasn't art.

title: Moslem Patrol Helps Cut Crime in Brooklyn
description: In more than 20 years as a businessman in Brooklyn, Eric Bullen has faced riots and looting and mounting drug-related crime, including more burglaries than he cares to remember. But lately, he says, the sense of siege has been reduced, and he has noticed something unusual: customers browsing casually at the windows of his men's clothing store on Fulton Street.

title: BEAR HUNTING CASE YIELDS 17 ARRESTS
description: Federal agents arrested 17 people today, 12 of them in Virginia, and were looking for seven more in the conclusion of a four-year investigation into illegal bear hunting.

title: Vindication for a Leading Proponent Of Theory 'People Are Born to Be Fat'
description: For Dr. Jules Hirsch, a professor at Rockefeller University in New York and a senior physician at the university's hospital, the new studies showing that fat people are biochemically different from thin people are a vindication of a view he has promoted for more than two decades.

title: Arms for Hostages? No
description: In an answer to a question about the nature of Vice President Bush's reservations about the arms shipments to Iran, President Reagan insisted at his news conference tonight that he had never traded arms for hostages.

title: To Help the Botanical Garden Grow
description: The New York Botanical Garden, deeply concerned with the welfare of growing things, now faces the need for growth of its own. Its new expansion plan deserves the support of all who would celebrate and protect plant life around the globe.

title: WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a pretax charge of $4.7 million for estimated future environmental compliance expenses.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $600,000, or 14 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: New Obesity Studies Indicate Metabolism Is Often to Blame
description: Two new studies have provided the strongest evidence yet that many people become obese more because their bodies burn calories too slowly than because they eat too much.

title: AUSTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cuomo Presses For Testimony In Racial Case
description: Governor Cuomo today urged State Attorney General Robert Abrams to take ''whatever legal devices are available'' to gain Tawana Brawley's cooperation in the investigation of what she says was a racial and sexual attack on her.

title: Home Improvement
description: SLIDING doors - the kind installed in closets or cramped doorways - are excellent space savers. But the frustration they can cause when they malfunction is often a greater price than one wants to pay for the advantage.

title: Soviet Permits Accounts of Khrushchev Era
description: A Soviet political writer said today that Nikita S. Khrushchev risked his life when he denounced Stalin in a 1956 speech.

title: Civil War '88: Too Many Battles, Too Few Troops
description: History enthusiasts organizing re-enactments of major Civil War battles this summer are running into the same problem Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Gen. Robert E. Lee faced 125 years ago: not enough Yankees and Confederates to go around.

title: Ex-Agent at Peace With Himself but in Conflict With F.B.I.
description: Five months after the Federal Bureau of Investigation dismissed him, John C. Ryan. a former agent, is grappling with a religious renewal that caused him to question his past, challenge his supervisors and lose his job.

title: Bribing Foreigners: What the Law Says
description: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, the law that is at the center of a special prosecutor's investigation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, is so complicated that even prosecutors have trouble determining when it is broken.

title: Underwriting Test in Senate
description: The Senate Banking Committee chairman, William Proxmire, said today that he hoped a majority of his panel would approve a bill that would allow banks to underwrite securities.

title: U.S. Is Protesting Detention Of 28 Servicemen in Panama
description: The State Department said today that it would protest to Panama over the two-hour detention of 28 American servicemen on Monday.

title: Booby Trap in Home Equity Loan Agreements
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop: Michael Jackson Opens Tour
description: The electronic image of two unmistakable, scoreboard-high legs, strutting across the stage, opened Michael Jackson's first United States tour here tonight at a sold-out Kemper Arena. Those legs, as much as the hits that made Mr. Jackson's ''Thriller'' the best-selling album in pop history and his new ''Bad,'' a Top 10 album since its release in 1987, were the centerpiece of a show that reaffirms Mr. Jackson's place as one of pop's most brilliant live performers. Those legs shimmied, kicked, twitched, rose on their toes, moon-walked; they even pedaled air as Mr. Jackson lay on his back.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SEASON TICKET. A Baseball Companion. By Roger Angell. 406 pages. Houghton

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $320,000 for the quarter and $1 million for the year. c-Net loss The prior year figures are restated to reflect the sale of businesses.

title: Sweden Preserves Its Porcelain Stoves
description: IN the late 1960's, Kjell-Evart Sigvardsson realized he was one of Sweden's last master makers of wood-burning tiled stoves in a nation swiftly converting to central heating. He decided to fight back.

title: U.S. Loan Set For Argentina
description: The United States has announced that it will give $500 million in short-term financing to Argentina while it works out arrangements for a longer-term loan with the International Monetary Fund.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 113, Trail Blazers 112: Larry Bird scored 16 of his 44 points in the fourth quarter last night. The victory was the Celtics' second in six days over the Trail Blazers and brought their home-court record to 21-3. The Celtics overcame a 100-88 deficit with eight minutes remaining. Bird started a 25-12 spurt with a 3-point play, and with 1 minute 42 seconds remaining, he scored on a short jumper to put the Celtics in front by 1. It was the first time the Celtics led since early in the second quarter. The Celtics' Dennis Johnson was fouled on a drive up the middle and made both free throws to provide the winning margin. Clyde Drexler led the Blazers with 36 points. Bird also had 11 rebounds and 8 assists. (AP) Bucks 97, Pacers 94: Jack Sikma scored 27 points, including a tiebreaking layup with 1:40 left, to lead visiting Milwaukee. The score was tied, 89-89, when Sikma scored and Terry Cummings followed with another layup to make the score 93-89. Two free throws by Vern Fleming with 22 seconds left cut the deficit to 94-93. In the final seconds, Steve Stipanovich stole the ball on an inbound pass, but Reggie Miller missed a potential game-tying tip-in.(AP) Spurs 123, 76ers 121: Greg Anderson scored the game-winning basket after an offensive rebound with 20 seconds left in overtime to help deal the 76ers' their 16th consecutive road loss. Philadelphia's Maurice Cheeks missed a 3-point attempt at the buzzer. The Spurs tied at 115-115 with 57 seconds left in regulation when Charles Barkley, who had 37 points and 21 rebounds for Philadelphia, was called for goal-tending on a layup by Alvin Robertson.(AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 5, Canucks 4: Stephane Richter capped a 5-point performance by setting up Mats Naslund for the winning goal with three minutes to play, giving Montreal its fourth consecutive victory. Richer, who had two goals and three assists, slid a pass to Naslund, uncovered at the right side of the Canuck crease, and Naslund slammed the puck into the corner for his 26th goal. (AP) Maple Leafs 4, North Stars 2: Peter Ihnacak scored twice and Ed Olczyk added the game-winner late in the second period as Toronto ended an 11-game streak without a victory at home against Minnesota. The Maple Leafs had gone 0-3-4 against Minnesota this season and were 0-9-2 at Maple Leaf Gardens against the Stars since Feb. 27, 1985. (AP) Blackhawks 6, Oilers 4: Dirk Graham's tie-breaking goal with 7:03 remaining was the winner. Edmonton's Keith Acton tied the score 44 seconds into the final period. Craig Simpson had two goals for the Oilers. (AP) HORSE RACING Tanzanid Wins Golden Grass Stakes: Tanzanid, who held on by just half a length over Cefis in the Palm Beach Stakes Jan. 24, scored an easier victory over the same rival yesterday when he finished first by 1 3/4 lengths in the Golden Grass Stakes for 3-year-olds at Gulfstream Park. Cefis is expected to make his next start in the $500,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream March 5.(AP) BOXING Dokes Stops Richardson: Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, continued his comeback when he knocked out Eddie Richardson in 2:18 seconds of the last round of a scheduled 10-round bout at the Felt Forum. For Dokes, it was the third straight knockout victory in his comeback, which began last December. Before that, Dokes had not fought since March 1985 because of problems with cocaine. Dokes improved to 32-1-2 with 19 knockouts. Richardson is 12-10 with 6 knockouts.

title: Reformbusters in the Senate
description: How far will Senate Republicans go to resist limits on campaign spending by candidates for the Senate? One answer is 5 feet 11 inches. Normally, that's how tall Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican, stands. At dawn yesterday he wasn't standing; he was carried into the Senate, feet first, by Capitol police officers. He was one of the Republicans, resisting a campaign finance reform bill, who had walked off the floor and had to be brought back under warrant.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Colombian Official Talks of Legalizing Cocaine
description: Calling Colombia's war against drug traffickers totally useless, Attorney General Alfredo Gutierrez Marquez has declared that the Government might have to consider negotiating with drug barons and legalizing cocaine.

title: Double-Barrel Judgement; The Hustler Decision Bolsters Protections Of First Amendment and the Sullivan Rule
description: The unanimous Supreme Court decision yesterday in the Hustler case was an extremely valuable two-tier victory for journalists and First Amendment advocates.

title: CORCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Yields Down For Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly down for the week ended yesterday. But fewer financial institutions were posting lower rates as compared with last week.

title: Berg Quartet Concert
description: The Alban Berg Quartet is to give an all-Beethoven program tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall. The musicians - Gunther Pichler and Gerhard Schulz, violinists; Thomas Kakuska, violist, and Valentin Erben, cellist - are to play the Quartet No. 2 in G (Op. 18, No. 2), No. 11 in F minor (Op. 95, ''Serioso''), and No. 15 in A minor, (Op. 132). Tickets, at $17, $15, $13.50, $11 and $9, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: At the annual meeting Commerical Shearing's shareholders approved changing the company's name to Commercial Intertech Corp., effective immediately.

title: Washington Talk: Senate; Age of TV Catches Up With an Anachronism
description: Once again, as it has done periodically over the last seven decades, the Senate has pinned itself to the floor with its own unusual wrestling move: the filibuster.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Justice Department's failure to provide the Congressional Iran-contra committees with a memo on a Middle East pipeline project misstated the committee's means of seeking documents from the department. It requested them in a letter to the Justice Department, not by subpoena.

title: An ID Card That Travels to Nondrivers
description: LEAD: Although a lot of the members don't drive, attendance at the Lynbrook Senior Citizen Club on Long Island was excellent the day representatives of the State Department of Motor Vehicles visited. Even some nonmembers showed up.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. and Bonn Seek Harmony Over Missile Issue
description: The United States and West Germany have agreed to put aside the contentious issue of modernizing short-range nuclear missiles to guarantee harmony in the Atlantic alliance, according to American and German officials.

title: PENTAGON DELAYS ON MISSILE BASING
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci retreated today from the Pentagon's plan to begin deploying MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars in 1991 to make it easier for them to escape detection by an enemy. He said more research and discussions with Congress must come before the program proceeds.

title: Judge Orders E.P.A. to Ban Sale Of 2 Pesticides Used on Termites
description: A Federal judge today gave the Environmental Protection Agency until April 15 to ban the sale and commercial use of products containing an anti-termite pesticide believed to cause cancer.

title: Senator's Office an Electronic Command Post
description: Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, a former airline pilot, now spends his days in solitude with his computer and his headset, working in a hideaway office where he feels as though he is back in a DC-9 cockpit.

title: New York's Flags: Long May They Wave
description: NEW YORK CITY'S flag - a tripartite design of orange, indigo blue and white with a seal in the center depicting an Indian and a sailor -doesn't readily come to mind to most people. But no matter; 40 of the city's artistic minded have just redesigned it.

title: Advertising; Nike Is Persisting In 'Revolution' Theme
description: The fourth TV commercial in Nike's ''Revolution in Motion'' campaign featuring the Beatles song ''Revolution'' began last night, just as a spokesman for the shoe company earlier in the day had said it would.

title: Year at Dartmouth $18,199
description: Tuition, room and board at Dartmouth College will cost $18,199 next year, up 6.4 percent from this year, the trustees have announced. Tuition will rise from $12,474 to $13,335, a 6.9 percent increase. Room and board will go up 5 percent. Robert Field, the college treasurer, said continued pressure for higher salaries and increases in financial aid were largely responsible for the increases.

title: A Senator Is Captured, but Not His Mind
description: ''One arrest, no conviction,'' Senator Bob Packwood said today, summing up his brush with the law in the early morning.

title: Unscheduled Landing
description: A Delta Air Lines jet flying from Boston to Salt Lake City made an emergency landing today at O'Hare International Airport here after the crew shut down one engine. Delta Flight 235, a Boeing 757 with 127 people on board, landed safely and taxied on its own to a terminal, said a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The cre shut down the engine as a precaution because an indicator guage showed low oil pressure, said a Delta official.

title: Dole and Dukakis Are Big Winners in Minnesota
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, Democrat of Massachusetts, emerged as the big winners in the Minnesota Presidential contests on Tuesday.

title: Court Upholds Rent Controls
description: In a sharp setback for landlords, the Supreme Court upheld, by 6 to 2, the constitutionality of a San Jose, Calif., rent control law. Page A23.

title: ANCHOR GLASS CONTAINER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $673,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter, and an extraordinary gain of $1,531,000 for the year. The extraordinary gain in the prior year is from a $2.2 million gain on pension asset reversion less a $700,000 charge from the early retirement of debt. The latest fourth quarter results were reduced by about $300,000 due to the writeoff of expenses incurred for the proposed 3 million share offering of common stock which was subsequently withdrawn due to market conditions. Year-ago fourth quarter results were reduced by $1.1 million due to the retroactive elimination of investment tax credits under the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The company said sales reflect the acquisition of Diamond-Bathurst Inc. in August 1987.

title: AIDS Panel Calls for Major Effort On Drug Abuse and Health Care
description: The chairman of President Reagan's AIDS commission today called for a $2 billion-a-year effort to expand treatment programs for drug abuse and improve health care services to combat the growing epidemic. He urged hiring 32,000 drug treatment specialists and setting up 3,300 drug centers.

title: A DELEGATE COUNT
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions. Preferences are based on delegates' public statements or binding state laws or party rules. Some Democratic delegates outside U.S. mainland have fractions of votes. title: Students Learn Under a Cloud
description: Students at Richland High School in this city, the home of a major nuclear weapon plant, have voted overwhelmingly to retain a nuclear mushroom cloud as their symbol.

Don't Withhold Tip
description: To the Editor:

title: For Stavropoulos, Nothing Too Trendy
description: GEORGE STAVROPOULOS is not given to pontificating about fashion. Ask him the design message of his newest collection, and he will say, ''To make women feel pretty - as usual.''

title: VALERO NATURAL GAS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures are on a pro forma basis; the partnership was formed in March 1987. Share earnings represent preference units.

title: Stockbroker Parlays Long Shot Into a Job
description: Fred Kayne makes investments by playing conservative odds. But he owes his new job to a long shot: spotting a company that had the rights to the harness-racing franchise in California and owned land in a Los Angeles suburb.

title: OIL-DRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
They Won't Fail Swaggart
description: LEAD: As the weary postal clerks of Baton Rouge, La., can attest, the Jimmy Swaggart ministry gets a lot more letters each day than the next biggest mail customer in town: the state government. But, then, Mr. Swaggart's constituency -at least up until his fall from grace last Sunday for apparent sexual misconduct - was easily as large as the population of Louisiana, and more committed than the most dedicated follower of the state religion, which is football.

title: OVERMYER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $543,000 and $170,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: Suns Trade Edwards
description: The Phoenix Suns traded James Edwards, a 32-year-old center, to the Detroit Pistons yesterday for Ron Moore, a rookie center, and a second-round choice in the 1991 college draft. Moore, 25 years old and 6 feet 10 inches tall, was the second-round pick of the Knicks in the 1987 draft. He was traded to the Pistons in October for Sidney Green and played in only nine games for Detroit this season, averaging 1.1 points. Edwards, 7-1, averaged 15.7 points and 7.8 rebounds per game this season. Last April, he was one of three Suns players indicted on charges ranging from possession to trafficking in cocaine and other illegal drugs. Edwards entered a program last summer that calls for dismissal of charges after a year of drug counseling.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Feb. 5 incorrectly described the activities of National Intergroup Inc. of Pittsburgh. The company's principal business is wholesale distribution of pharmaceutical products.

title: At a Crucial Period, Dissent Splits S.E.C.
description: In several key policy areas - particularly regarding regulatory responses to the October collapse of the stock market - the Securities and Exchange Commission has almost become a house divided.

title: Austria Is Not to Blame For Waldheim's Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: BISHOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of lease receivables of $22,000.

title: COURT, 8-0, EXTENDS RIGHT TO CRITICIZE THOSE IN PUBLIC EYE
description: The Supreme Court, in an 8-to-0 ruling today, broadly reaffirmed and extended its rules protecting criticism of public figures as free speech, even if the criticism is ''outrageous'' and offensive.

title: YESTERDAY'S MEDAL WINNERS
description: Alpine Skiing: Women's Giant Slalom; Gold: Vreni Schneider, Switzerland Silver: Christa Kinshofer Guetlein, West Germany Bronz: Maria Walliser, Switzerland Nordic Combined Team Gold: West Germany Silver: Switzerland Bronz: Austria Ski Jumping Team 90 Meter Gold: Finland Silver: Yugoslavia Bronz: Norway Totals: Soviet Union - 8 gold, 8 silver, 6 bronze; East Germany -7 gold, 6 silver, 4 bronze; Finland - 4 gold, 2 bronze; Austria - 3 gold, 3 silver, 2 bronze; Sweden - 3 gold, 1 bronze; Switzerland - 2 gold, 5 silver, 3 bronze; West Germany - 2 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze; United States - 2 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; the Netherlands - 1 gold; 2 silver, 2 bronze; France - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Norway - 3 silver, 2 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 3 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 2 bronze; Yugoslavia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze; Italy - 1 bronze.

title: Music: Liliane Montevecchi
description: WHEN Liliane Montevecchi struts onto the stage of the tiny Kaufman Theater, 534 West 42d Street, in her one-woman show, ''On the Boulevard,'' we know at once that here is a woman who has been in mythical places.

title: Airbus Holds Talks
description: The European consortium Airbus Industrie is discussing a wide range of manufacturing ventures with United States aircraft makers, and it hopes to announce a deal within a year, Airbus executives said. Adam Brown, Airbus vice president for strategic planning, also said the company had held negotiations about manufacturing arrangements with McDonnell Douglas, Lockheed and Rockwell International. Airbus has an urgent need for increased production capacity in light of its current backlog, Mr. Brown said. In 1987, Airbus made firm sales of 194 aircraft, bringing its total firm-order backlog to 841 aircraft.

title: The Big Chinook Arrives
description: NEVER underestimate the power of wishful thinking. Before these Winter Games ever began, some southerners at heart prayed for a Chinook wind to warm up the Alberta prairie.

title: Joint of Shuttle Rocket Said to Pass New Test
description: A joint on the redesigned space shuttle booster rocket apparently survived another test of its ability to contain the hot gases blamed in the explosion of the Challenger, a space agency official said today.

title: Schneider Wins Giant Slalom
description: Seven men in wooly fur coats, accompanied by an accordion player, stood on the side of an icy slope, singing the praises of Mateja Svet, their heroine from Yugoslavia. Another man held a sign wishing the eventual winner, Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, much luck. And, of course, all eyes were riveted on the giant slalom course when those other Swiss misses, Maria Walliser and Michela Figini, took their runs, trying again to win that elusive gold medal.

title: Resentment in the Open
description: A principal leader of the Afghan resistance alliance brought into the open tonight the guerrillas' smoldering resentment of what they believe to be American collusion with the Soviet Union to reach a compromise over Afghanistan.

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for
Davis Near Decision
description: Since Tom Flores resigned as head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders on Jan. 20, Al Davis, the team's owner, has been interviewing candidates in the hope of filling the vacancy before the National Football League meetings begin on March 14. Yesterday, The Associated Press said Davis was leaning toward one of five candidates but would not say which one: Mike Shanahan, the offensive coordinator of the Denver Broncos; Dennis Green, an assistant coach with the San Francisco 49ers; or one of three Raider assistant coaches, Charlie Sumner, Tom Walsh and Sam Gruneisen.

title: LIQUI-BOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: The Nasdaq National Market table in Business Day last Thursday and last Monday carried an erroneous identification supplied by The Associated Press for the Xplor Corporation. The company is no longer named

description: b-Net loss All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Market Place; Bankrupt Utility's Sale a Question
description: TAKEOVER proposals always raise questions about price and terms, and often about regulatory approval, but an announcement that the New England Electric System had opened discussions with the bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire has more than the usual share of uncertainties, experts in the field say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the world of debate about public affairs, many things done with motives that are less than admirable are protected by the First Amendment.'' - Chief Justice, William H. Rehnquist. [ A22:3. ]

title: Devils Score Once on 45 Shots
description: An inability to convert scoring chances, failure on the power play and inspired goaltendng by the opposition cost the Devils their second consecutive defeat.

description: b-Includes net realized gains of $222,000 and $1,659,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes net realized gains of $1,497,000 for the quarter and $9,285,000 for the year.

title: ABC Olympic Coverage Puts Network at No. 1
description: ABC's coverage of the Winter Olympics gave the network 4 of the top 10 places in last week's ratings, and moved ABC into first place for the month among the three major networks, according to figures by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: Physical for Klecko
description: Joe Klecko, the four-time Pro Bowl defensive lineman the Jets waived earlier this month, will meet with the Denver Broncos' doctors next Tuesday to find if he is medically fit for a tryout. When the Jets dropped Klecko, a 34-year-old pass rusher who played 11 seasons in New York, Dr. James Nicholas, the team physician, recommended that Klecko retire because of an unstable left knee that had undergone two major operations. Nicholas also said that the knee ''cannot withstand the rigors of training camp, the preseason and 16 regular-season games.'' Klecko played in only 7 games last season and had 14 tackles and 1 sack.

title: Architect's Vision: Pyramid To Suburbia
description: A CHAIR with an asphalt shingle roof and wood siding that resembles the facade of a house; tables that burst apart into four cracked pieces; lighting that looks like a piece of scaffolding. Such are the intriguing designs by the architect Allan Wexler, in a show at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts.

title: Homes On a Budget
description: ''IT was all done on a shoestring,'' said Tom McIntyre, the South Boston union leader who was the motivating force behind the Andrew Square housing development. In fact, Mr. McIntyre had the edge over many nonprofit housing corporations, tapping the power of two labor unions in the Bricklayers and Laborers Nonprofit Housing Company.

title: J.T. Lanman, 70, a Pediatrician
description: Dr. Jonathan T. Lanman, a pediatrician who served in a high research post at the National Institutes of Health, died of a lung ailment Monday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 70 years old.

title: Excerpts From High Court's Affirmation of Speech Protections
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today as the Supreme Court rejected an award for the Rev. Jerry Falwell from Hustler magazine. All other members of the Court joined his opinion except Justice Byron R. White, who filed a separate opinion concurring in the judgment, and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who took no part in the case. FROM THE OPINION By Justice Rehnquist

description: General Assembly

title: New Designs on the Rose: Floral Home Furnishings
description: THE versatile and ornamental rose - the center of attention in fashion, where floral fever is approaching epidemic proportions - is now taking on a leading role in decorating.

title: Myerson Takes the Fifth in a Civil Case
description: Bess Myerson, testifying under subpoena, invoked the Fifth Amendment yesterday at a civil proceeding in State Supreme Court in Manhattan when a lawyer asked if she had taken anything from the Long Island beach home of her companion, Carl A. Capasso.

title: EQK GREEN ACRES LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units. The company began operations June 30, 1986.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Feb. 12 misidentified the creator of the ''snap, crackle, pop'' slogan for Kellogg Rice Krispies. The N. W. Ayer advertising agency created the slogan in the late 1920's.

title: Clement Chen, Hotel Architect, 58
description: Clement Chen Jr., the first architect to participate in a joint international venture in China, died Friday. He was 58 years old.

description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $16,000.

title: Sale of Real Estate By First Interstate
description: A subsidiary of First Interstate Bancorp said it had put up for sale $165 million worth of property, or about 24 percent of its portfolio of nonperforming real estate assets. The accelerated asset sale is part of a restructuring begun by the Los Angeles-based bank holding company last year.

title: NATIONAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' losses included an after-tax charge of about $7 million for additional provisions for uncollectible accounts and allowances, charges associated with the disposition of two rural hospitals, and for an accounting change. The year- ago second quarter loss is also after a tax credit of $3.4 million.

title: Dance: Peridance At the Joyce
description: IN recent seasons, Peridance has been attracting well-deserved attention because of the gusto of its dancing and the craftsmanship of the choreography by its artistic director, Igal Perry. These virtues were in evidence once again Tuesday night when it opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) with the world premiere of Mr. Perry's ''Theatrical Gesture,'' a trilogy to music by Luciano Berio.

description: For Bob Dole, a week of brooding finally gave way to buoyancy today.

The commission chairman is George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees and a member of the U.S.O.C. Executive Board representing the private sector.
