title: BREAKWATER RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Africa Said to Need $2 Billion More in Aid
description: Africa's poorest nations will require an extra $2 billion a year in aid for the next few years if the nations are to achieve further economic development, an independent panel of experts reported today.

title: Stage: Rodeo '88 At Olympic Festival
description: Anything that moves, so to speak, falls within a dance critic's purview. So why not saddle-bronc riders who, like ballet dancers, earn points the more they turn their toes out?

title: CARIBBEAN SELECT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Blood Screening Studied
description: The American Association of Blood Banks announced today that it was studying new screening techniques that might further reduce the chances of transmitting the AIDS virus through blood transfusions.

title: Women as Predators
description: To The Home Section:

title: Hers
description: ''IT'S a rare bone infection!'' exclaimed the oral surgeon who stuck a needle in my mouth and drew screams. He gave me an hour to get to Santa Monica Hospital for a six-week course of i.v. antibiotics, 30 hours in a hyperbaric chamber and surgery.

title: Other Bids Sought By Stop and Shop
description: Eager to escape Dart Group Inc. and the Haft family, which controls it, the Stop and Shop Companies said it was negotiating with several other parties with a view to being acquired. But the Boston-based retailer, which operates 113 Stop and Shop supermarkets and 169 Bradlees discount department stores, did not identify the companies it was talking with and said there was no assurance that a deal would be reached.

title: How the Dying Can Save the Living
description: Several months ago in New York City, a young girl died while waiting for the heart and lung transplant that was the only means of extending her life. A few weeks later, a baby boy died before he could be given a new heart.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Secret Weapon
description: Worried that the elimination of several classes of nuclear missiles and the sharp reduction of other strategic weapons may dangerously weaken the United States or the Soviet Union? Rest easy. According to Alan Greenspan, by way of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, there is another megaweapon that nobody has thought of scrapping.

title: BRINKMANN INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago results are on a pro forma basis, which give effect to purchase accounting adjustments which are a result of the acquisition of the company's former parent Sybron Corp., as if such acquisition occurred on Jan. 1, 1986.

title: Q&A
description: Q.My parquet oak floor was stripped and refinished about five years ago. Now, stains and spills have caused dark spots. Can I do anything to lighten these stains without stripping and refinishing the entire floor?

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,800,000 from an accounting change.

title: West Virginians Put A Budget Crisis Aside
description: A crisis over the legality of the state budget blew over today almost as quickly as it developed after state officials agreed to continue government as usual until they hear more on the issue from the State Supreme Court.

title: RANGER OIL LTD (CANADA)(N) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $7,307,000 tax credit. c-Net loss and includes a $50,352,000 writedown of North Sea drilling equipment operations and a $18,045,000 loss on disposal of U.S. oil and gas properties.

title: ERLY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TV Review; McKellen as a Retarded Man in 'Walter'
description: ON American television, addicted to uplift, society's outsiders will inevitably find the friendship and love they crave. On ''L.A. Law,'' for instance, a mentally retarded man named Benny fortuitously wanders into an office full of compassion and understanding. We all know, of course, that that is hardly always the case. As a vivid illustration, a very different view can be found in ''Walter,'' tonight's offering at 11 on Channel 13's ''Channel Crossings.'' ''Walter,'' made in England for Channel 4, was directed by Stephen Frears, who has since gained substantial acclaim with the films ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' and ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Tom Bolton, pitcher, and Danny Sheaffer, catcher. MINNESOTA (AL) - Traded Julius McDougal, infielder, to the Detroit Tigers for Doug Baker, infielder. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Doug Drabek and John Smiley, pitchers, to one-year contracts. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Waived Darren Daye, forward. PHOENIX (NBA) - Traded James Edwards, center, to Detroit for Ron Moore, center, and a 1991 second-round draft choice. FOOTBALL DENVER (AFC) - Named Charlie Waters defensive secondary coach. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Named Howard Tippett special teams coach and Richard Moseley outside linebackers coach. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Recalled Brian Curran, defenseman, from Springfield of the American Hockey League. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Recalled Steve Guenette, goalie, from Muskegon of the International Hockey League. Sent John Callander, right wing, to Muskegon. COLLEGE ARIZONA STATE - Named Bill Stewart offensive line coach. DUKE - Named Dan Hammerschmidt assistant football coach. ST. JOSEPH'S - Announced the resignation of Michael Schultz, director of athletics and recreation, effective June 30. TUESDAY BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Tim Crews, pitcher, to a one-year contract. METS (NL) - Agreed to terms with David Cone, pitcher, and Dave Magadan, infielder, on one-year contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Agreed to contract with Brad Komminsk, outfielder, and Randy Veres, pitcher. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Fred Toliver, pitcher, to a one-year contract. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Mark Eichhorn, Duane Ward and David Wells, pitchers, to one-year contracts. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed Steve DeAngelis, outfielder, to a one-year contract.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Bankers Trust Trader Quits on Bonus Day
description: Andrew Kreiger, a 31-year-old trader in the Bankers Trust Company's foreign-exchange unit, resigned unexpectedly on the day he received his bonus for 1987.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adler & Shaykin announced that it had completed its acquisition of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc. for $14 a share, or about $190 million.

title: Nykaenen Becomes Triple Champion
description: Matti Nykaenen became ski jumping's first triple Olympic champion today when he led Finland to a gold medal in the team 90-meter jumping competition.

title: Dow Barely Budges, Posting Gain of 0.83
description: LEAD: The stock market treaded water yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average managing a gain of only 0.83 point to close at 2,039.95.

title: South Africa Bans Most Anti-Apartheid Activities
description: South Africa today banned the activities of 17 leading anti-apartheid organizations, including the nation's largest, the United Democratic Front, and prohibited the major labor federation from all political action.

title: Contraceptive Device Is Approved for U.S. Market
description: A panel of the Food and Drug Administration today gave final approval to commercial sale of the cervical cap, a contraceptive device similar to the diaphragm, that could be made available as early as April.

title: Driver in Howard Beach Case Is Penalized
description: The driver of the car that accidently killed Michael Griffith, the black victim in the Howard Beach racial assault case, has been ruled guilty of state motor vehicle violations in the death and is scheduled to lose his driver's license for 30 days.

title: Advertising; Public Service Effort Promotes Teaching
description: Because it believes that the nation will need 1.5 million new teachers in the next six years, an organization called Recruiting Young Teachers turned to the Advertising Council for a public service campaign.

title: Critic's Notebook; Fixing the Blame for 'Serious Money'
description: CARYL CHURCHILL'S ''Serious Money,'' a runaway hit in its production at the Public Theater last fall, opened and closed in less than two weeks on Broadway this month. We can all guess the meaning of this cautionary tale, but, should anyone fail to, surely someone connected with ''Serious Money'' will remind us of the moral in a public pronouncement sometime soon. ''Serious Money'' was butchered on Broadway, we will be told, by the usual culprits (pick one):

title: Trompe l'Oeil Ornaments That Paste Onto Walls
description: RIBBONS and bows, swags and rosettes are still popular in interiors, though using them has always taken skill and a professional eye. In response to a growing do-it-yourself market, several companies are producing these decorations as precut pieces of wallpaper, some to coordinate with wallpaper and fabric lines. Clarence House, for example, is introducing Ornamenta, a line of architectural and decorative elements from England. Paper swags and rosettes, bows, ribbons and knots, all precut, can give architectural interest to entire rooms or be used in such smaller ways as around mirrors or above paintings.

title: PRIMARY AND CAUCUS TOTALS
description: Unofficial results from the South Dakota Presidential primary with 1,150 of 1,151 precincts reporting, and the Minnesota caucuses with 3,004 Democratic and 3,274 Republican precincts reporting. Minnesota has 4,076 precincts. Percentages are rounded. *2*S.D. primary *2*Minn. caucuses Tally Percent Tally Percent DEMOCRATS Babbitt 345 0% 59 0% Dukakis 22,367 31 8,990 34 Gephardt 31,226 44 1,970 7 Gore 5,990 8 274 1 Hart 3,876 5 184 1 Jackson 3,866 5 5,270 20 Simon 3,991 6 4,766 18 Uncommitted - - 5,038 19 REPUBLICANS Bush 17,416 19 5,979 11 Dole 51,529 55 23,923 43 Du Pont 575 1 143 0 Haig - - 49 0 Kemp 4,266 5 8,535 15 Robertson 18,275 20 15,969 28 Uncommitted 1,220 1 1,613 3 (Source: Associated Press)

title: DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $247,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $54,000 for the 9 months.

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
DIGITAL OPTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a development stage company.

title: Worcester Journal; Town Asks Springsteen, Why Here? (and Smiles)
description: Bruce, why Worcester?

title: Prague Journal; In Red-Garlanded City, Unbidden Specter of '68
description: Rich red bun-ting on the principal buildings and posters in store windows announce that the Czechoslovak Communist Party is about to celebrate the events leading up to Feb. 25, 1948, when its leader, Klement Gottwald, announced the death of parliamentary democracy and the beginning of Communist rule.

title: Books: Empire of Fur
description: CAESARS OF THE WILDERNESS. Company of Adventurers, Vol. II. By Peter C. Newman. 450 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $25.

title: The Practical Reason to Restore Wetlands
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy Killed and Man Lynched in a Clash of Arabs
description: An Arab accused by fellow villagers of collaborating with the Israeli authorities opened fire in a West Bank village today, killing a 4-year-old boy and wounding 13 other people, before he was captured and hanged, according to Israeli and Palestinian reports.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KOREANS INSTALL A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Roh Tae Woo, who transformed himself from co-conspirator in a military coup to avowed champion of democracy, assumed the presidency today in South Korea's first peaceful transfer of power in four decades as an independent nation.

title: Saudis Plan Refining of Oil Abroad
description: Fifty years after it first discovered oil, Saudi Arabia is setting out to establish its own marketing and refining network abroad, primarily in the United States and Western Europe.

title: APPLIED BIOSCIENCE INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago results are pro forma, reflecting the elimination of certain charges by the company's former parent, and making certain other adjustments necessary to present the company on a stand-alone basis.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS ANY CONTRA HELP
description: President Reagan said tonight that any aid package Congress was willing to pass to keep the Nicaraguan rebels in existence was worthwhile even if it did not include money for military aid.

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $19.7 million resulting from the company's purchase of the majority of outstanding units of its research and development limited partnership.

title: Ethel Saniel Brook, 84, Essayist and Professor
description: Ethel Saniel Brook, an essayist and former professor of French literature at New York University and Hofstra University, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 84 years old. During her career, Mrs. Brook served as liaison in France for the Loyalist international brigades during the Spanish Civil War. After World War II, she was the interpreter for Andre Malraux during his tour of the United States. Mrs. Brook was also a strong supporter of the legal defense of the Hollywood Ten against blacklisting during the 1950's.

title: Books of The Times
description: SEASON TICKET. A Baseball Companion.

title: BMW Price Rise
description: BMW of North America Inc. said it would raise the price of its cars by an average of 1.8 percent, or $686 a car, effective with shipments to dealers on March 15. The greatest increase is for the top-of-the-line model, the 12-cylinder 750iL, the price of which will rise 3 percent, to $69,000 from $67,000.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Watching the Watchdog
description: Who audits the auditors?

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed on Jan. 15, 1988.

title: Jazz: Art Blakey Group
description: THE great drummer Art Blakey has, since 1955, been leading bands which effecively function as schools, producing generation after generation of jazz's best soloists. His more recent groups haven't always lived up to the sum of their parts - like the seasons change, so do Mr. Blakey's young band members, occasionally making for a ragged ensemble sound. But in his new group - Phillip Harper on trumpet, Javon Jackson on tenor saxophone, Robin Eubanks on trombone, Bennie Green on piano, and Peter Washington on bass - Mr. Blakey has one of the best bands he's led in the last decade.

title: Play Uses 'Butterfly' As Subtext
description: John Dexter has directed many plays and operas but never Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly.''

title: U.S. Says It May Seek a Cut in Its U.N. Dues
description: The United States may seek a reduction in its financial commitments to the United Nations and affiliated organizations because Congress refuses to pay the current dues, Reagan Administration officials say.

title: Sentences in Panda Killings
description: Eleven men have been given prison sentences ranging from three years to life for killing two giant pandas, the official New China News Agency said today. The report said a court in Sichuan Province, one of the last natural habitats of the endangered species, found the men guilty in two incidents of killing pandas and selling pelts. It did not say how many of the men were given life terms. Only about 1,000 giant pandas still survive in the wild, all in southwest China.

title: Excerpts From Report of Commission on AIDS
description: Following are excerpts from recommendations presented today by James D. Watkins, chairman of the Presidential Commission on Human Immunodeficiency Virus Epidemic, for consideration by the full commission.

title: Arbitrager Said to Have Helped Boesky
description: One of John A. Mulheren Jr.'s closer friends on Wall Street was the fallen arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky. It was a relationship that helped Mr. Boesky greatly at a crucial time in his career.

title: Dykstra Displays New Look
description: The first fat cat of the spring arrived today when Lenny Dykstra checked into the Mets' training camp with 20 extra pounds. Manager Dave Johnson wasn't sure that he liked what he saw.

title: ALDUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WCBS to Buy Program; May Shift 'Evening News'
description: WCBS Channel 2 is expected to announce today that it has purchased the new syndicated news-and-information program based on the USA Today newspaper, a move that may lead to the removal of the CBS ''Evening News'' from its customary 7 P.M. time slot on the network's flagship station.

title: A City Hopes to Strike Oil
description: The City of Baytown, banking that City Hall may be sitting on a pool of oil, is looking in its own backyard for more income. The City Council voted Tuesday to approve a plan for Trace Oil and Gas to drill a well 5,000 to 6,000 feet deep near the entrance to the 30-acre wooded City Hall complex. The city would receive a 20 percent royalty on any petroleum uncovered under the agreement.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS AFGHAN ALLIANCE
description: A State Department official met with representatives of all seven Afghan guerrilla factions today in Pakistan to discuss a Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, the department announced.

title: Fire Dept. Plans A Court Action On Sick Leaves
description: The Koch administration threatened yesterday afternoon to seek a court order to halt what it called an illegal job action organized by the firefighters' union to protest the quick and quiet closing of a Brooklyn firehouse last month.

title: Bob O'Farrell, Catcher, 91
description: Bob O'Farrell, a catcher with four National League teams from 1915 to 1935, died last Saturday at St. Therese Medical Center. He was 91 years old.

title: An Avid and Successful Risk-Taker
description: If John A. Mulheren Jr. had his way, he would now be a member of the United States Olympic luge team in Calgary, Alberta, where he hoped to become an instant celebrity. Not only had he developed a daring new technique in his training, but the fun-loving Mr. Mulheren even planned to speed down the Calgary run wearing a mask. He told friends he looked forward to being interviewed on television as ''the masked luger.''

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: During 1987 the company sold about one percent of its Japanese subsidiary through a private placement in Japan, which added $1.6 million, or 12 cents a share, to net income. During the prior year the company also sold 20 percent of Shaklee Japan K.K. through an initial public offering, which increased 1986 net income by $43.8 million, or $3.32 a share.

title: St. John's Late Surge Beats Georgetown
description: For all of the tension preceding Georgetown's appearance at Madison Square Garden last night, it was St. John's who wound up doing the muscle flexing.

title: OSHKOSH B'GOSH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Australian Is a Favorite At Saatchi
description: GEOFFREY A. COUSINS, a second-generation ad man, arrived in Times Square yesterday morning looking unbelievably fresh after a 22-hour flight from Sydney, Australia.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (AUSTIN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an $11.6 million addition to loan reserves, which brings total loan loss reserves to about $30 million.

title: Trial of Hunt Brothers In Silver Case Begins
description: A $150 million lawsuit against the Hunt brothers of Dallas went to trial yesterday in Manhattan, with a lawyer representing the leading Peruvian mineral company accusing the Hunts of engaging in an elaborate scheme in 1979 and 1980 to manipulate silver prices.

title: Chinese Film Named Best In Berlin
description: ''The Red Sorghum Field,'' an epic film about seduction and war in China, has won the best-picture award at the 38th Berlin Film Festival.

title: Scandal Spurs Interest In Swaggart Finances
description: In the most recent issue of his magazine The Evangelist, the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart offered some ruminations on the flood of dollars coursing through the evangelical world.

title: Reagan Denies Meese Impropriety, Seeing a 'Lynch Mob Atmosphere'
description: President Reagan defended Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d tonight against accusations of impropriety and said his opponents had created ''a kind of lynch mob atmosphere'' that unfairly charged members of his Administration with ethical misconduct.

title: Calendar: Workshop, Antiques And Crafts
description: The World's Gardens

title: Vehicle Sales Up By 14.5%
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 14.5 percent in mid-February from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: 'Fawlty Towers' Does Not Live Again
description: LEAD: WHEN Peter Kindred designed the set for ''Fawlty Towers,'' a BBC comedy series about the world's most exasperating hotel, he never imagined that someday he would run his own hotel.

title: Essay; Bailing Out Moscow
description: We have just been told by a well-placed informant inside the Kremlin that the Soviet Union is not the economic power our intelligence analysts have long thought it was.

title: QANTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reflects a $2.2 million reversal of reserves as a result of the company's sale of its minority interest in a Mexican joint venture.

title: Ultimatum Is Sent To Foster Wheeler
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman said that he might present his proposals to acquire or restructure the Foster Wheeler Corporation directly to the company's shareholders if its management refused to meet with him.

title: KEY RATES
COTTON STATES LIFE & HEALTH INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $149,000 and $916,716 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $518,721 for the quarter and $1,016,841 for the year.

title: Missiles Are Being Removed, 2 Allies of Soviet Announce
description: Czechoslovakia and East Germany say they will start removing shorter-range Soviet nuclear missiles from their territory on Thursday in accordance with the missile treaty signed by Moscow and Washington in December.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THERE'S a public-service announcement on national television in which a teary-eyed girl flinches as she hears her parents call her stupid and clumsy. A few seconds later a young boy smiles proudly as his parents tell him what a good job he's done. The message is clear. Children learn who they are by how we label them. Your child's self-image - her mental photograph of herself - is a reflection of what you say to her. One child will grow up to be a winner; the other is doomed from the start.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an administrative judge's ruling on an investigation of a Manhattan dentist's refusal to treat an AIDS patient, carried an erroneous identification of the dentist, supplied by the patient's lawyer. The dentist is Dr. Michael Hurwitz, not Dr. David Hurwitz.

title: 7 Convicted of Racketeering, 1 Acquitted, in Westies Trial
description: Seven defendants were convicted yesterday of racketeering charges involving several murders and other crimes carried out by the Westies, a gang accused of terrorizing a Manhattan neighborhood for 20 years.

title: Cello: Semyon Fridman
description: SEMYON FRIDMAN, a Soviet-born cellist who won first prize at the 1987 Concert Artists Guild International New York Competition, made an impressive New York debut Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Focusing on the passionate side of his instrument's literature, Mr. Fridman plunged briskly into the recital's major works - the Brahms Sonata in F minor and the Shostakovich Sonata - yet only in the third movement of the Brahms, which grew choppy, did matters threaten to slip beyond his control.

title: Time to Greet the Year of the Dragon
description: Since the eve of the Year of the Dragon, members of New York's Chinese community have been struggling to fit New Year's festivities into busy lives.

title: Bomb Blast Kills 2 Soldiers On Northern Ireland Patrol
description: Two soldiers of the Ulster Defense Regiment were killed and a civilian and two soldiers were wounded in a bomb attack in Belfast tonight, a police spokesman said.

title: Meese Encouraged Those Who Prejudge Him; Arguing the Right Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Norma Kamali Moves on to Furniture
description: WHEN they find OMO SoHo closed on April 1, shoppers may think it is Norma Kamali's idea of an April Fools' joke. But in fact Ms. Kamali, a fashion designer, is closing her doors at 113 Spring Street (Mercer Street) from April 1 to 18 so the space can be transformed from a clothing store to one devoted to home furnishings. ''I've always collected antiques, and I've also loved rearranging furniture,'' she said. ''Now I'll have a place to do both without disrupting my own home.''

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital losses of $15,000 for the quarter, and the year includes capital gains of $5,556.000. c-Includes capital losses of $186,000 for the quarter; the year includes capital gains of $1,984,000.

title: Untimely Exercise
description: To the Editor:

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1.8 million for the quarter and $4.3 million for the year, and tax credits of $3.4 million and $15.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3.4 million and a tax credit of $93 million, both items for the quarter and year; the year also included a gain from an accounting change of $7.5 million. The year-ago periods are restated to reflect a change in accounting for inventory and consolidation of a wholly owned leasing subsidiary.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $256,000 from the repurchase of debt. c-Net loss and includes losses of $1,500,000 and $2,343,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Soviet Buys More Wheat
description: An additional 700,000 metric tons of subsidized United States wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Overall wheat exports, spurred by subsidized sales to China and the Soviet Union, are expected to rise more than 50 percent from last year, reducing the American stockpile to its lowest level in six years.

title: Bridge: 11-Year-Old Collects Points In Quest to Be a Life Master
description: Most players of the highest class began bridge when they were teen-agers, and a few began even earlier. The record for the youngest to achieve Life Master rank is held by Douglas Hsieh of Manhattan, who was 11 when he did so.

title: TOWNE-PAULSEN INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Includes net of $2,128,729 from discontinued operations for the latest year and a loss of $7,098,247 from discontinued operations for the prior year.

title: Peres Aide Says Bechtel Offered Oil At Reduced Price for Pipeline Pledge
description: The Bechtel Group offered to sell oil at reduced rates to Israel for 10 years - a reduction worth $650 million to $700 million - in exchange for an Israeli pledge not to attack a proposed oil pipeline from Iraq to Jordan, an aide to Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today.

title: House Panel to Delay Move to Expel Biaggi
description: Be-cause Representative Mario Biaggi is involved in litigation, the House ethics committee has decided to delay intro-ducing a resolution caling for his ex-pulsion, according to a statement re-leased today.

title: Talking Deals; Murdoch's Focus On Bottom Line
description: FOR Rupert Murdoch, buying The New York Post was a bad deal, a financial failure. In the 12 years that he owned The Post, he lost an estimated $150 million.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $72,000 and $308,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,953,000 and $1,877,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss Share earnings were less than 1 cent for the latest year.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUESFarm Credit Sale Comprises 4 Issues
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering four tranches of bonds totaling $3.3 billion at par through various securities dealers.

title: Brain Wound Eliminates Man's Mental Illness
description: A mentally ill young man who shot himself in the head in a suicide attempt suffered a brain injury that apparently eliminated his phobia of germs and his obsession with washing his hands, doctors say.

title: I Lost to Kasparov: A Chess Patzer's Tale
description: How does a patzer feel while playing Gary Kasparov, the chess champion of the world, in a simultaneous exhibition?

title: Stun-Gun Trial Ends With Four Being Convicted
description: A former New York City police sergeant and a suspended officer were convicted yesterday of felony assault and other charges for torturing a marijuana dealer with an electronic stun gun at a Queens station house.

title: Tot Badly Bitten by Ants
description: A 16-month-old girl bitten by a horde of ants was in critical condition today, a spokeswoman for Sacred Heart Hospital said. Tiffany Cheatam of Navarre, a community about 20 miles east of this Panhandle city, had stopped breathing when rescuers arrived at her home shortly after noon Tuesday, emergency personnel said. A witness said a dog knocked the girl into a bed of ants in her backyard.

title: Rabbi Seymour Siegel, 61, Leader In Conservative Judaism, Is Dead
description: Rabbi Seymour Siegel, an architect of contemporary Conservative Jewish theology whose writings helped open the door for the ordination of female rabbis and other innovations, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Woman's Friends
description: To The Home Section:

title: Baseball No-Shows
description: Wally Joyner, the California Angels' first baseman, and Danny Tartabull, the Kansas City Royals' outfielder, failed to appear for the first full-squad workouts of spring training yesterday because they are unhappy with their contract negotiations. Tartabull, who is asking for $425,000, made $145,000 last year. A third-year player, he hit .309 with 34 home runs and 101 runs batted in last season and is one year short of arbitration. Joyner and the Angels are reportedly about $100,000 apart. Last season, Joyner hit .285 with 34 home runs and 117 r.b.i.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices, 6 to 2, Hold Rent Control Law in San Jose, Calif., Is Constitutional
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of a rent control law in San Jose, Calif., in an opinion suggesting that challenges to rent controls are unlikely to succeed except when particular landlords can show they have been denied a fair return.

title: Bonds Slip in a Stagnant Market
description: Bond prices dipped slightly in light, directionless trading yesterday. Dealers said the activity was mostly confined to professionals, with little or no interest from retail customers.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Schlage Lock Company to Mojo Advertising, San Francisco, part of Mojo MDA of Australia.

title: FEDERAL HOME LOAN MORTAGE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said reclassifications have been made in the financial statements to certain 1986 amounts as previously reported in order to make them consistent with the presentation of 1987 amounts.

title: TV Ad Expenses Questioned On Dukakis and Gephardt
description: The Federal Election Commission's general counsel today urged the commission to deem ''unreasonable'' a practice used in Iowa by the Presidential campaigns of Michael S. Dukakis and Richard A. Gephardt. Those candidates counted half the cost of television advertising as a fund-raising expense.

title: BELVEDERE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment loss of $71,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $518,000 for the year. c-After realized investment gains of $2,274,000. The company broke even in the year-ago fourth quarter. The company said fourth quarter revenue included about $6.3 million in earned premiums from reinsurance assumed by Belvedere America Reinsurance Co. under an agreement in September 1987 under which Belvedere America assumed all the in-force business of Aegon Reinsurance Co. of America as of July 1, 1987.

title: Big Loan to Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has secured a three-year loan of $5 billion from a group of international banks to help finance its acquisition of Sterling Drug Inc. The bridge loan - in the form of a revolving credit -comes from a syndicate of 23 international banks, with the Bankers Trust Company of New York acting as agent for the interim financing. Kodak's treasurer, C. Michael Hamilton, said the short-term interest rates on the loan were ''currently in the range of 7 percent.'' The cost of the takeover is $5.15 billion.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said a reduction in its estimated effective tax rate for fiscal 1988 contributed an additional 2 cents to second quarter earnings per share.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Advertising; Tracy-Locke to Handle Texas Commerce Bank
description: Tracy-Locke of Dallas, part of the Omnicom Group, has won the retail business of the Texas Commerce Bank, a subsidiary of Chemical New York Corporation. The former agency was Della Femina, Travisano & Partners in New York.

title: Jackson's White Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz to Press Eventual Goal of an Israeli Pullout
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to seek agreement among Israelis and Arabs on a set of principles linking an interim plan for self-administration in the Israeli-occupied territories with the ultimate goal of territorial compromise, a well-placed State Department official said today.

title: Trump's Promise Wins Relicensing for Casino
description: The Casino Control Commission voted, 5 to 0, today to relicense the Resorts International casino, a day after the company's chairman, Donald J. Trump, pledged that it would meet its obligations to build housing in Atlantic City.

title: Soviet Trying to Quell Ethnic Unrest
description: The authorities in two southern Soviet republics moved today to quell Armenian nationalist protests that appeared to be developing into a major problem for Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Communist Party.

title: 2 Held Hostage for 3 Hours at Brooklyn Office
description: A man who said he was dissatisfied with the settlement of his worker compensation case held two lawyers hostage at gunpoint for three hours yesterday in downtown Brooklyn before freeing them unharmed and surrendering.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $416,000 and $628,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $167,000 for the quarter and $478,000 for the 6 months.

title: Who Are We? Our Furniture Speaks Volumes
description: LEAD: I RECENTLY committed good money to shipping a truckload of old family furniture from my mother's basement in the Northwest to my apartment in San Francisco. Upon arrival, the pieces appeared less imposing than they had to my 10-year-old eyes as I dusted them in my grandparents' house in long-ago Seattle.

title: Music: Bill Monroe
description: THE longstanding kinship between traditional Celtic music and American bluegrass was fruitfully explored on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall where Bill Monroe, the man who virtually invented bluegrass music shared the bill with the Boys of the Lough, the noted quintet from the British Isles that plays toe-tapping reels, jigs and hornpipes in a carefully arranged ensemble style.

title: U.S. Spurs Drive for Exports
description: The Commerce Department began an effort today to help smaller companies capitalize on a highly competitive dollar-exchange rate to penetrate foreign markets.

title: Laszlo G. Versenyi, Philosophy Professor, 59
description: Laszlo G. Versenyi, a philosophy professor at Williams College, died Tuesday of cancer at his home in Williamstown. He was 59 years old.

title: Memo Urges Justice Department 'To Polarize Debate' on Key Issues
description: An internal Justice Department memorandum urges officials to ''polarize the debate'' on key legal issues such as drugs, AIDS, obscenity and the death penalty and to seek confrontation instead of consensus in the remaining months of the Reagan Administration.

title: Study Sees Threats to New York Region's Growth
description: Economic growth in the New York metropolitan region is being slowed, and could be stopped, by fundamental problems with education, housing costs and labor shortages, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Comedy From John Waters
description: The concept of Smell-o-Vision never really took hold in America's movie theaters, but it's very nearly a reality in John Waters's "Hairspray." During this bright, bouncy film's opening montage of early 60's teen-agers preparing their coiffures for a television dance program, it's almost possible to sniff the huge clouds of poison they spray onto their teased, empty heads. Such is the realism of ''Hairspray,'' which is hardly the only film to recapture this period (roughly that of ''American Graffiti'') but may be the worst looking. That — a merry cavalcade of the period's most authentically awful props, fads and textiles — appears to be exactly what Mr. Waters was after.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $900,000 from the favorable settlement of litigation.

title: Halliburton Agrees To Buy Gearhart
description: The Halliburton Company, the large oil-field service concern, has agreed to acquire a smaller rival, Gearhart Industries, for about $276 million. Gearhart, based in Fort Worth, has lost money for several years and has not paid a shareholder dividend since 1985. The company stopped servicing its debt in 1986, when oil prices reached a low of $10 a barrel.

title: Plan for Rezoning Area Near the Park Is Stalled
description: A plan to ease zoning limits on the size of buildings along much of Central Park's most exclusive East Side properties was dealt a setback last night when the matter was removed from Board of Estimate consideration.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $620,000 for the quarter and $1,274,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $406,000 for the quarter and $1,029,000 for the year. The income from discontinued operations included a gain on the sale of Webtron Corp. of $448,000.

title: Revision Lifts G.N.P.'s Rise To 4.5% Rate
description: The nation's economy grew at a 4.5 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1987, somewhat faster than the preliminary estimate a month ago, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Late Selling Depresses U.S. Issues
description: Late waves of selling eroded prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday despite a flow of generally positive news for fixed-income securities.

title: TV Weekend; Salute to Dizzy Gillespie
description: TIMED to coincide with Black History Month, public television's ''Great Performances'' is presenting - tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 -''Wolf Trap Salutes Dizzy Gillespie: An All-Star Tribute to the Jazz Master.'' The 90-minute special includes highlights from a concert performed last June before a full house at Wolf Trap Park Farm for the Performing Arts in Vienna, Va.

title: U.S. Finishes 7th in Hockey
description: They ended their Olympic experience with a victory that they didn't celebrate. Then, with their fraternity disbanding and their Olympic plans dissolved, the hockey players from the United States went back to the business of coping with life as they used to know it.

title: Film: 'Hairspray,' Comedy From John Waters
description: The concept of Smell-o-Vision never really took hold in America's movie theaters, but it's very nearly a reality in John Waters's ''Hairspray.'' During this bright, bouncy film's opening montage of early 60's teen-agers preparing their coiffures for a television dance program, it's almost possible to sniff the huge clouds of poison they spray onto their teased, empty heads. Such is the realism of ''Hairspray,'' which is hardly the only film to recapture this period (roughly that of ''American Graffiti'') but may be the worst looking. That - a merry cavalcade of the period's most authentically awful props, fads and textiles - appears to be exactly what Mr. Waters was after.

title: Profits Rise in Canada
description: Operating profits of Canadian companies, led by a sharp upturn in mining, rose 11 percent in the last quarter of 1987. It was the fifth consecutive quarter of strong gains.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tomba Is First In Giant Slalom
description: His name echoed on Mount Allan from the moment he left the starting chute on his first run in the giant slalom today, and built in a crescendo by the time he crossed the finish line a conquering hero after his second successful trip round the gates.

title: Executive of Guinness Will Head Storehouse
description: Michael Julien has been named group chief executive and chairman-designate of Storehouse P.L.C., the British retailing company formed by Sir Terence Conran.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,152,000 for the quarter and $1,639,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after tax benefits of $244,000 and $577,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter results included special charges of $56.8 million from restructuring. In the latest quarter and 6 months, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Dining Out Guide: 3-Star French, Part 2
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. The date of original publication is listed after the phone number. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: The Stage: Heiner Muller's 'Quartet'
description: Heiner Muller's ''Quartet'' is a dense, mordant rumination on Choderlos de Laclos's novel, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' This means that Robert Wilson's production of ''Quartet'' is twice removed from the original novel. The production at the American Repertory Theater is filtered through two diverse sensibilities, the one German and philosophical, the other American and visual. As it turns out, Mr. Wilson's freely interpretative version offers an intriguing variant impression.

title: MAIL BOXES ETC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Kaolack Journal; Where Western-Style Politics Thrives in Africa
description: Ouza and the Ouzettes, a big-time band from Dakar, had just struck up a dance tune when the candidate appeared, resplendent in an electric-blue caftan.

title: Woman, 82, Stabbed to Death In a Staten Island Apartment
description: An 82-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Staten Island apartment on Wednesday, the police said. Her body was discovered by neighbors who found her apartment door ajar, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman, said.

title: Film: Marcel Pagnol's 'Angele' in Series at Public
description: MARCEL PAGNOL made ''Angele'' in 1934, soon after the screen adaptations of his plays ''Marius'' and ''Fanny'' had spread his reputation as a chronicler of life in southern France. So why has ''Angele,'' one of Mr. Pagnol's first efforts as a movie director, not found its way into American theaters until now?

title: Our Towns; Neighborliness, The Homeless And Westchester
description: There are 4,000 homeless people in Westchester right now, and it is projected that by the time President Reagan leaves office there will be 6,000. Perhaps no suburban area has felt the turmoil of the President's dismantling of Federal low-income housing programs worse than Westchester. Robert M. Hayes, counsel of the National Coalition for the Homeless, calls Westchester the ''nation's capital of homeless families'' - quite a title for a county with some of the nation's richest suburbs.

title: Surgeon Testifies Chambers's Hand Showed Evidence of Punching
description: The chief hand surgeon at the Bellevue Hospital Center testified yesterday that X-ray photographs of the broken bone in Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s right hand showed a ''classic picture of a wild swing of a forceful nature striking a hard object.''

title: Thomas Leads Skating; Witt Second
description: She did not receive the scores she wanted, but Debi Thomas of the United States nonetheless moved into the lead in the Olympic women's figure-skating competition tonight.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Italian Doubles Offer for Belgique
description: Carlo de Benedetti doubled his public offer tonight for Societe Generale de Belgique's shares, from 4,000 Belgian francs a share, or about $113, to 8,000 francs in an attack on the French-Belgian coalition that claims to have 52 percent of the vast holding company's capital.

title: At the Movies
description: De Palma's New Film

title: Mideast Long Shot Worth Taking
description: Everyone knows that Secretary of State Shultz's foray into the Middle East doesn't stand much chance of success. But here is a clear case where it pays to fail, and even fail again. If the United States doesn't make every effort to get an Arab-Israeli peace process under way, the only beneficiaries will be the extremists.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Telephone May Be Helpful in Some Trials
description: The lawyers were surprised at the idea, and the telephone bill has yet to arrive. But the plaintiff, the defendant and the judge all seem pleased by a recent experiment to hold a trial by phone.

title: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary items. The share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (ADR). Four units of Imperial Chemical ordinary stock are represented by each ADR. The results are in U.S. dollars and are calculated using the exchange rate prevailing on Dec. 31 of $1.87 to each pound.

title: A Little Time Left
description: There is still time for President Reagan to make sure that a great victory in the making does not become a tragedy. But not much time.

title: BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Sounds Around Town
description: Many Strings Attached The 1988 String Band Festival, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Fingers will fly at this all-star gathering of bluegrass and old-timey bands. Breakfast Special, Lazy Aces, the Wretched Refuse String Band and Tony Trischka and Skyline are all trying to bring bluegrass music into the 1980's without losing its essence: close-harmony singing and amazing, virtuosic picking on instruments from the backwoods. Andy Statman, who plays mandolin and clarinet, and Matt Glaser, a fiddler, will also be sitting in. By the end of the evening, the room should be flooded with 16th-notes. Tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets $12.50. Jarman at Kampo

title: MINNETONKA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $1,040,000 for the quarter and $3,440,000 for the year, and gains of $44,795,000 and $45,031,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from disposal of discontinued operations. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $201,000 for the quarter and $2,420,000 for the year.

title: New Delay Is Seen for Bomber
description: New charges of financial improprieties at the Northrop Corporation may result in a further delay of the first flight of the secret Stealth bomber and could lead to financial penalties against the military contractor, a member of the House Armed Services Committee said today.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Knicks' Road Slide Ends at 18
description: The Knicks ended an 18-game road losing streak tonight, beating the Los Angeles Clippers, 106-96. Gerald Wilkins scored 9 of his 25 points in the last five minutes for New York.

title: By Law, 'Public Figure' May Not Be So Obvious
description: The Supreme Court's decision Wednesday further limiting suits by public figures against their critics underscores the importance of the legal line the Court has drawn between such people and everyone else.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $33,000 for the quarter and $156,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: N.B.A. to Check Early Woolridge Alert
description: The National Basketball Association said yesterday that it would investigate allegations by Dave Wohl, the former Nets coach, that he made team officials aware of Orlando Woolridge's drug problems during training camp last October but they took no action.

title: Late Selling Sends Dow Down 22.38, to 2,017.57
description: Stock prices swung widely yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average ahead as many as 33 points before a late-session wave of selling pushed the Dow to a close of 2,017.57, down 22.38 points.

title: U.S. Officials Move to Clarify Reagan's Remarks
description: Government officials moved today to clarify statements President Reagan made at a news conference about Palestinian unrest, the Iran-contra affair, terrorism and problems in South Africa.

title: Shultz Urges 'Historic' Israeli Step To End Impasse Over Palestinians
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on Israel today to make ''decisions of historic proportions'' to help change the status quo in the Middle East.

title: New Seoul Chief's Aides Dampen Expectations
description: As President Roh Tae Woo took charge of the South Korean Government today, his advisers and neutral analysts warned against overly high expectations for swift or dramatic political and economic change.

title: Leader to Take AFG Private
description: Randall D. Hubbard, the founding chairman of AFG Industries, said today that he intended to take the glassmaker private for $33 a share in a deal valued at about $726 million for the stock that he does not already own.

title: JONES MEDICAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMNET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds increased $2.56 billion, to $279.99 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $2.01 billion, to $83.02 billion. Assets of the 208 general purpose funds were down $522.8 million, to $81.44 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased $1.07 billion, to $115.52 billion.

title: Irwin Chanin, Builder of Theaters And Art Deco Towers, Dies at 96
description: Irwin S. Chanin, an architect and builder whose skyline signature was formed of jazzy Art Deco towers and whose legacy to Broadway was a half dozen elegant theaters, died of natural causes Wednesday at his Manhattan home, his family said. He was 96 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl Is Upset: Sixteenth-seeded John Fitzgerald upset Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, 7-6, 6-4, last night in the third round of the $600,000 United States Pro Indoor Tennis Championships in Philadelphia. Lendl had trouble making his first serve and became irritated by distractions from a game on an adjacent court, slamming a ball into the Spectrum's overhead scoreboard. Fitzgerald, who had lost twice to Lendl, rushed to the net frequently, hitting placement shots beyond Lendl's reach. The 27-year-old Australian is ranked 57th in the world. In the quarterfinals today, the defending champion, Tim Mayotte, will play Jim Grabb; Jorge Lozano will face 14th-seeded Dan Goldie; Fitzgerald will face ninth-seeded Kevin Curren, and Sammy Giammalva will play sixth-seeded Christo van Rensburg.(AP) N.B.A. Mavericks 108, Rockets 106: Rolando Blackman, who scored 29 points, made a 20-foot jump shot with 26 seconds remaining to give the Mavericks their seventh straight victory in a key Midwest Division game last night in Houston. Blackman, who scored 9 of Dallas's last 13 points, had 6 assists and 7 rebounds as the Mavericks increased their lead in the division to 4 games over the Rockets. (AP) Suns 109, Cavaliers 103: Walter Davis scored 16 of his 35 points in the fourth quarter, including 8 in the final 1:18, as Phoenix beat the visiting Cavaliers just hours after the teams made a multiplayer trade. Armon Gilliam, a rookie, scored 24 points, and Eddie Johnson had 22 and Jeff Hornacek 16 plus 15 assists for the Suns. Cleveland got 24 points from Mark Price, 15 in the first half. Ron Harper added 23 points. None of the players involved in the trade dressed for the game, leaving both teams with eight in uniform.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 5, Whalers 2: Michael Thelven and Randy Burridge each scored two goals for the Bruins in Boston last night. Thelven's first goal, his fifth of the season, came as the teams were playing four to a side at 13:33 of the first period, and gave the Bruins a 2-1 lead. He made it 3-1 at 10:28 of the second period, beating the Whaler goaltender, Mike Liut. Rejean Lemelin made 36 saves, 15 in the second period when the Whalers outshot the Bruins, 15-9. Boston had 29 shots at Liut. (AP) Sabres 5, Blues 2: Ray Sheppard, a Sabre rookie, scored two power-play goals, leading Buffalo at home. Both of Sheppard's goals came in the first period and increased his season total to 27. Mark Napier, Scott Arniel and Phil Housley added the other Buffalo goals. Gino Cavallini and Doug Gilmour scored for St. Louis. Buffalo had lost two consecutive games(AP) GOLF 4 Tied for Lead: Jay Haas, playing some of the best golf of his 12-year PGA Tour career, shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday to tie with three others for the first-round lead in the $750,000 Los Angeles Open. Haas's opening round at Riviera Country Club gave him a share of the lead with Chip Beck, Dan Pohl and Jumbo Ozaki of Japan. A group of five, including Corey Pavin and Ed Fiori, were one shot back. (AP) Stephenson Moves Ahead: Jan Stephenson overcame an early bogey with five birdies to shoot a four-under 68 for a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $300,000 Hawaiian Ladies Open in Honolulu. (AP)

title: The A.M.A. Euthanasia Fiasco
description: LEAD: Strange and unsettling things are happening in American medicine. On Jan. 8, The Journal of the American Medical Association published an anonymous article by a young, tired, unsupervised physician-in-training who admitted that he deliberately killed another doctor's patient by administering a fatal dose of morphine sulfate after the patient told him ''Let's get this over with.

title: Pat Robertson's Special Sources
description: As a Presidential candidate, Pat Robertson plays down his past as a television evangelist, but he still claims knowledge from obscure sources. Just before the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Robertson announced he had information that there were Soviet missiles in Cuba. That surprised everyone from Fidel Castro to Defense Secretary Carlucci to Admiral Crowe, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. This week, he asserted that Vice President George Bush was responsible for the disclosure of the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart's sexual misdeeds, supposedly to smear Mr. Robertson by association.

title: Distortions Abound on Life of Koreans in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
USG Chairman Fights To Discourage Raiders
description: LEAD: Robert J. Day, the chairman of the USG Corporation, did all he could to ward off raiders. He oversaw a restructuring that added $600 million in debt, helped the company adopt a ''poison pill,'' and saw that directors' terms were staggered so they could not all be replaced at once.

title: Churches Will Protest Crackdown, Tutu Says
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu indicated today that churches would try to take up the mantle of anti-apartheid resistance after the Government crackdown Wednesday on 17 anti-apartheid organizations.

title: Auctions
description: In the 1960's, when Leo Castelli sold a painting by Roy Lichtenstein, it wouldn't be unusual for the dealer to give his client a lithograph of the artist's work. ''It was a way of helping to promote Lichtenstein's image,'' recalled Pat Marie Caporaso, director of Castelli Graphics. ''But what were freebies over 20 years ago are now fetching upward of $20,000 at auction.''

title: IRISH MUSIC
description: Ian Carney on button accordion, Deirdre Carney on fiddle and Mary Coogan on guitar will play Irish traditional music tomorrow at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets ar $5.

title: Waldheim Won't Speak at Anniversary Rite
description: Amid a continuing uproar over his war record, President Kurt Waldheim said today that he would not speak as scheduled at the main ceremony on the 50th anniversary of Nazi Germany's annexation of Austria.

title: Autopsy Finds Drinking Led To Death of Rutgers Student
description: An autopsy confirms that alcohol consumed by a Rutgers University freshman at a fraternity party led to his death, the Middlesex County Prosecutor, Alan A. Rockoff, said today.

title: World Noise Capital
description: To the Editor:

title: Pregame Brawl Studied
description: Bryan O'Neill, executive vice president of the National Hockey League, met with representatives of the Montreal Canadiens and the Quebec Nordiques in Montreal yesterday, seeking explanations for a brawl before their game Tuesday night. O'Neill said he would announce today whether suspensions would be assessed. Gord Donnelly of Quebec and John Kordic of Montreal fought before the start of the game in Quebec. Both received major penalties and game misconducts. In addition, each team received an automatic $25,000 fine under a new rule governing fights at the start or end of a game or a period. Three days earlier, the two fought six seconds into a game in Montreal.

title: Salute to Black Dancers At Columbia University
description: Charles Cook, Ernest Brown and the Norma Miller Jazz Dancers are to perform in ''Black History Salute to the Legendary Black Dancers'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium, 115th Street and Broadway. Other performers include Juanita Boisseau, a former Cotton Club dancer; Jack Hammer, who will perform a tap-dance homage to Bill Robinson and Baby Lawrence; Melvin Moore, the singer, and Bill Dillard, the trumpet player, and his orchestra. Speakers include Harold Cromer and Delilah Jackson.

title: Arms Control Question: What Is Helms Up To?
description: Officials of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency are used to dealing with arcane technical questions involving throw-weight and treaty verification.

title: Billions Are in Play Today in Mexico's Bond Sale
description: Bankers were playing a guessing game yesterday, trying to gauge how many banks around the world will bid for the novel Mexican bonds being offered today at a special auction and the prices at which they might be offered.

title: Woody Allen and 'Self-Hating Jew' Drivel; Is It Not Incredible?
description: To the Editor:

title: Film: 'Thy Kingdom Come'
description: A CONGREGATION sings a hymn - its members' heads thrown back, eyes closed, voices raised in ecstasy -and it seems they have surrendered their hearts to Jesus and their minds to their preachers. ''Thy Kingdom Come, Thy Will Be Done,'' Antony Thomas's documentary about born-again Christians and the political right, is powerful enough to lead to that conclusion, and hectoring enough to make us aware of Mr. Thomas's own manipulation.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TGI FRIDAY'S reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $2.5 million for unperforming restaurants. c-Includes a pretax charge of $5.8 million for the disposition of assets. d-Net loss

title: Viacom Loss For Quarter
description: Viacom Inc. reported a $35.4 million net loss for the fourth quarter, in contrast to a $695,000 profit in the third quarter. Revenues rose to $265.8 million, from $246.3 million the previous year.

title: Spending Rises in Japan
description: Japan's inflation-adjusted consumer spending rose 1.9 percent in December from a year ago, the Government reported today. The Government also said that major retailers reported a rise in sales of 7.1 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,282,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Includes gains of $1,478,000 and $31,242,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary charges of $2,503,000 for the quarter and $4,361,000 for the year.

title: Fed Clears Bid by Bank of New York
description: The Federal Reserve Board voted unanimouslytoday to permit the Bank of New York to proceed with its $1.08 billion takeover bid for the Irving Bank Corporation, provided it raises large amounts of new capital.

title: Key Witness Against Noriega Sentenced in Drug Operation
description: A witness who was instrumental in an indictment of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama was sentenced today to 14 years in prison without parole for his part in an operation that smuggled drugs and laundered drug profits.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter included a pre- tax gain of $219,000 from currency exchange, compared with a similar gain of $148,000 for the year-ago period.

title: An Array of Artists, Styles and Trends in Downtown Galleries
description: FOR better and for worse, SoHo is still the place to go for an overview of the current art scene. Inevitably, there are always exhibitions, representing artists of different generations and styles, that are worth seeing in themselves. Just as inevitably there are also shows that provide temporarily valuable data, keeping one current with some of the latest trends and fads. This weekend is no exception. As SoHo continues to expand, the East Village continues to shrink, with several (but not all) of its best remaining dealers planning either to close or to make the move a dozen or so blocks southwest, to SoHo.

title: Reagan Gets More Than Cues, Scripts Show
description: President Reagan's use of 4-by-5-inch cue cards at meetings is well known, but according to ABC News, the cards are not simply sketched notes but are occasionally word-for-word scripts.

title: Museum Honors James Stewart at the Waldorf
description: ''Jimmy Stewart is the quintessential American man to millions of moviegoers,'' said Rochelle Slovin, the founder and director of the American Museum of the Moving Image, which presented a tribute to the actor last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Saint-Gobain Seeks Rest of Certainteed
description: Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, the large French glassmaker, said it had begun a $41-a-share cash offer for the 42.9 percent of the Certainteed Corporation of Valley Forge, Pa., that it does not own. Certainteed shares jumped $13.50 each, to $45.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, above Saint-Gobain's offer price of about $334.3 million.

title: CROWN ANDERSEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $62,740,000 for both the quarter and year, and income from discontinued operations of $367,000 for the quarter and $1,050,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,141,000 and $7,490,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: A Recently Healed Boston Is Facing a New Racial Issue
description: With the pain of a decadelong school desegregation battle still fresh, the people of Boston are reluctantly confronting another sensitive and divisive social issue.

title: Jets Cut 4 Veterans In a Move to Youth
description: The Jets yesterday cut Joe Fields, Dave Jennings, Gordon King and Barry Bennett, veterans all more than 30 years old. The move followed the recent dismissal, for medical reasons, of 34-year-old Joe Klecko.

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Cut in Cable Disrupts Phone Calls in East
description: A cut in a major telephone cable 15 miles south of Newark disrupted communications along the East Coast today, according to American Telephone & Telegraph Company officials.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $50,000 for the quarter; the year is after net from discontinued operations of $2,874,000, a tax benefit of $20.3 million, and the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $3,872,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $181,000 for the quarter and $1,080,000 for the year; the quarter also included a tax credit of $600,000 and the year included a tax benefit of $1,750,000.

title: Signs of Spring Erupt in Galleries And Museums
description: THIS is the season when the art world gets a jump on spring. At the Jewish Museum, Marc Chagall goes heels over head in his ''Homage to Gogol.'' At the New York Public Library, the red-vented bulbul sits high in a custard apple tree as part of the ''Bird Illustrated'' exhibition. At the Cordier & Ekstrom Gallery, on East 75th Street, Varujan Boghosian tells us the tale of a beautiful young woman with a mantilla of queen-sized butterflies. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fragonard reinstates the swing as the ultimate dating machine. February, this weekend, has April's prerogatives - and not least downtown, where the highfliers of the future are readying their Easter eggs. (Reviews of these and other art shows in New York are on pages C28 and C29.)

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Industrial Beachhead
description: Not even Japan has one, nor any other country in the European Community. The West Germans have stolen a march on everyone by setting up a Washington office that represents their private sector exclusively.

title: Film: 'Apprentice to Murder'
description: THE film that announces for no good reason that it is ''inspired by a true story'' often lacks any authenticity of its own. Certainly that's the trouble with ''Apprentice to Murder,'' which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters and tells of strange goings-on in rural Pennyslvania, circa 1927. A mysterious neighbor begins showing signs of demonic power, and Donald Sutherland, pleasant but unremarkable as a nice-guy country doctor who is in fact conversant with these darker forces, takes up the cudgel on behalf of his community and does battle with the mystery man. He is aided by young Billy Kelly, who must say things like, ''I ask of the spirit of Cayumba: Are you with us?''

title: Signs of Spring Erupting in Museums
description: THE Museum Mile, as it is called on festive occasions, begins at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and goes north along Fifth Avenue. Its attractions include the Guggenheim Museum, the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the National Academy of Design and the Jewish Museum (in geographical order). But there is another Museum Mile, or mile and a half. It goes north from 42d Street, with the Whitney Museum at Philip Morris, takes on strength and autonomy with the the Museum of Modern Art and the American Craft Museum, face to face on West 53d Street, ducks aside to the Whitney Museum at Equitable Center on West 51st, and bears right toward the Frick Collection on 70th Street at Fifth Avenue, the Asia Society on Park Avenue at 70th, and the Whitney Museum of American Art itself, on Madison Avenue at 75th Street.

title: Conner Set to Sail
description: In a change of heart, Dennis Conner, the America's Cup defender, said he would compete in the world 12-Meter championships in northern Sweden June 22 through July 7. Conner had declined to participate, citing time pressure because he may face a New Zealand challenger in the America's Cup in September. ''But when I saw that all the big names entered the world championships I realized how important the event was and decided to join the field,'' Conner said. He will not sail Stars & Stripes, the boat in which he won the cup. ''Instead, I will sail the Australian boat Kookaburra II, now owned by the San Diego Yacht Club,'' he said.

title: Botanic Garden Teaches Nurturing Trees in City
description: How to nurture trees in a tough city environment will be discussed at a free daylong syumposium on Sunday jat the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section.

title: CENTOCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1,266,963 tax credit. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss of $1,207,272 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards.

title: New Leaders in Arab Unrest: Radical and Loyal to P.L.O.
description: To find the new Palestinian leadership that is said to be emerging from the protests in the occupied territories, Secretary of State George P. Shultz could look in places like this isolated village off a side road in the stony hills northwest of Nablus.

description: b-Net loss

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net realized investment loss of $18,383,000 for the quarter and a net realized investment gain of $781,000 for the year. c-Includes net realized investment gains of $98,576,000 and $161,991,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Broken Hill Plan
description: Shareholders of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company have approved a restructuring. Broken Hill, a steel, oil and mining company, will pay about $1.5 billion for 300 million shares controlled by Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier. It will also pay about $412 million to Elders IXL Ltd., a company run by the entrepreneur John D. Elliott, for a 50 percent interest in an Elders unit that owns 19 percent of the company. The men, whose stakes will be reduced substantially, have agreed to resign from the Broken Hill board.

title: U.S. Gives Morgenthau Data in Schiff's Murder
description: Information that could help solve the murder of Irwin Schiff, the millionaire businessman who was killed in an Upper East Side restaurant last August, has been turned over to the Manhattan District Attorney's office, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: BOSTON CELTICS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units. There are no per unit earnings for the year-ago periods because the company went public in October 1987.

title: Economic Scene; Election Year's Monetary Drama
description: THE conflict between the Federal Reserve and the Reagan Administration over what monetary policy should be and whose monetary policy is it, anyway, can easily be turned into a morality play.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $689,000 for the quarter and $1,387,000 in the year. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss of $409,000 from the reversal of tax credits for the quarter, and the year includes a tax credit of $224,000. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the prior year.

title: Profit Scoreboard
Film: 'Aloha Summer'
description: ''ALOHA SUMMER'' features Bobby Darin songs, surfers, wholesome guys and their girls singing around a fire on a beach in Waikiki. An unironic memoir of six teen-aged friends in the summer of '59, it is more likely to inspire deja vu about 50's movies than about the year Hawaii became a state.

title: MATSUSHITA ELECTRIC INDUSRIAL CO LTD (JAPAN)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Matsushita Electric changed its fiscal year, which formerly ended each Nov. 20, to a new one ending March 31, beginning in 1987. The above results represent the new third quarter and first nine months ended Dec. 31, 1987. Because of the fiscal-period change, figures for the comparable three- and nine-month periods in 1986 are not available. The year-ago three-month and nine- month periods ended Nov. 30 are for reference and not for comparison. The share earnings are in American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represents 10 shares of common stock. The results are in U.S. dollars and were translated at the rate of U.S. $1.00 equals 123 yen, the approximate rate on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market as of Dec. 31, 1987.

title: BKW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $16,089,163 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $5,390,000, or 20 cents a share, and $9,626,000, or 37 cens a share, from disposal of vessels for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a net gain of $2,506,000, or 10 cents a share, refecting the sale of the company's 50 percent interest in a joint venture involving nine liquefied petroleum gas carriers for the quarter, and included a net gain of $5,110,000, or 20 cents a share, from the disposal of vessels and related charter and other interests.

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,480,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Crude Prices at Year's Low After U.S. Inventory Report
description: Prices of crude oil futures dropped to their lowest levels of the year yesterday after a Government report placed American crude oil inventories at surprisingly high levels.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * B P Chemicals, Danbury, Conn., a subsidiary of British Petroleum Co., said it had formed American Acetyls, a venture with Union Carbide Corp. to supply and market acetic acid and vinyl acetate.

title: Mini vs. Super
description: CBS News and NBC News have offered an unconvincing reason for something they have every right to do - reducing their prime-time coverage of the results of Super Tuesday voting. Spokesmen for the networks said they would do so because caucuses and primaries in 20 states that day, March 8, would not be ''definitive'' (NBC) but would produce ''muddled results'' (CBS).

title: Board of Britoil Accepts B.P. Offer
description: The North Sea oil company Britoil P.L.C. conceded defeat and accepted a takeover offer by the British Petroleum Company. Britoil's board advised shareholders to accept B.P.'s offer of $:5, or about $8.50, a share, while describing the offer as inadequate.

title: Piano: Weissenberg at Carnegie Hall
description: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG is a continuing enigma. Few pianists play with his staggering facility, but even fewer give such maddeningly uneven performances on a regular basis. Tuesday evening's recital by the Bulgarian-born musician at Carnegie Hall turned out to be one more in a series of such erratic events, redeemed here and there by the flashes of keyboard brilliance that have always been the Weissenberg trademark. A characteristically flashy attack on Rachmaninoff's Sonata No. 2 in B flat minor was a reminder, late in the program, that Mr. Weissenberg is one of the rare pianists around nowadays who are capable of handling the technical scorpions that the composer planted in his piano music.

title: CATCH A RISING STAR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Union County, a Network Aids the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Salary Rate Of Custodians Is Criticized
description: New York City's Board of Education pays more for its custodial services than other major cities but receives less in return, according to a study released yesterday by a nonprofit group that monitors the public schools.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The friendship and ties between Israel and the U.S. have never been so strong. The time is right to move ahead. The time is right, together, to make decisions of historic proportions.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ A1:3. ]

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE: SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. AND 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. AND 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON CHARTER - 10:30 A.M. AND 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M.

title: College Basketball; Syracuse Trounces Providence, 91-73
description: Steve Thompson scored 18 points tonight as Syracuse used 15-point runs in each half to rout Providence, 91-73, giving the Orangemen their 18th consecutive Big East Conference victory over the Friars.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Lydall attributed its higher fourth quarter earnings to its controlling interest in Compudyne Corp. Compudyne contributed 50 cents a share to Lydall's earnings in the latest quarter, compared with 19 cents in year- ago period, and for the latest year, 46 cents a share, compared with 26 cents a share, for 1986.

title: Political Marketing; Gephardt Ads Summon a Proud U.S.
description: The pattern has been unrelenting. Hundreds of times over two months, the Missouri Congressman with the famous disappearing eyebrows appeared on television to gaze into voters' living rooms and hammer home his message: jobs, pride, strength, America.

title: AMERICAN CABLESYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Liberace Items at Christie's
description: Objects from Liberace's collection - personalized jewelry, cigarette cases, candelabra, pianos, music stands, sculpture, crystal and porcelains - are to be exhibited tomorrow and Sunday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: India Tests Its Own Surface-to-Surface Missile
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi announced today that India had successfully tested a surface-to-surface missile. He said it would be used ''purely for defense purposes.''

title: North's Testimony on Casey Is Made Public
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that he discussed specific plans with William J. Casey for covert operations that would have been financed with profits from the Iran arms sales, according to testimony made public today by the Senate Iran-contra committee.

title: Martin Starts To Grow Impatient
description: Another day passed, and there was still no Rickey Henderson in the Yankees' training camp, and no Gary Ward, either. With next Tuesday as the deadline for reporting, the absence of Henderson and Ward from the second day of workouts remained a low priority for Manager Billy Martin. But his patience seemed to be thinning.
