description: b-Includes a tax credit of $308,000. c-Net loss and after a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $156,000.

title: In South Carolina, Republicans Find Import Issue
description: The battle over foreign imports, a powerful and dividing question in the Democratic race for President, has become a major issue for the Republican candidates as well.

title: Suns Trade Nance To the Cavaliers
description: The Phoenix Suns, unhappy with the prospect of heading for a fourth consecutive losing season, traded Larry Nance, their All-Star forward and Mike Sanders, another forward, to the Cleveland Cavaliers yesterday. The five-player transaction also involved the exchange of draft choices.

title: John Zorn and Trio
description: John Zorn on reed instrtuments, Big John Patton on organ, Bobby Previte on drums and Bill frisell on electric guitar will perform tonight and tomorrow at 9:30 and midnight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $7.

title: Regulators Study Plunge
description: The Federal Reserve Board is involved in a series of meetings with other Government regulators about October's stock market plunge, a Commodity Futures Trading Commission member confirmed today.

title: Blair Putting Hockey on Hold
description: TELEVISION'S instant ability to create a heroine, a goat, or a meanie has affected what millions of people will see tonight.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $47,000 and a loss of $400,000 for the latest 9-months and year-earlier period, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: Philips '87 Net Declined 15%
description: The Dutch electronics giant Philips N.V. said today that the weak dollar had cut the 1987 profit by 15 percent, and that it would eliminate up to 20,000 jobs worldwide in the next two years to cut costs as it consolidates operations in Europe and perhaps expands operations in Mexico.

title: A Financial Head Start For Campaigns Is Cited
description: Members of the New York City Board of Estimate will have a ''substantial fund-raising head start'' for the 1989 campaign as a result of between-elections contributions, according to an analysis of campaign finance records.

description: Foreigners won nearly half of the patents awarded by the United States last year, the Patent and Trademark Office reported today.

title: Robert Lapham, 58, Demographics Expert
description: Dr. Robert J. Lapham, an authority on international demographics, died of brain cancer Saturday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 58 years old.

title: INCOME OF FAMILIES IS UP, WITH RICHEST BENEFITTING MOST
description: American families are better off than they were in 1970, largely because of the increase in two-worker families, but there are bigger income gaps between rich and poor, according to a major study issued today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. named Douglas S. Cramer vice chairman and E. Duke Vincent president of its executive committee.

title: C.I.A. Official Who Administered Contra Aid Program Quits Agency
description: Alan M. Fiers, the Central Intelligence Agency official who was in charge of aiding the Nicaraguan rebels and who was reprimanded in the wake of the Iran-contra affair, has resigned from the agency.

description: It cost Cornelius Kelly $100 in cash to bail his best friend, Jerry Bugs, out of jail last week.

title: Woody Allen and 'Self-Hating Jew' Drivel
description: To the Editor:

title: Film: 'Frantic,' From Polanski
description: ALFRED HITCHCOCK would have appreciated the inexorable process whereby Dr. Richard Walker (Harrison Ford), a surgeon visiting Paris to address a convention and enjoy a kind of second honeymoon, is drawn into a web of intrigue. It is perhaps no accident that Dr. Walker's troubles begin in the shower. The quiet, brilliantly unremarkable opening sequence of Roman Polanski's ''Frantic'' follows the doctor and his wife, Sondra (Betty Buckley), as they take a taxi from the airport, check into their Paris hotel, call home to say they've arrived and prepare to work off their jet lag. The only tip-offs that anything may be amiss are the film's title and the presence of Mr. Polanski at the helm.

title: FLEEMAN AT SPEAKEASY
description: Gregory Fleeman and the Fleewomen are to perform Mr. Fleeman's songs tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $6 with a two-dring minimum.

title: Union Pressure At Chrysler
description: The United Automobile Workers' council at the Chrysler Corporation voted today to halt all cooperative undertakings with the company, such as productivity and quality improvement programs, and threatened to disrupt operations with strikes at local plants until plans to sell Acustar, a Chrysler division, are shelved.

title: Election Unit Eases TV Ad Limit, Rejecting Advice of Own Counsel
description: The Federal Election Commission, rejecting its lawyers' recommendation, today condoned a practice used by two current Presidential campaigns to skirt state spending limits.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a previously-announced after-tax charge of $53 million relating to litigation, including environmental matters, the Bhopal case, and general corporate litigation. Without this charge, net income would have been $285 million, 119 percent higher than a year ago, and share earnings would have been $2.16, a 73 percent increase. Results for 1987 benefited from a $160 million, or 29 percent, decrease in interest costs, a result of reduced debt levels and lower interest rates. c-Net loss d-Includes a one-time gain of $569 million, primarily from the sale of businesses, a $270 million credit from the reversion of surplus pension funds, and an extraordinary charge of $473 million resulting from the purchase of long-term debt at a premium as part of the company's recapitalization program.

title: Abbey Simon: Evolution of 'a Pianist's Pianist'
description: Some years ago, a music critic called Abbey Simon ''a pianist's pianist.'' Mr. Simon has never been one of the big, publicized headliners, but his has been a solid, consistent career, and when he gives a recital - as he will on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall - the audience will be full of professionals trying to figure out how those infallible fingers do this or that, how he gets the kind of color he does, and what he does with the rhythms to make them so flexible.

description: An Army private who fled his post in West Germany for the Soviet Union last year was convicted today of having been absent without leave but was cleared of the more serious charge of desertion.

description: Share earnings are in units. Angell Real Estate converted from Angell Care Master L.P., effective Jan. 1. This is the company's first full year of operation.

title: The Shrinking Supercomputer . . . Will Add to Turmoil in Industry
description: Severe price cutting and the market clutter created by many new products have slowed growth in the mini-supercomputer industry, which many analysts had thought could achieve $1 billion in sales in 1990. Although demand continues to rise and sales hit $300 million last year, these experts think the industry will not reach the $1 billion benchmark until 1992.

title: Blues at Tramps
description: A.C. Reed and his Red Hot Spark Plugs will play Chicago blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th jStreet (777-5077). With sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Jeff Sellers, pitchers, and Todd Benzinger, outfielder-first baseman, to one-year contracts. CINCINNATI (NL) - Agreed to terms with Barry Larkin, shortstop, on a one-year contract. METS (NL) - Signed Rick Aguilera and Terry Leach, pitchers, to one-year contracts. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Tom Nieto, catcher, to a one-year contract. TEXAS (AL) - Signed Steve Buechele, third baseman, to a one-year contract. YANKEES (AL) - Agreed to terms with Jose Cruz, outfielder, on a one-year contract. BASKETBALL PHOENIX (NBA) - Traded Larry Nance and Mike Sanders, forwards, to Cleveland for Mark West, center; Kevin Johnson, guard, and Tyrone Corbin, forward. COLLEGES CINCINNATI - Suspended Hollis Smith, defensive end-linebacker, indefinitely from the football team after being arrested for assault and creating a disturbance. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA - Named Ray Dorr assistant football coach.

title: Officer Testifies Again In Killing of Her Partner
description: In quiet tones that belied the high-stakes drama, a New York City police detective dueled with defense lawyers in a Queens court yesterday over a shootout that left the detective wounded and her partner dead.

title: House Panel Chief Questions Pact With Russians on Space Payload
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee criticized the Commerce Department yesterday for granting an export license to an American company that has contracted to fly commercial payloads aboard a Soviet space station.

description: UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan. By Christopher Nolan. Preface by John Carey. 163 pages. St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: 4 Drivers Punished
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board announced yesterday that it had revoked the harness-driving license of Henri Filion and upheld 30-day suspensions for three other drivers - Michel Lachance, Rene Poulin and Joe Marsh Jr. The actions came after the board reviewed a one-month appeals hearing that ended Jan. 15 in which the drivers defended their tactics in the fourth race at Yonkers Raceway last Nov. 14. In that race, the payoff for the triple was so unusually low as to create suspicions among stewards and board investigators. On Dec. 3, Filion was suspended 90 days for ''driving in a manner inconsistent with an effort to win,'' and five other drivers received 30-day suspensions for ''lack of effort.'' James Marohn and Jay Randall, who also drove in the race, were cleared by the board. However, the charges against Filion were upgraded to the more serious violation of fraudulent acts in racing, based on testimony from Marohn and Leo Bauer, the winning driver. Attorneys for Filion and the suspended drivers said that they had not seen copies of the report, but that they might seek redress through state courts.

description: b-Includes a $35,000 tax credit.

title: 2 Soldiers Seized in Security Case Linked to Drug Trafficking
description: Two Army enlisted men have been arrested on charges of improperly handling classified documents, and Federal officials say the suspects may be linked to an illicit drug operation at Fort Irwin in the Southern California desert.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a man whose mental illness improved after he shot himself in the head characterized Physicians Weekly incorrectly.

title: The Shrinking Supercomputer . . .
description: Using a supercomputer has always been a little like flying on the Concorde: it may be fast, but traffic can still cause delays on the way to the airport. The lines of engineers and scientists waiting to get time on the company machine could shrink, however, with the arrival on the market of a new generation of small but extremely fast computers.

title: Koch and Firefighters Resolve Their Dispute
description: Mayor Koch and the New York City firefighters union yesterday announced the settlement of a two-week-old job action that, in the rosy glow of resolution, neither side seemed willing to acknowledge had occurred.

title: Approval Is Sought On Foremost Stake
description: Two Texas investors said that they would seek Federal approval to increase their stake in the Foremost Corporation of America to about 15 percent, from 10.1 percent.

title: Louis Iacucci, 52, Expert on Italian Wine
description: Louis Iacucci, a wine merchant and an authority on Italian wines, died of a heart attack yesterday after an automobile accident on Tuesday near Siena, Italy, according to his family. He was 52 years old and lived in Queens.

Correction
description: An editorial yesterday about The New York Botanical Garden's expansion plan overstated the size of the garden's adult education programs. The programs enroll more students than any other cultural, not eductional, institution in the country.

Israeli Troops Kill 2 Arabs; Palestinian General Strike Protests Shultz Visit
description: Two Palestinian demonstrators were shot and killed by Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories today and 100 were arrested.

title: Rangers Survive a Late Scare
description: There were 5 minutes 26 seconds left in the third period last night when Kelly Kisio's stick crashed across Randy Cunneyworth's back. Fortunately, Cunneyworth, a forward for the Pittsburgh Penguins, skated away unhurt. The incident, though, still posed an enormous threat to the Rangers. It was their backs it threatened to break.

title: Californians Enrich Gulfstream Finish
description: The last seven days of Gulfstream Park's meeting were already going to compose the best racing week of the winter, with seven stakes races worth $1.4 million being offered starting Saturday. A planeload of California horses that arrived last Sunday will make it even better, the kind of week that less modest tracks routinely call a ''festival of racing.''

title: Many Pitfalls on Path From Congress to Court
description: When 110 Democratic Congressmen concluded last fall that the Reagan Administration was conducting operations in the Persian Gulf in defiance of a Congressional resolution, they did what comes naturally to Americans in and out of Congress: they went to court.

title: BURNHAM AMERICAN PROPERIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: This was the company's first quarter as a real estate investment trust.

title: Olympics Rewrite Moscow's Schedule
description: Two of the more unusual minutes in Soviet television history took place this week. At 9 P.M. Sunday, the time every night when the familiar ''Greetings, comrades; here is the news tonight'' is heard, audiences were watching the Soviet women's ski team winning the cross-country relay.

title: When Rikers I. Erupted: How the Tension Mounted
description: For months before a Rikers Island jail erupted in violence last week, there were hints that tension was mounting, New York City jail officials said yesterday.

title: Omitted Remarks by Reagan
description: Following is the portion of a transcript of President Reagan's news conference inadvertently omitted yesterday. Q. Mr. President, who precisely are you criticizing when you say that the riots are not homegrown and not spontaneous? A. Well, we have had - it's a little difficult for me because I've -there's some things I shouldn't be saying, but we have had intimations that there have been certain people suspected of being terrorists, outsiders, coming in not only with weapons but stirring up and encouraging the trouble in those areas.

title: Football in the Garden
description: Arena Football, an indoor professional league with a miniaturized field and wide-open offenses that played its first season in the spring and summer of 1987 with four teams, will return in April with six teams. One of the new teams will be the New York Knights, who will play their home games in Madison Square Garden.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1988
description: The Economy

title:
Advertising;
St. Gillian Fashion To Burkhardt & Christy
description: LEAD: Burkhardt & Christy Advertising has been named to do advertising for the St. Gillian Fashion Group. The client promises a budget of ''several'' million dollars.

title: Richardson Applies
description: After two years, Micheal Ray Richardson formally applied to the Na-tional Basketball Association yesterday for an end to his suspension for drug use and for readmission to the league as a player for the Nets. Under the drug agreement between the league and the National Basketball Players Association, Richardson, 32 years old, had been banned from the N.B.A. for cocaine use, but was eligible for reinstatement after two years. The league's investigation and decision could take four months. To persuade David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, to overturn the ban, the burden of proof will be on Richardson to show that he is no longer addicted to drugs and is living without a dependency on any chemical substance. Richardson, the first player to be banned under the league's drug policy, could apply again if his first request for readmission is rejected.

title: DICK CLARK PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Weekend Show of Antique Fishing Gear
description: THOSE who deal in antique collectibles know that old fishing gear, whether rods, reels, lures or even yellowing tackle catalogues, has become highly prized in recent years. To this, one may now add antique fish decoys, used, usually through a hole cut in the ice, to lure large fish within range of a spear. A lure without hooks, if you will.

title: Fed Alters Economic Monitoring
description: In a significant change in policy, the Federal Reserve Board has altered the way it monitors the economy, its vice chairman, Manuel H. Johnson, said today. The new approach will give the financial markets a better sense of where interest rates are heading.

title: National Rise Reported in Teacher Pay
description: The country's average teacher salary rose 5.3 percent in 1987 while the percentage of students graduating from high school stayed roughly the same, the Department of Education reported today in its annual state-by-state review of public education.

title: Distortions Abound on Life of Koreans in Japan; Anger Over Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Vice President Bush's demand for an apology from Pat Robertson misstated some results of Tuesday's Presidential contests. The vote percentages given for Albert Gore (8 percent), Paul Simon (6), Jesse Jackson (5) and Gary Hart (5) were for the South Dakota Democratic primary, not the Minnesota caucuses.

title: Advertising; New Effort By Insurance Institute
description: IN carrying out the industry's mandate, the 29-year-old Insurance Information Institute publishes brochures, monographs and books; does original research; sponsors seminars, and trains speakers for radio and television.

title: Disputed Court Nominee Promises No Surprises
description: Bernard H. Siegan, a California law professor whose nomination to a Federal appeals court has touched off intense liberal opposition, insisted at his Senate confirmation hearing today that he would follow Supreme Court precedent ''without question or reservation of any sort.''

title: BLOCKBUSTER ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
Isabel Hoopes Grinnell, Art Curator, Dies at 89
description: Isabel Hoopes Grinnell, a former assistant curator in the department of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan Museum, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. She was 89 years old and until recently lived in New York City and Waquoit, Mass.

title: Gault's Sled Fails In a Bid to Compete
description: For eight years, Willie Gault has been trying to compete in the Olympics. His quest may have ended today. In 1980, when he made the United States Olympic track team as a sprinter, the United States boycotted the Moscow Olympics. In 1984, he was playing wide receiver for the Chicago Bears of the National Football League. When the Bears' season ended last month, he rejoined the United States bobsledders in Europe.

title: News Cut Off as Armenian Protests Continue
description: Armenian nationalist protests continued today in two southern Soviet republics as the authorities in Moscow moved to limit the flow of information from the area.

title: EDO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1987 earnings include Barnes Engineering Co. for the full year. In 1986, Barnes results were included from July 1, 1986.

title: Astoria Journal; Where a River and the Sea Eat Ships
description: Just before a recent sunrise the unforgiving edge of the Pacific Ocean claimed another boat here at the mouth of the Columbia River, a place locally considered among the shipwreck capitals of the world.

title: Film: Wilford Brimley Stars in 'End of the Line'
description: THERE is a moment when ''End of the Line'' looks like a small miracle. However, that moment is extremely brief, and it occurs during the film's opening credits; no such impression ever comes again. Here in the cast of this unprepossessing small-town story are such singular actors as Mary Steenburgen, Holly Hunter, Kevin Bacon and Levon Helm, whose presence alone ought to be enough to hold the interest. But ''End of the Line,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street, is hopelessly mired in local color and unimaginative good intentions.

title: It's Still a Republic, Not a Corporation
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Suggests Poor Readers Are Hurt by Teachers' Tactics
description: A new report suggests that poor readers are left at a disadvantage by school teachers who help them figure out hard words but neglect to make them discuss the meaning of the passages the words are in.

title: Market Place; Niche Companies In Technology
description: WHILE certain large technology companies reported lackluster operating earnings in their most recent quarter, some smaller companies are expected to experience strong gains in both earnings and stock prices in 1988, benefiting from their niche markets.

title: Timeless Calendar
description: With the White House up for grabs and Congress unable to plan its schedule more than a day at a time, some may take comfort in the fact that at least one major institution of Government maintains an air of immutability.

title: AT THE BAR
description: A decade ago, George C. Kern Jr. described his frenetic life as Sullivan & Cromwell's premier corporate takeover lawyer. ''Fulfilling? Challenging? Exciting? You better believe it!'' he gushed. ''Happy? You betcha! And the answers would have been the same on any day in the past 28 years.''

title: Pop/Jazz; City College Offers Sound Of Tangier
description: THE Gnaoua musicians of northern Africa carry an exalted musical tradition. In the public squares of Marrakesh and Tangier, they perform for ecstatic, all-night ceremonies. They accompany dancers and acrobats; they summon spirits; sometimes they work what Westerners would regard as miracles - walking on hot coals, or making wounds disappear. The music revolves around call-and-response singing and the propulsive riffs plucked on the guenbri, a three-stringed, camel-skin-faced lute that can sound like a cello. The network of riffs and rhythms is related to West African music - more so than most North African music, which looks toward Arab music - and by way of West Africa to Caribbean and North American music.

title: Restaurants; Downtown bistro, uptown Italian.
description: WHEN the French bistro Quatorze opened three-and-a-half years ago along West 14th Street, a Latin-flavored commercial strip of bodegas, cut-rate clothing emporiums and bilingual driving schools, it seemed as incongruous as Yves Montand in a salsa band. Yet the restaurant was an immediate hit, both for its ingenuous, reasonably priced food and its casual, convivial setting. It remains so today - and deservedly so.

title: COMMONWEALTH MORTGAGE OF AMERICA LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: About Real Estate; Lot Layout Aids Privacy In Big Westchester Tract
description: An unusual way of laying out houses on a large tract is being devised for a Westchester development of 306 high-priced homes in Harrison, N.Y. The idea is to provide privacy amid an unspoiled natural setting.

title: Advertising; Chock Full o'Nuts Spot by TBWA
description: New Yorkers may get plenty of Chock Full o'Nuts coffee, but of late they haven't been getting much Chock Full o'Nuts advertising. And those of you who remember the advertising are probably glad.

title: Infringement Case Ruling Disclosed
description: Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass., said that a United States district judge had ruled that Amgen Inc. had infringed on its patent covering recombinant erythropoietin, or EPO, a hormone used to treat anemia in kidney dialysis patients. Amgen, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., had sued Genetics Institute for infringing on Amgen's patent, which covers the production of the genetically engineered EPO.

title: Reagan Trade Panel Urges New Move Against Japan
description: An Administration advisory body voted unanimously today to recommend that President Reagan initiate a trade retaliation case against Japan because of deadlocked negotiations on opening its construction market to foreign companies.

title: MIDDLE EASTERN MUSIC
description: Zusaan Kali Fasteau, who plays soprano saxophone, piano and wind and percussin instruments from the Middle East, Japan, Morocco, Brazil and elsewhere, is to lead a trio with Sirone on bass and Badal Roy on Indian tabla drums tonight at 8 at Greenwichh House, 27 Barrow Street. Tickets are $10; information, 206-1050.

title: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After non operating income of $5,837 and $23,895 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a realized investment loss of $2,284,208 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $307,205 for the year. c-Includes a loss on non operating income of $7,734 for the quarter and non operating income of $33,900 for the year, and realized investment gains of $389,367 and $3,341,914 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ALOETTE COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Campeau Maneuvers In Bid for Federated
description: The Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Brooks Brothers chain to Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the big British retailer, for $770 million if Campeau acquired Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: Yesterday's Medal Winners
description: Alpine Skiing Men's Giant Slalom Gold: Alberto Tomba, Italy Silver: Hubert Strolz, Austria Bronze: Pirmin Zurbriggen, Switzerland Cross-Country Women's 20 km Gold: Tamara Tikhonova, Soviet Union Silver: Anfissa Reztsova, Soviet Union Bronze: Raisa Smetanina, Soviet Union Totals: Soviet Union - 9 gold, 9 silver, 7 bronze; East Germany -7 gold, 6 silver, 4 bronze; Finland - 4 gold, 2 bronze; Austria - 3 gold, 4 silver, 2 bronze; Sweden - 3 gold, 1 bronze; Switzerland - 2 gold, 5 silver, 4 bronze; West Germany - 2 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze; United States - 2 gold, 1 silver, 1 bronze; the Netherlands - 1 gold; 2 silver, 2 bronze; France - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Italy - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Norway - 3 silver, 2 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 3 bronze; Czechoslovakia - 1 silver, 2 bronze; Yugoslavia - 1 silver, 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Brawleys Called Willing to Be Jailed
description: Tawana Brawley and her family would go to jail rather than testify to a grand jury empaneled by State Attorney General Robert Abrams, a minister who has been advising the Dutchess County teen-ager said today.

title: BERCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Includes accounting change gains of $61,000 for the quarter and $141,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income The company said that during the latest third quarter it reversed the income tax benefit and expense previously recognized during the first and second quarters ended July 3, 1987, and Oct. 2, 1987, respectively, as a result of the third quarter loss and the anticipated year-end results.

title: Bridge: New York City Tournament Is Focusing on Newcomers
description: An assortment of events will be provided at the first tournament of the year to be played in New York City, but the focus will be on newcomers - players with little or no experience in serious play.

title: Diner's Journal
description: PERIPATETIC nibblers should note the name of a new Spanish tapas bar and restaurant on the Upper West Side: Alcala.

title: COMPUDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from divestitures of $4,068,000 and $4,401,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $94,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $5,000 for the quarter and a gain of $5,206,000 for the year, both from divestitures, and the year includes a tax credit of $446,000 and net from discontinued operations of $866,000.

title: Candidates Err About Both Deficits
description: LEAD: The leading Presidential candidates are virtually unanimous in their belief that the Federal budget deficit must be cut significantly if the economy is to remain healthy and if the trade deficit is to come down. As always, this spirit of agreement should be regarded with the highest degree of skepticism.

title: BRITISH TELECOMMUNICATIONS PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. Results are in U.S. dollars. Results for both the 1987 and 1986 periods have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.89 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Dec. 31, 1987, the last date of the reporting period.

title: Torrence's Streak on the Line
description: Theater tickets? Perhaps Gwen Torrence might be interested in some otherwise unattainable theater tickets.

title: Uptown, Novices and Modern Masters
description: WHEN voices are raised, cooler heads generally prevail. So it is that with all the high-flown rhetoric one can see nowadays in works on display at galleries along 57th Street and uptown, several of the more soft-spoken artists make the most persuasive statements: at the Cordier & Ekstrom Gallery (417 East 75th Street, through March 19), for instance, are the small, Surrealistic collages of Varujan Boghosian. A show of Giacometti's quietly anguished, gracefully drawn postwar works on paper is now at the Arnold Herstand Gallery (24 West 57th Street, through April 30). And the art of Paule Vezelay, the English painter who died in 1984, can be viewed at the Zabriskie Gallery (724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, through April 2).

title: Film: 'The Last Minute'
description: IN the last minutes of ''The Last Minute,'' we seem about to be treated to the big soccer match for which we have been prepared by the first hour and a half of the Italian movie that opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room. And, sure enough, the game starts - only the camera is facing the wrong way. Foul! We see the stands filled with rooters, the dugout with players, the press box with reporters; we see the stadium's passageways and locker rooms; what we don't see is the field. When the 17-year-old ''yearling,'' who we know will save the game in the last minute, kicks the crucial goal, the news is brought to us by a radio announcer. It's enough to drive a fan to riot.

title: Corrections
description: The Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Wednesday misidentified a rumored candidate for executive director of the National Economic Commission. He is Stephen E. Bell, head of the Washington office of Salomon Brothers.

title: The Way It Oughta Be
description: John Ziegler President, National Hockey League 650 Fifth Avenue New York, N.Y. 10019 Dear John,

title: Sunset for a Baseball Tradition: They're Lighting Wrigley Field
description: After 72 summers of playing only daytime baseball at Wrigley Field, the Chicago Cubs were given permission by city officals today to install lights and schedule night games at home this season.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mets Ponder Pitching Outlook
description: So what about those eight pitchers who were disabled last year for a combined total of 457 days and who probably cost the Mets the pennant? Have they recovered? Are the Mets sure they can go out and start winning again this year?

title: Olajide-Barkley Bout
description: Both Michael Olajide and Iran Barkley lost in their bids for middleweight titles last October, Olajide to Frank Tate for the International Boxing Federation title and Barkley to Sumbu Kalambay for the World Boxing Association title. But neither sounded like a loser at a news conference yesterday for the Olajide-Barkley bout at the Felt Forum March 6. Olajide told Barkley: ''You better buy industrial-strength toothpicks to pick the leather out of your teeth,'' a reference to the punches he intends to land on Barkley. Barkley told Olajide: ''I'm bringing a bucket of water. And when I knock you out, I'm going to throw it on you and wake you up. And knock you out again.'' Olajide (25-1 with 17 knockouts) is the I.B.F.'s top-ranked middleweight contender. Barkley (22-5 with 13 knockouts) is ranked seventh by the W.B.A.

title: Panel Urges Retesting of All New York Physicians
description: All 50,000 physicians in New York State would have to be re-examined to retain their licenses under a plan unanimously agreed on by a state medical panel formed by Governor Cuomo.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Two Years Later, Manila Flounders
description: If the peaceful ouster of Ferdinand E. Marcos was, as a popular song here has it, ''the Philippines' lesson to the world,'' it was hard to know today, on the second anniversary of his flight out of the country, just what that lesson was.

title: PURIM CELEBRATION
description: The Jewish holiday of Purim, which begins on Wednesday, is to be celebrated this Sunday with a parade and fair at the Loeb Student Center of New York University West Fourth Street and La Guardia Place. At 12:15 P.M., youngsters in holdiay costumes are to walk from the arch in Washington Square to the student center, where food, crafts and entertainment will await. Sponsors are the Educational Alliance West and other organizations from the Lower East Side. Admission is $5 ($3 for students and the elderly and $2 for those under 12). Information: 463-8588 or 420-1150.

title: OAKITE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kentucky Star Sidelined
description: Rex Chapman, Kentucky's standout guard, is expected to be out for two weeks while he recovers from a back injury, the team physician said. Chapman fractured a small bone next to the vertebrae that is attached to muscle in the lower back, in a 95-69 victory over Louisiana State Wednesday night. ''His return will depend on his comfort and rest over the next few weeks,'' said Dr. Michael Ray. Chapman leads Kentucky with a scoring average of 18 points a game.

title: Insurance Plan for Pipeline Involved Israeli Aid Pledge
description: Supporters of an Iraqi-Jordanian pipeline project offered a plan in late 1985 under which Israel would be allowed to pledge American military aid as insurance against an Israeli attack on the project, according to Government officials.

title: Outrageous Speech? Yes, and Free.
description: When a Supreme Court headed by William Rehnquist declares the deepest commitment to free speech, and does so unanimously, it furthers a thrilling principle of liberty. Larry Flynt's rancid Hustler magazine may have ridiculed the Rev. Jerry Falwell in the coarsest and most outrageous way. But freedom of speech, the Court declares, extends to utterances that are outlandish, even detestable. The Court thus reaffirms its historic trust in the people to decide for themselves what to read and what to heed.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $293,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: At Least 9 Are Killed In Army Copter Crash
description: An Army helicopter carrying 18 soldiers crashed and burned in a pasture today, killing nine people,the authorities said. Nine others were seriously burned. The helicopter, a twin-rotor Ch-47D Chinook based at Fort Sill, Okla., crashed about 3 P.M. near this community northwest of Fort Worth, Wise County sheriff's officers said. Two of those aboard leaped 35 feet to the ground before the crash. One died after the fall.

title: Mr. Bork Regrets
description: True to his promise when he left the Federal bench, Robert Bork is refighting his unsuccessful battle for the Supreme Court. In TV appearances, he complains that the Senate's refusal to confirm his nomination has discouraged lawyers from publishing controversial legal articles. Like Attorney General Meese, who called the Senate's action ''anti-intellectual,'' Mr. Bork says all this is ''bad for the intellectual life of the law.''

title: Advertising; People
description: * Anthony J. Adams and Paul N. Mulcahy have been named vice presidents of marketing research and advertising, respectively, at Campbell Soup Co.

title: Corrections
description: A table of New York City school reading scores on Tuesday gave an incorrect ranking for Junior High School 59 in southeastern Queens. It was 39th. In addition, the scores for 19 Staten Island elementary schools were omitted. They are printed today on page B4.

title: BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
On Stage
description: 'Around the World'

title: Afterlife of the Famous: Heirs Warn of 'Poachers'
description: In Modigliani-esque repose, the likeness of W. C. Fields - in white gloves, cane, top hat, bow tie and absolutely nothing else -bore witness to the legislative proceedings yesterday.

title: Filibuster on Campaign Spending Bill Ends
description: The filibuster that had halted activity in the Senate ended this evening, setting the stage for Republicans to win their effort to stop a bill limiting spending on Congressional campaigns.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Soviet Indicates Easing of Stand On 'Star Wars'
description: A senior Soviet official indicated today that the Soviet Union might drop a key objection to the American development of a space-based missile defense system by permitting the testing of components in space.

title: A String Quartet Savors the New
description: THERE are those who worry about the future of classical music. But insofar as the string quartet, the core ensemble of such music, is concerned, their worries seem misplaced. On both sides of the Atlantic, composers are writing new quartets with beaverish glee and audiences are flocking to hear them. And although many performing groups are playing a part in this renaissance, two stand out.

title: Reading Scores Are Reported For 19 Staten Island Schools
description: Nineteen elementary schools on Staten Island were omitted from a table on Tuesday that listed reading scores for city schools. They are listed here.

title: Soviet Skiers Score A Sweep
description: Tamara Tikhonova led a Soviet medal sweep in the women's 20-kilometer race today, the final women's cross-country event of the Winter Olympics.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jessica Brodax Is Married To D. J. Harris, Executive
description: The marriage of Jessica Brodax, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Brodax of Weston, Conn., to David Jay Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Robert Harris of New York, took place last evening at the East River Yacht Club in New York. Rabbi Benjamin M. Kahn officiated.

title: Bush Makes Big Gains in New York
description: Without a single vote cast, Vice President Bush has within his grasp 45 Republican National Convention delegates from New York State, more than two-thirds the number he has won in bitter primaries and caucuses in Iowa, New Hampshire and other states.

title: Vandals Paint Swastika In a Yonkers Apartment
description: Early today someone spray-painted a swastika on the wall outside the apartment of Laurie A. Recht, the only Yonkers resident who spoke in support of a court-ordered desegregation plan at a City Council hearing last month.

title: Nine-Year Fugitive Arrested
description: A man sought for nine years on a Florida sex charge has been arrested in Tucson, where he has been living under an assumed name, the authorities said today. Retha Rogers said she was unaware that David Elliott Rogers, her husband of six years, was Charles Danison. Local officials, acting on a tip from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, arrested Mr. Danison at his home late Wednesday.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BIG GAIN REPORTED ON AIDS PNEUMONIA
description: An antibiotic drug treatment has prevented the onset of a rare but deadly form of pneumonia that is the most common cause of death in AIDS patients, the authors of a new study reported today.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $153,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Mamdouh Salem, 70; Was Egyptian Premier
description: Mamdouh Salem, a former Prime Minister of Egypt, died in London on Wednesday while undergoing treatment for an undisclosed illness, a Foreign Ministry official said today. He was 70 years old.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,635,000 for the quarter and a gain of $12,458,000 for the year from the disposal of discontinued operations; the year also included a gain of $625,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $1,115,000. c-After gains of $674,000 for the quarter and $2,268,000 for the year from discontinued operations and losses of $50,000 and $626,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from disposal of discontinued operations.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday TERRA-COTTA BUILDINGS

title: Dole's Chairman Angrily Dismisses 2 Senior Campaign Aides
description: A power struggle in Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign ended abruptly today when Bill Brock, the campaign chairman, angrily dismissed two senior aides who have been traveling with the Kansan.

title: SITUATION UNCLEAR
description: Panama's civilian President announced yesterday the dismissal of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the country's principal leader, as commander of the Defense Forces.

title: Third Investor Seeks Sizable Texaco Stake
description: A third investor has announced plans to buy a stake in Texaco Inc.

title: Helmick Outlines Concerns
description: With the United States about to finish one of its less successful Winter Olympics, the United States Olympic Committee this week took the first step in trying to learn how to make its programs more efficient and its athletes more productive.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Most Latin Nations, Ending Reticence, Back Deposed Panamanian
description: Most Latin American Governments today condemned the move to dismiss Panama's civilian President in a confrontation with the military ruler.

title: Living With Violence: Disbelief and Fear Shake South Jamaica
description: When the man known only as Arjune and his family moved into a vacant three-story house on Inwood Street and 107th Avenue in South Jamaica, Queens, last September, the double lot was overgrown with weeds and littered with whisky bottles and vials for crack. He cut back the brush, cleaned the lot and had the house painted and remodeled.

title: Resorts Holder Rejects Trump Bid
description: Dale V. Scutti, an investor based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said he would not tender his 5.6 percent stake in Resorts International Inc. class A common stock to the New York real estate developer Donald J. Trump.

title: Art Show on the Seasons
description: Winter in the city - as well as summer, spring and fall - can be seen in a free photography exhibition that opens March 8 at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street. About 30 photographs by Jonathan Weld that capture the seasons' changes are featured in the show, which will be up through April 1. Gallery hours are 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday.

title: The 'Secret' Warranty
description: How long does an automobile warranty last? Sometimes a lot longer than the document states.

title: NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax gain of $27.3 million on curtailment or settlement of pensions for the quarter and year, and after a pre-tax loss of $718,000 for the quarter and a pre-tax gain of $3,882,000 for the yeart from the sale of business units, and a loss from discontinued operations of $30,025,000 for the both periods. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $15.6 million for the quarter and $38,734,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter had net from continuing operations equal to 11 cents a share after provision for preferred dividends and excluding losses attributable to NL's series C preferred stock. Both year-ago periods' net from continuing operations is after a pre- tax gain on pensions of $81.5 million. The final net loss for 1986 is after a second quarter charge of $247.8 million reflecting a writedown in the carrying value of petroleum-service assets and other restructuring costs, including $224.7 million charged to continuing operations.

title: Film: William Richert's 'Reardon'
description: ''A Night in the Life of Jimmy Reardon'' is hardly the first film about the sexual exploits of a very busy adolescent boy, and it won't be the last. But since it's the work of William Richert, director of the unforgettably nutty little masterpiece ''Winter Kills,'' it's anything but standard issue.

title: HARLEYSVILLE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $183,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $194,000 for the year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $9,409,000 and $11,063,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and capital gains of $109,000 for the quarter and $2,226,000 for the year. Year-earlier quarter and year net from discontinued operations both include a gain from the sale of a business of $9,148,000.

title: Obituary of James Marcus Seemed an Editorial
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: HBO's 'On Location' Presents Dennis Miller
description: On NBC's ''Saturday Night Live,'' Dennis Miller is the ''Weekend Update'' anchor, reviewing the week's headlines with a flip grin that challenges the audience to realize just how clever he is. On his first solo television special, ''Mr. Miller Goes to Washington,'' he brings the same carefully honed manner to his stand-up comedy act. This Dennis Miller/Brad Grey Production, produced by Vic Kaplan and directed by Paul Miller, is a Home Box Office ''On Location'' presentation. It is having its premiere on the pay-cable service tonight at 10 o'clock.

title: SOVIET TO HOLD ART AUCTION IN PACT WITH SOTHEBY'S
description: The Soviet Culture Ministry and Sotheby's auction house announced an agreement today to hold the first international art auction in Moscow since the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I call on you to display civic maturity and restraint, return to normal life and work, and observe social order.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in address to Armenians. [ 1:4. ]

title: XEBEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: The latest quarter results included a net gain of $4,360,000 stemming from the settlement of the Xebec development partners dispute and $676,000 of charges from the settlement of the KS xA marketing judgment against Xebec.

title: NEW YORK MARINE & GENERAL INURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $27,876 for the quarter and $48,498 for the year. c-After net realized investment gains of $142,538 and $359,434 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Farm Export Gains Seen
description: The Agriculture Department has predicted that the value of United States agricultural exports will rise to a four-year high in the fiscal year 1988.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: St. Patrick's Program Planned for Radio City
description: The Irish tenor Frank Patterson will be featured in a St. Patrick's Day celebration of music and dance, March 16 at 8 P.M. at Radio City Music Hall, Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street. Mr. Patterson, who has been a singer since childhood, has performed for the Pope, for President Reagan, and at churches and concert halls in the United States and Europe. He also appears in the John Huston film ''The Dead.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the alignment of political convention delegates in New York misidentified a Democratic candidate for delegate for the campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson. He was Allen Roskoff.

title: Church Elders Reject Leniency For Swaggart
description: The elders of the Assemblies of God today rejected a recommendation of lenient punishment for the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart and returned the issue to Louisiana church officials for reconsideration.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 16
Donald C. Adams, Banker, 83
description: Donald C. Adams, a retired vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died Wednesday at the Holy Spirit Hospital in Camp Hill, Pa. He was 83 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Q-MED INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $465,539. The year-ago results restated to reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid May 11, 1987.

title: Campaign Spending Bill Is Lifted After Vote Fails to End Filibuster
description: Democrats withdrew a bill to limit spending on Congressional elections today after failing for the eighth time to break a Republican-led filibuster against the measure.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter includes a provision for an unrealized gain on marketable securities of $45,000. The latest 9-month includes a provision for an unrealized loss on marketable securities of $351,500.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6, 32 In Panama's power struggle, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared to cemented his place as principal leader after rebuffing a Presidential move to oust him. Instead, the President himself was declared removed by the National Assembly. Page 1 Support for civilian rule in Panama was voiced by the Reagan Administration. The United States threw its full support behind the civilian President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, in his attempt to oust General Noriega. 5 U.S. curbs troops movements in Panama 5 Most Latin nations back deposed Panamanian 5 Mikhail Gorbachev urged Armenians to end nationalist protests in two Soviet southern republics. Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward called the shooting a ''deliberate assassination.'' 1 The killing of the officer has brought incredulity to the neighborhood in South Jamaica. Your Money;
Mixing Financing And Friendship

While some such ventures have rewarded their early backers with extraordinary returns, financial planners warn that these investments require an extra-careful weighing of the risks.

description: Apparently rebuffing American demands for improvement in human rights policies, Rumania has told the United States it no longer wants the trade benefits that Washington links to such policies, the State Department announced today.

title: Judge Bars U.S. Damages in Shuttle Suit
description: The widow of an astronaut who was killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded cannot sue the Government for damages because her husband was on military duty at the time, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: Drug Smugglers Used Cuban Base For U.S. Shipment, Jury Charges
description: Two Federal indictments unsealed today charge 17 people with smuggling Colombian cocaine into Florida through a Cuban military base. A Federal drug official said the operation apparently had official cooperation in Cuba.

title: Societe Generale
description: The Brussels bourse halted trading at the start of business today in shares of Belgium's biggest company, Societe Generale de Belgique, the object of a five-week takeover battle between Italy's Carlo de Benedetti and an array of rivals. Bourse officials suspended stock of Societe Generale, a huge conglomerate, when it jumped 15 percent, to a new high of 8,060 francs, or about $228.32, a share.

title: It's All in Genesis
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Nordiques Beat Red Wings: Michel Goulet's 35th goal of the season, 5 minutes 57 seconds into the second period, broke a 2-2 tie last night and Quebec held on for a 3-2 victory in Detroit. Mario Brunetta, the Nordiques' goalie, stopped the final 27 shots he faced as Quebec won for only the second time in its last six games. The loss was the third straight for Detroit. The score was tied at 2-2 after one period before Peter Stastny slipped a pass to Goulet, whose shot from the slot beat Glen Hanlon.(AP) Cycling Phinney in the Lead: Davis Phinney of Boulder, Colo., regained the lead in the Florida portion of the Tour of the Americas bicycle race yesterday when his six-rider team won a 28-mile time trial in St. Petersburg. Less than three hours later, Phinney extended his lead by winning a closely contested one-hour circuit race. He surged ahead of the pack of 91 riders in the final yards to edge Paolo Rosola of Italy. In the first race, Phinney's six-rider team had a time of 54 minutes 15 seconds. Steve Tilford of Topeka, Kan., who led the event going into yesterday's fourth and fifth stages, fell to second place, 37 seconds behind Phinney. Tilford's team was eighth in the time trial, more than two minutes behind Phinney's team. A 101-mile race is set for today in West Palm Beach. The final leg will be tomorrow in Coconut Grove, a Miami suburb.(AP) Tennis Navratilova in Semifinal: Martina Navratilova beat Zina Garrison for the 21st straight time yesterday, posting a 6-1, 6-3 victory to gain a berth in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament in Fairfax, Va. Navratilova, who has never lost to Garrison, has won 42 of 44 sets against her. The top-seeded Navratilova will next play Hana Mandlikova, who overcame an 0-3 deficit in the final set to eliminate Natalya Zvereva, 5-7, 6-3, 6-3. Pam Shriver and Gabriela Sabatini also advanced and will face each other in the semifinals. Shriver, seeded second, registered a 6-2, 7-5 decision over Helena Sukova. Shriver has won 465 matches, which puts her 10th among female professionals in the Open Era, which began in 1968. Sabatini won 9 of the final 11 games in a 6-3, 6-2 triumph over Barbara Potter.(AP) Another Upset: Unseeded Jorge Lozano, who has left a trail of upsets in the United States Pro Indoor tournament in Philadelphia, did it again yesterday by defeating 14th-seeded Dan Goldie, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, to advance to the semifinals. Lozano reached the quarterfinals by beating Wally Masur, Amos Mansdorf and Jim Pugh. In another quarterfinal match last night, Christo Van Rensburg defeated Sammy Giammalva, 7-6, 6-2.(AP) Golf Strong Showing by Crenshaw: Ben Crenshaw, an extremely disappointed runner-up in the Los Angeles Open a year ago, shot a seven-under-par 64 yesterday to share the second-round lead in this year's tournament at the Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles. Crenshaw was in a tie with Jay Haas at nine-under-par 133. Haas, in a four-way tie for the lead at 65 after the opening round, shot a 68 yesterday. Chip Beck, who also had a 65 on Thursday, shot a 69 yesterday to join three others at 134. Last year here, Crenshaw made an 18-foot birdie putt on No. 18 on the final day to take a one-shot lead over T. C. Chen. But Chen rolled in a 16-footer to send the tournament into overtime. Crenshaw missed a 3-foot par putt on the first playoff hole to give Chen the victory.(AP) Delk Ahead in Hawaii: Joan Delk battled stiff winds on Oahu's north shore yesterday to shoot a three-under-par 69 for a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. Hawaiian OpenDelk, who has won in two years on the L.P.G.A. Tour, matched the best round of her career despite winds gusting to 25 miles per hour on the 6,220-yard Turtle Bay Resort course. Delk made four birdies and one bogey for a 140 total, four par, going into today's final round of the 54-hole tournament. JoAnne Carner and Ayako Okamoto, the 1987 L.P.G.A. player of the year, one stroke back 141. Carner shot a 71 yesterday; Okamoto finished with a 72. Anne-Marie Palli shot a 71 for a 142 total and sole possession of fourth place.Five players, including Thursday's, leader Jan Stephenson, were three strokes back at 143. The others were Sally Quinlan, Kathy Postlewait, Beth Daniel and Cathy Gerring.(AP) Hill Leads Seniors: Dave Hill struggled with his putter but still shot a four-under-par 68 for a one-stroke lead after one round of the Aetna Challenge for Seniors in Naples, Fla. Bob Charles, Bruce Devlin and Don Massengale were tied for second at The Club at Pelican Bay.

title: Cubs and Commitment
description: Mayor Eugene Sawyer of Chicago said yesterday he will not sign the ordinance allowing the Cubs to play at night unless they agree to stay until 2002. ''I am convinced they will sign'' such an agreement, Sawyer said. ''I heard from them last evening.'' The City Council approved Sawyer's plan to allow 8 night games this year and 18 each subsequent year until 2002, but the Mayor said, ''We won't sign unless we get a commitment from the Cubs that they will stay.'' Wrigley Field has been the only ball park without lights for 40 years. The last team to start playing night games was the Detroit Tigers in 1948. The City Council voted Thursday to allow lights at the park after two and a half hours of impassioned debate. The Cubs say a $5 million lighting system should be ready in four to six months.

title: Music: Ronstadt in Mariachi Show
description: As Linda Ronstadt has floated from one musical genre to another over the past decade, she has often exuded the aura of a privileged storybook princess wafted by magic carpet from enchanted world to enchanted world. ''Canciones de Mi Padre,'' the elaborately produced show of Mexican mariachi music that she brought to the City Center Theater on Thursday for a four-night run, carries Ms. Ronstadt's penchant for building dream worlds around her own musical fantasies to a logical and enthralling extreme.

description: Three companies accused of fraudulently selling as kosher thousands of pounds of non-kosher poultry have agreed in a legal settlement to leave the business, officials said today.

description: Gerald Wilkins scored 8 of his 34 points in the final 6 minutes tonight, leading the Knicks to their third straight victory, a 125-119 decision over the Golden State Warriors.

title: IU in Reversal On Buyout
description: IU International Inc. said this evening that its board had withdrawn its approval of a $21.50-a-share leveraged buyout led by the Dean Witter Capital Corporation. The bid, made on Monday, was immediately topped by an unfriendly offer of $22-a-share by Neoax Inc.

title: Judge Drops Murder Charges In the Hurricane Carter Case
description: A Superior Court judge today formally dismissed 22-year-old triple murder charges against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter a week after prosecutors said they would not seek a third trial of the former boxer.

title: Bid for Atlas Stake
description: A New York investment firm, the Tweedy Browne Company, said that it had rejected an offer from the Edgar Bronfman family to buy its 20 percent stake in the Atlas Corporation for $34 a share. But the firm also said it was actively seeking to sell its stake in the gold-exploration concern, which is based in Princeton, N.J. Atlas shares jumped $4.25 today, to $37.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tweedy Browne also favored a restructuring plan from Blasius Industries, an Erie, Pa.-based rubber and metal concern.

title: SEIZURE OF MARINE IS DIVIDING SHIITES
description: A conflict among Lebanon's Shiite Moslems over the abduction of an American marine has grown into an armed confrontation and led to a rift in the main Shiite militia.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: NORIEGA PREVAILS AS ASSEMBLY PICKS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: After rebuffing a presidential move to oust him, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared today to have solidified his power as Panama's principal leader.

description: More than the prizes and the money, the purpose of coming to Madison Square Garden yesterday, on a stop somewhere on the way to Seoul, South Korea, was to complete the indoor track and field season in one piece.

title: BUSINESSMAN BOUGHT WHITE ROCK IN 50'S
description: Alfred Y. Morgan Jr., chairman of the White Rock Products Corporation, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Santucci Urges A Judge to Quit An Abuse Case
description: The Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, has demanded that a state judge remove himself from a child molestation case because the judge has advocated allowing the defendant to lecture on pedophilia in place of serving a prison sentence.

description: Alpine Skiing: Women's Slalom Gold: Vreni Schneider, Switzerland Silver: Mateja Svet, Yugoslavia Bronze: Christa Kinshofer-Guetlein, West Germany Biathlon: 30-km Relay Gold: Soviet Union Silver: West Germany Bronze: Italy Speed Skating: Women's 1000-Meters Gold: Christa Rothenburger, East Germany Silver: Karin Kania, East Germany Bronze: Bonnie Blair, United States Totals: Soviet Union - 10 gold, 9 silver, 7 bronze; East Germany - 8 gold, 7 silver, 4 bronze; Switzerland - 3 gold, 5 silver, 4 bronze; Austria - 3 gold, 4 silver, 2 bronze; West Germany - 2 gold, 3 silver, 2 bronze; Finland - 4 gold, 2 bronze; United States - 2 gold, 1 silver, 2 bronze; the Netherlands - 1 gold; 2 silver, 2 bronze; Norway - 3 silver, 2 bronze; Sweden - 3 gold, 1 bronze; Canada - 1 silver, 3 bronze; Italy - 1 gold, 2 bronze; Yugoslavia - 2 silver, 1 bronze; Czechoslovakia -1 silver, 2 bronze; France - 1 gold, 1 bronze; Japan - 1 bronze.

title: Chrysler Seeks Growth in China
description: The Chrysler Corporation hopes to add passenger cars to the line of Jeeps that it produces in China, a top official of the auto maker said. Gerald Greenwald, head of the Chrysler Motors division of the Chrysler Corporation, said his company had been negotiating with First Automotive Works of Changchun, in northeast China, to produce higher-priced autos for use as official cars and taxis.

title: Piano: Nina Tichman
description: The shimmering textures of Claude Debussy's piano works can seem three dimensional in the right hands, yet many pianists present the music's intricacies as if through a layer of gauze. Wednesday evening, in the second of three Merkin Concert Hall recitals devoted to Debussy's complete piano music, Nina Tichman offered an unusually extroverted look at this composer's canon, and proved herself a perceptive interpreter with a distinct point of view.

title: Wrestling Benefit
description: The 1984 Olympic gold medalist in heavyweight freestyle wrestling, Bruce Baumgartner, was named yesterday to lead a 10-man team against 10 wrestlers from the Soviet Union in a meet March 29 at Madison Square Garden. The meet is a benefit for the Kiwanis' Say No to Drugs Foundation, the United States Olympic wrestling team and the Metropolitan Wrestling Association. John Giura, the wrestling coach at New York University, and Richard Salamone, a seven-time national lightweight champion, were also named. The others will be named later.

title: French Inflation Down
description: French consumer price inflation fell sharply, to an annual rate of 2.4 percent last month from 3.1 percent in December, the National Statistics Institute said today. It attributed the fall mostly to exceptionally high price rises recorded in January 1987, which had an inflation rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent. The monthly inflation rate was two-tenths of 1 percent in January, the ninth consecutive month in which inflation has been running at two-tenths of 1 percent or less, the Finance Ministry said.
