But Noriega loyalists won't go along, and Panama moves closer to a showdown. Washington's best stance for now is to continue backing the democrats while staying out of the field of fire.

title: GBI INTERNATIONAL INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $181,812 for the quarter and $496,104 for the 9 months. The company said year-ago results are not comparable.

title: Federated, Campeau Near Deal
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Campeau Corporation yesterday moved close to a $6.3 billion merger that would be the biggest ever in American retailing.

title: Specialist Sanction
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that a fifth firm of specialists - market makers on the floor of the exchange - would lose the right to deal exclusively in a stock because of poor performance during the market collapse last October.

title: Recital: Victor Derevianko
description: Victor Derevianko's program of Brahms and Liszt at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was narrow in its choice of repertory but probably said the most any music could about his tastes and skills. Mr. Derevianko, who is a pianist, teacher and chamber player in Israel, has the bigness of sound and gesture we associate with the Russian school, but his playing is refreshingly free of the leaden aggression that so often accompanies it. His broad Romantic expressivity, in other words, rarely hurries, with relaxation and patience replacing the tense hard-sell of his younger colleagues.

title: ADVANCED POLYMER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Guidepost; Saving Your Shoes
description: Pavement, rain and snow can damage shoes quickly. With preventive care each season, it's possible to avoid buying new shoes every year. The cost of repairs should be a guide to whether the shoe is worth fixing. Do-it-yourself maintenance can delay professional repairs. Frequent polishing of shoes is the best way to preserve them, industry experts say. Lanolin polish, used with waterproofing products like silicone spray, helps preserve leather. Shoes should be worn in rotation and stored on shoe trees. Shoes caked with salt should be dabbed immediately with a mixture of warm water and white vinegar, or wiped with a liquid salt remover (about $3). For high heels, a clear plastic scuff guard ($1.50) will prevent scrapes and holes. Here is a guide to professional shoe repair. Prices are approximate, based on New York City averages. $ Prroblem Solution Cost Tears in seams Leather patches $7 to $20 Hand-stitching $10 and up Worn heels New lifts Women: $3 and up Men: $7 and up Broken high heel Replace heel $25 to $30 Soles: holes or worn thin New leather soles Women: $25 Men: $30 to $35 Rubber half soles $10 to $15 Faded or stained leather Dyeing $15 to $20 Stiff or worn leather Reconditioning $3 to $20 source: Footwear Industries of America, Washington.

title: Restoring Abyssinian Church's Stature
description: During 34 years of charismatic and controversial leadership under the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church came to be regarded as black New York's most influential institution. The church stood alone as the epitome of the civil rights movement in the area, its influence extending from the network of black churches to City Hall and Congress.

title:
Patents;
A New Effort To Spur U.S. Inventions
description: LEAD: The Patent and Trademark Office said yesterday that it planned to put renewed emphasis on its Project XL to overcome the growing proportion of United States patents granted to foreigners. It was disclosed last week that these patents accounted for 46.6 percent of the 89,385 patents granted in 1987.

title: Dr. Perihan Rosenthal, Psychiatrist, Dies at 55
description: Dr. Perihan Aral Rosenthal, a children's psychiatrist, died Tuesday of a brain tumor at her home in Short Hills, N.J. She was 55 years old.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18.

title: German Steel Week Cut
description: West German steelworkers agreed with employers today to cut the workweek in the troubled industry to 36.5 hours, the shortest ever, beginning Nov. 1. The agreement, covering the majority of West Germany's 150,000 steelworkers, is expected to be ratified by union members on Tuesday. The powerful I.G. Metall union said the 1.5-hour-a-week cut would save about 4,000 jobs. West Germany's steel industry has eliminated thousands of jobs in recent years. jobs in recent years.

title: KEY RATES
FOR ARMENIANS IN U.S., AN ISSUE OF SOLIDARITY
description: Thousands of Armenian immigrants here, and children and grandchildren of immigrants, are watching the Armenian protests in the Soviet Union with anticipation, concern and frustration.

title: Lucille Lortel's Elixir of Youth: Enthusiasm
description: You would think it was her first stage production instead of her 500th.

title: Shamir Resists Shultz on Parts Of Peace Plan
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was reported to have met resistance today from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to at least two key elements of American proposals aimed at starting Arab-Israeli peace talks.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of the artist Isabel Bishop on Monday omitted the sponsor of an achievement award she received from President Jimmy Carter in 1979. It was the Women's Caucus for Art.

title: Life Insurance Sales Rise 11%
description: New sales of life insurance increased 11 percent in 1987, to $11 billion, an industry group reported this week. In releasing its figures

title: Military Manufacturers Warned on Reliability
description: The head of the Tactical Air Command says he has told companies producing fighter planes and other war materiel that he will no longer accept their products unless they are made more reliable.

title: Pop: Springsteen Starts First Tour in 2 Years
description: Bruce Springsteen wants to grow up, settle down and remind his huge audience that there's no escape from responsibility. ''One of the hardest things for me over the past 10 years,'' he said Thursday as he introduced and partly disavowed a song from 1975, ''Born to Run,'' ''has been trying to understand what growing up and being a man is all about - trying to make some kind of home for myself and then trying to hold on to it.''

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $844,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: GUEST SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest quarter includes non-recurring charges of $890,000 for severances, consulting fees and costs associated with the proposed divestiture of its retail division.

title: AMERICAN INTEGRITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $25,000 and $75,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After realized investment gains of $15,000 for the quarter and $164,000 for the year.

title: Israel Liberated Gaza From a Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: Visa Charges Increase
description: United States Visa card holders charged nearly $100 billion last year, a $13 billion increase over 1986. the company said Thursday. Third- and fourth-quarter volumes set records and exceeded expectations by more than 50 percent, Charles T. Russell, president of Visa U.S.A. Inc., said. The number of card holders increased from 98.2 million in 1986 to 106.5 million in 1987, including more than five million Premier Visa card holders, the company said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1988
description: The Economy

title: BRALORNE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $14,417,000 for the latest year and $22,031,000 for year-earlier period. The company said the special charge in the latest period is the net result of a writeoff of goodwill and losses on the sale of discontinued businesses and gains on the settlement of long-term debt and the sale of property.

title: Lone Officers Aren't Unusual, Authorities Say
description: New York City Police Department officials said yesterday that it is not unusual for a sole police officer to be assigned to guard a witness's home, as Officer Edward Byrne was when he was killed early yesterday.

title:
Patents;
Using Optical Couplers In Telephone Networks
description: LEAD: Rapitech Systems Inc. of Suffern, N.Y., received a patent this week on the use of optical couplers in telephone networks. This invention was described as a replacement for cumbersome electromagnetic components in voice and data communication instruments.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $2,143,962, or 23 cents a share, from the sale of properties. c-After a loss of $282,163 on early retirement of debt. Year-ago results are restated for the merger with Harris-Teeter Properties. The company said the latest year includes a gain on the sale of properties of $610,354, compared with $3,052,679 in 1986.

title: U.S. Curbs Movements Of Its Forces in Panama
description: Defense Department officials said today that United States military personnel in Panama had been ordered to remain circumspect and stay out of the political turmoil there.

title: 3 Judges Concern U.S. Coach
description: Despite Debi Thomas's slim lead in the Olympic figure-skating competition, her coach said today that he doubted she would prevent Katarina Witt of East Germany from winning her second Olympic gold medal when competition ends Saturday night with the freestyle program.

title: Of Political Flip-Flops in the '88 Democratic Race
description: After campaigning more or less at arm's length for months, three of the main Democratic Presidential candidates began slugging it out in earnest this week with direct attacks on one another's records.

title: DOW RISES 5.64, to 2, 023.21, IN DULL SESSION
description: LEAD: Stock prices traded in a narrow range yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,023.21, for a gain of 5.64 points.

title: Dispute in South China Sea
description: Vietnam says China has landed troops on two reefs in the South China Sea claimed by both countries, according to a Communist Party newspaper. The paper, Nhan Dan, said Chinese had landed on the reefs in the Spratly Islands between Vietnam and Malaysia. The area is said to have oil deposits.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
NATIONAL ENTERPRISES BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $350,000. c-Net income and after tax credits of $107,000 for the quarter and $1,497,000 for the year. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago fourth quarter.

title: Soviet Clinches Gold in Hockey
description: When the buzzer sounded and they knew for sure that hockey's Olympic gold medal once again belonged to the Soviet Union, the players in red jerseys dropped their sticks and embraced.

title: A Downhill Sport, a Rising Business
description: Snowboarding, a relatively new winter sport that combines elements of surfing, skateboarding and sailboarding, has grown so popular that it is creating a new industry built around the boards and bringing new consumer money to ski shops and resorts.

title: New Ban on Activity of Foes Has '60 Root
description: The South African Government's crackdown this week on anti-apartheid groups is in many ways a logical progression of the process that began with the outright banning of the African National Congress and the Pan Africanist Congress in 1960.

title: Death on Slopes Is Ruled Accident
description: Officials said today that no one appeared to be to blame for the death of the Austrian Olympic team's physician in a skiing collision Thursday.

title: Memphis Slim, Singer Of Blues, Is Dead at 72
description: Memphis Slim, an American blues singer who lived in Paris for more than two decades, died Wednesday in Necker Hospital here, his family announced today. He was 72 years old.

title: USG Rejects Bid by Desert
description: The USG Corporation, the nation's leading maker of gypsum board, today rejected a $2.1 billion takeover bid from Desert Partners L.P., telling the investment group that it had ''no interest in discussing your proposal.''

title: Nance's New Home
description: Acknowledging that the move was contrary to his franchise's commitment to build with young players, Wayne Embry, general manager of the Cleveland Cavaliers, said he traded to obtain Larry Nance because Nance was the best small forward the team could expect to find for several years. ''We thought that it was an opportunity to get an All-Star small forward,'' Embry said. ''And as we look at the draft this year and in the following years, we didn't see that caliber of player there for us.'' The Cavaliers sent three players and three draft choices to the Phoenix Suns for Nance, a seven-year veteran, and Mike Sanders, another veteran, plus a draft choice. The trade was announced Thursday night less than an hour before the National Basketball Association trading deadline. The Cavaliers parted with Kevin Johnson, a guard, Tyrone Corbin, a forward, and Mark West, a center.

title: P A M TRANSPORTATION SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year net included a gain of $167,031 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Article 777088 -- No Title
description: After several weeks of intense talks, a $2.9 billion agreement by three leading cable television companies to buy SCI Holdings Inc., a major force in the industry, fell through late Thursday night.

title: Poll Finds Sharp Differences Among Supporters of Presidential Candidates; Robertson Republicans Stand Out
description: It's not always easy to tell a Bush Republican from a Dole Republican. But Pat Robertson's supporters really stand out, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll of people who say they vote in Republican primaries.

title: UNIVERSAL MATCHBOX GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $239,000 for the quarter and $557,000 for the year. c-Net income and after tax credits of $1,386,000 for the quarter and $1,980,000 for the year. The latest year loss is after $19.2 million of writeoffs relating to unsuccessful promotional products, costs associated with sales and manufacturing reorganizations and the restructuring costs relating to staff reductions.

title: George J. Charles, 69, A Television Producer
description: George Joseph Charles, a television producer and director, died Monday of a heart attack at Lancaster General Hospital in Lancaster, Pa. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. to Require Wider Security for Largest Airports
description: The Government is drafting regulations that will require the nation's largest airports to install new security systems to screen the movements of airport and airline workers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Begley Co., Richmond, Ky., a drugstore chain, said that it had agreed in principle to sell its drugstore business for $19,950,000 to Rite Aid Corp.

title: Shortchanged by Part-Time Work
description: LEAD: America's job machine has a production-control problem. Although most workers want full-time jobs, the machine persists in cranking out excessive part-time positions. Part-time jobs have grown much faster than full-time jobs during the 80's, and more than half of all new short-schedule jobs go to people who want but cannot obtain full-time work.

title: First-Run Syndicators Find Tight TV Market
description: In recent years, the business of making programs for local television stations has been one of the fastest-growing segments of the entertainment industry, if also the least glamorous.

title: Soviet Captures Biathlon Relay
description: The Soviet Union took the lead on the second lap and coasted to victory by 1 minute 7.4 seconds over West Germany today in the 30-kilometer freestyle biathlon relay at the Olympic Winter Games.

title: Poll Finds Sharp Differences Among Supporters of Presidential Candidates; Democrats Have Distinctive Bases
description: Democrats used to complain that their Presidential candidates were too much alike. That is still a matter of debate, but it is clear that their supporters are different.

title: New York City Fights For 4,600 Jobs at Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, which may relocate 4,600 of its Manhattan employees, is becoming a cause celebre among New York City officials trying to attract more development to the boroughs outside Manhattan.

title: Consumer Price Index Rose by 0.3% in January
description: The Consumer Price Index climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in January as higher charges for a broad range of goods and services were substantially offset by the second straight month of lower energy costs, the Labor Department reported today.

title:
Patents;
An X-Ray Device For Chemical Analysis
description: LEAD: An X-ray dispersive and reflective device, which is regarded as important for chemical analysis, was patented this week for the Ovonic Synthetic Materials Company of Troy, Mich. The invention is a synthetic multilayer structure that behaves like a crystal for focusing X-rays.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Two
description: Twice in three days over the last week, John Kordic of the Montreal Canadiens and Gord Donnelly of the Quebec Nordiques squared off, once before the opening face-off last Saturday and the other time just after it last Tuesday. Yesterday, both were suspended for five games each by Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League vice president. The suspensions will take effect next Friday unless the clubs decide to appeal. Coach Jean Perron of the Canadiens and Coach Ron Lapointe of the Nordiques were fined $1,000 each, in addition to the automatic fine of $25,000 to each club for fighting before play began.

title: 4 More Palestinians Killed in Protests
description: Four Palestinians were killed today as widespread protests continued in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Pirates Sign Berenyi
description: Bruce Berenyi, who last pitched in the major leagues with the Mets in 1986, has signed a minor league contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Berenyi, a right-hander with a 45-55 record in seven major league seasons, is 33 years old. He went to spring training with Montreal last year, but underwent shoulder surgery in March and did not play. ''We worked him out last Friday and we liked what we saw,'' said Larry Doughty, assistant to Syd Thrift, the general manager, of the Pirates. Bernyi's best season was in 1984 when he was 12-13 with a 4.45 earned run average while pitching for Cincinnati and the Mets.

title: Buyer Sought For Magazine
description: Psychology Today, the 21-year-old monthly magazine owned by the American Psychological Association, has been put up for sale, according to Dr. Gary R. Vandenbos, the association's executive director for publications and communications.

title: Musical for Children
description: ''Simple Things,'' an original musical for children, will begin Monday at the Manhattan Children's Museum, 314 West 54th Street. The production, which has a medieval theme, will be presented by the Children's Musical Entertainment. The show was jointly created by Sherry Edelman, Lynn Schnurnberger, Emily Squires and Seymour Wishman. Tickets are $6. Information: 925-7895.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net loss and after net charges of $7,840,000 for restructuring costs and other non-recurring charges for the quarter and year. The latest periods' net income included unusual credits totaling $11,093,000 before taxes. The credits are principally from a gain of $15,703,000 on the settlement of pension obligations less a reserve of $3.5 million established to cover anticipated losses on leasing obligations.

title: Photo of Dalit Paz Warshaw (NYT/Dith Pran); Music Prodigy, 13, Reflects on Her Work
description: Dalit Paz Warshaw was about a year old, in bed with a high fever, when her aunt put on a record of Israeli songs. The infant heard it once, ''perking right up,'' her mother said. ''Then she sang half the record back - on pitch of course, and remembering all the Hebrew words.'' That's when Ruti Warshaw began to suspect her baby daughter might be a genius.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $6,003,000 from an accounting change.

title: Uncle Sam, Statesman - and Sucker
description: Every American President has to decide what the nation's interests are in a given foreign country and how much influence the U.S. can have over that country's policies. President Reagan this week demonstrated reasonable success in his calculations concerning South Korea - and ugly failure in his miscalculations concerning South Africa.

title: Bush, a Cautious Front-Runner Again, Avoids Attacks and Personal Campaigning
description: George Bush is back to broad themes, attacks that leave his targets unnamed and campaign events that do not include much handshaking with the voters.

title: About New York; Suing the Hand That Insists On Feeding Them
description: Even the soreheads who live in St. Margaret's House, a low-income, congregate-care, pretty fair deal across the street from the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan, thank their lucky stars for the blond brick building. The best part of it is that no one's rent is more than 30 percent of his income. Some of the tenants have made a Federal case out of the food, all the same.

title: Must We Victimize Crime Victims?
description: LEAD: Crime victims, who are regularly ignored when the subject of constitutional rights is discussed, are being assaulted anew. Several book publishers have recently filed challenges to the so-called Son of Sam laws, enacted in some 30 states, that prevent convicted criminals from profiting by depicting their crimes in books, plays and movies.

title: Category Widened of Cubans Who Can Be Deported Home
description: Cuban immigrants who commit crimes in the United States can be deported to their homeland, even if they have obtained United States citizenship, the Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service has said.

title: DATA I-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latet year includes an $8.2 million pretax provision for the restructuring of the company's computer-aided engineering business.

title: The Day of Light
description: When Democrats talked about holding a brokered convention they thought of Mayor Daley and a smoke-filled room, forgetting that Mayor Daley was dead and that nobody smoked anymore.

title: Books of The Times; A Happy Ending
description: THE HEARTS AND LIVES OF MEN. By Fay Weldon. 357 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Teresa Berganza Replaced
description: The American mezzo-soprano Florence Quivar is to replace Teresa Berganza, who is ill, as guest soloist with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe in a concert at Carnegie Hall Thursday at 8 P.M. Miss Quivar is to sing Mahler's Ruckert Lieder. The orchestra, under the direction of Claudio Abbado, is also to play Prokofiev's Classical Symphony, Schoenberg's Three Pieces for Orchestra, and Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 3 (''Scottish''). Remaining tickets, at $18, $16 and $12.50, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,575,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Music: The Berg Quartet
description: It made perfect sense that the Alban Berg Quartet, whose playing often resembles a civilized discussion among amiable gentlemen, should decide to begin its all-Beethoven program at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening with the String Quartet No. 2 in G (Op. 18, No. 2), sometimes known as the ''conversation quartet.'' Beethoven evidently did not call it that, but the tone of cultivated dialogue that characterizes the score's Hayd=nish opening movement gives the nickname plausibility.

title: Pat Robertson: A Candidate of Contradictions
description: By now Pat Robertson has made clear that he cannot be written off as an electronic Elmer Gantry, a colorful distraction from the rest of the Republican Presidential field.

title: Mystery Writers Select Nominees for Awards
description: Nominees for the 1988 Edgar Allan Poe Awards were announced this week by the Mystery Writers of America.

title: Mimi Moody, Puzzle Creator, 62
description: Mimi Moody, a composer of crossword puzzles for newspapers, including The New York Times and The International Herald Tribune, died of emphysema Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Blair Third to East Germans
description: Maybe there was too much peanut butter on her sandwich. Or not enough jelly. Or maybe it was just too much East German speed. Whatever it was, Bonnie Blair had to be satisfied with a bronze medal tonight in the 1,000-meter sprint of the XV Olympic Winter Games.

title: BLOCK, H & R INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said that during its latest first quarter it reduced its effective income tax rate to reflect the effect for the full fiscal year of the lower corporate tax rates provided by the 1986 Tax Reform.

title: Good Fortune: The Leap Year Saves Tax Rise
description: In Dogpatch, the comic strip environs of Li'l Abner, leap year signals Sadie Hawkins Day, a special celebration. In New York City, human error could have cost the city a bundle in real-estate taxes, but leap year saved the day.

title: Donald S. Macdonald, Real-Estate Broker, 82
description: Donald S. Macdonald, a real-estate executive, died of emphysema Thursday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Siesta Key, Fla.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: School Boards Favor AIDS Mandate
description: Local school boards normally resist orders from above, but many say they need strong state leadership to overcome community obstacles to teaching children about AIDS.

title: Positive Signs on Cyprus
description: LEAD: Moments of diplomatic opportunity are difficult to create, and when they do occur they are often the result of unexpected developments that would have seemed implausible only a few weeks before.

title: Trash Cargo Returning
description: A cargo ship laden with refuse is abandoning its 18-month, six-nation quest for a place to dump 15,000 tons of Philadelphia incinerator ash, a Coast Guard official said today.

title: Hospital Head Forced to Quit
description: New York City officials have forced the head of Goldwater Memorial Hospital to resign amid a prosecutor's investigation into a private group associated with the institution.

title: Screenwriters' Contract to Expire on Monday
description: Contract talks with 9,000 movie and television writers are coming down to the wire, but the negotiations have none of the soap-box orations and hysteria that accompanied the bargaining with directors last June.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,441,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a gain of $4,124,000 from excess for future losses on discontinued operations. c-Includes a tax credit of $5,199,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year includes a gain of $9,633,000 from excess provision for future losses on discontinued operations. The latest quarter and year net both includes a gain of $1,176,000 from the sale of certain assets and the settlement of a lawsuit, and the year also includes a gain of $4,781,000 from adjustment to provision for discontinued operations and plant restructuring. The year-ago quarter includes after- tax gains of $13,571,000 from the implementation of a restructuring plan, and the year includes an after-tax gain of $28,251,000 from restructuring and reversal of excess reserves. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter sales and fiscal 1987 sales include $29,596,000 and $119,614,000, respectively, from divested operations.

title: SEOUL DECLARES AN AMNESTY, BUT NOT FOR EVERYONE
description: In the first major test of its follow-through on election pledges, the new Government announced an amnesty today for hundreds of political prisoners. But by refusing to release many dissidents, including several prominent ones, it faced charges of having reneged on commitments.

title: FINANCIAL CRISIS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Mayor Art Agnos said today that San Francisco faced a $172.4 million deficit in the next fiscal year and city workers would have to be furloughed, city services reduced and transit fares increased.

title:
Patents;
Separating Proteins
description: LEAD: William M. Ayers, a chemical engineer in Princeton, N.J., has invented what he describes as a new method of separating proteins and other charged biological molecules. Proteins are to be separated according to their mass by rotation and application of electric and magnetic fields. Patent 4,726,904 is assigned to Senetek P.L.C., a biotechnology company in Mountain View, Calif.

title: A Killing Mutes 'Joyous' Event Of Police Dept.
description: The slaying of a rookie police officer who was guarding the home of a witness in a drug case in Queens yesterday cast a pall over a promotion ceremony for 91 people at Police Headquarters, where the Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, had planned a congratulatory speech.

title: Jersey Panel Backs Shift in Tax Burden From Towns to State
description: A panel endorsed, 23 to 4, a $1.1 billion proposal today to assist counties and municipalities by cutting property taxes and shifting many expenses to the state.

title: Federal Action Seen as Option In Brawley Case
description: Saying he did not want Tawana Brawley to become ''a pawn in a political shell game,'' a lawyer for the black Dutchess County teen-ager said yesterday that he would turn to Federal officials if Governor Cuomo did not replace the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, as the special prosecutor in the case.

title: Coping: With a Consumer Problem
description: It happens to every consumer: a transaction goes awry, an injustice is suffered. Redress may be yours for the asking, but you have to know how to ask.

title: Common Market Makes Deal With Moroccans on Fishing
description: Morocco and the European Community reached an agreement on Thursday that will allow thousands of Spanish and Portuguese fishermen to resume fishing in Moroccan waters.

title: William Harold Cox, Outspoken U.S. Judge
description: William Harold Cox, a Federal district judge who enraged civil rights advocates with his remarks about blacks but presided over a 1967 trial that convicted eight members of the Ku Klux Klan of killing three civil rights workers, died Thursday at his home here. He was 87 years old. Judge Cox, the son of a Sunflower County sheriff, had a successful practice in corporate and civil law before being named to the Federal bench in 1961. He was an active judge until 1983.

title: Choosing Up Sides: What a Poll Found
description: Robertson backers are more likely to call themselves independent, Bush Republicans are younger, and more Dole supporters are women.

title: INFOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Rangers Move Up As Devils Drop
description: The Rangers climbed into a potential playoff spot for the first time since Nov. 1 and the Devils fell into the cellar of the Patrick Division for the first time this season as a result of New York's 2-1 triumph tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Up Sharply
description: The Treasury securities market rebounded sharply yesterday, largely in reaction to further declines in the price of energy and gold. But the bond market largely ignored another key inflation indicator, the Consumer Price Index, which rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in January.

title: Stop Meddling With the Fed
description: President Reagan seems not to know that his Administration still has problems with the Federal Reserve Board. Carping from the Treasury and the Council of Economic Advisers continues, even though all board members are now Reagan appointees with a Reagan chairman, Alan Greenspan. The President needs to brush up - on current events and on proper policy roles.

title: Officer Guarding Drug Witness Is Slain
description: A rookie New York City police officer was shot to death early yesterday as he guarded the home of a Queens man who had complained to the police about crack dealers bedeviling his South Jamaica neighborhood.

title: PRICE INDEX JUMPS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose twice as fast as those in the rest of the country in January, spurred largely by increases in housing and grocery costs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: New Financial Tool Revives Old Block
description: Five years ago, the block on Underhill Avenue in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn looked like many streets in New York City's most devastated neighborhoods. Opposite an elementary school stood two small apartment buildings that, though deteriorating, were still occupied. They were flanked by three abandoned shells.

title: Justice Kennedy Shuns Special Prosecutor Case
description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who joined the Supreme Court last week, has disqualified himself in one of the most momentous cases the Court has faced in years, the challenge by the Reagan Administration and others to the constitutionality of the special prosecutor law.

title: Sun Ra and Arkestra
description: Sun Ra leads his Arkestra tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Study for Regents Finds Higher Scores and Cut in Dropout Rate
description: The State Education Department said today that scores on standardized state tests were rising, annual dropout rates were declining and class sizes were shrinking.

title: Dance: Peridance Offers Work Based on Folk Mass
description: Peridance is a company connected with a popular Manhattan dance school of the same name.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on Thursday about decorative rose patterns gave an incorrect price for a Bellini ceramic pitcher and washbowl set. It is $90 at Bloomingdale's.

title: U.S. Puts Full Support Behind Delvalle
description: The United States threw its full support today behind Panama's civilian President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, in his attempt to dismiss Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and remain in power himself.

The Political Children Of George Washington

title: USLICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $185,000 for the quarter and $6,838,000 for the year; the year also included a tax credit of $2,160,000. c-After capital gains of $1,065,000 for the quarter and $8,088,000 for the year.

title: WEAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $267,000 for the quarter and $790,000 for the year representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-After an extraordinary gain of $1,237,000. The company said the results for the latest fourth quarter primarily reflect a provision in excess of $11 million related to a previously announced divestiture.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $224,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss of $211,000 and net of $30,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations, and a net gain of $1,725,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. 1986 results are restated to reflect discontinued operations. The company said its underwater diving equipment operation was sold on March 31, 1987, with no gain or loss resulting from the disposal. On Dec. 31, 1986, the company sold its life support equipment operation. The combination of these disposals resulted in the discontinuance of the company's underwater diving and life support equipment segment of operations.

title: Cassini Drives a Winner
description: He's 74 years old, the oldest man to be given his first driving license in harness racing, and he was coming off an inauspicious debut the day before. Besides, his career had been built on fashion lengths, not racing lengths. No matter. Oleg Cassini drove a 10-1 shot to victory at Freehold Raceway Thursday, the second day of his career as a professional harness racing driver. Cassini started in the second position on Hi Po Bay Myst and never trailed, pacing the mile in 2:05 2/5. Hi Po Bay Myst paid $22.20, $13.40 and $7 for $2 across the board, winning by three-quarters of a length over Champaign Johnny. ''I feel great,'' said Cassini in the winner's circle. ''I am very happy to show everyone that I can be competitive.'' On his first day, Cassini finished last in his first race, at least 25 lengths behind the winner. He was thrown from the sulky at the beginning of his second race when his horse reared back and broke the axle on his bike. The track physician said Cassini's blood pressure was too high after the accident and he would not let him drive in his final race. But Cassini had other designs. After winning on Thursday, he drove Airborn Darby to a fifth-place finish in another race.

title: Ford to Overhaul 2 Plants in Ohio
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would invest $320 million in two Ohio plants that are to manufacture a new-generation Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar.

title: Why the Embargo
description: To the Editor:

title: Rio Journal; A City Awash in Beauty and Deluged With Peril
description: Carlindo Teixeira, a man of few means but great love for Rio de Janeiro, has to make some hard choices this week.

title: Broker in Winans Case Is Sentenced
description: Peter N. Brant, a former stockbroker who was a major prosecution witness in the R. Foster Winans case, was sentenced yesterday to eight months in prison for trading stocks using inside information about forthcoming articles in The Wall Street Journal.

Personal but Not Confidential: A New Debate Over Privacy
description: The privacy of personal records -those collected by employers, insurers, retailers and other private organizations - is primarily protected by the lack of interest in them, not by law. When curiosity or a business interest develops, privacy may vanish.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dance review of the Ballet of Los Angeles on Monday carried an incorrect reference, taken from the program notes, to an event in which two guest artists won silver medals last year. It was the New York International Ballet Competition.

title: Lyrical Plea to Preserve Fabric of Small Farms
description: All afternoon Wendell Berry, a literary man capable of wielding a pen or a plow with equal artistry, talked about farming and the unbraiding of the strands of rural culture.

title: Couple Is Slain in Brooklyn
description: An elderly couple were fatally stabbed yesterday in their Brooklyn apartment, the police said. The couple's son was arrested in the slayings. The victims, Michael Gaurilou, 81 years old, and his wife, Theresa, 78, were stabbed about 4:30 P.M. in an apartment at 765 Ninth Street in the Kensington section. Their son, Nick Gaurilou, 37, was seized as he tried to break into another apartment.

title: The Calgary Spirit
description: Measured in gold, silver and bronze, the United States hasn't gotten the kick out of Calgary's Olympics that it did from the one-sided extravaganza at Los Angeles four years ago, or from the spectacular American victory in hockey at Lake Placid in 1980. But who cares? Calgary has been what the Olympics ought to be - a test of the best, and a great show.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring investment loss of $186,015. c-Net income

title: JAMES ROSATI, 76, SCULPTOR NOTED FOR MONUMENTAL WORKS, IS DEAD
description: James Rosati, a sculptor whose monumental yet precisely crafted geometric works stand in the gardens and plazas of many art museums and corporate headquarters, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: GORBACHEV URGES ARMENIANS TO END NATIONALIST FUROR
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, faced with one of his most difficult challenges since taking office, called on Armenians today to end nationalist protests that have disrupted two Soviet southern republics.

title: Darkly Go The Cubbies
description: Highpockets doesn't understand why the Cubs are doing what they're doing. Highpockets has lived in Chicago all of his life, and for him lights in Wrigley Field are not, as some believe, a matter of coming out of the Dark Ages.

title: Henderson Shows Up and Comes Out Swinging
description: He arrived in the early morning, smiling as he always does and simply saying that personal business had prevented him from being here sooner. But as he dressed and talked, Rickey Henderson seemed to grow more disturbed over the events of last summer that caused him to miss 67 games with a hamstring injury.

title: LEARNING BY DOING
description: ALTHOUGH COMPUTERS CAN now coordinate such crucial variables as floor plans and color selections, decorating is still an old-fashioned profession, based on the ancient system of apprenticeship. Those just starting out generally spend their time sorting through fabric samples and measuring rooms, overseeing workmen and running errands, all under the critical eye of a mentor. With experience, decorators develop a style of their own, but values taught during these early days have a lasting influence, one that forever pervades their work.

title: THE EARTH WAS HERE FIRST
description: A SAND COUNTY ALMANAC And Sketches Here and There. By Aldo Leopold. Introduction by Robert Finch. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95. COMPANION TO A SAND COUNTY ALMANAC Interpretive and Critical Essays. Edited by J. Baird Callicott. Illustrated. 308 pp. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $12.95. ALDO LEOPOLD His Life and Work. By Curt Meine. Illustrated. 638 pp. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press. $29.50.

title: A Florida Landmark Restored
description: AT first glance Coral Gables appears more likely the goal of upwardly mobile Miami residents than the destination of winter vacationers.

title: AYCKBOURN'S LAUGHTER HAS A BITTER EDGE
description: Last year, in an interview, Alan Ayckbourn said that he did not think he would ''ever write, or want to write, really heavyweight pieces,'' and categorized his forthcoming play as ''middleweight.'' He has now written three such plays in a row - ''A Small Family Business,'' ''Henceforward'' and ''Woman in Mind'' (now at the Manhattan Theater Club). It is evident from the three that the English author is extremely comfortable at his chosen writing weight.

title:
GARDENING;
New Perennials Worth Trying
description: LEAD: EACH year seed companies and nurseries release many new plants for us to try.

title: Red Tape Entangling Housing for the Aged
description: LEAD: JANE CHIURCO, a physician and infective-agent medical director for E.R. Squibb & Sons in Lawrence Township, was helping a friend understand how her mother's daily life was complicated by the aging process.

title: E. Landzberg to Marry Laurence Friedman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Landzberg of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Ellen Landzberg to Laurence Matthew Friedman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Friedman of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Gentle Winds Estate, St. Croix, V.I. The couple plan to marry May 14.

title: DUKAKIS TOUGHENS STANCE IN DEBATE
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates, led by an increasingly aggressive Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, battled today in a debate that at times turned sharp, angry and personal.

title: WATER MILL GROWTH: FACTS ARE NEEDED
description: An article on Jan. 10 about Water Mill contained errors [ ''Fears on Growth Divide Residents of Water Mill'' ] . I believe the following to be more accurate.

title: Smile! Your House Is on the Assessor's Tapeb
description: THE newest use of videos has nothing to do with rock-and-roll music. Assessors are increasingly using taping to help them in compiling revaluation records.

title: WHEN BAD NEWS WAS NO NEWS
description: UNCOVERING SOVIET DISASTERS Exploring the Limits of Glasnost. By James E. Oberg. Illustrated. 317 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: IT'S THE CUT THAT COUNTS
description: AS ANY WOMAN WHO has wielded a can of mousse, a tube of gel and a blow-dryer knows, styling products today have their virtues, but efficiency may not be one of them. In fact, these items bear a striking similarity to the hair sprays and teasing combs of the 1960's.

title: MECHAM TO SEEK TO BLOCK HIS TRIAL
description: Two days before the scheduled start of his impeachment trial in the state Senate, Gov. Evan Mecham said he was preparing to ask a Federal court to halt it. He said he feared his constitutional rights would be trampled in ''a lynch-mob atmosphere.''

title: Yearning To Be Free
description: LEAD: Today, the story was about Cubans bringing New Jersey's Union City back to life. Yesterday, it was the story about the Asian Westinghouse semifinalists in Queens, N.Y. Both are parts of the same story: The United States' new immigrants are infusing old cities with a dose of long-missing vitality. The only thing wrong with the story is that it might have been told many years sooner.

title: THE WORLD: Nicaragua; Pushed From Left or Right, Masaya Balks
description: SANDINISTA army recruiters swept through neighborhoods of Nicaragua's towns and villages in the last month, stopping buses and lying in wait outside cinemas. Sometimes they used force as they rounded up young men for military service, and there were occasional confrontations. But only in the town of Masaya, 19 miles southeast of the capital of Managua, did the conscription spark a full-blown street clash.

title: Anne Cameron To Wed in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Richard R. Dailey of New York and Lyme, Conn., and William A. Cameron of New York and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Anne Hamilton Cameron to Terrence Patrick Cunningham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Cunningham of Lancaster, Pa., and Rock Hall, Md. The wedding is to be next fall.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 2 MUSICAL GENERATIONS Experienced and novice musicians star in two concerts this afternoon. Unfortunately, a scheduling conflict makes it impossible for music lovers to be able to contrast what was and is with what is and will be; audiences will have to choose between the Senior Citizens Pops Orchestra and the Training Orchestra. The veterans, 75 strong under Bart Ferrara's baton, perform Strauss waltzes, Sousa marches, Broadway show tunes and light classics at 2 P.M. at Amityville High School on Merrick Road. The youngsters in the Nassau County section of the Performing Symphony offer Tchaikovsky, Milhaud, Grieg, Strauss and, with Paul Clive, a graduate of the Training Orchestra who has gone onto a succesful professional career, as English horn soloist, Sibelius and Donizetti. With Paul Rudoff conducting, this all takes place at 3 P.M. at Bethpage High School on Stewart Avenue. Both concerts are free. FIRE DEPARTMENT BAND

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNALNorth Salem in Music
description: LEAD: The flier for ''Small Town Life,'' a musical celebrating North Salem's 200th birthday, boasts that the play offers ''only the slightest nod to historical accuracy.'' The show, with a cast of 60, all of whom live or work in North Salem, is billed by Rita Gilbert, the author, director and lyricist, as a ''lighthearted view'' of the town's past, presented in 16 scenes and a dozen songs.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: VALLEY OF DECISION. By Stanley Middleton. (New Amsterdam Books/Meredith Press, $15.95.) In his 24th novel (the first to be published in America), the Booker Prize-winning British author Stanley Middleton enters the world of semiprofessional musicians, those seldom appreciated players and singers who perform for love of music and, occasionally, a little money.

description: Calling portions of a former Panamanian official's Senate testimony ''lies and slanders,'' President Fidel Castro of Cuba said he would be willing to travel to Washington to rebut testimony against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. But Mr. Castro said a visit to Washington would have to include discussion of other issues, which he did not specify.

description: Sam Jacobs scored 29 points and James Paul had 20, both career highs, as Cornell stretched its winning streak to 11 games and clinched a share of the Ivy League title tonight with a 94-84 victory over Brown.

description: JEAN FORMAN is a jeweler with a mission. ''These are the kinds of things people should wear when they travel, so they can feel relaxed and don't have to worry about hiding them,'' she said. ''Or they might be just the thing for someone who has the originals in the vault.''

title: VENI, VIDI, LEGI
description: THE Italians over the years have adorned their historic buildings with countless inscriptions: So-and-So lived here, So-and-So built (or rebuilt) this building, here lies So-and-So, and the like. Before the 19th century virtually all such inscriptions were written in Latin. This used to mean that they could be read by all literate people, from anywhere. Now, ironically, it has almost the opposite effect.

title: A Brimming Dance Schedule About to Begin
description: LEAD: MARCH will bring with it not only spring, but also a brimming dance calendar. The state's three major ballet companies and several modern troupes have designed programs that include reconstructions of important works by major 20th-century choreographers as well as a spectrum of current choreography.

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: Billy Martin will bring the Yankees to the World Series and will get into some kind of fight with George Steinbrenner and be dismissed. GEORGE FULTON HELLER Summit, N.J.

title: LIBERTARIAN GUILTY IN INCOME TAX CASE

title: Architect of Perestroika Sells It in The West
description: THE changes under way in the Soviet Union are invariably identified with their leading apostle, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But the real architect of perestroika, as the restructuring is called in Russian, is Abel G. Aganbegyan, an Armenian economist Mr. Gorbachev summoned from Siberia to impart new dynamism to a sagging economy.

title: Trident Missile Succeeds
description: A Navy Trident 1 missile was launched successfully today from a submerged submarine off Cape Canaveral, after two failed launchings last year and one on Feb. 6, officials said. The missile was fired down the Air Force Eastern Space and Missile Test Range at 10:27 A.M. from the U.S.S. Stonewall Jackson and landed in the Atlantic. The distance of the shot was not made public.

title: Moscow Opens Door a Bit to Former Citizens
description: For more than 50 years, citizens of the Soviet Union who were allowed to leave understood that they would not be welcome back as visitors. But over the last year or two significant numbers of recent Soviet emigres have been permitted to return to their homeland for short visits.

description: ''THEY'RE just some old tenements,'' said Harold Pine, the owner of 167 West 83d Street, referring to his building and its neighbors at 169, 171 and 173. ''There's nothing special about them.''

The future bride is the daughter of Barbara Adler Katzander of New York, who has announced her engagement, and the late Howard L. Katzander. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald David Gold of Atlanta.

title: Poverty and Bureaucracy Hurt the Young
description: I AM a pediatrician at a federally funded, nonprofit community health center that sees all patients regardless of their ability to pay. I serve children who live in one of the poorest neighborhoods in Connecticut, the lower east side of Bridgeport. Recently, a mother came to see me; she asked me to cure her 6-month-old son's cough.

title: Ms. Idzik to Wed Harry T. Bahr 3d
description: Rebecca J. Idzik, a daughter of Ann Beckner Idzik of Rye, N.Y., and Daniel R. Idzik of Stamford, Conn., and Harry Theodore Bahr 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bahr Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., plan to be married June 11.

description: Only two months after surgery on her right foot, Yvonne van Gennip of the Netherlands tonight created the opportunity to win three speed-skating gold medals in the XV Olympic Winter Games.

description: Dina Meryl Schupak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Schupak of Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Daniel Alan Leyden, a son of Harriet Leyden of New York and Stuart Leyden of Ocean, N.J. Cantor Sol Zim performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

description: In percent

title: Theater Sound in the Home
description: Back in the early 1950'S, when the rise of television began to deplete the movie houses, Hollywood fought back by offering what television couldn't: color, a wide screen and multidirectional sound.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: West Chester, Pa.;
Rapid Growth In Penn's Land
description: LEAD: CORPORATE growth in Chester County over the last 10 years has brought a spurt in the development of expensive housing. The 800-square-mile county in southeastern Pennsylvania is about 30 miles west of Philadelphia. West Chester is the county seat.

title: The State Must Help the Mentally Ill
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S failure, in his recent budget proposal, to provide adequate financing for New Jersey's mental-health system demonstrates a startling insensitivity to the needs of the mentally ill men and women of this state.

title: Sunday Observer; Intimations of Mortality
description: AS THE YEARS passed, it became increasingly obvious that if I died it would be my own fault. This saddened me.

title: The Markets Need Stricter Regulation
description: WELL before last October, many seasoned investment professionals worried that newly developed techniques and instruments for trading stocks would destabilize markets. Now studies of the October crash by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Brady Commission and others conclude they were right. The main new instruments are stock index futures, representing the average price of a large bundle of stocks, and the Designated Order Turnaround system, which allows whole market baskets of individual stocks to be traded on the stock exchange in a single swift transaction. The main new techniques fostered by these instruments are arbitrage between stocks and stock index futures and ''portfolio insurance,'' whereby selling of financial futures is triggered if stock prices fall by some predetermined amount.

title: Robertson Makes Gesture of Support for Swaggart
description: Pat Robertson made a stop at an airport here today to offer a message of support to the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, the evangelist who stepped down from his television ministry last week after admitting to unspecified sins.

title: Brawley Lawyer Urged as Prosecutor
description: Governor Cuomo should ''deputize'' a lawyer for Tawana Brawley as a special prosecutor to investigate what the black Dutchess County teen-ager says was a sexual attack on her by six white men, a minister who has become involved in the case said at a rally here today.

title: WEST BERLIN
description: Paris, Venice, Rome, Athens. Berlin is often omitted from the list of great cultural cities of Europe. In the early 20th century, just when it seemed the city on the Spree would succeed the city on the Seine as the cultural center of the Continent, the Nazis stifled expression throughout the country.

title: BEARING WITNESS
description: When the history of the 1980's is written and the heros that everyone is supposedly looking for are found, I believe they will be personified by people like George Whitmore, fighting the ultimate battle with grace, fortitude and wisdom. STEVEN MULLER Richmond Hill, Queens

title: Texaco Is Facing Another Big Payout
description: Texaco agreed to pay $1.25 billion to the Energy Department to settle a complaint that it overcharged customers when oil-price controls were in effect in the 1970's. Texaco, trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, has also agreed to pay $3 billion to Pennzoil in a dispute over Texaco's acquisition of Getty Oil. In addition, Texaco faces a $6.5 billion claim from the Internal Revenue Service. The Government has won about $7 billion in payments from oil companies in similar overcharging cases. Texaco said the payment, to be made over five and a half years, would be covered by a reserve and would not greatly affect earnings.

title: Two Men Rob Jeweler of $4 Million in Gold
description: Gold chains, estimated to be worth $4 million, were taken Friday afternoon from a safe in a midtown jewelry business after two gunmen tied up the owners.

title: City Auctions
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: 'BESIDE HER JOYCE SEEMS INNOCENT AS GRASS'
description: JANE AUSTEN Her Life. By Park Honan. Illustrated. 452 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: Jerry Zaks, Guide to 'Wenceslas Square'
description: IN LARRY SHUE'S PLAY ''WENCES-las Square,'' opening Wednesday at the Public Theater, a narrator recalls the 1974 trip he took to Czechoslovakia as a college student, along with a professor named Vince Corey, who was finishing up a book about the Prague Spring and its aftermath. The narrator (Victor Garber) is now a scenic designer whose artistic ambitions were fueled and whose maturity was shaped during this visit to Prague, and he tells his story as a kind of tribute to Vince Corey, his onetime mentor. At the end of the play, the narrator turns to the Professor (Jonathan Hadary) and a younger version of himself (Bruce Norris), who are both frozen in time. ''Vince?'' he calls quietly. ''This is for you. Thanks.'' For Jerry Zaks, the play's director, this moment is particularly resonant. When his friend and colleague Larry Shue died in a plane crash in September 1985, Mr. Zaks had already directed Mr. Shue's hit play ''The Foreigner'' in New York, and he planned to direct the playwright's other two full-length works, ''The Nerd'' and ''Wenceslas Square.'' (The current Broadway production of ''The Nerd'' is directed by Charles Nelson Reilly.) ''I remember the way Larry asked me; it was so wonderfully typical of him,'' says Mr. Zaks in his office at Lincoln Center, where he is resident director of the repertory company. ''If we were drinkers, I'd say it happened over drinks, but it was probably over french fries somewhere. He didn't look me in the eye, but he said something like, 'Gee, I certainly wouldn't mind if you want to direct all of my stuff.' So doing this play is for me, in a sense, unfinished business.''

title: Arafat Names a Delegation to Meet Shultz
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that a delegation of Palestinians had been named to meet Secretary of State George P. Shultz during his Middle East tour, but that Mr. Shultz had not said whether he would see them.

title: Selling Your Sanity With the House
description: THE telephone rings. After a few terse words, you dash around the kitchen storing your half-cooked dinner in the refrigerator and everything else, including the baby's toys, in the dishwasher.

title: 2 New International Magazines to Open
description: A NEW magazine called Northeast International Business - said by its founders, David E. Moore and David L. Hall, to be the country's first regional/international business publication - will be delivered Tuesday to 40,000 targeted business people.

title: BEARING WITNESS
description: George Whitmore's perspective will prove of inestimable value - particularly to those of us who share the journey of persons with AIDS, and their families, but who will do so from a vantage point that is second-hand -the vantage point of the healthy.

title: A Contralto, 2 Pianists And a Horn Player
description: Anne Gjevang

title: Trina Schreier to Wed R. K. McKeever, Artist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Weeks of Buffalo have announced the engagement of Mrs. Weeks's daughter Catherine Callanan Schreier to Robert King McKeever, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher K. McKeever of Water Mill, L.I. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Talking: Conversions; A Fourth Option for Insiders
description: Until recently, most tenants of rental buildings going co-op in New York City had only three options: buying at the insider price, staying on as a regulated tenant or selling their purchase rights to an outsider - a move that normally required giving up the apartment.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: New Bedford, Mass.;
Making a Mill Into a Mall
description: LEAD: CANADIAN developers have blended this working-class city's past with what they hope will be an bright future in renovating an aging cotton mill into an off-price designer shopping mall.

title: Pamela Kripke to Wed R. N. Chimbel in April
description: Pamela Gwyn Kripke's engagement to Robert Neil Chimbel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Chimbel of Torrington, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. David C. Kripke of Scarsdale, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: WALKING THE WAY OF THE SURVIVOR
description: LEAD: THE IMMORTAL BARTFUSS By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 137 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: Attack on a Black Woman Stuns A Mostly White New Jersey Town
description: An assault this month on a 50-year-old black woman by two white men has stunned and drawn together black and white residents of her hometown, Newton, N.J.

title: A First for the National Park Service
description: SIX paintings in one of the richest art competitions in United States history appear on the first National Park Service stamps. The stamps will be used to validate the $25 Golden Eagle Pass that entitles holders to free access for one year to all areas of the National Park System and National Wildlife Refuges.

title: Budget Offers Insights Into Reagan as A Visionary
description: AS a blueprint for the Government, President Reagan's latest budget, for a fiscal year that begins just before he leaves office, will have only limited influence. But as a reflection of his view of the world, it is a matchless source of insights.

title: Halpin Outlines a Different Agenda
description: IT was in a small conference room, minutes after Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin delivered his recent State of the County speech, that the most telling moment of the afternoon took place.

title: Halfway Houses: What Goes On Inside
description: WHEN Westchester neighbors learn that our organization, Search for Change, is looking into a site for a halfway house for the recovering mentally ill, we start to hear all the elaborated versions of Nimby -Not in My Backyard. We heard it when we were opening our Scarsdale house, and now we hear it again at meetings about our plans in Larchmont. But when panic is peeled aside, the questions are predictably similar, and they can be answered rationally with data and facts.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 7 about a New York State Bar Association conference on AIDS misstated findings of a report by the state Department of Correctional Services. It found that inmates with AIDS survived about one-third as long as other AIDS patients.

title: Looking Ahead at 94
description: WHEN my Uncle Alex moved to Bellport in the fabulous 50's, I was approaching my roaring 20's and he was approaching his sizzling 60's. He was old, or so I thought.

title: James H. Douglas Jr. Dead at 88; Served Presidents and the Military
description: James H. Douglas Jr., a lawyer, investment banker and former Secretary of the Air Force and Deputy Secretary of Defense, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 88 years old.

title: Time to Buy Oil and Gas Income Funds?
description: WORLD oil prices are dropping again. Not to worry, say the sponsors of the new wave of oil and gas income funds. That just means that those who buy into the funds now will make that much more money later, when oil is sure to rebound.

title: Weicker and Lieberman Shape Images for Senate Campaign
description: WHEN Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman announced in Hartford last week his campaign for the United States Senate, he presented himself as ''the people's lawyer'' who worried about such issues as high housing costs and who would fight for ''everyday pocketbook concerns.''

title: Health Insurance
description: To the Editor: I have good news for millions of Americans insured by Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: I fully expect Billy Martin to be the Yankees' manager for many, many years. (Unless, of course, they lose the home opener.) DAN BERNSTEIN Philadelphia

title: European Ensemble to Visit State
description: THE American itinerary of the visiting Chamber Orchestra of Europe lists just nine cities and two of them are in Connecticut.

title: Lois M. Cross Is Engaged To Gregory Tilford Willis
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Cross 3d of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Cross's daughter Lois Moore Cross to Gregory Tilford Willis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Willis Jr. of Greenwich and Seal Harbor, Me. A May wedding is planned.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Livingston
description: LEAD: MEMORIAL PARK OVAL is Livingston's centerpiece - a tidy green with wooden benches and a jogging track and framed by the township high school, library and municipal building. Residents gather there to meet friends, attend community events or enjoy the quiet of an idle afternoon.

title: Traffic Stalls Royal Visit
description: Britain's Prince Andrew and his wife, Sarah, began a 10-day visit to Southern California today, and they were greeted by a freeway traffic jam that delayed their arrival at a City Hall ceremony by 25 minutes. The car carrying the Duke and Duchess of York had to make a detour around the congestion on the trip from the royal yacht Britannia, moored at Long Beach, 25 miles south of Los Angeles. The traffic jam was caused by an accident on the Santa Monica Freeway.

title: Funds on the Defensive
description: THE bull in the Merrill Lynch television commercial, which galloped along a breezy coast while a woman sang, ''To Know No Boundaries,'' is off the air. Today, Merrill's ads feature straight-talking financial consultants with no music and sober advice. One of them might be speaking for the whole mutual fund industry when he intones, ''These are uncertain times.''

title: Trump's Vision: Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight to Save Polo Field Inspires Greenbelt Effort
description: A ONE-MAN fight to save an Old Brookville polo field has inspired a neighborhood campaign to preserve open space in the village.

title: Trump's Vision: Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD WEIGHS INSURANCE CURBS
description: Here in this city long synonymous with insurance, women's rights groups have run into their toughest opposition yet in an already difficult struggle to ban what they assert is sex discrimination by insurance companies.

title: No Smoking Or No Work
description: MANY companies restrict smoking on the job. The USG Corporation may be the first in the nation to ban it outright - after work as well as at work.

title: JAMES WEBB'S NEW 'FIELDS OF FIRE'
description: BATTLE SHIP gray clouds lay at anchor in the Annapolis sky. On the Severn River, beyond the parade ground where the Secretary of the Navy, James H. Webb Jr., stood at attention, sailboats sauntered by. Midshipmen passed in review, dark sleeves and starched white trousers swinging in unison to the martial beat of the Marine Corps Hymn. The scene mirrored precisely the prologue to ''A Sense of Honor,'' a novel written by Webb seven years ago about this same United States Naval Academy: ''The drums begin. You can hear them, like a million heartbeats from the deepest corner of your own insides.'' Vintage James Webb - military imagery punctuated by masculine cliche.

title: National Hall: Westport Revival
description: National Hall in Westport, Conn., is on the Saugatuck River, but no one need look outside to realize that. ''The basement is tidal,'' said Peter F. Tauck, general manager of the company restoring the structure, which is in a historic district. ''When the tide comes up, the cellar fills up.'' A leaky foundation is only one of troubles plaguing the one-time home of The Westport News, the Westport Bank and Trust and the Westport High School. Its top floor had been a ballroom and social center; now its cast-iron facade is crumbling. Built in 1873, the building at 2 Post Road was left behind by the city that built up and fixed up around it. Last used as a furniture store, it was vacant when Tauck Tours, a realty and travel company across the street, bought it at auction for $1.6 million.

title: President Suharto Replaces Commander of Indonesia Armed Forces
description: Gen. Benny Murdani, until recently considered the second most powerful man in Indonesia after President Suharto, was replaced today as armed forces commander. The move is seen as a prelude to more Government changes in the next few weeks.

title: Officials Say Ortega Will Name Economic Chief
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra will soon shake up his Cabinet and may name a senior former guerrilla to a new post overseeing all economic policies, officials say.

title: Santana Comes Full Circle
description: Rafael Santana pointed casually toward a distant corner of the Yankee clubhouse today, and suddenly the memories returned. It was 1980.

title: An 18th-Century Journey and New Shapes
description: IN a 1762 portrait painted by Pompeo Batoni, James Bruce of Kinnaird stands corpulent, wearing a richly frogged coat and a periwig and looking the embodiment of kindliness. So much for appearances: the rest of the evidence suggests that the naturalist and explorer was something of a scoundrel, and mean-spirited to boot.

title: Top Gelding Dies
description: Zany Tactics, thoroughbred racing's world-record holder for six furlongs on dirt, has died of an apparent heart attack after a workout at Santa Anita.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: WISE CHILD By Monica Furlong. 228 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: HIS LIFE AS A GOD
description: LEAD: THE LAST EMPEROR by Edward Behr. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $9.95. THE PUPPET EMPEROR The Life of Pu Yi, Last Emperor of China. By Brian Power. Illustrated. 230 pp. New York: Universe Books. $17.95.

title: A Setback On Utility Rates
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the county suffered a potentially major setback this month in its drive to keep electric rates stable, Consolidated Edison's customers are paying less for electricity today than they have since 1980.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Florham Park $425,000 2 Lauri Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old ranch; c/a, fireplace in family room, 2-car attached garage; taxes $3,319. Montclair $150,000 43 Gray Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old colonial; den, porch, full basement, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,045. Piscataway $162,000 36 Deborah Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old contemporary; fireplace, patio, deck; taxes $2,011. Randolph $237,500 1 Warren Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split-level; fireplace in den, c/a, 2-car attached garage; taxes $2,933. Short Hills $470,000 61 Baltusrol Way 7-bedroom, 3-bath, 2 half-bath, 26-year-old colonial; sun porch, family room, 4 fireplaces, library; taxes $5,815. Springfield $216,000 15 Marcy Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, deck; taxes $2,333. OTHER AREAS Nesconset, L.I. $207,000 17 Standish Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, circular drive; taxes $4,407.
