Branford, Conn. $525,000 5 Tyler Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 80-year-old former waterfront summer cottage; views, patio, 0.2 acre; taxes $2,748.

title: Theater
description: The vitality of youth in black South Africa is celebrated in ''Sarafina!'', a musical with a message that reverberates long after one has left the theater. ''Sarafina'' is a song of freedom, persisting in spite of years of repression. Watching the show, one is saddened by the slowness of change in South Africa, at the same time one is uplifted by the idealism on stage. What makes the show so special - in addition to the vibrant score by Mbongeni Ngema and Hugh Masakela -are the young people who comprise the large cast, students and non-professionals who fill the Cort Theater (138 West 48th Street) with a life spirit that goes far beyond exuberance. The show was first performed at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center and recently moved to Broadway, where it continues to be one of the most moving events of the theater season.

title: A Haven for Children's Fantasies
description: LEAD: A 20-ACRE woodland in Weston with six weathered barns and log cabins is home to children's fantasies. The compound houses Weston Woods Studios Inc. and CC Studios Inc., producer and distributor of children's films and videos.

title: Beyond White Rats and Rabbits
description: FOR years, an emotionally charged ethical debate over the morality and reliability of animal testing has bedeviled the cosmetics, chemical and pharmaceutical industries. Nevertheless, the tests have remained firmly entrenched as the underpinning of the nation's efforts to insure that new products work as intended and that consumers are not harmed by them.

title: Playing to a Parade of Different Tastes
description: LATE last year, in the plush 60th-floor aerie that is the executive dining room for Chase Manhattan Bank, the Canteen Company, which has 1,600 corporate clients, sponsored its seventh annual culinary contest. Canteen chefs for dining rooms of businesses and government agencies were able to exchange ideas and show off their skills before customers, peers and a panel of six judges.

title: Jacquard Coverlets Weave a Spell
description: In a sense, the Hirschl & Adler Folk Gallery is attempting to do for Jacquard coverlets what the Whitney Museum of American Art did for quilts in its 1971 exhibition ''Abstract Design in American Quilts'': elevate the craft to an American art form. The show of 55 Jacquard coverlets opened yesterday at the gallery (851 Madison Avenue, at 70th Street), where it will run through March 26.

title: O'Rourke Sets a Low-Key Agenda
description: IN his State of the County address before a packed legislative chamber, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke looked back at 1987 with a measure of satisfaction last week but warned that there could be hard times ahead for Westchester.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Advice for a New President

title:
INVESTING;
A Noted Bear Turns Bullish on Stocks
description: LEAD: WHEN Elaine M. Garzarelli was just a market strategist, she could make stock market judgments and simply deliver them to her clients, the institutions and individuals who invest through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Trump's Vision: Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Light Infantry Is Given Taste Of Real Thing
description: It was cold and still in the dark of an early morning on the side of the hill amid the scrub pine of western Arkansas. Moonlight seeped through wispy clouds, and the only sound was the chop of a helicopter circling in the distance.

title: LITTLE GAIN SEEN AS SHULTZ VISITS JORDAN AND SYRIA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew to Jordan and Syria today to discuss a package of American proposals for a Middle East negotiating formula but made little apparent headway in his quest.

title: For Those Passionate About Pasta
description: RISTORANTE IL POZZO in Hauppauge was conceived with love. At its heart is the owner, Pat Zummo. He is everywhere: greeting diners, table hopping in the dining room and on weekends popping out from the kitchen in his chef's whites. On a slow night, diners might find his gregariousness a mite intrusive, but he has a genuine enthusiasm for food and his restaurant that's contagious.

title: Kempton Is Winner Of George Polk Prize For 45-Year Career
description: Murray Kempton, the columnist for Newsday, has won the George Polk Career Award in Journalism, one of 14 awards announced yesterday by Long Island University.

title: Purdue Winner After Scare
description: Troy Lewis made a pair of 3-pointers to cap a 13-point run that opened the second half as second-ranked Purdue rallied for a 69-51 victory over Northwestern today.

title: Dr. Ruth Gershen To Marry Rabbi
description: The engagement of Dr. Ruth Susan Gershen to Rabbi Hillel David Gold, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Raphael Gold of Savannah, Ga., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Gershen of Princeton, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Cherished Royal Retreat
description: BY permission of her great-great-granddaughter, the public has access each spring to Queen Victoria's most treasured and private memorial to Prince Albert, the Royal Mausoleum at Frogmore. Hidden in the shadow of Windsor Castle, the mausoleum and gardens of Frogmore House are opened to the public in aid of charity for a few days each year - this year on May 4 and 5, May 18 (gardens only) and May 25 (mausoleum only).

title: Learning From a Fall
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Focus: Self-Storage;
Success Breeds Changes
description: LEAD: THROUGH the 1970's and early 80's, Granados Management Company reaped the income generated from its ministorage warehouses and, like other self-storage operators during this boom period, the company expanded. With each expansion there were customers eager to rent warehouse space to store boats, furniture and other items.

title: CLOSE-UP LOOK AT POLAR BEARS IN MANITOBA
description: YOU don't have to look far to see polar bears when you camp out with them on the shores of Hudson Bay near Churchill in Manitoba province. Even at the cocktail hour, when you're having a snotch (Scotch poured over a cup of snow) and a smoked oyster, you're likely to hear and feel half a ton of bear slam against the school bus that serves the camp's meals and smack its black snout against a frosted windowpane inches from your face. It's Alfie, Maxwell, Metal Mama or one of their fellow bears telling you they're hungry, too.

title: Miss McNeeley, Student, Marries
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Adair McNeeley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. McNeely of Newark, Del., to Jack Scott Snoeyink, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Snoeyink of Grand Rapids, Mich., took place yesterday in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Lauren Teschemacher to Marry in July
description: Lauren Elizabeth Teschemacher and Robert Andrew Casey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Casey of Westwood and Edgartown, Mass., plan to marry in July, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Teschemacher of Chatham, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., have announced.

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: Until he isn't waiting in his room for a call from George.

title: THAT OLD BLACK MAGIC
description: AL-KEMI Hermetic, Occult, Political, and Private Aspects of R. A. Schwaller de Lubicz. By Andre VandenBroeck. Illustrated. 286 pp. Great Barrington, Mass.: Inner Traditions/ Lindisfarne Press. $22.95.

title: A Banker With A Gift for Giving, A Golden Touch And a Taste For Dining Well
description: AT THE VERY HEART OF the financial district of London, known as the City, there is an intersection where eight streets converge. Approach it from the west, with the Bank of England on your left and the Mansion House - the Lord Mayor's residence - on your right, and you will find yourself facing the Royal Exchange.

title: A RISK OF UNREST SEEN IN EAST BLOC
description: Reagan Administration officials who analyze political and economic trends in Eastern Europe say they believe three of the six Warsaw Pact countries face domestic instability, mainly as a result of deterioration in their economies.

title: About Those Irritating Gremlins
description: IT was a little more than a year ago that my mother entered the brave new world of point-and-shoot photography. She did it in high style, with a Pentax IQ Zoom, which can boast of being the first simple, automatic camera to sport a zoom lens. The IQ Zoom has been widely successful and widely imitated; several manufacturers are introducing versions of their own this weekend at a trade show in Las Vegas.

title: FRAMES OF MIND
description: BARBRA STREISAND'S lawyer in the movie ''Nuts,''

title: STORIES MAKE THE FAMILY
description: The stories of Elizabeth Stone's family remind me of how my childhood was also enriched by a myriad of true and semitrue stories of immigrant forebears.

title: THE REGION: Two Approaches to Housing Families; Ending the Dependency on Welfare Hotels
description: WHAT should government be doing about the families living in New York City's welfare hotels?

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: I do not think he will make it to opening day. FRANCIS W. RODGERS Rensselaer, N.Y.

title: Dance: Jane Comfort Company in a Yuppie 'Macbeth'
description: MACBETH wore a business suit. The witches were punk rockers who predicted he would become chief executive officer - news that greatly pleased the social-climbing Lady Macbeth.

title: Witt Is Gold Medalist for a Second Time
description: It all came down to the long program. Katarina Witt of East Germany, the defending women's figure-skating champion, skated well tonight, but nothing like she or a sellout audience in the Saddledome expected, nothing close to her glittering standards. If Debi Thomas nailed her routine, the gold medal in the 1988 Winter Games could be hers. She didn't. With a flat, flawed program, she failed to take advantage of the opening provided by Witt and her so-so scores. Further, she could not keep Elizabeth Manley, the Canadian champion, from finishing ahead of her.

title:
GARDENING;
New Perennials Worth Trying
description: LEAD: EACH year seed companies and nurseries release many new plants for us to try.

title: Henry Broido, Retail Executive, Dies at 87
description: Henry W. Broido, a retail executive who was president of Hammacher Schlemmer in the 1950's, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Contest: Big City, Big Canvas
description: Many drab New York City blocks have been brightened by murals painted boldly onto the bare sidewalls of buildings. Among them is the picture Heung Sun Cho drew while he was a student at Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn. His 60- by 30-foot mural depicting all races benefiting from the Constitution adorns the sidewall of 291-293 Seventh Avenue, at 29th Street. It got there as the winner in last year's Mural Design Contest sponsored by the Hudson-Shatz Painting Company.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE REAL WAR: The Classic Reporting on the Vietnam War, by Jonathan Schell. (Pantheon, $7.95.) Who were we fighting in Vietnam, Jonathan Schell wonders in a new essay introducing his war reports for The New Yorker - Hanoi, the National Liberation Front, the Soviet Union, China, world communism or ourselves? In 1967, John Mecklin said here that ''The Village of Ben Suc,'' one of the works included in this book, was ''written with a skill that many a veteran war reporter will envy, eloquently sensitive, subtly clothed in an aura of detachment, understated, extraordinarily persuasive.'' The book also includes ''The Military Half: An Account of Destruction in Quang Ngai and Quang Tin.'' TEXASVILLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) When Larry McMurtry returns to Thalia, the fic-tional Texas town of his novel ''The Last Picture Show,'' he finds that the movie theater has burned down and been supplanted by VCR's, satellite dish antennas and cable television. Last year our reviewer, Louise Erdrich, said that the book read too much like a screenplay but that it contained scenes that are ''sharp, spare, full of longhorn humor and color. . . . The characters who seemed, at the conclusion of 'The Last Picture Show,' destined to carry on the kindliest of small-town virtues have turned cartoonish and begun to crack.'' THE WHALE AND THE REACTOR: A Search for Limits in an Age of High Technology, by Langdon Winner. (University of Chicago, $8.95.) If only we can awake from our ''somnambulism,'' the author argues, we can make pluralistic technological decisions - like rejecting nuclear energy - and avoid concentrating power in the hands of an elite. ''He may not have totally convincing answers,'' David Dickson said here in 1986, ''but the questions he poses about the relationship between technical change and political power are pressing ones that can no longer be ignored.'' INDIAN COUNTRY, by Philip Caputo. (Bantam, $4.95.) With the Vietnam War behind him, a veteran finds life in Michigan's remote Upper Peninsula as frightening as in ''Indian Country'' - G.I. slang for an area under enemy control. Philip Caputo ''is a fine action writer, controlling the sweep of the narrative with musical skill,'' Frank Conroy said in The Book Review in 1987. ''The climactic passages have a kind of hallucinatory clarity, and they stick in the mind.'' RUSSIAN STUDIES, by Leonard Schapiro. Edited by Ellen Dahrendorf. (Penguin, $9.95.) The longest of these essays by the former lawyer and scholar Leonard Schapiro, who died in 1983, chronicles the formation of Lenin's philosophy. ''It is a model of clarity, close reasoning and tight-packed scholarship and leaves you very much regretting that Schapiro didn't complete the longer study of which it was originally intended to form a part,'' John Gross said in The Times last year. THE KING MUST DIE, by Mary Renault. (Vintage, $6.95.) The best known of Mary Renault's novels is about Theseus, the mythical king of Athens who slays the Minotaur in the labyrinth of Crete. ''What has previously been consigned to ancient vase paintings and frescoes . . . takes on a new meaning,'' our reviewer, Siegfried Mandel, said when the book was first published in 1958. ''She ventures into the complex pre-Hellenic era confidently and with imagination and insight, takes the myth out of mythology by creating a persuasively realistic and touchable canvas crowded with ancient people and places.'' Vintage has also reissued at the same price three more of the British author's fictional re-creations of life in ancient Greece. THE MASK OF APOLLO, published in 1966, is narrated by an actor, Nikeratos, who becomes involved in a power struggle between a friend of Plato's and the tyrant Dionysios the Younger. The hero of THE PERSIAN BOY (1972) is Alexander the Great's young servant and lover, Bagoas. THE PRAISE SINGER (1978) is about the poet Simonides, and offers an inside view of Greek politics in the sixth century B.C., the Age of the Tyrants. NOBEL DREAMS: Power, Deceit and the Ultimate Experiment, by Gary Taubes. (Tempus, $8.95.) The focal points of this story about big science are Carlo Rubbia, the egocentric Italian physicist, and the CERN particle accelerator in Geneva, the largest in the world. Last year, our reviewer, Louise B. Young, praised Gary Taubes as ''a good storyteller, [ who makes ] his characters come alive. He recounts amusing anecdotes and describes the competition, the excitement and the tension that are undeniable facts of life in these big laboratories.'' THE LIMITS OF SCIENCE, by Peter Medawar. (Oxford University, $8.95.) There are some questions, Sir Peter Medawar writes, that science cannot answer, yet it is ''incomparably the most sucessful enterprise human beings have ever engaged upon.'' The Nobel laureate ''continues to radiate a confidence in rationality coupled with a no-nonsense didactic pragmatism that verges on the heroic,'' one reviewer said in 1985. SYMBOLS OF AMERICA, by Hal Morgan. (Steam Press/Penguin, $14.95.) As Hal Morgan shows in this well-illustrated book, America's heirlooms include our whimsical menagerie of trademarks, which can be at least as enticing as the products they represent. ''We have reached the region where mythical beings - Elsie the Cow, the Quaker Oats man, the Green Giant - take on a life of their own,'' John Gross said in 1986, ''where chickens are dressed like chefs and peanuts wear monocles; a land of winged heels and winged horses, blue ribbons and golden arches.''

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Fairfield's Auto Dealers Feel the Squeeze
description: THE high cost of real estate coupled with restrictive zoning in lower Fairfield County has put an essential suburban industry, the local automobile dealer, at risk. Land on which to store new cars, cars under repair and even employees' cars has become unaffordable or unavailable.

title: Large and Small Gifts Aid the Neediest Cases
description: Ten-year-old John S. Machell of Glens Falls, N.Y., sent $5 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with a request that the money go to help the homeless.

title: Shultz Tries To Move the Immovable in The Mideast
description: THE United States has often served as a catalyst in the peculiar chemistry of Arab-Israeli accord. After the 1973 war, Henry A. Kissinger was able to get Egypt and Syria to enter troop disengagement agreements with Israel. In 1978, President Carter brokered the Camp David deal between President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel - the agreement that led to the first peace treaty between Israel and an Arab state.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $450,000 123 Commodore Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old frame contemporary; greenhouse alcove, keeping room, pool and spa, .93 acre; taxes $8,264. No similar demonstration was mounted against the Norwegians or, later, against a French arms company that sold similar equipment to the Soviets.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Some of the floorboards in our house have raised slightly at the edges, and they often break when stepped upon. As a result, we now have spaces between the boards. This condition seems to have developed after the floors were stained. Can you help us solve this problem?

title: About Cars; Newsletter Helps Drivers Adjust to Speed Limits
description: All right, the name is silly, but the organization does serve a purpose. It is called the Radio Association Defending Airwave Rights, the acronym being RADAR, and it is headed by Janice Lee, who used to work for Electrolert, the company that makes Fuzzbuster radar detectors.

title: Play On!
description: IN THE RATHER DANK basement of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, the history of the New York Philharmonic, America's oldest symphony orchestra, is sitting in cardboard boxes. According to Barbara Haws, the archivist whose task it is to organize it all, the correspondence, photographs, financial records, programs, scores and other memorabilia would fill 1,600 file cabinet drawers. ''When I walked into this room in November 1984,'' she says, ''it was utter chaos. There was no way of knowing exactly what was there.''

title: Gunborg Klason Weds
description: Gunborg Marie Klason and Eric Hubbard Litchfield were married yesterday at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Richard F. Van Wely. Mrs. Litchfield is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Klason of Norrkoping, Sweden. Mr. Litchfield, a partner in Fine Wines and Spirits in Greenwich, is a son of Philip Axel Litchfield of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Isabel Crouse Litchfield of Greenwich.

title: FROM FIVE DEVICES, A WORLD OF MACHINES

title: Opera: 'Fairy Queen,' in Philadelphia
description: Henry Purcell wrote only one theater piece we would describe as opera, but his interest in the musical stage kept alive the dying tradition of the masque. ''The Fairy Queen'' - written in 1692 and presented by the Pennsylvania Opera Theater tonight - hangs somewhere between his wholly operatic ''Dido and Aeneas'' and these earlier mixed-media entertainments of the European courts..

title: Conversion to Offices Debated
description: THE future of a century-old Hempstead house has become the focal point of a larger issue: the conversion of old houses into offices and the consequent change in patterns of neighborhoods within the village. The Zoning Board of Appeals is scheduled to decide the house's status Thursday.

title: AN INNOCENT AMONG COPS
description: MAN WITH A GUN By Robert Daley. 475 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Deborah Strauss Weds Craig Cogut
description: The marriage of Deborah Charlotte Strauss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Strauss of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Craig Myles Cogut, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Cogut of Roslyn, L.I., took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony.

title: Sag Harbor Weighs Sale of Village Hall
description: IN a move that would save village taxpayers more than $1 million, the Sag Harbor Village Board is considering selling off the 142-year-old Municipal Building on Main Street to build a modern village hall elsewhere.

title: NONFICTION
description: BREAD UPON THE WATERS. By Rose Pesotta. Edited by John Nicholas Beffel. (ILR Press, Cloth, $32; Paper, $10.95.) It was hard to faze Rose Pesotta. When a Spanish-language radio station in Los Angeles was pressured to stop carrying strike bulletins, she took her message across the border and broadcast from Mexico. When the press ignored her continuing garment workers' strike and fussed instead over the showings of the new spring fashions, the former sewing machine operator dressed her strikers in the evening gowns they had made and staged a high-fashion picket line that stole the show - and the headlines. ''Bread Upon the Waters'' (first published in 1944, and unavailable for many years) is a passionate, personal account of her experiences as a national labor organizer from 1933 to 1944, when she served as the sole woman member of the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. Pesotta's inventiveness, drive and spunk shine through on every page of the book, which she wrote with her friend John Nicholas Beffel. Feminist, anarchist and immigrant Jew, Rose Pesotta (1896-1965) regularly defied sexists, racists, anti-Semites and ideologues inside and outside union ranks. She reached out to ''mothers and daughters [ who ] spent days and nights ruining their eyesight and lungs over finery they never could hope to wear.'' But in 1944, deciding she could no longer tolerate being the token woman on the board of a union whose rank and file was 85 percent female, Pesotta resigned in protest. The feisty, forthright and, ultimately, tragic story she tells is worth the attention of anyone interested in the history of women or labor in America.

title: Stalking the Woolly Hemlock Killer in New York
description: Like a detective looking for a criminal, Michael S. Birmingham was on the road the other day, checking the trail of the deadly hemlock woolly adelgid, an insect that kills hemlock trees.

title: DATA UPDATE: February 28, 1988
NONFICTION
description: MABEL MERCER: A Life. By James Haskins. (Atheneum, $19.95.) Mabel Mercer was the antithesis of a show-business personality. She was shy, self-conscious and had little confidence in her singing talent. She never reached a wide audience, but was a strong influence on singers who did - singers such as Frank Sinatra and Peggy Lee, who appreciated her superb craftsmanship. James Haskins, a co-author of books about Lena Horne and Nat (King) Cole, sketches the casual, almost aimless way in which Mercer's career developed. Her mother was an English-Welsh vaudeville singer, her father was a black American musician, and she was illegitimate. Born in 1900 and raised initially by her maternal grandmother and then in a Roman Catholic convent school in England, she was on her own from the age of 14. She became a favorite of the international set in Paris in the 1920's and 30's and, after coming to the United States in 1938, found a niche for herself in small clubs in New York. Mr. Haskins did not have an opportunity to interview Mercer before her death in 1984, but he draws on the recollections of people who knew her in Europe and the friends and neighbors she acquired after she bought a farm near Chatham, N.Y., in the 1950's. They build a warm, appealing picture of the private Mercer as a simple, down-to-earth person with a strong sense of propriety. But her qualities as a performer are harder to pin down. She had to be seen for an appreciation of what one of her accompanists, Loonis McGlohon, calls her ''unmatched'' power of communication. ''It is something that is difficult to explain in words,'' Mr. McGlohon says, and Mr. Haskins proves it. But when he has the material to deal with her simply as a woman, Mabel Mercer comes vividly alive.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: The Swaggart Case; When a Religious Leader Strays, What Path Should Be Followed?
description: FROM the anguished Rev. Dimmesdale of Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''The Scarlet Letter'' to the urbane Rev. Tom Marshfield of John Updike's ''A Month of Sundays,'' the drama - or melodrama - of men of the cloth brought low by the sins of the flesh has captured the American imagination. And ever since Sinclair Lewis charted the rise and fall of Elmer Gantry and H. L. Mencken scathingly lampooned backwoods preachers, some strands of American culture have been primed to suspect any outspoken and unreconstructed fundamentalist of moral hypocrisy.

In one particularly bountiful day recently, the Ketch-All hauled in four luckless city-variety mice. ''In many respects,'' said William F. Baker, the new president of WNET, indicating the station's $15 million headquarters on West 57th Street, ''this place is a dump.''

description: THE Metropolitan Opera's current production of Wagner's ''Siegfried,'' unveiled two weeks ago, was offered Thursday evening with an almost entirely new cast. Only Wolfgang Neumann, as Siegfried, and John Macurdy, as the offstage voice of Fafner, remained from the original lineup.

title: For Democracy
description: As Roh Tae Woo took over as President last week in the first peaceful transfer of power in South Korea's history, he served notice that his tolerance for violent dissent would be limited. Mr. Roh, a former general who once participated in a military coup, promised an era of ''democratic reforms and national reconciliation,'' but said the days were over when civil unrest could be ''irresponsibly created on the pretext of freedom and participation.'' For those who didn't get his drift, Mr. Roh added: ''I do not want to be a President who pushes his fellow countrymen around, but I will not be one who is pushed around by mobs.'' The same day, police battled hundreds of anti-Government protesters in the most serious disturbances since the Korean elections in December.

title: Lisa Rose Curran Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Lisa Rose Curran to Michael Aaron Sexter, a son of Dr. Jay Sexter and Deborah Sexter of Grandview-on-Hudson, N.Y., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Dr. Roseann Cappella of East Stroudsburg, Pa., and Dr. Charles C. Curran of Lexington, S.C. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Curran, a softwear developer for International Business Machines in Kingston, N.Y., graduated from Pennsylvania State University and is studying for a master's degree in computer science at Syracuse University. Her father is a professor of library and information science at the University of South Carolina in Columbia. Her mother is a professor of psychology at East Stroudsburg University.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
THE AGE OF 26
description: LEAD: I TURNED 26 A COUPLE OF months ago. The occasion seemed less a cause for celebration than a reason to renegotiate my contract with the future. My life has become a compromise. Expectations made in youth have been postponed, standards set for adulthood have been forgotten or ignored. Certainly I am no longer a child, but neither am I at a point that I can consider myself a full-fledged adult: I still wear baseball caps, still order beer with dinner, still keep Playboy face-down in the sock drawer.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: In Rye, Clothing At Up to 75% Off The Bay Window in Rye has reductions of up to 75 percent on winter clearance merchandise in its upstairs sale room. Separates, turtlenecks, gloves, sweaters, dressy dresses, evening gowns, belts and pantyhose are available. In addition, through March it offers 20 percent reductions on sterling silver and other jewelry from downstairs and on Regina Porter spring separates, including special orders.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MONDO BOXO: Cartoon Stories. By Roz Chast. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Roz Chast's cartoons, which frequently appear in The New Yorker - and on countless refrigerator doors - are witty, knowing revelations about the mundane routines of urban life. She knows, for example, what type of takeout Chinese food one always orders (Cold Sesame Noodles, Moo Shu Pork) and what one never orders (Braised Calf Brain in Happy Sauce).

title: Music: Philharmonic's Wind Players
description: THE oboe d'amore is a small musical reminder of how poor communications 300 years ago promoted an almost limitless variety of invention. Closeness to one another has bred standardization; thus double-reed instruments are now narrowed to roughly the same bassoon, English horn and oboe one meets in every part of the world. (Note, however, the small differences of construction in Vienna and parts of Central Europe.) The oboe d'amore is one of the many Baroque winds that lay somewhere between our current classifications, and its dark, slightly dulled timbre was favored both by Bach and by Telemann - whose Concerto in G for the instrument began the New York Philharmonic's program at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night.

A SINKING ISLAND: The Modern English Writers, by Hugh Kenner. (Knopf, $22.95.) McPherson. (Oxford University, $30; after July 1, $35.) The bloodiest and most tragic of our nation's wars, delivered with up-to-date scholarship, unfailing lucidity and a skilled, literate narrative style.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photography review on Dec. 27 about Robert G. Ketchum misidentified the source of the silk embroidery in the show. It was made by members of the Suzhou Embroidery Research Institute in China. Also, the bridge at Bear Mountain was misidentified. It is Popolopen Bridge. The review characterized Mr. Ketchum's experience incorrectly; he has been a photographer for more than 15 years, not for 25.

title: 'Peace' for Ex-Soldier After A Soviet Odyssey
description: Wade Evan Roberts, the American serviceman who defected to the Soviet Union last year, is leaving today for West Germany, where, he said, he hopes, at last, that he and his wife can ''live at peace.''

title: Waterbury Wrestlers to Visit Soviet Union
description: LEAD: When 85 youngsters and adults leave for Moscow on Wednesday, they will be trying to accomplish more than just winning three wrestling matches.

title: Where Do the Wires Go? A Guide
description: BY making a map of your home's electrical circuits, you can know at a glance which paths of wiring routed throughout the house serve which outlets. A map can also help you determine whether any circuits supply too many outlets and thus are overloaded.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE WHEEL OF CHANGE HAS STOPPED
description: LEAD: Reading VANISHING TRIBES: Primitive Man on Earth (Dolphin/Doubleday, $35) is a lot like watching the slides of a friend who has just returned from a wonderful trip. But Alain Cheneviere, a linguist and documentary film maker, didn't bother photographing the Parthenon or Big Ben. Instead, he spent two decades tracking down primitive tribes from Tibet to Borneo, New Guinea to Mali, Panama to Mauritania.

title: Distracting Details
description: 'We waste a lot of rhetoric and excessive time on a couple of little issues while the forest behind us is burning. '

title: Nancy Abelson to Wed Broker
description: The engagement of Nancy Stanton Abelson to Avery Fabyan Knox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Knox 3d of Buffalo, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel O. Abelson of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: Constance Smith And Bank Official To Marry in June
description: Constance Gene Smith's engagement to Hollis Winslow Plimpton 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Plimpton Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. James W. Smith of Greenwich, Conn. The couple plan to marry in June. Miss Smith, an associate production manager at Harrison Services in Manhattan, a publisher of fashion catalogues, attended the Chapin School and graduated from the Greenwich Country Day School, Miss Porter's School and the University of Richmond. She was presented at the Thanksgiving Eve Ball of the Junior League of New York and at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball. Her father is an associate professor in plastic and reconstructive surgery at the Cornell University Medical College. Her mother, Nancy Keck Smith, is an owner of the Homestead Inn in Greenwich.

title: Understanding A Mother's Death
description: THE sun shines on a sparkling carpet of snow.

title: Radio's Global Earful
description: When public con-fidence in the government is shaken, it seems that people are eager to hear what is said about us in other countries. That's why the sale of shortwave radios perks up during political crises. For example, during last year's Congressional investigation of arms sales to Iran, there was a run on such radios, and - according to trade reports - they have been selling briskly since. Surprisingly, interest in shortwave radios is not confined to hams (ham, in radio parlance, inexplicably stands for amateur radio operator) who chat on the air with electronic pen pals all over the world. Even dealers specializing in audio components say they have had an unusual number of inquiries about shortwave equipment.

title: For Families Of Hostages, Ire and Hope
description: An acquaintance stopped Marilyn Langston at her local supermarket yesterday to ask how her father was doing. She had to pause a moment to control her temper and keep from shouting the response that first came to mind: ''How's he doing? He's being held at gunpoint, is that good enough for you?''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Practical Traveler column on Jan. 31 gave an incorrect price for the rental directory of the Recreation Vehicle Dealers Association of North America. It is $5.

title: Mimi Dore Bride Of D. J. O'Connell
description: Mary Ann Dore, the daughter of Mrs. Edward J. Dore Jr. of Bloomfield Hills and Glen Arbor, Mich., and the late Mr. Dore, was married yesterday to David James O'Connell, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence O'Connell of Yonkers. The Rev. Anthony Tocco performed the ceremony at St. Hugo of the Hills Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield Hills.

title: Beating Across the Sound, Boats Against the Winter
description: FRED HALL'S taste for bad weather is odd, yet understandable. In the winter, he is happiest when it is snowing, raining or sleeting.

title: Classical
description: String quartets are busy this week in New York City. If one keeps moving Sunday, it is possible to begin at Alice Tully Hall in the afternoon and hear the Alban Berg Quartet play three works from the Beethoven canon and later on advance into the 20th century with an evening by the Arditti String Quartet. The latter's music is from Carter, Ferneyhough, Lake, Ligeti and Xenakis - all at Merkin Concert Hall. Competing with the Alban Berg at 3 is the Manhattan String Quartet which is advertising Bartok and Schumann at Wave Hill (675 West 252d Street) in Riverdale.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DELAYING A DEAL
description: In his article ''Leveraged Buyouts: On the Level?'' (Jan. 17), Benjamin J. Stein presumes, but never offers any proof, that management's offer for Narragansett Capital was below fair market value. No higher bids emerged from outsiders and 97 percent of the shareholders voted in favor of the deal, so only a small minority of those involved appear to agree with the author.

title: STORIES MAKE A FAMILY
description: Elizabeth Stone's article ''Stories Make a Family'' (Jan. 24), awakened wondrous memories in me. I stared at those beautiful dark eyes in the photograph and remembered the magical tale I would beg my mother to tell me over and over. My grandfather, a wealthy landowner's son, had fallen in love with a beautiful peasant girl. Of course, such a marriage could never be. But my grandfather would not be denied. He took the prize oxen that were to have been exhibited at the fair and brought them to be slaughtered, instead. With that money, he came to America. Three months later, he sent for his bride. From those two extraordinary people an American family was founded. I feel fortunate that such a legacy is mine. Thank you for rekindling so many beautiful moments. NANCY ROSATI Norwalk, Conn.

title: Catherine Bolton Is Wed
description: Catherine A. Bolton, the director of corporate development at Channel 13 in New York, was married yesterday to Richard Bolus, president of Richard Bolus Imports of Scranton, Pa., an automotive importer. The Rev. Robert Woods performed the Episcopal ceremony at Sardy House in Aspen, Colo. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Joseph R. Bolton of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Mr. Bolton. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Charles Bolus of Scranton and the late Mr. Bolus.

title: Deirdre Hanofee to Marry Eric T. Friedland in August
description: Judge and Mrs. Eugene M. Hanofee of Liberty, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Constance Hanofee to Eric Todd Friedland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Friedland of Liberty. An August wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Some of the floorboards in our house have raised slightly at the edges, and they often break when stepped upon. As a result, we now have spaces between the boards. This condition seems to have developed after the floors were stained. Can you help us solve this problem?

GARDENING;
New Perennials Worth Trying

title: Wedding Planned By Stacey Raider
description: The engagement of Stacey Raider to Richard Henderson Gowen, a son of R. Harold Gowen of Portland, Me., and the late Marian E. Gowen, has been made known by the mother of the bride-to-be, Mrs. Leonard J. Raider of New York and Milford, Pa. A September wedding is planned. Miss Raider, also the daughter of the late Dr. Leonard J. Raider, is a graduate of the McBurney School and Skidmore College. She is an associate producer at Lancet Media Productions in New York, a producer of television programs. Her father was the president of Blue Shield of Greater New York. Her mother, Honey Raider, is the president of Talent Representatives, a theatrical agency in New York.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor: Several inaccuracies should be noted in Paul Hofmann's article ''Agrippa and the Hamburger'' (Travel, Jan. 24). The Pantheon is on what is properly called the Piazza della Rotonda, and only two of Italy's four kings are buried there: Vittorio Emmanuele II (d. 1878) and Umberto I (d. 1900). The two later kings lived in exile in Egypt and Portugal and are not buried in the Pantheon (nor in Italy). Besides Raphael and the two kings, five others are buried there, including Queen Margherita. Rome has suffered endless damage throughout the centuries, so no doubt it will survive the hamburger invasion. EFFINGHAM P. HUMPHREY JR. Wynnewood, Pa. Paul Hofmann replies: Mr. Humphrey is right in that the square around the Pantheon is officially the Piazza della Rotonda, but most Romans keep calling it Piazza del Pantheon the way New Yorkers keep calling the Avenue of the Americas Sixth Avenue. The first two kings of unified Italy are buried in the Pantheon; the third and fourth both died in exile. Italian monarchists are now campaigning to have their remains transferred to the Pantheon.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Controlling the State's Growth to 2010
description: LEAD: AFTER nine months of review, the Office of State Planning late last month released its second draft of a coordinated growth plan for New Jersey to accommodate an anticipated 212 million more square feet of office space, a million new jobs and 1.3 million more residents by the year 2010.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: FRANK LANGELLA still hasn't forgiven a girlfriend of many years ago who persuaded him to get rid of the romantic letters he had received from other women.

title: Life in a Remote Village
description: JOHN AND THE MISSUS Starring Gordon Pinsent (in photo), Jackie Burroughs, Randy Follett, Jessica Steen, Roland Hewgill. Directed by Gordon Pinsent. 1987. Cinema Group. 98 minutes. $79.98. Rated PG.

title: 'Discovery' and Rediscoveries In Two Shows in the County
description: FRANK S. HERRMANN, at the White Plains Public Library, is an artist brought back from the dead. The 11 painters and sculptors forgathered at the Hudson River Gallery in Ossining are rediscoveries, too, although very much alive. Herrmann, who lived from 1866 to 1942, never had to worry about money, while the Ossining artists can have worried about little else in their early years, because all worked for the Works Progress Administration's Federal Art Project. Given the effect that financial security or its absence can have on an artist's output, it's this difference more than any other that makes the two events worth comparing. Herrmann, whose show is hung in the library's Museum Gallery, was the son of a rich businessman. A couple of years younger than Alfred Stieglitz, he grew up with the photographer-to-be on the same East 65th Street block in Manhattan. The two studied in Germany at about the same time, took vacations together, exchanged letters - were, in short, lifelong friends.

title: HORST: A MAN OF STYLE
description: COCO CHANEL ONCE explained to Horst the essence of elegance. ''If you walk into a room and people say, 'What a marvelous dress,' you are badly dressed,'' the designer told the photographer. ''If they say, 'What a marvelous woman,' you are well dressed.''

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
>Into the Microchip Era, Kicking and Screaming
description: LEAD: ''BARBARA, I'm going to bring you into the 20th century,'' said my friend Steve, who sells word processors. Actually, you can't blame Steve. He's a businessman. And businessmen are supposed to be optimistic.

title: PANAMA PRESIDENT FLEES FROM HOME
description: Military officers arrived today at the home of the ousted President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, apparently to detain him, but they found that he had fled during the night.

description: Saudi Arabia is struggling with ways to handle tens of thousands of Iranian pilgrims who will arrive for the annual pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca in July.

description: SERINO'S, that fine, cozy Italian restaurant in Branford, has moved to New Haven. Its new venue is the former home of another familiar Italian restaurant, the long departed and lamented L'Avventura.

description: ''We still need a front stoop, and we need a paint job inside,'' said Jeanine Kelley-Williams, president of the co-op corporation at 364 West 120th Street, a five-story walk-up in West Harlem. ''But we're running well now. We're not going to give up.''

title: Greenspan And His Fed Call Shots in Political Year
description: IF the President's economists and other politically interested parties would just clam up, Alan Greenspan said darkly last week, he could get on with the business of keeping the economy afloat. Otherwise, he implied, the whole thing could sink, regardless of which party ends up in the White House.

description: 'A COUNTRY GARDEN' One early harbinger of spring for the past 28 years has been the Greenwich Greenfingers Garden Club Show. This year's theme is ''A Country Garden.''

description: The Center for Strategic and International Studies released a bipartisan report this week warning that political cohesion of the NATO alliance will be a major problem for the next administration, regardless who is elected President.

description: Dana Barros scored 27 points to lead Boston College to a 74-65 Big East Conference victory over St. John's tonight in a game played at Boston Garden.

description: NOBODY noticed it at the time, but one deal in the 1987 world championships in Jamaica, shown in the diagram, produced a combination of circumstances that is probably unique on a major occasion: At all four tables in the semifinal play-offs the five-level was reached. All four suits were selected for the final contract.

description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Federal and state efforts to halt the dumping of sewage sludge in the Atlantic accelerated after last summer's beach-pollution incidents, environmental officials and the dumpers themselves suggest that the end is far from in sight.

title: BEARING WITNESS
description: It is unlikely that AIDS would have spread in this country if there had been vigilant guard against unhygienic and promiscuous sexual practices and a serious effort to eradicate or at least control drug addiction. The current campaigns for ''safe'' sex and ''sterile'' drug use will do little to reduce the spread of disease.

title: Reed to Arrive Today and Is Likely to Get Nets' Coaching Job
description: Willis Reed will be the next coach of the Nets. The only thing holding up the official announcement, a source close to the negotiations said tonight, was finishing touches on a three-year contact. The contract is expected to be approved Sunday by Darwin Dornbush, who has been representing Reed.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Arts Center Is 10
description: LEAD: Ten years ago, Bira Rabushka collected money for an arts center in Goldens Bridge in the town of Lewisboro. ''Each person gave $5,'' Ms. Rabushka recalled. ''We had $55 in the kitty, and we bought mirrors for the ballet room.''

title: Bad Approach To Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hardy Flower Seed to Plant Now
description: LAST call to start seed indoors of petunias, snapdragons, impatiens, coleus, salvias, begonias, lisianthus, ageratums and geraniums, which need a long season to grow and set flower buds. Use sterile mixes and keep seed pans moist and warm to hasten germination; once seeds have sprouted, put them under fluorescent lamps to accelerate growth. Annual Poppies

title: SEEKING AN END TO UNWANTED MAIL
description: A few weeks ago you published a very interesting article about direct mail [ ''Behind the Flood of Mail: Name Brokers,'' Jan. 24 ] , and the companies who provide us with the wealth of catalogues which we -even I - receive daily. Some are addressed to people whom I call ''ghosts'' because they lived at this address long before me, the ''current resident.'' You also included an address to which we sufferers could write if we wanted relief. I have done so and hope it is effective.

title: Pop
description: The New York folk performer, Christine Lavin and the Seattle-based trio, Uncle Bonsai, who are sharing the bill at the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth St.) this Friday and Saturday, use acoustic music as a springbord for very different styles of sophisticated humor.

title: Student Drinking Creates Problems for Colleges
description: The alcohol-induced death of a Rutgers University freshman earlier this month underscored one of the most persistent frustrations of college officials: Despite their best efforts, there is often little they can do to prevent underage drinking and fraternity hazing.

title: PAINTERS WHO USED CAMERAS AS MEANS AND END
description: THAT ARTISTS WHO ARE KNOWN primarily as painters also take photographs is not news. Photography, after all, is no longer considered a natural enemy of the brush, as it was in the dark ages 100 years ago. As a result, what matters today is not whether an artist uses photographs, but the part that camera images play in his or her work.

title: THE GARDEN PATH TO EUROPE
description: FOR gardeners and garden lovers, Europe is the place. Its gardens not only display some of the finest collections of rare plantings but also reveal the development of landscape design. Some encompass flowing fountains and conservatories; others are nestled in woodlands and parks; many feature rock gardens, herbaceous borders and topiary as well as carpets of dazzling blooms. This horticultural diversity is made available on a host of special tours.

title: A FEW GOOD WOMEN
description: SOUND OFF! American Military Women Speak Out. By Dorothy Schneider and Carl J. Schneider. 259 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Dance: Nancy Zendora Presents Three Creations
description: DANCERS often stood with their backs to the audience. There was some muted reaching out when they faced each other. Grain or birdseed was poured over a reclining woman who soon crawled out. It was a night of artfully tenuous connections on Thursday when Nancy Zendora presented three dances at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace.

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: If Martin can keep his head about him and his flame out from under George Steinbrenner, he'll last the season. SADIE MCKEOWN New York

description: THE FORGOTTEN WAR America in Korea 1950-1953. By Clay Blair. Illustrated. 1,136 pp. New York: Times Books. $29.95.

title: Notebook; Teams' Play in Spring Is No Gauge of Autumn
description: Teams begin playing exhibition games later this week, but anyone looking for clues to the coming season's division champions should not waste too much time on the spring training standings. No correlation exists between a team's success in spring training and its performance during the season.

title: Take Away the Fed's Independence
description: THE popular version of the political economy in the 1980's describes a moral drama in which the good guys won. The politicians, it is said, were wildly irresponsible in their conduct of fiscal policy, but Paul Volcker and the Federal Reserve saved us from ruin.

title: Amid Political Furor, One Regent Is Expected to Return
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING several weeks of intense questioning by state legislators, Regent J. Edward Meyer of Armonk appears likely to be reappointed as the area representative on the state's educational policy-making board.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
House Must Go
description: LEAD: TOMORROW is the deadline for moving a two-story wooden house, built in 1751, from a commercial area within the town's historic district. If the structure that has remained on the site for 227 years is not moved, it is to be demolished, much to the dismay of Somers's Supervisor William C. Harding, who has been trying to save it.

description: * The imaginative new spring fashions from Paris and New York.

description: A QUARTET of new one-act plays is not only enlivening the state's theater season, but also fortifying a modest emerging professional company now in its third year here.

title:
DINING OUT;
Princeton: A Wilsonian Reminder
description: LEAD: PRINCETON'S Forrestal Village on booming Route 1 is a shopping mall with a twist. Instead of a large, enclosed space, the new center features red-brick shop fronts and boutiques lining narrow streets and open-air walkways.

title: He Peered Into The Souls of Russia's Artists
description: The exhibition of paintings and drawings by Leonid Pasternak that can be seen at the Jewish Museum through May 22 will be irresistible to those who prize the long-lost and quite irretrievable world of the pre-revolutionary Russian intelligentsia. It was both a completely cosmopolitan world and a world without prejudice. The people in question lived for art, music and literature and had the good fortune to experience them, new-minted, in forms that have still not lost their fascination. Anyone who remembers the hush of wonder and bemusement that came over the audience at the Moscow Conservatory when Vladimir Horowitz turned to Scriabin on his return to Russia will know the world in which Leonid Pasternak, his wife and his children lived.

title: Comedy's Bad Boys Screech Into the Spotlight
description: Resplendent in glittering rock-star garb, Eddie Murphy prowls the stage in his hit concert movie, ''Raw,'' like a sleek young lion.

title: What the Child Hears Sounds Right to the Man
description: Being some four dec-ades removed from childhood myself, and not being on a basis of daily intimacy with childish ways, I have come late to the phenomenon of Raffi. But to judge from the enthusiasm of my 19-month-old niece, and the long-suffering tolerance of her parents, who have heard Raffi's album ''The Corner Grocery Store and Other Singable Songs'' more times than they ever thought they'd listen to any album in their lives, I have been introduced.

title: Debate in London: Can Good Books Be Popular?
description: In 1942 George Orwell, deploring Kipling's mass appeal, wrote, ''It is no use pretending that in an age like our own good poetry can have any genuine popularity.''

title: In Texas, Two Kings of the Beauty Queen Business
description: IN a brownstone office in the center of this city stand three cardboard women in evening gowns.

title: Mary Dunhill; Business Executive, 81
description: Mary Dunhill, the last surviving child of Alfred Dunhill, founder of the tobacco and pipe-making company, died Wednesday, death notices said today. She was 81 years old. The only daughter among Dunhill's four children, Ms. Dunhill joined the board of Dunhill Holdings in 1944, explaining ''they were rather short of men,'' and in 1961 became chairman, succeeding her eldest brother, Alfred. In 1975, she became president. During her tenure as chairman, the company won the Queen's Award to Industry three times.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EVOLVING CATSKILLS The Hudson River Museum in Yonkers has organized an exhibition, opening today and on view through May 29, that documents the development of the Catskills from a wilderness in 1820 to a back-to-nature environment for tourists by 1895. Following the Westchester showing, it will travel to the Strong Museum in Rochester, the Albany Institute of History and Art, and the Everson Museum in Syracuse.

title: Hiring Women To Haul Garbage
description: ANOTHER male stronghold in New York City crumbled in August 1986 when the Sanitation Department hired two women for its garbage collection force.

title: TV COMPETITION SERVES THE ISLAND
description: The article examining News 12 [ ''Cable News Station Catching On,'' Jan. 24 ] provided valuable information about the nation's first (and excellent) 24-hour all-news regional service.

title: May Wedding Planned By Beth Whittingham
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Whittingham of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Whittingham to Charles Frederick Goehring, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Goehring of Falmouth, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Enfolding India in A Length Of Cloth
description: THE sari is merely a length of cloth about six yards long, but it enfolds all the exoticism of India. Without the need for tailoring, buttons or zippers, the sari provides its wearer with the modesty of a veil, a shield from the sun and protection from the cold. Like the sarong and the serape, the sari combines simplicity with ingenuity to become an elegant solution in the technical sense of the word. This universal uniform of both Moslem and Hindu women is also elegant in the word's high fashion sense. Whether woven of simple cotton or precious silk the sari is considered by many to be the world's most feminine costume.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PRISONERS. By Bill Ripley. (Atlantic Monthly Press, Paper, $6.95.) This frenzied first novel tells four interlocking stories of the sex and drug underworld in Texas and California. Its overly full cast of characters centers on the sociopathic Lester, who is trying to launch a video scam involving subliminally programmed erotic films, and Hugo, Lester's naive and oafish employee at the telephone company in Houston, who picks up a hitchhiking porn star named Chuckles and quickly falls in love with her.

title: Richard Lee Kauffman, an Executive, And Ellen Jewett Plan to Wed in June
description: The engagement of Ellen Jewett, an associate in municipal finance at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, to Richard Lee Kauffman, a vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York, has been announced by Constance Comly Jewett and Dr. Frank Sniffen Jewett, both of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond H. Kauffman of Encino, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Mother Wins a Timeout From Soccer
description: SUDDENLY, I'm a free woman. No, I have not become single. My children haven't prematurely flown the coop or otherwise become minors of (financially) precociously independent means.

title: Life on Midwest Farms Is Reaping Loneliness
description: Allen Adair is a tall, strapping 30-year-old bachelor with a square jaw, an honest smile and a steady job. He is just the kind of man many single women say they can't seem to find.

title: AU REVOIR TO IDEOLOGY
description: IT WAS WITH SOME amusement that Roland Dumas, an urbane lawyer who served as Foreign Minister under the Socialists, recently recalled the roiled and polarized political climate of France's last presidential campaign, in 1981. ''I know people in the liberal professions, friends of mine, who quit France, went to England or elsewhere after Mitterrand was elected,'' said Mr. Dumas, sitting in his smartly appointed office on the Quai de Bourbon hard by the wintry Seine. ''They thought the country was finished.''

title: Iraqi Planes Attack Teheran; Raids on Refineries Reported
description: Iraq said its warplanes pounded Iran's major oil refineries in a wave of air strikes today that also attacked Teheran. Iran vowed to hit Baghdad in retaliation.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Great Day for the Polish NEW YORK STATE has added a commemorative day to honor Polish-Americans, but no one has bothered to tell Long Island's Polish-Americans about it.

title: Pilgrim Mothers
description: To the Editor:

title: Swaggart's Troubles Show Tension of Passion and Power in TV Evangelism
description: One night about 30 years ago, as he hovered somewhere between sleep and consciousness, Jimmy Swaggart says, he found himself in a windowless, bare room suffused with a palpable sense of evil.

title: Q&A
description: Driving to Music

title: Miss Martell Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Karen Jean Martell to Timothy Paul Angelotti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas C. Angelotti of Midland, Mich., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Martell of Franklin Lakes, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Wandering Ash Ship From Philadelphia Abandons Its Quest
description: A cargo ship laden with refuse is abandoning its 18-month, six-nation quest for a place to dump 15,000 tons of Philadelphia incinerator ash, a Coast Guard official said Friday.

title: The Paradoxical Hemingway
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art of Matching Cooks and Clients
description: EACH year more and more companies decide to farm out their food programs to independent contractors. Battling for this market are the small regional contractors and the Goliaths with a national reach - notably the Marriott Corporation, ARA Services, Inc. and the Canteen Company.

title: For Stylish Women, Jackets Required
description: THIS season marks the return of the dinner suit, an ensemble that evokes the long-legged, cigarette-in-a-holder look of New York in the 40's. Not many cigarette holders are in evidence these days (nor many cigarettes, for that matter), but the suit still wafts up its share of heady, nighttime-in-the-big-city sophistication.

title: Early Music Is Icumen In on New Disks
description: Early music is flourishing on recordings. The term early music serves as a convenient label for the vast number of works composed before the universal adoption of our modern scales, around the time of Bach. Pre-Bach music is based on scales that differ significantly from our present major and minor, and therefore often sounds strange to modern listeners. It is equally strange to the ears of modern performers, who have to master a whole ''new'' world of pitch relationships.

title: RUNNING OUT OF TIME AND LANDFILLS: Incinerators: Safety Issue in Congress
description: WITH budget cutting and contra aid behind it for the moment, Congress is about to focus its energies on new matters, among them a lack of safety standards for the disposal of garbage.

title: New Rochelle Recaptures Its Tie to Remington's Old West
description: LEAD: ONCE there was a wild and beautiful land, where trappers took to majestic mountains and buffalo skinners to sweeping plains, where Indians and cavalry troops each defiantly stood their ground, and where cowboys, soiled from driving cattle, sought whisky and women in two-bit towns.

title: THE HIGH COST OF THINNESS
description: SUCTIONING fat from the thighs, rump, knees and face may seem an extreme way to pursue good looks. But the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery announced recently that this technique, called liposuction, is ''safe and effective.'' Only 11 deaths, the surgeons said, have been reported since liposuction was imported from France six years ago.

title: Plane Crash in Cyprus Kills All 15 on Board
description: A Boeing 727 owned by a Turkish charter company crashed into mountains today near the coastal resort city of Kyrenia in northern Cyprus, killing all 15 people aboard, rescue officials said.

title: CABLE TV FAILS IN MANHATTAN
description: Cable television service to 218,000 customers in Manhattan was disrupted for about two hours yesterday shortly before the broadcast of the gold medal figure skating competition at the Winter Olympics.

title: You Pays Yer Money
description: YOU PAYS YER mon-ey and you takes yer choice,'' I wrote in this space recently, using what I assumed to be an old Americanism meaning, as the oddsmakers say, ''Pick 'em.''

title: Next Week; What Was Good and Bad in the Olympics?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
GARDENING;
New Perennials Worth Trying
description: LEAD: EACH year seed companies and nurseries release many new plants for us to try.

title: The Heartland Still Belongs to Trains Ives (pg. 39)
description: The most haunting sound ever made by an instrument of human devising is the far-off whistle of a steam locomotive. The impact is doubled if the locomotive is visible in the middle distance, pulling a fast train from one city to another, blowing for every curve and crossing. It's tripled if all this happens at night, so that you wake at 2 A.M. to hear the lonesome whistle, and, going to the window, see the string of lighted cars moving by, bright beads against the night. Not even a steamboat, not even a foghorn can match that.
