title: Dr. Taya Glotzer Wed to M. S. Sommer
description: Dr. Taya V. Glotzer, a resident in internal medicine at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, and Michael S. Sommer, a law clerk to Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum of Federal District Court in New York, were married last evening. Rabbis Judah Nadich and Hershel E. Portnoy officiated at Beth Emeth Synagogue in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Mark Stone Wed To Miss Hellmold
description: At the Harvard Club of New York City, Margery Hellmold, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hellmold of Leonia, N.J., and Mark Jonathan Stone, a son of Marion L. Stone of Stamford, Conn., and Elhanan C. Stone of Mount Washington, Mass., were married yesterday by Judge Jacqueline Silberman of Civil Court in Manhattan.

title: Beheading a Tower to Make It Legal
description: Lopping the top 12 stories off the ''too tall'' condominium building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and rebuilding the roof would be a project unprecedented in the New York construction industry.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Some of the floorboards in our house have raised slightly at the edges, and they often break when stepped upon. As a result, we now have spaces between the boards. This condition seems to have developed after the floors were stained. Can you help us solve this problem?

title: Hospice Concept Gains in County
description: LEAD: ''THE greatest misconception about hospice is that it is a place - a building, a shelter - and most people who call hospices are in fact looking for that,'' said Carol Selinske, executive director of the New York State Hospice Association, based in White Plains.

title: A Family Marks Its Horse-And-Carriage Sesquicentennial
description: THE Farclough clan is preparing to celebrate the sesquicentennial of a family tradition.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The economy doesn't exhibit the geriatric characteristics of the very late stage of an economic expansion.''

title: RUNNING OUT OF TIME AND LANDFILLS: Recycling: Are Markets Becoming Saturated?
description: LEAD: WHILE most municipalities on Long Island are supporting recycling efforts, new questions are being raised on whether enough markets can be found for the collected and separated materials.

title: DATA BANK: February 28, 1988
NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: POLITICAL SATIRIST Mark Russell, the political satirist whose line is ''I have 535 writers -435 in the House and 100 in the Senate,'' will appear in Sparta Saturday evening.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Turning Off Ivan; Why the Russians Scorn Their Schools
description: FOUR teen-agers are laden with presents and good cheer when they go to their mathematics teacher's apartment for a surprise birthday party. But the surprise turns vicious. They lock the teacher in her apartment, cut off the phone and begin a nightmarish siege to force her to give them access to their examination papers so that they can change their grades.

title: PROTEST LEADERS AGREE TO SUSPEND ARMENIAN UNREST
description: After receiving assurances from Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he would personally study their grievances, Armenian nationalist leaders called today for a one-month suspension of the demonstrations that have shaken two southern Soviet republics, Armenian representatives said.

title: D'Amato Strays, Willfully, From New York Party Line
description: ON the surface, the New York Republican Presidential primary pits Vice President Bush against Senator Bob Dole. Just beneath the surface, however, is an increasingly bitter struggle between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and the state Republican establishment.

title: THE NATION: Regional Appeals; Candidates Try to Draw A Winning Map of U.S.
description: GEORGE BUSH has campaigned as a Connecticut Yankee and a Texas cowboy.

title: How About a 32d of July?
description: LEAD: An old tradition holds that once every four years - on Feb. 29 - it is acceptable etiquette for a woman to propose marriage to the man of her choice. Obviously, because of the advances of feminism such behavior is no longer restricted to leap year. But to the best of my knowledge no other disposition of that extra day has been suggested lately.

title: Long Beach Theater Plan Opposed
description: LEAD: THE City of Long Beach may soon have its own seven-screen, first-run movie theater in the long-vacant Laurel Theater on Park Street in the western end of the town. That is, if neighbors in homes surrounding the movie house drop their concerns about increased traffic and the lack of parking for the theater.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Q and A
description: Uptown Landmark

title: HE LIKED HIS MEAT POACHED
description: ONE LIFE AT A TIME, PLEASE By Edward Abbey. 225 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: New York Area Is Ranked High on Environment
description: For the second year in a row, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut ranked among the top six states in efforts to establish and enforce environmental programs, according to a report released this week.

title: 4 Sentenced in Plotting Escape at Leavenworth
description: The leader of a Puerto Rican independence group and three sympathizers who plotted to help him escape from prison with rockets, grenades and a helicopter have been sentenced to up to 15 years in prison.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE DINING
description: ''FEEDING employees is part of the corporate culture,'' said Stephen Elmont, president of Creative Gourmets Ltd., a Boston contractor that provides corporate food services. ''Business and industry will continue to provide food. How they'll provide it is the question.''

title: NONFICTION
description: UFO-ABDUCTIONS: A Dangerous Game. By Philip J. Klass. (Prometheus, $18.95.) In his new book the U.F.O. debunker Philip J. Klass examines the current wave of reported contacts with unidentified flying objects, including the tale told by Whitley Strieber in his best-selling book ''Communion.'' Mr. Klass describes the work of those self-proclaimed experts whose first guess about any puzzling incident involves a U.F.O. He details claims of everything from straight kidnapping to impregnations by U.F.O.-nauts, supposedly uncovered by investigators. And he pays particular attention to the use, and abuse, of hypnosis in analyzing U.F.O. reports. During treatment, for example, the hypnotist can inadvertently plant ''pseudo-memories'' that later seem real to the subject. Some people may be further damaged or deluded by irresponsible researchers. For instance, one woman who had had an abortion was told that extraterrestrials had removed her fetus for an interbreeding experiment. The interested reader will be fascinated by the story of Christy Dennis, a woman who gained acceptance in U.F.O. circles for two years before admitting her experience with eight-foot-tall golden-haired beings was a hoax. In a tone that is more snide than skeptical, Mr. Klass presents an uncommon view of the methods, motivations and personalities behind all this. The author of ''UFO's: The Public Deceived'' and other books, he does a thorough job in his role as a muckraker.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CONTACT PRINTS. By Philip Kreiner. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Philip Kreiner's third novel opens with his cocky, Toronto-bred protagonist flying north to teach at an isolated community on the shore of Canada's James Bay. Joe comes to the town of Fort Henrietta-Maria solely for the money. But he gets a good deal more than he bargains for in his relations with the local Cree, as well as with a complex net of interests involving the Inuit, the Ottawa Government, English and French Canadians, and a cast of pioneer community characters.

title: Hong Kong Tunnel Will Link 2 Towns on Kowloon in '91
description: Hong Kong will spend more than $512 million on a 2 1/2-mile toll tunnel linking two towns on the Kowloon Peninsula, an official said today.

title: Agriculture Is Learning to Fight Nature With Nature
description: IN Maryland, crab shells are being turned into a natural insecticide.

title: For Consideration
description: Judith Campbell Exner, who has claimed that she was having an affair with John F. Kennedy when he was elected President, says that with her death from cancer imminent, she has another tale to tell. Mrs. Exner said in an interview published last week in People magazine that Kennedy had her arrange more than 10 meetings with Sam Giancana, a Chicago mob boss who Mrs. Exner said was also her lover. She said the meetings concerned, among other things, Kennedy's need for Mr. Giancana's help in the West Virginia Presidential primary. Mrs. Exner, who had previously denied any Kennedy-Giancana link, said she was changing her story now ''to put my life in order so that I may die peacefully.'' But Kitty Kelley, who interviewed her, said Mrs. Exner also did it for money - about $50,000 from the magazine.

title: A New Initiative On Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: EFFORTS to combat Lyme disease took on new urgency last week when the State Assembly's Health Committee unveiled a report that called the illness ''a clear and present danger'' and called for the creation of a $1.7 million tick-borne disease institute.

title: The Mini-Series: A Hymn to Consumerism?
description: Way back when, Mickey Rooney taught Elizabeth Taylor to ride in the movie ''National Velvet.'' That was a delight - warm and sentimental, and when Ms. Taylor won the Grand National you cried. In ''My Friend Flicka,'' Roddy McDowall cried. In movies, the care, feeding and ownership of horses has been steeped in family feeling.

title: Samuel L. Duboc And Marina Kalb To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kalb of Rockville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margot Marina Kalb to Samuel Livingston Duboc, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Duboc of Fox Chapel, Pa. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: COGNAC IS...
description: GERARD Allemandou recent-ly moved his little fish restaurant, La Cagouille, from the rue Daguerre to the Square Brancusi, and it lost a lot of its charm. The rue Daguerre was old Paris; the Square Brancusi, just around the corner, is a neighborhood of ugly new apartment buildings, in one of which the restaurant is now quartered.

title: Hostage in Lebanon: The American 9
description: Terry A. Anderson: Chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press; missing since March 16, 1985. Thomas M. Sutherland: Dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut; June 9, 1985. Frank Herbert Reed: Director of the Lebanon International School in Beirut; Sept. 9, 1986. Joseph James Cicippio: Acting controller of the American University of Beirut; Sept. 12, 1986. Edward Austin Tracy: Author; Oct. 21, 1986. Jesse Turner: Visiting professor of mathematics and computer science at University College; Jan. 24, 1987. Robert Polhill: Assistant professor of business at Beirut University College; Jan. 24, 1987. Alann Steen: Journalism professor at Beirut University College; Jan. 24, 1987. Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins: Marine officer, head of an observer group attached to the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon; Feb. 17, 1988.

title: THE SINS OF THE MOTHERS
description: COMPLICITY By Elizabeth Cooke. 262 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: THE REAL KEY WEST
description: THE ''CONCH REPUBLIC'' is the only place in the United States where you can stroll past shrimp-pink houses shaded by chocolate-colored orchid trees and eat ''jelly'' coconuts with a spoon. The Conch Republic is better known as Key West, where native islanders call themselves Conchs, after the giant sea snails that once sustained pirates and other renegades, and now feed tourists with conch chowders, fritters, salads, steaks, burgers and pizzas. But behind the tourist flap-doodle, authentic Conch cooking is produced by the descendants of Bahamian English and Cubans, who migrated to this coral reef over a century ago and discovered that here meals seem to leap from the waters and fall from the trees.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: NEW ENGLAND NOW

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: NO MORE 'MELTDOWN MONDAYS';
Blame Archaic Markets, Not New Tools
description: LEAD: THREE of the most recent major studies of the financial markets have laid much of the blame for the Oct. 19 stock market crash on program trading. The most recent report, by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is pointed in its criticism of computer-driven program trading as the primary reason for the depth of the October plunge.

title: MR. GIBBON AND THE HUNS
description: This, I think, is a very reasonable passage of English prose:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think there has been, in great part, a ceding of the black vote to Jesse.'' -Bill Campbell, a City Councilman in Atlanta. [ 28:2. ]

title: Troupe Tries to Preserve Old Style of Operettas
description: WHAT is operetta? Who's to say when old Broadway musicals like ''Carousel'' and current hits like ''Les Miserables,'' all all with serious and symbolic overtones, are being so classified?

title: A Telling Finish Indoors
description: To listen to the competitors at the USA/Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, the completion of the indoor season in an Olympic year, the most intense race may have been the one to the door.

title: MULTIPLEX CINEMA FEATURES TRAFFIC
description: Your recent article about the new All-Westchester Saw Mill Multiplex Cinema in Hawthorne [ About Westchester, Jan. 31 ] completely missed what is, in our view, the most significant feature of the new center: traffic access in and out of the mammoth parking lot is entirely inadequate. Our recent visit to the complex on a Saturday night provoked vivid and heated comparisons to a descent into hell, as we waited, and waited, for the traffic to inch down into the packed and poorly laid-out parking area. We do not plan to return until this problem is solved. The sole means of entry into and departure from the parking area are two small, two-lane ramps. Each ramp carries one lane of traffic in each direction, and both ramps were, upon our arrival about 20 minutes before show time, jammed in both directions. In an effort to beat this mess, emissaries from cars around us were seen jumping out of their blocked cars to sprint across lanes of traffic for the ticket windows. The traffic flow is so poor that we weren't even parked within 20 minutes, much less inside the gargantuan lobby. In the parking lot itself, traffic seemed to be going in every direction simultaneously, and hence was moving, truly, at a snail's pace. The crowning touch was the theater's incomprehensible decision to have several of the most popular shows begin at the same time, which maximized the load on the sadly inadequate entrances and exits. We can't imagine how the developers of this monstrosity thought two small traffic ramps would suffice, and by what means the local planning officials were persuaded to unleash this disaster upon the people of Westchester.

title: Baby-Sitting Grandchildren: Love Them and Leave Them
description: I AM not fond of baby-sitting. It is anxiety producing. I have no problem speaking to large audiences. I conduct myself admirably in interviews. I give dinner parties with appropriate ease. I drive without flinching at tailgating trucks.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Safety Valve for Violent Schools
description: The dispute, between class sessions at Bryant High School in Long Island City, was like one of thousands in urban high schools every day. Four white students had gathered on a stairway when Michael, a black, tried to push past. Tempers flared. Charles, one of the whites, threatened Michael with a knife. Michael drew his own knife but a friend pulled him back. Michael threatened to get Charles later.

title: Change Advised for New York Middle Schools
description: Sweeping changes are needed in the way New York City's middle schools -intermediate and junior high schools -are run, according to a Board of Education report released last week.

title: U.S. INDICTS FOUR IN A PAYOLA CASE
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted two music promoters, the wife of one of them and a former radio executive on charges of tax evasion and paying more than $260,000 in cash and cocaine to get records played on the air.

title: Stockbroker Turned Winemaker Finds Success in Vermont Apples
description: Joseph Cerniglia knew nothing about making wine when he decided to build a winery here two years ago. He didn't know anything about apples, either, when he decided to buy an orchard here in 1978.

title: Fitting In on Campus at Princeton and Bard
description: If there is anything that unifies all great college campuses, it is a sense of wholeness - a sense of place, a feeling that the identities of individual buildings have been played down in favor of something larger. It is not that all the buildings on the best campuses look the same, although often enough they do. But the architect's more compelling challenge is much subtler than playing a look-alike game. It lies in trying to make coherence out of different kinds of architecture, in trying to bring a diverse range of buildings into harmony.

title: Pro-Iran Kurdish Group Frees Three Italian Hostages in Iraq
description: A pro-Iranian Kurdish group today released three Italian engineers who were taken hostage in Iraq last fall to protest Italian warships patrolling in the Persian Gulf, the Foreign Ministry reported.

title: Music: Trinity-St. Michael's
description: THE Orchestra at Trinity-Saint Michael's is a 23-member ensemble from Fairfield, Conn., that performed in Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening under the baton of its able young music director, Duilio Dobrin.

title: To Emanuel Ax, the Future Is Increasingly the Present
description: ''Wouldn't it be unbelievable,'' muses Emanuel Ax, ''for someone to read that there was this fine pianist in Beethoven's time but he never actually opened a piece of Beethoven's?'' Contemporary music has a new, if unlikely, champion. Though he has built his considerable reputation interpreting the works of Chopin, Brahms, Beethoven and Mozart, Mr. Ax of late hungers for more recently conceived repertory. Why the switch?

title: Knight Rerouted
description: After driving nine hours down the length of Florida to report to the Baltimore Orioles' training camp in Miami, Ray Knight found out that he had driven about four hours too far. The Orioles are still in Miami, to be sure, but while the former Mets star was on the road from South Carolina with his wife, Nancy Lopez, and their two daughters, the 35-year-old third baseman was being traded to the Detroit Tigers, whose camp is in Lakeland, Fla., 200 miles to the north of Miami.

title: NONFICTION
description: FORGING PEACE: The Challenge of Central America. By Richard R. Fagen. (PACCA/Basil Blackwell, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $7.95.) For Americans seeking an alternative to the ''covert intervention, surrogate war, and systematic deceit'' that brand our Government's policy in Central America (as George McGovern puts it in the foreword to ''Forging Peace''), this political primer offers some refreshing ideas for reform. The book is a group project of the liberal organization Policy Alternatives for the Caribbean and Central America that was overseen by Richard R. Fagen, a professor of Latin American studies at Stanford University. He argues convincingly that the best way to secure vital American interests in the region is to promote ''peace through diplomacy'' and ''security through development.'' Unfortunately, events have somewhat overtaken the book. Mr. Fagen suggests that the United States support a ''Contadora-type'' peace initiative, which, among other features, called for a ban on all foreign military bases and personnel in Central America; there is no mention of the current Arias plan, which makes much the same proposals. But never mind. The strength of the book lies in its recommendations for formulating a new United States policy toward Central America. Essentially, that entails stopping all aid to the contras and vigorously promoting throughout the region economic, political and social reform consistent with democratic values and ideals. A pie-in-the-sky idea? Perhaps. But after more than seven years of costly war in Nicaragua, it surely is worth a try.

title: Two Top Executives Named By New York Urban League
description: The New York Urban League has announced the appointments of William J. Brown as interim president and John J. Barrett as chairman.

title: Beer Is Excellent as, Yes, an Ingredient
description: ALMOST every nation in the world makes beer of some sort. And these days it seems that they are all being sold here.

title: CLARIFYING CURLING
description: The article on curling by Jack Cavanaugh on Jan. 24 (''A Little Notice for a Little-Known Sport'') captured the essential flavor of curling and focused attention on a game that suffers from a lack of exposure in the United States.

title: U.S. CHARGES CUBA SMEARS DELEGATE
description: The Cuban Government has begun a campaign to discredit a former Cuban political prisoner and writer chosen by the Reagan Administration to lead the United States delegation to this year's meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva, according to American diplomats.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After spending most of the last two years in detention for distributing cocaine, Tony Robinson, the former Tennessee quarterback, was released from the Knox County Penal Farm in Tennessee yesterday after winning a parole. . . . A former United States Boxing Association middleweight titleholder, Alex Ramos, was taken into custody late Friday in an investigation of charges of assault with a deadly weapon, kidnapping and false imprisonment after police said he attacked a female roommate in Los Angeles. He was jailed in $160,000 bail, police said. . . . The former Atlanta Hawks guard, Eddie Johnson, pleaded guilty to possession and sale of crack, the cocaine derivative, and was sentenced to an 18-month suspended prison term in Florida. Johnson, 33 years old, was also placed on probation for four years and was ordered to perform 250 hours of community service. . . . He maintained a 2.66 earned-run average while saving 33 games for the St. Louis Cardinals last season, and now Todd Worrell, who had a 8-6 record, has his reward: a one-year contract worth $200,000, $50,000 more than he made last year. . . . The Montreal Expos catcher Mike Fitzgerald will see limited action for the next three weeks because of a fractured bone in his left wrist. He was injured when he was hit by a foul tip during batting practice Friday. . . . Wally Joyner called off his holdout yesterday and reported to the California Angels' training camp in Mesa, Ariz. Joyner is still unsigned, but is prepared to have the Angels renew his contract by the club-imposed deadline of March 3. . . . Glen Rice, Michigan's junior forward who is the Big Ten scoring leader, said he had decided not to turn pro after this season. . . . Arthur Ashe, Althea Gibson and Bill Talbert were among nine luminaries elected to the new Eastern Tennis Association Hall of Fame. Also enshrined will be Hy Zausner, owner of the Port Washington Tennis Academy, and the late Allison Danzig, who covered tennis for The New York Times for 45 years and was the first journalist elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: Miss Kahn Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Kahn of Boca Raton, Fla., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Sue Kahn, to Dr. Barry M. Zingler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Zingler of Fair Lawn, N.J. Miss Kahn, a registered respiratory therapist at University Hospital in New York, and her fiance, a resident in internal medicine at the New York University Medical Center, plan to marry in May.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Suburban Offices; 25% Vacancy Rates Starting to Worry Developers
description: SAY this about 1988 within the suburban office markets of New York City: At least it is not 1986, when developers put up far too many buildings. Or 1987, when the stock market crash shattered the expansion plans of many companies.

title: Keeping Beach Barricade Is Debated
description: LEAD: THE Southampton Town Board is trying to decide whether to continue a barricade on Dune Road in Westhampton Beach that it erected to prevent people from going into the barrier beach section, which has been severely damaged by storms.

title: U.S. Film Stars Delight Muscovites
description: Daryl Hannah, swathed in white from her cotton jacket and pants to her high-top sneakers, appeared center-stage at the Zaryade movie theater just as the lights went back on and the credits rolled for ''Roxanne.''

title: Linda Eglin Is Engaged
description: Linda Hilliard Eglin's engagement to Cole Edmund Harrop, a son of Yolanda W. McPhee of Princeton, N.J., and David C. Harrop of New York, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Thomas Wilson Eglin of Lawrenceville, N.J., and Watch Hill, R.I. A May wedding is planned.

title:
FILM;
An Exile Spices 'Babette's Feast'
description: LEAD: The Danish film direc-tor Gabriel Axel is a man inhabited by two sharply conflicting spirits. Meet Mr. Axel in his modern, functional apartment in Paris and he looks a tall, reedy, austere Scandinavian, a director who values Craft over Passion, Technique over Inspiration. He wears relaxed corduroy slacks but keeps his sweater primly buttoned up tight under his gray spade of a beard.

title:
GARDENING;
Native Wildflowers Go to Finishing School
description: LEAD: MONARDA Purple Crown. Achillea Apple Blossom. Eupatorium Gateway. The names are English, but the cultivars are not. They're German.

title: Lauren Razook Becomes Bride Of John M. Roth
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lauren Claudia Razook, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Razook of Rye and Lake Placid, N.Y., to John Michael Roth, a son of Mrs. Robert E. Roth Jr. of St. Louis and the late Mr. Roth. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Damian O'Connell, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Pop: Daugherty and Field
description: THE fact that Bill Daugherty and Robin Field do almost one song every minute during the hour that they are onstage at the Ballroom might simply suggest that they sing very fast. But nothing could be farther from their intention.

title: Jersey Asserts Tidal Land Rights After U.S. Ruling
description: When the United States Supreme Court ruled last week that Mississippi owned all lands affected by the ebb and flow of the tides, officials in all coastal states, including New Jersey, heaved a collective sigh of relief.

title: Battle for Crack Trade in Queens May Hold Key to Officer's Killing
description: The brazen slaying of a rookie police officer as he guarded a drug witness may have been an outgrowth of turf wars among crack dealers in southeastern Queens, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Teaching Explored in 2 Plays
description: ''I DON'T believe in the educational process,'' Professor Hiller blithely informs his students, while he sips a martini.

title: ON TRAIL AND MEADOW
description: BACK-COUNTRY skiing is cross-country skiing in areas that are not groomed and tracked by machines. You can do back-country skiing in three kinds of areas: public parks and state forests, where bridle paths and carriage roads become perfect ski trails in winter, touring centers that have back-country trails linked to their main trail systems, and true wilderness regions, which may involve skiing up and down mountains on hiking trails.

title: Lyle Nelson Worth Mention
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Flight Attendants At Northwest Delay Strike Over Wages
description: Northwest Airlines planes continued flying today and a union spokesman said strike preparations by 6,700 flight attendants had been ''put on hold'' even though all-night contract talks had hit a snag. The union had set a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Amateur Night at the Apollo: Boo Birds and Happiness
description: LEAD: It is almost showtime at the Apollo, and backstage at the legendary Harlem theater the Amateur Night contestants are awaiting the call for their moment in the spotlight.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Mayotte Advances: Tim Mayotte, the defending champion, defeated sixth-seeded Christo van Rensburg, 6-2, 7-5, yesterday in the semifinals of the United States Pro Indoor tournament in Philadelphia. Mayotte, who extended his winning streak to 14 matches, rallied from a 2-5 deficit in the second set to take the 1-hour-19-minute match. In the final today, he will play the winner of last night's match between unseeded Jorge Lozano and 16th-seeded John Fitzgerald. The key eighth game of the second set turned in Mayotte's favor when van Rensburg hit a service return into the net on set point. Mayotte then broke van Rensburg's service in the 9th and 11th games to lead, 6-5.(AP) Shriver to Face Navratilova: Second-seeded Pam Shriver saved her best tennis for the latter stages of each set yesterday in a 7-5, 7-6 victory over Gabriela Sabatini that propelled her into the final of the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament in Fairfax, Va. Shriver won the first set with a final-game service break, and then won the final 5 points of the tiebreaker in the second set. Shriver, who fired seven aces in eliminating the third-seeded Sabatini in 1 hour 37 minutes, will play Martina Navratilova, a 6-4, 6-2 semifinal winner over Hana Mandlikova.(AP) Golf Okamoto Wins Hawaiian Open: Ayako Okamoto shot a par 72 yesterday and held off a late challenge from JoAnne Carner to win the Hawaiian Open. Carner, who fell out of a tie for the lead with a bogey on the 17th hole after rallying with three birdies on the back nine, missed a 12-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole that would have forced a sudden-death playoff. Okamoto finished with a 54-hole total of three-under-par 213 on the 6,220-yard Turtle Bay Resort course on Oahu. Okamoto, the 1987 L.P.G.A. player of the year, earned $45,000 for winning her first L.P.G.A. Tour appearance of 1988.(AP) Beck Takes Lead: Chip Beck, often a runner-up but never a winner in 10 years on the PGA Tour, shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday to take the third-round lead in the Los Angeles Open. Beck, at 14-under-par 199, will take a three-stroke lead over Jay Haas, Ed Fiori and Steve Elkington of Australia into today's final round at the Riviera Country Club. The 31-year-old Beck has finished second in nine tournaments since joining the Tour.(AP) Charles Leads Seniors: Bob Charles shot a two-under-par 70 yesterday to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Aetna Challenge for Seniors in Naples, Fla. Harold Henning and Gary Player were at 140, a stroke behind Charles.(AP) Soccer Liverpool Streak at 27: John Barnes scored two goals in the second half as Liverpool defeated Portsmouth, 2-0, in English League play yesterday. The victory enabled the runaway First Division leader to stretch its unbeaten streak to 27 games, two short of the First Division record held by Leeds United. The loss snapped Portsmouth's 10-game unbeaten string. Liverpool has won 21 games and tied 6 for 69 points. It leads Manchester United by 14 points with two games in hand.(AP) P.S.A.L. Basketball Lincoln Advances: Undefeated Lincoln defeated Boys and Girls High School, 56-47, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League playoff game at Canarsie High School in Brooklyn. Lincoln scored the first 10 points, led by 31-18 at halftime and then held off a determined comeback effort. Norman Marburi scored 16 points and Darrell Mims snatched 11 rebounds to lead Lincoln to its 22d straight victory and a berth in the final eight. Boys and Girls ended the season at 20-4. Lincoln's next game will be the borough championship on Saturday at Canarsie against Grady, a 56-45 winner over Westinghouse yesterday. Pat Alphonse led Grady (18-6) with 16 points. Westinghouse finished 18-5 as its 13-game winning streak was snapped. N.B.A. Trail Blazers Nip Hawks: Jerome Kersey's steal and 3-point basket at the buzzer gave Portland a 123-120 victory at Atlanta last night despite a 47-point effort by the Hawks' Dominique Wilkins. Kersey, who had 25 points, intercepted Scott Hastings's inbound pass and launched the game-winning shot after Clyde Drexler's jumper lifted the Blazers into a 120-120 tie with three seconds to play.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres Top Whalers: Mike Donnelly and Mikael Anderson scored in the final three minutes for Buffalo, and Tom Barrasso, the Sabres' goalie, stopped 24 shots, including 16 in the third period.(AP) Bruins Beat North Stars: Geoff Courtnall had the first three-goal game of his career as Boston spotted Minnesota two goals in the first 34 seconds before rallying for a 7-4 victory over the North Stars in Boston.(AP) Cycling Phinney Keeps Top Spot: Michel Vaarten of Belgium won the fifth stage in the Tour of the Americas in a sprint finish yesterday. He narrowly defeated his countryman Marnix Lameire, and Greg LeMond of Minneapolis. The stage was held in West Palm Beach, Fla. Davis Phinney, of Boulder, Colo., remained the overall leader of the 580-mile race, which will end today in the Miami suburb of Coconut Grove. Phinney earned a 15-second time bonus at the end of lap 11, increasing his overall lead to 52 seconds over Steve Tilford of Topeka, Kan. LeMond remained in fourth place, 1 minute 20 seconds behind Phinney.(AP)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 14 about a proposed reorganization of the White Plains school system incorrectly described Richard H. Bernstein, who spoke at a public hearing. Mr. Bernstein, a parent who lives in the city's Mamaroneck Avenue School district, urged the school board to consider proximity as one factor in matching students to a school. He did not speak in favor of neighborhood schools.

title: I.O.C. Acts to Halt Drug-Test Dodging
description: The International Olympic Committee said today it would punish laboratories that conduct pre-event checks to help athletes avoid controlled drug testing and the penalties involved.

title: Listening to Opportunity
description: In today's society, two of the most often encountered feelings are lack of confidence and poor self-image. I think this is especially true of people at the point in their lives where they are facing new challenges.

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: By April Fools Day. That's when George Steinbrenner will inform us that Billy's hiring was a big joke. JEFFREY DIAMANT Staten Island

title: Broader Day Care Is Aim of Harvard Union Drive
description: American labor's fight for new members is crystallizing around a new issue, affordable child care, on an unlikely battleground, Harvard University.

title: Canada Has Hard Time Deporting Palestinian
description: After weeks of embarrassment over its efforts to deport a convicted Palestinian terrorist inadvertently accepted in Canada as an immigrant last year, the Canadian Government is pondering how it bungled a 7,000-mile round trip that took him from Toronto to London and back in 24 hours.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: TWO environmental organizations have demanded mandatory fines and jail sentences for alleged major violators of water-pollution permits, contending that the state's Department of Environmental Protection has failed to exercise its discretion to enforce pollution laws.

title: Bush Shows Strength in Maine
description: Vice President Bush maintained a solid lead today in Maine's Republican caucuses, forging occasional alliances with Senator Bob Dole's supporters to fend off a strong challenge from Pat Robertson.

title: 'Woo 'em or Lose 'em' to Local Delis
description: THE EASTMAN KODAK COMPANY has the nation's largest self-operated food service for its employees. At its Rochester headquarters, 45,000 employees frequent 56 dining areas and use 1,300 vending machines.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE RIGHT TO REMAIN SILENT. By Charles Brandt. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) In 1961, Lou Razzi, a tough, aggressive, straight-arrow cop, is framed for theft in Wilmington, Del., convicted and sent to prison. Fifteen years later, as an embittered expatriate in Brazil, he learns he has been exonerated.

title: Finding Ways To Meet the Needs Of Potential school Dropouts
description: AS the new legislative session gathers momentum, it seems appropriate to outline the legislative agenda for public education in New Jersey.

title: Edward Knabusch, 88; Founder of La-Z-Boy
description: Edward M. Knabusch, who began making chairs in a garage in the 1920's and later founded the La-Z-Boy Chair Company with a cousin, died here Thursday. He was 88 years old.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CINCINNATI;
RAPID GROWTH WITH NOSTALGIA
description: LEAD: SINCE 1980, the northeast section of this city and its nearby suburbs have become high-growth areas with upper-income residential developments, private lakes, jogging trails and other amenities to lure home buyers.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SECOND SIGHT. By Anne Redmon. (Dutton, $17.95.) To say that Irene Ward, the epileptic heroine of Anne Redmon's third novel, takes too much upon herself is to put it mildly. Indeed, so responsible is she that she yields herself up to the cruel psychological games of her sister and brother, the twins Mathilde and Durrand, struggling with the confusions they plant in her unstable mind, then feeling guilty for doubting them.

title: Joan Baez Apologizes
description: To the Editor:

title: Alisa Newhouse Bride Of Mark Haskell Smith
description: Alisa Newhouse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert P. Newhouse of New York and Block Island, R.I., was married last evening to Mark Haskell Smith, a son of Mrs. Ward Dengler of Kansas City, Kan., and Jackie Lee Smith of Boise, Idaho. Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony at the Newhouse home in New York.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Times Magazine today - ''James Webb's New 'Fields of Fire' '' - describes tensions between Secretary of the Navy James H. Webb Jr. and his superiors.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
Models
description: LEAD: MANY models might come across as beautiful but blase, but Lovey Helene King - with legs that go on forever and the high cheekbones of a photographer's dream -does not appear jaded. In 1985, she won the Miss New York-U.S.A. contest that leads to Miss U.S.A. and Miss Universe. Now the 21-year-old resident of New Rochelle, who has modeled since she was 16, is guiding other young women into modeling through her own business, Helene Models, on East Post

title: FROM THE MINES OF CURRY POWDER
description: THE TROTTER-NAMA A Chronicle. By I. Allan Sealy. 575 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: WHEN FEAR CONQUERS: A DOCTOR LEARNS ABOUT AIDS FROM LEPROSY
description: THE LAST THING I WANTED TO DO at 3:30 in the morning was replace an intravenous line on an AIDS patient. It was the kind of summons I had come to receive with a feeling of injustice. Why hadn't it been checked earlier? Why did it have to be an AIDS patient? And why was it my responsibility?

title: Outdoors; Exposition in Suffern Is Largest in the Northeast
description: A visit to the 11th annual World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition in Suffern, N.Y., Wednesday to Sunday, might help persuade you that spring is nigh.

title: Behind the Hits
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging Out After the Storm In England
description: WHEN gale-force winds ripped across southern England last fall, they destroyed in a few hours what generations of gardeners and landscape planners had labored to achieve. Thousands of trees - some of them planted centuries ago - were felled in gardens and parks. Ornamental avenues were battered, rare species damaged or destroyed. The leafy silhouettes of grand country house gardens designed by such masters as Capability Brown were torn apart overnight.

title: NONFICTION
description: PLAYING GOD: The New World of Medical Choices. By Thomas Scully and Celia Scully. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Thomas Scully, a professor of pediatrics at the University of Nevada School of Medicine, and the freelance writer Celia Scully have written a medical handbook for consumers that is laced with useful tips for improved communication between health professionals and their clients. Many controversial cases - like the story of Baby M, who became a national symbol of the surrogate-parents issue, and that of a 12-year-old child whose parents chose unorthodox cancer therapy over standard treatment, resulting in accusations of child neglect - are replayed and analyzed as learning exercises for the reader. Discussions of symptoms, diagnoses and extenuating family circumstances are followed by lists of medical options and legal ramifications. There is an unfortunate tendency to avoid discussing the moral aspects of ethically disturbing issues. The authors, however, do offer valuable questions to ask when considering organ transplants, for example, or when making life-and-death decisions for another person. Other subjects include how to redress malpractice and billing fraud and even how to handle the news media in precedent-setting cases. ''Playing God'' will appeal to people who have a hard time separating emotions and intellect when they are confronted with difficult choices, but it may chill those readers who perceive that profoundly complex issues have been reduced to consumer health topics.

title: 'Womansword' in China
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Tree Adoptions: Make Mine Maple

title: Morocco Cliff Slide Kills 21
description: A cliff, weakened by days of rain, collapsed today onto a shanty settlement, killing at least 21 people and injuring 6 others, the authorities said. Rescue workers dug through ruins in search of other victims. Those left homeless by the disaster and numerous families whose homes were threatened were evacuated and given temporary refuge in the suburbs. Heavy rains fell in the region for several days.

title: A Pair of Rehnquist Opinions Sets Legal Experts Buzzing
description: CHIEF Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote two decisions issued last Wednesday, involving free speech and rent control, that did not sound like the Court's most predictably conservative member.

title: Housing Panel Offers Carrot and Stick
description: THE state's Blue Ribbon Commission on Housing will recommend this week a package of largely voluntary programs to increase affordable housing, but also plans to warn that the state will eventually have to intervene in local zoning if the housing crisis is not eased.

title: BLUE SKY
description: Simple or zany, sparkling or smooth, familiar or foreign - whatever the angle, if a new spring style is good, it's got a sunny-side-up quality. This sense of high spirits, of having a bit of fun with fashion, pervades the best of the new clothes. It can come from the cut and shape of the shoulders, the skirt or the sleeves. Sometimes the combination of colors or the telling decorative details delineate it. Accessories accentuate it. Whether the price is as high as the moon or more down to earth, the impact of this new blue sky style can be measured in pleasure.

title: Big Drop In Scaup, A Fowl Of Shore
description: WILDLIFE biologists noticed during a recent survey of waterfowl an alarming drop in the number of scaup duck, a diving bird usually common along the Connecticut shore.

title: From Hits To Misses, But Why?
description: There was a time when he cared only about dreaming up new ideas and persuading friends and relatives to work for nothing, but that was before he got lucky. That was before his sleeper, his pet project, his low-budget labor of love became an overnight sensation. After that, studio executives pursued him tirelessly and the press sang his praises; everyone seemed to share the single happy hope that this golden goose would repeat his miracle. But the next time around, things worked out very differently. All he did was lay an egg.

title: Honoring the Builders: Hall of Fame
description: Cornelius Vanderbilt, John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Dewitt Clinton are some of the ''creators of New York'' who will be inducted Tuesday into a new hall of fame sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: CARVING UP AFRICA
description: THE RACE TO FASHODA European Colonialism and African Resistance in the Scramble for Africa. By David Levering Lewis. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $24.95.

title: THE FOOD OF THE ROMAN GHETTO
description: IN Roman restaurants the versatile artichoke appears in all sorts of guises -over fettuccine, in omelets, stuffed with garlic and mint, drenched in olive oil and displayed at the entrance of even the most humble trattoria. But no artichokes undergo such a spectacular transformation as ''carciofi Romani alla giudia,'' Roman artichokes, Jewish style.

title: Battle for the Black Vote Is Over Before It Started
description: In 1984 Walter F. Mondale came to this proud citadel of the civil rights movement, wrapped himself in the approbation of its black establishment, and began a head-to-head, vote-to-vote struggle with the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the support of Southern blacks.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: TULSA;
New Life for The North Side
description: LEAD: GREENWOOD AVENUE, a turn-of-the-century ''Main Street'' on the predominantly black north side of Tulsa, is experiencing a revival as a near-downtown retail-office center.

title: Florida Favorite Is Facing Big Test
description: By Land By Sea, who had been knocking heads with Very Subtle in California all winter, had an easy time with a softer field today and scored a front-running 2 1/4-length victory over Queen Alexandra in the $200,000 Rampart Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: What Makes a Good School Principal?
description: NEW JERSEY may soon push Humpty Dumpty off the wall. Despite volumes of evidence and testimony documenting the importance of principals as instructional leaders, the state's Board of Education is being asked to approve a plan that would eliminate classroom teaching experience as a requirement for those who would lead our state's schools and would require all prospective principals to pursue the equivalent of a Master of Business Adminstration.

title: Elster Hoping To Fill Key Job
description: When the Mets open the season in Montreal on April 4, only one rookie will be in the lineup, maybe only one on the 24-man squad: Kevin Elster, the 23-year-old ''shortstop of the future.''

title: Practical Traveler; In Sunny Spots, Room at the Inn
description: A TOURISM official for one Caribbean country said candidly that it had so far been a ''soft'' season, and she did not mean the weather. But her unhappiness at the slowness of business translates into good news for people who find themselves sick of winter at the end of February but still with no reservations for a sunshine fix.

title: The Right Fight Against AIDS; As the Admiral Says, Focus on Addicts
description: Through the fog of fear and ignorance, the AIDS epidemic in America is taking clearer shape.

title: 3 Talented Pianists In Transition
description: Three youthful, Soviet-schooled pian-ists recently passed through the revolving door that is New York's concert scene, none for the first time but each at an age when seismic changes can take place in an artist's thinking. Vladimir Feltsman and Alexander Toradze, both Soviet emigres in their mid-30's, played concertos with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. Last, and in some ways least, Ivo Pogorelich, a 29-year-old Yugoslavian who studied in Moscow and married his Russian piano teacher, returned to Carnegie Hall for another of his alternately exhilarating and dismaying recitals. Simply in terms of keyboard technique, it would be difficult to rally a more talented threesome in the under-35 class. All have major careers in the making.

title: MINOR POET IN THE FAMILY
description: THREE NIGHTS IN THE HEART OF THE EARTH By Brett Laidlaw. 255 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: Trump's Vision: Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: The Industry Comes to the Mountain
description: MORE than 400 of the most powerful figures in the business gathered at the 11th annual Personal Computing Forum last week - the industry's winter summit meeting. They came to the Gulf Coast of Florida to cut deals, settle old scores, form alliances and try to anticipate where the PC market is headed.

title: The Sounds of Music
description: For Promising Talent

title: The Chief Justice
description: The Supreme Court's decision last week in the Jerry Falwell case was seen at once as a landmark reaffirmation of American principle. In this country we are free to subject public personalities to the most caustic comment.

title: HOW THEY TOOK OVER THE STATEHOUSE
description: THE SUN SET OVER MISSISSIPPI last Nov. 6, Ross Robert Barnett, the fire-and-brimstone segregationist who made that state a civil rights battleground in the 1960's, drew his last breath and, at the age of 89, quietly died in a hospital bed in Jackson. At his side, his son, Ross Jr., couldn't help but note the symmetry of the moment. It happened to be election week, and the state that had once cheered as Ross Barnett blocked a black student's entrance into the University of Mississippi had now chosen as its new Governor a young Harvard lawyer from Sargent S. Shriver's law firm in Washington. ''Things change, people change, times change,'' the younger Barnett later reflected, ''and Mississippi changes, too.''

title: Pop: Paul Carrack and Band
description: PAUL CARRACK, a gifted English soul singer, songwriter and keyboardist, has been assiduously plying his talents on records for 18 years. But it was not until this winter that he finally scored a top-10 hit as a soloist, with ''Don't Shed a Tear.'' An impeccably crafted blue-eyed soul ballad, the record distills Mr. Carrack's sweetly husky vocal style, which blends a touch of the roughness one associates with Joe Cocker and a smoother, more ingenuous brand of melismatic pop crooning.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Feeling Like a King With a Presidential election approaching, it should be particularly interesting to us to know how political leaders feel about their vocation. This is a passage from the memoirs of Louis XIV, written for his son, describing a time when he had resolved to be a conscientious, hard-working king. It is quoted in ''Louis XIV: A Royal Life'' by Olivier Bernier (Doubleday).

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: EVE: Her Story. By Penelope Farmer. (Mercury House, $15.95.) Precisely as warned by the title, readers of Penelope Farmer's eighth novel are invited to an introspective, carefully examined and sociologically loaded return to Eden. Here we are privy to the thoughts of the Mother of Us All as she dazedly observes the wound closing on Adam's breast, as she learns to make love and marital adjustments, as she forms a bond with the rebellious Lilith (Adam's ex) and experiences jealousy for the first time.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: BRIDGEPORT;
City's Latest Black Eye: Fiscal Calamity
description: LEAD: BRIDGEPORT is growing accustomed to crises.

title: Alliance Fights For Better Housing
description: LEAD: ''There isn't much fanciness,'' Helen Brame said of her home, ''but the necessities are in very good condition.''

title: John Savage Uses Film To Help His Neighbors
description: THE theater was a dimly lighted room in the basement of a church in Manhasset, L.I. The star - John Savage, best known for his roles in films like ''The Deer Hunter'' and ''Salvador'' - arrived two hours late. And the audience and critics - a group of teen-agers, parents and youth workers - sat on legless couches and discarded pews.

title: Year-Round on the Ocean: Condos for Long Branch
description: Every apartment of the High Horizon condominium in Long Branch, N.J., will face the ocean, but its developer expects few to be used as summer homes. Jeffrey Aidekman, vice president of Mountain Development Corporation, said a survey indicated 70 percent of potential buyers for the 58 two- and three-bedroom units, priced from $195,000 to $400,000, would live in the beachfront community year round. ''I think you're going to see that shift all throughout Monmouth County,'' he said, due to nearby office construction and improved rail service to New York City.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Travel Advisory column on Jan. 31 about air fares to Australia misstated terms of Air New Zealand's lowest fare. No stops en route are permitted.

title:
DINING OUT;
In Yonkers, a New Chinese Spot
description: LEAD: LAM's, an offshoot of the Manhattan establishment Foo Chow, arrived with the new year, settling into the lofty greenhouse storefront last occupied by Central Hunan Garden. There is no doubt that the Westchester affiliate has much to commend it. The kitchen allows fragrant black mushrooms to turn otherwise plain dishes into extravagant affairs; makes masterful use of browned bean curd, lovely, thick, chewy slabs of it; holds the monosodium glutamate and is normally miserly with salt.

title: Outrageous Remark on TV
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Rivalry at Airports: Skycaps vs. Baggage Carts
description: Kenute Robinson, a baggage porter at Kennedy International Airport, approached Mary Bradner's car as it pulled up to the British Airways terminal and repeated the question he has asked for eight years: ''You need some help?''

title: Hearings on Hazing Planned
description: LEAD: ASSEMBLYMAN Anthony M. Villane Jr., the Long Branch Republican who sponsored the state's 1980 anti-hazing law, said last week that he planned to summon college administrators to hearings within ''two or three weeks'' to find out ''exactly what they're going to do to stop'' hazing rituals.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WEST CHESTER, PA.;
Building Boom In Penn's Land
description: LEAD: CORPORATE growth in Chester County over the last 10 years has brought a spurt in the development of expensive housing. The 800-square-mile county in southeastern Pennsylvania is about 30 miles west of Philadelphia. West Chester is the county seat.

title: Abduction Renews Hostage Policy Debate in U.S.
description: The abduction of yet another American in Lebanon has renewed debate in foreign policy circles about President Reagan's handling of hostage situations and the effectiveness of his ''no deals'' approach.

title: FAR AWAY FROM THE LONG LIFT LINE
description: BEFORE they invented triple chairlifts and 45-minute lift lines, rear-entry plastic boots and step-in bindings, before ticky-tacky condos, discotheques and hot tubs displaced the forests, before snow reports on the radio, artificial powder on the slopes and pilferage in the parking lot, there existed a sport called skiing. The idea apparently was conceived a few thousand years ago in what is now Norway. It consisted of strapping wood slabs on your feet, pointing them the direction you wanted to go, and sliding there across snow too deep to walk in. The pioneers propelled themselves with a long stick, though by the time I was introduced to the sport, someone had proved it was more efficient to push with a pole in each hand.

title: John Guinness, 52, Irish Banker, Dies in Fall
description: John Guinness, an Irish banker and a cousin of the Guinness brewing family, was fatally injured today in a 500-foot fall on Snowdon Mountain in northern Wales, the police reported. He was 52 years old.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption accompanying an article on the USA/Mobil indoor track and field championships in some copies of yesterday's Sports Pages misidentified the runners who finished in a dead heat in the women's 55-meter dash final. Evelyn Ashford was in lane six and Gwen Torrence was in lane four.

title: Alzheimer's Care Facility Opens in Maine Town
description: Sally Fitzgerald's life had settled into a grueling routine: leave work, fix supper for her ailing father; wake early on weekends, fix breakfast for her father.

title: Virus Discoveries Help an African Outpost of AIDS Research Gain Notice
description: Scientists here have helped to discover two viruses similar to the main AIDS virus -one in humans, the other in monkeys -and in doing so have focused attention on a rare outpost of AIDS research in Central Africa.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Colonial Cookery Courses Offered
description: LEAD: A FIRST-TIME collaboration between the Museum of American Folk Art in New York City and the Montclair Historical Society will enable those involved in an open-hearth-cooking course to take advantage of facilities in both places, combining seminar instruction with hands-on participation.

title: CHILD STYLE
description: MANY DESIGNERS include children's versions of adult fashions in the presentation of their major collections. In this season of whimsy and fantasy, however, children's clothes often seem to be the inspiration for a designer's entire line. Among the Europeans, Sonia Rykiel, Kenzo and Elisabeth de Senneville created a striking variety of Lilliputian looks. And in New York City, Betsey Johnson and Joan Vass often gave the idea a new twist by offering women's and children's designs in the same fabric, but different styles. Although the children's outfits were not always for sale (the ones here are), they were a welcome pause in the serious, multibillion-dollar world of fashion.

title: Cable TV
description: Alfred Hitchcock fans - and who isn't? -can sample a revealing batch of the director's early thrillers this Wednesday on Bravo. And there's a bonus on Friday.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $158,000 443 Renee Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; den with fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 0.25 acre; taxes $3,500. Lawrence $625,000 10 Wedgewood Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; maid's room, fireplace, den, breakfast room; taxes $8,500. Levittown $185,000 10 Loring Road 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 44-year-old colonial; Florida room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Nesconset $207,000 17 Standish Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, circular drive; taxes $4,407. Rocky Point $242,500 361 Sound View Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old waterfront ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 0.25 acre; taxes $3,330. Woodmere $280,000 541 Redwood Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; den, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $4,300. OTHER AREAS White Plains, N.Y. $265,000 147 Davis Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 60-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, tennis court, den; taxes $1,900. Branford, Conn. $525,000 5 Tyler Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 80-year-old former waterfront summer cottage; views, patio, 0.2 acre; taxes $2,748. Piscataway, N.J. $162,000 36 Deborah Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old contemporary; fireplace, patio, deck; taxes $2,011.

title: Capitals Shut Out Islanders and Close In
description: For the Islanders, the zero on the scoreboard, technically an accounting of goals scored, could have applied to a host of other things a team measures itself by.

title: Vineyarders Call For Ban on Growth
description: Residents of Martha's Vineyard, faced with a report that their county has the highest growth rate of any county in New England, are calling for a one-year halt on most development and sweeping changes in government.

title: Question of the Week; How Long Will Billy Martin Last?
description: Until three things are exhausted: Tommy John's arm, Ron Guidry's shoulder, and last, but never least, George Steinbrenner's patience. BILL WADE East Hartford, Conn.

title: Angry Crowd Disrupts Rally By Ku Klux Klan in Dallas
description: A Ku Klux Klan protest against the Dallas Police Department's new affirmative action hiring plan turned into a melee today when a crowd of about 200 people charged the hooded Klansmen and other white supremacists.

title: Miss Bentsen Has Wedding
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Houston, Elizabeth Jean Bentsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Bentsen of Houston, and Stephen David Newton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philippe W. Newton of Bethesda, Md., were married yesterday by the Rev. John W. Lancaster. Molly Bates Bentsen was her sister's maid of honor, and Richard Philippe Newton was the best man for his brother.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: DINNER was held up by some glitch in the kitchen. Conversation that had begun as a spirited crossfire tapered off to alternating volleys and, finally, to short bursts interspaced by periods of silence.

title: Terri Ann Bantle Engaged To E. Christopher Walker
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Bantle of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Terri Ann Bantle, to E. Christopher Walker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Walker, also of Darien. The couple plan to marry June 25.

title: For Vietnamese, Realism Is in Short Supply
description: VIETNAMESE officials ask American visitors, over and over: Why does Washington put such effort into improving relations with Moscow and Beijing, but not with us?

title: A Talk With Aharon Appelfeld
description: Aharon Appelfeld lives a few miles west of Jerusalem in a mazelike conglomeration of attractive stone dwellings directly next to an ''absorption center,'' where immigrants are temporarily housed, schooled and prepared for life in their new society. The arduous journey that landed Appelfeld on the beaches of Tel Aviv in 1946, at the age of 14, seems to have fostered an unappeasable fascination with all uprooted souls, and at the local grocery where he and the absorption center residents do their shopping, he will often initiate an impromptu conversation with an Ethiopian, or a Russian, or a Rumanian Jew still dressed for the climate of a country to which he or she will never return.

title: Laurie E. Strauch And Wayne Dix Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Berish Strauch of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Ellen Strauch, to Wayne Gardner Dix, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Dix of Manchester, Mass. The couple plan to marry in September.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Ancient Coins To Be Sold
description: LEAD: A major public auction of ancient Greek and Roman coins will take place March 9 and 10 in West Hollywood, Calif. It will feature an exceptional group of Roman silver portrait coins. Steve Rubinger, president of the auction company, Numismatic Fine Arts International Inc. of Los Angeles, estimated that the 829 lots will realize well over $2 million.

title: PLOT AGAINST U.S. DESCRIBED IN COURT
description: Two former leaders of a racist religious sect and paramilitary training camp have told a jury here of a 1983 plan to set in motion murders and robberies intended to bring down the Federal Government and replace it with an ''Aryan nation.''

title: Crack Houses Searched By Police In Effort to Find Officer's Killers
description: Teams of police officers swept through suspected crack houses and other drug-trafficking areas in southeastern Queens yesterday, searching for information in the slaying of a rookie police officer as he protected a man who had complained to the police about drug dealing.

title: Tomba Captures 2d Gold
description: It has been said that the Olympics lacked a compelling figure, someone whose signature of success could be stamped on the Winter Games. The search could have very well ended on the slopes of Mount Allan today, where Alberto Tomba of Italy won his second gold medal, prompting a wild celebration that turned the base of a ski trail into a street festival.

title: Coghlan, at 35, Looks to Olympic Gold
description: LEAD: EAMONN COGHLAN of Rye has been a star runner in the international track circuit for more than a decade. He has won the world championships and set three world records, including his indoor mile time of 3 minutes 49.78 seconds - making him the only man in history to finish under the mythical barrier of 3 minutes 50 seconds in the indoor event.

title: Builders Battle 'Takings' of Property
description: Last February, G. K. Hunnewell, president of Kendall Homes Inc., gave the Independence, N.J., Township Committee preliminary notice that he planned to build 59 houses costing about $400,000 on 100 acres that he had bought a month earlier.

title: NAVY AND MAINERS CLASH ON MISSILES
description: Stephen Bean likes to think he's a patriotic fellow. He served in the Air Force doing maintenance on B-52's and he believes people sometimes have to put up with some inconveniences for national defense. But cruise missiles over Maine? He's not too sure about that.

title: Hemlocks Threatened By Aphids
description: OVER the years, Gun Sharp has had to contend with swarms of gypsy moths, spiders and fungi that have attacked the trees and shrubbery around her Stamford home. This year, she said, she is fighting her worst insect battle yet: a white, dot-size aphid called adelgid that kills hemlock trees.

title: Two Concerts for Four Hands
description: UNUSUAL keyboard duos frame the week in the county. David Friddle and Gregg Redner divide their musical ministrations among harpsichord, organ and virginal today at 4 P.M., while Gary Steigerwalt and Dana Muller apply their four hands to one piano next Sunday, also at 4 P.M.

title: THE WORLD: Arab and Israeli - The Roots of the Conflict; The Battleground from the Jordan to the Sea
description: IN the West Bank, Gaza and Jerusalem, the conflict between Israeli and Palestinian is being shaped by a fratricidal agony: competing, centuries-old claims to the same precious strip of land between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, and the right to exist there as a nation.

title: Lilco's G.E. Suit: Who Pays For Mistakes?
description: LEAD: A FEDERAL suit the Long Island Lighting Company filed this month has served notice that, long after the fate of the Shoreham nuclear plant is decided, questions of who pays what share of the $5 billion project will remain before the courts.

title: Trooping the Color
description: To the Editor: In the Jan. 31 Travel Advisory was an article on how to order tickets in the lottery for Trooping the Color in June.

title: For Communism
description: As Andrei A. Gromyko tells it, Mao Zedong believed the Chinese could win a nuclear war even before China became a nuclear power. Mr. Gromyko, who became President of the Soviet Union 1985 after nearly 30 years in the more important position of Foreign Minister, includes his surprising report about Mao in a forthcoming political memoir. In an advance copy released last week, Mr. Gromyko said that in 1958, Mao proposed to lure American troops into Chinese territory and then attack them with Soviet nuclear weapons. Mao apparently felt that China could survive a nuclear war, even if it lost 300 million people, and then be in a position to win a conventionally fought war against the capitalists. Mr. Gromyko said he responded to Mao that the proposal would not be greeted by ''a positive response'' from the Kremlin.

title: THE NICE OLYMPICS
description: Jim McKay, who's been around, says he always assumed Canadians and Americans were pretty much the same people - until he came to Calgary to work the Winter Games for ABC.

title:
ART;
Images That Reflect the Psyche
description: LEAD: IN the deep recesses of the human psyche, complex and sometimes turbulent emotions are formless yet undeniably real. Artists have long endeavored to find visual equivalents for these fundamental feelings. Those who have pursued such a quest are often labeled visionaries or expressionists, for their imagery springs from interior sources and must be viewed in turn with the inner eye.

title: Thankless Task
description: Don't blame the arbitrator for the arbitration award, and don't blame the arbitration award for a rise in the price of beer. That, essentially, is the plea from Thomas Roberts, a Los Angeles lawyer who has served as one of baseball's most visible arbitrators.

title: Early Music Finale
description: An all-Beethoven program is to be presented on March 7 at 8 P.M. as the last of the ''On Original Instruments'' series at the Merkin Concert Hall, Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. The performers are to be Malcolm Bilson, fortepiano; Daniel Pincus, tenor; Stephen Hammer, oboe; Lawrence McDonald, clarinet; William Purvis, horn and Dennis Godburn, bassoon. On the program are Quintet for Fortepiano and Winds in E flat (Op. 16); ''An Die Ferne Geliebte'' (Op. 98) and Sonata in E flat (Op. 81a). Admission is $10. Information: 362-8719.

title: Concert: The Takacs
description: SHORT, precisely imaged pieces by two 20th-century masters brought the best playing from the Takacs String Quartet Friday evening in Weill Recital Hall. Webern's Six Bagatelles (Op. 9) and Stravinsky's Three Pieces for String Quartet were composed at nearly the same time, at and just before the beginning of World War I. They come from different worlds - beside Webern's meticulousness and restrained intensity, Stravinsky sounds almost a cartoonist in his bizarre shapes and highlighted eccentricities. But the cartoons are drawn with the finest, most economical and telling lines, and both sets of pieces demand the utmost concentration and refinement of execution.

title: The 15-Second Career
description: IT took Debi Thomas 15 years to get there and 15 seconds to lose it. The moment she felt her body and her skates slip out of synchronization her active mind went a third direction - south.

title: French Trial Hears Report of Experiment on Patient
description: France's medical world is an uproar over an accusation that a comatose patient was made the object of an experiment to shed light on the trial of two doctors charged with killing another patient.

title: Britain Names New Regulator
description: Britain has replaced the chairman of its financial regulatory agency, the Securities and Investment Board.

title: Tottenville, Clinton Win
description: Nnennah Lynch and Ramon Espinosa turned in outstanding performances yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championships at Manhattan College in the Bronx.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a major leaguer ever failed to bat at least .300 in a season in which he had 200 or more hits?

title: U.S. Plans No Stiff Sanctions on Panama
description: President Reagan will not impose the maximum economic sanctions against Panama when he declares Tuesday that it and several other countries have failed to take adequate steps to control drug trafficking, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Curtain Falls on a Hit Show in Calgary
description: The flame lighted 15 days ago by a 12-year-old Calgary girl was to be extinguished tonight by a 32-year-old city engineer who wasato ournro f the gas and thus end the longest Olympic Winter Games ever staged.

title: Opera: Cimarosa's 'Matrimonio Segreto,' Set in 1936
description: WITH the wisdom of hindsight, we now regard Domenico Cimarosa as a footnote among 18th-century composers, scarcely to be mentioned in the same breath as his contemporary, Mozart. Yet, in their day, Cimarosa's operas found greater favor with the Viennese public, and while they lack the consistent depth and ingenuity of Mozart's scores, the most durable of Cimarosa's works, ''Il Matrimonio Segreto,'' proves to be not only a charming example of the period's style, but also a precursor of Rossini's later innovations.

title: DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements in the year-ago first quarter exceeded net income.

title: 5 Years Changes Much In Child-Molesting Case
description: It has been 10 months since the trial began, seven months since the first witness appeared and five years since the child-molesting charges against the McMartin Pre-School hit the courts. And there is no end in sight. Prosecutors say they will conclude their presentation by July. The defense is not saying how long it may take.

title: Final Chapter in Chemical Scare Story Is Starting
description: Do you remember EDB? Four years after the grain fumigant was banned as a possible cancer risk after widespread concern over its discovery in popcorn, breakfast cereal and muffin mixes, most of the the public seems to have forgotten it.

title: Federated-Campeau Terms Shaped
description: Negotiators for Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Campeau Corporation mainly discussed contract terms, including financing, as they worked through the weekend on proposals for a $6.3 billion merger of the two companies, according to people close to the talks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we can say we both feel we have a package that is promising - at least that we think is promising. Whether anybody else thinks it's promising is a question. But we will be working together to make that so.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz after seeing President Hosni Mubarak. [ A1:6. ]

title: Smoke in Cockpit Prompts Unscheduled Landing by Jet
description: A Midway Airlines 737 flying from Tampa to Chicago made an unscheduled landing here today after its pilot reported an electrical problem that produced smoke in the cockpit, the authorities said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova Defeats Shriver: Martina Navratilova defeated Pam Shriver for the 23d straight time yesterday, 6-0, 6-2, to win the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Washington. It was her third tournament championship in three weeks. She won the first six games and the final six games. Navratilova, the world's No. 2-ranked player, earned $60,000. (AP) Mayotte Wins 2d Straight: Tim Mayotte won his second straight United States Pro Indoor tournament in Philadelphia yesterday with a 4-6, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3 victory over 16th-seeded John Fitzgerald. (AP) GOLF Beck Gets His First Victory: Chip Beck shot a three-under-par 68 yesterday to win the $750,000 Los Angeles Open at the Riviera Country Club. He finished at 17-under-par 267, four shots in front of Bill Sander and Mac O'Grady. It was his first victory in 10 years on the tour. (AP) Player Takes Aetna Challenge: Gary Player shot a final-round 67 and held off Dave Hill yesterday to win the $300,000 Aetna Challenge for Seniors at Naples, Fla. Hill made a hole-in-one on the 16th hole, but Player replied with a tee shot that landed six inches from the cup on the par-3, 157-yard hole. Player won $45,000 with his 207 total.(AP) HORSE RACING Sweep for Lukas and Santos: Fulbright Scholar completed a sweep of Aqueduct's weekend stakes for D. Wayne Lukas, her trainer, and Jose Santos, her jockey, when she raced to a two-length vitory in the $66,700 Busher Handicap for 3-year-old fillies. On Saturday, the Lukas-Santos combination took the Cicada Stakes with Feel the Beat. Fulbright Scholar, who raced coupled in the wagering with Shuffle Up, led throughout. She covered a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:53 2/5 and remains undefeated in three career starts. Joe's Tammie was runner-up in the field of four. Fulbright Scholar earned $40,020 and paid $2.60 for $2 to win. AUTO RACING Neil Bonnett First in Australia: Neil Bonnett scored his second straight Nascar victory yesterday, outdueling Bobby Allison, in capturing a $250,000 500-mile race before 46,000 fans at Calder Park Raceway in Melbourne, Australia. Bonnett held off Allison by 86-hundredths of a second in a thrilling finish to the first Nascar event held outside the United States. Dave Marcis of Wausau, Wis., finished third. (AP) INDOOR LACROSSE Gold Brothers Help Defeat Saints: The Gold brothers were too much for the New Jersey Saints last night. In a key game of the Major Indoor Lacrosse League, the Washington Wave beat the Saints, 21-14, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena as Mark Gold scored seven goals and Joe got three. The result set up next month's playoffs. Washington gained a bye in the first round of the playoffs. The Saints will meet the Philadelphia Wings at East Rutherford, N.J., next Sunday, and the winner will then play the Wave for the league championship in Landover, Md., on March 19. CYCLING U.S. Cyclist Wins Tour: Davis Phinney of Boulder, Colo., burst from a close pack of 80 racers today to win the 82-mile final stage of the Tour of the Americas and gain the overall victory for six days of competition in Florida. Phinney finished in 3 hours 11 seconds. Stefano Allocchio of Italy was less than a bike length behind. Phinney's total elapsed time for the 580-mile race that started Tuesday was 21:42:08.(AP) N.H.L. Flames 3, Oilers 2: Jim Peplinski, returning after playing for Canada at the Olympics, scored the winning goal at 9:15 of the third period to give Calgary the victory in Edmonton. Peplinski took a pass from Brad McCrimmon, gave the puck to John Tonelli at the left faceoff circle and rammed Tonelli's return feed for the goal. Wayne Gretzky returned to the lineup after missing three games with an eye injury and gave the Oilers a 2-1 lead at 10:14 of the second period.(AP) Sabres 5, Jets 3: Benoit Hogue, a rookie, snapped a 3-3 tie with his first N.H.L. goal midway through the third period to lead Buffalo to victory. Hogue converted feeds from Mike Ransey and Dave Andreychuk at 10:46, beating the goaltender Steve Penney from in front of the net. (AP)

title: Dignity Sues St. Patrick's Over Taping
description: A group of Roman Catholic homosexuals has asserted that on at least four occasions since October, officials of St. Patrick's Cathedral and the New York City Police Department ''conspired'' to conduct illegal surveillances of the group's protests inside the church.

title: SPENDTHRIFT FARM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Los Angeles Journal; Traffic Guru Gives Rush-Hour Relief
description: Through the morning fog, smog and freeway jams comes the blast of Bill Keene over the radio:

title: Land Rover Pay Pact
description: About 2,000 white-collar workers at Land Rover U.K. Ltd. have accepted a two-year pay increase that was previously rejected by 6,000 striking production workers, the vehicle company said on Friday. The state-owned company said the pay package represented a 14 percent raise, but the strikers contend that it amounts to 8 percent. The strike has been costing Land Rover $:3 million, or about $5.3 million, a day in lost production.

title: Champion Sets Layoffs
description: The Champion Spark Plug Company announced that it would lay off more than a quarter of its work force here. The layoffs, which will begin March 22, will be phased in over four months, said William Walker, Champion's director of industrial relations. A total of 243 workers - 119 people from the aviation products group and 124 from automotive operations -will lose their jobs in Toledo, where Champion employs 834 production workers. Another 62 people will be laid off at the company's other three plants in the United States, he said.

title: RESIDENTIAL MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Several Large Accounts Move to New Agencies
description: A good number of agencies ended last week with new business assignments.

title: Panamanian's Wife Recounts Crisis
