description: With the deposed President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, still in hiding today, his wife has said he intends to remain in Panama as long as possible to assert that he is still the constitutional President.

title: China Hasn't Done Much for Ordinary Tibetans; A Submerged Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: ADELPHIA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: The Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Friday misstated the number of rapes that occurred in buildings operated by the General Services Administration in the fiscal year ending last October. Two rapes took place in the 7,000 buildings for which the Federal agency is responsible.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; An 18-Year Court Fight Still Awaiting an Ending
description: Gather round and listen to the tale of Saul S. Weitzman. It is the oldest one in the book - the docket book, that is, of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. For that matter, it ranks among the 100 oldest civil cases still active in the Federal judicial system.

title: Hyundai's Success Is Challenged in Canada
description: When the Hyundai Motor Corporation began exporting cars to Canada in 1984, there were few signs that its competitors were concerned. The Canadian industry was recovering from its worst recession since the 1930's and its executives had little time to worry about a South Korean manufacturer with less than 20 years in the business and no experience in selling cars in the competitive North American market.

title: World Trade Increased 4% in 1987
description: International trade, led by a sharp rise in shipments of manufactured goods, grew by 4 percent last year and is likely to match that rate again in 1988, economists of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said in a report scheduled for release Monday.

title: Washington Talk: Intelligence Agencies; Secret Life of a Roosevelt Is Now an Open Book
description: Banker, intelligence officer, amateur scholar, grandson of a President, Archibald B. Roosevelt has long been a low-key presence in Washington. He has been perhaps best known in recent years as the smiling fellow frequently captured by photographers at the side of his wife, Selwa, at the many social occasions she attends as the State Department's Chief of Protocol.

title: MOSCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $899,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: SAGE SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Koch and LeFrak Agree on Plan For 1,200 Middle-Income Units
description: The Koch administration and Samuel J. LeFrak have reached an agreement for the developer to build 1,200 apartments for limited profit on the Lower East Side. The plan would involve a creative financing arrangement and would be among the largest middle-income projects built in New York City in a decade.

title: VW Increases Prices
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said Friday that it would increase the average price of its vehicles by 2.2 percent, or $248, effective Monday. Prices of the least expensive models, the two-door Golf hatchback and the Fox line, are to remain the same.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A FOOL AND HIS MONEY. The Odyssey of an Average Investor. By John Rothchild. 251 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Business and the Law; More Obstacles For the Raiders
description: FOR corporate raiders, these are not happy times. State and Federal regulators have made it harder for hostile bidders to conceal their intentions. They have given the prey of raiders more time to defend themselves. And they have made several forms of takeovers more costly.

title: Tension for Asset Agency's Chief
description: Gerald P. Carmen has never been one to shrink from political heat. As a lobbyist and consultant for conservative causes, he has faced occasional controversy before, but in his new job he seems certain to face plenty of it.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago share earnings restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 15.

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $3,000 and $179,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and $242,261 for the 9 months.

title: HEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,280,000 for the quarter and $751,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $247,000 and $49,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: A Drive for Basketball
description: Wayne and Carol Lis of Killingly, Conn., suspected they had a burgeoning hoop prospect in the family, when their 8-year-old daughter, Tracy, started spending hours shooting baskets in the driveway of their home. She seldom missed.

title: G.M.'s Specialist in Job Shake-Ups
description: When Roy S. Roberts was manager of the General Motors Corporation's aging assembly plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., he was instrumental in forging a coalition of management, labor and government that secured a future for the once-endangered plant and its 4,500 workers.

title: Advocacy Group Seeks Park For Westway's Replacement
description: Saying that government is not paying enough attention to the Hudson River waterfront, the Parks Council yesterday proposed its own accompaniment to the Westway replacement - a 65-acre park along the West Side of Manhattan.

title: SOUTHERN STARR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: As Salvadoran Vote Nears, Political Killings Increase
description: The worst wave of political killings in the last two years has swept El Salvador in recent weeks as campaigning picks up for legislative and municipal elections next month.

title: Censures in Hutton Case Reported
description: George L. Ball, the chairman of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., has agreed to be censured by the New York Stock Exchange for a supervisory failure during an illegal check overdrafting scheme when he was president of E F. Hutton & Company, according to Wall Street professionals with knowledge of the settlement.

title: Continental Grain Getting New Leader After 44 Years
description: In what is the end of a virtual corporate dynasty, Donald L. Staheli, president of the Continental Grain Company since 1984, has been named chief executive, a post held at the international agribusiness company since 1944 by Michel Fribourg.

title: Dutch Skater Wins Third Gold Medal
description: Yvonne van Gennip of the Netherlands won her third speed-skating gold medal of the XV Olympic Winter Games today, cutting more than six seconds off her world record in the women's 5,000-meters.

title: Anne D. Nayer Is Bride of James McMenamin 3d
description: The marriage of Anne Dennison Nayer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herman R. Nayer of Oakland, Calif., to James Leo McMenamin 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McMenamin Jr. of New Hyde Park, L.I., took place yesterday in Charlotte Amalie, V.I. The Rev. Tyrone Woods of the Universalist Church of Christ in Charlotte Amalie performed the ceremony in the chapel at Louisenhoj Castle.

title: Knicks Defeated by Nuggets
description: Michael Adams scored 15 of his 18 points in the first quarter, helping Denver get off to a fast start today as the Nuggets went on to defeat New York by 109-100 and snap the Knicks' three-game winning streak.

title: Brawley Case: Stubborn Puzzle, Silent Victim
description: She vanished on a cold, moonless autumn night in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., from a strip of gas stations and fast-food outlets that stand as a kind of neon-lit mockery of Washington Irving's quaint old haunts up the Hudson.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Esquire magazine to Kirschenbaum & Bond.

title: TV Review; 'Perfect People,' With Perry King
description: KENNETH and Barbara -think of them as Ken and Barbie dolls - are married, middle-aged and morose. Their daughter is heading for college. They have let themselves disintegrate into acute frumpiness. Visiting the local disco on an uncharacteristic lark, they find that they have become invisible while the merry singles and cheerfully divorced seem to be having all the fun. What to do? Thanks to the wonders of modern science and technology, Kenneth and Barbara have an option: Change their looks. Welcome to the world of obsessive exercising, dieting and surgical adjusting. It is explored superficially but amiably in ''Perfect People,'' the television movie on Channel 7 at 9 this evening.

title: For Women in India Prisons, a 'Grim Picture'
description: An official study of women in Indian prisons says many of them are beaten, sexually molested or otherwise harassed in jail.

title: Advertising; People
description: * William R. Kelly and William G. Weigold were named presidents of the BBDO Detroit and Minneapolis offices, respectively, and Bruce A. Macdonald was named executive vice president of BBDO Worldwide.

title: A Giddy Witt Is All Smiles After Figure-Skating Final
description: Long after the strains of ''Carmen'' had ended Saturday night with Katarina Witt's version on ice impressing the judges far more than Debi Thomas's, the would-be Spanish gypsies from East Germany and the United States reflected upon the tragedies of their performances.

title: ATLANTIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $280,000 for the quarter and income of $759,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $420,000 and $1,996,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: IDENTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics of The Times; A Tasteless Meal
description: The Friends of Harvey Mudd College may have already nailed down the prize for unappetizing meal of the year. The Southern California school recently staged a fund-raising dinner featuring Robert Ballard, leader of the expedition that found the remains of the ''unsinkable'' Titanic three years ago. Naturally, he had a few disparaging words to say about plundering of the relics, but apparently he kept a discreet silence about the food.

title: M-I SCHOTTENSTEIN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dance: Tom Evert Company, From Cleveland
description: THE Tom Evert Dance Company made its New York debut Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, and it was no surprise to see members of the Paul Taylor Dance Company in the audience.

title: Liverpool Journal; There's No Preaching, Just the Clean Needles
description: Peter McDermott, a 32-year-old Liverpool drug addict, is a regular at the Hope Street clinic here, Britain's largest program for giving out clean needles to drug addicts in an effort to curb the spread of AIDS.

title: HOME UNITY SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $191,000 for the quarter and net of $994,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $698,000 and $479,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $749,000 for the quarter and $1,629,000 for the year. The company reported no per share earnings in the year-ago periods because it converted to stock ownership in November 1986.

title: IMRE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results for 1987 included payments of $520,000 to settle all litigation pending against the company and $320,000 paid in connection with the termination of a contingent lease. The 1986 loss included a review payment of $1,500,000 received from Takeda Chemical Industries Ltd.

title: Sledders' Medal Slips Away
description: For all the unpleasantness surrounding their Olympic experience, the United States bobsled team probably should have named its sleds Fussing, Fighting and Feuding. Today, however, the Americans were on the verge of making all the controversy of the past three weeks ancient history. Its top four-man sled, driven by Brent Rushlaw, sat in third place after its fourth and final run, a bronze medal unexpectedly within reach.

title: AMERIBANC INVESTORS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net income in the latest year was adversely affected by an increase in the effective tax rate to 43 percent.

title: Stage: 'A Walk in the Woods'
description: IN one of several funny passages that threaten to quicken ''A Walk in the Woods'' into nearly a trot, a Soviet disarmament negotiator tells his American counterpart that the real blame for their nations' nuclear deadlock belongs to Switzerland. With its bucolic mountains and centuries of peace, Switzerland is so soothing that it drains the urgency from diplomatic talks about Armageddon. ''We should put the table at the bottom of a missile silo,'' argues the Russian, Andrei Botvinnik (Robert Prosky), to the American, John Honeyman (Sam Waterston). ''Then we would negotiate.'' It's a smart point, and one only wished the evening's playwright, Lee Blessing, had taken it fully to heart. Like his two characters, Mr. Blessing is an earnest foe of the arms race, frustrated by the intractable political games superpowers play with the destiny of mankind. But as a piece of theater, ''A Walk in the Woods'' is the esthetic equivalent of Switzerland, and not only because its setting is ''a pleasant woods on the outskirts of Geneva.'' The play at the Booth fudges the distinctions of actual international politics and arms negotiations, choosing instead to telescope the messy, life-or-death conflict into a sentimental relationship between two likable envoys. Because the candied antagonisms of that relationship are more reminiscent of ''The Odd Couple'' or ''I'm Not Rappaport'' than harsh reality, Mr. Blessing has made a subject as volatile as the bomb seem as pleasantly cool - and as safely remote - as his neutral forest setting.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Closing Up Shop
description: The Congressional Iran-contra commmitees are scheduled to go out of business Tuesday. But they will be leaving behind something for journalists and aficionados of the affair to chew on. The committees are scheduled to make public upward of 40,000 pages of deposition testimony and documents that will be published by the Government Printing Office.

title: Payout Delay At Santa Fe
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said Friday that it would suspend for 10 days the payment of a special $5 dividend to be paid in debentures, to allow a Delaware Chancery Court judge time to study the legality of the payment.

title: Carbon Monoxide Kills Five
description: Four children and their baby sitter were killed by carbon monoxide fumes from a gas heater, officials in this northern Florida community said. Pronounced dead Saturday at the home of Ola Weerts were two of her three children, 10-year-old James and 6-year-old Sherri. Julie Meador, 10, granddaughter of a friend of Mrs. Weerts, and the baby sitter, Jennifer Bias, 17, were also dead. A third Weerts child, 12-year-old Tanya, died later in a hospital.

title: GOULD INVESTORS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a gain on properties, mortgages and invetments of $1,094,000, or 88 cents a share, compared to $106,000, or 8 cents a share, a year ago. Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Swaggart, After 'Darkest Week,' Thanks Faithful of All Religions
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, who stepped down from his electronic pulpit after confessing to moral lapses, thanked members of all religions today for their support during ''the darkest week'' he has experienced.

title: Topics of The Times; No-Fault Fat
description: Two studies published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week won't help the obese drop any pounds but the research should lift another enormous weight: guilt.

title: Yankees Are Nurturing Leiter With Confidence, but Quietly
description: The arm is discussed in reverential tones around the Yankee camp, where such notable former pitchers as Whitey Ford and Eddie Lopat have cautiously nurtured it over the last two springs. They speak glowingly about the young pitcher attached to the arm, and they say without hesitation that it could happen this year. Al Leiter could make it.

title: Showdown on Selling Newspaper in France
description: France's Finance Minister, Edouard Balladur, may not have realized what a spat he was creating when he provisionally blocked the sale of Les Echos, France's largest financial daily, to Pearson P.L.C. Last week the publisher of Les Echos turned up the heat even more.

China Hasn't Done Much for Ordinary Tibetans
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Includes a one-time restructuring charge of $6,659,000. c-Net income

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Departure Pays Off
description: Anthony Mason remembers playing at Brandeis High School on the Upper West Side with Mark Jackson, Walter Berry and Eddie Pinckney in pick-up games made for new dribbles, new dunks, and razzle-dazzle basketball moves that coaches detest. Even though Mason was a senior in high school in 1984, and they were in college, he was on their level.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Recital: Ax and Ma Perform
description: A DECADE ago, at the height of the vaunted chamber-music boom, much was made of soloists banding together for recitals. Since then, comparatively few teams of stellar soloists have decided to cultivate chamber playing as an art, and to make it part of their artistic agendas. The cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the pianist Emanuel Ax are among this minority, and in recent years, their collaboration has yielded several magnificent recordings.

title: TV Review; Superman At 50, A Special
description: BETWEEN 8 and 9 this evening, you can choose between two specials. At 8, CBS is mounting a pop-culture party in ''Superman's 50th Anniversary: A Celebration of the Man of Steel.'' At 8:30, NBC has a preview (another is scheduled Thursday), of a new sitcom called ''Day by Day,'' which will have an official premiere in its regular time period next Sunday night at 8:30. Supposedly there is method behind these scheduling intricacies.

title: Kentucky Outlasts Syracuse
description: To mark a rare game against Kentucky and a trip to the Adolph Rupp Arena, the Syracuse Orangemen traded in the orange uniforms they have worn on the road for the last 13 seasons for sharp new blue ones.

title: Advertising; Faberge Builds Up McGregor
description: WHEN Mark R. Goldston, the president of Faberge USA, asked the Smith/Greenland agency to create something new to introduce the McGregor line of men's cologne and after shave, he certainly could not have expected an ad with the headline: ''Introducing Scotch before breakfast.''

title: Iran Hangs 2 for Bombing
description: Two Iranian men were hanged today in a Teheran square where they had planted a bomb on orders from Iraq, Iran's national news agency reported. The agency, monitored here, gave few details, but several people were killed and dozens wounded when a car bomb exploded in Tajrish Square in December 1985. The hangings brought to 14 the number of Iranians executed since December on similar charges, including five hanged in another Teheran square on Saturday.

title: Carter Hopes New Strength Can Restore the Kid in Him
description: Gary Carter knows what people were thinking. He remembers the headline last season that said: ''Kid on Skids.''

title: Republicans Focus on Regional Issue
description: The Republican Presidential candidates disagreed today on trade and budget policy but broke little new ground in their last debate before the Southern primaries and caucuses begin next weekend.

title: Developer Sues To Force Couple To Alter House
description: If imitation is the most sincere form of flattery, Chris Demetriades, a builder known for his stately $2 million-plus homes, should be glowing.

title: Cameras' Scrutiny May Add to Stress
description: DID Peggy Fleming and ABC's coverage unwittingly contribute to Debi Thomas's failure to land the gold medal on Saturday night?

title: Weight Lifting A Complement To Aerobics
description: THE advertisements buried in comic books have always promised that in just a few weeks we could be transformed from 90-pound weaklings, scorned by all, into muscular specimens so imposing that no one would dare kick sand in our faces at the beach. All we had to do was lift weights.

title: For Refugees: Open Arms, or Stiff-Arm?
description: In Moscow, the Secretary of State won a Soviet promise to let more emigres out. In Washington meanwhile, the Reagan Administration proposed a budget that would cut by a quarter the funds for resettling refugees in the United States. This beckoning with one hand and shooing with the other constitutes a two-faced policy, unacceptable even given dire budget difficulties.

title: The Hostage Scourge: How Europe Is Faring
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl recently referred to hostage-taking as ''the pest of modern times,'' and it is one few West European countries have escaped.

title: E.P.A. Proposes Giving States Say on Pesticides
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has issued the draft of a policy that would let states decide when, where and how to use pesticides that could contaminate underground water.

title: School Board Is Ready For a Custodian Strike
description: The New York City Board of Education is prepared ''to take a strike if necessary'' by school custodians to win contract concessions from their union, the board's president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said in a television interview broadcast yesterday.

title: NATO Summit Meeting: Emphasis On a Show of Solidarity, Not Results
description: President Reagan and the other NATO leaders gather in Brussels on Wednesday, determined to demonstrate solidarity in the face of differences and disputes that have afflicted the alliance.

title: 10 or More Groups Vie For Queens Drug Trade
description: The violence-ridden drug trade that is said to be the backdrop for the execution-style killing of a rookie police officer in Queens on Friday includes 10 or more groups plying their drugs and vying for turf in southeast Queens, law-enforcement authorities say.

title: Irving Foresees Bitter Fight
description: Last week's decision by the Federal Reserve Board to allow the Bank of New York Company to proceed with its hostile takeover bid for the Irving Bank Corporation has set the stage for a bitter April 21 proxy fight, Irving said yesterday.

title: Older Than The Post
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Jew Lands in Tel Aviv And Ends a 13-Year Struggle
description: A 77-year-old Soviet Jew who battled for 13 years to leave the Soviet Union embraced his daughter when he arrived today in Israel.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; That Political Game
description: ''We're not very big, but we're slow,'' said Representative Michael G. Oxley of Ohio, the captain of the Republican basketball team in the House.

title: Market Place; Interpreting Standard's Plan
description: WHAT'S a shareholder to do when assessing the rival offers for American Standard Inc., the big producer of plumbing fixtures and air-conditioning units. The Black & Decker Corporation has offered $68 in cash, while American Standard is proposing a recapitalization plan whose value is less certain but has been estimated by some analysts to be worth as much as $71 a share. On Friday, the shares closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $68.75, up 12 1/2 cents.

title: Cyprus Leader Pledges Talks in Taking Office
description: President George Vassiliou ushered in his administration today by promising to seek direct talks with Turkey to unify this island, divided between Greek and Turkish Cypriots for 14 years.

title: L.I. Group Presses Fight Over Shoreham
description: Citizens to Replace Lilco, a powerful organization credited with starting the public power movement on Long Island, is opening an advertising and letter-writing campaign this week against a negotiated settlement to end the long stalemate over the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Metro Matters; Residency Laws: Costly Realities Complicate Issue
description: More New York City police officers commute from Suffolk County than come from Staten Island. As many live in Nassau as in Brooklyn. Almost as many come from Rockland as from Manhattan.

title: Israelis Sink a Dinghy, Thwarting P.L.O. Raid
description: An attempt by Palestinian guerrillas to infiltrate Israel from Lebanon by sea was foiled today when an Israeli naval vessel intercepted their rubber dinghy and sank it.

title: Iranian Missiles Hit Iraqi Capital; Renewal of 'War of Cities' Feared
description: Iran fired three surface-to-surface missiles at the Iraqi capital early today, the Iranian press agency said. [ Reports from Baghdad said that two Iranian missiles slammed into the Iraqi capital, killing or wounding a large number of residents and destroying houses, shops and cars in two residential areas. No casualty toll was given. An Iraqi military spokesman was reported as saying Iraq would strike back. ] The official Iranian press agency, monitored in Cyprus, said that the missiles were aimed at a radio and television building and two military centers and that the attack was in retaliation for what it described as Iraqi attacks on nonmilitary areas of Teheran last week. At least 28 Iranian civilians were killed in those attacks, Iran said.

title: Faster Drop in Interest Rates Seen
description: Further large declines in interest rates, until recently considered possible only in a medium-term context, may in fact be on the verge of occurring, according to credit market analysts.

description: Net income represents net investment income.

title: Singapore's Economy Up
description: Singapore, one of Asia's richest nations, made an impressive economic recovery in 1987, but growth will slow this year with consumers having less money to spend, the Government's annual economic survey said.

title: Creating a Bernstein Tribute
description: When Julia Migenes steps onto the stage of Alice Tully Hall this evening to sing Leonard Bernstein's ''I Hate Music,'' the song, which opens an evening celebrating the composer's 70th birthday year, will set the freewheeling musical mood of a concert devoted entirely to Mr. Bernstein's songs.

title: A 27-1 Shot Wins The Pan American
description: Canada finally won a gold medal of sorts today when a 5-year-old Canadian mare named Carotene scored a major upset victory at 27-to-1 odds in the $300,000 Pan American Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

description: Item: With help from Morgan Guaranty, Mexico promotes a plan to exchange some of its foreign bank debt for securities backed by U.S. bonds.

title: The 'Two Societies' Today
description: It has been 20 years since the Kerner commission's report on urban riots predicted that America was heading toward ''two societies, one black, one white - separate but unequal.''

title: Stage: Moliere's 'Miser,' at Yale Rep
description: For a septuagenarian with a cane, Harpagon, the funniest skinflint in literature (''so mean he won't even give you a good day, he'll lend it to you'') is covering a lot of stage in ''The Miser'' at the Yale Repertory Theater. He comes on with a bound and goes off with a dive. In a burst of despair, he jumps and jumps and jumps, higher and higher till he threatens to fly from the premises; in an excess of agitation, he climbs a pole that occupies the center of his living room for no particular purpose other than to provide something for people to climb when emotions require it.

title: PS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $953,000, less an extraordinary charge of $969,000, and $55,962,000, less an extraordinary charge of $4,339,000, for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter net also included a pretax gain of $8.3 million from the sale of the company's interest in a producing oil and gas property. The extraordinary charge of $969,000 in the latest quarter represents the premium paid on purchase and retirement of 14 percent senior notes net of tax credit of $800,000. The 1987 net from discontinued operations of $55,962,000 includes a gain from the sale of Pacific Southwest Airlines; the airline was sold to USAir Group Inc. in the second quarter of 1987. The extraordinary charge of $4,339,000 in 1987 represents the premium paid on purchase and retirement of 14 percent senior notes net of tax credit of $3.6 million. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5,679,000 and $4,181,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect discontinued operations and full consolidation of Statex Petroleum Inc.

description: b-Includes securities gains of $23,000 and $427,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a writeoff of FSLIC secondary reserve, net of tax, of $264,000. c-Includes securities gains of $439,000 for the quarter and $1,342,000 for the year. Per-share results for the year-ago fourth quarter and both full years were not available; the bank converted to stock ownership in June 1987.

title: New Helmets Add Speed
description: Jim Gentes, a bicycle racer and industrial designer from Santa Cruz, Calif., has designed a helmet that he claims will make a cyclist go 20 percent faster than he would without the helmet. Yet speed isn't as big a factor with the new helmet as weight. The Giro Prolight weighs 7 1/2 ounces, 50 percent less than conventional bike helmets.

title: Arts Troupes Caught In East-West Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Instruction Is Essential to Improve in Cross-Country
description: WHEN cross-country skiing was gaining popularity in the 1970's, its advocates often said that anyone who could walk could ski.The ease of learning the sport got a lot of people out on skis. It also caused a lot of people to miss the joy of skiing with expertise.

title: Outdoors: No Medals, but One Rewarding Trout
description: THE quad in the Olympic Village is nestled between the athletes' dorms and the dining area. It is protected from the wind, but at least part of it receives full sunlight all day, and the athletes, like college-age kids everywhere, like to hang out and catch rays during the warm and breezy afternoons that have bedeviled the skiers, sliders, ski jumpers and bobsledders for the last two weeks.

title: Topics of The Times; Injudicious, to a Degree
description: According to The Wall Street Journal, Solomon Casseb Jr., the Texas judge in the Pennzoil-Texaco trial, never graduated from law school. That's no great offense. He apparently did pass the Texas bar exam, and otherwise met the minimum requirements for service in the state's courts. But there is reason to ask why he lists a degree from the University of Texas Law School on state bar association and military service records. Like Judge Casseb's $10 billion award to Pennzoil, his resume inflation is, well, injudicious.

title: Soviet Gains Seen in Air-Launched Cruise Missiles
description: The Soviet Union has rapidly expanded its ability to fire air-launched cruise missiles armed with nuclear warheads at the United States, according to Maj. Gen. Jimmie V. Adams, the Air Force officer responsible for the air defense of the continental United States.

description: Owens-Illinois Inc. has won another victory in its attempt to purchase Brockway Inc., another glass maker. The company said that the Court of Appeals in Washington on Friday unanimously denied the Federal Trade Commission's motion to block the merger.

description: Dan Jansen, the speed skater from West Allis, Wis., was named today as the winner of the Olympic Spirit Award for these Winter Olympics.

title: Trade Move by Rumania
description: Rumania, one of three Communist countries to which the United States has granted favorable tariffs on exports, has said it will not seek renewal of those special trading rights when they expire in July, the State Department said Friday.

title: Stowaways Set Fire in Ship
description: Four Dominican stowaways who were locked in the cargo hold of a container ship set a fire early today to get the crew's attention, but the blaze burned out of control, the Coast Guard said. A spokesman said no one was injured in the fire.

description: It has been compared with the colonies' fight to overthrow King George III, the underdog fighting for a principle.

title: One Barrier to Banks Due to Fall This Week
description: Unless a Federal Appeals Court decides otherwise, subsidiaries of 13 commercial banks will be able tomorrow to enter, once again, the hurly-burly world of investment banking.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $47,000 for the quarter and $296,000 for the 6 months. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest and year-ago second quarters and in the latest 6 months.

title: DRESHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prescribing Methadone
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ SAID TO GET MUBARAK SUPPORT IN TALKS IN CAIRO
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today became the first Middle East leader to support the peace proposals being offered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, American officials said.

title: GRANGES EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Washington Talk: The State Department; Delicate Task Puts Drug Agency in Limelight
description: Each year about this time, a little known agency within the State Department, the Bureau of International Narcotics Matters, emerges from the shadows to issue a report on worldwide drug problems.

title: Baby With Brain Defect Is Taken Off Life Support
description: A Texas infant born with almost no brain was taken off life-support equipment that was intended to help preserve her heart and other organs for transplant, a doctor said Saturday.

title: Jet Sets a Mark Circling Earth
description: A crew of four flew a corporate jet to a new round-the-world speed record on Saturday, breaking a mark set last month.

title: Attention Is Focused on Florida Derby
description: The last two Kentucky Derby winners, Alysheba and Ferdinand, emerged from obscurity and California late in the spring. This year, though, it appears that the East may rise again.

title: FISHER TRANSPORTATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes for the latest year a pretax gain of $15.3 million, including a $9.3 million gain from the sale of marketable securities; the prior year includes a tax credit of $1.3 million. The company said the lower latest fourth quarter earnings were primarily due to the absorption of costs related to the integration of Moxie Industries, and other acquisitions made in 1987.

title: GREENERY REHABILITATION GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago first quarter results are adjusted for a change in tax rates.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $273,000 from prepayment of long- term debt.

title: Louis Zhang Jiashu, Bishop, 96
description: Louis Zhang Jiashu, bishop of Shanghai under China's independent Catholic Church, has died at the age of 96, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Gore Redirects Message at Workers
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., acknowledging that his Presidential campaign has lacked a clear focus, has begun a major effort to redefine his quest for the Presidency as a battle for ''average working men and women.''

title: Privatization Faces Test in Britain
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's plan to end Government ownership of Britain's electrical power system is emerging as a major test of public satisfaction with her policy of privatization.

title: Brazil Debt Agreement Is Reached
description: Brazil and its principal commercial creditors announced tonight that they had reached preliminary agreement on a financial package that should help end this country's yearlong moratorium on its debt payments to foreign banks.

title: The Sweat Merchants
description: Two million times a year, American citizens - people who have done nothing more criminal than to apply for a job - are subjected to the humiliation of being hooked up to a polygraph machine.

title: UNICARE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $60,000 and $733,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $281,000 and $2,091,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Topics of The Times; Toy Gun Terror
description: Brandishing a pistol, a crazed man disrupted a Burbank, Calif., news broadcast last August and demanded that his statement be read by the commentator. The weapon turned out to be a fake. But the real terror it caused underscores the need for Federal legislation barring the manufacture of realistic-looking toy guns.

title: At Leetch's First Workout, Advice for On and Off the Ice
description: Money, the old adage goes, attracts money. It was therefore not all that startling to find Lou Eisenberg and Curtis Sharp, two of New York's more cheerfully ubiquitous millionaires, at today's practice session for the Rangers.

title: Harvey Kuenn, 57, Ex-Manager Of Milwaukee Brewers, Is Dead
description: Harvey Kuenn, a former American League batting champion who managed the Milwaukee Brewers to their only pennant, died today at his home in Peoria, Ariz., the club announced. He was 57 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 29, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT Brazil has reached a preliminary agreement with its commercial creditors on a financial package that should help end its yearlong moratorium on debt payments to foreign banks. [ Page D1. ] The new owner of La Coupole is starting to be called the king of Paris's brasseries. [ D1. ] A Canadian tribunal is hearing a case brought against Hyundai for selling cars at below-market prices. [ D12. ] A considerable spat has arisen in Paris over the blocked sale of Les Echos, France's largest financial daily, to Pearson. [ D12. ] A plan to privatize Britain's electrical industry is emerging as a test of public satisfaction with this policy. [ D13. ] THE ECONOMY Machine tool orders in January rose 23.7 percent from December, the industry's trade association states in its monthly report to be released today. [ D1. ] The new head of FADA is prepared for controversy. [ D4. ] COMPANIES George L. Ball has agreed to be censured by the New York Stock Exchange for a supervisory failure when he was president of E. F. Hutton, according to Wall Street professionals. [ D1. ] A number of factors appear to be helping the airlines. While Americans are taking advantage of lower-priced package tours to Europe, more Europeans are visiting the U.S. [ D1. ] Federated and Campeau negotiated through the weekend, with contract terms being the main matter under discussion, according to people close to the talks. [ D8. ] Commercial banks will again be able to operate investment banking units starting tomorrow, unless a Court of Appeals rules otherwise. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS When Saul Weitzman sued Sidney Stein, he didn't know the case would still be open 18 years later. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Corporate raiders are finding it harder to succeed these days. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] American Standard's proposal to shareholders is complex and subject to differing interpretations. Market Place. [ D8. ] Interest rates may decline further and faster, according to analysts. Credit Markets. [ D9. ]

title: Elephants Kill Kenyan
description: Elephants trampled a 60-year-old Kenyan man to death in southeastern Kenya Friday, and a hippopotamus emerged from a sewage pond and attacked a bicyclist on the outskirts of Nairobi, a newspaper said today. The Daily Nation said the 35-year-old man bitten by the hippopatmus on Thursday was hospitalized in serious condition.

title: House Vote on Contras To Defer Real Decision
description: The vote that House members are scheduled to take Thursday on rival Democratic and Republican plans to aid the contras will once again postpone rather than establish a real decision on United States policy toward Nicaragua, members of Congress said this weekend.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 29, 1988
description: International A2-15

title: CYBEROPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Unexpected Strong Traffic Allows Airlines to Lift Fares
description: Americans are seeking lower-priced package tours to offset the higher prices in Europe. Many travelers have shrugged off the stock market crash and are not crimping on their vacation and business travel. And Europeans by the thousands are flocking to the United States to take advantage of the greater buying power of their currencies.

title: TV on the Open Market: An Industry Convention
description: As the executive in charge of CBS News for five years, Van Gordon Sauter lived in a maelstrom stirred by his determined drive to make news programs more popular.

title: Appeals Court Finds Mother Guilty of Abuse in Son's Death
description: A Manhattan appeals court has overturned a Family Court ruling and found a Bronx mother guilty of abuse in the death of her 19-month-old son, who was found scalded and drowned in a bathtub. The appeals court also ruled that her 5-year-old son should be removed from her custody.

title: RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Will Sell $12.8 Billion of Bills Today
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market. The Government will auction $12.8 billion of three-month and six-month securities today.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jewish Groups Examine Farm Crisis
description: Representatives of Jewish groups from around the country met with state and Federal Government officials and agricultural leaders in New York City yesterday to discuss the farm crisis and formulate a national Jewish response to the plight of small farmers.

title: EMCON ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1986 periods are pro- forma, reflecting reductions in operating expenses and net income from changes in the company's compensation policies.

title: Very High Levels of Alcohol Are Found in Drunken Drivers
description: Half of the jail inmates convicted of drunken driving had consumed the equivalent of at least 12 bottles of beer or eight mixed drinks before their arrest, the Federal Government said today.

title: Getty Petroleum Chief Sees Gains for Texaco
description: Leo Liebowitz has been besieged with questions about his company's moves, announced last week, to purchase a stake of more than $15 million in Texaco Inc. But Mr. Liebowitz, who is president and chief executive officer of the Getty Petroleum Corporation, insists that he is interested is the stock ''for investment purposes only.''

title: Soviet Team Stunned By Finns
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, the captain of the Soviet Union's hockey team, stood atop the victory stand and gazed thoughtfully at his gold medal. The shaggy-haired player who is rumored to be joining the Devils next season studied first one side of his medal, and then the other, as if it were the relic of an achievement he might not experience again. Then he shook off his musings and led his team in a victory lap around the Saddledome.

title: Winners Satisfied With Losing
description: This has been a winning season for basketball at Hunter College, but at first glance it doesn't appear to be for its winning basketball coaches. The women's varsity team and the men's junior varsity won their divisions at the annual City University of New York tournament.

title: Armenian Protests Reportedly Subside
description: The streets of Yerevan were quiet today for the first time in more than a week as organizers of huge nationalist demonstrations that had paralyzed the Armenian capital met to discuss a planned monthlong suspension of the protests, Armenian nationalists said.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Koch Ad Asks Help of Reagan in Drug Battle
description: Once again Mayor Koch is taking on the White House and the hearts and minds of anyone who will listen. This time it is in a full-page ad in The New York Times.

title: 20 Years After the Kerner Report: Three Societies, All Separate
description: Like a line on a graph, Euclid Avenue traces 20 years of race relations in this old industrial town, an east-west passage from American dream to American nightmare.

title: Seoul Opposition Leaders Agree to Merge Parties
description: Hoping to avert another disaster at the polls, South Korea's rival opposition parties are about to merge so that they can present a united front in National Assembly elections this spring.

title: Abortion Group Opposes Cuomo's Medicaid Plan
description: A proposal by Governor Cuomo to expand Medicaid coverage for prenatal care, but not for abortion, has abortion rights groups gearing up for their first major fight in the state in almost a decade.

title: Results and Standings
description: HOCKEY YESTERDAY'S GAMES Finland 2, Soviet Union 1. Sweden 3, West Germany 2. SATURDAY'S GAME Canada 6, Czechoslovakia 3. Medal Round

title: Mismanaging Public Lands
description: LEAD: Long after James Watt was forced to resign as Interior Secretary, largely because of political indiscretions, his most cherished policies continue to be quietly implemented by the Administration. What we now have in Secretary Donald P. Hodel is a James Watt with good public-relations skills. The result is that the long-term economic and environmental costs of gross mismanagement of public lands are escalating.

title: Advertising; Ruder Finn & Rotman's President Resigns
description: Morris B. Rotman, who will be 70 years old June 6, has resigned his post as president of Ruder Finn & Rotman, the public relations firm, and will take on the newly created title of senior consultant. David Finn, 66, continues as chairman.

title: Environmental Records Rated
description: Senator Paul Simon received the highest rating among the Presidential candidates graded by an environmental coalition but no candidate in either party rated better than fair.

title: Reed Will Become Nets Coach Today
description: Willis Reed, who as a player led the Knicks to the only two National Baskeball Association championships the franchise ever won, will be officially named today as the head coach of the New Jersey Nets, a struggling franchise that needs wholesale rebuilding.

title: Capturing New York's History on a Carousel
description: In a cramped workshop here, Gerry Holzman is building a merry-go-round for the more than 17 million people of New York State.

title: Inquiry in Officer's Slaying Is Said to Be Stalled
description: A high-ranking New York City police official said yesterday that the investigation into the slaying of a rookie officer had stalled.

title: Verbeek and Muller Help Devils Win
description: After scoring only a single goal in each of their previous three games, the Devils exploded for eight this afternoon at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and beat the Minnesota North Stars, 8-6.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Tool Orders Jumped 23.7% In January
description: Bolstered by increased exports and Federal policies requiring some Government agencies to buy more domestic products, orders in January for American-made machine tools rose 23.7 percent from December's level, the industry's trade association said.

title: Raiders Name Shanahan
description: The Los Angeles Raiders will name Mike Shanahan, an assistant with the Denver Broncos, as their new head coach Monday.

title: NEWHALL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net income The share earnings are in units.

title: A Kibbutz Is Confronted With a Hard New Truth
description: Duby Bar is the secretary of this kibbutz 600 yards from the border with Jordan, and last Friday, he said, a faith that survived wars and four decades seemed suddenly to whither.

title: Advertising; Rodale Press Prepares A Magazine for Lipton
description: Rodale Press plans to publish Kidsmarts, a magazine for children, that will be used by Thomas J. Lipton Inc. as a premium offer. Consumers of its Lipton Cup-A-Soup, Lipton Side Dishes, Wyler drinks and Sunkist Fun Fruits can get copies through on-pack coupons.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Baton Rouge, La., on Thursday about the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart misidentified the television station that interviewed a woman who said she had several sexual encounters with him. It was WVUE-TV in New Orleans.

title: Dead or Alive, Who Is Safe From Scavengers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Move On
description: Tommy Kane, a wide receiver from Montreal who was on the undefeated Syracuse team, has decided to pass up a fourth season with the Orange and seek a career in the National Football League.

title: Music: At the Triplex, Costinescu's 'Seminar'
description: GHEORGHE COSTINESCU'S ''Musical Seminar'' is less interesting for its stated purpose - a United Nations-like reconciliation of styles - than for its confrontations between music and language.

title: TIMBERLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year net income and both year-ago periods' net income are on a pro-forma basis.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $608,000, or 8 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: 65 Bolshoi Dancers Coming to Boston
description: Maya Plisetskaya is to lead 65 dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow in the dance component of the Festival of Russian Music and Dance in Boston, in March and April. The festival has been organized by Sarah Caldwell, the artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston; Miss Plisetskaya, a prima ballerina with the Bolshoi, and her husband, Rodion Shchedrin, a Soviet composer. It is to run from March 17 through April 3.

title: A Restaurant Empire, Parisian Style
description: Jean-Paul Bucher, a former chef at world-famous Maxim's, just might have the most successful recipe in Paris: Take a half-dozen preferably large and ornate brasseries, spice up the traditional fare of cabbage and sausage with some nouvelle cuisine fish dishes, blend in some Beaujolais and beer and throw in a little business sense.

title: PLACER DOME reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an accounting change gain of $156,000. The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend last December.

title: China's Coastal Plans
description: The Chinese leader Zhao Ziyang said his country is planning to concentrate on developing the economies of its coastal areas, strengthening their links with international markets, according to a Japanese newspaper. He said economic reform and open-door policies have led to considerable progress and that the economy of the areas would gradually be transformed to look outward.

title: Metrodome's Din Echoes Through Viola's Winter
description: THERE had never been much reason for Frank Viola and his young family to remain in Minnesota for Halloween. The Minnesota Twins did not have any obligations once the baseball season ended at the beginning of the month. That is, until last year, when Halloween week began with their deafening victory in the seventh game of the World Series under the fiberglass roof of the Metrodome.

title: SANDERSON FARMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,250,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: The 'Siegfried' Dragon: 6 Men in the Belly of the Beast
description: O.K. Nobody has moved on stage for five minutes. Siegfried is going strong and hasn't even got his second wind. He'll sing for another 15 minutes at least. Time for a quick nap.

title: Venture Capitalist Back, But She Is Nearer to Top
description: In her long career as a venture capitalist, Patricia M. Cloherty has often managed to squeeze something extra from a deal. When her company, Alan Patricof Associates, tried to buy the Childcraft Education Corporation, a maker of educational toys, in 1972, one shareholder balked. ''He thought the price was too low,'' she recalled.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Passport Denied
description: Once again, the State Department has refused to issue a passport to Philip Agee, the former C.I.A. agent turned Government critic, whose writings have disclosed the names of fellow intelligence agents and exposed covert operations.

title: Israeli Officers Ordered to Watch Tape of 4 Soldiers Beating Arabs
description: The Israeli Army commander in the West Bank summoned all his officers above the rank of captain today and made them watch American television footage taken of four of his soldiers beating two captured Palestinian youths for nearly 40 minutes.

title: Dance Award Winners
description: The winners of the 1988 Dance Magazine Awards are Kyra Nichols, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet; P. W. Manchester, a critic and dance historian, and Moscelyne Larkin and Roman Jasinski, the artistic directors of the Tulsa Ballet Theater. A special award will also be given this year to the presenters of ''Dancing for Life,'' a benefit last fall that raised $1.4 million for AIDS programs. The awards will be presented on April 25 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, in a ceremony at 5 P.M. The event will be open to the public for the first time in its 32-year history. Tickets are $10 and will go on sale at the Town Hall box office on April 18. Information: 245-9050.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year figures reflect a change in method of accounting for income taxes.
